column2: THIS book, says Dorothy Thompson in her first chapter, is intended to be a political dictionary: to be, especially, "the intelligent woman's guide to Isms."
LIGHTNESS, compactness and a somewhat fanciful air will be important in the design of this season's furniture, to judge from previews.
The Treasury is studying a proposal to. consolidate the gift and estate taxes and thus raise a more positive barrier to avoidance of the higher tax brackets.

A hearing to decide whether Federal aid for old-age assistance should be withheld from Ohio on account of alleged political appeals to pension recipients by Governor Davey and his aides was ordered for Aug. 29 by the Sociay Security Board today.

Henry Hartz Helf, Cleveland's third-string catcher, stood today in Cleveland's public square and speared a ball thrown off the Terminal Tower, 708 feet up, to break the altitude catching record established thirty years ago when Gabby Street caught a ball thrown from the top of Washington Monument, 550 feet high.

The 146 members of the South Bend Building Trades Unions at work on construction of the Rockne Memorial Field House at the University of Notre Dame gave a day's labor today as their contribution to the memorial fund.

In another week the high and mighty Gold Cup pilots, who assume they have a right to look down with some disdain on the lesser fry in the world of speed boating, will start moving their great, superpowered craft to Detroit for this year's thirty-fifth running of the famous blue-ribbon classic. The climax of the racing season is near at hand, and little by little the veils of mystery are being pulled to one side.

The problem of how to get beer and ginger ale bottles in the apartmentsize refrigerator without taking up too much room has been solved by Norman Bel Geddes, in a patent (No. 2,127,212) just granted here to the noted designer.

With faith unshaken in the promise of their pastor, the Rev. Joseph A. Frey, to return from the dead, members of the First Spiritualist Church of Allegheny sat by the clergyman's bier in a Northside funeral home yesterday and today and waited for his spirit to appear.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad was absolved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today of negligence in the wreck of its crack flyer, the Olympian, near Saugus, Mont., June 19, when forty-seven persons were killed and severty-five injured.

Walter A. Hirsch of 31 East Seventy-second Street, a member of the law firm of Riegelman, Hess, Strasser Hirsch of 160 Broadway, died yesterday in Mt. Sinai Hospital at the age of 56 after a long illness. He had a Summer home at Rye, N. Y.

THE results of national bridge tournaments, and the rules under which they are played, affect only a handful of this country's millions of bridge players. Most games are rubber bridge games, and the four players neither know nor care about the more technical aspects of the rules.

Miss Margaret Fletcher, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jefferson B. Fletcher of this place and New York, was married here this afternoon to Robert Stone Stoddart, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John H. Stoddart of New York.

Organized relief workers picketed the WPA offices at 70 Columbus Avenue yesterday to protest recent wage cuts. WPA guards and the police estimated the crowd at 1,150, but leaders of the demonstration said 3,000 ware in the picket line.

Chicagoans today gave Douglas Corrigan one of the most enthusiastic demonstrations in the history of this city. It began the moment his silver monoplane suddenly appeared over Chicago Airport at 10:50 in the morning.
THE placid Summer surface of the New York art world was stirred last week by announcements bearing on the plans for an exhibition of contemporary American art at the World's Fair next year.

Tension between the Vatican and the Fascist party over Catholic Action associations, which in recent weeks the Italian press has accused of being hostile to Italy's racial doctrines, was eased today by the announcement that Achille Starace, Fascist party secretary, and Lamberto Vignoli, president of the Italian Catholic Action, had reached an understanding that places their relations on the basis of the accords of September, 1931.

The soft, mild, Southern voice of Cordell Hull, American Secretary of State, was raised last week in the cause of peace. His words, pleading for international law and order, were addressed to a world gripped by mounting fear of war, a world that relies more and more on the use of armed force.

Class 9. Model Saddle Horses--First, Miss Harriet Rubin's ch. m. Charm of Dunwoodndrion; second, Edgar A. Luckenbach's blk m. Lucky Nira: third Edgar F. Luckenbach's br. m. Lucky San Juan: fourth, Misses Ursula and Elise Burkard's b. m. Vivacious Lady. Class 59, Saddle Ponies--First, Misses Ursula and Elise Burkard's br. m. Hob Nob Fancy; second, Miss Jane Renwick St. John's br. m. Bonnie Lassie; third, Jack Spratt's ch. m. Miss Stepin.

To the Art Editor: I HAVE been reading with some interest and a great deal of impatience--the usual impatience of the American exposed to the usual provincial superiority complex of the European--the resume of French critical opinion regarding the pictures sent abroad from this country by the Museum of Modern Art.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. IN a natural amphitheatre on the wooded banks of the beautiful, unhurried Suwannee River in North Florida, a memorial is to be erected to Stephen collins Foster, the composer of the undying song "Old Folks at Home," which made famous the river that the never saw.

Miss Helen Longworth Roberson, daughter of Mrs. Helen Griffith Roberson. of Duke University, was married here this afternoon in the chapel of the university to John Lockwood Hammond, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B, Hammond of White Plains, N. Y.

Anthony Carlin, president and treasurer of the Anthony Carlin Company, rivet manufacturers, and a prominent Catholic layman, died today after a brief illness. He was 81.years old. Born in Donegal, Ireland, he came to this city as a boy in 1872.
Philadelphia at New York--Butcher (6-5) vs. Melton (10-11).
The Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., of Cleveland, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue 9,500 shares of $6 cumulative preferred stock with a stated value of $950,000.

The marriage of Miss Vivienne French Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Brown of East View, to Lieutenant Joseph B. Mitchell, U. S. A., son of Colonel and Mrs. William A. Mitchell of Arlington, Va., took place here today in the Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea.
Two sixty-family garden type apartments are being erected in the residential section of this city and considerable rivalry exists as to which unit will be completed first.

Alwyn Court, the twelve-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, which is being remodeled into small suites, now is 66 per cent rented, reported Edgar Ellinger, president of Edgar Ellinger, Inc., who has charge of both the reconstruction and renting of the property, yesterday.

After scores of persons had witnessed his attempt to escape from two detectives in a chase through Riverside Drive Park, a man who described himself as Edward Baumgarten, 32 years old, of 783 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, was captured on the New York Central tracks near 139th Street at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

THAT Mark Twain's attempts at self-expression were being thwarted by his wife and that William Dean Howells was at least aware of it is the minimum inference to be drawn from a letter he sent Howells in 1875 regarding "Tom Sawyer." "Mrs. Clemens received the mail this morning," he wrote,

IN ALL the long gallery of cat characters Buttons is destined to take a pre-eminent position. It may be, in spite of his later life. in the rogue's section, but wherever it is it will ??e his by rights just as everyhing in his native alley was his.

The Rebels suffered a severe check in the Ebro sector, according to tonight's War Ministry communique. "Forces at the service of the invaders," said the communique, 'after intense artillery preparation and with the aid of massed aviation of more than 100 planes, as well as thirty tanks, attacked our positions near Vilalba de Arcos [five miles north of Gandesa].
The practice of dedicating a portion of the basement to recreational use has increased the necessity for noise control in the home, points out an FHA official.

THE Hoffman twins went together to Iraq when Ruth married an English man who was working there. And with all due respect to the whimsical allurement of their book's title, it must be stated at once that they are writing about their life in Iraq, and only incidentally about the marriage or the Englishman.

SKYLINES are things that artists love to make pictures of. Travelers rave about 'em; civic orators point to them with pride. Nature made some of them with wide sweeps of sea and plain, with rolling hills, forestclad slopes and jagged mountain ranges. Here in New York we have made our own, a magic vision rising from the sea, its towers and pinnacles gleaming in the sunlight or looming in the mist.

Advocating as the next great advance in Negro education' the improvement of religious and theological training, Benjamin E. Mays, dean of the School of Religion at Howard University, states that, "notwithstanding the fact that the Negro ministers, as a group, have lost prestige, it is still true that the Negro minister is the most 'significant leader of the Negro masses."

A strong public sentiment for the restriction of freight trucks on the highways during week-ends and holidays, as provided by law in several Midwestern States, is revealed in a cross-section survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Dr. Rufus D. Smith, provost of New York University, announced yesterday the faculty and staff of the university's new Graduate Division for Training in Public Service. The unit, which will be under Dr. Smith's direction, will open next month.

Senator James J. Davis charged in a speech here today that the country, under the Roosevelt Admininistration, had degenerated to the "political pandering of relief as was done in the days of imperial Rome."

THE Malvern Festival's chief contribution to the contemporary theatre so far has been J. B. Priestley's finely adventurous experiment in technique. If the experiment had completely succeeded, it would have given us a masterpiece. "Music at Night" is not that, but, taking risks all along the line, it succeeds in gripping the attention of its audience.

While former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan was preparing to retire last night at his Salem Center home in Westchester detectives at police headquarters kept telephone and telegraph lines busy trying to locate him and finally sent out a teletype alarm from the Missing Persons Bureau.
Carl Weiler, 38 years old, of 123 Leonard Avenue, Milford, N. J., was instantly killed here tonight when his car was in a collision with another automobile on Route 6, near Liberty Street.

Mel Harder held the White Sox to seven hits today and registered his eleventh victory for the Indians, 8 to 2. Home runs by Ken Keltner and Jeff Heath led the Tribe's twelve hit attack on Monte Stratton.

WITH a monopoly probe of the broadcasting industry scheduled to begin in October, the Federal Communications Commission faces a busy final quarter of the year. It is expected that participants will be given a month's notice to prepare for the hearing.

Largest attendance in ?? eral years featured the August here yesterday by the ?? Fur Auction. Prices genar?? showed substantial advances ?? keen demand, and bulk of sa?? went to New York accounts, though Eastern Canada and Eruopean houses were well represente

With the phenomenal interest created by the introduction of the new Russell lupines from England, this fine old garden flower has been catapulted into the limelight of the garden world. Folks who had never thought of growing lupines beforeeven though the flowers. have been commonly available in good strains for years-are now assiduously "trying them out."

The strong stand of the Red Army against Japan evokes the question of whether the Red Army suffered so greatly from the effects of the "purge"--or anyway, whether it has not recovered quicker--than was generally believed abroad.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20.--Badly beaten by Australia in the first three matches of the Davis Cup interzone final, Germany's four-man tennis team today was "requested" to cut short its American tour and return home for a "rest."

Pushed by a special switch engine, a picketed freight car, bone of contention in a warehouse dispute, continued its plant-closing travels today to increase to thirty-five the number of idle warehouses.

A COUNTRY at war marches on its resources. Only so long as her resources hold out can the war continue. What, then, of Japan's resources? Japan is unique among the "have-not' powers, both for what she does and for' what she does not possess. Unlike Italy and Germany, she is independent of food imports; she grows the rice she needs on her tiny farms and sends her fishing
Attendance at the World's Fair next year will reach its peak in August, with 24 per cent of the total visitors expected to come in that month, according to estimates yesterday by fair officials.

More than 200 papers and addresses on every phase of management, including administration, production, distribution, personnel, agriculture and the home, will be read at the seventh International Management Congress to be held in this city

The unfavorable trend of German foreign trade, prevalent since the first of the year, continued during June with further declines in both imports and exports, and another considerable import surplus, according to a report from the American Consulate General at Berlin made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Perhaps it is an optical illusion, but yachtsmen seem to have the notion that the Hudson River is at its best in the late Summer. They save for August and early September their upstream cruises along this canyon between the Palisades and the Catskills on the west and the easy-rolling country to the east that eventually mounts into the foothills of the Berkshires.

Evidence that many of the 1,258 signatures upon a petition designating David S. Murden of Peekskill as Independent Republican primary candidate for Westchester County President were forgeries and that the sworn statements of several subscribing witnesses were perjured will soon be presented to the grand jury, it was indicated today at the office of District Attorney Walter A. Ferris here.

Representative Jerry O'Connell, Democrat, of Montana, told the California Committee for Industrial Organization convention today that he hoped the day would come "when we will expropriate the oil industry in this country also."

THE annual convention of the Photographio Society of America will be held in Rochester this year on Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 15 and 16, according to an announcement. High point of the season for many amateur photographers, the convention program calls for tours through photographic factories, exhibits of prints and photographic materials and an unusually -attractive list of special events.

Except for some loose ends to be tied up next week, the joint Congessional committee investigating the TVA has completed its inquiry into the Berry case, which apparently just escaped becoming a cause celebre.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien was asked yesterday to deny the application of Corporation Counsel William C. Chandler to have the court declare illegal the resolution creating the special committee of the City Council to investigate municipal radio station WNYC because the resolution had not been submitted to Mayor La Guardia for his approval.

When Admiral Nicholas Horthy sets foot on German soil at Kiel on Monday he will initiate a visit of state which is intended not only to give hearty confirmation '- an ancient friendship but also ??o emphasize the unity of the Reich's and Hungary's foreign political aims.

The keel of 'he ship that will replace the liner Leviathan in the fleet of the United States Lines will be laid tomorrow. morning with appropriate exercises at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at Newport News, Va. The liner will be the largest merchant vessel ever built in an American yard.

An increasing use of glass shower enclosures over bathtubs and glass doors for shower cabinets is reported by the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. Any built-in tub, it is explained, can be converted into a water-tight shower compartment by the installation of a glass enclosure.

Mr. and Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth gave a large dinner tonight at O-Go-Ya-Go, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw. Among the other guests were Mr. Thaw's brother-in-law and sister, Count and Countess Roger de Perigny of Paris, who after a trip In the West arrived here today to visit Mr. and Mrs. Thaw at Wind

A letter, "posted" by being tossed overboard in a bottle from a ship off the Florida coast last Sunday, has been delivered as safely as if it has been dropped in the street corner letterbox, Mrs. R. John Carlson of this city, the addressee, disclosed today.

Colony House, the 107-family apartment building nearing completion at 232d Street and the Henry Hudson Parkway, in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx, will have such modern improvements as individual cocktail lounges for the six-room suites and a floor layout that will provide access through individual vestibules from the gallery.

An announcement today said an American ship was due shortly in Barcelona with a $250,000 cargo of clothes, food and medicine for Government Spain. A. A. Heller of Chappaqua, N. Y., purchasing agent for the North American Committee to Aid Spain, said another campaign would be launched in the United States to send an additional shipload of relief supplies.

The official census of Jews residing in Italy is under way and will be completed Monday, it was announced today. The old figures were said to be inaccurate because many Jewish families did not declare their religion while others had been converted to other religions and did not consider themselves Jews.

Members of society who will be at their country homes on the North and South Shores by the end of August will participate in the most active and varied program since the Autumn "little season" became a feature of their social calendars. Debutante parties, weddings, international yachting at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, with attendant entertaining for the visiting skippers;
The six-story apartment house known as the Crestwood, under erection on the blockfront from Eighty-fourth Road and Austin Street, Kew Gardens, L. I., is expected to be ready for occupancy Sept. 1.

Outlining his case against Tammany District Leader James J. Hines, whom he is prosecuting as the alleged political protector of the policy numbers lottery, District Attorney Dewey last week said to the jury: "I would like first to describe to you the game of policy or numbers. I take it that no one of you has ever played it."

Real estate and mortgage transactions by the real estate sales division of the Title and Mortgage Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department during the three years of that division's activity totaled 1,023 deals, representing a financial value of $15,349,403.

ON the train from Guayaquil to Quito, Captain Loch tried to talk to his companions about the scientific objects of this expedition into the mountains of Ecuador and into the unmapped regions of the Oriente beyond the twin ranges of the Andes.
The nineteenth revised edition of Real Estate Principles and Practices, has just been published by Prentice-Hall, Inc.

Three former metropolitan golf champions, Gene Homans of Englewood, John R. Parker of Essex County and Jess Sweetser of Maidstone. won their way into the semifinals of the Maidstone Club's seventh annual Maidstone Bowl tournament today.

In the last hour of trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, prices fluctuated more rapidly than at any other time in the entire week, advancing almost 15 points and then losing all the gain to end 1 to 2 points lower than on Friday. Trading became active on the advance as shorts covered for the week-end and mills took contracts from the market.
The 136-year-old meeting house which was restored last year as a memorial to George Jones, founder of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was the scene today of the annual meeting of the Poultney Historical Society.

By winning the State tournament at Cazenovia a week ago, Arnold S. Denker of the Manhattan Chess Club gained his first major title since he starred at De Witt Clinton High School and N. Y. U. and subsequently became champion of the Bronx. In the interim, however, he participated in several high class competitions, in addition to gaining a place on the Manhattan Club's Metropolitan League team.

FRANCO-AMERICAN memories of Lafayette and the Revolution, of Pershing and the World War will be revived on Sunday, Sept. 4, when the massive granite shaft, consecrated to the glory of these military chieftains and to the ideals for which they battled is to be dedicated at Verdon, near Bordeaux, with picturesque ceremonial.
The Jacoby Building at 57 East Main Street, in the heart of Patchogue's business district, has been purchased by Ludwig Brall, Inc., of this village.

Share prices fluctuated narrowly and closed slightly higher in the two-hour trading period yesterday. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was only 245,000 shares, smallest since June 18, which was the Saturday before the present rise in prices began.

A large dinner dance took place tonight at the Devon Yacht Club. One of the dinners was given by Mr. and Mrs. Otto B. Reimer for Mr. and, Mrs. Joseph W. Powell Jr., Mr. and Mrs. E. Ritzema Perry, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Davis, Mr. and Mrs. John N. Cole, Mr, and Mrs. Alex J. Pagel, Mr., and Mrs.
Sixteen homes of different architectural types will be opened for Inspection today by Philip Kraushaar, Queens builder, in his new residential development at Woodmere, known as Fair Oaks.

Capturing all seven first places, the Broadwood A. C. of Philadelphia conquered the St. George Dragon Club of Brooklyn, 44 to 30, in a women's swimming meet at the Broad Channel Bathing Park in Queens yesterday.

ONE thing above all others seems to characterize the Autumn and early Winter coats: Grace. They have lost the heavy, bulky look that gave them their style when they flared like an Arab's tent or their shoulders were built out in imitation of Tarzan's. There's fullness, yes, but it is handled with discrimination; shoulders are broad, but discreetly so. This is to be a Winter of subtlety rather than clumsy exaggerations.

Talk of a wheat export subsidy by Secretary Wallace brought varied reactions from business men here last week. Foreign traders expressed active antagonism to the proposal, declaring that if carried out it would prove disastrous to the success of the entire reciprocal trade treaty program of the Administration.

A model food and drug bill for introduction in State Legislatures in January of next year is now being prepared and will be ready in December, Charles Wesley Dunn, counsel to several associations in the food and drug fields, revealed here yesterday.

Twenty-three members of the Don Cossack Russian Male Chorus were badly hurt today when a bus in which forty singers of the organization were traveling crashed into a tree. Thirteen were injured severely.
Even if destiny has plainly marked young Thomas E. Dewey for a public career, it does not exclude the thought that he has in him the makings of a great creative writer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--The American League for Peace and Democracy was directly linked with Moscow today before the House Committee on un-American activities in testimony by J. B. Matthews of Washington, N. J., who said he was the first head of the American League Against War and Fascism, its predecessor.

Five hundred demonstrators carrying French flags and singing the French national anthem paraded the streets of this historic citadel city today in protest against the current Belgian "independence" manoeuvres in the Ardenne mountains.
Many building managers hold that a terrazzo floor should not waxed because waxing makes it dangerously slippery. The usual alternative is nightly mopping and occasional scrubbing, which is expensive.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor R. Eve, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Eve of Floral Park, to Gregory Pierce Marburgh, son of Mrs. Percella Marburgh of Williston Park, took place here this afternoon in, St. Thomas's Episcopal Church. The Rev. John Williams Jr. performed the ceremony.
Ellison (Tarzan) Brown, Bradford, R. I., Indian runner, today won the National Amateur Union twentyfive-kilometer championship by defeating a field of sixty-four starters in 1:26:18.

Fifteen minutes after he returned to New York, Israel Leder, 32 years old, who had been sought by police for eight months after the robbery of a jewelry store in Brooklyn, was arrested early yesterday morning by Detective John Broderick

John Roosevelt, the President's youngest son, and his bride, the former Miss Anne Clark, will occupy a five-room Brookline apartment within the next two weeks, the bride's mother, Mrs. F. Haven Clark, said today.

Ellison D. Smith has represented South Carolina in the Senate since 1909. He is the dean of Democratic Senators and was 72 on Aug. 1. Yet he discharges his duties as chairman of the Committee on Agriculture and as a member of five other Senate committees with vigor belying his age.

The only woman member of Iceland's Parliament, Mrs. Gudrun Lausdottir, was killed with her two young daughters today when her automobile skidded on a ridge across the Tungufljot River today and plunged to the botton of a ravine.

Games, poems and drawings are used to sugar-coat lessons in a new grammar written by Winifred Watson, a teacher in the St. Paul public schools, and Julius M. Nolte, director of the Center for Continuation Study of the University of Minnesota.

The mystery of the away-from-home activities of Premier Juan Negrin of government Spain deepened today when he failed to cross the FrancoSpanish frontier en route to Barcelona as scheduled. Rafael Mendes, Secretary of State for the Interior in the Negrin government, landed alone at Perpignan in the Premier's special plane in which they flew to Zurich, Switzerland, Thursday.

Miss Elena L. Villa, eldest daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa, became the bride this afternoon of Robert Grant 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grant Jr. of Jericho, L. I., at Fairholme, the Summer home of the Count and Countess, at one time the John R. Drexel residence.

In order to get the benefit of exemption from the income tax in exchanges of securities, the Board of Tax Appeals and the courts now hold that corporate reorganizations must be real and not merely a series of steps taken with a view to complying with prescribed statutory formalities.
THE biography Philip Guedalla likes best to read, according to an interview given to The Book Window, is a one-volume life, supplemented by all the letters and papers published separately;

REARMAMENT is leading Britain to scrutinize every joint in her national armor, and many of the British are not altogether happy about their sea-borne food supply. They want to be certain that in a country which before long will be armed to the teeth

YOU are now about to attend vicariously the fifteenth annual meeting of The Fifteen Masters with Nero Wolfe, the well-known gourmet, as guest of honor. The meeting is held at Kanawha Spa in West Virginia,

Joseph F. A. O'Donnell of this city, head of the New York City real estate firm of Joseph F. A. O'Donnell, Inc., Lexington Avenue at Forty-third Street, died at New Rochelle Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

ANY invasion of the free American system of broadcasting from any quarter whatsoever, even though it be governmental invasion of freedom of the air, would meet with determined resistance of the American people, and the National Association of Broadcasters, Neville Miller, president of the organization, warned in a recent address at Peabody Teachers' College at Nashville, Tenn.
Clonel Charles A. Lindbergh visited industrial plants outside Moscow today while Mrs. Lindbergh, here on an airplane trip with him, remained in the capital and toured museums and art galleries.

Defending the New Deal spendpolicies, although expressing doubt of the adequacy of some Administration measures, Aubrey Williams, executive director of th National Youth Administration, told the World Youth Congress in seson at Vassar College this afternoon that the problem of youth was a grave one, with "deep and ugly sources."

WITH the close of the twentyfirst season of the Lewisohn Stadium and Goldman Band concerts the time is eminently ripe for seasonal statistics which are traditionally held to be bristling with indications of trends, portents and sundry significant conclusions.
A new slate blue woolen uniform for the army is to receive a year's test, with indications pointing to eventual adoption by the War Department.
Retail sales of shoes in the last two weeks have fallen behind the volume of last year, after two months of sales ahead of a year ago, it was reported yesterday.

NASH MOTORS introduced recently its second prosperitysales campaign of the year. Called a "job-making" drive, it was announced by C. H. Bliss, vice president and sales director, as an extra selling effort to create 1,735,000 "man-days" of work in August and September.

Criticizing the city administration for abusing its powers of reappointment, Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo ordered the reinstatement of John M. Kelly as chief inspector of five public markets yesterday.

The United States Golf Association, through the chairman of the Curtis Cup Committee, Mrs. Willard P. Sullivan of Ashland, Va., has issued a call to the members of the 1938 Curtis Cup team to meet their captain, Miss Frances Stebbins, at the Essex County Club, Manchester, Mass., on the morning of Sept. 1 for practice preceding the matches, which are to be played against a picked British team Sept. 7 and 8.
Important political developments may result from the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, -by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.---Leading swimmers and oarsmen among the 150 lifeguards along the beaches of the four resorts on Absecon Island will hold their annual competition in the surf at Margate next Friday.

The social activities of Tennis Week were brought to a close tonight with a subscription dance at the Clambake Club, which was attended by more than 200 members of the club and guests who late in the afternoon had attended the marriage of Miss Elena Villa.

When manufacturers began to produce steel casement windows no provision was made for attaching screens, points out the Metal Window Institute, and in a short time it was found that users were having difficulty in screening their rooms.

The Catholic priest of Kamnik, Slovenia, recently received a letter from Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Chancellor of Austria, requesting copies of the birth certificates of his grandfather and great-grandfather, both of whom were born there.
Public employment offices made 226,855 job placements in July, of which 156,042 were with private employers, the Labor Department announced today.
Commenting on the settlement of the PanamaCosta Rica boundary, the newspaper Estrella today said that the treaty would be approved by the National Assemblies of both countries.

AUGUST and September are the months for tomatoes ripened on the vine. North and West, home gardens are bearing heavily, harvest is on in the truck areas, city market supplies are at their peak, andweather permitting-prices are at the year's low level.

Miss Janet Isabel Stevenson, only daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. H. Stevenson of this place, was married here this afternoon to William Dunn Thomas, elder son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley G. Thomas of Montreal, in Trinity Church by the Rev. W. E. Long.

Players of England, Argentina and America took part in the polo today at the Meadow Brook Club as a round-robin and a cut-in game provided play. The open teams split up for the workouts and will come together again tomorrow, when test games bring Greentree and Aknusti into action at Sands Point, Old Westbury and the Optimists at Meadow Brook and Roslyn and the Ramblers at Bostwick Field.

APPELBAUM--WOLBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Morris Wolberg announce the engagement of their daughter, Miriam, to Mr. Bob Appelbaum, son of Mrs. Anna Goldberg and the late Mr. Isaac Appelbaum. BODOW--BURKAN--Mrs. Rose H. Burkan, wife of the late Benjamin Burkan, announces the engagement of her daughter, Adelaide, of 535 West 110th St., to Edward L. Bodow of New Rochelle and New York City.

BERLIN. ANY era, whether close to us or distant, can best be understood by a study of the development of the important personalities who really lived in it and shared in its struggles, who adopted the ideas and viewpoints of their time as their own or opposed them and became forerunners of future ideologies.

Many people of the theatrical world were at the Heath estate overlooking Setauket Harbor in the village of Poquott this morning to pay last tribute to Thomas K. Heath of the blackface comedy team of McIntyre and Heath, who died Thursday night at the age of 85 on the first anniversary of the death of his partner, James McIntyre.
WASHINGTON.--The old political adage often applied to members of the national Legislature-that "few die and none resign"-is receiving a buffeting this year.

Today's single session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science reviewed its knowledge of cosmic rays. The discussion centered around the new X particle, discovered almost simultaneously this year by Dr. Carl Anderson of California and Dr. J. S. Street and Dr. E. C. Stevenson of Harvard.
Intensive recruiting for the air corps was announced by the French Air Ministry today as part of Premier Edouard Daladier's plan to increase France's fighting air fleets.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his Summer home in Plymouth, N. H., of F. Schuyler Mathews, author and illustrator, of Cambridge, Mass. He was born in New Brighton, S. I., eighty-four years ago.

On a spacious corner plot on Maple Drive, Great Neck Estates, Great Neck, L. I., a large home of attractive design has just been completed for Mrs. Anna H. Abrams from plans by Thomas C. Rogers, architect. I. G. Wolf R. A. White, Inc., were brokers in the deal.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Armstrong Clute, daughter of Mrs. Warren Wakeman Clute of this place and Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Clute, to Hathaway Turner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Hathaway Turner of Westover Hills, Montour Falls, took place here this afternoon.

Premier Edoward Daladier's radio talk tomorrow night, in which he says he will announce "energetic measures for defense of the currency and of the nation," is awaited with impatience and uneasiness in both political camps here.

The German military manoeuvres have given Italy another opportunity to show the depth of her friendship for her partner in the Berlin-Rome axis. Far from feeling nervousness, Italy views the manoeuvres with frank complacence and sympathy.

To the Drama Editor: In his letter to you published on Aug. 7, William M. McBride seems disturbed. I wonder why? The new regulations between Equity and the League of New York Theatres allow a 75 cent maximum for service on the sale of theatre tickets, and that is all Mr. McBride receives now and has received for years.

Cash income from farm products marketed in 1938 plus government payments to farmers probably will amount to about $7,500,000,000, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today. Farm cash income amounted to $8,600,000,000 in 1937 and $7,944,000,000 in 1936.
FARMING is charming. At least, that is the impression that Mr. Tetlow conveys in every page of his book of experiences. He was panicked into going back to the land.

Current low prices for wheat and the promise of doubled government benefit payments for acreage reduction are expected by county officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to increase greatly cooperation the coming year in the Federal farm program.

Plans for Norway's exhibit at the World's Fair, which were made public yesterday following their approval by the fair's Board of Design, call for a pavilion of unusual construction, on which work will be begun by Sept. 1, according to Frederik Odfjell, Norway's commissioner general at the fair.

Six destroyers carrying 166 midshipmen of the second. class of the United States Naval Academy arrived here yesterday morning and anchored in the Hudson River between Sixty-third and Seventy-first Street. They will remain until noon tomorrow.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has continued its upward movement, reaching 83.9 for the week ended Aug. 13. This compares with 83.3 (revised) for the preceding week, and 111.2 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Martin H. Carmody of Grand Rapids, Mich., Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, on his way to Rome where he expects to have an audience with Pope Pius.

Poland's greatest tennis player, Mlle. Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, stepped back into the American picture yesterday from the gangplank of the Gdynia America liner Pilsudski. Her chief objective is the United States women's championship, which will be settled at Forest Hills next month.
A carrier pigeon brought a message that sent Coast Guardsmen from Manasquan inlet to the rescue of sixteen fishermen in two disabled motorboats about fifteen miles southeast of here this afternoon.
President Roosevelt's assurance that the United States would not stand idle in the

Light Horse Harry Cooper of Chicago took a seven at the eighteenth hole on his final round of the Canadian open golf championship at the Missisauga Club today and landed in a deadlock after 72 holes with Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

An Old Home Day celebration arranged by the Andrew Mygatt Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars came to what 3,000 citizens considered a fitting climax tonight when Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, directed a band and chorus in the rendition of "The Star-Spangled Banner."

PERTINENT: There's an old New York joke: "What famous person is buried in Grant's Tomb?" Last week George D. Burnside, for forty-one years curator of the tomb, revealed that the question is not a mere witticism.

Despite the trial of James J. Hines a survey of the Harlem Court records disclosed that operators of the numbers game were still active last week. In the last seven days thirteen cases involving possession of policy slips were heard by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger.

To the Music Edttor: In your column "From the Mail Pouch" you published a letter written by Miss Valerie Philipps, New Brunswick, which impresses me as demanding an answer from the other side of the fence, so "Audeatur altera pars."

When Adolf Hitler and the Nazis took charge of Germany they had, among others, certain ideas on psychology in war. At this moment of tensity in Europe they are worth recalling. First, the Nazis accepted the military thesis that the army had not been beaten in the World War and would not have been beaten had the home front not collapsed.

A "dead spot" lasting two weeks, during which almost no orders from abroad were received for American manufactured products, ended last week with a flood of purchasing from practically every corner of the globe, export executives reported last week.

Reminiscences of early Park Avenue days when that thoroughfare presented more evidences of a plebian character than is the case today are recalled in the recent sale under foreclosure of the three large apartment buildings on the northeast corner of the avenue and Fiftythird Street.

Grain markets made a firm start and a tame finish today. Early there was scattered buying of wheat futures attributed to mills, but as soon as the buying ceased the market started to react and prices declined more than 1 cent a bushel from the high point, closing trades were about at the bottom, with net losses on the Board of Trade here 3/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

IT is said that when the estimable Louis B. Mayer, voice of the film industry and head of Mettro-Goldwyn-Mayer, asked Jean Gabin, the Gallic actor, to come to Hollywood on his own terms, the Frenchman replied in the negative because "the wine he liked best didn't travel well!"

Japan's failure--or refusal--to throw the whole force of her strength into a great, decisive drive on Hankow and, if necessary, on into the deep interior of China as well as a complementary drive on Canton and the south, is due to three guiding motives of policy, a high official of the government explained today.

An improvement for shower-bath conveniences, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau, is the pressure-controlled mixer. This type of valve automatically cuts off the hot water and prevents scalding, should the supply of cold water fail.

IN his re-creation of the biblical saga Thomas Mann lets the youthful Joseph probe into the origins of human life, and, in a somewhat audacious quest of mysteries, even into God's complicity in the fall of man.

The fourth dinner dance of the Bar Harbor Club was held this evening. One of the largest dinner parties was that given by Mrs. Pauline Disston Wanamaker for Miss Fernanda Wanamaker and John Wanamaker 3d.

THE Pendell Hill Music Association announces a festival of two performances to be held Aug. 28 and Sept. 11, at 4 P. M., on Pendell Hill, a quarter of a mile from U. S. Route 11 at Whitney Point, N. Y.

MORE than three-quarters of a million schoolma'ams have their place in this country's system of public education, and "it is reasonable to conclude," says the author of this book, "that classroom teaching is being done largely by women."

Charges that the cost of Federal-relief had been "skyrocketed" under the Roosevelt Administration until it currently stands under the WPA at $19 a week as against less than $3.50 a week in May, 1933, and a little above $7 a week in 1935, were made by the Republican National Committee today in an analysis printed in its publication, The Republican Reporter.

One hundred and twenty-four craft were out today for the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Yachting Department of the New York Athletic Club, and what gave promise of being a fine event was spoiled by a falling breeze.

The Jewish Morning Journal has started a campaign in New York City for funds for the Jewish community in Palestine and to help improve the "internal Jewish economic situation so that it might continue to provide a haven for Jews from Germany, Austria and other oppressed lands."
DURING recent months Europe has been on the verge of war over Czechoslovakia. In the heart of the Continent

THE book "My Days" is a collection of excerpts from Mrs. Roosevelt's daily newspaper column, through the years 1936 and 1937 and the first five months of 1938. The author is not only the most prominent woman in America, but the one whose whole personal life is most completely and pitilessly public.

A new monthly production record was established in July by Leitch Gold Mines in the Beardmore-Sand River area, when the mill treated 2,514 tons of ore with an average recovery of $24.34 a ton, to set the return at $61,200.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler, accompanied by Colonel-General Waither von Brauchitsch, commander in chief of the army, and several other generals, attended the troop training exercises of the Second Army Corps at Grossborn, near Stettin. They are expected to remaina there two days.

Prospects of a long drawn-out battle in the concluding cricket test match between England and Australia appeared likely today as the teams prepared for the second day's play Monday, with the English total at 347 runs for one wicket.

Charles Gabor, representing the Lake Mohawk Yacht Club, took the lead in the sixth annual North Atlantic Coast Snipe Class championship on Lake Mohawk'today, piloting his Chaseme II to victory in the morning race and placing third in the afternoon contest.

This precarious business of hanging on for dear life with crippled fingers proved too much for even the doughty Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday and, despite heroic measures, Colonel Bill Terry's riddled troops went down before Jimmy Wilson's supposedly forlorn Phillies in the second game of the current series, 8 to 7.
Japanese exports of canned salmon were slightly above normal during May, the American Commercial Attache at Tokyo reported to the Department of Commerce today.

WASHINGTON.--By applying the automobile factory belt-line technique to housing construction, the Farm Security Administration in now turning out rural homes on a FSA resettlement project near LaForge, Mo., at an average cost of $1,050 each, including all field overhead.

The railroads should have greater freedom in raising and lowering rates to meet competition, M. J. Gormley of the Association of American Railroads, told the Nickel Plate Veterans' Association at Cedar Point, Ohio, yesterday.

An interesting air-conditioning system has been installed in a new apartment house in the suburban area of St. Louis. An air-conditioning unit is installed above the ceiling in each apartment. Each of these units is equipped with a silent fan to deliver the correct amount of air to each room of the apartment and to withdraw the air after it has performed its function of

Alexander Pompez, the Negro policy banker and sports promoter of Harlem, will resume the witness stand tomorrow when the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, is continued before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and a blue ribbon jury.

What purported to be photostats of statements lauding the spirit of American volunteers fighting for the Spanish Loyalists, purported to have been made by Abraham Sobel and Alvin L. Halpern, former Loyalist. volunteers who testified last week before the Dies investigation committee that many of their companions were virtual prisoners in Spain and unable to return home, were made public yesterday by the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.

President Roosevelt conceded today for the first time since the enactment of the National Labor Relations Act that it was in need of revision, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who had a conference with the President this morning.
The waterfront estate of Robert C. Webster at Kings Point, Great Neck, L. I., has been purchased by John T. Kirby, vice-president of W. R. Grace Co. De Beaumont Mott was broker in the deal.
It was a case of all's well that ends well with Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Miss Marion Turpie, in the women's fifty-four-hole invitation golf tourney on the Ekwanok Club course today.

CLEMENCE DANE'S special distinction as a writer is to have won distinction in many different literary fields and to have been mediocre in none. Even when she amused herself collaborating in the "Sir John" detective yarns a bull's eye was invariably scored.

LONDON. IT is a pity Cambridge festivals are not more frequent events. Their organization places onerous duties on men whose time is already fully occupied and, possibly, the university's authorities may not look with pleasure on the crowds that invade their town and colleges.

THE position of Czechoslovakia as a storm center in Europe lends particular in terest to a book entitled "They Gave Us a Country," which Alfred A. Knopf announces for publication later in this season.

IS there anything you would like to know about youth in the United States? The answer is probably in this book, a handy volume of reference indispensable to those who have a professional or casual interest in any of the many phases of the youth problem. Virtually everything of authority or importancewritten about youth in recent years is included in the 2,500 literary items listed in these

ON April 11, 1914, the Strand Theatre opened amid considerable head-shaking and mournful soothsaying by artful augurs who presumably had practiced hepatoscopy or charted the course of geese flying high over the Astor at midnight. At any rate, Variety gave them official recognition in its report:

In a finish which electrified a crowd of 25,000, the Brookmeade Stable's Handcuff today came from behind to win the $7,500 added New England Oaks at Narragansett Park. The 3-year-old brown daughter of Whichone, favored to win, moved up from last place at the threeeighths pole and crossed the line, with Jockey Jackie Westrope swinging his whip lustily, a length and a half ahead of Playdis.

A dance was given in the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight, preceded by many cocktail parties and dinners. Harold H. Sherburne entertained at cocktails in the clubhouse, his guests later attending a dinner at the club.

Japan's carefully manufactured indignation at what is termed "French aid to Chiang Kai-shek" must have been viewed with unfeigned surprise in Paris and with rueful amusement in Hankow and Chungking. For the sober fact of the case-unhappily for China-is that France is doing nothing to aid the Chinese cause.

Well satisfied with the results achieved in the command and staff war problem conducted at Camp Smith here for the last two weeks, Major Gen. Wiliam N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, in commenting on the manoeuvres said today.

The pamphlet report of the Atlantio Refining Company and its subsidiaries, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,863,511 for the first six months of this year. This is after Federal income taxes, intangible development costs, depreciation, depletion, amortization and minority interest.
Rudy York's twenty-sixth and twentyseventh home runs paced the Tigers to their sixth consecutive victory today, a 6-to-4 conquest of the Browns. The two blows scored four runs.

Somebody said that Howard Oots, the Kentucky veteran who used to train for James Cox Brady and now trains for his son, had a young raccoon for a mascot out at Barn No. 47 in the Oklahoma division here.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 19: COLONELS Butcher, E. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, one month leave, Dec. 16. Buckner, S. B. Jr., Inf., Ft. George G. Meade, Md., to 22d Inf., Ft. McClellan, Ala.

Reversing the usual seasonal trend, used car prices for August are showing a tendency to remain stationary rather than drop off, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Automobile Dealers Association.

A hunger strike, in which 650 of the 1,481 inmates of the Philadelphia County prison at Holmesburg enlisted last night, lost in popularity today, with about 100 of the original strikers changing their minds and accepting a fare of bread and water.

A carefully devised dragnet, spread over Shanghai in the period marking the first anniversary of the outbreak of hostilities here, ostensibly designed to catch Chinese terrorists, has confirmed the conviction of authorities of the International Settlement that more than half the recent assassinations and bomb throwing were perpetrated by Japanese.
Phi Epsilon Phi retained its position as leader in the scholastic averages made by Rutgers University fraternities, a registrar's report for the scholastic year disclosed today.

EXPERIMENTAL telecasts from Radio City through the NBC transmitter atop the Empire State Building will be resumed on Tuesday after a sign-off period of several weeks devoted to overhauling the equipment. The weekly schedule will comprise six one-hour programs.

Dr. William M. Higgins of 549 Riverside Drive, who had practiced medicine in this city for more than twenty-five years, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital after an illness of five weeks. He was 57 years old.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Ferris Clare-Patton, daughter of Mrs. John C. Crowley of Bayside, Queens, and the late Dr. Reginald ClarePatton of Bangalore, British India, and South Devon, England, to Donald Ross Hamilton, took place yesterday afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church, Bayside. The Rev. Richard W. Trapnell officiated.
Further improvement in business during September appeared almost certain, unless thwarted by "politicians," said the United States Chamber of Commerce today in a summary of business conditions.
Lawrence Camp, President Roosevelt's candidate for the Senate, defended the Chief Executive's intervention in the Georgia primary campaign, asserting today it was for the State's own good.

Establishment of a 30-cent-anhour minimum wage for the textile industries, which was suggested in informal conferences of labor leaders, trade association executives and government officials last week, would have no immediate effect on production costs, traders said yesterday.

Thirteen - year - old Herbert Kwass of 4,508 North Tenth Street, Philadelphia, wanted to have "one more little swim" tonight before his family took him back home from their day's outing. Twenty minutes later he was found floating face-downward at the foot of Boston Avenue--dead.
KING'S HOST: King George VI of Great Britain for several days last week was the guest of a visitor to hisrealm, J. P. Morgan of Wall Street and

After sitting with his wife, the former Barbara Hutton, on the Lido bathing beach for half an hour yesterday afternoon Count Court Haugwitz-Reventlow told his friend, Alice Heming, Sunday Dispatch contributor, over the long-distance telephone that "it was the end."

The lag of 18 points in the rate of production of the United States Steel Corporation, compared with that of independent companies, is explained mainly by the fact that the corporation has a higher percentage of plants devoted to heavy steel production than have the independents, taken in the aggregate. For the week ended on Aug.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Monday Briggs Stratton Corp. Gannett Co., Inc. Waldorf System, Inc.
ALTHOUGH Marie Antoinette has been dead these hundred-odd years, she was ably represented in New York this past week by a lady who also possesses certain regal attributes herself.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a marked tendency today on the part of the Federal Government to disregard the lessons of experience, to put aside the wisdom of the ages and, incredible as it seems, to believe that something new has been found or discovered in the realm of government and in the realm of finance.
A special committee to consider the establishment of a State-owned beach at the head of the lake has been named by Robert Moses, State Park Commissioner.

New mortgage financing, according to Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, has recently been increasing in volume in all the principal cities of the country covered in the index prepared for the association.

Stench and tear gas bombs were exploded in twelve Brooklyn motion picture theatres, all units of a single chain, between 8:30 and 9:30 o'clock last night, causing capacity Saturday night crowds of 400 to 2,000 persons in each theatre to rush to the doors.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Stuart of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Emily Stuart, to William T. Heydt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles O. Heydt, also of Montclair.

" It is a start on tearing down the walls of our common prison, and once we are free, Croats and Serbs can unite to build a better future," said Vladimir Matchek, Croat peasant leader, to tens of thousands of enthusiastic followers in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, last Sunday after his arrival for conferences with Serbian democratic leaders.
Joseph H. Nassoit, president of the Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation, old realty firm specializing in West Side apartment buildings, has acquired sole ownership of..the stock of that corporation.

President Roosevelt's pledge to Canada as interpreted by James Louis Garvin, editor of The Observer, "is not by long chalks a positive assurance to European democracies that in the event of a conflict the United States would come in but an intimation to the dictatorships that at a pinch the United States would be unable to keep out."

BERKWIT--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Berkwit announce birth of their son, Michael Allen, Aug. 14, at Fitch Sanatorium. DRAKE--Mr. and Mrs. Erie, announce birth of a son, Aug. 16, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. DUHAN--Dr. and Mrs. Eliot, announce the birth of a daughter, Nancy Ellen, on Aug. 14.

The New York Football Giants will stage their initial scrimmage of the season here tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock. With the exception of Ox Parry, ailing regular tackle, every member of the squad will scrimmage, that strenuous contact work which puts every player strictly on his own merit.

Don McNeill, Oklahoma City, and Hal Surface, Kansas City, qualified for the final of an international tennis tournament today. McNeill defeated George Toley, Miami, 6-1, 6-1, while Surface disposed of Ernie Sutter, New Orleans, 6-8, 6-1, 6-2. The finalists will meet tomorrow.
In the Fall of 1936 the people of the State of New York were in an affirmative mood. They were for the New Deal and what it was proposing.

IN the low ebb of the current music season, when most performing musicians and their managers are making plans for the new one, the Federal Music Project and the Hippodrome Opera Company at Jones Beach and Randalls Island are doing most of the town's music-making.

The price of the world's precarious peace today is somewhere in the neighborhood of fourteen to fifteen billion dollars per annum, six times the amount paid in the year before the World War. This vast sum is being spent in 1938 on the world's armies, navies and air forces.
Paul Edgerton Gardner, retired stock broker, died at his home here last night of a heart ailment. His age was 49. Born in Chicago, Mr. Gardner was graduated from the University of Chicago in 1911.

The marriage of Miss Mary Jane Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Earle Freeman of this city, to Joseph Wallace Oman Jr., son of Rear Admiral Oman, U. S. N., retired, and Mrs. Oman took place here today in Grace Memorial Episcopal Church.
Supply contracts valued at $7,440,300 were awarded in the week ended on Aug. 18 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.
The Red Sox made it five in a row today by trimming Washington, 10 to--7, in a free-hitting game.
Plans for immediate construction of a $3,000,000 addition to the Virginia Electric and Power Company's plant in Richmond, Va., were announced yesterday by J. G. Holtzclaw, president of the company.

BEACH visitors in Summer find a strange fascination about echinoderms-those sea animals which are so conspicuous for their spiny outer covering or little calcareous plates embedded in the skin. As there are nearly 8,000 known species, the collector meets with various interesting and colorfill forms.

IN response to recent tourist demands for local sight-seeing opportunities, metropolitan travel bureaus and services have inaugurated a series of interesting trips, ranging from circuits of the city to all-day jaunts in surrounding country, in automobiles manned by experienced guides and chauffeurs.

ADAMOWSKA--Mme. Antoinette Szumowska, Aug. 18, at home of her daughter and son-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Guido Pantaleomi, Rumson, N. J. Service, 10 A. M., Monday, Aug. 22, at Holy Cross Church, Ward Ave., Rumson. ARNSTEIN--Mrs. Sadie, dearly beloved mother of Daniel G., Sidney Arnstein, Mae Schuman, Hattie Renberg, and sister of Mrs. Rose Amter.

Eighteen of the men who formed the 141st Aero Squadron, A. E. F., came to Princeton University today to pay tribute to the memory of Captain Hobart A. H. (Hobey) Baker, their war-time commander, who was killed when his plane crashed near Toul, France, on Dec. 21, 1918, while he was making a test flight.

Four stipulations to discontinue certain misrepresentations in connection with the advertising and sale of women's garments have been entered into with the Federal Trade Commission by Archie and Michael Polsky, co-partners trading as Atlanta Knitting Mills and Myra Joy Products, 149 Madison Avenue;

Delegates to the Pennsylvania American Legion convention roared enthusiastic assent today to a call from Daniel J. Doherty, the Legion's national commander, to help start a "purge of the indoctrinators and propagandists now masked as teachers in our American public schools and universities."

Chrysanthemum growers have long complained that in some seasons and in some localities the browning of the lower foliage and subsequent falling were affecting the good looks of their prize plantings. Finally their cry was heard and investigations were carried on in several experiment stations. In New Jersey one graduate student, after a year's study, reported that a bacteriological disease was responsible.

Net receipts of $4,608,853 from the 158 national forests were reported today by the National Park Service for the fiscal year ending June 30. This was $327,000 less than for 1937, but was $545,000 more than for 1986.

THE amateur lensman who has mastered the elementary principles of picture-taking often turns to trick photography. Here he finds no end of'opportunities for calling into play all he has learned of camera handling and darkroom technique.

While Japanese forces continue their artillery and airplane attacks, heralding ever-deeper penetration into Chinese territors, rotably in the Kiukiang region in the drive toward Hankow and in Southern Shansi Province, ever-increasing attention is being given by foreign observers to developments far behind the Japanese front lines.

Maurice W. Monheimer of 2,200 Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn, a corporation lawyer with offices at 1,270 Sixth Avenue, Manhattan, died yesterday morning of pneumonia at the Rockefeller Institute Hospital. His age was 54.

Milton Lockwood Bouden, bank executive of New Orleans, died of pneumonia today at New Rochelle Hospital after an illness of nine days. He had been visiting his brother-in-law, Edward H. Fennell, at Larchmont. His age was 68. Mr. Bouden had been for thirty years manager of the real estate department of the Whitney National Bank in New Orleans.

ON Sept. 15 in the Postoffice Department there will be opened a group of the most interesting bids that the air mail has seen in its recent history. These bids are for experimental feeder service for two routes.

United States postal authorities dipped into the widespread investigation of the National Talent Pictures Corporation today as police bunco squad officers said they had smashed one of the biggest movie racket schemes ever started here.

Prince Charming II, bay gelding belonging to the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., today was named champion hunter of the Pocono Mountains Horse Show during the closing program of the exhibition.

A FEW weeks from now, people all over the country will be comparing this new novel with "Gone With the Wind." Perhaps it is best to say at once, for the benefit of those who would declare a moratorium

Valya Valentinoff is the featured dancer this week in the stage show at the Radio City Music Hall, appearing in Leonidoff's production, "The Brimming Stein." On Tuesday evening, the African dance-drama, "Zunguru," will begin its third week at the Davenport Theatre in East Twenty-seventh Street.

Recent progress in residential building throughout the country, in the opinion of the Federal Housing Administration, indicates that the 1937 record, which was the best since 1931, will be surpassed this year.

Getting into the United States Army nowadays involves a lot more for a young man than looking at a recruiting poster and deciding he wants to enlist. The army doesn't want him unless he is an American citizen, between the ages of 18 and 35, physically fit, at least 5 feet 4 inches tall, not less than 115 pounds in weight, single, of good character, with no police record and fairly well educated.

BY way of concluding this Summer series of articles on American art I want today to clarify--if I can, beyond a shadow of doubt--one or two fundamental factors that perhaps need a little more specific emphasis than has thus far been established.

In an effort to offer needy students additional opportunity, recent improvements, including the installation of a new library, establishment of a $20,000 student loan fund, and construction of a complete $65,000 athletic field, have been made at Ferris Institute in Michigan.
Behind locked doors guarded by State troopers, official counters began an involved check today of ballots cast in a referendum on a State-Federal milk marketing agreement.

Ray Mullane, 22-year-old Flushing ace, regained the metropolitan A. A. U. senior one-mile swimming championship yesterday in the Jerome Cascades pool, turning in the second fastest time in the sixyear history of the event.
MARY HEATON VORSE has long been a familiar figure on the active labor front both as an organizer and a writer.

More than 200 members and guests attended a clambake tonight at the Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington. Mrs. George Church was tea hostess at the club, and among those assisting were Mrs. George E. Stewart, Mrs. Ponsonby B. Ogle, Mrs. Arthur A. Somers, Mrs. Sarah Shiras and Miss Annabelle Terrell.

J. Harry Stroup, a retired insurance broker who was active for many years in politics in Dauphin County, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 80. He became Recorder of Deeds of Dauphin County in 1904, Register of Wills in 1908 and in 1912, started serving a four-year term as chief clerk to. the county commissioners.

The marriage of Miss Eunice Ellen MacNabb, daughter of Mrs. Charles MacNabb of this place and the late Mr. MacNabb, to Glenn Fletcher Fairman, son of Charles Albert Fairman of Valhalla and the late Mrs. Fairman, took place at noon today in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church here. The Rev.

An increasing number of inquiries received from large advertisers and advertising agencies indicate that the slight pick-up in printing volume shown in this area during August will be accelerated shortly, executives of printing plants reported here yesterday.
JOHN HYDE PRESTON, author of "Revolution 1776," has written a novel which digs into the foundations of' the modern economic structure and exposes much of the rot which undermines it.

The sirocco, they call it in Southern France and Northern Africa, that hot wind from the Sahara that leaves crops blasted and steals vital moisture from men and beasts. In Southern Russia-the lower Ukraine, Volga and North Caucasus- its name is "sukhovey," "dry wind." Its breath shrivels the swelling grain before it has a chance to ripen.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 18: COMMANDERS (MEDICAL CORPS) Davis, B. P., orders July 21 revoked; to continue duty Naval .Hospital, Mare Island. Calif.
The younger set making up George H. Bull's house party here for the week-end was honored tonight after the races at a dinner dance he gave at the Saratoga Golf Club.

Perhaps more notice will be taken of the butterfly weed sine Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt announced recently that she had brought a single plant of this beautiful flameorange wild flower to Hyde Park and was "putting it in the ground with plenty of water and much prayer."

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today approval of additional loans up to $7,250,000 to the Dairy Products Marketing Association in Chicago for buying up to 25,000,000 pounds of butter to help stabilize dairy prices.

ANATOLE FRANCE got his initial recognition in the United States because a queer young Graeco-Irishman wanted to go to Japan. In 1889 Lafcadio Hearn came back to New York from the West Indies, but was soon overcome by a yen for the Orient.

A fleet of sixty-four boats raced off here today in the annual invitation regatta of the Point o' Woods Yacht Squadroni A dazzling sun and a light southwesterly made sailing conditions perfect. Duncan C. Arnold's Class R boat Querida, a converted Islip one-design, won easily, finishing nine minutes ahead of Frank M. Weeks's Yankee. Alva Collins's Alouette was third.

A 4.7 per cent increase in revenue passenger miles flown by domestic airlines during July as compared with the previous month was announced yesterday by Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of
The cost of living for families of wageearners and lower-salaried workers in thirty-two cities increased 0.4 per cent during the quarter ended on June 30, the Department of Labor announced today.

AN analysis of the American tourist made recently by the United States Travel Bureau ranks him as the nation's third largest industry, contributing to practically all businesses in every section of the country. In the South, which had over 40,000,000 visitors last year, he's still "that Yank from the North," observers note.

An aggressive campaign against the Administration's reciprocal trade treaty, concentrated in areas where workers and employers are particularly sensitive to foreign competition, will be carried on this Fall by opponents of the treaty program in both parties, it was revealed here last week.

TO commemorate the end of the first decade of passenger transportation by air in the United States, the commercial air lines of the country are now laying plans for a National Air Travel Week to be held throughout the land from Oct. 1 to 9.

Maryland's Legionnaires adjourned their annual convention tonight after a heated session which split their ranks over the Senatorial battle between Senator M. E. Tydings and Representative David J. Lewis.

Czechoslovakia must propose "a radical solution of the Sudeten German problem in order to prevent outside pressure and safeguard its sovereignty," says the Prager Presse, which speaks for the Foreign Office, today In an article headed "Search for a new basis for negotiations."
THE steady increase in demand by American collectors for the stamps of their owncountry is reflected in the upward trend in quotations as set forth in the advance sheets, released last week,

Angered because a WPA orchestra, scheduled to play last night in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, failed to appear, 2,500 persons booed, hissed and milled about for thirty minutes before they went home. As early as 7 P. M. persons began to arrive for the concert. At 8:30, the hour set for the start, all the seats in front of the bandstand were occupied.

A vast Manhattan terminal produce market that would be capable of handling the $400,000,000 annual flow of foodstuffs through the West Side marketing area is the next major improvement that Mayor La Guardia plans for the city.

" When the German business men and workers perceive that Hitler is leading them to bankruptcy, not even his use of the mailed fist can suffice to keep him in power," Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared in his sermon yesterday morning at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
The Mexican Government is finding, in the school of hard knocks, that mere control of sources of wealth, whether in agricultural or industrial fields, does not in itself constitute wealth.

Four teams went into the lead in the Scottish Football League today with two triumphs each. Celtic, victor over Kilmarnock last week, gained a 1-0 decision over the Hamilton Academicals today. Clyde, Hearts and Partick Thistle were other teams to post two straight decisions.
Though they rallied somewhat last week, stocks on the Berlin Exchange have been falling almost continuously since Spring. This has been attributed to a variety of causes.

Few changes appear on the new honor roll that accompanies the Fall edition of the Metropolitan Golf Association's handicap list. When the Spring edition appeared Ray Billows, the Poughkeepsie printing salesman who was a member of the American Walker Cup team that lost to the British for the first time in history, was honored with a scratch handicap rating, the only golfer in the metropolitan district so honored.

Tass, the official Soviet news agency, said today that the Moscow government had sent a note to Japan "resolutely protesting" against "unprecedented lawless actions" concerning the alleged mistreatment of a Russian ship crew.

ANATOLE FRANCE got his initial recognition in the United States because a queer young Graeco-Irishman wanted to go to Japan. In 1889 Lafcadio Hearn came back to New York from the West Indies, but was soon overcome by a yen for the Orient.

A fleet of sixty-four boats raced off here today in the annual invitation regatta of the Point o' Woods Yacht Squadroni A dazzling sun and a light southwesterly made sailing conditions perfect. Duncan C. Arnold's Class R boat Querida, a converted Islip one-design, won easily, finishing nine minutes ahead of Frank M. Weeks's Yankee. Alva Collins's Alouette was third.

A 4.7 per cent increase in revenue passenger miles flown by domestic airlines during July as compared with the previous month was announced yesterday by Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of
The cost of living for families of wageearners and lower-salaried workers in thirty-two cities increased 0.4 per cent during the quarter ended on June 30, the Department of Labor announced today.

AN analysis of the American tourist made recently by the United States Travel Bureau ranks him as the nation's third largest industry, contributing to practically all businesses in every section of the country. In the South, which had over 40,000,000 visitors last year, he's still "that Yank from the North," observers note.

STILL a little bewildered by the swift turn of events which landed her overnight in Hollywood at the Selznick-International studio for the role of Ellen Fortune in "The Young in Heart," Minnie Dupree tried as best she could the other afternoon to straighten out the maze of contradictory reports which cropped up during her twenty-four-day stay in topsy-turvy land.

A Georgian colonial house of twelve rooms and five baths, with a three-car garage, on about an acre of land on Delancey Cove Road and Orienta Point, Mamaroneck, has been purchased by Charles L. Casanave of New York from Edward M. Newald of Florida.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--Henry Ford's experiments in the decenralization of industrial operations, Directed at giving employes "all he advantages of rural life with a :ity income." are reviewed by W. J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company in a paper prepared for discussion during one of the technical sessions of the seventh Internaional Management Congress, which s to be held here Sept. 19 to 23.

Skippers of the Mantoloking Yacht Club, representing Barnegat Bay, won the Barclay Cup, emblematic of team honors in 15-foot Perrines or Sneakboxes, today after the committee had acted on a protest by the Little Egg Harbor crews against the Bay Head Yacht Club.

Every kind of fire-fighting apparatus used in this city, except a fire boat, will be seen in action at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 8, 9 and 10, when the Fire Department's show, "The Midnight Alarm," will be staged for the benefit of the department band.

The Wissaboo Kennels' smooth fox terrier, Champion Nornay Saddler, was best in show today in the fourth annual Mohawk Valley Kennel Club exhibition at the Hotel Sagamore. Dr. Henry Jarrett of Chestnut Hill, Pa., the judge, praised the terrier highly in a fine tribute to the breeder, James M. Austin of Old Westbury, L. I.
Deaths from railway-crossing accidents in the first five months of this year numbered 590, a decrease of 164 from the same period last year, according to the Association of American Railroads.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis L. Baxter gave a reception this afternoon at their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Rhea Baxter, to Lieutenant Wallace Stafford Ford, United States Army Air Corps, of Pass Christian, Miss.

A nation-wide search was begun today for William G. Waldron, elderly Stockbridge tree surgeon, after the body of his wife, Edith Blair Waldron, had been exhumed from Stockbridge Cemetery and the vital organs submitted to State pathologists for analysis.
One of the most valuable tennis trophies in competition passed permanently into the keeping of J. Donald Budge today as he won the Newport challenge cup for the third time at the Casino.

IN the field of North Atlantic aviation, interest in the development of very large flying boats now is shared with that of the use of land planes for over-water flights, so successfully demonstrated by the round-trip crossing of the Atlantic by the German plane Condor for Lufthansa in fast time.

A total of 10,267 labor disputes in nineteen countries last year involved 4,223,994 workers and resulted in a loss of 50,755,454 working days, according to the 1938 edition of Labor Statistics Year Book, just published by the International Labor Office.

State American Federation of Labor President George Meany today charged the American Labor party was being run to suit the C. I. O. and not "to help labor." Speaking at the annual convention of the Carpenters and Joiners of America, Meany asserted:

Considering the repercussions of the German Army manoeuvres both in Germany and abroad, which went so far as to produce another war scare, there is as yet remarkably little evidence of them in the German landscape.

The gener?? level of wholesale prices in July about the same as in June, ?? ing to the Board of Trade index issued here today. The J?? index figure was 100.6, ?? with 100.7 for June and 111.5 ?? July, 1937.

Blood transfusions today strengthened the wife of Karl Krueger, conductor of the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra, and physicians expressed hope that she would recover from two bullet wounds inflicted in a strange "jealousy" shooting on Hollywood Boulevard.

Having attained the highest rating in a competitive examination, Miss Katherine Marie Turner of Victor, N. Y., who was graduated in June as head of a class of thirty-two pupils in the Victor High School, has received the Mother Augustine Gill Scholarship of the College of New Rochelle.

Among the passengers who sailed last night for Europe on the French liner Ile de France were Clark Eichelberger, director of the League of Nations Association in the United States, and Melvin Hildreth, member of the board of the organization.

Plans for the Westchester County Fall Flower Show, which will be held at the County Center at White Plains Sept. 14 to 17, will be completed at a special meeting on Monday, Aug. 29. Chairmen of the various committees will be present to answer questions and arrange lastminute details.

Although Tommy Goodwin's golf conquests have carried him through many sections of the country, he won the New York Athletic Club championship for the first time today at the Winged Foot Golf Club as he administered a 6-and-5 defeat to Joseph Gagliardi, former Williams linksman.
