The only event during the third day of the Silvermine Guild Music Festival today was the junior concert presented by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Quinto Maganini. A large audience including about 2,000 children attended the program this morning.

Miss Alice Marble, America's topranking woman tennis star, today won her third successive singles title of the year and then teamed with Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Cambridge to win the doubles title at the fourteenth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tournament.

LONDON.--The "Lambeth Walk," a new dance which had its origin in the spontaneous jollity of the old London Cockneys, is taking the ballrooms of Britain by storm. It seems destined to encircle the dancing world and has written a new chapter in English folklore.

WESTPORT. -- Friday and Saturday of this week have been set aside for what is expected to become a permanent feature of the late Summer season in the Adirondacks and the Champlain Valley: The first annual "Back to Dudley" father-and-son reunion at Camp Dudley on Lake Champlain.

Manuel Romero of Spain, seeded third, and Luis Chais, Puerto Rico, unseeded, advanced a round ahead of the field as the New York State Spanish open tennis singles championship tournament began on the courts of the Hispano Tennis Club yesterday.
A storm that has been brewing in the ranks of Cuyahoga County Democrats for years broke today and W. Burr Gongwer, political "czar" for more than thirty years, was ousted.

Several leading members of diplomatic and civic circles of Venezuelawere "proxy" attendants, following a Spanish tradition, at the marriage here yesterday morning of Miss Lulu Vargas Vila, daughter of Mrs. Josefa Tinedo de Vargas Vila of this city, formerly of Caracas, Venezuela, and the late Jose I. Vargas Vila,, to Chailes Henry Lee Jr. of New York.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is talk that Labor Stage, Inc., will invade the cinema and make a featurelength entertainment film. During the engagement of "Pins and Needles" in Los Angeles, Louis Schaffer, executive director of the theatrical unit of the I. L. G. W. U., spent considerable time in Hollywood investigating picture costs and methods of distribution, providing the film had a general appeal.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 20--Miss Margaret Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Potter Frothingham of this city, was married to Robinson Dudley Buck, son of Mrs. Henry Robinson Buck of Hartford and the late Mr. Buck, this afternoon in St. Mark's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Michael R. Barton.
Dr. Emil H. Rausch, president of the Wartburg Theological Seminary in Dubuque, Iowa, since 1932, died Friday night in a hospital after an appendectomy. He was 63 years old.

This week thousands of teachers are pouring out of their university and college classes to begin belated vacations or to return to early opening schools. As one large city school system warns its teachers about "degree chasing," others raise their requirements and send teachers credit hunting. I am a member of an increasingly large group who ask:

The Yankees and the Athletics, moving at express-train speed in precisely opposite directions, continued their flights at Shibe Park today as the Bronx Bombers toppled the Philadelphians, 11 to 3, before the derisive gaze of a gathering of 9,000.

ASHMAN--BARNET--Mr. and Mrs. I. Milton Barnet announce the marriage of their daughter, Ruth, to Mr. Wilbur C. Ashman, son of Mrs. Maurice W. Ashman and the late Dr. Ashman, on Aug. 19, 1938. FLANK--SCHWARTZ--Mr. and Mrs. Marks Schwartz, 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, announce the marriage of their daughter,

Howard R. Hughes added another aviation record to his growing list yesterday when he landed his round-the-world special Lockheed 14 monoplane at Floyd Bennett Field after a non-stop dash across the continent that set a new mark for commercial transport planes.

Zionists, leaders of the movement that seeks to make Palestine a cultural and economic homeland for Jews, met last week in Warsaw in what was called an "Emergency Conference." Chief among the problems discussed was that of the increasing terror that stalks today in the Holy Land. Should reprisals be taken when Arabs attack Jews, or should reliance be placed on the government, or British, protection?

Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, accompanied by his wife, Premier Bela Imredy, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya and War Minister Eugene Ratz, left Budapest tonight on a State visit to Germany.

Production of silver in the United States in June amounted to 4,679,000 fine ounces, compared with 4,813,000 in the preceding month and 5,487,000 in June, 1937, the American Bureau of Metal Statistics reported yesterday.

Improvement in securities and commodity prices last week was fairly general, responsive to the lessening of political tension in Europe and to. further assurances on the outlook for domestic industry and trade.

EFFORTS to popularize television are being renewed by the British Broadcasting Corporation in cooperation with the Radio Manufacturers Association. In two years only about 3,500 sets have been sold to the public in the Greater London area. According to statisticians, the potential market for receivers at the current price is 75,000 in the service area of Alexandra Palace.
Five new speed marks that will go on the books as world records were registered in the opening series of races today of the eighth annual National Sweepstakes Regatta.

AT Saint-Brieuc, in Brittany, they celebrated on Aug. 6 and the centenary of Jean Marie - Philippe - Auguste Mathias, Count de Villiers de l'IsleAdam, novelist, essayist, poet and eccentric from top to toe. Among those who lent to the ceremonies the luster of their names were Maurice Maeterlinck and Paul Valery.

Joe Burk of Bridgeboro, N. J., regained the Philadelphia singles sculling crown today on the Schuylkill River-in his first Philadelphia appearance since his overseas conquest of the Diamond Sculls. He took the mile event at the eighty-seventh annual Navy Day in 5:562-5 to win by two and a half lengths from C. Wurts Bissell of the University Barge Club. Al Voght did not defend his title.
Senator Pope of Idaho, whose defeat in the recent Democratic primary was a setback for the Administration, said today he was considering entering the November election as an independent candidate.

This Fall the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences in the University of Illinois will inaugurate an extensive personnel bureau service which will cover the three fields of educational, vocational and personal adjustment of the individual.

The latest attack by the chairman of the Republican National Committee on the Administration's reciprocal tradeagreement program will presumably be analyzed and answered by Secretary Hull in due season.

The Vancouver Daily Province in its news columns today says that German industrial interests, supported by the Berlin Government, have offered to provide the city of Vancouver with a modern, fully equipped fireboat in exchange for $200,000 worth of lumber.

A big, outdoor living room where family and guests can seat themselves in comfortable chairs, in among lilies and roses and delphiniums, and hear water cascading down over rocks near at hand, is the outstanding feature of the garden that Mr. and Mrs. Leon E. Daniels have created for themselves at New Dorp, S. I. There are surprises, too, in this garden,

The collection of bearded and Japanese iris at the New York State Institute of Applied Agriculture, Farmingdale, L. I., was started in 1935 as the result of an infestation of iris thrip-then a relatively new pest-at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where Dr. George M. Reed was engaged in growing and collecting iris varieties.
A fleet of Star Class yachts, contestants for the Twelfth District championship in a three-day regatta here, rode at anchor tonight after race officials postponed the final race for lack of wind.

A large home center is under development at Clifton, Passaic County, N. J., on the former Peter Hellnan estate comprising several acres.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 7, Special Orders 169, dated July 22, 1938, as orders Lieut. Col. Will I. Levy, CA.-Res., to active duty at Fort Hancock. N. J., for the period Aug. 19, to Sept. 1, is amended so as to order Lieut. Col. Levy to active duty at Fort Hancock, N. J., for the period Aug. 21, to Aug. 30.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Jane Hilbish, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Hilbish, to Adick Augustus Longway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Longway of this city, took place this afternoon in the Fourth Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Paul Holden Hays performed the ceremony.
TIMELY warning on the question of tire care in hot weather is given by the Rubber Manufacturers Association.
The Czechs are proving themselves the biggest disappointment in Europe. Throughout the past six months they have been the center of European interest.

SINGER, SAMUEL (Aug. 9) Estate, more than $10,000. To Beatrice Singer, widow, executrix, 110 Riverside Drive, insurance, Income of $200 per week for two years from stock in M. Singer Sons and residuary estate; Floflo Singer, 110 Riverside Drive, and Louise Singer. 5 Riverside Drive, daughters, succeeding estate in stock of M. Singer Sons until they reach 25, then principal of trust.

Samuel Sussman, president of the Pennsylvania Finance Company, now in temporary receivership, and Howard J. Levitt, former securities dealer, were held today in $5.000 bail for further hearing next Friday on charges of embezzlement and conspiracy.

EFFORTS to popularize television are being renewed by the British Broadcasting Corporation in cooperation with the Radio Manufacturers Association. In two years only about 3,500 sets have been sold to the public in the Greater London area. According to statisticians, the potential market for receivers at the current price is 75,000 in the service area of Alexandra Palace.
Five new speed marks that will go on the books as world records were registered in the opening series of races today of the eighth annual National Sweepstakes Regatta.

AT Saint-Brieuc, in Brittany, they celebrated on Aug. 6 and the centenary of Jean Marie - Philippe - Auguste Mathias, Count de Villiers de l'IsleAdam, novelist, essayist, poet and eccentric from top to toe. Among those who lent to the ceremonies the luster of their names were Maurice Maeterlinck and Paul Valery.

Joe Burk of Bridgeboro, N. J., regained the Philadelphia singles sculling crown today on the Schuylkill River-in his first Philadelphia appearance since his overseas conquest of the Diamond Sculls. He took the mile event at the eighty-seventh annual Navy Day in 5:562-5 to win by two and a half lengths from C. Wurts Bissell of the University Barge Club. Al Voght did not defend his title.
Senator Pope of Idaho, whose defeat in the recent Democratic primary was a setback for the Administration, said today he was considering entering the November election as an independent candidate.

This Fall the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences in the University of Illinois will inaugurate an extensive personnel bureau service which will cover the three fields of educational, vocational and personal adjustment of the individual.

THE story is told-and it happens to be true-of the wellknown stage star who, in La Crosse, Wis., a decade ago, hadn't arrived at the theatre at the scheduled starting time of her performance one evening.

Wesley J. and Edward Van Sciver of Island Heights, representing the Barnegat Bay fleet, sailed Serius to an easy victory in the first annual 25-mile ocean race held under the auspices of the Little Egg Harbor Yacht Club today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to bring to your attention the statement in THE TIMES for Aug. 19, commenting on the President's declaration at Queen's University. This statement reported from the State Department implies the extension of the Monroe Doctrine to Canada.

Miss Adele Ingalls, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wilson Ingalls of this place, has completed plans for her wedding to Carl Martin William Jenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin T. C. Jenter of Pelham.

A three-alarm fire yesterday afternoon wrecked the Monroe Street side of the Pechter Baking Company plant at 468 Cherry Street, between Corlears and Jackson Streets. Two firemen were slightly hurt. Arthur Hollender, day manager of the bakery, estimated the damage at $75,000.

The United States today is the safest and most independent of democratic powers. If this country has heavy problems that weigh upon its mind and disturb its internal peace, they are the problems of a divided household which is capable of solving them without either outside aid or outside hindrance.

Stabilization of retail prices in the New York gasoline trade through Feld-Crawford contracts may have a marked effect on advertising here, although, since the heavy selling season is drawing to a close, changes will not be put into effect until next year, according to comment in agency circles.

George Kame, president of the World Horse Traders Convention, locked up his office this morning and went to church, thus closing the 1938 meeting after four days in which he said 2,000 deals were made.
The schooner General A. W. Greely, with the MacGregor Arctic Expedition aboard, cleared Greenland at 10:30 Friday morning on its homeward voyage. We are now headed for the Straits of Belle Isle.

The Rev. Dr. S. C. Netting, president of the Western Theological Seminary, died at his home here this morning His age was 63. Besides his widow, two sons and a daughter survive: the Rev. James Netting, who has just taken a pastorate in New York,

ABRAMS--On Aug. 21, Martha widow of Myer Abrams of 118 St. Paul St., Brookline, Mass., in her eighty-third year; beloved mother of Maurice D. and David Abrams, Mrs. John S. Slater and Mrs. Hettie Bresky; grandmother of Mrs. Gerome M. Ullman and Mrs. George Weiss of New York City. Funeral on Aug. 23.

Members of the House committee investigating "un-American" activities considered today summoning General Hugh Johnson to tell what he knows of Communist or Left Wing agitation among Federal employes here and in New York.

Miss Kitty Wickes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forsyth Wickes of Newport, R. I., has chosen Sept. 9 as the date for her marriage to Ralph Hutchinson Poole Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Poole of Lake Forest, Ill.

There was an improved tone on the Boerse as the week ended amid less pessimism, but without any certainty that stocks touched their lowest levels during Wednesday's collapse, nor that the week-end rally marked the beginning of a period of recovery.
Touring American track and field stars, one of three squads now traveling in Europe, gained semen victories in thirteen events at a meet here today.
The Government of Costa Rica is preparing to build a sixtymile section of the Pan-American Highway to San Carlos, near the Nicaraguan border. Bids for machinery and equipment will be asked soon.

The number of documents certified by the foreign trade bureau of the Merchants Association in 1937 in connection with foreign trade shipments reached a higher total than ever before, according to the bureau's annual report, issued for publication today.

The third annual lawn and beach party sponsored by the Jewish War Veterans of Queens County for the patients of the Convalescent Home for Hebrew Children was held yesterday in front of the home, 110th Street and the Boardwalk, Rockaway Park.

Women's beach slacks and shorts are not in the Spanish tradition, so Enrique Ortega, Director of the Institute of Tourism sponsored by Governor Blanton Winship, has had cards printed for presentation to tourists that bear the following requests:

Twenty thousand regatta goers, sunning themselves on the decks of spectator yachts or on the sloping lawns of North Shrewsbury estates, came to see the thrills, spills and crashes at today's second and final afternoon of the national speed-boat sweepstakes but, instead, Jack Rutherfurd made the dangerous sport look disarmingly easy.
Following is the text of the answer of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Insurgent leader, to the British proposal for the withdrawal of foreign soldiers from the Spanish Civil War.

Count Court Haughwitz-Reventlow, who has talked with his wife, the former Barbara Hutton, here several times, left today by automobile for Salzburg, Germany. He twice had postponed his departure and yesterday went swimming with his wife at the Lido beach. This caused some speculation that there might be a reconciliation.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,890,473,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

For the first time in several months the price structure of Texas crude oil is seriously threatened, according to information received by the Railroad Commission. The disturbing factors may spread to the industry in Oklahoma, Kansas and other producing States, it was said.

Mrs. Elizabeth Lincoln Clark Webb, widow of George Leighton Webb, former vice president of the Storrs Bement Company, Boston, paper merchants, died on Friday in Boston, according to word received here yesterday. Mrs. Webb,

Demand for cash oats featured trading in that grain last week. Excessive rains and other unfavorable influences resulted in a light test weight oats crop to the bushel over a large area this year. The East, which normally draws supplies of oats from Ohio and Indiana at this season, has been forced to go further West.

Motion-picture theatres throughout Brooklyn were guarded by patrolmen and detectives yesterday as police officials continued their investigation of the stench and teargas bombings of twelve theatres of the Century Circuit, Inc., in that borough Saturday evening.

Michael J. Brown, president of Esslinger's Brewery here for the last twenty years, died tonight at his Summer home in Margate, N. J. He was 62 years old. Born in this city, he was educated in the public and parochial schools.

In seeking only happiness we have found neurosis, according to the Rev. Frank C. Williams, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, in a sermon yesterday in the Hanson Place Central Church in Brooklyn. "Lacking a great concept of the nobility of life, we have added sensation to sensation and we find ourselves in struggle
Bad weather today prevented the French Ministerial party from reaching Vallot Refuge near the summit of Mont Blanc and so it was dedicated from a distance.

The decisions of the French Government with respect to its choice of solutions for the financial problem will not become known until tomorrow. Financial circles expect that the government will insure greater stability for the currency and put to an end the contingency of further devaluation.

Bituminous coal producers' boards in the Central and Southwestern States were ordered today by the National Bituminous Coal Commission to file by Sept. 14 proposed minimum prices and marketing rules and regulations for their coal.

The British steel industry continues to lag. Some blame is placed on the stabilization of prices until the end of this year, but the falling demand and large stocks on hand are principal factors in the situation.

Relations between the Catholic church and Italy, which seemed to have returned to normal with yesterday's understanding between the Fascist party and Catholic Action, took a sudden turn for the worse today when the Pope termed exaggeration of nationalism "a real curse" in a short speech during a visit to missionary students at their college near the Papal villa. It was the first time the Pope has left his villa while vacationing at Castel Gandolfo.

Dudley P. K. Wood, in 950 Park Ave; Charles P. Coleman, in 960 Park Ave; Carpenter Realty Corp, broker. A. N. Spanel, in 1.100 Park Ave, through Douglas L. Elliman Co; Mrs. Paula Sherman, in 1,235 Park Ave. through Walter McMeehban: Henry Muench, in 20 E 55th St. through Potter, Hamilton Co; Meyer Steinberg, in 19 E 88th St. through Wallenstein Construction Co; Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

The challenge in the call to keep America Christian was discussed by the Rev. Dr. Ralph Walker, pastor of the Temple Baptist Church, Los Angeles, in a sermon yesterday in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 79.9, which compared with 80.2 the week before, 81 two weeks before, 81.6 three weeks before and 81.5 four weeks before.

With the exception of the sale by the New York School for the Deaf of its property on upper Riverside Drive for $1,500,000 to the Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center, realty activity in July was characterized chiefly by deals in districts where the lower valued properties abound, according to the Real Estate Board of New York in announcing its monthly analysis yesterday for the month of July.
Germany's Minister of Economics, Walther Funk, launched an attack today against "dollar politics" in a speech defending the Nazi German system of barter agreements in foreign trade.

E. R. Squibb Sons announced yesterday the creation of an industry-supported research enterprise dedicated to pure science in the medical and biological fields, comparable with the Bell Telephone and General Electric laboratories in the sphere of physics.

As the Administration prepared to subsidize exports of part of the nation's surplus wheat, the National Associtation of Manufacturers issued a statement declaring that "whether we shall ever be able to recover the export market for grains depends almost entirely on production and marketing control and on loan and price features of the new Agricultural Adjustment act."
The marriage of Miss Blanche Sukoenig, daughter of Mrs. Abraham Sukoenig of 160 West Ninetyfifth Street and the late Rev. Mr. Sukoenig, to Dr. Irvine Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris

Through William Jerome Daly, secretary of the Board of Transportation, the police located yesterday the chauffeur in connection with whose whereabouts they had broadcast an alarm for former Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan Saturday night.

Mrs. James Carneval, wife of a New York real estate operator and long a leading figure in various philanthropies, died suddenly Saturday morning in Lenox Hill Hospital of complications after an operation. Her age was 57.

In these effete times, when ice-cream sodas have come to the forecastle and "salt horse" and the grog tub are but memories of the past, it is reassuring to learn that the new has not entirely displaced the old, and that the traditions of yesterday still loom large in our sea service of today.
A deaf and mute congregation attendea a special mass in celebration of Ephphatha Sunday yesterday morning at the St. Francis Xavier Chapel, Sixteenth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

Present-day Christians have got themselves into a "desperate mess" by their faltering and compromised attitude toward their religion, the Rev. C. Leslie Atkins said in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets. Mr. Atkins is pastor of the Purley Congregational Church, Purley, England.

" Rigoletto," given last night at Randalls Island Stadium by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, drew an audience estimated at 6,000. In a last minute change, Leta May, soprano, substituted for Dea Lovati, in the principal feminine- role of Gilda.

James S. Cheek, a director of Silver, Burdett Company, textbook publishers, and manager of the firm's South Central division, died today in his sixty-second year, after a brief illness, at his home here.

France's economic and financial difficulties are far from being solved, but financial circles here welcomed the declaration in which Premier Edouard Daladier denied all rumors circulating to the effect that a further devaluation of the franc and control of exchange were in preparation.

The prosecution and defense analyzed over the week-end the testimony developed in the first week of the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, who is charged with conspiracy in the policy racket, and planned their procedure for the resumption of the case today before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and a blue-ribbon jury.

Industrial production for the second quarter of 1938 was 7.8 per cent less than in the first quarter and 8.7 per cent below the second quarter of 1937. The Board of Trade index, based on 1930 as 100, shows that industrial activity in the second quarter of this year fell slightly below that for the second quarter of 1936, the indices for these two periods being 122.1 and 122.3 respectively.

Mrs. J. Hunter Barton and her son, Alfred I. Barton of Philadelphia and Miami Beach, have as their house guests Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Miller of Cincinnati, Mrs. Mercer P. Mosley and Mr. and Mrs. E. K. Ludington of Great Neck, L. I., and others.

As the initial purchase in the assemblage of a large tract for a new Federal detention home. and farm near Danbury, Conn., the Federal Government has acquired 146 acres in the Pembroke district, a part of the Alfred Ruffles place, long known as an outstanding farm in that part of Connecticut.

George Baskin and Harry Goldstein, defending champions, advanced to the semi-final round of the national A. A. U. one-wall doubles handball tournament by defeating Joe Garber and Dave Lerner, 21-12, 21-19, at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Our master motive in life should be love of Christ in order to make life worth living and to bring us closer to other peoples, declared the Rev. Dr. J. Alfred Kaye, pastor of the New Court Congregational Church, London, in a sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Late rallies today decided both ends of a double-header by one run as the White Sox took the opener, 4 to 3, and the Indians eked out a nightcap decision, 3 to 2. Blanked for seven innings, Chicago drove Johnny Allen from the mound with a four-run rally in the eighth inning of the first game.

Stocks closed higher in slowest trading since week ended June 18; turnover, 3,321,930 shares. Treasury bonds reached new high levels; traction issues sharply higher; other bonds steady and mixed; transactions $23,547,875.

Landing in a storm, Dr. Thomas Melling and I reached the hospital at Chesterfield Inlet with Okumaaluk at 1:30 P. M. yesterday after 1,200 miles of an Arctic flight during which fog once forced us down and once forced us back.

Britain is finding herself powerless to cope with the present reign of terror in Palestine. After two and a half years of continuous Arab terrorism she still has not succeeded in subduing the rebellious elements. On the contrary they are growing stronger and bolder daily.

Infantrymen taxed the capacity of the Camp Smith cantonment today with the arrival of 2,400 State guardsmen from the New York and Buffalo areas for a two-week tour of instruction that will include rifle practice , musketry problems and tactical training, both on the reservation and in the bivouac area.
Senator Tydings called upon the people of Maryland tonight to rebuke President Roosevelt for his "interference" in the State's selection of its representatives in Congress.

The German wholesale price index for Aug. 10 was 106.1, unchanged for the week. In the first seven months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.9, on July 27. The lowest was 105.3, in the first two weeks of June.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Dayton of Sewaren, formerly of this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy A. Dayton, to Albert A.

The National Association of Manufacturers said yesterday that the recovery of foreign markets for United States farm products depended largely on three major agricultural items, according to a special report prepared by its agricultural committee, which finds that the shrinkage in exports of grain, meat and cotton accounted for more than 85 per cent of the decline in all United States farm exports.

Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana had a dinner party tonight at Birchwood, Lenox, for Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Morris and George Townsend Adee. At Bluefens, Stockbridge, Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas gave a dinner for Miss Frances M. Clucas.

Construction will begin today on the General Motors exhibit building at the New York World's Fair, with William S. Knudsen, president of the corporation, driving the first rivet. The building, to be known as "Highways and Horizons," has been designed by Norman Bel Geddes.

Today was a great day for the Gaels, when teams from each Province participated in games at Croke Park, marking the opening of the new Cusack Stand. The stand commemorates the name of Michael Cusack, first secretary and founder of the Gaelic Athletic Association. The ground now is capable of holding 70,000 spectators.

A total of $506,859 has been contribute to date to the Greater New York Fund by companies and employes of the electrical industry, it was announced last night. The group included power companies, broadcasting stations,
Mr. and Mrs. John D. Wing of 515 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of Mr. Wing's stepdaughter, Miss Barbara Belmont of 155 East Seventy-third Street, to Robert Livermore Jr.

The engagement of Miss Rosalie Rita Chambers, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Chambers of this city and Far Rockaway, and the late Mr. Chambers, to David W. Kaplan, son of Mrs. Jacob Kaplan of New York and the late Mr. Kaplan, has been announced by her mother.

Among the books that Viking will issue this Fall are "King of the Beggars," a life of Daniel O'Connell, the Irish "liberator," by Sean O'Faolain; Carl Van Doren's biography of Benjamin Franklin; "Parliamentary Government in England," by Harold J. Laski, and "It Is Later Than You Think," a challenge to liberals to defend democracy, by Max Lerner.
Twenty communities are listed in a special survey by the State Department of Health as having less than 35 per cent of their children under 5 years of age immunized against diphtheria as of June 1.

Indications that the stock market had not over-emphasized the proportions of a business upturn this Fall came in rapid succession last week and overshadowed the improved performance of the share prices. Apparently the market

In an effort to meet the constantly increasing demands of industrial concerns, public agencies and even large recreational centers for trained weather forecasters, New York University announced yesterday that a new Department of Meteorology would be opened at the College of Engineering next month.

Senator Pope of Idaho, who was recently defeated for renomination in the State Democratic primary, said after a conference with President Roosevelt today that he might run as an independent to succeed himself against Representative D. Worth. Clark, the party's
Ten orchestras will play swing, "sweet" and symphonic music next Wednesday night at the Randalls Island Stadium in the first of four "bandfests" for the benefit of blind musicians. Leon Leonidoff is

Judge Michael A. Musmanno of the Common Pleas Court, who has long contended that the Sacco-Vanzetti trial in Massachusetts was "framed," said today he would publish a book this Fall in which he would "prove their innocence" and name "the guilty persons."

BEHIND THE SCREEN, edited by Stephen Watts. (Dodge, $2.50.) An account of film production. CHANGING THE SKCYLINE, by Paul Starrett. (Whittlesey House, $3.) The autobiography of the builder. HOW -TO BECOME A GOOD DANCER, by Arthur Murray. (Simon.- Schuster, $1.95.) Instruction in modern ballroom dancing.

After three weeks of declining prices, the cotton market registered moderate gains last week. At the close on Saturday, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 7 to 15 points for the week. In the preceding week prices dropped 29 to 36 points here.

Francis Callus Sr., 93 years old, suffered a heart attack while taking a walk at noon yesterday on Parsons Boulevard, Jamaica. He was assisted to the Central Queens Branch of the Y. M. C. A. at Parsons Boulevard and Eighty-ninth Avenue and died before an ambulance from Mary Immaculate Hospital arrived.

MAURICE HINDUS made his discovery of America when he was a boy in his 'teens. Though that was a good many years ago, he hasn't said much if anything about it in print up to this point, having been interested rather in helping Americans discover Soviet Russia through such books as "Humanity Uprooted," "Red Bread" and "The Great Offensive."

W. C. Mennen, manufacturer of toilet preparations, tonight announced the marriage of his son, George, to Miss Mary Elizabeth Mahoney of Rochester, N. Y. "They ran away and were married and I have no objection," Mr. Mennen said.

Pacific Northwest Indians have paid to their "Great White Father in Washington," President Roosevelt, what to them is an unusual and sacred tribute. They have carved on a new totem pole on the Swinomish Reservation a bust of the President, sketched by an Indian maid, Eva Robb, of the Tulalip Reservation.

Dullness prevails on the Bourse, partly because of the war scare induced by Germany's mobilization for Fall manoeuvres, but the inaction appears to be ascribable above all to the unfavorable impression made in financial circles by the persistently weak tendency of the franc.

The text of Senator Tydings's radio speech tonight was as follows: Men and women of Maryland: Three weeks hence the Democratic voters of this State, at a primary election, will nominate a candidate for the United States Senate.

Carl Owen Hubbell entered a hospital tonight preparatory to placing his famed left arm under a surgeon's knife tomorrow in an attempt to remove the barrier to his resuming action with the new York Giants. An X-ray examination yesterday revealed a chip of bone loose in the south pawls pitching arm.

Miss Elsie Marie Wachter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Wachter of 2,320 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, was married last night to John Gustav Engel, son of Mrs. Edward Engel of Astoria, Queens, and the late Mr. Engel, in St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

Three United States naval cutters headed a parade of more than 200 other vessels from Clayton, N. Y., down the St. Lawrence River and back under the new Thousand Islands Bridge today, concluding a four-day

Mrs. Arthur Hoe, of the printing press manufacturing family, was fatally injured in an automobile collision here today. Funeral arrangements are awaiting arrival of her husband from New York. They maintained homes here and in New York.

Goodyear Waterproofing Co., raincoats, store at 799 Broadway; Margo Bags, Inc., ladies' handbags, in 20 W. 17th St; Frederick Fox Co., brokers. Charles Schumacher, restaurant, store at 127 E. 28th St; James Felt Co., brokers. Stanley and Max Greenwald, candy and stationery, store at 79 Audubon Ave; Edward Florence, radios, store at 599 W. 187th St Sokolow Co. brokers.

Hank Greenberg hit his forty-second home run today, but the Browns defeated Detroit, 9 to 4, to end the Tigers' six-game winning streak. Alton Benton started for the Tigers and pitched no-hit ball for five innings, but weakened in the sixth and was touched for two runs. A five-run rally in the eighth enabled St. Louis to clinch the victory.

With abandonment of "Northwest Passage," Metro will start "Stand Up and Fight" within two weeks. Walter Pidgeon, who recently completed "Too Hot to Handle," is the latest to be added to the cast, which will be headed by Wallace Beery and Robert Taylor. J. Walter Ruben will direct.

The ever-dangerous Cardinals defeated the Reds, 7-6 and 3-0, today at a time when the Reds had a chance to tie New York in second place the National League standings. After battling 2 hours and 44 minutes to win the first contest, the Cards needed only 1 hour and 29

The closing performance of the Dodger troupe at Ebbets Field yesterday, attended as it was by 26,885 paying patrons, was a monetary success. But as an artistic presentation it fell a bit short even of the drama critics' overworked "adequate."

Prices did not continue to recede here in the second week of August. The wholesale index on Aug. 17 was 644, compared with 640 a week before and 652 two weeks before. The gold index of raw materials was 41.0, compared with 42.0 and 42.1, respectively, in the two preceding weeks.

In a letter to Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating unAmerican activities, Nikander Strelsky of the Vassar College faculty defends Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, head of Federal Theatre Projects, who was for eight years his associate at Vassar, from "slanderous statements made before your committee."

Some 1,500 members of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, many in vividly colored academic robes, attended services at Great Saint Mary's Church to hear the Right Rev. C. F. Garbett, Bishop of Winchester, pass judgment on the part science has played in fashioning the world and to attribute to the lack of human character the abuse of science today.

Beethoven's Ninth symphony brought the second Silvermine Guild music festival to a close here tonight on a jubilant, heroic note, Eugene Ormandy directed the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the final event of the four-day festival, and for the last movement of the Ninth, he had the assistance of four soloists and a chorus of about 500.

A fundamental readjustment of Japan's relations with the principal powers that are interested in China, the United States, Britain, France and Germany, is expected to result from a resumption of conversations between Sir Robert L. Craigie, the British Ambassador, and General Kazushige Ugaki, the Japanese Foreign Minister, according to Tokyo newspapers.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Dora Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

The corn market made only a moderate response last week to the strength in wheat and to the announcement that the Argicultural Adjustment Administration would pay a larger benefit to farmers who agreed to cooperate with the government in its effort to adjust. supply to demand.
Miss Emily Maxine Ullman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell L. Ullman of this city and Far Rockaway, Queens, will be married to Louis Praeger Heyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Heyman

Leonard Carney of the Dragon Club captured the Metropolitan A. A. U. senior fancy diving championship from a ten-foot board yesterday at the Broad Channel Bathing Park. He compiled 112.10 points to win by a wide margin. A clubmate, Sol Schrebnick, was runnerup with 106.17.

A feature length film designed to portray a dramatic and comprehensive picture of the history of the motion picture to date will be produced for general release by the Film Library of the Museum of Modern Art, it was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, president. The picture is as yet untitled.

In an effort to restrain the police from preventing the reopening of the Orangeburg dog-racing track under a new system of betting the operators of the track have had a show-cause order served upon three State officials, it was learned today.

Jenter Exhibits, Inc., is putting up a new plant and office building in Ridgewood, N. J., in anticipation of twelve months of record-breaking business in connection with the New York World's Fair. The building is designed especially for the production of exhibition displays.

Exchange Buffet Corporation-First quarter, ended July 31: Net loss, $30,083, after depreciation of $29,069, compared with a loss of $23,544 after $28,378 depreciation in first quarter of previous fiscal year.

Fine weather favored the opening of the two Canaans' bicentennial celebration today, and a crowd of 5,000 visitors joined hundreds of Canaan and Falls Village residents this afternoon at the historical exhibition following church services in the forenoon.

No attempt to enter into competition with other European countries as regards transatlantic flights will be made by The Netherlands for several years, it is indicated in a statement published today by a government official.

A good demand for housing properties in Brooklyn was indicated by transactions reported over the week-end. The Kingston Savings Bank sold to Lexington Builders, Inc., Philip Davis, president, the four-story brick building on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 1,077-79 Bedford Avenue, assessed at $15,500.

Sir John Rahere Paget, British lawyer and banking expert who advised United States authorities on financial problems before -the World War, died in his sleep last night after a brief illness. He was 90 years old.

For the first time since mid-July, the average for active stocks on the Boerse on Saturday closed higher than on thepreceding Saturday. In the first three days of last week, the collapse proceeded at an accelerated pace, with drops ranging up to 7 points on single days and in exceptional cases to much more thanthat.
Robert Bowman Dodson of 960 Park Avenue, a retired banker and broker, died yesterday at his country home in West Islip, L. I., after a long illness, at the age of 89.

The combined cost of home and work relief in this city for the first seven months of 1938-was $9,048,701 below the total for the same months last year, but there were 41,115 more cases on the rolls on Aug. 1, 1938, than there were a year before, an analysis disclosed yesterday.

This week's unrest in the foreign exchange markets was again of an intricate nature. Apart from fear of a European conflict and seasonal demand for dollars creating general weakness in European currencies, nervousness regarding the pound-dollar parity was the dominating influence.

Funeral services for Dr. William M. Higgins of 549 Riverside Drive will be held at 2 P. M. today in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. Dr. Higgins, who died on Saturday at the age of 57, is survived by his widow, Mrs. Sarah Burke Higgins; two sons,

W. B. Gorman, acting treasurer of Franklin Simon Co., will become controller of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, N. J., on Oct. 1, according to announcement for publication today by William J. Wells, president of Bamberger's. Mr. Gorman will operate under the direction of Hector Suyker, treasurer of the Newark store. Paul Loeb,

The statement for the first half of 1938 of the American Smelting and Refining Company, released for 1 publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $5,112,668 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.53 1/2 each on the 2,191,669 common shares.

The markets are standing up well under the complexities and anxieties of the industrial, political and financial situations. The worst that is happening to the securities markets is the gentle sagging of quotations, and even this is traceable partly to the holiday inertia under which the City is now laboring.
Miss Jane Margaret Hart, daughter of Mrs. Ray Henry Hart of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to William Du Pont Staab, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Staab of Glen Ridge.

Almost six hours of slow sailing today brought results to D. Swing Starring's Scamp from Southport, Conn., in the "long-distance" race for Atlantic Class boats. They went from Hicks Ledge to Captain's Island and return, a distance of twenty miles for the round trip.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Beatrice Gleason of this city and East Orange, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert James Gleason, to William C. Moore
The Campbell Soup Company announced today the establishment of a retirement and pension find for all its full-time employes who reach the age of 65.

The death of an elderly man at the wheel of his automobile caused the car to swerve into a roadside stand on Jerusalem Avenue, near Jerusalem Road, East Hempstead, today, injuring four persons. The driver,

Classing President Roosevelt with Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin, as ones who had "made a good thing of the theories of Karl Marx," Theodore Dreiser declared upon bis arrival here today that a five-weeks' trip abroad had convinced him the leaders would not succeed in changing the people.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 71.4 on Aug. 17, compared with 72 a fortnight before, 72.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain. The present level

Washington came from behind today to gain its first victory of the season in Boston, 5 to 4, but dropped the second half of a double bill with the Red Sox, 7 to 2. The nightcap was Joe Heving's second victory in a row since he came to the Sox recently from the American Association.

Unless we sink our roots in Christ we shall have no spiritual vision, according to the Rev. Dr. Olin McKendree Jones, former pastor of the Glen Avon Presbyterian Church, Duluth, Minn., in a sermon yesterday in the Fort Washington Church, 174th Street, near Broadway.

Undeclared wars rage in two continents while the nation observes this week the tenth anniversary of the Kellogg pact designed to outlaw war. Historians say that the Kellogg pact, intended to eliminate war "as an instrument of national policy," has had the unfortunate effect of producing a new type of conflictthe undeclared war and even the concealed war.

Mrs. Alice L. Freudenthal of 24 West Eighty-eighth Street, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a lengthy illness. Her age was 73. She was the widow of Dr. Wolff Freudenthal, one of the leading throat specialists in this city at his death in 1930.

Vienna's West Station was transformed into a huge reception hall this morning to welcome Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, and his wife, accompanied by many distinguished persons. The party was received by Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Governor of Austria, and his wife, who presented a magnificent bouquet to Mme. Horthy.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 41 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the week before and up 4 points in three weeks.

The Rev. Lester H. Bent, pastor of the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, ascended a winding stairway to a high pulpit in the old Dutch Church at Sleepy Hollow here this afternoon and conducted the first of eight Sunday vesper services for which the little fieldstone edifice is reopened each Summer.

Bryce P. Holcomb, business agent of Local No. 368 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, announced today that his organization had endorsed Representative John J. O'Connor of New York for re-election.
Mr. and Mrs. George Tyson, who have the latter's sister, Mrs. George Mesta, as their guest at Beach Mound; gave a large luncheon today.

Aces back to back form a good combination in baseball as well as stud poker and since Marse Joe McCarthy had the foresight to deal his two pitching aces, Lefty Gomez and Red Ruffing, at Shibe Park today the Yankees took the entire pot.

Orders by railroads for freight cars were at the highest level of the year on Aug. 1, the Association of American Railroads announced today. There were 10,234 freight cars on order on Aug. 1, compared with 5,021 a month earlier and 38,089 on Aug. 1, 1937.
Twenty burglaries in the Bronx, Westchester, Albany and North Jersey were attributed to two suspects arrested here yesterday by the New York and Westchester County Parkway police.

A twenty-five-foot putt that missed the cup on the eighteenth green by inches cost Jess W. Sweetser of Maidstone, former British and American amateur golf champion, his Maidstone Bowl final today with John R. Parker of Essex County and a chance to retire the handsome silver trophy. Sweetser,

A cotton textile factory in the town of Parras de la Fuente, in the State of Coahuila, has discharged 500 workers and operations have been reduced, the newspaper Universal says. According to the manager

F. D. Russell, president of the Security Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Binghamton, and chairman of the newly formed New York State unit of the National Conference of Investors, has addressed a letter to 200,000 railroad bond and stock owners in this State urging them to organize and use their influence with their governmental representatives,
A two-day hunger strike at the Philadelphia county prison in Holmesburg was described tonight by William B. Mills, the superintendent, as "all over but the grumbling."
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rita Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Joseph Rose of 645 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, to Jacques Laitmon, also of Brooklyn.

Samuel William Jacobs, lawyer and first Jewish member of the House of Commons, died at his home here today after a year's illness. Mr. Jacobs, who had been a Liberal member for Cartier (Montreal) since 1917, was 67 years old.
The Burnt Mills Polo Club's winning streak was threatened for a time today when the Long Acre Farms four staged a last-period rally. But Burnt Mills set up a stiff defense to triumph 7-6.
John L. Ackley, widely known because of his services in the pure food enforcement division of the State Department of Agriculture, died at his home in Penn Yan last night at the age of 72.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today spent a Sunday of intensive study of Soviet technical progress in aviation. In the morning engineers showed him the Soviet Union's principal airplane motor factory near

Secretary Hull's comments on State Secretary Rudolf Brinkmann's address here are not well taken, and their effect has been deepened by President Roosevelt's address at Kingston, which the Beobachter describes as "warlike."

The Little Entente conference held its first formal meeting at Bled, Yugoslavia, this morning. The Czechoslovak Foreign Minister arrived at 10:30 on a special train to which the Rumanian Foreign Minister's special car was attached at the frontier.

Putting down his cup of tea and peering across the luncheon table, Racing Secretary John Blanks Campbell said to his cheerful assistant, Francis P. Dunne: "I don't know about that." "Well, you know now," said Francis in a lordly way, "because I'm telling you. El Chico isn't in the Futurity. I looked it up."

In a statement released through the local headquarters of the Legion of Decency, the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Cincinnati and chairman of the Episcopal Committee on Motion Pictures, announced yesterday
The six destroyers that anchored in the Hudson off Eighty-sixth Street on Saturday were joined yesterday by a battleship, the U. S. S. Arkansas.

In a radio talk lastweek and more fully in an article in THE TIMES Magazine yesterday, Thurman Arnold, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust activities, set forth more clearly than hitherto the Administration's present policy in this regard.

The peace of the world depends more on the United States than on the British Empire, and the greatest impetus toward peace comes from the friendliness between the countries of the North American continent and their cooperation with the British Empire, the Rev. E. D. Jarvis of the Wellington Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland, declared here yesterday.

Charged with grand larceny in the theft of medical supplies and equipment valued at $300 from the United States Marine Hospital at 67 Hudson Street, five men were held yesterday by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Felony Court for a hearing Friday.

A peace agreement designed to end the sixteen-week strike of employes of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company will be submitted to members of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, a C. I. 0. union, tomorrow.

The Democratic State Committee will meet today at the National Democratic Club to set the date for the- party's State convention this Fall, to pick the convention keynote speaker and temporary and permanent chairman and, unofficially, to pick a slate of candidates.

Governor A. Harry Moore criticized today the Broad Street Association's efforts to get the Newark City Commission to discontinueWPA projects and substitute direct relief. The association, which includes the city's largest merchants, says Newark pays $15 a month for persons on WPA and only $6.60 for those receiving direct relief.

Miss Zeda Elizabeth Sorensen of this city, a teacher in the New York City public school system since 1909, died in the White Plains Hospital today after an illness of eight months. She was 58 years old. Born in Denmark, she was graduated from White Plains High School in 1900 and from Jamaica (Queens)

The Pegasus Polo Club of Rockleigh, N. J., competing in the sport for the first time this year, made a splendid comeback to top the Governors Island quartet, 7-6, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field for the Northeastern Intra-circuit championship.

More things are right with the world than wrong, the Right Rev. Fred Ingsley, Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Colorado, said in his. sermon yesterday morning at the Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street.
Among arrivals for the national rifle and pistol matches today were the New York National Guard and the New York civilian teams, representing the best pistol and rifle shots of the Empire State.

Joseph Cadden, chairman of the United States delegation to the Second World Youth Congress now in session at Vassar College, made an apology today to the foreign delegates for what he termed the "rude and stupid" treatment they had sustained at the hands of a few American "publicity seekers."

Eugene M. Lowenthal, senior partner in the firm of Max Lowenthal Sons, knit goods manufacturers, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 61. Mr. Lowenthal, who was born in Rochester, had been in the knitting business since 1897. He was prominent in civic circles.

Charles A. Gabor of the Lake Mohawk Yacht Club regained the North Atlantic Coast Snipe Class title which he held in 1933 by capturing the third and final race of the sixth annual championship on Lake Mohawk today. Gabor,
Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy of Philadelphia and Palm Beach are visiting Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse. Mrs. Woodhouse gave a dinner for them tonight at the Hedges Inn.

Free competition and the working of economic laws will control adequately the size of big business, and the government should step in only where monopolistic practices and price-fixing agreements exist, according to a consensus of business executives queried in a recent

Further paralysis of San Francisco's vital warehouse industry, already hit by the tie-up of thirty-five major warehouses, is threatened tomorrow when a picketed Woolworth freight car resumes its journey past the platforms of warehouses still in operation.

The Southwest's most wanted desperadoes, Floyd Hamilton and Ted Walters, were captured by six Dallas detectives early today soon after they had eluded several Federal agents who had swooped down on their South Dallas hideout.

General Joseph Vuillemin, chief of the French air force, on returning to France after a visit to Germany that gave him a full view of the Third Reich's accomplishments in aviation, tonight telegraphed his congratulations to Air Minister Hermann Goering.
Dr. O. H. Tittman, former head of the Geodetic Coast Survey and president of the National Geogrpahic Society, 1915-19, died in his home here today at the age of 88.

Today the Civil Aeronautics Authority takes over the direction of civil aviation in these United States. It is too much, perhaps, to say that the day marks the beginning of a new era for aviation, but it cannot be gainsaid that the date is an auspicious one for all persons interested in the future of commercial and private flying.

New York State carpenters joined the Allied Printing Trades Unions in an attack on the American Labor Party today as delegates gathered for the annual convention of the State Federation of Labor here this week.

Because they fail to achieve the end for which God made man, the most "successful" men in the world are often the greatest failures, the Rev. John C. McCarthy declared yesterday in his first sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father McCarthy, who was ordained in the cathedral in June, is a temporary member of the staff.
Mrs. Chauncey Olcott entertained with a moonlight barbecue in the gardens of Innescarra, her villa, tonight for Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler Jr. and their house guests.
Willis Anderson of Los Angeles won the men's singles championship of the national public courts tennis tournament today, rallying to beat David Freeman of Pasadena, Calif., 7-5. 3-6. 3-6. 6-1. 6-2.

Celebrating her ninety- seventh birthday today at the home of her daughter,. Mrs. Charles Rochat of 311 North Fullerton Avenue, Mrs. George F. Lewis looked forward to paying a visit next year to the New York World's Fair. As a girl of 10,
The longest funeral procession Shanghai has witnessed in twenty years marched today behind the body of Lo Liang-kwei, International Settlement police official who was assassinated last Thursday.

A plot of land on the Tisdale Road in the Crane-Berkley development at Scarsdale, N. Y., has been sold by the Crane-Berkley Corporation to the Cottage Colony Corporation of Scarsdale for improvement with a dwelling. Prince Ripley arranged the sale.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William W. Weitlich of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Virginia Weitlich, to Charles Frederick Gieg, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Frederick Gieg of Rosemont, Pa.

There is a happy augury not only for the automobile industry itself but for general business, in which it plays so important a part, in Secretary Roper's summary of the motor-car situation in the United States.

Light Horse Harry Cooper of Chicago and Slammin' Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., will meet in an 18-hole play-off at the Mississagua Club tomorrow for the Canadian open championship and $400 in prize money.

" The object of Christianity is to enable us to understand the nature of our kinship with God, not merely to make us good, for true goodness is merely a by-product of this kinship," the Rev. Dr. John C. Schroeder, Professor of Homiletics at the Yale University Divinity School, said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

The government has decreed the establishment of a special State tribunal at Vienna to try members of the former Austrian Federal and provincial governments for "violations of law or acts believed inimical to the State."

A valuable, or rather invaluable, addition to the History of the Recorded Word Exhibition in The New York Times Annex, Conrad Gesner's book on fossils (Zurich, 1565) contains the first known reference to the lead pencil. He describes it as an article for writing made of wood and a piece of lead or, as he thought, a composition called stimmi anglicanum (English antimony). As the Borrowdale Mine
Members of the Summer colony of Mount Desert Island, who entertrained at the supper in the Bar Harbor Club tonight, included General and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth, Miss Frances Coleman,
By the narrow margin of two points, a team of United States swimming stars shaded Europe's top-flight performers, 38 to 36, in a two-day meet which ended at the Olympic Swimming Stadium today.

Mrs. Catharine I. McCooey, widow of John H. McCooey, who was the Brooklyn Democratic leader for many years, died yesterday morning at her home, 90 Eighth Avenue Death was caused by heart disease, from which she had been suffering for several months. She was 66 years old.

Billy Winn of Detroit and Kansas City, rated among the country's leading automobile race drivers, died late last night of injuries incurred yesterday when his car blew a tire and overturned on the fourth lap of the 100-mile race at the Illinois State Fair.

Trade in lard futures on the Board of Trade was somewhat restricted last week. The market was influenced at times by the action of cottonseed oil and corn, liquidation by holders of futures was absorbed by brokers who frequently act for packers and cash interests and closing trades yesterday were at net gains of 5 to 12 1/2 cents a hundredweight.

Commercial and industrial activity is virtually at a standstill here because of the holidays, but nevertheless it is observed that many industries, particularly textiles, are renewing their stocks of raw materials, so that the conclusion is drawn that an increased demand is expected this Autumn.

Si Johnson stood off three lateinning stands by the Newark Bears today to notch a 4-3 triumph for the Red Wings in the first half of a double bill, but the league-leading Bruins took advantage of one bad inning by Al Sherer in the nightcap to win, 2-1.

Madison St. 112: Theodore L. Bailey to John A. Garone ($1). 8th St, 58-60 W; Douglas Manor Realty Associates to Ralph-Guffin Realty Corp, 271 Madison Ave; mtgs $176,850 and purchase money mtg $12,500 ($25). 40th St. 108-12 W; Duval Realty Corp -to Arjento Realty Corp; mtg $712,800 ($131).

Railroads still kill people, as the report of the Interstate Commerce Commission for the first five months of 1938, made public a few days ago, reveals. During those five months they killed 1,629 persons-some of them employes, a few of them passengers, many of them in the class legally called trespassers.

Autumn plans for the "Q" Theatre include a dozen new plays, most of which are eventually expected to reach the West End. The first of these, "Room for Two," a comedy by Gilbert Wakefield, will have its premiere tomorrow. Produced by Richard Bird, the cast is headed by Elsie Randolph, who will be seen in her first straight part.

Harry C. Ferringer, who as Mayor from 1929 to 1934 was the leader in wiping out this city's debt, died suddenly this morning at the age of 68. Death was due to injuries suffered ten days ago in an automobile accident. Ferringer served with
The police broadcast an alarm last night for a hit-and-run boy bicyclist after he struck and knocked down Johnson Lowe, 39 years old, of 295 Broome Street, at Broome and Forsyth Streets.

Jenny Morris, wartime "mother" of the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry, arrived here tonight aboard the liner Antonia to visit her "boys" and was hugged and kissed by a contingent of veterans greeting her.

Six crews representing the Coast Guard districts embracing the Atlantic Coast from the Canadian border to South Carolina will engage in a capsize race as an added attraction to the twelfth annual international lifeboat race on Sept. 10 in the waters of the harbor off the Bay Ridge shore.

A circulation of 232,249 volumes for the last academic year was reported today by Lawrence Heyl, acting librarian of the Princeton University Library. Mr. Heyl also pointed to a significant increase in Princeton's borrowing and lending to other institutions.

Lionel F. Cutten, president and founder of Cutten Foster, Ltd., importers and manufacturers, died at his home here today after a brief heart illness. Born 66 years ago in Guelph, Ont., he was active in business until his illness.

Nello (Flash) Falaschi and Leonard (Feets) Barnum, the two prize rookies of the New York Football Giants' bumper 1938 crop, passed their first real test with flying colors today as Coach Steve Owen's squad, preparing for the battle with the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7, held its first scrimmage at the Blue Hill Country Club.

Further details have been made public of Philip Dunning's plan (outlined in these columns last Wednesday) for a show comprising scenes from plays of other Broadway years. Under the tentative title of "Great Scenes from Great Plays," and scheduled for a Broadway opening before Thanksgiving, there will be two and perhaps three alternating bills, each consisting of six excerpts running fifteen or twenty minutes.

The world wheat market steadied last week after having been on the down-grade several weeks. The recession ended when the September delivery on the Board of Trade here sold at 60 cents a bushel, the lowest price for any delivery in more than thirty years with the exception of the depression period of 1931-33.
St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church of Flushing, Queens, died yesterday at Westfield, N. Y., while on his vacation. His age was 70.

The State Constitutional Convention when it meets for its final session Thursday will have its last opportunity to rescind its suddenly passed amendment declaring proportional representation unconstitutional, or to make any other changes it desires. It is not expected, however,

Dr. Hugh R. Munro of Montclair, N. J., president of the Stony Brook Assembly, opened the twenty-eighth annual session of the General Bible Conference here this morning with a challenge to the 400 persons present to go forward to a fuller spiritual life.

President Roosevelt's first campaign thrust at Senator Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith, the remark that he (the President) did not believe "any family or any man can live on 50 cents a day in this State," is obviously rebounding now to the benefit of the veteran Senator in

The annual "ocean race" of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet from Manhasset Bay to Captain's Island off Greenwich today was taken by Durbin Hunter's Foo. Thirty-five yachts started in the twenty-five-mile event, which was sailed in light and variable breezes.

Acting on instruction from the Foreign Office, Marian Chovacki, Polish High Commissioner in Danzig, has officially protested to the Nazi authorities in Danzig against the mistreatment of Poles in the Free City.

The body of Ben Leider, said to have been the first American to die fighting for the Spanish Loyalist forces, was buried yesterday in Mount Hebron Cemetery, Rodman Street and Horace Harding Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, in the presence of 300 of his relatives and A: friends. Mr. Leider, formerly

The village of Ruzomberok was packed today by thousands of mourners who had come to follow Mgr. Andreas Hlinka's coffin to its last resting place. The funeral procession was a mass of color, furnished by picturesque Slovak costumes and foreign delegations that included deputations from the Polish Sejm
Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw Entertained with a dinner tonight it Wind Break, their place on the cean, for his brother-in-law and ister, Count and Countess Roger Le Perigny of Paris.

Lumber production in the United States in the week ended on Aug. 13, when 519 mills produced 220,524,000 feet of hardwoods and softwoods, was the highest of the year to date and was equivalent to 66 per cent of the average weekly production in 1929, the National Lumber Manufacturers Association reported today.

The cotton market here was quiet last week, with traders unwilling to enter upon new commitments until some definite announcement should be received from Washington concerning the terms and conditions of the government loan on new-crop cotton. Fears that to resort to the

Former State Senator William H. J. Ely of Rutherford, former WPA administrator of New Jersey, opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator here today by declaring that he has been associated with the political family

Dr. Joseph Tenenbaum, chairman of the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and Jewish Labor Committee, has sent a statement to Vladimir Hurban, the Czecholovak Minister, emphasizing that no boycott has been carried on in the United States against merchandise originating in the Sudeten area of Czechoslovakia.

An announcement in Battle Creek that a tractor manufacturing company there was to be taken over by the Federal Government and moved to Arthurdale, W. Va., was cited in a statement today by Representative Shafer, Michigan Republican,

A more cheerful tone prevailed in commodity markets last week and virtually all items moved into higher ground, according to The Annalist. The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 0.6 point to 79.9 on Saturday. Prices are now fractionally above the low levels for the last four years and compare with 94.6 a year ago.
Mr. and Mrs. John Courtland Maxvell of New York were luncheon Losts today at the Nassau Country club, Glen Cove, during the tennis latches on the club courts. Others who entertained were Mr. and Mrs.

The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., Reports net earnings for the fiftytwo weeks ended on July 16 of $1,378,568, after provision for taxes, depreciation and all other operating charges. This is equivalent to $4.92 a share on the 280,000 shares of stock outstanding.

Louis S. Ritter, formerly vice president and secretary of Connecticut Distilleries, has been appointed district manager for the sale of Carstairs products in metropolitan New York, according to announcement by James M. Elliott, vice president of Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company.

The National Labor Relations Board today issued an order against the Freed Heater and Manufacturing Company of Collegeville, Pa., based upon a settlement agreement disposing of unfair labor practice charges filed against the company by Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of North America, Lodge No. 1847, a Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate.

Aknusti served notice today on the polo world that it would be a factor in the coming national open championship, when the Gerry team extended Greentree to the limit at the Sands Point Club, yielding only in the last two periods

The finals of the annual "Barber Shop Quartet" contest and the "Hill Billy" contest will take place on the Central Park Mall on Sept. 8 at 8:30 P. M. The borough eliminations for both contests will take place as follows: Thursday, 8:30 P. M.-Brooklyn, Prospect Park; Queens, Forest Park.

Won by Ward Frauenthal, Freeport, L. I.: Thomas Cudney, Westville. N. J., second; Louis Heintzelman, Allentown, Pa., third; M. Duane Whitney, Red Bank. N. J., fourth; Kent Linkins, Annapolis, Md., fifth; Edward P. Evans, Dover. Del., sixth. Time--8:08. Speed-36.885 M. P. H.
Heavy machine gun fire enveloping the entire western boundary of the city caused excitement among residents there early today as Chinese guerrillas renewed attacks upon Japanese outposts.

The fall of the pound sterling against the dollar appears at last to have been definitely arrested, while the rush to hoard gold is slowly abating. It was only a question of time before these movements exhausted themselves naturally, but the scare which has now subsided lasted considerably longer than had been expected.

Benjamin Crawford Cutler, 30year-old orchestra leader and former all-around star athlete at Yale, narrowly escaped death early yesterday morning when the borrowed sedan he was driving battered down trees, concrete benches and an iron railing and then plunged into the East River near East Sixty-fifth Street, settling in forty feet of water.

Highly beneficial rain fell last week over a large part of the Corn Belt, and while more is needed in some areas to carry the new crop to maturing, a considerable percentage of the grain has developed to a point where there is likely to be little damage to pollination from now on.

The Supreme Soviet (Parliament) ended its sessions today after sitting since Aug. 10. The last day's proceedings ineluded voting a tax on horses of uncollectivized peasants which probably will have the effect of inducing most of them to join collective farms. At present only 7 per cent

The first show of the Wildwood K. C. drew a crowd of about 5,000 today as Champion My Own Brucie, owned, bred and handled by Herman E. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie. took chief honors. The handsome black cocker spaniel was named as best by Peter A. B. Widener in a splendidly balanced field of group winners.

The Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1936, further enforcing his statement that he would not accept the nomination "in the remote contingency" it was offered to him in 1940, presents here, in the second of a series of four daily articles,

The United Kingdom and the United States were Canada's best customers in July, according to a report by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics today. The United Kingdom took $25,796,000 of goods, compared with $36,495,000 in July, 1937, and the United States took $21,646,000, compared with $40,354,000.

Foreign exchanges developed a moderately higher trend last week in contrast to the general irregularity and new lows established in the preceding fortnight. Bankers ascribed the rally to the disappearance of the nervousness over the international situation, this calmness being heightened at the week-end by reports of concessions by Czechoslovakia in the dispute with the Sudeten Germans and the appointment of the latter group to minor government posts.

Three seizures of Mexican oil have occurred in Holland recently. The first embargo of 10,000 tons effected by the Batavian Petroleum Company - Royal Dutch operating unit-was withdrawn on order of the Middelburg court, which held that the Dutch-judge was not competent to test the constitutional nature of the Mexican expropriation laws, and that it was not proved that the oil originated from the former Mexican Eagle fields.

A total of 779,449,000 riders used the city's rapid-transit, street-car, motor-bus and Manhattan Hudson tube lines in the quarter ended last March 31, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.

A total of 779,449,000 riders used the city's rapid-transit, street-car, motor-bus and Manhattan Hudson tube lines in the quarter ended last March 31, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission.
Another day of heavy and ceaseless attacks by the Insurgents against the Villalba position at the Ebro bridgehead has ended in failure to break the Loyalist front, says tonight's official communique.

Dick Merrill, veteran flier, said tonight that he was planning a twelvehour flight across the Atlantic Ocean in September in a stock plane manufactured by an unnamed company for a demonstration to the French Government.

Motivated by sheer desperation, the Giants traded all sorts of blows with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday but though they managed to come off with a good draw in a fist fight, they lost the ball game which, so far as 8,970 onlookers were concerned, was really the main point at issue.
Dr. Frederick W. Marvel, director of athletics at. Brown University, died today at his Summer home in Richmond, R. I., at the age of 69.

The first submarine mail arrived at Barcelona yesterday afternoon from the Valencia zone providing a unique item for stamp collectors the world over. Thousands of letters were carried safely and on schedule.

Festoon Farms coupled teamwork with accurate goal shooting today to down the Monmouth County Country Club poloists, 11 to 8, in a special match for the Phillips Trophies. Milton F. Untermeyer Jr. registered five goal for the winners.
A five-car I. R. T. subway train inched slowly south under the stalactites of the deep-set 181st Street station early yesterday morning on an unprecedented man-hunt.

Mrs. Edwin A. Strong will return to the Plaza this week after visiting at Saratoga Springs and Cape Cod. Prescott Childs, United States Consul at Barbados, British West Indies, and Mrs. Childs are expected to arrive this week at the Madison.

The Cubs, beaten in six of their last seven games, regained their winning punch today before a nearcapacity crowd of 40,402 and defeated the National League's pacesetting Pirates in both games of a double-header, 6 to 4 and 6 to 1.

The National Geographic-Harvard University Expedition yesterday discovered without question the largest glacier system in the world outside the Polar ice caps. We landed at Cordova Saturday afternoon after a wonderfully successful flight down the backbone of the St. Elias Range.

David S. Muzzey, Professor of History at Columbia University, on his return yesterday on the Anchor liner Cameronia from a ten weeks' tour of Europe, declared there was more uneasiness in this country concerning the prospects of a European war than there was abroad.

Recreation crowds out God from the life of vast numbers today, according to the Rev. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, associate pastor, in a sermon yesterday in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

The Mexican Supreme Court ruled late yesterday that foreigners who have been charged by the Secretary of the Interior with violating Mexican immigration laws cannot appeal to the courts before being expelled from the country.

PRINCIPAL DRAFTSMAN (METAL FURNITURE), $2,300 A YEAR-For filling the position of draftsman and designer of metal furniture Federal prison industries, incorporated United States Northeastern Penitentiary Department of Justice, Lewisburg, Pa. Applications must be on file with the manager, Third United States Civil Service- District, 1,006 Gimbel Building, Philadelphia, Pa., not later than Sept. 16. Competitors will be rated

The ordinary man was advised to expose himself to the power of the Bible, by reading it every day, in a sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. John Thorn Golding, a member of the staff in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

" The first-timers"--including, in years. a few old-timerscame down out of the Blue Ridge Mountains last night to see a motion picture that talks-or "talkie," in the parlance of the outlanderss." They came by invitation only, and before an invitation was issued, the prospective recipient had to sign an affidavit that he had never in his life seen a talking motion picture.

E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., will offer today $198,000 school bonds for Central School District No. 1 of the towns of Ellenburg, Altona, Mooers and Clinton (Clinton County), N. Y. The bonds are priced to yield from 1.00 to 2.75 per cent for maturities ranging from June 1, 1940,

Prospect Ave (18-5629), n w cor of Main St, 140x61; William L. Griffin to Monika Pankau, 265 City Island Ave; mtg $10.000. Wallace Ave (15-4039). s w cor of Van Nest Ave. 95x20; Jack Moses to City of New York.

The police were searching yesterday afternoon in Washington Heights for a small boy with a small, monkey. The animal bit 11year-old Grace Nettler of 295 Fort Washington Avenue on the left thumb as she petted it at the entrance of J. Hood Wright Park,

The wage order setting minimum wages for some 22,000 women and minors in the laundries of New York State, issued on March 7, will become mandatory today. Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

Active Republican support for Senator George to promote a Democratio split in 1940 stirred mixed reaction in Georgia today and heightened the national significance of the State's coming Democratic primary.

Trade comment here on the United States wheat subsidy plan is mixed. It is recalled that four consecutive short crop years, from 1933 to 1936 inclusive, culminated in wheat imports by the United States and it is thought that this would have deterred the government from interfering with the natural laws of supply and demand.
