We hear very little from Ocean City, Md., these days, but according to the Montauk, Freeport and Brielle skippers the angler from the metropolitan area can find better fishing nearer home. We were glad to learn that Mrs. Stephen J. Strook of New York had taken her annual white marlin at Ocean City, and the tackle she used should be a lesson to some of our local males. Last year Mrs. Strook

Mr. and Mrs. Stewart F. Hancock of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Hancock, to James Lukens McConaughy Jr. of New York, son of President McConaughy of Wesleyan University and Mrs. MeConaughy of Middletown, Conn.

It would be a pity if readers of the Hines trial news carried away the impression that Harlem's colored people are or were at any time solidly engaged in playing the lottery. After all, the entire Negro population of Manhattan cannot be much more than a quarter of a million.

Reorders on Fall apparel received iii the wholesale market last week fell into sharply defined groups. In dresses the fur-trimmed costume suit held the center of interest and schoolgirl frocks in sheer wool also were reordered. Coat business stressed dressy models in fur sleeve, bolero and tuxedo treatments.
In a radio address to the nation tonight, Premier Edouard Daladier struck at the forty-hour week as detrimental to the safety and prosperity of France under present conditions.
Buffalo's Bisons took a doubleheader from the Jersey City Giants today, 8 to 7 and 12 to 2.

Strong support for proposals to amend the Wagner act to safeguard the jurisdictional rights of craft unions, strip the National Labor Relations Board of its judicial powers and restore the right of employers to let their employes know their views on the relative merits of legitimate trade unions was evident ...

The name of Senator Sherman Minton of Indiana, a New Deal champion, received mention anew today in speculation over President Roosevelt's probable choice to succeed Justice Cardozo on the Supreme Court.

Industry is relatively quiet, but a good inflow of Fall orders is reported. The July trade return, although it shows the first export surplus since March, has not induced any particular optimism, because of the seasonal influence at work.
The Rev. John Mark Ericsson, formerly of New York and Chicago, died at his home here today of a heart attack. His widow, the former Annie Louisa Patrick, survives.

Theodore Kemm, wine steward of the Waldorf-Astoria since December, 1936, died here on Sunday after a brief illness. He would have been 65 years old tomorrow. Born in Speyer-on-Rhine, Germany, Mr. Kemm received his early training in his father's hotel there.
Harry Lee Rust, president of the H. L. Rust Company, a Washington real estate and mortgage firm, died of a heart attack today, after a brief illness.

The Mandates Commission, referring to Palestine in its report to the League of Nations Council, published today, says it "cannot but recognize that application of the mandate is partially suspended now, as events have prevented some of its essential objects from being pursued."
Mr. and Mrs. Michaei M. van Beuren arrived this afternoon for the races and entertained with a luncheon at the Trackside Restaurant. Later they were guests of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney J. Smith at a tea.

John R. Latham. has become president of the American Cigarette and Cigar Company, makers of Pall Mall cigarettes, it was announced yesterday. He -was formerly in charge of the radio division of Young Rubicam, Inc., and recently has been assistant to George W. Hill Jr., vice president of the American Tobacco Company.

Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, executive secretary of the bondholders committee for Republic of Colombia dollar bonds, announced yesterday upon his return from Colombia that he had advised the committee not to press now the contemplated suits to enforce the rights of United States bondholders, in deference to the new Colombian administration in whose "high purpose of a good-neighbor policy" he expresses confidence.

A crowd of nearly 2,000 persons was drawn to the streets in front of the House of Detention for Women at 10 Greenwich Avenue last night as one of the prisoners, fearing that her term of imprisonment was being extended, screamed and made flaming torches of newspapers within sight of the street.

Ramon Gonzalez Pena, who rose from leadership of dynamite-throwing Asturian miners to a post In the Cabinet of Prime Minister Juan Negrin of Spain, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to confer with trade unionists here and in Mexico.

The social legislation which has sometimes been called France's New Deal was passed in 1936. The FortyHour Law, enacted in June of that year, has acquired most eminence. It limited the work week to forty hours in commercial and industrial establishments of all kinds.
Bill Boyd of New York scored his twenty-first knockout in twenty-two fights tonight when he disposed of Billy Nichy of Pittsburgh in the second of a scheduled ten-rounder.

Young Johnny Hubbell held the Maple Leafs to three scattered singles tonight and pitched Jersey City to a 6-to-2 triumph in the opener of a three-game series. Two of the three safeties were collected by pinch-hitters and a wild throw by Shortstop Honeycutt deprived Hubbell of a shut-out.
Mrs. Henrietta King Trowbridge Powell, widow of Dr. S. Cambreleng Powell and a great-granddaughter of Noah Webster, died here' at-her home, the Anchorage, today in her ninetyfourth year.

Mayor Frank L. Shaw and nearly a score of other city officials today were accused by Harry J. Raymond, private investigator, who was bombed Jan. 14, of having conspired with gambling and vice interests to murder him. The charges were in a suit for $300,000.

The average interest rate on the Treasury's weekly bills sold today went to 0.048 per cent against 0.047 per cent last week, the Treasury announced tonight. The average two weeks ago was 0.044 per cent.

Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, arrived in Mexico City today. He insisted again that the primary objective of his trip was not to attend the constituent assembly of the Latin-American Labor Federation beginning on Sept. 5 which John L. Lewis is scheduled to attend.

The weekly one-day pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association was won by Maurice Walsh of Sunningdale and Homer Eagles of the home club with 33, 34--67 at Winged Foot today.

Cotton price adjustment payments averaging about 2.89 cents a pound and amounting to approximately $127,000,000, will begin next month to farmers who planted within their 1938 acreage allotments, the Agricultural Adjistment Administration announced today. About 1,400,000

Phil Bieber's Dunade was disqualified today after finishing first in the Putnam Purse, Narragansett Park feature, when stewards charged the horse had fouled Mrs. T. Stevenson's Icy Wind and Ral Parr's King Pharamond at the head of the stretch and again in front of the stand.

Mrs. Hugh Bullock gave a luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Charles King Mallory and Mrs. Edward M. Latham. Mrs. Julius Walsh's guests there were Mrs. Wellington Cross and Mrs. Henry Miller.

The Dodgers dropped into this Western Indiana town long enough today to beat an aggregation of the State's semi-pro All Stars, 17-2 and then rolled on to St. Louis for the more serious business of trying to get out of sixth place again.

It was a dull enough session at the Hines trial yesterday morningfor the spectators. Not a single word of the prolonged and private conference of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Lloyd Paul Stryker of defense counsel and Justice Pecora reached the ears of any of the spectators.

The New York City Housing Authority filed yesterday the plans for the Queensbridge project in Long Island City, the cost of which was estimated at $8,073,000. The lowrent housing development will occupy a tract 447 by 115 feet bounded by Fortieth Avenue, Twelfth Street, Forty-first Avenue, Tenth Street and Vernon Boulevard.

Frederick Thomas, 29 years old, arrested for robbing the home of Frederick Bauer at 115-60 178th Place, St. Albans, Queens, on Friday, admitted in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday that he had once been assigned to guard the Bauer home while he was working as a special patrolman for a protective agency.

The Syracuse Chiefs and Buffalo Bisons earned approximately $4,000 tonight for Woodley Abernathy, Buffalo outfielder, who is in a Syracuse hospital with a fractured skull, and Syracuse won a ball game, 8 to 6.

The Cold Spring Harbor crew, skippered by Harry Platt, took the lead by a quarter-point as the Long Island Sound midget championship series started today off the Stamford Yacht Club. The committee sent the boats out for two races in the afternoon.

The meeting of the directors of the Chesapeake Corporation called some months ago to consider its dissolution, which has been postponed several times, is expected to be held this week, according to present plans. It was conceded, however, that another postponement was possible.

There's still three months before the opening of the basketball season, but H. Gabriel Murphy, president of the Eastern Intercollegiate Conference, has wasted no time in arranging next year's schedule.
Issuance of 6,095 building permits in July for construction estimated to cost $79,956,071, nearly three times the value of June projects, was reported by the State Labor Department.

W. Warren Barbour of Rumson will be opposed for the Republican nomination for United States Senator by at least two other candidates, but it was uncertain tonight whether William H. J. Ely of Rutherford, former State WPA Administrator, would have competition for the Democratic nomination.

Continuing the Thomas E. Dewey ,cycle, Warners will start filming immediately "The Bigger They Are," which will deal with the current Tammany prosecutions in New York. HumphreyBogart and George Brent have been assigned two of the leading roles, with Walter Abel as the district attorney.
A forced landing of a military scout plane in Alexanderplatz--one of Berlin's liveliest traffic centers in the heart of the city--brought death to five civilians today.

By the candid terms of his Sunday night radio speech Senator Tydings made of the Maryland Democratic primary a clear test between the President's position and his own. He did not, like Senators George and Smith, resort to the subterfuge that the President is "misinformed."
Mine prices of anthracite coal will be increased 10 to 25 cents a ton on Sept. 1 by leading producers, the trade was notified today.

Reports from the fronts today say a general Japanese offensive is in progress south of the Yangtze River in the Kiukiang region. This drive follows the testing of vulnerable spots in Chinese defenses on the Western shores of Poyang and Chih Lakes. The operations on the north bank and east shore of Poyang Lake are synchronized.

Fortified by the recent vote of the Board of Estimate stamping the Sixth Avenue elevated line as an obstruction to street traffic, the city went before the Transit Commission yesterday to ask for a ruling- that public convenience and necessity no longer require continued operation of the line from Morris Street in downtown Manhattan to Ninth Avenue and Fiftythird Street, where it joins the Ninth Avenue line.
Premier Ea-mon de Valera completed the new Senate tonight by nominating the following eleven persons who are the same eleven he had nominated to the last short-lived Senate:

A number of dwellings in various sections of Staten Island were reported yesterday as having been sold. Among them was the eightroom, house on a large plot on Oakland Avenue, West Brighton, formerely owned by the Staten Island Savings Bank.
A southbound local of the I. R. T. Lexington Avenue subway crashed into the train ahead, which had stopped for an emergency at the 116th Street station, at 9:23 o'clock yesterday morning.

Construction on the "Highways and Horizons" exhibit of General Motors Corporation at the New York World's Fair was officially started yesterday morning by William S. Knudsen, president of the company.

Smith, Barney Co. and Cassatt Co., Inc., head the banking group which is to offer today 30,000 shares of Scott Paper Company $4.50 cumulative preferred, no par value, at $104.75 plus dividends accrued from Sept. 1, 1938, to date of payment. Janney Co.,
Premier Juan Negrin of Government Spain returned today from Zurich, Switzerland, where he went last Thursday to attend the International Congress of Physiologists.

The house here where William Wordsworth was born is threatened with destruction, it was learned tonight. The poet's birthplace has been acquired by a bus company, which has petitioned the Cumberland County Council and the Cockermouth Urban Council for permission to demolish it and erect a new bus station.

A Her long-distance committee of thirty-three men and for more than 20 women was appointed by Governor altitude record is Moore today to study accomplishments of the National Health Conference and to advise him whether to call a State health meeting.

Ralph H. Nodine, for ten years New England regional Boy Scout executive, who recently was transferred to a similar post in his native city of Chicago, died today at the Newton Hospital from an infection; He was 42 years old.
A surgeon cut a bone chip from Carl Hubbell's left arm today and tonight the freshly bandaged incision held the answer to the question: "Will the screwball king return to his baseball throne?"

With the date when the Chandler Bankruptcy Modernization Act becomes effective just one month off, members of the National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy opened their thirteenth annual conference yesterday at the Hotel Commodore with a symposium on the workings of different sections of the act.

Initial honors in the Atlantic coast championship for Star Class sloops went today to Hercules B. Atkin of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. He sailed his Jubilee to victory in the first race of the series being held by the Riverside Yacht Club.
Britain's ever resourceful diplomats today began a search for some way out of the new deadlock over the withdrawal of foreign troops from Spain.

Riflemen representing the New York National Guard and civilian teams were busy today, their time being spent at the first session of the small arms firing school and in target practice on the ranges. This routine work is to be continued until Saturday when the first matches of the competition will be fired.
The Corn Exchange here declared a three-day strike today and the Amsterdam Corn Exchange decided to follow suit tomorrow and cease business entirely for a few days.

Dr. George E. de Schweinitz, famous eye specialist and educator, who treated Woodrow Wilson and served as president of the American Medical Association in 1922, died at his home here today after an illness which caused his retirement from practice two years ago. He was in his eightieth year.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Pitou entertained with a dinner tonight at Adare for Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West of Palm Beach and Biltmore, N. C., who are passing the late season here at the Meadow Club. Among the other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran and members of their house party at Ranley House.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today approval of the application of the Southern Railway Company for a loan of $11,795,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, together with an extension of time to the railroad on a previous loan from the RFC of $12,475,204, which would have matured on Sept. 1.

Unless the delegates to the State Constitutional Convention deliberately wish to sabotage the work on which they have been engaged for many weeks they will lose no time in taking two necessary steps when they reconvene on Thursday.

Dan Smith, who was identified yesterday at the Hines trial by Alexander Pompez as a bodyguard to Harry Schoenhaus, was a former city policeman and was dismissed from the force on Aug. 5, 1929, by Grover A. Whalen, then Police Commissioner.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 17, aggregated $7,310,000,000, or 16 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
1st Ave, 189, 5-story tenement, 22.11x100; Dry Dock Savings Institution against 191 First Ave Realty Corp; due, $28,199; taxes, etc.: $424; to plaintiff for $1,000. By H. LOUIS HOLLANDER

Directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and officials of savings banks and insurance companies are expected to announce tomorrow an agreement for a voluntary reduction in the rates of interest paid by the railroad on its bonds.

BLOCH, ALFRED, 50, 846 Freeman Street, the Bronx; possible fractured skull; taken to Harlem Hospital; guard on second train. DILEVELLO, STEPHEN, 63, 242 East 109th Street; possible spine injury; Harlem Hospital.

The Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1936, further enforcing his statement that he would not accept the nomination "in the remote contingency" it was offered to him in 1940, presents here, in the third of a series of four daily articles, his impressions of his losing fight and the lessons he learned in it.

The White Sox caught up with Bob Feller in the eighth inning today, scored three runs on Mike Kreevich's triple with the bases loaded and handed the Indians a 4-2 defeat in the fifth and deciding game of the series.

The promotion of Lieut. Col. Alfred C. B. McNevin to the rank of colonel, effective on Aug. 16, was announced yesterday at the Second Corps Area Headquarters, United States Army. Colonel McNevin is commanding officer of the 441st Field Artillery at Pine Camp, Great Bend, N. Y. He is a lawyer and his home is at 537 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn.

The Theatre Guild's first production of the new season is to beand the announcement is without great surprise--"Dame Nature," or Patricia Collinge's adaptation from the French of Andre Birabeau. Rehearsals start on Monday under the direction of Worthington Miner, and the play is to open in New York Sept. 26. Jessie Royce

Tunica, claimed for $1,000 less than three months ago, raced to his fourth victory today for owner Joe Desopo of Louisville, taking Washington Park's feature, the Dolton Handicap at a mile and seventy yards.

The firm of Smith Johnson, steamship agents at 80 Broad Street, announced yesterday the receipt of a cable message from Norway reporting the death of T. H. Brovig, 61 years old, veteran Norwegian shipping operator. Mr. Borvig, who lived at Farsund, died early yesterday in Oslo.

An $11,000 mortgage for ten years at 5 1/2% has been placed on the building at 240 E 2d St, through Barton Chapin Jr., and Arthur J. Palermo Co., co-brokers. The $3,750 first mortgage on the 1-story store building at 2,894 Gerritsen Ave, Brooklyn, has been sold by Samuel Hurwitz to an investing client.

The entire women's garment industry should "join with the retailers and get behind the National Retail Demonstration scheduled for the week of Sept. 19, as it offers a wonderful opportunity to spur business recovery," Morris W. Haft, head of Morris W. Haft Brothers, Inc., and

High Administration officials moved quickly today to discount reports from Shanghai that relations between Japan,and the United States were becoming strained as a result of the Japanese blockade of the Yangtze River.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis P. Clark, who are at Mr. Clark's mother's home, Wrentham House, gave a dinner there tonight for a group of young friends. There was dancing later.

Mayor La Guardia is expected to open a fight for separate submission of the proposals advanced at the State Constitutional Convention when he discusses the work of the convention in a radio talk over WABC from 7 to 7:15 this evening.

The marriage of Mrs. Alice Foote Fleischmann of Millbrook, N. Y., daughter of Mrs. Robert Dumont Foote of this city and the late Mr. Foote of Morristown, N. J., to Dr. John J. Moorhead, also of New York, took place here yesterday morning at the home of the bride's mother, 21 East Sixty-sixth Street.

Charles S. Whitman, who successfully prosecuted the Rosenthal murder case while District Attorney of New York County from 1910 to 1914 and later became Governor of New York, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen with his son from a cruise to the North Cape. They also visited Leningrad and Moscow.

The allotment of $13,175,600 for the construction of 12,118 miles of power lines in twenty-six States was announced today by the Rural Elec- b trification Administration. These lines will make electric service available to more than 40,000 farms

As the site for a casino of modernistic design overlooking Mecox Bay, a parcel fronting 660 feet on the bay and the Atlantic Ocean at Southampton, L. I., has been purchased by John H. Livingston Jr. of New York City and Southampton.

The announcement of the establishment of a State tribunal in Vienna to try prominent members of the former Austrian government on charges of "law violations and actions hostile to the people," was followed

The marriage of Miss Mirma Wallace of this city, daughter of George Harvey Wallace of WaukeshaWis., to Charles Hulbert Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Angus Kerr Young of North Sydney, N. S., took place here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the associate pastor, the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder.

France may soon build fighting planes in Canada in a plant to be erected here, The Montreal Daily Herald said today. "French interests, believed to be under the sponsorship of the government of France, have completed plans for the erection of a large aircraft plant in the Montreal district, which in time may employ several

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, in Brooklyn, awarded yesterday $1,129,003 for 108 parcels of land taken by the City of New York for the extension of North Beach Airport in Queens. The owners sought a total of $1,906,231 for the land and the city appraisers listed it as worth $1,059,637.

Gustav A. Weidhaass, head of the Weldhaas Studios, 538 West -Twenty-ninth Street, who had long been well known in the theatre world as a creator of stage effects, especially "illusions," died- Sunday night of heart disease at his home in Bronxville. His age was 62.

Unusually active buying for the first day featured the opening yesterday of the eighteenth semi-annual gift show at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the National Gift and Art Association, Inc.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which broke all speed records of the North Atlantic on her last eastward voyage and now holds Atlantic records in both directions, returned to port yesterday with her officers and officials of the line still disclaiming any interest in speed.

Irene Racz, 30-year-old Hungarian-American artist, committed suicide yesterday by taking an overdose of a sleeping potion. She was found dead in bed at 10:20 A. M. by her mother, Mrs. Catherine Racz, who shared with her a threeroom suite at the Hotel Oliver Cromwell, 12 West Seventy-second Street.

A price reduction of 1 cent on leading brands of cigarettes has been put into effect by the United Cigar Stores and C. A. Schulte, Inc. Denying the readjustment means a "price war," executives of the tobacco chains said yesterday the cut was made to "meet competition." No change in wholesale

Blazing shotguns fired three new records into the clay target books today as the thirty-ninth annual Grand American trapshoot program opened at the permanent home of the Amateur Trapshooting Association along the banks of the Miami.

Bids received today by the Coast Guard included: Boathouse, launchway and accessories, Ocean City (Md.) Station: Robert F. Engler, Inc., Wilmington, $45,950; Anthony P. Miller, Inc., Atlantic City, $47,232. Equipment building

Aviators were cautioned yesterday by the United States Navy Hydrographic Office that squadrons from the naval air station at Cape May, N. J., will conduct dive bombing practice in the vicinity of Cape May from now until October.

Representatives of six foreign nations gathered with the leading tennis players of the United States today for the opening of the fifty-seventh annual national doubles championships at the Longwood Cricket Club.

A business property in downtown Manhattan was assembled yesterday when an investor purchased a loft building; a plot improved with a gasoline station and the lease of another plot, all three parcels forming the southeast corner of Canal and Church Streets.

Federated Land Estates, Inc., bought the two apartment buildings containing forty suites at 11837 and 118-41 Metropolitan Avenue, Kew Gardens, L. I. Assessed at $130,000, the buildings are on a plot 120 by 100 feet and are fully rented. Each house has twenty apartments of three to five rooms and is maintrained separately.

Hopes of an understanding between the Little Entente and Hungary rose today when it was learned that the Little Entente conference had been prolonged until tomorrow. The final communique had been expected this afternoon, but it was announced it would be issued tomorrow.

George Henry Kirchner, president of the Union Guardian Trust Company, died early today at Harper Hospital at the age of 72. Born in Detroit, Mr. Kirchner had been in the banking business virtually all his life.

Francls Sterne Palmer, former private secretary to the Collector of the Port of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was born in Belmont, N. Y., son of the late Representative George William Palmer and Frances Lynde Palmer.
Colonel Theodore Davis Boal died at his ancestral estate, Boalsburg, near here, early today at the age of 71. Born in Iowa City, Iowa, the Colonel was the son of George Jack Boal.
Dr. John Martin Wheeler, a leading ophthalmologist, died at his Summer home, Underhill Center, near here today. Ie was stricken with a heart attack a week ago. He was 58 years old.

Two aspects of the policy racket operations--a bondsman's card that had a magic effect on the police and a $100-a-week representative in the courts to "take care of those who got arrested"-were put in the record of the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, in
THE BODY BEAUTIFUL, compiled and edited by Heyworth Campbell. (Dodge, $3.) The fourth annual volume. CONTRACT BRIDGE FOR BEGINNERS, by Josephine Culbertson. (Winston; $1.50.)

Hesketh Hughes, British internationalist, will replace Eric Pedley, veteran American player, on Winston Guest's team in the national open polo championship starting at Meadow Brook on Sept. 4. Unexpected business will keep Pedley from competing.

Production of petroleum in Venezuela in June amounted to 2,410,315 metric tons, an increase of approximately 0.21 per cent over June, 1937, and 1.8 per cent over May, 1938, according to a report received by the Department of Commerce today from the United States commercial attache at Caracas.
Pedro Montanez of Puerto Rico has ended training for his ten-round bout with Orville Drouillard of Canada at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. This bout, topping

Governor Blanton Winship tonight recommended the commissioning of another artist to do the Puerto Rican mural in the Postoffice Building at Washington to displace that of Rockwell Kent. He asked for an appropriation of $3,000, His message said:
Pairings for the national polo tournament at the Oak Brook Club were announced today by Paul Butler, chairman of the Central Polo Association.

The leadership of the United , Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners in New York City was accused yesterday in a Supreme Court action by a member of employing dictatorial tactics to maintain itself in power. The officers, the plaintiff

Among the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday was one signed by John R. Alpine, associated with the Grinnell Company, Inc., for space in the new apartment building nearing completion at 3 East Sixtyninth Street. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers.

It is just possible that tourFear ists are overdoing the contrast of between peaceful Europe and War war-excited America. Travelers come home and say they have heard more war talk over here in a day than they did on the Continent in a month.

The Bureau of Social Hygiene of the city Department of Health, in a summary of its work for the first half of this year, made public yesiterday, reported that the Department of Health and private physiclans had developed a mutually satisfactory plan for coordinating their activities.

Talen Hats, Inc., millinery, in 49 W. 38th St., Sterling Schwartz, direct mail service, in 250 W. 40th St. through M. L. Mess, Inc.; Lazar Wisotsky, furs; Altman Kliger, furs, in 253 W. 27th St.; Patent Design Photo Screen Co., photo studio, in 42 W. 48th St.; Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., brokers.

Lew Raymond, 143 pounds, Baltimore, won the decision from Charlie Gordon, 145, Orange, in the tenround feature boxing bout of a benefit show tonight. Referee Hymie Kugel of Newark awarded seven rounds to Raymond, two to Gordon and called one even.

Miss Barbara Ransom of Stockton, Calif., gave Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis and other ranking stars in the women's Western golf championship at the Olympia Fields Country Club something to think about today.

Miss Margery Florence SIoss, daugh- ri ter of Mrs. Mortimer M. Sloss of this place and New York and the late Mr. Sloss, was married to Dr. John Henry Heldt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Heldt of Woodmere, this evening at the Woodmere Country Club. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Isaac Landman of the Eighth Avenue Temple, Brooklyn.

A still further slackening in the demand of Europeans for gold and United States dollars was shown yesterday as the principal foreign currencies strengthened, after the firm stand of the French Government on recovery measures and Premier Edouard Daladier's announcement of his determination to defend the position of the franc.

The five-family apartment house at 33-35 Poplar Street, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Hudson Building Loan Association to S. Jacobson, who will hold it for investment. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The recent comment here that young Tom Taggart might have started something that would lead to collegiate rivalry on the turf had a repercussion yesterday. Owner Taggart named a good colt after his class in college, which was Yale '09. On the clubhouse porch yesterday this tourist encountered Harry M. Stevens 2d of the noted catering clan and Yale '32.

5th St, 520 E; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 520 East Fifth St Corp 36 W 44th St; purchase money mtg $16,269 and building loan mtg $14,000 ($16.50). 105th St, 228-232 E: Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, to Manhattan School of Music, 238 E 105th St. ($12).

Capt. Clarence A. Rycraft, AG-Res., 141 Northumberland Rd., Rochester, N. Y., is ordered to active duty. Aug. 28, at Syracuse, N. Y., for training. Date of rank: Dec. 1, 1937. He will revert to an inactive status Sept. 10.

Eight of the forty American track and field athletes sent on a tour of Europe this Summer returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd t liner Bremen. They were the first contingent to arrive, but another group is due next Monday on the Europa of the North German Lloyd line, and the rest will return in odd lots for another fortnight or so.

William Livingston Clark, a retired lawyer, died early today after an illness of two weeks. He was 82 years old and lived at 150 West Ridgewood Avenue. Until fourteen years ago Mr. Clark lived in Passaic, where he was active in civic affairs.

Worcestershire, well down in the English county cricket standing, defeated Lancashire by ten wickets today. It was the only match concluded in games started Saturday. Rain cut play at Newport and canceled competition at Cardiff, Eastbourne and Taunton.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 42.8 per cent of capacity this week, a gain of 2.4 points or 5.9 per cent over last week when the rate was 40.4 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
A drop of $25,647,808 in collections of internal revenue for July, compared with those for the same month of 1937, was reported today by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Spokesmen for the youth organizations in fifty-seven countries represented at the World Youth Congress at Vassar College expressed faith tonight that, despite the wars now waging and the growth of the forces making for war,

Mayor "Emeritus" Samuel A. Carlson accepted today the Democratic nomination for Congress from the Forty-third District-a Republican stronghold. He will run against Representative Daniel A. Reed, who has held the office for twenty years.
Depositors of the defunct Manufacturers National Bank received today final payment on deposits of record on Aug. 9, 1931, the date the bank was closed.
Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 7 to 13 points yesterday. Pressure came mainly from houses with foreign connections, with some hedge selling by producing sections.
The forty-seventh annual program of the Middle States Regatta Association will be held Sunday, Sept. 4, at Baltimore under the auspices of the Arundel Boat Club. Seventeen contests are on the card.

The wholesale price level was slightly lower last week, according to the commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer'Association. This index in the week ended Aug. 20 was 72.9 against 73.1 in the preceding week, 74.6 a month ago and 87.2 a year ago, based on the 19261928 average as 100.

The thirty-fourth conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union was opened here today by Premier Hendryk Colijn. Count Henri Carton de Wiart, the president, opened the first session, at which more than 400 delegates from thirty-five countries participated.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today that thirteen regional offices had been established throughout the country to expedite the determination of unjust enrichment tax liabilities and to obtain the earlier settlement under Title VII of the 1936 Revenue Act of taxpayers' claims for refund of processing and floor stock taxes which have been paid.

James Alonzo Abernethy, who fifty-one years ago built a small cotton mill at Laboratory, Lincoln County, W . C., and later became a power in the southern textile industry, died last night at his Lincolnton home in his eighty-sixth year.

Administration farm leaders described the farm problem confronting the nation today as perhaps the most difficult since the 1934-36 drought period. Good crop-growing weather during the last two seasons, the business recession and unsettled world

Japan's war in China appears to have been the chief factor in cutting Japanese exports to the United States down to little more than half the former volume. Commerce Department reports showed today that imports into the United States from Japan dropped about 47 per cent in the first half of this year from the value recorded in the 1937 period.

Preliminary steps for the formation of a national tavern association will be discussed at a meeting of the representatives of seven States to be held under the auspices of the New Jersey Licensed Beverage Dealers' Association to be held at Atlantic City from Sept. 19 to 22, inclusive, it was stated yesterday by John J. Daly, president of the New York State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association.
New appointments to the Soviet Union's Council of Commissars illustrate the difficulties and successes of the present Soviet internal policy.

Among those who arrived yesterday from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen was Miss Hanna Reitsch, 26-year-old German flier who holds the women's world's record for sailplane flying both in distance and in altitude.

The mail orders received by resident buyers in the market here yesterday were only fair. Reorders are not developing at the rate expected at this time, with the reports general that the spell of hot weather has prevented expansion of early consumer interest in Fall merchandise. In the mail orders received,

Freddie Fiducia of Newark floored Joe Wagner of Cleveland seven times tonight before Referee Joe Mangold stopped their boxing match in 2:30 of the seventh and awarded to Fiducia a technical knockout victory in a scheduled ten-rounder at a Milk Fund Show. Fiducia weighed 192 pounds and Wagner 181.
Norman Thomas has delivered to Harper the manuscript of his new book entitled "Socialism on the Defensive." It is scheduled for publication in November.

Charles Lovell, 42 years old, a Negro, of 84 Hopkins Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned before Magistrate Sabbatino in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, yesterday on a charge of having refused to stop soliciting shoeshiness on Sunday in violation of the Sabbath Law.

The engagement of Miss Jane Anne Eiseman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Francis Eiseman of Belle Harbor, Queens, formerly of Scarsdale, to Edward C. Weil Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Weil of Ridgefield Park, N. J., has been announced by her parents.

Trading continued dull in the bond market yesterday and prices moved in a narrow range. On the New York Stock Exchange transactions amounted to $3,429,800, compared with $5,041,250 on Friday. The turnover was the smallest for a five-hour session since Aug. 15, when sales touched a twenty-year low level.

R. N. Denham, examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, recommended to the board today that it order the Ford Motor Company to re-employ about 450 members of the United Automobile Workers of America..

Norman A. MacDonald Jr. and Frank S. McKay, botanists, of Nutley, N. J., arrived yesterda on the Grace liner Santa Rosa at the end of a nine-month expedition to the mountains and jungles of Colombia and Venezuela in search of new species of orchids.

With the pressure off their shoulders, the Yankees today faced the first of five successive double-headers with a feeling of complacency. The Bronx Bombers will clash with the White Sox at the Yankee Stadium today and tomorrow, with the Indians coming in for three twin bills starting on Thursday.

The Bayside Golf Club was much in the limelight at the Garden City Country Club today as two of its amateurs and its assistant pro were among the four prize winners in the foursome pro-amateur tourney held under the auspices of the Long Island Golf Association.

John Dos Passos, the American novelist who has been warned that he would be painfully thrown across the border if he set foot in Italy, returned yesterday on the Queen Mary after spending a month cruising in Italian waters with Gerald Murphy, a friend, and calling at various Italian ports. Both Mr. Dos Passos and Ernest Hemingway are unwelcome in Italy, but Mr. Dos Passos said yesterday he had never received the warning.
Former Governor Hoffman, a Republican, would be glad to give the Democratic National Committee and the C. I. 0. some advice, he said today, but didn't say what kind.

The most provocative of all the issues ever to trouble the South, the Negro question, is being raised deliberately as a chief defense of oldline Southerners against the current New Deal drive to "purge" their champions from the high councils of the Democratic party.

Miss Cardine Elizabeth Bogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lawrence Bogert of this city and Glen Cove, L. I., has selected the afternoon of Sept. 10 for her marriage to Thomas Hildt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hildt of Baltimore, and Black Point, Conn. The ceremony will take place in the Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Vallev. L. I.

Prices of wheat advanced today around 1/2 cent a bushel at the opening on the Board of Trade here, largely a reflection of independent strength in Liverpool but the buying movement quickly subsided and the market reacted about 1 cent from the top and closed 3/8 cent a bushel lower.

Scattered trading in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday included leases of business and housing properties and the resale of a tenement house in Harlem for altering to meet the requirements of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

Stocks moved narrowly and closed firm at irregularly lower levels in the slowest trading since June 17; turnover, 396,620 shares. United States Government and other bonds steady and mixed, in dull trading; transactions, $3,429,800.

The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today the exemption of the Page Power Company, a subsidiary of the Republic Service Corporation, from the provisions of Section 6a of the Public Utility Holding Company Act in the issue of 1,400 shares of its no-par value common capital stock at $50 a share.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Moora, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Moora of this place, to Marshall Branson Nunlist, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Nunlist of Brooklyn, N. Y., took place this evening in the First Congregational Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Victor G. Mills, pastor of the First Methodist Church. Montclair.

A syndicate composed of Dougherty, Corkran Co., Butcher Sherrerd, Schmidt, Poole Co., and Moore, Leonard Lynch will offer today a new issue of $380,000 city of Uniontown, Pa. The issue consists of $330,000 of 31/4 per cent sewer bonds due on Oct. 1, 1939 to 1968, and $50,000 of 23/4 per cent disposal bonds due on Oct. 1, 1939 to 1948. Prices for the 23/4 per cent

A three-day "old-timers" gathering of executives and dealers of the Packard Motor Car Company began yesterday at the Westchester Country Club. The day started with golf games for the twenty men, all veterans of twenty-five or more years of association with the company, who came from many parts of the United States.

The death two weeks ago of Clark Twelvetrees, 34-year-old actor and the former husband of Helen Twelvetrees, the screen star, is being investigated as a homicide and not as an accident, it was disclosed yesterday by the police, following the arrest of James Paskovics, 29,
Henry Armstrong's monopoly on three boxing titles is hurting the sport, and public interest in the fight game is low, Gene Tunney, former heavyweight champion, said here today.

Reports from Washington that the Department of Justice was actively studying the steel price structure and practices were not surprising in financial circles, where it has long been expected that the vast monopoly studies to be pursued by the joint legislative and administrative committee would inquire thoroughly into the steel industry.

In an apartment of the Weimar Hotel in Marienbad, Konrad Henlein, Sudeten German leader, today held a five-hour conference with his delegation that has been negotiating with the government. The purpose of the meeting was to allow him to inform the delegation on his conversation with Viscount Runciman. and arrange the party's future campaign following its emphatic rejection of the government's proposals, last week.

Entries will close on Saturday for the first annual exhibition of amateur photography by colonists to be held in the Guild Hall Galleries, beginning on Sept. 1. Miss Nancy Meier and Everit Herter are chairmen of a committee planning the exhibition.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 17: Increases of $11,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; $10,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities and $14,000,000 in "other securities";

Two of golf's great army of "extras," an unemployed youth from New York and a shopworker from Kentucky, blazed their way to starring roles today in the sports' annual big show for the working man-the national Public Links championship.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald Markle and Miss Mary Orme Markle of The Evergreens, Jeddo, Pa., and Pass Christian, Miss., are at the St. Regis. Miss Markle's engagement to Charles Embrie Rockwell of Smithtown, L. I., was announced last week.

Turning on the heat when the chips were down, Slammin' Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., posted a brilliant 101 for 27 holes and defeated Harry Cooper, the defending champion from Chicago, in a prolonged play-off for the Canadian open golf championship today at the Mississauga Country Club.

The issuing of warrants today for the arrest of Dr. Benjamin S. Barringer, a New York surgeon who lives in New Canaan, and his son, Benjamin L. Barringer, a New York lawyer, -revealed that the surgeon and his son, exasperated at the blocking off of-a old road by the Merritt Parkway,

Johnny Gilbert scored a consecutive double today with Marica and Royal Sortie, as another disqualification and fine were added to the already long list at the meeting, and the crowd booed another bad start.

Documentary evidence to substantiate charges of anti-labor activities was introduced yesterday at the public hearing on the application by the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, Inc., of 75 East Forty-fifth Street, for a renewal of its license as a private detective agency, before the Division of Licenses of the Department of State, at 80 Center Street.

A new note from this government to Mexico on the subject of compensation for lands expropriated by Mexico was delivered to the Mexican Embassy here this evening. The text will be made public simultaneously here and in Mexico City on Friday morning.

Alfred M. Landon of Kansas is not the only former Presidential nominee who has found consolation in his own defeat. Arriving yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after vacations aboard were two other men who once were aspirants for the post of Chief Executive of the United States, and both agreed during the crossing from Cherbourg that they had no regrets.

JUNIOR SCIENTIST (NAUTICAL), $2,000 a year, Hydrographic Office, Navy Department. Applications must be on file not later than Sept. 22 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and not later than Sept. 19 from all other States. Competitors will

Senator Key Pittman of Nevada praised the foreign policy of the Roosevelt Administration tonight in an address before national officers of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at the organization's thirty-ninth encampment.

Leo Altman, who is 36 years old and who resides at 409 Edgecombe Avenue, was an elevator operator, a doorman, a shipping clerk, a longshoreman, a boxer, a waiter and a seaman aboard a New Bedford whaler before he got into the numbers game in 1932, he said.

The stock market here was quiet but generally firm today. Gilt-edge issues were steady, but among the foreign bonds German issues weakened. Transatlantic stocks reflected the firmer tone in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.
Ed Oliver and David Douglas of Wilmington, Del.; put together a sensational nine-under-par 63 today to win the pro-amateur golf tournament at the Lancaster Country Club for the second straight year.

The police of Seoul, Korea, reported that seven Soviet bombers had violated the Soviet-Japanese truce by crossing the Korean border at about 10:30 A. M. Saturday, flying at a low altitude over the Keiko, Keigen and Kumju areas, but dropping no bombs.

Automobile production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 37.9 from 33.9. The seasonal variation factor used in computing the index was 75.0. For the week ended Aug. 21, 1937, the index stood at 147.5.
An attempt by friends of Representative Maury Maverick, ardent New Dealer, to run him for re-election this Fall as an independent suffered a substantial setback today.

Twenty-nine of the thirty stalwart athletes who will represent the Eastern College All-Stars in the night game against the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7 reported to Coach Andy Kerr today, ready to begin training immediately.
Big Jim Tobin hurled five-hit ball and his mates bunched four hits for three runs in the seventh inning today to give Pittsburgh a 4-to-2 victory over the Cubs in the final game of their series.
A third State auditor was arrested yesterday on charges involving bribery growing out of the investigation of frauds in the administration of the State workmen's compensation insurance fund.

The report of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company for the fiscal year ended on June 30, issued yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, shows a consolidated deficit, after all operating expenses, taxes and deduction for Manhattan Railway dividend rental, of $11,600,470. This compares with

To realty interests and builders perhaps the most interesting section of the National Emergency Council's recent report on economic conditions in the South was that dealing with the housing situation.
The Civil Service Commission warned 533,000 Federal employes today against engaging in any city, coun- L. ty, State or national election campaign.

Reed Vetterli, veteran investigator of the Department of Justice, who became head of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last September after making a notable record for himself in the Western States, resigned yesterday from the service at the age of 35 to enter private business.
Best U. S. and Australian Players Named for Match
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 22, unless specified: Norfolk to New Orleans, Aug. 21: Babbitt, Roper, Tillman. New York to Norfolk: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert Leary

A soft-spoken bandit contemptuously rejected $6 as the proceeds of a toy-gun hold-up yesterday morning in a Brooklyn hat shop and stalked out of the store in a temper after buying and paying for an eighty-nine-cent cap.

The nation's textile industry, with its hundreds of thousands of men and women employes, became today the testing ground for the new WageHour Act. Twenty-one men, representatives of manufacturers, labor and the public, will draft the first regulations of working hours and wages under direction of Elmer F. Andrews, Wage-Hour Administrator.

Declaring that a "disgraceful condition" existed in the city under which school teachers could hold as many as four positions simultaneously, Mayor La Guardia criticized the courts yesterday for having tied his hands when he sought to change the system.

Records went by the board today as England compiled 634 runs for five wickets in the second day's play of the fifth and final cricket test match against Australia. Making only one mistake during eleven hours at the wickets, Leonard Hutton was unbeaten when stumps were drawn with 300 runs, the highest individual score made by an Englishman in Anglo-Australian tests.

Physical assets of the New York Queens Railway Company, which operates five trolley lines centering in Long Island City, Queens, were bought in for $65,000 at auction at the Queens County Court House in Long Island City yesterday by a bondholders' reorganization committee which plans to substitute buses for trolleys on the lines.

In the most ambitious thrust it has yet made against the Committee for Industrial Organization, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor authorized today the establishment of an integrated maritime department embracing an estimated 500,000

Vincent Pimpinella, Brooklyn welterweight, will fight Phil Furr of Washington in the eight-round main bout at Canarsie Stadium in Brooklyn tonight. If he wins, Pimpinella will advance a step toward matches with some of the leading contenders in his division.

Jacob, beloved husband of Estella and dear father of Rosalind Weiss. Burton and Gertrude. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Tuesday, Aug. 23, at 2:30 P. M. Kindly omit flowers.

Members of the Southern Hosiery Manufacturers Association were warned today to prepare and protect themselves against losses that are likely to follow changes in prices when the Wage-Hour Law becomes effective.
The police were investigating today the mysterious death by electricity of Michael Donlan of this city at the Fletcher Dry Dock Company's plant here.

With a budget slightly less than 15 per cent under that for last year, the American Gas Association is launching a $400,000 advertising campaign in September issues of consumer, trade, industrial and professional magazines. Nine general and twenty-three trade and other magazines will be used.

Two Ministers of Premier Edouard Daladier's Cabinet resigned this morning because they disagreed with the Premier's declaration of last night that the forty-hour week must be adapted so as to keep factories running full time if France was to hold her own against other nations.

Style settlements last week totaled 2,777, a gain of 16.6 per cent over the preceding week, but about 23.5 per cent below the corresponding week of last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Joint Board -Dressmakers Union.

A Juggler with no audience Doing my round of empty halls I longed for one, wide-eyed, intense To watch my myriad colored balls, Even a child to cup his chin And wonder at my brilliant play, At how I made the planets spin, And tossed the sun to light his day.

The American Committee for NonParticipation in Japanese Aggression has been formed for the purpose of ending American "economic assistance to Japan in her illegal invasion of China," the committee announced yesterday.

The Agricultural Department estimates the cash income from farm products, plus Government benefit payments, in the neighborhood of $7,500,000,000 this year, as compared with $8,600,000,000 in 1937 and $7,944,000,000 in 1936.

Mrs. Henry Addison Alexander of 167 East Seventy-fourth Street, mother of Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at her Summer home in West Dover, Vt. Her health had not been good since she fractured

The refusal of General Franco to accept much beyond the "principle" of the British plan for the withdrawal of foreign troops in Spain leaves the twenty-seven nations of the non-intervention committee where they were last Spring. In fact, it leaves them

Douglas Corrigan, the youth who put humor into the serious business of transoceanic flying, brought his $900 "crate" here today for a visit to its "birthplace." The smiling aviator had an escort of Illinois National Guard planes from Springfield, Ill., "to help him find St. Louis."
The week-end seems to have been a satisfactory one for the salt water brotherhood, although Montauk reported only one white marlin for Sunday, while Freeport and Brielle drew blanks on this species.

A delivery jam of proportions, varying according to grade, has developed in suede leathers, tanners reported yesterday, and it was said that spots cannot be bought in most grades. This situation has developed despite the early season predictions of shoe stylists that, after two years of leadership, suedes would be less" popular this Fall.

Albert A. Snyder recently was appointed head coach of football, basketball and baseball for the 1938-39 season at Tome School, Port Deposit, Md., according to an announcement by Headmaster C. J. Keppel.

Primary elections within the next month will determine the success or failure of President Roosevelt's first efforts to oust unfriendly Democratic Congressmen. Although this year's primaries are more than half over, major party nominees are yet to be chosen in twenty-two States.

The new Civil Aeronautics Authority took formal possession today of its offices in the Commerce Building, formerly occupied by the officials of the Bureau of Air Commerce, and began the task of regulating the nation's aviation industry.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday that it had the largest sales in its history in the first six months of this year. Including spare parts and special equipment, sales amounted to $5,111,699, compared with $2,644,991 in the first six months of 1937, an increase of $2,466,708, or 92 per cent. For the full year 1937, sales,

The "united front" movement of the Communist party had made more progress in the United States in a few recent years than had been hoped for in fifty and the movement continued in full swing, James B. Matthews
Admiral Nicholas Horthy, sailor Regent of Hungary, reviewed the German fleet in Kiel Harbor today and his wife officiated at the addition of another powerful unit to the fleet.

Argument on the application of the S. S. Pike Company, Inc., of 50 East Forty-second Street for a permanent injunction restraining city officials from enforcing the recent ruling against the trailing of advertising banners by airplanes over the city took place yesterday before Justice Charles W. Froessel in Supreme Court, Queens.

Unemployment insurance benefit checks totaling $2,936,288 were prepared by the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance during the week ended Aug. 13. They were forwarded to the Department of Audit and Control for release or cancellation as claimants returned certifications of continued unemployment or re-employment.

Turpentine firm, 22 1/2c; sales, 61 barrels; receipts, 676 barrels shipments, 297 barrels; stock, 45,877 barrels. Rosin firm: sales, 453: receipts, 3,007; shipments, 1.079; stock, 220.468. Quote: B. $3.50; D, $3.85; E, $4.20; F, G, H, I, K, M, $4.35; N, $5.25; WG, $5.50; WW, X, $6.30.

The committee aiding plans for the benefit concert to be given by the Choral Art Society on Thursday night at the Old Field Club here met this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Frederick L. Johanns to discuss final arrangements.

Fanning to Imre Filkovich, 3,639 Tibbett Ave. Hering Ave (15-4112), w s, 195 ft s of Van Nest Ave, 61x100; Florence Marshall to John Caprarulo,-1851 Bronxdale Ave. Fulton Ave, 1,193 (10-2609); Estelle Holden to Rajam Realty Corp, 202 Brook Ave.

The fourth annual Nestledown Horse Show will be held Sept. 3 on the estate of Bernard E. Smith for the benefit of the Westchester Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Miss Cynthia Smith heads the committee in charge. She will be assisted by the Misses Lillian M. Chambers,

The Democratic State Conventibn will be hold in Rochester starting Sept. 29, the day after the Republicans convene at Saratoga, it was decided yesterday by the Democratic State Commnittee, meeting at the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

Annual academic grants made by Manhattan College to five incoming freshmen to cover the cost of tuition for four years and five Knights of Columbus four-year scholarships were announced yesterday by the college.

The City Affairs Committee "publicly denounced" yesterday the action of the Constitutional Convention in adopting a proposal designed to make proportional representation illegal. "The convention's move is more repugnant when one realizes that it was taken secretly, without the benefit of a public hearing or extended debate," the committee said.

President Roosevelt will take advantage of a Labor Day opportunity to invade the home territory of Senator Tydings of Maryland, against whose nomination he said recently he would throw his influence, it was indicated in White House circles today.

News of the deplorable accident in the East Side subway in which two persons were killed and more than twoscore injured brings a shock which is all the greater because of the extraordinary record for safety which has been set up by New York's underground railroads.

Primary elections within the next month will determine the success or failure of President Roosevelt's first efforts to oust unfriendly Democratic Congressmen. Although this year's primaries are more than half over, major party nominees are yet to be chosen in twenty-two States.

The committee aiding plans for the benefit concert to be given by the Choral Art Society on Thursday night at the Old Field Club here met this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Frederick L. Johanns to discuss final arrangements.

The fourth annual Nestledown Horse Show will be held Sept. 3 on the estate of Bernard E. Smith for the benefit of the Westchester Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. Miss Cynthia Smith heads the committee in charge. She will be assisted by the Misses Lillian M. Chambers,

The Democratic State Conventibn will be hold in Rochester starting Sept. 29, the day after the Republicans convene at Saratoga, it was decided yesterday by the Democratic State Commnittee, meeting at the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

Annual academic grants made by Manhattan College to five incoming freshmen to cover the cost of tuition for four years and five Knights of Columbus four-year scholarships were announced yesterday by the college.

The City Affairs Committee "publicly denounced" yesterday the action of the Constitutional Convention in adopting a proposal designed to make proportional representation illegal. "The convention's move is more repugnant when one realizes that it was taken secretly, without the benefit of a public hearing or extended debate," the committee said.

President Roosevelt will take advantage of a Labor Day opportunity to invade the home territory of Senator Tydings of Maryland, against whose nomination he said recently he would throw his influence, it was indicated in White House circles today.

News of the deplorable accident in the East Side subway in which two persons were killed and more than twoscore injured brings a shock which is all the greater because of the extraordinary record for safety which has been set up by New York's underground railroads.
Traffic accidents, deaths and injuries dropped sharply last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of last year, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.

With its population of 7,500,000, plus a visiting population estimated at 2,000,000 to 3,000,000 daily, New York City leads all other large municipalities in the reduction of automobile accidents, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in the quarterly bulletin of the Department of Health.
Captain James E. Kennedy, veteran river man and former superintendent of transportation in the United States Engineering Corps, died at his home here yesterday.

Steel companies incurred an average net loss of $1.75 a ton on products shipped to consumers in the first half of 1938, the American Iron and Steel Institute has computed from reports of companies producing more than 90 per cent of total steel output in the period.

There were 2,483 marriages in New Jersey last month, compared with 3,187 in July of last year, according to a report by the State Bureau of Vital Statistics today. Last month was the first during which the new law requiring premarital blood tests to show freedom from communicable syphilis was- operative, but Health

This area was shaken late last night and early today by a series of earthquakes that rocked buildings and aroused thousands of households in alarm. Newspaper offices and police stations were deluged with telephone inquiries.
Brig. Gen. Frederick A. Barker, who retired from the marine corps, due to physical disability, last year, after a distinguished career, died today at the Naval Hospital here. He was 58 years old.

The number of infantile paralysis cases recorded in Western Canada this Summer has reached 128. Nine persons have died from the disease, seven of them residents of Alberta, where the situation is the most serious of the four Western Provinces.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President's speech in Ontario assuring Canada of this country's aid in the event of foreign invasion of the Dominion recalls what seems to be a relevant incident of eighteen years ago at Geneva when the Assembly of the League of Nations was holding its first session.

German pig iron production during June totaled 1,508,558 metric tons compared with 1,545,062 in May and 1,304,243 in May, 1937, the United States Consulate at Cologne reported today to the Department of Commerce.

The Corps of Cadets, less the second class now absent on leave, began field exercises today. The manoeuvres will continue among the lakes anal mountains west of the military reservation for the rest of the week.

According to reports from the Comet Class fleets all over the country, competition is expected to be decidedly keen when the forty-five or more sixteen-foot sloops gather on Skaneateles Lake, N. Y., for the three-day national championship series on Sept. 9, 10 and 11.
Four ringleaders in a convicts' hunger strike were found dead in adjoining isolation cells in the Philadelphia County prison at Holmesburg today.

Howard Newton Corbett, for five years manager of The Times of London and afterward an executive of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died here today at the age of 55. Mr. Corbett joined the staff of The Times of London Jan. 1, 1914, and Lord Northciffe, then the proprietor, appointed him as manager in October, 1915:

John L. Makeever, 81 years old, a retired New York investment broker, died at noon today in Peekskill Hospital, where he was taken under vigorous protestation after he had been run over by an automobile. Mr. Makeever, who was staying at a tree nursery he operated here, made his home at 646 Argyle Road, Brooklyn.

The French liner Normandie arrived at Havre today with fourteen stowaways. Three, who had smuggled themselves aboard at Havre for the westbound crossing, were returned to France. Eleven Americans had slipped aboard the liner in New fork.

Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, yesterday announced that an agreement had been completed for the extension until Jan. 30, 1940, of $3,681,937 in bank loans and equipment trusts which originally were to mature earlier.

This desert, scene of record-breaking automobile runs, will have its first motor cycle speed trial Sept. 15. E. N. Olson, Salt Lake City motor cycle police officer, said he would use an especially built 400-pound machine in an attempt to break the world record of 76 miles per hour for a 24-hour motor cycle run.

Political coercion of relief workers and solicitation of campaign contributions from them were condemned today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, after a conference with President Roosevelt.

Miss Diana Fishwick, former British women's golf champion, will be married in Paris tomorrow to Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley, English sports promoter, it was announced today. General Critchley is managing director of the Greyhound Racing Association and introduced the sport in England in 1926.
The Internal Revenue Bureau has settied, for $5,032, the half-milliondollar income tax claim against John ("Jake the Barber") Factor, of Chicago, central figure in a kidnapping five years ago.

Organized industrial research began in the United States hardly thirty years ago. The laboratories of some of these organizations, such as Bell Telephone and General Electric, are among the best in the world. The fruitfulness of their work is common knowledge.

Today's story from the Ebro front is the same as every day recently; Extremely heavy Rebel attacks repulsed without any loss of ground. The Loyalists held on so long that it is now believed the Insurgents will soon have to pause for rest and reorganization.

Occupants of the two subway trains that were in collision yesterday in the 116th Street station under Lexington Avenue painted a picture of hundreds of panic-stricken persons screaming and struggling in total darkness to escape from the smoke-filled trains to the platform.

Frank E. Gannett, newspaper publisher, returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary greatly amused by a suggestion made recently by Lord Beaverbrook "nominating" him for President.

MANHATTAN HUSING, HENRY (Aug. 13). Estate, $7,500. To Bertha Husing, widow, executrix, 225 West 69th St. LURIE, MARK (July 13). Estate, more than $20,000. To Olga Lurie, widow, executrix, 1,851 Madison Ave.

The Reds broke loose with an eighteenhit attack today against four Cardinal pitchers to give Paul Derringer his seventeenth victory of the season, 11 to 4. The Reds exploded for five runs in the fourth, the inning after Manager Bill McKechnie was banished

The round-the-world service of the Dollar Line, which has been suspended for several weeks because of financial difficulties, will be resumed in mid-September after the company's ships have been renovated to conform to Federal safety requirements, it was learned yesterday.
Hughes Ave. 2,338. 2-story dwelling, 25x 87.6; Eugenio Gallo against Stanislao Ferraro; due, $7,752; taxes. etc., $54; sub to 1st mtg, $6,500: to plaintiff for $100,000 By VINCENT J. DEO
Stockholders of the Carrier Corportion will vote on Sept. 12 on a financing program recommended by the directors, comprising an issue of $2,500,000 of ten-year convertible debentures. Negotiations

Governor Earle notified David L. Lawrence, democratic State chairman, today that he was curtailing his aerial vacation in Latin America and would start for home tomorrow to speak Saturday at the opening meeting of the Democratic campaign at Hershey.

Though he has been predicting a depression for the last three years and though evidences of the depression are here, even economists were startled by the statistical analysis of conditions presented by Sir William Beveridge, formerly of the

Trading opened slow in most classes, of fresh meats. Veal and calf were steady, other classes showed strength with some sales higher. Kosher lamb opened stronger, but. other classes of kosher meats opened very slow at steady prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended Aug. 18 was 218, which compares with 159 a year ago and 221 a week ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Joe Hunt and Sidney Wood, seeded second in the American group, and Ferene Puncec and Franjo Kukuljevic of Yugoslavia were eliminated from the national doubles tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club today, while the top ranking teams of Donald Budge and Gene Mako and Adrian Quist and John Bromwich of Australia dropped opening sets before turning back their opposition.

Harry Balsamo, 1611/2, Harlem, knocked out Young Terry, 1571/4, Trenton, in 2:34 of the first of their scheduled ten-round encounter which featured the card at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 2,800 persons saw Referee Johnny McAvoy halt the contest after Terry had gone to the canvas for the fourth time.
Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner today, dipping fractionally early in sympathy with Liverpool, only to rally later about 1 cent a bushel from the low point.

In sympathy with a strong stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange here recovered 6 to 8 points and ended at top figures yesterday. Rumors circulated in the last hour to the effect that the government loan might be fixed at 8.30 cents a pound, with differentials for grades or staple, combined with scattered professional covering- to stiffen the list.

Italy started her special census of Jews today. Questionnaires more than a yard long were distributed to all Jews and "suspected Jews" with the admonition that there would be severe penalties for those evading the census or giving false information.

Carl O. Parsons, salesman, was substituted by the American Labor party last night for Miss Grace Gosselin as the party designee for the State Senate in the Twentythird Bronx District, to oppose Senate Majority Leader John J. Dunnigan, incumbent Democrat. The laborites are confident they have a chance to win the district.

A permanent mortgage loan of $175,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for 10 years has been placed by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., with a savings bank on the two-story theatre, store and office building at 3,448-60 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, owned by the 3,460 Jerome Avenue Corporation, Max H. Sklar, president.

A minimum wage scale for mem-\ bers of the American Federation of Actors appearing in the private entertainment field was set up yesterday afternoon at a special meeting held at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Fortyeighth Street.

What was declared to be the first settlement completed under a system set up by the Federal district court in Manhattan for the benefit of sufferers in the two accidents of the Agwi Navigation Company-the to Morro Castle disaster and the collision of the Mohawk-received official approval yesterday in the Queens Surrogate's Court.

The day-long story told by George Weinberg at the Hines trial yesterday, which may have made history for Tammany Hall and may have marked an important step in the career of Thomas E. Dewey, was unfolded with all the casualness of an ordinary proceeding in a Magistrate's Court. The simple telling of the story provided the only drama of the day.

A banking syndicate headed by Hallgarten Co. will offer today to the public by means of a prospectus $10,000,000 of ten-year sinking fund 41/2 per cent debentures, Series A, of the Crucible Steel Company of America.
Brooding over the death of his mother, whose funeral took place Monday, Allen Street, 42 years old, of 333 Mosholu Parkway North, committed suicide at his home at about 8 o'clock last night.

Leslie B. Krumsick, vice president of the Fort Dearborn Securities Corporation in Chicago, was found dead of motor exhaust poisoning this afternoon. His body was discovered in his parked car in the Forest Preserve a few minutes before raiders from the blue sky division of the State's Attorney's office took charge of his company.

A number of dwellings in various sections of Queens were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Queens County Savings Bank. In Corona, the three-family dwelling at 32-17 107th Street was purchased by Mrs. Sadie Burton;

The Internal Revenue Bureau said today that production of whisky and other distilled spirits totaled 5,692,461 gallons in July, compared with 9,313,598 in July, 1937. However, withdrawals of tax-paid liquor from bonded warehouses was 5,732,370 gallons last month, compared with 5,303,755 gallons in July, 1937.

The apartment building at 7,609 Fourth Avenue, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, accommodating eighty-five families, has been purchased by Castel Court, Inc., of which Benjamin Hirsh is president, through Riker Co., brokers.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 23, unless specified: Norfolk to Annapolis: Badger, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott. At Navy Yard, New York: Brooklyn, Wandank. Hampton Roads to Annapolis: Texas, Wyoming.
Mgr. Edward J. McGolrick of Brooklyn died here today in a private nursing home to which he had come from Ballyshannon in Donegal. He was 81 years old.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,392,700 barrels, compared with 3,359,900 in the preceding week, an increase of 32,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Among the Manhattan properties figuring in sales reported yesterday were two East Side tenements. In each case a savings bank was the seller. An investing client of James Felt Co., brokers, purchased from the Citizens Savings Bank the five-story double flat at 118 East 102d Street, on a plot 25 by 100 feet.

Dr. Frank C. Ard of this city, eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, who retired in 1932, died today at his Summer home in Westfield, N. Y., in his seventy-fifth year. Dr. Ard studied at Freiburg, Germany; Johns Hopkins and University of Maryland. He also took

Blaine Ulmer of Webster Grove, Mo., turned in the perfect score of 200 to capture the laurels in the junior rifle corps Division A match today. Competition in the event was unusually keen, but the 17year-old Ulmer proved his worth under stern conditions.

Mace Ave, 807-811, 75x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Thomas M. Steccato; due, $15,249; to plaintiff for $500. Liebig Ave, 6,178, 2-story dwelling, 25x 91.11; Home Owners Loan Corp against Margaret Dolan; due, $11,073; to plaintiff for $500.

The Yankees' prospective gallop down the home stretch, two strides at a time, stubbed a toe yesterday, as Jimmy Dykes's White Sox, with the 40-year-old Jimmy himself in his battlefront as a second baseman, gave the world champions a sound thrashing in the opening clash of the afternoon's doubleheader at the Stadium.

IF the seismograph charts showed any wavering marks yesterday, that was no earthquake; it was England quivering with amazement and joy. An astonishing thing happened at the Oval. Suppose Glenn Cunningham ran a mile in four minutes flat. Suppose Lou Gehrig hit five consecutive home runs in five consecutive times at bat in a world series, with the bases filled each time for an added flourish.

Y.; pr mtg $21,300, due July 1, 1943, 4 per cent; $2,700. 70th St, 130 W, 18.6x100.5; Rexhold Realty Corp, James H. Cruikshank, president, to John W. and Laura S. Stewart Foundation, Inc, 420 Lexington Ave; p m mtg, 3 years. 5 per cent, $10,000; same

The Jersey City Giants, benefiting from the effective pitching of Tom Baker and Glen Gabler, scored a twin decision over Toronto tonight. Baker outpitched Earl Caldwell to win the opener, 5-1, and Gabler shaded Joe Sullivan in the nightcap, 2-1.
By unusual coincidence, the death of the two leading eye surgeons of this country occurred on Monday-Dr. George de Schweinitz of Philadelphia and Dr. John Martin Wheeler of New York's Medical Center.

The engagement of Miss Willette Alberta Ockendon, daughter- of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Ockendon of 71 East Seventy-seventh Street, to B. Gratz Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bruce Brown of Great Neck, L. I., has been announced by her parents.

The German plane Brandenburg had been eighteen hours in the air in its fine flight from Berlin to New York before news of its start was even made public. A German official remarked: "Had the plane crashed at the start or been forced to turn back, we naturally would have tried to cover the failure."

The Senators fought off the Browns for twelve innings today and finally won a 6-to-5 victory. Buddy Myer singled with the bases loaded and nobody out in the twelfth to score Pinch Runner Jimmy Wasdell with the winning run for Washington.

The body of Benjamin Langmaid, 29, of Marblehead, captain of football and hockey at Williams College in 1930, was found today in his automobile on a lonely road. Medical Examiner Michael F. Burke said he had committed suicide with a rifle found in the car, apparently some time yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Burt C. Ward of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elisabeth Ward; to Thomas Gerald Burke of Rye. Miss Ward was graduated from Smith College in June. Through her mother, she is a great-granddaughter of the late Richard Birks of Montreal, and, on the paternal side, she is descended from William Ward, who settled in Massachusetts the early part of the seventeenth century.
Opening with a field of twentyeight, the girls' Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, reached the quarter-final round yesterday without upsets.

With 413 new cases of whooping cough reported among New York City children during the week ended last Saturday, a new high record for this disease was established, Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner,

Evidences of a slight improvement in business were seen in the reports on trade factors from European countries made public today by the Department of Commerce. France showed larger trade values in July than a year ago, but a decrease in the volume of the trade,
