The stockholders of Pillsbury Flour Mills Company will be asked at their annual meeting on Sept. 13 to vote upon a proposal to authorize a new mortgage and to pledge all or substantially all or any part of the property and assets of the company as security for an authorized bond issue of not more than $7,500,000.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and C. Edgar Honnold of Oklahoma City, will offer today $1,713,000 State of Oklahoma 2 per cent Treasury notes. Of the total, $1,413,000 is dated Aug. 20 and $300,000, Sept. 1, 1938. All will mature on May 1, 1939. They will be priced to yield 0.50 per cent. They are issued to fund outstanding warrants.
Robert Feilich, associate buyer of children's shoes for L. Bamberger Co., Newark, has resigned, effective Friday. Edmund Beattie, buyer of blankets and towels, will take over Mr. Feilich's duties.

Miss Hope Holland and Cornelius Van Reypen Bogert Jr., who will be married on Friday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Englewood, N. J., were the guests of honor at a dinner with dancing given last night by Miss Holland's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paterno, on the St. Regis Roof.

Making a strong plea for separate submission of proposals in the new constitutional convention to the voters in November, Mayor La Guardia served notice last night on the 168 convention delegates that all their work would be destroyed at the polls if the document were submitted for approval as one unit.
Marquis Childs has delivered to the Yale University Press the last chapter of his new book, "This Is Democracyy" which will be published in October. The author of "Sweden: The Middle Way," again
Mississippi's electorate indicated its satisfaction\ with its Congressional delegation by renominating all seven incumbents at today's Democratic primary, which is tantamount to election.

Store leases in the Fifth and Madison Avenue districts formed an important part of the commercial leasing activity reported by brokers yesterday. The last store, mezzanine and basement in the building at 509 Madison Avenue was rented to Gordine, Inc., women's apparel,

President Roosevelt today called on all friends of the direct primary election system to repudiate Republican participation in Democratic primary contests, a practice which, he said, violated simple political morality and only hastened a return to the old boss-ridden convention system of selecting candidates for public office.

Justice Meier Steinbrink, in the Supreme Court, in'Brooklyn, awarded yesterday to the Pan American Securities Corporation of 70 Fifth Avenue a summary judgment of $188,947 with interest and costs against Friederich Krupp, Inc., of Essen, Germany, manufacturer of steel products and munitions.
Competition in two professional bike-racing national championships will be resumed at the Coney Island Velodrome tonight. Mike DeFilippo leads in the forty-mile motor-paced contest. but his martin

Fed steers and hogs worked 10 to 15 cents lower today. Cattle receipts exceeded expectations, and the crop ran almost to fed steers scaling 1,070 pounds upward, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Light yearling steers, cows and other killing classes of cattle sold actively. Prime steers topped at $12.75. The outside on hogs was $8.85. Native lambs sold at $8.90.

White Plains Rd (15-4287), e s, 100 ft s of Maran PI, 100x100; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee, to Milton S. Guiterman, trustee, 1,140 Ocean Ave, Elberon, N. J. 173d St (11-3014). s s, 121 ft e of Boone Ave, 71x88; Irving Trust Co., trustee, to Ida Epstein, 2,807 Webb Ave.

" Tegart's Wall" is the biggest barbedwire fence in the world. A triple line of wire entanglements fifty-seven miles long, it was built and electrified by the British to keep the Arabs of Syria out of Palestine. It would not have been

Joe Hiestand, 32-year-old farmer from Hillsboro, Ohio, master craftsman of the clay target sport, ran up an unbroken and unfinished string of 766 clays for a world record and won the North American championship today for the third time in four years at the Grand American trapshoot.

The annual Fall field day of the Bond Club of New Jersey will be held Sept. 23 at the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, C. Wallace Smith of H. M. Byllesby Co., chairman of the arrangements committee, announced yesterday.
Governors of the New York Stock Exchange will receive today and relay to the membership the reports of special committees headed by Charles B. Harding and Gayer G. Dominick.

The city's move to obtain a finding that public convenience and necessity no longer require continued operation of the Sixth Avenue elevated line was attacked on legal and factual grounds yesterday by Charles Franklin, counsel for the Manhattan Railway Company,

The signing of the "Vassar pact" of peace and friendship on a basis of collective security by the representatives of youth organizations in forty-seven countries- brought to a close today the second World Youth Congress here,

The current price cuts on cigarettes in this city will strengthen efforts to have the leading cigarette companies place their products under the provisions of the FeldCrawford Fair Trade Act, William A. Hollingsworth,

Those of you who are on the lookout for some good surf casting along the New Jersey coast can stop looking, and just plan to fish at Normandy Beach, Lavalette, Seaside Heights or Bay Head. According to all reports they are taking bluefish and stripers from these points in almost unbelievable numbers.

Governors Island won the annual Monmouth County Country Club ten-goal polo tournament today by defeating the Monmouth Freebooters, 5 to 3, in the hardest encounter of the tournament. The army officers led, 3 to 0, at half time, but the Freebooters scored one in the fourth period and two in the sixth to tie the count.
New and dramatic evidence of how a feeling of economic insecurity colors the political attitude of American voters today is revealed in a cross-section survey just completed by the institute.

Leonard Hutton, 22-year-old youngster, who comes from a town named Pudsey, made more news in England today than any war scare. He did it by scoring more runs than any one in the 64-year history of the cricket "world series" between England and Australia.

MANHATTAN ANDERSON, KATHERINE M. (Aug. 12). Estate, more than $5,000. To Lillian M. Anderson, sister, executrix, 606 W. 116th St., residue. BUTTENWEISER, JOSEPH L. (Aug. 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, $100,000 to be divided into four separate trusts as memorials to the decedent's father, Laemmlein Buttenwieser; his mother, Leah Buttenwieser;

The first official confirmation came today of reports that General Evangeline Booth would remain in charge of the Salvation Army for ten months after her scheduled retirement on Dec. 25 of this year, when she attains the age of 73.
A respite, temporary at least, from the heat was promised for today by the United States Weather Bureau, which predicted showers and cooler weather.
Approximately 40,000 factory workers returned to employment in July and weekly payrolls increased almost $500,000, Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor announced today.

Universal will star Deanna Durbin in a dramatized biography of Jenny Lind, based on a story of the Swedish singer's early life, which the studio has purchased from Hans Rameau. Henry Koster will direct with Joe Pasternak producing.
The Park and Fifth Avenue sections, as well as the East Side generally, accounted for the larger part of, the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday.

Potato growers from New York and more than a dozen other States will end their voting tomorrow on a proposed Federal-State marketing agreement aimed at - bolstering prices to farmers. Balloting began Friday on a proposal calling for the restriction by government inspection of the movement of cull potatoes in interstate commerce during years of bumper croos.
Another turn has been given to the screw that is so relentlessly forcing all persons of Jewish lineage out of the eco?omic and social life of Germany and into a ghetto existence of their own.

A story of how honest policemen who "interfered" with the operations of the Dutch Schultz policy racket by making arrests and raiding policy premises were "broken," reduced' in rank and transferred to out-of-the-way precincts was told yesterday by George Weinberg at the Hines trial.

Because of the effects of "a severe attack of neuritis," which has kept her out of competition since returning from her Wimbledon triumph, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody yesterday notified the United States Lawn Tennis Association she would not play in the forthcoming women's national singles championship at Forest Hills.

Leon Jouhaux, general secretary of the French Confederation of Labor, stated yesterday that French labor will not subscribe generally to the appeal of Premier Edouard Daladier to modify the application of the forty-hour week law in France in the interest of national safety.

Francis H. Biddle, counsel to the Congressional committee investigating the TVA, started a new phase of the inquiry today designed to show that the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and its local subsidiary sought to defeat public power for Chattanooga.

Justice George H. Furman in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, denied yesterday a motion made last Thursday by the newly formed Sanitation Benevolent Association for an order compelling Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey to give it the same recognition that has been extended to other associations made up of workers in the Department of Sanitation.

Judge William O'Dwyer, in Kings County Court, yesterday reserved decision on a motion of Leo Healy, attorney for Assistant District Attorney William F. McGuinness, for a trial by jury for the latter on charges made against him of accepting a bribe of $100 to "fix" a charge of perjury.
Spanish Insurgent armies shifted their main assault today from the deadlocked southern and eastern fronts to the Tagus River area on the central front, ninety miles southwest of Madrid.

Hank Greenberg hit his forty-third home run of the season, Rudy York his twenty-eighth, and sundry other Tigers swung with vigor and success today as Detroit downed the Athletics in both ends of a double-header, 13 to 5 and 8 to 3.

The future looked bright late yesterday for Mildred Small, a Negro, despite the fact that she lost a winning ticket in last Spring's Irish Sweepstakes worth $15.0,000. The story was heard in Felony Court where Frank Oxley, 34 years old, a Negro of 120 West 138th Street, was released in $100 bail on a charge of assault brought by another Negro,

Colonel Sam A. Robertson, developer of the Rio Grande Valley, died here last night. The Colonel built a railroad to the Rio Grande, founded the city of San Benito, near here, and built much of the irrigation works in what is now the rich lower Rio Grande Valley.

Steel ingot production increased last week, running counter to the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 63.8, its highest point since the week ended Nov. 6, 1937. The figure was 59.4 for the preceding week and 131.4 for the week ended Aug. 21, 1937.

The light steer kills during the last month or more have finally taken effect, and supply and demand are now about equal on the hindquarter end. Trading in steer hinds and ribs was active and prices strong to 50 cents higher in local markets yesterday. Demand for other cuts and classes was fair to slow. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly,

Two firemen were injured in a smoky fire which wrecked the interior of a two-story brick building in which are a bar and grill, a restaurant and a billiard parlor at 7 East Twenty-eighth Street, shortly before 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Two alarms were sounded as
Eleanor Grace Flanagan, 18 ed years old, who was chosen to sponsor the city's newest fireboat by a novel competition, was received yesterday by Mayor La con Guardia at the Summer City Hall in Queens.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, is to be commended for his public opposition to the plan of the Workers Alliance to solicit contributions from persons on Federal relief to be used to elect candidates who are in favor of higher relief payments and defeat those who are not.
Says Brooklyn Staff and Students Have Right to Own Views

Walter E. Corwin, veteran Republican district leader in Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing his endorsement of Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for the Kings County judgeship.

Merchants in more than twenty important cities throughout the country have already announced their intention to participate National Retail Demonstration to be held during the week of Sept. 19. it was announced yesterday at the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association,

Benjamin Marx, well-known auctioneer, suffered a heart attack yesterday afternoon near 158 West Fifty-eighth Street while walking. A doorman assisted him into a vacant apartment, where he died. His age was 66.

Police officials yesterday reported an easing of traffic congestion at the 158th Street and Ninety-sixth Street ramps of the West Side express highway due to the opening of two ramps into the parkway at 133d Street.

Jack Birnbaum has been appointed advertising manager of Browne Vintners Company, Inc., Samuel Lentz, executive vice president, announced yesterday. Mr. Birnbaum has been with the company for two years,

The net operating income of the first eight railroads to report for July showed a decline of 32.8 per cent from July, 1937. The results of these roads for the month are shown in the following table, the last three ciphers being omitted:

Governor Phil La Follette today wired an urgent request to the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation to purchase part of' Wisconsin's huge surplus of Swiss and American cheese to alleviate the glutted market condition and prevent a further drop in prices.

Believing that a solution for continuing the needlework industry in Puerto Rico, employing upward of 100,000 persons, would be found, Edward J. Leon, New York attorney for the industry, flew homeward today. A formal request,

Cod tongues, served piping hot on toasted crackers, were introduced yesterday to guests at an exhibit of the arts and crafts 'of the French-Canadians of the Gaspe peninsula, at the Waldorf-Astoria. Douglas Cole, Canadian Government Trade Commissioner,

The Navy Ministry announced today that Cesar Campinchi, Minister of the Navy, had ordered the construction of a new 35,000-ton battleship. It will be named Clemenceau in honor of France's wartime Premier, Georges Clemenceau.

Plans for developing a closer business and financial relationship between New York and Amsterdam were announced yesterday by the Holland House Corporation of The Netherlands, a non-profit organization recently formed by commercial and banking interests here and in The Netherlands.

Principal scenes of Smetana's "The Bartered Bride" will be given tonight in concert form at the Federal Music Theatre by the Federal Opera Chorus, the Greenwich, Orchestra and soloists. Fritz Mahler. will conduct, and a commentator will explain the action of the story between the scenes.

Vice Chancellor W. Frank Sooy refused today to appoint a receiver for the Camden, N. J., local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers. Five of the 759 members of the local union, dissatisfied with

President Emanuel Cortes signed today a decree of the Costa Rican Congress which recommended the sale of bonds to pay for the expropriation of the properties of the Costa Rica Electric Light and Traction Company, Ltd., which is controlled by the Electric Bond and Share Company, great superpower organization of North America.

Declaring the Republican primary petition of David S. Murden of Peekskill, candidate for County President of Westchester, to be "unquestionably a fraud," the County Board of Elections refused tonight to place Mr. Murden's name on the Sept. 20 primary ballot and asked the District Attorney's office to conduct an investigation.

After a peaceful night in Kiel Harbor the German naval yacht Grille, carrying Chancellor Hitler, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, and their personal staffs, steamed slowly this morning through Kiel Canal to a point opposite Cuxhaven. There her passengers boarded the new liner Patria, which carried them with some additional guests to Helgoland.

Joseph J. Haggerty, through Talbot J. Taylor Jr, at Ivy Gates, for Bertron M. Webb; Edward T. Roche, at East Cottage, Halsey Lane; Remsenburg, L. I., leases by Butler Baldwin, Inc, brokers. William A. O'Brien, at 41 Harvard Dr, renewal, for New Rochelle Trust Co; James L. Green, at 24 Harvard Dr, for Ruth W. Glebe; White Plains leases by the Robert E. Farley Organization.
The bitter hatred of the Madison Square Garden Democratic convention of 1924 cropped up in California today with the charge that
The French flying boat Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris alighted on the Tagus River here today at 4:05 P. M. (12:05 P. M., E. D. T.), completing the first leg of an experimental flight to New York.

The Census Bureau announced today that cotton of this year's growth ginned prior to Aug. 16 totaled 313,934 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 514,524 bales a year ago and 208,509 bales two years ago.

A stockholders' suit to obtain title to the Scarsdale estate occupied by William R. Davis, oil land promoter, who is currently identified with Mexican oil transactions, was disclosed today in Supreme Court when Justice Gerald Nolan reserved decision on a motion to appoint a receiver of the estate.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Ruth Pratt Talcott, daughter of Mrs. Francis Cole Pratt of New York and the late Mr. Pratt of Schenectady, N. Y., to Gerard Merrick Ives, which took place on Monday at Autumn Acres, the bride's home in Center Harbor, N. H.

The Commonwealth Southern Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $12,342,647 for the twelve months ended on July 31, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to 10 cents a share on 33,662,594 common shares, compared with $15,660,911, or 20 cents a share for the common stock, in the preceding twelve months.

With all of the open championship teams planning test matches for tomorrow, players today confined themselves to informal polo at the Meadow Brook Club. Nine teams were in action on the various fields, including in Their line-ups several of the American and foreign stars who are preparing for the open.

With Donald W. Smith's term as a member of the National Labor Relations Board expiring Saturday, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that Mr. Smith "lacks the qualifications to serve on so important a board."

A committee of eight prominent Methodist ministers and laymen visited New York yesterday on an inspection tour to select a city for the national "unifying conference" of the three branches of the denomination next April.

The report of Remington Rand, Inc., and its subsidiaries yesterday for the three months ended on June 30, which was the first quarter of the company's current fiscal year, shows a net profit of $93,152 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

A few weeks of clear, warm weather are needed throughout the West to provide suitable conditions for the completion of harvesting, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today in its weekly report on crop conditions in the Prairie Provinces.

A festival of folk dances and songs will be held at 2:30 P. M. today on the athletic field of Abraham Lincoln High School, Ocean Parkway and Guider Avenue, Brooklyn, with 5,000 children in costume from 155 school playgrounds participating.

The testimony at yesterday's session of the trial of James J. Hines, consisting chiefly of the continued story of George Weinberg, former Schultz lieutenant, follows: When court opened at 10:16 A. M. yesterday, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora announced that counsel had agreed that the testimony of Joseph Ison to the effect that he was "taken for a ride" by Bo Weinberg and Abe Landau

W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for United States Senator, issued at his campaign headquarters here today a statement declaring that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic State leader, was "the one issue no one in New Jersey or in Washington can sidestep."

The Rev. Thomas A. Nolan, S. J., former dean of men at Xavier University, died in Good Samaritan Hospital here today. He was 75 years old. Father Nolan, a member of the Society of Jesus for fifty-twoyears and a priest for thirty-eight, was a native of Cincinnati and a member of the university staff for the last fourteen years.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 22: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Thomas, C. W. Jr., Inf., one month and fourteen days leave. Sept. 14, with permission to visit foreign countries. Gerow, L. T., Inf., General Staff Corps, one day leave, Aug. 22.

The Dodgers ran out of luck and all but ran out of players today as they dropped their opening Western engagement to the Cardinals in a free hitting contest, 9 to 7, before a Ladies' Day crowd of 5,575.

Storage butter futures fell 13/8 cents a pound today, touching, before a slight recover, their lowest level since 1934. At the low point of 227/8 a pound, November contracts were down 71/8 cents from the season's best quotation, and the close at 231/4 was a full cent below yesterday's finish.

By taking third place today following his victory yesterday, Hercules B. Atkin of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club still led on points in the Atlantic Coast championship for the Star Class sloops being held at the Riverside Yacht Club.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt gave a small dinner tonight and afterward took her guests to the Casino Theatre for the presentation of "French Without Tears." Mr. and Mrs. G. J. Guthrie Nicholson also had a box party, and others who brought dinner guests to occupy boxes were Miss Ruth Vanderbilt Twombly and Mrs. Beverley Bogert.

Dally average sales of chain grocery stores for July were about 3 per cent below the dollar volume of July, 1937, and were lower than for any month since August, 1935, according to preliminary figures made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

The executive committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange approved today the application of the Commonwealth Edison Company to list $50,208.745 of stamped convertible debentures, 31/2 per cent series, due on July 1, 1958, and 10,041,749 rights to subscribe for the debentures.

The English county cricket championship race tightened today when the weakened Yorkshire team lost on the first innings to Nottinghanshire. Five Yorkshiremen are playing for England against Australia.

Reductions of 35 to 40 cents a yard in tropical worsted and gabardine prices for the Spring, 1939, season, were named yesterday by the American Woolen Company, and it was expected in the market that similar cuts would be made by other producers.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of seamen, accepted yesterday the challenge to a battle for control of the seamen of the American merchant marine which was issued Monday in Atlantic City by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Discord among China's defenders was brought into the open today by an order of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Chief of Staff suppressing organizations of students and workers that were inspired or sponsored by Chinese Communists.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine disclosed yesterday in answer to a question by reporters that Chief Inspector Alexander C. Anderson, highest ranking police officer of the uniformed force, was away from his duties on sick leave following a slight stroke.

John L. Lewis, president of the Committee for Industrial Organization, was called upon today by opponents of Homer Martin, president of the Ge United Automobile Workers, to appoint an administrator for the union and sanction a movement for a special union convention to elect new officers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Hardy Jr. of Sterling Ridge, Rye, N. Y., and Wainscott, L. I., of the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Ruth Lehmer Hardy, to Charles G. Miller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Rye.

The Brunswick - Balke - Collender Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange that options have been granted to S. E. Meyers and C. G. Bonner to buy 500 common shares each at $11 a share until May 31, 1940, old options being canceled;

Under new border defense measures disclosed by the Czechoslovak-National Defense Ministry today, any citizen upon seeing anything leading him to suspect an invasion is under way may step to a telephone and say, "This call is in the interests of the defense of the State."

With one race remaining on the schedule, to be sailed tomorrow morning, the Knickerbocker crew, skippered by Robert Mosbacher, has a considerable lead in the point total for the midget yacht racing championship of Long Island Sound. The third and fourth races of the series were sailed off the Stamford Yacht Club today.

Turpentine firm, 221/2c; no sales; receipts, 504 barrels; shipments, 40 barrels; stock, 46,341 barrels. Rosin firm; sales. 503: receipts, 2,773; shipments, 430; stock 222,811. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.85: E, $4.20; F. G. H. I. K, M. $4.30; N, $5.20; WG, $5.50; WW, X, $6.30.
The National League announced through The Associated Press yesterday the following dates for playing off tie games, postponed games and schedule changes:

One of the chief musical events of the season here will take place the night of Sept. 3 at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng, when the studio players under the direction of Leighton Rollins will present "The Headless Horseman," a new American operetta by Stephen Vincent Benet and Professor Douglas Moore of Columbia University.

The Caravan units of the Federal Theatre will make the following one-night stands in the city tonight: The Bronx, "Melodies on Parade," a variety revue, at Crotona Park; Brooklyn, "Mr. Dooley Jr.," at Gravesend Park;

Cooperation of government, Industry and labor was urged by Governor Lehman and Senator Wagner in keynote addresses opening the convention of the State Federation of Labor at Buffalo yesterday. [Page 1.]

The tonnage of steel in use in the United States reached a new high of 1,050,000,000 gross tons at the end of 1937, compared with 1,020,000,000 tons a year before, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimates, making the fifth consecutive year of gains. The present figure is 25 per cent above the 1929 total of 840,000,000 gross tons.

The further engagement of $2,025,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as sterling continued to display a weak tendency in the foreign exchange market.

President Roosevelt volunteered the information today that he had discussed with William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, the subject of clarifications of the National Labor Relations Act and confirmed the labor leader's statement that, while agreement was reached on a need of changes, specific alterations had: not been mentioned.

Armed police patrolled the streets tonight and officers carrying carbines guarded the Presidential palace after attacks in which three persons were assassinated, including one American. The serious character of the incident developed when an unidentified, assailant attacked the residence of Deputy Ricardo Moreno Canas, firing three shots and killing the Deputy.

As hinted a few days ago, Joseph Losey has definitely decided against the Ernest Hemingway play "The Fifth Column." A "combination of casting and financial difficulties," he notes, though he still is in the market for other plays, expecting to produce one or two this season.

Walter Burkemo, 20, of Detroit, 126 pounds of golfing grit, whipped par and a crack field to win medalist honors in the seventeenth annual national public links golf championship today, posting a brilliant card of 69 for a thirty-six-hole -qualifying total of 141 strokes.

In a decision of importance to manufacturers of collars that remain stiff even though they are not starched when they comew out of the wash, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday the validity of the Camille Dreyfus patents, which cover a process of bringing this about.

Despite criticism by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and Chairman Sheppard of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, the Workers Alliance continued yesterday its plans to raise $50,000 to help elect candidates pledged to the expansion of relief and the WPA program.

J. Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., with three fellow-Coast stars, Robert Riggs, Joseph R. Hunt and C. Gene Mako, all of Los Angeles, have been designated to defend the Davis Cup against the challenging Australians, it was announced yesterday by Walter L. Pate, chairman of the United States Lawn Tennis Association Davis Cup Committee of Management.

To take effect 8 A. M., Aug. 24: PATROLMEN-Thomas A. Coyne, from 9th Precinct to 18th Division, assigned to duty as chauffeur. John W. Brown, from Traffic G to 18th Division, designated as third-grade detective.

Everybody seems to agree that President Roosevelt's promise to defend Canada against foreign attack, though important, is not new. It follows from the Monroe Doctrine. This, has hitherto looked to the
Informed persons said today that Secretary of State Cordell Hull had proposed to Mexico a compromise solution of differences over Mexican expropriation of American-owned agrarian lands.

The announcement or the discovery in South Africa by Dr. Robert Broom of the fossil of a hitherto unknown anthropoid ape has left anthropologists of the British Association for the Advancement of Science with a feeling that all props have been kicked from under them.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is sailing today for Cherbourg and Southampton. Passengers are Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen of Newport and her daughter, Mrs. Serge Mdivani, the Hon. William Waldorf Astor, M. P., and Philip Mainwaring Broadmead, First Secretary of the British Embassy in Washington.

The New York Football Giants will hold their second scrimmage tomorrow morning for their game with the Eastern All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 7. It is expected that Ward Cuff, regular halfback, will return to his post after a short absence because of a leg injury received in Sunday's scrimmage.

Miss Helen M. Lambert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Lambert of this city, has chosen Sept. 7 as the date of her marriage to William A. Hamilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Hamilton of Staunton, ya. The ceremony will take place in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

David C. Johnson, president of New York Steam Corporation, announced yesterday that the company would redeem on Nov. 1 at 105 all of its first mortgage gold bonds then outstanding of each of the following three series: First mortgage gold bonds, Series A, 6 per cent, due 1947; first mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due 1951, and first mortgage gold bonds, 5 per cent series, due 1956.

George Weinberg, a gangster who ran the policy racket for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, put in more than five hours of detailcrammed testimony yesterday, telling what Tammany District Leader James J. Hines allegedly did

Led by railroad issues, the general bond list on the New York Stock Exchange registered yesterday some impressive gains in the heaviest trading in almost two weeks. Spurred on primarily by the announcement that the Interstate Commerce Commission had approved a loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Southern Railway to meet its maturities

The Maritime Commission is considering the transfer of the Munson Line ships Pan America, Western World and Southern Cross to a trans-Pacific service operating from Seattle, after the Munson ships are withdrawn from the South American service in the next two months.

A tattered quilt in which the twelfth victim of Cleveland's "torso slayer" was found a week ago today offered promise of solution of the crimes, police said tonight after they had traced brief possession of the quilt to Elmer Cummings, a 56year old junkman.
Carl Hubbell, the greatest southpaw in baseball; lay on his hospital bed tonight, reconciled not to return to duty with the Giants this season.

Interest in color, the sparing use of furs and a tendency on the part of a few couturiers to offset the decline of the franc by raising prices were the outstanding features of the recent Paris couture openings, according to Samuel
The St. Elias Mountain range, one of the highest in the world, got that way by climbing over the top of the younger coastal rocks.

James Paskovics, 29 years old, of 142 East Thirty-third Street, a house painter, accused of striking and causing the death of Clark Twelvetrees, actor and former husband of Helen Twelvetrees, motion picture actress, was held without bail yesterday by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould .Schurman Jr. in Homicide Court, on suspicion of homicide, for examination Sept. 1..

The Republican candidate for the Presidency in 1936, further enforcing his statement that he would not accept the nomination "in the remote contingency" it was offered to him in 1940, presents here, in the fourth and last of a series of daily articles his impressions of his losing fight and the lessons he learned in it.

Schick Dry Shaver, Inc., reduced the price of its electric shaver from $15 to $12.50 yesterday, a move which is generally expected to bring about lower levels on most types retailing above $10. Company officials, however, discounted the idea that the action would lead to a price war.
Lloyd (Whitey) Moore shut out the Phillies today as the Reds backed him with nine hits for a 3-to-0 victory. Cincinnati thus increased its thirdplace margin over the Cubs to two games.

THE other day a letter came from a man asking what one American novel I would recommend for preservation in a box that was to be buried in the ground for several thousand years. Although it would have been no task to reel off the names of about 500 novels that might be buried until doomsday without particularly hurting my feelings, I was stumped when it came to the One Great.

Led by Peter Fick and Ralph Flanagan, the touring United States swimming team split honors with a German side today in a sixevent meet. Fick, who represents the New York Athletic Club, won the 100meter free-style in 0:59.3, with Otto Jaretz of Chicago second in 0:59.5.

The alleged inventor of a newly discovered racket that defrauded filling station operators was captured here yesterday by detectives, one of whom fired a shot at the suspect as he fled up Broadway and into West 146th Street.

The relapse of the Democratic primary campaigns in South Carolina and Georgia into the depths of the "white supremacy" issue is a natural and inevitable result of the President's attempt to dictate Senatorial and other nominations in that part of the country. Destructive and noxious as are

Following is the address by James H. Fay, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Sixteenth District, over the Columbia Broadcasting Company's network: Last Thursday evening Congressman John J. O'Connor spoke over this radio network and attacked the President of the United States.

Triumphant in two slugging matches with Cleveland, which were high-spotted by Jimmy Foxx's game-winning homer with the bases loaded, the Red Sox today took over second place in the American League by more than a game margin.

Miss Marie Spence Kiely and James M. Snowden, whose engagement was announced early in July, will be married on Sept. 15 at the home of Miss Kiely's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Kiely, at 1,021 Park Avenue.

Floyd L. Green, president of General Refractories Company, says in a letter to stockholders that as a result of recent negotiations with holders of first mortgage 41/2 per cent sinking fund bonds, the maturity date of the issue will be extended from July 1, 1945, to Jan. 1, 1949.

Senator George L. Berry, defeated for renomination in the recent Tennessee Senatorial primary, charged in a letter filed with the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures today that WPA employes had been assessed $125,000 in the campaign and that this fund was used against him.
THE ART OF PERSUADING PEOPLE, by James A. Worsham (Harper, $2.) ATTAINING MANHOOD, by George W. Corner. (Harper, $1.25.) Subtitled: "A Doctor Talks to Boys About Sex."

The industrial property at 37-12 Fifty-seventh Street, Woodside, L. I., has been leased by the Treasury Department for the Works Progress Administration and will be used for the manufacture of concrete park benches, Lehr Benes, brokers in the deal, announced yesterday.

Frank Black, orchestra leader, has sold his 116-acre estate near Mechanicsville, Bucks County, Pa., to Arthur J. Wieland, head of the extension department of General Motors, according to J. Carroll Molloy, Doylestown realty man.

John Nicholas Luff, one of the greatest American authorities on postage stamps and generally considered to be unequaled in his knowledge of United States issues, died yesterday of heart disease in his apartment in the Hotel Bretton Hall, Eighty-sixth Street and Broadway, after an illness of more than a year.

Mrs. John M. Dodd is arranging a fashion show for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Dr. Carlson's School for Handicapped Children in East Hampton. It will take place on the afternoon of Aug. 31 in the John Drew Memorial Theatre here.

Reaching of an agreement in principle with savings banks and insurance companies for a temporary reduction in the rate of interest on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's bonds was announced yesterday at the office of the company here.

The Maritime Commission today started the distribution of thousands of application blanks for enrollment in the United States Maritime Service under which those who are accepted will be trained as merchant seamen.

Mr. and Mrs. William J. Mills of the Bayville Summer colony have announced the engagement of Mrs. Mills's sister, Miss Ada Berryman, daughter of Harry Berryman of Jericho and the late Mrs. Berryman, to Timothy Oleinikoff of New York.

" The next Senator from South Carolina will be the man who beats 'Cotton Ed' Smith. Now you just go out and find the man who can lick him." The above were the exact words of a South Carolina farmer, uttered as he sat on a knife-marked bench on the side porch of a little country store on the highway between Greenwood and Charleston.

The bothersome Bees shut out Pittsburgh's National League leaders, 6 to 0, in the first half of a doubleheader today and then battled for fourteen innings before finally giving way, 4 'to 3, in -the nightcap. The baseball marathon kept 12,294 fans in their seats more than five hours.

ALTMARK--Betty (nee Davidson), beloved wife of Arnold, devoted mother of Jack, dear sister of Anna Greenwald and Maurice Davidson, beloved niece of Gussle Blumoerg. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Wednesday, Aug. 24, at 1:30 P. M.
The thirty-fourth exhibition in the series by New York Artists, at the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street, opens to the public today. Three of the groups,

Emanuel Tobiessen, electrical engineer for the Allis Chalmers Company for more than thirty years, died yesterday in Norway, a cablegram from Mrs. Tobiessen to their children here announced today. He was 59 years old. The parents were

William A. Irvin, vice chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, has become chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements to welcome to this city a group of nearly 300 British industrialists, engineers and metallurgists who are coming to the United States in October, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As I write, dairymen of this and adjoining States who supply the metropolis with fluid milk are voting on the question of Federal and State price-fixing and control.

Pure Thoughts, owned by Henry W. Leh of Allentown, Pa., captured the juvenile pace in two straight heats as the Monmouth County Fair opened today. Pure Thoughts led Banner Hanover in the initial brush and Villanova in the second.

The offering price of the $33,000,000 of Commonwealth Edison Company 31/2 per cent bonds scheduled to be marketed on Thursday will be 1031/2. The company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington an amended statement giving the offering price.

Members of the Queens Valley Golf Club, Forest Hills, L. I., were advised last night at a special meeting that title of their club property will pass on Dec. 1 to new owners, who intend to develop the tract for housing.
Although the Federal Government has spent vast sums in recent years for buildings to house its various agencies, it still pays out many millions each year for rental of privately owned space.

Through its twenty-five publications, each of which serves a division of business and industry, the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company will launch an editorial program on the subject of public relations beginning in October.

Pedro Montanez, whirlwind Puerto Rican lightweight, will oppose Orville Drouillard of Windsor, Ontario, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Montanez, who was decisively outpointed by Lou Ambers a year ago, is seeking to fight his way back to the position of leading contender for the 135-pound championship and earn a match with Henry Armstrong.

The stock market here was quiet and generally dull again today, although prices improved in late dealings. Gilt-edge issues advanced, but among the foreign loans German and Austrian bonds lost ground. Transatlantic stocks showed strength, and the gainers included United States Steel and International Nickel.

The payroll sheets of the Dutch Schultz policy combination listed James J. Hines as "Pop" in recording the $500 a week that was allegedly paid to him, George Weinberg asserted yesterday in his testimony. Weinberg said he and Harry Schoenhaus were in charge of the sheets.

MANHATTAN BORMANN, EMMA M. (March 22. 1938). Gross assets, $26,380; net, $19,092. To Anna M. Darran, sister, $8,200 and residue; Emma L. Price, niece, $8,000; six varying bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance. $14,555. Salter Steinkamp, attorneys, 342 Madison Ave.
An extensive rotogravure campaign in newspapers for the Fall season will be launched with fullpage ads by the Cohen, Goldman Company, maker of men's clothing,

Francis W. Conner, assistant passenger traffic manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died of a heart ailment last night in Pittsburgh while on his way to his home in Wayne, near here, after a vacation in Colorado. He was 60 years old.

In a move to increase the efficiency of the League of New York Theatres the membership of that organization voted unanimously yesterday that hereafter decisions by a majority of the members will be binding on individual members.
Miss Ethel Zabriskie of the Carlyle will leave today for Newport. Mrs. Smith Hempstone of Washington has joined her husband, Captain Hempstone, U. S. N., at the Ambassador.
One gathers from some of the testimony given before the House Committee on un-American Activities that it is now possible to be a Communist without knowing it. One may think he is

A servant in the home here of Mr. and Mrs. S. P. Haldenstein spent her evenings during the last month in ransacking eight dark houses and numerous parked automobiles, Police Chief William Short charged today. Loot valued at about $1,000

General Francisco Franco probably will be asked to reconsider his demand for prior belligerent rights and for equal instead of proportionate withdrawal of foreign "volunteers" from rival armies in Spain.

Assertions that the administration was planning to oust various Federal appointees of Senator Millard E. Tydings in Maryland, made in various quarters since Representative Lewis, of the Sixth Maryland District, announced his candidacy for the Senatorial nomination nearly two months ago, appear to have little authority to support them. Only two officials have been dropped, both assertedly for good cause.
A group of fourteen Japanese newspaper men departed for Europe aboard the Bremen last night after spending several days here studying American newspaper operation and seeing the sights.

Although normally the County Clerk's office closes at 2 P. M. in Summer, its several entrances are being kept open during the Hines rial to help secrete District Attorney Dewey's witnesses. The entrances lead to a maze of corridors and stairways, which to those who know their way around the building are advantageous for ushering witnesses in without running the gauntlet of news photographers.

Telephone operating subsidiaries of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in eight foreign countries handled about 1,500,000 more long distance calls in the first half of 1938 than in the same period of 1937, which was a record year, with every company reporting gains over a year ago.

Retired Captain James Foley, formerly a member of Engine Co. 292, residing at 63 Centre Street, Woodmere, L. I., died Aug. 20. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 9:30 A. M., Wednesday. Aug. 24, thence to St. Joseph's Church, Broadway, Hewlett, L. I. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, L. I.

Miss Dorothy Crum, daughter of Mrs. E. Wylly Crum of this city and Raymond Crum of Stamford, Conn., has chosen Sept. 4 as the date for her marriage to Granger Hollister-Frost, son of Mrs. Walter Dabney Blair of Tarrytown-onHudson and New York, and of the late Eliott Park Frost of Rochester.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT. Reorganization Petitions GAYTIME FROCKS, INC., operating chain stores, 313 W. 35th St.: voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $50.969 and assets of $35,892. The corporation operates retail stores in Ohio and West Virginia and departments in stores located in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia.

Mrs. Woods Robinson gave a small luncheon today for her house guest, Mrs. A. Dalton Kennedy of Camden, S. C. Another small luncheon was given by William Woodward for Henry Case and Edward Potter. John Sanford entertained at a luncheon before the races, as did Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin.

With the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's plan for tiding over its interest charges in shape, the Erie Railroad, bankrupt line controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, was reported yesterday approaching fiduciary institutions with a plan for a revision of its financial structure.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were well below the figures for the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals were 907, as against 1,004 In the previous week and 856 in the same period last year.

Martial del Nero, 44 years old, who described himself as a manufacturer from Rome, N. Y., was under arrest here yesterday on a grand larceny charge for alleged participation with others in the theft of $11,000 worth of negotiable City of New York bonds.

James H. Fay, New Deal opponent of Representative John J. O'Connor in Manhattan's Sixteenth Congressional District, assailed Mr. O'Connor last night in a nationwide radio address over WABC as a Democrat disloyal to the President.

The Suffolk County Agricultural Society's "Blue Ribbon Fair" opened here today. Several thousand persons attended and in addition it was children's day. The feature tomorrow will be the police day program, under the auspices of the Suffolk County Police Association.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Lucille Hutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Seymour Hutt of this city, to the Rev. Robert Sloan Beecher, pastor of the South Congregational Church, Hallowell, Me., son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Allen Beecher of this city, took place here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

115th St, 102 W, 31.6x100.11: Harry Rodwin, trustee, to Annie Cantor, 146 Beach 82d St, Rockaway Beach; mtg, $20,875 ($2.50). 2d Ave, 2,491, 24.11x100; Gustave Schwartz. Inc, to Anna Kaplan, 1,505 Shakespeare Ave; mtg, $10,000 ($1.50). Riverside Dr, 40, 32x53 irreg; Ruth B. Kugelman to Margaret E. Wells, 40 Riverside Dr; mtg, $35,000 ($5).

Four members of the crew of a French Navy seaplane were killed and two injured this evening when in the course of a freakish accident their plane struck a sunken warship on alighting in Cherbourg Harbor.

The eighteen-room house with seventeen of the 292 acres comprising the historic Mine Brook Farm at Barnardsville and Far Hills, N. J., has been purchased by the Mount Kemble School, which will begin Classes there next month. The estate of William H. Page was the seller.

Commander Frank Hawks and a companion were fatally injured tonight in a flaming plane crash, less than a year after Hawks gave up the speed flying which made him famous and took up "safety and comfort" flying.

Although every effort has been made by the Henlein [Sudeten Nazi] press and the Runciman mission to keep it secret, a story leaked out tonight that an interview between a representative of Lord Runciman and Konrad Henlein did, in fact, take place in Marienbad Sunday as predicted.

If it is true that coming events cast their shadow before, this final swing of the Giants through the hostile West will be an exciting march. It started in gala manner today at Wrigley Field, where the Terrymen in one furious exhibition of concentrated fire submerged the Cubs, 6 to 2, before a gathering of 14,538.

The Rev. James P. Stofflet, pastor of the West Presbyterian Church here, died yesterday in the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Wolf at Hopatcong, N. J. He had been taken ill on Sunday while conducting a service at the Community Church, Hopatcong, but had finished the service before going to the Wolf home, where he later suffered a heart attack. His age was 65.

Henry Rutgers Beekman of 38 East Seventy-sixth Street, New York, an artist who specialized in paintings for children and was a member of the old Beekman family of New York, died today of a heart attack in his Summer home here. His age was 57.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies receives a legacy of $100,000 in the will of Joseph L. Buttenwieser, real estate operator and philanthropist, offered for probate in Surrogate Court yesterday. Mr. Buttenwieser,

Possibility that, following establishment of a 30- cents- per- hour minimum wage for the cotton, rayon and silk industries, the industry committee to be named by Administrator Elmer F. Andrews may recommend upward revision,

Mr. Roosevelt was on sound ground yesterday when he criticized the practice of crossing party lines in order to affect the results of a primary election. When Republicans who would not vote in any circumstances for a Democratic candidate in the general elections go into a Democratic primary, help

Although the Temporary National Economic Committee, made up of representatives of executive departments and six members of Congress to investigate monopolies, does not expect to start formal hearings before October, the investigation itself is actually under way.

The California and Hawailan Sugar Refining Corporation, Ltd., a California corporation, has completed arrangements for the marketing of its products on the Atlantic Coast, according to an announcement yesterday by F. E. Sullivan, president.

Howard J. Mountrey yesterday announced his resignation from the Borden Company as director of sales activities for its manufactured products. He was at one time advertising manager and successively became Western division sales manager, general sales

The League of Nations Yearbook on World Productions and Prices, published today, finds that "despite a certain decline, world economy as a whole so far has shown a relatively high degree of resistance to depressive influences emanating principally from the United States."

The four-story apartment house at 361 Powers Avenue, near East 143d Street, the Bronx, was purchased by a syndicate headed by Julius Borenstein, represented by Abraham L. Sobil, attorney. A client of Goodman Mabel, attorneys, was the purchaser.

The special House committee investigating Communist, Fascist, Nazi and other un-American activities in the United States asked President Roosevelt today to request various departments of the government to "loan" to the committee attorneys, investigators and clerical and stenographic assistance.

Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association held over the White Beeches Golf and Country Club course today with a score of 45. 40-85.

Stifling heat in an airless isolation cell, which was compared by investigators to the grim Black Hole of Calcutta, killed the four prisoners whose bodies were found in the fortresslike Philadelphia county prison at Holmesburg, it was learned here tonight.

" The biggest Little Entente achievement since it came into existence" and "a contribution to European peace equivalent to that of the Saloniki pact" are two comments typical of the satisfaction over the unexpected agreement between Hungary and the Little Entente concerning nonaggression and on the question of rearmament by the Entente conference in Bled, Yugoslavia, today.

Harry Kuhlmann of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was elected temporary chairman yesterday of a committee to plan a mass meeting of sporting goods dealers and producers, and manufacturers of sportswear, aimed at bringing about greater participation of these groups in World's Fair activities.
Court Haugwitz-Reventlow, who arrived at the Bristol Hotel from Venice yesterday, explained to the writer tonight that his visit with the Countess was one of courtesy only.

With the assertion that he was "dignifying for the last time the insinuations and innuendoes" of his New Deal opponent, Senator Millard E. Tydings tonight declared that all the charges made against him by Representative David J. Lewis were "utter falsehoods."

Temporary Assignment PATROLMAN-Harry Schaffel, from 22d Precinct to 19th Division, duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 22 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 25. Leave With Pay Authorized under Section 245, Military Law, State of New York. PATROLMAN - Murray Trilling, Harbor Precinct, 14 days, 4 P. M., Sept. 17.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry MacDonald, who were married last Saturday in Cold Spring, N. Y., sailed yesterday on the Queen Mary for visits in England and Scotland. Later they will go to France and Italy. Mrs. MacDonald is the former Miss Charmian Campbell, daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Archibald Campbell.

Miss Catherine Adams Mitchell, nationally r known in conservation circles, died tonight in her home in Riverside, 111. She was 54 years old. Miss Mitchell, a graduate of Smith College, was secretary of the Conservation Council in Chicago and of the Illinois Audubon Society.

The death this morning of Egerico Vargas, a local merchant, brought to four the victims of Beltran Cortes, the criminal who ran amuck last night and assassinated Dr. Moreno Canas and Dr. Carlos Manuel Echandi.

A goal by Robert Eisner after one minute of play in a sudden death period gave Evergreen Farms a 6-to-5 victory over the Norwood Polo Club in the opening match of the latter's annual eight-goal tour nament today.
Additional organizations and individuals joined yesterday in protesting the action of the State Constitutional Convention in adopting the proposal to ban proportional representation in the State.

Having retired the trophy a year ago by winning it three times, Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Marion Turpie, started to work on its replacement in the annual Long Island women's medal play championship today.

Viscount Runciman's principal assistant, Frank Ashton-Gwatkin, flew to London today to report on the situation following his recent meeting with Konrad Henlein, Sudeten Nazi leader, and dinner last night with Premier Milan Hodza.

Pennsylvanian applied today for a Government job as a lion hunter-and the Civil Service Commission hastened to explain that it had s none. The applicant wrote the commission that he noticed "your ad regarding an examination for civilservice jobs as lion hunters."

An important conference on major political strategy will be held here within the next few days between President Roosevelt and Chairman Farley it was learned in an official quarter today. The conference is expected to deal primarily with the progress of the New Deal "purge" in the four States where President Roosevelt has intervened in Congressional primary contests-Georgia, South Carolina, New York and Maryland.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain today discussed the international situation with Viscount Halifax, Foreign Secretary; Sir John Simon, Home Secretary; Sir Horace Wilson,

Expressing dissatisfaction with the policies of Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin, a committee including four former presidents of Congregation Emanu-El announced here today that more than fifty persons had discontinued membership in the congregation to form a "conservative synagogue." Congregation.

Plagued by a sudden rush of stowaways, the French Line has appealed to the New York police for assistance and strengthened its own pier police force in an effort to apprehend free-riders who slip aboard liners as visitors and remain hidden.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation, paper manufacturer, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $970,055 for the three months ended on July 31. This was after depreciation, depletion, interest and taxes and after deducting the minority stockholders' proportion of the net profit of Pacific Mills, Ltd.

While single-family residential construction, as measured by building permits, has declined slightly in recent months here and in nearly all other parts of the country, this loss has been more than offset by a rise in apartment and two-family projects.
Savings deposits in chartered banks in Canada at the end of July totaled $1,622,606,000, an increase of $50.000.000 in a year, according to the monthly report of the banks to the Finance Minister.

Carter Warner Wormeley, advertising and publicity director for Virginia, died early today at his home here. He was 64 years old and had been in poor health for several years. A former Richmond newspaper man, Mr. Wormeley also wrote verse and several years ago the General Assembly elected him "poet laureate of Virginia,"

The Board of Tax Appeals held today that the Amerex Holding Corporation, New York, should pay, $510,226 in income taxes for 1928. The corporation, formerly the Chase Corporation and the Chase Securities Corporation, had protested a deficiency assessment

Funeral services were held here today for Dr. John Martin Wheeler, eye specialist, who died on Monday. The Rev. Dr. C. G. Atkins of the Auburn Theological Seminary, Auburn, N. Y., officiated, and honorary pallbearers included Dr. John H. Dunnington, Dr. Thomas J. Johnson, Dr. Daniel Kirby, Dr.

Wheat futures in the domestic markets opened somewhat higher today in sympathy with Liverpool and the firmness in securities, but turned reactionary around noon, and general selling in sympathy with weakness in Winnipeg disclosed a lack of support.

The British Association for the Advancement - of Science wound up its meeting today with the appointment of a committee to form the nucleus of a newly created division to deal with social international relations of science.

Miss Doris E. Eldridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Eldridge of this city, will be married to Louis W. Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Carter of Los Angeles, on Sept. 10 in the Epworth Methodist Church here.
Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today to reduce the commission charge on the sale and purchase of cash wheat from 1 1/2 to 1 cent a bushel. The new rate goes into effect tomorrow.

Production of men's and youths' suits made wholly or partly of wool by 531 manufacturers during the four weeks ended June 25 totaled 529,693 garments, compared with 1,036,578 in the corresponding four weeks of 1937, according to the Department of Commerce.

It was a tremendous sensation whistling over the salt at 347 miles per hour. Whistling is the only word I know to describe it. Thunderbolt behaved beautifully. I never dreamed there was such acceleration in the car.

Oscar B. Bach, designer and craftsman whose sculpture, glass and metal work is incorporated in many public buildings of this country and Europe, was host yesterday at a private preview of the exhibit which the Bach Products Galleries will house permanently in Rockefeller Center.

Miss Mary Beard, who since 1924 has been associate director of the Rockefeller Foundation's International Health Division, will be the first director of the unified Red Cross Nursing Service, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, announced today.

Indications today were that producers of milk entering the New York City metropolitan market from seven States voted more than four to one in favor of a Federal-State milk marketing agreement regulating producer prices.

Justice John M. Lewis handed down in Municipal Court yesterday a decision establishing the right of a physician to recover a fee from an employer for services to a workman employed by the company, although the treatments may not have been authorized by the emplayer.
The Japanese strategy in the advance toward Hankow seems, in the opinion of foreign military observers in Shanghai, to have been changed to a vast enveloping move ment including:

Joseph Perlmutter, proprietor of the Perlmutter furniture store here since 1925, a former member of the Board of Education, honorary president and former president of Temple Beth-El, was found dead in bed at his home this morning. Death was attributed to a heart attack. His age was 65.

Emanuel List of the New York Metropolitan Opera Company, scored the most notable triumph of any male opera singer at the Colon Theatre this season when he appeared last night as Osmin in the first production here of Mozart's "Entfuehrung aus dem Serail."

An order which may have the effect, if upheld on appeal, of hamstringing the State Labor Relations Board and casting doubt on the validity of some acts of the National Labor Relations Board was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer in deciding an appeal taken by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company from a decision of the State board.

Many parties were given tonight at the dinner dance at Piping Rock for the Saratoga Golf Club, among them that of Mr. and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon, who entertained Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard W. Fox, Mrs. J. Ferguson Mohr, Mrs. Laurence Brengle, Buckley M. Byers and William Frazier Brinley.

Basil B. Elmer, New York Stock Exchange member of Eastman, DilIon Co., was appointed yesterday a governor of the Exchange until the next annual election to fill the vacancy created by the election of Edward E. Bartlett Jr. as chairman of the board.

A new issue of $20,000,000 of Lone Star Gas Corporation fifteen-year 31/2 per cent sinking-fund debentures due on Aug. 1, 1953, is to be offered to the public today by an underwriting group headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation of Pittsburgh at a price of 102 and accrued interest.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., head a nation-wide syndicate which will offer today $33,000,000 of Commonwealth Edison Company first mortgage 3/2 per cent bonds, Series I, due on June 1, 1968. The bonds will be priced at 1081/2 and accrued interest.

Mrs. Jean Hathaway, who starred in serial films in the early days of Hollywood, died last night of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 62. She was the mother of Henry Hathaway, film director. From a small-time vaudeville circuit, Mrs. Hathaway came to Hollywood in 1908 and was immediately starred in a series of one-reel adventure films.

Water that had been so smooth it could have been ruffled with a straw was churned into a tossing, tumbling threat today for the third race in the Atlantic Coast championship series for Star Class yachts.
A friend of Lieut. Comdr. Frank M. Hawks made ready tonight for flight to Connecticut with the ashes of the speed ace, who was killed in a plane crash near East Aurora late yesterday.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 15 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had increased to 122.83 per cent from 122.14 per cent on July 31.

A meeting of stockholders of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation has been called for Sept. 14 in Richmond, Va., to consider a proposal to increase authorized capitalization from $2,000,000 to $3,000,000. The company, which is without funded debt or preferred stock, has 1,648,285 common shares of $1 par value outstanding.

Mr. and Mrs. Leo T. Kissam gave a dinner last night on the St. Regis Roof. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Cullen, Miss Kathleen Cullen and Robert Smith. A luncheon was given there by Mrs. Frederick K. Barbour for Mrs. William Warren Barbour, Mrs. Sidney Lee and Miss Alison Barbour.

In a collision with another automobile on the 207th Street Bridge yesterday a taxicab was hurled through the iron guard rail and dropped thirty feet to a ramp. The cab driver was extricated from the wreckage and taken to Fordham Hospital suffering from a, concussion of the brain and possibly a fractured skull.

Use of Jewish man power to reinforce the British, whose few regiments are finding it ever more difficult to cope with the situation, is a proposal put forward to the Palestine Government by some Jewish leaders here.

Retail credit collections during July decreased 1.86 per cent, according to the twenty local stores index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 44.12, against 45.98 in July, 1937.

The 1938 Federal project construction program is "making a new record for speed," the Public Works Administration announced today. "As of Aug. 15, contracts were awarded on Federal projects with a value of $70,466,250, and force account work was started, while contracts were made ready for award

Joe Hiestand, Hillsboro, Ohio, farmer, cracked 200 targets today to run his unfinished string to 966 without a miss, the greatest performance ever turned in by a clay disk expert-but failed to win the national Class AA championship, the day's feature at the Grand American trapshoot.

Their voices exuberant and spirits lively after a Summer of recreation in the city, 5,000 boys -and girls from 157 vacation playgrounds in Brooklyn held a song and dance festival yesterday afternoon in the athletic field of Abraham Lincoln High School, at Ocean Parkway and Guider Avenue.

Miss Elizabeth Alice Sudler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar M. Sudler of East Orange, was married to Harry William Mieth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Mieth of Maplewood, this afternoon in St. Agnes Episcopal Church here by the Rev. Curtis Junker of New York.

Bobby Jacobson, a former titleholder, won the medal in the metropolitan junior golf championship today with a score of 75 over the Sunningdale Country Club course. Jacobson did not compete a year ago. The 20-year-old Dartmouth senior and other college golfers are eligible to play in this tournament under the new age-limit rule.

After the annual luncheon which precedes the open polo championship at the Meadow Brook Club, the Anglo-American team, the Jaguars, organized by Winston Guest, got into action for the first time on Belmont Field today.
The government decided today to support a large-scale development of lead mines throughout the country, with financial backing and other measures, in order to avoid further importations.

An issue of $2,255,000 of water revenue bonds of Grand Rapids, Mich., has been awarded to Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and Paine, Webber Co. on a bid of 100.048. Of the total $1,355,000 were purchased as 3s and $900,000 as 2 3/4s.
Alfred G. Clay, credit manager of the John Wanamaker store here until his retirement recently, died today in his Summer home at Bay Head, N. J. He would have been 80 years old in October.

Three members of the City Homicide Bureau, without warrants, took two guards from the Philadelphia County Prison at Holmsburg today, later arrested them and precipitated a mix-up which brought to a standstill the investigation of the steaming to death of four inmates of the institution last week-end.

Two members of the Dies House Committee investigating un-American activities, Representatives John J. Dempsey, Democrat, of New Mexico, and J? Parriell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, met here yesterday in the Federal Building at Foley Square to hold private hearings in preparation for public hearings after Labor Day.

Olaf Swenson, 55 years old, noted Arctic fur trader, was found shot to death in his office here today. An elephant rifle which Mr. Swenson bought recently for big game hunting lay partly under the body.
Bruce Campbell's big bat and Mel Harder's stingy hurling gave the Indians a 5-3 victory over the Red Sox today, but the Sox retained a bare percentage hold on second place in the American League.

Miss Nancy Holbrook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Holbrook of Barrington, Ill., was married today to Guy Stillman, youngest son of Mrs. Fowler McCormick of Barrington and James A. Stillman of New York.

The report on nation-wide employment in July, just published by the Department of Labor, is more interesting from the trend which it shows than by actual scope of change for the better. The month's rise in the index number of factory employment is only from 75.7 per cent of the 1923-25 average to 76.4, and last month's percentage is still the lowest of any July since 1934.

Secretary Roper said today that, on a seasonal basis, national income improved in July for the first month in a year. The total of wages, dividends, rents and other sources of national income was slightly lower in July than in June, but did not go down by the usual seasonal amount, he explained.

A searching party returned today from another fruitless hunt for the lost Russian transpolar plane, but members said that they were convinced that Eskimos actually saw Sigismund Levanevsky's craft disappear near Oliktuk a year ago.

Ten officials of the Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan, in Southwestern Asia, were sentenced to death today for participation in a counter-revolutionary plot to separate Azerbaijan from the Soviet Union. They were convicted of belonging to an organized group of conspirators within the Azerbaijan Commissariat of Agriculture.

The Osservatore Romano, Vatican City newspaper, disclosed today that the understanding between the Catholic Action organization and the Fascist party, which the Italian press asserted had been concluded last Thursday, had been reached "only very recently."

Mrs. Hazel Huffman, secretary of the Committee of Relief Status Professional Theatrical Employes of the Federal Theatre Project, denied yesterday a statement by Paul Edwards, administrative officer in charge of the five WPA Federal Art Projects in the city, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Saturday that she was the "organization's only member."

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ashton Wyckoff of Stepping Stones, Greens Farms, Conn., and Stuart, Fla., formerly of Pelham Manor, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Ashton Wyckoff, to Roderick Clanranald McNeil 2d of Bridgeport, Conn.

A total of twenty-eight policy arrests have been made and the prisoners taken into Harlem and Washington Heights courts in the first three days of this week, a checkup showed yesterday. Of those arrested, ten were discharged and eighteen were held for Special Sessions.

The county grand jury, criticizing political publications "organized apparently for the sole purpose of printing copy that the established newspapers in the community would not publish," indicted an, editor yesterday on a criminal libel and slander charge.

Condemning the American Labor party, the State Federation of Labor, meeting at Buffalo yesterday, set up its own "nonpartisan committee" to guide labor's choice of candidates according to A. F. of L. policy. [Page 1.]

Miss Doris Spence, daughter of Mrs. A. Pyott Spence of this place, will be married the evening of Sept. 20 to Norman Low Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Norman Kennedy of Short Hills. The ceremony will take place in the chapel of the First Baptist Church of Montclair, in the presence of relatives and intimate friends.

Thousands of men, women and children seated on newspapers on the ground or perched on fireescapes of adjacent buildings swelled the applause last night for Orlando Estanislaus and Helen Maguire at Chelsea Park, where these two divided first prize in the juvenile amateur contest held in connection with the weekly motion

Suffolk St, 56; Preston Lockwood, referee, to Metropolitan Savings Bank, foreclosure ($2). 11th St, 53 W; Bertha Gregory to Village Equities, Inc. 570 7th Ave; purchase money mtg, $38,500 ($40). 50th St, 251 E; Frank Kilian, executor of George Kilian, to Emily S. Kilian, administratrix of George Kilian.

The Maritime Commission, by a vote of five to two, held today that an agreement between the Dollar Steamship Lines and the Matson Navigation Company, under the terms of which the Dollar Lines paid to the Matson company 50 per cent of gross receipts from their Hawaiian-Pacific Coast traffic, was detrimental to commerce.

" The Landsmanschaften of New York," written in Yiddish and devoted to the social, economic, cultural and political history of Eastern European Jewish immigration, is rapidly nearing completion and will be issued early this Fall under the sponsorship of the Jewish Writers' Club.

Several leases of apartments in buildings on Fifth Avenue were among contracts for suites reported by brokers and renting agents yesterday. Arthur J. Kinsman, president of the Purepac Corporation, took a duplex terrace suite in 965 Fifth Avenue, the building under construction on the site of the former Schiff residence.

Dr. William G. Beckers, director of the amateur photographic exhibit to be held here on Saturday, today announced that the judges would be Ray Loughlin, president of the Glens Falls Camera Club; Robert Brown, camera editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and W. O'Hagan of Albany.

Returning to Washington today from a 9,000-mile aerial survey of Alaska, Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, declared that aviation was the real answer to the future development of the great Northwest territory.

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican aspirant to the world welterweight championship, had little trouble with Orville Drouillard of Windsor, Ont., at Madison Square Garden last night. The West Indian stopped his Northern rival in 2 minutes and 14 seconds of the fifth of a scheduled 10-round encounter.

In a brief address delivered here today to more than 500 persons at the sixtieth annual outing of the Joel Parker Association, oldest Democratic group in New Jersey, William H. J. Ely, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, criticized his Republican opponent, W. Warren Barbour, for injecting "Hagueism" into the campaign.

Police Commissioner and Mrs. Carlton S. Preston of Kingston announced the marriage today of their daughter, Rosalene Morse Preston, to Dr. Paul Perlman of this city. The ceremony was performed in Sharon, Conn.

Jack Haley of the Newark Bears notched his fifteenth verdict of the year tonight as he stopped the Red Wings with a four-hit, 5-to-1 victory in the nightcap as the Bruins took both ends of a double bill. Atley Donald stopped the Wings, 2-1, in the nine-inning first game, while Syracuse was beating Buffalo, putting the Bladesmen back in third place and the Chiefs in second.

Concerned with talk that agriculture is now in the same plight as it was in 1932, Secretary Wallace cited graphs and figures today at his press conference to show that the farmers were, on the average,

After nearly two hours of tumult and confusion in the jammed auditorium of a Bronx public school yesterday three bewildered judges announced the winners of a beauty' contest for boys and girls under 7 years of age.

The women's division of the national tennis doubles championships furnished the exciting moments at the Longwood Cricket Club today. In the men's tourney Donald Budge and Gene Mako and Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn scored crushing victories to gain the semi-finals.

A first mortgage loan of $30,000 for five years at 5% on the Physicians Hospital, ?? cor of 73d St and 34th Ave, Jackson Heights, L. I., has been obtained from the Jamaica Savings Bank by Hosinger Bode, Inc. ,broker, for the Hayes Seventy-third Street Corp, owner of the structure.

John and Mack Rust, co-inventors of a mechanical cotton picker, announced formation today of the Rust Foundation, through which, they said, they proposed to apply a large part of their personal profit on the invention to uplift agricultural workers of the South.

William B. Woodbury of Lake George has been appointed chairman of the Constitution Day Committee for the State of New York, William S. Murray, chairman of the Republican State Committee, announced yesterday.

In day and night conferences with leaders of the factions in the United Automobile Workers Union, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, today fought to establish harmony in the ranks of the union. The conferences will continue tomorrow.

John Bardak of Coney Island was adjudged yesterday the champion municipal lifeguard at the City Park Department's first annual lifeguard tournament. The contest was held at Jacob Riis Park before a crowd of 30,000.

The National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy closed a threeday conference last night with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore, at which Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals declared the stability and strength of the American Government had been due chiefly to an independent judiciary.

The Ridgewood Borough Commission took action today designed to prevent strike picketing in the community by introducing an A ordinance imposing a fee of $50 a week for any person desiring to carry a sign on the borough's streets.

A glass display which will depict the history of the glass industry in America and present also specimens of work done in past centuries will be a feature of the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was announced yesterday at the dedication of the Glass Center at the fair grounds in Queens.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, made public today detailed features of the State's financial operations during the fiscal year which ended June 30.

After a night spent in an oarless rowboat in the lower bay, Ambrose Channel and Swash Channel, weaving in and out of the path of tankers, steamboats and other vessels, Premean Carmen, 15-yearold Staten Island schoolboy, was picked up yesterday afternoon by the crew of the excursion steamer Keansburg, into whose path he had drifted in Ambrose Channel.
