Hungary wants to keep on good terms with the Third Reich, on the good-will of which her very life depends, while at the same time reinsuring herself against being involved in the German-Czechoslovak conflict.

The better tendency in Wall Street was reflected in the stock market here today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edged issues were in good demand, but foreign bonds in general were inactive, European issues being fractionally lower.

Criticism by spokesmen for several garment manufacturing groups that the shrinkage rules promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission do not take production problems into account and announcement that the women's organizations would strongly press for labels giving shrinkage data,

With eighty-four contenders in the junior event of the small-bore rifle competition today, John Fondahl, 13-year-old Washington (D. C.) expert, scored 194 out of a possible 200 to win. Richard Woolshlager, 14, Castorland, N. Y., took second place with 193 and Richard Rolfe, 13, Syracuse, was third with 191.

Top hogs and lambs reached $9 today, hogs selling mainly 10 to 15 cents higher and lambs strong. Most other meat animals except prime medium weights and weighty steers sold 25 cents lower 'on a slow, uneven market, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Outstanding Nebraska fed steers scaling 1,267 pounds topped at $13, equal to the season's peak.

Aside from the Kendrick case, which apparently started with the arrest of the messenger of the British passport sho: control office in Vienna four days before Captain Thomas Kendrick himself was arrested, there is another case engaging police attention in which a British subject's was name has been introduced.
Senator Sheppard suggested today a constitutional amendment empowering Congress to prescribe the conditions under which primary elections for Federal offices shall be held.
Senora Francisca de Benavides, wife of the President of Peru, sailed for the United States today with her daughter, Maria, her sons, Oscar and Jose, and her niece, Malvina Malachoswky Benavides.

The Latin-American Trade Union Congress, opening in Mexico City on Sept. 5, was denounced today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, as a device of "extreme leftists" for spreading communism through the Western Hemisphere.

Although another strong stock market influenced sentiment on the Cotton Exchange here and advanced prices for a time yesterday, a break in wheat and a continuation of favoring weather over the major portion of, the Cotton Belt had a depressing effect in the last hour, causing net losses of 6 to 8 points.

ARON--Henry, beloved husband of Hattie, dear father of Louis M. Reposing at Park West Memorial Chapel. 115 West 79th St. Services Friday, 1 P. M. ARON--Henry. Rehoboth Widows and Orphans Society, No. 38, B'nai B'rith, are grieved to announce the untimely departure of its ex-President and ex-Secretary.

There were 1917 4,126 marriages in Austria in July, to g against 1,092 in July of last year. In April, May and June there were 5,483, against 3,384 in those months of last year. It is hoped in official circles that next year's birthrate will be at least double that of 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson entertained with a dinner tonight at Wyndcote, where Dante V. Leland and J. Gordon Douglas are Visiting them. Earlier in the day Mr. and .Mrs. Robertson gave a luncheon at the Southampton Beach Club.

The portable stages of the WPA Caravan Theatre will stop at the following public locations tonight: Manhattan, "Melodies on Parade," a vaudeville unit, at Corlears Park; Brooklyn, "Mr. Dooley Jr.," at Kelly Field; Queens, "Are You Listening?" a variety revue,

Irvin A. Medlar, editor and publisher of The Midwest Hotel Reporter and secretary-treasurer of the Northwestern Hotel Association for forty-three years, died here today at the age of 65. Mr. Medlar was executive secretary of several State hotel associations in the Midwest.

New income tax regulations, designed to carry out Section 820 of the Revenue Act of 1938, which in effect provides in certain cases for the lifting of the statute of limitations where a question of time arises over the payment of a tax,

The efficiency of the marine division of the police will be greatly increased soon by the use of two-way radio communication between Manhattan headquarters and one of the department's ten launches, it was announced yesterday afternoon

12:05-12:25 P. M.--From Switzerland: Music Festival. Arturo Toscanini, Conductor--WJZ (Again 12:30 to 1:10, WEAF). 4:00-4:30 P. M.--"Employment for Men Over Forty," A. W. Robertson, Chairman Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, at V. F. W. Convention, Columbus, Ohio-WABC. 8:00-9:00 P. M.--Vallee Varieties: Sketch, with Frank Craven, Actor; Eric Blore, Comedian; Ethel Merman, Songs, and Others-WEAF. 8:00-8:30 P. M.-Sinfonietta, Cesare Sodero, Conductor-WOR. 8:00-8.15 P. M.-"Outlook for Labor," Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner--WNYC.

Army and navy officers and military attaches of foreign governments will watch the erection tomorrow of a fifty-ton concrete "pillbox" fort by a new method which, its inventor says, will have it ready for use in five hours.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, speaking last night over Radio Station WQXR, assailed President Roosevelt's policies as having been we "both capricious and inconsistent ter on any other terms except ad- fea vancing his own power."

Sam A. Lewisohn, the only son of the late Adolph Lewisohn, philanthropist and donor of the Lewisohn Stadium at City College, will continue his father's interests in the annual series of Summer symphonic concerts at the stadium presented
A Transcontinental Western Air skyliner skidded to a forced landing a moment after taking off here early today, but its eight passengers and crew of three escaped with only cuts and bruises.

Provisional President Manuel Maria Borrera issued a decree yesterday placing a surcharge of 50 per cent on customs duties on imports from countries with which Ecuador has an unfavorable trade balance.

Representatives of up-State New York cities laid plans today to attract World's Fair visitors next year to up-State vacation lands. Meeting last night, the group proposed a ten-point program based on additional appropriations by the Legislature to advertise at the fair the "historical and scenic advantages" of up-State areas.

Lightning struck figuratively and literally in the women's Western golf today as Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., the defending champion, was eliminated in the second round played in drenching rain, thunder and blinding flashes.

The week past marked the completion of the military survey of the route between Lake Habbema and the Idenburg camp and also the establishing of friendly relations with the natives along the route. Two units made the survey, meeting in the newly discovered Grand Valley.
The Federal Reserve Board estimated today that industry had gained back in the last seven weeks nearly all of its losses of the previous seven months.

Eugene Goossens, composer, and conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, sailed on the United States liner Washington yesterday to conduct a series of five operas at Covent Garden, in London. He was accompanied by his wife.

Expectations of a continuing upward trend in steel operations are based on a number of factors, Iron Age says this week. These are listed as follows: "New orders before mid-September from automobile companies and parts makers for production runs on new models;

The accurate tossing of Andy Stopper, Boyd Brumbaugh and Vic Fusia featured passing drills as the Eastern College AU-Stars continued their double workouts today at Peddle School in preparation for their Tribune Fresh Air Fund contest against the New York Giants the night of Sept. 7 at the Polo Grounds.

A fire in the piling under the front end of the 760-foot Department of Sanitation pier at Fiftyninth Street and the North River caused considerable damage yesterday afternoon as firemen had to chop about fifty feet of the flooring away to play a hose on the flames.

Dr. Henry Howard Whitehouse of 205 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York, distinguished dermatologist, who formerly was president of the medical board of the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital, died at his Summer home here this afternoon in his seventy-fifth year.

The newly appointed Bishop of Danzig, Carl Maria Splett, was solemnly entroned in Oliva Cathedral today, succeeding Papal Count Alexander O'Rourke. Bishop O'Rourke, a Russian-born Irishman, incurred the displeasure of the Nazis by his alleged pro-Polish attitude.

A sharp increase in British imports from the United States and sharp decrease in exports to this country in the first six months of this year, imports exceeding exports by [pound]50,889,834, were reported today by the Department of Commerce. The excess for the same period last year was [pound]24,138,243.
Electric power production increased last week, but the gain was less than seasonal and the adjusted index receded to 95.2 from 96.0. The figure was 108.5 for the week ended Aug. 21, 1937.
The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange has approved the additional listing of $1,000,000 first mortgage 31/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due in 1966, of the Kansas Electric Power Company.

The residence at 34 East Seventyfifth Street of the late Dr. and Mrs. Arpad G. Gerster was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of their granddaughter, Miss Dorothy Fox Gerster, to Thomas Kirby Schmuck Jr.

Active support of newspapers and the trade press for the National Retail Demonstration to be held during the week- of Sept. 19 was promised at a special conference held yesterday in the Empire State Club. A resolution was adopted

Archibald S. Leckie, one of the organizers of what is now the City News Bureau of Chicago, died Monday in San Gabriel, Calif., at the age of 75. He rose from a reporter's job with The Chicago Daily News in 1885 to the co-managership with Harry L. Sayler in 1891 of the City Press Association of Chicago.
The three-year sentence imposed on Major Ferenc. Szalasi, Hungarian Nazi leader, for subversive political activities was confirmed today by the Supreme Court,

Almost all available information points to a period of rising business activity in the last quarter of this year, according to the monthly survey of business conditions in Banking, the official publication of the American Bankers Association.

A starlight Summer festival and dance recital was given on the lawn at the C. B. Hayes estate here tonight by Miss Anita Zahn and a concert group in her school of the arts. Proceeds went to the school's scholarship fund.

The fear that came to trouble Lewis W. Douglas more than the dark economic future he envisaged when he quit the President's government was that lavish, continuous and centralized spending and political administration of relief would enable persons in power to perpetuate themselves and their successors in office.
The Reds combined five hits and four Philadelphia errors for a 3-to-1 victory today to sweep the two-game series and place them one-half game behind the second-place Giants.

The Maritime Commission's plan to establish a training school at Hoffman Island for officers and seamen of the merchant marine found a ready response among seamen yesterday when the first group of applicants for appointment to the school was received at Federal offices here.
The six-family dwelling at 48-26 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, was purchased by Mrs. Estelle Jameson, a client of Hosinger Bode, Inc., agent, through Siegfried P. Brusack, broker.

Paul J. paid Banker, assistant managing editor of The Sun, was drowned today when he fell from a small sailboat near the mouth of the Magothy River. His son, Paul, 17, who was sailing with him, dived repeatedly as the boat drifted away and then swam a half mile to land for aid.

Motion picture advertising in both newspapers and magazines will take a substantial spurt during the Fall season, according to executives of agencies handling such accounts yesterday. The industry's campaign will go far toward improving attendance and, inasmuch as many "specials" have been held back for Fall showing, heavy promotion will be put behind them, it was said.

Gertrude Lawrence, appearing here in "Susan and God," has disclosed plans here to restore the fire-razed Angels Camp Theatre in the Mother Lode country in which Edwin Booth player Hamlet in the days of Forty-nine.

The Siboney of the New York and Cuba Mail Line is sailing today for Havana and Veracruz, Mexico. Those on board are Miss Marie Carlin, James Howie, Mrs. H. M. Bailey, Miss Henel Feldman, Miss S. R. Feldman, Dr. Jack Levine and Mrs. R. A. Phelps.

The last of a row of old private dwellings on the west side of Lexington Avenue, between Sixtysecond and Sixty-third Street, to withstandd modernizing will be improved as the result of the sale by Mrs. Michael Doherty of the onefamily house at 810 Lexington Avenue.

A rare, block-frong Chippendale desk, described as a "museum piece," topped sales at the Odell Mansion auction today with a price of $1,650. At the end of the third day of the auction, value of the sales had reached $20,000.
A religious delegation departed for the United States today to bring back a relic of the late Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini for her formal beatification on Nov. 13.

MEN'S DOUBLES Quarter-Final Round Donald Budge and Gene Mako defeated Russell Bobbitt and Frank Guernsey Jr., 6--3, 6--2, 6--3; Wilmer Allison and John Van Ryn defeated Robert L. Riggs and Bryan Grant Jr., 6--1, 8--6, 6--2.

116th, 113-121 E, 89.3x100.11; 116th St Building Corp to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank pr mtg; demand, int per bond; $40,849. Same property; same to same: building loan, pr mtg., $40,849; demand, 4%; $124,000. 118th St, 105 W. 20x100.11; Leo Levy to Guardian Life Insurance Co of America, pr m mtg, due, etc, as bond; $8,500.
Alfred Short, one-time boilermaker and long a Labor member of Parliament, died today at the age of 55. He was Parliamentary Under Secretary for Home Affairs from 1929 to 1931.

Soviet border patrols who recently crossed the Japanese border of Sakhalin, near Anbetsu on the west coast of the island, fled to Soviet territory when detected by Japanese policemen, according to the Domei news agency. The border is now quiet.
The British Government does not overestimate the effect of the Little Entente agreement with Hungary although the newspapers here threw their editorial hats into the air over it this morning.

Mauling six pitchers for twenty-five hits, the Athletics defeated the Tigers twice today, 10 to 5 and 11 to 2, to end a nine-game losing streak. The Mackmen clubbed Elden Auker and Jake Wade from the hill with a six-run rally in the fourth inning of the first game. Nelson Potter, allowing eight hits, 'gained his second victory of the season.

The four seeded players in the girls' Eastern grass court tennis championships at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, Miss Jane Wagner, Cincinnati; Miss Josephine Sanfilippo, Brooklyn; Miss Nellie Sheer, Miami, Fla., and Miss Elaine Fischell, Santa Monica, Calif., advanced to the semi-fina round yesterday.

Tanks will be filled with wheat and with gasoline, sealed and sunk in the Swiss lakes as protected war stores, if the Swiss Parliament adopts one proposal made to its National Defense Committee today.

" Unwise and mistaken State taxation on business" was responsible for a situation in which Pennsylvania had 25 per cent more idle workers than the average for the nation, WalterD. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, declared tonight in a radio address.

Jamaica's cricket team won the second Colony match today, beating the Oxford-Cambridge eleven by an innings and 74 runs. Jamaica had tallied 343 in reply to the universities' first innings total of 128.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced yesterday that it had acquired distribution rights in the Western Hemisphere to George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion." Mr. Shaw wrote the screen adaptation for his play, which was produced in England independently by Gabriel Pascal and directed by Anthony Asquith.

Cleveland at New York (2)-Whitehill (8-4) and Allen (13-6) vs. Ruffing (17-4) and Ferrell (14-9). Chicago at Boston (2)--Whitehead (7-7) and Knott (4-8) vs. Wilson (12-9) and Heving (3-1). St. Louis at Philadelphia (2)-Hildebrand (8-7) and Newsom (1510) vs. Ross (6-11) and Williams (0-7).

The 1938 edition of the New York State Labor Law was published yesterday by the State Department of Labor. The text includes the unemployment insurance law with the latest amendments, the minimum wage and State labor relations law, child labor law,

The Security Traders Association of New York is formulating plans for the inauguration of a program of publicity for its employment council, it announced yesterday. The results obtained by the council since its formation in 1937 have been sufficient, in the opinion of its heads, to warrant carrying on the work with increased aggressiveness.

The world of the air has suffered a substantial loss in the tragic death of Frank M. Hawks. The speed flier who knit together the cities of America and of Europe in closer bonds of time than they had ever known was much more than a seeker after records.

Hundreds of persons prominent in public and political life attended yesterday morning funeral services of Mrs. Catherine Sesnon McCooey, widow of John H. McCooey, for twenty-five years the Democratic leader of Brooklyn, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, Carroll Street and Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.

Lovell Henry Carr, former executive of the Alpha Portland Cement Company, with which he was associated for twenty-eight years, died last night in the Elizabeth General Hospital at the age of 72. He retired from business in 1932.

A number of properties of various types in Brooklyn were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn. Among them were the apartment building at 116 Willoughby Street, which was purchased by George B. Monroe through Bernard

In the second inning of today's finale between the Dodgers and Cardinals Ernie Koy barely beat out a bunt toward first base and thereby robbed Curt Davis of a no-hit game. The veteran right-hander went on from there to face only three men per inning while the Gas Housers were winning the contest, 5-0, on nine hits off Luke Hamlin, including Muscles Medwick's sixteenth homer of the year.

Three of Mack Sennett's successes of several seasons ago are to reach the screen again through the medium of remakes, it was disclosed today by the veteran producer. Commenting on rumors that attached his name to two major lots, he said that modern scenarios were being prepared for "Down on the Farm," "A Small Town Idol" and "Molly 0," three of his outstanding moneymakers.

The New York Stock Exchange has been advised by the Conde-Nast Publications, Inc., that the option granted to M. F. Agha in 1934 to purchase 2,000 common shares at $5 a share has been extended for one year to Dec. 15, 1939.

The special court here to try political cases, whose judges will be appointed by ChancellorAdolf Hitler, is not likely to begin its operations until the end of September and certainly not before the Nuremberg Congress is finished.

George Weinberg's continued direct testimony at the trial of James J. Hines yesterday follows: Arguments by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel, in Justice Ferdinand Pecora's chambers delayed the reopening of the trial of James J. Hines yesterday until 11:36 A. M., when George Weinberg continued his testimony under direct examination.

It is gratifying to learn that the President has been won over to the view that some changes are needed in the Wagner act. It would be most unfortunate, however, if such changes were limited to the "clarification of ambiguities" in that law, and if the "ambiguities" were only those that a particular labor organization now objects to.

The Tennessee Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, will be turned over to public operation next Wednesday and from then on will receive electric power from the Tennessee Valley Authority, provided the city of Knoxville, which the private utility now serves, has completed plans for the financing of $6,000,000 of revenue bonds with which to reimburse the TVA for funds advanced to foster municipal ownership.

Today the Constitutional Convention reassembles to adopt the revised Constitution and to decide upon the manner in which it is to be submitted to the people. The new document contains some excellent, some doubtful and some intolerable proposals.
The German Navy has been holding large-scale manoeuvres in the Baltic Sea in the last few days, greatly disturbing the inhabitants of southern Danish islands.

Leopold C. Gosselin, president of the New York Nickel Plating and Manufacturing Company, with which he had been associated since 1898, died yesterday in his home, 41-15 Seventy-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, of heart disease. He was 70 years old.

Although the new price levels on tropical worsteds and gabardines. for the 1939 season are 35 to 40 cents a yard below the revised lists of a year ago, no such proportionate reductions will be made in wholesale clothing ranges, manufacturers said here yesterday.
Long shots set a blistering pace which ran one favorite after anotheramong them the defending champion-out of the national public links golf championship race today.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for groups of small dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens. Some of the larger groups of houses will be erected in Elmhurst, Maspeth and Richmond Hill. Architects also filed for numerous alterations in buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Preparations have been completed for the annual reception to be given by the Art Association on Friday afternoon for the officers of the Naval War College, the Naval Training Station, the Torpedo Station and of Fort Adams. The guests will be received by the officers and council of the association, headed by President Harrison S. Morris.
Active buying in the railroad group again provided the impetus for a broad advance yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange, while the volume
Whatever sacrifice Canada may be called upon to make in the interests of an Anglo-American trade agreement, nothing has been surrendered yet, Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King declared today.

As the leaders in the Constitutional Convention reassembled here tonight in preparation for the closing days of the convention tomorrow and Friday, they were met with a message from Governor Lehman, asking for submission to the people separately of all controversial questions involved in the proposed new State Constitution.
Rallying in the eighth inning to break a 6-to-6 tie, the Senators took fourth place in the American League today with an 8-to-6 victory lover the St. Louis Browns.
The Costa Rican Legaiton said today that Minster Ricardo Castro Beeche had left for New York.

Senator Rush D. Holt, youthful Democratic critic of the Roosevelt Administration, charged tonight his enemies were trying to "shut me up" as a Federal indictment was returned accusing his brother of forging endorsements of two WPA checks.

The annual encampment of Veterans of Foreign Wars today urged prompt disposition of the case of Harry Bridges, Pacific Coast C. I. 0. leador, and advocated his deportation if charges that he has conspired to cripple the merchant marine were sustained.

Pleas for labor unity throughout the world as a force against dictatorship and fascism were made here yesterday by French, Spanish, Dutch and American trade union leaders at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor to welcome foreign guests en route to the Latin-American Labor Congress in Mexico City next month.

Francis H. Biddle, counsel for the TVA Congressional Investigating Committee, delved today into efforts of citizens to block the erection of public-owned power facilities while minority members of the committee objected to methods of his investigators in examining private bank accounts.
The outcome of the Senate race in this State's Democratic primary between Senator Millard S. Tydings, prominent on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, and Representative David J. Lewis,

Something new in labor disputes Is going on in this hill-crowned city at the Golden Gate, which for years has had the distinction of being one of the strongest union towns and the scene of some of the most violent industrial battles in the country.

Whitford Drake of 14 East Ninetieth Street, president of Electrio Research Products, Inc., and a former commander in the United States Navy, died yesterday at his Summer home in Chatham, Mass., after a long illness, according to an announcement made here by his son, Rockwell Drake.
Captain George E. T. Eyston drove his ponderous automobile nearly six miles a minute today, but a blazing desert sun threw the delicate timing device out of gear, depriving him of an official record.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions 7 EAST 44TH STREET CORP., lessee and operator of 16-story office building, with offices at 1,400 Broadway. Involuntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law filed by three bondholders holding $4,500 of bonds of an issue of $750,000. The petitioners are Fred Tonsor, Mary Scanlon and Mary McKeon.

Alfred Halliday, retired fur buyer and Spanish-American War veteran, died on Tuesday at the Veterans Administration Facility, 130 West Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, after a three-month illness. Mr. Halliday, who lived at 411 Beach 139th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, was 71 years old.

Following an extended series of conferences with liquor retailers here during the last fortnight, Schenley Distributors, Inc., yesterday announced its decision to return to a complete fair-trade price basis, thus terminating controversy which began on Aug. 2

The Eastern States Petroleum Company announced yesterday that had received the first cargo of crude oil purchased under contract from the Mexican Government at its plant at Houston, Texas. The equipment, 40,000 barrels, was from The Poza Rica field.

The flattering attention bestowed this week by her former ally and her former enemies is a novel experience for Hungary, since the death of Austria the most battered survivor of the World War. Admiral Horthy, Regent of this diminished kingdom without a king, must have been surprised by the royal honors accorded him in Berlin.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 22: CAPTAIN Leahy, L. R., to duty in connection with New York World's Fair, instead of to duty Third Naval District. LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Davenport, R. E., granted sick leave for three months.

BEATING ABOUT THE BUSH, by Brian O'Brien. (Lee Furman, $2.50.) A romantic novel. THE DAWSON PEDIGREE AND LORD PETER VIEWS THE BODY, by Dorothy L. Sayers. (Harcourt, Brace, $2.) A new, combined edition.

Friedrich Fischerauer, former Austrian Consul General in this city, sailed yesterday for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. He said he was returning to Vienna after serving here since the World War. He expects to retire because the Austrian consulate has been closed.

The testimony of George Weinberg that he paid $3,000 to James J. Hines in the presence of former District Attorney William C. Dodge to be used as campaign funds in Mr. Dodge's 1933 campaign was flatly denied last night by Mr. Dodge.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 24 unless specified: At Annapolis: Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary, J. F. Talbott, Texas, Wyoming. Blue, Norfolk to Canal Zone, Aug. 22. Bridge, at San Francisco. Marblehead. at Chinwangtao.

Backed today by the executive committee of his own Radical Socialist party, Premier Edouard Daladier is going ahead with his proposals to modify the application' of the forty-hour week law so as to permit overtime at 10 per cent above the normal wage rates.

THIS morning books by Clemence Dane, Anne Parrish and Sigrid Undset. All three are novels.* Miss Dane's "The Moon Is Feminine" is the oddest of the lot and the most tantalizing. It interested me enough that I read parts of it twice, and still I can't say for certain what the story means-whether it was intended as sheer fantasy or as a mischievous and carnal allegory.

Swiss authorities here today explained to Lord Duncannon the severe measures taken last week to prevent Jewish refugees from Germany entering Switzerland without visas. Lord Duncannon, who is assistant to Sir Neill Malcolm, League Commissioner for Refugees from Germany, arrived by plane from London to inquire into conditions.
The death total in Tokyo's worst aviation disaster grew to twentyeight today with 130 persons still in the hospital, twenty of them in a critical condition.

The city or Detroit announced yesterday that it would receive offerings of its bonds for redemption up to Aug. 31 in the amount of $148,000 for the Water Board Sinking Fund and $159,000 for the Street Railway Sinking Fund.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, and Roger N. Baldwin, its director, sent a letter to President Roosevelt yesterday urging him not to appoint a United States District Court judge in New Jersey "who now is taking orders or at any time has taken orders from" Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City.

Several thousand Queens homegoers were late for dinner last night when fire broke out just before the di rush hour in a tool shed of the 01 Willets Point Station of the I. R. T.B. M. T. Flushing Line,

Eight Thirty, rated one of the main rivals of El Chico for the juvenile championship and a 1-to-2 favorite in the $6,600 Albany Handicap today, was disqualified after finishing first by a length and a half. The chestnut son of Pilate,
Sales of copper were made in the export market yesterday at 10.10 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, compared with 10.025 on Tuesday. The domestic price was unchanged at 10.125 cents.

George Weinberg, the Dutch Schultz mobster who likes to play badminton, was still a cool and crisply tailored person when he stepped down from the witness stand late yesterday afternoon after unfolding for two days a story of political corruption the like of which has not been heard in New York City since the days of "Boss" Tweed.
With the possible exception of Bill Dickey, the Yankees, it seems, are still content to chug along toward that inevitable third straight pennant on half-steam.
Emil Kropf, German stunt and exhibition flier, visited Newark airport today. His plane, which he describes as the "slowest airplane in the world," was brought here on a truck from Port Newark.

Reductions of 15 to 20 cents a pair from Spring levels were named in Thom McAn shoe stores on the Fall line yesterday. The new prices are $3.15 for men's shoes and $3.30 for women's shoes, compared with $3.30 and $3.50 in the Spring.

New records in the number of motor vehicles registered in New York State and the United States were made in 1937, the Automobile Club of New York announced yesterday. This State had 2,561,703 vehicles, or 8.6 per cent of the national total of 29,705,220, according to figures released by the club.

Charles E. Hauselt, a retired New York real estate operator, died here today of heart disease at the home of a daughter, Miss Emma Hauselt, in his seventy-fifth year. Mr. Hauselt, a former treasurer of the Republican State Campaign Committee,

The shoe was on the other foot today as the Giants bade a fond farewell to Wrigley Field for the year. The explosive siege guns of yesterday were merely harmless firecrackers and the Terrymen skidded ignobly backward in the National League flag race.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William J. Morrissey of Newark of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen M. Morrissey, to Edward J. Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Ryan of Elizabeth. Miss Morrissey is a graduate of Benedictine Academy,

England tied the count in the 1938 cricket test series with Australia, winning the concluding match today by an innings and 579 runs, the biggest margin in the sixty-two-year history of international matches. Discourage by the absence of Bradman, their captain, and J. H. Fingleton because of injuries, the Antipodeans were dismissed

Gold in the amount of $6,409,000, consisting of $3,710,000 from England and $2,699,000 from Canada, was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, according to reports made to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by commercial banks arranging the transactions.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Clinton Knight of Clinton Corners, Dutchess County, N. Y., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Knight, to Elliott Beach Macrae of this city.

The second program of racing at the Monmouth County Fair today saw a new State pacing record for 3-year-olds over a half-mile track when Pioneer Hanover owned and driven by Joseph Hylan of Norristown, Pa., covered a mile in 2:06 3/4 wresting the heat from Lady Win, who set the mark at 2:07 1/4 last Spring at Flemington.

President Will Harridge announced today the following revised list of American League double-headers and schedule changes: At Philadelphia-Aug. 25, St. Louis, 2; Aug. 26, St. Louis, 2; Aug. 27, St. Louis, 2; Aug. 28, Chicago, 2 (game of Aug. 29 moved up); Sept. 4, Boston, 2.

Of Julien St. Charles Chaqueneau's production plans for "Waltz in Goose Step," the latest news is as follows: James Dale (last seen here in "The Green Bay Tree") will have one of the six major roles in a cast of sixteen which will enter rehearsal the first week in October. Arthur Hopkins will direct.

A number of dwellings in the Bronx were included in deals reported yesterday by brokers. Among them was the seven-family house at 4,435 Carpenter Avenue, which was purchased for cash above a mortgage of $12,000 by Cornelia Ziliani. A client of P. C. D'Onofrio, broker, was the seller.
The War Department released the following orders, today, dated Aug. 23: MAJOR GENERAL Adams, E. S., The Adjutant General, three days' leave, Aug. 25. COLONEL Spurgin, H. F., C. A. C., to retirement.

About 7,000 jitterbugs and alligators, 1938 version, invaded the Randalls Island Stadium last night by automobile, bus and foot for a "jam" session provided by Broadway's leading exponents of swing and salon music.

Things are beginning to look a bit brighter at Liverpool, Nova for Scotia, which will be the scene of the rod and reel battle among British, Cuban and American teams this week-end. Although there has been a noticeable lack of big tuna at Liverpool, word arrives of a catch last Monday that indicates the big fellows are arriving.
A large representation of the Summer colony attended the special showing of "Moonlight Sonata," the film starring Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist, at the Building of Arts this evening.

Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, the blue water sailor, who now rules a country without a coastline and without a navy, yet is happiest when again treading a quarter deck, forsook the German seaboard today and came to Berlin for his official welcome.

THE manager of the White Sox is also the second baseman of the White Sox these dire days. Jimmy Dykes is rising 42, an age at which most major league infielders have retired to green pastures. But, seated in a heavily upholstered chair in his room yesterday morning, J. J. Dykes was faced with the problem of getting up and going out to play through another doubleheader against the Yankees at the Stadium.

Richard Spamer, former music and drama critic, died here early today in Missouri Baptist Hospital of a gallbladder inflammation. He had been in the hospital for seven weeks. His age was 82. Mr. Spamer was born in Cincinnati and was employed in the public library there before coming to St. Louis in 1877.

The Weather Bureau tonight warned all interests in the Northwestern Caribbean Sea to exercise "extreme caution" until a hurricane has passed. "This is a severe storm," said a 9:30 P. M. advisory warning, which placed the center of the tropical

Senator Prentiss M. Brown of Michigan, chairman of a special Senate committee studying tax-exempt securities, said today that he favored enactment of a simple statute permitting reciprocal taxation of Federal and State obligations and salaries.

Trading was active to slow In local markets yesterday with the exception of a few cuts. which were higher, the wholesale markets were little changed from Tuesday. More favorable weather stimulated the demand for kosher meats and most kosher markets opened stronger. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The dollar value of sales on all registered exchanges in July showed an increase of 84.9 per cent over the value of sales in June and a jump of 25.6 per cent over July, 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
The of the year. Pirates belted the Bees, 6 to 2, on seven hits today to take the series, two out of three, and extend their National League lead to six games over New York.

German names such as Fritz, Hans and Gretchen have been abandoned by Jewish children who immigrated into Palestine, because they are detrimental in the new environment, and have been voluntarily replaced by them with Hebrew equivalents, according to a report of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, answering President Roosevelt's assertion Tuesday that Republican participation in, Democratic primaries violated simple political morality, asked today if Mr. Roosevelt, "not satisfied with merely telling the people of sovereign States how they must vote," contemplates a Federal "force act" to compel States to revise their election laws.
Police said tonight they title had recommended to government officials the expulsion of a man calling himself Harold Oldofredi on the ground that he is "an undesirable person."

Captain Hiram A. Taft of the American freighter Wisconsin was arrested yesterday by Spanish police but liberated at 2 A. M. today when authorities decided not to hold him responsible for the presence of four alleged spies on his ship.

The close of play scores in county cricket matches started today: Glamorgan 279 (Dyson 96, Jim Parks five for 52); Sussex 32 for none. at Eastbourne. Worcestershire 73 (Woodhead seven for 24); Nottinghamshire 239 for six (Jones 60 not out, Beane 58), at Nottingham.

Responding to a special message from Governor Blanton Winship, the Puerto Rican Legislature today approved' a $1,200 annual pension for the widow of Colonel Luis A. Irizarry, who was killed July 25 at Ponce during a parade celebrating the fortieth anniversary of American occupation.

While the intense pressure the Nationalists [Insurgents] are concentrating in the Ebro sector continues to drive the Republicans [Loyalists] closer to their last bridgehead over the river, according to military headquarters here, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Estremadura offensive is said to have added in the last three days 500 square miles and ten more towns and villages to territory under Insurgent control in Southwestern Spain.

There is every hope that Max Liebermann's portrait of Professor Albert Einstein, which is now on exhibition at the new Burlington Galleries, will be purchased here and so prevented from going to Germany where it would stand a good chance of being destroyed.

BASEBALL New York Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, two games, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx, 1:30 P. M. Newark Bears vs. Jersey City Giants, at Ruppert Stadium, 262 Wilson Avenue, Newark, N. J ..................3 P. M. BOXING Fort Hamilton, Fort Hamilton Parkway and Ninety-ninth Street, Brooklyn, 8:30 P.M.

The defending champion, Johnny Goodman of Omaha, and the British amateur champion, Charley Yates of Atlanta, head a list of 882 entries for the 1938 national amateur golf championship, to be played Sept. 12-17 at the Oakmont Country Club, Pittsburgh.

George L. Kelley, member of the local Board of Tax Assessors for twenty-one years, died yesterday at his Summer home in Belmar, N. J., after two weeks' illness. His age was 63. Born in Orange, Mr. Kelley was formerly an architect in New York. Surviving are a brother, David S. Kelley Jr.,

The vagaries of life in its myriad ways, as it seemed to him after ninety years of experimentation, were expounded yesterday by August Heckscher, financier and philanthropist. with positive convictions on subjects ranging from communism to the relative merits of beer and champagne.
Miss Maxine Rode and Norman Bishop Bullard, whose engagement was announced early in June, will be married here on Sept. 9 in the Church of the Ascension.

Some executives in the oil industry are becoming disturbed over the increased shipments of Mexican oil that are being made to this country. With the crude-oil price structure none too firm and with the regulatory bodies of various States doing all that they can to hold the nation's output of oil within consumptive demands, heavy shipments of oil from Mexico might impair the present price structure.

Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, commenting on a letter from the Community Councils charging him with lack of action on its complaint of polluted waters near the Jameco pumping station in Queens, said he had personally visited

Caught in an icy gale 4,000 feet above sea level while crossing the Presidential Range of the White Mountains, Joseph Caggiano, 18, of Long Island City, N. Y., died of exhaustion today while two companions struggled through the storm for aid.

Leo May, Joseph M. Byrne Jr. and Harold Jackson have been elected directors of the G. Krueger Brewing Company, succeeding W. Paul Stillman, Hugo Boepple Jr. and F. I. Wilson, respectively, all of whom have resigned.

A. M. 9:00--Donald J. Hardenbrook, Garden City G. C.; John F. Riddell Jr., Garden City G. C., and Henry Picoli, Garden City G. C. 9:06--Bert Kohlmann, Woodmere; Kenneth H. Sheldon, Nassau, and Harry V. Brower, Maidstone. 9:12--John P. Mikrut, Shore View; Anton Rudert, Sound View, and E. Leonard Beard Jr., Pomonok.
The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer at these headquarters, at 11 A. M., on dates specified:

The to increase Netherlands has increased monopoly fees on imports of rye and barley from 3 to 3.50 florins a 100 kilograms, and that on wheat, corn and oats from 2 to 2.50 florins, the Deapartment of Commerce was informed today from The Hague.

English libel laws are notably severe, so it would be interesting to know whether one can slander an ocean. An editorial in The Times of London would seem to be very near the edge. Commenting on the Queen Mary's fast runs The Times is very impatient with people who think that the Queen Mary was hunting for records and blue ribbons.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange received yesterday two reports containing 30,000 words on permissive incorporation of member firms and the suggestion that nonmember general partners of allied members be placed under the Exchange's control and were told to make up their minds as to the merits of the proposals.

For the second straight year, the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League defeated the Eastern College All-Stars at Temple Stadium before 25,000 spectators tonight, 14 to 7. The game marked the start of the Eastern season.

Five Japanese military planes shot down an unarmed Chinese-Americanowned passenger plane this morning half an hour after it had left Hong Kong for Chungking, the temporary capital. They machinegunned the nineteen persons' on board, including H. L. Woods, American pilot, three Chinese members of the crew and fifteen Chinese passengers.

A concert version of Smetana's "The Bartered Bride," given last night at the Federal Music Theatre by the Federal Opera Chorus, the Greenwich Orchestra and soloists, attracted one of the largest houses of the project's Summer activities. Fritz Mahler was the conductor.
Malley, WPA client whose last name was not given; is doing a man's work now-but only after a turn in the sewing room.

A stiff northwest wind that put a seagoing ruffle in the first half of the Sippican Harbor mile course forced a postponement to 10 o'clock tomorrow morning of the international crew race between Radley College of England and Tabor Academy.

Gross assets. $7,565: net, $6,065. To husband, Thomas Hennessy. Chief assets, real estate, $7,515. Jacob Semmel, attorney, 186 Joralemon St. HOFFMAN, LOUIS (Dec. 6, 1937). Gross assets, $11,132; net. $9,861. To wife, Ida G. Hoffman, one-third of residuary estate; son, Irving Hoffman, and daughters, Nettie and Sylvia Hoffman, and Gertrude H. Wilinsky, one-sixth of residuary estate each. Chief assets, personal property, $11,132. Edward Light, attorney, 70 Pine St.. Manhattan.

The usual reason for not finishing a yachting series on Long Island Sound is that there is no wind. Today it was not a case of too little but of too much. The young skippers sailing for the midget championship would have ended their five-race series if conditions had been moderate, but instead a blustery northwester turned out to be entirely too boisterous to handle.

The Dutch Schultz policy racket paid $32,000 into the Democratio campaign funds of 1933, principally for the election of William Copeland Dodge as District Attorney, George Weinberg, the gangster who ran the racket for Schultz, testified yesterday at the trial of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines.

Cherry St, 228, n w cor Pelham; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co to Bring Realty Corp, 51-01 Queens Blvd, Woodside. L. 4. ($2). 18th St, 215 W; North River Savings Bank to Chelville Estates, Inc, 270 Madison Ave ($12.50).

An oversold condition developed today in North American wheat markets following an early decline of 1 cent or more a bushel, with Winnipeg in the lead. Prices in Winnipeg were at new low levels for the season on all deliveries, but when short covering developed there was little pressure.
Freshman enrollment figures at ProvIidence College are at an all time high for this season of the year, it was announced at the office of the registrar this morning.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company has received approval of its plan to avert bankruptcy or receivership from government agencies and a substantial number of the institutional holders of its securities, it was announced yesterday by D. J. Kerr, president of the road. Agreement now will be sought, Mr. Kerr said, from the rank and file of bondholders.

In conformity with a policy started some months ago by Delaware Hudson Company's management, the holding company has disposed of about 90,000 New York Central Railroad shares acquired in a stock market coup some years ago.
Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, gave out two statements today. The first read as follows:
It seems to be no longer true that the Presidency is the greatest gift within the power of the American people to bestow.

Chairman Dies replied to critics of the House committee investigating un-American activities by charging today that a "calculated campaign" of abuse and "fabricated reports" had been directed at the committee.

Czechoslovakia will be asked to make vital concessions-far bigger than any yet made or proposed-as a result of new "advice" just sent to Viscount Runciman, British mediator in Prague, by the British Government.
Patty Berg of Minneapolis moved closer today to her first women's Western championship by beating Miss Eleanor Dudley of Chicago, Illinois State champion, in the quarter-finals, 7 and 6.
Major George T. Irvine, superintendent of buildings and grounds, alumni secretary and a director of Kemper Military School here, died today. He was 61 years old.
In a statement sharply criticizing the Wagner Relations Act, George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, today made several suggestions for amending the law.
Leases of business space reported yesterday included contracts for retail stores in scattered sections of Manhattan.

This town has banned the wearing of shorts by men in public. Mayor Alexander Lafrenier said today that complaints by village residents of "immodest" and "immoral" costumes worn by, Summer visitors, male and female, resulted in the Town

Amid rumors of disagreement with President Roosevelt over the attempted "purge" of Democratic conservatives, James A. Farley came to the Summer White House here today to urge the President to speak in Maryland in an effort to end the Senatorial career
In a unique ceremony attended by Mrs. Harry Houdini, white-haired widow of the famous magician, this town today cleared Eunice "Goody" Cole of Colonial-Era charges that she was a witch.

Miss Virginia Kernochan, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Kernochan and the late Justice Kernochan, and Frederic Foster Carey, whose families have long been identified with Tuxedo Park, were married secretly in Belair, Md., on Aug. 7, it was. revealed after the couple returned here yesterday from the South.

M. L. Wilcox, director of operations of the Maritime Commission, conferred yesterday with officials of Moore McCormack at the company's offices, 5 Broadway, on details of the proposed new service of the American Republics Line to South America. The commission recently awarded the contract for operation of the service to Moore McCormack, and the first sailing will be on Oct. 8.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 25: Annapolis to New York, Badger, Decatur, Fairfax, Herbert, Leary. Wyoming. At Canal Zone, Bagley, Craven, Raleigh. Cuyama, San Pedro to San Diego. Enterprise at Rio de Janeiro. Marblehead, Chinwangtao to Shanghai. Mindanao, at Hong Kong.

Bills centralizing the control over the trucking and dumping of refuse were signed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall on the World's Fair grounds. After a statutory hearing he designated the Department of Sanitation as the central agent.
Butter for future delivery declined sharply in price today, the second time this week, as traders dumped holdings in the belief "pegs" were going to be set lower on future government purchases.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 73.5, establishing a new "high" since the close of 1937. The figures were 69.3 for the previous week and 84.8 for the week ended Aug. 21, 1937.

The scheduled International League baseball game between Syracuse and Baltimore was postponed tonight when the lighting system went out of order at the Municipal Stadium. Jack Corbett, president of the Chiefs, said the teams would play a double-header tomorrow night. More than 4,000
Helped by a lilting coloratura voice and the dimes of 10,000 schoolmates of Passaic, N. J., Angelina Ciofani, aged 13, arrived in Hollywood today to see what there was in store for her talents here.

William G. Betsch of William Iselin Co., Inc., has been appointed chairman of the textile fraud prevention prosecuting committee of the National Association of Credit Men, according to announcement yesterday by John L. Redmond, president of the New York Credit Men's Association. Mr. Betsch

The Union House of Assembly, which early today after an all-night sitting endorsed a declaration by Prime Minister James B. M. Hertzog that the country would have no official national anthem until the English and Afrikaans sections
The names of 310 New York City high school pupils who passed the June examination for State scholarships were announced today by the State Department of Education.

Harry Cunningham of 2,302 Valentine Avenue, Bronx, who was a city realty appraiser under Controller Taylor, died Tuesday in the House of Calvary Hospital, the Bronx, in his forty-third year, after an illness of several months.

A preliminary tabulation indicates that the producers of milk entering the New York City metropolitan market from seven States have voted more than four to one in favor of Federal-State control to boost and fix the price that they must be paid for their product.

The Times-Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, was found guilty today on five counts of contempt of court by Superior Judge Emmet H. Wilson in an action growing out of charges filed by a committee acting in the name of the Los Angeles Bar Association.

Covering their retreat with vigorous protests about the "intangibility" of the fortyhour and other social laws and then adding a covering phrase about the necessity of assuring national defense and independence, the extreme Left parties today began

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, replied yesterday to an attack by George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, upon himself and the Labor party, terming the attack and the anti-Labor party resolution adopted by the

Prizes totaling $3,500 were awarded yesterday by Theodore T. Hayes, executive commissioner of the United States New York World's Fair Commission, to seven sculptors who were runners-up in the government's recent $10,000 contest for two statues, 34 feet high, to adorn the facade of the Federal area main building at the 1939 New York's World's Fair.

Average employment by General Motors Corporation for the first half of 1938 declined 27 per cent from the 1937 period and weekly pay checks were 25 per cent lower, while sales of automobiles declined 38 per cent in value and earnings fell 70 per cent, according

The report of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and subsidiaries, for the twelve months ended on June 30, released for publication today, shows consolidated net income of $5,653,765 after operating expenses, taxes and charges, but before foreign exchange adjustments.

MANHATTAN BAKER, CHARLES W. (Aug. 8). Estate, more than $20,000. To Frances C. Baker, widow, 325 West End Ave., household, personal effects; Charles W. Baker Jr., Greenville, Del., and Newcombe C. Baker, Rumson, N. J., sons, executors, one-half residue each.

The tenth Summer season of Camp Manhattan, Boy Scout camp at Ten Mile River, N. Y., will close today with the return of 480 campers to the city. The camp is the first of the five borough Scout camps at the Ten Mile River reservation to end the 1938 season.

No civilian airplanes that fly over any Chinese territory eastward of a line running northward from Pakhoi, on the South China Coast, to Sian, in Shensi Province, North China, will be entirely safe in the future, Japanese naval and army authorities here

The Argentine State railways are taking delivery of ten mountain-type steam locomotives supplied by the Krupp Works of Germany, according to a report from the office of the American trade commissioner at Buenos Aires to the Department of Commerce.

Henry G. S. Noble, oldest member of the New York Stock Exchange and its World War president, has posted his seat for transfer after more than fifty-six years of continuous membership. The seat will go to his grandson, Henry Stebbins Noble. The senior Mr. Noble likewise inherited his seat from his grandfather, Henry G. Stebbins, who joined the Exchange in 1831.

In the old romantic days, when going to war was thought to be only a little more dangerous than staying at home on the farm, soldiers were dressed as though they were on their way to a masquerade ball.

The League of Nations gave out today a note from the Chinese delegate, Hoo Chi-tsai, charging the Japanese Army with annihilating two Chinese battalions through the use of poison gas in the Juichang sector, west of Kiukiang.
The Government of Puerto Rico has received permission to appeal to the Boston Circuit Court from the decision of the United States District Court here in which Judge Robert

After the daring shooting by Arabs yesterday of W. S. Moffatt, Assistant District Commissioner at Jenin, who died of his wounds last night, the authorities declares a twenty-twohour daily curfew in that town.
The vote in the Constitutional Convention tonight, which had the effect of upholding the outlawing of Proportional Representation, was as follows:

The first fifteen railroads to re port showed a decrease of 30.6 per cent in net operating income for July, compared with July, 1937. As a result of increased shipments of manufactured goods and reduced maintenance charges, the July result of $10,544,000 was a gain, corn pared with June, when a net oper eating income of $8,430,000 was reported.

It is a significant indication of the rising opposition to the Wagner Labor Relations Act that both the New York State Federation of Labor and the United States Chamber of Commerce should on the same day denouce the operation of what was hailed three years ago as the workingman's Magna Carta.
Effective Saturday, the Mexican Government is restoring import duties on 189 commodities to the much lower rates in effect prior to last Jan. 18, the Commerce Department announced today.
Bishop Ludwig Sproll of the Catholic diocese of Rottenburg has been banished from Wuerttemberg, in which his diocese is located, according to an announcement made here today.
The newspaper Noticias reports that the government is considering the calling in of all gold and the punishing of hoarding of gold by private individuals and business houses.

Net asset value of the International Mining Corporation on June 30 was $7,025,791, or $13.42 a share for 523,273 common shares, after deducting $256,834 set up before the current year for losses on mining ventures, other reserves, taxes and provision for $470,000 estimated Federal income taxes on unrealized appreciation of listed securities which would be payable next year if such securities had been sold at closing market quotations of June 30.

The third day of the junior rifle corps small-bore matches brought high scores from the boys and girls on the firing line and Richard Gardner, 17, of Toledo captured the group A event today with a total of 288 out of 300 for the prone-sitting-kneel competition. Robert

The Bud Lerner coltl Thanksgiving, who captured the! Travers in such impressive style, was just as keen a winner today in the thirty-sixth Huron Handicap, in which he carried scale weight of 126 pounds to a length-and-a-half victory. Mr. and

Stocks closed firmer and slightly higher after drifting irregularly; turnover, 826,570 shares. United States Government issues steady and slightly higher; other bonds irregular and dull; transactions, $5,282,575.
The Senators, collecting 12 hits for 24 bases off Southpaw Harry Eisenstat, tightened their hold on fourth place today by defeating the Tigers, 8 to 2, in the first of a three-game series.

By RALPH W. LONG 3d St. 47-49 E: 5-story tenement, 77.2x48.1 irreg. parcel 2; also Houston St, 288-90 E, 40.5x80; 6-story tenement, parcel 1; due. $12,712; taxes, etc, $7.80; parcel 1 subject mtg, $30,000; parcel 2 subject to mtg, $23,500; to plaintiff for $4,000.
Many old New Jersey homesteads rich in historical lore are changing hands, to be used by the new owners as Summer retreats, country estates, or as the background for new residential developments.

A Summer school student came upon the beaten body of an unemployed theatre usher near the campus of Western Reserve University today, and the police homicide squad, already vexed and worn by twelve unsolved "torso killings," added a new mystery to its list.
Although no announcement has been made by City Hall, bankers expect within a few days official notice that this city will sell about $30,000,000 bf revenue bills to matture in three months.

Miss Margery Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Reid of 55 East Ninety-third Street, and Richard Bolles Paddock Jr., a grandnephew of General John J. Pershing, will be married the morning of Sept. 19 in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The Rev. Thomas S. Delihant will perform the ceremony.

Owing partly to increased industrial production and partly to heavier freight shipments, business in the Pittsburgh District reflected a moderate gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

As so oftern is the case when the President is deeply involved in a controversy, it is possible to find certain major flaws in the opinions he expressed at his press conference the other day: (1) It is "immoral" for the adherents of one party to enter the primaries of another.

The Giants are back again in the National League pennant picture, for the first time in three weeks, four and one-half games away from the pacesetting Pirates, after a stirring battle of eleven innings and more than three hours of elapsed time with the Cards today at Sportsman's Park.

The foreign exchange market turned soft again yesterday as Europe wavered toward a more pessimistic view of the French financial outlook and of the general European political situation. No further engagements of gold in London for shipment here were reported because the gold price rose to $34.778, too high for profitable arbitrage, but dealings in the metal abroad continued active and there were indications of some increase' in the demand for hoarding.
Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers now are being repaid for the havoc they created on their two previous Western trips when they bowled over contenders like tenpins. Today,

A 50 per cent reduction in the price of the Packard Lektro-shaver, one of the leading brands in the field, and a 33 per cent cut in the new Packard Roto-shaver were put into effect yesterday by the Progress Corporation, distributor of these brands, the company announced.
Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wright gave a luncheon at the Gideon Putnam today for William Woodward, Robert A. Fairbairn, W. Goadby Loew and Henry Case.

The War Department released the following orders dated Aug. 24: BRIGADIER GENERAL Honeycutt, F. W., Fort Leavenworth, Kan., to command Fort Stotsenburg. Phillippine Islands, to sail from San Francisco about Oct. 1.

Government troops report they have routed the Rebels on the western side of the Zujar River, in Southwestern Spain, thus lifting the immediate threat from the west against the Almaden mercury mines, according to tonight's communique. Many prisoners

Tower Brothers Stationery Company and D. T. Crossman, Inc., will combine on Sept. 1, the two concerns announced yesterday. The new name will be Tower-Crossman Corporation and the address will be 53 West Twenty-third Street, which has been occupied by the Tower Brothers Company for the last thirty years. Officers will be

All divisions of the dress industry were urged yesterday by Harry Uviller, impartial chairman, to begin immediate consideration of the new labor pacts to succeed the current agreements with the union, which expire Jan. 31, 1939.
Bank clearings this week were only slightly under the total for the preceding week, while the decline from the corresponding week of last year was the smallest reported for the past five weeks.

The weekly bank statements yesterday disclosed a continuance of the expanding trend that began three weeks ago. Local member banks added $71,000,000 to their loans and investments, making the three-week rise $125,000,000. Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans gained another $10,000,000, making their total advance for three weeks $37,000,000.

The fate of the Montreal Maroons was decided for one year, at least, when the Canadian outfit was granted a year's suspension from the National Hockey League at a meeting of the loop's board of governors at the Hotel Commodore last night.

Whether or not George Weinberg, former Dutch Schultz gangster and State's star witness against James J. Hines, is competent to pass on District Attorney Dewey's qualifications as an attorney provoked another sharp exchange in court yesterday between the prosecutor and Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel.

Mike Phipps returned to action today in the Meadow Brook Club polo, having been on the ground yesterday with a cold. He will be ready for the important test. match between Old Westbury and Greentree at Sands Point on Sunday.
A six-story tenement house for a site in Greenwich Village and alterations to existing structures comprised building projects in Manhattan for which plans were filed yesterday.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Aug. 24 were announced today: Ramsey, 1st Lt. A. A. Jr.; Laster, 1st Lt. C. A., and McGill, 1st Lt. W. N., Navy Yard, New York, N. Y., to Signal Corps School, Fort Monmouth. N. J., to report Sept. 15.

Still hopeful, the United States Lawn Tennis Association has given Mrs. Helen Wills Moody through Aug. 30 to file her entry for the national championships starting at Forest Hills Sept. 8, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
H. L. Woods, American pilot whose Chinese transport plane was shot down by Japanese near Canton yesterday, has been a commercial flier in the Orient since 1933.
Coffee exports from Santos, Brazil, in July amounted to 899,246 sacks, or 287,160 less than in June, the Department of Commerce was informed today by the United States Consulate at Sao Paulo.
Two young women who left their mountaineer hsubands in Tennessee for hitch-hiking thrills on the open road were charged today with the murder of Felix Shannon, 56.

The Rev. Peter E. Kelaher, pastor of St. Athanasius Roman Catholic Church, Sixty-second Street and Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, observed the twenty-fifth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood yesterday. He celebrated a low mass of thanksgiving at 8 A. M. at the church.
Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of an unofficial committee to consider the possibility of renewing operation of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.
The schooner General A. W. Greely, with the MacGregor Arctic Expedition aboard, is now off Northeast Newfoundland. The ship is leaking badly.

The woolen sales departments and credit and accounting departments of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., will be moved from 261 Fifth Avenue to the Empire State Building, H. Hamilton Weber, rental manager of the building, announced yesterday.

Meat, the most expensive single item on the food shopper's weekly bill, is expected to be moderately priced in the next few years because of anticipated larger supplies of feed and cattle forecast in the latest reports of the United States. Department of Agriculture.

As a preface to an expected courtroom effort to substantiate testimony of a Dutch Schultz henchman that James J. Hines protected the numbers racket, District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey has subpoenaed all the records of the last of the Tammany Hall police commissioners pertaining to the "breaking" of honest policemen who persisted in raiding Harlem policy operations.
Pensioned On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight Aug. 26: PATROLMEN John H. Stemmerman, 81st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 27, 1913.

The theft of small packages from the Railway Express Agency, Inc., over long period of time was disclosed yesterday when Alexander Karsh, 23 years old, of 26 Jefferson Avenue, Jersey City, was placed in the line-up at police headquarters.

Alfred L. Simon, president of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs, said today he had called a conference or Young Republican leaders from seventeen States, to be held here Sunday.
A 16year-old newsboy, playing as coolly under fire as any champion, stole the show today as the semi-final field was formed in the national public links golf championship.
For the last ten years Henriette Schnier, proprietor of a beauty parlor, has been looking for a man she suspected of stealing her purse which contained two diamond rings value at $3,250. The suspect,
Two more patrolmen were arrested yesterday on "shakedown" charges, bringing to five the number of members of the police force locked up as aides of alleged extortioners in the last two weeks.

Contracts were signed today between Selznick-International and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, by which Metro will distribute "Gone With the Wind" and Clark Gable will be loaned Selznick for the role of Rhett Butler. Gable was announced

In one of the largest sales of plottage in the financial district in recent years the northeast corner of Washington and Albany Streets was purchased yesterday by an investor from Mrs. Mary D. Harding of Waterville, N. Y. The property

Lowell R. Slagle, husky 31-year-old garage mechanic, maintained tradition today by "popping up from nowhere" to win the $5,000 preliminary handicap, dress rehearsal for the grand American handicap trap shoot tomorrow which will close the thirty-ninth annual clay target bombardment.
The Athletics split a double-header with the Browns today, losing the first game, 8 to 5, in thirteen innings, and winning the second, 4 to 1.

With the C. I. O. offering peace terms, the Association of San Francisco Distributors made a new show of strength today in its "united front" drive to re-establish the open shop in the local warehouse industry.
William F. Kopp, Representative in Congress from the First Iowa District from 1920 to 1932, died at his home here last F night of a cerebral hemorrhage. Hi's age was 69.

Aylmer Maude, friend of Leo Tolstoy and an authority on his works, died today at Ladywell House near Chelmsford at the age of 80. As a translator of Tolstoy, Mr. Maude was assisted by his wife, Louise; He also was the author of numerous works on art, religion and peace.

Mrs. Julia K. Willets Comly of Philadelphia has taken up residence here to divorce Robert R. Comly. Mrs. Comly is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets of this city. She was married on Feb. 12, 1933, to Robert Rowland Comly, son of Mrs. Robert Rowland Comly of Devon, Pa., and the late Mr. Comly.

The arrangement of 106 defendants accused of being members of the largest alcohol ring that has functioned here since repeal of the Prohibition Law was interrupted yesterday when a cry of "Help!" sounded from the corridors of the Federal Building.

Registration on the Chicago Stock Exchange of the 1,447,784 shares of capital stock, $5 par value, of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation will become effective tomorrow and the stock will be admitted to trading, it was announced today.

A will drawn on June 11, 1937, by Pearl White, heroine of the "Perils of Pauline" of silent film fame, was filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday by Charles Schwartz of the law firm of Schwartz Frohlich, who was named executor. Mr. Schwartz
George N. Thompson of East Orange was elected to the board of directors of the Franklin Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of Newark, N. J., yesterday, to succeed the late Frederick Bowden.
Three United States Navy men received today the Navy Department's highest decorations for heroism during the sinking of the U. S. S. Panay by Japanese aircraft last Dec. 12.
Dixie Girl, a chestnut filly owned by Dr. Edmund J. Robbins of Bay Shore, captured the 3-year-old trot at the eighty-sixth annual fair of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society today.

Five to seven arrests will be made this afternoon in connection with the Holmesburg County Prison case in which four prisoners were suffocated when the steam was turned on in the isolation cell block, Coroner Charles H. Hersch announced early this morning.

Fifteen girls with one ambition, to be acknowledged the best jacks player in Greater New York, gathered yesterday afternoon in the recreation room of the Heckscher Playground, Central Park at Sixtyfirst Street. When the last set

Death Announced Retired Fireman Bernard F. Murphy, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 105, residing at 464 73d St., Brooklyn. died Aug. 22. Legion Convention Leaves of absence for fifteen days, With pay, may be granted to members of the uniformed force, who are war veterans and are desirous of attending the American Legion National Convention at Los Angeles, Calif. on Sept. 19 to 22.
The Governors Island Blues and the Bethpage Knaves will be rivals in an Eastern Polo League contest at Morris Memorial Field Sunday.
The role of obstetrician was forced upon Patrolman Robert Freimann yesterday and he performed his duties so well that he was commended by the ambulance doctor when the latter arrived.

Fire caused damage estimated at upward of $500,000 today at the plant of the Socony Vacuum Company here. The plant covers about twenty acres and the fire started in the center fuse house, a building about thirty feet high and 250 feet square. An employee said this

William P. Lawson, self-suspended Police Commissioner and former State Republican chairman, was presented by the grand jury today on twelve criminal charges, including conspiracy, false pretense and hypothecation and fraud in the conduct of his brokerage business, now closed.

Irene Dunne and Don Ameche have been adjudged the movies most accomplished female and male speakers in a survey conducted among the nation's 15.000,000 to 20,000,000 hard-of-hearing persons by the American Society for the Hard of Hearing, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler, president of the society.

Trading was very active to fair yesterday. AU local markets showed strength with bull higher; some sales calf and veal higher; fresh pork cuts strong to higher. Kosher business was confined largely to lamb at slightly stronger prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Last week we devoted a column to the fly fisherman and his problems. A good part of this column was taken up by excerpts from an article written by Dan Brenan of Syracuse in the current issue of The New York State Sportsman.

The swaying Pirate brig grounded on a Philadelphia sandbar today, the National League leading Buccaneers dropping two games to the suddenly vicious cellar occupants by the identical. scores of 2 to 1, the second contest going eleven innings.
Several taxpayers in various sections of Long Island were among the properties in that section reported yesterday by brokers as having. been sold. Among them was
The text of the resolution of the State Federation of the A. F. of L., denouncing the operation of the National Labor Relations Act reads:

For years on years the black coat, symbol of respectability, has been a modest but momentous part of the British Constitution. It is a pleasure to know that it has survived the American invasion. Our irresistible slang pervades the tight little island.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Aug. 24 were announced today: Hamlet, Capt. H. G., Washington, D. C., placed on retired list with rank of Rear Admiral (upper half), Sept. 1.

Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart Young gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Astor. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence C. Willard, Mr. and Mrs. Ellwood G. Hart, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Oliver, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Blackstone and Mr. and Mrs. Alan Ross.

The proposed fifteen-round bout between Tommy Farr, British heavyweight, and Maurice Strickland of New Zealand at Madison Square Garden Sept. 16 has been called off, according to an announcement yesterday by the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Philip Sebold, deputy police chief in Newark, was criticized today by another deputy police chief, Frank E. Brex, for the alleged breakdown of police protection June 4 at a Socialist party meeting in Military Park,

The 1938 edition of the New York State Labor Law with amendments to Dec. 31, 1938, has just been published copies are available at the State Department of Labor Printing Bureau, State Office Building, Albany, or at the State Department of Labor, 80 Centre Street, this city.
Authorizations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the recovery program during July totaled $314,088,954. Rescissions of previous authorizations amounted to $9,162,490.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 22: Humphrey, Lt. Corn. F. D.; granted sick leave for 2 months. Arnold, Lt. M. W., Medical Corps, Guam: to Naval Recruiting Station, Baltimore, Md.
The general level of wholesale prices continued to decline during the week ended Aug. 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Everett Bacon shot a record 33, 36--69 on his home course today to win the qualifying medal in the eighth annual invitation amateur tournament of the Sagamore Golf Club. Five birdies and an eagle enabled Bacon, a five-time winner of this event, to better par by three strokes and set a new amateur mark for the course.

A plan devised by John L. Lewis and other C. I. O. officials for settling the factional fight within the United Automobile Workers of America was accepted today by union officers ousted by Homer Martin, union president, while Mr. Martin promised to submit it to his executive board "as soon as possible."

The Bronx Zoo is scheduled to become host to a colony of "parasol ants" next month in compliance with numerous requests by the public following the recent publication of Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars's "Book of Insect Oddities," in which the curator of mammals and reptiles describes the peculiar habits of the insects.

The stock market here reflected Wall Street's uncertainty today and most sections were idle. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the forsign bonds changes were unimportant. The transatlantic list

Amory L. Haskell, dollar-a-year director of the New Jersey Council, created by the Legislature to advertise the State, announced today the appointment of Richard C. Maddux of Boston as assistant director, at $10.000 annually.

A special session of the Legislature to provide by Oct. 1 for a Nov. 8 referendum whereby the State could approve a $33,000,000 bond issue for highway construction was urged here today by E. Donald Sterner, State Highway Commissioner, who said the proceeds of the issue and a Federal PWA grant of $27,000,000 would provide a $60,000,000 program giving work to 60,000 men for one year.

Donall O'Neill, assistant production manager of The Sun here and former assistant advertising production manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who was an expert in newspaper typography, art and engraving, died Wednesday of a bloodstream infection at his home, 30 Nicholas Street, St. George, S. I. He was 40 years old.

Mayor La Guardia's attempt to block investigations by the City Council into relief expenditures and into the operation of WNYC, the municipal broadcasting station, received a setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien ruled that the resolutions

MANHATTAN ARCHER, JOSEPHINE (Nov. 27, 1937). Gross assets, $29,924; net, $19,583. To Drucile A. Rickaby, daughter. Chief assets, real estate, $16,000. Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, attorneys, 120 Broadway.

UNITED STATES PLUMBER, $6.72 per diem. Ordnance Department, Watervliet Arsenal, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the local secretary, Board U. S. Civil Service Examiners, Ordnance Department, Watervliet Arsenal, Watervliet, N. Y., not later than sept. 5. 1938. Competitors will not be

Archbishop Samuel David, pastor of St. George's Churdh here and claimant to the titular leadership of the Syrian Orthodox Church in the United States, Canada and Mexico, was excommunicated by Alexander III, Patriarch of Antioch, in a manifesto made public here today.
