Miss Elaine Fischell of Santa Monica, Calif., fourth-seeded player, upset the second-seeded Miss Josephine Sanfililppo of Brooklyn yesterday in straight sets, 6-4, 6-3, to gain the final round of the girls' Eastern grass court tennis championship at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island.

General Mills, Inc., is opening a new campaign in behalf of Wheaties, tying sales of the product to free admissions to the State Fair at Detroit and to theatre parties out-State in Michigan. Newspapers, radio and billboards are scheduled to promote the idea. The campaign was worked

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today 4ts analysis of statements registered under the Securities Act in July, showing that $233,897,000 of new securities became fully effective. The net total, exclusive of issues registered solely for reserve against conversion of other securities, was $222,595,000.

Labor's Non-Partisan League today submitted to the House committee investigating un-American activities documents to -support its charges that Edward F. Sullivan, the committee's senior investigator, has himself engaged in such activities.

The Federal Government's attitude toward business and labor as reflected in the Fair Labor Standards Act, and the inquiry into the industrial set-up to be conducted by the National Economic Committee will be featured subjects in addresses and discussions at the nineteenth annual convention of the American Trade Association Executives at the William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh, Sept. 22 to 24, it was announced yesterday by V. P.

Arthur Case Wadley of 375 Park Avenue gave a dinner at his home last night at which he announced the engagement and approaching marriage of his daughter, Miss Jean Reid Wadley, to Malcolm Ludlam Pearson. The ceremony will

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 16, Special Orders 184, dated Aug. 9, 1938, as relates to 1st Lt. James J. O'Donovan, Cav.-Res., is revoked. So much of paragraph 15, Special Orders 184, dated Aug. 9, 1938, as relates to Capt. Sidney R. Smith, Cav.-Res., is revoked.

Four buildings consisting of a four-family apartment house, a twofamily dwelling, a corner store and apartment building and a four-car garage at 676 Palisade Avenue and 212 Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N. J., were sold by the Eflor Realty Company, Inc., to Louis Ring, who will hold them for investment.

Bonds held steady in quieter trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and closing prices were irregular. The turnover fell below the previous day, With total sales at $5,282,575, compared with $6,485,450 on Wednesday.

SOME time back when the Cleveland Indians were leading the American League the happy slogan of the club was: "Christmas is coming! They really thought it was. This time the annual Cleveland threat was going to be something more than a broken promise at the bitter end.

Thirty-one of the physically handicapped children who are patients at the Wave Crest Convalescent Home of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society gave a performance yesterday before 100 patrons and friends of the institution at its annual lawn party on the grounds of the home at Elk Court and Central Avenue on the ocean-front at Far Rockaway.

The Congressional Committee investigating the TVA wound up its hearings here today after hearing testimony that power company representatives tried to dissuade farmers from signing up for TVA power by telling them there was a "bunch of Yankees behind it" and the lines would never be built.

Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, it was explained yesterday, voted last week for the constitutional ban on proportional representation under a misapprehension, and after he discovered his error moved to have his vote changed.
Alfred Paul Machris, official and cofounder of the Wilshire Oil Company, died last night at his home here after a heart attack at the age of 58.

In a fine northerly breeze, the best sailing one for the Star sloops since the Atlantic Coast championship started at the Riverside Yacht Club, William Picken's craft High Seas of the Great South Bay fleet over on Long Island came through today in the fourth contest.

Ten gang-style killings here in as many weeks were attributed today by John L. Sullivan, veteran chief of detectives, to a mysterious and bloody "purge" of the Chicago underworld by a "mob" or "mobs" unknown.
Eleven-year-old Bobby Mosbacher from Knickerbocker lost the decision in a protest hearing this evening and with it the midget sailing Championship of Long Island Sound.

Trustees of the Public Utilities Securities Corporation and the trustee of the Webster Securities Corporation have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to their application for a report on and approval of their plan of reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.

Two army pursuit airplanes flying at 10,000 feet in combat formation with four others, were in collision near Tawas City today, but their pilots, Major H. R. Wells, 49, and Lieutenant A. P. Clark Jr., 25, leaped to safety with their parachutes.

A handful of invited military and diplomatic observers watched a demonstration today at the Bureau of Standards, in which a concrete fortress was constructed and made ready for use in less than one working day by use of a

Miss Janette Bourne, a Negro, of 443 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, who said she was born in Barbados, British West Indies, 40 years ago, was among those who appeared yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, in naturalization proceedings.

Richmond Hill Girl Will Be Wed to Carlton F. Putnam Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George V. Siegmund of Richmond Hill, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Siegmund,to Carlton F. Putnam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Haldemand S. Putnam of Springfield, Mass.

Hitler displayed the flower of his army to Admiral Horthy of Hungary in a parade in Berlin yesterday. Sensational arms revelations were made. One was a mobile 10-inch gun, carried in motorized sections, said to be capable of sending shells seventeen to thirty miles.

Emil Kropf, German ace aviator, stopped off here this afternoon on his way to the national air races in Cleveland to demonstrate a new kind of stunt flying in his high-winged Fieseler Storch monoplane which he termed "foolproof."

A favoriteson demonstration, staged by more than 1,000 Bergen County Democrats to honor William H. J. Ely of Rutherford, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, marked the last Governor's Day celebration of the season here today. Delegations were also present from Ocean, Atlantic and Morris Counties.

Pre-season apartment renting is continuing at a brisk pace, reports received from brokers yesterday indicated. Among those reported as having signed contracts for space was Paul J. Kern, president of the Civil Service Commission, who leased an apartment at Harperly Hall, 41 Central Park West, through Potter, Hamilton Co.. broker.
In its first international crew race in this country, Tabor Academy's eightoared shell defeated a crew from Radley College of Abingdon, England, by a third of a length over a mile course today.

Dudley, Brothwell, who runs a riding school at Fairfield, Conn., identified a photograph of Dutch Schultz as one of his old customers. Schultz started coming to the riding school, which is about five miles from Bridgeport, in May, 1935. The gangster was not choosey
One day ahead of schedule, two English county cricket matches ended today. Essex defeated Derbyshire by six wickets and Somerset gained a 20-run decision over Kent.

Morrison Ave. (15-3867), w s, 292 ft n of 172d St, 28x100; Lewis Kaplan to Prudential Insurance Co, 763 Broad St, Newark, N J; installments, 5 per cent; $11,000. Nereid Ave (17-5054), a e cor of ly Ave, 85x100; Palmer Central Corp to John Whole, 500 W 123d St; 1 year, 6 per cent; $16,000.

America's swimming tourists and Germany's aces, meeting for the fifth time, divided the victories in six events today. The Americans won three free-style events, including a 150-meter relay, while the Germans won the back-stroke, breast-stroke and medley relay events.
Florence Arnold Tugwell obtained a secret divorce yesterday at Yerington, Nev., from Rexford Guy Tugwell, former Under-Secretary of Agriculture, on grounds of mental cruelty.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Frank Reavis will return soon to-their home at 19 Sutton Place from Bar Harbor, where they have been visiting Dr. and Mrs. R. Foster Kennedy.

HEAT waves may go, cold waves may come, but whatever the temperature, one thing remains steadfast-the unwavering hero of historical fiction. Change his uniform, and he may be made to serve equally well in the Second Punic War, the Crusades or the American Revolution. He will be always unflinchingly courageous, immovably loyal to the cause, and unmistakably victorious by page 496.

The Public Works Administration today announced the allotment of grants totaling $10,544,051 and loans of $2,659,500 for 105 approved nonFederal PWA projects having an estimated construction cost of $23,431,239. Including allotments
The five Federal Arts Projects for New York City will open their "Carnival of the Arts" in Washington Square this afternoon and evening. Motor traffic through the square will be suspended.

The United States Government. through the Works Progress Administration, is about to enter into a partnership with Lee Shubert for the proposed October road tour of "Prologue to Glory," the E. P. Conkle play dealing with Abraham Lincoln's early manhood, it was announced yesterday by George Kondolf, director of the Federal Theatre Project for New York City.

The American Federation of Labor, which has traditionally avoided entanglement in the political and economic rivalries of European nations, will go to "the extreme limit" in mapping a cooperative program with labor organizations abroad to end the world armament

Dudley Brothwell, a ruddy-faced riding master from Fairfield, Conn., picked out Tammany District Leader James J. Hines in court yesterday as the man who had visited his riding school with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in the Summer of 1935 when Schultz was dodging the police of New York.

Condemnation of the National Labor Relations Board as biased in favor of the C. I. 0. was voted by the State Federation of the A. F. L. in a resolution approving curtailment of the board's powers. [Page 1.]
The Public Contracts Board made public today its recommendations regarding minimum wage scales in the Portland cement industry.

Following is the official explanation of the work of the Constitutional Convention under the title of "Address of the Delegates of the People of the State of New York in Convention Assembled to the People of the State of New York":

Some changes have been made in the Autumn schedule of hunts meets in the metropolitan area, it was learned yesterday. The season here will not get under way until Sept. 17, when the West Hills meeting will be held on Long Island.
The Michelosens and Colwells played a 6-6 tie in a touch football game that ended a two-and-a-halfhour drill by the Eastern College All Stars at their Peddie School training camp today.

Moorhead, 115 E 64th St, due etc, as bond; $40,000.
The industrial property at 707-9 East 135th Street, between Southern. Boulevard and Willow Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Mid Brooklyn Realty Corporation to Sherry Gordon, Inc.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $71,000,000 to $7,613,000,0,00 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

Despite the closing of many warehouses in the San Francisco area in the last few days, grocery shipments from Eastern manufacturers continued to go forward yesterday. Manufacturers here said that there had been some drop-off in new business this week from the affected wholesalers, but that no orders had been received to cancel or defer any deliveries.

Secretary of Commerce Roper has given his unqualified approval to the national retail demonstration scheduled for the week of Sept. 19, it was announced yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which, with other retail organizations, is sponsoring the project.

Australia qualified two teams for the semi-finals of the men's national doubles tennis championship today as Miss Alice Marble and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan gained the final round of the women's tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.
Echoes from the James J. Hines trial were heard yesterday at the closing exercises conducted by children of the play school of Recreation Rooms and Settlement in their auditorium at 84 First Street.

Revenues of the electric power and light industry in the United States in June amounted to $174,271,000, according to the Edison Electric Institute, based on the Federal Power Commission's classification of accounts. Revenues
United States Ambassador Hugh R. Wilson will attend the annual Nuremberg congress of the Nazi party, which begins Sept. 5, the embassy disclosed today.
Mrs. George Christopher Lane of West Hartford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Mary Lane, to Wesley Hulburt Garner of De Pere, Wis.
Mrs. Harriette Ruth Harris Work of this place and Palm Beach, widow of Horace Hutchins Work, financier and sportsman, was married in the rectory of St. Vincent's Church here...

Dairy farmers of Pennsylvania have voted overwhelmingly in favor of establishing a Federal milk marketing area to control producers' prices in the New York milk shed, Howard G. Eisaman, chairman of the State Milk Control Commission. said today.

Uncorking a nine-run attack in the eighth inning, Newark overwhelmed Jersey City today, 14 to 5. The late uprising was featured by Buddy Rosar, who had two singles and drove in three runs as a pinchhitter in the big rally as the Bears batted around.
The annual ballad contest for the amateur hill-billy bands and barber shop quartets of Brooklyn was held last night before an audience of more than 3,500 persons in the Prospect Park Music Grove.

Walter H. Rhodes of London, founder of the W. H. Rhodes Canada Educational Trust, established to bring fifty secondary school boys from England and Scotland each year for a month's tour of Canada,, will sail for England today on the Laconia after accompanying a group on the first tour. Mr.
In every country in the world the party in power argues that any economic recovery that may have taken place has been due to that party's efforts.

While strictly choice and prime steers and yearlings held steady today, the general run of fat cattle dragged along at 25 cents lower prices for day and mostly 25 to 50 cents under Late last week, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Prime heavies topped at $12.85. Hogs were 10 to 15 cents lower, butchers showing the full decline, top fell to $8.85. Lambs were strong and active,

Engineering construction awards for the week ended yesterday amounted to $57,907,000, a gain of 30 per cent over the previous week and 55 per cent above the corresponding week of 1937, according to reports compiled by Engineering News-Record.

During the week ended Aug. 24 member bank reserve balances increased $71,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $34,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, $31,000,000 in Treasury

Deputy Jorge Gonzalez von Maree, leader of the Chilean Nazi party, will be compelled to serve a sen-tence of one and a half years in prison as a result of the rejection of his appeal today, it was announced-in well-informed circles.

Charles Amandoles of La Tourette, Staten Island, paced the field in the New Jersey State public links championship at the Rivervale Country Club today. Amandoles, Staten Island champion, toured the 7,000yard layout in 76 to lead by a stroke.
Lieut. Comdr. Andrew McAllister, U.S.N., retired, died Wednesday at his home, 159 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, after having suffered a paralytic stroke on Aug. 18. His age was 80.

Dr. Charles Hazzard of New York and Mount Vernon, N. Y., one of the nation's leading osteopaths, died on Wednesday of a heart attack at his Summer home at Stinson Lake, N. H., according to word received here yesterday.
It is good to see that our Republican friends, about to confabulate i Indiana, have sought to give their meeting that touch of rural poetry supposed to please the Middle West.

The Social Security Board is nearing completion of a three-month study of the problem of extending Federal old-age insurance to 16,000,000 farm hands, hired girls and other wage-earners now excluded from the system. A report to the board's advisory council is -due Sept. 15.

At a two-hour conference here this afternoon between three officials of the United States Department of Agriculture and three officials representing as many departments of the Canadian Government, the wheat marketing policies of the two countries were compared and discussed. The meeting ended

The sixteen-week strike against the Collier Advertising Service, Inc., which was revealed publicly in the mutilation of subway car cards, was ended yesterday with the signing of a two-year contract, the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, announced.

Mrs. Beverley Bogert was a luncheon hostess today, and Mrs. McNamee, wife of Rear Admiral Luke McNamee, U. S. N., retired, gave a luncheon at the Muenchinger-King and a dinner there tonight. Mrs. William Hayward entertained with a bathing party and luncheon at Clarenden Court today.

Major and Mrs. John A. Warner entertained with a dinner tonight at their home for Count and Countess Roger de Perigny of Paris, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw, brother and sister-in-law of Countess de Perigny.

The proposed new Constitution for the State of New York, 271 pages in length, was put in the hands of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention tonight. Two hundred copies were rushed from the printer's late in the afternoon, and distributed.

The cross-examination of George Weinberg at the trial of James J. Hines yesterday follows: Resuming his cross-examination of George Weinberg at the James J. Hines conspiracy trial, when court reopened at 10:18 A. M. yesterday, Lloyd Paul Stryker,
Merchant ships flying the flag of Panama increased from 114 to 135 in the past year, a gain of twenty-one ships and 60,628 in the net registered tonnage.

Trotting honors on the third day of the Monmouth County Agricultural Fair today went to Hinieyou, owned by W. E. Miller of Washington. The big bay gelding took all three heats of the 2:17 event scoring in 2:08 1/4, 2:08 and 2:09 1/2.

The Reds sailed higher than a kite in the closing innings of two games with the Bees today, losing the first, 6 to 4, in twelve innings, and the second, 3 to 2, when Boston got to Bucky Walters for all their runs after two were out in the ninth.

In honor of the nineteen years' service of Henry B. Cocheu, who recently retired as Brooklyn and Long Island director of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, a new American flag and bronze plaque were dedicated yesterday morning at the New York State Building, 320 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn. Nearly 300

August hasn't been much of a holiday time for anybody. The weather has been fine for tropocal fish, but too much hot air has been playing on too many combustibles for the comfort of the human species.

The three-story building at 168 Butler Street, between Hoyt and Bond Streets, Brooklyn, containing six apartments, has been sold by Mary A. Cassano to a client of Samuel Hurwitz for cash. The assessed valuation is $7,500.
A picture of the days when there was plenty of room on a great continent was brought back here today as Canaan and North Canaan reached the high point of their celebration of 200 years of history.

Edward H. Frohner, chief of the research department of the InterChemical Company of New York, died at his home here today. Coming to this village in 1874, Mr. Frohner, a chemist, joined the firm of A. F. Buchanan Sons, oil-cloth manufacturers. He was until 1917

A moderate upturn in activity in d cotton gray goods which began on c Wednesday became a bulge of preciable proportions yesterday, when price advances were paid for substantial quantities. Print cloths and broadcloths were sold at 3% cent higher than Wednesday's opening prices, and, at the close yesterday, mills added another cent to their asking prices.

The St. Louisan, Pennsylvania flyer, roared at sixty miles an hour through a thickly populated countryside today with no one in the engine cab. The engineer John L. Breen, 54, and fireman, R. B. Mitchell, 46, had jumped or been blown from the cab in a steam explosion and were dead.

Feeling the time had finally arrived to prepare for their annual Fall display of might and power, the Yankees opened the throttle yesterday and thundered over the green flat of the Stadium at such tremendous speed as to all but sweep the once pretentious Indians into complete oblivion.
The Weather Bureau said tonight a tropical hurricane reached the coast of extreme northeastern Yucatan at 7 P. M., Eastern standard -time.
The Constitutional Convention tonight refused to reconsider the action by which it voted last week to outlaw the use of proportional representation in elections any place in this State.
Exports of iron and steel continued at a high rate in July, but declined sharply from the abnormal figures for the same month last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.
An investigation into the death May 31 of Littleton Kirkpatrick, manufacturer and former Princeton football player, was ordered today by William E. Dowling, chief assistant prosecutor.

The value of United States exports declined about 15 per cent in July from the corresponding month a year ago but more than half of this decline was accounted for by a lower price level, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Thomas Donahue, a former New York police inspector, was found dead this afternoon in the room he was occupying in the Nelson House. Doctors said he succumbed to a heart attack during the night. He was 71 years old.

Grigore Pilipescu, former Rumanian Cabinet Minister, died yesterday after an operation. Born in 1886 and educated in Paris and Zurich, he had been editor of the Bucharest newspaper Epoca for many years, and at one time was president of the 3 Rumanian Telephone Company.

Daily newspapers have been found to be the best media for advertising, according to the Canadian Life Insurance Officers Association, which has just unanimously voted to continue its campaign in newspapers for the nineteenth consecutive. year. The "Life Insurance
The text of Secretary of State Cordell Hull's note to the Mexican Government on the subject of compensation for expropriated property of United States citizens, dated Aug. 22, follows:

John Henry Lewis, 1841/2, of Phoenix, Ariz., world light-heavyweight champion, knocked out Dominick Ceccarelli, 179, of Italy, claimant of the European title in his division, tonight in 1 minute 15 seconds of the third round of a scheduled tenround non-title bout at the Velodrome.

Disestablishment at the Fore River and Boston plants of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., of its employes' representation plan of twenty years' standing was recommended in a report served on the corporation today by the National Labor Relations Board.
The Red Sox today tightened their grip on second place by taking two games from the White Sox, a 1-0 pitching duel and a 9-5 struggle in which the teams piled up thirty hits.
Opposition by the Larchmont Civic Association to a proposed $270,000 PWA school project was announced here today by Walter M. Franklin, president of the association.

Cooler weather found reflection in improved retail trade here yesterday. While the gain was not particularly marked, it was regarded in retail quarters as an encouraging harbinger of rising volume with the approach of the Labor Day turning point. Most retailers have
" Political" members of the Cabinet sat twice today, their second meeting being attended by President Eduard Benes after Premier Milan Hodza had a short conference with Sudeten German leaders.

Cromwell Ave (11-2872), n w dor of 170th St, 89x1l ft; Raelk Holding Corp to D. E. Garage Corp, 1,401 Cromwell Ave; mtg $27,900. 175th St, 764 E (11-2952): Jennie Levy to Fanny Tandeter, 1,879 Prospect Ave; mtg $10,000.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

While the market remained virtually deadlocked awaiting official loan details from Washington, the feature of trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange was the elimination of the October discount, with the near month going to a premium over the July for the first time.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Frederic N. Towers of the law firm of Frost, Meyers Towers has been elected a director of the Lincoln Service Corporation. John Frank Wood was appointed an assistant trust officer in the personal trust department of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

Several hundred foreign delegates and business executives and many agement specialists in this country, attending the Seventh International Management Congress to be held in Washington, Sept. 19 to 23, will visit industrial plants and institutions in more than thirty towns and cities in New England, the Middle West and along the Atlantlc seaboard.
The Rev. Endicott Peabody, 81 years old, headmaster of Groton School, Groten, Mass., suffered three broken ribs today in a taxicab collision.

On the very spot where Wagner composed them, Arturo Toscanini this afternoon conductedd matchless performances of the "Siegfried" idyl and the introduction to the third act of "Die Meistersinger." Thereby he

Fifty delegates representing thirteen countries and forty million persons living in minorities met here today for the twelfth European Minority Congress under the presidency of Dr. Joseph Wilfan, former Slovenian member of the Italian Parliament.

Mexican expropriation of land without provision for "effective payment" constitutes "unadulterated confiscation," which the United States cannot condone, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said in his note of last Monday to Mexico, which was unexpectedly made public tonight.
Baltimore "is one of the flourishing centers of the national vice ring," Herbert M. Brune Jr., independent candidate for Governor, told the Kiwanis Club today.

A bid of $155,000 by John Rosenbloom of New York was the lowest submitted for the renovation of buildings at the proposed merchant marine training school on Hoffman Island, it was announced yesterday. The bids were opened at the Treasury Department's offices, in the Custom House.

The Democratic designation petition of James H. Fay, New Deal opponent of Representative John J. O'Connor in the Sixteenth Congressional District, Manhattan, does not bear sufficient legal signatures to make it valid, O'Connor campaign headquarters charged yesterday.

A. H. Whittemore of Vermillion, former University of South Dakota football coach and a star guard at Brown University in his own football days, died in a hospital here last night. Mr. Whittemore was 60 years of age and had been suffering from diabetes.

Dr. Victor E. Verdades de Faria, Consul General of Portugal at New York, and his wife, Katherine Mahon de Faria, were instantly killed today when their coupe was demolished by a train on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at Proctor's Crossing in West Barnstable.

Under the auspices of William A. Brady and the firm of Bushar Tuerk, a melodrama called "Come Across" will enter rehearsal today for a Sept. 14 premiere at the Playhouse, the event being in part a sentimental reunion; for it was in Mr. Brady's office that Mr. Tuerk started his theatrical career.

Thirty-eight envelopes, containing 296 policy slips bearing 2,192 numbers, were found in the pockets of William Bryan, 25 years old, a Negro, of 200 West 113th Street, when he was arrested yesterday, Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky was told in Harlem Court, when Bryan was arraigned.
Robert Spitzer of 188 Linden I Boulevard, Brooklyn, formerly with the Motor Vehicle Bureau for twenty years and at one time keeper of Borough Hall, died Wednesday in I Utica, N. Y. His age was 86.
Adverse weather today caused a day's postponement of the departure of the big French flying boat Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris for New York on the third leg of a transatlantic experimental flight.
Tenders were invited today by the Secretary of the Treasury for ninetyone-day Treasury bills amounting to about $100,000,000 to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidder.

Mrs. Edith Hedden Allen of 315 East Sixty-eighth Street, widow of the Rev. Dr. John Stevenson Allen, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Portsmouth, N H., where she was spending the Summer. She was 69 years old.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Ruth Cairns Conne, daughter of Mrs. Robert Andrews Cairns of Waterbury, to Dr. Robert Stanley Buol, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Buol of New Britain. They will be married in the Spring.

Two squadrons of United States naval planes emerged from the mist over Rio de Janeiro harbor this morning and flew over the city for an hour. The planes were from the planecarrier Enterprise, twenty-five miles at sea. The thirty-six planes flew in formation offering Cariocans a view they had never witnessed before. At one time the planes manoeuvred forming the three letters. "Rio."

Although Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the Sound View golf star, was the only one who had her sights properly adjusted on the flags at the Women's National course in yesterday's opening round of the women's Long Island medal play championship, today several improved their marksmanship.

Word has been received from London of the marriage there on Tuesday of Miss Helen Safford Bonnell, daughter of Mrs. Henry Houston Bonnell of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Bonnell, C to David Cook Scott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of Providence, R. I.

As a result of testimony at the Hines trial that six policemen had been demoted and transferred because they had interfered in the Dutch Schultz policy racket, the Municipal Civil Service Commission adopted a resolution yesterday to give extra promotion credit to policemen who can establish they have been demoted for good work.

With a bullet through the right temple and powder marks on the head, the body of a man about 35 years old was found early yesterday on a hill hear the Center Drive of Central Park at Sixty-second Street. A .32 caliber revolver was lying beside his right hand.
Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, announced at Camp Smith here today three changes in the commanding personnel of the guard. The changes,
Robert Spitzer of 188 Linden I Boulevard, Brooklyn, formerly with the Motor Vehicle Bureau for twenty years and at one time keeper of Borough Hall, died Wednesday in I Utica, N. Y. His age was 86.
Adverse weather today caused a day's postponement of the departure of the big French flying boat Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris for New York on the third leg of a transatlantic experimental flight.

As a result of testimony at the Hines trial that six policemen had been demoted and transferred because they had interfered in the Dutch Schultz policy racket, the Municipal Civil Service Commission adopted a resolution yesterday to give extra promotion credit to policemen who can establish they have been demoted for good work.

With a bullet through the right temple and powder marks on the head, the body of a man about 35 years old was found early yesterday on a hill hear the Center Drive of Central Park at Sixty-second Street. A .32 caliber revolver was lying beside his right hand.
Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, announced at Camp Smith here today three changes in the commanding personnel of the guard. The changes,

With favorable weather under dun skies scores of swimmers from the Park Department's thirteen pools throughout the city held a meet yesterday at Astoria Park, Queens, to determine the best among them. Late in the afternoon Mayor La Guardia arrived in a Coast Guard plane to join about 3,000 spectators.
Gold imports during the week ended Aug. 19 totaled $49,839,395, the Department of Commerce announced today. Japan accounted for about 35 per cent of this, shipping $17,622,751 in gold here that week.

Action taken by the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange at a special meeting on Wednesday will provide for a vote on the Exchange's reorganization report when it is submitted to the membership for action, instead of permitting the measure to pass through failure of any opposition.

Over the windswept seaside Seawane Club course three teams tied for the medal in the annual memberguest invitation tournament today. Edward H. Muhlfeld and Ken Smith of Oceanside, Dr. Ernest J. Coates and George Van Nostrand of Oakland, and A. C. Giles and Percy E. Furber of Wee Burn each produced a 70, two under par.

Stocks moved down fractions to more than 1 point yesterday and THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks closed lower for the first time since Aug. 13. The opening was fairly strong and active but the strength was short-lived and prices drifted irregularly lower through to closing, with final quotations near the lows of the session.
Three firemen were overcome by smoke early last night when fire destroyed an abandoned brick church at the corner of Hopkinson Avenue and Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

The State of New Jersey has an opportunity to improve substantially its already enviable system of fine highways if the Legislature officially authorizes, before Oct. 1, a referendum at the general election on Nov. 8 on a proposed grant by the Public Works Administration of $27,000,000.

The Federal-State milk marketing program for the New York metropolitan area was approved today by Secretary Wallace and Commissioner Holton V. Noyes of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. The program is to become effective Sept. 1.
Jimmy Foxx, Red Sox "muscle man," made the 2,000th hit of his major league career today, then added two home runs for good measure as the Red Sox split a double-header with the White Sox.

The Works Progress Administration hospital service project which, on orders from Washington, was to have been discontinued yesterday, will operate until Monday, giving the workers scheduled for dismissal two more days of pay, Lieut. Col.

Deposits of chartered banks with the Bank of Canada decreased $101,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, while Dominion government deposits increased $4,327,000, the weekly statement of the bank today showed. The ratio of net reserves to notes and deposit liabilities was 55.23 per cent. The week before it was 54.86.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Terhune of West Milford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Terhune, to Thomas B. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Miller of West Milford.

Young matrons, debutantes of this and recent seasons and young men at home from schools and colleges, comprising a cast of seventy-five, presented the gala performance of the "Hampton Follies of 1938" tonight in the auditorium of the Southampton High School fox the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

Emery Roth Sons, architects, filed yesterday the plans for the eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building to be erected at 140147 Riverside Drive, the block front between Eighty-sixth and Eightyseventh Streets.

Another episode in the series of Summer jewel robberies on Long Island occurred early this morning when a burglar escaped from The Chimneys, the home of Mrs. Christian R. Holmes on Sands Point Road, here, with two rings valued at $1,000 and $125 in cash.

Clarence (Buddy) Combs went on a scoring spree today as he led the Ponolo Polo Club to a 10-7 victory over Evergreen Farms in the first semi-final match of the Norwood Polo Club's eight-goal tournament.

A sharp protest against the shooting down of a Chinese civil passenger airplane piloted by Hugh L. Wood, an American, was made today to the Japanese Government by Joseph C. Grew, American Ambassador at Tokyo, on direct instruction from the government here.

John David, Inc., men's wear chain here, will launch one of its most extensive advertising campaigns in years Labor Day week, to announce that it is handling two new clothing lines, Ralph Ladue, president. announced yesterday.

An authorized State edition of a textbook on driver education, for use in high schools, has been published by the New York State Traffio Commission. Copies will be available at cost next Thursday, through the commission.

The Japanese forces advancing along the Yangtze River banks toward Hankow and those pressing southward toward Nanchang, Kiangsi capital, are suffering enormous depletion as a result of illness, mostly malaria and dysentery and some cholera, despite a rigorous campaign of inoculations.

Following United States and British protests against Japanese censoring of mail and cable and radio messages in Shanghai, the Japanese spokesman said today that the censors had the right to refuse to deliver any class of message.

While the next step in the survey program which goes forward so busily in the North Atlantic area this Summer will be the flight of the sixengined, forty-ton flying boat of Air France, now at the Azores,
Surrounded by friends, his office staff and business associates, August Heckscher celebrated his ninetieth birthday yesterday with a buffet luncheon in his office at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue.

Figures upon the secretary wil showing the volume of stock trans- each regular member a c actions for the account of all mmbers of the New York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 6 were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows:

The English County cricket championship still is undecided and prospects are the race will not be determined until the schedule closes next week. Yorkshire has two matches to play before the 1938 campaign ends while Middlesex, a close second, has one.

Miss Patty Berg, Minneapolis, and Miss Edith Estabrooks of Dubuque, Iowa, a youngster of 17, will battle tomorrow for the women's West ern closed golf championship in a thirty-six-hole final at Olympia Fields Country Club.

Firing a barrage of five birdies, Gene Kunes, curly-headed professional from Philadelphia, today carded a par-shattering 70 to pace a field of nearly 100 golfers in the $3,000 Lake Placid open tournament.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the declaration of the Eastern Utilities Associates, a Massachusetts voluntary association, to Issue and sell an unsecured 3 per cent promissory note for $1,625,000 dated Aug. 1, 1938, and due on Aug. 1, 1941. The note is to be sold to the First National Bank of Boston, for the purpose of refunding outstanding notes of the declarant held by the bank.

The percentage of realty sales being closed for "all cash" is running higher on the lower East Side of Manhattan than in most other sections of the city. The comparatively low prices prevailing in that old district make it easy for properties to be purchased there without mortgage, on an outlay of only a few thousand dollars.

New financing scheduled for next week by fifty-seven municipalities totals $13,689,823, compared with $6,790,661 this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer, which gives the weekly average of new offerings for the year to date as $24,696,026.

THE grasshopper has been grossly libeled in fable. It would be no more surprising to find the Big Bad Wolf a mild-eyed vegetarian than it is to discover the grasshopper really not a thriftless fiddler who thinks the world owes him a living.

Thirty players are expected to report for the opening session of the Brooklyn football club's pre-season practice campaign at Farmingdale, L. I., today. A dozen others are to join the club following all-star games soon to be played here, in Chicago and Providence.

Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency, announced today that receivers of thirteen insolvent national banks had authorized dividend payments of $1,026,800 in the week ended yesterday. These payments were made to 36,879 claimants with proved claims of $14,168,000.

Robert H. Schwartz, 19 years old, of Linden, N. J., received the medal of the National Patriotic Council for first place in an essay contest on "What is the Value of Military Training?" at this afternoon's

The ten tenement buildings at 137-53 Fifty-sixth Street and 677-99 Lexington Avenue were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. They were bought in 2 by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, as plaintiff, for $1,000.

The Constitutional Convention of 1938 adjourned sine die at 3:32 o'clock this afternoon, after it had voted, 105 to 57, to submit its proposals to the people of the State in nine separate propositions.

The Athletics and Browns split another double-header today, St. Louis winning the second game, 6-4, after Philadelphia had pounded three pitchers for an 11-6 decision in the first. Lynn Nelson, who received credit for the first victory, was put on the shelf with an injured arm-when a muscle gave way as he threw a fast ball in the seventh inning.

Women who are members of the North American delegation to the eighth decennial meeting of the International Missionary Council, to be held in Madras, India, from Dec. 13 to 30, will be guests at a dinner on Sept. 6 at Schrafft's, 556 Fifth Avenue.

Seth Bradford Dewey, for twenty years president of Gage Tollner's restaurant, Fulton Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital after an illness of one month. He was 56 years old.

Restoration of Mexican import duties on 189 items to the lower rates in force prior to last January will not bring any appreciable increase in sales from the United States to Mexico until internal economic conditions improve there, it was said in foreign trade circles here yesterday.

Traffic on the northbound Lexington Avenue express line of the I. R. T. was tied up for ten minutes yesterday afternoon when a man described by police as Ralph Ingalls, 50-year-old writer and statistician, of. 72 1/2 Irving Place, fell or jumped to his death in front of a northbound express train at the Fourteenth Street station.

Two questionnaires issued by the German Government are being sent to Germans in the Union of South Africa. All bearers of German passports are required to send to Berlin full personal information and records of military service.

While a number of Bridgeport residents waited to be called by the prosecution as witnesses in the Hines trial today, Lloyd Paul Stryker, attorney for Hines, sent his own aides into the city to check on the background of these witnesses.

George Weinberg, the gangster who ran the policy racket for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, completed his testimony against James J. Hines yesterday after three and a half days on the witness stand.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,157,000 bales, against 1,163,000 a week ago, 1,191,000 two weeks ago, 1,172,000 three weeks ago and 728,000 a year ago, c of which American 648,000 bales, against 658,000 a week ago, 674,000 two weeks ago, 676,000 three weeks ago and 239,000 a year ago.

The policy racket, which has spelled the undoing of more than one man in recent times, has crashed down upon the head of a 41-year-old Negro who, the police say, escaped from a North Carolina chain gang four times.

Vassar College will receive under the will of Eliza Buffington of Madison, filed for probate today, art objects collected by her in years of world travel. Miss Buffington, who died Aug. 13, was a daughter of the late Brig. Gen. A. R. Buffington, chief of ordnance, U.S.A., who died in 1922.

The general public has been instructed to make purchases of tickets for "The Midnight Alarm" performances from companies. Deputy chiefs shall make redistributions of tickets within their respective divisions so that all companies may have a supply on hand for public demand.

The breach that once existed between Mike Jacobs and the Madison Square Garden Corporation, a breach which attained its widest point in June, 1937, when the Garden attempted to prevent the then heavyweight champion of the world, James J. Braddock, from defending his title under Jacobs's promotion, was completely closed yesterday.

Terms of the strike settlement signed by the Collier Advertising Service with the United Carders and Bill Posters, Local 811, on Thursday were made public yesterday by the company in the following statement:
The State Deapartment of Education announced today the names of thirty-nine persons who passed the June examination in veterinary medicine and who will receive licenses to practice that profession:
New York State farmers, by the slender margin of two votes, approved today the proposed Federal marketing agreement, planned to bring higher prices to potato producers.

With a statement that he had been exonerated by a county grand jury, which investigated an egg and vegetable attack on Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, in Military Park, June 4, Deputy Police Chief Philip Sebold today laid criticism of his handling of police at the disturbance to personal antagonism.

A collection of architectural renderings, said to be the only complete record of early New York dwellings and other buildings dating from 1760 to 1835, will be added to the Avery Architectural Library of Columbia University as a permanent loan.
A physically fit youth near Coblenz was sentenced to a week's imprisonment for refusing to accept a job offered to him because he had no desire for the work, according to the publication Arbeitsmann.

Estate, more than $5,000. To Loretta M. Bailey, niece, petitioner, 2,427 Ashby Ave., Berkeley, Calif., jewelry, personal effects and nine-twenty-fourths residue; Gordon J. Burkett, nephew, 19,314 Andoner Blvd., Detroit, Mich., and Leo Burkett, nephew, 732 East Lawrence St., Mishawaka, Ind.,
THE WORKER'S STANDARD OF LIVING. (International Labor Office, 734 Jackson Place, Washington, D. C., 50 cents.) An outline of the problem of comparing standards of living in different countries.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Betty Goldstone, daughter of Mrs. Morris L. Goldstone of Larchmont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Goldstone, to Robert E. White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazarus White of this city and Larchmont.

Stanley Zaksewski, 21 years old, of 209 Second Street, who narrowly escaped death four times in accidents in the last ten years, was drowned this afternoon as he was attempting to dive underneath' a railroad car float in the Hudson River at the foot of Sixth Street.
A diary kept by a son killed in the World War has been received from Germany by Mrs. William Nixon of Geneseo twenty years after he fell tin battle. The return of the diary

The long session of the Constitutional Convention ended yesterday with a wise decision. This was to submit the new Constitution in the form of nine separate and independent propositions, rather than as one all-inclusive document.

A total sued in the pe of 1,384 passenger cars were airconditioned by Class I railroads and the Pullman Company during the year ended July 1, 1938, the Association of American Railroads announced today. Of that number 1,003 were air-conditioned by the railroads and 381 by the Pullman Company.

A price of $12.50 has been established on the new Gem-lectric shaver by the American Safety Razor Company, Brooklyn, officials announced yesterday. While announcement of the new razor had been made several months ago, no price had been definitely set.
The Public Works Administration today allotted giants totaling $1,674,968 and loans of $82,000 to thirty-four approved non-Federal projects having an estimated construction cost, of $3,722,155.

The Constitutional Convention completed its work today with a balance of $233,808.39 left from the $1,350,000 appropriated by the Legislature, according to a statement by the Committee on Contingent Expenses. This surplus, which was hailed by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane, president of the convention, does not take into account expenses to be incurred by publication of the constitutional proposals in newspapers.

James Burkitt Jr. announced here today that he would not emulate his father by trying to speak in Jersey City in defiance of a police ban. James Burkitt Sr. is now serving a six-month sentence at Hudson County penitentiary as the result of an attempt to give an address in Journal Square without a permit.

Owen N. Malone, secretary and treasurer of eleven subsidiary corportions of the Coca-Cola Company, died last night at his home here at the age of 60. A native of Cherokee, Ala., he came to Delaware last year when the company moved the main division of its bottling companies to Wilmington.

Emmons Loom Harness Company of Lawrence, Mass., has leased a plant and will make Charlotte the home of the South's largest factory for textile loom reeds. The Massachusetts concern hats taken over the plant of the Charlotte Manufacturing Company and will retain its entire working force and office personnel.
H. E. Boning of Kansas City, Mo., was elected president of the International Association of Convention Bureaus, which closed its annual convention in the Hotel Ambassador here tonight.

After more than thirteen hours of questioning at Holmesburg County prison yesterday and last night, Coroner Charles H. Hersch admitted early today that he had struck a snag in his efforts to pin down responsibility for the fatal overheating of four convicts last weekend.

As the Saratoga racing season draws to a close today with the running of the Hopeful and the Saratoga Cup, two horses and one economic development are the talk of the Spa. The two horses are El Chico, William Ziegler's sparkling 2-year-old, and War Admiral, the great little campaigner from the Glen Riddle Stable.

After seventeen years on the bench Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud announced yesterday in Bronx Magistrate Court that he had applied for retirement although his term does not expire until 1943. When asked why he was retiring he replied, "Well. I'm 60 years old."

The Brazilian training ship Almairante Saldanha, which left New York early in July for Rio de Janeiro, sailed into harbor today with her flag flying and Captain Washington Perry de Almeida still aboard.

The three-story brownstone house on a plot 20 by 100 feet at 24 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Robert Topping of Sagaponach, N. Y., to Rose Glicksman, who will alter the structure. The Bulkley Horton Company, brokers, negotiated the sale.

Mrs. Reginald Norman entertained a large group with a picnic party at Black Point Farm in Portsmouth tonight. Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr. were hosts at a dinner at Paulholme, and Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Fletcher also had dinner guests at Faxon Lodge.

Winners of $50,000 for the best rules for safe driving, offered by the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, were announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Whitehall Club, 17 Battery Place, at which the three principal winners, who shared $32,500, were present.

Japanese military authorities at Hsinking, the capital of Manchukuo, declare the Russian military preparations near Possiet Bay and in other sectors embrace every form of military fortifications from rifle pits and machine gun nests to emplacements for the heaviest artillery.

Alfred E. Smith's speech today at the Constitutional Convention opposing a single submission of the new Constitution was as follows: Early in the convention there was appointed by the chair a committee, the membership of which was evenly divided between the two political parties.

The statement of the Consolidated Oil Corporation for the first six months of this year, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,000,341 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to 28 cents a share on 13,915,144 common shares.

In the hope of developing new leads to the slaying here Oct. 23, 1935, of Dutch Schultz and three of his aides, Police Chief John H. Harris said today that certain members of the Newark Police Department homicide squad have been detailed to rotate in attendance at sessions of the trial of James J. Hines in New York.

A three-year penitentiary term was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Albert Gross, 39 years old, an ex-convict, of 250 St. Nicholas Avenue for defrauding Irving Schachs, a drug store manager, of 1,650 Lexington Avenue of $27.

The 1940 Olympic Games will begin on July 20, according to an announcement made by the organizing committee today. The scheduling of the Olympics on their traditional midsummer dates by Finland is sure to be welcome news to many athletes and officials in this country, as the United States team generally includes a large number of college athletes who will be on vacation at that time.

Turpentine firm, 22 1/2c; no sates; receipts, 596 barrels; no shipments; stock, 46,109 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 404; receipts, 2,697; no shipments; stock, 228,114. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.85; E, $4.20; F, G, H, I, K, $4.373; M, $4.37 1/2-.40; N, $5.25-.30; WG, $5.50; WW and X, $6.30.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert imposed a fine of $300 yesterday upon Armour Co., meat packers, when the company, through counsel, entered a plea of guilty to six counts of an information charging that it violated the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906 by misbranding putter.

Lambs and hogs strengthened today on comparatively small supplies. Steers and yearling cattle trade was a lifeless affair. All slaughter classes of cattle sold slowly and weak to lower. the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Strictly choice-fed steers and yearlings were absent but the demand had been well satisfied with increased supplies earlier in the week and even local buyers were very indifferent.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reelected in the following list of representative high-grade State city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
The Navy Department announced today the award of contracts for the purchase of motor gasoline and fuel oil at a total cost of $195,111.

Another unit in Harry Young's vaudeville dates at Randalls Island Stadium went on last night before more than 2,000 people. Dedicated in part to the works of Irving Berlin, in part just to vaudeville, the program was well received.

Councilman Louis Hollander announced yesterday that he was accepting the post of chairman of the American Labor party's campaign committee to elect Louis Waldman Kings County judge. Mr. Waldman, who is seeking the Republican nomnation for the same office, is being opposed by a Republican district leader, Harold L. Turk,

Now that the United States Government has gone out in the open market to purchase wheat for export, the question uppermost in the trade is how will it affect the domestic and world markets for that cereal.

Miss Hope Lilian Holland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Willard Holland of this place, was married this afternoon to Cornelius Van Reypen Bogert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bogert of Bogota, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. J. John Sharkey performed the ceremony.

The regular Democratic organization in Bay Ridge went on record yesterday for the nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. as its candidate for Governor on the Democratic ticket. Mr. Bennett, who lives near the Democratic Club, has been an avowed candidate for the nomination for the last three months.

New bond financing for the week ended yesterday was featured by the offering of $55,000,000 of public utility obligations which brought the total for the week to $72,762,000. This compared with $7,940,685 in new bonds marketed in the preceding week, and $88,707,000 for the week ended on Aug. 12.

Joshua Nilo, 40 years old, an unemployed barber who has been living at 141 West Fourth Street, was arrested yesterday as a fugitive from justice from Pottsville, Pa. According to the police, Nilo is alleged to have aided Joseph Bruno, Republican leader in Kelayres, Pa.,

Otto B. Schoenfield, former world's champion fencer, died today at the age of 66. He won the championship at the Paris Exposition of 1900. He had also won handicap wrestling matches with the champions Tom Jenkins and Frank Gotch.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Con- ca troller, sold yesterday to twenty- be six banks and trust companies $30,000,000 of revenue bills of New York City at an interest rate of 0.35 per cent. The bills, dated Aug. 29, are payable Nov. 1, 1938, from the Oct. 1 tax installment. Proceeds of the sale will be used for the th city's current requirements.

A raiding party from Borough headquarters in Manhattan swooped down on a policy bank last night, confiscated 18,632 policy slips listing 319,013 individual plays and arrested eight persons, including two women who police said had testified at the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader.

Walter J. Grant, general merchandise agent of the Boston Maine Railroad and former assistant to the vice president of the Acme Fast Freight, Inc., and Shippers Service Express, died today at the Forest Hills Hospital at 40 years of age.

The biggest military review ever held in The Netherlands will open, on Monday, the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of Queen Wilhelmina's reign, which falls on Sept. 6. The royal palace in Amsterdam has been entirely renovated for the fate. Formerly it contained no electric lights,

Republican leaders from thirteen Midwestern States converged on Indiana today for an old-time spirit revival which, party leaders hoped and predicted, would start the current toward impressive victories in Congressional and Gubernatorial races next Fall.

The United States liner President Harding, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has on board nine wounded veterans of the International Brigade in Spain. They are Elijah Botuk, Walter Callion, Alen Duerden, Morris Dashovsky, Peter Gaspar, Irving Morrison, Albert Prago, Themistocles Saligopoulos and Louis Zlotnick.

Trading was generally active to fair in local markets yesterday. The lamb market was higher, veal hindsaddles and fresh pork strong to higher, other classes and cuts steady to strong. All kosher markets opened higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The amendment outlawing proportional representation was termed "disgraceful" and its passage by the Constitutional Convention "shocking" by Mrs. Samuel Sloan Duryee, president of the Women's City Club, in a statement yesterday.

Lady FisherSmith, one of the leading political and social workers in Yorkshire, died today at her home in Halifax. Appointed a magistrate in 1920, she was a strong advocate of children's courts and the probation system.

The arrest of the first employer in New Jersey charged with violation of the recently amended Minimum Wage Law of the State was made here this afternoon. David Wishnevsky, operator of a small laundry here, was held in $500 bail for grand jury action by Dover Township Recorder Tom L. Corwell, charged with failing to keep a record book of employes' hours and not paying wages in keeping with the New Jersey Minimum Wage Law.

Mass formation flying and tactical manoeuvres by eighteen P-35 Seversky Army Air Corps single-seater fighters will be demonstrated for-thirty minutes daily throughout the National Air Races at Cleveland, Sept. 3-5, according to the War Department.

The Phils walloped the wobbling Pirates for the third straight time today, 6 to 4, clustering five runs in the fifth inning to come from behind. Lefty Al Smith, who like Bill Hallahan yesterday had not won a game all season, handcuffed the jittery Pirate hitters and limited them to seven safe blows.

Lexington Ave, 192-96, 67.8x100 irreg; Continental Bank Trust Co. trustee, to Union Dime Savings Bank, due and interest as per bond; $48,000. Payson Ave, 83, 31.3x100; Elizabeth Rocco to Carmino Rocco, 205 W 34th St, 5 yrs, 6%; S5,000. 2d Ave, 1,174-76, 50.5x89.6 irreg; 1,176-78 Second Ave Corp to Excelsior Savings Bank. 5 yrs, 5%; $15,500.
Ward's Automotive Reports said today in its weekly survey of the motor-car industry that it estimated that $60,000,000 had been spent to retool factories for production of the new models.

Miss Nancy Edith Proskauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richman Proskauer of this place and New York, was married here today in the garden of her parents' home to Donald Dryfoos, son of Mrs. Jack A. Dryfoos, also of New York, and the late Mr. Dryfoos. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman of New York .

A 10-cent fare for a ride to or from the World's Fair grounds in Flushing over the city's Independent Subway System is still a possibility, it was disclosed yesterday. Specifications for the turnstiles to be installed in the World's Fair station of the city system at Horace Harding Boulevard call for a mechanism adapted for a ten-cent "entrance fare" and a five-cent "exit fare."

Miss Marjorie O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. O'Connor of 1,107 Fifth Avenue and Larchmont, N. Y., will have her four sisters among the members of her bridal party when she is married on the morning of Sept. 7 in St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, to James T. Naughton.

Quite unexpectedly three Ministers of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's Cabinet were changed today. Although no political importance is attached to this change, the general public, in view of the situation in Czechoslovakia, is far from reassured, particularly in the case of the Minister of War.

The Bees took the third game of the four-game series with the Reds today, 6 to 1, as Johnny Lanning allowed seven hits. Paul Derringer was sent to the showers in the ninth after a threerun eighth-inning uprising.
Blaming "terroristic tactics" by Yellow Cab Company strikers, independent cab drivers took their cars off the streets today, leaving Philadelphia for eighteen hours without metered taxicab service.

The liquor license of the Chalet Bar and Grill, 1,288 Sixth Avenue, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, just north of Radio City, has been revoked by the State Liquor Authority because the "premises were operated as a' clip joint," it was announced yesterday.

Close finishes marked the harness racing at the eighty-sixth annual fair of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society today. The 2-year-old pace was taken by Derry Dale, a brown horse owned by L. T. Gustin of Holicong, Pa.

The stock markets here were quiet and generally firm today. Yesterday's improvement in Wall Street assisted sentiment. Gilt-edge issues were somewhat hesitant, and among foreign bonds Austrian liens suffered small declines in an almost idle list.

Mrs. Samuel Dodds, the wife of an educator and the mother of three, including Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, died suddenly yesterday in her home here. She was 77 years old. Her husband, 80 years old, is recovering from injuries received a month ago in an automobile accident.

The American Federation of Labor Non-Partisan Committee reiterated last night that it would take no stand on candidates for Congress and the State Legislature until after the primaries. No endorsement of any primary candidate has been given, it was said.

A number of homes in the Bronx were reported yesterday as having been sold by various owners. Among them were the four dwellings at 2,152-58 Story Avenue, near Casthe Hill Avenue, which were sold by the Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Association to Silas Broadhead, John Cassidy, John Grosso and William Fixley, respectively.

Almost the entire population of this small city turned out this afternoon to welcome the members of the three teams, Cuban, British and American, who will compete in the second international tuna angling matches for the Alton B. Sharp Trophy.

The Summer social activity in Northwestern Connecticut will be climaxed this week-end with the sixth annual Lakeville Horse Show to be held tomorrow and Sunday on the George N. Miner farm here. With 131 entries for the varied program beginning at 9:30 A. M. tomorrow, the show will be the largest in the history of the event.

Mrs. M. Schaub and Jimmie Hines of Lakeville and Mrs. A. Granger and Henry Rogan of Sound View divided the top honors today in the Long Island pro-ladies' Scotch foursome handicap tournament at the Sound View Golf Club. Both teams turned in low nets of 69.

The Lincoln Building, 60 East Forty-second Street, had a gross income for the first six months of this year of approximately $916,000 and a net income of $367,000, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. Occupancy is said to be around 80 per cent and thus far this year $30 per $1,000 has been paid on the $13,351,000 in bonds outstanding.

Miss Charlotte Epstein, chairman of the United States Olympic Women's Swimming Committee and long a leader in women's swimming activities, died yesterday in her apartment at the Hotel Ruxton, 50 West Seventy-second Street, after an illness of eleven months. She was 53 years old.

A New York syndicate, represented by William I. and A. Alpert, attorneys, purchased from the Jamaica Savings Bank the taxpayer at 621-25 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, L. I. Purchase was for cash above a mortgage of $31,500 for five years with interest at 4 per cent.

The Rev. Dr. William G. Ivie, 78year-old chaplain of the Police Department and rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Conselyea Street, near Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, for nearly half a century, was taken to St. John's Hospital in Brooklyn with an abdominal ailment yesterday morning.

Miss Elaine Fischell of Santa Monica, Calif., captured the girls' Eastern grass-court tennis championship yesterday at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, when she defeated the firstseeded Miss Jane Wagner of Cincinnati, 6-2, 6-4.

A 27-year-old building custodian of the New Rochelle Board of Education today claimed the amateur marathon golf record after he had played 235 holes between 5:40 A. M. and 7:55 P. M. here on the Broadmoor Country Club links.

Theodore Dreiser leaned against the railing of the Hotel George Washington roof yesterday and, with the morning sun shimmering his white hair, quietly tore the state of American literary criticism to pieces. Sixty-seven years old today,

Judge Myron Westover ruled today that Georgia McNally McNutt is the legal widow of William Slavens McNutt, the writer, who died on Jan. 25. Judge Westover held that Mr. McNutt's Mexican divorce, obtrained in 1926, and his subsequent marriage to Louise Tanner Glorius, were illegal.

Billy Clark, 20-year-old Ridgewood, N. J., golfer, succeeded a friend, Wilson Flohr, defending titleholder, as junior metropolitan golf champion today. Clark bowed in the final a year ago at Englewood to Flohr, his former room-mate at Dartmouth, but today the tall,

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market continues extremely dull both in the East and in the West. The few sales reported are for small quantities and usually at prices which are on the soft side, although the yielding in prices has been comparatively little.

Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol, Women's New Jersey Golf Association champion, led a field of forty-nine to win low gross honors with a card of 37, 43--80 in the weekly one-day tournament of the association over the picturesque Somerset Hills course today.
Realty activity centering in Harlem was featured yesterday by deals in which savings banks continued to unload their holdings in that section of Manhattan.

Mayor La Guardia, dedicating the Fire Fighter, new 583-ton pride of the city's marine fire division, at Staten Island yesterday, morning, told several hundred persons that the new boat typified the end of the entrenched favoritism that,

Arthur (Dutch SchuItz) Flegenheimer is a ghost at the Hines trial, but ample testimony is accumulating on the record to give the public what probably is its first accurate picture of a powerful New York City gang leader.

As of late yesterday afternoon the League of New York Theatres had received no formal complaint from any of its members concerning the proposed October tour of "Prologue to Glory," under the auspices of the Federal Theatre Project and Lee Shubert.

The technique of "trigger men" in big-time gangs was discussed yesterday by George Weinberg in testimony that covered such matters as the etiquette of "packing a rod." What was surprising in the picture was its fidelity to the classic Hollywood version.

Eric La Guardia, 7-year-old son of the Mayor, was quoted yesterday as having expressed the personal opinion that President Roosevelt is not "so hot." Despite the reported opinion, however, he has a strong curiosity to see the Chief Executive, and today,

Completing negotiations under way for some time, W. Laurence Dickey today stepped out as president and editor of The Kansas City Journal-Post, and Marion B. Sharp did likewise as vice president and general manager.

Ortello William (Ted) West, 45year-old County Highway Superintendent from Coshocton, Ohio, won the Grand American Handicap trap shoot title today, and Mrs. George Peters of Springfield, Ohio, won the feminine division of the clay target world series.
Twentyone Arabs, including two children, were killed this morning and thirty-seven were wounded when a bomb exploded In a vegetable market in Jaffa.
The Tigers advanced within a game and a half of the Senators today in their battle for a first division berth, winning the second of the three-game series, 9 to 3, behind Al Benton's steady hurling.
Delicate inquiry among the La Guardia commissioners disclosed yesterday that the administration was running low on public errors of judgment thinly clothed in the best of intentions,

The two standout horses of this stormy meeting will go to the post tomorrow in the rich Hopeful and historic Saratoga Cup, in what is hoped by all will be a happy conclusion to a session that has tried the patience of many.

The field in the New Jersey State public links championship was cut to sixteen after two rounds over the 7,000-yard River Vale Country Club course today. Among the casualties was Mike Petrone, defending champion.

The C. I. O. was challenged today to contradict charges made by an A. F. of L. official that many of its organizers were Communists. The challenge was made by Chairman Dies of the Committee on UnAmerican Activities, in a letter to E. L. Oliver of labor's Non-Partisan League, political arm of the C. I. O.

Cooler weather aided retail trade toward the close of the week, with the result that the decline under a year ago was somewhat smaller than for the preceding week. Department store executives estimated that sales here averaged about 13 per cent lower, which compares with the drop of 14.3 per cent reported yesterday by the local Federal Reserve Bank for the week ended Aug. 20.

An audience of 4,500 persons attended the performance of "Carmen" last night at Jones Beach. The title part was sung by Hilda Kosta. Pasquale Ferrara had the tenor role of Don Jose, while Mario Cozzi, baritone, appeared as Escamillo.

An order was signed last night by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora requiring the Board of Elections to show cause Tuesday why it should not throw out a petition designating State Senator Leon A. Fischel, Democrat,

A Loyalist communique today tells of a further strong advance in the Estremadura sector in Southwestern Spain. It sums up a full month of successful fighting in the Ebro sector, where again today the lines are said to have held against all Rebel attacks.

As flowers drifted earthward from planes droning overhead, funeral services were held today for Commander Frank Hawks in the sunparlor of his home, Hawks' Nest. Some 300 friends, including many who had shared air adventures with him, attended the services for the speed flier killed Tuesday night in the crash of a small commercial plane at East Aurora, N. Y.

Reports that details of the government loans on cotton night be announced before Monday and that the terms would turn the new crop into loan channels unless market prices were more attractive, brought aggressive buying yesterday by one or two commission houses on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange were irregular yesterday in dull trading. The turnover amounted to $4,429,625, compared with $5,282,575 on Thursday. Interest in the Treasury issues continued at a low ebb.

Rates and schedules of the passenger and freight service between the east coasts of North and South America that will be started on Oct. 8 by the Maritime Commission were announced yesterday by Commander Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, operator of the service.

Announcement made today after the close of the Board of Trade by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration that the government would buy choice varieties of hard Winter and soft Pacific Coast cash wheat for export threw the domestic grain trade into a furor.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Tomorrow will be the last Sunday but one of the Summer season in the churches. Labor Sunday, which will be Sept. 4, will mark the formal close of vacation programs. Thereafter more than half of the city's pastors will be back from their vacations and the Winter's program will be under way.
The Weather Bureau reported that a Caribbean hurricane passed near the southeastern coast of Mexico today and headed westward across the Bay of Campeche toward the lower Central Mexican coast.

With C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N. J., and Bolton Landing, medalist and five-time winner, eliminated in the second round, Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot today led the way into the semifinals of the Sagamore Golf Club's eighth annual invitation tournament.

The appointment as deputy precurement officers of forty-two representatives of distributors, who will assist in the purchase of miscellaneous garments for distribution to the needy by the Works Progress Administration, was announced yesterday by T. J. Forde, Treasury Procurement Officer for New York State.

The Rev. John K. Balkunas of Maspeth was re-elected president of the American Lithuanian Roman Catholic Priests' League at a meeting held in the Hotel New Yorker, according to an announcement made yesterday.

THERE are times when a man can sit at ease and there are other times when he must stand corrected. However, it's one way of learning. The following is offered in evidence: "Sir: Your column on chess contained some 'howlers' that remind me that chess pictures in art galleries frequently--and movie 'close-ups' of chess games almost invariably--show the chess board or pieces in impossible positions--that is, impossible under the laws of the game.

LIEUTENANTS-From commands indicated to 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Sept. 1, 1938: T. P. Browne .....46 J. J. Fox....5thDiv. SERGEANT Joseph F. Dunn, from 78th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn-Richmond, assigned to duty in Felony Court, Brooklyn, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., Sept. 1.

The textbook Long Island State Park Commission announced today that effective immediately the bringing of beer in kegs or cases of wines or hard liquor into the State parks of Long Island will not be permitted. Beer in bottles or cans and cocktails in thermos bottles are allowed at the discretion of police officials, according to C. R. Blakelock, secretary.

Employers received official assurance today that they could continue to employ boys and girls of 16 to 18 years of age until the Federal Children's Bureau decided formally that the occupation involved was hazardous or unhealthy.

W. Va., Aug. 26.-The sixty-fifth annual Lee Monument benefit ball took place tonight at the Greenbrier, bringing to a close the observance of Robert E. Lee week at this resort. More than 500 persons attended the event.
Plans are in process here for a dramatization of unemployment, in a motion picture to be made for and distributed by the Federal Government. No definite commitments have been made, however.

Miss Alice Marguerite Scott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Scott of this place, was married this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church of Upper Montclair to William Gamble Wood, son of Charles E. Wood of Montclair and the late Mrs. Wood.

Elsmere Pl (11-2985), n s, 88 ft e of Crotona Pkway, 104x101: Hope Conracting Corp to Elsmere Land Corp, 899 E 169th St; mtg $95,475. Washington Ave. 1,141 (9-2388); Minnie Iammrino to Giuseppe Toscano, 1,141 Washington Ave. 228th St (17-4852), s s, 280 ft e of Barnes Ave, 37x114; Peter Bavusi to Frank Bavusi, 826 E 228th St. Eastchester Rd, 2,413 (16-4477); John L. Coyle, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Edward Augustus Crowninshield, connoisseur of porcelain and furniture, died yesterday at his residence, 333 East Sixty-eighth Street. He was 68 years old. Mr. Crowninshield was the son of Frederic Crowninshield, an artist.

Meadow Brook polo was curtailed to one members' match today, with Winston Guest and two of his Jaguar team-mates playing an 8-to-8 tie with the veteran Earle W. Hopping's White riders at the neighboring army polo center, Mitchel Field.

With the newly ambitious Cubs giving them many a helpful push, the Dodgers today continued diligently to dig their way toward the National League basement. Before a ladies' day crowd of nearly 33,000, they dropped their third straight to the Bruins, 7-3, and ran their losing streak to six games.

For a day in the midst of the thirty-ninth National Automobile Show to be held Nov. 11-17 in Grand Central Palace, visiting car manufacturers and distributors in foreign countries will be guests of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, sponsors of the show, it was announced yesterday.

Howard Rathe Ickes, commercial artist with the Ruthrauf Ryan advertising agency in New York, died last night in his home here at the age of 51. Born in Deadwood, S. D., he was a distant relative of Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes.

Insisting that the forty-hour law must be made flexible so that there will be no risk of a failure in the national defense or economic recovery, Premier Edouard Daladier today pushed more extreme members of the Left Popular Front into a corner, causing them to defer their final answer until tomorrow.

President Roosevelt put an end today to rumors of a rift between the White House and Postmaster General Farley over the "purge" of Democratic critics of the New Deal by announcing "complete agreement as usual" on the subjects canvassed in their conference yesterday.

George H. Houston, president of proved within t the Baldwin Locomotive Works for ten years, resigned yesterday, the resignation to take effect on Sept. 30. The board of directors at its meeting in Philadelphia accepted the resignation and announced that Charles E. Brinley, a member of the board and of the executive committee, had been appointed an acting vice president with executive powers.
