A Cleveland WPA worker and a railroad man from Oregon fought their way into the final of the national public links golf championship today, with one of the victories representing the greatest comeback in the tournament's seventeen-year history.

At his own request the Rev. Dr. Wilbert W. White, 75 years old, has been relieved of the financial responsibility of the Biblical Seminary, 235 East Forty-ninth Street, which he founded thirty-eight years ago and of which he has ever since been the president.

Under gray skies and amid a downpour of rain the visit of Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, to Berlin ended this afternoon, although the Regent's state tour of Germany will not close until tomorrow evening at Nuremberg.

The expulsion of Bishop Johann Baptist Sproll from his Rottenburg diocese provoked a strong protest in today's Osservatore Romano, Vatican organ. It terms the action "the latest violation of the concordat between the Holy See and Germany."
A noble experiment born of the desperate pitching situation which surrounds the Giants went awry at Sportsman's Park today and the Terrymen lost a glowing chance to gain on the faltering Pirates.

Jack Cummins of Akron, Ohio, came from behind in a spectacular finish today to defeat Larry Warren, Philadelphia Country Club, 1 up, in the second round of the twenty-fifth annual Buckwood Trophy golf tournament of the Shawnee Country Club.

Speaking in behalf of Ernst Kundt, Sudeten German representative, Dr. David told the Minority Congress here today that the present international situation prevented his discussing the Sudeten German problem, as he could not afford to risk being misunderstood or misinterpreted.

The United States liner American Farmer sailed yesterday afternoon for London, bearing the ashes of Malcolm McKenzie. late executive officer of the ship, who died a week ago at the Marine Hospital on Staten Island.
Thomas W. Phelps, editor of Barron's for two years, will become a general partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Francis I. du Point Co. on Sept. 1, the firm announced yesterday.

Republicans of the nation should not endorse Democrats for election this year merely because the Democrats have won for themselves a place on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, Allen W. Dulles, Republican organization designee in Manhattan's Sixteenth Congressional District, contended last night in a nation-wide radio address.

A visitor from Ohio who recently spent ten days in New York charges in a letter published on this page yesterday that the people here know amazingly little about their city. He can think of no other city where the inhabitants are so poorly qualified to help out the stranger.

A pair of Australian sculling huskies threw a scare into Bob Pearce, the world professional champion from Hamilton, on the Canadian national exhibition course tonight before Pearce knocked aside their challenges in quartermile races.
Gross assets, $35,577; net, $34,877. To Virginia M. Freeman, Anna A. Zisch and Julia V. Evergood, daughters, equally. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $13,024. A. B. Halliday, attorney, 545 5th Ave.

Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas has come from Newport to the Savoy-Plaza. Dr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Boots of 993 Park-Avenue are at the Manoir Richelieu, Murray Bay, Que. Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Grasselli have arrived from Wilmington and are at the Plaza.
The Association of American Rail- less a majority roads recommended today the appointment of M. Roland Reed of Harrisburg, Pa., as the railroads' representative on the Railroad Retirement Board.

Hemmed in by a Ladies' Day crowd of 37,139 and seemingly caught in a net from which there loomed no escape, Oscar Vitt's harassed Indians did a most astonishing thing yesterday as they resumed their futile struggle with the Yankees in the second successive double-header at the Stadium.

The fast pace of the Eastern College All-Stars produced the first casualty of the week at Peddie School today when James Bowman, Holy Cross center, sprained his back and was ordered to rest until next Monday. Bowman sustained the injury during the live tackling drill in the morning workout, but did not become aware of it until he tried to straighten up in the locker room.

Assigning international complications as the reason for the shift, Metro has abandoned plans for immediate production of Robert Sherwood's "Idiot's Delight" as a vehicle for Norma Shearer, and probably will replace it on the schedule with Clare Boothe's "The Women."

The Public Service Commission has authorized the South Bay Consolidated Water Company, Inc., to extend the maturity date of $400,000 of Great South Bay Water Company first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due Nov. 1, 1938, to Nov. 1, 1949. Great were assumed in 1935 by the South Bay Consolidated Water Company, a subsidiary of the Federal Water Service Corporation.

Orders booked by the furniture industry in July were 45 per cent higher than in June, and the decline from July, 1937, Was narrowed to 27 per cent, the best year-to-year comparison recorded thus far in 1938, according to figures issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
The Commerce Department announced today that exports of foodstuffs during July aggregated $37,962,000, or more than double the $17,361,000 of such exports during July, 1937.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I want to call attention to the fact that your boxing writer seemed to agree emphatically with two of the three officials who voted for Armstrong and disagree just as emphatically with the one who voted for Ambers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the Atlantic Refining Company, Philadelphia, had filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of fifteenyear debentures due on Sept. 1, 1953.

Since her arrival in the metropolitan district Mrs. Harry McNaughton, the former Marion Turpie of New Orleans, has scored many a golf triumph, but none of them compared to what she accomplished today when she annexed the Long Island women's fifty-four-hole medal play title at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club.

Mrs. Amelia Steinhardt of the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn, social worker who was active in many borough charities, died Thursday night of a heart attack in the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. She was 84 years old.

Magistrate Overton Harris in Jefferson Market Court yesterday held two men, accused of having policy slips in their automobiles, in $500 bail each. One of the men, Joseph A. Walsh, 38 years old, of 31-63 Forty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, was arrested in his car Thursday afternoon on Twenty-second Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues.

The first concrete step toward ending labor's war since negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization broke down last December was taken here this week at a secret meeting attended by William Green, president of the A. F. of L., and three executives of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. O. affiliate.
The logic of Secretary Hull's reply to the Mexican note of Aug. 3 is so devastating as to leave the Mexican Government's position on the question of its land seizures without legal or moral support.

Dr. James Robert Nelson died Wednesday in Kingston, where he was an eye and throat specialist for many years. Born in Cambridge, Mass., 90 years ago, he was graduated from the College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1869.

Led by umbrellas, parasols and canes, which had an increase of 33.9 per cent, five divisions of local department stores showed sales rises in July over the corresponding figures for 1937, according to the figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The last part of your editorial on the Interborough subway accident reiterates the oft-mentioned warnings for passengers to keep their hands and arms away from the train doors. This advice is less applicable to the Interborough than to either of the other two subway companies.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, replied to charges made at the convention of the New York State Federation of Labor in Buffalo that she and the NLRB were biased in favor of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
Washington Square glowed with light and echoed with music last night as the WPA Federal Art Project in New York City staged a carnival of the arts.

Beverly John Reynolds, who said he was beaten by pickets during a labor dispute at the plants of the Eagle Pencil Company and Niagara Paper Box Company, on July 8, has instituted a personal injury suit in Supreme Court for $50,000 against the- officers of two unions and fifteen individuals.

Adequate care for all veterans of willing the army, navy and marines, launched whether they serve during peace or war, was demanded by the Army and Navy Union of the United States of America in a resolution adopted at its fiftieth annual convention in the Hotel Jefferson here tonight.

Radio Attractions, Inc., transcribed radio programs, in RKO Building, Rockefeller Center. Helena Penrose-J. H. Edgette, Inc. antique dealers, store at 904 3d Ave; S. Abrahams, broker. Newman, Decor. Inc., picture frames, in 19 W 24th St: Girdamo Russo, parking of automobiles, building at 422-6 E 104th St; Meryle Publishing Co and Humorous Publishing Co, greeting cards, in 55 W 16th St: Blattan Weber, employment agency, in 1,243 Lexington Ave;

The verbal orders of the Commanding General, of July 1, 1937, announcing the promotion, of Capt. David J. Loria, EngrRes., who was ordered to active duty at Fort DuPont, Del., for the period June 20, 1937 to July 3, 1937, to Major, to date from July 1, 1937, date of his acceptance, are confirmed and made of record.

Ten years ago today, in Paris, fifteen nations solemnly signed the Kellogg-Briand pact renouncing war as an instrument of national policy. By the close of 1930 this act of renunciation had been affirmed and ratified by sixty-one sovereign states.

While future commitments continued light in the principal wholesale markets, heavy demand from retailers who found original orders insufficient to cover more active consumer buying gave support to volume this week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly survey.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday he was pleased by the improvements undertaken by the WPA on Staten Island and with the progress made on them. He made a six-hour inspection of sixteen of the projects in company with Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, WPA administrator.

President Roosevelt yesterday appointed Donald W. Smith to the National Labor Relations Board over protests of William Green and independent unions. [Page 1.] A new move for peace between the C. I. O. and A. F. L. was made at a secret meeting Monday, William Green revealed at Atlantic City. [Page 28.]

While eighteen patients and a large group of visitors in a sixth-floor ward of the French Hospital at 326 West Thirtieth Street watched in horror, a patient in the ward dashed to a window soon after 3 P. M. yesterday, plunged through a screen and fell six stories to his death.

Mr. and Mrs. Bryan S. Reid of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Mary Reid Chatilion, to Russell Trufant Foster of Cleveland, son of Dr. and Mrs. William T. Foster of Newton, Mass.

The Public Works Acministration punished seven California communities today for engaging Glenn E. Miller to speed action on project applications. Acting administrator Howard A. Gray said investigation disclosed the six cities and one county involved paid amounts aggregating at least $7,100 to Mr. Miller,

The new frame and stucco house with approximately seven acres of land on Quarry Road, North Castle, Westchester County, formerly owned by the Johnsonfamily, was purchased by Nelson Thompson of the Homelite Corporation,

Italian and German shipyards are building the backbone of a Philippine merchant marine. The government-owned Philippine National Bank recently loaned $3,500,000 to the Hijos de la Rama Company to finance construction of four ships for transocean and interisland trade.
The Commercial Credit Corporation of New York has filed with the State Banking Department a request to change the location of its White Plains branch from 151 East Post Road to 8 Church Street.

The entries of Donald Scott of Canaseraga won seven firsts in eight events they started today in the first program of the annual two-day Genesee Valley Breeders Association horse show. Maxwell Glover of Geneseo also did well, taking three blues, a second, third and fourth ribbon.

Several leases for space in buildings on Park Avenue were included in the contracts for residential space reported by brokers yesterday. Among those who took apartments was Robert S. Pirie of Carson, Pirie, Scott Co., who leased an eleven-room penthouse suite at 130 East End Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agent.

By coincidence or otherwise a great part of the British Home Fleet will reach its fighting stations at Invergordon in the far north of Scotland during the week of the Nazi party congress at Nuremberg.

Yesterday a chartered motor vessel carrying nearly a hundred invited guests and today three planes cartrying Governor Charles C. F. Dundas and an official party went to Hatchet Bay to witness the launching of a cold storage ship and the opening of an extensive farming enterprise started by Austin Levy, a Rhode Island manufacturer.

Caleb Hatch, known most of his life by his stage name, Harry Fielding, died shortly before midnight Thursday in the Maine General Hospital at the age of 86. He and his wife had lived with their daughter, Mrs. Pauline Fielding Stephens of Peaks Island, since he retired from the theatre.

Stocks of all oil products on the Pacific Coast, except those held at sales and service stations, on July 31 were 150,480,702 barrels, an increase of 1,510,830 from the total of 148,96??,872 on June 30, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

Magistrate Charles Solomon in Brooklyn Traffic Court yesterday suspended for ten days the driver license of Alfonso Baccio, 51 years old, of 2,922 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, a traffic violator whom he described as "a total illiterate."

Alfred E. Smith as an elder statesman gave a lecture on practical politics today to the delegates of the Constitutional Convention. As Republicans and Democrats alike listened in thoughtful silence, the former Governor ended allchance of submission of the new Constitution as a single document by asserting that such a move would alienate

Staging a three-run rally in the ninth inning that was topped off by Frankie Kelleher's single with the bases filled, the Newark Bears tonight romped to a 5-to-4 victory over the Jersey City Giants before a crowd of 11,597.

Senator Sheppard, chairman of the Cohen Committee on Campaign Expenditures, threatened today to ask action by the Department of Justice if the Workers Alliance of America carried out its plan to raise a $50,000' political fund from WPA workers to aid the campaign of members of Congress favorable to relief measures.
Twenty persons were seriously wounded today in a fight between students, taxicab drivers and police in front of the Medical School of the University of Mexico.
William A. Burke, Mayor of Garfield from 1922 until 1927, died this morning of a heart attack at the age of 53. He was visiting his sister, Miss Mary C. Burke of Passaic, when he was stricken.
Following was the roll-call on the proposal to submit the new State Constitution to the people in nine sections:

Volney E. Lacy, naval architect and for many years secretary of the Rochester Yacht Club, died last night in General Hospital. He was 55 years old. Born in Lansing, Mich., Mr. Lacy was a graduate of Massachusetts Institute of Technology and specialized in naval architecture and marine engineering as applied to yachts and gas-propelled boats.

Edith Wharton's last novel, "The Buccaneers," has gone into a second printing three weeks before the date set for publication, according to an announcement from AppletonCentury, who will publish it on Sept. 16.

Many parties were given be Mrs. here today preliminary to the close of Mr. of the racing season tomorrow. Mr. and Mrs. John C. Clark entertained at a luncheon at the Trackside Restaurant for Mr. and Mrs. Alex B. Hagner, Randall H. Hagner, G. Tinsley Garnett and Robert C. Winmill, all of Warrenton, Va.

New Hampshire and Vermont celebrated today the award to the Chesterfield-Brattleboro Bridge as the most beautiful medium-sized bridge built last year. The award was bestowed by the American Institute of Steel Construction and a stainless-steel plaque was presented by F. H. Frankland,
This is the form in which the nine proposals for amending the Constitution will appear on the voting machines this Fall:

Mexican newspapers today strongly attacked the United States note that insisted upon arbitration or prompt and adequate payment for United States properties nationalized. The note, published in full, caused widespread consternation here.
Cotton-mill activity held steady last week, in line with the normal seasonal tendency, and the adjusted index was unchanged at 127.6. The figure was 141.9 for the week ended Aug. 21, 1937.

A Negro who described himself as James Hines, 30 years old, of 392 Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of possessing a policy slip.

When Robert Lafferty, 17, of Aurora, Ill., scored a total of 375 out of a possible 400 in the four-position match at prone-sitting-kneeling-standing stages today, he won the junior rifle corps small bore title on the junior national match program.

An investigation of practices used by the General Electric Company, AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company and Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company in the sale of heavy electric equipment was recommended to the National Economic Committee today by the Public Utilities Committee of the National Lawyers Guild.

Charged with the attempted bribery of two inspectors for the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures, and with possessing two different weight-delivery tickets, two coal-truck drivers were held in $500 bail for Special Sessions yesterday by Magistrate Charles G. Keutgen in West New Brighton Court, Staten Island.

The sentencing of two. men who pleaded guilty last week to a charge of withholding payments to the State Insurance Fund was postponed yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions when the defendants' lawyer announced his clients were prepared to pay the State $10,000 in restitution.

A digest of the testimony of witnesses in the trial of James J. Hines yesterday follows: Dudley Brothwell, the Fairfield, Conn., riding master who identified James J. Hines as a companion of Dutch Schultz on a 1935 visit to his riding school,
The united front drive of San Francisco employers against the closed shop, frequent "quickie" strikes and "slow downs," and "restrictive" union rules proceeded today on three battlefields.

Magistrate Michael A. Ford disqualified himself yesterday from hearing in -Traffic Court charges of dangerous driving against Ben Cutler, dance orchestra leader, because Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, had written him suggesting that "justice tyke its course" if Mr. Cutler did not pay for $241 damages he had done to park property with his automobile.

Five men who pleaded guilty to a charge of concealing and transporting narcotics were sentenced yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, in Federal Court, Brooklyn. The men were originally indicted on a charge of sale of eleven and a half ounces of heroin to a government

August B. Hook has been named district manager of the Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company, Inc., for New Jersey. He was formerly Eastern division manager for the Mohawk Liqueur Corporation of Detroit.

Department store sales for the week ended Aug. 20 were 9 per cent lower than for the corresponding week last year and for the four-week period ended Aug. 20 were 11 per cent lower than for the comparable period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. St.

Speeding six miles to a blazing schooner yacht off shore from this town, the Eastern Steamship liner New York tonight picked up two men and a young woman and later set them ashore safely at the Cape Cod Canal. The flames, which burned the craft, the 84-foot auxiliary Liria, to the water's edge, followed an explosion.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation will undertake immediately a program of buying surplus wheat for export and for relief. Secretary Wallace, in making the announcement today, did not state how the government will dispose of the wheat abroad. He was expected to outline the plan in a speech tomorrow morning in Montreal.

A period of outstanding good health for the people of the United States and Canada is indicated by the fact that the industrial policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company set two new health records in the month of July, the company announced yesterday.

113th St. 34 W. Fifth Ave. Bank, trustee, to Henbildo Realty Corp. 9 E 40th St; purchase money mtg S13,000 ($15). Same property, Henbildo Realty Corp. to Frieda A. Danielsen, 545 W 142d St; mtg $13,000 ($2). Madison St, 156, s w cor Pike St.Joseph Becker to Concetta Garone, 1,321 49th St, Brooklyn; mtg $23,000 (50 cents). 47th St, 519 W, Bankers Trust Co. trustee, to Ernestine Fischer, 3,605 Bedford St, Brooklyn ($5.25).
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh left Moscow at 11:10 A. M. today in their own plane for Kharkov. After a short stay there, they will go on lig to Rostov.

Additional engagements of gold in England for shipment here, in the amount of $2,100,000, were reported yesterday as the foreign exchange market continued to weaken. These engagements brought the total of gold shipped here from England since July 26, when the current movement began, to $51,800,000.

The Congressional committee investigating the TVA all but completed its inquiry into the marble claims of Senator Berry today. The next important phase of the inquiry, it was indicated, will involve a report of the Controller

The Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals today for a redetermination of tax deficiencies, aggregating $153,856, assessed by the Internal Revenue Bureau. The assessments were directed against the Standard Steel Car Corporation of Delaware and the Standard Steel Car Corporation of Pennsylvania, which Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing succeeded.

William H. Button, a former commander of William J. Sewell Camp, Spanish-American War Veterans and a leader in veteran circles in the State, died today at the Alexian Brothers Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
Exports of industrial machinery in July were valued at $20,948,548, a decline of 7 per cent from the July, 1937, figure of $22,436,301, the Commerce Department announced today.

Two young wives, who left their mountain homes in Tennessee to become vagabonds, told today how they killed a middle-aged farmer whom they had plotted to rob. Each blamed the other for firing the fatal shots.

Rolland J. Hamilton, president of the American Radiator Company and a member of the Business Advisory Council of the United States Department of Commerce, writing in a recent issue of Dun's Review, declares that homebuilding in America is evolving from a speculative to an investment basis, and the FHA mortgage guarantee system is making an outstanding contribution toward the achievement of that goal.

THOREAU once said of man that in youth he gets together the materials for a bridge to the moon and in middle age he makes a woodshed out of them. The same line of thought, suggests Mr. Hambidge, can be applied to the writing of a book.

EVER since Stella Gibbons's riotously hilarious "Cold Comfort Farm" was pub lished people have been telling her to do it again. She has never done so. Probably she never will. That brilliant parody would seem to have been by way of clearing the ground for later constructive action.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--The policy of expropriation without immediate compensation, adopted by Mexico to solve one phase of its tangled economic situation, has placed the first serious strain on the good-neighbor policy which President Roosevelt has made a cardinal point in his foreign program.

BROOKLINE, Mass., AUg. 27.--In one of the drabbest and most puzzling finals in the history of the tournament, J. Donald Budge and Gene Mako scored an overwhelming victory over Australia's hitherto invincible Davis Cup combination of Adrian Quist and John Bromwich today to regain the national doubles tennis championship.

Building in the Chicago region in July increased by more than 12 per cent in comparison with July, 1937, according to the survey of sixty-seven suburban communities by the Greenebaum Investment Company. It shows that permits amounting to $2,801,731 were issued in July and $2,486,729 in July one year ago.

MEXICO the name echoes through the headlines of the news, bringing visions of men in peaked hats and battles over expropriated oil Mexico .. volcanic land of treasures and legends and revolutions Mexico .. bronze faces and lustrous eyes and ceremonious manners Mexico brooding temples, music wailing in the night, hungry dogs, blazing light and fierce, irritable dignity Mexico .. what is Mexico?

FORTUNATELY for the balance of our economic system, most drinkers can take it or leave it alone. If but 10 per cent required hospitalization as chronic alcoholics most of the nation's wealth would be syphoned into medical services.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Aug. 27.-- Secretary Ickes's censure of Senator Carter Glass as typical of "political hypocrites" brought a reply from the outspoken Virginian today that Mr. Ickes "has become a confirmed blackguard."

THE local WPA put forward its best foot, or rather, if one may be pardoned such a multipedal figure, all its best feet, one day last week, demonstrating on Friday in Washington Square the nature and extent of the activities through which the Federal Art Projects have brought entertainment and instruction to hundreds of thousands of children and adults in the last two and a half years.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange here eased 3 to 6 points yesterday and the October ended at 8.30 cents a pound, compared with 8.28 on the previous Saturday. Trading was restricted again by uncertainty over the government's plan for loans, which was not announced until after the market had closed.

PARIS. WHEN Burke wrote his "Reflections on the French Revolution" he made them a well-con structed treatise where the ideas were presented in logical order, linked by appropriate transitions, enhanced by fragments of elaborate rhetoric.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Aug. 27.-- Frank Manning of Penn Brook gained the semi-final round of the New Jersey State public links golf championship at the River Vale Country Club today by defeating George MeCarthy of Essex Parks, 5 and 4, in the morning and going on to eliminate Jack Spinelli of La Tourette in the afternoon, 1 up.

The wind hauls round to the northwest, and it turns cooler and stops raining for a while. Real breakers are riding in on the ordinarily quiet beach. Mother says the children mustn't be allowed to go out so far, on account of the undertow. Father says they're too old to be coddled--didn't they pass the super-porpoise tests?

TAKEN from green sea depths a white morsel has saved an Australian town. The town is Broome, in the far north, metropolis of the Australian pearling trade, and the fragment which has changed its destiny is a pearl valued at $50,000.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Aug. 27.--Miss Louise W. Ripley, daughter of Dr. Charles David Ripley and the late Mrs. Ripley, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Andrew Jon Valois Klein of East Orange, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Klein.

The general executive board of the Workers Alliance decided yesterday to go ahead with the organization's plan to raise funds to aid in the election of Representatives in Congress favorable to relief measures.

QUILTS in Colonial days were, many of them, not only practical bed covers but definite evidence of artistic ability, as four unusual ones displayed at the Metropolitan Museum reveal. Various techniques contributed to their attractive effect, combining, perhaps, in one cover, quilting, embroidery and applique or patchwork.

STOREKEEPERS in the Ninth and Tenth Avenue tenement section on the upper edge of Chelsea report the annual Summer shortage of empty boxes which has taken place each Summer in the neighborhood for over a quarter of a century.
(All time is P.M., Eastern daylight saving, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are in megacycles.)

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Aug. 27.--Bobby Weichel, Scranton, won the Buckwood Trophy today by defeating Don Allan, Pittston, 6 and 5, in the twentyfifth running of one of the oldest golf tournaments in the country over the Shawnee Country Club course.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 27 (AP).--John Coolidge was elected a delegate to the Connecticut Republican convention today, but promptly disclaimed any desire to follow in the political footsteps of his famous father, the late President Calvin Coolidge.

THE island of Cuba, principal intellectual and social center of the entire Antilles, is witnessing the gradual replace ment of its basic Spanish culture by the ever-increasing influence that comes from the near-by continent of North America.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 27.-- Maxwell Howard's great thoroughbred Stagehand ran third behind the Calumet Farm's Bull Lea and H.C. McGehee's Purple King today as Bull Lea took down $10,220 top money in the mile-and-a-furlong James C. Thornton Memorial Handicap before 30,000 spectators at Narragansett Park.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced for the fourth consecutive week, and reached 84.4 for the week ended Aug. 20. This is its highest level since the week ended Dec. 18, 1937. It compares with 83.9 for the preceding week, and 109.8 for the corresponding week a year ago.

Not quite in the home tradition is a little dispatch from Washington about a new fast-drying cement which permits a large machine-gun pill box to be built in a day. The inventor, who demonstrated it before military and diplomatic observers at the Bureau of Standards, says that with practice the construction time may be brought down to two hours.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Private enterprise has normally recov ered from past depressions. However bad conditions were, it had to accommodate itself to them.

The Socialist State ticket this Fall will be headed by Norman Thomas, veteran party leader, as candidate for Governor, James Lipsig, State secretary of the party, announced yesterday. The ticket has been approved by the Socialist State Committee.

THIS young couple who found their Eden on a rural hillside did not move to the country because of the depression. They moved to the country in the roseate years of prosperity, and they were well dug in to their contented retreat by the time the depression arrived.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 27.--After winning the play-off for the medal, A.C. Giles of the home club and P.E. Furber of Wee Burn went on today to reach the semi-final round in the annual member-guest golf tournament at the Seawane Club.

IN the years immediately preceding the stock market crash and the great depression Edna V. O'Brien was one of the most successful women in stock market work. Her offices occupied half of one of the upper floors in a Fifth Avenue skyscraper, and the figures of her financial activities and even of her personal income tax seem nothing short of staggering to the lay public of today.

THE automotive industry this week reached that "between the hay and the grass" period with production near its lowest ebb for the year. Ford was the only major producer remaining active on 1938 production, while other makers who had previously closed were not able to resume with any degree of volume.

THE First Central American Philatelic Exhibition will be held in Guatemala City from Nov. 20 through the 27th, and Guatemala plans to commemorate it with a miniature sheet and six air-mail stamps. The show will represent the fruits of several years of planning by its sponsors and is expected to do much to increase interest in the hobby in the Central American countries.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 27.-- Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, told 1,500 party leaders at a rally at Fort Hill today that the campaign in this State now had developed the question "whether the people of Pennsylvania are going to allow the government to control their election."

Some significant suggestions as to what should be done with industrial plants when they have become of no further use to their original owners are given in the current issue of Freehold, published by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

"To provide for us in our necessities is not in the power of government. It would be a vain presumption in statesmen to think they can do it. The people maintain them, and not they the people. They are the pensioners of the poor, and are maintained by their superfluity."

ROME, Aug. 27.--Pope Plus reaffirmed today the right of the church to consider the "racism" problem within its spiritual domain, in a speech delivered to a group of members of Catholic Action of Rheims, France. In another speech he delivered to pilgrims from Bergamo in Northern Italy, the Pope expressed his disapproval and grief over the recent persecution of Catholics of that city.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 27. --Convinced that the Committee for Industrial Organization is disintegrating through the "disillusionment" of its members, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, opened the door today for the admission into the federation of C.I.O. unions on an organizational basis.

STE. ANNE DE BELLEVUE, Que., Aug. 27 (AP).--Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of the United States Department of Agriculture, proposed today that farm officials of all nations meet to formulate a set of principles designed to assure farming classes a "fair" share of the world's income.

PARIS, Aug. 26.--A tiny gold vase holding fresh flowers is a novel orna ment for boutonniere or corsage. Sequin violets and green composition leaves worked in a stylized bouquet are smart in a buttonhole on an after noon tailleur.

WITH a decided lack of pretension and somewhat of a genius for condensa tion and clarity Dr. Cattell describes the general principle, underlying the theories of Freud Jung and Adler in the first five chapters and then outlines the major problems of the child's environment and the more important causes of maladjustment.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 27.--The Spanish Government destroyer Jose Luis Diez was intercepted in darkness in the Strait of Gibraltar by several Rebel warships early this morning while endeavoring to reach Valencia from Havre, where the vessel had been undergoing repairs.

LABOR DAY week-end, official climax of Summer festivities in the United States, is almost with us again and a mood of quiet-before-excitement hangs over New York City as some two million residents prepare to get away for the long holiday.
THE Sixth International Festival of Contemporary Music, to be held in Venice in September, announces the following program:

In the World War the Kingdom of Hungary, as part of the Dual Monarchy of Austria-Hungary, fought shoulder to shoulder with the German Empire and was an outpost in the "Drang nach Osten"--the "push to the East." It then had a population of 25,000,000, an area of 125,000 square miles.

TOKYO, Aug. 27.--Leading members of the Japanese Government, particularly the Ministers of Foreign Affairs and Finance, are making a definite effort for improvement in Anglo-Japanese relations in the face of extremely serious opposition.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 27.-- The marriage of Miss Chloe Louise Shear, daughter of Dr. Theodore Leslie Shear and the late Mrs. Nora Jenkins Shear of Princeton, to Lincoln Gilmore Smith of Princeton took place here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Two champions strode through Saratoga's historic homestretch today, dominating their opposition and confirming more than ever that the thoroughbred strain has a glorious heritage which carries on.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 27.--The official news agency warmly received Sir John Simon's statements today on the Czechoslovak problem.

Sales of homes owned by the Home Owners Loan Corporation for the first six months of the present year almost doubled the total sales up to Dec. 31, 1937, announced Charles A. Jones, general manager of the corporation, yesterday.

The minimum standards of construction established by the FHA have resulted in giving the small, low-cost home greater attractiveness, efficiency and more livable conveniences, declares Howard Vermilya, director of the technical division of the FHA.

"WORKING like a beaver" is a time-honored proverb of industry. Until the government decided to put beavers to work on PWA projects and CCC construction it occurred to nobody to examine very closely whether these roly-poly little aquatic mammals are really as hard-working, intelligent and frugal as they have long been reputed to be in woodsmen's tall tales, trappers' fireside mythology, early travelers' unverified accounts.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will be named as the Republican candidate for Governor whether or not the Hines trial is ended by the time the Republican State Convention meets in Saratoga Sept. 28 and 29, it was learned yesterday.

WITH the 1940 Olympic Games scheduled for Helsinki, Finnish capital, reached through the Bal tic Sea, travel prophets are already forecasting a new popularity for coast towns along that ocean. Surrounded by some eight countries and connected with the North Sea by the Skageriak Strait, touching Denmark, the Baltic Sea offers a large territory for the wandering traveler. One may sail to the head of the Gulf of Bothnia.

THERE are two ways of writing about Shakespeare: the short and the long way, Professor J.W. Mackail is not likely to be surpassed in his achievement of the first. In eight compact pages he has set down all that we definitely know about Shakespeare's life.
COLUMBIA CITY, Ind., Aug. 27. --Brig. Gen. ("Hiking") Hiram I. Bearss, 63 years old, of Peru, Ind., was killed today in an automobile collision near here.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 27.--Led by Billy Post, who rode at No. 3, Long Island scored an easy victory over a makeshift Roslyn team in a test polo match on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today. The score was 10--3, with Ivor Balding and Devereux Milburn each scoring three goals for Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--The United States is still in the position of experiencing want in the midst of plenty--in the case of farm products, in the midst of great surpluses. This situation has brought forward the question whether, if the surpluses could be distributed among the needy, they would be consumed.

IT is time to entirely revise our judgment of the gastronomic discrimination of household mice. Their pas sion for cheese, their willingness to risk life itself in filching a small portion of it from a trap, is known to every one--but only a few people realize their degree of epicurean discernment.

CAPEHART FARMS, Washington, Ind., Aug. 27.--Republican campaign charges of 1936, brought up to date to include the evidence furnished by the current Democratic "purge," echoed today across the plains of Southern Indiana.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 27 (AP). --Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, deposed chairman of the TVA, renewed charges of "dishonesty in public office" against the remaining two directors, while he was testifying before the Congressional investigation committee today, but made it clear that he did not accuse them of personal corruption.

A BIT of orange peel carelessly thrown on the sidewalk was the origin of The Safe Way Club. It was Peter who threw it there and when a passerby shipped and fell, seriously injuring his back, Peter felt responsible and did his very best to keep the man from losing his position.

NEWSPAPERS in Britain are predominantly Conservative. It is in books that, from time to time, pent-up liberalism finds an outlet. This book is an example of such freedom of the press. It says what, as a rule, is left unsaid.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 27.-- Miss Ruth Macloon, a former student at Rosemary Hall, was married here this afternoon in St. Bede's Chapel at the school to Eugene L. Belisle of Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E.R. Taft of Christ Church, Greenwich.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 27.-- Under the spreading maples which shade the front lawn of Moses Smith, his tenant farmer, President Roosevelt sat down today with his village neighbors and in the course of an informal talk to the small gathering bade welcome to the "Heaven" of Father Divine and his "angels," the new neighbors across the river.
LANARK, Scotland, Aug. 27 (AP). --The text of the speech of Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on Czechoslovakia follows:

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Aug. 27.-- Barnegat Bay was strewn with disabled yachts and craft blown ashore with rigging in tatters as the result of a series of wind and rain squalls today. The fleet was hit while at anchor preparatory to the start of the championship races scheduled by the Toms River Yacht Club on the lower bay course at Cedar Creek Point.

STRANGELY quiet these days --when they should by rights be chorusing "I told you so"-- are the Broadway prophets who for years have been predicting the revival of film production hereabouts. Whatever has become of them is immaterial, though. For the big news about town just now, cinematically speaking, is that the semidormant Eastern Service Studios in Astoria will be buzzing like a veritable beehive within a few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Ind., Aug. 27.--Following are the prepared texts of speeches by Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York and John D.M. Hamilton, national chairman, before the Republican Cornfield Conference here today:

Foreclosures on urban real estate throughout the country have been steadily declining for four years, according to a survey recently made by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the results of which were announced yesterday. This gradual decline, it was stated, is still continuing.

TAKING her title from Thomas Paine's opening paragraph of "The Crisis," Leane Zugsmith in "The Summer Soldier" has written a novel which cuts with acid strength into the problem of American freedom Paine's words written in an hour of darkness during the American Revolution are as pertinent today as they were a century and a half ago.

SANTA FE, N.M.--Santa Fe will share the opening of its annual fiesta with the rest of the world on Saturday night through a broadcast over a national radio hook-up, with short-wave transmission for Latin America. It will be the first nation-wide broadcast of this famous merry-making.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 (AP).-- Four home runs today moved the Browns out of the American League cellar by giving them a double victory over the Athletics, 8 to 3 and 6 to 5.

THE Los Angeles Philharmonic Symphony, Dr. Otto Klemperer conductor, will open its regular season of Thurs day night and Friday afternoon biweekly concerts on Nov. 3 and 4, with Yehudi Menuhin as soloist. The popular-priced series of Friday afternoon and Saturday night concerts will begin on Nov. 11 and 12.

A new feature in the "yardstick" program of the Tennessee Valley Authority has been incorporated into a contract recently signed by the TVA and the city of Knoxville. The municipality completed last week negotiations with the Tennessee Public Service Company whereby the private utility will be turned over to public operation as a municipally owned project receiving TVA power.

On Sept. 2, the ninety-ninth anniversary of the birth of Henry George, the Henry George School of Social Science will take title to a five-story building capable of handling 6,000 students a week at 30 East Twenty-ninth Street, according to Frank Chodorov, director of the school.

As a result of the large number of difficult and unexpected economic problems presented within recent years the tendency is becoming stronger in all departments of our business work, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to look to some particular trade association for the proper solution.

INDIA'S new short-wave station at Delhi, VUD-3, operating on 19 meters, has been tuned in of late broadcasting a clear signal into the New York area. When heard on recent Friday and Saturday evenings beginning at 9:30 o'clock, daylight time, weird native tunes, sent out at breakfast time in Delhi, filled the 15.16 megacycle lane.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--American wheat markets responded sharply today to the announcement made late yesterday that the government in Washington would buy cash wheat for export and relief purposes. This news, coupled with the statement of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration that the government would lend 57 cents a bushel to farmers on last year's corn crop, compared with 50 cents previously, threw the grain trade into confusion.

A jury before Federal Judge Edward A. Conger returned a verdict of guilty yesterday at noon against two bus corporations and three of their officials on three counts of an indictment charging a $21,400 fraud during 1937 in connection with a WPA project at Orchard Beach, City Island, the Bronx.

The ghosts of many dead men walk through the plain and dignified Supreme Court chamber where James J. Hines is being tried on the charge of influencing and intimidating public officials to help out the Dutch Schultz policy gang. They will not down, these shades of the underworld, although some of the men they represent lie six feet underground and one is believed to be encased in cement at the bottom of the East River.

The following excerpts are taken from the diary of Joris Ivens, camera man and producer of the film "The Spanish Earth," who has recently been in China filming scenes in the undeclared war there. The material will be assembled shortly for release this Fall. Mr. Ivens has been backed by Contemporary Historians, a group composed of Luise Rainer, Ernest Hemingway, Archibald MacLeish, Herman Shumlin, Lillian Hellman and others.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 27.-- Princeton University's extra-curricular activities will be in the hands of 132 undergraduates during the coming academic year. The list of officers for 1938-39, announced today by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college, is the largest in recent years.

WASHINGTON.--Some time around Jan. 1 the Federal Government will come into possession of one of the most historic canals in the United States--the 185-mile Chesapeake and Ohio Canal connecting Cumberland, Md., and the national capital along the east side of the Potomac River.
BOSTON, Sunday, Aug. 28 (AP).-- May Yohe, once a famous actress and one-time possessor of the illstarred Hope diamond, died early today of heart disease.

THE Peter Conley Attraction of San Francisco, Calif., will offer three musical series to be held at the Opera House. The so-called "de luxe" series will present Fritz Kreisler on Nov. 4; Serger Rachmaninoff on Nov. 18, Jascha Heifetz on Jan. 9; Josef Hofmann on Feb. 14; Marian Anderson, contralto, on Feb. 21, and Richard Tauber, tenor, on March 2.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 27.-- Camp, bay gelding owned by Mrs. Norman K. Toerge of Locust Valley, today was awarded the championship rosette in the hunter division of the twenty-ninth annual Smithtown Horse Show, the culminating event of a fine exhibition.
TO assist visitors in foreign lands to determine the restrictions and taxes faced if they take a radio set with them, World Radio of London has prepared the following table of liabilities.

A LOT of people will certainly be very happy to learn that Mary Boland and Charles Ruggles are going to get married again--with the blessing of Paramount Pictures, Inc. For, up to a couple of years ago, they were, without any exception, the cinema's most consistently connubial comic couple--professionally speaking, of course.

The fourth national skeet shooting championships will be held at the Southern Hills Country Club, Tulsa, Okla., from Tuesday until Saturday. Miss Viola Siedhoff of Wichita, Kan., who won the women's title in 1937 in a two-round shoot-off with Mrs. E.C. Crossman of Los Angeles, will defend her laurels.

Calling of three large issues of public utility bonds featured a somewhat larger volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity. Various small amounts of foreign and domestic municipal bonds made up the bulk of the remaining announcements.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (Canadian Press).--Colorful ceremonies marked the opening of the 1938-29 English football seasont oday. More than 700,000 persons flocked to the fortyfour carded matches and closeness of scores all down the line augured well for a banner year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 27.--What a squall can do to a nice, fresh southwest wind was demonstrated to 129 skippers in the Port Washington Yacht Club's regatta today, eighteenth in the Yacht Racing Association championship series.

THE beautiful Cloisters at Fort Tryon Park has settled into its stride. Attendance figures for the time elapsed since the opening in May run close to 250,000. On week-ends, as would be expected, the popularity of this most charming embodiment of the Middle Ages reaches its crest.

Harry Stelljes, 70 years old, of 88-20 Union Turnpike, Glendale, Queens, appeared yesterday before Magistrate Charles Solomon in Brooklyn Traffic Court. He was charged with having driven his provision truck past a red light a second time in six months.

ROME, Aug. 27.--One point which circles close to the government and the officially inspired press have particularly stressed since the Burgos reply to the British plan for evacuation of foreign volunteers from Spain became known is General Franco's pledge that he will defend to the last Spain's territorial integrity and that neither political nor economic concessions ever will be granted to foreign powers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP).-- The Tigers defeated the Senators today, 12 to 11, in a slugfest which moved Detroit within half a game of Washington's fourth-place position.

NOT much change was reported in retail trade trends for the week. In some of the large city areas of the country wide losses were narrowed somewhat and in some of the farming sections there was a bit more lag which was put down to sinking agricultural prices.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP).--Miss Patty Berg, the golfing marvel from Minneapolis, today defeated Miss Edith Estabrooks, 17-year-old school girl from Dubuque, Iowa, 4 and 3, in the thirty-six-hole final for the women's Western closed championship at the Olympia Fields Country Club.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Aug. 27.--Captain George E. T. Eyston broke his own automobile speed record here today, raising the mark to 345.49 miles an hour.

The greatest security for investments in rental housing is to be found in projects which are both large enough to withstand deteriorating neighborhood influences and low enough in rental to tap the vast market provided by families of moderate means, states the FHA.

The Department of Education of the Museum of the City of New York has in preparation the fourth series of "portable history sets," which it will lend, on request, to New York schools for study purposes.

Announcement was made yesterday by Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, that the Department of Public Works is preparing plans for the improvement of two bridges which form an important part of the Eastern Boulevard project, otherwise known as the easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP).--An agreement presaging peace in "Bloody Harlan County," Ky., was signed today by attorneys for the United Mine Workers of America and the Harlan County Coal Operator's Association.

Since the beginning of her undeclared war last Summer, Japan has concentrated on cutting China's external and internal communications. She has seized the vital railroad lines of North and Central China, converting the stations into sandbagged fortresses in provinces that she has been too busy to conquer completely.

THIS has been a big week for our town, particularly the autograph-hunting section of it. It isn't often that we get such a diversity of spectacle as that afforded by Tallulah Bankhead and Max Reinhardt within the space of twenty-four hours.

A large increase in attendance at vacation playgrounds and play schools is attributed to greater cooperation this Summer between the Board of Education and the Works Progress Administration, in a report made public yesterday by Mark A. McCloskey, director of the board's bureau of extension activities.

CROW AGENCY, Mont.--The Indian powwow here from Aug. 29 to Sept. 2 has become a national event unique in character, for it draws no fewer than thirty tribes of the plans Indians from an area extending from the Great Lakes to the Pacific.

Encouraging factors in the field of home financing and new residential building were revealed yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in announcing the consolidated balance sheet of the 3,927 member institutions of the Federal bank system for the year 1937.

There will be a parting of the ways among speed boat pilots this week. While the inboard drivers will concentrate on Detroit as a mecca for the Gold Cup's thirtyfifth annual regatta, the chauffeurs of the skimming outboard craft will divide their attention among a number of smaller race meets.

American orders for Czechoslovak merchandise have begun to turn upward in the last two weeks, for the first time since political tension in Europe was aroused by troop mobilizations on the Czech-German border last May, and this rise may provide the first actual test of the Czechoslovak trade treaty signed in March, according to Frank J. Rosner, secretary of the AmericanCzechoslovak Chamber of Commerce.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 27.-- Qualifying in the marksmanship tests occupied the attention of the majority of the 2,400 infantrymen of the Eighty-seventh Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, throughout their first week of training at Camp Smith here.

Coming as a thrilling climax to an amazing demonstration of superiority over an already thoroughly beaten foe, Monte Pearson, slim right-hander of the Yankees, swept into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday when, to the accompanying roars of 40,959 onlookers, he pitched a dazzling no-hit, no-run game against the Indians.

Builders in many of the suburban localities of Bergen County, N.J., report a steadily rising demand for low-cost and medium-priced homes, and in several instances the construction programs prepared early in the Spring for the year's activity are being materially enlargad.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the great emergency arising from the current intrusion of President Roosevelt into the electoral functions of the States, I am bringing to your attention a public letter addressed to President Wilson in 1913, pointing out the deep and pervading illegality and extremely serious evils which must flow from it of interference by the Federal Executive in State elections.

Two leading authorities on American politics went motoring together last Thursday. At the wheel of a Ford touring car equipped with manual control was the President of the United States, head of the Democratic party. At his side was James A. Farley, Postmaster General, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

PERHAPS the Drama Department of THE TIMES had its tongue in its cheek when it asked one who often has been referred to as a retired playwright (though never, I am afraid, as a retiring one) to write a little piece explaining why five of us have banded together to form the Playwrights Producing Company.

AMATEUR photographers interested in the scientific application of photography to map making from airplanes may obtain permission to attend the semiannual meeting of the American Society of Photogrammetry which will be held in New York on Sept. 8 and 9 at the American Geographical Society, 156th Street and Broadway.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--On behalf of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and the deeply uneasy British Government, Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, served notice today that Great Britain might not be able to stay out of a war that began as a local quarrel in Central Europe.

Recommendations of the Public Contracts Board for minimum wage scales in the iron and steel industry, expected to be supplied to the United States Department of Labor this week, may have the effect of "freezing" minimum wage levels in the industry, in the view of financial observers.

ATLANTA, Aug. 27.--Both retail and wholesale trade continued below expectations in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. A group of leading department stores reported sales slightly above the previous week but from 8 to 12 per cent below a year ago.

The Board of Elections will start hearings tomorrow on objections that have been filed against 162 primary designating petitions. Of the objections, seventy-one have been lodged against Democratic designees, sixty-five against designees of the American Labor party and twenty-six against Republicans.

ALBANY, Aug. 27.--An acquaintance of years culminated after the four and a half months of the Constitutional Convention, in the announcement today of the engagement of former Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse and Mrs. Bertha S. Moore of Bronxville.

Sir Arthur Keith made a comment which is illuminating in more ways than one in his address the other day before the British Association for the Advancement of Science. He was discussing recent discoveries and conclusions touching on the early history of man, among them a new analysis of the famous Piltdown Man, whose weathered remains were brought to light in Sussex in 1913.

FIORELLO LA GUARDIA said recently that he was "Mayor of New York twenty-four hours a day"--a statement that few will dispute in view of the amount of energy he puts into the job. Nevertheless in the first six months of the second administration he found time to project himself far beyond the limits of the municipality, and political observers agree that the Tammanybusting Mayor has definitely became a salient personality in the national political scene.

Although business has done little better than hold its own in the last month, the consensus of purchasing agents is that changes occurring in the early Fall will be for the better and that, while a rapid increase in turnover is not anticipated, the replenishment movement so long expected is bound to get under way before the end of the year.

Pointing out that there is a large volume of private and public construction going on in the Rockaways, John H. Morris president of the Long Island Real Estate Board and chairman of the real estate committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways, predicted yesterday that more than $20,000,000 will be spent for both pubic and private improvements in that section before June, 1939.

THREE admirable and worthwhile books which will be exceedingly useful for ref erence in schools and libraries and which will also be read for pleasure by many young people from 10 to 14. The style is lively and interesting and the author never condescends to his readers.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 (AP).--Chancellor Adolf Hitler's deputy in party matters, Rudolf Hess, together with Julius Stretcher and the Bavarian Premier, Ludwig Siebert, at Nuremberg today extended the Nazi party's welcome to Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary; Mrs. Horthy and their party, including Premier Bela Imredy, Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya and Minister of War Eugene Ratz, who arrived by special train.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is commonly assumed, I think, that the unemployed in the United States are concentrated to a large degree in great cities and industrial regions. Perhaps our attack upon the unemployment problem would be redirected if this were clearly shown to be a fallacy.

Forty-six Fordham University football men will report to Coach Jim Crowley at Fordham Field tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock for the beginning of Fall practice. Thirteen letter men, eighteen reserves from last season and fifteen sophomores constitute the squad that will begin preparation for the Maroon's fiftieth football season.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 27.--Midshipman Edward L. Beach Jr. of Palo Alto, Calif., has been named commander of the regiment of midshipmen, or "five-striper," for the first of the three periods of the academic year, from Sept. 23 to Dec. 23.

The indications are for fair weather today and partly cloudy weather tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock, Eastern Standard Time, last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--The steaming to death of four convicts in the Philadelphia county prison this week, as an aftermath of a hunger strike, not only added another chapter to a long story of major and minor riots at the Holmesburg institution but centered attention anew upon the set-up of the Pennsylvania prison system.

PENNSYLVANIA has been setting a fast pace for other States to follow in the reduc tion of highway accidents. This is a reversal of last year's trend, which found Pennsylvania fifth highest State in highway fatalities, with 2,545, or just 50 less than Illinois.

Pointing out that many notices of violations have been served on merchants in the Bronx for having illuminated signs projecting beyond building lines, the Bronx Board of Trade has asked Councilmen Charles E. Keegan and Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx to have a resolution introduced in the Council which would permit the installation of such signs.

NEBRASKA, in recent seasons, has more than come into its own as a setting for frontier fiction. In point of time, as well as point of view, Chalmer Richardson's rather solemn novel about Nebraska in the early Eighteen Eighties falls somewhere between the spectacular and lawless frontier described by Mari Sandoz in "Slogum House,"' and the grim realism of Sophus Winther's prairie trilogy --with perhaps an edge to the former.

Nine days ago, after a session lasting more than nineteen weeks and costing $1,350,000, New York's Eighth Constitutional Convention completed the draft of a new 50,000-word Constitution to be submitted to popular vote in November. The 168 delegates at Albany had approved fifty-seven amendments, covering such controversial matters as reapportionment, proportional representation, home rule, social welfare, housing, taxation, the judiciary and labor relations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP).--Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, declared in a radio speech today that "it is the alliance of crime and politics and the Communists out to destroy the republican form of government that is attacking the press in a new form of populist front."

The Excelsior Savings Bank in the twelve-story building at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street will be completely renovated and modernized. The contract for the work has been awarded to George Colon Son, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Reginald Roome, president of the bank. J.M. Berling is the architect.

OHIO'S Lake Erie Islands, lying from four to twenty miles off the coast like a giant's handful of fragments from the mainland, are preparing to receive thousands of visitors on Sept. 10, when the 125th anniversary of the Battle of Lake Erie will be celebrated by nine States.

PARIS.--"The French Singapore in Indo-China" is the name hopefully given here to Cam-Ranh Bay on the Annam coast, which the government means shortly to fortify for use as a naval base. Funds for this work, to be begun almost at once, have been obtained out of proceeds of a 400,000,000-franc loan recently floated, partly in Indo-China, for the defense of France's Eastern possessions.

Among the novelties promised for next season will be the first American tour by the Yvonne Georgi Ballet, which will begin in January. Miss Georgi herself is, of course, no newcomer to this country, having appeared in copartnership with Harald Kreutzberg from 1929 to 1931, and again in solo recitals two seasons ago.

THE Concours International Eugene Ysaye is open in yearly rotation to violinists, pianists and conductors. In 1937, when the competition established by the dowager Queen of Belgium was inaugurated in Brussels, the violinists had their fling.

The James J. Hines defense was thrown into furious activity yesterday as the result of the arrest of two of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's women witnesses in an alleged Harlem policy bank of the same flourishing kind that Hines is said to have used his political power to protect for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 27.-- A declaration that if returned to the Senate he would vote in the future exactly as he has in the past, was the reply of Senator Frederick Van Nuys tonight to further peace overtures from the powerful McNutt-Townsend organization in Indiana.

It wouldn't be surprising to find Metropolitan yachtsmen extending their 1938 cruising season way into September, if not October. They have a good excuse, too. Perhaps the deluges of July rains were a blessing in disguise. Skippers fretted, fumed and undoubtedly cussed (as all good mariners do) when so many wet midsummer week-ends kept boats hanging on home moorings.

THE industry is employing spectacular methods to launch much of its product these days. Previews and premieres now take place in the most unexpected localities. The stunts are calculated to garner space in the press --and very often they do.

There are many garden tasks which can be done at almost any season of the year when the ground is not frozen, but for which there is only one "best" time. The planting and transplanting of peonies is one of these. The writer has moved peonies without losing them during every month from March to December.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 27.-- Major and Mrs. George G. McMurtry of New York were hosts at the dinner dance of the Bar Harbor Club this evening for a large group of the Summer colony.

Aided by cooler weather, retail trade here made a slightly better showing last week. Department store executives estimated the decline from a year ago in dollar volume at about 13 per cent, compared with 14.3 per cent in the preceding week.

The home State of Senator Robert Wagner, author of the law setting up the National Labor Relations Board, last week became the scene of criticism of the NLRB. In convention at Buffalo, the New York State Federation of Labor adopted a resolution condemning the board for what it described as "constant favoritism to the C.I.O. and consistent prejudice against the American Federation of Labor."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27.--A diminutive Cleveland WPA worker--with the courage of a Dempsey when it counted most--became the hometown boy who made good and the new national public links golf champion today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25.--The newspaper Pravda in a dispatch from the Far Eastern "front," entitled "The Vanguard Role of Communists in Battle," throws interesting light on the methods of the political department of the Red Army.

New York University announced yesterday that safety education research fellowships and scholarships with a total value of $11,000 in the new national center for safety education at the university had been awarded to twenty-eight teachers and directors of accident control in thirteen States.

"A definite improvement in the employment situation" was reported last week by Secretary of Labor Perkins. Statistics compiled by her department showed that in July 40,000 factory workers returned to their jobs, causing a rise of 0.7 per cent in the employment index over June.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "The Good Loser" dis plays that urbanity that we have learned to expect; would that it also contained such accuracy as we usually find in your columns!

Summer cabins have recently been completed at Highland Lakes, near Stockholm, Sussex County, N.J., for Samuel Meeker of Ridgewood, Gordon Johnson of West Englewood, Miss Marie V. Miller of Bergenfield, Miss M. Smith of Butler, Harry Gutheil of Lyndhurst, Henrietta Thompson of Arlington, Otto Schuler of Little Falls, Charles Knowles of Belleville, Robert Morris of Orange and Christopher MacDowell of Maplewood.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 27.--The violent press attacks against the United States which were started yesterday were amplified by all newspapers here today.

Color engineers who have experimented with the psychological effects of color in the house, have found, it is stated, that the use of harsh, irritating colors may easily excite sensitive temperaments and cause family discord. Dull, uninspiring colors, on the other hand, may be both mentally and physically depressing.

RESUMING experimental television programs after a shut-down since June to install new devices, the National Broadcasting Company during the past week demonstrated that the radio eye, or iconoscope, in the electric camera has been made more sensitive and all-seeing.

THE importance of Dr. Kolnai's book for an understanding of the ideology of National Socialism can hardly be overestimated. With a patience which seems never to flag the author has taken time to wade through the great mass of German literature, most of it the product of the past few years, in which the theories, assumptions and claims of National Socialism are expounded, and has marshaled its essence to show what National Socialism is.

BECAUSE Mr. Eberhart is one of our own who has for some time been asso ciated with that group of enjants terribles, Auden, Day Lewis and Spender, one pauses to observe with care the work of this young poet.

To the Art Editor: PERMIT me to express my gratitude for your Sunday's chronicles on Innocents Abroad. Indeed, they have been just about the only cooling breeze this long Summer. The trip abroad was a great and invaluable experiment, although I wonder just what was the purpose.

Share prices moved within a narrow trading range during yesterday's two-hour session and closed lower. Losses ranged from fractions to more than 1 point, with a few issues off about 2 points. Attendance in the financial district was small and the volume of outof-town business indicated lack of interest elsewhere in proceedings.

The contract for landscaping the Scarsdale Manor apartment development on Garth and Grayrock Roads just south of the Scarsdale railroad station, Westchester County, has been awarded to the Lewis Valentine Landscape Corporation of Rye, announces William Jackson, president of the corporation.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Country Club, Mamaroneck, Princeton University's leading golfer, won the eighth annual Sagamore invitation tournament today with a 1-up victory over Ben Lord Jr., Glens Falls Country Club champion and captain-elect of the Union College golf team.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--Great Britain's fastest airliner, the huge new de Havilland Albatross, the first of its type built to inaugurate an Atlantic service next month, was wrecked at Hatfield Airfield tonight in what air experts describe as one of the strangest air accidents ever known.
On their own applications--To take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 28.

ANOTHER woman has just taken over the office of New York State In dustrial Commissioner. Frieda S. Miller is the second to hold that office since the job in embryonic form was created by Governor Cleveland more than fifty years ago. The first was Frances Perkins, who left the State service to take the Labor portfolio in President Roosevelt's Cabinet.

IN less than five minutes fast German bombers could reach this Czech village and shower it with death. The lovely hills behind which the morning sun rises are casemates of destruction. The Czech Army would yield this territory inch by inch, until it reached those hills which conceal the Maginot Line of Czechoslovakia. The Moravian Quadrangle behind it bristles with arms.

DONALD GRANT, president of the Dancing Teachers Business Association, has just issued a statement in which he has condensed under five headings the principal conclusions reached at the association's recent annual convention here.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, characterized as "senseless" yesterday the action of Magistrate Michael A. Ford, who disqualified himself Friday from hearing traffic court charges of dangerous driving against Benjamin Crawford Cutler, leader of the orchestra at the Rainbow Grill, Rockefeller Center.

Residential construction in July showed a marked increase over the preceding month and also over the month of July, 1937, according to statistics presented yesterday by Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins in her monthly building report for the Department of Labor.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27.--Unlike previous weeks of the present Summer season here, this week was concluded tonight without a large dancing party.

LAKE PLACID.--Based on authentic legend and traditions of the Iroquois Indian tribes, the thirty-sixth annual In dian Council Fire ceremony will be held on Friday evening in the Iroquois forest on the estate of the Lake Placid Club.

For those gardeners who are fortunate enough to have a small stream running through their grounds, there are a number of native plants available for brookside planting. Sometimes they may be gathered from their native haunts, but it is usually more satisfactory to obtain them from nurseries.

THERE'S no place like home as far as radio is concerned in the opinion of Linton Wells, roving reporter of WJZ's Sunday afternoon variety hour, who recently trekked 27,000 miles through fifteen LatinAmerican countries to broadcast a total of ninety minutes, a 6-minute interview from each country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26.-- Senator William G. McAdoo's preferred position as the Rooseveltfavored candidate for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself at the primary next Tuesday has made him the target of every other aspirant in a feverish lastminute campaign.

The current month should indicate whether the 25 per cent increase in passenger-coach rates that the railroads put into effect on July 24 has resulted in the diversion of more traffic to the highways, according to views in railroad circles.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 (AP).--The Boston Bees made a clean sweep of the four-game series with the Cincinnati Reds by scoring an 8-to-4 victory today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--A football coach who became president of the university for whose teams he sought victory for twenty-one years became a highly important factor this week in the determined efforts of the New Deal to prevent the conservative Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland from obtaining another nomination.

Much is being written these days about the value of humus in soil improvement. The old saying that "everything the garden produces should go back into the soil" is still sound advice. Late Summer, when much bulky plant growth--such as cornstalks and the "left-overs" of many vegetable crops, grass clippings, stray weeds and the like--is available, is an excellent time to start the compost heap.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP).--Scoring from second on Pitcher Bill Harris's double squeeze play bunt, Ben Chapman today gave the Red Sox a 1-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox and rounded out an earlier 19-6 triumph to account for Boston's third double feature victory of the week.

Construction of seven additional units of the same type will start immediately upon completion of the first six now being erected in the new Fort Hill apartment development on Central Avenue, Greenburgh, Westchester County, it was announced yesterday by Rae Craerin, president of the owning corporation.

INTO this homespun tale of a handful of humble men and women in a grimy Welsh mining district seventy-five years ago, Jack Jones has woven stout strands of sympathy and understanding. Himself the son of a Welsh collier, Mr. Jones as a boy worked in the pits, lived in a filthy "company" house, and received scarcely enough schooling to enable him to write and read.

A RICH vein of American folklore, unknown to the general public, will be brought to light in a book which the University of Pennsylvania Press will publish in October "Minstrels of the Mine Patch," by George Korson.

To the Music Editor: It is perhaps a distinctly Christian virtue for the American people to give asylum to those who have been evicted from their homes and their work, but it is as distinctly an American fault to fail to understand the problem of the home-trained American musician in his ambition to become a conductor.

VACATIONISTS bent on seeing more of America's expanding playlands are breaking all past records for tourist travel on the Great Lakes. Four hundred and four years after its discovery by the intrepid French explorer Jacques Cartier this "tideless sea" of more than 94,000 square miles has become one of the busiest cruising waters in the world.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27.-- Sensation, bay gelding owned by W.H. Parkhurst of Maplewood, trotted the fastest mile of his harness racing career to score the outstanding victory of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

The American Sumatra Tobacco Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on July 31 a net profit of $462,223. This was after depreciation, Federal income taxes, the surtax on undistributed profits and other charges.
ALANTIC CITY, N.J.--Sail and motor boats will gather here next week-end for the annual regatta of the Abse con Island Yacht Club, which will be held on the back bay on Saturday and Sunday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 27.-- Mrs. James Hewlett of Jericho piloted Dr. Watts, a bay gelding owned by George H. Van Wicklen of Glen Head, to victory in the special amateur trot for women drivers in the eighty-sixth annual fair of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society today.

How often one hears the statement: "We'll have a garden after the children grow up." But it isn't necessary to wait. The grown-ups need not do without their roses and shrubs and flowers, nor the youngsters miss all the educational values these things will have for them, if the simple plan carried out in a Bronxville garden known to the writer is put into practice.

Henry Waltemade Sr., a real estate broker and operator and first chairman of the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, died of a heart ailment yesterday morning at Lutherland, Pa. He was 69 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27.-- With peace negotiations continuing under the auspices of the Committee of Forty-three, an advisory council of San Francisco's business interests in the "united front" against the closed shop and "restrictive union" rules, the Association of San Francisco Distributors shut more warehouses today and laid off members of the C.I.O. warehousemen's union.
