STRIKINGLY resembling the short-lived "streamlined Ed ward" stamps of Great Britain, the "new reign" series of the British Virgin Islands has as the common design a portrait of King George VI in upper left and the familiar "Virgin and Lamps" in lower right.

Direct investments of United States citizens in the countries of Latin America are estimated at $2,847,000,000. The security of this stake has become increasingly uncertain as Uncle Sam's neighbors in the Western Hemisphere embark on national economic programs which restrict foreign capital.

THE seven defendants (Ely and Josephine Culbertson, Oswald Jacoby, Walter Malowan, Waldemar von Zedtwitz, William J. Huske and Lee Langdon) whom Willard S. Kain, once a prominent champion player, is suing for $1,000,000, were victors in the latest round of their court battle.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 (AP).--Newark's league-leading Bears made it three in a row over the Jersey City Giants today, winning by a score of 7 to 3.

Harlem's inveterate bettors of small money still play the numbers game--a raid last Friday night revealed a numbers bank in full operation, those arrested including two women who had testified downtown against Tammany District Leader James J. Hines. Visitors to Harlem observed that money also was being risked on current questions: How many days will the Hines trial last?

ALL over the world people are asking how the Japanese are holding up under the strain of protracted war and what effect the struggle is likely to have on them. The visitor--I have just returned from Tokyo--who expects to find a nervous and alarmed population, feverishly attempting to keep pace with the requirements of a national emergency, will be surprised by the calm atmosphere of Japan.

CESAR FRANCK was satisfied to work in units of one. He left behind one violin sonata, one string quartet, one piano quintet, one piano concerto (Variations symphoniques) and one symphony. When he ran into numbers, as in the case of his trios and tone poems, the result generally lacks the solidity of his various single essays, as though he was experimenting toward mastering a form.

A fleet of forty auxiliary and sailing craft, split into four divisions for the annual overnight races of the City Island Yacht Club, started from the mouth of Eastchester Bay at noon yesterday, with a fresh southwesterly breeze pushing the contestants along at a merry clip.

The ability of a fire chief to sense when a building wall, strained by the weight of tons of water, was about to topple saved fifty firemen from probable injury yesterday afternoon as they fought a fire in a small warehouse at 390-94 East Third Street.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug 27.-- Vic Ghezzi, Deal, N.J., pro, carding four birdies and an eagle, blazed his way into the lead at the half-way mark of the $3,000 Lake Placid open golf tournament today with a sub-par 68 and a total of 142.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the Labor Day week-end ap proaches it makes me think of the Monday morning accounts of the week-end automobile deaths and accidents, and this thought impels me to make the following suggestions:

The most ambitious national advertising campaigns attempted by large companies this year will be started soon after Labor Day, as growing belief in the validity of the business upturn over the last few weeks has led executives to approve schedule releases.

FACTORY ships are plowing the seas. They freeze and package fish, catch and can crabs, manufacture sardine oil and meal and reduce whales to oil and feed. They fly the ensigns of a dozen countries, among them Argentina, Germany, Great Britain, Russia and the United States, and the fleet is growing.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--Temple University has enlarged its curricula of hobby or avocational courses whereby men and women without any previous training may perfect themselves, after business hours, in their favorite pastime.

Prime Minister Chamberlain and his advisers in London may, or may not, have imagined that Germany was still so unready for a general war that she would be willing to let Britain find a compromise formula in Czechoslovakia--or would be willing to let the situation drift while Viscount Runciman pursued his leisurely inquiry. If they did, the developments this week in the great game of sword rattling provided much disillusionment.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 27.-- Coach Andy Kerr divided the Eastern College All-Stars into elevens of Blues and Grays today at Peddie School for a scrimmage that signaled the end of their first week's training for the Tribune Fresh Air Fund football game against the New York Giants on Sept. 7 at the Polo Grounds.

The large ten-story apartment building known as MacEvoy Court, under construction in the Roseville section of Newark, N.J., is nearing completion and is expected to be ready for occupancy Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by Clifford F. MacEvoy, head of the Clifford F. MacEvoy Company, builders.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--Officials investigating the deaths of four convicts in an overheated isolation block at the Philadelphia County Prison in Holmesburg put nine jail guards through intensive questioning today and announced that further arrests would be delayed until after the inquest on Wednesday.
IT was one of the Cleveland tourists at the Yankee Stadium who pushed back his cap, heaved a sigh and said:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--A record of fifty years of progress in interracial relations in the South is being seriously menaced by the family fighting now going on in the Democratic party.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 27. --The southern tip of Texas was fortifying itself late today against a tropical storm moving inland from the Gulf of Mexico, with its center apparently headed toward a point on the coast of Mexico, a hundred miles south of here.

The markets remained comparatively dull last week. Stock and bond prices averaged slightly higher on the week. Some commodities made small progress and others gave ground. The sharp rally in wheat futures yesterday enabled the active contracts to finish the week with net gains of about 1 cent a bushel; cotton showed little change.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 27. --The Brooklyn football Dodgers completed the equivalent of one week's practice in the first day of their training regime toady as the voluble Potsy Clark drove his husky and eager young charges through twin drills at the New York Aggies spacious campus layout.

PARIS.--France is preparing to construct an oil pipeline which will be the largest enterprise of the kind in Europe. It will be a secret line running inland from the coast to a point south of Paris and with probably a branch extending toward the east frontier near Nancy.

WITH a destination in mind, the week-end motorist off for a short but pleasant trip should be well provided with maps. These maps will show shorter, more beautiful and more convenient ways to arrange half-day to two-day itineraries than by the most obvious and most traveled routes.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 27.-- After tearing through two squalls, one of them a rare white one that screamed and stung, George Nichols's six-meter Goose, the United States defender, today easily won the first race of the international series for the Gold Cup of the Scandinavian Yacht Racing Union.

As provided by Congress, the Federal Savings and Loan Advisory Council holds at least two meetings a year in Washington, to consult with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on general business conditions and on special matters pertaining to the board and its agencies, including the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

THE completion of an order of seven autogiros for the Army Air Corps and the provisions of the Dorsey bill, allocating $2,000,000 for the development of rotary wing and other aircraft, have centered interest anew in the Philadelphia district upon the 'giro.

ALBANY, Aug. 27.--The decision of the Constitutional Convention to split its proposals into nine sections, for submission to the people, has probably increased the chances for the convention's proposals, but some of them face formidable opposition at the polls.
PROSPECTS for new speed records in closed-course racing appear excellent for the National Air Races which are to be held at Cleveland Airport next Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--When President Roosevelt last week told William Green, head of the American Federation of Labor, that he agreed on the need for legislative clarification of the National Labor Relations Act he aroused some not too exuberant hopes among many employing interests of the country and also considerable puzzlement as to just what he had in mind.

COMPARING New York and London television after a sixweek inspection trip of Euro pean tele-projects, Thomas H. Hutchinson, program director of the National Broadcasting Company, reports that a marked difference exists, chiefly because of what he terms "different conceptions of the purpose of the new art."

SEPTEMBER flashes the cue for the broadcasters to cast aside the Summer pattern of showmanship, and so this week the acts begin to shift, bringing old-timers back from vacation with new program ideas.

Prices of bonds eased yesterday in exceptionally dull trading in those securities on the New York Stock Exchange. The day's business aggregated $2,102,900, compared with $1,903,200 a week before, when business had been the second smallest in twenty years.
CANTON, China.--If the spirit of defeatism and compromise would seem natural and excusable in any city in China, it would seem so in Canton.

LIDO BEACH, L.I., Aug. 27.-- Burly 200-pound Mike Howlett dominated the scoring spotlight as the Illinois A.C. of Chicago defeated the Rio-Diablos team of Pittsburgh, 8 to 4, today in the opening match of the National A.A.U. men's senior outdoor hard-ball water polo championship.

IN the wake of the August symphonic festivals a scattering of notes remains to be recorded. First in importance is the rumor that there was a meeting between officials of the Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association and William Matheus Sullivan.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 27 (AP).--Ed Collins, 27-year-old former convict was stripped, nailed to a cross and left to die with his clothes burning at his feet because, he said, "I know too much."

Editor The New York Times Book Review I am grateful to Mr. Cameron McR. Plummer for assuming so kindly that the mention of Plymouth Brethren in my review of Stephen Leacock's playful work on Canada was a mere slip of the pen. In fact the slip occurred on the typewriter in hitting the upper case instead of the lower case "B."

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 27.-- Horace Havemeyer, a skipper with more than fifty years of experience, easily took the Star Class contest today with his Gull as the Great South Bay racing fleet sailed in the third invitation regatta sponsored this season by the local club.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27.--The Giant pennant ship, wallowing in the stormy pennant seas of the National League, fell apart at the seams today and all but foundered at Sportsman's Park.

Plans for the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York in Syracuse Sept. 15-17 are assuming definite form and several speakers have been obtained for the various sessions, Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights, president of the association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Eight complaints have been issued by the Federal Trade Commission charging certain manufacturers of tile with violation of the Robinson-Patman act by discriminating in price between different purchasers of tile of like grades and qualities.

FEW fliers have contributed more to the development of aviation than Commander Frank Hawks, who was killed last week when his tiny private plane crashed near East Aurora, N.Y. And few men had more genuine friends within the industry or among the general public.
PAU, France, Aug. 27 (AP).--Two accidents to army airplanes last night took eight lives, bringing to seventeen the number of French army and navy flying men killed in accidents in less than a week.

THE American Theatre Council means business. The business should ultimately mean Business, too. The theatre numbers among its members a large percentage of skeptics. "The Ticket Code won't work" and "The American Theatre Council is ineffectual."

Amendments to strengthen its code of ethics and nominations to members in its board of governors will be considered at the annual meeting of the Real Estate Board of New York, to be held on Tuesday, Sept. 20, in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--On the tenth anniversary of the KelloggBriand pact, Secretary Hull today reminded nations at war and those engaged in preparation for it that modern experience had demonstrated that even a victorious nation could not profit from armed conflict.

Attention has been called by the directors of the American Kennel Club to Section 8, Chapter 16, of the rules applying to dog shows, which reads in part: "A dog that is dyed, or whose appearance has been changed by artificial means other than those recognized by the standard of its breed, shall be ineligible to compete at any show."

Drapery and upholstery fabrics in new muted colors, made of inexpensive rayon and cotton, are in the decorating shops of some of the department stores waiting to be pounced upon by those who want to do over their homes this Fall without too great an outlay.

To the Music Editor: I was deeply shocked and grieved to find in Sunday's TIMES moral support to a group which I cannot think of except as utter morons. And that is the group one invariably encounters at opera and at symphony concerts--chronic clappers, who, if given the slightest opportunity, will burst into unbridled noise-making of the most distracting nature.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Aug. 28.-- Momentous developments south of Kiukiang on the west shore of Poyang Lake are indicated by the wording of an official Japanese Navy announcement that all day yesterday naval planes, assisting the army, had been intensively bombing Chinese forces in that sector.

Reviewing some of the improvements in appraisal technique which have been accomplished by the Home Owners Loan Corporation since it was created five years ago, Asa Groves, chief appraiser of that organization, declares that the modern appraisal of residential properties substitutes facts for guesses, with assurance to investors that they will get their money's worth.

A MAN especially familiar with dealer problems last week was elected president of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation. The board of directors chase from among their number S.L. Davis of Chicago, who has been the company's largest distributor for many years and a director for the last fifteen months.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--Sir John Simon's speech today, reiterating without any additions Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy as defined last March, came at the end of a week marked by two other events in the field of diplomacy--General Franco's adverse reply to Britain and the renewal of the German press campaign against the Czechs, accompanied by reports of German threats of intervention if the Czech deadlock continues.
MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 27 (AP). --Bjoern Borg of Sweden scored an upset victory in the 100-meter freestyle in an international swimming meet today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 25:
Mrs. Joseph M. Gazzam has arrived from Philadelphia, and is at the Hotel White.

Activity in the New York wholesale markets slowed perceptibly last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. "This lag was due to the adequate size of Fall retail stocks and slow consumer purchasing," the summary explained.

AFTER an interlude of eleven years the world's foremost tennis stars will stage their annual Davis Cup battle on American turf. It is all because, twelve months ago, a freckled, red-haired Californian brought the cup from its long exile abroad. Where Tilden, Vines and others failed, J. Donald Budge succeeded.

UNDERGROUND: "The Safest Railroad in the World" is the claim made by the Interborough, which operates one of New York's three subway systems. In the past nine years the road has carried 9,985,483,804 passengers, and until last week only one passenger had been killed during that period because of accidents in operation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 27.--Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, who is on a visit to South America, held a three-hour conference last night with Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Foreign Minister, and with Arthur Costa de Souza, Finance Minister.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 27.--Two Arab youths were wounded, one fatally, when troops today opened fire on a group that refused to disperse on order when caught setting fire to a closed wine shop at Jaffa.

BOSTON, Aug. 27.--The Senate committee investigating campaign expenditures declared tonight that Federal employes in California had been guilty of making illegal contributions to the primary campaign fund of Senator McAdoo but they found no evidence that the donations were "assessed or solicited."

LONDON, Aug. 27.--Still under the influence of the favorable United States foreign trade figures, the dollar was firm here today against sterling, closing at $4.87 1/16 to the pound. Spot francs hardened to 178 5/16 to the pound but the threemonth discount rose to 3 15/16 francs.

LIVERPOOL, N.S., Aug. 27.-- The United States tuna team took a long leg on the Alton B. Sharp Trophy today when they returned to the dock shortly after noon, having reeled in a score of sixteen fish, which gave them an eight-fish lead over the Cuban team and a sixteen-fish lead over the British.

In years of Presidential elections, this has usually been the time of greatest uncertainty regarding actual results of the campaign, the reason being that the high hopes of nomination week had not yet been reinforced, in the voting constituencies, by intensive canvass.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 27.--The unexpected resuscitation of the Little Entente at Bled is expected here to hamper Germany in carrying out any aggressive plans against Czechoslovakia.

THE shipment for which Susannah and her young mistress waited in a fever of excitement was General Washington's annual shipment of goods from London, and they fervently hoped for presents in it Susannah held a very special place at Mount Vernon and if the other slaves bent their efforts to keep her from becoming uppity little girls will find her a lively and ingratiating character.

IT is probably more than coincidence that has brought us, in this decade, a series of fine novels dealing with our historical past--the frontier the American Revolution, and, of course, in plethora, the Civil War. At least one English observer has suggested that American writers are seeking in their past an escape from a vision of the future which no longer seems bright and assured.

SHAD used to be so common along the mouth of the Con necticut River that it was considered actually plebeian to make much use of them for nourishment, and salmon were common, too. Once, long before the period of Edward M. Chapman's memories, a shoal of twentyeight--or was it thirty-eight?-- sharks were caught in Oyster River Bay, and hauled up the beach in two ox-carts.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 27-- President Roosevelt announced today his acceptance of the resignation of Adolf A. Berle Jr. as Assistant Secretary of State, effective Sept. 15. In a letter to the President asking his release Mr. Berle gave as his reason for leaving the State Department that the work for which he was appointed had reached a point where his services were no longer required.

CAMP FERRY, Ohio, Aug. 27.-- Detroit's policemen were outstanding on the pistol ranges in competition with many police teams from all parts of the United States and Mexico today. William Dale, with 293 and Clyde Sayers, 292, totaled 585 in the two-man team match for a new world record, but to win they had to outrank their Detroit rivals, Harry Reeves and Alfred Hemming, who also had 585.

AS literary critic, editor and biographer; as one of the more prominent scholars in the field of American history; as an author who has twice won Pulitzer Prizes, Mr. Allan Nevins holds the enviable position of a man whose pronouncements should be received with more than usual respect.

The increasingly ominous course of events in Central Europe brought renewed pressure upon the principal foreign exchanges yesterday and caused $10,250,000 of gold to be engaged in England for shipment here. This was the largest single day's engagement of gold since the movement began on July 26, and lifted the total shipped here from England since that date to $62,050,000.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27. --Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Bartlett Jr. gave a large reception this afternoon at their Summer home for Mr. Bartlett's daughter, Miss Betty Bartlett, and Lewis Kimball of New York and Kenosha, Wis., who will be married this Autumn.

A material known as opalescent floor coating has recently been developed by O.W. Ten Eyck, manager of the building at 33 Liberty Street, in cooperation with the paint engineers of Toch Brothers, Inc., of Staten Island. It was perfected after a careful study of methods toward solving some particular cement painting problems which arose in the Liberty Street building.
MORE and more hand-knitted clothes are entering into the conventional everyday picture. They are ceasing to be just hand-knits and are assuming the charm of city clothes, both in detail and color.

Another addition will be made today to the large number of welllaid-out and neat home communities on Long Island's North Shore with the formal opening of the New Salem residential center at Port Washington by the Williams-Harter Corporation, composed of Walter J. Harter and Cy Williams.
How wise is President Roosevelt in turning the New Deal's guns on the conservative sections of his own party?

LONDON.--The women of Britain --500,000 of them, between the ages of 17 and 65--are rapidly being enrolled in the new coordinated Women's Voluntary Services organization for national defense. The first of the many regional headquarters to be established throughout the country was recently opened in Liverpool by the Dowager Lady Reading, chairman of the new group.

The new motor liner Noordam of the Holland America Line, which will enter service between Rotterdam and New York on Sept. 28, completed her technical trials on a shake-down cruise in the North Sea, it was announced yesterday in a cable message to the New York offices of the line.

Although officials of the A. P. denied any such decision, considerable interest developed in the food trade last week over the report that the chain had ordered a halt on all negotiations for new super-market sites. This action was supposed to be in line with the growing belief that the super-market boom has about reached its peak and that from now on it may be expected to wane in many sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--In announcing today that the Department of Justice would proceed on Sept. 26 with the new trials ordered by the court for some of the defendants in the Madison oil case, Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, made the first specific proposals offered by any official of the New Deal for tightening of the anti-trust laws.

A total of 227 entries has been received for seven stakes which stud the meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club, starting tomorrow at the Aqueduct race course on Long Island. Carrying $45,500 in added money, the stake events will have a gross value of close to $60,000, and have attracted many of the best-known horses in the various age divisions.

Ten minutes after the audience of 2,200 persons had left, the large tent that housed the WPA circus presented for the last week at Tremont Avenue and East 177th Street, the Bronx, was destroyed by fire last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Printing ink that "explodes" to dry itself after it has been applied to the paper is described in a patent (No. 2,127,956) granted to Robert Helmer of Douglaston, N.Y.

France, caught like the rest of Europe in an international diplomatic crisis, has for months wrestled also with an economic crisis. Business has been poor. Public works, franc devaluation, attempted government economy have failed to spur improvement. Many Frenchmen have blamed the situation on the forty-hour week established during the 1936-37 Popular Front Ministry of Leon Blum.

GREAT cases crowd the holds of steamers Europe and Asia bound these days as the American aviation industry exports to the world. Curtiss pursuit planes roar above China's flooded battlefields; Martin bombers wing above Formosa, Consolidated flying boats take off from the icy waters of Russian harbors; Boeing fighters built on license abroad spin and whirl in dog-fights in Spanish skies; Douglas commercial airliners span Europe.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 26.--Idaho's New Deal Democrats feel their Senatorial candidate, James P. Pope, was defeated in the State's Aug. 9 primary election by three factors: invasion of the Democratic primary by Republican voters, shift in support by a strong Townsend following, and a bitter Gubernatorial contest between former Governor C. Ben Ross and Governor Barzilla W. Clark.

THIS late August morning's prime bulletin would say, simply, that the Group Theatre's next Broadway offering will be a play by Clifford Odets, its name being "Rocket to the Moon," its plot containing the first love story told by that author.

HERSHEY, Pa., Aug. 27.--Governor Earle accused the State Republican organization today of preparing to pour $5,000,000, "the greatest slush fund in Pennsylvania's political history," into the Fall campaign in an attempt to rout the New Deal and obtain "tax immunity" for "wealthy friends" of Republican leaders "at the expense of the needy."

In response to many requests a second annual Summer Institute for Garden Club members will be held at Rogers Rock on Lake George, N.Y., from Aug. 29 to Sept. 3. The sessions have been arranged by the Essex County Garden Club and many garden club officials and amateur horticulturists throughout the East are helping to develop the plans.

In so far as the United States Senate Resolution (S. Res. 215) only calls for the gathering of information on profit-sharing systems between employers and employer for dissemination among interested employers, its purpose is merely that of a fact-finding proceeding.

Negroes, whose struggle for jobs has been symbolized by picket lines in the black belts of large American cities for the past decade, have found encouragement in the recent agreement committing Harlem establishments to an employment policy which provides that at least a third of their sales, clerical and executive staff shall be taken from the race which provides the bulk of the population of the uptown district.

According to the way you look at it, if the President visits Baltimore, either "the despot's heel" will once again be placed on Maryland's shore or the national Democratic party leader will make a friendly visit there to notify Marylanders that their senior Senator, Millard Tydings, has not properly represented their adherence to the New Deal.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 27.--In accepting the challenge of his Democratic opponent, William Harvey J. Ely, former State WPA Administrator, to discuss his stand on the New Deal policies of President Roosevelt, W. Warren Barbour, Republican candidate for United States Senator, declared at his headquarters here today that Mr. Ely by asserting he was "100 per cent" for Roosevelt policies had made himself an "echo" rather than a genuine candidate for the United States Senate.

A COLLECTOR who starts out with the idea of confining himself to a single subject usually finds his desires outstripping his intention. The tendency to digress, so prevalent in conversation, becomes almost irresistible when it is a question of restricting book collecting.

BACK TO SCHOOL: When classes at the Columbia University Law School get under way next month, students will again have the opportunity of listening to Professor Roswell Magill. Since 1937 he has been on leave, serving as Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

An English observer, tolerably familiar with the United States, has recorded his impressions of one American "world" of whose existence we are all aware. It is, he wrote, "a world below that agreeable surface of genial acquaintances, excellent travel arrangements and scrupulous hygiene, which the visitor knows.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--Return of cool weather brightened the Chicago retail trade picture and indications were that the percentage of decline in comparison with a year ago had been reduced to below 8 per cent. In the preceding week, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, sales had been off 10.3 per cent for this city.

ASHEVILLE, N.C.--The second annual Mozart Festival will be the feature of the calendar here this week. The three-day festival, one of the first of its kind to be established in the United States, is sponsored by the Saturday Music Club.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP).-- Pittsburgh presented a patchwork line-up today and turned the tables on Philadelphia, 6 to 1, behind the seven-hit pitching of Big Ed Brandt.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 27. --Resumption of service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railway depends on clearing the company of its top-heavy debt structure, getting lower taxes and revising its operating budget and running schedule, it was said today by members of the citizens' committee appointed by Governor Lehman to study the predicament of the line.

A vast new apartment center is to be added to the growing residential accommodations of Forest Hills, Queens, following approval by the Federal Housing Administration of insurance for a $2,306,000 mortgage on the rental housing project.

BERLIN, Aug. 27.--For five days this week the German Fuehrer and the Hungarian regent have been intermittently in each others' company while Chancellor Adolf Hitler showed Admiral Nicholas Horthy the newly acquired might of the Third Reich and its great activity and apparent prosperity under his regime.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--After Manager Burleigh Grimes had shaken his batting order from top to bottom, the newly arranged Dodgers romped on Wrigley Field today and proceeded to shake the cocky Cubs from stem to stern, taking the series finale, 4 to 1, and breaking a losing streak at six games.

BELVIDERE, Kan., Aug. 27.-- Scattered through ten counties of South Central and Southwestern Kansas are the units in an agricultural industry doing a gross business of $10,000,000 a year which are finding nothing to complain about this Fall.

PARIS, Aug. 27.--After almost a week of protesting, arguing and playing politics with a close eye on the electors, Premier Edouard Daladier's Left Wing supporters came into line today in support of such modification in the application of the Forty-Hour Week Law as will assure national defense and national economy and finance.

TORONTO, Aug. 26.--A new record for the production of gold was set by Ontario mines in July. The previous high mark was exceeded by more than $600,000. Tonnage treated also set a new monthly reord, while average recovery for a ton jumped sharply compared with that of the two previous months.

PURPLE is young this year. For generations this color and all of its derivative shades have been relegated to that class called "old." Dowagers with chins cascading over their dog collars wore it. Widows emerging into second mourning swathed themselves in purple or lavender.

To the Art Editor: YOUR articles on American Art are very provocative. It seems to me that while we have had a number of good American artists, whose work you have shown, there is no distinctively American art. Others may feel differently, but certainly there is a widespread doubt.

Roy Wenzlick, president of Real Estate Analysts of St. Louis, points out that some illogical deductions have been made from the "back-tothe-farm" movement figures recently announced by the United States Census Bureau. The figures as given out, he admits, were accurate, but they failed to mention all the facts, as only the total was given of those who left the cities for the farms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--A loan program for the 1938 cotton crop, providing rates of 5.3 to 10.75 cents a pound, and an increase in the rates for loans on the 1937 corn crop from 50 to 57 cents a bushel, were announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Elmer F. Andrews, in his two weeks on tho job here as Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division in the Department of Labor, has proved surprisingly cool and unperturbed despite the tremendous task confronting him.

Seven runs in the first three innings enabled the Flatbush Indians to withstand the rally of the Flushing Blue Sox in the late innings and win, 8 to 7, to gain the final round of the Class C League in the New York City Baseball Federation play-off contests yesterday at Ebbets Field.

The plan for a vast new terminal market along the West Street waterfront of New York, recently proposed by Mayor La Guardia, has interest for housewives who shop around for the best values in beets and carrots and corn, and who are well aware that a penny saved is a penny earned.

ADHERING to "the Manchester idea," the Southern Vermont Artists yesterday opened their twelfth consecutive annual exhibition. Under the procedure adopted for these shows, any artist living within a fifty-mile radius of Manchester may send at least one work of art to be exhibited.

Interests connected with the Associated Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that they had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to their plan of reorganization for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, now undergoing reorganization proceedings in the United States District Court in Chicago.

Flood tide in New York Harbor shortly before noon yesterday brought with it the moment of launching for two warships, the light cruiser Helena, a 10-000-ton vessel costing about $16,000,000, in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, and the destroyer Lang, authorized in 1935 as a 1,500-ton ship at $4,000,000, in Kearny, N.J.
BOSTON, Aug. 26.--Vermont hears with astonishment of President Roosevelt's interest in a highway through the Green Mountains from the Canadian border to the Berkshires in West Massachusetts.

To all intents and purposes a college presents a group health problem. In an ordinary community, from a medical point of view, individuals may be considered chiefly as individuals; in a college they must be considered also as a group --fairly homogeneous in age and in general run of ailments, and for whom the college has a common responsibility.

WARSAW.--While it is easy to say that Polish opinion has been deeply moved by the events of the last few months in Central Europe, it is much more difficult to say how it has been moved and what the final reaction is likely to be. One thing stands out clearly.

Income derived by the average department store from the carrying charges of one-half of 1 per cent a month on installment purchases provides less than half the cost of handling the deferred payment business, according to the results of a study just completed by a committee headed by W.S. Martens, credit manager of Carson, Pirie, Scott Co., Chicago, under the auspices of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
An eleven-point platform for the coming State campaign was made public yesterday by the State committee of the Communist party. The platform was approved by the committee at a recent meeting.

Figures from average Wall Street houses support the contention that, while segregation of broker-dealer functions might be excellent for an ideal society operating in a perfect vacuum, it hardly can be made to work in the financial organism of today.

With the rise in commercial loans of banks in this city that has been shown in the last three weekly reports of the Federal Reserve Bank, a definite upturn in bank credit seems to have been established finally and the banking statistics have joined other business indicators in pointing toward recovery.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--What action, if any, will result from the hearings of the House committee to investigate un-American activities, now acessed in Washington for further research in other cities, depends upon the amount of public sentiment aroused.

ADHERING to "the Manchester idea," the Southern Vermont Artists yesterday opened their twelfth consecutive annual exhibition. Under the procedure adopted for these shows, any artist living within a fifty-mile radius of Manchester may send at least one work of art to be exhibited.

Interests connected with the Associated Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that they had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to their plan of reorganization for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, now undergoing reorganization proceedings in the United States District Court in Chicago.

Flood tide in New York Harbor shortly before noon yesterday brought with it the moment of launching for two warships, the light cruiser Helena, a 10-000-ton vessel costing about $16,000,000, in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, and the destroyer Lang, authorized in 1935 as a 1,500-ton ship at $4,000,000, in Kearny, N.J.
BOSTON, Aug. 26.--Vermont hears with astonishment of President Roosevelt's interest in a highway through the Green Mountains from the Canadian border to the Berkshires in West Massachusetts.

In an ordinary community, from a medical point of view, individuals may be considered chiefly as individuals; in a college they must be considered also as a group --fairly homogeneous in age and in general run of ailments, and for whom the college has a common responsibility.

WARSAW.--While it is easy to say that Polish opinion has been deeply moved by the events of the last few months in Central Europe, it is much more difficult to say how it has been moved and what the final reaction is likely to be. One thing stands out clearly.

Income derived by the average department store from the carrying charges of one-half of 1 per cent a month on installment purchases provides less than half the cost of handling the deferred payment business, according to the results of a study just completed by a committee headed by W.S. Martens, credit manager of Carson, Pirie, Scott Co., Chicago, under the auspices of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
An eleven-point platform for the coming State campaign was made public yesterday by the State committee of the Communist party. The platform was approved by the committee at a recent meeting.

Civilization itself has done much to make faith weak, said the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, special preaching missioner of the Free Church Council of Great Britain and formerly pastor of the City Congregational Temple, London, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

The bodies of fourteen Chinese victims of the Japanese machine-gunning of a Chinese-American-owned airliner in South China were reported recovered today from the sunken wreckage. [This accounted for all nineteen persons aboard the China National Aviation Corporation plane

Senator Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith is leading Governor Olin D. Johnston for the Senatorial nomi- The nation in South Carolina by a com fortable margin in a special preelection survey just completed throughout the State by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 43 per cent of capacity, up 2 points in a week and 6 points in four weeks. A fairly consistent increase has been in progress since the end of June, except for the setback in the week containing Independence Day.

The mystery surrounding the absence without leave of Harold White, until recently a patrolman at the West Sixty-eighth Street police station, was solved yesterday when Sergeant Fred Meyers found him contentedly operating a steam shovel in an upper Manhattan coal yard.

That the decline in exports of the Reich since April is only partly due to world reaction and is also partly due to the inability of the mechanical branches of German industry to deliver promptly is shown by a statement of the secretary of the German-Russian committees, who attributes the diversion of Soviet orders to the United States to the fact that German industries have not been able to meet delivery dates.

Bulgarian, Turkish and Greek troops today were in charge of the former demilitarized zone set up in 1923 in Thrace when it was divided among the three countries. They moved in yesterday to occupy sections of the zone along the borders of their respective countries.
Thomas W. Hulme, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad in charge of real estate, valuation and taxation, will retire from active service on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Louise Bloomingdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Bloomingdale, to Edgar Meyer Cullman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Cullman Jr. of New York and Stamford, Conn., took place here this evening on the lawn of her parents' home.

Hearty approval was given in financial circles to Premier Edouard Daladier's appeal to increase industrial activity so that the nation's defense program would not fall short of its goal. These circles feel that making the forty-hour week more elastic is the principal condition of economic and financial recovery.

Senator E. D. Smith issued a statement tonight expressing his "regret that President Roosevelt has seen fit to inject himself into the South Carolina Senatorial campaign in an eleventh-hour attempt to influence the voters."

After a firm opening, the stock market here reacted later in the week and, as no appreciable recovery followed, closed with substantial losses and a little above the lowest level of the mid-August decline.

167th St, 230-248 E (9-2452); Algy Building Corp to Prudential Insurance Co, 763 Broad St, Newark, N. J. extends mtgs. to Sept. 1, 1948, at 4 1/2 to 5%......$245,000 167th St. (9-2452), s?e cor of Sherman Ave, 204x58; Algy Building Corp to Prudential Insurance Co.................$71,000 Johnson Ave, 3,215 (13-3409B); Rebecca

The National Horse Show, one of the most important events of the late Autumn to members of society, will be held Nov. 5-12 at Madison Square Garden. The opening has been set for a Saturday this year instead of the traditional Wednesday after election day.

Dudley A. Giberson, assistant district attorney of Northampton County from 1920 to 1924, died today in Easton Hospital at the age of 46. He was stricken ill on Monday while on vacation at Ocean City, N. J., and underwent an operation on Friday.

Bolivia and Paraguay will exchange ratifications of the Chaco peace treaty here tomorrow at a special plenary session of the Chaco peace conference convened for that purpose. It is expected that immediately after this formality the delegates of the six mediating American nations, Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru, the United States and Uruguay, will form themselves into a new entity to be known as the Arbitral College of the Chaco.

" THE book which is pure baloney," observed Theodore Dreiser the other day, "gets the same space [from reviewers] the really good book gets. * * * Giving the same amount of space each day to a book, whether it is lousy or good, is misleading. Why should Thomas Mann get exactly the same linear space on Tuesday that is accorded a particularly unimportant book on Wednesday?"

The home here of James H. Baker, general manager of the Franklin Baker Division of General Foods Corporation, was partly destroyed by fire today, with damage estimated at $10,000. Firemen attributed the blaze to a defective chimney.

Willie ("Suicide") Jones, Negro, of Norfolk, Va., jumped out of a plane at Markham Field this afternoon. After a long delay he opened his parachute and landed safely. Then he announced he had broken the world's altitude record for parachuters.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Shea of this place and 1,100 Park Avenue, New York, announced tonight the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alicia Norma Shea, to Frank White Nesbitt of New York. The prospective bride attended the Dwight School in Englewood and the Marymount School and College in New York.

Contending that the farm problem can be solved only through the development of new uses for agricultural products, Representative Bertrand W. Gearhart, Republican, of California, requested Secretary Wallace today to support legislation for the development of such markets.

A bronze tablet was unveiled today in the First Presbyterian Church here in memory of the Rev. Dr. W. Courtland Robinson, who with his father, the late Rev. Dr. James H. Robinson, served the church either as pastor or pastor emeritus for a period of seventy-five years. The former died on March 15.

Military experts estimate that 2,500,000 persons have been killed in warfare throughout the world since the signing of the Kellogg-Briand Anti-War Pact in Paris ten years ago. At least $10,000,000,000 has been spent or lost in warfare since then, and the world now is spending well over that amount annually on its armies, navies and air forces.

King Christian's cousin, Prince Axel, director of the East Asiatic Company, had a narrow escape from drowning today while boating off Elsinore. Observing an angler playing a 400-pound tuna, Prince Axel tried to help him throw a line around the fish and was dragged from his boat into the water.

The American Communications Lloyd Association, C. I. 0. affiliate, made public yesterday a letter to Admiral E. S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, signed by Mervyn Rathborne, president of the association, declaring that it would not cooperate with the commission because of its alleged policies and actions.

Pirate Pennant Preferred dropped sharply again today as the boisterous Dodgers invaded the Forbes Field mart and, with bland disregard of the date and the Buccaneers' hopes, beat them, 8 to 5, in a knockdown-and-drag-out affair before 16,045 paying and pained patrons.
French prices showed mixed changes in the third week of August. The wholesale index on Aug. 20 stood at 644, unchanged from a week before and compared with 640 two weeks before.

A marked improvement for the franc in foreign exchange developed last week. Early in the week the official control fund had to intervene several times to bolster the currency, but subsequently buying and selling were fairly well balanced.

Frederick Brown, president of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1,919 Madison Avenue, said in his annual report, made public yesterday, that more than three-fourths of the service last year was given to patients who were either unable to pay anything or only a portion of the cost of their care. The total gross deficit of the hospital was $320,850, the report showed.

It would be difficult to imagine an occasion more ironic than the commemoration on Saturday of the tenth anniversary of the Kellogg-Briand pact. Great nations that ten years ago pledged themselves solemnly to renounce war as an instrument of national policy have since betrayed in their policy no evidence that such a pledge was ever made.

The New York Civic Orchestra, conducted by Milton Katims, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre. Virginia Peterson, 'cello, was the soloist and Caesar Finn the commentator. Miss Peterson was heard in Faure's "Elegy" and the Saint-Saens "Allegro Appassionata," Op. 43. The chief orchestral numbers were Schubert's "Unfinished" symphony and Mendelssohn's "Fingal's Cave" overture.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, accused the National Labor Relations Board today of having conspired with John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and the coal operators of Harlan County, Ky., to violate the Wagner act through what he described as a closed-shop agreement delivering the Harlan miners, like "sacks of salt," into Mr. Lewis's own union, the United Mine Workers of America.

Miss Dorothy Adelaide Milenthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Milenthal of 900 West End Avenue, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 11 for her marriage to Eugene King of this city. The ceremony, which will take place in the Sherry-Netherland, will be performed by the Rev, Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson of Temple Emanu-El.

Officials of the WPA circus announced yesterday that a new tent to replace the one that burned after a performance in the Bronx Saturday night would be ready for the next scheduled performance of the circus Wednesday at West New York. N. J.

A solemn mass for the repose of the soul of the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, who was Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will be sung Wednesday morning at 10 o'clock in the Church of the Annunciation, Convent Avenue and West 131st Street.

Almost 2,000 chronically ill and infirm aged persons in this city are receiving free housekeeping and nursing service in their homes, according to a report made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

Two sets of speeches have been delivered in the past fortnight by the spokesmen of the two leading governments of the world. Both were addressed to the same situation. To a Germany testing her armed strength at a time of acute European crisis, both carried a clear warning that war, once started, cannot be confined.

A dwelling on the upper West Side that is assessed for $20,000 has been sold for $7,000 in cash by the Andrew estate of Boston. It is at 123 West Seventy-eighth Street and was bought by a client of Charles K. Clisby Co., brokers, who said the seller's father was John A. Andrew, Governor of Massachusetts during the Civil War and a friend of Lincoln.

With a crowd of 6,000 lining both sides of the field, Old Westbury and Greentree came together at the Sands Point Club today in the most important test match the open polo championship teams have played as yet.

Even the mightiest of men, wearing Yankee uniforms, are not indefatigable. So it came to pass that Marse Joe McCarthy's roaring world champions, after five days of turbulent warfare and doubleheaders, suffered a sharp let-down yesterday as they squared off against Gabby Street's lowly Browns in the opening clash of a two-game series.

While the influence of the large favorable trade balance of the United States is considerable, the pound sterling derived some of its initial weakness from the increase in the size of Great Britain's adverse trade balance. For the first seven months

With a further decline of [Pound]3,900,000 in the circulation figures of the Bank of England for the week ended on Wednesday, the total decline in the three weeks since the August holiday peak amounts to ??19,100,000, compared with [Pound]15,600,000 for the same period in 1937.
Benigno Ramos, leader of the extremist Sakdal organization, was arrested on sedition charges as he arrived today from Japan, where he had spent four years in voluntary exile.

After a boardwalk parade today of sixty girls in bathing suits from cities, towns and villages throughout New Jersey, Miss Gloria Riley, 19 years old, of 228 Paterson Avenue, Paterson, was selected as Miss New Jersey, She will represent her State in the national beauty contee to be held at Atlantic City on Sept. 6.
Aviation authorities said today that the crash of the Albatross, Britain's fastest commercial airliner, would in no way retard the development of transatlantic service.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, who had a number of week-end guests at Beaulieu, gave a dinner tonight. Among those giving luncheons today were Mrs. Bradford Norman, who entertained at Brook Farm, Mrs. Nicholas Holmsen at Stoneleigh and Miss Julia A. Berwind at the Elms.
The Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., announced for publication today that its members have adopted the following principles as regards claims against merchandise:

The National Safety Council announced today that "for nine consecutive months--beginning last November-there has been an unbroken decrease in motor vehicle fatalities for the country from the corresponding months of the previous year." It added that "the saving in lives for the nine months was 5,310."
Exports of both pork and lard in July gained over those of the same month last year, the Institute of American Meat Packers reported today. Imports of pork declined substantially for the same period.
The discharge of explosives damaged a main line of the Tennessee Electric Power Company near Calhoun tonight, putting thirteen Tennessee communities in darkness.

Dr. William Lyon Phelps, Professor Emeritus of English Literature at Yale University, commented in his annual book lecture tonight on the "chilly reception" accorded by critics and the public to four books of the past year by recognized leaders of American fiction.

The trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader charged with conspiracy in the policy racket, will be resumed before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora this morning with corroboratory testimony from a group of new witnesses. The trial will enter its third week and attorneys for both sides seemed agreed that at least five more weeks would be required to complete all the proof.

Representatives of the New York A. C. maintained their grip on the national A. A. U. men's senior outdoor hardball water polo championship in decisive fashion today, splashing their way to a 4-to-1 verdict over the Illinois A. C. The Winged Foot organization took the title for the ninth straight year.

Behind the excellent pitching of Pete Lopes, who yielded three hits, the McKinley Triangles of Brooklyn turned back the Bronx Missions at Ebbets Field yesterday, to 0. The game was the first in double-header conducted by the New York City Baseball Federation.

Chautauqua's Summer residents spent the last week of their 1938 season giving their opinion on public matters. The results of the secret voting, as announced by Sanford Griffith, director, were as follows:

Miss Mary Imlay Taylor, author, died in a hospital today after an illness of three months. She came here from Washington two years ago. Her first book, "The Rebellion of the Princess," was published in 1903. Among her other books were

A hint has come from the congressional TVA investigation that the members of the inquiry committee may recommend a different executive board, in place of the original three-man directorate which was split up by friction between the now removed chairman, Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, and the other two directors.

As 8,500 Midwest Republican campaign workers milled around their tented city in a cornfield at Capehart Farms, Ind., they did not listen to the grass roots alone. The loudspeaker in the central tent boomed repeated warnings against pickpockets. Vicious disparagers assert that Republicans have nothing left in their pockets to pick, not even an issue.

The growing popularity in Great Britain of American sponsored radio programs is one of the arguments advanced in a statement just issued here by the radio defense committee of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, Ltd., as to why the British Government should not attempt to stop the broadcasting of sponsored programs in English from continental stations which sell time.

Life is like having to play a violin solo in public and to learn the in- in strument as one goes along, the Rev. Frank W. Murtfeldt, assistant pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Senator Vandenberg of Michigan warned here today that any attempt to subject the Supreme Court to political controls would be a potential blow at religious liberty. In an address before the Michigan Conference of Seventh Day

The marriage of Miss Sally Veronica Logue, daughter of Mrs. Walter J. Logue of this city and the late Mr. Logue, to Alan J. MacAdams, also of New York, son of Mrs. Henry Zavada and of Edward MacAdams, took place here yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd.

President Roosevelt called on South Carolina Democrats today to vote for Governor Johnston in the Senatorial primary Tuesday and to bring to an end the twenty-nine-year term of Senator. Ellison D. Smith, dean of Senate Democrats, as one who "thinks in terms of the past and governs his actions accordingly."

Bridge St, 27, s e cor Thitehall St: Scandinavian American Line BuildiBig, Inc, to Second Park West Corp, 11 Broad St ($147) Bowery, 245, ? e cor Stanton St; Vernon Murphy, referee, to Society for the Relief of the Destitute Blind; foreclosure ($35).

Prices of cotton moved within a narrow range last week as the trade awaited the announcement of the government's terms for loans on the crop. At the close of the market on Saturday, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points up to 4 down from the close of the week previous.
The Federal Trade Commission has charged the United States Maltsters Association of Chicago and its nineteen members with fixing and maintaining uniform prices for malt in violation of law.

With an exhibition of pitching courage seldom excelled, and a touch of neighborly assistance from the agreeable Dodgers, Hal Schumacher kept the Giants in the National League pennant fight as he downed the Reds today. 7 to 3.

National Socialism's fight on the Catholic Church, and on the Christian faith as such, today drew a rebuke from the College of Bishops in a pastoral letter read from Catholic pulpits throughout the Reich.
A four-alarm fire in the lumber yard of the Belmont Sash and Door Company, 649 Van Sinderen Avenue, near New Lots Avenue,

Washington dropped into the American League's second division today by losing to Cleveland, 6 to 5, and falling from fourth to fifth place. The Senators pounded Mel Harder for thirteen hits, but were ineffective in the pinches. It was Harder's thirteenth victory of the year. The Indians collected eleven hits against Monte Weaver and Joe Krakauskas.

Miss Dorothy W. Hafner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Hafner of Malba, Queens, will be wed on Sept. 22 to Miguel A. De Capriles, son of Mrs. A. M. De Capriles of Hempstead, and the late Mr. De Capriles. The ceremony will be performed in the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Hubert Wood,

A demonstration of the activities of the various bureaus and divisions of the New York Police Department will be given Sept. 28, 29 and 30 and Oct. 1 at Madison Square Garden, when the department's second annual show, "Around the Clock with New York's Finest," is presented for the benefit of the Police Athletic League.

Dr. Mary E. Dennis, a physician, died yesterday at her home here, after a brief illness, in her sixty-ninth year. Born in Boone, Iowa, Dr. Dennis came to California in 1890 and attended the Medical College at the University of Southern California. She practiced medicine

Gene Sarazen of Brookfield Centre, Conn., veteran campaigner of the fairways, today shot sub-par rounds of 70 and 68 to capture the $3,000 Lake Placid open golf championship with a seventy-two-hole total of 281.

The past and present sins of the church are no argument against the vitality and power of those parts of the Christian community that in every age have given ample evidence that their members were inspired by the living Christ, the Rev. John Thorn Golden said

Three men died today in a feud over a septuagenarian's alleged courtship of an octogenarian's wife. In the village of Canaje, an 81year-old native whose name was given only as Mariotti barricaded himself in his house after he was accused of killing a 72-year-old neighbor named Cappelloti.

Charges that the Home Owners Loan Corporation employs arbitrary methods and levies excessive legal fees on owners in distress are containted in a statement issued yesterday by the Bronx Home Owners Association, representing HOLC mortgagors in the borough.

The Larchmont Civio Association, at a public hearing in Mamaroneck Senior High School Tuesday night, will oppose a bond issue of $148,500 which the Board of Education of Union Free School District No. 1 of the town of Mamaroneck seeks to float. This represents the board's

Eugene Paton, president of the Warehousemen's Union, today charged the Association of San Francisco Distributors, representing about 180 warehouse owners, with "conspiracy" to smash this new C. I. 0. mass union by the "hot cargo" lock-outs which have closed about 110 warehouses in the past two weeks.

Plans have been completed by Miss Ruth Neilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franz Neilson of Maplewood, for her marriage to Louis Ettlinger McFadden of Peekskill, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William A. McFadden, which will take place here in St. George's Episcopal Church on Sept. 17.
Administration leaders have agreed to seek lower freight rates on farm products. moving to the sea for export, according to Chairman Jones of the House Agriculture Committee.

The fifth annual convention of the National Security Traders Association will be held in the Miami Biltmore Hotel, Miami, Fla., from Nov. 14 to 18, it was announced yesterday. Arrangements for the session are being made by the Florida Bond Traders Club, of which Clyde C. Pierce of the Clyde C. Pierce Corporation, Jacksonville, is president;

In the first sale of property opposit the court house in Jersey City in some time the Franklin National Bank sold to the Fieldman Company, Michael M. Kane, president, the two store buildings at 558-560 Newark Avenue, adjoining the northeast corner of Baldwin Ave nue. The buildings are three

The American Museum of Natural History has appointed Dr. George Gaylord Simpson, associate curator of the Department of Vertebrate Palaeontology, to lead an expedition to collect fossils in the heretofore almost untouched prehistoric beds of Northern Venezuela, it was announced yesterday.

Protection and strengthening of the National Labor Relations Board "to stop its emasculation by a reactionary judiciary" is one of his campaign pledges, it was declared here today by C. Dan Coskey, Republican liberal candidate for United States Senator, who will oppose former Senator W. Warren Barbour, organization designee, in the September primaries.

HARRIS-USOSKIN-Mr. and Mrs. Edward Usoskin announce the marriage of their daughter, Geraldine Katherine, to Mr. Irving Paul Harris, Thursday, Aug. 25, 1938, Great Neck, L. I. KAUFMANN - MARKS - Miss Josephine Marks to Mr. Myron Kaufmann on Saturday evening, Aug. 27, 1938.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.4, which compared with 79.9 the week before, 80.2 two weeks before, 81 three weeks before and 81.6 four weeks before.

N. B. Nelson, in 235 E. 73d St.: Mrs. Louis Hedley, in 14 E. 30th St.; Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers. Dr. Marsh McCall, Rye A. Wimer, Dr. John McGibbons, in 430 E. 86th St.; Irving Lugetkin, Dr. Thomas Howell, in 325 E. 79th St.; Sydney Landi,

Government loans of 57 cents a bushel on corn from last year's crop, which figure was nnounced yesterday and is expected to be named for the coming harvest, were regarded as temporarily bullish on United States markets, but are expected ultimately to have just the reverse effect.

The Board of Transportation is considering moving from ?? present location at 250 Hudson Street to a new building to be erected on cityowned property in Manhattan or Brooklyn, or to a commercial structure near City Hall, it was disclosed yesterday.

A fuller realization of life's limitations, especially limitations of time, strength and ability, was urged by the Rev. Dr. George Caleb Moor, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, at Thirty-first Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

Mexico's commerce with Japan has increased 1,250 per cent since 1932, it was stated today in a front-page article in the newspaper Popular. Noting that commerce with Japan was nearly thirteen times greater than it was six years ago, the article says:

The sixth annual Congress of Germans Living Abroad, officially other known as the Foreign Organization last f of the National Socialist party, was formally opened today with a speech by Rudolf Hess, Chancellor Hitler's deputy, in which he told countries that Germans abroad "do not mix in the affairs of other countries."

Heartened by England's success this Summer in winning the Walker Cup for the first time, eight members of Great Britain's women's golf team arrived today aboard the Franconia, seeking their nation's first triumph over the United States in competition for the Curtis Cup.
Current industrial reports are conflicting, but forecasts of an impending decline are fairly general. The Koenigsberg Eastern Fair was successful and Leipzig seems likely to do as well.

Acceptance of Christ is only the beginning, not the end, of the the Christian life, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Colgate-Rochester Baptist Divinity School, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.

J. B. Priestley's "I Have Been Here Before" will open at a Broadway theatre on Oct. 13, the Gilbert Miller office announced yesterday. It is news calculated to widen still further the breach between Mr. Miller and the Dramatists Guild, whose basic agreement between playwrights and producers he has never signed.

The disappearance of Lieut. Col. Edward G. McCormick, 50, from the steamship Borinquen en route to New York was announced today. The officer, who had been on duty with the Sixty-fifth United States Infantry here since last November, was bound for Walter Reed Hospital Washington, D. C., for observation and treatment.

An estimated 10,000 bathers saw 18year-old John Bianchi win the annual Long Beach lifeguard championship one-mile ocean swim this afternoon. Bianchi, a first-year man on the patrol, beat fifteen other contestants in the time of 18:01. He also holds the fifty-meter Long Island interscholastic title.

The Indian Rights Association, through its president J. M. Steere, made public today a letter addressed to President Roosevelt appealing for drastic correction in the administration of the affairs of 50,000 Navajo Indians in New Mexico and Arizona.

Michael Alburg, 33 years old, a citizen of the Netherlands, faced deportation when he arrived yesterday on the Holland America liner Statendam after a free round trip to his native land. He is one of the few persons, officials said, who ever has been able to get to Europe and back stowed away on the same vessel.
Frank J. markets. Hogan, president of the American Bar Association, announced today the appointment of the association's committee on labor, employment and social security.

While officials investigating the isolation block deaths of four Holmegburg prison convicts took a much-needed rest today, plans were completed for scientific tests to be made at the jail tomorrow under the direction of Charles I. Engard, State Secretary of Welfare.

Governments that try to use the church for their nationalistic ends were attacked in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive secretary of the National Lutheran Council, at the Advent him Church, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

DRIVERS UP, by Dwight Akers. (Putnam, $5.) The story of American harness racing. FULL RECOVERY OR STAGNATION, by Alvin H. Hansen. (Morton, $3.50.) A study of cyclical fluctuations and of full employment of resources.
Six men charged with reselling tickets issued for renting rowboats in Belmont Lake State Park here are under arrest awaiting a hearing before Justice of the Peace John C. Robbins on Tuesday morning.

A supreme test of Catholic faith in this country may not be far off, the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg said yesterday in his sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Father Kellenberg is a member of the cathedral staff.

Miss Virginia Trofter Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Maxwell Hyde of this city and the late Mr. Hyde, has chosen the afternoon of Sept. 22 for her marriage to W. Radford Bascome Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bascome, also of New York, formerly of St. Louis.

Lumber production in the week ended on Aug. 20 was about the same as ?n the preceding week, which was highest of the year to date, but shipments were the lowest in four weeks, according to a report of the National Lumber Manufac?rers Association, based on statistics from regional associations covering the operations of important softwood and hardwood mills.

John A. of the Albatross, Britair Roosevelt, the President's youngest son, will begin his business career tomorrow as a stock clerk in a deapartment store. His salary will be eighteen dollars a week. His carefree college days at Harvard and a honeymoon in Bermuda

Jarvis S. (Chubby) Hicks and Whitney Harb, his brother-in-law, staged an amazing finish to win the Arthur Mann Memorial golf tournament for member-guest teams at the Seawane Club today when, 3 down at the fourth tee, they strung out thirteen holes in 2 under par to beat A. C. Giles of Seawane and Percy Furber of Wee Burn, 3 and 2, in the 18-hole final.

Several important decisions taken by the Nazi party in Germany jointly with the Nazis of Poland and military quarters in the Third Reich are likely to upset Germany's plans to strengthen her bonds to Poland.

Nicholas Massue, Canadian-born tenor of the Metropolitan Opera of New York, appeared before an enthusiastic audience in the Chase Barn Theatre here this evening for the benefit of the Whitefield Athletic Field, sponsored as a war-time memorial by the American Legion, members of which attended in overseas uniform.

THE football fellows are passing the ball around, the leaves are beginning to turn and there may be a hard Winter coming on. Apparently the Montreal Maroons, late of the National Hockey League, couldn't face it. They folded up. That cuts the league down to seven teams, which approaches the ridiculous for a game as popular over such a wide area in the United States and Canada.

Professor A. U. N. Camera, head of the Department of Romance Languages at Brooklyn College, who had been here on vacation with his wife, died early today in a hotel after a brief illness. His age was 59. Mrs. Camera left New Orleans for New York tonight, accompanying her husband's body.

This writer is in a position to say that Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Austrian Chancellor, is in good health and, as a prisoner of honor, he is allowed to read books and write while detained at secret police headquarters here. He is not, however, allowed newspapers and he has no radio.

An edition of Shakespeare's plays in thirty-seven volumes, designed by Bruce Rogers and illustrated by such artists as Molnar, Eric Gill, Legrand, Lapshin, Carnevali, Ricart, Gordon Craig, Boardman Robinson and Arthur Rackham, is being published by the Limited Editions Club in a subscription edition of 1,750 sets.

The flow of German political refugees to the United States under the Roosevelt-Hull policy of aiding emigres has started at the rate of nearly 100 a day. Dispatches reaching here say that the United States Embassy in Berlin is not accepting any more applications from German (including former Austrian) Jews, and has enough on hand to fill available immigration quotas for virtually two years.

Twenty-five thousand silk and rayon dyers of North Jersey and New York will start work under a new two-year contract Thursday. Following a meeting of Paterson Local 1733, officials of the Federation of Dyers, Finishers,

President Roosevelt says that the United States will gladly reduce its armaments if other nations reduce theirs. He gave this assurance in a letter sent to John Callan O'Laughlin, publisher of The Army and Navy Journal, for publication in a seventy-fifth anniversary number of the journal.

Mrs. Walter B. Sullivan of this city, who also resides at the Ambassador Hotel in New York, gave a dinner at her home here this evening at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Clayton Sayre Sullivan, to Gregory S. Mangin of New York, well-known tennis player.

Forsyth Wickes, who will arrive today on the Normandie, will be at the St. Regis before going to Newport to join his family at Zee Rust, their Summer home there. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shepard Lee of Cincinnati will return to the Waldorf-Astoria today. They will go to Bretton Woods, N. H., on Wednesday.

Gales that howled along the lower Texas coast died down tonight and barometers rose, indicating that the hurricane which imperiled ten Texans on an island midway between Brownsville and Tampico had passed inland during the day. The fate of the ten still was unknown.

President Lazaro Cardenas has paid at least one person for agrarian land nationalized by Mexico, it was revealed today when the Society of Mexican Small Agriculturists inserted an advertisement in the newspaper El Universal.

Mr. and Mrs. George Conover Osborn of 277 Park Avenue, formerly of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Osborn, to George Jackson Pearson, son of Mrs. George Jackson Pearson of 510 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Pearson.
Jack Eelman pitched the Paterson Red Sox to a 7-2 victory over the New York A. C. yesterday at Travers Island.

It is still impossible to report any apparent increase in activity in 'the British markets. Neither the international political problems nor the business situation in the United States has warranted a revival thus far or offered any inducement to financial leaders to cut short their Summer vacations and return to the City.

Four teams polished their weapons today for the start next Sunday of the national open championship as Aurora defeated the Ramblers, 8 to 5, at Bostwick Field, while Aknusti vanquished the Jaguars, 8 to 6, at Meadow Brook's Cochran Field.

Six of the twelve titles at stake in the metropolitan championship rowing program on the Harlem River yesterday went to the New York A. C. as the Winged Foot oarsmen romped off with the principal honors. The remaining crowns were

Charles Amandoles of La Tourette, S. I., today captured the New Jersey public links championship. In the four-day event at the River Vale Country Club Amandoles took the medal in a field of ninety-one. In the final he defeated Joseph Sage of Mosholu, 5 and 3. Sage was the runner-up last year.

Production in the shirt and pajama industry in July, increased 4 per cent as compared with July, 1937, according to figures issued for publication. today by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers. The industry operated at 69 per cent of capacity during July, against 73 per cent in June and 64 per cent in July a year ago.

The statement of William Green attacking the NLRB and John L Lewis on their handling of the liar lan mine case follows: The press reports that the Harlan County, Ky. coal operators association has signed a closed shop contract with the United Mine Workers of America, covering from 12,000 to 15,000 employes.

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against CHARLES S. LANGBERG CO., INC.. sheet metal and ventilating equipment, 437 W. 53d St.-By Mandel Levy, doing business as West Side Supply Co., $933; Shanker Steel Ceiling Co., Inc., $210; W. E. Pruden, Inc., $104. Mordecai M. Richter was appointed receiver under $1,000 bond by Judge Patterson.

The foreign trade statement published for July shows no change in the general trend which began in the Summer of 1937, along with business reaction, and which has contrasted so strikingly with that of the preceding twelvemonth.

Burton Oliver Gibbs, who retired last June after twenty-five years' service as New York district manager of John Morrell Co., Inc., New York meat packers, died at his home here this morning of heart disease. He was 73 years old.

Foreign missionaries on the Tibetan border today reported the death of The Regent, through whom the Dalai Lama, or Political Pontiff of Tibet, acted. Tibet thus is without three key figures. The thirteenth Dalai Lama died in December, 1933.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt aligned himself yesterday with Representative John J. O'Connor in the fight of the Democratic House Rules Committee chairman for the Republican nomination this Fall in the Sixteenth Congressional District. Mr. O'Connor is opposing Allen W. Dulles for the Republican nomination. His Democratic primary opponent is James H. Fay.

The Lord has need of man just as much as man needs God, the Rev. J. Alfred Kaye declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. Mr. Kaye is pastor of New Court Congregational Church, Tollington Park, London, England.

Three hundred and sixty-four days of the year Cloudy is just an or-, dinary cat. Yesterday, as residents of East Eighty-third Street suspected as they heard his mournful Voice rending the air at 5 A. M., was the 365th day.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, denied today, in a letter to the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, the charges of Senator Berry of Tennessee that WPA officials had engaged in political activity to defeat Mr. Berry in the recent primary election. Mr. Hopkins counter-charged that Senator Berry had sought to dominate WPA appointments in Tennessee soon after he entered the Senate last year.

Archibald S. Knight, who retired in 1936 as principal of the George Inness Junior High School, died at his home here today after a long illness at the age of 79. Coming to Montclair in 1907, he served as the first principal of the Central Grammar School, continuing with the school when it became the Hillside School and later was made a junior high school.

John J. Ryan, noted oldtime sculler, died at his home here tonight from a heart attack. His age was 74. Mr. Ryan was winner of three Canadian singles championships, and won twice the United States national title when he was at the height of his career forty-five years ago.

By coincidence the massing of German troops along the Czechoslovak border, which is causing undisguised concern here, occurs just as a new annual class of recruits is being inducted into the Red Army.

Official anouncement that the United States Government would buy cash wheat ??nd sell the grain for export, the ??ourse that is being followed by the Canadian Wheat Board, a government organization, injected late ??ast week a new influence into the world wheat situation.

Continuing their unbeaten pace, the Governors Island Yellows routed the Bethpage Shamrocks, 11 to 4, yesterday at the Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L. I., for their fifth straight Eastern Polo League victory. The home quartet provided the Army champions with keen opposition for two periods before succumbing to a powerful drive.

The New York Americans, National Cup winners in 1937, defeated the Glenyard soccer eleven of Montreal,-4 to 1, before 2,000 fans in the opening game of the season at Starlight Park yesterday. The New Yorkers led at half-time by 1-0. Fred Ludkefedder shot the first three goals for the victors.
