A charge made at the recent Constitutional Convention that the Children's Court division of the Domestic Relations Court had a record of 100 per cent reversals in the Appellate Division last year, was flatly denied by Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court in a supplement of his annual report for 1937, made public yesterday.

Justice and Mrs. Norman S. Dike of New York were luncheon hosts at the Bar Harbor Club for Mr. and Mrs. William McNair, Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant, Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, General and Mrs. J. W. Kilbreth, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Sweeney, Mr. and

James F. Burkitt Jr. charged yesterday that all visitors to his father, who is serving six months on a disorderly conduct charge in the Hudson County penitentiary at Secaucus, N. J., as the result of a political speech against Mayor Hague of Jersey City, had been barred.

13th St, 416-18 E; Dora Kaplowitz to Nathan Kaplowitz, 1,018 Ocean View Ave. Brooklyn: prior mtg $22,500; purchase money mtg $10,000, 3 year, 6 per cent. 81st St, 418 E; Minnie Ohmer to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; purchase money mtg $20,321.

Miss Mary Beall Ewing of 616 Palisade Avenue, youngest daughter of the late General Thomas Ewing of the Union Army, died today in Sorrento, Me., at the Summer home of a brother, Thomas Ewing, New York lawyer.

One of the most important smallbore matches of the national program was fired today, nearly 600 competing in the preliminary Dewar event, with .22 caliber rifle. Charles G. Hamby of Atlanta headed the list of seven who came through with possible scores of 400, his string of 31 Vs in the bulls-eye giving him first place.

Cliff E. Grover of Newark, N. J., and Norman B. Smith of Philadelphia brought Teaser home a winner once more today in the International Star Class race and annexed the Barnegat Bay fleet championship and the Grover Trophy.

The announcement at Hyde Park of a Presidential visit to Maryland in behalf of Representative David J./ Lewis's Senatorial campaign drew a crisp "no comment" from Senator Tydings, who was put on the Administration's "purge list" early in the campaign.

The starting eleven of the New York football Giants, captained by Mel Hein, outscored a rival squad led by Ed Danowski, six touchdowns to two, in a regulation game today ordered by Coach Steve Owen to prepare for the game with the Eastern College All-Stars on Sept. 7 at the Polo Grounds.
The government's Monopoly Investigation Committee is considering the possibility of using the merchandise-buying power of Federal agencies as a big stick in commodity markets.

After three months on the market, production of "Wings" shirts, made by the Piedmont Shirt Company, Greenville, S. C., has been stepped up to 3,000 dozen a week and an expanded advertising campaign in newspapers and magazines will be launched-for the Fall season, according to Samuel Wolf, manager of the New York office.
The day. "only major circus on the road" since the "Greatest Show on Earth" closed has shown a profit and will continue its tour, John Ringling North decided.

Detectives Peter Merylo and Emil Musil today took Emil Fronek, a middle-aged man, on a tour of a section where several victims of Cleveland's twelve torso killings were found, in an effort to run down the newest "clue" in the slaylings.

As pretty Eleanor Flanagan stepped forward to smack the nose of the city's new fireboat with a bottle of champagne the breeze from Kill van Kull flung back her long red cape, fluttered the plumes of her helmet-like hat and carved her white dirndl gown into the classic curves of the Victory of Samothrace.

The tendency of Americans to think more of their rights than of their duties was described yesterday by the Right Rev. Fred Ingley, Bishop Coadjutor of Colorado, as "the fatal weakness of American democracy."

Major Alexander P. de Seversky, airplane manufacturer, flew into Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn at 7 o'clock last night in a new type of military pursuit speed plane and announced that he would take off at 6 A. M. today in an attempt to break the transcontinental speed record.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and forthcoming marriage of Miss Ada Spiegle, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Spiegle of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Spiegle, to the Rev. Dr. B. Benedict Glazer, son of Mrs. Simon Glazer of this city and the late Rev. Dr. Glazer.

Connecticut Democrats will vote tomorrow in primaries, caucuses and conventions which may have an important bearing on the outcome of the bitter fight for nomination to the Senate seat now held by Augustine Lonergan, accused by New Dealers of "disloyalty" to President Roosevelt.

The army high command intends to ask President Roosevelt's active support for an appropriation from the next Congress to start work on an air base in Alaska. The project would supplement defensive measures already undertaken or proposed by the navy along the shortest route between America and the Orient.

California's primary campaign, marked during its closing days by many charges involving candidates for major offices and by the re-entrance of President Roosevelt into the Democratic Senatorial fight, was nearing an end tonight with the largest field of candidates in the State's history seeking the balilots of 3,454,058 voters, a record enrollment.

Lacking the fanfare that should be attendant upon such an event, the first scene of "Gone With the Wind" has been shot. During the week-end Selznick-International dispatched a camera crew to a local hospital and photographed the newly born son of Mrs. Vincente Servin Numo. The infant will be used in the picture as Bonnie Blue, Scarlett O'Hara's firstborn.

The German wholesale price index for Aug. 17 was 106.1, unchanged for the week. Non-ferrous metals reacted sharply. In the first seven months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.9, on July 27.

The statement yesterday by Sir John Simon, British Chancellor of, the Exchequer, was received with relief in League of Nations circles today and Germany's reported annoyance with the British stand has encouraged the hope that it will give Berlin pause for this year at least.
Stocks slightly higher for second consecutive week; turnover, 4,706,670 shares. United States Government issues irregular, corporation and foreign bonds irregularly higher; transactions, $26,851,800.

With ables set on the lawn of the Lenox club, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Blake Payne of New York, who are at lakeside , gave a luncheon for a large party today. The guests inluded Mr. and Mrs. John D. Kennedy and their guest, Mrs. Granger Blair of Washington;

Many non-Christians notice no difference between professing Christians and those who do not Profess Christianity, the Rev. Dr. Lloyd Russell Gillmett, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Duluth, Minn., said yesterday in a sermon at St. James Episcopal Church,

There was a new leader in the standing for the Bermuda Trophy after today's International Class race, while the top skipper in the Atlantic Class series for the Noyes Trophy had his advantage cut sharply by three other competitors.

Mr. and Mrs. Don Mundy, North Vancouver mountaineers, believe they have found a great new peak in the Coast Mountain Range. Accompanied by their daughter Edith, Henry S. Hall Jr. of Boston, and Hermann Ulrichs of San Francisco, they sighted the peak near Bella Coola in the Southern British Columbia coast district.

Alpine rescue squads brought down into the valley near Schwyz today the bodies of six Swiss Army fliers who were killed when their three planes crashed into Muolathal Mountain in a heavy fog yesterday. Two fliers who survived the crash of a fourth army plane were taken to a hospital.

Many luncheon parties were given today at estates throughout the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin entertained with a luncheon at Les Alouettes, their place on Lake Agawam, for Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler.

Imports of iron and steel products, other than scrap, in July amounted to 14,094 tons, valued at $955,215, compared with 15,573 tons, valued at $1,035,536 in the preceding month and 41,188 tons valued at $2,084,401 in July, 1937, according to preliminary information issued today by the metals and minerals division of the Department of Commerce.

Although the daily turnover in the London bullion market continues on a large scale, it is steadily subsiding and is now less than half of the volume reached during the currency scare which was revived in such pronounced fashion earlier this month.

A three-alarm fire at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning destroyed the one-story brick factory building of the Carvin Bottle Cap Company at 418 Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn. Firemen prevented the spread of the fire to near-by frame buildings and -no one was injured.

Offering will be made to the public today by Lord, Abbett Co., Inc., of a new issue of $3,000,000 of 5 per cent ten-year secured convertible debentures of Affiliated Fund, Inc., an open-end investment trust. The debentures will mature on Jan. 1, 1948. They will be offered by means of a prospectus at par and accrued interest.

Dress orders arriving in the wholesale market last week were for diversified types, with the costume suit leading, and schoolgirl types in woolens, velveteen and combinations of these fabrics also favored. In the coat market fur boleros and fur sleeves or tuxedos were favored style details, and orders began to arrive on two-piece suits for under-coat wear, furtrimmed sport coats and unfurred tweeds and fleeces.

Winners of Six John Bard honorary scholarships at Bard College, a residential unit of Columbia University, were announced today by Dean Harold Mestre. Named for the principal founder of the college, these scholarships are awarded annually to upper classmen for distinguished achievement in their studies and are the highest scholastic honor given by the college.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has reported for the six months to June 30 a net profit of $3,715,130 after depreciation, amortization, contingencies and Federal income taxes. This is equivalent to approximately 96 cents each on the 3,840,000 shares outstanding.

France moved troops into position on her eastern frontiers facing Germany and Italy today for manoeuvres. [These operations were announced Saturday. More than 20,000 men-including an infantry division and cavalry, artillery,

To the accompaniment of the plaudits of a gallery of several hundred enthusiasts, Champion Nornay Saddler, on the other end of the lead from his handler, Leonard Brumby, marched out of the ring today with the best-in-show award in the first exhibition staged by the recently organized Suffolk County Kennel Club, which was held on the grounds of the Timber Point Club in this village.

United States swimmers continued to make a good showing in their barnstorming trip through Germany by winning three of six events in competition with German, British; Hungarian and Swedish swimmers today.

The water was calm, the weather mild and the herring numerous, but the second day of the international tuna angling matches among Cuba, Great Britain and the United States was almost victory for the tuna.

Bromley Stone's Teal II and Seward De Hart's Rissa were established as the victors in the City Island Yacht Club's annual 150mile overnight race to Cornfield Light vessel and return yesterday, as other first prizes in the four-inone regatta were taken by Curtis Arnall's Truant II, Harold M. Scott's Dawnell, Robert P. Baruch's Kirawan II and Ralph W. Proctor's Allouette.

Dr. Arch B. Chappell, head of the department of pediatrics at Horton Memorial Hospital, Middletown, since the hospital was established in 1929 and consultant in children's diseases at several hospitals in Southern New York and Northern New Jersey, died today at the age of 55.

Samuel Goldberg, paper boxes, in 39 Broome St: Equipment Custom Service Corp, auto accessories, in 645 11th Ave; Patsy Benza, men's clothing, in 142 5th Ave: B R Soda Fountain Mfg Co, in 130 Bleecker St, through Simon Doyne; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, brokers.

Near-by deliveries of lard sold at new seasonal low levels last week on the Board of Trade, with the cash article selling at the lowest price since August, 1934. Scattered liquidation by holders of September contracts, induced by weakness in grains and prospects of liberal supplies of heavy-weight hogs in the near future, was responsible for the decline.

Torrential thunderstorms prevented Regent Nicholas Horthy and his wife from reaching Hungary tonight on the Danube. They left Linz this morning after the Regent had inspected the Danube flotilla having headquarters there.
Ed Gossett, 35-year-old attorney, defeated Representative W. D. McFarlane in the Democratic runoff primary yesterday.

Hubert C. Verhey Jr., a former memper of varsity football, basketball and track teams at Bucknell University, from which he was grad??ated in 1934, died in Germantown Hospital today of an internal ailment. He was 26 years old.

Applications are now open for the following positions in the City Service. Details are available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Municipal Building, or in The City Record. Here are physical and residence requirements:

As the result of an urgent request from Viscount Runciman, British mediator, Konrad Henlein, Nazi leader, today canceled his inflamatory "inspection tour" of the Sudeten area to confer with Lord Runciman.

Alexander Newlands, former thief civil engineer of the London, Midland and Scottish Railway, died in Glasgow today at the age of 68. Mr. Newlands, who was chief civil engineer of the London, Midland and Scottish Railway from 1927 until his retirement in 1933, had previously been engaged in many railway surveys and had supervised the construction of several lines.
The Newark Bears swept their four-game series with the Jersey City Giants today, winning the final, 4 to 3. The Little Giants outhit the Bears, 12 to 7.

Representative Hamilton Fish said today that Republicans of Dutchess County, President Roosevelt's home district, had no fear of political threats, reprisals or coercion. "Liberalism, backed by coercion and compulsion, is orthodox Nazi doctrine," Mr. Fish said in an ad- made dress before a Republican meeting near here.

When she was 200 yards from the finish in the second race for the Scandinavian Gold Cup today, George Nichols's United States defender Goose of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club had used-up the time limit for a contest, which is required to be sailed at a minimum average of three knots an hour.
Charles Gabor won the International Snipe Class championship today by taking the final of the series of races on Lake Wawasee.

Long Island society turned out 10,000 strong for a charity baseball game here today on Pete Bostwick's polo field. They alternately cheered and roared with laughter at a game that surpassed in humor what it lacked in skill.

It was Connie Mack Day at Shibe Park today and his Athletics responded with a double victory over the White Sox, 5 to 4, and 7 to 2. Baseball's "Grand Old Gentleman" was presented with a plaque at ceremonies between the games. Will Harridge, president of the American League, made the presentation.

Brien McMahon, assistant attorney general in charge of the Criminal Division and chief of government counsel at the Harlan, Ky., trial, said in Washington today that he had made "no commitments of any kind or character" to "any

Carlos Saavedra Lamas, former Argentine Foreign Minister, has announced his inability to attend the meeting of the committee for codification of American international law in Lima in November. The committee will meet on the eve of the eighth Pan American conference.
Gordon M. Ibbotson has been appointed Eastern district manager in charge of a new branch sales office just opened in this city by Gerber Products Company, Fremont, Mich., makers of Gerber Baby Foods.

Science has given us eyes to see how evolution worked but it has not told us why it works, the Rev.. Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, associate pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon.
There vet was plenty of good pitching today as the Cardinals and Bees split a twin bill, the Red Birds taking the opener, 5 to 1, and the Bees scoring a 2-0 shut-out in the nightcap.

The Boston police team eleven mil was leading with a score of 1,479 in the second day's shoot of American Legion Post 509 on the range here. Patrolmen Markland and Baker held high scores for their team with 297 each. New York City Police Team No. 3 was second with a score of 1,459 and the Erie Railroad Police Team No. 1 third with 1,455.

This schooner, bearing the MacGregor Arctic Expedition homeward, was seventy-five miles northeast of St. Johns, Nfld., today. There were strong south winds and the weather was foggy. We were driven back about thirty miles last night. A heavy sea

Certainly the humming bird is among the most attractive of our feathered friends. The owner of a country garden who has not had it expropriated by a rubythroated humming bird lacks a flicker of color as dazzling and tremulous as any his blooms can show.
Although there were fewer fatalities, Arab irregulars in the past twenty-four hours were as active as ever with sniping and arson. Two Greek monks who were kidnapped nearly a week ago from

The French liner Normandie, due today from France and England, has among her prominent passengers Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Henry Morgenthau; Ira Nelson Morris, former United States Minister to Sweden; Jules Bache, banker; Antonio D. Marin, Spanish Consul in New York;

(Figures in parentheses indicate par.) Brookville (72)-Mixed foursome competiion: Mrs. W. J. Fisher and A. H. AnIrews, 85-13-72; Mrs. Sidway and H. B. seaman, 80-7-73. Low gross winners, Mrs. H. K. Seaman and George Meredith, '7. Final round for Governors' Trophy: C. Gower defeated H. B. Allen, 3 and 1.
The Cubs swept their third doubleheader in eight days and crept within half a game of the secondplace Giants today by defeating the Phillies, 6 to 5 and 3 to 1.
Supply contracts valued at $4,796,075 were awarded during the week ended Aug. 25 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Twenty-five priests and ten nuns, headed by Archbishop Michael J. Curley of Baltimore and Archbishop John J. Cantwell of Los Angeles, returned from Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic. Most of them had attended the Eucharistic Congress at Budapest.

Sixty Young Republican State presidents, national committee representatives and other leaders in the organization from thirteen Eastern States and District of Columbia were in conference here today. They exchanged views of problems of different geographical areas and heard an address by Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher.

I owe to smoking, more or less, Through life the whole of my success; With trusty pipe I'm sage and wise, Without I'm dull as cloudy skies. When smoking, all my ideas soar; When not, they sink upon the floor. The greatest men have all been smokers,

Leaders of 46,000 United Automobile Workers in Wisconsin, Minnesota and Northern Illinois revolted today against John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. They voted to ask the international executive board to discontinue per capital payments to the C. I. O. The auto workers have been paying 5 cents a month per closed ab man to the C. I. O.

Declaring that freedom of labor and religious freedom "stand or fall together," the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America made public its annual labor Sunday message yesterday with a warning against all dictatorships and with an appeal for constructive cooperation between industry and Way labor.

The dollar volume of wholesale trade declined 18 per cent in July, compared with the same month of 1937, according to reports made public today from 2,360 wholesalers cooperating in the monthly joint study of the National Association of Credit Men and the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick Motor Division of General Motors Corporation, said today that orders for 35,000 tons of sheet, strip and bar steel had been released by Buick to meet production requirements for new models in the next three months.

A genuine recovery never has been built on actual or prospective currency depreciation or the artificial stimulus of governmental borrowing and spending, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York declares in a discussion of business depressions and recoveries in the current issue of its monthly publication, The Guaranty Survey.

United States Maltsters Association, Chicago, and its nineteen member manufacturers are charged in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission with fixing and maintaining uniform delivered prices for malt. The respondent manufacturers are:
Increased nervousness over the government's financing methods and the distribution plans for raw materials brought about some unsatisfactory developments in the last week.

The theft from St. James Church at Merrick Road and 108th Avenue, South Jamaica, Queens, used by a Negro congregation, of silver articles used in the services was reported to the police yesterday by the Rev. Montravalle Spatches, the minister. Burglars evidently entered the church by breaking a basement window Saturday night, he said, and took the articles from a closet.

Funeral services for the Right Rev. Kirkman George Finlay, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Upper South Carolina, will be held tomorrow. Bishop Finlay died last night after a heart attack at the age of 60.

I found Bishop Arsene Turquetil's ship Therese bound by ice at Cape Wilson, and flew Captain Cox around. The ice condi- e tions are not hopeless provided a strong northwest gale, already overdue, drives the ice from the shore.

Government At the same t leaders reported tonight that their Southern Army had cut the Castuera-Cabeza del Buey highway and railroad today in an effort to halt the Insurgent drive on Almaden, center of Spain's rich mercury mines.

Detroit's veteran curve-ball artist, Tommy Bridges, outlasted Rookie Emerson Dickman over the ten-inning route today and the Tigers took a 4-to-3 edge over the Red Sox in the series opener. It was the first extra-inning game the Red Sox lost this season. By winning the Tigers gained fourth place.

Odell Ave, (15-3933), ? w cor of Starling Ave, 95x25 ft; Franklin Society for Home Building and Savings to Beatrice Satine, 563 St. Paul's Pl. Johnson Ave, 3,215 (13-3409B): Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn to Rebecca Schlossman, 3,325 Rochambeau Ave.

Richard Diender, horticulturist, whose customers for bulbs and seeds included the late Queen Marie of Rumania, King George of England, the late, President Marshal von Hindenburg of Germany, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and many other notables, died at St. John's Hospital here today of a stroke. His age was 66.

Nine crews representing six nations have entered the twelfth international lifeboat race to be held Sept. 10 off Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, according to E. P. Rees, president of the race. Mr. Rees announced there may be additional crews in the contest as entries do not close until the end of this week.

The 13,000,000th automobile passed over the Henry Hudson Bridge spanning the Harlem River at 1:56 P. M. yesterday with Morton Downey, radio and night club singer, at the wheel, according to an announcement by the Henry Hudson Parkway Authority.
Jack Nasow, 45 years old, who reported to the Brooklyn police on Thursday that he had been kidnapped, beaten and robbed by two men who had accosted him in the Bronx, was held in $25,000 bail by

The Rev. Dr. David S. Kennedy, former editor of The Presbyterian and one of the foremost leaders of the fundamentalist wing of the Presbyterian church in the earlier years of the fight against the modernists, died last night at his home in Wayne, a suburb. He had been ill of diabetes for a long time. He was 82 years old.

Judge Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, was accused today of having refused to resign his seat on the Superior Court bench unless his backers guaranteed him, R in event of defeat in November, the amount of his salary for the re- in maining five years of his term. This would be $90,000.

A meeting of the British Cabinet was called for tomorrow to consider the Czechoslovak-German situation. Ambassador Henderson arrived from Berlin to report to his government. Prime Minister Chamberlain was believed to be still unwilling to pledge help either to Czechoslovakia or to France. [Page 1.]

The racing scene will shift to the Aqueduct course on Long Island today, with thirteen, including Roguish Girl and Silverette, named for the- Woodmere Claiming Stakes. Here are two mares from the West, and a great many think that the. victory in the seven-furlong dash that will feature the opening program of six events lies between them.

To the extent that all possible beneficiaries of Social Security do not now share in benefits, the system set up three years ago is discriminatory. For, directly or indirectly, the burden of sustaining the various payments for old-age pensions and unemployment insurance attaches itself to all, in the forma of higher prices for all products

Rives Matthews, editor of The Hastings News, declared today that this village might appropriately be nicknamed "Hastings-on-Billboard," and announced that on Wednesday afternoon he would picket the dozen or more advertising billboards that he declared block a view of the Palisades from Albany River Road above the Hudson here.

Solid-gold evening gowns that will last forever, light as silk, cheaper than the costlier fabrics now sold in fashionable stores, are made possible by a discovery just reported by Dr. Charles S. Gibson of the staff of Guy's Hospital here.

Announcing that three new aircraft hangars at North Beach Airport are planned in line with the $22,000,000 development, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that construction was being started on the second and third of those already approved. Work on the first build.

The sturdy Chinese defense in the rugged hills northwest and south of Juichang has brought almost to a standstill the Japanese offensive in the Chih Lake sector which culminated Wednesday in the capture of Juichang.

Work will begin here tomorrow on a feature-length film depicting the progress of motion pictures from the first commercial movie, "The Kiss," made by the Thomas A. Edison laboratory, to -the talkies of today.

Observance of Veterans' Day by the Seventy-first Infantry of Manhattan, combined with a review of the Eighty-seventh Brigade, New York National Guard, by Governor Lehman at Camp Smith here today, attracted between 7,000 and 8,000 visitors to the reservation.

Efforts to mediate the railroad wage dispute were interrupted today to give the heads of eighteen unions involved opportunity to consult with the union general chairmen. More than 800 of the general chairmen are in Chicago.
Prescott Childs, United States Consul at Barbados, B. W. I., and Mrs. Childs, who have been passing some time at the Madison, will leave today for Madison, Conn.
The Church of Our Savior was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Anna Lois Paull and John Stacy Hejinian, both of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Richard Atwill.
In a statement which applied to William Green such appellations as "traitorous renegade" and "pusillanimous ingrate," John L. Lewis

Informed persons said today that the War Department had received a report from High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt in the Philippines concerning 'a conference between Mr. McNutt and the German Consul General at Manila.

The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday began its canvass of 500 sports leaders throughout the country for the winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy for 1938. The award goes annually to the athlete who "by his performance as a competitor and by his example and influence as an amateur" did the most to advance the cause of sportsmanship during the past Year.

A meeting of Congressional tax leaders to speed plans for revenue legislation and extension of the Social Security Act to include "all those who need its protection," has been tentatively set for the second week in September.

A full all-angle view of the Statue of Liberty will be possible to visitors to Bedloes Island if plans of the National Park Service, the present guardian of the statue, are approved by the United States Army Engineers, it was announced yesterday.
The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that the net operating income of Class I railroads for July was $38,387,209, compared with $60,985,276 for July, 1937, a drop of 37.1 per cent.
Afternoon newspapers here say that President Lazaro Cardenas will not reply to the latest United States note on the payment of expropriated lands until after he opens Congress on Thursday.
The Public Service Commission approved today the transfer of operation certificates covering nine Southwestern New York bus routes to the Buffalo Erie Coach Corporation.

Details were available today concerning two interviews that Viscount Runciman and his assistant, Frank Ashton-Gwatkin, had yesterday with the Sudeten leader, Konrad Henlein. They indicate that the gravity of the situation was increased by the attitude of mind of Herr Henlein.

Continuing the trend toward lower inventories, stocks on hand in department stores in this district were 12.4 per cent lower than a year ago at the end of July, according to the monthly review issued by the Federal Reserve Bank here yesterday. Stocks in apparel stores were 12 per cent lower.

Settlement of government tax claims last week has opened the way for further payments to bondholders and creditors of the bankrupt Grigsby-Grunow Company, former manufacturer of radios and refrigerators.

W. C. MacFarlane, president of the Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company, said upon arrival from abroad on the steamship Europa yesterday that business for his company in the Northwestern States is expected to be good this Fall.

The fortieth conference of the International Law Associations was opened here today by Prince Bernhard, who in welcoming those present expressed in English the wish that they might find in this country an atmosphere favorable to fruitful collaboration.
The Tigers today swept a two-game series with the Red Sox, 15 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Elden Auker and the long-distance clouting of Rudy York.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Aug. 25 was 230, which compares with 155 a year ago and 218 a week ago, according to figures released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The world silicosis conference, which was called by the International Labor Office on the United States Government's proposal, opened here today with eleven countries represented by medical experts.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 24, aggregated $6,570,000,000, or 10 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 12 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Yorkshire clinched the county cricket championship for the twentieth time today. The Northern County whipped Kent at Dover by an innings and 49 runs in a match concluded a day ahead of schedule.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 44 per cent of capacity this week, compared to 42.8 per cent last week, a gain of 1,2 points, or 2.8 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Jersey City gained a 12-to-9 victory over Baltimore tonight in a game of thirty-two hits. Gabler got four safeties before the Orioles chased him from the mound in eighth.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a public hearing would be held on Sept. 15 in Chicago on the application of the Chicago Board of Trade to strike from listing and registration the 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of the Joliet Heating Corporation, Joliet, Ill.

The Association of San Francisco Distributors today rejected the latest peace proposal of the C. I. O. Warehousemen's Union and closed two dry goods warehouses, making a total of 112 warehouses now closed in the "united front" drive of employers against the union.

Letters of administration in the estate of Police Inspector Louis Rosenfeld were granted to the widow, Theresa Rosenfeld, by Surrogate George Albert Wingate in Brooklyn yesterday. The petition said he left an estate of "not more than $15,000 in personal property."
Workmen repaired the undersea diving bell "Explorer" here today preparatory to shipping it to Little Current, Ont., to search for the body of Daniel C. Dodge in the north channel of Georgian Bay.

Jules Bache, financier, returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday expressing optimism about the European outlook. He said he did not think there would be a war because "Hitler is too smart to move while every one is looking."

Warren Pershing, son of General John J. Pershing, arrived with his wife yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line, completing a wedding tour around the world. Mr. Pershing said he had only one reply to all questions about conditions in the many countries they visited during the Summer.

The Securities and Exchange Commission was ready tonight to begin evaluating the properties of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, reputedly worth $300,000,000, in an effort to enforce for the first time the "death sentence" section of the Public Utility Holding Company ct of 1935.

A determined assault on par fell short by a single stroke today as Mrs. Leon Solomon of Memphis, Tenn., led the qualifiers in the annual women's Mason and Dixon golf tournament with a 79. An eight on the sixth hole was the only bad break for the medalist.

Observers wise to the political tides in Maryland were of the opinion tonight that the nomination of Representative David J. Lewis, opponent of Senator Millard E. Tydings, for whose defeat in the Democratic Senatorial primary President Roosevelt has asked, rested solely upon the President's ability to sway two counties on the Eastern Shore when he speaks at Denton on Labor Day.

Miss Camilla Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Charles Morgan of 132 East Ninety-fifth Street and the late Mr. Morgan, has chosen Sept. 24 for her marriage to Remsen Ditmars Donald, son of Mrs. George Donald of 1,220 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Donald.

The Eastern College All-Stars, resuming training at their Peddie School camp after their week-end holiday, were sent through a double workout today by Coach Andy Kerr, who ordered an intrasquad scrimmage in full equipment.
Troops marched past the royal family today while ninety planes flew in squadrons in the biggest military review ever held in The Netherlands.

With the principal construction work now complete, the new building of the Museum of Modern Art at 11 West Fifty-third Street will be opened to the public in time for the World's Fair next year, it was announced yesterday.

Four men stood up in Supreme Court yesterday and pointed fingers at James J. Hines, Tammany distric leader, as the man they had seen with Arthur (Dutch Sehultz) Flegenheimer when that boss gangster was hiding In Bridgeport, Conn., in the Summer of 1935.
The German Foreign Office mouthpiece warned tonight that "a latent crisis is threatening to become acute," as Chancellor Hitler made a whirlwind ??ur of fortifications along the French border.

Kuhn, Loeb Co., as fiscal agents of the .city of Osla, Norway, nineteen-year 4 1/2 per cent sinking-fund external-loan bonds due on April 1, 1955, notified yesterday bondholders that $141,000 principal amount of these bonds had been drawn by lot for redemption on Oct. 1, 1938, at their principal amount.

The Central Institute of Statistics reported today that Italy, engrossed in her broad program of economic selfsufficiency, had experienced a drop in both exports and imports during the first seven months of this year.

The stock market here suffered all-around losses today as most groups of securities were influenced by the unsettled political situation in Europe. Gilt-edge issues fell sharply while among the foreign bonds European loans sagged.

State's Attorney Courtney's men used axes on three more handbook establishments today. In raids No. 20, No. 21 and No. 22 in the prosecutor's twelve-day drive against gamblers, police squads broke into one Loop betting establishment and two on the South Side, routed 450 patrons and smashed doors, wall boards, radios, money booths, chairs and tables.
The eight-room house on a plot 70 by 150 feet at 207 Halstead Avenue, White Plains, Westchester County, was purchased by Elsie Lampry from a client of ClarkRobinson Co., Inc., broker in the deal.
William R. Bagley, Madison's oldest lawyer in point of service and a leader of the Wisconsin bar, died today at the age of 78.
Navy officials undertook to clarify today the situation in respect to the United States gunboat Monocacy, virtually interned by the Japanese on the upper Yangtze and endangered by exploding mines.
Balked by rain, John Cobb, London broker, set dawn tomorrow for his attempt to break the three-day-old world land speed record of 345.49 miles per hour set by his compatriot, Captain E. T. Eyston.
Norma Shearer, motion-picture actress, who has been under medical treatment at Mount Sinai Hospital, is expected to leave the hospital today, it was said there last night.

ROGER VERCEL has written a fine modern legend about St. Michael's Mount in Peril of the Sea, that ancient agglomeration of cut stone and wood clinging to its famous rock off the coast of Normandy. He calls it "Tides of Mont St.-Michel,"* and the title is significant.

The will of Mary T. Muldoon, of 56 East Eighty-ninth Street, who died on Aug. 4, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday provides legacies of $8,000 each for the Corporation of the Roman Catholic Clergymen, Maryland, with an office at 501 East Fordham Road, and the Congregation of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 West Fifty-ninth Street.

Two persons were killed and four injured, one of them critically, in a Collision between an automobile and a Public Service bus on the Black Horse Pike in Bellmawr, five miles from here, early this evening.
A group of United States diplomats and refugee experts today planned an approach to Germany on ways and means of facilitating evacuation of prospective refugees.
The large one-story factory building at 545-47 Park Avenue and 106 Twelfth Street, West New York, N. J., was sold by Mary Vitale to Gedlia Jaffe,

In an effort to prevent unsound horses or those which have been tampered with from starting, Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the State Racing Commission announced a new method of inspecting all horses entered on New York tracks.
Dr. Joseph Wiener, a specialist in the application of local anesthesia, died at his home here last night of a heart ailment after an illness of several weeks. He was 66 years old.

Young women from East Hampton's Summer colony will model in the fashion show to be given at Guild Hall Wednesday afternoon for the scholarship fund at Dr. Earl R. Carlson's school for handicapped children here.

George Zengaras of the East Side won a decision from Eddie Brink of Scranton, Pa., in the main bout of eight rounds before a crowd of 2,000 at Dyckman Oval last night. Zengaras weighed 136 and his opponent was four pounds heavier.

The Department of Parks lacks the legal authority to prohibit the use of loudspeakers or curb the activities of "barkers" on private property adjacent to the Coney Island Boardwalk, according to a decision by Magistrate James E. Finegan yesterday in the Coney Island Court, Brooklyn.

A truck carrying a shipment of men's clothing to the Bush Terminal, 80 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, for distribution by the WPA among the needy was held up yesterday and robbed of contents valued at from $47,000 to $57,000.

British leaders met yesterday to discuss the Czechoslovak situation in preparation for today's Cabinet meeting. There were indications that Ambassador Henderson would be instructed to warn Germany, without threat or bluster, of the risks she would take by invasion.

Coroner Charles H. Hersch charged tonight that "either Deputy Warden Frank A. Craven or a guard" at Holmesburg Prison prevented a routine medical inspection of convicts in the isolation block the Sunday afternoon before four of them were found "baked" to death.

Elmer F. Andrews, Wage-Hour Administrator, will confer again tomorrow with representatives of the textile industry, and hold on Wednesday his first conference with representatives of the tobacco industry.

July, like the 1938 months that have preceded it, fell far behind last year as far as Chicago business was concerned, it is disclosed in the monthly survey compiled by the Chicago Association of Commerce. Unlike June, however, there were certain signs of improvement.

With the fates of the Insull, Foshay and Hulswit holding companies as a background, the Central States Electric Corporation. through which Harrison Williams holds working control of a vast public utility superpower system through a relatively small investment, disclosed yesterday that it was considering an offer to its creditors for a reduction of interest payments.

BLOCK-HEADS, from a story and screen play by Charles Rogers, Felix Adler, James Parrott; Harry Langdon and Arnold Belgard: directed by John G. Blystone; a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production. At the Rialto.

As soon as Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora was seated on the bench yesterday, Lloyd Paul Stryker, chief counsel for James J. Hines, announced that he wanted Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Brothwell returned for further cross-examination. District Attorney Thomas E.

More than 200 college, prep and high school coaches were present at the opening session of the fourth annual football coaching school in the Herald Tribune auditorium yesterday. Dr. John Bain Sutherland, Pittsburgh's head mentor, lectured on offensive tactics.

The flight of European capital away from the mounting danger of war and toward gold or dollars as a haven took on fresh speed yesterday. The British pound sterling and the Netherlands guilder were hammered down in the foreign-exchange market to their lowest prices in years, and additional shipments of $3,038,000 gold from London to this country were announced.

THIS National League race is fast becoming embarrassing for all concerned. The common quip is that the clubs in the first division are backing away from the prospect of having to meet those powerful Yankees in the world series. Of course, that couldn't be. Not as long as the losing players in the October struggle can hobble off with something like $4,000 or more to add to their bank accounts.

A special session of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association was called tonight to consider the national health program proposed a month ago by a committee appointed by the president.
The average rate on the Treasury'sbills sold today declined to 0.047 per cent, against 0.048 per cent last week. The average two weeks ago was 0.047.

The Right Rev. James Gordon, Suffragan Bishop of Jarrow and noted for his aid to the unemployed, died last night at the age of 55. He opposed the clergy meddling in politics but he established an occupational center and eighty-two clubs to give jobless people something to do.

How a German refugee smuggled [Pound]5,000 out of Germany in the middle of a bale of hops was told today by customs officials here. The anxious consignee met a German hops shipment personally, they said, claimed the money hidden in tubes inside one of the bales and headed for Kenya Colony in East Africa.
Reflecting the improved retail trade toward the end of last week, mail and wire orders for ready-towear, furs and accessories were heavier yesterday, resident buying office executives reported.
The National Life Insurance Company of Montpelier, Vt., has avoided railroad bonds for investment purposes even when this class of security was considered of the highest type, Elbert S. Brigham,

The European political situation dominated the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and forced prices in all groups down 1 to 4 points. The total turnover amounted to $4,930,150, compared with the last full trading session on Friday of $4,429,625.
It appears likely that Fifth Avenue's celebrated shopping district, once centered in Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets, soon will extend solidly all the way to Fiftyninth Street.

The question of why the Tennessee Valley Authority paid $678,000 for mineral properties which were bought a few years earlier by the International Agricultural Corporation for $148,000 may be made the subject of a special investigation by the Department of Justice.

A police search for Mrs. Fleurette Bowen, daughter of Victor Parravicino, Italian consul to the British West Indies, was begun today after she had been missing forty-eight hours from the home of her uncle, Philip C. Kullman Jr., at 48 Bon Air Avenue.

Tucson, Ariz., will be in the market Sept. 19 with an issue of $277,000 of water bonds at an interest rate not exceeding 3 per cent. The loan will be dated July 1, 1938, and is to mature serially from Jan. 1, 1940 to 1949.

Racing returned to metropolitan New York yesterday with Benjamin Deutch's Roguish Girl, the "rheumatism horse," finishing first in a thrilling finish to the $3,500 Woodmere Claiming Stakes at Aqueduct.

The livid war clouds roll ever deeper across China. They break only to reveal bomb-shattered homes, bleak battlefields strewn with dead and frantic fugitives streaming away from the horror. Yet one tiny ray of sunlight penetrates even that darkness and flashes around the world.

Four men, all carrying pistols, held up Archie Phillips, 34 years old, of Square Brook Road, North Haledon, the cashier of the Nutley Velodrome, Nutley, N. J.. at 1:35 o'clock this morning, as he was driving through near-by Clifton, and robbed him of $5,000.

The Annisquam (Mass.) Yacht Club crew held a slim lead tonight at the conclusion of two races in the series for the national junior sailing championship being held under the auspices of the Pequot Y. C.

Higher prices of home-delivered and other retail milk may be expected as a result of the increase in wholesale milk prices that will go into effect under the FederalState nailk marketing agreement, spokesmen for the large milk distributor's said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a delegate to the State Constitutional Convention it is clear to me that you do not take into consideration all of the elements involved in the question of reapportionment, as that question had to be voted on, particularly by those of the delegates who were not members of the Reapportionment Committee.

Warm weather and tricky winds have been experienced by the many rifle and pistol shooters taking part in the national matches during the past three days, but high scores are prevailing and many ties have been registered.

Two corporations were-restrained yesterday from continuing operation of a "thrift plan" here. Injunctions were issued in the Federal and State courts against the Continental Reserve Funds Company, Inc., of- Pennsylvania, and the Continental Guaranteed Deposits Company, Inc., of New York.

UNITED STATES SENIOR MEDICAL TECHNICIAN, $2,000 ?? year; ASSISTANT MEDICAL TECHNICIAN, $1,620 a year (optional subjects: ??acteriology, roentgenology, bacteriology and roentgenology combined); MEDICAL TECHNICIAN (Stetnography-Electrocardi??graphy), $1,800 a year; Public Health service, Treasury Department. Applications must be on file not later than Sept.

Frederick Mitchell Munroe, whose wife was the late Elizabeth Lee Bowles, youngest daughter of Samuel Bowles, second editor of The Springfield Republican, died today in his eighty-first year at Hempstead, L. I. He was for many years the publisher of Brooklyn Life, which he founded, also of Town and Country.

Many younger members of the Summer colony, as well as their elders, are aiding in the plans for the recital by Arnold Belnick,. 13-year-old violinist, tomorrow afternoon at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Mrs. Charles E. Mitchell will entertain with a luncheon at her home on the ocean for the young artist before the recital.

Five trade associations and their members who produce veneer containers used in packaging fruits and vegetables were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with fixing and maintaining uniform prices for their products.

Agreement on principal rates involved in the pending trade treaty with Great Britain has been reached by negotiators, and, while details remain to be settled, the treaty is now "over the top," according to data sent to members of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., by the institute's office here yesterday.

A detonator exploded on the Danube quay here this afternoon forty minutes after Regent Nicholas Horthy had arrived on his return from Germany. Cabinet members and military and civil officials had been present but the official reception had been unexpectedly short because of the heavy rain.

Vincent Pimpinella of Brooklyn and Phil Furr of Washington, welterweights who fought a week ago, will meet again tonight at the Canarsie Stadium in aneight-round battle. Pimpinella received the decision in their last meeting.

Out in California more than 800,000 persons signed petitions backing a proposal which is an issue among the candidates in the primary today, to pay $30 every Thursday to every person over 50 who is not employed or an employer.

Connecticut's pro-amateur golfers today retained possession of the John Golden Memorial Trophy at the Wee Burn Club, defeating the Westchester County team, 763 to 786. The record field of 101 pairs finished in semi-darkness.

76th St, 152 W; to 4-story tenement; Union Dime Savings Bank, 1,065 6th Ave, owner; J. S. Burrill, architect; cost, $8,000. 75th St, 424 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Francis Bohaty, premises, owner; S. A. Hertz, architect; cost, $6,500 2d Ave, 1,325; to 5-story tenement and stores; the Ruth Planten Trust, 31 Nassau St, owner; Johnson Porter, architects; cost. $3,000.
The international stock market indices for Aug. 27, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

From a study by the Statistical Division of the National Industrial Conference Board come some curious figures about employment. In 1929, of 47,885,000 employed persons 2,070,000 worked for government. Federal, State or local.

Four men and two women, all Negroes, were arrested yesterday on charges of possession of policy slips in a raid made by Harlem detectives on a second-floor apartment in the tenement house at 208 West 143d Street.

Operations of the Richfield Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a consolidated net profit of $1,005,383 after all charges, including estimated provision for Federal Income taxes.

MANHATTAN ARMSTEAD, HILLIARD (Aug. 7). Estate, less than $5,000. to Adrianna Bough, nephew, executor, 20 E. 119th St., about $1,600; four specific bequests. BARZAGHI, ARTHUR J. (July 18). Estate, less than $10,000. To Julia C. Barzaghi, widow, executrix, 15 Park Ave. BRUCKMAN, CAROLINE (Aug. 3.) Estate, $11,600. To Louisa Bruckman and Ludmilla Bruckman, sisters, executirces, residue equally.

The dozen international women tennis stars representing this country, England, France and Australia who are to play a series of matches at the Newport Casino Wednesday and Thursday will arrive Wednesday and most of them will be guests of Summer residents.

Count Geza Andrassy, a close friend of the Duke of Windsor, died today. The Count was the head of a wealthy family, and had served as a member of the upper house of the Hungarian Parliament and as privy counselor of the late Crown Prince Rudolph of Habsburg.

While C. I. O. members were picketing the plant of Laird, Schober Co., shoe manufacturers, today, the company signed a closed-shop contract with the Boot and Shoe Workers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, who arrived from abroad on the SS. Europa yesterday, said that "due to the change-over in automobile models and the lower trend in general business which characterized the third quarter, it is not to be expected that earnings for the period will be important.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania is due today from England and France. Among her passengers are James Speyer, banker; Julia Lady Reckitt, Dr. and Mrs. James M. Doran, Mrs. Stuart Hanna, Dr. Hans Kruger,
Mrs. John W. Herbert gave a luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Bernard E. Pollack, Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson and Miss Nancy Van Vleck.

When 18-year-old Raymond L. Conklin Jr. of Beach Glen, Denville Township, pleaded guilty here today to the theft of three silver dollars and a handful of old coins from Chester Gordon's Morris Avenue home last Tuesday night local authorities sighed with relief.
Chancellor Hitler spent four hours this afternoon inspecting the new fortifications on the Rhine just north of here. He was accompanied by an automobile full of generals glittering with medals.

Had the record of improvement in highway safety been marked by peaks and valleys during the first seven months of this year it would not be nearly so impressive as the continuing downward trend in fatalities which the National Safety Council is able to report.

Taking the lead in the second inning with two runs and adding three each in the third and fourth, the Fire Department baseball team defeated the Police Department, 12 to 5, to take the Class A championship of the Municipal- Baseball League at Ebbets Field yesterday.

More than 300,000 of the country's employable persons now idle would be unable, because of illness, to go back to work tomorrow even if jobs awaited them, according to a national survey made by the Public Health Service.
The trial of Elifaz Escobar, charged with the murder. of Luis A. Irizarry during the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the American occupation, commenced at Ponce today.
W. N. Nixon, a retired lumberman, died of a heart attack eleven days ago at his home in Paden, Miss. His wife and son, Liston Nixon, were not told of his death because both were ill.
The South Greensburg plant of the Walworth Company was forced to suspend operations today when a union "pay your dues" campaign kept half the force of 1,600 from entering.

Arthur H. James, Republican nominee for Governor, characterized tonight as "false" a charge by John B. Kelly, Democratic chairman in Philadelphia, that he had refused to resign from the State Superior Court bench unless he received a guarantee amounting to $90,000 if he lost the November election.

After twenty-five years of experiments in a laboratory building at 116th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, the Columbia University Institute of Cancer Research moved yesterday to new quarters on two floors of the School of Medicine for graduate medical instruction at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Mayor La Guardia contributed $10 yesterday to a fund being raised to send the Junior Drum Corps of the Sheridan Police Post of the American Legion to the national convention in Los Angeles on Sept. 19.

At its lowest price yesterday, $4.86 3/4, the pound sterling was less than 1/8 cent above its old parity of $4.8665 and was cheaper than it had been in more than three years. Unless there is an abrupt change in the trend today, sterling seems likely to fall through the old par rate, which has come to be looked upon as an important resistance point.

Wheat prices were on the downgrade today with net losses on the Board of Trade here 7/8 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel. While Liverpool was firm there was an absence of aggressive buying, and when it became apparent that no cash wheat of consequence had been sold to the government over the week-end, bearish sentiment developed and the professional element turned to the selling side.

Colonel Avery J. Cooper has been named commander of the Second Coast Artillery District, it was announced yesterday. Colonel Cooper, until recently a member of the War Department general staff, succeeds Colonel Earl Biscoe.

Mayor George V. L. Spratt announced today that Governor Lehman had accepted an invitation to attend exercises here Sept. 17 commemorating the 150th anniversary of New York's ratification of the Federal Constitution.

Fourteen more American track and field athletes returned from a competitive invasion of Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Europa yesterday to bring the number of returning tourists to twenty-two.

13th St, 704 e, 23.10x103.3; Orella D. Brown, et al, execrs Robert D. Brown to Mildred Bierman, 232 E 6th St, (deed dated April 30, 1935) ($2). 56th St, 407 W. 23x98.9x irreg; John V. Mara, ref, to Bowery Savings Bank; foreclosure ($13.50). 141st St. 201-9. 100x99.11;

Stocks weakened on Euorpean crisis and closed with losses of 2 to 5 points in leaders; turnover, 1,248,850 shares. Czechoslovakian loans higher, United States Government and other bonds lower; transactions, $4,930,150.

Her boy friend, Bill, is "no gentleman," Hilda, the 8-year-old twoand-one-half-ton Indian elephant at the Prospect Park Zoo, Brooklyn, learned yesterday after Bill had almost broken her back by pushing her into a deep concrete moat.

The Munson Building, 67 Wall Street, showed a gross income of $355,600 for the year ended April 30, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. After payment of operating expenses, taxes, etc., $84,000 was available for the payment of interest on the outstanding first mortgage.
Representatives of Bolivia and Paraguay today formally exchanged instruments of ratification of the July 21 peace treaty, which ended their century-old dispute over the Chaco.

Because of the unusually large number of passengers landing here yesterday from foreign ports, the United States Customs Service was forced to summon additional inspectors from Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston to examine the baggage of 7,904 persons arriving on fifteen steamships. The number set a record for this year.

Ford Frick's conclusion that the "rabbit" ball is responsible for the epidemic of sore arms among pitchers has been greeted with a mingled chorus of "rights" and "wrongs" from the managers of the two major leagues.

State Senator Leon A. Fischel, Democrat, of the Seventeenth Manhattan District, won the permission yesterday of the Board of Elections to withdraw voluntarily a petition designating him as an aspirant for the American Labor Party nomination for the post he holds.
The law establishing the National Labor Relations Board and the board's administration were praised by Chairman J. Warren Madden in a radio address tonight over the Columbia chain.
An additional protocol to the Cuban-Italian friendship, commerce and navigation treaty of 1903 was signed here this morning, providing a new commercial agreement between the countries.
Hite H. Huffaker, referee, turned down today a bid of $110,000 by the Parkway Distillers, Inc., New York, for the assets of the Independent Distillers of Kentucky, Bardstown, Ky.
William G. Waldron, a Stockbridge tree surgeon, pleaded innocent today to a charge of larceny from the estate of his wife, Mrs. Edith B. Waldron.

The Republican National Committee charged today that President Roosevelt had used the civil service to cover "the greatest spoils grab in our history." Its publication, The Republican Reporter, printed statistics to show that the percentage of civil service posts in the Federal service had declined since Mr. Roosevelt took office.
John E. Stickney, editor and owner of The Wantage Recorder, a Sussex County weekly newspaper, died yesterday at his home here in his fifty-ninth year, after an illness of several months.
Canada must not rely upon her neighbor or sister nations to pay the premium on her national insurance, Ian Mackenzie, Minister of National Defense, declared tonight.

With his left foot swathed in bandages and wearing street clothes instead of the familiar practice togs, Jimmy Crowley started his sixth season as head coach of Fordham football yesterday morning. The genial mentor was the only casualty of the day.

The Sunray Oil Corporation, New York, a holding company, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a registration statement for $4,000,000 of 5 per cent convertible debenture shares, to be offered at $25 a share.
The wholesale price level rose slightly last week, according to the commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index in the week ended Aug. 27

The National Association of Furniture Manufacturers reported today that new orders booked during July were 27 per cent less than a year ago. At the close of the month the volume of orders booked thus far in 1938 was 38 per cent less than during the corresponding seven months in 1937.
AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF WILLIAM BUTLER YEATS. (Macmillan, $5.) A onevolume reprint of "Reveries Over Childhood and Youth," "The Trebling of the Veil" and "Dramatis Personae."
Pie Traynor's Pirates had pitching today, while Burleigh Grimes had only pitchers, with the result that Cy Blanton coasted to a 10-1 triumph over the Dodgers.
John Roosevelt punched his first timeclock today and went to work for $18 a week in the basement of a Boston department store.

MANHATTAN BURKHAM, CAROLINE TOUSEY (March 4, 1937). Gross assets, $295,754; net, $56,810. Blue Ridge Industrial School, Inc., $7,500; Berry School, Mount Berry, Ga., and Lees-McRae College Dept. of Edgar Tufts Memorial Association, Inc. McBanner Elk, N. C., $3,750 each; Anne P. Burkham and Lucie B. Reid, niece, specific bequests and seven thirty-sixths residue each;

Dr. Frank Richmond, former head of the State Psychiatric Field Service, which now gives mental and physical examinations to all inmates of State penal institutions, died here today. He was 65 years old.

Samuel Goldwyn has loaned Sigrid Gurie to Alexander Korda for the leading role in "Burmese Silver," which is described as a continuation of "The Adventures of Marco Polo." The picture will be made in London, with Miss Gurie resuming her role of Princess Kukachinu.

Being in Nyack for the Summer, Helen Hayes thought she would drop over to the County Theatre to act in Barrie's "What Every Woman Knows" this evening. It is one of the grandest thoughts any woman has had for some time.

A plan for bringing to this country Jewish refugees from Germany and Austria under the sponsorship of the ninety-six posts of the Jewish War Veterans in this State was discussed last night in a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker of the council of administration of the State department of the veterans organization.

What the inhabitants of the earth 5,000 years hence may think of the present era, its scientific developments and labor-saving machinery can easily be clarified for them when an 800-pound metal "letter" addressed to the people of that period is unearthed and made public in New York City.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 29, unless specified: Brazos, at San Pedro, Aug. 28. Chaumont, Canal Zone to San Diego. Cuyahoga, Washington to Chesapeake Bay area.
Last night the Jewish settlement of Ein Shamer, near Hedera, was attacked by a gang of Arabs while the settlers were listening to a radio in the mess room.
The German Propaganda Ministry today denied charges by the country's Catholic Bishops, except Austrian, that efforts were being made to destroy the church.
A ruled red line wrote finis today on Boston police books to the adventurous case of Victor Brevoort, who sailed from here last year in a thirty-six-foot motor yawl and was never heard from again.

After receiving a report yesterday from William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, which described night patrol and store protection agencies as having assumed the proportions of a racket, Mayor La Guardia said he would seek local legislation to impose city regulation upon such enterprises.

Miss Elizabeth Jane Forsyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Forsyth of this place, has chosen Sept. 9 for her marriage to Richard Donald McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. McCarthy of Orange. The ceremony will take place here in the Church of St. Andrew.

The seven-room house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 50-37 195th Street, Flushing, L. I., was purchased for occupancy by Emily Braun of Astoria from Mrs. Arthur Bleiler. The Halleran Agency was the broker.

As South Carolina prepared tonight for the Democratic primary election tomorrow, President Roosevelt and his "elimination committee" faced the danger of defeat in the "purge" campaign planned for this State.

Backed into 3-to-5 favoritism, Victorious Ann today won the West Warwick Purse at Narragansett Park before a crowd of 15,000. Amneris, a length behind, took the place, beating Porcellus, the early pace-setter.

Oil to the amount of 2,500 gallons, the first petroleum found in quantity in Britain, was shipped from the test well at Dalkeith, Scotland, the other day, amid enthusiastic cheers, to Purfleet, Essex, to be refined.

Student interests in Princeton University's yearly program of public lectures have won recognition here with the announcement that two undergraduates will sit for the first time this Fall with the university committee on public lectures, heretofore composed solely of faculty members.
Oscar A. Kropf, Chicago lawyer and banker and a national figure in Masonic circles, died today in the Presbyterian Hospital here.
Space has been leased in the Pershing Square Building, at 1 Pershing Square, opposite Grand Central Station, for a second New York unit in the chain of Stouffer's restaurants.

Representatives of forty-five organizations explored last night at a conference in the Hotel Commodore the possibility of a national congress that might serve as a clearing house in this country for all organizations combating race hatred and fostering better racial understanding.

Secretary Ickes is a very busy executive, but he has found time to set up in his own mind, apparently, a new code of behavior for Congressmen. They are "hypocritical" if, after opposing the Administration's spending program, they seek PWA grants for the States they represent in Congress.
The Kenwood Investing Corporation sold the two-story business property at 1,757 Bath Avenue and the house at 1,613 Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn, to Herman Gelb and Herman Weinstock, respectively.
A solution of the hit-andrun-driver problem was put before the International Police Congress today by Fred W. Frahm, Superintendent of the Detroit Police.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Paragraph 13, Special Orders 197, dated Aug. 24, relating to Capt. Russell P. Westerhoff, C.A.-Res., is revoked. Capt. Roy H. McKibben, C.A.-Res., 64 Park Ave., Bloomfield, N. J., 521st Coast Artillery, is ordered to active duty, Sept. 13, at the Coast Artillery School, Fort Monroe, Va. Date of rank, Aug. 29. He will revert to an inactive status Dec. 8.

A tenement house fire, which spread rapidly after children seeking to extinguish it broke a window and thus created a draft, drove ten families from their homes and resulted in the injury of four persons shortly after 9:30 o'clock last night at 303 East Eighty-ninth Street.

Mrs. June Rainsford Butler of Washington addressed the Great Barrington Garden Club this afternoon at the South Egremont Summer home of Mrs. James P. Robinson of Washington on "Garden Trends in the Eighteenth Century."

East Bay Ave (10-2773), n w s at s w s of Preble St. 100x100: Consolidated Edison Co of N. Y. to John R. Flick, 1,701 Bussing Ave. East Bay Ave (10-2773), n w s at n e s of Falconer St, 50x100; Consolidated Edison Co of N. Y. to John R. Flick, 1,701 Bussing Ave.
Six excited and overjoyed Cubans received the Alton P. Sharp Trophy from the hands of its donor this afternoon, and with the trophy the invisible crown for angling supremacy.
Officials of the Federal Reserve Board expressed confidence today that the vast credit expansion sought by the Roosevelt Administration had begun.

Nobody can look with any complacency on the picture of the world painted by the reports from Europe this morning. There is no peace on that Continent, shaken by a kind of rhythm of crisis that for the third time since March speeds up toward climax.

Gilberto de Andrada, prosecuting attorney of the Security Tribunal, today asked Sao Paulo police to start an immediate investigation of the Deutscher Segel Club, which is allegedly engaged in Nazi activities contrary to law.

The New York Football Giants today concentrated on defensive formations for plays expected to be used by the Eastern All-Stars. Ed Danowski's second team forward-passed the Polo Grounds "varsity" for frequent gains.
The navy announced today that its Reserve Inspection Board had recommended award of the Edwin Francis Conway Memorial Trophy to the Oakland Naval Reserve aviation base in California.

Goose, United States defender of the captured Scandinavian Gold Cup, stuck out her long neck today and sailed away with her second straight race of the international series being held by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
Loyalist troops pushed ahead on the Estremadura front, according to tonight's communique. The drive up behind Cabeza del Buey appears to have been particularly successful.
Lodewick Vroom, president of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, has resigned and thus far has refused to reconsider his decision, it was learned yesterday.

Federal Judge John W. Clancy signed yesterday a preliminary order enjoining the Associated Gas and Electric Company from extending the term of 5 1/2 per cent convertible investment certificates without filing a notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission and receiving its permission to do so.

Strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold on a firm basis today but others were weak to 25 cents lower. Top steers again brought $13 and a sprinkling was good enough to get $12-$12.85, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hog market was fairly active and strong to 10 cents higher with practical top $9.
Douglas Corrigan, who is still on his way to California via Ireland and a number of American cities, will ??et a real seashore re ception wheat he arrives in Atlantic City Wednesday afternoon.

Great Britain's growing unfavorable balance of trade with the United States. which has caused manufacturers of this country so much concern, is graphically shown by the latest official foreign trade statistics just issued here.

Ten States have sent their Democratic leaders from the distaff side of the party to the regional conference opening here tomorrow under the auspices of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee.

A blue-ribbon panel of 127 talesmen was drawn yesterday in the Brooklyn Municipal Building by William A. Lane, Deputy Commissioner of Jurors, before Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith and Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd

Five men arrested last month in the raid on an elaborate gambling establishment near the exclusive colony of Lake Success pleaded guilty in District Court- here today and were fined a total of $3,500 and two of them received fifteen-day jail sentences.

Newport Industries, Inc. has concluded arrangements for the sale of its interest in the Armstrong-Newport Company to the Armstrong Cork Company, which has become sole owner of the assets and business of that corporation, it was announced yesterday.

Pensioned On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 31: LIEUTENANT-Alfred C. Hoffman, 105th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum, appointed June 3, 1908. PATROLMEN To take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 26: William C. Abram, 75th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 27, 1913. To take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 31: Peter Darcy, 22d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 20, 1905.
It was an "off day" and not "possum-playing strategy" that cost Australia's Davis Cup team its recent match with the American pair from whom they'll try to take the cup next week-end.
The Senators made the most of eight hits off three hurlers to defeat the Indians, 6 to 4, today.

Colonel Carl C. Oakes, who returned from France after the armistice as inspector general of New Jersey's Seventy-eighth (Lightning) Division, was appointed yesterday a member of the staff of Brig. Gen.

The National Coal Association asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny the petition of Class I railroads, filed on Aug. 19, asking continuance of the increased rates on bituminous coal, scheduled for termination on Dec. 31.

General John J. Pershing suggested today that leaders of industry, with an eye to a possible future conflict involving this country, prepare to pass on to their successors the knowledge they acquired in the World War.

The Justice Department has given the Chrysler Corporation, officials of which were indicted on charges of violating the anti-trust laws, until Oct. 1 to approve a consent decree regulating automobile financing practices.

Senator Pope of Idaho said today that he would confer with President Roosevelt and the National Chairman of the Democratic party, James A. Farley, before deciding whether to seek re-election as an Independent.
With Chancellor Hitler making a personal examination of the bridgehead fortifications at Kehl the French Cabinet met today and will meet again tomorrow to discuss the foreign and internal situations.

Quien-Sabe, a 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by the Rochester Cavalry Troop, was the outstanding jumper tonight at the ninety-eighth annual Empire State horse show. The chestnut scored the only double of the evening, taking the two main jumping events.
We can hear with our eyes-and maybe see with our ears. This is demonstrated by a curious experiment just reported from the Cambridge University psychological laboratories.

In a letter to stockholders of Dominion Stores, Ltd., E. Gordon Wills, president, announces that, in accordance with a resolution adopted by shareholders at the annual meeting in March, the company has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States to withdraw its stock from listing and registration on the New York Stock Exchange.
Newell Bent, insurance broker and sportsman, died last night at the Country Club, Brookline, where he has been making his home. His age was 65.

George Knight Budd Wade, a retired investment counselor, died yesterday at his home in Wood mere, L. I., after a long illness. Born in St. Louis sixty-five years ago, he prepared for college at St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., and received his A. B. from Yale in 1895 and his law degree from Haryard three years later.

Mrs. Eleanor McCammon Pool of this place was married here this afternoon at the home of her brother-in-law and sister, Dr. and Mrs. David Stoddard Dooman, to Frederick Ralph Crane, only son of Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the New York Court of Appeals and Mrs. Crane of Garden City.

Winston Guest's Jaguars and Greentree will meet next Sunday in the opening match of the year's national polo championship. The game is to start at 4 o'clock on the famous turf of International Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

The roofs of Teian, railway town half way between Kiukiang and Nanchang, became visible to advancing Japanese forces yesterday afternoon, when, after a four-hour battle, they stormed two stoutly defended heights.

Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., will address the luncheon meeting of the Association of Buying Offices to be held on Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to mark the active support of the resident buying offices in the National Retail Demonstration, to be held during the week of Sept.

Unsettled foreign markets, resulting from increased tension over the situation in Europe influenced prices on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. A combination hedging pressure and liquidation brought about declines of 11 to 14 points. Several houses with trade connections bought on a- scale down,
The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the issue and sale of $3,309,375 of unsecured promissory notes by six subsidiaries of the North Boston Lighting Properties.
Park Department officials discovered yesterday that vandals had spaded up the sod at ten holes of the Mosholu golf course in Van Cortlandt Park, apparently Sunday night or early yesterday morning.
Mrs. John Dibert, whose donations, chiefly to New Orleans hospitals and religious institutions, were estimated at $2,000,000, died here on Saturday night. The funeral took place yesterday.

Two college men who walked and hitch-hiked from their homes in Saginaw, Mich., to the Panama Canal Zone where their southward trek was halted by worried American officials, arrived in New York on the Grace liner Santa Paula yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth H. Gregory, daughter of Mrs. Frank Keresey of High Hill Beach, L. I., was married here today to Sydney W. Fraser of this city in the chapel of the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Robert Brewster Beattie.
Pounding two pitchers for fifteen hits, Newark smashed Syracuse's six-game winning streak, 8 to 3, in their' series opener before 4,700 tonight.

A Foreign Office spokesman said today that he saw no need for further investigation of the machine-gunning of the American and Chinese owned passenger plane in which fourteen persons were killed off the South China coast last Wednesday.
Al Leach, Clevelander who won the national public links golf championship Saturday, parted today from his $73.50-a-month job as a WPA timekeeper.
Several leases for full-floor space headed the reports of commercial leasing submitted by brokers yesterday. Armour Co., meat packers, took the entire sixth floor in the County Trust Building,

A pajama-clad psychopathic patient on an eighth-story ledge of Bellevue Hospital kept more than 1,000 spectators in horrified suspense for nearly an hour and a half yesterday afternoon until he was tackled by a daring fireman and dragged to safety while the crowd cheered.

A conflict developed today between Senator Sheppard of Texas, chairman of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, and Secretary Morgenthau as to whether Federal employes could contribute legally to campaign funds.
Quick thinking by the captain of a government cruiser saved two members of the Newfoundland Commission Government from being imprisoned by a mob of the unemployed at Bonne Bay on Wednesday.

A new east-to-west transcontinental speed record was set today by Major Alexander P. de Seversky, airplane designer and manufacturer. He flew here from New York in 10 hours and 3 minutes. Colonel Roscoe Turner held the previous record of 11 hours and 30 minutes.
The United States today formally and finally renounced extra-territorial rights enjoyed by its citizens in Egypt for more than a century.

That Senator Robert F. Wagner is acting as intermediary in an effort by President Roosevelt and the American Federation of Labor to reach a common understanding on amendments to the National Labor Relations Act was indicated here tonight.
