The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors decided today to discontinue a Supreme Court action to force Herman F. Bishop to surrender his office as County Superintendent of Highways.
Germany planned to withdraw her pilots and air force technicians from Spain by Oct. 1, Erich Naumann, captured German pilot, told this correspondent today.

A feature of the foreign demand for cash wheat, it was said here today, was the purchase of 14,000,000 bushels of Rumanian wheat credited to a British grain firm. In commenting on the latter business the Uhlmann Grain Company said:
With a slight variation in the usual method of procedure, the Yankees fired away with two big innings instead of one against the Browns at the Stadium yesterday, but the result was the same.
The Carnegie Institution of Washington announced today that twonew satellites of the planet Jupiter have been discovered by its Mount Wilson Observatory in California.

News of the death yesterday in Pasadena, Calif., of Dr. Homer C. House, head of the Department of Languages and Literature at the University of Maryland, was received here today. He was on a tour in the Middle and Far West.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Normandie, accompanied by his wife and their two children, Henry and Joan. The Secretary was in France for a month and spent several days in Switzerland.
The second annual Summer Institute of Garden Clubs opened today at the Rogers Rock Club and will continue through Sunday. Hundreds of persons attended the exhibition today.
Led by Miss Helen Bernhard of New York, seeded first, fourteen players today reached the round of sixteen in the girls' national tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The three Six-Meter yachts which complete the British team of four that will face an American quartet for the British-American Cup in a series to be held by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club arrived yesterday aboard the Anchor liner California.

For six excitingg innings as they made their season's farewell at Crosley Field against the Reds today, the Giants were in grave danger of establishing an odd record for the month of August. They were confronted with the pleasant experience of winning two games on successive days.

Apartment renting continued brisk over the week-end, reports received yesterday from brokers indicated. Among those reported as having taken space in the thirty-story Century Apartments, 25 Central Park West, were Graham McNamee, radio announcer, and Al Goodman, orchestra leader.
Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities charged tonight that some groups under scrutiny were trying to sabotage his committee's work.
A new novel by Hugh Walpole entitled "The Joyful Delaneys," will be issued by Doubleday, Doran Sept. 23. On the same date, the firm also will issue Daphne du Maurier's romantic novel, "Rebecca."
Following the arrival of the liner Borinquen from San Juan, P. R., yesterday a board of army officers began an inquiry into the disappearance from the ship Saturday morning of
A reduction of 10 cents a barrel in the price of East Texas crude oil was announced today by the Stanolind Crude Oil Purchasing Company and the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

In an attempt to improve department store merchandising and advertising of men's clothing, Cohen, Goldman Co. next week will launch a cooperative effort with four department stores, whereby the latter will use advertising copy and plans prepared by the company's agency, Hirshon-Garfield, Inc.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 26: Whitehead, Comdr. E. L., Med. Corps., Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y., in Aug. or Sept., to the Beaver. Hurner, Lt. Comdr. H. A., San Diego, Calif., to the Oglala as executive officer, Oct. 1.

Mrs. Monica Stoute, 40 years old, a widow, was found dead about 3 A. M. yesterday after an explosion had wrecked her two-room. apartment on the fourth floor of a building at 80 Winthrop Street, Brooklyn, and caused slight damage to an adjacent, unoccupied apartment.

Princeton teams had a winning record during the past academic year, tabulations released today show, and took a good step out of the slump which Nassau athletics had found themselves in recent seasons.

Swinging a twenty-pound sledge hammer, which he thought weighed only eight pounds, Borough President James J. Lyons smashed a corner of a building at Southern Boulevard and 141st Street, the Bronx, and began the work of demolishing sixty buildings for the easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge.

British Columbia's "mystery falls" on the Atnarko River in the Bella Coola area west of here, where the waters of Turner Lake drop about 830 feet, were reached recently by a party of three Americans and a Canadian. The falls are south of Tweedsmuir Park in the interior wilderness of the province through which the Dominion's Governor General passed last Summer.

Jose C. Plowell, city editor of El Porvenir, Monterrey Newspaper, said tonight that nine were known dead and 400 families homeless after gales and floodwaters hit this area today in the sweep of a Caribbean hurricane.

Hair styles, involving the appropriate types of millinery to-conform with them, will dominate women's fashions for the new season, according to designers and retail executives who returned yesterday from Paris style showings on the liner Normandie.

The Department of Agriculture's wheat export subsidy program is to be carried out by purchasing wheat and reselling it to exporters at a price enabling them to meet competition in the world market. Acting Secretary M. L. Wilson today made the announcement on policy in the absence of Secretary Wallace.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 24:

Sir Henry Bovell, former Chief Justice of British Guiana, died yesterday at the age of 84. He had retired in 1912. Sir Henry, a native of Barbados, was Attorney-General of the colony from 1896 to 1902.
Forty-two contestants, only one of them a girl, took part yesterday in the finals of the skatemobile derby in which 1,500 youngsters throughout the city were originally entered.
Franklin William Lord, junior vice commander of the Illinois department of the Grand Army of the Republic, died suddenly today at his home in Plano, Ill., at the age of 90.

The two five-story brownstone dwellings at 414 and 415 Riverside Drive, near 114th Street, have been purchased by the Sisters of St. Ursula and will be converted into a school, it was announced yesterday.

Prices on the Toronto Stock Exchange declined sharply today, reflecting general nervousness over the war threats in Europe. Losses of 4.53 and 4.40 points were shown for the gold and base metal indices at the close and the industrial index was down 4.54.

Republican leaders of the State, it was learned yesterday, have drawn up a tentative ticket headed by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for Governor, with Representative Bruce Barton for the long United States Senate term and endorsing Governor Lehman, whom they expect to be the Democratic choice. for the short Senate term.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Duschnes, daughter of Mrs. Philip L. Duschnes of 123 West Ninety-third Street, and the late Mr. Duschnes, to Adrian A. Bendix, also of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Bendix, has been announced by her mother.

Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., tennis player, and Miss Madeleine Cheney of this city were married today. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George P. Cheney of New London and the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. B. Mulloy of Miami.

Councilman Louis Hollander, campaign manager for Louis Waldman, who is seeking the Republican nomination for Kings County judge, yesterday accused Councilman Abner C. Surpless, campaign manager for Harold L. Turk, who is opposing Mr. Waldman, of being a "Tammany Republican."

Mrs. Stephenia Drew Wentworth Collins, wife of William Herschel Collins, died suddenly today of a heart attack at her home, 72 South Mountain Avenue, at the age of 77. She had been active for many years in the work of the First Methodist Episcopal Church and as a director of the Colored Y. W. C. A.

Mrs. Evelyn Gerber Gerard of White Plains, former motion-picture and musical-comedy actress under the name of Evelyn Stevens, died on Sunday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital after a week's illness. Her age was 47.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., a Brooklyn resident, spent nearly an hour yesterday with Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, discussing State politics. After the conference neither would comment on their discussion, although it was learned that the Democratic nomination for Governor had been one of the subjects.

Plans have been completed for the Harvest Festival to be sponsored by the Child Study Association of America on Sept. 10 at the Contemporary Club here to augment its play schools' fund. Guests are asked to come in "jeans and ginghams."

Gilbert Miller's defiance of the Dramatists Guild is gradually stirring that group into action. Mr. Miller, a nonsigner of the Guild's basic agreement between producers and dramatists, has announced the October production of "I Have Been Here Before," the work of J. B. Priestley, a Guild member.

A team representing the Boston police force won the Eastern States Championship trophy today in the last meet of the three-day pistol shoot sponsored here by American Legion Post 509. The team's score was 1,479.

Madison Ave, 1,516, 25.10x95; Joe Isman to Harlem Savings Bank; p m mtg due etc as bond; $26,000. 2d Ave, 604, 24.2x80; Clajaca, Inc (Charles J. Carroll, pres), to Charles Weisbart, 1,440 Broadway, pr mtg $17,370, 2 yrs, 6%; $3,500.

Henry Petersen appeared today before Municipal Judge Dennis O'Brien on a charge of "treating animals in a mean and inhuman manner" because he strung a charged wire in his yard to keep dogs from knocking over a trash receptacle..
Now that the new State Constitution has been submitted to the people in nine mouthfuls, and the question is entirely academic,
Many members of the Summer colony attended a musical which was presented this evening at The Birches, the Summer residence of Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall in Northeast Harbor.

Secretary of Agriculture Wallace called today upon S. W. Gongoll of Minneapolis, Minn., to show cause why he and eight concerns described as being under his control should not be barred from all commodity exchanges for alleged violation of the Commodity Exchange Act.

A resolution adopted by eleven locals of the Auto Workers' Union in the Flint area demands that John L. Lewis refrain from interfering with the affairs of their union. The resolution was wired to Mr. Lewis in Washington Sunday night.

Amy Jane, owned by the Arden Homestead Stable of Goshen, N. Y., and driven by Pownall, captured the feature event of the Grand Circuit opening program today, winning the $1,000 Yates Hotel Stake in three heats.

California's primary campaign ended tonight with Senator McAdoo's supporters fighting an array of opposition charges and at the same time predicting a majority victory for their Roosevelt-endorsed candidate.
Sir David Wilkie, Professor ofSurgery at the University of Edinburgh since 1924 and a close friend of the late Sir James Barrie, died here today at the age of 56.

The continued decline in automobile accidents in the city last week and week-end permitted the weekend period to go by without a single fatality, tabulated reports of the safety bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday.

General business is "pretty good" in England despite the fact that the British people are depressed over the possibility of war, Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday on his return from abroad. He said, however, that Ford operations in Britain were somewhat lower.
A strong earthquake, starting last night and continuing with occasional tremors early today, inflicted heavy property damage on Masbate Island, southeast of this city.
Automobile production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index eased to 34.9 from 37.9. The figure was 155.2 for the week ended Aug. 28, 1937.

The American Federation of Labor Seamen's Union, an Atlantic Coast body of unlicensed seamen, will oppose any proposal for the establishment of a national seamen's union which would permit Pacific Coast officials and members to become "dictators" of the Atlantic members' affairs, it was announced yesterday by Robert Chapdelaine, president.

There will be no prosecution of forty heads of families in this city who have been discovered to have been accepting relief while holding jobs or having bank accounts, Austin Tighe, director of relief in Hoboken, declared today.

In the interest of the national good health it is highly useful that the President, forsaking recent subterfuges and evasions, has ordered an extension of his party "purge" to new fronts and is leading his troops in person.

T. Towar Bates, retired New York stock broker, who later was active in real estate here, died of a heart attack yesterday at a neighbor's home. He lived here at Black Brook House, a large farm. His age was 64.

An action to foreclose the $1,400,000 mortgage, with accrued interest of $105,000, against the Lido Club Hotel of Long Beach, L. I., brought by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and John Holley Clark Jr., as attorney for a committee representing holders of $867,000 of participation certificates, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Brooklyn upon the ground that the plaintiffs were without legal capacity to sue.

President Roosevelt brought to a close tonight his stay at his family home and departed at 11 P. M. for Washington to await the outcome of tomorrow's Democratic Senatorial primary in South Carolina, prepare for his trip into Maryland next week-end and confer with State Department officials on the troubled international situation.

Leading stocks fell 2 to 5 points and the stock market suffered its widest decline yesterday since March 29 as anxiety increased over the political tension in Europe. The turnover of 1,248,000 shares on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest since Aug. 12.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Damarin Scudder of Portsmouth, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Scudder, to James W. Bannon 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bannon Jr.

A sharp upswing in retail jewelry sales during the Christmas holiday period, bringing volume even with or ahead of the corresponding 1937 period, was predicted yesterday by William D. McNeil, president of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, at the opening of the twenty-third annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Benjamin A. Cook, Mayor of Fitchburg in 1914 and 1915, and a member of the Legislature in 1908 and 1909, died in his home here today at the age of 71, after a long illness.
Central American dictatorships, modeled on the totalitarian examples of Italy and Germany, are proving difficult for newspapers not subsidized by the governments.

Five new stamps of the Postoffice Department's "Presidential series" will be issued next month. The 10-cent stamp bearing a likeness of President Tyler is scheduled to go on sale in Washington Sept. 2 and in the rest of the nation Sept. 3.

Stockholders of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company at a special meeting yesterday voted to waive preemptive rights on not more than 500,000 shares of authorized but unissued common stock and to empower directors to confer upon holders of any securities which may be issued by the company the right to convert such securities into common stock.
Mr. Dewey-Mr. Curry, you have been a leader in the Democratic organization of this county for some years? A-I have. Q--Of what district? A-Fifth Assembly. Q-During what years? A-1905 to 1934.

The boundary treaty between Panama and Costa Rica has received its final revision by Dr. Narciso Garay, Foreign Minister of Panama, and Tobias Zuniga Montufar, Foreign Minister of Costa Rica, and is now ready for the signatures of President Juan P. Arosemena of Panama and Leon Cortes Castro of Costa Rica.
The battle lines of the "clean government" Republican faction were strengthened in the Tenth, Eleventh and Twelfth Congressional Districts today.

Two gunmen were killed in an exchange of shots with three deputy sheriffs in the southeastern part of the city today. They opened fire when the deputies halted for investigation a taxicab in which the men were riding.

James Speyer, senior partner in the international banking firm of Speyer Co., on his return yesterday from his annual vacation in Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, confirmed reports published in June that he would retire from business. Mr. Speyer, who is 77 years old, said no date had been set for his retirement.

A single funeral service was held yesterday for Dr. Milton M. Abeles, senior psychiatrist in the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital, and his bride of last month, the former Miss Dorothy Cohen of this city, who were killed in an airplane accident in Germany on Aug. 13.

Miss Elizabeth Alden Fish, who will be married today in the Riverside Church to John Alden Stanton, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon given on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria by Mrs. Frederick E: Ringwald of Greenwich, Conn. Other guests included Mrs. Cornelius Vanderveer Lovett, Mrs. Philip Hays Dater, Mrs. Richard Cukor, Mrs. Woodford Rhoades and Miss Barbara Elder.

Guillermo Alonso Pujol, president of the Cuban Senate, resigned from that office today by cable from France, where he is spending a vacation. In a lengthy message Senor Pujol affirmed that the state of his health makes it impossible to return at present.
With Britain in a state of "psychological mobilization" over the Czech-German conflict, the Cabinet equipped the Ambassador to Berlin yesterday with power to warn the Reich against precipitating war.

J. M. B. Hoxsey, executive director of the stock list department of the New York Stock Exchange, will retire on Sept. 15 after twelve years of service with the institution. He announced his retirement in May, but the date was not decided until recently.

Bissell Ave (17-5124); n s; 7 e of Monticello Ave, 335x100; Frank Calegari to Vito Italiano, 467 S 5th Ave, Mt. Vernon. Paulding Ave (15-4328); e s. 50 n of Esplanade Ave, 50x100: Anna Clarke to Isaac Eisenstein, 2,181 Wallace Ave. 133d St, 753 E (10-2562); Kunigunda Simon-air to John Pillig, 326 E 82d St.

The French liner Normandie, sailing today for Havre and Southampton, has among her scheduled passengers: Ronald Tree, Major O. L. Prior-Palmer, City Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, Senator Andre Morizet, Dr. Harry Plotz, laboratory chief of the Pasteur Institute, Paris;

Babe Ruth has asked Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail, through Secretary John McDonald, to be placed on the Dodger active list, so that he may serve as a pinchhitter. McDonald said today MacPhail was considering the request, but that no action had been taken.

Fed steer and yearling trade firmed up today when supplies were moderately reduced, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs and hogs, however, sold lower and lambs remained slow at the decline.

Coincident with a can issued yesterday for redemption of its preferred stock on Oct, 1, the Consolidated Oil Corporation announced that it jad obtained from private sources a twelve-year loan of $25,000,000 without discount.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent editorial, "Democratic Process," you suggested that milk consumers are equally entitled with milk producers to vote on adoption of the milk marketing order. You point out that consumers outnumber producers by nearly a hundred to one, and hence you question whether allowing producers alone to vote is a true application of "the democratic process."
Uniformed Nazis raided a synagogue here last night. Acting obviously with approval of the Nazi party and the police, a group of forty Nazis raided a synagogue not far from Danzig Police Headquarters.

The forty-one-ton French flying boat Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris, engaged in transatlantic flight surveying operations, hopped off from here at 8:30 P. M. Greenwich mean time (3:30 P. M., E. S. T.) today on a 2,397-mile trip to New York.

Dismissal of the stop order against the Austin Silver Mining Company apparently brings to an end that company's sixteen-month tangle with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The concern is now free to prepare a new prospectus, file a new registration statement and resume its interrupted search for financing to develop its huge properties.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 29: COLONEL Matheson, J. R. D. (Eng'rs), General Staff Corps, one day leave, Sept. 2. MAJORS Paul, W. S. (Inf.), Adjutant General's Dep't., fifteen days leave, Sept. 6.

Cancellation of the registration of William P. Lawson, doing business as William P. Lawson Co., Baltimore, as an over-the-counter broker-dealer was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Detroit's refurbished Tigers, who a few weeks ago changed leaders in the hope that this might confuse the enemy, barged into the Stadium yesterday on the wings of a four-game winning streak which they doubtless hoped would prove equally as confusing to the Yankees.

Movement of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 30; unless specified: San Francisco to San Clemente: Perry, Trever, Wasmuth, Zane. Allegheny, at Lewes, Del., Aug. 29. Cincinnati, San Francisco to San Pedro, via Operating Area. Paul Jones, at Min River.

The ashes of Warner Oland, the Charlie Chan of the motion pictures, who died here on Aug. 6, were buried today. Besides his widow and four cousins, there were present at a simple ceremony before the body was taken to a crematory, Nils Asther, Swedish screen actor, and 200 other friends.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Firestone of this place and Akron, Ohio, on Aug. 21 at the Mercer Hospital, Trenton. Mrs. Firestone is the former Miss Mary Seagrave Davis, daughter of Judge and Mrs. J. Warren Davis of Lawrenceville.

On arriving at the White House from Hyde Park, N. Y., just before 9 o'clock this morning, President Roosevelt went almost immediately into conference with Secretary of State Cordell Hull on what the latter described as "routine matters" requiring Mr. Roosevelt's attention.
The following applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter market have been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission:

" Springtime for Henry," the final production of the Forty-Niners for the fifth season at the Chase Barn Playhouse, opened here today to the largest first night audience of the season. The play, Benn W. Levy's farce, was directed by Beatrice Beach MacLeod, director of dramatics at Swarthmore College.

Mr. Erskine M. Harmon, who will take office this week as Market Administrator for the New York City milk market, approaches his task with a naive attitude in one respect. He has been conferring in Washington with Secretary Wallace and others about the new controls that are to be set up.

Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey McCormick of Chicago were dinner hosts at East Point, their Summer residence in Seal Harbor, this evening. Others entertaining with dinner parties included A. Atwater Kent, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Borden, who entertained at Anchorhold, and Mrs. Edward Browning, who was hostess at Point d'Acadie.

IN the whole history of science, I suppose, there has been no angrier controversy than that which swept nineteenth-century America on the question of anesthesia. For at least twenty years the name of the true "discoverer" was a subject for debate among physicians, journalists and even Congressmen, and no doubt one can still get into an argument on the point should one be so inclined.

With the selection tonight of a New Haven delegation favoring the renomination of Senator Augustine Lonergan, although not definitely pledged to him, his selection on the Democratic ticket became assured.

Sales of household refrigerators to distributors and dealers in the United States during July totaled 82,825 units, compared with 179,414 in the same month last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

An alphabet lottery, something unusual if not entirely hew in the policy racket, was uncovered here today in an arraignment before Judge Leroy Huckin in the Second District Criminal Court of Bergen County.

A general revision of administrative personnel and a redrafting of policy on the part of the National Maritime Union has been started as the result of the recent national elections which placed .the so-called anti-Communist bloc in control of the executive committee, it was learned yesterday.

Bran, egg-white and a little sawdust with a bit of chemical manipulation, a Rockefeller Institute scientist has created the first synthetic vaccine against disease. The new agent, offering protection against pneumonia, Points the way to new methods of fighting bacteria-produced infections.

There was no hospitality in this American Rhineland for the Dodgers today. Instead they ran afoul of a lot of Red menaces and, as twilight crept over Crosley Field, Burleigh Grimes's boys were staggering under two crushing defeats.
The Yale University Press will publish on Sept. 13 "Fanny Keats," by Marie Adami. It is the story of Keats's younger sister, who lived most of her life in Spain and died in 1890 at the age of 87.

Replying to John L. Lewis's plea that deposed officers of the international union, United Automobile Workers of America, be reinstated - pending a general convention, the executive board of Local 156 of Flint today rejected it and informed the C. I. O. chairman that they would not tolerate any interference from outside their ranks.

Miss Anne Wythe Jenkins, daughter of Captain H. E. Jenkins, U. S. N., of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Jenkins, has selected Sept. 10 as the date for her marriage to Lieutenant Benjamin Robin Crosser, U. S. N., attached to the Great Lakes Naval Training Station.
The Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, will battle tomorrow night to regain the prestige the professionals lost to the collegians a year ago.
The Gibbs Cox nine won the Manhattan Industrial Baseball League championship yesterday by beating the New York Mortgage Commission team, 4 to 2, in the final-round game at Central Park.
Senator Harrison of Mississippi, chairman of the Finance Committee, gave further notice today of his independence of the Administration on major fiscal policies.

Yesterday the French Cabinet virtually abandoned the forty-hour week and even the Left seems convinced of the necessity of such action. What is perhaps more remarkable, even some American left-wingers now concede that longer legal hours are desirable-for France.

The annaul Fall Style Conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association, to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Sept. 12 anbd 13, will be featured by a fashion Show on the evening of the first day,

Earl Averill's base on balls, a double by Hal Trosky, followed by Bad News Hale's single, gave Cleveland two runs in the eighth inning today and a 10-8 victory over the Athletics in a see-saw game. The defeat dropped Philadelphia to eighth place.
Puerto Rico's birth control program is in violation of Federal statutes, the United States Attorney General's office has ruled, United States District Attorney Cecil Snyder announced today.

The second Bandfest at Randalls Island will be given tomorrow evening by all-colored bands, including those of Cab Calloway, Erskine Hawkins, Ovie Alston, Count Basie, John Kirby, Roy Eldridge, Louis Russell, Teddy Hill, Andy Kirk, Don Redmond and Willie Bryant.

Steel ingot production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced for the seventh successive week. It now stands at 64.6, compared with 63.8 for the preceding week and 130.3 for the week ended Aug. 28, 1937.

Dog races that permit spectators to share in the winnings of the animals are illegal, Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled today in dismissing a suit brought by Joseph F. Meyers to enjoin' officials from interfering with -contests at the Rockland County Fair Grounds in Orangeburg.

With improvement in securities here and in foreign markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned upward nearly $1 a bale yesterday to end with net gains of 14 to 17 points. Quotations improved in both Liverpool and Bombay, which led to Increased foreign buying,
Europe will not-get back the coveted Scandinavian Gold Cup for at least another year. It will remain at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

William B. Woodring led a field of 445 sharpshooters in the race for the national small-bore rifle crown today. He has held the honors for the past two years. In the United States Cartridge Trophy match, Woodring's score of 400 out of 400 with thirty X's in the bullseye, outranked William P.

East Broadway, 232, 23.10 to Division St; Frances G. Padwee and another to Agnes K. Prendergast, executrix of James W. Prendergast, Greenwich, Conn; 2 quitclaim deeds. East Houston St, 288-90, 40.5x80; Ira H. Holly, referee, to John A. LeVoy, 1,101 Euclid St, N. W., Washington, D. C., et al. executors of Fanny Henning; foreclosure ($2.50).

Mrs. Lucy Wadhams Dodge entertained at Guestwick this afternoon, for the Richmond Garden Club and Miss Mabel Choate gave a talk, illustrated by motion pictures, of gardens in India. Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, president of the club, and Mrs. Seth Nichols of Wayland presided at the tea tables.

A new realty firm, known as the Samoset Realty Corporation, has been formed, with offices at 271 Church Street. It will deal principally with the purchase and rehabilitation of old-law tenements. Joseph D. Gollon is the treasurer.

National advertisers are beginning to display considerable interest in the proposed New York City Food and Drug Bill, which also has a section devoted to advertising. The bill has been referred to the temporary committee on general welfare of the City Council,

Karl Karch of Bayside scored his fifth straight tournament victory today when he led a field of fortyone golfers over the Hempstead Golf Club course to take low gross prize in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur tourney.
For the first time the Soviet Naval Commissariat has admitted that the chief Russian admirals and naval experts were shot in recent months.

Plans for the alteration of three five-story tenements in the section west of Central Park at a cost of about $85,000 were announced yesterday. The structures at 211-15 West Sixty-sixth Street, between Amsterdam and West End Avenues,

A crew that made a long journey to compete-the youthful sailors of the South Shore Yacht Club, Milwaukee, who represent the Lake Michigan Yachting Association-assumed the lead today for the Sears Cup, emblematic of the national junior sailing championship of the United States.

Harry D. Hopkins, Administrator of the WPA, went to the defense of the governmental agency he directs and still more vehemently to the justification of President Roosevelt's "purge" program- in an address before Democratic women assembled tonight from ten Northeastern States.

A sixty-nine page rep rt upholding the proportional representation system of voting as an "important advance in democracy" was submitted yesterday to Attorney General John J, Bennett Jr. by R. Lawrence Siegel, Special Assistant Attorney General, who has been investigating for nine months charges of inefficiency and fraud in P. R. in the Bronx and other boroughs.
Mrs. Rose Friedman Freezer, widow of Jacob Freezer, shirt manufacturer, died early yesterday morning after a prolonged illness at her residence, 845 West End Avenue, at the age of 61.
Word has been received here of the birth of a son to Mr. and Mrs. Mahion S. Kemmerer 2d last Wednesday in Salt Lake City, where they make their home.

Crucible Steel Company of America ten-year 5 per cent gold debentures due in 1940 have been called for redemption at 101 and interest on Sept. 29. The New York Curb Exchange has suspended the issue from unlisted trading.

Dr. Friedrich Opel, fourth son of the founder of the Opel automobile firm in Germany, died of heart disease this morning in the Bristol Hotel here. He had come to Vienna to open a new branch of the company of Adam Opel, Ltd., of which he was vice chairman. He was 3 years old.

Cloudbursts, minor floods and lightning-started brush fires plagued Southern California today in the third day of an oppressive heat wave. One death was indirectly caused by stormy weather. A cloudburst flooded a six-mile area in Antelope Valley with two to three feet of water.

STAND back, men. The footballers may be coming around this end any time now and it wouldn't be healthy to get in their path. Punting in the dark will start tonight along the lakefront in Chicago, where the "Washing Done" Redskins, owned by that spotless laundryman, George the Magnificent Marshall, will take on the college All-Stars in a charity game.
Plans to abandon entirely the 249 miles of line of the Quincy, Omaha Kansas City Railroad have been changed. It is now proposed to give up the operation of only 145 miles of the road in Missouri.

Leading corporations and trade associations with which the monopoly investigation of the joint legislative-departmental body known as the Temporary National Economic Committee is concerning itself are now actively engaged in extensive programs of self-analysis and compilation of data preparatory to the receipt of subpoenas, questionnaires or demands for information on all pertinent matters, it was learned yesterday.

Sterling plunged yesterday below it old dollar parity of $4.86 2-3 and the price of gold skyrocketed to a three-year high as a condition approaching panic, induced by the threat of a European conflict, broke over the foreign exchange market.

About 150 internationals are leaving the front today and starting on furloughs abroad whence they will return, or not, as they please. Among this group are thirty from the Fifteenth Brigade which means Americans, Canadians and British.

Trading was generally only fair on most classes of traefer meats. The cow market was higher, fresh pork cuts strong to slightly higher, light weight choice steer hinds and ribs lower, other weights and grades, including other classes. mostly unchanged.

An agreement for a temporary deferment of interest payments on bonds of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad has been reached with representatives of savings banks and insurance companies, Daniel Willard, president of the railroad, announced yesterday. The announcement followed a special meeting of the B. O.'s directors here.

Mrs. Jean Solomon of Memphis, Tenn., medalist in the Mason-Dixon women's golf tournament, led the championship flight home today by defeating Mrs. K. C. Boggs of Huntington, W. Va., 8 and 7, in the first round of match play.

There were several famous Hollywood figures sitting in the spectators' seats at the trial yesterday, but Hollywood never supplied the kind of drama that John F. Curry gave to the last thirteen minutes of the afternoon session of the case of People against James J. Hines.
With "Moving Day" exactly a month away, many persons already are signing leases for space in apartment buildings in scattered sections of the city, reports received yesterday from brokers indicated.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Stiles of this city and Hastings-on-Hudson last Wednesday in Harwich Port, Mass., where they have been passing the Summer.

The Bureau of Navigation released the. following orders today, dated Aug. 27: Nimitz, Rear Admiral C. W., Commander Cruiser Division 2, to command Battleship Division 1. Watson, Rear Admiral A. E., Battleship Division 1, to command Battleship Division 2.

The Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 4 to 3, in the first game of a doubleheader today, but a jittery infield robbed them of a possible tie in the nightcap, won by the Cards in ten innings, 8 to 7. The even split sent the Cards to sixth place in the standing.
The Rev. Richard Townsend Henshaw, pastor of Christ Episcopal Church of Rye, N. Y., died in Mercy Hospital here today after a week's illness.
President A. F. Whitney of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen said today that his union intended to seek legislation to bar heavy freight trucks from highways in Illinois on weekends and holidays.

Germans who want to dance the "Lambeth Walk," the London Cockney dance that has come into popularity, may now strut the floor, slap their knees and shout. "Oi," in approved Cockney manner without incurring the displeasure of the authorities.

Greyhound, world champion trotter, failed to threaten his own record of 1:56 in an exhibition mile at the New York State Fair today when Sep Palin drove him in 1:591/4 over a track slightly heavy from overnight rains.

Exports of leather footwear from this country in July continued the upward trend manifested earlier this year, it was shown today by a report of the Leather and Rubber Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

Paragraph 12, Special Orders 199, dated Aug. 26, 1938, relating to Sapt. William S. Johnston, Air Res., is revoked. So much of Paragraph 13, Special Orders 184, dated Aug. 9, 1938, as relates to Lt. Col. Azel F. Hatch, F. A. Res., is revoked. So much of Paragraph 22, Special Orders 196, dated Aug. 23, 1938, as relates to 2d Lt. George F. Nash Jr., Cav. Res., is revoked.

Amateur golf players were hot and cold all over the nation yesterday as on thirty-one fronts 800-odd golfers fired sectional qualifying rounds for the National Amateur. Hottest of the 156 players to qualify for the classic at Oakmont, Pa.,

Senator Berry denied today that he had tried to "take over the WPA" in Tennessee. Writing to Senator Sheppard, chairman of the Senate Committee to Investigate Campaign Expenditures, Mr. Berry asserted that the recent accusation to that effect by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, "is untrue and is disassociated from a scintilla of fact, and nobody knows that better than Administrator Hopkins."

Even isolated little Bermuda has the war jitters. The German cruiser Emden arrived this morning to visit until Saturday and anchored a short distance from Hamilton. At present all ships of the British West Indies Fleet are cruising elsewhere, and rumors are current that one of the British cruisers has been ordered to Bermuda "just in case."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has vacated the stop-order issued on July 13 against a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Austin Silver Mining Company covering 225,000 shares of common stock.
Three games were played in the English Football League today. In a second division match, Burnley defeated Southampton, 2-1.
Unemployment benefit payments to insured jobless workers in twentyeight States in July totaled $36,665,000, making the disbursements since Jan. 1 $216,000,000.

Sentiment was well prepared for the slackening in the commodity and security markets during August, according to the National City Bank review of economic conditions for September, since the June and July rise had been greater than expected and the better feeling which then spread over business has not been seriously disturbed.

The Anglo-American reciprocal trade treaty has reached a stage of virtual agreement on rate changes affecting all major commodities, but it has not yet been approved formally by the heads of the British and American Governments, according to information from an authoritative quarter.

There was nothing new today in the deadlock created by the Henleihist leaders' unwillingness to have any further negotiations with the Czechoslovak Government or even to hear details of the cantonal plan that the government put forward as a new basis.

Coney Island has begun to feel the esthetic influence of Park Commissioner Robert Moses. For the first time in its history a ballyhoo artist was found guilty yesterday for practicing his trade on Surf Avenue, Magistrate Solomon holding that the "barker" had violated Mr. Moses's ban on unnecessary noise in the vicinity of park property.

Lodorick Ave, 2,225 (16-4401); Salvator G. Maraventano to Edwin Gould Fbundation for Children, 595 Madison Ave.; installments, 4 1/2 per cent; $11,500. University Ave (11-3211), e s, 350 ft s of 183d St, 37x102; Louise A. Talmage to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtg. to Aug. 26, 1943. at 4 1/2 per cent; $11,000.

Charges of "injustices" in the personnel department of the Tennessee Valley Authority were Pmade by Representative Charles A. Wolverton, Republican, of New Jersey, here today as he developed the story of a $3,600-a-year employee, discharged for economy a few months after the Authority's total payroll had been increased $275,000.

Bleby Albury, who stabbed and killed Jerome Pratt July 31, was hanged in Nassau prison at 8 o'clock this morning. The period that elapsed between the commission of the crime and the execution was the shortest in the history of the colony.

Henry Dodge Cooper of 620 Park Avenue, New York, who retired in 1919 as senior partner in James F. White Co., importers of burlaps and coarse linens, died here this morning in his room in the South Side Sportsmen's Club, where he had been ill for three weeks. He was 85 years old.

Financial markets have become so accustomed to recurrent "European war scares" that Monday's decline in stocks, which on the basis of the averages was the most considerable since March, hardly convinced the public that the "general war" was about to begin. Monday's decline, indeed, was accompanted only by the cabled conjecture which has reappeared at intervals during a year or more.

2d Ave, 1,398-1,400; two 5-story tenements, 50x75; Edgar S. Davis, trustee, against 1,400 Second Ave Corp; due, $86,270; taxes, etc., S2,000; to plaintiff for $40,000. By MICHAEL F. SHEA 6th Ave, 579; 3-story store, 23x75; Virginia L. Abbott against Julia G. Skelly; due, $27,085; to plaintiff for $15,000.

War risk insurance rates on American property in Europe have doubled, in general, during the last week, and yesterday these rates were fluctuating hourly, according to executives of the American Foreign Insurance Association, who declined to be quoted by name. Rates vary sharply according to location of the risk and the character of the risk, it was explained.

A situation said by veterans in Wall Street to be virtually without precedent was caused yesterday when the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad, contrary to information previously furnished to the New York Stock Exchange, announced that the road would default on the interest due on Sept. on its refunding 4 1/2 per cent bonds of 1938.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice reported today the arrest of two dealers in securities in Detroit on charges of violating the fraud provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 and the mail fraud statute in the sale of securities issued by the Ozark Corporation.

The report of the Boeing Airplane Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, released yesterday, shows a net loss of $35,975 after depreciation, interest, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

Frank Bane, who has been executive director of the Social Security Board for three years, resigned today to become executive director of the Council of State Governments, with headquarters in Chicago.

The Eastern All-Stars served notice today that they are ready for the New York Giants when they clash at the Polo Grounds a week from tomorrow night by handing the Brooklyn Dodgers a general maltreatment in a long scrimmage at Peddie School.

A moderate scarcity has developed on several types of wool suiting fabrics and traders said yesterday that, with clothing production now swinging into seasonal activity, the shortage is likely to become acute in September.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somerveil, WPA administrator for New York City, announced yesterday that President Roosevelt had authorized a new WPA hospital service project which would indefinitely extend the jobs of more than 3,000 WPA physicians, nurses, orderlies and other employes in twenty-six city-owned hospitals here.

If the State, counties and municipalities do not issue new bonds in the next ten years, a total saving of $304,800,000 in debt-service charges can be effected, the State Chamber of Commerce declared today in urging taxpayers not to authorize additional borrowing unless need is shown conclusively.

Buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a total slightly higher than the figure for the preceding week and somewhat in advance of the number for the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

Some time in the Summer of the year 6939 A. D. a New Zealand archaeologist may come upon a marsh on the shores of what was once Flushing Bay. Consulting a crumbling map dated 1939 and preserved under transparent metal he may begin his cross-trenching and eventually unearth a five-foot cylinder of cupaloy.

The American Tarriff League concurred yesterday in reports which have circulated in the last few days that the negotiations for the pending trade treaty with Great -Britain have been largely completed.

The four-story structure known as the Marguerita Apartments at 536 Beach Twenty-second Street, Far Rockaway, L. I., was sold by the 536 Beach Twenty-second Street Corporation to a client of Netter Netter, attorneys.
Waldemar Young, film scenarist, who wrote "The Unholy Three" and "The Miracle Man," died of pneumonia today in the Hollywood Hospital. At his death he was under contract to Metro-GoldwynMayer.
Exports of cotton by Argentina slumped in the year ended on July 31, 1938, to only a fraction of the figure for the former marketing year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Turpentine steady, 22 1/4c; no sales; receipts 729 barrels; shipments 1,265 barrels; stock 45,418 barrels. Resin firm; sales 454: receipts 3,202; shipments 1;498; stock 228,964. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.85; E, F, G. H, I, K, $4.10; M, $4.15; N, $5; WG, $5.20; WW, X, $6.15.

The Official Gazette announces today a decree of Chancellor Adolf Hitler whereby the Austrian postal saving system will be extended to include all of Germany. This system, founded in 1883, was taken over by the Reich's postoffice on Hitler's order at the time of the annexation.
Police Commissioner Valentine is ready to make short work of the "protection" racket, it was learned yesterday, if the City Council will enact the. necessary licensing and supervisory laws.
An inquiry by Congress into charges that the United Mine Workers, a C. I. 0. affiliate, has created a "reign of terror" was demanded by the A. F. L. Council at Atlantic City yesterday. [Page 1.]

The War Department is expected to ask the next Congress for increased appropriations to make possible the speeding up of the army's mechanization program and for obtaining at the earliest possible moment the "latest and best in all types of military equipment."

Johnny Rigney pitched the White Sox to a 3-to-2 victory over Washington today. He held the Senators to six hits and squelched a threatened uprising in the ninth. With Chicago leading, 3 to 1, Cecil Travis opened the ninth with a double. Rigney forced Zeke Bonura and Al Simmons to fly out before Buddy Myer singled to score Travis. Then Sammy West hit an outfield fly to end the game.
The stock market here was quiet today but apparently the more hopeful political outlook in Europe bolstered sentiment and most sections did well.

Mike Jacobs yesterday closed with Henry Armstrong 'for the latter to defend his welterweight championship of the world against Ceferino Garcia at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 2. Jacobs negotiated with Eddie Mead, Armstrong's manager, in a lengthy telephone conversation.

To seventy-two non-Federal projects, ineluding four in New Jersey, were allotted today loans of $3,425,000 and grants of $6,551,111 by the Publie Works Administration. Having an estimated construction cost of $14,559,162, today's list, increasing to 4,470 the total of approved non-Federal projects,
The Federal grand jury in-Brooklyn handed up yesterday an indictment charging three employes of the WPA circus, a unit of the Federal Theatre Project, with conspiracy and embezzlement.
The twenty scheduled airlines operating in the Continental United States carried in July this year 127,590 passengers and 541,346 pounds of express, the Civil Aeronautics Authority announced today.

Leonard St. 62, 50x100.3; Rednu, Inc., to City of New York; p m m tg, due July 29, 1940, 4 3/4%; $75,000. 86th St, 211-215 W, 75x100.5; 211 W 66th St Corp to Jacob R. Schiff, 575 Park Ave; demand, int per bond; $5,000. Same property; same to Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States; p m mtg for $33,000 and building loan for $52,000; due Sept 1, 1948; int per bond; total $85,000.

Edith and Agatha, two blackeyed, brown-haired chubby hulahula dancers, 5 and 6 years old respectively, were the hit of the show yesterday as eighty-seven children gathered at the Stuyvesant Neighborhood Summer play school, 74 St. Mark's Place, to bring to a close the thirteenth year of the school's Summer activities.

William Lewis Juhring of New Rochelle, chairman of the board of R. C. Williams Co. of 265 Tenth Avenue, wholesale grocers and importers of wines and liquors, died here yesterday afternoon in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 82.

The London correspondent of James Talcott, Inc., textile and general factors, has changed its name from Erst Company, Ltd., to James Talcott, Ltd. J. G. Seddon-Brown and Benedict Erstein continue as managing directors.

Retail enterprises figured largely in the lists of commercial rentals submitted yesterday by brokers. The store and basement in 272-4 West 125th Street was leased by Gonshak Brothers, Inc., through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., who also rented the store and basement in the Kimberly Hotel,

Three convicts who survived days and nights in the overheated punishment block at Holmesburg prison told in open court today of the experiences that killed four fellowprisoners and drove others into delirium or unconsciousness.

Manhattan Alterations 59th St, 53 to 59 W; to a 1, 2 and 32 story hotel and stores; Nielmo Realty Corp, 502 Park Ave, owner; C. Glaser, architect; cost, $35,000. 84th St. 520 E; to 5-story tenement: Arthur Elsenbast, N Y Athletic Club; John Elsenbast, 37-24 84th St, Jackson Heights, Queens, and Ida Elsenbast. 189 E 64th St, owners; L. E. Ordwein, architect; cost, $7,500.

The Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool, minister of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, president of the Union of Sephardic Congregations of America and president-elect of the Synagogue Council of America, arrived from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

The Marquis de Talleyrand, son of the late Comte Archibald de Talleyrand Perigord, married Mrs. Lela Mackintosh, stepdaughter of the Hon. Alfred Anson, in a private ceremony here today in the Church of Notre Dame des Victoires.

Miss Nancy Lee Warner, daughter of Mrs. Henry Giebel of this place, has chosen Sept. 17 for her marriage to William Harvey Webster Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster of Bronxville and Homer. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. John Henderson Powell Jr. in the Reformed Church here.

An increase of 11/4 cents a quart for Grade B milk will be put into effect tomorrow by the Sheffield Farms Company/as a result of the new Federal-State marketing order, which will increase payments to more than 60,000 dairy farmers supplying the metropolitan area, it was announced last night by Benjamin S., Halsey, vice president of the company.

Seneca Ave, 1.360, 1-story laundry, 160x 100; Albert W. Pross, trustee, against Senwit Realty Co, Inc; due, $44,174; taxes, etc, $2,305; to plaintiff for $30,000. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Cruger Ave, 2,555, 3-story dwelling, 28.9x 100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Leo Schwartz; due, $13,919; to plaintiff for $500.
Many luncheons were given before the recital by Arnold Belnick, 13-year-old violinist, which took place this afternoon at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.
British diplomacy is openly accused in the German press today of panic-mongering by making the Czech-Sudeten issue the occasion for an extraordinary Cabinet session.
Senator Pope of Idaho, who was defeated by Representative D. Worth Clark for the Democratic Senatorial nomination, stated today that he would not enter the general election. He said:

Roger D. Lapham, vice chairman of the Committee of Forty-three, chairman of the Industrial Association and president of the AmericanHawaii Steamship Company, disclosed plans today for a new labor relations set-up for San Francisco business and industry, modeled after the unions' organization of central labor councils.

The two-family dwelling at 189 Griffith Street in the Heights section of Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Hudson Trust Company to Abraham Blum. The building contains twelve rooms and has a twostory shop in the rear. J. I. Kislak, Inc.. was the broker.

Miss Laddie Irwin, 19-year-old Glen Ridge star, led a field of 114 starters, the largest that has ever taken part in a Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day golf tournament, and captured low-gross honors for the second week in a row today when she carded 42, 41-83 over the difficult west course of the Westchester Country Club.
The bond market continued to dedine yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as trading again was moderate.
Miss Dorothy Wightman of Boston today sprung the first major upset in the girls' national tennis singles tournament by defeating Miss Jessie Grossnickle of Columbus, Miss., seeded eighth.
Jim Turner held the Cubs to five hits today as the Bees won the opener of a three-game series, 8 to 1, and kept Chicago from taking second place.

Stocks recovered and closed steady and moderately higher in quiet trading; turnover, 630,650 shares. Czechoslovakian loans advanced 10 1/2 to 12 1/2 points, other groups of bonds lower; transactions, $4,289,540.
The combined Oxford - Cambridge squad, its, tour ended, sailed today after winning the rubber game of its soccer series of three with Jamaica yesterday, 1-0. Walford scored in the first half.

Industrial activity continued to show improvement during July and the first three weeks of August, according to the monthly survey of business conditions issued yesterday by the economic research division of the National Industrial Conference Board.

The manufacture of heavy nitrogen for the first time on a"massproduction" basis, with a yield of two grams of a 75 per cent concentrate of the precious substance every twenty-four hours, was announced yesterday by Columbia University.' This represents a tenfold increase over the current maximum production.

The dedine in daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas in July, compared with a year ago, was relatively smaller in the Middle West, where the decrease was about 6.5 per according to a Commerce Department study.

Carded yarn manufacturers from five Southern States, representing 900,000 spindles, met here today and ratified action taken recently by a joint committee in adopting fairtrade-practice rules for cotton yarn spinners.

A strong earthquake shook this city at 7;21 o'clock tonight. The shock, a swaying east-west motion lasting several seconds, was felt in downtown Los Angeles and more heavily in the harbor district and beach cities. No damage was reported.

Larry Carney, who defense counsel in the Hines trial, may contend was mistaken for Hines by Bridgeport, Conn, witnesses, was the subject in 1932 of affidavits describing him as too old, timid and feeble to look after his own money.
Pensioned On his own application. To take effect 12 midnight, Aug. 31: PATROLMAN-John K. Quealy. 72d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903.

Charles J. McIlvain Jr., retired architect, died of a heart attack today at his home here at the age of 67. Mr. McIlvain was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1890. He planned or supervised the construction of many buildings in Philadelphia.

Hilda, the 8-year-old Prospect Park Zoo elephant who was pushed into a moat Monday, remained unable to use her hind legs yesterday, but further examination by Dr. Harry Nimphius, veterinarian, indicated no bones were broken. He said Hilda's apparent paralysis was due to shock, and barring- unforeseen complications, he expected her to be up and around within a few days.

The rubber industry of the United States stands on the threshold of expansion into many new and important fields, according to Harvey S. Firestone Jr., vice president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, who discussed its outlook at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel - yesterday.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $11,858,084.

Sheridan Downey, avowed New Dealer and champion of a $30-aweek "scrip" pension scheme, took a surprising lead of better than 2 to 1 over Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, who was endorsed by President Roosevelt, for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in early primary returns tonight.

Middlesex concluded its county cricket campaign today in second position, the same as last year. Yorkshire won its twentieth championship yesterday with an innings and 49-run decision over Kent. Middlesex lost on the first innings to Surrey.

An additional issue of $10,000,000 of Gulf States Utilities Company first mortgage and refunding 4 per cent Series C bonds due in 1966 will be offered today by a banking group headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., at 104 and accrued interest.

The Plymouth division of Chrysler Corporation showed its new models for 1939 yesterday to 1,200 dealers and salesmen from Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester at a confidential preview in the Hotel Astor.

Richard C. (Dick) Harlow of Harvard was the lecturer at the second session of The Herald Tribune football coaching school at the Tribune auditorium yesterday, discussing, principally, the various methods of combating the five-man line defense.
Pennine Paramount of Prune's Own, pointer owned by Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke of Tuxedo Park, was named best in the annual dog show at the State Fair today.

In order to dispel unfounded rumors, members of the uniformed force are advised that promulgation of the eligible list for promotion to the rank of lieutenant is withheld at the requst of the Fire Chief and Commissioner, in order that he may dispose of the remaining names on the present list for lieutenant. The new list will be published Immediately after Oct. 1, 1938.

When the United States aircraft carrier Enterprise leaves for the United States, Saturday President Getulio Vargas will be aboard. The President will board the Enterprise just before she sails and will remain aboard until the vessel is about twenty-five miles at sea.

Max Factor, cosmetics manufacturer ,and a half-brother of John Factor, former Chicago speculator whose testimony after he had been kidnapped helped send the Tuohy gang to prison, died in Beverly Hills today. He was 61 years old.
The MacGregor Arctic Expedition, aboard the schooner General A. W. Greely, arrived here today after a very stormy trip from North Greenland.
President Roosvelt's "purge" campaign in South Carolina apparently was defeated tonight at the hands of .the dean of Senate Democrats, 73-year-old Ellison D. Smith.

John J. Greene of this city, a World War veteran and member of the Second Air Squadron of the United States Army, who died at Mitchel Field, Hempstead, L. I., on Sunday, will be buried here tomorrow after a service.
Twentieth Century-Fox today announced that Eddie Cantor had asked for cancellation of his contract over a dispute involving "Mr. Average Man," which was to have gone before the cameras yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,388,500 barrels, compared with 3,392,700 in the preceding week, a decline of 4,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 49,600 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,438,100 daily by the Bureau of Mines for August.

About 680 men seeking jobs as porters in the city service were waiting in line last night under the south portico of the Municipal Building for the opening this morning of the offices of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to file their applications.

Chairman Sheppard, Democrat, of Texas, of the Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee, classed as "unsatisfactory" today a breakdown of contributions and expenditures for a three-place Democratic ticket in Tennessee, including the Senatorial nominee, A. T. Stewart.

Held even for five rounds, Enrico Venturi, 140 pounds, Italy, spurted to win the decision from Johnny Rohrig, 137 1/2, Clifton, N. J., in the feature ten-round bout at the Queensboro Stadium in Long Island City last night.

With the second international tuna tournament over, the conversation among the anglers, rod and gun writers, boat captains and members of the board of governors today concerned the future of the matches and the problem they offered.

Discovery of large mountain caves in Canada's Northwest wilderness, believed to contain evidence of habitation by primitive men who migrated from Asia thousands of years ago, was reported today by Dr. Wesley L. Bliss, University of New Mexico archaeologist.

As the Democratic primaries proceed, more and more has been said about the President's "mandate" from the people. It is pointed out that Mr. Roosevelt was re-elected in 1936 by the greatest of all popular majorities and it is argued, by those who favor his active intervention in his party's primarines,

ALLEN--J. William, beloved husband of Ellen and father of Helen, Margaret, Elizabeth, James W., John and Joseph, on Aug. 30, 1938. Funeral from his late residence, 33 Haven Esplanade, Brighton Heights, S. I., on Friday. Requiem Mass at Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel at 10 A. M. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery.

Declaring it has taken twentyfive years to accomplish 25 per cent of the job of price maintenance in the retail jewelry field, Harley H. Noyes, sales director for Oneida, Ltd., urged retailers to back up the fair trade laws in forty-three States "with a definite course of action."
Representative W. D. McFarlane charged today that 5,000 Republicans voted in Saturday's Democratic run-off primary election to defeat him for re-election from the Thirteenth congressional District.

The largest advertising appropriation in its history has been set up by the Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., for the last four months of this year, Harry pardee, advertising manager, announced yesterday at a Fall sales meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., was the successful bidder yesterday for a new issue of $6,000,000 of electric revenue bonds of Knoxville, Tenn., with a tender of 100.005 for $4,280,000 of 32 per cent bonds and $1,720,000 of 3 1/4 per cent bonds, equivalent to an interest cost basis to the city of 3.39 per cent.

J. William Allen of 33 Haven Esplanade, New Brighton, S. I., a charter member of the New York Curb Exchange, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island after a brief illness, at the age of 55.

Alexander P. De Seversky is certain the air record of 10 hours 3 minutes and 7 seconds he set yesterday between New York and Los Angeles will not stand up long. He says an army pursuit ship will be able to crack his record soon.

Mrs. Frances Fisher Wood, mother of Colonel Eric Fisher Wood, commander of the 107th Field Artillery at Pittsburgh, died today at the home of her son near here. She was born in Cleveland eighty-seven years ago.

Ted Kleinhans and Earl Cook both pitched four-hit games to give Syracuse a double victory over Newark before 9,000 fans tonight, 6 to 1 and 2 to 1. A big second inning, in which the Chiefs put together five hits and an error for four runs, gave, Kleinhans a working margin in the seven-inning opener.
Baltimore swept a double-header with Jersey City tonight, taking the opener, 10 to 0, behind Harry Matuzak's three-hit pitching, and winning the second, 11 to 10, with a five-run rally in the ninth.

The Treasury announced today that bids on the usual weekly offering of about $100,000,000 of ninety-one-day discount bills would be received at the Federal Reserve Banks and their branches until 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Friday. The bills will be dated Sept. 7, 1938, and mature on Dec. 7, 1938.

In reply to an inquiry from Mervyn Rathborne, president of the American Communications Association of the C. I. O., regarding the Maritime Commission's policy as to collective bargaining agreements, the commission called Mr. Rathborne's attention today to a statement of July- 27 asserting in effect that the commission is for collective bargaining as a "stabilizing influence," but lacks any jurisdiction in the issue.

Lieut. Col. Enrique Urrutia of the Sixty-fifth Infantry, on the witness stand at Ponce testifying in the murder trial of Elifaz Escobar, identified the regiment's American flag and the holes in it from shots fired on July 25 when Governor Blanton Winship was fired on and Colonel Luis A. Irizarry of the National Guard was killed.

The Schwarze Korps, official organ of the Hitler Elite Guard, today publishes a reply to the German Catholic Bishops' pastoral letter read from the pulpits Sunday in which the Bishops attacked "the war that is being waged against Christianity" and demanded that anti-Christian teaching should cease.

The Rev. Mother Cephas, provincial counselor and former superior of the Ursuline Convent, College of New Rochelle, died yesterday at 3 A. M. at the college after a lingering illness.- Mother Cephas was 52 years old.

Miss Helen Dixie Wolfe, daughter of Mrs. Townsend Durand Wolfe of this city, was married to Donald Patrick Baker of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank Baker Jr., this morning in the Catholic Church of the Holy Family here. The Rev. Harold Mulqueen, S. J., of Fordham University, performed the ceremony.

Defending President Roosevelt's attitude in intervening in the Senatorial primary, Representative David J. Lewis, the Administration candidate, answered tonight Senator Tydings's charges. that the President's entering the State "savored of old-time carpetbagging."

The marriage of Miss Doris Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett F. Smith of this place, to W. Menzies Whitelaw of Ottawa took place this morning in Christ Church here. The Rev. Morton C. Stone performed the ceremony, which was followed by a small wedding breakfast at the Smith home.

T. P. Morgan, the Texan who took over the turf holdings of the Waggoner brothers in the Lone Star State, scored a double at Aqueduct yesterday with Smart Crack and Gin Daisy, both of them gray fillies.

Because of many complaints that this year's automobile license plates in New York State were hard to read, the 1939 plates will have numerals threequarters of an inch taller, the same size they were before the World's Fair line was added.

The garden of The Manor, the home here overlooking the St. Lawrence River of Mr. and Mrs. J. Archibald Gray, was the setting at noon today for the marriage of their, daughter, Miss Katharine Nairn Gray, to Dr. Gilman Sterling Currier, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Gilman Currier of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. B. Boibin of Pointe-au-Pic.

Although the prices paid for lower East Side properties this year have been, without exception, far below the assessed valuation when the buyer was able to offer "all cash," many recent sales by banks indicate that even these outmoded holdings often may bring prices close to the assessor's figures if only a small down payment is required.

Norma Shearer, who entered Mount Sinai Hospital last Saturday, left at noon yesterday. Upon her departure Miss Shearer posed for camera men and said "I am feeling fine. I am no longer under the doctor's care."

Mrs. Vincent Astor arrived today to be the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse at Eastbourne Lodge, who have just returned from a visit at Dark Harbor, Me. It is Mrs. Astor's first visit of the season, and Mr. and Mrs. Whitehouse gave a luncheon and dinner in her honor today.

The New York University Graduate School of Business Administration will offer more than 150 evening courses in investments, banking, public utilities, transportation, marketing and real estate beginning Sept. 20, Dean A.
Back at his desk after a two-week absence, President Roosevelt turned his attention today to the Maryland Democratic Senatorial contest.

Weakness in Winnipeg, where wheat futures closed 1 7/8 to 2 1/3 cents a bushel lower than yesterday, combined with less warlike news from Europe and a lack of export demand resulted in a break of about 1 cent a bushel in domestic markets.

Barbed wire has been strung at places along the Swiss frontier with Austria to help keep out Jewish refugees, the Journal de Geneve declares today. These and other police measures, it says, have cut off the "flood"a fortnight ago Jews were entering the Canton of Saint-Gall clandestinely at the rate of 140 daily--but it adds:
A revamped Jaguar four rode into action among the open polo championship contenders in test matches today, with Jimmy Mills at No. 1 in place of Hesketh Hughes.

First warning for the 1,200,000 New York City school children that the Summer vacation is coming to a close was given yesterday, when Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced that registration days would be Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of next week from 9 A. M. to noon and 1 to 3 P. M. Schools will open Monday morning, Sept. 12.
Premier Edouard Daladier's government has affirmed once more the French determination to march to the aid of Czechoslovakia in the event of a German invasion.

To London a week ago today went Oscar Hammerstein 2d to find some expert in the D'Oyly Carte tradition who would serve as adviser in the presentation of "Knights of Song," the forthcoming show about Gilbert and Sullivan.

Relief from the excessive heat caused the general death rate, the infant mortality and maternal mortality rates to decline during the Week ended last Saturday, it was reported by Thomas J. Duffield, City Registrar of Records, to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Charles C. Burlingham, long noted as a civic leader. was born eighty years ago today, but the Civil Service Reform Association, of which he is vice president, appraising him yesterday on the basis of "youthful understanding," refused to concede him more than 50 years.

Reports of important Japanese advances yesterday indicate the Chinese resistance is seriously crumbling north of the Yangtze, while in the Juichang and Singtze sectors south of the river the Chinese lines are stanchly held.

Clipping a stroke off Cherry Valley's par of 72 on his afternoon round, after doing the same thing to Garden City Golf Club's par in the morning, Richard (Dick) Chapman of Greenwich today set the pace in the metropolitan district's qualifying round for places in the national amateur championship,

While the drama in Europe continues to unroll like a tremendous scene in a theatre, in an atmosphere of sustained suspense, all the signs point to a consolidation of the forces working against war. We have seen Herr Hitler and his generals dashing along the unfinished Siegfried line on an inspection tour.

The value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles, as indicated by the preliminary adjusted index figure, showed a contra-seasonal increase from June to July, according to the Department of Commerce.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Aug. 25 increased in three of five trade divisions, as compared with the same week in 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:

The interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Hudson River Connecting Railroad to issue $12,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series A, and $12,548,600 of $100-par value common capital stock, both to be delivered to the New York Central Railroad Company at par in substitution for $24,550,100 of notes which are to be canceled .

Roger (Doc) Cramer, who thrice has been named center fielder on the American League all-star team, came to the aid of a beleaguered Red Sox pitching staff today, hurling the last four innings of a game lost to the Browns, 9 to 5. St.. Louis advanced from eighth to seventh place as a result.

Two men who nearly two weeks ago pleaded guilty to a charge of withholding payments to the State insurance fund received suspended sentences yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions after they had paid $10,000 to the State in restitution.
The State Emergency Board, summoned by Governor George D. Aiken, today appropriated $3,000 from its contingent fund to employ expert counsel in a study of the railroad situation in Vermont.
With the largest entry in the nineteen years of its history, the Rhinebeck Dutchess County Fair horse show opened this morning and will continuee through tomorrow afternoon.

Lord Poulett, who had been visiting in Newport, is at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. James Lakeman Ward have returned from Europe and are at the Sherry-Netherland. Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets of Cassilis- House, New Marlboro, Mass., are expected to arrive today at the Carlyle.

President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell of Wayside, this place, and 270 Park Avenue, New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sackett Bissell, to Captain James J. Christie of Riverdale, N. Y.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Samuel Edwards of New York, formerly of Toronto, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Winifred Edwards, to Dwight Nelson Chapin of New York and Stafford, Va.

An order requiring James H. Fay., New Deal opponent of Representative John J. O'Connor in the Sixteenth Congressional District, to show cause tomorrow why his Democratic designating petition should not be declared invalid was signed late yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.

Five Star Final, the seemingly invincible chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N. J., captured the featured five - gaited saddle horse class at the Empire State Horse Show tonight, defeating an exceptionally fine field.

Some time having elapsed since Laurette Taylor has been visible and audible to the Gotham playgoer, there is chance to renew a fond acquaintance this week. She is now playing Candida in Shaw's comedy of that name at the Tuttle Skinner Westchester Playhouse.

Gus Suhr took it into his head to do some long-range hitting at Forbes Field today as the Giants opened their final visit of the year as guests of the Pirates, and the result was that the not- so - immovable Corsairs stepped another game away from the less-than-irresistible New Yorkers, who dropped a 7-to-1 decision.
Professor Joseph Bedier, a member of the French Academy, educator and author, died today at the age of 74 in his chateau in Grand Serre, District of Drome.

Bids for the construction of a $185,000 laboratory at Underhill Avenue and Park Place, Brooklyn, for the chemical and bacteriological analysis of the city's water supply were received by the Department of Parks yesterday.
These are the times that try customs inspectors' souls. Very nearly 8,000 returning travelers were dumped by fifteen ships on the New York

Dr. Robert Ley, head of the German Labor Front, tonight addressed several thousand Germans from abroad, telling them in passionate language and with graphic examples what has been achieved by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Germany. Not only was the nation more united and vigorous than ever in its history, he said, but, most important of all, "Geneva no longer exists."

Farmers in this area of broad cotton plantations estimated today that the new cotton loan rate would cost them money. They said that many were already having a hard time taking care of farmhands whom acreaage reduction had left with nothing to do.
MANHATTAN CASAZZA, ANNA (June 28). Estate, about $5,000. To Charles Casazza, husband, excutor, 44 Carmine St. FULD EMANUEL L. (Aug. 16). Estate, less than 10,000.

John F. Curry, under whose leadership Tammany Hall fell from power, took the witness stand yesterday to lay bare the manner in which James J. Hines and other Democratic district leaders manipulated the city's police. Policemen were transferred at the request of the district chiefs with no questions asked, he testified.

Denouncing what he termed "pressure being exerted through Federal offices" to thwart his re-election, Senator Walter F. George today accused Secretary Ickes and Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA Administrator, of favoring relief programs because of "enormous powers placed in their hands as administrators."

If Senator Sheppard is wrong, and Secretary Morgenthau is right in his contention that no law prevents political contributions by those on the Federal payrolls to persons not also in the service of the government, then the text of the law evades its spirit and its purpose.

An investigation of the city's bureau of real estate conducted for three months by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and Lee Thompson Smith, director of the bureau, led yesterday to the filing of formal charges against four of the employes.

Enormous smoke clouds passed over Finland, Sweden and Norway this evening, stretching as far north as Leksand and as far south as the Baltic States. Even in the center of Stockholm smoke was observed and a strong smell of forest fire noticed.
Only about half the States, a survey showed today, have workable methods of preventing voters from disregarding normal party affiliations in primary elections.
John Cobb, wealthy fur broker from London, sped his racing car over the course twice today, but postponed an assault on the world land speed record.

Denouncing what he termed "pressure being exerted through Federal offices" to thwart his re-election, Senator Walter F. George today accused Secretary Ickes and Harry L. Hopkins, the WPA Administrator, of favoring relief programs because of "enormous powers placed in their hands as administrators."

If Senator Sheppard is wrong, and Secretary Morgenthau is right in his contention that no law prevents political contributions by those on the Federal payrolls to persons not also in the service of the government, then the text of the law evades its spirit and its purpose.

An investigation of the city's bureau of real estate conducted for three months by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and Lee Thompson Smith, director of the bureau, led yesterday to the filing of formal charges against four of the employes.
