Enormous smoke clouds passed over Finland, Sweden and Norway this evening, stretching as far north as Leksand and as far south as the Baltic States. Even in the center of Stockholm smoke was observed and a strong smell of forest fire noticed.
Only about half the States, a survey showed today, have workable methods of preventing voters from disregarding normal party affiliations in primary elections.

A group of experts recruited from the garment industry began yesterday examining 30,000 samples of miscellaneous apparel, representing offerings of about 3,000,000 garments, for the Procurement Division of the United States Treasury, T. J. Forde, State procurement officer, announced yesterday.

Ben Temple, a white and lemon pointer dog owned by C. A. Rugg of Jamestown, N. Y., won the all-age stake of the fifth annual Saskatchewan field trials at Buffalo Lake today. Miss Broomhill's Jake, owned by B. C. Goss of Cleveland, was second, and Highland Bimpkins, owned by Dr. L. O.

Sagging under the pressure of the flight of European capital to seek refuge in this country from the threatened war, the pound sterling fell further yesterday in the foreign-exchange market, and additional gold to the amount of $4,079,000 was engaged in London for shipment here.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company filed yesterday the plans for the first group of buildings in its housing development for the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx. The first unit

The Associated Gas Electric Company announced yesterday that it had made an offer to purchase the remaining outstanding amount of its 51/2 per cent convertible investment certificates. Tenders will be received until Sept. 15 and the certificates tendered at the lowest prices will be accepted in a sufficient amount to exhaust the available funds. About $2,000,000

Potato growers in the fifteen States which market-a late crop appear to have rejected the AAA proposal for a marketing agreement for the current year's output, Agricultural Department officials said tonight.

The annual husband - and - wire tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was won by Mr. and Mrs. Foy Porter, who played alternate shots to score 37, 38-75, over their home course at the Rock Spring Club today.

Mrs. Margaret Hill McCarter, author and a leader in woman's suffrage, died of a heart ailment here today. She was 78 years old. Mrs. McCarter wrote many novels portraying family life in early frontier days. She began her literary career shortly after coming to Topeka as a high school English instructor in 1888.

A moderate proportion of the recent gain in steel production has been brought bout by the building up of semi-finished inventories in anticipation of further improvement, Iron Age says this week, adding that "some mills are trying to keep a little ahead of actual demand in stocks of slabs and sheet bars so that anticipated requirements of the automobile industry can be rolled quickly."

A client of Frank M. McCurdy Co., Inc., has purchased from W. T. Thomas a first mortgage of $24,625 on the property at 559 Saratoga Ave., Brooklyn. Nehring Brothers, Inc., has arranged the extension of the first mortgage of $36,000 on 375 E. 199th St., the Bronx, for five years at 41/2 per cent for Mrs. Anna Otto.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has notified its depositors that in the future it will send out monthly statements and canceled checks prior to the end of the month to avoid a concentration of work at the end of the month.

Exports of electrical equipment during July were valued at $9,795,964, a decrease of 3.5 per cent from June and 21.4 per cent from July, 1937, the Commerce Department reported today. Decreases were noted

The statement of the Borden Company for the first half of this year, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $2,823,674, equal after charges and taxes to 64 cents each on the 4,396,704 common shares outstanding. This compares with $2,883,085, or 65 cents a common share, in the first six months of 1937.

Homer E. Capehart, sponsor of last week's Republican "cornfield conference" here, today telegraphed Mrs. Norman E. Mack of Buffalo, N. Y., associate Democratic national committeewoman for New York, a request that his name be withdrawn as a candidate for Democratic precinct committeeman in Amherst. N. Y.

A vast assortment of foreignmanufactured war material captured from the Loyalists has been assembled as a "war exposition" which was opened here Monday by Nationalist (Rebel) authorities. In the presence of the German, Italian. Portuguese and Japanese Ambassadors as well as the Papal Nuncio and the rest of the diplomatic corps accredited to Burgos, Count de Jordana, Foreign Minister and Vice Premier of General Francisco Franco's Government, officially inaugurated the exhibition.

About 5,000 persons witnessed last night the last of this Summer's athletic contests sponsored by the Police Athletic League in Sheridan Square, Sheridan Square and Seventh Avenue. The exhibition was the tenth in the series held in various parts of the city.

Robert Gordon and his Pequot Yacht Club mates, Howland Hayes and Roderick McNeil, struck two good blows in defense of the national junior sailing championship and the Sears Cup to become the new leader in the eight-race series today.

While the five international sixmeter yachts made a big showing in the Scandinavian Gold Cup event off Oyster Bay, a still larger one has been arranged for Saturday in the Long Island Sound championship race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club there.

Professor Roger S. Strout, former physics instructor at the Georgia School of Technology, and Mrs. Strout, arrived yesterday in the 37-foot ketch Igdrasil, of Portland, Me. He said they left North Carolina in January.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie for what he described as a "muchneeded rest." He said he would spend forty hours in Paris and then return on the Normandie to New York on Sent. 12.

Old Westbury played six periods on Waterbury Field of the Meadow. Brook Club today in the last hard workout the team is expected to have before it starts the defense of its title in the national open polo championship which opens here Sunday.

Prince Charming II, owned by the Claredda Farm of Mr. and Mrs. E. V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., today added to his many brilliant horse-show victories by annexing the highest honors of the nineteenth annual Rhinebeck-Dutchess County Fair Horse Show. It was the second time in succession this grand hunter has taken the bestin-show award here.

Mrs. Gwladys Whitney, who remained in racing with a stable of jumpers when her husband temporarily retired from the turf, scored yesterday with Gay Charles in the $2,935 Bushwick Steeplechase Handicap, feature of the program at Aqueduct.

The world series spirit permeated Forbes Field today. Pop bottles and fresh fruit showered the field in manifestations of wrath, cushions rained from the stands attesting to joy unconfined as, hemmed in by an overflow crowd of 43,586 and weighted by the strain of their pennant struggle, the weary Giants split a twin bill with the league-leading Pirates.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, on a flying trip around Europe, alighted today under the protection of a heavy army and police guard. About 10,000 persons had waited at the airport since early morning, but when the American couple arrived at 3:45 P. M. from Odessa, Russia, the guard was so heavy they saw little of the fliers.

John C. Looker, formerly one of this State's largest oil producers, died today in his home at the age of 84. Mr. Looker was chosen as the "grand old man of the oil industry of the world" at the Sixth International Petroleum Exposition in Tulsa, Okla.; in 1929.

Attracted by the richest purses in the eighteen-year history of the national air races, eight of America's premier speed pilots and as many of the nation's fastest closed-course racing aircraft began the dangerous qualifying trials today to determine the entrants in the races to be flown here on Sunday and Monday.

Tewfik Shanti, an Arab broker, was shot dead this morning in the waiting room of an Arab doctor in Jaffa. He had just left a hospital where he had been since he was wounded in a cafe about a week ago. The assailant escaped.
August engineering awards, with a total of $236,271,000, were 39 per cent above last year, and reached the highest point for any August on since 1930, the Engineering NewsRecord reports.

The guerrilla tactics of the Chinese have been so "enormously" successful that the Japanese Army in China is "slowly bleeding to death," according to two medical missionaries now making their first visit to the United States since the outbreak of the war after having spent many years in hospitals and Red Cross work in China.

Substantial advertising campaigns for several men's hat companies will begin within a few days and continue for four months, according to advertising agencies yesterday. Newspapers are obtaining the major share of the appropriations, they said. With a "return

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will be among the speakers at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which will be held in Mr. Jones's home city, Houston, Texas, on Nov. 14 to 17, it was announced yesterday by Orval W. Adams, president of the association.

George Thomson Moore of Short Hills, N. J., an executive of Benjamin Moore Co., paint manufacturers, died in a hospital here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 39. While at Dartmouth, where he was graduated in 1922, he played on the varsity eleven, won the intercollegiate heavyweight boxing championship, and joined the Psi Upsilon fraternity and the Casque and Gauntlet Club.

An eyewitness account of the cold-blooded murder of Jules Martin-with Dutch Schultz himself pulling the trigger-was given by J. Richard (Dixie) Davis to District Attorney Charles J. Ranney of Rensselaer County two weeks ago yesterday, it was learned last night after Justice Ferdinand Pecora had...
The stock market here was generally quiet today, but yesterday's improvements were well maintained and a number of advances were registered.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that hearing on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the no-par value common stock of the Advance-Rumley.

The Red Sox snapped out of a three-game losing streak today by beating the Browns, 6 to 3. The St. Louis hurler, Howard (Lefty) Mills, allowed only seven hits but was wild. He walked five men and four of them scored. Bobby Doerr led the Boston attack with a double, two singles and two stolen bases.

Miss Elizabeth Alden Fish and John Alden Stanton, both of whom are descendants of John Alden, were married yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Eugene C. Carder. The bride was given in marriage by her father, Harry Potter Fish of 140 West Fifty-eighth Street.

The largest cash settlement for back pay negotiated by the National Labor Relations Board was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board for New York, when she also made known the adjustment of the long-standing dispute in the shipyards operated by the Todd Shipyards Company and its subsidiaries, the Robins Drydock and Repair Company of Brooklyn and Tietjen Lane of Hoboken.
Charles Alexander Tosi of Ridgewood, N. J., died last night at the age of 52. His widow will accompany his body to the United States tomorrow.

Imports of gold received in New York in August totaled $77,415,000, the largest for any month since June, 1937, and the largest for an August in more than ten years. They compared with imports of $1,119,000 in July and $47,551,500 in August, 1937.

Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's top-ranking tennis star, was disclosed today to be employed as a clerk in the Lehrterstrasse jail, where he is serving a year's sentence for violation of a moral delinauency statute.

With a "Bon voyage!" from Mayor La Guardia, hundreds of children and mothers enjoyed their last excursion of the Summer yesterday aboard the municipal ferry boats Murray Hill and Queens. Similar outings were conducted for the last time this season by the League of Mothers Clubs and St. John's Guild.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was featured yesterday by a sharp decline in the issues of the Nickel Plate Railroad, but the remained of the list was mixed. Sales amounted to $3,682,625, compared with $4,289,450 on the preceding day.

Harry R. Bridges, West Coast regional director of the C. I. O. and president of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, asserted today that the evidence on which the Dies committee seeks to have him deported as an alien Communist consisted of "nothing but lies."

As if the assistance of the to provide an "object lesson"- to the strife-torn union of the United Automobile Workers of America, a statement was issued today by John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, reporting that complete harmony had been brought to the Federation of Flat Glass Workers by intervention of the C. I. O. in its affairs.

Japan rejected yesterday the United States protest over the machine gunning of a Chinese civilian plane piloted by an American. The Tokyo note [text on Page 10] held that the incident did not involve any third power and that the attack was justified. [Page 1.]

MANHATTAN BENEDICT, PAUL (Aug. 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To Barbara Benedict, c/o The Marine Midland Trust Co. of New York, 120 Broadway, life estate in residue with power of appointment. Marine Midland Trust Co., of New York, 120 Broadway, executor.
John G. Bergquist, president of the American Gas Accumulator Company and the Highway Lighthouse Company, died yesterday of heart disease in the New York Hospital at the age of 69.

Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum, to take effect at 12:01 A. M., Sept. 1:

It seems that Mr. Charles C. Burlingham was 80 yesterday. We don't dispute the records, but dates are sometimes deceptive. By some art of doing easily, quietly and well many sorts of hard work, he has retained the intellectual vitality and energy of youth.

Several commercial and industrial buildings in Long Island City and Jackson Heights figured in the Queens realty deals announced by brokers yesterday. The four-story building at 47-10 Amstel Place, Long Island City, was leased by the United Auto Storage Company from the Schulte Real Estate Company, Inc., through Roman-Caswell Company, Inc., brokers. The structure contains

John Roosevelt feels that his wages of $18.50 a week as stock clerk in a Boston department store will not allow him to come to work in his car from the suburbs. The figures would seem to be unanswerable.
George W. Mason, president of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, announced the appointment today of Ray Legg. as general sales manager of the Leonard division. Mr. Legg had been
Two world's records were broken and another equaled, while a seventeen-year-old track record also fell in brilliant Grand Circuit races at the New York State Fair today.

The Conversion Office for German Foreign Debts announced yesterday that its offer to exchange certain matured dollar bonds for an unmatured series or to pay their reichsmark equivalent into an amortization blocked reichsmark account in the name of the holder,

Dr. Ellwood L. Kemp, former president of Wichita (Kan.) University and once principal of East Stroudsburg Normal School, died of heart disease last night in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital here. He was 82 years old.
Average discount rates on the Treasury's weekly bill issues, which firmed up sharply in July, leveled out in August at figures somewhat above those that had prevailed in recent previous months.

Mrs. Julian S. Myrick and Mrs. Lion Gardiner assisted Mrs. John M. Dodd this afternoon in Guild Hall at a tea which followed a fashion show in which a group of young women of East Hampton's Summer colony acted as models. The scholarship fund of Dr. Carlson's School here was the beneficiary.

Two new names in the annals of the pro-amateur team championship of the Westchester County Golf Association were inscribed in the books tonight as Fred Anunziato, assistant to Paul Runyan at the Metropolis Club, and Howard Bergman, amateur, won the title today with a best-ball score of 67 over the Sunningdale Country Club course.

F R Coat Makers, Inc, floor in 599601 Broadway; Promotion Displays, Inc, floor in 23 E 21st St; Beacon Curtain Co, Inc. floor in 24 W 25th St; Emanuel D. Glelch in 110 W 27th St; Lady Amherst Hat Co. Inc, in 49 W 37th St; Katzka Greenspan, Inc. in 21 W 38th St, Aronowitz Helt, store in 1,178 Broadway; Williams Co, Inc. brokers.

The Palace Theatre, once regarded as the premier vaudeville house in this country, today will celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of its opening with a doublefeature motion-picture program. The Palace, built by Martin Beck in the Spring of 1913, opened on Sept.

Mrs. Anne Lyell Erskine, widow of Albert Russell Erskine, president of the Studebaker Corporation, died here last night of heart disease. Her age was 62. The funeral will be held Friday at 2 P. M. Burial will take place in a Huntsville, Ala., mausoleum beside the body of her husband.

Indian Chief White Eagle, with a bright-yellow lollypop between his teeth, roared his fiercest war whoops yesterday but could not frighten the 300 children and mothers who came to bid farewell to the Summer program of the Grand Street Settlement Play School, 283 Rivington Street.

Describing the mechanics of the purge against him, John J. O'Connor, seeking renomination for his seat in the House of Representatives on the Republican and Democratic tickets in the Sixteenth Congressional District, last night accused the Federal Administration, the Communist party, the Workers Alliance, Mayor La Guardia and three Republican district leaders of working together to prevent his return to Washington. He spoke over radio station WINS.

Employment in the steel industry during July averaged 424,000 workers, with the total payroll for the month, $45,802,000, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This compares to 424,700 employes and a payroll of $46,706,000 in June and to 594,000 employes and a payroll of $90,550,000 in July, 1937.

MANHATTAN BERNSTEIN, HAROLD (April 14, 1937) Gross assets, $17,109; net, $14,335. To Ruth Bernstein, widow, one-third residue: Richard M. Bernstein, son. twothirds residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $12,200. Bernard B. Smith, attorney, 350 Madison Ave.

William D. Hand has joined the resident buying office of Jack Hartblay, Inc., as special representative, it was announced yesterday. For the last fifteen years he has been associated with the resident buying field, and recently has been head of his own office.

Mills H. Husted, representing the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, took the first event in the East Coast Atlantic Class yachting championship series at Indian Harbor today, sailing his Rumour home eleven seconds ahead of G. S. Franklin of Cold Spring Harbor. Husted is the defending champion.

The Board of Tax Appeals disclosed in an opinion today that President Roosevelt's first "fireside chat on March 12, 1933, during the Bank holiday was a factor considered in valuing the estate of Daniel P. Hower, vaccum cleaner manufacturer.

Goose, America's defending sloop, laid a golden egg in the spanking Sixmeter series. Though Sweden, Norway, Finland and, by way of Bermuda, Great Britain bid stoutly for, it, the Scandinavian gold cup remains with the Sewanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club another year at least.

John F. Curry, testifying yesterday at the Hines trial, proved to have a bad memory about the number of votes he polled last year in Mr. Hines's Eleventh Assembly District, one of the districts in which Mr. Curry ran for election as a delegate to the Constitutional Convention. Mr. Curry ran in the Seventh, Ninth and Eleventh districts and was defeated.
Speedboat drivers, officials and camp followers, representing three nations, welcomed Count Theo Rossi di Montelera of Turin at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Charles Stewart Davison in his recent letter to THE TIMES scores the New Deal for disregarding "the lessons of experience," and cites our recent monetary and financial policies as a case in point. He caustically speaks of the "expropriation [of] all the privately owned gold"; of "debasing the 'value' of the paper dollar" which, he says, "is simple dishonesty."
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 31 unless specified: At San Clemente, Perry, Trever, Wasmuth, Zane. Allegheny, Lewes, Del., to Bellevue. Argonne, Navy Yard, Mare Island, to San Pedro.
Mrs. Herrika W. B. Prather of New York City and Dallas filed suit today to divorce John Armstrong Prather of Dallas. She charged cruelty. They were married Aug. 12, 1933, at

Word has been received here of the marriage in Carson City, Nev., on Tuesday afternoon of Mrs. Nancy Ryan Haynes of this city to Carl Fleischmann Holmes, son of Mrs. Christian R. Holmes of 1,107 Fifth Avenue and the late Dr. Holmes.

Writing in the seventy-fifth anniversary number of The Army and Navy Journal, General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the Army, gives credit to General Pershing for the set-up of the existing General Staff organization. Credit for the basic law which made the General Staff possible belongs, says General Craig, to Elihu Root of New York, while to Major Gen. William H. Carter belongs the credit for shaping the original staff organization.

Besides one obvious inference to be drawn from what happened at the Democratic primaries in South Carolina and California-that two more candidates for Senator whom the President tried to defeat cannot be counted on 100 per cent for his legislative program and his 1940 purposesthere are several others of great importance.

The report of the Kennecott Copper Corporation for the first half of this year, to be made public today, shows a consolidated net income of $8,238,985 after charges, taxes, depreciation, but before mine depletion. This is equal to 76 cents each on the 10,821,686 common capital shares outstanding.

W. T. McCleery, who for two years has been in charge of The Associated Press feature service, submitted his resignation to Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press, yesterday, effective Sept. 30. Mr. Cooper said that Mr. McCleery's departure "will be a great loss to the A. P. feature service for under him it has progressed notably."

Dividends declared by 765 companies in August amounted to $244,641,824, compared with payments of $190,228,957 by 837 concerns in the preceding month and $389,022,270 by 880 companies in August, 1937.
Lloyd's underwriters, who in former days were ready to write policies against all sorts of calamities, are not laying any odds on the likelihood of another war sweeping over Europe.

Reviewing the results of primary elections in many parts of the country, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that the federation's policyof supporting labor's friends on a nonpartisan basis had proved "practical and successful," while the plan of independent political action followed by the Committee for Industrial Organization could be classed as a "failure."

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Aug. 30, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of general science in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

The stores, dwelling and private garages at 2,152-6 Westchester Avenue, near Castle Hill Avenue, in the vicinity of the Bronx housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, have been sold by David and Lena Faith to the Waycross Realty Corporation.

It is very doubtful that Flash Falaschi, sensational recruit quarterback from Santa Clara, and Howie Yeager, speedy halfback from Santa Barbara, will be ready for action when the New York Football Giants battle the Eastern All-Stars at the Polo Grounds next Wednesday night.

The announcement in Chicago that efforts at mediation in the railway wage controversy had failed and that the calling of a strike vote and the appointment of a fact-finding board by President Roosevelt appeared likely was all "according to Hoyle."
Our Dodgers won't be emulating the ancient Spartans when they come home Saturday morning to face the Giants at Ebbets Field. They just haven't any shields, either to bear or be borne upon.
United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels and his staff will attend the opening session of the Mexican Congress tomorrow morning, Stephen A. Aguirre, the Ambassador's secretary, announced today.
A Yorkshire to village war memorial that shows German soldiers cutting off a woman's head and burning babies has brought a protest from the German consul general in Liverpool, it was learned today.

With earnings of the Commonwealth Edison Company this year running about equal to those in 1937, there is a distinct possibility that the company may increase its quarterly divided rate this Fall, according to information from financial sources.

All schools in this city have been closed by health authorities until further notice because of an outbreak of infantile paralysis. Since Jan. 1 twentyseven cases of the disease have broken out here, three of which were fatal.

William Greenblatt of 211 West 106th Street, founder of William Greenblatt, Inc., at 305 Seventh Avenue, manufacturing furriers, died early yesterday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases, at the age of 74, after a short illness.

The annual inspection tour of the new crop of oysters in Great South Bay, L. I., by oyster cultivators and dealers, State and Federal conservation and health officials, food editors and restaurateurs was held yesterday, under the sponsorship of the Long Island Oyster Growers Association. The oysters tested

Dr. William I. Williams, for three years a tackle of the University of Pennsylvania varsity football team, and Glen Frey, former halfback and quarterback on the Temple University squad, have accepted appointments on the Pennsylvania football coaching staff, it was announced today.

Renewed flight of capital to this country and payments for the continued large merchandise export balance of the country brought about the accelerated flow of gold here and the accompanying pressure on the foreign exchanges in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York explains in a discussion of the gold inflow in the current issue of its monthly review.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey in two similar opinions ruled yesterday that creditors and' general bondholders of the now defunct Chicago Joint Stock Land Bank and the Southern Minnesota Joint Stock Land Bank were entitled to recover a 100 per cent assessment from holders of stock in the two banks who live in this district and were made defendants in a recovery action.
An interesting deal has just been consummated in Newark, N. J., which will result in the development of a new industrial center on land previously purchased for a model housing project.

That may be considered a renewal of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff's invistation to the non-Fascist powers last March to confer on practical measures to forestall German aggression against Czechoslovakia was contained today in an editorial in the Journal de Moscou, a French language weekly newspaper reflecting the views of the Soviet Foreign Office.
Ludlum Steel Company $1-par value common stock was stricken yesterday from listing and registration on the New York Stock Exchange. It was suspended from dealings on Aug. 19.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $10,292,063, as compared with a net of $11,251,309 in the twelve months to June 30, 1937.

D. Bert Gilbert has been appointed Southern representative of the Northrup Glove Manufacturing Company. Ben F. Levis, Inc., resident buyer, has been named to represent General Merchandise Company, Lima, Ohio.

G. Grant Mason Jr., member of the Civil Aeronautics Authority, was named by President Roosevelt today as chairman of the delegation to the Fourth International Conference on Private Air Law, which will convene at Brussels, on Sept. 19.

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following Reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area are assigned to units as indicated: 433d Quartermaster Regiment--2d Lt. Richard H. Carlisle, QM-Res., 330 Winton Road, S., Rochester, N.Y.

Ernst Wilhelm Bohle, Britishborn leader of the Nazi foreign organization, said in an interview that the importance of his organization was much overrated. He asserted the membership in all the world was only 50,000 and that it was not his plan to obtain a large membership, because the limited number was capable of caring for Germans abroad.

Celebrating the twentieth anniversary of the beginning of the Battle of the Argonne, the officers of the Seventy-seventh Division of the A. E. F. will hold their first reunion dinner on Monday night, Sept. 26, at the University Club, it was announced yesterday.

President Roosevelt today gave Douglas Corrigan a good-humored warning not to take any more chances, as he received the flier in the midst of a series of conferences. Mr. Corrigan arrived at the White House bare-headed but wearing windbreaker, gray slacks and an emerald-green shirt.

Cuyahoga County, Ohio, will enter the market on Sept. 22 with $6,120,000 of refunding bonds bearing an interest-rate of 31/2 per cent. They will be dated Oct. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on April 1 and Oct. 1, 1940 to 1949.

The Rev. Arthur Harold Hope, formerly pastor of the Congregational Church here, died last night in Northampton, Mass., at the age of 64. He was graduated from Oberlin College in 1904 and from Union Theological Seminary in 1907.

The City of New York has conveyed to Rednu, Inc., the two vacant lots at the southwest corner of Church and Leonard Streets, which it acquired several years ago in connection with subway construction. The property is 50 by 100
The government lost about 5.4 cents a bushel on the first wheat sold for export under Secretary Wallace's subsidy program.

Effective today, the Associated Merchandising Corporation will become American buying representative for Aux Galeries Lafayette, leading Paris department store, and its branch in London, according to an announcement yesterday by P. J. Reilly, director of the buying agency.

British beer drinkers, who until recently had been proof against the trade recession and had managed somehow to maintain their thirst during an unseasonable Summer, are now finding less expensive tipples.
Although the Japanese War Minister reiterated the declaration that Japan never Would deal with Generalissimo

The worst typhoon to strike the Tokyo area since 1905 today spread death and disaster. The seventy-mile-anhour wind plunged Yokohama into darkness. All the street lights in Tokyo are out of commission and railway and other traffic are seriously threatened by steadily rising rivers.
The Capitol Daily said tonight that underwriters of Lloyd's of London had refused to quote odds for or against a third term for President Roosevelt.

O. M. Mosier, vice president of American Aairlines, conferred with Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall yesterday on final arrangements for a lease of hangar space at North Beach airport for his company.

While consumers' organizations began mapping a campaign to organize "consumer resistance" against "unwarranted" price increases in milk, the Borden's Farm Products Company yesterday followed the Sheffield Farms Company in announcing that beginning...

Miss Barbara Gene Hills was married to William Keith Topping of New York this evening in the First Congregational Church of Oakland. The Rev. Charles Hobart, who had married the bride's mother and father, officiated.

The number of aircraft manufactured in the United States in the first six months of this year was approximately 22 per cent greater than in the corresponding period in 1937, the Civil Aeronautics Authority announced today. The number was 1,974 against 1,623 last year.

The plans of the Cooperative Health Association to offer medical and surgical care to New Yorkers for $24 a year on a group basis hit a snag yesterday when doubt was expressed by the Attorney General's office that the scheme was legal in this State.

The close of play in English cricket matches started today: England eleven 132 (Ward six for 44, O'Reilly four for 30) and 33 for one; Australians 174 (Amar Singh six for 84), at Blackpool. Essex 457 for four (Nichols 123 not out, Avery 138, O'Connor 83, Pearce 70 not out) vs. Gloucestershire, at Gloucester.

Europe's war thunderings sounded a little more distant yesterday, though the storm signals were still up. As British Ambassador Henderson returned to Berlin the German press moderated its at- wil tacks on Czechoslovakia, pre- sto sumably pending the envoy's the communication with the Wilhelmstrasse. [Page 1.]

Miss Ann Carroll Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Baxter of Brooklyn and Bay Shore, L. I., will be married to John de Lacey Regan, son of Mrs. John F. Regan and the late Mr. Regan, on Sept. 22 in the Church of the Holy Innocents, Beverly Road and East Seventeenth Street. Flatbush.
The Rev. James B. Henry, S. J., mathematician and astronomer, died today in the Queen of the Angels Hospital after a long illness.

Industrial and civic leaders attending a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to open a sales campaign under the sponsorship of the Electrical and Gas Association of New York, Inc., hailed the drive as an impetus to industry.

That kindly and beloved veteran of Yale, Professor Emeritus Phelps, has issued his annual list of books of the past year that he "enjoyed reading." Any such selection, the product of an individual with catholic taste, is intertesting and sure to irritate persons who have their own string of favorites.

The Park Department's checkers championship for persons over 50 years was won yesterday by a 59year-old retired salesman, Isidore Weisburd of 7,313 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn. He "worked for it," he said. He played uninterruptedly for four hours and thirtysix minutes.

J. Lewiston Birdsall, prominent real estate dealer of the North Shore for many years, died here tonight in the North Country Community Hospital after a brief illness that followed a heart attack. His age was 68.

The formation of Fuller, Rodney Redmond, combining Fuller, Rodney Co. and Redmond Co., will take effect today. Partners in the new firm include Samuel L. Fuller, Earle H. Rodney, Stuart Hedden, Lucius P. Ordway Jr., Arthur J. Goldsmith, James C. Fuller, member of the New York Stock Exchange; Melville L. Brown, member of the New York Curb Exchange, and Byron G. Webster of Chicago, manager of the Chicago office. Franklin Q. Brown,

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has authorized a loan of $2,000,000 at 23/4 per cent interest to the Tennessee Valley Authority, which it is understood, will be used partly to finance purchase of facilities of the Tennessee Public Service Company in Knoxville.

The Father and Son Championship Trophy of the Long Island Golf Association makes another trip back to the hilltop perch of the Oakland Golf Club, for at the Cherry Valley Club today the trophy that Perley and Olin Boone brought back after a year's possession returned to Oakland in the keeping of Joseph and Gordon Upton.
More than 200 members of the Ku Klux Klan paraded through the Negro quarters last night in a demonstratioN which spokesmen said was the result of two Negro slayings here in two weeks.

Twenty-six persons, including State Senator Joseph P. Dando of Schuylkill County, two other Democratic politicians, a county WPA director and a group of WPA foremen and timekeepers, were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to misuse WPA funds and labor.

Mrs. Vance McCormick entertained with a tea at Westward Way, Northeast Harbor, for members of the committee of the Mount Desert Island Hospital who met there this afternoon. Mrs. Malcolm Peabody presided at the session, which was attended by many members of the Summer colony.

Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate that controls the Alleghany Corporation, was appointed yesterday a member of the committee of directors of the Chesapeake Corporation established to carry out a plan for the latter company's dissolution.
Properties included in Westches. ter transactions announced yester-0 day consisted largely of private residences in various parts of the county.

The dogged persistence of more than 5,000 men standing in line for hours outside the Municipal Building to file applications for jobs as city porter, paying from $960 to $1,200 a year, prompted Mayor La Guardia yesterday to criticize strongly the civil service laws which provide that the jobs be given in order of application, provided the applicants pass a physical examination and can read and write.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey directed the North American Company yesterday to surrender two promissory notes for a total of $4,000,000 and accept in exchange 2,666,667 shares of stock of the North American Light and Power Company, its debtor.

Through its president, Robert L. Johnson, the National Civil Service Reform League, with offices at 521 Fifth Avenue, addressed a letter yesterday to George H. Davis, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, suggesting that the chamber include among its specific recommendations for amendment of the Wagner act, recently announced, a provision for placing all employes of the National Labor Relations Board under civil service rules.

AMERICAN SHIPPING POLICY, by Paul Maxwell Zeis. (Princeton University Press, $3.) Subtitled: "Why Government Subsidy Has Failed to Produce a First-Rate Merchant Marine." BLACKBERRY WINTER, by Evelyn Hanna. (Dutton, $2.50.) A novel laid in Georgia between 1800 and 1870.

A special train will leave Vienna Eastern station at 1:30 tomorrow morning containing 760 Jews en route to Greece, who hope, despite their present lack of visas, eventually to reach Palestine. They will proceed through Hungary and Yugoslavia without leaving the train.

The youngsters have taken possession of the fourth annual national skeet tournament here. Six amateur championships have been decided, and, although three were open to adults, the only winner old enough to vote is Jack

County officials sought for an hour and a half at an inquest today to get "into the record" from the lips of William B. Mills, superintendent of county prisons, exactly what happened, and why, at the Holmesburg Prison during sixty hours of the week-end of Aug. 19-22, when

Two straight victories in the English Football League campaign which started Saturday put Everton and Leeds United in front following completion of the midweek schedule today.' Everton blanked Grimsby Town, 3-0, and Leeds United got a 2-0 decision over Birmingham.

Miss Ellen Wells Hooper daughter of Mrs. William T. Hooper of this place, will be married here to Paul Rutherford Jr. on Sept. 9. Miss Hooper will have as her matron of honor Mrs. Frank S. Rutherford of West Islip, L. I. Her sister, Miss Elizabeth D. Hooper, will be maid of honor, and the other attendants will be Mrs. James G. Batterson 4th and Miss Mary Elizabeth Bush.

A man and a youth were fatally burned here today when a steam valve burst in the New Jersey State Reformatory. A third man received burns on the face and body. The dead were Walter Barkalow, 41 years old, engineer at the reformatory, and Joseph Marse, 18, an inmate. Anthony Barberi. 20.

Premier Bela Imredi said today that Hungary's agreement for non-aggression pacts with the Little Entente States-Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia--would not be considered effective until Czechoslovakia solved her minority problems to Hungary's satisfaction. This decision, made at a Cabinet meeting last night,

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican contender for the world welterweight championship, will box Jimmy Garrison of St. Louis in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16. The contest was arranged yesterday by Bill Farnsworth, matchmaker of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

Representatives of 3,500 truck operators agreed today to sign contracts with the American Federation of Labor covering wages and working conditions for 1,000,000 drivers and helpers. The terms of the agreement were approved by A. F. of L. leaders who attended a meeting of owners and operators here.

William Clark Fonda, known as Skagway Bill, colorful adventurer who was the model for Alonzo Victor Lewis's 24-foot statue "The Sourdough," which towers above the grounds of the State Capitol at Olympia, died here this morning. He was 82 years old.

Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, said today he did not believe a European war likely. He reported this belief yesterday to President Roosevelt, but nevertheless advised the Chief Executive of the possible effect of such a war on United States business.
Deliberately violating several cardinal principles of store lay-out, Lord Taylor yesterday opened its newly designed third floor, where dresses, coats and suits, furs and millinery are sold.
Amity and optimism dominated the final session here today of the two-day regional conference of Democratic women from ten Northeastern States.

Scheduled to go into effect today, the new code of fair practice regulating the sale. of theatre tickets will not be applied until the first show of the 1938-39 season arrives, it was learned yesterday. While many brokers still resent the code, and none has yet signed
Stocks drifted narrowly and closed mixed in quiet trading; turnover, 461,160 shares. All groups of bonds irregularly lower in dull trading; transactions, $3,682,625.

Traffic on the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad in August was about the same as in July, J. M. Davis, president, said yesterday. Loadings of freight were below last year, but general freight shipments, which provide about 32 per cent of the company's revenue, and less-than-earlot shipments held up well. he added.

The two-family dwelling at 360 Webster Avenue, Jersey City Heights, N. J., has been sold by Ernest F. Oster to Walter C. E, Traboldt, who will occupy one of the apartments. The house stands on a plot 26 by 100 feet and contains eight rooms.
Eleven Colts and one filly were named today as final acceptors for the St. Leger Stalces next Wednesday at the Town Moor Course, Doncaster.

Charles L. Bowman, formerly vice president of Vitab Products, Inc., has been elected a vice president of the International Vitamin Corporation. Welsh Green, Inc., of Chicago, announced yesterday the segregation of their municipal investment business through the organization of a new corporation, Welsh, Davis Co. The parent firm will continue its general investment business.

Ellen Wilson McAdoo, daughter of Senator William Gibbs McAdoo and granddaughter of President Wilson, will be married to William A. Hinshaw, French horn player newly under contract to the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra.

Herbert Thornton Banks, 36 years old, an attorney of 51 Chambers Street, who pleaded guilty on July 12 to second-degree forgery in connection with the operation of a fraudulent "divorce mill" whereby seventeen couples were victimized, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer to three to ten years in Sing Sing Prison.
New York employes of the Federal Theatre Project who testified recently in Washington before the Dies House Committee investigating so-called un-American activities had their pay docked,

The Chinese on the Juichang front south of the Yangtze River during the last week's fighting have scored one of the most important successes against the Japanese since the Battle of Taierhchwang in Shantung, jubilant military leaders dedared today.

Large-scale the production of an ingenious type of autotruck that generates its own gas from wood picked up as it goes along has been ordered by Soviet authorities as the result of a successful test run for such vehicles that ended at Moscow yesterday.

Addressing the nation on the occasion of her fifty-eighth birthday in a broadcast relayed to the colonies this afternoon, Queen Wilhelmina expressed her gratitude to all those who during her forty-year reign have helped her accomplish her task.
Two new Jane Engel shops have been opened, one in Pittsburgh to be known as Rose Grastenfield, and the other in Wilmington to be known as Eleanor Wells, it was announced yesterday.
Pensioned On their own applications. To take effect 12 midnight. Aug. 31: PATROLMEN-Joseph C. Vance, 8th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 8. 1909.

America's touring swimming team cleaned up in the freestyle contests but lost the other three races in a six-event meet against a team of German stars today. The United States swimmers won the 100-meter and 200-meter free-style and the 400-meter freestyle relay, with the home forces capturing the back-stroke, breaststroke and medley relay.

Six employes in the office of City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio have been suspended because of the theft of $5,000 worth of 1-cent cigarette tax stamps from the office, James M. Kieran, one of the Mayor's secretaries, said yesterday at the Summer City Hall.

Displaying marked style and action, Flashing American, an upstanding chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Samuel Schiffer of Elberon, N. J., tonight was judged the best saddle gelding at the Empire State Horse Show. Dare Juan. the property of Mr. and Mrs. Mark H. Zettlemeyer of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was runnerup.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was at a slower pace, the volume being the smallest since May. The largest business for a day-1,479,690 shares--was recorded on Aug. 12, and the month's smallest396,620 shares-on Aug. 22. Sales for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, aggregated

Raymond Ayala, Venezuelan Consul General in New York, officiated yesterday at the placing of a wreath by a delegation of thirty Boy Scouts from Venezuela at the base of the statue of Simon Bolivar, South American liberator, on the west side of Central Park, near Eighty-third Street.

Speaking lengthily on offensive tactics, Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith of Villanova addressed more than 200 at the The Herald Tribune football coaching school yesterday at The Tribune auditorium. Carrying on where Dick Harlow of Harvard had left off the day before, Smith concentrated on the various plays that might work to advantage against a five-man line defense.

A contract for 30,000 workers in fiftyone silk and rayon dyeing plants in New Jersey and New York was signed here today. The two-year compact, which is effective tomorrow, provides for a forty-hour week, 66 cents an hour for men and 48 cents for women, which is the same as the old contract. However,
The Civil Aeronautics Authority has created a private flying unit, a new section designed to handle the problems and interests of airplane operators other than the scheduled airline companies.

The personal possessions of Andrew W. Mellon were appraised today at $37,000,000. Inventory of the estate filed by his executors listed $35,000,000 in personal property and $2,000,000 in real estate holdings.

Henry Gessner, formerly president of the Interstate Department Stores, Inc., has been appointed general manager of the National Silver Company, effective today, it was announced yesterday by Samuel E. Bernstein, president.
Leading British grain concerns are arranging a contract to take 400,000 tons of Rumanian wheat during the next eight or nine months at a cost of ??2,000,000, The Daily Telegraph reports.

St Nicholas Ave. 929-39. 103.7x144.9xirreg; Anita H. H. Morrell. referee, to Citizens Savings Bank: foreclosure (51). 6th Ave. 579, 23x75; Edward A. McShane. referee, to Virginia L. Abbott at Huntington, N. Y.; foreclosure ($15). 2d Ave. 623. 20.5x76; Corlam Realty Corp to Schulte Real Estate Co. 386 Broadway.
A client of Samuel Hurwitz has purchased from the estate of Helen Walter the two-story dwelling at 2,217 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, for cash.
The status of Maryland's bitter and tangled Democratic Senatorial primary contest between Senator Tydings and Representative David J. Lewis seemed in doubt tonight.

Joe Beggs scattered six Syracuse hits and blanked the Chiefs, 7 to 0, to give the Newark Bears an even break in their four-game series tonight. The Bears drove Johnny Gee from the mound in the sixth and continued their assault on George Miner, collecting thirteen hits, of which Rosar and May got three each.

BERENSON-At her home, in Brookline, Julia, widow of Albert Berenson, in her ninety-second year, mother of Bernard Berenson, Mrs. Herbert V. Abbott and Miss Elizabeth Berenson. Funeral services at the Eastman Funeral Home, 896 Beacon St., Boston, on Thursday, Sept, 1, at 11 A. M. Burial at East Boston.

Judge W. T. Harrison today filed an order denying a petition of Mrs. Emily Ringling for a review and amendment to the divorce decree granted her husband, the late John Ringling, in July, 1936. Mrs. Ringling's petition, filed last Summer, charged that the divorce was obtained by fraud and that she had some newly discovered evidence which she desired to present.

The Surplus Commodities Corporation announced today that it would buy 2,681,340 pounds of dry skim milk from the Dry Milk Committee Corporation of Chicago for $118,262. It said the milk represented sixtyseven carloads of surplus stocks of twelve manufacturing plants in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan,

Ordinarily it is not seemly for a newspaper to comment on the proceedings of a court while a trial is in progress. If there is an exception it would seem to be when the decorum of the proceedings themselves invites comment. The conduct of the trial of James J. Hines before Justice Pecora affords such an occasion.

Following is the text of the Japanese note, handed .to United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew tonight, replying to the American protest of Aug. 26 against the destruction of a Chinese-American airliner near Canton Aug. 24:

The $1,000,000 publicity campaign sponsored by the American motionpicture industry to make the general public more "motion-picture conscious" will be inaugurated today in nearly 16,000 threatres and through the medium of more than 2,000 daily newspapers.

Marshal Sir Edward Ellington, Inspector-General of the Royal Air Force, who recently visited Australia at the invitation of the government to report on the Australian air force, urges the need in a searching report of improving flying discipline, improved advanced training, better conditions of service for officers and closer cooperation with civil air lines.

Now that the frosting has been scraped from the international tuna angling matches, interest along the seaboard will be 'centered on the United States Atlantic tuna tournament, to be held off Ambrose Light, Shrewsbury Rocks or the Mud Hole next week.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Aug. 29: Willenbucher, Lt. Comdr. F. O.. the Oglala. to home, relieved of all active duty. about Oct. 28. Walker, Lt. G., Receiving Ship at San Francisco, to 12th Naval District, an Assistant District Communication Officer, in September.

Total assets on June 30 of this country's commercial banks carrying deposit insurance amounted to $54,357,658,000, which was $143,497,000 larger than the total on Dec. 31, 1937, but $527,040,000 below the figure for June 30, 1937, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today.

Four touchdowns, two of them on intercepted passes, were more than Washington's Redskins could match tonight, and the collegiate All-Stars swamped the professional football champions, 28 to 16, in the highest scoring splurge of the five-year-old series.

Miss Carol Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert MacClellan Barnes of 775 Park Avenue, and Edson Scott Eddy, also of New York, were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Lewis T. Reed. No formal announcement had been made of the engagement.

In his usual quiet and sober fashion Premier Edouard Daladier today laid before the army commission of the Chamber of Deputies precise facts and figures of the military preparedness not only of his own country but of all France's neighbors, with special reference to their supplies, sources of supply and power of production.

Douglas Fairbanks Sr., motion picture actor now in London, petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine a claimed deficiency of $87,283 in his 1930 income tax payment. Mr. Fairbanks reported a profit of $689,594 on the sale of bonds, on which he paid a 121/2 per cent capital gains tax.

A hearty welcome to th e Tricolor, which now joins the flags of the Unit ed States, of Great Britain and of Germany in successful survey flights in the North Atlantic. The huge and ponderous flying boat, Lieutenant de is Vaisseau Paris, now 8 years old, is no greyhound of the skies.

Secretary Wallace, in an order setting Sept. 12 as he date for hearing further evidence in the Kansas City stockyards case, refused today to disqualify himself and,. in explaining his action, apologized for "hasty" criticism of the Supreme Court in April for invalidating his 1933 order lowering. commission charges-at the stockyards.

The cardinal interest of the California primary is the large vote given to Sheridan Downey, candidate for Senator against Mr. McAdoo. Mr. Downey, an old worker for Dr. Townsend, became the champion of the socalled California Pension Plan, approprivately born in Hollywood.

Services for Mgr. Edward J. MeGolrick, pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, who died in Dublin ten days ago at the age of 81, will be held tomorrow and Saturday. The body will be brought here today on board the Manhattan. Hundreds of parishioners plan to escort the cortege from Union Avenue and Richardson Street, near McCarren Park, to the church at North Henry and Herbert Streets.

Boston's Bees cashed in on the wildness by Bill Lee and Clay Bryant in the ninth inning today, scoring three times to win, 6 to 4, after the Cubs had taken the lead with a thiee-run blast in the eighth.

In the familiar seaside surroundings of La Salle Military Academy, but with a new skipper at the helm, Manhattan's 1938 football ship was launched today as a squad of thirty-four candidates reported to Herbert M. Kopf, starting his first season as mentor of the Jasper eleven, for their initial workout.

Ken Keltner, rookie third sacker, led the, Indians to an 8-6 victory over the Athletics today. Keltner hit homers No. 23 and 24 in him 1938 record. His second round tripper of the day knotted the score at 6-all in the eighth inning.

Litigation brought by private power companies against the Tennessee Valley Authority caused a loss of $13,500,000 to the Authority and to electric consumers, J. Lawrence Fly, general counsel, told the Joint Congressional Committee investigating the Authority here today.

Miss Joyce Marguerite Hobart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Manchester Hobart of New York, and Lawrence Mason Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Bullard of Berlin, Mass., were married here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur T. Cort.

Trading in traefer meats was mostly only fair to slow In local markets yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were weak to lower; lamb sold lower; other classes were mostly steady with exception of steer cuts, which sold unevenly. Kosher beef opened fully steady, veal and calf steady to weak, lamb lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

It may be that the Yankees, with two of their vital cogs, Bill Dickey and Robert Red Rolfe, down in the pits for repairs, could not have done much better in any event. Then, again, it may have been that the world champions, feeling in a playful and venturesome mood.

The New England Council's index of business activity rose to 85.7 per cent of normal in July, as compared with 77.3 per cent in June, the council reported today. The figure compared with 104.6 in July, 1937.

Dr. Jerome T. Syverton, assistant professor of bacteriology at the University of Rochester, tonight received the Eli Lilly Co. prize of $1,000 and a medal, given annually to the American scientist under 31 who has made outstanding contributions to knowledge in the fields

Following a recovery of nearly $1 a bale from the low levels of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned easier again yesterday and ended with losses of 9 to 11 points. The absence of any active demand from trade or commission house interests, with scattered hedging pressure as gins in the cotton belt turn out more cotton each day, filled scale-buying limits and carried the October below 81/4 cents a pound.

Samuel Goldwyn today loaned Jon Hall to Alexander Korda to be starred in "Thief of Bagdad," made in 1924 as a silent with Douglas Fairbanks Sr. Hall will leave for London in October. The picture will be made in color and will co-feature Sabu.

Injunctions permanently restraining the partners in Williams, Bailey Benjamin of 1 Wall Street, overthe-counter dealers in securities, from acting as securities dealers in this State were signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church on the complaint of Attorney General Bennett.

President Arturo Alessandri submitted to Congress this afternoon his sixth and last annual budget estimate, which, like the previous one, shows a balanced total. The President admits -that world economic conditions probably will unfavorably affect Chile's revenues and stresses that if the budget balances it will be considered satisfactory in view of the great increase of expenses and a decrease in revenues.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against PHOEBE REALTY CORP., formerly known as Gertner Realty Corp., restaurant, 1,380 Broadway, by R. C. Wlliams Co., Inc., for $86; Jaburg Bros., Inc., $171; Elmhurst Cream Co., Inc., $1,060. JOSEPH POMERANTZ, doing business as J. Pomerantz, shoes, 118 W. Broadway, by Frank Mercantile Corp., for $2,415; Principal Shoe Co., Inc., $1,486; Charles H. Cobb Shoe Co., Inc., $1,400.

Three armed thugs held up the jewelry store of Rimler Horning, Inc., on the eleventh floor of 565 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-sixth Street, at noon yesterday and escaped Thomas with jewelry valued tentatively at $100,000.

Sheridan Downey, exponent of the $30-a-week proposal, has been nominated for the Senate by California Democrats over Senator McAdoo. [Page 1.] South Carolina hailed the victory of Senator Smith as setting the pace for the South in later primary "purge" battles. [Page 2.]

Letters that were identified by the swastika emblem as a signature, were sent to influential Jews in Sao Paulo demanding large sums of money, It has been established by policemen investigating the alleged racket.

The Board of Estimate, considering a request from the Department of Public Works for an.appropriation of $10,000 to finance an engineering survey of its sewage treatment program demanded by the PWA, was forced to mark time for an hour yesterday while James J.

Two Easterners and two Californians reached the semi-final round of the girls' national tennis tournament today. Top-seeded Miss Helen Bernhard, 16-year-old Wadleigh High School girl from New York City, advanced with a 6-2, 6-2 victory over Miss Dorothy Wightman of Boston, 16year-old daughter of the donor of the Wightman Cup.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the large reception given this afternoon by Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre Jr., Miss Cathleen Fox and Miss Virginia L. Alexandre at Breese-In, the home of Mrs. George Howard. A feature of the entertainment was a fashion show of the latest costumes for all occasions.

The opening this afternoon of a twoday series of international women's tennis exhibition matches on the Newport Casino courts, with, America, England, Australia and France participating, drew a large gallery of Summer colonists, their guests and others.

Mr. and Mrs. Roy T. Wallace gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Astor. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Harrison B. Coe, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Neville, Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. George Duncan Burke and Mr. and Mrs. Frederic C. van Duesen.

The first survey crossing of the North Atlantic by French aviators, to explore a route for Paris-New York air service, was completed here this afternoon, when the giant eight-year-old flying boat, Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris, landed off Pan American Airways base on Manhasset Bay at 3:18 P. M., Eastern daylight time.

State Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink yesterday sent out the first payment on an initial $10,000,000 cash dividend for the allowed claims of creditors of the National Surety Company, equivalent to 35 per cent on each allowed claim.

The engagement of Reginald Bryan Owen of New York, son of Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, former American Minister to Denmark, to wed Miss Louise Weber of Denver was announced by Miss Weber's parents here today.

ONCE again the rest of the world trembles in its boots while Germany comes to grave decisions. For the past few years it has always been Germany that makes them; petty States like Britain, France and Italy merely take them. The reason would seem to be that the German mentality has the rest of the world badly frightened.

The wife and daughters of the late William Fox made today a further compromise offer in the long litigation over the motion-picture man's $9,535,000 bankruptcy. Their latest offer was to open to creditors for examination the books of the All-Continent Corporation, a Fox family concern.

Dr. Leroy Hubbard, appointed head of the Warm Springs, Ga., Foundation by Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1926, died tonight at a sanitarium here. He was 81. A native of Malone, N. Y., Dr. Hubbard established and developed the foundation under the inspiration of President Roosevelt, retiring about a year ago.

A tale of judicial tampering, stuffed ballot boxes, sudden riches and murder, through which was interwoven an equally spectacular account of the making and wrecking of William Copeland Dodge's career as District Attorney, was unfolded yesterday at the trial of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines.
Electric power production eased about seasonally last week, and the adjusted index held to the previous week's level of 95.2. For the week ended Aug. 28, 1937, the figure was 108.4.

The attempt to settle the railroad wage dispute all through mediation collapsed today. Dr. William M. Leiserson, chairman of the national mediation board, announced tonight that joint meetings between representatives of the railroad managements and the unions had failed to reach any result.
The Cardinals had to battle all the way today to achieve a twin victory over the Phillies. They won the opener in the tenth inning, 2 to 1, and took the nightcap. 7 to 6.

William Phil lips, United States Ambassador, called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, Minister of Foreign Affairs, last evening to learn the Italian Government's views on the European situation with particular reference to the Czech-German crisis.

Work has been started on a fourstory addition to the Beth Abraham Home for Incurables at Allerton Avenue and Bronx Park East in the Bronx, and plans have been drawn for the erection also of a five-story nurses' home.

The Spanish Government said its troops smashed ahead on the Estremadura front today, completing occupation of the important hills of Benquerencia despite stiffened Insurgent resistance in Southwest Spain.

Jim Crowley, head coach of football at Fordham, underwent a minor operation- at Union Hospital yesterday for the removal of half the nail of the left large toe. The operation was necessitated because the ingrown nail had infected the toe. He is expected back at Fordham tomorrow.

Dick Ward of the San Diego Padres pitched thirteen and two-thirds hitless innings but missed no-hit baseball glory because it took his teammates sixteen innings to score. Ward bested Ray Prim of Los Angeles, Pacific Coast League leader, 1 to 0, yesterday.

Government both Federal and State, should bend every effort to help solve the agricultural problem, Governor Lehman asserted tonight at the annual farm dinner given by Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Post-Standard, at the Onondaga Golf and Country Club.

Thousands of tons of cabbages will start moving out of Ontario County tomorrow. Plans for sale of the heavy crop to the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation at prices ranging from $5 to $6 a ton-double the local market price-were completed at a meeting of 500 growers here last night.

Harold Smith, American representative on the jury considering films shown at the world cinema exhibit here, walked out of the Doges' Palace today in protest against award of the Mussolini Cup to a German documentary film on the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin.

Wheat prices declined around 11/2 cents a bushel in the early trading today with holders of September contracts selling freely, fearing heavy tenders of yellow hard wheat on future contracts. Cash interests absorbed

Three men charged with conspiracy and embezzlement in the handling of ticket sales of the WPA Circus, a unit of the Federal Theatre Project, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Federal Court, Brooklyn. They were held in bail of $500 each for trial on Sept. 8.
Great Britain drew back perceptibly today from the stiff condemnatory attitude toward Germany that had caused such anger in Berlin in the past few days.

In a prolonged drought every raindrop is of value, and so, after days without one hopeful indication, a number of minor developments have imparted a faint touch of cautious optimism to Czechoslovak political feeling today,

After further examination and on the request of the American consulate. the Spanish police authorities decided today to release four seamen of the American freighter Wisconsin, who were arrested a week ago on spy charges.

The decisive victory of Senator Smith of South Carolina, one of three Senate Democrats on the Administration "purge list," and the rout of Senator McAdoo, who had President Roosevelt's support in California, were interpreted here today as indicating resentment of the voters against Presidential interference in local affairs.

The White Sox,,behind an impressive four-hit pitching performance by Johnny Whitehead, trounced the Senators, 7 to 0, today in the second of a three-game series. Whitehead retired the first six men befone Sammy West beat out a slow roller to Luke Appling at short and then retired twelve Senators in order before allowing another hit.

The Public Contracts Board of the Labor Department today recommended that a minimum wage of 45 cents, with a maximum work week of forty hours, be put in effect at plants of the ammunition and related products industry where such plants have government orders.

A colorful display of the latest fire equipment, with a fire boat and stationary engine sending sprays of water through the air in the beams of a searchlight, was staged last night by the Fire Department at the parking field of Riis Park on the Rockaways.

Mrs. Morgan Belmont is at the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Seth Bliss Hunt, who returned yesterday on the Conte di Savoia, will be at the Drake for the Autumn and Winter. Miss Emma Romeyn has returned from a North Cape cruise to her home at 14 Sutton Place South.

Justice and Mrs. Timothy A. Leary of this place and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Leary, to Vernon Murphy of New York. The prospective bride's father is justice of the Supreme Court, First Judicial District, City of New York.

As further returns from yesterday's Democratic primary continued to increase the size of Senator Smith's victory over the New Deal "purge" South Carolinians indulged today a belief that again they might set the pace for the South.

Cash dividend payments by the companies in the Standard Oil group for the third quarter of this year will approximate $25,427,000, a decline of 20.5 per cent from the $31,984,000 in the similar period last year, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.,

Houghton Mifflin reports that a total of 35,000 was reached in the prepubulcation printing orders for ". . . And Tell of Time," Laura Krey's story of reconstruction days in Texas, and a new printing of 10,000 was ordered two days after publication.

The steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines is due today from the Channel ports. Among the 1,113 passengers are Judge John J. Fitzgerald of Kings County and Mrs. Fitzgerald, Judge James L. Coke, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Honolulu, and Mrs. Coke; Walter L. Rice, Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Feis, Francis J. MacNamara, Bolard More, United States vice consul at Barcelona;

Apparently because of recent financial reverses, Henry W. Freeman, 55 years old, an attorney, shot himself dead early yesterday morning in the bathroom of his apartment on the ninth floor of 155 East Forty-seventh Street.

According to figures released here today, German crude oil production reached an all-time monthly high in July with a total of 54,500 tons. The figure for the average monthly production in 1937, which, seemingly for purposes of comparison, includes Austria, was 40,500 tons.

Representative Bruce Barton, speaking today before 800 members of the Federation of Republican Women of Nassau County at the home of Representative and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon here, told how he thought the Republican party might march on to victory.

Leading department stores here are planning to remain open on Armistice Day, according to reports in well-informed quarters here yesterdays While the State Legislature has declared Nov. 11 a legal holiday, Armistice Day has become increasingly important as one of the major selling days in the late Fall retail calendar.

A man who said he was Lawrence Harding, 28 years old, of the Paramount Hotel, White Plains, -was taken to Bellevue Hospital last night after he had been found wandering around Central Park with no shoes or socks on his feet.

Despite the civil war and a future which outsiders consider is so uncertain for the Loyalists, the Spanish Government is preparing to open a pavilion at the New York World's Fair next April and intends to keep it going throughout the exposition's entire six months, it was learned today.

Final arrangements for the beatification of Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini were started yesterday when a Catholic delegation of nine, headed by Mgr. Salvatore Natucci of Rome, Procurator-General of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, arrived here on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.

Houses on Park Avenue on the East Side, and on Riverside Drive and West End Avenue on the West Side, added many names to their tenant rosters in lists of new leases released yesterday by broker's and renting agents.

45th St, 357 W, Harglor Realty Corp to Frank C. J. Becker, 66 Reid Ave, Rockeville Center, L. I.; prior mtg $15,000; purchase money mtg due Sept 1, 1943, 6 per cent, $4,000. 49th St, 249 W, Byron Hotel. Inc. to City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee; purchase money mtg due May 1, 1945, 4 per cent, $41,000.

Cardinal Villeneuve of Quebec was among the 1,566 passengers who arrived from Mediterranean ports yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. He had been in Italy and had spent ten days in Rome and at Vatican City. He had an audience with the Pope, who appeared to be in excellent health, he said.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Fleming of this place of the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Marion R. Fleming, to William Glen Bartlett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartlett of Elizabeth.

While the Robinson-Patman Act has now been in effect for 'more than two years, "many of its important provisions still remain shrouded in uncertainty" and it "has not fulfilled the hopes of those who saw in it the means of restoring the supremacy of the independent merchant,"

Emmet O. Swanson, Minneapolis dentist, set the pace today for 2,000 riflemen seeking the coveted President's Cup. Swanson scored 99 out of 100 over the 200 and 600 yard ranges. The final stage will be fired over the 1,000-yard range tomorrow.

Turpentine quiet, 221/4c; no sales; receipts. 1,065 barrels: shipments. 70 barrels; stock, 46,413 barrels. Rosin firm; no sales; receipts, 2,154; no shipments: stock. 231.118. Quote: B. $3.50: D. $3.85; E, F, G. H, I. K, $4.10; M, $4.15; N, $5; WG, $5.20; VW', X, $6;15.

Mrs. John J. Meenan of the Nassau Country Club today carded an 89 to take low gross honors in the Women's Long Island Golf Association weekly one-day tournament at the Creek Club. The tournament was originally scheduled for July 21, but was rained out and postponed until today.

The Summer season of al fresco operas given at Jones Beach and Randalls Island by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company will come to a close this week-end. Tomorrow night Rossini's "Barber of Seville" will be given at Jones Beach. with Lucrezia Sarria.

Premier Benito Mussolini this evening had a onehour conversation with Mgr. Borgongini Duca, the Papal Nuncio. It was the first meeting between the head of the. Italian Government and the Nuncio in years.

Led by the defending champion, Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, N. Y., the favorites advanced another round today in the Mason-Dixon women's golf tournament. Miss Guilfoil had an easy time defeating Mrs. M. C. Geiger of Charleston, W. Va., who was ill from indigestion, 9 and 8. Mrs. Jean Solomon of Memphis, Tenn.,
Charles Schwimbersky, real estate man, former Fire Department captain and prominent Mason, died on Tuesday in his home at 45-43 149th Street, Flushing, Queens, after a long illness. His age was 68.

The Manila Gas Corporation, Manila, P. I., an operating utility, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of $830,000 of 6 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1945, for the account of the Islands Gas and Electric Company.

The marriage of Miss Agnes Durant Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bryant Halsey of 803 Fifth Avenue, New York, to James Carey Thomas Flexner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Simon Flexner of 530 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York, took place here this morning at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

Of the victory of Senator Smith in South Carolina one thing can be said with certainty. It demonstrates that the President's influence is not in itself enough to decide the issue of a Congressional primary even in the solidest tier of the Solid South.

Angered by the possibility of losing the Eastern Steamship Line's service St. George's freeholders are circulating a petition asking the Governor to dissolve Parliament to permit a referendum on the bill barring ship hotels from the colony's two harbors, Hamilton and St. George's. The bill is awaiting crown assent.

The New York Stock Exchange has under consideration a proposal to permit its member firms to pay customers' men and other employes who "produce" business on a commission basis, instead of the present straight salary.

By MICHAEL F. SHEA St. Nicholas Ave, 929-39. 6-story apartment, 103.7x144.9xirreg; Citizens Savings Bank against Widsam Realty Corp, due, $231,828; to plaintiff for S1,000. By RALPH LONG 27th St. 118-20 WV, 12-story loft and store, 37.6x98.9; Harlem Savings Bank against Twenty-seventh Management. Inc, due, S134.312: to plaintiff for $2.000.
TRANSFERS IN THE BRONX

Activity featured the bed steers and yearlings market today with prices generally 10 to 15 cents higher Numerous loads strictly choice and prime steers sold above $12, and the top moved up to a new high for the season at $13.15. The United States Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs wree also higher mostly 10 to 20 cents and Spring lambs were firm.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Aug. 30: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Beach, W. A., Adjutant General's Dept., five days leave, Sept. 6. Strong, R. W., Cav., General Staff Corps, ten days leave, Sept. 1. O'Kelliher, V. J., General Staff Corps, seven days leave, about Aug. 30.

The reorganization plan for the New York Curb Exchange, undertaken by a special committee on organization and administration, was received yesterday at a special meeting of the board of governors of the Exchange. Later copies were mailed to all members of the institution for their information.

Increased business today placed Bethlehem Steel Corporation's huge strip-steel mill here on a five-day work week for the first time in seven months. The mill has been operating only two or three days a week.

As soon as Lou Gehrig can be caught off base, this observer Will ask him for the real lowdown on the recent international tuna-catching championship conducted on the dusty waters adjacent to Liverpool, Nova Scotia. Buster Lou is a real expert on deep-sea angling and all its curves.

Greater formality in daytime apparel, the almost, complete absence of "little" dresses, and the appearance of colors in larger proportion than heretofore marked the collections of Paris fashion importations which arrived on the Normandie on. Monday, and which were viewed yesterday by a reporter for THE TIMES.

Senator B. K. Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, said today the defeat of Senatorial candidates favored by President Roosevelt in the California and South Carolina primary elections "shows very clearly the people do not want rubber stamps in Congress."
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Miss Dorothea F. Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Dixon of this place, will be married on Sept. 10 in St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Roselle, to Albert W. Metz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Metz of Elizabeth. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Johnson A. Springsted of Oneida, N. Y., who will be assisted by the Rev. Dr. Clarence S. Wood of St. Luke's.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 1 unless specified: At San Pedro: Argonne, Cincinnati. At San Diego: Brazos, Aug. 29; Wasmuth, Zane. New York to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Dunlap, Fanning.

They certainly are harvesting the big tuna off the New Jersey Coast, and if only the fish remain there for another week there is every possibility that the boys in the Atlantic Coast derby will have their hands full and their lines tight most of the time.

President Roosevelt will speak here as well as in Denton on Monday when he "invades" the Eastern Shore to campaign for the defeat of Senator Tydings, prominent on the Presidential "purge" list, and for the election in his stead of Representative David M. Lewis, New Dealer.
