Dr. Otto Ender, former Auatrian Chancellor, has been transferred to the Dachau concentration camp, his family learned today. Dr. Ender was arrested immediately after Germany annexed Austria last March 13. Later he was transferred to Innsbruck.

Certain fundamentals in the European equation have been clarified during these critical days. The concentration on the contest in Central Europe to the exclusion of the wars actually raging in China and Spain, where the armies seem to be waiting to see what is going to happen in Czechoslovakia, reveals that those fronts are in reality secondary fronts.
Settlement of 231 industrial disputes out of 274 accepted for mediation in the last twelve months was announced by the New York State Mediation Board in its first annual report made public yesterday.

After his demand for an arrest in the case of a Brooklyn physician beaten and robbed Aug. 10 had failed to bring results, Mayor La Guardia ordered License Commissioner Paul Moss yesterday to hold a hearing on revoking the pawnbrokers license of Henry D. Goodstein, who took the doctor's watch in pawn for $7.

First Lt. Lester H. Smith, FA-Res., 18 Beach Pl., Maplewood, N. J., 308th Field Artillery, is ordered to active duty Sept. 18, at Headquarters Newark Reserve District, Postoffice Building, East Orange, N. J., for training. Date of rank: Aug. 21, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status Oct. 1.
Chicago's Great Lakes champion eight-meter yacht crew successfully defended its title in a three-day regatta here and tonight accepted the Commodore Otto Barthel Trophy for another year.

The South Penn Oil Company yesterday announced a reduction of 12 cents a barrel in the price of Pennsylvania grades of crude oil. This is the sixth price-cut within a year and brings prices to the westt level since 1933.

Miss Peggy Seyburn and Edward McIlvaine, who will be married on Sept. 10 in the Emanuel Church at Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass., were the guests of honor last night at a dinner given by Miss Seyburn's aunt, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, in the Palm Garden of Larue.

On Wednesday it was announced by the National Mediation Board that its proposal to settle the railway wage dispute by arbitration had been rejected by the unions. Yesterday those unions ordered a "strike ballot" of their membership, in case the wage reduction proposed by the railways were to become effective.

Announcement was made today by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation that it would purchase 10,000,000 pounds of butter from the Dairy Products Marketing Association of Chicago, a producer cooperative organization.

Michael Lerner of New york, big game hunter and contributor to the American Museum of Natural History, arrived here today to prepare for a new expedition into the Rockies along the Alberta-British Columbia border.

Payrolls of the Westinghouse Electric Manufacturing Company took 38.9 cents out of every dollar of income in 1937, and shareholders received 7.4 cents, a breakdown of distribution of the company's revenues sent to stockholders reveals.

The State Motor Vehicle Department studied today issuance of permanent metal operators' licenses that were expected to save Connecticut $25,000 annually. Commissioner Michael A. Connor said the tags would eliminate many operations now necessary and facilitate distribution in rush periods.

A net profit of $901,526 was reported yesterday by the Diamond Match Company and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on June 30. The result was after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The Chicago Bears packed too much power for the College All-Stars and scored a 26-to-14 victory in the Shrine charity game before 20,000 at Brown Field tonight. Byron (Whizzer) White of the AllStars stole the show, however, with a dazzling display of fancy stepping.

Supporters of Senator Walter F. George in his resistance to the New Deal "purge" were greatly encouraged today as practically final returns from South Carolina's Democratic primary disclosed an overwhelming victory for Senator Ellison D. Smith, who also had been marked for elimination.
Fall residential moving activity has begun to be felt. among the van owners and furniture warehouse firms, and many of them apparently are much busier than they were at this time last year.
Representative John J. O'Connor, who is on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, lost out twice yesterday in drawings for positions on the primary ballots at the office of the Board of Elections.

The International Longshoremen's Association, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, will demand a forty-hour week for its men in Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports in a new contract to be effective on Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president.

Garment Machinery Co, store and basement in 79 5th Ave; William C. Spring, buyer, in 229 4th Ave; Saulle Longhi, custom tailor, in 160 5th Ave; Hamilton Shirt Co, Inc, through Williams Co, Inc, floor in 40 W 27th St; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, brokers.

Pounding the offerings of Jake Mooty for thirteen hits, and profiting by three errors and as many walks, the Jersey City Giants scored a 9-to-4 victory over the Chiefs in the opener of a four-game series tonight.
Colonel and Mrs. Charles A Lindbergh, flying toward Prague from Rumania on a European aerial jaunt, were held up by fog today and made an unscheduled landing at' this Moravian city.

" I said to schoolmaster, 'Tell me. boss, what's the plural of rhinoceros?'" Dr. Julian S. Huxley is having fun. In a "leader" in The Times of London the plural of "rhinoceros" was set down as "rhinoceri." Dr. Huxley shuddered at the "barbarism." He took down the Q-R volume of the New Oxford Dictionary.

New York District Council 9 of the Painters Union, representing twelve A. F. L. local unions with a membership of 16,000, has endorsed the candidacy of James H. Fay, New Deal candidate for the House of Representatives from the Sixteenth Congressional District, according to an announcement yesterday.

The morning newspaper La Prensa, official organ of the Republican party headed by former President Miguel Mariano Gomez, was closed late this afternoon by the military authorities, who took possession of the plant.
Secretary Ickes announced today award of a contract to the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company of Denver for construction of the three largest electric power generators in the world.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller heard testimony yesterday that more than 100 forged signatures on the American Labor party petition of State Senator Leon A. Fischel, Democrat, had been obtained at a sand-lot ball game. Senator Fischel, who told Justice Miller that he wanted to withdraw the petition,

Romeo C. Martell, who held both the war-time Croix de Guerre and the peace-time Carnegie Medal, died yesterday at the United States Naval Hospital in Philadelphia after three months' illness, at the age of 44. He was a produce salesman here.

Further details of how Communists behave in battle-of especial interest in view of the possibility of the Soviet Union's being involved if war breaks out in Europe-were told today in a letter from a political leader who participated in the fighting at Changkufeng.

While the diamond industry suffered its first setback during the first half of this year since the Summer of 1932, improvement began in May and is still in force, Sydney H. Ball, of the mining engineering firm of Rogers, Mayer Ball, said yesterday at the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

The majority of city people whose diets are now below par could be better fed at no extra cost if they selected their food wisely, according to Dr. Hazel K. Stiebeling, senior food economist of the Bureau of Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture, in an article prepared fort discussion at a session of the Seventh International Management Congress to be held in Washington from Sept. 19 to 23.
For the first time since 1932, when the Naval Scouting Force was transferred to the Pacific, a fighting unit of the navy is to be assigned to duty in the Atlantic.

Miss. Charlotte W. Diffenderffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hungerford Diffenderffer of Wynnewood, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Joseph Gray Duncan 3d, son of Mrs. Joseph C. Duncan Jr. of Ardmore.
Dr. Frank L. Waite, an eye specialist for forty-five years, died today at Hartford Hospital, where he had been ill for more than a month. He was 72 years old.

Digging into the voluminous "Mynatt report," which criticized the land acquisition department of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the joint Congressional committee heard a statement today from John I. Snyder, land chief, that F. J. Carr, controller for the authority when the report was prepared, had "repudiated" the report.
A. A. Berle Jr., who resigned last week as Assistant Secretary of State, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a member of the New York City Housing Authority for a five-year, non-salaried term.
Mrs. John Eyre Sloane of Llewellyn Park, daughter of the late Thomas A. Edison, became a candidate today for the Republican Congressional nomination in the Eleventh District.

Reorganization of the production, marketing and research set-up in the power alcohol industry, and election of John Orr Young, cofounder of Young Rubicam, Inc., New York, as president of the Atchison Agrol Company, Atchison, Kan., was announced yesterday by William W. Buffum Sr., general manager of the Chemical Foundation, Inc.

Governor Lehman, speaking before 5,000 persons in Empire Court at the New York State Fair today, called upon the State to lead the nation in framing a protection against future economic depression and to make sure "that nothing we can do will be left undone to prevent or minimize future economic disaster."

Collective bargaining is a successful integral part of British industrial relations because of almost universal acceptance and support of it by employers and labor alike, in the opinion of a group of experts who reported to President Roosevelt today the results of a factual survey made this Summer at his request in Great Britain.

His defiance of the New York County grand-jury and General Sessions Judge William Allen in openly refusing to produce documentary evidence demanded in a "John Doe" investigation by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's office brought a ten-day jail term and a $100 fine yesterday to George M. Spector, a middle-aged insurance broker, who lives at 785 West End Avenue.

The belief is widely held that if drunken drivers could be kept off the roads the problem of hit-and-run accidents would be carried a long way toward solution. Perhaps so. No doubt the trend toward heavier penalties for drunken driving will help. But there is no reason to assume that the hit-andrun driver is always drunk.
With the vacation goods season virtually over, drug stores will use stationery, school supplies, housewares and toilet articles as promotion items this month, according to drug supply houses.

The eight-story garage and showroom at 247 to 259 West Fifty-fourth Street has been leased by the Bank for Savings to clients of Stang Boxer, attorneys. It contains 125,000 square feet and will be used as a public garage and automobile showroom.

Five yachts were added yesterday to the list for the Stamford Yacht Club's race out around Vineyard lightship and back, which will get under way at 6 P. M. today. The 232-mile contest is open to both racing and cruising craft from 30 to 75 feet long overall and offers a variety in the way of tide figuring, and often wind guessing.
Captain Samuel A'Court Ashe died here Wednesday night of injuries suffered in a fall at his home three weeks ago. He would have been 98 years old on Sept. 13.

An increase in foreign buying yesterday absorbed hedging and liquidating pressure on the Cotton Exchange and held fluctuations within narrow limits. The market closed unchanged to a point lower than on Wednesday.

Dropping fashion magazines entirely and concentrating in newspaper rotogravure at the request of its retail accounts, the American Lady Corset Company, Canton, Ohio, will launch an expanded campaign on Sept. 11, according to the Grey Advertising Agency, which handles the account.

The delays, frauds and inefficiency that marked the working of proportional representation in the Bronx last election can be avoided hereafter by using voting machines, reducing the number of candidates, and paying ballot clerks a flat sum instead of by the day, R. Lawrence Siegel, special assistant attorney general, reported in his study of P. R., which was made public yesterday.
New fair trade contracts were Issued yesterday by Schenley Distributors, Inc., and Schenley Import Corporation, and prices were lowered on a few products.

A bit puzzled by a penalty of $800 which she was compelled to pay before her party of four could travel from Honolulu to San Francisco on a Japanese liner, Kirsten Flagstad, soprano of the Metropolitan, arrived by train yesterday from California.

The Loyalist Government has offered through the British commission for the exchange of prisoners to suspend the execution of all pending death sentences for crimes committed before today, if the Rebels will do likewise, it was announced today.

Vernon C. Brown, president of the Sperry Hutchinson Company, a trading stamp firm with offices at 114 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday morning at his home, 375 Park Avenue, after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

Seymour Knox's Aurora Riders, with young Skiddy Von Stade playing with them for the first time, sprang something of a surprise today at Mitchel Field when they held a strong Jaguar quartet to a 9-to-9 tie.

A proposed new city charter for Philadelphia, under which a City Council of eleven members would be elected by proportional representation and a city manager would become administrative head of the municipality, Was made public today by a commission which spent fifteen months at its task.
Roger Don Rae of Los Angeles, a commercial transport pilot on vacation, qualified two planes today for the Thompson Trophy race Monday. He took up a third plane but failed to qualify it.

Added significance was given to the national open polo championship which starts Sunday at the Meadow Brook Club by the announcement yesterday of the formation of a defense committee by the United States Polo Association.

An estimated 2,000 truck drivers and helpers were on strike tonight, with the operations of almost all major trucking concerns here affected. Police escorts were provided during the day to truckers to permit their continued operation.
Announcement Was made here today of the appointment of MacManus, John Adams, Inc., as the advertising agency for Nunn Bush Shoe Company of Milwaukee. James R. Adams will be the account executive.

A 2-year-old boy and a 19-year-old girl, residents at the Woman's Shelter of the Travelers Aid Society, 630 East Sixth Street, were sought vain.ly by the police last night after they had been missing since 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

Governor Blanton Winship has forwarded to Washington for the Interior Department to study the recently passed bill to create a water resources authority, sponsored by Secretary Harold L. Ickes and known locally as the little TVA.

At a conference at Berchtesgaden yesterday of high Nazi officials and Konrad Henlein, Sudeten German leader, Chancellor Hitler rejected a Czech offer of a three-month truce, it is reported, but sent Henlein back to Prague with counter-proposals.

The training ship Empire State of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy arrived yesterday morning at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, the home base of the academy, after a three-month training cruise to Bermuda and Europa.

Lieut. Col. Alvan C. Sandeford, 48, intelligence officer of the Fifth Corps Area, died tonight of injuries incurred earlier in the day when the automobile which he was driving overturned south of Harrisburg.

James A. barley, tional chairman, called on Maine voters tonight to vote for Democratic candidates "close to the Administration in Washington" on Sept. 12 and thus "get in step with the rest of the country."

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on July 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $8,543,329.

Flotations of securities in August were larger than July's, principally because of a sharp increase in public utility bond financing. Bond offerings of $237,852,000, representing forty-one issues, were the second largest total for a month since March, 1937,

Miss Linda Marion Wyckoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rapelye Wyckoff of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Houston Hutchinson Wasson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Washington Wasson of Nashville, Tenn., which will take place on,
Many dinner parties will be given tomorrow night before the circus barn dance to be held on the estate here of General Howard S. Borden for the benefit of the Oceanic Free Library.

Surgeons removed seventeen stitches today from the great left arm of Carl Hubbell, pitcher of the Giants, who underwent an operation here eleven days ago. The lanky southpaw said the pain had left his arm and that he would remain in the hospital another week.

Charges that the Waterfront Employers Association, composed of all the shipowners on the Pacific Coast, is planning a "lockout" of C. I. 0. longshoremen on Sept. 30, when the present contract expires, were made in an interview today by Harry R. Bridges, C. I. O. regional director for the West Coast and president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's they Union.

Senator Vandenberg, addressing a Western Michigan conference of Rotary Clubs tonight, called for a revision of the Wagner Labor Relations Act, which he charged was "one of the major contributing factors to the industrial uncertainties which precipitated and prolonged the new depression."

Warren H. Keller, an accountant for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, testified today before the Securities and Exchange Commission that the arrears on the corporation's preferred stock and debenture interest totaled about $11,900,000 at the end of 1937. The commission is considering the question of simplifying the company under. the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utilities Holding Company Act.

Formal notice of the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization for the Chicago Great Western Railroad by the committee for the company's first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due il 1959, headed by Harry C. Hagerty, treasurer of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, is to be sent to bondholders within a few days, it was announced yesterday.

The War Department issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 31: COLONEL McIntire, A., F. A., 5 days' extension of leave. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Colladay, E. B., C.A.C., General Staff Corps, 4 days' leave, Sept. 3.

Captain Angus Walters, skipper of the champion racing schooner Bluenose of Lunenburg, is worried about his October races with Gloucester's Gertrude L. Thepaud. The worries are caused by the pair of Diesel engines in the Bluenose.
This weeks figure for engineering construction lettings is $52,219,000, a rise of 25 per cent above the $41,625,000 reported in 1937, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The general level of wholesale prices rose during the week ended on Aug. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 77.8, compared with 77.4 on Aug. 20, and 86.5 on Aug. 28, 1937.

Although the report of local member banks of the Federal Reserve System for this week showed a further large rise in the total of loans and investments of the banks, it conveyed a disappointing impression by reason of the decline of $1,000,000 shown in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans.

Sergeant Edward V. Seeser, United States Marine Corps, of Lynn, Mass., had close competition in winning 'the President's Match today while shooting against a field of 1,971 riflemen. Seeser had a score of 146 out of a possible 150, with ten v's in the center ring.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial on "American Recovery" in THE TIMES, in which you discuss, on the basis of the League of Nations compilations of production and productivity indices, the relation between recovery and economic policy, illustrates the difficulty with which scientific method is applied in the analysis of economic and political problems.

Subject to the usual changes of mind, the first week of Broadway's 1938-39 season now shapes up like this: Wednesday, Sept. 14 - "Come Across," at the Playhouse (with Richard Taber and David Orrick lately added to the cast).

Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada totaled $12,793,000 yesterday, a decrease of $1,546,000 in the week, it was shown today in the bank's statement for the week ended yesterday. Chartered bank deposits declined to $202,250,000 from $202,374,000.

Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken, for many years active in society and philanthropic causes, died yesterday in her apartment in the Hotel Ambassador of a heart ailment from which she had been critically ill for the last two weeks. She was 58 years old.

Easing of the tension in Europe yesterday resulted in a moderate degree of stabilization in rates quoted here on war-risk insurance for American property abroad, to the extent that "general" rates were quoted at no change during the day, in contrast with hourly fluctuations earlier i the week.
Religious and other private schools of German Austria will be closed Sept. 19, it was announced today, and the State and the National Socialist party will take over the education of youth.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Mullins of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Kirkwood Mullins, to Arthur Vreeland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Vreeland, also of Ridgewood.

General orders" at Holmesburg Prison during the last nine years called for heat to be turned on in the radiators of the isolation block as "part of the treatment" for unruly prisoners confined there, it was stated today at the inquest into the "heat exhaustion" deaths of four convicts.

The New York Central Railroad received today authorization from the Interstate Commerce Commission to borrow $5,000,000 from the National City Bank of New York, the loan to be guaranteed as to payment of principal and interest by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

William Blackmer, 10 years old, of 2,007 Gildersleeve Avenue, the Bronx, is no swimmer, but he is a quick thinker. When his brother, John, 7, fell into Pugsley Creek yesterday afternoon he rushed to the rescue.

The New York Roverettes scored their fourth straight victory last night by beating the Connecticut Yankees of New Haven, 5 to 3, in the feature game of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden. In the opener, a Metropolitan League test, the Trevoc Girls topped the Brooklyn Rangers, 3-2. A crowd of 7,500 was present.

The destructive Insurgent air raid on Alicante on May 25 in which 272 persons were killed and 224 wounded was "a deliberate attack on the civilian area of a city," according to a report issued tonight by the special British commission of investigation.
Frank B. Carbone, an official of the Colonial Sand and Gravel Company, has bought from the Savings Bank of Richmond Hill the onefamily house at 83-65 116th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens.

Miss Helen Bernhard of New York and Miss Margaret Jessee of Sacramento, Calif., will meet tomorrow for the girls' national tennis title. Top-seeded Miss Bernhard defeated Miss Joan Bigler, 18, of Pomona, Calif., 6-4, 6-2, while Miss. Jessee beat Miss Marguerita Madden of Boston, 6-4, 6-3.

The Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn near the busy intersection of Nostrand and Lafayette Avenues was thrown into an uproar for about half an hour yesterday noon when 300 members of the Workers Alliance became involved in a fight with thirty policemen under Deputy Inspector Charles Mulligan. When the melee outside a home relief office ended, sixteen rioters were under arrest, four of them charged with felonious assault.

Tens of thousands of young conscripts--World War "armistice babies" born in 1918--set out today for frontier training grounds, starting a movement that in four days will swell France's standing army temporarily to 825,000 men.

Rayon loom activity for the week ended Aug. 27 reflected very little change in operations from the week before on most items, the exception being in the lining taffetas, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Rayon Weavers Association.

Sales of small Jersey City residential properties featured the New Jersey realty deals announced yesterday. George Behringer bought, through the C. B. Snyder Realty Company, broker, from the Franklin National Bank, the two-family house at 277 Thirteenth Street.

Promises of party harmony succeeded campaign squabbling today as the last returns cemented the victory of Senator Smith in Tuesday's Democratic primary. Governor Johnston, who had the endorsement of President Roosevelt, sent a good-will message to Mr. Smith, veteran of thirty years in the Senate. In a statement, Mr.

Donald O'Melveny has returned to the investment banking field, joining Griffith-Wagenseller Durst, it was announced today. The firm name has been changed to O'Melveny-Wagenseller Durst and Mr. O'Melveny has been elected president.

Frank L. Nagle, 77 years old, of Newtonville, a former commander of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, revealed today that he and Mrs. Beside B. Van Tassel, 70, also of Newtonville, were married on Aug. 5 in what he described as an "elopement."
A soundproof gambling room on the-second floor of the exclusive Surfside Bath Club, near the west end of Long Beach, was raided this afternoon by District Attorney Edward J. Neary of Nassau County.
The New York Curb Exchange has stricken from unlisted trading the fifteen-year sinking fund 5 per cent gold bonds due in 1942 of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of California.

The Osservatore Romano quoted Pope Pius today as deploring the education of children "toward irreverence and violence." The Vatican City newspaper said the Pope had made the remarks to a group of Italian Catholic Action child welfare workers at Castel Gandolfo, his Summer palace.

Nearly 5,000 dangerous weapons seized by the police, seven and onehalf tons of mangled slot machines and 700 pounds of slugs found in turnstiles of the city's Independent Subway System were dumped into Long Island Sound off Huntington Harbor yesterday under the joint supervision of the Police Department and the Board of Transportation.

Having dropped "Mr. Average Man" from their schedule because of the cancellation of Eddie Cantor's contract, Fox has announced a new musical, "Thanks for Everything," to feature Adolphe Menjou, Jack Haley and Arleen Whelan.

United States exports and imports declined in July from the same month a year ago, but exports for the first seven months of this year were slightly ahead of the total from January to July of 1937, the Deapartment of Commerce reported today.

Avenging his loss in the Hambletonian, in which he had been installed the favorite, Long Key, owned by E. J. Merckle of Columbus, Ohio, and driven by Ben White, today won the $7,500 Governor's Stake, outstanding event of the six-day Grand Circuit meeting at the New York State Fair.

New Yorkers began a mass migration yesterday to what they considered greener fields for the three-day Labor Day week-end, while visitors from New England, the Midwest and - near-by Eastern points started moving in to enjoy the city many residents had deserted.

On the same stretch of turf at the Germantown Cricket Club where the Davis Cup was lost to France in 1927, members of the Australian and American tennis teams worked out this afternoon in preparation for their meeting here Saturday, Sunday and Monday in the first challenge round match to be staged in this country in the eleven years intervening.

The government of France has made nineteen awards to American architects whose work was shown in a photographic exhibition of American architecture in the United States Pavilion at the Paris International Exposition, according to announcement yesterday by the American Institute of Architects.

Adolf Winter, 49 years old, of 179-67 137th Avenue, Springfield Gardens, Queens, member of the firm of Emmelin Winter, 58 West Forty-eighth Street, Manhattan, wigmaker to the theatrical profession, was killed by a Long Island Railroad train late Wednesday night.

Many members of the Summer colony attended the annual concert by the Red Croft Glee Club, comprising debutantes of forthcoming seasons, organized and directed by Miss Doris Francklyn, which took place tonight at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng.
Polo players from out of town are being entertained in the Westbury and Wheatley Hills homes of the Long Island players in the national open championship series which will begin on Sunday.

Mayor La Guardia denied yesterday that Major William J. Walsh, secretary of the Finance Department, had received a leave of absence to manage the campaign of James H. Fay, candidate for Congress from the Sixteenth New York District.

The Rev. F. Eppling Reinartz, for the last eight years pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church, East Liverpool, Ohio, has been appointed to the new office of "promotional editor" of the United Lutheran Church in America.

W. S. Faron, for three years advertising and publicity director of the Ross Federal Service, Inc., and the Ross Federal Research Corporation, has resigned to become advertising manager of the Glass Container Association of America, Inc., is was announced yesterday.

Nearly two thousand painters, members of District Council 18 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A. F. of L. affiliate, went on strike in Brooklyn yesterday following failure of negotiations between the union and the Associated Painting Employers of Brooklyn.

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor gave its full support today to the Dies committee and charged that critics of that committee's work were animated by a fear that it would ultimately expose the foreign sources of subversive movements in this country.

M. Donald Grant has been admitted as a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Fahnestock Co., according to an announcement. He began his financial career with the Bank of Montreal in Canada and was associated with the bank four years.
The value of persistency was shown here today by young Jack Gerlin, towsled - haired former Hempstead High School star.

TO THE SECRETARY, OF LABOR: We have the honor to send you herewith our report on Industrial Relations in Great Britain, in accordance with the letter of the President of June 16, 1938. The Appendix containing the discussion of the statutory law will be submitted shortly.

D. S. Starring of the Pequot Yacht Club captured the second race in the series for the East Coast Atlantic Class championship today off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Starring, sailing his Scamp, crossed the finish line ahead of Solera, skippered by G. S. Franklin of Cold Spring Harbor.

Governor Moore was informed today by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation that in four weeks it has bought 722 carloads of New Jersey potatoes at a cost of $151,556 to relieve the depressed market.

Sales of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded purchases by 38,316 shares in the week ended Aug. 27, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This was against the price trend which, on the basis of THE NEW YORK TIMES averages for fifty stocks, showed a net advance of 1.06 points.

Joseph Eli Eron, president of the Eron Preparatory School, teacher and an Americanizer of the foreign-born of the East Side, died yesterday morning of a heart ailment in his home at 55 East Tenth Street. He was 69 years old.

The Cubs gained a tie for second place in the National League with Cincinnati today by capitalizing on Johnny Lanning's wildness and beating the Bees, 4 to 2. Carl Reynolds's double and Bill Jurges's single, combined with three walks by Lanning, gave the Cubs three runs in the second inning.
The Department of Agriculture reported today that wheat bought under the government's export subsidy program has totaled 2,257,472 bushels to date. Purchases yesterday amounted to 1,530,000 bushels.
Foreign Minister Julio Tobar Donoso confirms a report of Ecuador's desire that President Roosevelt settle her boundary dispute with Peru, said the newspaper, Telegrafo today.

Army's football squad of forty-eight players went into action today for the first time this Fall. Captain William H. (Bill) Wood, new head coach, was in charge of the workout, which featured conditioning drills and group work in starting, passing and kicking on The Plains gridiron.
A large Long Island City plant formerly used for the manufacture of automobiles will be turned into an airplane manufacturing center as the result of an important realty deal consummated yesterday.

President Juan Demostenes Arosemena intimated that relations with the United States could be more cordial if a new Canal treaty were approved by the United States Senate in a message he delivered today at the opening of the regular session of the National Assembly.

Arnold Greenberg, who was judge of the Criminal Court of Duval County, Fla., for twenty-five years, died last night at Bellevue Hospital. He had been under treatment for heart disease and developed pneumonia.

The first annual Camera Show opened today in theWoodhouse Gallery at Guild Hall, to continue for one week. Tea was served to several hundred persons. Assisting at the tea table were Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, Mrs. Albert Herter, Mrs. N. N. Tiffany, Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey, Mrs. Clifford C. Edwards and Mrs. I. Y. Halsey.
Flood waters caused twelve deaths in two sections of the Quebec district today. Thirty-eight persons were injured and material damage was estimated at close to one million dollars.

Surprised by the defeat of the champion Washington Redskins by the college All-Stars in Chicago last night, the New York Football Giants today held a snappy threehour signal drill. Practice was frequently interrupted by Coach Steve Owen, who demanded harder blocking and better execution of plays.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation has booked more than 12,000 tons of heavy steel in the last week, including 3,500 tons for hangars at Fort Lewis, Wash.; 3,100 tons for a dam and power house at Pensacola, Fla.:

Plans for a fight between Petey Sarron of Birmingham, former featherweight champion, and Baby Manuel of Cuba were canceled today after Sarron was ordered to drop the bout by Major Harvey Miller, chairman of the District of Columbia Athletic Commission.

The sudden, swift revival of the "Townsend" movement in this country as evidenced by its victories in primaries scattered literally from Maine to California, is in itself a sufficiently impressive and disturbing fact.

Making his first start since his brilliant no-hit performance last Saturday, Monte Pearson stepped out on the mound at the Stadium yesterday feeling reasonably assured that nothing succeeds like success. He had just enjoyed four solid days of rest, he had won his last ten games and as the Yankees had blown a game the previous afternoon there was little likelihood that they would blow another.

Tad Wieman of Princeton addressed the group attending The Herald Tribune football coaching school at The Tribune auditorium yesterday, his discussion featuring offensive line play. The Tiger mentor told of the various offensive line assignments, which might offset the shifting defense.

A large rise in the total of loans and investments, reflecting chiefly the market's preparations for the forthcoming Treasury financing, and a disappointing, setback in commercial loans were disclosed in the weekly statement as of Wednesday of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Aug. 30, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of history and civics in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Henry Necarsulmer, New York lawyer, died Wednesday night of a heart ailment at Metis Beach, Quebec, after a two-day illness. A founder and member of the legal firm of Meighan Necarsulmer, 120 Broadway, Mr. Necarsulmer lived at 225 West Eighty-sixth Street. His age was 65.

Mrs. Dorothea Draper Blagden of 129 East Thirty-sixth Street, New York, and Woodbury, L. I., widow of Linzee Blagden and daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. William H. Draper, was married here this afternoon to Henry James of 455 East Fifty-first, Street, New York.

The alleged impersonation by two brothers of their elder brother, who was dead, in applying for civil service labor jobs brought Pietro Pollo DeLucia, 21 years old, of 1,594 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, into magistrate's court yesterday on a misdemeanor charge, and may mean trouble later for Joseph N. DeLucia, 27, of 698 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, a sweeper in the Sanitation Departmnt.

J. Donald Budge, the defending champion, and Miss Helen H. Jacobs, a former titleholder, were designated to head their respective divisions as the' draw for the national amateur tennis singles championships, which get under way next Thursday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, was completed yesterday at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

Alice and Hugo Rutherfurd of Baltusrol today recaptured the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association brothersister championship when they scored an 80 over the Yountakah Country Club course. The Rutherfurds won the title in 1935 at White Beeches, dethroning Maureen and Sinclair Orcutt.

A "dark horse" team-Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., and Ben Hogan of White Plains, N. Y.-shot spectacular golf on the Hershey Country Club course today to lead at the end of the first round in the Hershey round-robin best-ball tourney.

Mr. and Mrs. Johannes A. L. van den Bosch of 17 East Eighty-fourth Street and Huoge Vuursche, Baarn, The Netherlands, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Frederique van den Bosch, to John Murray Begg of this city, son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Begg of Guilford, Conn.
Chinese military commanders reported today that Japanese forces had been defeated on Yangtze Valley fronts in the bloodiest fighting of recent months.

By remaining models of consistency and showing themselves to be able successors of other youngsters from their club, Robert Gordon, skipper; Howland Hayes and Roderick McNeil of the Pequot Yacht Club are the new national junior sailing champions and Long Island Sound has the Sears Cup for another year.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, the young lawyer who hired out to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's crime machine and became the "affectionate" friend of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines, put in a second bizarre performance at the Hines trial yesterday, confessing his sins under the cross-examination of Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel.

In this period of watchful waiting for the next turn of events in the European political situation, the stock market continues without buying power or selling pressure of any consequence. Those traders and investors desiring to sell were slightly more numerous yesterday than those interested in purchasing, and share prices drifted lower.

Trading was fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Veal and calf were weak and some in-between sales lower; pork loins were steady to slightly lower, other classes of traefer meats were mostly unchanged. Thursday being an off kosher day, the small amount of business was confined mostly to lamb at higher prices.

Reports by 141 Class I railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that they incurred a net loss of $15,954,225 in June, against a net income of $18,359,775 in June, 1937. The statement follows:

Charges by Representative J. P. Thomas of New Jersey that the pay of New York employes of the Federal Theatre Project, who testified before the Dies committee here, had been docked were denounced today by Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, director of the project, as "inaccurate and misleading."

Secretary Morgenthau said today that, since the matter of tax legislation ties in closely with the new budget, it was unlikely that the administration's tax recommendations would be determined before December.

Close friends of President Roosevelt denied today that he had ever countenanced a proposal that Chief Justice Hughes or any other member of the Supreme Court be asked to resign as a part of a plan to compromise the Court Reorganization Bill fight last year, as charged in a speech at Hyattsville last night by Senator Tydings of Maryland.

President Lazaro Cardenas today refused the demands of the United States for arbitration of payments for seized land in a sharp speech opening the Mexican Congress. The United States demands were made in a note on Aug. 25.
The total of liquor concerns in the United States decreased 3,000 during the fiscal year ended June 30, the Treasury reported today, principally in the ranks of retail dealers in hard liquors.

Information contests now sweeping this fair land are amusing and often instructive, but not always as practical as they might be. For the moment we recall no quiz in print or on the radio which wanted to know, among other things, the comparative value of the nation's wheat crop and potato crop.

A dependable market on fed steers and yearlings wound up today at firm to slightly higher prices. Top again was $13.15, but the quality was not as good as that displayed on Wednesday, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Not many steers passed $12.

John A. Barben, vice president of the Bank of Montclair, and Robert Roy White, 7, of Verona were injured fatally last night when an automobile overturned after a tire blowout on the Lincoln Highway near here.
Cecil Isbell of Purdue today was voted the most valuable player of the collegiate All-Stars in their 28-to-16 victory over the Washington Redskins last night.

Air Minister Guy Lachambre announced tonight a reorganization of the French air force in an effort to stop the epidemic of crashes, which has killed twenty-two military fliers since Aug. 22. An investigator reported that the latest crash, in which Lieut.

Frank E. Lenane, assistant PWA Administrator for Massachusetts, died today at the age of 55 in the Chelsea Soldiers' Home after a long illness. Before his appointment by Secretary Ickes in 1934, he was assistant PWA engineer for the State.

The Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, Detroit, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $34,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1963 and $8,000,000 of 4 per cent serial notes due on Aug. 1, 1939 to 1948. The proceeds are to be used chiefly for refinancing.

MANHATTAN Estate, more than $10,000. To Jane Carlisle Allen, widow, executrix, 11 E. 68th St., household, personal effects and life estate in real property and in residue; Frank Douglas Allen, 3,422 81st St., Jackson Heights, L. I., and William Lathrop Allen, Malone, N. Y., brothers, $5,000 each; Laura C., Fredericka L. and Mary L. Allen. daughters. executrices, all of 11 E. 68th St., equal remainders in real property and in residue on termination of trust.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against SIMION DAVIS, INC., furs, 258 W. 30th St., by Silberman Fur Corp., for upward of $250; Isaan Habinsky, upward of $250: Thorer Hollender, Inc., upward of $250. Petitions Filed-By JOHN A. FAIELLA, physician. 27 Ludlow St., Yonkers-Liabilities, 5167,649; assets. $14.370. The East River Savings Bank is listed as a judgment creditor for $114,450.
Business in the Pittsburgh district recorded a further gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Fifty-four prize water fowl on the estate of George Washington Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company, were dead tonight and fifty-six were ill because tar being applied to Harriman Road overflowed into a brook and-drained into a duck pond on the estate.

In Philadelphia a Federal grand jury has indicted twenty-six persons for conspiracy to commit offenses against the United States Government by violation of the Emergency Relief Appropriation Acts of 1935 and 1936. The alleged offenses were committed in Schuylkill County in 1936 and 1937.

The National Power and Light Company will redeem the remaining outstanding 5 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Tennessee Public Service Company, aggregating approximately $1,050,000, at 104 and accrued interest, it was learned yesterday.

Silas Wilder Howland, noted lawyer, member of the firm of Guggenheim Brothers, 120 Broadway, mining industrialists, and a leading amateur chess player, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rye, N. Y. Mr. Howland was 59 years old.

Increased selling from the East weakened the California municipal bond market today as prices sank approximately 2 points in second-day reaction to yesterday's decision of the State Supreme Court approving the inclusion of the Single Tax and the "$30-every Thursday" pension plan. on the ballot for November.

Thornton Lee scored his tenth victory of the season today as the White Sox slammed three Washington hurlers for eighteen hits to sweep the three-game series, 11 to 6. Al Simmons made his nineteenth home run of the season into the left-field bleachers to feature a belated eighth-inning rally by the Senators and broke the all-time record for home runs hit by a Washington player.

Corporate Leaders of America, Inc., New York City, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 2,500 trust fund certificates, Series A, to be offered at $1,200 each for estimated cash proceeds of $3,000,000.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 75.3 from 73.5. The figure was 82.9 for the week ended Aug. 28, 1937. Shipments also were higher, but orders decreased, according to the special reports wired to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations.
The Rightist newspaper Journal today published an interview with Chancellor Hitler quoting him as saying that France and Germany have more reasons for reciprocal admiration than for hate.

Headed by Coach Clair Bee, a squad of nine Long Island University basketball players sailed yesterday aboard the S. S. Borinquen of the Puerto Rico Line bound for San Juan to participate there on Sept. 9 in ceremonies which will

Joseph F. McCoy of this city, an associate of the late Thomas A. Edison and the eldest employee in point of service of the Thomas A. Edison Industries, Inc., of West Orange, died last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth.

A digest of yesterday's testimony by J. Richard (Dixie) Davis follows: Davis took the stand again when the Hines trial reopened at 10:20 A. M. yesterday and was crossexamined by Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense attorney.

Charles Morgan's first play "The Flashing Stream" opened tonight in the Lyric Treatre. Godfrey Tearle, who also produced the play, and Margaret Rawlings portray two mathematicians among a group of naval specialists working on an isolated island to perfect an aerial torpedo.

Bob Feller gained his thirteenth triumph of the season today by defeating the Athletics, 11 to 4, in the final of a three-game series which the Indians swept from the Mackmen. The Cleveland youngster fanned eight batsmen.

The crack athletes of the West Harlem unit of the Juvenile Aid Bureau carried off nearly all the honors yesterday afternoon at the Police Athletic League's third annual city-wide track and field meet at Macombs Dam Park, the Bronx.
Weakness in foreign markets, a slow export demand and uncertainty as to the effect of the domestic and Canadian subsidy programs dominated sentiment today in the wheat markets.

Miss Elizabeth Linton, daughter of M. Albert Linton, president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company and Mrs. Linton of Moorestown, N. J., was married at the Friends Meeting House in Moorestown this afternoon to Philip H. Jacob, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jacob of West Chester, Pa.
Miss Christina Holmquist, daughter of Mrs. Gustave S. Holmquist of New Hope, Pa., and of the late Mr. Holmquist, was married this afternoon to Clark Johnson, also of Newhope, son of Mrs. Carl Becker.

Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland and Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Parcel post for Denmark, Finland, Poland and Sweden. South America, West Indies, Etc. COTTICA (Royal Netherlands), Inagua Sept. 6, Port au Prince Sept. 7, Curacao Sept. 10, Porto Cabello Sept. 11, La Guayra Sept. 12, Guanta Sept. 13, Porto Sucre Sept. 13, Pampatar Sept. 14, Carupano Sept. 14.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, served notice yesterday upon the Committee for Industrial Organization, of which his union is the second largest affiliate, that it would not tolerate any undue influence in the affairs of the automobile workers' organization and that the issues that have led to the expulsion of four officers of the union could not be compromised.

Mauve decade colors, Winter pastels and "king's red" are suggested as featured fashion dress colors for late September and early October wear, by the color coordination committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which will issue a new color card for retail stores this week, it was announced yesterday. The new card,

Describing milk consumers throughout the metropolitan area as "the victims" of price manipulations for the benefit of "greedy" milk distributors, Dr. Caroline Whitney, chairman of the Milk Consumers Protective Committee, which embraces nearly 100 consumers' groups, reported yesterday that a preliminary survey of consumer organizations indicated they were "up in arms" against the advance in milk prices which went into effect yesterday.

Bonds called for redemption In August before maturity aggregated S45,071,000, the smallest total in three months and the smallest for an August since 1934, when $32,690,000 was retired. Last month's retirements compared with $201,958,000 in July and $129,661,000 in August, 1937.

Miss Dorothy Mortimer Kelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Palmer Kelley of Millington, N. J., was married to Robert Heard Hale of this city yesterday afternoon in Trinity Church by the Rev. Donald H. Morse.

Edward H. Smith, former Supervisor of the town of Lewisboro, died here last night at his home, at the age of 67. Mr. Smith, born in this village, was postmaster for thirty-four years and later was Town Clerk. He operated general stores in South Salem and Cross River.

J. Cullen Ganey, Federal attorney, said today that the trials of State Senator Joseph P. Dando and more than a score of others indicted yesterday for alleged WPA irregularities probably would begin Dec. 12. The court docket for the September term is overcrowded.

Mrs. Orin B. Mitcham, who has been passing the Summer in Quebec, has returned to the Beekman. Mr. and Mrs. Stuart G. Gibboney, who are at the Biltmore Forest Country Club, Biltmore, N. C., will return here on Sept. 15 and will go to their new home at 891 Park Avenue.

With the trading volume still small, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved lower yesterday with pronounced weakness among the railroad loans. Total sales amounted to $3,795,000 against $3,682,625 on Wednesday.
About 100 employes of the General Leather Products Company at 30 Wilsey Street returned to work today following a strike of four weeks, it was announced by officials of the plant.
The German Labor Front served notice today on all Jewish boarding house owners, "advising" them to liquidate their business by Sept. 30. Berlin Jews were thrown into consternation by this measure.

Plans for groups of small homes in Brooklyn and Queens formed the bulk of new projects for which plans were submitted yesterday by architects. Architects also filed for numerous alteration jobs in Manhattan and for a few small dwellings in the Bronx.
During the week ended Aug. 31 member bank reserve balances increased $23,000,000. Additions to member

Harold smith and Neville Kerney, American and British delegates to the International Moving Picture Festival here, protested yesterday when the international committee of awards assigned first prize to both the German film "Olympia" and the Italian "Luciano Serra Pilota."

The Oxford University Press has received from Harold Fields the completed manuscript of his book "The Refugee Situation in the United States." Mr. Fields has been a student of the immigration question for twenty-five years and is an authority in the field of migrations of populations.

Taxation of companies and profits was proposed today under amendments introduced in the New Zealand House of Representatives to the Government's Social Security Bill which received second reading yesterday.

Investors were active yesterday in two sections of Manhattan. They acquired housing properties on the lower East Side and in Harlem. The Felbe Realty Corporation, Dr. Felix Widder, president, purchased from Partman Associates, Inc., the five-story tenement at 110 Suffolk Street. Assessed at $20.000.
A crack field of 216 gunners fired at the first 100 birds in the 250-target all-gauge championship event of the national skeet tourney today with thirteen marking up perfect scores of 100 each.
Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. entertained with a dinner at Terra Mare tonight and among those giving luncheons yesterday were Mrs. George Tyson, Mrs. W. Starr Miller and Mrs. John R. Bryden.

Joey Fontana, 128, Bensonhurst, outpointed Al Ragone, 126, Greenwich Village, in the main bout of eight rounds last night at the Fort Hamilton Arena. Part of the proceeds of the show will go to the St. Anselm's Cadet Corps.

Still reeling from their disastrous Western campaign, the Dodgers suffered two blows under the lights tonight. First a deputy sheriff slapped an attachment on the gate receipts-or such of them as were available-and a bit later the Dayton Ducks knocked over the Grimes crew in an exhibition game, 8-4.

Michael Russo, sculptor and Communist leader and several times candidate for Mayor on that ticket, is being sued by Yale University for $200 for non-payment of bills incurred as a university art student, it was disclosed today when Deputy Sheriff Morris M. Hochheiser served the papers on him at Communist headquarters. The suit is returnable to the Common Pleas Court.
The Inland Steel Company placed in operation today a 44-inch continuous strip mill. The rated capacity of the mill is 45,000 tons a month, or 540,000 tons annually.

Paul Vineyard scored a double at the Flemington Fair harness races today with two sons of Abbedale, owned by T. L. Custin of Holicong, Pa. He drove the bay colt Prontodale to win the 3-year-old pace in 2:09, and the chestnut horse Dalehurst to take the handicap pace in 2:10.

The Giants bade farewell to the hostile West today with unconcealed pleasure. Their pennant chances are nearing the vanishing point and they now occupy their lowest position of the year in the National League standing.
A new variety program, much of which is musical, got under way yesterday at the Loew's State Theatre with Ed Sullivan, columnist, presiding in the role of master of ceremonies.

TO those who have thought the chief virtue of quicksand its ability to swallow the fleeing villain of fiction, the statement that it has been made to serve successfully as the foundation for a large New York building comes unexpectedly even from so experienced a builder as Paul Starrett.
Mrs. Margaret Elizabeth Grant, widow of the Rev. Frederick W. Grant, died today at her home here at the age of 100. She was born in Seneca Province of Ontario and moved here fifty-eight years ago.
The steamship Connecticut, an oil tanker built for The Texas Company, was launched today at the Bethlehem Ship Building Yards at Sparrows Point.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Newman Harris Co. head a syndicate which will offer today $6,000,000 of Louisiana State Board of Education 4 3/4 per cent bonds, 1938, due serially on Aug. 1, 1942 to 1966. The bonds will be offered at prices to yield 3.25 to 4.50 percent.

A record world wheat crop for 1938 was forecast today by the International Institute of Agriculture on the basis of latest estimates. Production in the Northern Hemisphere was estimated as "the extremely high figure" of 105,000,000 metric tons

Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark gained her first double of the flat racing season when Fred Hopkins saddled her Entracte and Trovadora to win at Aqueduct the former capturing the featured Glenwater purse yesterday. The Glenwater was a six-furlong dash with two of the six starters carrying Mrs. Clark's colors. The other was Lovely Night.

Miss Edith A. Winship, school textbook editor for the World Book Company, died in Flower Hospital yesterday after a month's illness at the age of 61. She lived at the Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street.

The Cardinals made it four out of five over the Phillies today by taking the series final, 6 to 5, and giving Curt Davis his eleventh victory of the season. Misplays on the part of Jimmy Wilson's team again figured in the outcome. In a double-header yesterday the Cards scored the winning runs with the help of errors.

A record enrollment of 50,000 students, an increase of 20 per cent over last year, is indicated for the vocational department of the New York City school system this Fall, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, reported yesterday.

Barcelona residents saw a Loyalist fighting plane tonight attack five Rebel bombers that had been caught in the city's searchlights, The Loyalist plane went for the bombers at the same level. In day fighting it is always a case of diving to attack, but tonight, while thousands roared in the streets, a stream of white tracer bullets could be seen on a level with the bombers.

Six under par for the day, Frank Moore of Quaker Ridge successfully entrenched himself tonight in defense of his Westchester open golf title by leading the field at the end of the initial 36 holes of play by five strokes.
The stock markets here were quiet and generally irregular today as most sections reflected hesitation over developments in the European political situation.

National Brands Stores, Inc., has introduced a fourth coffee brand to be known as Del Haven. Distribution will be through the organization's 418 member jobbers serving 24,000 retail stores from coast to coast, according to Carl F. Kraatz, advertising director.

According to his secretaries, the President, when asked what public comment, if any, he wished to make on the renomination of Senator Smith in South Carolina, remarked: "It is often said that it takes a long, long time to bring the past up to the present."

Retired Lieutenant Michael A. Lukas, formerly a member of Engine Co. 215, residing at 181 Russell St., Brooklyn, died Aug. 30. The funeral will take place from 87 Herbert St., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, Sept. 2. "Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

Fredie Miller, former world featherweight champion from Cincinnati, outpointed Johnny King, British Empire bantamweight titleholder, in a ten-round bout tonight. A crowd of 5,000 booed the decision. Each fighter weighed 127 pounds.
A total of 246,642 persons witnessed the thirty-day race meet at the Saratoga track, official records of the United States Bureau of Internal Revenue revealed today.

A stormy conference of the Sudeten German political committee ended today with the issuance of a communique saying cryptically that necessary resolutions had been adopted and that the attitude of the delegation that had been negotiating with Viscount Runciman, British mediator, and the government had been unanimously approved.

As a special meeting of the board of directors of- Electrical Research Products, Inc., yesterday, T. Kennedy Stevenson, -who has been associated with the Western Electric Company twenty-four years, was elected president and a director of Electrical Research Products, which is controlled by Western Electric.

The defending champion, Miss Virginia Guilfoil of Syracuse, settled down to a steady pace today to reach the semi-final round of the women's Mason-Dixon golf tournament by beating Pittsburgh's Miss Mary Kuhn, 5 and 4.

The difference is that this Miller doesn't sing at his work. The umpires wouldn't stand for it. But maybe Bing goes about with a song in his heart. Nobody yet has caught him without a smile on his face and a story on his lips. For all that, Edmund John Miller, called Bing, now a coach with the Detroit Tigers, was a good ball player in his day and it was a long day.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and THE NEW YORK TIMES, as trustee for the One Hundred Neediest Cases fund, are eventually to divide equally the estate of David J. Straus, according to his will, filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court, Brooklyn.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert granted yesterday a request by Johanna Hofmann, alleged member of a German spy- ring, for permission to examine Dr. Ignatz Griebl, another accused member of the ring, in Germany.

BELOW, ELIZABETH (Dec. 22, 1937). Gross assets, $23,744; net, $22,707. To grandchildren, Eleanor L. and Frederick W. DeChutkowski, .$500 each; daughter, Sadie DeChutkowski, jewelry and one-half of residuary estate; son, Henry W. Below, one-half of residuary estate.
Many of the new tenancies announced yesterday by brokers were in buildings to the east and west of Central Park. Several large suites on Park Avenue appeared in the lists.

Complete jurisdiction over fire prevention and fire extinguishment at the New York World's Fair was lodged in a "World's Fair Fire Battalion" by Mayor La Guardia after a conference with Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

Japan, clearing away, wreckage left by a seventy-five-mile-an-hour typhoon early today, counted tonight at least thirty-four dead, scores of persons injured or missing and property damage estimated as high as 100,000,000 yen [$28,000,000 at current exchange].

Bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation for the week ended on Wednesday declined 21.0 per cent to a total of $4,159,437,000 from $5,264,282,000 in the corresponding week of 1937, according to Dun Bradstreet.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, arriving today from Rotterdam and way ports, has among her passengers Major Gen. Robert Courtney Davis,, George Boochever, Dr. and Mrs. Emil Lengyel, Dr. David Emrich Weglein.

Southern Railway Company's East Tennessee reorganization mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds due Sept. 1, 1938, and Mobile Ohio collateral 4 per cent gold bonds due Sept. 1, 1938, which have matured, and City of Bergen thirty-year external sinking-fund 5 per cent gold bonds due in 1960, which have been called for redemption, have been suspended from Exchange dealings.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation defended today its rescue in 1932 of the Central Bank and Trust Company here, known as the Dawes bank, in a brief filed with the United States Court of Appeals.

Stuart A. Stephenson of this place, Professor of Mathematics and Engineering at Rutgers University, died in his home here today. He was 60 years old. Professor Stephenson came to Rutgers as an instructor in mathematics and graphics in 1910.

Strong diplomatic pressure is being brought to bear on Poland by three great powers simultaneously France, Great Britain and Germany are pressing her to state definitely whether she will stand on the side of the democracies or the Fascist powers in the event of a German attack on Czechoslovakia.

President Roosevelt directed steps today which are intended to bring the country's electric power distribution facilities to a state of greater efficiency as a vital part of the national defense program.
President Roosevelt praised the service of Jewish war veterans in a message sent today to the annual national encampment of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, which opens here tomorrow.
The Municipal Civil Service Commission received 2,357 more applications yesterday for jobs as porters in city buildings, bringing the total to 7,449 in two days. The jobs pay from $960 to $1,200.

Mayor La Guardia, it was disclosed yesterday, has won his protracted fight to bring the operation of major airlines into New York City at North Beach Airport, now under construction as a large-scale land-and-sea airport with WPA aid at a total cost of more than $22,000,000.

Officials of insurance and trust companies will act as a committee to supervise operation of the Lehigh Valley Railroad's plan to defer payment of interest and principal of bonds, according to a statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In a day that brought little encouraging news to residents of this country the government press found some consolation in the unusually warm language used by the new Italian Minister on presenting his credentials today.

With Jimmy Foxx's thirty-ninth homer signalizing a return to hitting form, the Red Sox took the odd game of the three-game series from the Browns today, 5 to 3. Lefty Fritz Ostermueller pitched steadily, giving the Browns only seven hits.

Elifaz Escobar, a Nationalist, was found guilty of first degree murder by a Ponce jury today in the killing of Colonel Luis Irizarry on July 25 when an attempt was made to assassinate Governor Blanton Winship. He will be sentenced tomorrow to life imprisonment, the maximum penalty.

A trophy donated by the New York World's Fair will be awarded to the outstanding collegiate player in the third annual Tribune Fresh Air Fund game between the Eastern College All-Stars and the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night, according to an announcement yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Jane Elizabeth Osmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Fassett Osmer of South Park, Franklin, Pa., to- John Thornton MacDonald Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. MacDonald, of Greenwich, Conn., took place here this afternoon in the Church of the Resurrection.

Ralph E. Ammon, director of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, sent out 3,300 invitations to Wisconsin dairy plants to attend a State-wide conference in Marshfield on Sept. 15 to discuss ways of cooperating in an interstate program for promoting a wider market for dairy products.

James Hamilton Lewis, Democratic senior Senator from Illinois, does not expect President Roosevelt to be elected to a third term. "By the time the President is finishing his present term new issues, largely foreign and international,

Finishing with a par-shattering 3 on the home green, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, former women's Westchester champion, carded an 80 today to take the low gross prize in the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day handicap tourney at the Wykagyl Country Club.

John P. O'Keefe has resigned as manager of the appraisal department of Joseph P. Day, Inc., and will organize his own company. Allen Mason Thomas, formerly with E. R. Munn Co., has been named assistant vice .president of Eadie Hart, Inc.
Twenty-seven of the thirty-one players who will introduce jai alai at the Hippodrome Thursday night, including Estanislao Piston, world champion,
The Italian Cabinet today approved a decree ordering all Jews who have taken up residence in Italy since the World War to leave within the next six months.

The touring Australian cricketers today obtained some measure of revenge for the innings defeat inflicted by England in the final test match last week by trouncing an England eleven at Blackpool by ten wickets. The home players were dismissed for 132 and 99, the Antipodeans replying with 175 and 58 for no wickets.

The Newark Bears clinched the International League pennant tonight by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, to 4, while Syracuse was losing. The Orioles held the pace of the Bears in hitting, with nine safeties, but Stine kept the Flock's blows well spaced in all except the ninth inning. May excelled for the Bears, getting a homer and two singles and driving in four runs.

Samuel von Kessler, 38 years old, who since July, 1936, had been sought as a fugitive by the Federal Bureau of Identification, the Securities and Exchange Commission and State Attorney General Bennett's office here was brought back to this city last night.
The Department of Agriculture, attempting to stimulate grain exports, sought today a reduction in freight rates on Wheat moving from Central and Western producing areas to seaboard shipping points.

Jason-Murray Press, Inc, 5,500 sq ft In 150 Varick St; Rochelle Undergarment Co, floor in 49 W 24th St; Ille Electric Corp, floor in 121 E 24th St; David Gorn, furs, additional space in 135-41 W 29th St: Lenin Mitchell, advertising, in 11 E 45th St; Peoples Press, Inc, additional space in 1,133 Broadway; Melrose Curtain Co, Inc; Hosiery Distributors of America, in 220 5th Ave; Spear Co, Inc, brokers.

President Roosevelt expressed his preference at his press conference today for liberal Republicans as against conservative members of his own party and gave notice that he would continue to campaign for the election of liberals in national and State politics, regardless of their party affiliations.

A clash between striking and non-striking Negro employes of the Spring Products Company, 47-39 Austel Place, Long Island City, shortly after 5 P. M. yesterday resuited in a riot on the eastbound platform of the Independent Subway at Queens Plaza.

New bond offerings for the week ended yesterday amounted- to $24,364,000, compared with. the revised figure of $70,762,000 for the previous period. For the corresponding week of 1937 the aggregate was $4,785,000.

The police search for the woman who "kidnapped" 3-year-old Bobby Daly from the Women's Shelter at 630 East Sixth Street Thursday, ended yesterday when the two were discovered at another settlement house at 184 Eldridge Street.

While the Japanese Army spokesman admitted today that there had been extremely heavy fighting near Juichang and north of Teian in the sector south of the Yangtze River, he denied there had been Chinese victories, as reported by Hankow.

Frank W. Xridel, for six years general manager of the Hotel Lincoln, has resigned and will devote his entire time to the Ritz Tower Hotel. Mr. Kridel is president of the company which operates the latter hostelry.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced here yesterday a plan for the deferment of interest on certain of its bonds which would result in reducing fixed interest by $11,376,435 annually for eight years and extend the date of near-by maturities.
Leases of a dozen or more apartments in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, for occupancy on Oct. 1 were announced yesterday by the management.

News of the agreement of the contending forces in the Czechoslovak dispute to let peaceful negotiations continue for at least another fortnight firmed up the stock market yesterday, following the more cheerful tone displayed by the leading European marts.
Shipments of gold to the United States that started at a considerable scale when the Aquitania left Southampton on Aug. 24 now are straining the insurance market.

Members of the board of trustees of the Henry George School of Social Science took title yesterday, on the ninty-ninth anniversary of the birth of Henry George, to a fivestory building at 30 East Twentyninth Street, bought for $50,000 from the New York Telephone Company.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday that it had contributed $100,000 to the Jewish National Fund for the acquisition of land in Palestine to be leased to Jewish settlers for 2 per cent ground rent.

Turpentine firm, 21 1/2c; no sales; receipts, 648 barrels; shipments, 710 barrels; stock, 46,745 barRosin firm; sales, 91; receipts, 2,902; shipments, 2,956; stock, 232,375. Quote. B, $3.50; D, $3.85; E, F, $4; G. H, I, $4.05; K. $4.10; M, $4.12 1/2; N, $4.95; WG, $5.15; WW, X, $6.10.

The State Banking Commission affirmed today its previous order suspending the securities license in Wisconsin of H. M. Byllesby Co. of Chicago. The commission suspended the Byllesby license on July 25.

The passenger and freight ship Uruguay, first of three ships of the new American Republics Line service to be renovated for operation to South America, sailed yesterday from Newport News for New York to be taken over by decorators.

J. (Woody) Platt and Morrie Talman advanced today to the final round of the Philadelphia amateur-pro golf tournament, along with Sydney Allman and Matt Kowal. Platt and his partner defeated Stanley Sanson and Clarence Ehresman, 5 and 4, after eliminating Bob Dunn and Marty Lyons by the same score.
The Most Rev. Churchill Julius, Anglican primate and Archbishop of New Zealand, 1922-25, died yesterday at the age of 91.

Production of pig iron and steel ingots in the United Kingdom in July fell to the lowest level for a month in three years, according to figures supplied to the Department of Commerce by the British Iron and Steel Foundation.

The three-story apartment and store building at 100-04 West First Street, Mount Vernon, Westchester, has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to the August Severio Construction Company, Inc., for cash above a five-year purchase money mortgage.

After a day of wildly contradictory reports from the Continent-so many and so divergent that even the British Government could not keep pace with them-hopes of the continuance of Czechoslovak-German negotiations began to grow dim tonight. The situation was felt to be at least as serious as at any time in the past fortnight.

Marine St (18-5625). n s, 650 ft w of City Island Ave. 50x90: also Marine St. n s, 350 ft w of City Island Ave. 75x90: also Palmer St, s a, 150 ft w of City Island Ave, 50x48; also Palmer St, n s, 450 ft w of City Island Ave, 50x90; Anita Realty Corp to Herbert's. the Home of Blue White Diamonds, Inc. 163 W 125th St.

The week-end entertaining here got under way tonight with a series of dinner parties. Among the larger events was that given by Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse, who have Mrs. Vincent Astor as their guest. Mrs. Bradford Norman, Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomay Jelke and Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward were amone the others who entertained.

A summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders for July, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that Pierre S. du Pont sold 10,000 shares of debenture stock of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.; W. S.
A joint experiment by the Departments of Health, Welfare and Purchase in the breeding of rabbits has met with only indifferent success, it was learned yesterday.

Almon E. Roth, president of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the Pacific American Shipowners Association, said in an interview today that the employers would refuse to renew their contract with the C. I. O.

Mrs. Willis D. Wood of Fort Hill House, Lloyd Neck, Huntington, was official hostess tonight at d theatre party for the Service League of Huntington at the Red Barn, where Cornelia Otis Skinner played the leading role in "Candida."

Europe continued to send gold to this country during the week ended on Aug. 26, but the amounts were somewhat diminished from previous weeks. Of $28,720,863 received during that week, $14,210,060 came from the United Kingdom, while Canada sent $2,821,654 and Japan $5,873,980.
The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Citizen News Company of Hollywood, publisher of The Hollywood Citizen-News, to disestablish Printing Trades Union, Inc.

James G. Peede, who represented such stars as Mrs. Fiske, George Arliss and William Faversham as business manager or advance press agent, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home, 55 West Twelfth Street. He was 51 years old.

A decision by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel in Queens, upholding Mayor La Guardia's temporary cancellation of all permits for advertising displays pulled by airplanes over the city, was said yesterday by Frederick P. Bryan, Acting Corporation Counsel,to establish the "very important principle that the city may enact laws and take appropriate action to protect its inhabitants from danger in the air as well as on land."

T. L. Gustin's stable of Holicong, Pa., continued its winning streak at the final meet of the Flemington Fair harness races today when Paul Vineyard drove American Hanover, bay gelding, to a straight-heat victory in the freefor-all handicap trot in 2:11 3/4.

Una Estates, Inc., has sold the fifty-three-family apartment at 1,612-16 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, to the Zee Realty Corporation. This is a five-story building on a plot 175 by 75 feet, adjoining the northwest corner of Mount Eden Avenue.

Miss Bunny Harshaw of Ursinus College led the Middle States to a 3-1 victory over the Western District in a junior Wightman Cup tennis match today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. She defeated Miss Christine Waples of Chicago, 6-1, 6-3.

The sailing time of six transatlantic liners from New York is being delayed until three minutes after midnight tonight in order that passengers booked on them will have the benefit of reduced round rates in the tourist and third classes which become effective tomorrow.

For "strategical" purposes the General Headquarters of the Army Air Force is being transferred from Langley Field, near Newport News, Va., to Scott Field, Ill. Headquarters of the Second Wing of the Air Force and some of its units will remain at Langley Field.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding weeks in thousands of marks:

After a chase through crowded downtown streets yesterday morning in which three shots were fired into the air by policemen, a Negro parole violator, Clarence Hayes, 20 years old, of 136 West 120th Street, was captured by a patrolman off duty and on his way nome.

The Duchess, owned by Count Paoli Mandelli of Italy and handled by Will Caton, scored a straight-heat victory in the $2,500 consolation stake for 3-year-old trotters, feature of today's Grand Circuit racing program at the New York State Fair.

The Owego Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the New York-PennsylvaniaNew Jersey Utilities Company, has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration in connection with the issuance and sale of 1,632 shares of no-par value common capital stock to the parent company for $81,600.
