The President ,at his press conference yesterday said that " a liberal Republican in the Senate is better than a conservative Democrat," although much would depend on what was in the liberal Republican's heart.

A continued small but steady increase in business added $31,000,000 to payrolls in July, with a pronounced effect on retail sales, according to the monthly survey of business issued today by the American Federation of Labor.
The Treasury announced today the minting in August of 8,340,174 coins for three Xoreign countries at the Philadelphia Mint.

The Dodgers tonight dropped their second exhibition game and their eleventh contest since starting this disastrous Western trip by losing to the Bisons, 7-5. A crowd of 6,000 sat through the cold, most of them attracted by Babe Ruth.

A truck driver was killed, his assistant painfully injured, and three others escaped injury when three trucks crashed, then burst into flames on Route 25, one mile north of here this afternoon. Two cargoes of silk and rayon, valued at more than $100,000 were destroyed.

Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., in its semi-annual statement made public by Jack Frye, president, shows total operating revenues for the first six months of 1938 amounting to $2,656,023, an increase of $245,769 over the corresponding half of last year.

The undertone in the fed-steer market remained firm today at the week's high time. Supplies were short, even for Friday, and there was a good clean-up, with all interests buying, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
The first life sentence under the New Jersey State Lindbergh law to be imposed since it was enacted was pronounced today on two men here by Common Pleas Judge Solve Tuso.
The Veterans Administration designated locations for two new hospitals in Texas today, one at Amarillo and the other in the Fort Worth-Dallas area.

Employing the usual satirist's license, it is permissible to speak of the average New Yorker as born of honeset but violent parents. Day before yesterday the Police Department dumped into Long Island Sound a large amount of confiscated material.

While playing football for Princeton in the not too dim past Eddie Driggs Jr. pulled many a surprise, but none of them matched his son Dixon's performance in the quarterfinal round of the Long Island junior golf championship at the Cherry Valley Club today.

The fifteenth annual report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corportion covering the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1938, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $578,168, compared with a net of $4,508,462 in the year to June 30, 1937, a drop of $3,930,294.
Cooler weather served to reduce the percentage of sales decline under a year ago for local department stores, but the showing was somewhat below anticipations.

Appointment of Arthur L. Fletcher of North Carolina as assistant administrator in charge of compliance in the Wages and Hours Division of the Labor Department was announced today by Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator.

For the second time this week the French Cabinet today gave lengthy consideration to the international situation, but in the same quiet and objective spirit in which the country is watching and waiting for developments.
Neptune, a black and white tom cat, stepped off the steamship District of Columbia yesterday, completing another of many journeys up and down the Potomac River.

Paul Phillippe, who was ousted here in July as president of Local 118 of the United Automobile Workers of America and later was stripped of union membership, declared today that the new regime did not reflect the true sentiment of the local in revolting against John L. Lewis and the C. I. O.

18th St, 409 W, Roy Callahan. referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp; foreclosure. 124th St, 73 W. Catherine Fitzpatrick, executrix of James J. Fitzpatrick, to Catherine Fitzpatrick, 73 W 124th St; mtg $3,200.

Senator Reynolds of North Carolina, who has returned from a long Summer trip extending from Labrador to Siberia, wants the United States to acquire Bermuda, Newfoundland and a big enough strip across Western Canada to build a highway to Alaska.
The Cleveland Rams of the National Football League scored 10 points in the second half of their game with the Ohio College All-Stars tonight to win, 10-7, before a crowd of 20,283.
Thirtysix communities received $150,000 today for the development of public forums where young and old may discuss current economic, social and political problems.

First place in the professional derby stake at the Saskatchewan field trials was awarded today to Island Park Boy, owned by E. J. Shaffer of Hutchinson, Kan. The winner was trained and handled yesterday by B. F. Epperson.

Ellis Colvin, a 46-year-old WPA worker, today fell while resting on his shovel and fractured a wrist. Colvin was working in a gravel pit. Fellow-workmen said Colvin had paused and was standing with his legs crossed, his hands cupped over the top of the handle and his chin resting on his hands.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Campbell of this city of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Haxall Campbell, to Charles Scott Bannerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Boyce Bannerman of New York and Blue Point, L. I. The wedding will take place Sept. 17 in Trinity Episcopal Church here.

While Tokyo is striving to recover from the effects of the most serious typhoon in the past twenty-one years and is hastily repairing roofs and cleaning up debris, the Central Meteorological Observatory states that another typhoon is forming in the South Pacific and is expected to strike Tokyo about Sept. 10.

The Rev. Dr. Alexander Ketterson, rector of the Ascension Memorial Episcopal Church, 251 West Forty-third Street, known as "The Little Brick Church in Times Square," with Mrs. Ketterson returned home Thursday afternoon from a vacation in Canada, their former home.
Engagements of gold aggregating $6,100,000 in London for shipment here were reported yesterday, as the pound sterling continued to fall to levels of depreciation not seen in more than three years.

The final round of the Mason and Dixon women's golf tournament took on an international aspect today when Miss Dorothy Traung of San Francisco and Miss Evelyn Marvin of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, won their matches.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 1,162,000 bales, against 1,157,000 a week ago, 1,163,000 two weeks ago, 1,191,000 three weeks ago and 72,000 a year ago; of which American 650,000 bales,
The Twenty-ninth Division Association, composed of World War veterans of the "Blue and Gray" from New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia, opened a fourday reunion here today.
Today was just a headache for 200 members of the National Puzzlers League, who opened their semiannual convention here.
Ernst Weisser, 36, was executed today for spying into State secrets and theft. The People's Court sentenced him to death on June 16.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today authorization of a loan of $10,000,000 to Seattle, Wash., of which $4,300,000 is to refinance the city's indebtedness in connection with its transportation system and the balance to be used to buy equipment and for construction.
There was a net gain of 35,200 telephones in service in the Bell System in August, compared with a gain of 55,100 in the same month last year.

Nettinga will preach his first sermon as minister in charge of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues. on Sept. 11, at 11 A. M. This will mark the resumption of services for the Autumn.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Elizabeth Moore, daughter of Mrs. John A. Scanlon of this place, to Ellsworth H. Boughton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Boughton of Glen Ridge, took place here at noon today in the Sanford Street Methodist Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Benjamin F. Dickisson.
Tomorrow 175 Austrian dancing teachers will undergo a rigorous examination following a week's instruction course in standardized dances of Germany by Berlin teachers.

President Rooseyelt today urged American workers and employers alike to adopt the British point of view toward industrial disputes, saying that the cooperative spirit which his special committee had observed in English industrial relations would go far toward solving labor disputes here.

Carlyle Bennett, tenor of the World's Fair Opera Company, and Wesley Boynton, leading man in the Theatre-in-the-Woods Company in Norwalk, were under arrest tonight on charges of larceny in connection with the theft of $4,000 in furniture, paintings, antiques, books and furnishings from the home of Mrs. Louis Robare of Greens Farms.
Despite strength in the stock markets here and relative steadiness in cotton markets abroad, prices on the Cotton Exchange reflected yesterday weight of the new crop and lost 2 to 4 points.

WHEN 300 years of history are condensed into some 300 pages of print,* there is not much space to record the amusing trivialities which must have leavened the lives of at least a few of the less orthodox Puritans, and which add vividness to the portrait of a period.

Philip Bancroft, rancher and lawyer, appeared assured of the Republican Senatorial nomination late today as he continued to hold a small but steady lead over Ray Riley, California Railroad Commissioner.

The Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation announced today that it had arranged the private sale of $2,375,000 of general refunding mortgage bonds to the Metropolitan, Prudential and Mutual Life Insurance Companies. Proceeds of the bonds, which will bear 3 1/4 per cent interest, will be used to refund an 1889 issue of Buffalo General Electric Company 5 per cent bonds, due on Feb. 1, 1939.

Resolutions urging manufacturers and wholesalers to avail themselves of the fair-trade laws and also endorsing the National Retail Demonstration to be held during the week of Sept. 19, were adopted yesterday by the American National Retail Jewelers Association at the closing session of its annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Olinville Ave, 3,722, dwelling, 25x95; Home Owners Loan Corp against Frank Klous; due, $7,692, taxes, etc, $1,264; to plaintiff for $500.
George R. Ford, long active in the Toledo glass industry, died today in his home after a two months' illness. He was 56 years old.
A state of insecurity with continuing disorders was apparent in Palestine today. Arab terrorism is not checked and both Arab and Jewish casualties are mounting steadily.
Mrs. Herbert Spencer of Hillsdale died today in the Hackensack Hospital of a heart ailment. She was 55 years old.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, who has made it a practice as chairman of the Democratic National Committee to telegraph congratulations to winners in Democratic primaries regardless of their standing with the New Deal, has failed to acknowledge the victories of United States Senator Ellison D. Smith in South Carolina or Sheridan Downey in California, it was disclosed yesterday.

President Roosevelt plans to remain close to Washington as long as the European situation is acute, he said at a White House press conference today. He added in response to questions that he did not consider the situation "delicate," an adjective used by a reporter, but that he would term it difficult.
George Clark, who died alone in his South End room Tuesday, today was identified through the efforts of Medical Examiner Timothy Leary as a member of Admiral Peary's Greenland expedition.
Plans for two more buildings in the moderate-rental housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx were filed yesterday.

Irving I. Ingraham was divorced today by Mae Bower Ingraham, former Sennett bathing beauty, because "he went for a walk around the block and never came back." She testified that he left April 2, after only twenty-six days of marriage.
Considerable progress appears to have been made recently in prefabrication and mass production of small houses.
A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Campbell of Radburn on Wednesday at the Mountainside Hospital here.
Putting that drew the gallery's cheers gave Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., and Ben Hogan, White Plains, N. Y., a commanding lead of nine points today in the Hershey round-robin, best-ball golf tourney.
Fill-in orders of clothing and house furnishings and regular stock buying of school supplies added heavily to wholesale volume this week, according to the weekly summary by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The Rev. Angelo Benvenuti, pastor of the Christian Pentecostal Church of this township, has appealed to President Roosevelt to give him citizenship papers denied in naturalization court because the minister said he would not bear arms in case of war.

Colonel Charles Arthur Carlisle, industrialist and banker, died today at this home here after an illness of six years. His age was 74. Colonel Carlisle was born in Chillicothe, Ohio, and in 1883 he entered the services of the Marietta Cincinnati Railway.
The Fort Hamilton four will meet the First Division in a non-league polo match at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn tomorrow.
Two more names went on the long list of sore-armed major league pitchers today-those of Van Lingle Mungo and Wayne LaMaster, both of the Brooklyn Dodgers.
The most intense earthquake to be recorded for some time was reported yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Lynch, head of the seismological laboratory at Fordham University.

Fordham's coaching staff concentrated on the right tackle candidates, Russ Monica, Bill Stanton and Joe Ungerer, as the football squad was sent through another intensive double workout on Fordham Field yesterday.

Cheered by a clear, cool afternoon and a weather forecast of fair and warmer today and cooler, with possible showers, tomorrow, New Yorkers by the hundreds of thousands deserted the city last night for the last Summer vacation holiday, the three-day Labor Day weekend.

Bob Pearce retained his world professional one-mile sculling championship in a race against three Australians tonight as Joe Burk of Philadelphia, considered the chief threat to Pearce's sculling supremacy, won the amateur mile event.

Into the rustic setting on the shore of shimmering Lake Sebago, the New York University football squad, forty-nine strong, moved today for the start of its pre-season training. And Dr. Marvin A. Stevens eventually will lead it out of the woods here for what he hopes will be a successful season.

Patrolman William Morey of the Atlantic Avenue station, Brooklyn, was suspended from duty yesterday after a companion, Vincent Daniels, 29 -years old, had wounded himself critically in the abdomen with Morey's pistol.

The Idaho Fruit and Vegetable Commission is planning to begin an advertising program at once for Idaho potatoes, prunes and onions, following a decision by the State Supreme Court holding the special advertising tax law constitutional.

A silver plaque, given in recognition of Lord Taylor's consistent promotional efforts in behalf of millinery, was presented yesterday to Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, by Max Meyer, chairman of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

Insurgent advices reported that their artillerymen had broken a deadlock in the Spanish civil war fighting today by opening a heavy bombardment of the Loyalists' growing circular fortifications on the Ebro front in Catalonia.

John I. Snyder, land acquisition director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, admitted today before the Congressional Investigating Committee that he had written to his father-in-law in 1934 proposing the purchase of a tract near the Fontana Dam site which promised a S30,000 profit.

Horses owned by Mrs. Samuel Schiffer of Elberon, N. J., and Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee of Larchmont, N. Y., divided the honors in the saddle-horse championships tonight at the final session of the Empire State Horse Show.

Trading was fair on most classes of traefer meats. Slaughter houses were about cleaned up on steer hinds and ribs and salesmen were asking higher prices. Veal and calf hindsaddles were weak to lower. Lamb carcasses were stronger.

George Audain, editor of The St. Thomas Mail and Notes, who is seeking election to the Municipal Council, today declared that if elected he will strive for the annexation of the British Virgin Island group by the United States.

Giving away seven goals on handicap, Aknusti nevertheless galloped to an easy 19-12 victory over Roslyn on Schiff Field today. It marked the final test match for Aknusti in preparation for the national open polo championship which starts Sunday at the Meadow Brook Club.
The action of the domestic wheat markets today was similar to that of preceding days, prices fluctuating in an erratic manner within a moderate range.
The Treasury ended the first two months of the fiscal. year on Wednesday with a deficit of $646,648,203.02, as compared with $372,488,750.82 in the same period a year ago.

Former United States Senator William M. Calder has been named chairman of the Republican campaign committee aiding the candidacies of Louis Waldman, for Kings County Judge; William T. Simpson and Edmund L. Palmieri, for City Court vacancies, and all other Brooklyn candidates who are on the Republican-American Labor Party coalition ticket.

Miss Helen Roberta Auch, niece of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Hanson of Fairfield Circle, was married to Elbert Orla Sowerwine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sowerwine, also of this place, in the Redeemer Evangelical Church here this evening. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Walter A. Reuning.

M. F. Greenwell of New Haven, a ship's cook, is one of the two short-range champion gun pointers of the navy. He is a member of the crew of the Tern of the Base Force of the navy and shares the championship with Chief Yeoman Thomas R. Ballard of San Diego.

Eight All-Star players and one other reported to the Brooklyn football Dodgers today. Coach Potsy Clark also announced the signing of two more backs. Joe Kilgrow, Alabama triple-threat, and Ed Berlinski, North Carolina State halfback, were placed under contract.
Irish bankers are opposed to the creation of a central bank in the former Free State area, which was one of the recommendations made by the Commission on Banking, Currency and Credit.

About 8,000 Philco radio workers, who have been out of jobs for four months because of a labor dispute at the plant of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company, voted today in secret ballot to accept a contract agreement that would reopen the factory.
Purification of Soviet art from "decadent modernistic influences" as well as the "sticky sweetness of romanticism" was demanded today in Izvestia, government organ.

Fighting Fox, once considered in the front rank of the 3-year-olds for championship honors, will be faced with stiff opposition from members of the older division in today's Bay Shore Handicap, main event at Aqueduct.

The Reading Company was 50 cents richer today through the troubled conscience of an unnamed man from Kansas. E. E. Leisey, station agent at Ephrata, Pa., sent the change to the general offices today with the explanation that an elderly man had handed it to him yesterday.

Dr. and Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell of this city and Locust Valley, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mallory Mixsell, to E. Coe Kerr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Coe Kerr of New York and Mill Neck, L. I.
The Mexican Government is seeking the support of Latin-American countries for its expropriation and indemnity program at the Pan-American conference at Lima, Peru, next December.

President Eduard Benes this morning received a Henleinist deputation consisting of Ernst Kundt and Dr. Wilhelm Sebekovsky. The delegation spent four hours with the President. The Henlein party describes the meeting as a continuation of the "private conversations of August 30" between these two delegates and the President.

Determined to lose very little time in mending his shattered Giant fences for the 1939 campaign, Manager Bill Terry yesterday announced the recall of nine players optioned during the season in the minors and the outright purchase of four others.

The Italian Cabinet met today for the second successive day and dealt a blow to Italian citizens of Jewish ancestry when it approved a decree banning both Jewish teachers and students from all Italian governmental, semigovernmental and private but legally recognized schools of any grade or class.
The crew of the Norwegian freighter Titanian walked out today in protest against the vessel carrying 9,000 tons of munition - making chemicals to the Spanish Insurgent port of Bilbao.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Fabian Franklin, in his letter to THE TIMES discussing the demolition of John D. Rockefeller's Harlem tenements in order to save taxes, writes:

Net profit of the Columbia Pictures Corporation and its subsidiaries amounted to $183,393 after amortization, production costs, depreciation, Federal income taxes,. Federal surtax on undistributed profits and other charges, according to the report for the fifty-two weeks ended on June 25 released yesterday.

The funeral of Mgr. Edward J. McGolrick, pastor of St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, Herbert him and North Henry Streets, Brooklyn, will be held there this morning. Five thousand parishioners were estimated to have attended three masses for him at the church yesterday morning.

The National Power and Light Company announced yesterday that the outstanding 5 per cent bonds of the Tennessee Public Service Company will be called for redemption on Oct. 4 at 104 and accrued.interest.

Three men and a woman charged with felonious assault in provoking a riot outside a home relief district station at 269 Nostrand Avenue on Thursday pleaded not guilty before Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday, and obtained an adjournment on the case until Sept.

The reunion of the United Confederate Veterans ended today with a parade down Main Street to the State Capitol. The veterans elected General John W. Harris of Oklahoma City their commander, but took no action on the invitation of the city of Trinidad, Col., to meet there next year.

With a strike of nearly 2,000 painters and paperhangers in progress in Brooklyn, District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, representing 16,000 members in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond,

Robert L. Riggs Jr. will have the responsibility of playing the first match in defense of the Davis Cup in the challenge-round series between the United States and Australia starting tomorrow on the turf of the Germantown Cricket Club.

Four and six cylinder models in the low-priced car field have been added to the Hupp Motor Car Corporation's line of products for 1939, it was announced yesterday by Norman de Vaux, general manager in charge of operations.

A wooded plot of about an acre, on the west side of Elderfields Road in the village of Flower Hill, Manhasset, has been purchased by Fred Riebow from the Carlos W. Munson Properties, through L'Ecluse, Washburn Co., agent.

A large group of women of the Summer colony, headed by Mrs. Francis Rogers, are active in the arrangements for an entertainment to be known as "Saturday at Nine-A Joyous Revue," which will be given Sept. 10 at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng, for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 27 amounted to 620,511 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 22,593 cars, or 3.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 162,965 cars, or 20.8 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 133,231 cars, or 17.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

The Trust Company of New Jersey sold to the 560 Park Avenue Realty Company for a consideration shown as $30,000 the plant formerly owned by the Denier Mirror and Plate Glass Company at 560-66 Park Avenue, West New York.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh avoided a welcoming crowd today when he landed here from Olmuetz, where foggy weather had held him overnight. As he was taxiing after landing here with Mrs. Lindbergh about 500 Czechoslovaks broke through a small police guard and ran toward the plane with bouquets and presents.

Scenery for the Theatre" is the title of a new work on the organization, processes, materials and techniques used to set the stage. The authors are Harold BurrisMeyer of Stevens Institute and Edward C. Cole of the Yale School of Drama. The book, which contains nearly 600 illustrations will be published by Little, Brown, Sept. 12.

Olin D. Gray, retired president of the Gray Lithographing Company of New York and first president of the National Lithographers Association, died here today at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Kenneth B. Jaffray. He was 83 years old.

Yachts in the third race of the Atlantic Class championships at Indian Harbor Yacht Club failed to finish tonight because of a calm, and the series championship was awarded, according to the rules, to the Indian Harbor entry, Rumour, sailed by Mills H. Husted, with a total of 16 points to its credit.
Rabbi Beltzalel Epstein, former head of the K. K. Beth Tefyla Congregation, died at his home here early today. He was regarded as one of the foremost Orthodox Jewish scholars in the country.

Hunters and jumpers featured the sessions of the horse show which opened today in connection with the ninety-fifth annual Orangeburg Fair, the oldest exhibition of the kind in the country. The show will continue through tomorrow.
Colonel Truman O. Murphy, U. S. A., retired, died yesterday at the Brighton Hotel here. He was born 71 years ago in Mansfield, Ohio, and was graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1891.

Superintendent William B. Mills, Deputy Warden Frank A. Craven and twelve other members of the Holmesburg prison staff were accaused of "criminal negligence" by a "blue-ribbon" coroner's jury this afternoon at the close of an inquest into the "heat stroke" deaths of four convicts in the prison's isolation block.

" The luck of the Irish" stayed with Douglas Corrigan today when his quick thinking saved him from a forced landing that might have had serious consequences. Taking off from this airport shortly after noon for Pittsburgh, Corrigan had risen with his $900 transatlantic "crate" to a height of about 100 feet when the engine started to sputter.

Dr. Thomas R. Boggs, Baltimore physician and former president of the Association of American Physicians, died at his Summer home here this morning at the age of 63. He had been ill several months. In April he retired.

A river boat race with all the color and frills of the historic contest between the famous Robert E. Lee and the Natchez in 1872 is to be staged over the same 1,154-mile course, New Orleans-to-St. Louis, next Spring.
Stories of "sucker claims" which made millionaires out of tenderfeet in the Klondike forty years ago were told at the annual convention of the Alaska-Yukon International Sourdoughs today.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis was excused as a witness at the trial of James J. Hines at the opening of court yesterday after nearly two days on the stand. Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel, announced that he had completed his cross-examination and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey said he had no further questions.
The revived Cardinals went on a scoring splurge for three innings today, then just nosed out the National League leading Pirates, 11 to 10, in the only game on the senior circuit program.

Miss Sally Marguerite Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Alden Knight of this place, formerly of Rye, N. Y., was married here tonight at the home of her parents to Paul Edward Godnecht Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Godnecht of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rev. John Daniel, pastor of the Highland Avenue Congregational Church.
Two men who, according to the police, attempted to snatch a $1,279 payroll shortly before noon yesterday were foiled by the quick thinking of a young woman.

Justice Julius Miller in the Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday directed the Board of Elections to strike from its records the American Labor party petition of State Senator Leon A. Fischel, Democrat, who is seeking renomination in the Seventeenth Senatorial District.

Mildred Baldwin, 25-year-old Callfornia soprano, has just been chosen from 400 singers in Fortune Gallo's auditions and given a contract to appear with his San Carlo Opera Company during its forthcoming season at the Center Theatre.

Labor Sunday will be observed in the city's churches tomorrow. There will be sermons on labor problems. In many Protestant pulpits excerpts will be read from the annual Labor Day message of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Trading by members for their own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 13 was 20.06 per cent of the total volume, compared with 19.76 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Transatlantic shares were the most prominent feature in quiet but generally cheerful stock markets here today. United States Steel and International Nickel advanced in a list where prices exceeded the New York parities.

Miss-Dorothy A. McLean, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William McLean of 390 West End Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to Clifford R. Baucom, son of Elias H. Baucom of: Charlotte, N. C., and the late Mrs. Baucom. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Edgar F. Romig of the West End Collegiate Church.
Department store sales for the week ended Aug. 27 were 14 per cent lower than for the corresponding week last year, and for the four weeks ended Aug. 27 were 11 per cent

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Picaso of Brooklyn and Sheffield, Mass., have announced- the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Abercrombie Picaso, to George Crosby Bartter, son of the Rev. and Mrs. George Bartter of Baguio, PhilipPine Islands.

Two masked men, roughly dressed, forced their way into the ranch home of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Meeks near Yuba City, Sutter County, north of here just before midnight, bound the middle-aged couple and kidnapped Mrs. Meeks for $15,000 ransom.

Leaves With Pay Leaves of absence, with pay, for 15 days from the time and dates hereinafter designated, are granted to the following members for the purpose of attending the National Convention of the American Legion at Log Angeles. Calif., as duly elected delegates of American Legion Posts, providing that each member produces satisfactory proof of such attendance:

A long blackboard session in the morning and a two-and-a-half-hour drill this afternoon prepared the Eastern College All-Stars for their final scrimmage tomorrow morning at their Peddie School camp. With this final contact work, the All-Stars will taper off in their training for the game against the Giants.
Prince Arthur of Connaught, the Duke of Connaught's son, who has been seriously ill here recently, is "now losing strength," according to a bulletin issued tonight.
The Southern Pacific Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $7,251,000 of first refunding 4 per cent mortgage bonds.

Declaring that freedom of worship is perhaps the main pillar of democracy, Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy today sharply condemned the persecution of religions by dictatorships. The Ambassador spoke at the laying of the cornerstone of a memorial in Aberdeen Cathedral to Samuel Seabury, first Episcopalian Bishop of the United States, who was consecrated at Aberdeen after the English hierarchy rejected him.

Miss Julia Larrabee Holmes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Hoyt Holmes of this city, was married to John Dudley Munger here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Michael Roy Barton performed the ceremony.

Members of Police Commissioner Valentine's confidential squad descended on Harlem yesterday afternoon and made a raid on an apartment where they arrested six men and one boy they charged had policy slips in their possession. All of those seized were Negroes.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Only a vacation atmosphere pervades the seaboard wool trade this week. The volume of business done

Mrs. William Hockenjos of Crestmont today scored another victory in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament when she led a field of forty-one at the Hackensack Golf Club with a score of 85. The former State match and medal play champion went out in 42 and returned in 43.

It is hardly possible to say when the "holiday week-end" exit of New Yorkers began; certainly it was no later than Thursday. Others hurried away yesterday, under the stagger plan, and still others will go belatedly, but nevertheless happily, today.

Cotton-mill activity last week held steady at the revised level for the previous week, although an increase was seasonal. The adjusted index has eased to 122.2 from 123.6 (revised) and compares with 134.5 for the week ended Aug. 28, 1937.

The marriage of Miss Carol Greeley Carpenter, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth Greeley Carpenter of St. Louis and the late Mr. Carpenter, to Franklin McKee Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin H. Gates of Montclair, N. J., took place here this afternoon in the Island Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Crocker, Episcopal chaplain at Princeton University.
With railroad loans assuming the leadership, bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved irregularly higher yesterday as the volume of trading quickened somewhat.
Announcement was made here yesterday of the engagement of Miss Katharine Miller Leas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stewart Leas of Weldon, Haverford, Pa., to Curtis B. Dall of this city.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,257,736,000 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price a share of all listed stocks on Sept. 1 was $30.55, compared with $31.38 at the beginning of August.

The good faith of reorganization plans for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation was challenged today at the hearing on the plans which is being conducted by Edward C, Johnson as trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Following a second conversation between Chancellor Hitler and Konrad Henlein, in which figured a friendly message to the former from Viscount Runciman, Berlin believed the Czechoslovak issue would not be precipitated at the Nazi congress next week.

Dr. John W. Phillips, pastor emeritus of the First Baptist Church here and widely known lecturer and world traveler, died at his home here early today. He had been in ill health for some time. He was 83 years old.

In an unprecedented action the New York Stock Exchange authorities yesterday invited G. D. Brooke, president of the Chesapeake Ohio and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroads, to "discuss" on Wednesday why the Nickel Plate announced on Aug. 1 that it would pay interest due on Sept. 1 and announced on Aug. 30
Mr. and Mrs. C. F. Raney of Fairfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Jane Raney, to Lebaron Stockford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stockford of Los Angeles.

William D. Woodring of Alton, Ill., not only won the Remington SmallBore Trophy match today but was declared national small-bore champion by making the highest aggregate score for four matches fired during the week.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 2, unless specified: At Guantanamo, Sept. 1: Babbitt, Dickerson, Roper, Schenck. Tillman. At San Diego: Cincinnati, Perry, Wright. At Perth Amboy: Decatur, J. F. Talbott. At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Dunlap, Fanning. Rio de Janeiro to Guantanamo: Enterprise, Shaw.
Negotiations between B. P. Schulberg and United Artists, under which he will produce for United Artists distribution, are reported near completion.

Two grand rounds of golf, a 70 and a 68, which duplicated his scores of the first day, enabled Frank Moore of Quaker Ridge to capture the Westchester open golf championship today for the second successive year.
John Graham, Pittsburgh veteran, scored a 76 today to lead at the end of the first eighteen holes of golf's Golden Jubilee tournament. Graham had a one-stroke lead over Sherill Sherman, Utica, N. Y.
Margot Grahame Lister, stage and screen actress, today obtained a divorce from Francis Lister, English actor, on a charge of cruelty.

Trading in futures on the three principal Cotton Exchanges in the United States totaled 2,816,100 bales in August, compared with 3,541,754 in July, the Commodity Exchange Administration announced today.

George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, sent a letter yesterday to Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, repeating again why the State Non-Partisan Committee of the A. F. of L. could not work with the American Labor party.
The report of the commission of experts sent by President Roosevelt to investigate labor legislation and relations in Great Britain is admirable in every way. Impartial, informative, compact,

The appearance of an eight-foot shark in shallow water at the Hudson Park Beach here drove fifty swimmers from the water this morning. The shark swam leisurely from shore when a patrolman fired two bullets toward it, but bathing was unpopular the rest of the day.

18th St, 409 W, 3-story dwelling, 25x92; Home Owners Loan Corp against Mary E. Gill, due, $12,538; to plaintiff for $500. By ROBERT FISHEL 172d St, 636 W, 5-story tenement, 65.4x95; Charles R. Morton, execr, against Adonatfree Realty Corp, due, $27,095; subject to mortgage of $65,000; to plaintiff for $66,000.

An Application by The Northeastern Water and Electric Corporation, an affiliate of the Associated Gas and Electric System, to acquire 9,600 shares of common stock of the Hazelton Water Company from the Lehigh Valley Railway Company has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission subject to the elimination of a commission of $25,000 which it was proposed to pay to W. C. Langley Co. of New York, investment bankers.

Yorkshire concluded its schedule in the county cricket competition today with a four-wicket victory over Sussex. The northern county clinched the championship for the twentieth time earlier in the week and finished the season with a total of 256 points out of a possible 336 for twenty-eight games, an average of 9.14.

Thirty-eight boats, representing clubs along the shores of Long Island Sound, answered the gun tonight at the start of the Stamford Yacht Club's annual Vineyard race. The boats sailed mill pond waters until they had passed Norwalk, where a light breeze, giving promise of increasing during the night, pushed them forward.
Brig. Gen. Sir Henry Page Croft, Bart., of London is at the SavoyPlaza. Mr. and Mrs. --Harrison McClure Thomas and Miss Joan Thomas have come from Princeton to the Ritz-Carlton.

Youngstown, Ohio, will be in the market on Sept. 23 with $2,861,680 of bridge, municipal-building, street and park bonds with an interest rate of 4 per cent. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1938, and will be due serially on Sept. 1, 1945 to 1964.

August Heckscher, philanthropist, was the guest of honor at a belated birthday party given to him yesterday in the Heckscher Playground in Central Park by the children of the recreation center and the Park Department. Mr. Heckscher celebrated his ninetieth birthday on Aug. 27.
Stocks closed from fractions to 2 points higher in slightly more active trading; turnover, 553,560 shares.

The government has passed an order-in-council designed to encourage production by automobile manufacturers who discontinued making cars here after the trade agreement reduced the tariff against United States cars from 35 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent.

Unless one is prepared to accept the theory that Signor Mussolini is willing to follow blindly wherever Herr Hitler leads the way, it is necessary to look further for an explanation of the extraordinary and ruthless decree of the Italian Government ordering all Jews who have taken up residence in Italy since the World War to leave that country within the next six months.

Clouds of heavy black smoke rising from the twenty-four-story World Tower Building at 110 West Fortieth Street late yesterday afternoon drew several hundred people from near-by Bryant Park and surrounding streets to the scene.

A scheme to hold up and rob the fourteenth-floor office of the Philadelphia Receiver of Taxes in City Hall Annex was blocked, detectives said today, with the arrest of twelve men. Attaches of the office said that had the plan been carried out $100,000 might have been taken.
Harvey Boltwood, director of the Bureau of Service of the Interstate Commerce Commission, died today at the age of 60.

The Yankees having long made a practice of running down a runnerup the moment he comes within hailing distance, it remained only for the second-place Red Sox to edge into the Stadium yesterday in order to put the McCarthymen immediately on their mettle.

The Garden State Lines of New Jersey has been served by the National Labor Relations Board with an intermediate report recommending that it bargain with the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen on its Bergen and Passaic divisions and reinstate with back pay from Dec.

Mounting indignation of the American community in Shanghai over various Japanese restrictions, which are interpreted as deliberately designed to throttle foreign interests in all occupied areas of China, has resulted in the cooperation of the American Chamber of commerce and the American community organization in a joint cabled appeal to the State Department in Washington.
Exports of aeronautical products for the first seven months of this year exceeded by 10 per cent the total exports for the entire year of 1937, the Commerce Department announced today.

World consumption of coffee in July and August, the first two months of the new crop year, amounted to 4,357,207 bags, compared with 3,525,527 bags in the same period last year, an increase of 831,680 bags, or 22.7 per cent, according to statistics released yesterday by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Gross assets, $393,845; net, $370,138. To St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church in Flatbush, $35,000; St. James Protestant Episcopal Church in Buffalo, N. Y. and Seaman's Church Institute, $5,000 each: Church Charity Foundation of Long Island for St. John's Hospital,
Dr. Jock Sutherland said today he has no intention of changing from his football coaching job at the University of Pittsburgh to another school.

Miss Eleanor Angle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Motley Angle, was married to Thomas Thacher Richmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Martin Richmond of Bridgewater, Vt., and Glen Head, L. I., this afternoon in Brick Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Harold L. Nicely, pastor, and the Rev. Guthrie Speers officiated.
Newark scored eleven runs in the ninth inning tonight to win, 13-7. The drive erased a 7-2 lead gained by the Orioles after a 6-run attack in the eighth.
What appears to be a strike of workers among the 1,500,000 honey bees of the Brooklyn Children's Museum is puzzling officials of the institution, it was learned yesterday.

Harrison Wood, publicity man and mountain climber, who was a son of Mrs. Harrison Eustis, founder and president of The Seeing Eye, an organization which trains dogs to lead the blind, died on Thursday at Berne, Switzerland, after a short illness. Mr. Wood, who lived at 134 East Fortieth Street, was 23 years old.
Manager Dick Porter came through twice as a pinch hitter to lead the Chiefs to a double victory over Jersey City before 4,500 fans tonight Both scores were 3 to 2.

The three-story apartment and store building at 1,712 Avenue U, Brooklyn,has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to Beatrice Prue and Jennie Bronberg for cash above a purchase money mortgage running for five years.
Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., Sept. 3: PATROLMEN-Frederick J. Wills, 79th Precinct, assigned to clerical duty; Michael Dennehy, from Traffic Precinct O to Traffic Precinct B.

Lou Little of Columbia, dean of The Herald Tribune football coaching school, brought to a close the fourth annual gridiron clinic at the Tribune auditorium yesterday with a lengthy discussion of offensive tactics. The off-tackle play and the end run were his main topics.

I., this afternoon in Brick Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Harold L. Nicely, pastor, and the Rev. Guthrie Speers officiated.

Mr. Wood, who lived at 134 East Fortieth Street, was 23 years old.

The three-story apartment and store building at 1,712 Avenue U, Brooklyn,has been sold by the East River Savings Bank to Beatrice Prue and Jennie Bronberg for cash above a purchase money mortgage running for five years.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 1: MAJOR GENERAL Embick, S. D., General Staff Corps, relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Washington, D. C Sept. 30, and assigned to the command of the Fourth Corps Area, Atlanta, Ga,

A great "if" hangs over Washington, a reflection of the suspense that hangs over Eutrope. And it is the deliberate intention of the government that another great "if" should add to the doubts of those governments now hesitating at the crossroads as they try to forecast the policy of the United States.

Plans for expanding one of the largest business enterprises of its kind on the lower East Side were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the seven-story building at 34-36 Cooper Square, near the Bowery.
HERE they go again competing for an international team trophy in tennis that, for a score of years, has been a team trophy in name only. It's really an individual prize.

Municipal bond issues aggregating $49,712,232 were approved by voters in 457 municipalities in thirty-seven States in August, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. This compares with $9,566,229 of bonds approved in July and $6.612,000 in August 1937.
Marko Oreskovich, driller in the McIntyre mine at Schumacher, Ont., married Miss Anka Oreskovich, 19-year-old Serbian immigrant girl, here today after winning her freedom from a deportation officer.
MANFHATTAN ALEXANDER, GRACE GREEN (Aug. 2). Estate, about $10,000. To Eleanor Butler Roosevelt, daughter, executrix, Old Orchard, Oyster Bay, L. I.

Plans for submission to the membership of a proposed new wage contract for the unlicensed personnel of ship lines operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports were drafted yesterday at a meeting of the newly elected national council of the National Maritime Union.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Despite the fact that they have been in camp only three days, the Manhattan football players went through a lengthy contact practice this afternoon under Coach Herb Kopf at La Salle Military Academy.

Applications for the 500 jobs as city porters in city buildings at $960 to $1,200 a year reached a total of 9,365 yesterday at 4 P. M., the deadline for filing, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced.
Mayor La Guardia took leave yesterday of his Summer City Hall in the grounds of the World's Fair, where he has made his headquarters since July 5.

The advance guard of the delegation of members of the British Iron and Steel Institute and the Institute of Metals of Great Britain which is to visit steel and metal plants in the United States this Fall will arrive at Quebec on the Empress of Britain on Sept. 22, headed by the Earl of Dudley, president of the first body.

With Labor Day marking the end of Summer for the business community, Autumn is faced with mixed feelings in Wall Street. There is some dejection over the failure of railroad wage negotiations, the pause of the automobile industry at "dead center," and the hopeless outlook for steel earnings.

After the second performance of "The Headless Horseman" at the John Drew Memorial Theatre tonight a reception and supper was given by Mrs. Harry Rollins and Leighton Rollins, director of the Studio Players.
The earliest arrivals from the August openings in Paris were shown yesterday at a preview of Autumn styles in the fourth-floor salon at Bonwit-Teller.
Toys and wars do not mix, say Americans in Tokyo. A report to the Commerce Department disclosed today that Japanese toy exports declined 37 per cent in the first half of this year.
Mrs. Susan Cleveland Yeomans, only survivor of nine brothers and sisters, one of whom was President Grover Cleveland, celebrated her ninety-fifth birthday with a family reunion in Brooklyn yesterday.

About seventy-five persons were arrested on gambling charges today here and in Naugatuck by Federal officers, ninety-five State policemen and a squad of local officers in a raid which came as a surprise to the city.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders, dated Aug. 31: COMMANDER Crosby, P. T., Med. Corps, to Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif., orders of'July 11 modified.

The organization certificate of the Manhasset Safe Deposit and Storage Company of Manhasset has been approved by the State Banking Department, it announced today. The incorporators include Henry R. Tibbits, Daniel M. Croucher, Henry A. Alker, Arthur H. Wright and Harrison E. Deyo.

The whole Canadian aircraft industry, according to a statement issued tonight by Sir Francis Floud, British High Commissioner in Canada, will participate in the construction of military airplanes for the British Government.

Canadian production of leaf tobacco increased from 41,966,375 pounds in 1928 to 71,457,000 in 1938, according to statistics compiled in Canada and reported to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce here.

A Dutchess County grand jury today cleared officials and employes of various relief agencies in President Roosevelt's home county of wrongdoing or neglect, but criticized the relief system itself as "a burden scarcely to be borne."

Because a fellow-passenger aboard the Staten Island ferry boat Gold Star Mother challenged his ability as a swimmer, George Rojabige, 25 years old, a laborer, leaped into New York Bay yesterday and struck out for the nearest shore, about a mile away.

Political expediency, without consideration for the lives of airplane passengers and pilots, was charged here today against Mayor La Guardia by Mayor Meyer Ellenstein of Newark, in connection with plans of major airlines to establish bases at North Beach Airport, now under construction.

After three days of qualifying trials for the Thompson and Greve Trophy races, chief closed-course speed events of the National Air races, which open here tomorrow, the entry list was officially closed after sundown tonight.
Colonel Americus Mitchell, U.S.A., retired, died at Tuscumbia, Ala., yesterday at the age of 68. He was a native of Alabama and graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1895.

Some of the old Paddy's Market, housed in new quarters in a lot on West Thirty-ninth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, already faces a factional dispute. A rival group of the former Ninth Avenue pushcart peddlers is trying to use the historic name.
Governor Earle interfered today with an attempt by Democratic officials to obtain campaign contributions from members of the Pennsylvania motor police.

From England is the big news for this first day of a long week-end; it concerns an English importation which will be showing up around these parts come November. The play is "Spring Meeting," by M. J. Farrell and John Perry.

With the exception of $50,000,000 of treasury bills of the Dominion of Canada, sales of new Canadian bond issues in August were the smallest for any month this year, according to the Dominion Securities Corporation.
Fourteen United States Navy planes arrived at the fleet air base at Coco Solo, Canal Zone, at 1:30 P. M. (2:30 P. M., E.S.T.) today, completing a flight from San Diego, Cal.

Colonel James E. Chaney, recently appointed commandant of this Army Air Corps post, will assume his new duties tomorrow, Colonel Thomas J. Hanley announced today. Colonel Chaney has been assistant chief of the Air Corps at Randolph Field, Texas.
Mr. Farley's visit to Maine was chiefly for the purpose of helping Mr. Dubord, Democratic candidate for Representative in Congress in the Second District.
Opposition to any move to substitute British labor legislation for the Wagner Act was expressed today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Having once been a track campaigner, I feel what I have to say is important-and wholly true. Amateur athletes in the United States must adhere to strict rules, on the making of which they have no-voice.

Despite the fact that the salt water is giving up a lot of fish, a legion of New Jersey anglers are forsaking the heavier tackle for fly rods and taking advantage of the thirty-day Fall trout season which opened in that State on Thursday.

Today's developments furnished considerable encouragement for the New York Football Giants as they continued training at the Blue Hills Country Club in preparation for their game with the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds Wednesday night, as well as their National League opener at Pittsburgh a week from Sunday.

In the last year more than 10,000 candidates received teaching licenses from the New York City School system, Dr. Joseph K.. Van Denburg, acting chairman of the board of examiners, disclosed in a report covering the 1937-38 academic year ended July 1, made public yesterday.

Before the Mexican Government sent a formal answer yesterday to the latest note of our State Department, President Cardenas took the unusual course of announcing to a cheering crowd in a public speech what his Government would say.
Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado" was performed yesterday at the Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, by members of the alliance between the ages of 10 and 16.

A canceled check for $500, talk heard on a tapped wire and the testimony of Max D. Steuer, lawyer and intimate friend of James J. Hines, were put in evidence yesterday to buttress the story of J. Richard Davis that the district leader got money from the policy racket and was connected with Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.
The Senators beat the Athletics, 4 to 2, today on Southpaw Ken Chase's seven-hit pitching and Al Simmons's twentieth home run of the season. Simmons also hit a three-bagger.

The Cuban House of Representatives tonight elected Marcelino Garriga, Liberal, of Pinar del Rio Province, president of the House to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Antonio Martinez Fraga on Aug. 2.

The Italian motorship Conte di Savoia is due to sail today for Mediterranean ports. Passengers are Sir Charles Gordon, president of the Bank of Montreal, and Lady Gordon,Mohamed Hassan Youssef, Egyptian Consul General in New York, and Mme. Youssef, Captain Ugo R. Giachery, G. V. Lombardi, Robert Coons, John J. Reed, Mrs. Mathilde A. Stier, Miss Esther Pearson, Mrs. Roy G. Pratt, Mr. and Mrs. George A. Blackmore and Dr. Rocco Quattrone.
The retirement of Major Gen. Fox Conner, U. S. A., on Sept. 30 because of physical disabilities was announced today by the War Depart-

A stocky brunette from New York City ran away today with the girls' national grass court tennis championship. Miss Helen Bernhard, 17, swung one steady, sure stroke after another in the final to defeat Miss Margaret Jessee, 16, of Sacramento, Calif., 6-3, 6-0.
Factional feeling among the Democrats of the Eastern Shore, Maryland's ultra conservative sector, continued to rise steadily today, with President Roosevelt's visit to the State only three days off.

Marking its tenth anniversary, the Boston Conference on Distribution to be held Sept. 26 and 27 in the Hotel Statler, Boston, will be addressed by thirty-one speakers, with a good portion of the program devoted to world aspects of distribution.

Favored by magnificent weather, a naval show was staged offshore here today in connection with the celebration of Queen Wilhelmina's fortieth jubilee. Thousands of spectators crowded all available vantage points to watch the naval parade led by two torpedo boats.

A sharp increase in retail institutional advertising will feature the National Retail Demonstration to be held during the week of Sept. 19. The committee in charge of the demonstration is requesting the advertising.executive of each store to run at least ten to sixteen inches of institutional copy as part of each ad during the week.
Fifteen craft entered for the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's nineteenth annual race out around Stratford Shoal, off Bridgeport, Conn., and back, which was started at 9:40 o'clock tonight.

Tomorrow Mr. Roosevelt advances into the Eastern Shore of Maryland. This region, especially its lower counties, is almost a State within the State. It has its own traditions, character and way of life. Once its counties were almost as English as their names. It was Anglican, sporting, manorial. If the aristocratic regime has long passed, the district, chiefly rural, and its inhabitants have a marrow and tang of their own.

The Misses Lilian and Marion Leale of 383 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Bianca Marvin Leale, to Alexander Gilchrist Hawes Cerf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Cerf of Montclair, N. J., and Quogue, L. I.

Celebrating his 100th birthday today, Alfred G. Randall of Hunter Lake and Tarrytown, attributed his long life to his regularity of living. He kept open house at his Summer home for a time this afternoon.

The Holland-America Line announced yesterday that Willem H. de Monchy, managing director of the line in Rotterdam, had been made an officer of the Order of Oranje-Nassau, by Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands, in recognition of his work in directing the construction of the new flagship Nieuw Amsterdam.
Under the heaviest volume of hedging operations of the season, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke yesterday into new low ground for the movement to end with losses of 10 to 15 points.
Lord Fitzwilliam's Snipe Wood, 4-year-old colt by Hurstwood-Becassine, today won the Prince Edward Handicap Plate over two miles, two furlongs and seventy-five yards.

Sales of multi-family buildings and dwellings in Brooklyn were reported yesterday. The Ridge Holding Corporation sold for cash over a first mortgage of $43,000 the four-story apartment house at 1,714 Sixty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

A gay party took place at the Newport Country Club clubhouse tonight. It was the annual White Elephant ball, arranged by a group of the young people of the Summer colony. Those attending appeared in a wide variety of costumes.

The Curtis Cup teams of Great Britain and the United States, which will oppose each other at the Essex Country Club in Manchester, Mass., Wednesday and Thursday, are practicing diligently there for the competition, in which three teams for each side will engage in Scotch foursome matches on the opening day, to be followed by six singles matches the next.

Miss Peggy Taylor Mifflen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Mifflen of Wykagyl Gardens, New Rochelle, was married here this morning to William Randolph Cosby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Cosby, also of New Rochelle.

Envious landlubbers who couldn't tell a stuffing box from a compass rose or a chock from a skag, but would like to know how, may imagine that a yachtman's life is all beer and skittles. But they don't know the half of it. They don't realize the pains and heartaches, the disappointment and jealousies which beset the yachtsman every September.

IN June, 1936, I took a company of actors, camera men and technicians--twenty-four in all--to the tiny and remote island of Foula, off the coast of the Shetlands in the North Sea to make a motion picture.
THERE is nothing so very formidable about The Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America. They are scholarly but not too learned or profound,

Several sales of estates and homes in various parts of Westchester County were reported yesterday. The Lucidor, former Kohn estate at Purdy, has been sold to William L. Dawe of New York, who will occupy it shortly.

Louis Lallemand, former marriage license bureau clerk, of 886 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, died Friday at Crown Heights Hospital, 460 Lefferts Avenue. Brooklyn, where he had undergone an operation a week ago. His age was 56. Recently he had been private secretary to Surrogate James A. Delehanty.

THERE'S been nothing like it in the Ozarks since the Civil War. Two weeks ago today, the Missouri Highway Department clocked one thousand cars an hour over the big bridge on U. S. Highway 71, and 700 of them turned across the little bridge into Noel, Mo., a sleepy Summer resort on the Elk River in the Ozarks,

LONDON.-Britain's recently inaugurated plan for the employment of a large force of highway "courtesy cops," who would politely chide erring motorists instead of issuing summonses, is now suffering from a lack of suitable police recruits.

The causes of the sporadic price cutting in liquor which has characterized the market here for more than a year are so deep that fairtrade contracts are ineffectual, according to dealers. They declared last week that the instability of the market stems not only from competition among retailers, but also from failure of distillers and wholesalers to maintain case-lot price lists.

Campaign headquarters of Senator Lonergan revised upward tonight its original estimates of 1.000 votes for his renomination in the Democratic State Convention of 1,100 delegates which will meet Sept. 13-14.

The Sanjak of Alexandretta henceforth will be known as the Hatay Republic, according to resolution adopted by the Parliament here today. The Sanjak of Alexandretta, now the Hatay Republic, became an autonomous State under a treaty concluded in June between France and Turkey.

A defender and seven ambitious challengers for the thirty-fifth award of the famous Gold Cup on Labor Day are here on the Detroit River scene, but two of the eight speed-boat camps still face qualifying worries.

Patrolman William Morey, who was held under guard at the Fifth Avenue station, Brooklyn, after Vincent Daniels, 29 years old, of 11 St. Marks Avenue, Brooklyn, a companion, had wounded himself critically Friday with the patrolman's pistol, was released yesterday after Daniels had absolved him of all blame.
Both sides in Maryland's sharply contested Democratic primary are saying that they will benefit by President Roosevelt's two-day visit to the State.

WASHINGTON.-Uncle Sam is putting-up the money to take the "fur" off Georgia peaches. High-speed de-furring machines run with electricity furnished by a rural power cooperative financed with a loan from the Rural Electrification Administration are now in operation in Upson County, Ga., the REA announces.

TWO new viewers for studying natural - color transparencies will soon reach the market. Accommodating standard 2x2 inch mounted slides, 35mm. strip film, and having extra channels for both 8 and 16mm. movie film, the viewers are available with or without a hole punch for marking strip film for selection.

Emil E. way E. Fuchs, chairman of the Massachusetts Unemployment Compensation Commission, and former president and part-owner of the Boston National League Ball Club, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy Federal court today.

John Marion, husky Negro from Prairie View College, Texas, smashed Phil Edwards's Canadian 1,000-yard record at the Canadian National Exhibition track meet-today, racing the distance in 2 minutes 10 6-10 seconds. The time was one-fifth of a second better than Edwards's mark, established over the same track in 1933.

TWO hundred and fifty years ago a youth knocked at the door of a pastor in the English town of Bedford. The young man had come from Reading to seek advice; he had quarreled with his father; he knew that the pastor had a great reputation as a peacemaker.

Retail trade, although improving in a few districts, where volume was within a few points of .1937, was sharply lower in others, and the last week of Summer brought spotty results for the country as a whole. Farm crop cash moved more freely, and back-to-school buying helped to lift sales elsewhere.

Miss Elizabeth Weld Betz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard W. Betz of this place, was married to Hollister Sturges Jr., editor and publisher of The Ulster County Press, here today in the First Dutch Reformed Church.

Efforts to bring the two rival labor movements and industry together on a plan for joint support of labor-industry legislation have been shattered for the time being by the growing bitterness between the C. I. O. and A. F. of L., according to comment here last week among promoters of the plan.

Legal difficulties of statistical reporting are studied by Benjamin S. Kirsh and-Harold Roland Shapiro in the current issue of the United States Law Review, to which they have contributed an article on "Trade Association Reporting Under the Anti-Trust Laws."

IT is seldom that Congressional elections and the primaries preceding them arouse the intense interest which this year's campaign commands. The nation has been anxiously watching the outcome of Mr. Roosevelt's attempt to "purge" the Democratic party of conservative elements; throughout the land men and women are wondering whether the Novemberr elections will forward the President's desire to remold our chief political parties along liberal-conservative lines.

Germans are on the marchfrom lively youngsters to husky, brown-shirted Storm Troopers-to rally around Chancellor Adolf Hitler in the tenth annual congress of the Nazi party at Nuremberg. The congress will open Monday and will run for eight days during which the Fuehrer will make several major speeches.

UNDER the influence of tragic world events, Hungarian literature has developed certain escapist tendencies. The present is overshadowed by the great national disaster of twenty years ago, when the country lost two-thirds of its territory. Now that Hitler's realm is less than an hour's airplane ride from Budapest, the future is uncertain.

The largest order ever placed with the Whitehead Metal Products Company of New York has just been received from the Olentangy Village apartment development nearing completion near Columbus, Ohio, J. J. Whitehead,

The Autumn hunts racing season will get off to an auspicious start Saturday with the fifth renewal of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase over the famous du Pont course of the Foxcatcher Hounds at Fair Hill, Md.

German troops, believed to number more than 50,000, moved today into the Reich's new Siegfried chain of fortifications facing France's steel and concrete Maginot line. Frenchmen in the frontier regions were calm as generally accepted reports said the German troops were strung along the entire FrenchGerman border from Luxembourg to Kehl, opposite Strasbourg.

SINCE the advent of broadcasting it has always been said that the season ends on St. Patrick's Day and opens again on Labor Day. This is apparently true because a long list of old-time performers have announced plans to return to the Autumn air.

One block of houses is nearly completed and five more blocks are expected to be completed in time for Fall occupancy at the University Manor development opposite the Hillcrest Golf and Country Club at Union Turnpike and Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, L. I. Eight homes already have been sold from plans. Druss-Taubkin are the builders.

With no intention of following the undistinguished example of the Washington Redskins who bowed to an All-Star team last week, the New York Giants will clash with the Eastern All-Stars at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night in a game that is expected to draw a crowd of 45,000.

THE English "Dictionary of National Biography." which has been followed by the no less meritorious enterprise of the "Dictionary of American Biography," is now to have a further sequel. The Cymmrodorion Society has announced its intention to produce a "Dictionary of Welsh Biography,"

H. M. Byllesby Co. announced today that the decision of the Wisconsin Banking Commission reaffirming its order of July 25 revoking their license to sell utilities securities in Wisconsin would be appealed immediately to the Wisconsin Banking Review Board and a petition of appeal filed with the Circuit Court of Dane County, Wis.

Two persons escaped injury at 9 o'clock last night in an automobile that crashed through a six-foot iron guardrail on the New York Central Railroad cut at Park Avenue, near 178th Street, and was plunging toward the tracks below when it struck the top of a southbound railroad train and rebounded back to the sidewalk above.

The New York World's Fair, besides donating a trophy to the outstanding collegiate player, will also award one to the best Giant in the benefit game between the Eastern All-Stars and the Maramen on Wednesday night, it was announced yesterday.

To the Art Editor: THE late George Luks, when asked whether a certain painting was not "typically French," replied (and we prudently omit the explosive preface: "-- No! It's a work of art!" If you can say "we have an American art because we are Americans," is it not possible to find a more basic postulate?

An increasing preference for American goods in Scandinavian stores which, however, cannot be satisfied because of important restrictions and costs of transportation, was reported here yesterday by H. I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. He has just returned from a sevenweeks' trip in which he visited retail establishments in Sweden, Denmark and Norway.

The Spanish Insurgents, concentrating troops, planes and guns on the strategic Ebro River front in Catalonia, launched an extensive new offensive at dawn today in an attempt to break through strong government lines that had held them without advances on this front for more than a month.

Miss Hope Haney, daughter of Lewis Henry Haney, columnist, and Professor of Economics at New York University, and Mrs. Haney, was married here this afternoon to William Henry West Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. West of New York and Grove Beach, Conn.
The Fighter and Fair Stein were the stake winners at Aqueduct yesterday before 15,000 persons, who saw the former conquer five others and the mare equal the mile and five-sixteenths track record.

Backing up Deacon Danny MacFayden's pitching with airtight fielding, the Bees today shut out the Phillies, 1 to 0, to open a home stay they hoped would carry them into the first division. Three rapid-fire singles in the third inning, with two gone, gave the Bees the only run of the game.

A second severe typhoon within a week is now rapidly approaching Japan proper, but it cannot yet be said exactly where and when it will strike, the Central Meteorological Observatory states today. It issued a typhoon warning.

The Royal Baking Powder Company, a subsidiary of Standard Brands, Inc., New York City, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine alleged deficiencies of $14,427 income taxes and $1,061 excess profits taxes for 1934, and $20,140 income taxes for 1933.
American Airlines, Inc., announced tonight negotiations had been completed for the rental of facilities at North Beach Airport in Astoria, Queens, N. Y.

Continuing its rise, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 84.8 for the week ended Aug. 27. It compares with 84.2 (revised) for the previous week and 109.4 for the corresponding week a year ago.

JAMES BARTON has been shuffling down "Tobacco Road" so long now that even old friends introduce him to audiences as a "legitimate actor." On behalf of Billy Rose's "Streamlined Varieties," in its sixth edition at the Casa Manana, Mr. Barton reverts to an earlier day and proves that at heart he is no such thing.

Two of the six teams that include in their ranks some of the greatest players of three countries, will start the year's national open polo championship today, with the first game scheduled for 4 o'clock on famous International Field at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L. I.

The Athletics bowed to the Senators, 7 to 0, today, for their fifth straight loss. Stopped yesterday by southpaw Ken Chase, the Athletics were even less effective against Joe Krakauskas, who allowed only three safeties. Only one was out of the infield.

Eighteen new school buildings and additions to old buildings-the largest number since 1930--are scheduled to be ready for occupancy when school reopens on Monday, Sept. 12, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell. Superintendent of Schools.

Dr. Bernhard Kahn, European chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, arrived last week on the HollandAmerica liner Nieuw Amsterdam to confer with the officers of the committee here concerning the pressing problems of the distressed Jewish communities overseas.

With 40,000 teachers and 1,200,000 children returning to the New York City schools on Monday of next week, it is important that the health of both be amply protected, Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the city schools, warned yesterday.
Miss Geraldine Isabel McCaslin and William S. Koenig, both of this city, were married yesterday morning in the chapel of the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. B. A. McLaughlin.

ABOUT 400 of the country's stamp collectors have returned to their homes after attending one of the liveliest conventions of the Society of Philatelic Americans, which concluded a three-day session Aug. 27 at the Hotel La Salle.

The United States team of twenty fired the Dewar international small bore rifle match today and finished with a record 7,953 out of a possible 8,000 to regain the trophy, won by Great Britain last year. The total topped by 4 points the mark of 7,949 set by American shooters in 1934.
RAIL travel is expected to show an upward swing this month, aided by the American Legion convention and the reopening of schools and colleges.

The Committee of 500 to Save F. R. sent a telegram to Attorney General John J. Bennett yesterday asking him to declare his position on Amendment No. 7, under which proportional representation voting would be barred in this State and abolished in New York City.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his New York Hippodrome Opera Company brought their season of operatic productions to a close here tonight on the marine stage on Zach's Bay with a performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" before an appreciative audience of 3,000 persons.

Seventeen bombing planes of Naval Patrol Squadron 1 will take off for Honolulu next Wednesday. The flight was described, when it was announced today, as "a routine delivery of new equipment to the fleet air base, Pearl Harbor."

Joseph C. Morris Jr. and Edwin J. Schoettle of Philadelphia, sailing Arrow II of Barnegat Bay, won the opening contest in the tenth annual Jersey Coast challenge series for International Star Class sloops today. Seventeen yachts from five fleets, Eastern Shore of Chesapeake Bay, Long Island Sound, Ocean City, Gravesend Bay and Barnegat Bay, competed over an eleven-mile course.
Mrs. Lizzie D. Smith, widow of Elliott J. Smith, attorney here for many years, died yesterday in her home. She was 78 years old.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tuesday American Express Co.

ALEXANDER -- SCHAFLER - Mrs. Sadie Schafler announces the marriage of her daughter, Grace, to Stanley H. Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Alexander, Thursday, Sept. 1. BAUM--OSK-Mr. Barnett Osk announces the marriage of his daughter, Fanny, of 161 West 75th St., New York, to Gabriel Baum of Brooklyn, Aug. 27.

Exactly one week after New York's Constitutional Convention refused to remove a ban it had voted on elections by proportional representation anywhere in that State, the Philadelphia City Charter Commission recommended "P. R." as the "keystone" of a proposed new charter for this city.

Two boys, imprisoned in a patch of quicksand on the Kearny shore of the Hackensack River for almost three hours tonight, were rescued after one of them managed to pull himself to safety and climb the girders of the Pulaski Skyway fifty feet to the roadway.

Miss Hildreth Barbara Fleck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank X. Fleck of Garden City, was married to Burton F. Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Hall of New Britain, Conn., this morning by the Rev. Edward McManus in St. Joseph's Church here.

An alleged campaign designed to deter residents of the Federal model suburban community project at Green Hills, Ohio, near Cincinnati, from making cooperative purchases attracted attention in distribution circles here last week. The reported drive is the first of its kind and was held significant from the standpoint of moves to line up the independent retailers against cooperative distribution.

A nation-wide "modernize for Winter" movement, designed to stimulate construction and repairs, will be started this month by building supply dealers throughout the country under the leadership of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, which has a membership of 23,000.
RECORD: A monoplane took off from New York's Floyd Bennett Field one day last week; 10 hours and 3 minutes later it landed at Los Angeles. Major Alexander P.

Miss Helen Fisher Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Parsons of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Ridgeview Congregational Church to John Crawford Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Pierce of Springfield, Vt., by the Rev. Everett W. MacNair.

THE most recent wave of invision and conquest to sweep over Central Asia is Russian. When Lenin was successful, the Bolsheviki started a great campaign to release the proletariat of Central Asia from its bonds. First organizers found great confusion.

With the high-goal players, except for one or two, resting for the opening of the national championship, three of the games in the Autumn Plates tournament were decided today, all in the twelve-goal division of play.

Long-continued heat and drought are increasing the forest fire menace in the Ural Mountain area in extreme Eastern Russia. On the slopes of the Urals in Sverdlovsk Province, forty-four fires were reported burning today.

This season's pack of Alaskan salmon through Aug. 30 totaled 5,992,964 cases, the Department of Commerce reported today. The total consisted of 2,473,111 cases of red salmon,* 2.638,157 of pinks, 678,346 of chums, 160,596 of cohos and 42,754 cases of kings.

Five hundred persons, among them many leaders in society and philanthropic causes, attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

IN spite of the financial fluctuations of the franc, French stock--figuratively speaking--is selling pretty high in the motionpicture industry these days. A succession of exceptional French films, which have reached these shores during the past few years, have attracted the same attention to the French as was devoted to the Germans a decade or so ago:
