In July and again in August the United States Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, addressed notes of mounting sharpness to the government of Mexico. He referred to the expropriation of American-owned farms below the Rio Grande for distribution among landless peons, and to the fact that the owners had not been paid except in promises.

United States swimmers won five events and lost one as a twoday meet between American and European stars opened today. Peter Fick, the New York Athletic Club's star free-style swimmer, won the 100 meters in 0:59.4 and qualified for the United States relay team, which will race against Europe's best tomorrow.
THE story of the organization that is now the Dallas Symphony Society is a striking example of the persistence with which a community has striven, despite many discouragements. to realize an ideal.

Miss Madeline Frances Goodwin was married to Lieutenant Arthur Edwin Owen, U. S. N., here today at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Goodwin. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George C. Ehardt of St. Agnes Church, New York.

WHILE tension in Central Europe increases from day to day, the Balkans, former powder-box of Europe, are becoming increasingly peaceful. Less than two weeks ago two Balkan powers, Rumania and Yugoslavia, together with their ally in the Little Entente, Czechoslovakia,

Europe waited last week on the word of one man, Adolf Hitler, who in the stillness of his mountain retreat at Berchtesgaden was deciding policies that for the Continent might mean the choice between war and peace.
AT a dinner given in honor of William Butler Yeats in Chicago, the chairman, preparatory to introducing the poet, began an eloquent eulogy. A strange droning sound

James Bridie's "The Last Trump," one of the most successful productions of Malvern's recent festival, will shortly be presented in the West End. Sir Seymour Hicks will have the lead and Cecil Trouncer will repeat his richly humorous study of an old Scottish doctor.

HOLLYWOOD is establishing a ritual that cannot but foster warm sentiments along the River Thames. Advance showings of the larger films in London, especially if they have a touch of hands-across-thesea, are, unlike try-outs of new plays, in the nature of a compliment and, held under the proper auspices, they thaw out the most glacial and snarkiest of dukes.

After detectives testified that the 2-year-old boy she was alleged to have kidnapped had not been harmed nor held for ransom, Magistrate Michael A. Ford in Felony Court yesterday held Vivian Platte, 18, no address, in $2,500 bail for a hearing' Thursday.
The Western Utilities Corporation, San Francisco, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $550,000 of 6 per cent sinking fund notes, due in 1952.

Championship honors in the hunter division of the ninety-fifth annual Orangeburg Fair Horse Show were awarded today to Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke of Tuxedo Park, N. Y. The champion was the chesthut mare, Because, ridden in most of her classes by Mrs. Duke.

Professor W. K. Gregory, curator of comparative anatomy at the American Museum of Natural History and Professor of Paleontology at Columbia University, returned yesterday from South Africa, where he studied the fossilized remnants of gorilla-like animals that lived in the Pleistocene Age and which had certain man-like characteristics indicating that they were advanced beyond the ape stage.

The Friends Meeting House here, built in 1790, was the scene at noon today of the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Smedley of this place to Moyer Wood of Port Washington, L. I. Traditional Quaker rites were observed at the ceremony.

NEXT week the Theatre Council will discuss, among other things, the relationship of the theatre to the impending World's Fair. That is a good and sufficiently innocuous topic for a general assembly; but, if the truth be known, it does not interest people of the theatre much.
A dispatch by Domei, Japanese News agency, from Seoul, Korea, said today a group of alleged radicals, held since May 19, had been released upon their promise to become loyal subjects of the empire.

Grand prize in the first annual baby parade of the Bretton Woods Yacht Club was awarded today to David John Doran 3d, 3 1/2 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Doran Jr. of Brooklyn. A total of fortytwo entries appeared in the parade.

WHEN Nina Warner Hooke wrote "Close of Play" as a sequel to "Striplings" she said in a foreword, "Perhaps there will be more to come. Perhaps not." Everybody who had been shocked. pleased and fascinated by the utterly unconventional childhood of Biff and Netta on a dilapidated Sussex estate hoped to hear more of them.

WASHINGTON. -- As headline makers Texas Congressmen are setting the pace this Summer. Chairman of the special Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures, Senator Morris Sheppard, dean of Congress, is keeping many candidates in the primaries and elections on the anxious seat.

An army pursuit plane from Langley Field, Va., crashed into a threeroom house near here today and injured three of the eight occupants. Fog and rain forced down twelve pursuit planes in this vicinity, including the one which struck the house.

THE industry is treading on dangerous ground with its mania for series pictures. This is the opinion of Max Golden, who started the cycle with the "Jones Family," the first of which was "Every Saturday Night," made by Twentieth Century-Fox in 1936. Golden is now at Universal,

Haverford College alumni cricketers today opposed an eleven representing the Brooklyn C. C. which last season captued all three titles competed for by leading clubs in the East. After an excellent exhibition of batting, victory rested with the alumni team by a margin of 27 runs.

New Zealand is turning to the United States for ideas for the con??truction of moderate-priced homes. The Government of New Zealand has as part of its program the provision of homes for low-salaried working people, and plans have thus far been worked out for about 5,000 houses.

Arrangements have been completed by the field trial committee of the American Chesapeake Club for the annual field trial meeting of that organization Nov. 11, 12 and 13. New grounds have been obtained for the event, and it is believed by the committee that they will meet every requirement for a thorough test of Chesapeake Bay retrievers.

Synthetic manufacture of food, fuel, paint, hormones, vitamins, rubber, wood and a host of other things vital to everyday life will be the theme of the American Chemical Society meeting here this week.

Government inspectors assigned to protect the nation's consumers against harmful foods, drugs and cosmetics have begun to enforce the new Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act. Already quantities of cosmetics for eye make-up, as well as drugs and foodstuffs, have been seized in different parts of the country.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Cuthbert of this place and Choke Cherry Island, Chippewa Bay, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Jean Cuthbert, to Loren Thompson Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Loren Newton Wood of Bound Brook, N. J.

As a result of the epidemic of sleeping sickness among livestock this year, more than 500,000 horses in the United States and Canada have been immunized by a vaccine from virus grown on chick embryos, it is reported from the offices of the Lederle Laboratories in Rockefeller Center.

BRIDGE clubs celebrate Labor Day as the best holiday of the year because it marks the beginning of the end of Summer's dull season. The increase in rubber play is felt almost at once, and attendance zooms at those duplicate games which have been continued despite the smaller turnouts of the season.

Joe Lucas, a sophomore guard, became Fordham's first football casualty of the season yesterday when he sprained his left ankle while taking part in the individual blocking drill for guards during the Maroon's workout at Fordham Field.

Permitting only one runner to get as far as third base, Lefty Max Macon hurled five-hit ball today as his Cardinal team-mates pounded two pitchers to shut out the National League-leading Pirates, 6-0. It was the second consecutive victory for St. Louis over Pittsburgh In the three-game series.

Britain is standing by to hear from Adolf Hitler. Up to a late hour tonight no official information had reached London of what happened between him and Konrad Henlein at, the Chancellor's mountain retreat at Berchtesgaden.

Westchester County could obtain approximately $4,000,000 annually for relief purposes by levying a 2 per cent sales tax on general merchandise and a one-cent tax on each package of cigarettes, supervisors estimated today while County Attorney William A. Davidson studied the legality of such levies.

Sergeant Frederick G. Reiff, attached to the police emergency crew stationed at the Grand Avenue station in Brooklyn, returned from his vacation yesterday afternoon just in time to catch an alleged burglar prowling about his two-story house at 231 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn.

ABRAHAMS-Sadie (nee Peiser), beloved mother of Emanuel, Raymond and Florence Abeles, dear sister of Jacob. Leo, Joseph and Beatrice Peiser. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St.-Amsterdam Ave., Sunday. Sept. 4, at 11 A. M. Interment Beth-El Cemetery, Long Island. Atlantic City papers please copy. ABRAHAM--We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved member, Sadie Abrahams. THE SPERLING FAMILY CIRCLE.

The Rumanian Minister to Berlin made a hasty visit to Bucharest today to report to Foreign Minister Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen on German-Rumanian relations. He returned to Berlin tonight. The visit is believed to be connected with the present intensive diplomatic activity between Bucharest and Warsaw on the question of Rumania's and

DRESSING UP: New York's famous Statue of Liberty has for several weeks greeted incoming and outgoing vessels without her crown The seven familiar spikes, ranging from eight to eleven feet in length, have been removed, victims of weathering. Last week WPA workers began to replace the copper spikes in Miss Liberty's crown.

The semi-centennial celebration of the founding of the American Mathematical Society will be held at Columbia University from Tuesday through Friday of this week. Thomas S. Fiske, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics, is to act as chairman.

With the second printing of the first bulletin of the "Friends of the Public Schools of America," edited by Major Gen. Amos A. Fries, the conflict over Federal aid to education heads toward a climax in the next session of Congress when legislation granting such aid to the States may be considered early.

Mrs. Mary B. Scott, wife of Charles R. Scott, retired banker, and daughter of the late Henry B. Hyde, founder of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died in Paris on Friday after a short illness at the age of 72, according to word received here yesterday. She had maintained an apartment at 1,015 Park Avenue.

A reference list of "warning signs" whereby the moderate drinker can tell when he is in danger of drifting into drunkenness is made available in a pamphlet on temperance, just published by the State Liquor Authority.

Westbound traffic between New York, Jersey City and Newark on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad under the Hudson River was tied up for thirty-five minutes beginning at 8:19 o'clock last night when the block signal system lights went out. The trouble was traced to a short circuit in a high-tension power line.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Alfred K. Stern's recent letter in THE TIMES states in effect that the minimum in private dwellings could not be produced for less than $5,500, that such dwellings could not be sold at a monthly carrying charge of less than $66 and that the construction thereof would serve- only to benefit families with annual incomes from $3,000 to $5,000.

HERE is a writer with a blend of qualities which is most rare-and most welcome: a capacity to grasp and portray the significance of present-day political happenings on the shores of the Mediterranean and the rich pageantry of the centuries behind

THE Police Department of Cleveland, Ohio, is installing what is described as "the most extensive and modern two-way radio system in the world," designed for instantaneous communication with all parts of the city and with police units in fifty-six suburbs

A growing field of opportunity for otherwise untrained middle-aged women is revealed in the merging of two WPA projects in New York City.- It is a free housekeeping service for chronically ill and aged persons, sponsored jointly by the Mayor and the Department of Hospitals and carried on in cooperation with the Henry Street Nursing Service and the Committee on Chronic Illness of the Welfare Council.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, through its chairman, William O. Douglas, has issued an ultimatum to all registered public utility holding companies to present plans for the integration of systems by Dec. 1,

Reminiscences of school days in Europe will come to former soldierstudents of the A. E. F. this month as plans proceed for a reunion of World War Veterans, who in the Spring of 1919, were assigned at their own request to educational centers established to help while
The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that it had lent $11,600,000 to the Dairy Products Marketing Association at Chicago for the purchase of 40,000,000 pounds of surplus butter.

The National Socialist party congress, which opens at Nuremberg on Monday, will meet in the receding flush of national jubilation over the Reich's union with Austria and the advent of Great Germany, but its deliberations will, nevertheless, also reflect concern over the outcome of the Czech crisis.

In South Carolina, in Reconstruction days, white Democrats, out to re-establish the supremacy of their. party and race, put on red shirts as a uniform. Bands of Red Shirts galloped across the countryside, holding their own political rallies, heckling speakers for the Republican regime of "carpet-bagger" whites that had been erected on the basis of Negro votes.

the corn loans are expected to check this expansion, AAA officials hope, sufficiently to prevent overdoing it. Generally speaking, the participant appears to have come out ahead on his bargain, especially if he is a commercial grower.

With school opening next week, the stores are outdoing themselves in back-to-school outfits for youngsters. Clothes for little boys and girls of the grammar-school age have real styles that change nowadays, and this holds true more this year than ever.
With the New York State conventions less than a month away, both Republicans and Democrats, the latter in a somewhat panicky mood, are giving thought to their State tickets.

A Greyhound bus and an automobile crashed near here late tonight killing five persons and injuring at least fourteen. The bus, crowded with thirty-eight passengers, careened down a fifteen-foot embankment and overturned.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The newspaper announcement of new group medical practice schemes in New York is "the most unkind cut of all" to a noble and honorable profession, the great majority of whose members have tried to practice according to the code and ethics established since the time of Aesculapius. This has been a tremendous handicap, in face of our modern ballyhoo and gigantic advertising of fake medicine and cures.

Continuing activity in the homebuilding industry in New Jersey is revealed in comparative figures released yesterday by Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey State FHA Director, showing the dollar volume of applications fo home-mortgage insurance received each week during July and August, 1937 and 1938.
A Black and White Ball was held at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight. The event was arranged by the entertainment committee headed by Harold H. Sherburne.
CAPE VERDE ISLAND coins minted in 1930 have just put in appearance in collections of American numismatists, the most recent being the 50-centavos piece of nickel alloy.

Fragrance in a garden is proverbial, and yet how often, in the rock garden, it is completely overlooked. Perhaps it is because so many of our more common rock garden plants have no odor at all that we do not associate fragrance with them.

Stockholders of the Phillips Petroleum Company have purchased $23,674,500 of convertible 3 per cent debentures due on Sept. 1, 1948, out of the total of $25,000,000 offered them, the company announced yesterday.

Of the more than three hundred young women who are to be presented to society in the 1938-39 season in the East and South, more than twenty have chosen to have their parties n country homes and country clubs in the North Shore colonies this month.

ASHEVILLE, N. C.-Three conAventions, a Labor Day program and a concert by the Municipal Orchestra are scheduled here this week. The annual three-day convention of the North Carolina Cosmetologists Association will open today at the George Vanderbilt Hotel.

NEW YORK television camera men are hopeful that they may be given a chance this Autumn to test their electrical optics on football. Spurred by the activity overseas in telecasting cricket, soccer, tennis and boat races,
Miss Maribel Yerxa Vinson, skating star, was married to Guy Rochon Owen, Canadian skater, at a simple home wedding today at noon with only members of the immediate families present.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Elizabeth Deknatel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francois Heyse Deknatel of Mount Vernon, N. Y., to Herbert Henry Smith Hinman of Chester, Pa., took place here this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lee Ashton.

The United States team virtually clinched possession of the Davis Cup for another, year by taking the opening two singles matches in the challenge round series with the Australians. Robert L. Riggs Jr. carried off the individual honors of the day by rallying to defeat Adrian K. Quist, 4-6, 6-0, 8-6, 6-1, in the first contest at the Germantown Cricket Club.

ITALY'S program of open-air "opera for the masses" is now being carried out with great success on a nation-wide scale unthought of during the first modest efforts of a decade or two ago. The enterprise is well worth watching for its simultaneous solution of both economic and artistic problems of operatic mass production, let alone other aspects.

THE writer finds himself this week in a position of embarrassment. Apart from a musical piece at the Hippodrome there has been but one openingthat of a play called "She, Too, Was Young," by Hilda Vaughan and Laurier Lister, at Wyndham's. Hilda Vaughan bears by marriage the name that appears at the foot of this article.

The home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Kennedy of Lincoln Way East, this city, was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Nancy Lavinia Kennedy, to Robert C. Gordon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon of Chambersburg.

Maximum points have been obtained by only six English football clubs although the league season is barely more than a week old. Everton, Fulham, Blackburn Rovers, Northampton Town, Rotherham United and Oldham Athletic are the pace-setting teams.

The European Danubian Commission, inaugurated eighty-two years ago, will cease to function over the lower Danube from Braila to the Black Sea in a few days. The commissioners' extraterritorial privileges have been rescinded and the Rumanian authorities have taken over their full sovereignty.

To grow up without settling down is the perpetual problem of any institution. Settling down, which unfortunately is often effected without growing up, carries in the very phrase dead weight: to get in a rut and stay there, to fear change, to lose a sense of wonder, excitement and belief in the impossible.

Gaylemakinnie, owned by C. H. Bowen of Columbus, Ohio, and driven by Harry Short, won the $1,000 Hilton Stake, feature event of the closing day of the Grand Circuit meeting at the New York State Fair today, taking all three heats with little opposition. The brown gelding was the only favorite to triumph.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was light, and prices, for the most part, ended close to the levels of the preceding day. Interest in United States Government obligations continued at a low ebb.

The War Department announced readiness today to start its peacetime "education" of industry to supply war necessities. Under the first year's program selected American industries will receive training orders for dies and other aids to wartime munitions manufacture.

NINE years after its completion, the first section of the West Side Highway is being rebuilt to conform to a new southward extension from Canal Street. The new project, costing more than $2,700,000, is expected to be completed on Feb. 6, 1939.

Senator Pope today pledged his support in the Idaho election campaign to the "entire Democratic ticket," including Representative D. Worth Clark, by whom he was defeated for renomination in the primary Aug. 9.

The American Trader of the United States Lines arrives from London today. Among her passengers are Miss Marie Holl, Miss Alice Edwards, Mrs. Elizabeth W. Gelber, Mrs. Charles C. Keedy, A. C. Hall, Miss Jean S. Davis, Miss C. T.

Paul Runyan, the national P. G. A. champion, and Slamming Sammy Snead couldn't down Vic Ghezzi and Ben Hogan today in the Hershey round-robin, best-ball golf tourney. They finished their match even and left Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., and Hogan, White Plains, N. Y., pro,

WHEN the public schools of the city reopen their doors next week the four-year vocational course in photography sponsored by the New York City Board of Education will begin its second year as quietly as, a year ago, it began its first.

Morris Perr, 21 years old, of 62 Sheriff Street, and Morris Beigeleisen, 28, of 95 Columbia Street, were held for hearing Thursday on charges of attempted robbery by Magistrate William Klapp in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday.

SARANAC.--Group meetings, which are steadily increasing each season during September in the Adirondacks, will this year reach a climax in the gathering of the State of New York Council of School Superintendents, to be held at Saranac Inn on Sept. 25, 26 and 27.

In preparation for the second annual baseball game between teams of the Police Department and the Department of Sanitation scheduled to be played next Sunday at the Yankee Stadium, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey will lead a parade of representatives of their departments to City Hall at noon Wednesday to receive from Mayor La Guardia the trophy that will go to the winning team, it was announced yesterday.

THE seventh National Ceramic Exhibition (Robineau Memorial) will be held from Oct. 27 to Nov. 21 at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts. All work must be received on or before Oct. 15. Canadian ceramists are, for the first time, invited to participate.

Trading in grain futures in the North Amerlcan markets today was of a preholiday character. Prices held within narrow limits. Outside interest was greatly restricted and professional operators were not disposed to take a decided stand on either side.

Into the smashing victory of seventyfour-year old Senator Smith over his youthful opponent, Governor Olin Johnston, many will read opposition to the New Deal in South Carolina, the most Democratic State in the Union. In the last Presidential election above 97 per cent of its ballots were for Roosevelt.

ROBERT BALLOU'S letter to his little son on the subject of religion is really the story of a modern individual's search for God outside the limits of any organized church. Brought up by a saintly mother of simple and orthodox faith,

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 1: CAPTAIN Jordan, J. N., Navy Yard. Washington, D. C., to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Navy Department. COMMANDERS Moloney, 3. B., Med. Corps., Pearl Harbor, T. H., to Naval Training Station, Newport, R. I.

Five new apartment houses which are being completed for Fall occupancy in Jackson Heights, Queens, will provide accommodations for 375 more families in this growing community. The suites range in size from one and one-half to four and one-half rooms.

King Zog granted amnesty to all political refugees abroad in a proclamation issued today in observance of the tenth anniversary of the monarchy. Several Albanians living in the United States were included in the decree, which grants the refugees permission to return home.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Labor Day heralds the opening here of the Showmen's Variety Jubilee, an annual affair which features the beauty and talent pageant and selection of "Miss America."

Rudy York, Detroit catcher, tied the major league record of four home runs with the bases loaded in a season and Pete Fox contributed another homer with two on as the Tigers defeated the White Sox, 11 to 4, today in the first of a two-game series.

A substantial number of member stores in two leading retail groups had higher furniture sales during August than a year ago, it was reported here yesterday. In one case, more than half of the member stores had increases over a year ago, an executive said. In the other, about a third of the stores increases.
With Summer weather staging a last-minute comeback that makes September dates on the calendar seem like a printer's mistake, it may appear a bit early to be thinking about flowers for Christmas.

Chester Leroy Gardner, 40 years old, automobile racing driver of Long Beach, Calif., was killed instantly today when his car apparently got out of control, crashed through a fence and turned over several times at the Flemington Fair Grounds.

In cooperation with the Federal Government, the University of Kentucky Department of Chemistry will operate, as a WPA project, a transportation organization research bureau, according to a recent announcement from the university.

Henry Steele Commager presents in today's TIMES Magazine a penetrating and illuminating study of American party lines. His thesis may be summed up partly in his words and partly in our own. "Almost from the beginning our party alignments have been illogical and fortuitous,

Europe's latest "war crisis" ruled the financial markets last week, and domestic trade and political influences cut relatively small figure. Considering the seriousness of the situation in Europe, the markets held up surprisingly well.
A UNIQUE art organization quietly and effectively carries on its highly specialized work for men and women not usually taken into account in the field of the arts.

Jerome J. Hanauer, retired financier, for many years a partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., died yesterday at the Manoir Richelieu, Murray Bay, Que., of a heart attack, it was announced here last night. His wife was with him when he was stricken. He was 63 years old.

The mystery of the contents of an iron Dutch chest that has lain unopened for 200 years in Gordon Castle, Fochabers, Morayshire, may soon be solved. The chest was sold with other antiques this week. J. Duchart, Perth dealer, paid [Pound]52 for it. He said it might be opened in a few days.

Announcement has been made by Louis C. Haskell of Malone, N. Y., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Ruth Annette Haskell of this city, to John Joseph O'Reilly, son of Thomas J. O'Reilly of 277 Riverside Drive.

Walter Schott, prominent German sculptor died of a heart attack in his Berlin studio today at the age of 76. Professor Schott was best known during the imperial regime, when he created several historical statues.

The Public Service Company of Oklahoma announced yesterday that it is contemplating offering, for a limited time, without any dividend adjustment, one share of its 6 per cent prior lien stock, par value $100, in exchange for each share of $6 preferred stock of the Southwestern Light and Power Company, and one share of the prior lien stock for two shares of the Class A common stock of Southwestern Light.

EXPERIMENTAL telecasts to be sprayed cross New York on ultra-short waves from the aerial rods atop the Empire State Building this week will offer the following variety shows from the Radio City studios:

Representative John J. O'Connor and James H. Fay, his New Deal rival for the Democratic nomination in the Sixteenth Congressional District, aimed statements at each other yesterday, with Mr. Fay assailing his opponent's political philosophy as inimical to organized labor and Mr. O'Connor charging that many names on Mr. Fay's petitions were those of non-existing persons.

Mayor La Guardia appointed a committee yesterday to draft legislation to correct evils in the substitute-teacher system in the city's schools. The Mayor particularly pointed out that the holding of more than one position by many teachers and the high teacher-retirement age resulted in years of delay before substitutes received permanent appointments and in discouragement and stagnation for the substitutes.

William R. Meeks, who reported his wife kidnapped Thursday, issued tonight the following statement, designated for newspaper publication: "Apeal to Kidnappers--Afraid to contact due to publicity. Arrange new contact. Lines clear.

If Round Freddy Fitzsimmons were a talkative fellow he might make one of those "at-long-last" speeches today. For yesterday he won his first decision of the season over the Giants, both by pitching and hitting, as the Dodgers won the series opener at Ebbets Field, 5-4.

THOUGH Bermuda has ruled against the ship-hotel, NasLegislature, on the other hand, last week expressed itself in favor of cruise passengers using steamers as. their hotels while in port if they so desire. While the action, say steamship officials, will make little difference in the number of ships docking at the two islands, the matter is of interest in view of the prolonged controversy over the status of the ship-hotel.

Miss Janet Marsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald E. Marsh of Bronxville, N. Y., was married here today in the rose garden of the Longshore Country Club to Walter Fuller Lathrop of Mystic, Conn., son of Mrs. George Leonard of Franktown. Nev., and the late Walter H. Lathrop.
TODAY Music Hall of the Air presents the Stradivarius String Quartet, Jan Peerce, tenor, and Ignace Strasfogel, pianist, in an hour concert: WJZ. 12:30 P. M.

A department of Biophotography has been established at Rutgers University, President Robert C. Clothier has announced. Dr. Earle B. Perkins, University professor of zoology and Antarctic explorer, has been named its head.
TELEVISION in the home" was the slogan of Radiolympia, London's annual radio exhibition, which closed last night. Each morning visitors were invited to face the electric cameras so that

The rampaging Reds pushed within five games of the league-leading Pirates today by taking a double victory over the Cubs. They won the opener, 6-0, and the final, 7 to 5. The McKechnie men took undisputed possession of second place as Derringer pitched his nineteenth victory of the season in the opener behind the thirteen-hit attack of his team-mates.
Now that Chancellor Adolf Hitler has again taken the leading part on the stage of European politics, Premier Benito Mussolini has been forced to assume the role of supporting actor.

A CITY-WIDE children's arts festival will be held on the Central Park Mall Tuesday and Wednesday. The opening will be attended by prominent city, State and national people. The festival is planned and sponsored by the Public Use of Arts Committee.
SUITS are taking an important place in the 1939 Winter fashion pageant. They set the pace, as it were, for all the new styles. Paris approves many different tailored silhouettes this season.

Under a decision of Justice Julius Miller of the Supreme Court yesterday, John F. Cronin of 327 East Eighty-sixth Street will oppose in the primaries Robert F. Wagner Jr., son of Senator Robert F. Wagner, for the Democratic nomination for Assemblyman in the Sixteenth District.
Hugh W. Ogden, an attorney of Boston, died today while making his annual visit to Bath with his wife. His age was 66. Burial will be in Brookline, Mass.

The Summer regatta schedule for 1939 will look vastly different to the speed boat pilots because of the New York World's Fair. Undercover plans have been quietly under way to have a series of race meets on Flushing Bay for the outboard fleets and for most of the inboard classes below the size of Gold Cup boats.

The use of electricity for power in and about British coal mines was increased by 83,000 horsepower last year, says the annual report of the electrical inspector of mines. The total electrical power in use in mining exceeds 1,000,000 horsepower.

There is one great hope spurring the Japanese to what they think may be victory in China. When Banking fell last December a small group of influential Chinese politicians led by Wang Ching-wei, former Premier and an outstanding member of the Kuomintang, advocated peace.
San Diego, Calif., took a 2-1 lead in games of the national American Legion junior baseball title series today by routing Spartanburg, 10 to 2.
Of all the menaces that face the corn crop from its infancy in May to maturity in September, only that of early frost remains. That is one that seldom works extensive damage.

Despite efforts in some bright tobacco areas to upset AAA production quotas in the courts, and thus to relieve farmers who have exceeded those quotas of paying a 50 per cent penalty tax, prospects are that the total income of the bright tobacco

Charles F. Noyes, realty broker, favors "little buildings" as Manhattan realty investments, and has backed up his judgment by acquiring more than 100 such structures in various parts of the borough, and particularly in the downtown business areas.

The annual training cruise for naval reserve personnel, officers and enlisted men, from Perth Amboy, Hoboken, Jersey City and Baltimore, got under way yesterday. It was estimated at the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn that about 400 sailed.

About 1,000 persons saw. a crime play, "Ten Minute Alibi," at the Maplewood Theatre tonight, unaware that while they had been having dinner a stagehand of the show was presenting a comedy melodrama of his own, with the theatre as his backdrop, the manager and treasurer as his cast and ticket receipts of $107 as his chief properties.

Promenade, 7-year-old chestnut mare owned by Marvin Y. Bell of Mountvale, N. J., won the grand championship today in the eighth annual Lake Mohawk horse show. She also took blue ribbons in the classes for model and gentlemen's saddle horses.
Edwin S. Smith, member of the National Labor Relations Board, in a speech here today denounced alleged attacks by employers on the NLRB as an attempt to arouse public sentiment against labor unions.

Some folks, it seems, never really know when they have been soundly thrashed, and well up in this select group one can easily find a place for Joe Cronin and his Red Sox, who in an astonishing turnabout at the Stadium yesterday walloped our supposedly invincible Yankees, 9 to 3.

THE American Guild of Musical Artists and the Grand Opera Choral Alliance are going at it tooth and nail for control of opera choristers. AGMA, new in the field, is naturally on the offensive, while GOCA, which used more or less to enjoy undisputed control, is kept busy not only in defense of its territory but also of its very right to that territory.

A national defense program will be conducted this Fall and Winter by the Daughters of the American Revolution, Mrs. Henry M. Robert Jr., president general, announced today. The program was outlined by Mrs. Imogen B. Emery, chairman of the National Defense Through Patriotic Education Committee, and has been put before every D. A. R. chapter in the country by Mrs. Robert.
Jerome Meckier of Jersey City today won the $3,000 Stone Harbor Gold Cup for outboards at the tenth annual Stone Harbor Yacht Club regatta.
President Getulio Vargas boarded the United States plane carrier Enterprise this morning for a short cruise in Brazilian waters and to witness a demonstration by planes from the ship.

THE subtle Improvements that have been so obvious in the recording of keyboard instruments during the past year quite naturally have resulted in an increased proportion of piano disks. Equally naturally, after lagging for some time, Chopin again has come in for attention.

Plans under consideration for some years by the Kingdom of Greece to increase the water supply of Athens and its port, Piraeus, by means of a new aqueduct which would unite waters of the springs of the Boeotian Kephissos with those of Marathon Lake, are about to be made effective, it was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Devaney, vice president of Ulen Co.
NEW YORK'S ocean-steamer piers dwell in states of almost continuous excitement these days as the volume of returning vacationists from abroad reaches the peak for the year.

Six thousand underprivileged boys and girls will be the guests of Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner McElligott Saturday afternoon at a matinee performance of the "Midnight Alarm," annual pagent of the New York Fire Department, at Madison Square Garden.

Many yachts are anchored off Fishers Island this week-end. Among them are the Saunterer, owned by Jeremiah Milbank of New York; Elda, owned by Arthur V. Davis of New York; Marita, owned by Franklin M. Haines of Ardsleyon-Hudson;
WASHINGTON. -- With an increased allotment of WPA funds, the National Youth Administration vocational training school at Quoddy Village, Me., enrolled this Summer its largest class.

Clarence Giles, 44-year-old livestock buyer, won a wager today by swimming 55 miles down the treacherous Yellowstone River in twelve hours. He entered the water at Fallon weighing 230 pounds and had lost 22 pounds when he arrived here late today.
Political and economic implications of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 came to the fore in the Middle West this week through a combination of developments.

With construction work on the $3,000,000 Federal exhibit at the halfway mark, Theodore T. Hayes, executive commissioner of the United States New York World's Fair Commission, announced yesterday the beginning of landscapseven elm trees, each forty feet high, matched so that theiring work which will transform the Federal exposition space into an elaborate garden.

The annual outing and clambake of the Iron Men's Association of the New York City Fire Department and the fire departments of White Plains, New Rochelle and Poughkeepsie was held this afternoon in the Saxon Wood Riding Academy here.

Reflecting recent large-scale financing, the volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity was the largest in many weeks. Public utility retirements, as was the case in the previous week, predominated in the new announcements, while several large industrial issues were also among the listings.

With the number of individual blood tests given in August at the Health Department laboratories to persons seeking marriage licenses more than 4,000 over the total for July, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, concludes that the public is beginning to accept the new law.

Residential construction, after a slow start early in the year, is now running ahead of 1937, and the number of homes built during July was almost twice the total for the same month last year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. Apartment construction accounted for most of the rise.

Floods raging down mountain canyons on a 200-mile front of the Eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains killed at least five persons, left three missing, virtually destroyed two resort towns and caused vast damage which armies of workers started to repair today.

A city-wide Children's Art Festival will be held Tuesday and Wednesday on the Mall in Central Park. Children from settlement houses, community centers and churches will stage shows and exhibit their handiwork under the auspices of the Public Use of Arts Committee, which is conducting the festival.
OFFICIALLY Carl Laemmle went into retirement in April, 1936, when he stepped down from the presidency of Universal Pictures after thirty years as a leading figure in the motion-picture industry.

Bearing placards "A. F. of L. unfair to distillery workers union," pickets paraded today in front of the headquarters of the Kentucky Federation of-Labor "They sold us down the river," said Edwin A. Frantz Jr. president of Local 20,560.

LAST Thursday was a big day for oystermen out of Long Island and along Chesa peake Bay, and a memorable date for restaurant patrons around town. September opens the procession of months with an "R" and oysters are back on the menu--chilled on the half shell, or sliding by the succulent dozens into saucepans at oyster bars where experts toss together their famous stews.

Winners of the National Football League title this year will play a post-season all-star game at Los Angeles, League President Joe F. Carr said today. The contest will be for charity early in January, but Carr announced that other details had not been completed.

A HALF century ago, on Sept. 11, 1888, there died at Asuncion, Paraguay, one of Latin America's greatest statesmen, Domingo Faustino Sarmiento, who had served as Argentina's fifth President from Oct. 12, 1868, to Oct. 12, 1874, an office to which he was elected while he was Minister to the United States.

RENEWED fear of war in Europe and the opening this week of the annual Nazi party meeting in Nuremberg throw Germany and Adolf Hitler into the center of world affairs. It is a commonplace as well as a literal fact to say today that "Adolf Hitler is Germany, and Germany is Adolf Hitler." Yet the statement is obviously too simple to contain the whole truth.
The wife of the Nicaraguan President, Senora Salvadora Somoza, her daughter, Lillian, and her sons, Luis and Anastasio, left for New York today by plane to Costa Rica and thence by the ship Limon.

Those who are interested in tennis details might lift an eyebrow at the information that the celebrated Davis Cup is really a three-piece silver set. as now displayed. A covey of officials brought it out that way and set it up before the spectators to show them what the players were arguing about.
An unusual log cabin being built by the Arthur D. Crane Company on the West Shore Trail, Lake Mohawk, N. J., has. been sold to William V. Wilmot, principal of the East Side High School, Newark.

The American people are spectators today of one of the strangest occurrences in their history--a bitter labor war waged between two increasingly powerful factions of organized labor. The conflict has developed with growing intensity for more than two years and, so far as can be told today, threatens to continue indefinitely.

The blessings of United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter were bestowed yesterday on.Nijib Tooni, an Arab from Iraq, and Doris Hisaw, his bride from Missouri. Thus were cleared up the charges of white slavery, love potions and evil oriental harems that had threatened their romance.

Money talks, and Manhattan realty purchasers who are able to put cash "on the line" when making a deal pay lower prices than buyers who operate on a shoestring and ask the sellers to take back a mortgage for the greater part of the amount involved.

Irving Eldridge and Phil Siriani, lightweight battlers from the Bronx, will meet in the star bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena Tuesday night. Both have large personal followings and their meeting is expected to attract a capacity crowd to the Long Island City arena.
Premier Mussolini was informed today that Italy had won this year 's'battle of the grain."

The nomination on Tuesday of Sheridan Downey, champion of the $30-aweek pension plan, as Democratic candidate for the United States Senate has jolted moderate New Dealers and. pleased Republicans far more than any conservative reaction against the President could have done.

The government farm program is meeting with varying success and reactions in different sections of the country. In the following dispatches correspondents in the Wheat, Corn, Cotton and Tobacco Belts report on how the farmers feel about the year's crops, prospective prices and the- political aspects of the program.

Apart from the arrival of the Bendix Trophy planes, the feature of today's program of the National Air Races, there were thrills without number for the more than 15,000 spectators in the enlarged stands on the west side of the 1,000-acre Municipal Airport.

The leading German newspapers this week complained that Great Britain had departed. from her accustomed neutrality and had sought in advance to place upon Germany the responsibility for war if it should break out over Czechoslovakia.

The New York State Horseshoe Pitchers Association opened its annual championship play here today, and with a 19-year-old entrant as the feature attraction, thirty-two stars vied until dark. Each completed eight of fifteen scheduled matches in a tandem round-robin, to be concluded tomorrow.

About 1,200 employes of the West Albany shops of the New York Central Railroad, idle since last Spring, were ordered today to return to their jobs on Wednesday. Rehiring of the workers, according to John G. Parsons, superintendent of the locomotive shops, was made possible through approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a $5,000,000 loan to the railroad.

Miss Catherine Mary Laidlaw, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Campbell Laidlaw of Ottawa, was married here this afternoon to Robert Bell Douglas of Montreal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Douglas of New York and Mexico City.

America's hold on the Davis Cup, reclaimed last Summer after a decade's absence abroad, was practically made secure for another year today as Australia was turned back in both of the opening singles matches of the first challenge round staged in this country since 1927.

The United States Navy has taken a ringside seat for the hurricane season. The "ringside" is tiny Swan Island, 150 miles off the coast of Honduras. The navy's weather man and two radio operators will swell its population to 22.

The following Foreign Service changes since Aug. 27 were announced today by the State Department: William W. Heard of Baltimore, Consul at Halifax, assigned Consul at Cartagena, Colombia. John J. Muccio of Providence, R. I., designated Second Secretary of Legation at Panama; assignment as Second Secretary at San Jose canceled.

The Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., announced yesterday that it had concluded arrangements for the purchase of substantial amounts of its 5 per cent redeemable debentures, with a present face value of $3.20 each, at $2.88 plus accrued interest to date of delivery.

The names of fifteen relief recipiernts today were ordered stricken from welfare rolls after Mayor William E. Kane, who several months ago fathered and then abandoned a cage-for-drunks plan, found them drinking.

Senator Sheppard said today that he would urge Congress to revise and broaden the Corrupt Practices Act to fix a uniform limit of expenditures in Senatorial campaigns. Permitted expenditures in Senatrial primaries, unregulated by Congress since the Supreme Court's decision in the Newberry case in 1924, now range from the legal allowance of $3,000 in Oklahoma to unlimited amounts in at least 11 States.
IF there is an unemployed saga writer in the house, this is to notify him that there is available for his talents a field which is practically guaranteed to change his status.

VISITORS to the Statue of Liberty on historic Bedloe's Island will find a reconditioned and more beautiful national monument when work on the statue and the island, now going on, is finally completed.

Formation of a department of Chinese and Japanese at Columbia University, to combine the formerly separate Department of Chinese and the Institute of Japanese Studies, was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Miss Beatrix K. Robinson of Lloyds Neck and New York and Dr. William T. Daily of Babylon, L. I., were married yesterday in the chapel of St. John's College by the Rev. Edward F. Doherty dean of St. John's Law School, Brooklyn.

Fire Lieutenant Christopher Plunkett, 43 years old, of 438 West Fortyseventh Stret, died at 4:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital from injuries received last Wednesday morning in a fall at a fire in an office building at 20 East Fifty-third Street.
Eight persons were reported drowned today in severe floods along the Oder and Neisse Rivers. Heavy rains in Silesia swelled mountain streams, causing many

The Real Estate Association of the State of New York will take formal action on proposed amendments to the State Constitution affecting realty at the annual convention of the association in Syracuse, Sept. 15 to 17.

Sixty candidates will report for practice to head Coach Ossie Solem on Tuesday when he starts his second season as football mentor at Syracuse. Included in the list are eleven ends, nine tackles, thirteen guards, three centers and twentyfour backs.

Accused of violating Section 1923 of the penal code, relating to the manufacture and possession-of coinsized slugs, a man who described himself as Joseph Adler, 32, of 24 East 103d StSreet, was arrested at 4:30 P. M. yesterday on Broadway near Walker Street, after a chase of several blocks, and was taken to police headquarters.

About one hundred and fifty delegates representing nudist groups in all parts of the United States and several American and foreign nudist leaders are expected to attend the annual convention of the American Sunbathing Association, formerly the International Nudist Conference, to be held next week-end at Rock Lodge,

JAMES MADISON. PHILOSOPHER OF THE CONSTITUTION. By Edward McNail Burns. 12mo. New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press. New Brunswick. N. J. $2.50. Rutgers University Studies in History. Volume I. BROOKLYN VILLAGE. 1816-1834. By Ralph Foster Weld. 8vo. New York: Columbia University Press.

Ten tons of "Blarney stone" were shipped to the United States today from Liverpool. The stone, quarried near Blarney Castle, was said to have been bought by an American syndicate to begin building a reproduction of the castle in Los Angeles.
The pound sterling fell yesterday further to cheaper levels than it has seen in more than three years and additional engagements of $16,500,000 gold in London for shipment here were announced.

A new American mezzo-soprano, Rise Stevens, making her debut at the Colon last night in "Der Rosenkavalier," received one of the most enthusiastic ovations ever given to a newcomer here. Critics unanimously praise her as an outstanding feature in what they describe as one of the best productions of the Strauss opera ever seen here. Erich Kleiber directed.

PRE-HOLIDAY drift made it difficult last week to gauge retail trade results. The reports reaching here told of some improvement through the country and wholesale orders from stores picked up. Nevertheless, there was considerable variation shown in the comparisons with last year's levels.

WITH "Hamlet" and "Henry IV" (Part 1) just ahead of him, and "King Richard II" always available in the storehouse, Maurice Evans will be spending most of this season on the Shakespearean aide. But comes Spring he plans to romp a while in other, less classical, pastures. Monckton Hoffe is writing a play for him, something about a historical character but treated in modern terms.

I. W. Clark, former manager of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company's kitchen-planning section, has been appointed manager of the company's new home planning department at Mansfield, Ohio, it was announced yesterday by R. E. Imhoff,

An army, judiciary and political "purge" to rid Italy of all Jews in these three professional branches is advocated today by the newspaper Tevere, whose anti-Semitic campaign started years ago and whose editors are now in charge of the official "racial" magazine The Defense of the Race.

QUEEN WILHELMINA completes forty years of her reign on Tuesday and the Netherlanders are making a jubilee week of it. It will be celebrated all over the motherland, in the empire overseas and wherever there are Netherlands colonies on foreign soil.

The Mexican Government is using strong diplomatic pressure in an effort to persuade South American republics to enter into' barter arrangements by which they take petroleum from confiscated United States and British oil fields and ship their own products to Mexico in payment.

Thousands of acres of cotton, much of it white with open bolls, ready for picking, are being plowed under by Southern farmers eager to qualify for farm bill benefits and to escape its penalties. Any accurate estimate of the number of acres being destroyed probably would run high into the thousands.

Practically everything entering into a complete heating installation has been materially improved in recent years, points out the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. High-efficiency boilers are available for use with stokers, oil burners and with gas. These special boilers, it is said, being designed for a specific type of fuel, operate with high efficiency, with noticeable reduction in fuel costs.

ADAMSON--ROSE--Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Rose of Brooklyn announce the engagement of their daughter. Sylvia, to Monroe K. Adamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adamson of Brooklyn. BARZILAY-SIMMONS--Mrs. Fred Tomerlin announces engagement of her sister, Nancy Ann Simmons, to Aaron Simon Barzilay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Barzilay.

COACHING days and coaching ways are here again. And if they are not the same old ways they are ways to which the traveler gives the pattern. The color and the stir of life are strung along the open road where the great buses roll, the vagrant motors swarm and the horns honk for more speed ahead.

Executives of producing and distributing concerns in a number of lines were concerned last week over a report that the Federal Reserve Board is considering abandonment of its compilation of department store sales statistics.

Reorganization of the Louisiana State University's lower division, which formerly included only freshman students, into the "junior division" with a two-year program, effective at the opening of the 1938-39 session this week, has been announced by Dr. James M. Smith,

The President has made us all acutely conscious of the very uneven distribution of our national income by his constant references to the one-third of the nation that is "ill-housed, ill-clad and ill-nourished." Today the National Resources Committee makes public a report running in the neighborhood of 80,000 words to document his challenge. to show what it means in exact figures.

Scores reported from the annual rifle and pistol contests at Camp Perry, Ohio, prove again that we are a nation of supermarksmen. In winning the President's match Sergeant Edward V. Seeser of the Marine Corps scored 146 out of a possible 150, with 10 v's in the center ring at 1,000 yards.

The new apartment house at 25 East Eighty-third Street, cited as the first multi-family structure erected here this year which places air-conditioning under the complete control of the individual tenant, is now 80 per cent rented, according to John F. Hamlin of Douglas L.

Ken McCombs of Detroit rode the thirtyday Washington Park race meeting to a brilliant finish today by booting home the winners of the last five races, including Dora May in the main event. The streak gave him forty-two winners and riding honors for the meeting.
THEME music is to a radio program what a song is to a bird. Distinctively the melodic warble identifies the unseen performer whether hidden in the foliage or in the ether.

GOOD results of the first C. I. T. Seminar of Safety in which newspaper men from some fifty key cities of the smaller population group learned the techniques of the many-sided attack on the accident problem have been collated by Editor Publisher.

Mrs. Ferdinand Thieriot and Miss Yvonne Thieriot, who returned on the Nieuw Amsterdam, will be at the Ritz-Carlton for a time before going to Burlingame, Calif. Mrs. Fellowes Davis will be at the Madison until she leaves late in December for Winter Park, Fla.

Although authoritative sources declare the Japanese authorities have rescinded their order for the evacuation of all Japanese from the British and French concessions in Tientsin, apprehension continues throughout the foreign communities.

THE Soviet East, which comprises an area of almost 6,000,000 square miles, is overwhelmingly Islamic, and almost everywhere in this vast territory women have lived in subjection or actual enslavement. It was not always so; to this day curious traces of ancient matriarchy may be found in some of these lands.

BLACKBERRY WINTER" is a long novel--something more than half as long as "Gone With the Wind," with which it should not be compared, although it inevitably will be. Probably it will be a long time before any one can write a chronicle of Georgia,

Many unusual features are incorporated in the design and equipment of the-new residence of Dr. B. Kaufmann at Kensington, Great Neck, L. I., which is considered one of the outstanding modern dwellings on the island.

NOBODY knows when the small business man was discovered. A Pharaoh of Egypt issued an edict to protect the "little dealer." Joseph planned an economy in his behalf. Colbert asked what would we do without him.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, indicated tonight the possibility of rejection of the British Government's scheme for the partition of Palestine when he asserted that Jews never would countenance any solution of the Palestine problem that would deprive them of the hope of large-scale immigration.

All thirty members of the Eastern All-Stars, selected graduates of fifteen colleges, participated in their final scrimmage today, concluding two weeks of practice at Peddie School for the game against the Giants.

The use of evergreens in decorative planting, even around small homes, has grown so rapidly during recent years that no arguments in their favor are needed. As a result of this "consumer acceptance," however, certain practices in connection with selling and planting them have grown up that are often responsible for failure' and disappointment.

Strapping Johnny Humm, former Chaminade High School golf and football star, annexed the Long Island junior crown for the second consecutive time today when he beat his former golfing team-mate, Jack Burke Jr., 2 and 1, in the thirty-six hole final at the Cherry Valley Club.

JUDGING from the speeds made in the qualifying trials, a new mark for the Thompson Trophy Race, America's speed classic, is apt to be set tomorrow when a full field goes to the mark for the Labor Day feature event of the eighteenth annual National Air Races.
Mr. and Mrs. Roderick S. Oakley of New York gave a cocktail party at their cabana at the Dunes Club today and later were hosts at a dutch treat dinner.

Miss Dorothy Traung, long-hitting golfer from San Francisco, today won the Mason-Dixon championship with a 3-and-2 victory over Miss Evelyn Marvin of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The California star had a battle all the way with Miss Marvin, who rallied after the Westerner had 3-up leads on both rounds of the thirtysix-hole final.

Central New York musicians carried off honors in the drums corps competition which featured the Legion Day program at the New York State Fair today. First prize went to the Drum and Bugle Corps of the Syracuse Sons of Polish-American Veterans, with the Sons of Legion of Syracuse Post 41 ranking second.

Every major holiday week-end shows all over again that we Americans are willing to suffer almost any inconvenience and face almost any danger in order to have a good time. No ones compelled to join the "holiday exodus" that causes so many headaches, by rail, highway, air and water.

Miss Marguerite Davenport Strong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Wheeler Strong of Strong's Neck, this place, was married here this afternoon in the Caroline Episcopal Church to Dr. J. Theodore Suckau Youngs of Columbus, Ohio, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Suckau of Berne, Ind.

The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commissioners of New Jersey, in a statement to the Interstate Sanitation Commission just made public, strongly opposed the proposal of New York City authorities to havethe waters of the upper Narrows included in "Class A waters,"

Indictments of fourteen men held in bail on charges of criminal negligence growing out of the deaths of four convicts at the Holmesburg County prison will be sought next week; Assistant District Attorney John A. Boyle announced today.

Miss Dorothy Margaret Skene, daughter of Dean and Mrs. Frederick Skene of New York and East Chop, near here, was married to Dr. James D. Page of the University of Rochester at the Summer home of the bride's parents in the East Chop Summer colony this afternoon.

In the background of the whole James J. Hines trial is the figure of Dutch Schultz, the man who built up the biggest rackets in New York and for a time dominated New York City's underworld, If there had been no Dutch Schultz there would have been no Hines trial--Schultz is the unmistakable cause of it.

Cloak manufacturers are taking care to avoid over-buying and over-production, according to a survey issued yesterday by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc. Of ten manufacturers queried none had "high" stocks of either piece goods or finished garments, a situation duplicated by producers of low-end merchandise.

AN event that promised to prove of not inconsiderable interest occurred in Chicago a few days ago. This was the opening of the first exhibition presented by the "Sanity in Art" group formed last year by Mrs. Frank Granger Logan.

The Social Security Act, which President Roosevelt called the ."cornerstone in a structure which is being built, but is .by no means complete," is to have its first overhauling when Congress meets in January.
The roll of French workers on strike hovered tonight at 15,000 while organized labor weighed its demands against the Daladier Government's efforts to place industry on a virtual wartime footing.

More than 50 per cent of the apartments in the first six units of Fort Hill Estates, the new apartment development in the Greenburgh section of Westchester County, already have been leased, Rae Crerin, president of the owning corporation, announced yesterday.

FIRST RACE - Purse $700; claiming; 3year-olds and upward; six furlongs. Lady Ariel, 108 (Fowler) 6.60 3.80 3.20 Strut, 108 (South) 8.20 6.00 Barbara S., 108 (Rosen) 6.40 Time-1:12 2-5. Bess B, Split Silk, Sun Madras, Countess Flora, Fountain Head and Wild Call also ran.

Stocks closed moderately higher in quiet trading; turnover, 357,390 shares. United States Government and other bonds, steady and mixed in dullest Saturday trading since December, 1917; transactions, $1,809,325.

Tonight's circus party at the Maidstone Club was attended by 500 persons, the guests coming as circus performers or country spectators, and enjoying games, side shows and competitive dancing. Harold R. Salembier headed the circus party committee.
The Second Baptist Church here was the setting at noon today for the marriage of Miss Phoebe Pendleton Crosby to Jean de Benneville Bertolet.

Mrs. Francisco Luis de Villa of New Rochelle, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lucy de Villa, to Harry Christopher Becker of this city, formerly of Mount Vernon, N. Y., the son of Mrs. Harry J. Bauman and the late Mr. Bauman. Recently Mr. Becker legally changed his name from Bauman.

FROM advance bulletins sent out by the San Francisco Opera Company it becomes evident that the organization's forthcoming sixteenth season will be of more than usual interest both as regards the repertoire chosen,

Cedar Park Homes, Inc., purchased ninety-eight lots in Cedarhurst Park, Cedarhurst, L. I., for improvement with one-family houses under the FHA plan. The sale was negotiated by Samuel Schein, broker. and was the first involving the property in seventeen years.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that the Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., had violated the Wagner act in its fight against the C. I. O.. The board issued a proposed order directing the company to refrain from recognizing the Independent Power Employes Association, which it dedared was under company domination, and from interfering with organization activities of its employes.

Uncorking the same burst of speed that had enabled him to nip Seabiscuit in the Santa Anita Handicap last Winter, Colonel Maxwell Howard's Stagehand today came from behind to capture the $25,000 added Narragansett Special before a crowd of 35,000 at Narragansett Park.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 2: MAJOR GENERAL Van Voorhis, D., Ft. Knox, Ky.,to command Fifth Corps Area, Ft. Hayes, Ohio, Sept. 30. LIEUTENANT COLONEL Tulley, J. M., Cav. Ft. Riley, Kan., to Military Academy, West Point, N. Y.

AIRCRAFT manufacturers have just counted the profits of the most prosperous half year in their entire history. Seven leading companies earned a total of $8,391,000 in the six months ended June 30, a jump of more than 80 per cent as compared with combined profits of $4,644,000 in the first half of last year.

The National Retail Demonstration the week of Sept. 19 should prove decidedly helpful in improving distribution of style and quality merchandise, especially in large retail establishments, Morris Kolchin. executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., asserted yesterday.
National interest in the development of library facilities of Howard University has grown as the new Founders Library, built at a cost of $1,105,000 by Federal appropriation, nears completion.

Following is the text of Secretary Hull's letter to John D. M. Hamilton: Sept. 2, 1938. My Dear Mr. Hamilton: I have received your letter of Aug. 13, 1938. You allude to my published letter of July 27, 1938, to Senator Pope in which I pointed out the misleading use of trade

Competing in their first international team match in this country, members of the Australian women's tennis team took three out of four singles matches and divided doubles honors against American opponents today on the Meadow Club's historic grass courts.
French and Dutch demand sent the dollar up here to the highest since early in 1935 and it closed at $4.84 3/3 to the pound after fluctuating between $4.84 1/4 and $4.85 1/4.

When the Hamilton College football squad of forty-five aspirants greets Coach Art Winters on the Clinton, N. Y., institution's field Thursday morning for the opening of preseason practice, there will be a promising junior, Reynold Salmela of Newport, N. H., among the linemen.

Uncas Flying Devil, a white and liver pointer dog owned by H. E. Eyster of York, Pa., won the coveted Saskatchewan championship event at the Saskatchewan field trials today. The winner, trained and handled by Dewey English, won for his owner approximately $900 in stake money.

The national construction cost index of the American Appraisal Company for July was unchanged from June, at 181, according to Lyle H. Olson, vice president of the company. The New York City index of 191 for July was one point below the previous month and six points below July, 1937.
United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt caused a sensation at a City Hall banquet here tonight by declaring France and the United States were "indefectively united in war as in peace."
The average family income of one-third of the nation was only $471 in 1935-36, the National Resources Committee estimated in its report, submitted today to President Roosevelt.

Henry N. Wightman of Upper Montclair, who is seeking his third successive New Jersey gliding title, set a new meet record for spot landing at the fifth annual three-day State championship meet which opened here today at Schley Field. More than 700 spectators attended the program which is sponsored by the Associated Gliding Clubs of New Jersey.

IT is fitting that a philosopher should write of the contributions to law and social welfare of the great philosopher-judge, Benjamin Cardozo. Dr. Levy, Professor of Philosophy as well as member of the New York bar, here 'undertakes an analysis of Cardozo's thought processes.

The Associated Milliners Industries, Chicago, will meet in that city on Sept. 13 to discuss ratification of the action of a convention of manufacturers in July in forming the National Council of Millinery Associations to represent all producers' groups in the country.

Lillian Shapero is staging the dances in Maurice Schwartz's forthcoming production of "Three Cities." This is by no means a new connection for Miss Shapero, who has collaborated with Mr. Schwartz in most of his productions at least as far back as the "Wise Men of Chelm."

Newark divided a double-header with Baltimore in the series final today, the Orioles winning the first game, 3 to 1, but dropping the nightcap, 4 to 1. In the opener Harry Matuzak had a three-hit shutout on the way until

The War Department has appointed Major Gen. Daniel Van Voorhis to command the Fifth Corps Area, with headquarters at Fort Hayes, Columbus, Ohio, on the retirement of Major Gen. William E. Cole t Sept. 30.

" The Celestial Army" E. M. R. wants a copy of the old poem by T. B. Read entitled above. It begins: "I stood by my open casement and looked upon the night." "The Hand Within My Own" J. M. desires the author's name and the poem part of which includes these lines: "Dear eyes, dear look, dear hand, I held within mine own; some time, somewhere, you'll come to me, by kind fate blown."

THE Yaddo Music Group will give the first concert of its current season in Saratoga Springs tonight at the Saratoga Spa Theatre. There will be five concerts in all. Three will be given at Yaddo Mansion Sept. 10 (afternoon), Sept. 11 (evening) and Sept. 11 (morning).

PARIS.--In 1914 French military circles were inspired with a passion for the offensive a outrance, which caused them to disdain the means of defense by fortification. The famous Plan 17 did not lay down any other use for the fortresses in the east than as a pivot for offensives in the grand manner.

More than $260,000,000 was spent on the upkeep of equipment of the American steel industry during 1937, a gain of nearly 15 per cent over 1936, according to a compilation made by the American Iron and Steel Institute from data supplied by companies representing about a 90 per cent of the industry's productive capacity.
WHILE the New York World's Fair is rapidly taking shape on the Flushing meadows, the Pacific Coast is getting ready for the opening of a similar enterprise-the Golden Gate International
TO the Colonial room the mantel contributes as much as any of the other furnishings. In wood or marble, it may set the tone of the decorative scheme and bring it into unity.
Plans for indemnity payments on exports of up to 5,000,000 barrels of flour, to supplement the wheat export program, were approved today by M. L. Wilson,. Acting Secretary of Agriculture.

Quantities of merchandise requested by stores last week were larger than for the two or three previous weeks, according to a special summary prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Wearing Howell Company. resident buying representatives. "There is a general note of improvement in the entire retail field, as shown by these requests," the report continues. "Mail requests stressed both open orders and reorders. indicating the actual development of consumer buying.

MR. SCHACHNER'S study of the medieval univercities is by way of being a "Hamlet without the Prince of Denmark"; it is principally concerned with the forms, the organization, which those originally free institutions were gradually compelled to adopt.
DEATH ON THE INSTALLMENT PLAN. By Louis-Ferdinand Celine. Translated from the French by John H. P. Marks. 593 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $2.75.
A newsreel theatre costing $150,000 is nearing completion on West Thirty-fourth Street, opposite the Pennsylvania Station, where it will be the first of its kind to serve the busy shopping district.

General Manager Jack Zeller of the Detroit Tiger baseball club announced tonight the purchase of seven players and recall of ten others from Toledo of the American Association and Beaumont of the Texas League.

Peter Scott of the Royal Norfolk and Suffolk Yacht Club of England captured the international dinghy race off the Canadian National Exhibition waterfront today. Scott's entry, third in yesterday's race, completed the course in 1:05:05.

THE subtitle declares, with accuracy, that this book presents "the strange training and adventures of a man whose work was melodrama." And that, of course, is quite in the tradition of the "revelations" of international espionage.

Mrs. F. Miller Parrill of 200 West Eighty-sixth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Gretna Ruth Parrill, to Joseph Wohl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wohl of this city and Hunter, N. Y.

A large throng comprised of Summer colonists and their holiday house parties attended the final supper dance for this season which was held tonight in the Colonial ballroom and the Japanese Room of the Meadow Club.

Henry V. Rourke, who was associated with David Lasser in the founding of the Workers Alliance and who has been a member of its paid organizing staff ever since, announced yesterday that his local, made up of WPA chauffeurs, mechanics and helpers, had voted to withdraw from the alliance in protest against "Communist domination" of the organization's affairs.

" One hundred thousand Rumanians living in Hungary have no churches, priests or schools," said the newspaper Universul today. The newspaper stressed that while Germans and Hungarians are demanding more than liberal regimes for their minorities living abroad and while Rumania
The automobile industry opens the Fall season with prospects more favorable than it has faced at any time in the last twelve months. Preparations for the 1939 production season are in full swing.

Miss Harriet Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Jackson of Providence, who are passing the Summer at their home in Northeast Harbor, gave a dinner tonight at the Northeast Harbor Golf Club for Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Jackson Jr. After the dinner the group

Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, together with its affiliated agencies, provided camp vacations and special outdoor programs on the roof gardens and in the playgrounds of day nurseries for several thousand boys and girls between the ages of 1 and 17. A report of the Summer activities has been issued at the headquarters, 477 Madison Avenue.

Ontario's gold mines reported further expansion in the first six months of 1938 in both tonnage of ore milled and value of bullion recovered. From the fifty-six mines reporting shipments, a total of $47,094,219 in crude bullion, gold and silver, was produced, compared with $43,054,465 for the same period in 1937.

Japanese forces will probably enter Teian, midway between Kiukiang and Nanchang, before dark this evening. Official sources reported a successful assault was made yester day afternoon upon the town of Mahuiling, which the Japanese forces said they entered at 4:30 P. M., thus capturing "the gateway to Teian," which is only five miles to the south.

Four employes of the Cole Bros.Clyde Beatty Circus, Inc., of Rochester, Ind., filed a suit in Federal Court here today asking that the circus be put in receivership. Irma Aurelis Zavatta, Raffaele Zoppe, Giovanna Zoppe and Claude Langlois, said the circus owed them $1,500 and had transferred its tangible property to the Associates Investment Company of South Bend to "defraud creditors."
Mrs. W. Harry Brown, a leader of the American social set in London and an entertainer of Continental nobility, died today at her home here.

Miss Dorothy Beatrice Gleason of New York and East Orange, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert James Gleason, was married in Holly Grove Methodist Church here today to William C. Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Leslie Moore of Tigrett. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E. M. Mathis of Dyersburg, Tenn.

Rives Matthews, newspaper man who announced last week that he intended- to picket a row of advertising billboards, on the ground that they obstructed the view of the Palisades from the Albany River Road, carried out his program today, with the assistance of four friends.

The Republican National Committee asserted today that the country, under the New Deal, was traveling down the road Europe took in the 1920's, and that the logical end is a completely planned economy, with Federal domination of all economic and political life, and the subsequent breakdown of constitutional democracy.

PENNSYLVANIA one year ago took a preliminary step toward a "new deal" in traffic regulation. By act of Legislature it placed in effect on Sept. 1, 1937, a fifty-mile-an-hour speed limit, ten miles higher than the previous maximum, and then, in succeeding months, prepared the machinery for an aggressive campaign designed to show doubting motorists that the State meant business.

Teams representing Ludwig Baumann and the Hotel Piccadilly scored victories at the Polo Grounds yesterday to enter the final round in the Industrial Division of the New York City Baseball-Federation championship tourney.

An earnest plea for cooperation by parents and physicians in efforts of the city Health Department to curb whooping cough, which is now about three and a half times more prevalent than normally, was made yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Letters, telephone calls and personal visits have testified to Wall Street's interest in the subject of merchandising, treated on this page two weeks ago. They have testified to widespread lack of sympathy for the Micawber school of conservatism and an intense
Sales of paint materials in August were substantially better than the July volume, countering the usual seasonal July to August decline, according to leading producers last week.

A cool, sunshiny day yesterday sent Labor Day holiday-bound New Yorkers away to a good start on the three-day week-end with no alarming weather changes in sight to mar what promised to be the biggest and best as well as the last week-end of the Summer season.

Elmhurst has become one of the most active sections of Long Island in residential building. A large low-cost home center has just been launched at Fifty-seventh Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, in that community, by Leon and Mortimer Levy, who in the past have erected many apartments in Queens, Manhattan and Westchester.

The twenty-four-hour trial of 175 Integralists (Fascists) charged with assaulting public buildings and private residences in the attempted revolt of May 11 ended today with 159 of the defendants sentenced to prison terms, severest of which was ten years. Sixteen were acquitted.

The strong attitude of the Mexican Government, re-emphasized this week by President Cardenas in his address to the National Congress, in the matter of expropriated property of Americans, has confronted the Government of the United States with a grave diplomatic problem.
