The London Economist, writing on "The Size of London," moralizes briefly on the disadvantages of enormous populations concentrated in single cities. It points out that, whereas the deploring of such concentration had for hundreds of years been the fashion chiefly of "poets, social reformers,...

A denial that the Waterfront Employers Association is planning to smash the C. I. O. Longshoremen's Union in an old-fashioned open-shop drive, as charged by Harry R. Bridges, West Coast regional director for the C. I. O. and president of the International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, was made today by Almon E. Roth, president of the employers' association.

To the Drama Editor: Although Elmer Rice writes an interesting bit of psychology anent the reasons for the pooling of the Five Playwrights, one point is rather vague. Mr. Rice mentions some "idealistic reasons" among which, "to create opportunities and provide training for young playwrights.

Growing indications that announcement of the conclusion of the long-discussed Anglo-American reciprocal trade treaty will come at an early date have focused a strong light on the extraordinary contradictions which mark this treaty.

John Curry, 53 years old, a Negro of 518 East 185th Street, the Bronx, was arraigned in Night Court last night before Magistrate Earl A. Smith on a charge of possessing a policy slip. He was arrested late yesterday by Plainclothes
This Berkshire week-end is crowded with four dances, three tennis tournaments, a dog show and many dinners and luncheons for house guests and visitors who are at the hotels.

Jai Alai, the game that has fascinated sports fans of Cuba and other Latin-American countries, will be introduced to New York Thursday at the Hippodrome, where forty of the best players in the world have been assembled to inaugurate a season of what is generally regarded as a fast and furious sport.

JUNIOR aged 7 and old for his age, knew all about hard times, yet this story of a little Charleston Negro and his search for work is far from being a lugubrious one. With the optimism of his people he was prepared to be cheerful,

Gardening, nature study and exploration are to be featured in the Autumn series of free Saturday afternoon lectures at the New York Botanical Garden. The series will open this week with a talk on "Exhibiting and Judging of Flowers" by Mrs. Ethel Anson S. Peckham, who will give demonstrations and show slides at 3 P. M. in the Museum Building.

The Class I railroads had more freight cars on order, under construction or being rebuilt on Aug. 1 than at any previous time this year, the Association of American Railroads has reported. The number of cars in this classification on that date was 10,234, against 5,021 on July 1. The total on Aug. 1, 1937, was 38,089 and on Aug. 1, 1936, it was 27,151.

AMONG the first of a number of important problems that the new Civil Aeronautics Authority will have to face will be the realignment of a number of international agreements before transatlantic air service can be established.

The $500 check that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey introduced in the trial of James J. Hines on Friday as a documentary link between the Tammany leader and the Dutch Schultz policy racket will be shown on Tuesday to have found its way into the cash drawer of a' well-known bookmaker with whom Hines laid bets, it was indicated yesterday by the prosecution.

Cotton farmers of Texas and the whole cottonraising South have come to the conclusion during the last few months that the Federal Government isn't quite the bewhiskered man in the red, white and blue suit they thought he was.

IN spite of his long silence, E. M. Forster's reputation has been steadily growing. Rose Macaulay shares her enthusiasm for his work not only with an army of readers but with a good many fellow-novelists, for Mr. Forster is a model technician, conscious, theoretic and analytical in his plot construction. As Miss Macaulay shrewdly observes:

The Binghamton Triplets clinched the Eastern League pennant today by defeating the secondplace Hazleton Club, 7 to 5. A two-run rally in the seventh by Binghamton broke a 5-to-5 tie and gave the Triplets the victory. The pennant is Manager Bruno Betzel's second.

The Browns announced tonight the purchase of Outfielder Ed Silber from San Antonio of the Texas League and recall of eleven other minor league players. The others, all to report with Silber next Spring, are Jim Walkup, Julio Bonetti and Bill Miller from Toledo;
Mergers have been a favorite form of corporate reorganization for more than a decade. And one of the inducing causes for the adoption of this form of reorganization has been the income tax.

RAPIDLY accumulating dealer orders for 1939 cars now indicate that public announcement dates for the new lines will be advanced and that a few makes of cars will be available by the middle of September, if not earlier.

In these days when many new places are being planted and old gardens redesigned, the selection of ornamental trees assumes a new importance. One of the most beautiful and most satisfactory of all decorative trees is the Carolina hemlock, as yet comparatively little. known to most home owners.

The sixth annual national convention of the German-American Bund opened yesterday in the Turnhall at Eighty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue with 632 delegates representing districts from coast to coast.

The Comsomol Pravda, organ of the Soviet Russian Young Communist League, announces that an Eskimo named Taian-mighty hunter, able bookkeeper and mechanichas been named Governor of Wrangel Island in the Arctic.

DESPITE the decline of the sun in the Arctic Zone, 19 and 16 meter short-wave signals from Europe continue to bound over the Atlantic with extreme steadiness during early evening hours. Classed generally as "daylight" waves, these signals at 7 o'clock now travel a route which, with Fall approaching, is almost completely covered by darkness.

MANHATTAN AGNEW, MARIA ANTOINETTE (Aug. 28). Estate, approximately $10,000. To Rose Gallagher, executrix, 160 E. S9th St.; Grace Agnew Erhard, niece, Hempstead, L. 1., and Arthur Agnew. nephew, Deposit, N. Y., one-third residue each.

Celebrating "Dick Porter Night" in honor of their manager, the Chiefs captured the fourth and final game of their last home series from Jersey City tonight, 5 to 0. The game, delayed nearly two hours by rain, was held to six and a half innings by agreement for train connections.

Every element of political drama invests the journey this week of the President into Maryland to ask Democratic voters not to renominate Senator Tydings. The past, the present and the future join in fact and implication to turn the country's eyes on a State smaller than all but seven others in the Union.

The New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance will offer sixteen courses in real estate and land economics, beginning on Sept. 20 in both day and evening divisions, Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday.

Attracting attention first in the display grounds of nurserymen and botanical gardens, the new dwarf asters have quickly found their way into the flower borders of small home plots. Although so recently introduced they have won for themselves an important and lasting place.
State and regional directors of the National Youth Administration will meet in a two-day conference here Sept. 9 to consider the N. Y. A. program for the current fiscal year.
Miss Jane Wyeth and Dr. Richard van Dyck Knight had twelve attendants at their marriage here today, which was performed by the Rev. Chester Fisk in Christ Church.

John Ramsay, president of the C. I. O. union of the Bethlehem Steel Company, told the world assembly of the Oxford Group movement here today: "There will be constant difficulty in industry unless the leadership and followers of both management and workers are changed.
In the first series of races in the annual Labor Day regatta at Bellport, Bill Torrey, star of the Cape Cod Class, was upset today by Skippy Lea in the yacht Horizon. Torrey was second in Shaver.

THIS is a big novel big in size with its nearly 600 pages. big in quality with its rare objectivity and fine simplicity, big in spirit. A generous and warm novel of the Victorian order, it is also a thoroughly modern book. an American novel of times and places familiar to all of us.

A revised list of the seating capacities in the stadiums which are home grounds for the seven clubs in the American Football Association brings to light the information that the average is 19,000. The stadia and their capacity are:

Miss Elizabeth Idabelle Firestone, only daughter of Mrs. Harvey S. Firestone and of the late Mr. Firestone, founder of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its active head for thirty-seven years, was married here late this afternoon to

Miss Helen Morgan Rotch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Rotch of this place, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Charles Lee Buxton of New York. The ceremony, which was followed by a reception, was held at Hill Top Farm, home of the bride's parents.

The Goose was cooked today. In the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's sixty-sixth annual Fall regatta, held on Long Island Sound, the foreign six-meter yachts were invited to race with the craft of that class in this country.
LIKE the easily amused old gent who used to bang his head with a hammer, I went off on the annual see-no-pictures, hear-no-pictures, speak-of-nopictures tour saying "It feels so good when you stop."
Jacqueline Cochran took the premier cross-country aviation honors of 1938 yesterday by winning the Bendix Trophy, and in addition became the holder of a new transcontinental record for women.

THE subscription series, "Music and the Dance," to be offered this season by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, will open Monday night, Oct. 24, with a presentation of Borodin's opera, "Prince Igor," under the direction of Eugene Fuerst and Mme. Marie Yakovleff. The work will be sung in Russian. There will be 100 participants on stage, not including the Yakovleff Ballet, which will perform the Polovetzian dances. The orchestra will number forty musicians.

To the Music Editor: Your rather vehement condemnation of recent attempts by leading conductors to limit applause to "natural" pauses in the symphonies would indeed be justifiable provided we accept applause itself as indispensable to musical enjoyment. But is it?
Bert Coote, British comedian, who delighted United States audiences at the end of the last century with the vaudeville sketch, "A Lamb on Wall Street," died last night in his London home. He was 70.

Rayon, the artificial silk from which dresses and stockings are made, may also find wide use in producing stronger, longer lasting and heat resisting auto tires as the result of an invention described in a patent

The 2,400 infantrymen of the Eightyseventh Brigade, commanded by Brig. Gen. Walter A. Delamater, are to leave Camp Smith tomorrow for the home armories after a fourteen-day encampment tour. They received a total of more than $70,000 from the paymaster today.

One phase of the great European conflict can now be regarded as finished. It is the psychological one. The German attack on the nerves of Britain, France, Czechoslovakia and others reached its climax last week. And it can be said to have failed. The assault, with all its menaces, in no way cracked the morale of the statesmen or peoples to whom was presented the prospect of great tragedy.
WASHINGTON.--An intricate and original protective system is being put to a test as the government progresses with its task of assembling valuable documents in the new National Archives Building here.
A smooth dachshund, Champion Herman Rinkton, owned by Mrs. Annis A. Jones of South Orange, N. J., today won the best-in-show award at the Lenox Kennel Club's 47th annual exhibition.

A city-wide postcard poll of Buffalo voters, conducted by The CourierExpress during the last week, disclosed that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey of New York was the outstanding choice for Governor among Republicans, with Representative James M. Mead in the lead among the Democrats.

Snakes, tadpoles, lizards, salamanders, tree frogs and tropical fish that are house pets competed yesterday as the New York Aquarium Society opened its three-day annual exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History.

Secretary Hull, in a vigorous denunciation of "the misleading use of trade statistics" by Chairman John D. M. Hamilton and his "wing of the Republican National Committee and its allies" told Mr. Hamilton in a letter today that these statements were circulated "even after attention has repeatedly been called to the actual facts."

The First Congregational Church here was the setting tonight for the marriage of Miss Barbara Claire Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merwin LeRoy Smith of this city, to Frederick Adams Groesbeck of New York.

FISHERMEN in the Bay of Mont St. Michel, and hunters going out to the islands, must always be watchful of the time-that moment when the tide would begin to gallop like a pursuing enemy across the wide sands. They must go warily, too, on the sands themselves,

The Swiss are flattered by proposals to "make Czechoslovakia into a second Switzerland." To them the idea of achieving this by "centonization" shows, however, too much misunderstanding of how the Swiss system works to be very promising.

Posting a new world record, H. B. Joy Jr. of Detroit won the blue ribbon event of the national skeet tournament today by finishing his allgauge program with a perfect score of 250. Jack Lindsey of Okmulgee, Okla., also set a world mark, hitting 540 of 550 birds in the high-over-all competition.
Candidates for the Kingswood School football team are slated to start practice at West Hartford, Conn.. on Wednesday, according to an announcement by Joe Gargan, coach of the squad.

KAPLOW--Mr. and Mrs. Adolph J. Kaplow announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Martin Myron, Saturday, Sept. 10, at Yeshivah of Bensonhurst, 2,025 79th St., Brooklyn, N. Y.. 9 A. M. NATHAN-Mr. and Mrs. Hyam Nathan announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Donald. Saturday. Sent. 10. Temple Rodeph Sholom. Reception, Hotel Bolivar, 230 Central Park West, 3 to 5:30.

Although New York State has paid out more than $66,000,000 in unemployment insurance benefits, its balance in the unemployment trust fund was put today at $10,000,000 more than on Jan. 29, when the first check was written.

Dr. James Kendrick Pyne, one of the most notable of British organists, died today at Ilford, Essex, at the age of 81. At one time he was the organist at St. Mark's Church in Philadelphia. He went to Manchester in 1876 and for half a century was the organist to the city of Manchester. He retired after a street accident.

THE San Carlo Opera Company opens its seventeen-day season at the Center Theatre Thursday night, Sept. 15, with a performance of "Carmen," featuring Coe Glade in the title role. Other operas announced for the first week are Puccini's, "Madama Butterfly,"

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being Sept. 3 unless specified: New York to Havana, Badger, Fairfax, Herbert, Tattnall. Guantanamo to Miami, Sept. 2. Babbitt, Dickerson, Roper, Schenck, Tillman. At Morgantown, Md., Sept. 2, Cuyahoga, Potomac. Perth Amboy to Havana, Decatur, J. F. Talbott.

Could the principle of "planned journalism" be laid down any clearer than in Napoleon's instructions to Fouchd. his chief of security? "Repress the journals

SIXTY-THREE miles southeast of Los Angeles, fifty miles north of San Diego. thirty miles from the Pacific beach at Oceanside looms Palomar Mountain, an uneven hump 5,500 feet high. There are taller mountains, but none more important to astronomers.

The United States Golf Association yesterday announced through The Associated Press the withdrawal of three likely contenders from the starting field for the national amateur golf championship Sept. 12-17 at the Oakmont Country Club near Pittsburgh.

The marriage of Miss Mary Dolan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward G. Dolan of Manchester, Conn., and Washington, D. C., to Simon N. Sterns, son of Albert R. Sterns of Demarest, N. J., and the late Mrs. Sterns, took place here yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The report of the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,537,562 after allowances for depreciation, normal Federal income taxes and other charges.

NEW appointments to the faculty of the New England Conservatory, Boston, Mass., have just been announced by Wallace Goodrich, director. Quincy Porter, dean of the faculty, will assume instruction in composition and theory. Marie Sundelius, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Association, has been added to the vocal faculty.

THE September issue of Theatre Arts Monthly, bearing the subtitle "In the Service of Comedy," devotes its pages to much delightful material on the gayer side of theatre practice, but, except for a passing mention of Bill Robinson and Fred Astaire, gives no space to the matter of choreographic wit and humor.
The annual Fall meeting and election of officers of the alumni association of the John Marshall College of Law will be held Sept. 13 at 8 P. M. at -the college.

A 25 per cent increase since 1937 in the membership of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States and a prospect that each of the 204 posts in thirty-eight States might be urged to adopt one German. Austrian or Italian refugee family, preferably that of a fellow-veteran, were leading topics at today's session of the national encampment.

Significant among the changes in Princeton. University's curriculum for the approaching academic year is the division of the undergraduate program in the department of modern languages to provide a broader and more coordinated plan of study.

Sudeten leaders were pressing a plan for a direct request to Germany to go to the aid of "German brothers" in Czechoslovakia. Viscount Runciman had a long talk with President Benes yesterday and was believed to have conveyed to him the views of Chancellor Hitler as received from Konrad Henlein.

MAJOR R. RAVEN-HART is an Englishman who has canoed on many of the important rivers of the world. Last Aug. 30 he started at Hannibal, Mo., with a small collapsible covered canoe; Josh, a boy from Sherwood Anderson's town in Virginia, whom, by previous arrangement, another boy, Phil, replaced at Memphis;

Jacqueline Cochran, who won Bendix Air Derby by flying from Los Angeles to Cleveland yesterday in 8 hours 10 minutes and 31 seconds, took off again from Cleveland fifteen minutes after her arrival there and flew on to New York with
In honor of the fifteenth birthday of Peter II, King of Yugoslavia, a Te Deum service will be held Tuesday, at 11, A. M., in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Saviour, 51 East 121st Street.

President Roosevelt today invited Governor Elmer Benson of Minnesota to visit him at Hyde Park, N. Y., Tuesday for a discussion of the farm situation in the Middle West growing out of low farm prices. The Governor will have here Monday, probably by plane.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh visited President Eduard Benes today during a series of conferences Dr. Benes had with Czechoslovak officials. The flier also saw Defense Minister Franz Machnik and General Ludwig Krejci, chief of the general staff.

The Democratic National Congressional Committee made known today that it intended to adhere strictly to its policy of working for the election of Democratic nominees for Congress. Victor Harding, executive secretary of the committee, said: ...

Construction will begin shortly on thirty new all-year colonial-style residences at Packanack Lake, near Boonton, N. J., Ira C. Jones, sales manager, announced yesterday. Ten of the structures will be for Winter sale and occupancy and the others for occupancy in March, April and May of next year.

ANCELL--Mr. and Mrs. John (Rose Patz), announce birth of a son, Aug. 31. 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. BODNER--Mr. and Mrs. Miltow Bodner (nee Adeline Trumper) announce the birth of a son, Aug. 28, at St. Mary's Hospital, Passaic, N. J., CANTOR--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Cantor (nee Sylvia Schulder) joyfully announce the birth of a son, on Sept. 1, at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital.

That Queens is one of the fastestgrowing communities in the United States is revealed in figures issued yesterday by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, which show that 73/10 per cent of the value of construction-permits issued throughout the country during the month of June was for buildings to be constructed in that borough.

PORTUGAL has just released 207 stamps, the largest single lot of postal adhesives to arrive here in several years, to publicize eight of the colonies--Angola, Cape Verde Islands, Guinea, Mozambique and St. Thomas and Prince Islands, in Africa; Macao and Portuguese India, in Asia, and Timor, in Oceania.
A popular modernization project for which funds may be obtained under the terms of the property improvement credit plan of the FHA is the conversion of attic space into living quarters.

Despite increased difficulties an efficient anti-Nazi movement has been organized inside Germany and is being further developed, according to a pamphlet, "The Underground Struggle in Germany," by Evelyn Lend, a British author.

The stock market continued Friday's substantial recovery in the two-hour.trading period yesterday. Final prices were up fractions to 2 points on the short session. Considering the fact that many tradersabsented themselves from the financia district for the holiday weekend, trading was fairly active.

The world's production of gold in July, excluding Russia, amounted to 2,728,000 fine ounces, compared with 2,589,000 in June and with 2,545,000 in July, last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

Keen interest has of late developed in the group of plants known as South Africans. Exhibits at flower shows and private collections have attracted much enthusiastic attention. Among this group are some excellent Winter-blooming bulbs--and fortunately the amateur will encounter little trouble in growing them.

Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration, reported yesterday that "an unparalleled record" for speed in putting men and materials to work on construction projects had been established by New York State communities applying for PWA aid this year.

WASIINGTON,-While climbing the ladder from farm tenancy to farm ownership is a standard procedure in American agriculture, the reverse process is now almost as standard, according to a survey just completed by the Bureau of the Census.

With a home run and six doubles in their collection of sixteen hits, the Indians had an easy time overwhelming the Browns today, 10 to 2. Jeff Heath smashed a homer in the first inning off Oral Hildebrand after Roy- Weatherly and Bruce Campbell had doubled in succession.

Julius J. Stahl, Treasurer of North Plainfield, has received a United States Treasury check for 1 cent, representing a refund to the borough on a deposit made for materials to be used in a WPA sewing room project.

Sheridan Downey, who won the Democratic nomination for the United StatesSenate from Senator William G. McAdoo, made public today a telegram from Postmaster General James A. Farley congratulating him upon -his victory and pledging hearty support."

A spurt in retail sales of millinery which coincided with the opening of a strong promotional effort behalf of Fall hats was reported a special summary of August buying activity prepared' for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Lord Taylor.

Trapped by detectives in a sevenstory loft building at 155 Waverly Place early yesterday, two burglar suspects jumped from the second floor of the building over a narrow court and through the window of the building next door at 153. Both men were captured and charged with possession of burglars' tools and burglary.

Banking's greatest bulwark against monopolistic trends in the United States is public sentiment, A. P. Stoll of Pierz, Minn., president of the Independent Bankers Association, said today in a talk at the organization's ninth annual convention.

THROUGH the generosity of Mr. E. E. Brownell, a descendant of Benjamin Franklin's teacher, George Brownell, the Historical Society of Pennsylvania is enabled to publish a folio volume in facsimile of the Indian treaties,

An exhibition of Westchester County's activities and industries probably will be held at the County Center here next year for the benefit of World's Fair visitors who pass through the county, it was announced today by an exhibition committee organized by the Westchester County Real Estate Board.
THERE come certain times in the development of a nation's art when it is not easy to distinguish clearly between provincialism and excessive interest in foreign products.

Announcement has been made by Francis A. Nelson of Upper Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaretta Quimby Nelson, to Donald Merrill Clayton, son of Mrs. Thomas R. Clayton of Providence, R. I.

" If it could be arranged, the most effective measure we could take for the preservation of the country's security," a Czechoslovak politician recently remarked, "would be the diversion of a quarter of our armament expenditure to provide free trips of representative Germans from the Reich to visit the Sudeten areas to see the situation for themselves and tell the Sudeten Germans how things really are in the Third Reich."

Brookshire Homes announced yesterday its 100th sale for 1938 to Samuel Seligman of the Bronx. Match Brothers, builders of this residential community in East Twenty-sixth, Twenty-seventh and Twenty- eighth Streets, between Avenues V and W, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, report that dwellings in this locality since June. 1937.

With a near-record turnout of boats, the eleventh weekly Saturday regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association, held today under the auspices of the Mantolooking Y. C., produced many close finishes.

With all space in the first two piers either already occupied or booked, the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., yesterday opened a third pier, according to Harry C. Shanks, president. Mr. Shanks said that, while use of the port grew steadily in the first few months of operation, there has been a more rapid increase during the last four to six weeks.

Interest in the three-week-old trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader charged with influencing judicial officers to tolerate the illegal "numbers" lottery, is by no means confined to the city where the alleged crimes took place.

Jacqueline Cochran, who has had that will-o'-the-wisp fame slip through her fingers many times in longdistance airplane speed races, took a firm grip on it today when she zoomed over the Municipal Airport here at 2:23 P. M. (E. S. T.) in her modified Seversky pursuit plane to take first prize in the annual Bendix Trophy race from Los Angeles.

THE art of retelling history in vivid narrative, that nevertheless has due regard to authority of statement, has been steadily widening for several years. When Miss Winwar announces on the title page that "Puritan City" is Salem's "Story" she says quite

The 14-inch main batteries of the battleship Tennessee fired a theoretically "plus-perfect" . score in short-range battle practice off San Clemente Island this week, Admiral Claude C. Bloch, Commander in Chief of the fleet, said today. The Tennessee's score was reported to have been materially above the all-time record established by the 16-inch turrets of the battleship West Virginia last year.

Tire impressions left on the roadway of Route 6 here, when Joseph H. Kirk, middle-aged boat mechanic of Lake Mohegan, was killed by a hit-run driver last Thursday led today to the arrest of Felix Gizzard Jr., 28 years old, Negro handyman of Carmel, N. Y. Gizzard was committed to the county jail at East View. William Ward, 40.

Representative Patrick H. Drewry, chairman of the Democratic National Congressional Committee, today predicted that the Democrats would not lose more than twenty-five seats in the House of Representatives as a result of the elections this Fall.

The church is the advocate of the cause of Christianity in the world and the agency of the work of God, the Rev. Dr. Walton H. Greever, secretary of the United Lutheran Church in America, said in his sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

A squad of nineteen policemen saved an ambulance that is to be sent by Queens Spanish-Americans to the Spanish Loyalist troops from vandalism and halted a clash between partisans of the Loyalists and the Insurgents in front of the Ditmars Theatre at 22-68 Thirty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, shortly after 9 o'clock last night.

At the beginning of the week the Paris Bourse was undoubtedly dull, because of the threats of war. The tendency improved slightly later, but chiefly in foreign securities, French issues remaining irregular..

The use of taxation to distribute national savings, bureaucratic control of the life of the population and the acquisition by the Presidential office of legislative power in addition to its executive authority are the three outstanding dangers threatening American democracy from within,

The following messages on the death of Cardinal Hayes were among those received yetserday at the Cardinal's residence, 462 Madison Avenue: Mgr. THOMAS J. McDONNELL, director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith--Most

Intercollegiate rules, with two prominent exceptions, will prevail in the third annual Tribune Fresh Air Fund football game between the Eastern College All-Stars and the New York Giants of the National League, to be staged at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday night by The New York Herald Tribune, it was announced today.
A shot was fired in a crowd here this afternoon as young King Farouk was about to enter his car after having attended the annual Egyptian swimming championships here.

The second typhoon within five days struck Japan this morning, hitting the southeastern coast of Shikoku Island and heading toward Kobe and Osaka. The center of the storm was expected to reach Osaka by nightfall, the weather bureau said.
The introduction of compulsory military training and speedy rearmament were among a number of measures announced for Hungary in a speech today by Premier Bela Imredi.

America's Gold Cup defender, the power boat Notre Dame, is on the bottom of the 30-foot deep St. Clair River, twenty miles north of Detroit, tonight and its designer-driver, Clell Perry, is fighting for his life in a hospital as the result of a tragic pre-race accident this afternoon.

The absolute demands of the modern State were assailed by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Dr. Norwood, who is special missioner for the National Free Church Council of London,

Premier Edouard Daladier is determined, as he announced in his recent broadcast appeal, to make the forty-hour week more elastic and to allow enterprises to work overtime if necessary. A decree was published this week to that end, and another will be ready soon.

The early capture by the Japanese of Teian, Matowchen and Kwangtsi in the Yangtze River campaign now seems inevitable. The loss of these three key points in the distant defense lines of the Hankow area will not only throw the Chinese armies back upon new less-stoutly prepared defensive positions but will present to the Chinese command a new crucial problem of attempting to retire without serious losses of men and supplies.

Thirty-five members of the WPA Mechanics and Helpers Union, which withdrew from the Workers Alliance in protest against "Communist domination," formed a twenty-four-hour picket line late yesterday afternoon outside the closed doors of City Hall.

One of the larger of the home luncheons given here today was that by former Ambassador and Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond at the Behr cottage, which they are occupying this Summer. Others who entertained were Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick,

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,990,616,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Seventeen families were routed in two fires in East Side tenements early yesterday morning. In a blaze in the butcher shop of Rose Kinsler at 19 Hester Street shortly after 1 A. M., Harry Mande, 30 years old, of 548 Third Avenue, a fireman attached to Engine Company 15, suffered smoke poisoning and required treatment at Gounerneur Hospital.

The touring team of the Brooklyn C. C. today defeated an Ardmore cricket eleven at Fairmount'Park. First at bat, Brooklyn put together a score of 145, Jack Poyer making 49, R. A. Wiles 34, Alec Edwards 23 and Jack Roberts 11.

Mayor William E. Kane, who has moved to cut off cash aid from drinking welfare recipients, threatened today to take their children away if the children lack proper care. He said he would put the proposal before the Welfare Board Tuesday night.

The British Government waited warily tonight to learn the full extent of Chancellor Hitler's terms for a settlement of the Czech-German quarrel. In some sections of the British press there was a sigh of relief that the crisis was over and the danger averted.

James Harvey Rogers, Sterling Professor of Political Economy in Yale University, and from 1933 to 1937 one of President Roosevelt's informal monetary advisers, has delivered to Yale University Press the final chapter of his forthcoming book, "Capitalism in Crisis,"

Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane of New York were luncheon hosts at Otherside, in Northeast Harbor, for a large group today. Others entertaining with luncheons included Mr. and Mrs. Morris B. Gregg Jr., who honored Miss Jeanette Higgins and Hendrik Hudson at the Malvern, and Mr. and Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge, who entertained at Greentree.

A demand that William H. J. Ely of Rutherford, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, prove his liberalism by coming out "unswervingly for the right of free speech in Jersey City" was made by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, in an address today at the annual Labor Day picnic of the Workers Defense League of New Jersey at the Goodwill Home here.
Five members of a New Jersey vacation party were killed instantly tonight when a Boston Maine Railroad train and their automobile crashed at Pollard's Crossing, three miles from this village.

Whether next year will be another 1917 depends largely on the kind of Congressmen elected this Fall, Frederick J. Libby, executive secretary of the National Council for Prevention of War, asserted in the leading editorial of Peace Action today.
A new record for a glider duration flight in New Jersey was made here today by Stanley Hruslinski, who remained aloft 3 hours 23 minutes and 44 seconds.
By a decision taken by the Medical Association of Danzig all Jewish doctors in the Free City have suddenly been deprived of their right to practice medicine.

The policies of the Roosevelt administration carry "a greater threat tb labor than any economic or political force that has confronted labor at any time in America's history," Amos R. E. Pinchot charged last night in a pre-Labor Day letter to John L. Lewis. chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The Amsterdam Stock Exchange displayed this week remarkable resistance to the war scare. There was only very slight selling during the week, the mid-European conflict reflecting itself in contraction of trade and shrinkage of long-term commitments rather than in liquidation.

The foreign exchange market was rather quiet here this week and no great outflow of capital was noted. The stabilization fund succeeded without difficulty in maintaining the franc sterling rate at a nearly stable level.

Subject to unforeseeable announcements by the forthcoming Nazi party congress at Nuremberg, the financial outlook is regarded more favorably here. In particular, it is believed that the rise on the Boerse will facilitate Reich borrowing operations.

Miss Jean Kearny McClelland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. McClelland of this place, will be married on Sept. 17 to Julian Shumway Barrett, son-of Mr. and Mrs. William Felton Barrett of Rye, N. Y., and North Egremont, Mass.
The armed forces of Cuba today celebrated the fifth anniversary of the enlisted men's revolt that ousted the de Cespedes Administration and placed them in control of the island.

More than 100 new indictment forms to take the place of old forms considered archaic in phraseology have been drafted by the indictment bureau of the District Attorney's office since Thomas E. Dewey assumed office on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. The bureau is headed by Assistant District Attorney Stanley H. Fuld.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Franke of Lakewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Franke of Irvington, to Clifford E. Greenland, nephew of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Supple of Bloomfield.

Standing beside the monument erected at Pointe de Grave by French subscription "to the glory of the American soldiers under General Pershing who came to defend the same ideal of right and liberty that inspired the volunteers of Lafayette," Georges Bonnet,
The Constitutional President of Ecuador, to be elected by the Constitutional Congress now in session, is expected to take office Oct. 9, anniversary. of the independence of the coastal provinces.

Theodor Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna, in a pastoral letter read in Austrian Catholic churches today, challenges the Nazi party, particularly on two points-namely, secularization of marriage and the dismissal of priests and nuns from teaching posts and nuns from hospitals where they served as nurses.

The committee for the nomination of Samuel Kupferman as the Republican candidate for Congress from the Twentieth Manhattan District announced yesterday the opening of headquarters at 1,706 Lexington Avenue.

John Couch, 23, of St. Louis, confessed kidnapper of a St. Louis couple, escaped from the Ramsey County jail late today. With a spoon he loosened a brick next to the window of his first-floor cell and because of the deterioration of the old mortar was able to loosen other bricks and drop to the street.

Mrs. Belle Kleinert Sessler of 271 Central Park West, president of the Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El, died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital after a twoday illness and an operation performed Saturday night.

The ban against visitors at Holmesburg Prison, scene of the recent "heat torture" deaths of four convicts, was continued today by Dr. Frederick S. Baldi, who was named last week as temporary superintendent following the holding of Superintendent William B. Mills and thirteen other members of the prison staff for the grand jury on charges of "criminal negligence."
The body of the seventh victim of North Central Colorado's floods was recovered today while thousands of workmen wielded picks and shovels to clean up debris over a wide area.

Church dignitaries and laymen high in the life of the State and nation expressed their sorrow yesterday over the death of Cardinal Hayes. All day long, as news of his passing became known, tributes to the Cardinal and to the place he had in the life of the nation were made public.

IN sauntered Mr. Si Goodfriend, 83 years old, as blithe as any cricket. Jaunty hat, snappy cane, trim gray suit, a pointed white beard, a flourishing crop of white hair. His only concession to age is a pair of spectacles. He still has his youthful zest for baseball. He was a baseball writer some fifty years ago before he went into the theatrical business and became secretary and publicist for Richard Mansfield.

Leslie G. Carlton, mining man, died early today after several weeks' illness. Since the death of his brother, A. E. Carlton, seven years ago, he directed the extensive Carlton interests which were strung over the Rocky Mountain region to the Pacific Coast.

The Mexican Government formally rejected the demands of the United States Government for immediate payments for lands of United States nationals that it has expropriated, in a note from Eduardo Hay, Minister of Foreign Relations, which was delivered to Josephus Daniels, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, on Friday and made public here and in Mexico'City today.
An airplane crashed while taking off from the Danbury Airport to-today, seriously injuring the pilot and a passenger, Worth Chatfield and Philip Shay, both of Farmingdale, N. Y.

An Adirondack Mountain climbing expedition which he organized ended in death today for Arthur Huster, 35, of Philadelphia. Vacationing at Lake George with four companions, Mr. Huster suggested late yesterday that they try to scale Tongue Mountain, about ten miles from here.
Two Oregon State College scientists announced today the discovery of a new chemical which they called as vital to life and growth as the vitamins and hormones.

Miss Edith Weisner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Weisner of New York, was married here today to Louis P. Williams of Jackson Heights, N. Y., at Camp Onota for Boys, of which the bridegroom is a director.

It is the duty of Catholics to "get into the parade. and. go down the road with labor," the Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, Catholic Bishop of Amarillo, Texas, declares in an article to be published tomorrow by The Commonweal, Catholic lay weekly.

Harry Dalrymple, a 30-year-old veteran parachute jumper of Phillipsburg, N. J., plunged 2,000 feet to his death at the Penn-Jersey airport this evening when his parachute failed to open as he made an exhibition jump.
France took military measures today to guard against any eventuality as German troops continued to move into the new Siegfried chain of fortifications.

Associated News Photographic Service, Inc., of 20 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, was charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with making misleading representations in promoting the sale of its pictures.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, has as passengers Sir Henry Chilton. British Ambassador to Spain; Raymond Massey, Douglas Fairbanks, Lieut. Col. C. M. Turner,

Mrs. Henry M. Bankhead, wife of the commercial attach of of the United States Legation, died here today after a long illness. She was born in St. Augustine, Fla., fifty-seven years ago, when Colonel Bankhead was appointed to the legation.
Mrs. Reginald H. Burcher of Scarsdale N. Y., died early today at her Summer home her of a heart attack, after being ill of pneumonia for a month. Her age was 61.

Miss Martha Dodd, daughter of William E. Dodd, former Ambassador to Germany, was married to Alfred K. Stern, New York housing expert, in a simple ceremony at noon today at the home of her father in Round Hill, Va., near Leesburg.
A bystander was shot in the back and wounded seriously by a policeman early yesterday morning during a chase of two hold-up suspects over the Manhattan Bridge and along the Bowery and Third Avenue.

More intensive practice of Christianity's "most distinguishing principle," which is "Love thy neighbor as thyself," was described as the only solution for many of the world's ills by the Rev. Dr. Harry Lathrop Reed, president of the Auburn Theological Seminary,
A stream of singing Nazis marched into Nuremberg yesterday in preparation for the party congress, opening today. Although rain was general in Germany, tens of thousands were on the roads.

Customs and immigration officials will be kept busy today at the North River piers with the arrival of four liners bringing 5,236 passengers from Europe. The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary has 1,993, the record number westbound this season;

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Edgar Shenkman, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre. Bruno Labate, first oboe of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, was the soloist, and Irving Hopkins the commentator.

The discovery of fragments of bisonhide moccasins, hark sandals, throwing sticks and other articles in- caves of Southern Oregon indicate that man may have inhabited the Pacific Northwest 10,000 years ago.
The first attempt to cure a baby boy of whooping cough by flying him in an open sports plane was made 10,000 feet above Vienna today.
The Phillies today ended a five-game losing streak, beating the Bees, 4 to 2, but Boston took the second game of the double-header, 6 to 2, behind a "kid" pitcher.

Of the nine legitimate attractions now resident on Broadway all but one wilt give Labor Day matinees today. (The single holdout is "You Can't Take it With You," moving this evening from the Booth to the Imperial.)

With only two weeks of Summer raining remaining for units of the New York National Guard, the final major movement for the season was completed today with the departure of 3,400 guardsmen from camp Smith and Pine Camp and the arrival of replacements totaling about 1,800.

About 100 veterans were here today for the opening of the seventy-second national annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. Meanwhile several hundred members of allied organizations, such as the Sons and Daughters of Union Veterans,
With Seymour (Shorty) Knox leading the attack with ten goals, the Aurora riders turned back the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 14 to 4, in the weekly high-goal match at Bostwick Field today.

The third largest crowd of the season at Ebbets Field, 33,465 paying patrons, saw the Giants and Dodgers split a double-header yesterday and neither the Flatbush faction of the fans nor the Terryless champions derived much satisfaction therefrom. The even break was particularly costly to the New Yorkers, who dropped to fourth place in the National League.

Outplaying the New York Americans in both halves, the Sparta Football Club of Chicago, national soccer cup-holder, defeated the former United States champions by 4 to 1 in the first game of its Eastern tour before 3,000 fans at Starlight Park yesterday.

Senator Schwartz, Democrat of Wyoming, a member of the TVA investigating committee, gave the government power and planning agency a clean bill of health today on the basis of evidence received to date.

Most people follow one of two techniques of living-they try to make the best of a tragic world or they live happily with God, the Rev. James Gordon Gilky, pastor of the South Congregational Church of Springfield, Mass.,

Kenneth A. Simpson, 23 years old, of 204 South Third Street, Harrison, was killed and John Ciampi, 24, of 64 Hunterdon Street, this city, was seriously injured early today when a motor cycle on which they were riding struck a tree on Broadway near Hinsdale Place.
Obligation of the Communist party to support President Roosevelt and the New Deal in coming elections was urged here today by Earl Browder, national executive secretary of the party.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Landers of Maplewood have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Thayle Landers, to William J. Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. R. Wolf of Fairmont, Minn. The wedding will take place this month.
The Athletics broke a five-game losing streak today by nosing out the Boston Red Sox, 12 to 11, in the first game of a twin bill, but were beaten in the second, 12 to 2.

The fall of European currencies in the foreign exchange market, particularly that of the pound sterling, is due to a concurrence of facts, the principal one of which, according to Dutch belief, is a somewhat sudden alteration in the position of trade balances of the sterling block and the United States.
Irvin H. (Call Me Pop) Hanes wants to be State Auditor because the $4,000 yearly salary is considerably more than he ever received before. Seeking the Democratic nomination,
Thomas C. Corner, portrait painter and one of the founders of the Baltimore Museum of Art, died this morning at Union Memorial Hospital. Death was due to an embolism.

Many New York City clergymen devoted their sermons yesterday to Labor Day and its significance. They held that the labor question was one of national concern and that the church must take an active stand on labor questions.

Paul Wood and Bud Euler of the Ocean City Yacht Club sailed Scarab to victory in a group of seventeen Stars from five Atlantic seaboard fleets by a minute and 50 seconds today in the second of the three-race Jersey Coast challenge series for the Valspar Trophy.

The crisis in character transcends the crisis in world economic and political affairs, the Rev. Frank W. Murtfeldt, associate pastor' of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle Church, at Fifty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Fritz Kuhn, newly re-elected national leader of the German-American Bund, announced to 2,000 Bund members and others assembled at Camp Nordland here today a ninepoint program which will be undertaken within the coming year.

Up-State marriages in July totaled 4,275, as compared to 7,243 during July, 1937, a decrease of 2,968, Dr. J. V. DePorte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the Department of Health, reported today.

Mrs. Johannes A. L. van den Bosch gave a tea at the Lenox Club today in honor of her daughter, Miss Jeanne F. van den Bosch, and her fiance, John Murray Begg, whose engagement was announced last week. A company of 150 attended. Tables were set on the south lawn and porches. Mrs. David T. Dana,

Views in The Netherlands regarding the Autumn outlook for trade and markets in the United States remain optimistic, although there are differences of opinion whether the advance there will be a bubble created by pump-priming or recovery of a sounder nature.
Mayor Nellie E. Leffler and the City Council have brought poker playing here out into the open. It is illegal to play at home, but five licensed card rooms operate under a recently adopted ordinance.

A United States swimming team which recently set what was claimed to be a world 400-meter relay record of 3 minutes 59.3 seconds cut that time to 3:56 today, but was disqualified for an illegal start.

Mike Chartak's single with the bases filled in the final inning of the nightcap today gave the Bears an 8-to-7 victory over the Jersey City Giants for a clean sweep of the twin bill. Newark won the opener by 5 to 4.

The only two unbeaten quartets in the Eastern Polo League, the Blind Brook Knights and the Governors Island Yellows, met yesterday at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, with the Westchester riders taking a thrilling match, 6 to 5. More than 3,000 attended.

Count Anton Luis Apponyi, 61-year-old industrialist, and Mrs. Madeleine Forrest of New York were married by a registrar here today. The Count is an uncle of Queen Geraldine of Albania, daughter of the former Gladys Virginia Stewart of New York.

The Queen Mary, flagship of the Cunard White Star Line, is due in port this morning. She will sail Wednesday on her 100th transatlantic crossing since entering the passenger and freight field in May, 1936.
The International Olympic Committee, at a meeting last night, decided to award the 1940 Winter Games to St. Moritz, Switzerland.
Harry M. Emerick, general agent of the Ocean Steamship Company, died suddenly here last night. He was 60 years old.

Miss Lillian Schoenbrun, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Schoenbrun of Dover, N. J., was married here today at the Park Lane Hotel to Dr. Benjamin E. Obletz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Harry Obletz of this city.
James T. Lee gave a large cocktail party this afternoon at his residence on Lily Pond Lane for his three daughters, Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d, Mrs. John J. Ryan Jr. and Mrs. Franklin D'Olier Jr.

Joe Kuhel's single with two out in the tenth inning today scored the rookie second baseman, George Meyer, from second base to give the White Sox a 2-to-1 victory over the Tigers and break up a pitching duel between Johnny Rigney and Al Benton.
Securities issued in August calling for new capital amounted to only [Pound]2,184,000, against [Pound]15,188,116 in the preceding month and [pound]7,141,184 in August, 1937.
The opera "Chaluzim" ("The Pioneers"), by Jacob Weinberg, New York composer, which won first prize at the International Music Contest of 1926 in Philadelphia, had its European premiere here today.

Any outlook for this nation for the present should take the soul into consideration, declared the Rev. William Van H. Davies in a sermon yesterday morning at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

The Spanish Nationalists [Insurgents] are establishing a form of government that, paradoxically, is totalitarian in appearance but not in operation. They resent the term "Fascist" and prefer to describe their government as an authoritarian instrument, centralizing authority or power in the State.

In the second and concluding Series of Australian-United States women's team tennis matches, played on the Maidstone Club courts today, the American stars atoned for yesterday's poor showing at Southampton by winning four out of the six matches played and tying the tally at six matches apiece.

The struggle between John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, for control of the second largest C. I. O. union is due for a showdown this week.

With the death of Cardinal Hayes, administration of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, looked upon as the largest, wealthiest and most influential archdiocese in the New World, passed momentarily into the hands of its Board of Consultors.

" The Oxford group represents the new industrial revolution," H. K. Twitchell, leader of the New York unit, told the Oxford groups assembly here in a discussion today regarding the need of finding the answer to industrial warfare within nations as a prerequisite to international peace. "The forgotten factor in

The United States small-bore shooters compiled a total of 3,952 out of 4,000 today to win the R. W. S. (Rheinisch - Westfalische Sprengstoff Aktiengesellsschaft) international trophy team match in which Great Britain reported a score of 3,913.
Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 44 per cent of capacity, a rise of 1 point in a week and an advance of 15 points from the average in June.

The sincerest tribute which can be paid to the memory of any man is to be mourned by the poor. Cardinal Hayes will be so mourned. He had them always in his heart. He rose from among them and went back among them again and again, ever on errands of mercy and charity.

State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee appealed to motorists today to be especially careful in their driving during the next months, when children throughout the State return to their classrooms.
Verdi's "Il Trovatore,": scheduled for last night as the closing performance of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company's season at Randalls Island, was canceled because of "threatening cold weather."

Charles Bradley, president of the Alliance Investment Company and the Saranac Realty Company, and formerly president of the brewing firm of P. Ballantine Sons of Newark, died early yesterday morning of pneumonia at his home in Convent, N. J. He was born in Newark eighty-one years ago last Wednesday.

A group of forty or more Roosevelt "enthusiasts," men and women prominent in their present or past support of the President, have been scheduled for speeches in more than 100 of Georgia's 159 counties between Tuesday and primary day, Sept. 14, in behalf of the renomination of Senator Walter F. George.
Mrs. Helen Montgomery of Detroit equalled the American women's duration record of five hours and fifteen minutes late today and continued aloft in the American open soaring meet.
The money value of British retail trade sales in July was 3.6 per cent higher than in July, 1937, following an increase of 8.6 per cent in June and a decrease of 6.1 per cent in May.
The main line between Boston and Portland via Portsmouth was severed today by the burning of a 224-foot trestle between Oak Island and Point of Pines in Revere.

Representatives of about fifty leading transportation, shipping and financial organizations will participate in a transportation conference in Washington on Sept. 14-15, it was announced today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.

More than 1,500 persons inspected the Raymere estate of W. C. Durant, former motor manufacturer, in Deal near here today at a preview of the furnishings to be sold along with the estate at a public auction Sept. 13 to 17.

Dr. Samuel A. Shaffer, physician and for the last seven years president of the Gloucester County Federation of Men's Bible Classes, died in the Methodist Hospital, Philadelphia, on Friday night, after an illness of several months.

Heavy Rebel attacks on the Ebro bridgeheads continued today, and two more hills in the Gandesa sector were admittedly lost by the Loyalists, so it now seems fairly certain that the Rebels have started a new counter-offensive against the sector.

Labor Day statements by leaders of the American Federation of Labor and of the Committee for Industrial Organization indicated their determination to continue their fight for leadership in the ranks of organized labor.
The Rev. Dr. W. Earl Ledden, minister of Trinity Methodist Church, Albany, N. Y., in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, said:

(Figures in parentheses indicate par.) Brookville (72)-First round for club championship, First Flight: Henry Blohme defeated J. Sullivan, 3 and 2. Second Flight: M. Petroccia defeated G. Cornelius, 1 up; S. Rabe defeated A. Syse, 2 up. Third Flight: M. Ryan defeated H. J. Murphy, 4 and 3; R. B. Davidson defeated A. Wright. 3 and 2. Fourth Flight: J. Conholly defeated W. Dowie, 2 up; Anderson defeated W. H. Maxwell, 2 up.
Further buying from Eastern financial centers was noted yesterday in the market here for California municipal bonds, but the week ended with prices showing average losses of around 3 points.
The first tocsin is sounded for school. Wednesday, Thursday and Friday will be registration days for children who are entering

A plea for Britain, France, the United States and Russia to preserve the democracy of Czechoslovakia was delivered by an English labor union leader today on the eve of the opening of the seventieth annual Trades Union Congress.
The fall of the pound sterling last week below its old parity with the dollar was, if nothing else; historically interesting, for it had not been so low since May, 1935.

Gordon William Carlyle Whiting has sent out invitations to the marriage of his daughter, Miss Natalie Contee Whiting, to Dr. Hugh Grigsby Whitehead Jr., also of Baltimore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitehead of Norfolk, Va.,

The 102 West Ninety-fourth Street Corporation sold to an investor the apartment house at that address for cash over a mortgage Russell H. Hines was the broker and J. Tobias Goldberg, attorney, represented the buyer.
To most of us Labor Day means a three-day week-end, a week-end of record travel, of record automobile accidents and drownings, and a sort of official termination of Summer and beginning of Fall.

Moderate temperatures and a warm sun conspired yesterday to make the second of the three days of the Labor Day holiday a pleasant one for every one-bathers, out-of-town visitors, autoists, hikers, theatre owners and beach concessionaires.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt today declared that 12,000,000 Americans were idle because "the half-baked policies of New Deal theorists have definitely prevented the return of prosperity on a sound basis."

The first effect of the North American wheatexport program was apparent last week in the world wheat market, with prices of that grain in Liverpool and Winnipeg declining in terms of the dollar to the lowest levels since 1932-33, without consideration being given to the change in the price of gold.
The Dionne quintuplets are reported to be scheduled to experience the first surgical operation in their young lives late this month when their tonsils will be removed.

President Roosevelt traveled into Maryland today to open his "purge" campaign against Senator Millard E. Tydings with the promise of a new $3,000,000 bridge across the Potomac River for which backers of Representative David J. Lewis, the Senator's opponent for the nomination, are already claiming credit.

A $5,000,000 program to improve Long Island rivers and harbors is now under way, it was disclosed today. The funds, to be provided from local State and Federal sources, will be more than twice the amount invested in such improvements in the area in the last 100 years.
Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons, in opening the British Commonwealth Relations Conference here today, said that the aggregate might of the British Commonwealth remained the decisive factor for peace.

Patrick Joseph Cardinal Hayes was as much a product of the "sidewalks of New York" as former Governor Smith. He was born on the lower East Side, he was educated here, and he rose from priest to Cardinal within the Archdiocese of New York.

Mr. and Mrs. James Hooper Grew, who have passed the Summer traveling in Europe, will arrive today on the Ile de France and after a short stay in New York will go to Boston, where they will be the guests of Mr. Grew's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sturgis Grew. Mrs. James H. Grew is the former Miss Alma Clayburgh.

Liquidation developed last week in the lard market here, the near-by deliveries dropping to the lowest level since August, 1934. September lard at the extreme was only a small fraction of a cent above 7 1/2 cents a pound.
The money market here was slightly tighter this week, because of fund requirements for the month-end settlement, but was becoming easier at the beginning of September.

Stocks recovered early losses and closed at levels of previous Saturday; turnover, 3,760,380 shares. United States Government and corporation bonds lower; foreign issues irregular; transactions, $22,323,850.

In what at the beginning of the week appeared to be a rapid drift in European politics towards a crisis, the security markets here have remained commendably calm. It is true that nerves were jarred by events of the previous week-end but there was no appreciable fall in values,

Mansfield Ferry, a member of the law firm of Mitchell, Taylor, Capron Marsh, at 20 Exchange Place, who was general counsel to the Alien Property Custodian throughout 1919, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 62 East Ninety-second Street, after a brief illness. He was born in Chicago fif ty-six years ago.

Louis Apfelbaum, 32 years old, a salesman, of 2,265 Dividson Avenue, the Bronx, was placed under $5,000 bail last night by Magistrate Bromberger in Night Court for a hearing tomorrow on a homicide charge growing out of the death Saturday night of James Hayes of East Granby, Conn., who was fatally injured by a hit-and-run driver at East River Drive and 105th Street.
Dr. Leston Du Bois, 35, Coroner of Ulster County since 1934, and his brother, Vernon Du Bois, 37, were killed last night when their automobile left a highway near here and crashed into a tree.

In the current issue of The Annalist appears the last of a series of three articles by Alanson W. Willcox, assistant general counsel of the Social Security Board, in defense of the muchcriticized Old Age Reserve Account.

The Pirates stopped the Cardinals' winning streak at six straight contests today with a 5-to-3 victory in the finale of their three-game series. The triumph boosted the Buccaneers' margin in the National League to six games over the second-place Reds, who lost to Chicago.

The extraordinary attention that attorneys for both sides in the James J. Hines conspiracy case were giving over the week-end to the $500 check transaction introduced in the trial Friday presaged one of the biggest contests of the whole trial when court is resumed tomorrow morning.

Jack Rutherfurd of Port Washington, L. I., drove his 225cubic-inch hydroplane Juno over the choppy waters of Great Egg Harbor Bay at an average of 48.077 miles per hour today to win the Absecon Yacht Club's annual free-for-all race for the third successive time.

One of the major Interests of Cardinal Hayes was the up building of the Catholic Charities, founded by him in 1920 and now regarded by professional welfare workers as one of the most efficiently administered organizations of its kind in the world.

In finer shape than Coach Steve Owen ever has seen his squad at this early date, the New York Football Giants participated in a brisk one-hour workout last night under the floodlights at the Polo Grounds, where they are to battle the AllStars on Wednesday evening.
Augie Galan hit a triple and home run to give the Cubs a 2-to-1 eleven inning victory over Cincinnati in the final of the series today. The defeat snapped the Reds' winning streak at six.
The army wants 8,000 more enlisted men next year to man the new planes, tanks and anti-aircraft guns now being made.

The Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that Christ alone was "the great unifier of the human race, but man's selfishness has been the cause of the divisions of the race."
Five were dead today and twentyeight injured, several seriously, as the result of a midnight collision of a Greyhound bus and a light sedan between Charlotte and Gastonia.
Various entertainments were given today for holiday guests at estates throughout the colony. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anderson Magowan entertained with a large dinner dance at the Beach House at Lyndune,
The German wholesale price index on Aug. 24 stood at 106, against 106.1 on Aug. 17. The August living-cost index was 126.5, against 126.8 for July.

After a week in which prices of securities moved irregularly but on the whole upward, the markets here closed yesterday confident, active and firm. To this condition unquestionably the improved international outlook contributed.

The pink-shirted Greentree poloists, champions two years ago and runners-up to Old Westbury last season, started their climb back to the heights today when they turned back the Anglo-American Jaguars, 15 to 9, in the opening game of this year's national open tourney.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.6, which compared with 80.4 the week before, 79.9 two weeks before, 80.2 three weeks before and 81.0 four weeks before.
Colonel Howard H. Derr, a working newspaper-man for fifty-nine years until his retirement last year, died at his home in Germantown today after an illness from a kidney ailment. He was 74 years old.

Deputy Police Inspector Richard F. Oliver, in charge of the Fourth Detective District in Manhattan, who was associated in some of the most celebrated criminal cases handled by the New York Police Department in his twenty-eight years of service died suddenly early this morning at his home, 684 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn.

Mrs. William R. Meeks, 55 years old, returned home today from a fifty-six-hour kidnapping ordeal, and officers said later that they had found the spot where the woman allegedly was held for $15,000 ransom, which was not paid.

Harold Halsted sailed his Star boat Chuckle III, to triumph today in the second series of the annual Labor Day week-end regatta. Harry Meislahn's Sunbeam was second and High Seas, sailed by Bill Picken, was third.

The stock market here opened the week with uncertainty, sellers predominating, but immediately it turned firm and later was almost strong. Better news from foreign markets stimulated the initial recovery, and later good reports from the steel industry and from banks, as well as from the potash industry, encouraged buyers, who were mostly of the investment class.

The Monmouth County Country Club poloists had little trouble turning back the invading Burnt Mills riders, 8 to 1, today. Fine team play and accurate hitting by Allison Stern, who tallied four goals, had much to do with Monmouth's success. The line-up:

It is a shock to learn that the city's effort to add a rabbit quota to our population has met with indifferent success. One would think that the warrens of this great metropolis would have appealed strongly to these engaging little beasts.

Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Bergen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Bergen of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Harold Frederick Relyea of this city and Rome, N. Y., which will take place in St. James Episcopal Church, Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue, on Sept. 29.
Dr. Edward Schnaper, a specialist in obstetrics and gynecology, died suddenly Saturday of a heart attack at his residence, 25 East Seventy-seventh Street, in his sixtyfourth year.

Miss Sarah Huber Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Logan Lewis of Plainfield, formerly of Syracuse, N. Y., will be married to Craig Hutchinson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Morrow Smith of this city, on the evening of Oct. 14 in the First-Park Baptist Church.

Miss Alice Neal Gordon and E. Kenneth Sandbach, whose engagement was announced here early in July, will be married the afternoon of Sept. 17 in the Paris Hill Church. The Rev. Hila Libby Ives of Portland will perform the ceremony.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent editorials and articles on the subject of the critical condition of the railroads have been very informative and extremely interesting, but they have failed to delineate one very important aspect of the situation-the attitude and policies of the managements.

While corn futures failed to sell here at new low levels for this season last week, the market showed a heavy undertone and closing trades yesterday were at net losses of 2 1/2 to 3 3/4 cents a bushel.
Ten persons were killed and forty injured today in a renewal of rioting among Burmese Buddhists and Indian Moslems.

By winning three events, Ernie Riedel, national champion and former Olympian, captured individual honors and possession for another year of the Walter Bonk Memorial Trophy in the sixth annual regatta at the American Canoe Association camp today.

Following is the text of the translation of the note from the Minister of Foreign Relations of Mexico, Eduardo Hay, dated Sept. 2, 1938, and handed to the American Ambassador at Mexico City on Friday:

In spite of a score of luncheons at country homes, country clubs and on yachts moored in North Shore waters for the holiday regattas and the international races off Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at Oyster Bay,

There was a fine southwester today that piped up to twenty knots for the Larchmont Yacht Club's Walter S. Sullivan Memorial regatta. Thirty-seven craft took part, seventeen of them in the Handicap Class, of which Sullivan was president sixteen years until his death last Fall, and a member from the time it was organized in 1906.

Nathan A. Rosen of Miami Beach, Fla., a banker, died here yesterday while on a visit, in the Beacon Hotel, Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street, after an illness of a few days. He was 42 years old. Before moving to Florida in 1930 Mr. Rosen had been in the investment business

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 70.4 on Aug. 31, compared with 71.4 a fortnight before, 72 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
About 4,000 persons, many of them described as Americans of Ukrainian descent, held a demonstration for Ukraine's independence last night at the Hippodrome.
After a Summer-long truce, the Amish "little red schoolhouse" argument promises to flare anew when school reopens in Lancaster County on Tuesday.

Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office at Geneva, declared yesterday in a Labor Day statement made public here through the American Federation of Labor that relations between the United States and the International Labor Organization appear to have become closer with each year.

Several persons who are planning fishing vacations this month have written for details on the famous Seigniory Club in Quebec. The trout and bass fishing there is well known to many anglers, and considerable interest is being exhibited by a number of American anglers who are planning trips to Canada.

Invitations have been issued by Mrs. Waiter Lyman Bunnell of this place for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Ernestine Bunnell, to Albert L. Birdsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Birdsall of Grand Rapids, Mich.

An indication that the Central American governments may stand together in opposition to any move against fascism at the Pan American Conference in Lima in December is seen in editorials in the newspaper La Prenza of San Salvador, capital of El Salvador.

PROFESSORS of history are not, as a rule, wonder men; some mighty comfortable morning naps have been taken in history classrooms while the professor droned like a large fly across the blackboard. For all I know, that is what happens in Allan Nevins's lectures up at Columbia; certainly any one who uses up as much energy as a writer of history can have relatively little left for oral purposes.
Miss Florence Gilbert Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Evans Tucker, who made her debut last night at a supper dance given by her uncle and aunt,

Patrick Joseph Hayes, Archbishop of New York and Cardinal Priest of the Roman Catholic Church, died quietly in his sleep early yesterday morning at his Summer home amid trees and spreading lawns on the 900-acre grounds of St. Joseph's Sanatorium and School, in Sullivan- County, near Monticello, N. Y.

R. R. J. Reynolds's new sloop Blitzen, winner in Class B in this year's Bermuda race, won the Vineyard Trophy today by having the best corrected time and was first in Class A in the Stamford Yacht Club's seventh annual race to the Vineyard Sound lightship and return, a distance of 232 nautical miles.
Darkness robbed the veteran Russ Van Atta of a pitching masterpiece as the Indians and Browns played to a 1-to-1 tie in a seven-inning second game of a double-header today.

Several persons who are planning fishing vacations this month have written for details on the famous Seigniory Club in Quebec. The trout and bass fishing there is well known to many anglers, and considerable interest is being exhibited by a number of American anglers who are planning trips to Canada.

Invitations have been issued by Mrs. Waiter Lyman Bunnell of this place for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Ernestine Bunnell, to Albert L. Birdsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Birdsall of Grand Rapids, Mich.

An indication that the Central American governments may stand together in opposition to any move against fascism at the Pan American Conference in Lima in December is seen in editorials in the newspaper La Prenza of San Salvador, capital of El Salvador.

PROFESSORS of history are not, as a rule, wonder men; some mighty comfortable morning naps have been taken in history classrooms while the professor droned like a large fly across the blackboard. For all I know, that is what happens in Allan Nevins's lectures up at Columbia; certainly any one who uses up as much energy as a writer of history can have relatively little left for oral purposes.
Miss Florence Gilbert Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Evans Tucker, who made her debut last night at a supper dance given by her uncle and aunt,

While holiday influences tended last week to reduce activity in the commodity markets, relatively large advances in the prices of hogs and affiliated products lifted The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices for the third successive week,

Reversing the result of their rout at Longwood, Adrian Quist and John Bromwich kept Australia in the fight for the Davis Cup today as they played Donald Budge and Gene Mako off their collective feet in the challenge round doubles at the Germantown Cricket Club.

Historians of the future will emphasize not the financial difficulties of this age, but its moral panic, declared Dr. Fred P. Corson, president of Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Mark's Methodist Church, Ocean Avenue and Beverly Road, Brooklyn.

In the week which is apt to be the most inactive of the year, no change occurred in the financial or industrial situation. The gradual recovery of steel production which has been in progress since the middle of June continued; last week's estimated output rose from 43 per cent of capacity to 44, against 37 per cent a month ago and 25 in June.

The general trend of cotton prices last week was to lower levels, the lows for the week being reached by Saturday. At the close of the market then, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 20 to 25 points in the week.

Lists indicating active apartment renting were released over the week-end by brokers and managing agents of multi-family buildings in Manhattan. The rush for rooms kept agents busy in houses in the Greenwich Village section showing apartments to prospective tenants who want their new living quarters ready for occupancy on Oct. 1.
Miss Dorothy Elizabeth Crum, daughter of Mrs. E. Wylly Crum of Poughkeepsie and of Raymond Crum of Stamford, Conn., was married in the Reformed Church here at noon today to Granger Hollister Frost.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull intends to forego the Labor Day holiday to keep in closest touch with the Central European situation. He is scheduled to go to his office tomorrow morning to read the long dispatches coming in from United States Embassies and Legations in Europe.
The condition of Prince Arthur of Connaught, son of the Duke of Connaught and grandson of Queen Victoria, was reported unchanged today after a restful night.
The Navy Department reported today that the United States gunboat Oahu had been damaged slightly by a barge which broke away from a Japanese tug on the Yangtze River above Nanking.

Harry R. Bridges, West Coast director of the C. I. O. and president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, asserted today that the present "united front" of employers was "an openand-shut drive, timed to coincide with the election campaign, to restore the open shop here on the basis that prevailed before the New Deal and the 1934 general strike."

Cross Bay Boulevard, one of the main arteries leading to the Rockaways, was closed to all traffic at 1 P. M. yesterday, when contractors working on the South Channel Bridge discovered that the north pier of the span was sinking and had caused a leaf of the drawbridge to rise three inches.

Paced by Joe Gordon, who appeared to be in a mood for great violence, the Yankees exploded four home runs before the admiring gaze of 14,107 onlookers yesterday, and thereby exterminated the Senators so swiftly that the entire visit of Bucky Harris's men for their single game in the Stadium was over in 1 hour 34 minutes.

The plan of capital reorganization submitted by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to its security holders may turn out to be particularly interesting as a test of the amended Federal Bankruptcy Act of August, 1935.
