A prayer for the unemployed was voiced by the Rev. Henry C. Offerman, pastor of Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning. "Our heart bleeds when we see somany standing around who want to work," he said. "Open the sluices of work-honest labor with a chance at advancement-and a hope for a better tomorrow.

The contrast between Washington and other world capitals was never more striking than it is today. In times of international stress, by now a chronic state, most Governments are at cross purposes in their foreign policy.
Vincent Daniels, 29 years old, a soda fountain clerk of 11 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, died at the Methodist-Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon of a bullet wound in the abdomen.

An urgent appeal to the British Government to relax its restrictions in Palestine so that mass immigration for Jewish refugees otherwise homeless might be permitted and a summons to world Jewry to furnish $10,000,000 as a minimum during the next year for the defense

Anthony Wilhelm (Tony) Levier, 25-year-old Los Angeles speed pilot, set a new record today for the Greve Trophy race, feature event of the second day of the National Air races, when he covered the 200-mile course at an average speed of 250.88 miles an hour. He received $10,000 for winning and $2,000 for breaking the record.

The last of the season's four concerts by the Naumburg Orchestra will be given tonight at 8:15 o'clock on the Mall in Central Park. Joseph Littau will conduct and Emil Borsody, 'cello, will be the soloist.

By Ignoring the City Fusion party in making up their coalition slate in Kings County the Republican and American Labor parties have given the leaders and workers of the fusion organization just cause for resentment, Michael Potter, chairman of the City Fusion party for Kings, declared yesterday.
The Jewish War Veterans, here for their annual encampment, paraded down Woodward Avenue this afternoon with more than 3,000 in line.

More than 900 parishioners, besides prominent clergymen of New York and Westchester County, attended funeral services this afternoon in Christ's Episcopal Church here for the Rev. Dr. R. Townsend Henshaw, its rector for more than twenty-eight years, who died last Tuesday in Laredo, Texas.

Douglas Fairbanks Jr., who will be starred in RKO's "Memory of Love" opposite Claudette Colbert as his first assignment under his new contract with the studio, signed last week at a reported figure of $75,000 a picture.
The French wholesale price index on Aug. 27 was 645, against 644 on Aug. 20 and Aug. 13.
Edgar Maurice Smith, former president of the Montreal Stock Exchange and partner in a brokerage firm here, died today at Whitefield, N. H., according to word received here. He was 68.

Secretary Perkins, in a Labor Day statement issued today, hailed the Wagner Labor Relations Act, the Social Security Act and the Wages and Hours Bill as the outstanding accomplishments of the Roosevelt Administration on behalf of the workers.
Cyril Harrison paced the Rumson Country Club polo team to a 5-3 victory over Shrewsbury before several thousand spectators today.

The German-American Bund, at its national convention yesterday in Turnhalle, 152 East Eighty-fifth Street, voted a petition for an amendment to the Constitution which would exclude Jews from election or appointment to public offices and the courts.

The Prague Cabinet formulated its "last-word" offer to the Sudeten Germans and it will be presented to their leaders probably today. It was said to include far-reaching concessions, but to maintain all essential principles.

While France moved troops to the German frontier as an "unavoidable precaution" today the British Navy quietly made last-minute preparations for the departure of the Home Fleet on "Atitumn manoeuvres" tomorrow.

General Yang Chieh, veteran Chinese political figure and military leader, today became China's new Ambassador to Soviet Rusia. General Yang said he welcomed the opportunity to establish closer relations between China and the Soviet Union.

A big sports show, entitled "Parade of Stars," will be held for about 80,000 children. tomorrow afternoon at the Yankee Stadium under the auspices of the Police Athletic League. Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine will lead a procession. of noted athletes to a flag-raising ceremony and, a salute to the flag by-the entire assemblage.

Hard' ground play, combined with twenty-two completed aerial thrusts that gained 293 yards, gave.the College All-Stars a 13-7 triumph tonight over the Washington Redskins eleven before a crowd of 18,000.
Elden Auker, Detroit pitcher, suffered a severe knee injury today as the Tigers won an abbreviated game from the Browns, 9 to 3, after losing the first of a double-header, 3 to 2.

The pennant-winning Bears swept their double-header with the Little Giants today, winning by 7 to 6 and 13 to 6, for a mark of nine straight over Jersey City and an edge of 17 to 5 in the season's series.

Plans for the two final units in the Rockefeller Center development are taking form rapidly. Both will rise in the south block of the commercial and amusement center, from Forty-eighth to Fortyninth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, on land now occupied as an automobile parking space.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The paradox of commercial and industrial stagnation in a country rich with material wealth goes on. The United States, which of all countries has the least reason not to take its fortunes in its hands, seems content to lie back supinely and to let the weakness of a jittery world infect it also.

A tour of the parks and playgrounds in the Bronx, under the auspices of the Park Association of New York City in cooperation with the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, will be conducted on Thursday, with members and guests of the two organizations inspecting the major park areas in that borough.

The Women's Rebellion which organized a "nonpartisan" fight four months ago against New Deal members of the House of Representatives who are up for renomination, will start a drive tomorrow to bar persons on relief from voting, it was announced here today by Mrs. Sarah Oliver Hulswit, head of the organization.
Witp Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, as the outstanding figure at the congress, the jubilee meeting of the Plymouth Chess Club began today at the Guildhall.

The season of religious conferences held since the beginning of July closed today at the Stony Brook Assembly when more than 900 persons gathered for the young people's Labor Day rally sponsored by the Christian and Missionary 'Alliance of. Brooklyn, coincident with the last session of the twenty-eighth General Bible Conference.

Mrs. Virginia Brooks Thompson McKelway, widow of Dr. St. Clair McKelway, former editor of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, died yesterday at her home, 21 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, after several years of invalidism.

An Italian treasure hunting expedition today decided to abandon for the present its efforts to recover silver bullion from the sunken Ward liner Merida that lies in 200 feet of water sixty miles off the Virginia Capes.

A new law designed to make soldiering financially a more secure profession was announced today. "The premise on which the law is based," says the official news agency, "is the National Socialist conception of military service as an `honor service' to the German people.

A north wind did blow for the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-first Fall regatta today. It fluttered and lightened for a time, but came back into a splendid sailing breeze, and with it went 148 craft for a fine wind-up of the Larchmont season, which brought forth a record fleet of 368 starters one day.

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep). The invasion of Maryland Free State has been accomplished with horse, foot, guns and the Postmaster General; the knife already between the Tydings ribs has been given an extra twist; the stiffnecked and embattled farmers of the Eastern Shore have stood to receive the shot which will be heard--not exactly around the world, perhaps, but, without question, through every corner of the Democratic party. Or what remains of it.
In his annual address at Southampton, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler pointed to the two great dangers to which democracy stands exposed today. One of these is that of attack from the totalitarian States.

Dr. Solomon Goldman, president of the Zionist Organization of America, in an address before the World Conference of the Palestine Foundation Fund today demanded that all Jews follow the example of Palestine Jews in fighting courageously for their rights as human beings instead of supinely accepting their present lot in many lands.

Subject to approval of stock bolders, W. Stuart Symington, former president of Rustless Iron and Steel Company, will become president and general manager of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company on Oct. 1, and Joseph Newman, present president, will become chairman of the board for the unexpired portion of his contract with the company, it was announced yesterdav by Mr. Newman. Mr.
A crowd which jammed the grandstand welcomed running horse races to the New York State Fair track today after a six-day harness meeting, which closed Saturday, had drawn disappointing turnouts.

Appointees to the new Merchant Marine Training School at Hoffman Island who have been notified in the last few days of their acceptance by the Maritime Commission will register today at the Barge Office at South Ferry, it was announced yesterday.

Fortune Gallo announced yesterday the engagement of Ivan Petroff, Bulgarian baritone, for special appearances with the San Carlo Opera Company during its forth-coming season at the Center Theatre. Mr. Petroff will make his debut with the company as Valentine in "Faust" on the afternoon of Sept. 17.

King Boris and. Queen Ioanna of Bulgaria arrived in London this afternoon and are expected to go to Balmoral Castle in a few days to visit the British King and Queen. Meanwhile they are staying at a hotel.

Senora Francisca Benavides, wife of President Oscar R. Benavides of the Republic of Peru, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria en route to Europe, where one of her sons will enter Saint-Cyr

The State Supreme Court will sit here tomorrow to break, the deadlock which has prevented either the Dauphin County grand jury or the Legislature from investigating charges of graft and corruption against the Earle administration.

Some of the changes in the Plymouth passenger ca- models for 1939 were made public yesterday by that division' of the Chrysler Corporation in connection with an exhibit of new models at the Michigan State Fair. It was announced that prices and complete details would be disclosed earlier than had been expected, probably before the end of this month.

After two weeks of a hunger strike, the "heat exhaustion" deaths of four convicts and a shift in its personnel as the outgrowth of the investigation of the deaths, Holmesburg prison will go back to "the usual routine" tomorrow.
Thousands of dollars will be saved annually by airlines through the Federal order forbidding passes, officials of airline companies said today.

The Mexican Government Petroleum Administration has completed its first direct oil barter deal with Germany, it was revealed here today. The arrangement calls for the shipment of expropriated petroleum to Ernst Jung of Hamburg.

President Roosevelt went before the voters of Maryland's Eastern Shore today to ask their support of Representative David J. Lewis as "the composite of a liberal" in his fight for the Senate seat of Millard E. Tydings.

It has not occurred to any of the calendar reformers, so far as one can recall, to suggest that we begin our new years at about the middle of September instead of on the first of January. Yet something might be said for this change.

The opening of the Nuremberg Nazi Congress, where the issue of peace or war is expected to come to a climax, finds Soviet officials and the press treating the Czechoslovak crisis with the utmost discretion.

The Jewsih War Veterans today elected Isador S. Worth of Riverside, N. J., national commander. He defeated Maxwell Cohen of Boston 1,171 votes to 1,082. Edgar Burman of Brooklyn, who ran second to Mr. Worth on the first ballot, withdrew in favor of Mr. Cohen.

A near-perfect Labor Day weekend from the standpoint of sun, wind and temperature was crowned last night by an almost accidentfree, orderly return to the city of the unestimated hundreds of thousands of city residents who sought their pleasure elsewhere over the three-day holiday.
Charles Chandler, 14 years old, of 49 St. Nicholas Terrace, was shot and seriously wounded late last night by one of five Negro boys at 128th Street and St. Nicholas Terrace.
Overwhelming power gave the Chicago Bears a 32-to-18 victory tomnight in a thrilling contest with the Southern All-Stars before a crowd of 12,000.

Guy Conwell Shepard, former administrator of packing -house products under the Federal Farm Relief Act, died of a heart attack late Sunday night in his home in Evanston, Ill. He was a well-known Chicago packing official.
Organized labor, both A. F. of L. and C. I. O., put on a tremendous show of strength today in its annual Labor Day parade.

After ten years of competition, the South Jersey fleet from the Ocean City Yacht Club won the Jersey Coast challenge series as Paul Wood and Bud Euler sailed Scarab to second place today-in the final of a three-race series.

Colonel Charles John Miller, Marine Corps officer who was credited with starting Gene Tunney on the way to the world's heavyweight boxing championship, died at the age of 54 yesterday at the Naval Hospital.

As a measure of precaution in the present tense international situation the French Government has suspended all army leaves and is calling to the colors sufficient reserves to fill all gaps in the Eastern fortification line and the covering regiments.

The Society for Jewish Farm Settlement in Russia-organized and financed by American Jews to assist Jews in the Soviet Union to readjust themselves to the Soviet economic system--is liquidating its affairs here and will withdraw entirely from the Soviet Union in about a fortnight.

A demand that they be called together gain to work out a remedy for Southern ills is rising among memers of the advisory committee which helped prepare a report of Southern conditions for President Roosevelt.

Ash Wednesday, Willow Brook Farm mare and Beckie Dale, the New brook Stable's fleet 2-year-old pacer, won the feature events at the holiday matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

After a 300-mile tour of Maryland's Eastern Shore, President Roosevelt arrived back at the White House tonight to pack his bags again for Hyde Park, for which he entrained a few hours after his return.

The Foreign Secretary is receiving favorable replies from South American countries to his circular requesting an opinion concerning arbitration of the. Ecuadorean-Peruvian boundary' question by President Roosevelt, according to reports in the local press.

Total advertising linage in the eight New York newspapers dedined 20.3 per cent in August, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The total last months was 6,117,312 lines, as compared with 7,675,866 lines in August, 1937.

A luncheon meeting will he held September 8 in the Hotel Commodore by the management division of the Real Estate Club of New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, at which plans will be arranged for the annual dinner of the division. Samuel G. Rosenthal and Richard L. Rafalsky are chairmen of the management division.
No more welcome guests than the Dodgers could have dropped in at the Bees' field today, and no hosts could possibly have been less hospitable than the Bees.

In response to a letter from the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement asking for comments concerning the work being done by the committee, the First Avenue Association, Inc., has suggested a change in the basis for the fiveyear tax exemption on building improvements.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Church Blunt Jr. of West Newton gave a tea today at their Summer home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Snow Blunt, to Edward Vermilye Cox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cox of Plainfield, N. J.

In accordance with plans approved by the Superintendent of Schools, the Police Commissioner and the president of City College, a course in "Physical and Moral Welfare of the Child" will be offered to a limited group of teachers during the Fall semester in the Twenty-third Street Building of City College, it was announced yesterday.

World recovery is found, in the current League of Nations yearbook, "World Economic Survey," out today, to depend most of all on the United States, the permanence of whose recent recovery the yearbook regards as problematical.

In a series decided in four matches the United States retained possession yesterday of the historic Davis Cup, which it had reclaimed last year after a decade in which the trophy had been held abroad. The meeting between the finalists in the interzone matches-the United States and Australia-at the Germantown Cricket Club produced sparkling tennis.

Henry Bernstein, 62-year-old dramatic author of French birth and Jewish ancestry, today returned to Premier Mussolini the insignia of the Order of Saint Maurice and Lazare with which he was decorated some years ago by the Italian Government.
Spanish Insurgent field reports asserted today that General Juan Yague's troops drove east in the Ebro River sector to dominate strategic government communications near Gandesa.

In its first detailed program for the second national convention of the legitimate theatre here on Sept. 13 and 14, the American Theatre Council yesterday announced that it would stress plans to revive the road, facilitate playgoing and "crystallize a sentiment toward greater cooperation, in every department" of the stage.

City realty deals announced yesterday by brokers involved business and residential parcels in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn. The six-story L-shaped garage building at 51-3 Lexington Avenue, running through to 136 East Twenty-fifth Street, adjoining the southeast corner, has been sold by the 136 East Twenty-fifth Street Corporation to a client of the Garage Realty Company, brokers.

Search for "a definite suspect" was begun today by authorities investigating the kidnapping of Mrs. W. R. Meeks, 55, who was recovering rapidly at her home from the effects of fifty-six hours of captivity.

Mrs. Alfred Knopf, vice president of Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., said on her return from Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France that her company would publish in February or March the latest work of Dr. Sigmund Freud, noted Viennese psychologist.

Three officers of the Chilean Army team, which will compete in the jumping competitions of the National Horse Show to be held at Madison Square garden, beginning Nov. .5, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Maria.

Soon after her arrival on the French liner Ile de France Mrs. Herbert Richter of Paris reported to the detectives of the East Fiftyfirst Street Police Station yesterday afternoon that she had lost jewelry valued at $10,000, apparently in a taxicab that took her from the pier to the Hotel Ritz Carlton.
The Hotel Piccadilly nine captured the Industrial Division championship of the New York City Baseball Federation by blanking the favored Ludwig Baumann team, 6-0,

Members of the Junior Devon Yacht Club gave a farewell luncheon today at the clubhouse on Gardiner's Bay. Several hundred colonists are planning to attend the benefit bridge, keno party and fashion show to be given on Wednesday evening at the Maidstone Club in behalf of the East Hampton Settlement House.
Austrians will obviously have to forget many things and learn many things before they are assimilated into their new German fatherland.
Several interesting anecdotes of sports as conducted some years ago are contained in "Athletics at Wesleyan," which was released to the press today.

Calls for Fall aparel-and accessories increased last week as retailers rounded out stocks in preparation for September business. Dress business was better at all price levels. Costume suits were reordered in good quantities. Wool sports and tailored frocks sold well.

A patrolman breathed into a stricken child's mouth for fortyfive minutes yesterday morning and later was credited with saving her life. He did not think the episode worth reporting to the Coney Island station, to which he is attached, but the child's mother and neighbors did.

The five chief cities of Japan-Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Kobe and Yokohama-apparently have been spared severe damage from the present typhoon. The Central Meteorological Observatory feared that it would be worse than that which struck Japan last week.

A Fascist uprising was put down in this capital after Your hours of fighting this afternoon, during which the firing of light artillery and machine guns gave residents of the city a steadily mounting scare.

Although hotel fireplaces were aglow with burning cordwood today, tables were set on the south lawn and verandas for the annual Labor Day luncheon at the Lenox Club. One hundred and sixty members and guests were present.
Edward W. Kelley, tax receiver of this city from 1917 to 1931, died on Saturday night in his home at the age of 85 after a long illness. He formerly was in real estate and grocery businesses here.
The Committee of 500 to Save P. R. made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia suggesting a renewal of his drive for a nonpartisan rather than a bi-partisan Board of Elections.

The text of President Roosevelt's speech here today was as follows: For two reasons which I think you will approve, I have accepted the invitation of your Congressman to come to the Eastern Shore of Maryland today.

Russell Hosler of Huntington, Ind., who had announced that he would take off yesterday morning for Cleveland with the hope of getting his "dark horse" homemade racing plane into the Thompson Trophy race, feature of the National Air Races, was informed by telephone from Cleveland that the deadline for qualifying had passed.

Out of another annual Gold Cup frenzy that this year cost sportsmen thousands of dollars in wreckage and found two of the expensive motor boats sunk to the river bottom, there emerged this cool, cloudy afternoon the spectacle of a foreign pilot in a European craft triumphing over the best speed ships the North American Continent could produce.

Mr. and Mrs. William McNair entertained with a dinner and theatre party tonight. The guests included Mrs. Shepard Fabbri, Mrs. Louis C. Lehr, Mrs. Richard Stevens, Miss Gertrude Sampson, Baron Mario Bucovich, Charles Sampson, John Livingston and Eugene Stein.

Funeral honors accorded only to those killed in the line of duty will be ordered today by the Fire Department in honor of Lieutenant Christopher J. Plunkett of Engine Company 8, whose funeral will take place tomorrow at 9:30 A. M. from 424 West Fifty-first Street, with a requiem mass at 10 o'clock in the Church of the Sacred Heart in Fifty-first Street near Ninth Avenue.
The army is revising its advanced training standards in order to bring more youthful officers into top command hosts.

The Frenc Government's action in canceling the leaves of officers and men in its army and calling out reserves to man its border fortifications elicited the following comment from the DNB, the official German news bureau, tonight:
America's defense of the Davis Cup was brought to a successful collusion against Australia today by the player whose omnipotent racquet reclaimed it abroad last year after an absence of a decade.

With interest centered in the threecornered Democratic Senatorial race, in which Senator Patrick A. McCarran's seat is at stake, and in the contest for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination, a record vote is expected tomorrow in Nevada's primary.

Queen Wilhelmina made an entry into the country's official capital today on the eve of the fortieth anniversary of her coronation, and, after welcoming ceremonies that included a piece composed for the occasion by Willem Mengelberg, was driven to the Palace in an open carriage drawn by six horses and followed by a small but brilliant train.

In its appraisal of events or tendencies in current finance or industry, publie attention nowadays converges more and more on "index numbers." The Federal Reserve Board publishes every month an "industrial production index," based on the monthly average of 1923-25 reckoned as 100.

Several shipping operators whose lines must sign a new agreement with the International Longshoremen's Association governing wages and working conditions during the next few weeks will urge a reduction of the wage now paid, it was learned yesterday.

Those who support the Committee for Industrial Organization are giving aid and assistance to division in the ranks of labor, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared in a Labor Day address here.

WTHILE he was at the Stadium with the Senators on Sunday Al Simmons encountered Earle Combs and Marse Joe McCarthy and, pointing to the silver-haired Earle, Al said to Mars'e Joe: "I remember that man when he had a hatful of money." "I'll bet he still has it," said Marse Joe with a wink.

Miss Mary Louise Odell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. G. Odell of this community, was married to Frederick H. Beach, son of Mrs. E. Eleanor Beach 'of Denville and the late Clarence Beach, this afternoon in the rectory of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Boonton.

Following its success against the New York Americans on Sunday. the national champion Sparta Football Club of Chicago defeated the Brookhattans of the American Soccer League, 5 to 4, before 2,500 fans at Starlight Park yesterday.

Entertainment for holiday guests continued today throughout the colony. Prince and Princess IrbainKhan Kaplanoff entertained with a luncheon at the Southampton Beach Club for members of their holiday house party, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Shattuck, Miss Marguerite Valentine, Lawrence Smith Butler and Pell Thompson. There were several other guests.

The Reliance Hose Company won the annual home tournament at Allen Field here today, defeating the five other companies in the village. Live Oak Engine Company was second and Eureka Hook and Ladder third.

Arguing that honesty would beget honesty in international relations, speakers of the Oxford Group World Assembly here today centered their attention on the need of "moral rearmament" in China and Japan.

There will be a high mass of requiem at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Refuge, Ocean and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn, tomorrow at 9 A. M., for Deputy Police Inspector Richard G. Oliver, who died suddenly early yesterday morning of a heart attack in his home at 684 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn.

Automobile production increased last week. With 67.0 used as the seasonal variation factor, the increase in production was greater than seasonal, and the adjusted index rose to 39.2 from 34.9. The figure was 157.0 for the week ended Sept. 4, 1937. .

John Andrew Myers, secretary for many years of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, died today at his home in Chestnut Hill. A year ago he suffered from a heart ailment, but recently he appeared. to be in good health.

Colonel Roscoe Turner, spectacular airplane racing pilot, became today the first man to take the Thompson Trophy race twice when he lapped the entire field in the 300-mile classic to set a new record of 283.419 miles an hour and win going away.

In consideration of his public service, his personality and his charm much is forgiven the President, including inconsistency. Yet that prevalent quality in Mr. Roosevelt's make-up was never more obvious than the other day when he said he would prefer in the Senate "a liberal Republican" to "a conservative Democrat" and would not oppose the election of the former when running against the latter.

A definite plan for hastening the colonization of Ethiopia by making it an, asylum or place of refuge for Italian Jewsperhaps at a later date also for Jews from other countries-was seen as a practical possibility today.

A bill signed by President Theodore Roosevelt on June 25, 1910, might have averted the World War, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler says in a preface to the current issue of International Conciliation, published by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

In a solemn procession, between long lines of bowed mourners, the body of Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, was escorted to St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday from the hills of Sullivan County, where he died in his sleep of a heart ailment early Sunday morning at his Summer home near Monticello, N. Y.

Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc., book publishers, have leased 90,000 square feet of space in the Port Authority Bilding at 111 Eighth Avenue, where, next May, the firm will concentrate its shipping, warehousing and other departments now operating in Garden City, L. I.

Raymond Massey, British actor, who was last seen here on the stage as the New England farmer in "Ethan Frome," two seasons ago, returned yesterday from London on the Queen Mary to play the part of Lincoln in Robert E. Sherwood's new play, "Abe Lincoln in Illinois." He said the play would go into rehearsal today and open in New York in October.

The German-Chinese Eurasia Aviation Corporation announced today that three Japanese planes had attacked a Eurasia passenger plane this morning over the Kwangtung-Kwangsi border when the plane was proceeding to Yunnan from Hong Kong.

Wage earners will suffer in the long run unless a method for healing the split between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization "can be agreed upon by the disputants themselves," Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, warned tonight in a Labor Day address over a national radio hook-up.

Joseph Marshall, former managing editor of the old Evening Telegraph here, died of heart disease Saturday night at his home. He was 78 years old. He had been on the staff of The Evening Bulletin since 1918.

While her husband and 18-yearold daughter pleaded vainly through a locked door, Mrs. Constance Amato, 39 years old, leaped to death from the bathroom window of her fourteenth-floor apartment at 41 Fifth Avenue at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

Two policemen were suspended from duty yesterday one after he had been arrested and charged with intoxication' and leaving the scene of an accident, following a collision at Bedford and Voorhies Avenue, Brooklyn.

C. E. Ward, Los Angeles policeman, captured the national pistol championship today, taking the individual match with 285 out of 300 in a field of 668 of the best shooters in the country. Ward established a new record for the test, topping last year's mark of 277, made by Emmett E. Jones, also of the Los Angeles Police Department.

Displarting a, brilliant burst of speed to capture the last two heats, McLin, winner of, the Ifambletonian, today took top money in the Horseman Futurity trot for 3-year-olds, feature 'event on the Indiana State Fair Grand Circuit program. He[ -was driven by Henry.Thomas.

The semi-centennial celebration of the founding of the American Mathematical Society will be held at the forty-fourth Summer meeting of the organization beginning today and continuing through Friday at Columbia University. Most of the sessions will be held in McMillion Theatre in the School of Business, Broadway and 116th Street.

William Woodward's Belair Stud color-bearers did well yesterday before 20,741 persons, Aqueduct's record crowd of the season, when Johnstown captured the $4,070 Babylon Handicap-and Isolater was first in the Aqueduct Handicap, which grossed $6,200.

One Allston youth was drowned and another was rescued when nearly exhausted after their row boat had capsized on Long Pond here early this morning. The body of Daniel Slason was recovered by Tyngsboro and Dracut police this noon.

Miss Helen Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Whiting of this place, became the bride today of Terry Staples, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alva Staples of Kingston, N. Y. The Rev. John Henry Wilson of Littleton, Mass., performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church.

The cannonading Cubs put a couple of slugs in Pittsburgh's pennant plans today with a double salvo which cut the Pirates' lead in the National League to its narrowest margin in some six weeks, Chicago won by 3 to 0 and 4 to 3.

Many persons of prominence in this city and surrounding communities are planning for the fourth annual charity horse show to be held here Sept. 16 and 17 on the grounds of the New Jersey College of Agriculture.
Heather Time, fleet juvenile chestnut filly, carried the pink and ir silver colors of A. E. Silver to vice tory today in the $7,500-added Old Colony Stakes before 55,000 fans. at Narragansett Park.

All was excitement along the Freeport dockside yesterday as a dozen boats bearing members of several of the- tuna teams headed for the open sea and the Mud.Hole. The first day of the Atlantic Coast tuna derby, otherwise known as the "great salt water. vendetta" got under way. with a sputtering of motors and an odor of mossbunker.

Creation of a Bureau of Commerce in New York to determine whether the State is failing to maintain its dominant position in business, commerce and industry, and, if so, to formulate a program to check this trend. was recommended by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, in an address at Rushford's Labor Day celebrations.

The first note sounded in this year's Nazi congress is one of jubilation over the absorption of Austria. The final note may be one of rejoicing over the release from Czech domination of the four millions of Sudeten Germans.
35,567 See Yanks Take Two; Giants Divide; Pirate Lead Cut to Four Games

Dr. Joseph Alexander, line coach' at City College during the 1934 and 1935 seasons, is returning to the Lavender staff and will replace Paul Riblett-as Benny Friedman's chief assistant, it was .announced yesterday-by Professor Walter Williamson,. college manage, of athletics.

Only the reintroduction of the system of consular visas" by neighboring States prevented refugee departures from Austria this year from "assuming the proportions of a wholesale exodus," Sir Neill Malcolm, League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees from Germany, says in his report to the League Assembly published here today.
Labor Day at the New York University football camp meant just that, with Dr. Mal Stevens sending his players through a hard fivehour morning and afternoon workout.
The Reds gained two games on the Pirates today, sweeping both ends of a double-header with the Cardinals, 4 to 3 and 4 to 2, as the league leaders fell twice to the third-place Cubs.

Cordial but far from enthusiastic crowds greeted President Roosevelt today in a score of Eastern Shore cities, villages and hamlets, as he came into this section of Maryland in behalf of Representative David J. Lewis, the New Deal choice for the Democratic Senate nomination.

The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, commonly known as the Wages and Hours Law, was hailed as a milestone along the road of American industrial progress by Elmer F. Andrews, administrator of the act, in a broadcast yesterday over the N. B. C. network.

Toppling the tail-end Athletics in straight sets, the pennant-bound Yankees wound up theircurrent affairs at the Stadium yesterday with a grand flourish, a wild hurrah from 35,567 spectators and another belt at the record books.

In a setting of white Autumn flowers, lighted by white tapers, Miss Helen LeCount Lefebre and Hughart Rea Laughlin were married yesterday afternoon in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, by the rector, the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee.
Net loss of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation for the six months ended on June 30 was reported yesterday as $44,671. A loss of $346,548 was reported for 1937.

THE second and final volume of Henry Adams's letters* appears today, edited, like its predecessor, by Worthington Chauncey Ford. The period covered is 1892-1918. Eight years ago we had Volume I, covering the period 1858-91. Mr. Ford is not the ideal editor--his annotations are far too casual and his principles of selection too obscure--but we have, nevertheless, to be grateful for an unrivaled (thus far) portrait of the oddest Adams of them all.
The press of San Salvador reports that the Manchukuoan Embassy in Tokyo has delivered to Salvadorean Consul Leon Sigunza decorations for himself and other high officials of El Salvador.

Mrs. F. Haven Clark and Miss Sally P. Clark, who have been passing the season in Nahant, Mass., are expected to arrive today at the Weylin. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor will return from Europe next week arid will go to Mayfair House.
Dorothy Hadikin, in 931 Madison Ave; Karl R. Free, Fannie T. Low, in 59 W. 37th St, Mrs. Lena Grossman, Nick Carpos, in 200 W 83d St; Mrs. Jennie Siglin, in 208 W 83d St; Louis Carreau, Inc, broker.

The appointment of Edward P. Mulrooney, former Commissioner of Police, as referee of the twelfth annual international lifeboat race, was announced yesterday. The race will be held Saturday at 3:45 P. M. over a two-mile course off the Bay Ridge waterfront, with crews entered by nine merchant ships.

Three new chemical "magic lanterns," each one of which makes it possible for man to penetrate into realms of matter hitherto beyond his reach, and to extend his dominion over the world he lives in, were reported today at the opening sessions of the twenty-sixth meeting of the American Chemical Society.
John K. Bolen, an Assistant Superintendent of Schools, died suddenly on Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 748 St. Mark's Place, Brooklyn. He was 61 years old.
Stpply contracts valued at $5,100,725 were awarded during the week ended Sept. 1 by fifteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Evidencing the high esteem in which Cardinal Hayes was held among non-Catholics, many tributes and messages of condolence from Protestants and Jews were among the thousands from persons in all walks of life received yesterday at the Cardinal's residence, 452 Madison Avenue.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara Rhodes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George I. Rhodes of this place, to Gordon Baxter Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford W. Brown, also of Glen Ridge.

The Labor Day holiday at the Manhattan College football training camp was marked by two lengthy praotice sessions. Fundamentals and a thorough review of plays were stressed in both morning and afternoon drills.

A memorial to the mothers of Ashland, done in bronze and paid for by contributions from hundreds of residents of this Schuylkill County mining town, stood unveiled today at the northern end of Hoffman Boulevard.

The last of the four concerts in the annual series by the Naumburg Orchestra was given last night on the Mall in Central Park before a large audience. Joseph Littau conducted. Emil Borsody, 'cello, as soloist, was heard in two movements from Victor Herbert's Second Concerto and Popper's "Hungarian Rhapsody."

Mrs. Herbert Shipman, who is soon closing Seaview Terrace, had dinner guests there tonight. Edward Sheedy, who has been the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young at Beechwood, entertained more than thirty of his friends with a dinner.
Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension plan leader, has announced his support to Sheridan Downey, Democratio nominee for Senator, and Governor Frank Merrlam; Republican nominee, for reelection.

Mrs. Ethel Humphrey Mellon, wife of Edward P. Mellon, architect, of 1,030 Fifth Avenue, New York, died early this morning in the Southampton Hospital after an illness of several months. She was a daughter of the late Judge Alexander Pope Humphrey of Louisville, Ky.

James A. Urquhart of Daytonia Beach, Fla., a former manager of the National Biscuit Company, died today in a hospital here at the age of 81. He was brought here from a holiday in the Muskoka district, where he had suffered a heart attack on Thursday.

By the end of 1938 the new Hall of North American Mammals of the American Museum of Natural History will have material for ten habitat groups, Dr. Harold E. Anthony, curator of the museum's department of mammals, announced yesterday. The case constitution in this hall is moving rapidly ahead so that the groups can be installed.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, called last night for "a substantial and not merely a clarifying amendment" to the Wagner Labor Relations Act, "as well as for a change in its administrative practice."

To the music of bagpipe bands, 6,000 Scots assembled at Theron McCampbell's Sylvan Forum here today for the seventh annual Scottish games, breaking all attendance records for the event which each year is sponscored jointly by the United Scottish Clans, Daughters of Scotia and Monmouth County Scots.

The three-story business property at 2,836-38 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Personal Credit Plan to an investor, who has given in part payment the five-family apartment house and two garages at 796 Inwood Terrace, Cliffside Park, N. J., and the fifteen-family house at 135337 Fortieth Street, Union City, N. J.

John Michelosen, blocking quarterback from Pittsburgh, and Edmund Franco, guard from Fordham, who were college rivals for three years, were elected co-captains of the Eastern College All-Stars today following the final practice at their Peddie School training base.
E. Leroy Pelletier, advertising manager for Henry Ford and a pioneer himself in the automobile industry, died of a heart ailment late today in Henry Ford Hospital. His age was 72.

Henry Wightman of Upper Montclair won his third consecutive New Jersey State gliding title and led his club, the Aero Club Albatross of Irvington, to victory in the team competition at the fifth annual three-day State gliding championship meet, which closed here today at Schley Field.

Sales of food retailers last week averaged 12 per cent below the corresponding week last year, much of the decline being due to a flood of cheap local supplies of fresh vegetables and fruits, according to the weekly bulletin issued yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distributlon, Inc.
Mrs. Barbara Sommer, who celebrated her 100th birthday on April 14, died yesterday in her home here after a year of ill health.
Everton retained the lead in the English football league today with a 3-0 victory over Aston Villa at Villa Park. It was the Lancashire team's fourth straight triumph.

Eight of Broadway's nine legitimate shows gave their scheduled holiday matinees yesterday, and the results were highly satisfactory. Five of the eight sold out, three of them playing to standees, the score reading: "I Married an Angel," at least 116 standing patrons; "Tobacco Road," thirty-seven; "Pins and Needles," twenty-five.

Fred L. Porter, former State Assemblyman from Essex County, was found dead today at his home here, victim of a heart attack. His age was 61. Mr. Porter served in the Assembly from 1919 to 1934. He had been chairman of its Ways and Means Committee.

Like a courageous fighter backed to- the ropes, weary and stung, the Giants made one desperate bid to stave off disaster at Shibe Park today. Cliff Melton hurled them to a 7-to-0 victory over the Phillies in the opening gamie of a twin bill that drew 10,000 fans.

Miss Margaret Christie Seckel, a descendant of Rolfe Swartwout, who settled on Long Island in 1653, was married to Robert Grayson Taylor, Washington correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, this afternoon in St. Thomas Church here.
For the first time in the long history of dog shows in America, a Labrador retriever today received the coveted title of best in show.

John W. Bricker, Republican Governorship candidate, opened his campaign for the Ohio labor vote tonight with charges that an alliance of the Communist party and the Committee for Industrial Organization leaders was seeking the election of his Democratic opponent, Charles Sawyer of Cincinnati.

Continuing Paramount's series of industrial epics, Frank Lloyd announced today that his next production would be "Ruler of the Seas," a story of the early days of transatlantic commerce climaxed with the triumph of steam over sail. Talbot Jerinings, who was one of the collaborators on "Mutiny on the Bounty," which Llcyd produced and directed at Metro, has been assigned to prepare an original screen play.

While the stock markets here bore up comparatively stoically today under growing fears of disturbances in Central 'Europe, the growing pace of the flight of European capital to the dollar and to gold furnished a sure indication of the fears of British and Continental capitalists.

Committees of the Bond Club of New York to serve for the coming year have been announced by John K. Starkweather, president. Henry S. Morgan is the new chairman of the committee on arrangements, which includes B. A. Tompkins, Sidney J. Weinberg, C. F. Batchelder, Victor Schoepperle, William J. Minsch, Lindsay Bradford, John W. Cutler and F. M. Warburg.

Old Westbury joined Greentree in the semi-final round of the national open polo championship today. Riding' against Aknusti in the second game of the tournament, the amazing four that has lost only one game in two seasons roared up and down the turf of Hitchcock Field Like a tropical windstorm,
The Red Sox pounded a half-dozen Senator pitchers for twenty-nine hits in a double-header today and won, 14 to 4 and 8 to 6.

What is perhaps most interesting in the President's speech in Maryland yesterday is its definition of the difference between "conservatives" and "liberals." According to the President a man is a "conservative" if he admits some particular evil but fears that government intervention to cure it might prove a greater evil.
Sheikh Mahamoud Daoud Ansari was shot and killed on a street in Jerusalem today. It was the third attack on him since the reign of terror started in Palestine two and onehalf years ago.

The trial of James J. Hines on charges of conspiring in the policy racket will enter its fourth week today with an otherwise obscure figure in the case returning to the witness stand to tell more about a transaction that has become one of the major issues of the trial.
The First Division polo team scored its sixth straight victory yesterday when it' defeated the Massapequa squad, 6 to 4, at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation before a crowd of 3,500.

If reports from Callander, Ontario, are as reliable as they seem, those five little girls whom Dr. Dafoe has been looking after will have to have their tonsils out this month. For many thousands of mothers this news will be as important as any that has been published in a week.

General conditions within the gas industry will be reviewed this week by leaders of the industry from various sections of the country at a series of meetings. The board of directors of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers will meet tomorrow at national headquarters, 60 East Fortysecond Street.

THE ACHIEVEMENT OF PERSONALITY, by Grace Stuatt; (Macmillan, $1.75.) Personality in the light of psychology and religion. AFFIRMATIONS, by Seven American Anglo - Catholics. (Sheed Ward, $2.) Studies in the application of Christian principles in a constantly changing world.
Herman LeRoy Edgar, book collector, amateur photographer and former real estate broker, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 73 years old.
John Couch, kidnapper, who escaped from the Ramsey County jail yesterday, was captured today in St. Paul by two policemen.
A gift of $100,000 toward the construction of two additional wings to the Engineering Building at Bucknell University was announced here today by President Arnaud C. Marts.
In the first two months of the current fiscal year there was a deficit in the Federal Treasury of $647,000,000. Total expenditures in the two months amounted to $1,445,000,000.

Putting psychologists into the War and Navy Departments immediately to strengthen. national defense was proposed today by Dr. Richard H. Paynter of Long Island University, vice president of the American Association of Applied Psychologists.

Frank Morrison, secretary-treasurer of the Ameican Federation of Labor, said today that the C. I. O. was only a new name for an old idea of one big union, which had been tried many times and had failed because it did not meet "practical requirements."

The Belgian Cabinet, notified that France had called up army reserves, asked King Leopold tonight to return immediately from vacation in Italy. The action was taken at a Special Cabinet session. The King is due tomorrow night.

While gifts and bequests to philanthropic enterprises generally have fallen off 50 per cent, contributions to community chests since the first of the year have shown a decrease of only 3.7 per cent, compared with the corresponding period of 1937, it was disclosed here yesterday by Charles P. Taft 2d of Cincinnati.

American agriculture needs new capital, according to a survey just completed by the Mortgage Brokers Association of America. A long neglected field for investors' funds, that of farm mortgages, can employ profitably at least a quarter of a billion dollars of new funds today, it was said today by A. D. Fraser, president of the association.

Jack Rutherfurd of Port Washington, L. I., won the annual free-for-all race of the Ocean City Yacht Club today by driving his hydroplane Juno over the ten-mile course in 11 minutes 45 seconds for an average speed of 51.07 miles an hour.

The executive group of the American Federation of Labor NonPartisan Committee, in a statement yesterday, accused the American Labor. party of being "a stooge" for the C. I. O. in the New York State political arena.

Sir Henry Chilton, British Ambassador to Spain, was one of the 2,005 passengers arriving yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. The diplomat said that "no one knows" when the Spanish civil war will end and that it is difficult to predict how it will end.
LATEST DEVELOPMENTS IN BUSINESS

Herbert Trinkle, 25 years old, of Madison County, Ind., won the national Amateur Athletic Union horseshoe singles championship yesterday in a hard-fought battle against fifteen contestants at Willowbrook Park, New Springville, S.I.

Merrill Phoenix and Harold Allen of this city set a new endurance flight record for light planes early today, having remained aloft more than 63 hours and 54 minutes, and late tonight sent down word that they would try to keep their yellow monoplane off the ground until tomorrow afternoon, when they will have been flying 100 hours.

An elaborate test effort, consisting of seven advertising campaigns, will mark the September and October promotion activities of Horlick's Malted Milk Corporation, Racine, Wis. Seventy-eight newspapers in fiftytwo cities will be used with results to be checked by' coupon returns, weekly sales reports from druggists, and jobbers' sales.

Alexander S. Burns Jr. of Spring Valley, N. Y., whose greenhouses there supplied lilies to eighteen American cities, and won for him the title of "Lily King," died Sunday in the Doctors Hospital after an illness of several months.

Henry V. Rourke, president of the WPA Mechanics and Helpers Union, which withdrew from the Workers Alliance as a protest against "Communist domination" and staged a 24-hour picketing demonstration at the empty City Hall over the Labor Day week-end, disclosed yesterday that he was prepared to build a national organization as a rival to the Workers Alliance.

A West Indian engineering student, enraged by the dismissal of assault charges he had brought against another West Indian, suddenly pulled out an automatic and fired thee shots in the Clerkenwell Police Court today.

The Indians ran their winning streak to seven games today by defeating the White Sox in a double-header, 6 to 4 and 4 to 2 but were unable to cut Boston's second place lead when the Red Sox also won a twin bill.

Plans to improve the work of Soviet labor organizations in many fields are being framed in a plenary session of the Trade Unionists Council of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in the House of the Trade Unions, the former Nobles Club.

Representative John J. O'Connor, who is seeking renomination on the Republican and Democratic primary slates, has canceled all his campaign activities until after the funeral of Cardinal Hayes Friday, it was announced yesterday by former Assistant United States Attorney James J. McCarthy, campaign manager.

Jimmy Crowley's toe was far from healed, but the Fordham coach was unable to keep himself from Fordham Field for another day. As a result, his football squad was sent through two more sessions yesterday.
Mrs. Eula Hull Jacobs, mother of Helen Jacobs, the tennis star, was confined to a hospital today by injuries received in an automobile accident here last Friday.

The European war-scare continued yesterday to press down on the foreign-exchange market, and the stampede of frightened foreign capital to find a refuge in the dollar drove the pound sterling and other important exchanges to lower prices than they had seen in years.

Several hundred persons, including former associates in financial circles and leaders in business and g industry, attended funeral services yesterday in Temple Emanu-EI for Jerome J. Hanauer, retired partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co.
Soviet Russia's customary district army manoeuvres have started quietly. Marshal Klementi E. Voroshiloff, Commissar of War, reviewed war games in the Moscow zone yesterday.

As a curtain raiser for morning and afternoon showings, which begin today in their newly redecorated salon, Jay-Thorpe executives and staff yesterday previewed the Autumn collection, which interspersed importations from Paris and London with the creations of their own designers.

A woman who went with her son to a Nazi rally of the GermanAmerican Bund at the Turnhalle, 152 East Eighty-fifth Street, last night, "to see if they really said such things as you read in the papers," rose from her seat during an anti-Semitic speech and denounced the speaker and the audience of 350.

Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church dismissed yesterday technical objections to a complaint filed by Otto Braunwarth, retired manager of a tire company, in a suit for $2,500,000 for alleged breach of contract which he is bringing against Herbert G. Wellington of Wellington Co., stock brokers.

Under a combination of liquidation and hedging pressure, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 12 to 15 points yesterday, all active months but December and January sinking below and closing under the 8-cent level.

It is a mode of moods, for the Winter of 1938-39. Evidence of this was submitted last night at the seasonal preview at Bergdorf-Goodman, oldest and largest of Fifth Avenue's style shows. Variety and versatility dominated both fabric and form.

Ace Parker has been granted a leave by Connie Mack of the Athletics for the remainder of the season and will join the Brooklyn Football Dodgers tomorrow when they depart for a night exhibition game at Albany.

The New York Central Railroad has recalled 3,804 employes to work in its locomotive, passenger-car and freight-car shops as of today, the company announced yesterday. Of these men 3,017 will start work today in locomotive shops and 472 in passenger-car shops. The remainder will resume work this week.
A requiem mass will be offered at 10 A.M. today in Our Lady of Victory Church, Throop Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn, for Mrs. Elizabeth Keefe, widow of Dr. John F. Keefe, who died Sunday.

Senator Millard F. Tydings of Maryland, in reporting his campaign expenses to the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures today, filed a series of complaints charging coercion of Federal employes to support Representative David J. Lewis, his rival for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

The famous Basque sport, jai alal, will be introduced at the Hippodrome tomorrow night, when four stars will be seen in action over the 25-point distance. Gabriel and Guillermo will oppose Piston and Segundo, marking the first time that the game's four outstanding players have been signed for the same campaign.
Edward R. Otheman, senior member of the law firm of Otheman Swain at 31 Nassau Street, died yesterday after a brief illness at his home, 150 East Seventy-second Street. His age was 65.

In a report issued today by Marshall R. Diggs, acting controller of the currency, a comparison of earnings, expenses and dividends of National banks as between the year ended on June 30, 1938, and June 30, 1928, showed that there had been a relatively small decrease in the net profits of these banks.

While city and State continued to mourn his sudden passing, the body of Patrick Cardinal Hayes was taken yesterday afternoon from his residence at 452 Madison Avenue to St. Patrick's Cathedral where it will lie in state until after his funeral there on Friday.
Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel, German stars, will ride once again as a team when the New York sixday bicycle race starts at Madison Square Garden a week from Sunday night.

The Trades Union Congress, representing about five million British workers, today overwhelmingly en- A dorsed the decision, of its governing body to discuss with the government means of speeding up the huge British rearmament program.
The German "national culture prizes," which have replaced the Nobel peace prizes since Germany declined to have anything to do with the latter after one had been

When striking dockers refused to resume work, the government tonight issued orders putting the port of Marseille under military control. The action was taken under a law voted by Parliament last July providing for organizing the nation for war in time of peace, and under which military action can be substituted for civilian in case of emergencies.
We came to Nuremberg this year more deeply moved than ever before. For many years the party conventions have not only been a festival of joy and pride but have become one of inner consciousness.
Mrs. Thomas Moran, wife of the naval commander, entertained with a musical and tea today at her home in honor of her father, Thompson McCllntock, who observed his ninetieth birthday.

Mrs. John Wheaton was a dinner hostess today at the Hedges Inn. Mr. and Mrs. William Allen Butler gave a small luncheon there. The Rev. and Mrs. Alben J. M. Wilson of Greenwich, Conn., are at Windmill Cottage, Amagansett. Dr.
Mrs. Malvina Thompson Scheider, personal secretary and traveling companion of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, has obtained a divorce from Frank J. Scheider of New York.

Turpentine firm, 21 1/2-21 3/4c; sales, 160 barrels; receipts, 621 barrels; shipments, 144 barrels; stock 48,390 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 486; receipts, 3,339; shipments, 1,567; stock, 235,907. Quote: B, $3.50; D. $3.85; E, $4; F, G, H, I, $4.15; K, $4.17 1/2; M, $4.20; N, $5.05; WG, $5.17 1/2; WW and X, $6.12 1/2.

Readjusted to take account of the Labor Day holiday, the true rate of activity of the steel industry this week is not far under 47 per cent, which would be the highest rate of activity since 48.6 per cent was recorded in the week of Nov. 1, 1937.

The American thirty-square meters yachting team excelled in the opening contest of the five-race series for the Beverly Yacht Clubs International Challenge Cup on Buzzards Bay today, but it took some splendid sailing by Alfred E. Chase in Viking to turn the trick by the slim margin of a quarter point over Sweden.
Vill Give Hague-C. I. O. Decision Later This Month

Walter E. O'Hara, former president and general manager of the Narragansett race track, today filed in this city and Pawtucket his nomination papers for Governor. He said he had 10,000 names on these and other papers to be filed throughout the State. Only 500 names are required.
Edward L. Reed, Counselor of the United States Embassy, asked the Foreign Office today to clarify questions arising from recent decrees concerning Jews.

The Glorious Sportswear Corporation of 254 West Thirty-fifth Street, New York City, agreed today to a stipulation by the Federal Trade Commission that in advertising its products it will state clearly that its dresses of "bemberg" are in fact made with rayon.

James Watson Bradin 3d of 438 West 116th Street, metallurgist and ore and metal broker with offices at 50 Church Street, died Monday night in St. Luke's Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 60.

The New York State Athletic Commission, at its regular meeting yesterday, 'allotted boxing and wrestling dates for the coming indoor season. Eight clubs made application for fights in the Greater New York area, and nine sought permission to stage mat encounters.

The September grand jury sworn in today, was instructed by Judge Theodore Rosen to hold itself in readiness to take some action in connection with the "heat exhaustion" deaths of four convicts in the isolation block of Holmesburg prison.

Many producers of lead outside the United States today decided to form a cartel to "take measures to bring production and consumption into balance." Some form of restriction in output is expected to follow should the appeal for action meet with a ready response.

A new process for the juggling of molecules of carbon and hydrogen in the natural gases produced at oil fields, which increases America's potential known resources of crude oil and gasoline by 150 per cent and promises an annual conservation of 62.5 per cent of these highly important national resources, was reported here today before the ninety-sixth meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Two petitions requesting that the North Shore Railroad be liquidated immediately for the benefit of its credittors, or else reorganized on a basis that will make possible the profitable operation of the line, were filed in the Federal Court here today. The petitioners are William R. Stuart, Edward B. Raub Jr.,

Spanish Insurgents asserted tonight that they were gaining important ground in the Gandesa sector of the Ebro front by constant chipping at government lines. Insurgent dispatches said the most decisive gains were on the left of the Gandesa-Mora de Ebro highway.

Prices of wheat were on the downgrade today from the start. At no time did the market reflect a disposition to rally and the close was as good as at the low point. Net losses on the Board of Trade here were 2 to 21/4 cents a bushel, with December and May at new low levels for the season.
Bobby Feller's four-hit pitching performance stretched Cleveland's winning streak to eight games today as the Indians blanked the Tigers, 6 to 0, in the first of a two-game series.

Reports that under the new Wage and Hour Law, which becomes effective Oct. 23, minimum wages for tufted bedspread workers may be vanced to 30 cents an hour caused concern in the dry goods market yesterday, and some selling houses refused to take orders for delivery beyond that date.
This is the phrase the French repeat as they mass up reserves along the Eastern frontier with a methodical calm characteristically at variance with their excitement over trifles.
First and foremost, it may be even more difficult now than it was in 1930 to restore confidence among business men and so stimulate private expenditure on capital improvemeant.

The wage-scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association appointed yesterday committees to draft a new wage contract with the Atlantic ship lines at a conference at 164 Eleventh Avenue. The association will demand a forty-hour week to replace the present forty-four-hour week in a contract which will expire on Sept. 30. Discussions will be continued this morning.

Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel; District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora joined in eulogizing Cardinal Hayes at the opening of court yesterday morning, after which Rose Wendroff, sister of J.

With a 200-pound safe covered with burlap slung over his shoulder like a sack of potatoes, a gunman walked calmly past fifty persons eating in the Dubrow Pure Food Restaurant at 1,110 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, at 5:30 A. M. yesterday, dumped the safe, containing $5,000 in cash and jewelry, into a sedan and fled with four companions.

The transatlantic survey flying boat Lieutenant de Vaisseaux Paris of the French Air Line left the Pan American base here at 9:20 A. M. today on a return flight to the Azores. The plane has a crew of eight, under the command of Captain Henri Guillaumat.
IT is largely of our own doing. Whenever a visiting English writer first submits to examination by the gentlemen of the press he (or she) is sure to be asked what he (or she) thinks of America.

Sales of Manhattan properties announced yesterday involved several buildings in the Sixties and Seventies, on the East and West Sides. All were residential' parcels, ranging from a ten-family house to a sixteen-story apartment hotel.

Following leads brought to light in the course of an investigation of the Nazi revolt of yesterday, which caused considerable bloodshed in the central section of this city, Chilean authorities proceeded throughout the day today to comb the country in an effort to arrest all the important leaders of the movement.

Today's casualties in the Arab-Jewish strife in Palestine include at least nine Arabs and six Jews killed and nine Jews and four Arabs wounded. Six of the Arabs killed were terrorists who were slain in engagements with government forces.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Sept. 1 was 226, which compares with 151 a year ago and 230 a week ago, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog told the House of Assembly today that South Africa had not become obliged to support Great Britain if she became involved in war as a result of British policy over Czechoslovakia. He added that the South African Government had not consulted or negotiated with the British Government on that policy.

Clayton E. Freeman, chairman ofthe New Jersey Republican State Committee, declared yesterday he had an "utter abhorrence" for a suggestion that persons on relief be forbidden to vote, while a delegation of leaders of the Women's Rebellion, the anti-New Deal organization that was organized last Spring to combat the "pump-priming" bill, conferred with Attorney General David T. Wilentz on the possibility of denying the vote to relief recipients on the ground they were paupers.
Paramount today announced the purchase of Clifford Goldsmith's high school comedy, "What a Life," from George Abbott.

The $3,000,000,000 Electric Bond and Share utility empire offered yesterday to retire from the field of electric power operation in sixteen counties in the State of Texas through the sale of power proper-' ties in the area to the Lower Colorado River Authority, the TVA of the Southwest.

The battle for freedom of the press is a battle for democracy and civil freedom, N. P. Duchemin, president of The Canadian Press and managing director of The Sydney (N. S.) Post-Record, told a Service Club luncheon today.

The Bears hung up their 100th victory of the season tonight as they whipped the Orioles, 10 to 4, behind eight-hit pitching by Nick Strincevich. The victory Increased their league lead to seventeen and a half games over Syracuse.
President Roosevelt, in a letter to Frank D. Schroth, new publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, which that paper published yesterday, stressed the "vital need for a strong, fearless and free press."

Outfitted brilliantly in new blue and gold uniforms and sporting the latest style headgear and coaching problems, Navy's eighty-twoman football squad took the practice field for the first time todaywith the William and Mary opening game just eighteen days away.

Jews of the world were formally called on today to raise $5,000,000 during the coming year for the building up of Palestine in a resolution adopted at the closing session this afternoon of the international conference of the Palestine Foundation Fund. Leaders of the Zionist movement participated.

A woman who described herself as Mrs. Eleanor Leamon, 33 years old, of 4 Alden Avenue, Philadelphia, when she was arrested yesterday, hanged herself in a cell in police headquarters early this morning by making a noose from a slip she was wearing and fastening it to the top of the cell door.
Conclusion of the CanadaUnited States trade negotiations leading to a revision of the existing trade agreement is expected in about two weeks, according to information here.
A Japanese Army communique today said a second Eurasia line passenger airplane was shot down yesterday afternoon thirty miles southwest of Hankow by Japanese Army aviators.

Fifty-nine football candidates reported today to Ossie Solem as he opened his second season as Syracuse University's head coach. Striking a fast opening day tempo, Solem called for dummy scrimmage in the afternoon, giving every player a chance on one of the various combinations, and indicating a heavy training camp program -to prepare for the tough schedule ahead.

Jerry Luvadis, known as Jerry the Greek, who seconded Jack Dempsey in some of the former heavyweight champion's greatest battles, died in Welfare Hospital on D Sunday after a long illness of cancer. Born in Greece fifty-three years ago, he came to this country as a boy.

Miss Helen Morris Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Smith of this city, was married to Frank Murray Gale, son of Mrs. Jane M. Gale of New York and the late Arthur Murray Gale, this afternoon here at the home of the bride's parents.

South Channel Bridge, between Broad Channel and Rockaway Beach, Queens, was reopened to traffic yesterday except for the half hour from 2 to 2:30 P. M., when, engineers replaced a latch lock on one of the leaves of the bridge which had been loosened by vibrations caused by the passing of a loaded bus.

The stock markets here were optimistic over the European political situation today and rises in prices were general. Gilt-edge issues went ahead and foreign bonds were strong. Transatlantic shares attracted firm support and United States Steel moved up.

On their own applications: PATROLMEN-To take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 2: Harold E. Parrott, 2d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 2, 1913. Nicholas J. Majewski. 34th Precinct, at $1.500 per annum. Appointed Aug. 28, 1913. To take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 3: William Petersohn, 104th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 2, 1913. Joseph Caracciolo, 108th Precinct, at $1,500 annum. Appointed Aug. 25, 1913.

Sent right back to competition after a creditable fourth in the $25,000 Special last Saturday, Mrs. Emil Denemark's Finance showed too much class for his field in the Greenwich Handicap at Narragansett Park today and scored an easy victory.

The wholesale price level was somewhat higher last week, according to the commodity price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association. This index in the week ended Sept. 3 stood at 73.6, against 73.1 in the preceding week, 74.0 a month ago, and 85.9 a year ago, based on the 1926-1928 average as 100.
Lady Ribblesdale, mother of Vincent Astor, has decided to place her huge London home, Regents Lodge, adjoining Regents Park, on the market, it was learned last night.

Hundreds of additional tributes and messages of condolence on the death of Cardinal Hayes were received yesterday at the Cardinal's residence, 452 Madison Avenue, from religious, civic, judicial and business leaders and other prominent Persons.

A requiem mass for Cardinal Hayes will be celebrated here on Friday at 10 A. M. in St. Francis Xavier's Church. School children will attend. Cardinal Hayes wintered in Nassau and is widely mourned here.

The nation's outstanding amateur linksmen, along with a sprinkling of foreign stars, will pit their skill against the 6,995-yard Oakmont Country Club course, overlooking the Allegheny River Valley near Pittsburgh, Pa., Monday, when the qualifying rounds of the forty-second amateur golf championship will start.
The Norfolk Western Railway, which is controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad and is said to epitomize the history of many railroads in the East, will celebrate today its 100th anniversary.

More than 300 young people between the ages of 15 and 18 attended the fourth vacation supper dance at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. The decorations consisted of colored autumn leaves, with a background of blue sky.
President Roosevelt at Hyde Park was told by Governor Benson of Minnesota yesterday that the Northwest backed his campaign to elect "liberals" regardless of party lines. [Page 1.]

For the first time in its history the New York Stock Exchange will give a hearing today to the head of a railroad to discover why an inaccurate statement concerning the performance of a contract of that railroad had been filed with the Exchange.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Aug. 31, aggregated $6,793,000,000, or 3 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 20 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The National Bureau of Standards announced today issuance of a pamphlet, procurable from the Superintendent of Documents, Government Printing Office, describing voluntary standards by manufacturers for marking platinum products to show actual content of that metal.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 31:
Talbot Co. announced yesterday that Harry J. Long and Ben Kessler have been admitted to general partnership. Walter B. McLear has joined Woodcock, McLear Co. as manager of their trading department.

Most classes of traefer meats met yesterday with a fair demand except lamb, which was slow, and about steady. Other classes ruled steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be steady, other classes higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The Oil and Gas Journal reported today that the nation's daily production of crude oil declined 41,068 barrels last week, reaching a daily average of 3,353,991. Oklahoma declined 4,650 barrels to a daily average of 432,400; East Texas, 413 to 440,787, and the State of Texas, 3,013 to 1,392,134.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company filed today an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $30,000,000 of convertible debentures, fixing the interest rate at 4 per cent and the offering price at 100 and accrued interest.

C. M. Zander, 61, one of five candidates for the Democratic Guernatorial nomination in next week's primary and an Arizona political leader for twenty-five years, was killed today when the plane in which he was making a campaign tour crashed near here.
The Senators unveiled a new pitching prospect today, 22-year-old Rene Monteagudo, and he hurled them to a 7-to-5 triumph over the Red Sox.

Less than 10 per cent of the motorists whose one-year drivers' licenses will expire on Sept. 30 have made renewals, according to reports made public yesterday from the Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Utica, Brooklyn and Manhattan offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.
The reinforced armies of France and Germany, their exact strengths closely guarded secrets, stood watch over the border zones tonight, awaiting the outcome of the Czechoslovak crisis.

Strong-hearted Greyhound, champion trotting gelding owned by E. J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., failed today in an attempt to break his record of 1:56, but hung up a new Indiana State Fair mile mark of 1:563/4 in the feature of the Grand Circuit racing program.

34th St, 222-8 E, 88x98: Kaybert Realty Corp to Theo Badman, 65 Madison Ave; mtg $42,000 (50 cents). 73d St, 238-44 W. 80.6x102.2; Singhi Holding Corp to Carrie E. Singhi, 240 W 73d St ($75). York Ave, 1,597, 26x75; Harriet C. Oppenheimer to Wm. C. Gruner, 2,300 Loring P1. one-half interest: mtg $8,000.

Queen Wilhelmina accepted the country's congratulations on the fortieth anniversary of her coronation in the New Church in Amsterdam today. Addresses from both houses of Parliament and from provincial Governors were read during a service in the presence of the diplomatic corps, East Indian princes and representatives from all parts of the country.

The Associated Theatre Ticket Agencies, Inc., composed of the smaller Broadway ticket brokers, will take legal action if necessary to fight the new code of fair practice regulating theatre ticket sales, it was indicated yesterday by Stanley C. Fowler, attorney for that group.
Jean C. Witter, a partner in the San Francisco investment banking house of Dean Witter Co., has been nominated for the presidency of the Investment Bankers Association of America for 1938-39.

With 2,018 competitors on the firing line today battling for the national individual rifle championship the first four stages were completed and four sharpshooters turned in scores of 194 out of 200 for the lead. The match will be finished tomorrow on the1,000-yard range.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, declared yesterday that he was unwilling to believe that the Federal Government would be so "unfair" as to view with pessimism the current negotiations between himself

The Southerner of the American Airlines made a special stop at Nashville, Tenn., last night to enable J. T. Lewis and his son, A. M. Lewis, to get home quickly after being notified of the death of Mrs. Lewis, it was disclosed here by the air line. Ordinarily,

Two of the four employes in the Bureau of Real Estate of the Board of Estimate against whom departmental charges have been filed have applied for retirement, Lee Thompson Smith, director of the bureau, announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wendell Endicott are expected to arrive today from Boston and will be at the Pierre. Dr. William S. A. Pott, president of Elmira College, and Mrs. Pott are at the Biltmore.

More than 200 of the debutante set of the North Shore and their house guests and many of the girls who will be introduced next season, with their guests, attended the farewell supper dance at the Nassau Country Club tonight, given for the students Who will return this month to school and college.
Woodrow Rich, rookie righthander, of Little Rock, pitched a no-hit no-run game tonight against the Atlanta Crackers, leaders of the Southern Association, while his team-mates scored four runs.

Six thousand members of the Retail Department Store Clerks Union of the American Federation of Labor voted late tonight to strike tomorrow morning in the twenty-seven leading department stores of this city.

The National Labor Relations Board today issued an examiner's report recommending drastic action to force the Ford Motor Company to bargain with a unit of the Committee for Industrial Organization in the operation of its assembly plant at Richmond, Calif.
