A squad of a dozen men who had been accepted for the first class at the new Merchant Marine Training School that the Federal Government has established at Hoffman Island were formally accepted and transferred to the school yesterday morning.

The opening of the theatre season-all classes-has been postponed again. The. Federal Theatre Project was to have thrown out the first ball-call it "Big Blow," by Theodore Pratt-this Friday, but yesterday decided to do some reconstruction work on one of the scenes.

Senator Pat McCarran, who opposed President Roosevelt's Supreme Court and governmental reorganization measures, drew steadily away from two "100 per cent New Deal" opponents tonight as returns from the Nevada primary election rolled in.

A special meeting of stockholders of the American Insulator Corporation of Delaware has been called for Baltimore for Sept. 30 to act upon a plan of recapitalization proposed by a stockholders' committee headed by W. D. Hines of New Oxford, Pa. The directors and management have recommended approval of the plan.

The will or Mrs. Ida L. Churchill, who died Aug. 15 in St. Petersburg, Fla., was filed for probate today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. One-third of the residuary estate was bequeathed to Mrs.

The first woman ever to serve on a Kings County grand jury, Mrs. Julia Coblens of 268 Ashland Place, Brooklyn, was sworn in yesterday by Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn, who inducted the September panel.
Residential properties in and near Plainfield, N. J., are reported sold by J. G. Mulford, broker, as follows: For Elias H. Bird to J. Grocco, 219 Netherwood Avenue, Plainfield;

The semi-annual report of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company and subsidiaries, released yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,037,807 after depreciation, Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges for the six months ended on June 30.
The possibility that Harold S. P Vanderbilt, thrice successful skip per of America's Cup defenders, would build a twelve-meter yacht and take her to England next Summer developed yesterday.

Miss Mabel A. Inkster of Havelock, Ontario, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Inkster, was married here yesterday to Reginald Edward Frewen of Glenlea, Devonshire, Bermuda, in the chantry of Grace Church.
The committee for selection of a president of the Chicago Stock Exchange will report tomorrow to the Board of Governors, Arthur M. Betts, chairman of the exchange, announced today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market during the pre-holiday week ended yesterday showed a total considerably under the preceding week but well in advance in the number reported for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

Out where the West begins there is something in the winy mountain air which impels veracity even in the most unexpected circumstances. There must be, because Irwin H. ("Call Me Pop") Hanes, seeking the Democratic nomination for Colorado State Auditor, is obviously telling the unvarnished truth by announcing that he wants the job because it pays more money than he could earn, or ever has earned, by honest toil.

A lengthy dummy scrimmage devoted to passing, offense and defense marked an intensive two-hour workout today for the New York University football' squad under the direction of Dr. Mal Stevens and Assistant Coaches Stewart Scott, Archie Roberts and Herster Barres.

Cool weather brought sharp gains in retail sales here and out of town yesterday and quickened the pace of reorder activity in many of the wholesale markets. Marking what was regarded as a turn in the retail situation, a number of leading stores here had good sales gains yesterday over the corresponding day last year.

Syracuse and Jersey City divided a double-header today, the Chiefs winning the second game, 9 to 2, after dropping the opener, 5 to 2. Glen Gabler went the route for the Little Giants in the curtainraiser, recovering after a shaky e first inning to hurl effectively the rest of the way.

Captain Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, Arctic explorer and author, is on his way home and will dock his Gloucester fishing schooner Morrissey at Brigus, Nfld., on Monday morning, wind and weather permitting, according to a message yesterday from radio station W20J.

Regulations were issued today for registration with the Secretary of State of persons in the United States engaged in propaganda or other activities for political purposes on behalf of a foreign principal.

Pleading for real estate leadership toward the restoration of confidence necessary for a return to normal business conditions, Joseph W. Catharine, president of the National Association of Real Estate

Notified of impending litigation in the Supreme Court, the State Board of Tax Appeals postponed indefinitely today hearing of appeals filed by municipalities from personal property valuations fixed by State Tax Commissioner J. H. Thayer Martin fdr apportionment of utility franchise and gross receipts taxes.

Miss Ellen Wilson McAdoo, daughter of Senator William G. McAdoo, appeared at the Hall of Records today with William Alfred Hinshaw, a member of the Kansas City Symphony Orchestra, and filed notice of intention to wed.

Rounding out its first year of existence, Modern Age Books, Inc., today moves to new quarters on "Publishers Row" at 432 Fourth Avenue. Modern Age has issued fifty-two titles and has announced an extensive Fall list.

Delegates to the Latin-American Labdr Congress from countries south of Mexico charged widespread restrictions upon organized labor. Most of the speakers urged the world's workers to cooperate in fighting fascism. Salvador Ocampo of Chile urged a boycott of merchandise from fascist countries.

Dr. Ernest McNeill fell dead of a heart attack yesterday in an apartment at 474 West 238th Street to which he was moving. His collapse occurred while he and his wife were standing in an empty room waiting for the moving men to bring the furniture from their former home at 340 Riverside Drive.
Mrs. Mary Watts, widow of George F. Watts, a Victorian artist whom she survived by thirty-four years, died in Compton, Surrey, today, at the age of 88. She was herself a promising art student,

Substantial gains in import activity at the loacl port compared with recent months is revealed in statistics covering August duty collections at the port. Collections for the month totaled $13,412,351.70, compared with $10,518,303.08 the month before and $16,947,246.36 for August last year.

Chairman Dies said today that he intended to suggest to the House committee investigating un-American activities that Secretary Perkins be summoned to testify about the deportation . case of Harry Bridges. West Coast C. I. O. leader.

The Lion Manufacturing Corporation filed suit in Federal court today seeking an injunction to restrain the Chicago Flexible Shaft Company from continuing to manufacture an electric shaver known as Shavemaster.

Miss Ann Bukowskis double in the sixth inning sent Miss Tina Stewart home with the run that enabled Kaufmann's Maids of Reading, Pennsylvania State champions, to defeat the New York Roverettes, 1 to 0, in the feature of the women's soft-ball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.
The battle for fourth place in the National League provided plenty of action yesterday at the Polo Grounds as the Giants launched their last home stand of the season against the Boston Bees.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept, 2: CAPTAIN Phelps, J. R., Med. Corps. Los Angeles. Calif., Naval Recruiting Station. on Dec. 1, ordered home, relieved all active duty. COMMANDER Kilduff, W. D.. First Naval Dist., on Oct. 1, to. home, relieved all active duty.

A reprimand, the lightest punishment under police regulations, has been meted out to Lieutenant Arthur Dallas, who two months ago caused the "unnecessary" arrest of Mrs. Ethel Tarvanovich after she had turned in a pistol she found on a Second Avenue bus.

Mrs. Mary Ella Williams Dignam, a leader in national women's organizations, died today after an illness of eight months at the age of 82. She was convener of the art sections of the International Council of Women and of the National Council of Women of Canada.
Although an ordinary chess game frequently lasts several hours anyway, a Princeton professor showed yesterday how an unending game could be played that would never lead to victory or a draw.
Ninety-nine per cent accuracy in a new type of public opinion poll was vouched for today at the convention here of the American Association of Applied Psychology.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: S. M., M. D., in his letter to THE TIMES makes the statement that "* * * optometrists are the worst evil against the medical profession," associating, by this statement, the profession of optometry with the "fake medicines and cures" and the "modern ballyhoo" he mentions previously.

Miss Mary Frances Bartnett, daughter of John J. Bartnett of this city and the late Mrs. Bartnett, was married this morning to Lloyd Vincent Juan of New York, son of Mrs. Louis B. Juan and the late Mr. Juan, in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here.
Furniture manufacturers in the final half of August received more orders than in any preceding two-week period in 1938, it was reported in trade circles here today.

In compliance with a recent court order, the Board of Education is planning to discharge 130 substitutes and replace them with regular teachers who already hold full-time jobs in the school system and in the future will have two jobs each.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a public hearing for Sept. 15 to determine the relationship of the Utilities Employees Securities Company and the New England Capital Corporation...

Mike Mitchell rode two winners on the five-event running-horse race program at the New York State Fair today, scoring with F. Coppa's Pepper Patch in -the second race and with Mrs. Marie Falmigiletti's High Treason in the third. Both horses are trained by Joe Gora.

Superior organization and momentum generated for their candidate in the early stages of the campaign are relied upon by his backers to deliver Maryland's Eastern Shore to Senator Millard E. Tydings, next up on President Roosevelt's "purge" list.

Forming part of extensive renovations that have been in progress during the Summer, six new display windows facing Broadway and Herald Square were placed in operation by R. H. Macy Co., Inc. Store executives described the new windows as "six little theatres,"

The partial French mobilization through the recall of reservists to the colors caused a considerable war scare here when it became known this morning. Stocks fell violently on the Bourse, and the probabilities that peace would be preserved were everywhere discussed animatedly, usually with far from hopeful conclusions.

E. Howard Miller, Spanish-American War veteran and former proprietor of plumbing supply houses at Poughkeepsie, N. Y., and Springfield, Mass., died here yesterday at his home. His age was 61. Mr. Miller was one of the organizers of Company L of the old Tenth Regiment, New York National Guard. Surviving are his widow, Mrs. Harriet Martin Miller;
Clifford Dempsey, a character actor for more than fifty years, died on Sunday of a heart ailment in his home at 104 Central Avenue here. He was 73 years old.

The British Government was relieved, but was hardly reassured today by the latest Czech concessions and by the absence of any reference to Czechoslovakia in Chancellor Hitler's proclamation at Nuremberg.

The Rev. Francis Hopkinson Craighill Jr., assistant rector at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, has accepted a call to become rector of Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, Va.

Steel ingot production increased last week, countering a seasonal decline, and the adjusted index rose to 67.5 from 64.6. A seasonal of 94.5 was used and 92.3 will be used for this week. For the week ended Sept. 4, 1937, the steel index was 130.4.

Miss Catherine Patricia Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bryant Butler of Riverdale, was married yesterday morning in the Church of St. Margaret, Riverdale, to Andrew John Corbett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Corbett, also of Riverdale.

With only twenty-one business days until the beginning of the fourth quarter of the year, the United States Steel Corporation's subsidiaries have not yet announced to the trade whether prices for their products for the quarter are to be reaffirmed or changed in any respect.

The marriage of Miss Julia Dyckman Andrus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamlin Foster Andrus of Yonkers, N. Y., to Frederick Franklin Moon Jr., son of Mrs. Moon of Syracuse and the late Dean Moon, will take place Saturday afternoon in Millerton, N. Y., at the home of the prospective bride's maternal grandmother, Mrs. Frank A. Hotchkiss.

The Bankamerica Company of San Francisco received yesterday the award of $2,000,000 State of California registered warrants at 2 per cent, plus a premium of $4,661. The warrants, issued for unemployment purposes, will be dated Sept. 8 and will be due on Feb. 27, 1939.

Curt Davis pitched five-hit shutout ball today while his St. Louis mates were hammering out seventeen to defeat Cincinnati, 8 to 0, and stretch the gap between the Reds and idle Pirates to four and onehalf games.

The Treasury asked about $2,100,000 in back taxes and interest today from Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob. Messrs. Raskob and du Pont recently lost a dicision of the Board of Tax Appeals on their 1929 income tax returns, after a legal battle which the two men said was intended to punish them for their anti-Roosevelt activities.

When things look darkest for the Dodgers there are always the Phillies. Today, after spotting Jimmy Wilson's dungeon dwellers four runs in the first inning, the Grimes clan came back to take the decision, 6--4, and break their losing streak at three games.

A petition of the Boston Transcript Company, publisher of the Boston Evening Transcript since 1830, filed today in Federal District Court for authority to reorganize under Section 77-B of the Bankruptcy Act, was approved by Judge Francis J. W. Ford.

There is strange parallel this year between the Fordham football coach and the Fordham football team. Sleepy Jim Crowley had a bit of one toe cut off and he is limping badly as a result of his operation. The Rams had graduation cut a large slice out of the Seven Blocks of Granite and old Rameses is limping on his own account.
Camillo Cardinal Laurenti, prefect of the Sacred Congregation of Rites, died today of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.
People coming back from woods and shore and mountain to the great city will feel its throb and clamor more quickly than its size.
EXPERIMENTS IN TELEPATHY, by Rene Warcollier. (Harper, $3.) Edited and abridged by Gardner Murphy from La Telepathie, articles in Revue Metapsychique and recent unpublished studies.

The Supreme Court today refused a request for the placing of an Austrian commissar in charge of Czechoslovak branches of an Austrian firm. Ostmark authorities had contended that the proprietor of Czechoslovak branches of what was formerly an Austrian Jewish concern should not be allowed the free disposition of his property In Czechoslovakia.

Captain Morton McD. Jones, star army polo player, at one time stationed on Governors Island, has been convicted by a court-martial of violating three articles of war and sentenced to Atlanta Penitentiary for five years, with a dishonorable discharge, it was revealed by the War Department today.

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, in a statement last night endorsed the candidacy of Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate, who is being opposed for the Republican nomination for Kings County judge by Harold L. Turk, a Republican district leader.

The United States Maritime Commission formally accepted the liner Brazil from the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation at brief exercises yesterday aboard the vessel at the company's Brooklyn plant at Fifty-sixth Street. She will be transferred today to Hoboken for final attention preparatory to her entry into the South American service on Oct. 8.

Strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold steady on a fairly active market today, Other steer and yearling trade was generally steady to 25 cents lower, and most other killing classes full steady, the United States' Department of Agriculture reports. Hogs strengthened and lambs sold strong to 25 cents higher.

Frank Buchman, American-born founder and leader of the Oxford Group, took the speakers' stand here today at the Oxford Group assembly for "moral rearmament." The entire gathering of 2,000 persons from forty-five nations listened in silence as he told them;

Amid continuing tension over Czechoslovakia Chancellor Hitler in his annual Nuremberg proclamation yesterday warned the world that Germany had had a good harvest, that she had stored food reserves and that the idea of an economic blockade "can henceforth be buried."

Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Chancery Court here today postponed until next Monday argument on a temporary order Restraining police officials of Union City from interfering with the production of "Tobacco Road," which opened an indefinite run at the Hudson Theatre -here last Sunday night.

The cost per capital for maintaining juvenile delinquents in institutions is fifteen times as much as probation supervision, it was disclosed today by the division of probation of the State Correction Department.

The pound sterling declined rapidly on Monday's London market and went lower still on Tuesday; reaching at one time, by the dispatches, $4.81 1/2, as against $4.84 1/2 at Saturday's New York closing, $4.86 1/4 a week before and $4.91 7/8 at the beginning of August. Some of the cables again ascribed

Woodsaw, 3-year-old owned by Mrs. J. A. Nix, made his first Chicago start a winning one today by finishing a length ahead of Lassator, the favorite, in the Discovery Handicap at Hawthorne. Decuria, a South American filly, closed fast to finish third.

The Ecuador Government has dented press reports that all importations from Japan have been stopped, but it is- understood that the control committee is no longer granting permits to import Japanese goods, since the country is already well supplied with them.

Deaths Announced Lieutenant Christopher J. Plunkett, of Engine Co. 8, died Sept. 3, in the discharge of duty, from injuries sustained while operating at Signal Station 881, at 4:41 A. M., Aug. 31, fire in premises 20 East 53d St., Manhattan. Funeral will take place from Barrett's Funeral Parlor, 424 West 51st St., Manhattan, at 9:45 A. M., Wednesday, Sept. 7. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert left Flushing court yesterday to play baseball on a vacant lot in Annadale Park, Queens, before ruling on a complaint that the games of neighborhood boys on the lot were a public nuisance.
Rollin H. Wilbur, a retired railroad executive, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital, to which he had been hurried by ambulance after returning from Europe yesterday on the Ile de France.

Gilbert H. Montague of New York entertained with luncheon at Beaulieu in Seal Harbor today in honor of Federal Judges Learned Hand and Augustus N. Hand of New York and Dean James M. Landis of the Harvard Law School.

The Supreme Court yesterday sentenced Cyril Edwin Ansell to five years' imprisonment at hard labor for the killing of W. J. Hanlon, a native of Syracuse, N. Y., who retired from the United States Navy in October, 1937.

The steamship Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line is sailing this afternoon for France and England. Passengers are Sir Owen Chalkley, P. G. T. Buchan-Hepburn, Member of Parliament; Brig. Gen Sir Henry Page Croft. Lieut.
Trial of William F. McGuinness, Assistant District Attorney of Brooklyn, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, on charges of conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case was adjourned

Pay for village letter carriers equal to that received by city carriers was urged in a resolution adopted today by the New York State Letter Carriers Association as it brought its convention to a close.

Mexican Government Railway System, through Carstens, Linnekin Wilson. Inc and additional space to Dicalite Co, in 120 Wall St, Publicaztoni del Mattino Co, publishers, Samuel Jackson, auctioneer in 401 Broadway; Charles F. Noyes ?? Inc, brokers.
Their practice rounds over and every one keyed up for play, women golf stars from Great Britain and the United States will 'begin tomorrow a closely matched biennial battle for the Curtis Cup.

John Joseph Hacket, who played baseball on the old Bloomington Rids with Clark Griffith, now owner of the Washington Senators, died last night following a long illness. He was 74 years old. In 1919 he had helped reorganize the Three-I League, one-of the oldest minor baseball circuits.

The Public Service Commission yesterday authorized the Buffalo and Niagara Electric Corporation to issue $2,375.000 of general refunding 3 1/4 per cent mortgage bonds due Aug. 1, 1968. The bonds are dated Aug. 1, 1938, and the proceeds will be used to refund firstmortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Buffalo General Electric Company, a constituent company of Buffalo and Niagara.

Hugh Govern, former counsel to the Immigration Department in the port of New York, who assisted in simplifying the naturalization laws, s died Sunday in the New Rochelle t Hospital after a week's illness. His age was 73.

The Trust Company-of New Jersey has sold to the Woodlawn Holding, Inc., the three-story brick building with stores at 110 Jackson Avenue, Jersey City, on a lot 25 by 100 feet. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $18,000.

Mrs. Mary Mehetable Taylor, 102 years old, died today of the infirmities of old age at her home here. Born in Montclair on Aug. 28, 1836, Mrs. Taylor, who was the daughter of Lyman B. and Martha Kent, had been a lifelong resident of this place.
The War Department announced today contracts for anti-aircraft equipment totaling $10,000,000 with private and government ordnance factories.

A proposal by the larger milk companies that the municipal restrictions on the shipment of skimmed milk into the city for manufacturing purposes be liberalized to allow entries in greater bulk will be considered next Tuesday by the Board of Health, it was learned yesterday.

Sir Hubert Wilkins arrived here today on route to join the Lincoln Ellsworth Antarctic expedition in Cape Town. He said that his ambition to exlore the polar regions .began as a boy in his native South Australia when he saw all his father's sheep and cattle lost in the drought of 1902.

Mrs. Catharine I. McCooey, widow of John H. McCooey, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, and mother of Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey, left her estate to her children and grandchildren, according to her will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court, Brooklyn.
The theft of $25,000 in jewels yesterday from her room at a Virginia Beach hotel was reported by Mrs. James Wilson Hall, 375 Park Avenue, New York, the police here revealed today.

A threeman scientific expedition set out today for the 8,000-foot Roraima Plateau, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's "Lost World." The scientists are P. S. Peberdy, curator of the British Guiana Museum; A. Pinkus,

An order authorizing the merger of the Bordentown Electric Company and the Cinnaminson Electric Light, Power and Heating Company of Riverton, N. J., into the Public Service Electric and Gas Company has been authorized by the Federal Power Commission.

City departments would like to spend more than $1,000,000,000 on capital improvements in the sixyear period from 1939 to 1944, according to estimates submitted by the commissioners to the City Planning Commission, it was learned yesterday.

A banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and including Paul H. Davis Co., Dean Witter Co., E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and the William R. Staats Company will offer today 208,006 shares of common stock of the Lane-Wells Company at $15.25 a share.

Three-quarters of a million young men and women and children of Moscow trooped their crimson banners through Red Square today in observance of International Youth Day, celebrated simultaneously in many countries under the auspices of the Young Communist League.

John Degelmann, assistant county counsel and town attorney for this municipality, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 42 years. Born in Hoboken, Mr. Degelmann was graduated from the New Jersey Law School in Newark shortly after the United States entered the World War.
Mayor La Guardia will leave for the West tomorrow for a threeweek trip. He expects to announce his itinerary today. He will take his 9-year-old daughter, Jean, with him.

Representative Bruce Barton, speaking last night at the opening of campaign headquarters for Allen W. Dulles, Republican designee for the House of Representatives nomination in the Sixteenth Congressional District, said that he hoped that Representative John J. O'Connor would defeat James H. Fay for the Democratic nomination in the same district.

Myron Selznick's Can't Wait, the 3-year-old son of Victorian, who finished third in the Kentucky Derby last Spring and has been promising better things since then, came back to his best form at Aqueduct yesterday and scored an easy victory in the Exile Handicap at six and a half furlongs.
Manager Pie Traynor announced tonight he was shifting the batting order of his sliding Pittsburgh Pirates for tomorrow's important game with the challenging Reds.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 6, unless specified: At San Diego: Blue, Sept, 4; Bagley, Raleigh, Bridge, Sept. 5. At New London: Cuttlefish, Sept. 2; Warrington, Sept. 4. Crisfield to Poughkeepsie, Sept. 5, Cuyahoga, Potomac. Miami to Houston: Dickerson, Schenck. Miami to New Orleans: Babbitt, Roper, Tillman.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the Princeton University Chapel, and Mrs. Wicks of Princeton, N. J., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Lansing Wicks, to Dr. William Ernest Gillespie, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Hamilton Gillespie of Exeter, N. H.

The gasoline service station on the southwest corner of Skillman Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Harpelt Realty Corporation to the Shell Union Oil Company.
Dr. Francis Keane MacMurrough, physician in the old Lafayette section of Jersey City, who also was a poet, died this morning at his home, 279 Pacific Avenue. He was 73 years old.

The American Chamber of Commerce gave a luncheon today for Warren Lee Pierson, president of the Export-Import Bank. About 100 American business men attended and Jefferson Caffery, the United States Ambassador, presided as honorary president of the organization.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a public hearing to determine whether the registration of the common capital stock of Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., should be suspended or withdrawn from the New York Curb Exchange will be reopened on Sept. 15 at its offices in New York.

The Public Use of Arts Committee opened yesterday its two-day CityWide Children's Art Festival on the Mall in Central Park. It included exhibitions of children's arts and crafts and a continuous series of performances by children on a stage in front of the shell.

An Interesting experiment in small-home construction has been worked out to help solve the problem of housing the families of workers to be employed in the vast new. plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company, now nearing completion at Clairton, Pa.
The stubborn Chiness defense at all critical points in the far-flung Japanese offensive toward Hankow yesterday barred further Japanese gains after their successes of the last few days.

Expressing a fair amount of confidence in the business outlook for the coming months, men's wear retailers here yesterday launched the Fall selling season, the first time in quite a few years that a practically unanimous drive has been started so early in September.
Greentree stands in the title round of the national open polo championship tonight, there to meet the winner of the Old Westbury-Aurora match of tomorrow on next Sunday.

The Chinese delegation here confirmed reports today that China would press strongly at the League of Nations Council session starting on Friday for League action against Japan under Article XVII of the League covenant.

Mrs. Mary Volkmann Wilmot, mother of Clifford R. Wilmot, member of the Greenwich Board of Assessors, died last night of a heart ailment at her home here at the age of 78 years. She was born in Germany, but had lived in Greenwich the last fifty years.

Harry Schoenhaus, who was a kind of secretary and treasurer of the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket, told Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and a blue-ribbon jury yesterday how he had been instructed to put James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, "on the payroll."

A style show, signalizing the revival of the Bramley trade-name applied to ready-to-wear dresses, was held yesterday by Franklin Simon Co. Eleven models displayed junior and misses' dresses, trimmed and untrimmed coats and jackets and suits.

Among the projects for which plans were filed-in the various boroughs yesterday was a six-story apartment house in the Bronx: costing $90,000, a group of twenty small homes in Brooklyn at an estimated cost of $90,000, and groups of twenty-one and nine houses in Queens, to cost, respectively, $105,000 and $40,500.

Another of the series of reports of trustfund investment accounts showing the securities held as investments in government trust funds and in accounts of certain governmental corporations and agencies was made public today by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau. It gave the status of the investments as of July 27, showed total investments in government securities of $4,320,596,000, as compared with $4,185,538,000 as of June 30. The statement follows:
Cardinal Hinsley, Archbishop of Westminster, said today that in the death of Cardinal Hayes "America and the church have lost a great and saintly father and ruler."

MANHATTAN BROVERMAN, MORRIS (Aug. 15). Estate, less than $10,000. To Sarah A. Broverman, widow, and Frederick S. Broverman, son, executor, both of 15 W. 81st St., residue equally. D'AGOSTINO, ANGELO (July 27). Estate, not more than $1,000. To John D' Agostino, son, 69 Baxter St., and Tessina D' Agostino, widow, executrix, 75 Baxter St., residue equally.

President Federico Laredo Bru signed a decree today exempting all Americans who are members of the American Legion from the effects of the Labor Nationalization Law provided they were residents of Cuba in 1933, when the measure was enacted.

Listed bonds did little more than mark time in quiet trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market appeared to be awaiting further news of developments in the Central European situation.

A few hours before he was to be married, John Gannon, 45-year-old World War veteran, died today in a fire which swept a duplex-wooden house in Brookline Village. The bride-to-be, Miss Sophie White, 28, of Florence, N. C., said they originally planned to wed during the holiday week-end, but had postponed the ceremony until noon today.

Many thousands of motor cars came and went in the metropolitan region over the Labor Day week-end with almost no serious accidents and with a relative freedom from congestion that would have been thought impossible a few years ago.

The check for $1,309.45; which had been allotted to her for expenses while' competing abroad with the Wightman Cup team and in the championships at Wimbledon, has been returned to Mrs. Helen Wills Moody by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George C. Waters were among those giving dinners last night on the roof garden of the Astor. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Sparks, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Berwind and Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Carver.
Two Syracuse endurance fliers, in the air since Friday, were forced down at 9:30 o'clock, Eastern standard time, tonight in the Onendaga Yacht Club basin.

Five appointment to instructorships, one of them a promotion, were announced today by Dr. Hugh P. Baker, president of- Massachusetts State College. Those appointed are Doric Alviani of Amherst, Instructor in Music;

When the Wagner act was passed, American unions generally welcomed it as a "Magna Charta for labor." There was coercion in the act, but it seemed to apply only to employers. It provided, in the words of one observer, merely for "unilateral compulsory arbitration."

Seventeen bombing planes, reinforcements for the navy's Hawaiian patrol squadrons, took off today in a 2,570-mile non-stop flight to Honolulu. The lead plane, carrying Lieutenant A. P. Storrs 3d, commanding the squadron, took off at 1:38 P. M. (5:38 P. M. Eastern daylight time).

Dwight Long, a 24-year-old adventurer who left the University of Washington four years ago when the depression made him pessimistic about his prospects after college, sailed into port here today on his thirty-two-foot ketch Idle Hour after a 34,000-mile cruise around the world.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 39.9 per cent of capacity this week, without adjustment for Labor Day, a decrease of 4.1 points, or 9.3 per cent from last reek, when the rate was 44.0 per cent. In the same week last year operations were 12.5 points, or 14.9 per cent lower, at 71.6 per cent.
Andrew B. Sweet, a retired captain of the New York Fire Department, who had been in the service of the city for thirty-seven years, died Monday in St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 76.

The Maritime Commission asked bids today for construction of twelve cargo ships, all of the newly designed C-3 type. It is the hope of the commission that the bids will be low enough to permit the immediate construction of all twelve. No one yard will receive a contract for more than six vessels.

Irving Eldridge, 133, Bronx, easily outpointed Phil Siriani, 132 3/4, Bronx, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw Eldridge triumph.

For the second successive year the team of the New York Curb Exchange, champion of the Wall Street Soft Ball League, will meet that of Lamson Brothers of Chicago, winner of the La Salle Street Soft Ball League, for the intercity champion ship.
When the President, as in 1932, can range the bulk of the votes of farm and factory behind his standard he is assured a comfortable popular and legislative majority of the American people.

Monty Stratton, making his first start since he twisted his ankle almost two weeks ago, allowed eight scattered hits today as he pitched the White Sox to an 8-to-2 triumph over the Browns. It was his fourteenth victory of the season.

The Transit Commission is prepared to support Mayor La Guardia in his fight to tear down the Sixth Avenue elevated line, it was learned yesterday. The final public hearing on the city's application for a Transit Commission certificate declaring that the Sixth Avenue elevated line is neither necessary nor convenient
Frank Lloyd Wright, architect, will. be the speaker at the first of a series of Fall and Winter meetings arranged by the Manhattan chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
This has been a perfect day for the second match in the four-day Atlantic Coast tuna tournament, with light winds and smooth water during most of the fishing period.
Mr. and Mrs. William E. Dodge Stokes, who are at the Lenox Club, were the guests of honor at a luncheon today given by Miss Natalie Bayard Merrill at Merrylodge, Stockbridge.

Evidence purporting to show that Ohio's administration of the old-age assistance program is "permeated from top to bottom with partisan politics" and has been used as a political machine in the interest of Governor Martin L. Davey and other State officials, was laid before officials of the Social Security Board today at a hearing.

The New York Football Giants and the Eastern College All-Stars, each rated a far more formidable team than a year ago, will clash under floodlights at the Polo Grounds tonight in a pre-season gridiron show of such savor that a gathering of 45,000 is expected to witness the proceedings. The Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund will share in the receipts.
B. S. Moss, operator of the Criterion and other theatres, announced yesterday the formation of Empress Pictures, Inc., for the production, exhibition and distribution of French pictures.

Today, as his quarrel with the C. I. O. leadership neared a crisis, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile' Workers of America, was reported in some auto union circles to be seriously considering an attempt to withdraw the U. A. W. from the C. I. O.

THE old familiar strains are about to make the welkin ring. "Block that kick!" "Hold that line!" "Why doesn't he penalize the other fellows once in a while?" Which means that football is about to burst into bloom again in this vicinity. The night-blooming variety

Despite the rar-reaching nature of the concessions that the Czechoslovak Government has offered the Sudeten Germans, it appeared evident today-many mysterious conferences notwithstanding-that the Henleinists intended to continue their stalling tactics until after Chancellor Hitler's main speech at the Nazi party congress in Nuremberg. Germany.

The body of a man who might have been King of Spain lay in a mortuary here tonight. The Count of Covadonga, riding in an old sedan with a night club cigarette girl at the wheel, died several hours after a crash D ended their early morning ride.

The archbishops' crypt at St. Patrick's Cathedral was made ready yesterday to receive the fifth Archbishop of New York, Patrick Cardinal Hayes. He will be entombed there at 3-P. M. tomorrow after the solemn pontifical funeral mass.

George Caster limited the Senators to six hits as the Athletics recorded a 5-2 victory over Washington today in the opener of a two-game series. The Athletics took a three-run lead in the second inning.

Led by Commissioner John J. McElligott, more than 100 uniformed members of the New York Fire Department joined in a final tribute yesterday at the funeral of Lieutenant Christopher J. Plunkett of Engine Company 8, who died on Saturday from injuries received in line of duty a week ago.

Following action by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court early in the day in Philadelphia, a special investigating committee of the House of Representatives began an inquiry tonight into graft and coreruption charges made against Governor Earle and thirteen fellowDemocrats.

In one of the most imposing funeral ceremonies ever planned in this city, Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, will be laid to rest with his predecessors tomorrow in a crypt beneath the high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Department of Commerce will undertake, in connection with the investigation of monopoly which is now under way, the first study of trade associations, collectively, ever made by the Federal Government, Calvert Judkins, chief of the trade association section of the department, announced today.

Spokesmen of the towboat employes of New York Harbor and certain New England port cities will demand a wage increase of $1 a day and other labor concessions at a conference next Wednesday with officials of the New York Towboat Exchange.
Lloyd Paul Stryker, chief counsel for James J. Hines, continued his cross-examination of Big Harry Schoenhaus yesterday when the trial reopened before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray said today that he- found the .sentiment of upState Democratic leaders to favor the renomination of Governor Lehman when the State Democratic Convention meets here Sept. 29 and 30.

The internationall Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has reported that its telephone operating subsidiaries in nine countries gained 40,500 telephones in service in the first seven months of this year, compared with a gain of 36,500 in the same period of 1937. All major companies reported increases.

Telegraphic requests from several San Francisco stores to delay shipments of merchandise until further notice because of the strike of retail employes in that city were received here yesterday by resident representatives of the Coast establishments.
Ralph E. Ladue, president of John David, Inc., predicted "tremendous business" for the men's clothing store chain at a dinner last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Heavy trading in the Bronx was marked yesterday by sales of housing properties and the assembling of a site for improvement with an apartment house.

Convinced that Colonel Bill Terry and his Giants bear a charmed life, Professor Casey Stengel spent another miserable afternoon at the Polo Grounds yesterday as his baffled Bees, who for weeks have been hungrily eyeing a spot in the first division, took a second straight tumble.

Requests for sales promotions, advertising and merchandising material have been received from nearly 300 gas companies to be used in introducing Certified Gas Range campaigns on or before Sept. 15, according to a report submitted to the board of directors of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers yesterday by W. E. Derwent, chairman of the association's domestic gas range division and vice president of the George D. Roper Corporation of Rockford, Ill.

Although it seemed to be common knowledge on Broadway yesterday that the J. B. Priestley play "I Have Been Here Before" is headed for the Guild Theatre, opening Oct. 13, the Gilbert Miller office declined to confirm the booking, saying thatn"no deal has been closed."

Told in Henry Hathaway's habitually direct and vigorous cinematic style, the Paramount's "Spawn of the North" is a satisfactorily wildeyed tale of the Alaskan salmon fisheries in the days, now dead we trust, when Russian pirates raided the fish traps and looked as mean as Akim Tamiroff with a stubble of whisker.
John Fischer, president of the United States Savings Bank of Newark for fourteen years until his retirement six years ago, died yesterday in his home here. His age was 81.

The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that Class I railroads employed 915,088 workers in June, an increase of 1 per cent over May, but a sharp decline from June, 1937. The June payroll was $140,391,948, compared with 1,171,683 employes and a payroll of $167,925,718 in June, 1937.
Mayo Clinic physicians tonight announced that James Roosevelt, son and personal secretary of the President, would be operated on early next week for a gastric ailment.
The government appealed to the Supreme Court today a deportation case which may affect the status of Harry Bridges, West Coast C. I. O. leader, against whom deportation proceedings are pending.
Mel Harder's two-hit pitching performance today gave the Indians their ninth straight victory and their second shut-out over Detroit in two days. The score was 1 to 0.

Pat McCarran, whom the Nevada Democrats this week overwhelmingly renominated for the Senate against two 100 per cent New Dealers who got no direct help from the President, has for years been a question mark on the lists of the Democratic whips.
Seventeen naval flying planes swooped down on Pearl Harbor here shortly before dawn today, completing a 2,570-mile flight from San Diego, Calif., in 17 hours and 21 minutes.
Mayor La Guardia will begin ? 'three-week trip to the South and West at 8:30 o'clock this evening When he leaves the Pennsylvania Station for Shreveport, La.

Justice Department officials said today they had found no evidence that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City had violated the Federal civil rights statute prohibiting conspiracies to deprive any citizen of constitutional rights.

The Pittston Company, which was formed by the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen as a "vertical trust" controlling the production, distribution and sale of anthracite, is to release its hold on its large anthracite properties in Pennsylvania and confine its activities to the distribution of fuel.

The Dollar Line, reorganized under the control of the Maritime Commission, plans to announce a resumption of round-the-world and transpacific passenger services, both on a fortnightly basis, within ten days, it was learned today.

Speaking yesterday to a group of teachers from Italian Catholic Action associations, Pope Pius replied severely to those fascist commentators who claim he should not intervene in racist questions because this is a problem that has nothing to do either with religion or philosophy.

Whether due to the decline of about $1 a bale below the Federal Government's lending figure or in anticipation of today's crop estimate from Washington, hedging pressure slackened materially yesterday on the Cotton Exchange.

Lawrence S. Camp, candidate for the Democratic Senatorial nomination in Georgia against Senator George, has expended $10,260.12 in his campaign, irrespective of "money that might have been spent by those of whom I have no knowledge," according to a report filed with the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures.

Four British and four American yachts are to start competition to- . day for the British-American Cup. They will get under way at 2:20 P. M. off Oyster Bay, L. I., under the auspices of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. The trophy will go to the first team to take four races, points counting in each.
The city-wide Children's Art Festival of the Public Use of Arts Committee in Central Park was brought to a close yesterday afternoon with the awarding of prizes.

Borls Spirldonovitch Stomoniakoff, Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs since 1926 and Acting Commisar at times in the absence of Maxim M. Litvinoff or Vladimir Potemkin, the First Assistant Vice Commissar, has been removed by a decree of the Council of People's Commissars, just made public.
Under the leadership of Paul Richards, who stepped down from the major leagues for his first managerial role, the Atlanta Crackers today had clinched the 1938 Southern Association pennant.

Dr. Frederick H. Flaherty, former president of the Medical Society of the State of New York, died early today after an illness of ten days. He was 65 years old. Dr. Flaherty was graduated from the Syracuse University College of Medicine in 1896 and completed studies at the University of Berlin in 1898.

Although the eleven-week Summer vacation is nearly over, yesterday was still holiday time for 40,000 boys and girls who shouted. themselves hoarse for four and one-half hours at a program of athletic events and a parade of sports and entertainment notables at the Yankee Stadium.

The wedding of Miss Lillian Arlene Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Nathaniel Edwards of Amagansett, L. I., and Samuel Henry Hostetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ross Hostetter of Hanover, Pa., will take place on Sept. 17 in the First Presbyterian Church here and will be followed by a reception at Gurney's Inn, Montauk.

After another break in butter prices in Chicago today the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced in Washington that it is prepared to make available more money, if necessary, to stabilize the market.

Gay Charles, owned by Mrs. Gwladys Whitney, galloped to another easy victory at Aqueduct yesterday when he captured the Westbury Steeplechase and set a new track record for the distance of about two miles.

At the Oxford Group assembly here today labor leaders from Britain declared that the "price of peace is to prepare for a world war against selfishness." "Workers guided by God can lead the world in waging this war," said Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, Oxford Group leader, in introducing Todd Sloan, British labor leader and former radical agitator among London's unemployed.

Municipal ownership of utilities Is not automatically the solution of financial difficulties of cities and it can lead to an unsound system of taxation, Harry E. Jordan, secretary of the American Water Works Association, has declared.

Statutes of the new "Federation of Latin American Workers" were approved today by the constituent assemly here. United States unions will not be formally represented by the new federation, which voted the Second International of Amsterdam in order to obtain European trade union support.

The combination of strenuous official support and more reassuring news from Central Europe yesterday halted the collapse of the foreign exchange market and permittd sterling and the other currencies to stage a modest rally.

Appointment of Mrs. Lillian L. Poses as regional attorney of the Federal Social Security Board for this State was announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, the board's regional director. Mrs. Poses succeeds Professor Walter Gellhorn of the Columbia Law School, who will devote his full time to teaching.

Charging that "American dictatorship, American style," was the objective of President Roosevelt, Senator Vandenberg said here today that in seeking to defeat Representative John J. O'Connor of New York the President was endeavoring to "gag" the legislative branch of the government.
Paul Sifton, Administrator of the New York Unemployment Insurance Law for a year, was named today as Assistant Administrator of the Division of Wages and Hours of the Department of Labor.
Miss Helen Ann Babcock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton L. Babcock of this place, was married tonight to Richard Elwood Harris, son of Mrs. Albert W. Harris and the late Mr. Harris of Newark.

Seidler-Bergheim, Ltd., manufacturer of men's neckwear, will open its New York office at 99 Madison Avenue today. The concern's office in Berlin is to be closed and the business will be concentrated here.
Organization of an international campaign against grasshoppers could control nine-tenths of hopper damage in Saskatchewan, Professor Kenneth King; Federal entomologist, said here today.
Albany's football Senators made their 1938 gridiron debut tonight by losing a 26-to-6 decision to the Brooklyn Dodgers in an exhibition game.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,349,100 barrels, compared with 3,388,500 in the preceding week, a decline of 39,400, .according to theAmerican Petroleum Institute.

Prague's plan for the solution of the minorities problem is displayed with a considerable degree of prominence in the Italian press. On the whole, its reception is very favorable. The general impression is that it represents an important step toward meeting German aspirations and has contributed greatly toward easing the tension.

Although it was not exactly his birthday, August Heckscher, financier and philanthropist, had a birthday party yesterday. He kept open penthouse last evening to a score of friends. His wife joined him in receiving guests on the top of the office building, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue.
E. Ralph Martin, chairman of the Wall Street Athletic Association's tennis committee, is receiving entries for the annual tennis tournament at the office of Tobey Kirk, 52 Wall Street.

Robert V. White, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange Committee on Stock List and a partner in Jackson Curtis, is slated' to become president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, it was reported in financial circles yesterday.

New York will have its first glimpse of jai alai tonight, when the popular Latin-American sport will be unfolded to public view at the New York Hippodrome. Plans to provide for a capacity crowd of 3,000 persons have been made by Mike Jacobs, who is promoting the enterprise together with Lee Shubert.

America's hopes of retaining the Curtis Cup, emblematic of women's golf supremacy between the United States and Great Britain, today were washed out almost as completely as the famed Essex County course, over which the international matches are being played, was by July's downpours.

Announcement of a price reduction of $2 a case in the wholesale price of National Distillers Products Corporation Eagle blended rye whisky and a statement by the Calvert Distillers Products Corporation that it will introduce a new brand of whisky which will be "the highest price whisky ever blended in America," featured the wholesale liquor market here yesterday.
A miniature steel mill, complete with open-hearth furnace, rolling mills and clanking steam hammer, is helping giant mills keep in step with research.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Watson of the Plaza will return today on the Bremen. Mrs. Forsyth Wickes and Miss Ann Wickes are at the St. Regis. Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius has returned from Hot Springs, Va., and will be at The Shelter, her home in Locust Valley, for the Autumn.
With the Davis Cup successfully defended against the challenge of Australia at Germantown, the tennis season will wind up in the East at Forest Hills with the biggest show put on there in years.

For various reasons, nothing exceptional is expected of Manhattan College's football forces this Fall. As the Jaspers lunched' today, prior to heading back to their New York City campus, Herb Kopf, their new coach, freely discussed the Green's chances for this year. He gave the impression that he was satisfied with the progress made thus far, but frankly admitted that there is considerable room for improvement.

The Indiana General Service Company of Marion, Ind., a subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration covering the issue of $6,500,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1968, as it proposes to sell the bonds to three life insurance companies at 101 1/2.

More than 600,000 soldiers are lined up on the Franco-German border. The two great defense systems, the Maginot and the Siegfried lines, are in sight of one another, or would be if anything could be seen except a few barbed wire barricades and a handful of sentries guarding pillboxes.

Coming from behind in the last quarter-mile, Scottish Union carried James Rank's silks to victory today in the 163d renewal of the St. Leger Stakes, last of the English turf's classics for 3-yearolds this year.

The United States Infantry shot its way to the top of a field of thirtyseven teams to annex the national pistol match today with a total of 1,335 out of 1,500, setting a new record in its victory. The Los Angeles Police,. winner of last year's match with a record score of 1,332, was runner-up with 1,308.

Scoring two points during today's sessions of the Plymouth Chess Club's international tournament at the Guildhall, Sir George Thomas of London regained the lead with four straight to his credit, leaving Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the world champion, in second place for the time being.

George D. Brooke, president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, appeared yesterday before the committee on stock list and took full responsibility for a misleading statement made by the railroad concerning the payment of interest which was defaulted last Thursday.

A protective committee representing holders of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., optional 6 per cent convertible debentures due on Sept. 1, 1939, of which $29,400,000 is outstanding, has been formed with John Nickerson as chairman. Other members are Benjamin F. Castle, C. M. Keys, Leslie L. Vivian and Leonard A. Wales. Douglas G. Wagner, 40 Exchange Place, is secretary.
Former Police Magistrate Herold E. Smith of Teaneck was arrested this afternoon on a charge of conversion and held in $1,500 bail by Prosecutor John J. Breslin of Bergen County.

Announcing that Friedrich Krupp, Inc., would appeal from Justice Meier Steinbrinck's decision in the New York State Supreme Court in a suit filed there by the Pan American Securities Corporation, an official German press communique sharply attacks a private individual who is allegedly behind not only this, but also similar recent European lawsuits against Krupp.

William R. Hearst's fourteenth century St. Donat's castle in Wales will soon be offered for sale. The castle was purchased by Mr. Hearst thirteen years ago and it is estimated he spent [Pound]250,000 to preserve and modernize it. It is now valued at about [Pound]300,000.

The 1,371 bond issues listed on the "St New York Stock Exchange, aggre- TE gating $49,423,890,528 par value as GI of Sept. 1, hid a total market value Cc of $44,182,833,403, according to a M compilation by the Exchange issued BI yesterday.
That familiar caustic cry of "losing pitcher, Mulcahy!" had to be revised today as the Dodgers wound up their two-day series with the Phils before vast stretches of empty seats in Shibe Park.

The United States Government was accused today by the International Law Committee of the District of Columbia Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild of violating the treaty of peace with Germany of 1921 and the neutrality act of May 1, 1937, in permitting munitions shipments to Germany.

Dr. and Mrs. George G. Lovett have announced at their home in Napier, W. Va., the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Thelma Jean Lovett, to Dr. Percy H. Jennings Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jennings of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.
Stanley H. Howe, executive secretary to Mayor La Guardia, was ordered by physicians yesterday to take a two-week rest after his collapse late Tuesday at his desk in City Hall.

Thd twenty-seventh annual conference of the Governmental Research Association opened at the Princeton Inn here today. Morning and afternoon sessions will be held daily until Saturday afternoon, with Iferman Loeffler of the Boston Municipal Research Bureau as general chairman.

Plans for the pavilion of the Soviet Government at the World's Fair, designed to give an effect of "dignified simplicity," were presented yesterday to the fair authorities by Vassilievich Bourgman, Soviet Deputy Commissioner, who arrived Monday from Moscow on the Queen Mary.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith and George MacDonald, Papal ] Marquis, two of the closest friends , of the late Cardinal Hayes, were I the speakers last night in a short I radio service broadcast in honor of I the Cardinal over Station WABC 1 and a national network.

Merchants and the owners of a number of properties in the neighborhood of Madison Avenue and Eighty-first Street are opposing the establishment of a funeral chapel there and will meet today to consider what steps they may take to discourage the plan, the Fifth Avenue Association reported yesterday.

George Emlen Roosevelt, yachtsman, banker and cousin of former President Theodore Roosevelt, was elected president of the Marshall Chess Club at a meeting of the board of governors at the clubhouse, 23 West Tenth Street, yesterday. Mr. Roosevelt,

Declaring that fingerprinting and other precautions could not prevent the practice of substitution in civilservice employment, Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, asked District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday to prosecute two such cases which had been brought to light.
More than 2,000 legionnaires had arrived here tonight for the opening tomorrow of the twentieth annual convention of the New Jersey Department of the American Legion.
The first disqualification ever seen in 'a running-horse race at the New York State Fair track marked today's program, run off in ankledeep mud and pelting rain.

The possibility that President Roosevelt might sponsor another "draft Lehman for Governor" movement was suggested in White House circles today as Mr. Roosevelt turned his attention temporarily from the Maryland Democratic Senatorial contest to some of the problems confronting party leaders of his home State.

IT was an overcast day and Casey Stengel was in a dark mood. The four runs the Giants had scored in the tenth inning on Tuesday had ruined his digestion and clouded his outlook on contemporary civilization.

One-fifth of American drivers avoid risk of sudden death in head-on collision by less than one second, according to the finding of investigators reported today at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.
The camera was unable to separate the two leaders in the $5,000 added Providence Handicap at Narragansett Park today, and top honors were divided between Merry Lassie and Lavengro.
The hesitancy and uncertainty of British policy in July, 1914, reappeared in London today as the Czechoslovak-German quarrel approached its decisive stage.

With the Summer sales slump having apparently ended rather abruptly in the last ten days, producers of whisky, gin, wine and beer will launch extensive advertising campaigns for their products for the Fall season, they revealed yesterday.

A number of duplex and terrace apartments were among the units appearing in brokers lists of new tenancies submitted yesterday, Mrs. Jean Cochran rented a duplex with a two-story living room in 322 East Fifty-seventh Street through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers, and Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., agents.
The "taxis of the Marne," which helped turn the tide of German invasion twenty-four years ago, will be replaced with buses if the necessity of rushing troops from Paris ever arises again.

Samuel Kessler; a former broker, accused of grand larceny, pleaded guilty before Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment charging that he jumped bail of $7,500 a year ago, when he was accused of grand larceny on a fraud complaint.

A spectacular fire, visible as a glow in the sky in parts of New York City and in many communities in Northern New Jersey, started shortly after 2 A. M. today at the Gates Avenue coal docks of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Jersey City.
Wahl Company will start a Fall campaign next week in behalf of Eversharp repeating pencils, pens and other products.

United States Attorney Lamar Hardy disclosed yesterday that two of his assistants and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had sailed for Europe Saturday on the liner Champlain to question Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, fugitive defendant in the German spy case.

The case against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, was completed yesterday after a battle between District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Milton Bernard, rackets accountant whom he had called as a witness, over the name of "J. Hines" on the back of a $500 check in evidence as one of the payments to the politician for protecting the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy gang.

A WPA book repair project working through the Summer vacation period has reclaimed 210,438 books from the school junk heap and made them clean and fit for use in the new school year, the WPA announced yesterday.
World zinc production in July amounted to 136.430 tons, compared with 131,885 in June and 156,816 in July, 1937, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

William La Motte , Day, former president and general manager of the General Motors Truck Company, died last night in a hospital at Ann Arbor at the age of 75. He had been ill several weeks. Mr. Day retired from business in 1924.

Coach Jimmy Crowley began working on his Fordham kickers yesterday. The Rams' mentor sent Pete Holovak, Steve Kazlo, Lenny Eshmont and Bill Krywicki through a long punting drill on Fordham Field in the morning as the squad had another intensive day of double sessions.
Howard Conkling, retired lawyer of New York, died in Butler Hospital here on Monday. He had been a patient there for some time.

Fed steers again hit a new high today at $13.35. All classes and grades were active and strong to higher, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Lambs and hogs were fully steady and the latter in instances showed upturns of 10 to 15 cents.

" Rumors" have reached London that Generalissimo Francisco Franco may shortly resign his leadership of the Spanish Insurgent Administration and be replaced by a "moderate politician," The Financial Times of London said today. Oberserving that the reports "appear to have some foundation," the article continues:

Noel Armstrong, a son of the late David Armstrong of this city, died Wednesday at his residence, Danskammer Farm, near Newburgh, N. Y., at the age of 56. The estate has been owned by his family for several generations.

The Atlas Plywood Corporation and its subsidiaries showed in its annual report for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net profit of $208,457 after interest, depreciation, Federal and Dominion income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on $1.25 convertible preferred stock, the profit is equivalent to 95 cents each on 136,027 shares of no-par common stock.

The report issued today by the Inter national Law Committee of the District of Columbia Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild charging the State Department with violating the 1921 treaty of peace with Germany. and the Neutrality Act of 1937 by permitting shipments of munitions to Germany is said to be published against the judgment of some of the members of the national committee of the Guild.

Winning the morning race and finishing second in the afternoon, Captain Frances McElwain's Cohasset boat today stepped into the lead with 111/4 Points in the women's national sailing championship and the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Trophy. Four more contests are scheduled.

Serge Koussevitzky will begin his fifteenth year in America as conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra when he directs the opening of the season in Symphony Hall, Boston, on Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday.
A new monthly record for home financing was set by the Federal Housing Administration in August, with mortgages selected for appraisal amounting to $104,226,887.

This was the day of the "massed glint," the one spectacle at Nuremberg calculated to tempt a hardened democrat to see some good in National Socialism despite its arrogance, stupidities and 'cruelties. The spectacle is put on by the lads of the Labor Service and in it is all the inspiration of youth and fe?vent patriotism.

Helped by five cardinall errors, the Cubs took the first of a three-game series from tse: Red Birds today, 7 to 5, but at the cost of injuries to Joe Marty and Rookie Vance Page, who was credited with the victory.

August Reinhold Franzen, portrait painter, who was president of the Gainsborough Studios, 222 West Fifty-ninth Street, died yesterday of a heart attack in his apartment at that address. He was born in Norrkoping, Sweden, seventy-four years ago, a son of John and Canon Franzen.
A fleet of eighty-two yachts sailed today as the sixth annual Fall regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club started. The series will continue through Saturday.

Mrs. Haruko Katayama, creative classical dancer who charmed Japanese audiences for three-quarters of a century, died today at the age of 100. She had been hailed by her admirers as "a national treasure."
France's powerful General Confederation of Labor, representing 5,000,000 workers, issued a communique tonight indicating that it will cooperate in strengthening national defense.

Japanese reports of the capture of Kwangtsi, a vital point on the route to Hankow just north of the Yangtse River, were denied by the Chinese military headquarters here today. Officers said the Chinese were still checking, a few miles from the city, three Japanese columns striking from the east.

The Rev. Dr. William Curtis Prout, for fifty-five years secretary of the annual Albany diocese convention, died late last night at the rectory of Middleville Memorial Episcopal Church at the age of 90.
A record number of examinations for regular teaching licenses for the New York City school system is planned for this Fall, Dr. Louis Marks. chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.

Wheat futures on the leading American markets dipped to new seasonal low levels in early trading today, but the selling movement quickly ran its course after prices had declined about 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish, and a strong rally followed in sympathy with the better character of the political news from Central Europe and the firmness in securities.

With a unanimity that could have found little dissent from any of the 40,382 spectators present, a press committee of thirteen voted Ward Cuff, whose mighty kicking toe carried the New York Giants to a 6-to-0 victory over the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo Grounds last night, the World's Fair Trophy as the outstanding performer on his team.

The Mead Corporation has borrowed $1,250,000 from the First National Bank of Chicago on collateral promissory notes secured by an equal amount of Mead Corporation Series B first mortgage bonds due 1945, according to a statement filed with the SEC.
The Spanish Insurgent command reported today that its drive along the Teruel-Sagunto Road toward Valencia, stalled for a month and a half, (1) lessened, had been resumed.

New York City's annual laundry bill amounts to more than $60,000,000, according to figures issued yesterday by Herman Brickman, impartial chairman for the arbitration of labor disputes in the laundry industry.
An attempt by Peter Tracy, vice president of the Hartford Central Labor Union, to inject the New Deal issue into the convention proceedings of the Connecticut Federation of Labor failed here today.

Dr. Edward Levis Prizer, a leader here in charities and civic affairs, died in a hospital this morning. His age was 54. He was born in Rochester, N. Y., a son of the late Edward Prizer, an officer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.
Wallace H. Miller, editor of The Bristol Press and brother of Dr. Francis Trevelyan Miller, the author, economist and historian, died today at the Bristol Hospital after a brief illness.

Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato declared yesterday that he would grant a jury trial to William F. McGuinness, assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, accused of conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case, although he officially reserved decision pending preparation of a written opinion.

The Board of -Transportation awarded yesterday to the George H. Flinn Corporation the contract for construction of the section of Fulton Street subway extension between Ashford and Crystal Streets along Pitkin Avenue in Brooklyn.

,A banking group headed by R. L. for bay Co./of Boston and including Sepi Estabrook Co.; Smith, Barney SepI Co.; Whiting, Weeks Knowles, at I Inc.; Newton, Abbe Co. and the per Lee Higginson Corporation received yesterday $1,810,000 of various pur- TI pose bonds of the city of Spring- Trui field. Mass. The grouDp aid a price not;

Last night's game under floodlights between the Eastern College All-Stars and the New York Football Giants serves notice that the year has passed definitely into the Sign of the Pigskin. There have been premonitions. Coaches have been granting interviews about prospects.

By anticipating the Dec. 15 maturity of $433,000,000 of 1 1/4 per cent notes and at the same time seeking $700,000,000 of "new money," the Treasury at its September quarterly financing date not only "clears the deck" for this year so far as refunding operations are concerned but also substantially augments its already strong cash position.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Sept. 1 increased in four of five trade divisions, as compared with the same week in 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:

One of the demands of the striking San Francisco department-store workers is for store-wide instead of department seniority. Seniority is the system under which those most recently emplayed are laid off first in dull times. The same rule often governs automatically also in promotions and demotions -the older employes being favored in the first and the younger bearing the brunt of the last.

The CzechSudeten German conflict became even more complicated tonight through reports from Moravian and Silesian areas that Czech police had "horse-whipped" Sudeten German Deputies and German declarations that the new Czech proposals were merely a subterfuge deliberately designed still further to hamper Viscount Runciman's negotiations.
Captain Alfred winsor brown, commanding officer of the battleship Arizona, died early today in his hotel apartment shortly after he had complained of being ill. He was52 years old.
Dartmouth began preparations for the defense of its Ivy League football championship when a squad of candidates reported to Coach Earl Blaik today in a driving rain.
Steady continuance of the "processes of recovery" evident since mid-June was reported today by Secretary Roper at his weekly press conference.

A suit was begun yesterday in Supreme Court by Attorney General Bennett against two corporations and nine individuals whom he accused of luring investors to "part with their money" by promises of profits up to 50 per cent on liquor stocks.
Steel production in the United States in August totaled 2,546,988 gross tons, the largest total in ten months and an increase of nearly 30 per cent over 1,982,058 tons produced during July.

Reorders continued to give a good account of themselves in the wholesale markets here yesterday, resident buying officials reported. The improvement in trade with the arrival of cool weather late last week was evident in a wide area of the northeastern section of the country, according to the source of the reorders.

Doubleday, Doran will publish on Nov. 4 the "O. Henry Memorial Award Prize Stories of 1938." The book, with an introduction by Harry Hansen, will include stories by Stephen Vincent Benet, Mary Hastings Bradley, Erskine Caldwell, Albert Maltz, William Saroyan and John Steinbeck.
The Workers Alliance of America announced today that it would not undertake its proposed plan to raise $50,000 to elect members of Congress sympathetic with its aims for persons on relief.
A special committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange suggested today to the board of governors that the Exchange continue to function without a paid president.

Establishment of a State bureau of prevention of crime in an effort to decrease juvenile delinquency will be advocated to the 1939 Legislature by a special joint legislative commission which for three years has been investigating problems of the State Children's Courts.

Australian players gained the major share of the successes in the annual team exhibition matches between the International Lawn Tennis Clubs of Great Britain and France, combined, and the International Club of the United States today on the grass courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

Lucky Frocks, Inc, in 1,385 Broadway: Percy Trilnick, Ltd. buying office, in 499 7th Ave; Alexander Caron, dresses, in 101-3 W 37th St; Simon Schreter, men's neckwear, in 270 W 39th St; Spear Co, Inc, broker.
Sir Charles Sanders, Assistant Controller General of Merchant Shipbuilding in the last year of the World War, died today at the age of 72.

Dr. Philip Marvel, 81, of Atlantic City, N. J., and Bethlehem, Pa., was found dead today on Hog Back Mountain near a resort hotel where he was vacationing. He had been missing since yesterday when he went hiking.

Book Week in the interest of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander, was formally opened this afternoon. Later a tea was given by Mrs. Stuart Duncan at her home, Bonniecrest.

Again led home by Alfred E. Chase's Viking, the United States team of thirty-square-meter yachts took the second race for the Beverly Yacht Club's International Challenge Cup today by a more impressive margin over their Swedish rivals than that by which they won yesterday's contest.

The texts of the Sudeten German party's communique announcing the. breakdown of minority negotiations with the Czechoslovak Government today and of the government's communique after consultations between it and representatives of the party follow:

Senator McCarran, an occasional administration opponent, won Democratic renomination by nearly a 3-to-1 margin over two "100 per cent New Deal" rivals, according to virtually complete returns from yesterday's primary election.
Miss Marjory MacLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Gordon MacLeod of Providence and Saunderstown, was introduced to society at a tea dance and reception this afternoon at the Dunes Club.

Three months ago Congress lightheartedly authorized the Roosevelt Administration to embark on a new "pump-priming" program. Today a less pleasant side of this experiment makes its appearance in the headlines. The Treasury announces that it will go into the market to borrow $700,000,000 in "new money," with which to finance a small part of the Government's forthcoming deficit.
President Roosevelt in his Denton speech drew the contrast between the conservative Mr. A's of the world who refuse to take a
The Khan el-Khalili, Cairo's 600-yearold bazaar, which is visited annually by thousands of tourists, soon will be demolished and 'will be replaced by buildings entirely of arabesque style.
Thanks to some homeric hitting by the redoubtable James Emory Foxx, the Red Sox succeeded today where the weather failed.

Twenty children from the New York Children's Opera Company will appear in the ensemble of "Carmen" on the opening night of the San Carlo Opera Company's Fall season at the Center Theatre on Thursday evening, Sept. 15, Fortune Gallo announced yesterday.

Mr. Elmer Benson, Farmer-Labor Governor of Minnesota, who has just brought to Hyde Park news or prophecies, mustn't be confused with Mr. Roosevelt's "composite liberal," Mr. B. Mr. Benson's liberalism is composite enough and he is constantly adding new elements, of which he left a few specimens for Mr. Roosevelt to inspect.

Mrs. T. R. Rudel of Oakland captured the low gross prize in the weekly women's one-day golf tournament conducted by the Long Island Golf Association today at the Hempstead Golf Club. Starting from scratch, Mrs. Rudel recorded an 87.

One of the most ambitious auction sales of lots ever held in the New York district will take place shortly as a result of the action of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors yesterday in giving final authorization for disposal of 20,000 properties, mostly unimproved lots and acreage, taken over by the county in recent years for non-payment of taxes.

Earl Cook beat Tom Baker in a pitchers' battle today, hurling the Syracuse Chiefs to a 3-to-1 victory over the Jersey City Giants. Cook gave up nine hits. Baker weakened in the seventh and eighth, yielding five hits and all three Syracuse scores.
Paramount's version of Kipling's "The Light That Failed". will go before the cameras Jan. 80 with Ray Milland in the male lead and Ida Lupino in a supporting role.

Calling Representative John J. O'Connor "Jim Farley's contact man with Tammany Hall," Allen W. Dulles, Republican organization designee for Representative in the Sixteenth Manhattan District, charged last night that Mr. O'Connor was "firsthand foremost a Tammany man and a vigorous supporter of the New Deal on every measure except the Reorganization Bill."

The marriage of Miss Margaret Virginia Lanigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Andrew Lanigan of Riverdale, this city, to Lieutenant Arthur William Oberbeck, U. S. A., son' of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Oberbeck of Chicago, took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's parents.
