By the wishes of his royal parents, the Count of Covadonga, once heir to the Spanish throne, will be buried here with Catholic rites.
Blackstone, owned by R. C. Mayo of Tarboro, N. C., paced to two easy victories today in the $10,495 Fox Stake for 2-year-olds feature of the day's Grand Circuit program at the Indiana State Fair.
The expected result came today in the second of the semi-final matches in the national open polo championship, with Old Westbury winning from Aurora at 14 goals to 8.
Movements of Vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 7, unless specified: At Poughkeepsre, Sept. 6; Cuyahoga, Potomac.

The Senate last night passed a notion to protest to President Federico Laredo Bru the closing of the newspaper The Prensa by military authorities. Senator Ramon Zaydin introduced the motion, which termed the governrent's action as "contrary to the Constitution and the laws n force."

French and German Armies on opposite sides of the border moved reinforcements and supplies up from the rear today while frontier populations anxiously watched every development in the Czechoslovak crisis.
Stocks advanced and closed moderately higher; turnover, 892,-460 shares. Czechoslovak bonds up sharply, Of United States Government and other bonds irregularly higher; transactions, $4,391,875.

Most classes of traefer meats met with a fair demand at about steady prices in local markets yesterday. Pork loins were barely steady to about $1 lower. Conditions s as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Each of the following Cavalry Reserve Officers, assigned or attached to the 61st Cavalry Division, is ordered to active duty, effective Sept. 3, at Fort Ethan Allen, Vt., for training with the 61st Cavalry Division: 1st Lt. Frederick DeAngelis Jr., 282 Ocean
A. Sidney Knowles has been elected vice president and a director of --the American 'International Corporation. He resigned as vice president of Adams Express to take the new position.
Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued to reflect the influence of day-to-day developments in the central European situation.

Jake Weber, five times Olympic trainer and varsity track coach and trainer at Fordham for twenty-six years, announced yesterday that he has relinquished his duties as track mentor for the Maroon but would remain as trainer.

Although his elevation to the episcopate dates only from 1934, the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, ranks among the widely known members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States.

A banking syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Smith, Barney Co. will offer today, by means of a prospectus, an issue of $30,000,000 of Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company convertible 4 per cent debentures. The debentures, priced at 100 and accrued interest, will be due on Sept. 1, 1948.

In an effort to harmonize the differences in the United Automobile Workers Union, with its future apparently at stake, officers of the international union conferred, here today with representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization on the latter's peace proposals.

While the number of new cases of whooping cough in this city declined from 407 to 327 in the week ended last Saturday, the deaths from the children's disease rose from four to six, it was reported yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, city registrar of records, to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Militant Fundamentalists who last year withdrew from the Presbyterian Church of America, which, in turn, had seceded from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, formally designated their year-old organization today as the Bible PresbyterianChurch.

The Cities Service Oil Company today entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to cease "certain misleading representations in the sale of its products," the commission announced here.

The official Treasury circulars announcing the September financing follow: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. 21/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1950-52, dated and bearing interest from Sept. 15, 1938-due Sept. 15, 1952. Redeemable at the option of the United States at par and accrued interest on and after Sept. 15, 1950. Interest payable March 15 and Sept. 15.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today began its inquiry into the affairs of insurance companies as part of the so-called monopoly investigation ordered by Congress, by sending a preliminary questionnaire to the 406 legal reserve life-insurance companies.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While I agree in all detail with what A. C. N. writes about the lack of imagination of American business, I think there is little mystery about the "inhibitions" which brought about this deplorable state of affairs.

The various city departments have informed the City Planning Commission that they would like to make capital investments of about one billion dollars during the next six calendar years. That is to say, this is the total of the request they have made under the capital budget provisions of the new city charter.

Two almost incredible field goals by Ward Cuff, the first of 43 yards and the second of 42, gave the New York Football Giants a 6-0 victory over the Eastern College All-Stars at the Polo grounds before a gathering of 40,382 last night and thus stretched their winning streak over the collegians to three games.

Meeting yesterday with representatives of the large and small Broadway theatre ticket agencies; the League of New York Theatres agreed to take under advisement certain modifications in the new code of fair practice regulating theatre ticket sales.

Great Britain's national debt was revealed today to have passed the [Pound]8,000,000,000 mark for the first time in history [the pound was quoted yesterday at $4.831/4]. A government White Paper showed that the debt outstanding March 31 was ?8,026,143,422, an increase of ?228,913,878 over a year ago.

Miss I. Malinde Havey, National Director of Public Health, Nursing and Home Hygiene for the American Red Cross, died late this afternoon at the Baker Memorial Hospital at the age of 51, She will be buried with national honors in Arlington Cemetery, Washington, later this week.

Charges that William Bioff, while acting for President George Browne of the International Alliance of Stage and Theatrical Employes, accepted a $100,000 bribe from Joseph M. Schenck, president of the Association of Motion Picture Producers, to balk collective bargaining-for studio employes, were contained in a complaint filed today with the National Labor Relations Board.

Plans for numerous dwelling units in Queens were filed yesterday by architects. The Bellerose Housing Corporation filed for a group of twentynine houses in Bellerose, and the Marvel Development Corporation submitted plans for four houses in Long Island City.

Mrs. William Whittingham Battie and Mrs. Joseph Reynolds Guernsey gave a luncheon today at the Devon Yacht Club. Their guests included Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen, Mrs. Philip Ruxton, Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse, Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley, Mrs. Frederick Hollister,

District Attorney John T. Delaney of Albany County said today that he had turned down an offer of an anonymous letter writer to give Inform%-. tion on the 1935 slaying of Jules Martin, -New York City racketeer, through anonymous replies to questions inserted in. newspaper personal columns.

Racked by political scandals which have caused an upheaval in both major parties, Democrats and Republicans in Connecticut are awaiting their State conventions, scheduled for next week, and the opening of a State campaign in which, as elsewhere throughout the country, the New Deal is bound to emerge as a dominant issue.

With the approval today by President Roosevelt of loan contracts totaling $48,279,000 for thirty more housing projects, including three in New York and two in New Jersey, the Federal Government's slum-clearance and low-rent housing program passed the $200.000.000 mark.

A decision to end its Monday night openings has been reached by John Wanamaker, New York, officials of the store said yesterday. During July and August the store was closed on Monday, until noon, but continued open until 9 P. M.

FOR God's sake, let us sit upon the ground and hear sad stories of the death of kings. James I of Scotland was a bold man, a good ruler, a father, a poet. In the year of Our Lord 1437 he was cornered in a vault in the Black Friars monastery at Perth-in a vault used as a privy, to be precise-and put to death by the sword of his kinsman Sir Robert Stewart.

Theodore W. Frink, former factory superintendent for the Lily of France Corset Company in this city, died Sunday at his home in Oneonta, N. Y., after a week's illness, in his sixty-third year. He was a descendant of Colonial families and belonged to the Sons of the Revolution.

Miss Marjorie O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. William P. O'Connor of this place, was married to James Naughton, son of Mrs. Lawrence C. Naughton of New York and the late Mr. Naughton, this morning in St. Augustine's Church here. The Rev. Thomas J. Deegan performed the ceremony.

The 100,000th patient to be hospitalized under the 3-cents-a-day plan of the Associated Hospital Service, Mrs. George C. Linn of 2,195 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, became the mother of twin baby girls yesterday at Woman's Hospital. The babies were the 29,000th and 29,001st born in the hospital.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Congregation EmanuEl, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street, expressed the following tribute to Cardinal Hayes yesterday: "I wish to join the thousands and thousands of the men and women of the community in general in expressing appreciation of his life and services.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Sept. 2, 1938, upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of speech in day secondary schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

It is impossible wholly to dissociate the rapid decline of wheat this week from our Agricultural Department's export subsidy plan. The Secretary announced on Aug. 26 his purpose of buying surplus wheat for export, the program being tentatively to dispose of be 100,000,000 bushels of such purchases on the foreign grain market.

The personal popularity of David J. Lewis in the five Western Maryland counties which he has represented in Congress intermittently over a period of twenty-seven years has presented to Senator Millard E. Tydings one of his greatest obsta-, cles in overcoming New Deal efforts to drive him from the Senate.

Despite Newark's threatened loss of Fed most or all of the terminal opera- Stri tions of four major air lines, the vote City Commission authorized today derl. issuance of $125,000 ill bonds as the pro] city's contribution to WPA projects pgos at Newark Airport, including coni- Sen pletion of a new hangar.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. McCandless of Bronxville, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor LaMar McCandless, to Archibald Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Stark of Boston.

Miss Helen M. Lambert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Lambert of Elmwood Place, became the bride of William A. Hamilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W'illiamsA. Hamilton of Staunton, Va., in Trinity Episcopal Church here today. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Robert Lee Bull Jr.
Miss Mary Marselis Pratt, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richardson Pratt of Dosoris, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner dance in the oval on the Pratt estate.

German consular officials on the Mexican east coast are now cooperating with Mexican officials by certifying that oil being shipped overseas is the property of Mexico. They have taken over this task as the German barter deals with Mexico are increasing.

This correspondent, who has seen the full protocol of the government's proposals, the text of which the Henleinists received today, is now able to give full and authentic details of their contents. They consist of eleven articles and a preamble.

Miss CarolynElisabeth de Chadinedes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean de Chadinedes of Flushing, L. I., and Kenneth MacLeish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald MacLeish, were married here this afternoon at Cricket Hill Farm, home of the bridegroom's parents.

The children Cardinal Hayes loved so well in life paid their sorrowing respects to him in death yesterday at a solemn pontifical requiem mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where his body lies in state. In the course of the day it was viewed by a total of 75,000 mourners of all religious creeds and from all walks of life.

The heavy increase in unemployment in 1937 and early in 1938 in the United States was "largely due" to a "strike of capital" against the New Deal's undistributed profits tax, Paul J. Morrin, representative of the American Federation of Labor, today told the British Trades Union Congress.

Hesitation over the Czech situation restricted today's business in the stock markets here and, although the tone was firm, various setbacks were registered. Gilt-edge issues recovered after early weakness, while among the foreign loans European bonds were steady. Transatlantic shares attracted support in late dealings and United States Steel improved.

The finals in the city-wide barbershop quartet and hillbilly band contests, annually conducted by the Department of Parks, will be held tonight, on the Mall in Central Park. Mkyor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and former Governor Alfred E. Smith :have been asked to act as judges.

In the First Christian Church here this afternoon, Miss Helene Elizabeth Ham, daughter of Mrs. Grant Taylor Ham of Mount Vernon and the late Mr. Ham, was married to Ferdinand Van Siclen Parr Jr., son of Mr. Parr of New York and the late Mrs. Parr.
Miss Elizabeth Oatman and E. Randolph Dunnell, whose engagement was announced in April, will be married on the afternoon of Sept. 30 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.
Fay L. Faurote, author and public relations counselor, with an office in the Graybar Building, died Monday at his home, 115 Roxbury Road, Garden City, L. I., of a stroke. He was 57 years old.

As its September financing program the Treasury announced today cash offering of $400,000,000 of twelve-tofourteen-year Treasury bonds paying 2 1/2 per cent interest and an additional $300,000,000 of 1 1/8 per cent Treasury notes due June 15, 1943, at par and accrued interest from June 15, 1938.

At a meeting yesteray of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, directors voted to declare an extra dividend of 25 cents a share. They also declared three regular monthly dividends of 25 cents each, payable on Nov. 1, Dec. 1 and Jan. 3 next, to holders of record of Oct. 20, Nov. 19 and Dec. 20, respectively.

One thousand uniformed policemen and detectives from the metropolitan district attended funeral services yesterday for Deputy Inspector Richard F. Oliver, who died of a heart attack on Monday in his home at 684 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn.
Bishop Robert H. Warren of the Free Methodist Church of North America died here last night of leukemia at the age of 62. He was stricken while presiding at a church conference in Michigan.

Sudeten German leaders abruptly broke off negotiations with the Czechoslovak Government yesterday, giving as their reason an incident in the Czech border town of MaehrischOstrau in which a Henleinist Parliament Deputy allegedly was struck by a policeman's riding crop.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, arriving today from Bremen and Channel ports, had as passengers Dr. Isaiah Bowman, Roscoe Pound, Sir Colin Fraser, Ernest Stinnes, Dr. Raoul Arnoldsen, Swedish Consul General in New Ycgrk, and J. J. Kennedy, son of the United States Ambassador to Great Britain.
Defeating Leicester City, 2-1, today, Birmingham registered its first victory in the English Football League campaign. Derby County lost its unbeaten record, going under 3-0 at Huhdersfield.

Konrad Henlein left Nuremberg suddenly and unexpectedly tonight after an interview in the afternoon with Chancellor Adolf Hitler. The Sudeten German leader's destination was unknown, but it is pretty well understood that he has hurried back to Czechoslovakia.
There's a lot more to tuna fishing than just dropping a bait into the chum line, as thirty-two anglers are discovering while fishing in the Atlantic Coast tournament, which closes today.

The Reynolds Metals Company entered into a loan agreement with the Bank of Manhattan and the Society for Savings of Cleveland on Aug. 12, under which the two banks agreed to lend a total of $2,500,000 on or before Sept. 15 and to accept therefore the unsecured notes of the company and its wholly owned subsidiaries, according to a report filed with the SEC, made public at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

With the country's volume of demand deposits as well as total deposits near the peak reached at the end of 1936, turnover of these deposits is at the slowest rate on record, the Federal Reserve Board reported today In its monthly bulletin reviewing recent developments in the banking field.

Mayor Robert S. MacCormack, Mayor of Westfield since August, al 1936, when Mayor Walter B. Barclay died, and Republican candidate for nomination to succeed himself in this month's primary, died this morning in Memorial Hospital at Rahway, after a short illness. His age was 56.

With 121 wholesale warehouses already closed by a lock-out of 3,000 C. I. O unionists, several thousand A. F. of L. retail clerks went on strike today in twenty-seven leading department stores and eight branches.

Magistrates James E. Finegan and Gustav W. M. Weiboldt were sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday for ten-year terms as justices of the Court of Special Sessions. The salary is $12,000 a year.

Synthesis of vitamin E, the vitamin of fecundity, without which, it is generally believed, no animals could reproduce themselves, was announced here today at the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

The premiere of "The Thread of Ariadne," an opera in three acts based on an ancient Greek myth, will be presented at Town Hall under the direction of its composer, Pasquale Rubino, on Saturday evening, Sept. 24, it was announced yesterday.
A local preview of new motor car styles for 1939, before the earliest models had been shown anywhere outside Detroit, took place yesterday as a feature of the Chrysler International Salon.

The league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates dropped the Cincinnati Reds to third place today by their 7-to-1 triumph as the Chicago Cubs moved into second place by their victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cubs trail the Pirates by five games.

The league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates dropped the Cincinnati Reds to third place today by their 7-to-1 triumph as the Chicago Cubs moved into second place by their victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cubs trail the Pirates by five games.

The body of Daniel C. Dodge, who was drowned on Aug. 15 in Georgian Bay while being rushed to a hospital in a speedboat after a dynamite explosion, was found today. A few hours later the body was placed aboard an airplane to be taken to the family home in Detroit.

18th St, 408-14 E; 4-story garage, 100x92; Jacob I. Berman, trustee, against 408 E 18th St Garage, Inc; due $116,591; to plaintiff for $5,000. By RALPH W. LONG 7th St, 49 E; 4-story tenement, 25x93.6; Dry Dock Savings Institution against 49 E 7th St, Inc; due $18,329; to plaintiff for $1,000.
Max Adamsky, former Chicago and New York musician: was injured fatally today when he fell through a glass door in his home. He was 73 years old.

The friendly relations between the United States and Canada were amplified by President Roosevelt's recent speech at Kingston, Ontario, in contrast with United States relations with its "less powerful neighbor on the south," says the newspaper Frankfurter Zeitung today in an editorial called "Good, Neighbors."
Eight barber shop quartets and six hillbilly troupes competed last night in the final sing-off in the Park Department's annual American ballad contest on the Mall in Central Park.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of directors of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., said last night that a published report that negotiations were under way looking toward a merger of Consolidated Edison with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company was "utterly- without foundation."

The military movements in .France: necessitated by the tension. caused by -the Czechoslovak dispute have now come to an end, it is announced. During the past four days the number of- young reservists and technicians needed to complete the, complement of the Maginot Line and covering regiments have rejoined their posts.

Jal alai, the Basque game that has fascinated the Latin-American countries with its speed and skill, made its bow in New York at the Hippodrome last night with all the glamour of a Broadway premiere and appeared to please a crowd of 4,000.
Officials of the Department of Commerce estimated today that the national income for 1938 would run close to $64,000,000,000, if current business improvement trends continued to the end of the year.
The Federal Trade Commission, acting for the first time under a provision of recent legislation which gives the commission limited powers in stopping false advertising,

Meager reports concerning conditions in San Francisco warehouses reached food manufacturers, jobbers and retailers here yesterday. The lack of information was considered a good sign by local executives, who said that if conditions were extremely serious the West Coast offices would have been in touch with them immediately.

An order to show cause why a writ of certiorari should not be issued in the case of George M. Spector, insurance broker, of 785 West End Avenue, recently found guilty of contempt of court, has been issued by Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller, John T. Dooling, Mr. Spector's counsel, told General Sessions Judge William Allen yesterday.

The upturn hog prices continued today, top reaching $9.35 on a 15 to 25 cent higher market, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Fed steers also brought firm prices after selling higher earlier in the week, Wednesday's new high top of $13.35 repeated. Lambs sold mainly from $8.25 $8.50.
While bands played the national anthem, Queen Wilhelmina launched here this afternoon the 20,000-ton motor ship Oranje, belonging to the Netherland Steamship Company.

Over twelve miles of windward and leeward sailing on 'Long Island Sound, which meant Genoa thrashing and parachute skimming, the United States team of four sixmeter sloops representing the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today took the first of four-races that are necessary to win the British-American CuD.

The Foreign Office spokesman said that the German Ambassador, Major Gen. Eugen Ott, reported on the European situation today to Kensuke Horinouchi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs. Some informed sources insisted that Japan had assured Germany of her support in the event of war, but the Foreign Office spokesman

The extremely conservative handto-mouth buying now prevalent and the low state of consumers' steel inventories lead the industry to believe that any Autumn improvement in sales of finished goods will be reflected quickly in the buying of steel. Iron Age says this week.

Charges that the WPA was creating a class of "professional paupers". and that Nels Anderson, di. rector of the labor relations section of the WPA, had given official enunciation of "a new American philosophy" in his defense of Federal work relief,

Carl Peterson has sold the property known as the Hoffman farm, in Oxford Township, near the Town of Oxford, N. J., through Charles C. Ort, broker, to William Ramsey, who will modernize the residence for permanent occupancy.

Several dealers in art objects were among the lessees of business space comprising yesterday's list of commercial rentals. The ground floor, mezzanine and basement in the building at 29-31 West Forty-seventh Street was taken by Meredith Galleries, Inc., in an expansion move.
Electric power production increased last week, although the seasonal trend was unchanged, and the adjusted index rose to 95.7 from 95.2. The figure for the week ended Sept. 4. 1937, was 108.9.

Miss Margaret Nichols, long-hitting 17-year-old linksworhan of the Hudson River Country Club, today won the metropolitan junior girls' championship with a brilliant 87 over the Glen Ridge Country Club course.

Santiago Gutierrez, 20-year-old waiter convicted last June of attempting to obtain $30,000 from Murray Levine by promising the return of his murdered son Peter, was sentenced to an indetermitnate term in Elmira -Reformatory yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan iit General Sessibns.

A request for the opportunity to present statistics and other data covering "the effect of cooperatives in preventing monopoly price fixing" has been made to the joint committee investigating monopoly by the Cooperative League of the U. S. A., it was announced yesterday.
Led by George Munger, new head coach, forty-four University of Pennsylvania football candidates left late this afternoon for Hershey for seventeen days of preliminary training.

Pensioned On their own applications, to take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 8: LIEUTENANT-Edward C. C. Xenodochius, 70th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Aug. 13, 1901. PATROLMAN--Edward S. Finneran, 30th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1905.

W. H. Sommer, president of the Keystone Steel and Wire Company, says in his annual report for the fiscal year-ended on June 30 that shipments of the- company in August about equaled those of August, last year, whereas in July, owing to the vacation shutdown and reductions of prices, shipments were considerably- lower than a year before.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Frederick Frothingham of Tuxedo Park are at the St. Regis. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. H. Conger Pratt have come from Washington and are at the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. J. Dickinson Este, who had been passing the season at their place in Hewlett Bay Park, L. I., have returned to the Carlyle.

Dr. Derrick Norman Lehmer, internationally known mathematician, composer and poet, died here today at the age of 71. Dr. Lehmer, Professor Emeritus of Mathematics of the University of California, was famed for his study of Indian lore, his assembly of Hopi, Navajo and Yosemite tribe music and his operetta "The Necklace of the Sun."

Soviet officials were unwilling to make definite statements today concerning the possible outcome of the interruption of negotiations between the Czechoslovak Government and the Sudeten Nazi party, but there was no indication here of such tension as exists in London, Paris and Berlin, according to radio reports.

Results from use of a new sex drug which is helping some types of people to succeed in their work and cutting down common worries and fatigues were reported to the American Psychological Association today.

" After five years of government experimentation in crop control, look where agriculture is today - no better off than it was five years ago," said Representative James W. Wadsworth of Geneseo in a Grange Day address at the Rochester Exposition today.

Stocks drifted back and forth and closed slightly lower in quiet trading; turnover, 568,920 shares. Italian loans weakened to new lows of the year, Czechoslovak issues reacted, United States Governtment bonds lower, others irregular; transactions, $4,093,000.

Forest Hills yesterday welcomed the finest field to gather for the national tennis championships in years with a setting representing the supreme effort of the management in the completeness of arrangements.

George Montgomery Glazier, general auditor of revenues of the New York Central Railroad, with an office here, until his retirement last March, died on Tuesday night at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla., according to word received here yesterday.

A motion to compel George Groves, investment trust operator, to answer certain questions before a Federal grand jury, granted yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, disclosed an investigation along criminal lines of the affairs of the General Investment Corporation and certain of its officials.

Miss Beatrice McConnell was put in charge today of administration of the child labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Miss Katherine F. Lenroot, chief of the children's division of the Labor Department, announced the appointment.

Dean Roscoe Pound, former head of the Harvard Law School, said on his return yesterday from an extended vacation tour of South America and Europe that the United States was losing out in the race for South American trade and that the Mexican expropriation of American property had established a dangerous precedent that might be followed by other Latin nations.
Seventeen C. I. O. union members were found guilty today of violating an injunction against interference in the operation of the Maytag Washing Machine Company.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index advanced to 75.7 from 75.3. The figure for the week ended Sept. 4, 1937, was 81.8.
Baron Louis Rothschild, it is reported, will appear before the special State court that is to begin operations at the end of the month, after which he will be allowed to leave the country.

Playing under the lights for the last time this year, the Dodgers defeated the eighth-place Phillies, 5-0, last night at Ebbets Field before 11,908 paying patrons, the smallest gathering to attend any of the Brooklyn nocturnal entertainments.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of NIew York reported yesterday that the Cornhill Building and Loan Association, Utica, N. Y., and the Palisade Building and Loan Association, Union City, N. J., had been admitted to membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

A new chemical process which makes the country's vast petroleum resources available for the manufacture of synthetic medicines, perfumes, dyes, plastics, high explosives and a host of other substances was reported here today at the closing sessions of the ninety-sixth meeting of the American Chemical. Society.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson applied yesterday in Supreme Court for an order attaching five savings-bank accounts of Max Harris, also known as Max Aronowitz, who has allegedly received $2,857 in relief since 1933.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., today will reduce tankcar and tank-wagon prices of gasoline throughout most of its territory, which comprises New York and the New England States. Other distributors are expected to make similar Changes.

Punning in four bandages, and with his ailing knees and ankles bothering him not a whit, the 4year-old Gold Flag scored by six lengths yesterday at Aqueduct in 1:16 3-5 for a new track record and a performance that was-only fourfifths of a second behind the world's mark for six and a half furlongs.

Controversial subjects should be taught in the classroom, else a "stultification" will take place on the campus, Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, former dean of Lehigh University, who assumed his duties as the new dean of New York University's Washington Square College this week, declared in an interview yesterday.
Spinning his fourth shut-out of the campaign as he notched his sixteenth victory, the singular Don Vernon Gomez today pointed the Yankees back on the victory trail at Fenway Park.

Sky-gazers in the city were entertained last night by the unusual sight of a varicolored ring around the moon. The phenomenon.was caused by light from the sun striking the moon and being reflected through layers of cirrostratus clouds, according to the Weather Bureau.

The appearance of dozens of witnesses today before the regular August grand jury and unusual activity on the part of the special October grand jury caused predictions that a long series of indictments would be returned tomorrow, naming "higher-up" and lesser figures in the city's gambling set-up.

How insigfiificant incidents are magnified by skillful Nazi propaganda can be revealed today by this correspondent, who investigated on the spot the events of yesterday that not only alarmed European Cabinets but also caused an abrupt suspension of the negotiations between the Czech Government and the Sudeten leaders.

The Hickey-Freeman Company of Rochester, N. Y., men's clothing manufacturer, gave the second of a series of three dinners last night marking a change in its merchandising policy in this city under which the company's products will be sold by three stores instead of one.

The body of Patrick Cardinal Hayes, lying in state at St. Patrick's Cathedral, was visited yesterday by 120,000 grieving men, women and children. Today the city will bid farewell to the man who was its Roman Catholic Archbishop for nineteen years, at a solemn pontifical funeral mass at 10:30 A. M. in the cathedral.
Normran Thomas, Socialist leader, charged here today that the reported decision of the Department of Justice to drop the investigation of the "deportation" of Mr. Thomas
Hugh French, formerly of R. H. Johnson Co., has formed the firm of Hugl\ French Co. to transact a general investment business at 70 Wall Street.
Seventy-four members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy of North America will be present at St. Patrick's Cathedral today for the solemn pontifical funeral mass for Cardinal Hayes.

Lou Smith, Rockingham race-track head, admitted today that thirtytwo members of the Legislature were on the park payroll, but he said they got "only $200 a year salary, or $6 a day," and that they had "to earn their money."

Bank clearings in twenty-two of Czeo the principal cities in the United jor States in the week ended on Wednes- iste, day were $4,158,605,000, compared on 1 to $4,434,738,000 in the correspond- ovei ing week last year, a drop of 6.2 nooi per cent, according to Dun Bradtsreet, Inc.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Aug. 31 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had declined to 122.10 per cent from 122.83 per cent on Aug. 15. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 83.78 per cent, against 86.43.

Lucius S. Hulburd, superintendent of Mid-Hudson and Rip Van Winkle bridges built by the State across the Hudson River at Poughkeepsie and Hudson, respectively, and engineer in charge of construction of the former, died in Vassar Hospital, Poughkeepsie, on Tuesday night. He resided in Poughkeepsie. Mr.

A blue-ribbon jury was chosen yesterday in the Brooklyn Supreme Court before Justice Erskine C. Rogers for retrial of Henry G. Singer, former chief assistant United States attorney of Brooklyn, on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

Traefer meats were in good demand in local markets yesterday, with the exception of veal hindsaddles, which were slow. Lamb and pork loins were higher. Hinds and ribs were steady to strong. Other classes steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Lafayette Ave (10-2768C, 2763, 11-3234),?? cor of Hunts Point Ave. 152x101; also Hampden PI, s w cor of W Fordham Rd. 136x119; Realty Purchasing Corp to Realty Freehold Corp, 515 Madison Ave; mtg $213.600.

Prosperous times and a more wholesome economic future were visioned here today by W. J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, who spoke before 300 members of the Ford Service Merit Club, composed of winning service and parts managers from Ford agencies throughout the eastern part of the country.
With simple rites and few attendants, the body of the Count of Covadonga, former heir to the Spanish throne, was buried today in a crypt in Graceland Memorial Park Cemetery.

Asserting that there could be no compromise with any form of dictatorship, Representative Hamilton Fish, speaking in behalf of Repretentative John J. O'Connor for the Republican nomination, declared last night that Mr. O'Connor had done more to defeat the President's Reorganization Bill as chairman of the House Rules Committee than any other person in Congress.

Representative John J. O'Connor, one of the Democrats on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, dropped his legal fight yesterday to exclude James H. Fay, his New Deal opponent, from the Democratic primary in the Sixteenth Congressional District, Manhattan.

German penetration of Argentina has reached much larger proportions than has been suspected, according to a report in the Berlinier Tageblatt reproduced in the newspaper Prensa here. The Berliner Tageblatt article, based on an annual report by W. Lutge,
The convention of Connecticut Democrats next week will result in a straddle over the New Deal, with the party's State platform approving it but with its aspirants for nominations marked for defeat.

New defense plans for South Africa, involving an expenditure of [pound]6,000,000 in the next three years, were outlined before the House of Assembly yesterday. Defense Minister Oswald Pirow summarized the strategic problems on which the new plans were basted and said that

Chinese troops recaptured the important town of Kwangtsi at nightfall today after Japanese had held the place for twelve hours, according to military reports released through the official Central News Agency tonight.

One year ago Dr. Marvin A. Stevens made the great strategic mistake of writing a book. The title of it was "How to Avoid Football Injuries." That, of course, was akin to thumbing a nose at the football fates, and the New York University squad paid heavily for it during the 1937 campaign.

The American premiere of the Gallic film "Grand Illusion" on Monday night at the Filmarte Theatre in West Fifty-eighth Street will be a benefit for Hamilton House, a branch of the Henry Street Settlement.

An authoritative source said today that Guido Segre, Italy's Consul General in Boston, had been-recalled because he was Jewish. Signor Segre formerly was Director General of Economic Affairs in the Italian Foreign Ministry.
Recalling 24,000 men to work, General Motors plants in Flint will go into high gear next week with the production of new model cars by Buick and Chevrolet.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 1st Lt. David Ehrlich, Vet.-Res., 89 Pulaski St., Brooklyn, N. Y., 18th Medical Regiment, ordered to active duty, Sept. 9, at Madison Barracks, N. Y., for training. Date of rank, Aug. 31, 1936. He will revert to an inactive status on Sept. 22.

R. H. Israel and O. L. Arnold, divisional sales managers of the Nash Motors division of Nash Kelvinator Corporation, have been promoted to assistant general sales managers, it was announced yesterday.

The remnants of the Grand Army of the Republic, "more than one hundred strong," have just ended at Des Moines what may be their last encampment. Long ago these men reached the crest of the mystic hill. They know the aspect of the other side and ever since have been marching down toward the dark river.

A one-cent reduction in the price of the standard loaf of white bread is expected to go into effect throughout the city Monday. The Continental Baking Company announced yesterday that its bread would go on sale then at 10 cents.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that it had protested to the United States Maritime Commission against a proposal of ship lines operating from California ports to reduce rates on shipments of sugar carried to New Orleans.

The current upswing in retail trade will bring a sharp increase in the number of buyers who will arrive in the markets here next week, reports here yesterday indicated. Resident office executives said they have received many notifications from out-of-town stores of the intended arrival of store representatives.

The Canadian Government, which has guaranteed an 80-cent minimum for a 1938 wheat crop, is awaiting with dismay the effect on export wheat prices of Secretary Wallace's plan to subsidize American wheat and flour.

The Medical Society of the State of New York at a meeting at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street, decided yesterday to send delegates to the forthcoming conference of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association without instructing them as to what stand they should take on proposals regarding socialized medicine.

Deviating for the first time from its policy of opposing toll roads in the Westchester County park system, the budget and appropriations committee of the county Board of Supervisors went on record today in favor of borrowing $1,800,000 from the Federal Government for completion of the cross county. parkway and then charging tolls on that parkway to amortize the loan.

A total of 1,130 new stock corporations were formed in New York City during August, it was announced today by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State. Of this number 540 had an aggregate capital of $10,686,965, the remainder issuing common stock without par value.

Five hundred members of the Catholic Club of New York, of Which Cardinal Hayes was honorary president, paid their respects at the bier of the dead prelate in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon at a brief service.

Rafael Martinez Nadal, President of the Puerto Rican Senate, who-has frequently complained of "colonial dictatorship," because of administrative measures or instructions from Washington regarding insular legislation, sailed for New York today en route to Washington, where he plans to see Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior.

More than 200 delegates of nudist groups from the United States and abroad will brave dropping temperatures tomorrow when they meet here for the seventh annual meeting of the AmericanaSunbathing Association.

Committees representing the ship lines operating from Atlantia Coast ports and the International Longshoremen's Association will confer this morning at 80 Broad Street-on a proposed new wage agreement to replace one that expires Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

The Westfield Republican Town Committee tday named Councilman Henry W. Pleister as candidate for the Republican nomination for Mayor of Wegtfield in the place of Mayor Robert S. MacCormick, who died yesterday.

Distraugnt over the groundless fear that she might communicate cancer to her young daughter and son, Mrs. Helen Novinski, 27 years old, killed both children and attempted- suicide in the chauffeur's cottage on the Karl Bissell estate on Westbury Road here this morning.

An unusual example of advertising cooperation among competing stores in New York will be given today, when F. R. Tripler Co., John David and Kolmer-Marcus join in a double-page spread in newspapers to promote HickeyFreeman clothes.

A new approach to the teaching of foreign languages in the New York school sy tem, which will emphasize the civilization and historic background of the country rather than the purely technical aspects of the subject, is to be tried experimentally this Fall, Dr. Theo.dore Huebener, acting director of the Department of Foreign Languages, disclosed yesterday.

Having in mind the importance of calories and vitamins in building strong bodies for the German people, a commission of restaurateurs, with the aid of the representatives of the Reich's Food Control Bureau, has prepared a "dietary primer" which will soon be published.

George H. Pendleton, New York clubman and World War veteran, died at his home in Broadmoor today at the age of 42. He was the great-grandson of Francis Scott Key, author of "The StarSpangled Banner." Funeral services will be held in New York.
The British Guiana police today started a wide search for $1,300 worth of gold sent by messenger, from Mazaruni, in the colony's interior, to Georgetown to be registered at the Mines Department.

British indecision resulted today in a call for a full Cabinet meeting to discuss Britain's role in the Czech-German quarrel. The meeting was fixed for next Monday morning, but the date may be pushed forward to Saturday if the crisis continues to develop as dangerously as tonight.

The Division of Public Contracts disclosed today that protests over proposed minimum wages for the cement industry had been received from Manufacturers in Louisville, Ky.; Birmingham, Ala., and Kenova, W. Va. Identity of the concerns was not, however, made known.

Rayon yarn deliveries in August reached an all-time high daily rate, according to Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau. The Organon index for August, issued yesterday, was-895, compared with 841 for July and a 1938 low of 372 in January. The index for August, 1937, was 693.

The Czechoslovak delegation stated tonight that Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta plans to be here Tuesday, when the Assembly of the League of Nations, which opens its meeting Monday, gets down to business. He expects to remain all week.

Arraigned on six counts of embezzlement rom the Greenwich County Day School, of which she was financial secretary up to a month ago, Mrs. Helen H. Volante, 38, was held in $20,000 bail today by Judge F. J. Whelan in Town Court. The case was put over to Sept. 15.

A petition for $15,000,000 for low-cost housing for slum clearance in Puerto Rico has been acknowledged at Washington by the Federal Housing Administration with the assurance that it will receive favorable consideration, at least in part.

Declaring that automobile horns now in use "cause more trouble and accidents than they avoid," Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had asked automobile manufacturers to install horns of subdued volume on the cars coming out in 1940.
A reduction of 163,000 bales in the indicated cotton 'crop by the Department of Agriculture yesterday failed to influence the course of prices on the contract exchanges.

KINGS CAPORALE, GENNARO (June 8, 1938). Gross assets, $5,427; net, $4,501. To wife, Filomena Caporale. Chief assets, real estate. $5,100; cash, $327. Antonio M. Luongo, attorney, 123 North Portland Ave.

The Greek dictatorship, which in the past has promoted nationalism in a big way, encouraging patriotism and Hellenic race consciousness, now has turned its attention to religion by issuing a number of decrees designed to raise the prestige of the State religion to a level perhaps unknown in Greece's recent history.

Everything is in readiness for the opening of the final event of the national rifle matches, which will be fired tomorrow and Saturday when 125 teams of ten members each will battle for the country's Lop honors. Today the teams went to the ranges for final practices.

The appliance package sales campaign launched this week by the Consolidated Edison Company evoked similar, promotions on the part of two leading retail stores here yesterday, with the result that before the day was over keen competition between the stores had driven their quotations well under the advertised prices.

Declaring the years of school life are usually the period of greatest stress and danger for eyesight, Lewis H. Carris, managing director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, recommended yesterday the beginning of the new school year as a good time for children to have their eyes examined.

The indictment on which James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, is being tried was- vigorously attacked yesterday as "the phoniest I ever saw" by Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel, in a lengthy effort to convince Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora it should be dismissed. Judgment was reserved.

Guy Avery, 33 years old, of Tampa, Fla., who sailed his eighteen-foot sloop Miss Tampa to Bermuda from Miami in forty-two days, is encountering official opposition from the United States and Bermuda to a continuance of his journey to Italy.
Both sides in the Democratic Senatorial primary in Maryland were under attack today, the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures condemning the activities of Mrs. Maude Toulson,
Two days after he had returned, in ill health, from a visit to the South Yangtze war fronts, Lieut. Col. C. Rousselle, French military attache, died here today from acute dysentery.

Factory sales of passenger cars and trucks in August were 91,300 units, the Automobile Manufacturers Association estimated yesterday, indicating a total of 1,547,776 units for the first eight months of the year.

At the annual Fall tournament of the New York Stock Exchange Golf Association held yesterday at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing, Reinert M. Torgerson took low gross honors with a score of 77-4--73.

Retired Fireman John Dreeke, formerly a member of Engine Co. 271, residing at 77-16 64th Lane, Glendale, N. Y., died Sept. 6. Funeral will take place from William Buss Son, Inc., Funeral Home, 67-08 Myrtle Ave., Glendale, Queens, at 2 P. M., Friday, Sept. 9. The deputy chief of the 15th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

After the mother of. the 2-yearold boy she was accused of kidnapping had asked the court not to send her to jail, Vivian Platte, 18, was discharged yesterday in Felony Court by Magistrate Michael Ford.

Mr. Maurice Leahy, well known in this country by his lectures on Catholic and Anglo-Irish literature, will return to Notre Dame University in mid-September. The first number of The Ireland-American Review, founded in Dublin "to promote cultural relations between Ireland and the American people," is here before him.
The interpreters have no great difficulty explaining how President Roosevelt can continue to be popular and go on

For its foresight in acquiring and developing, with the aid of WPA funds, the best site available for a major airport, New York is to be rewarded. The four chief domestic airlines which now make Newark their terminus,

The newspaper Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung today announced the death of Professor Ludwig Borchardt, famous Jewish Egyptologist whose wife was a descendant of one of the, founders of the New York financial firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co. His age was 74.

A hearing, ordered by Governor Lehman, was held yesterday on demands by the private hospitals of this State for $5.50 a day for care to injured workers and on the contention of the workmen's compensation insurance companies that $4.50 a day was adequate.

The city's No. 1 fire buff, Mayor La Guardia, left a special meeting of the Board of Estimate at City Hall yesterday to drive to a spectacular four-alarm fire in the Hill section-of Brooklyn where he saw an unconscious fireman rescued from one of the burning buildings and was unrecognized by a policeman who ordered him to get behind the fire lines.

In a report filed yesterday in Supreme Court, Referee James A, Martin recommended approval of an offer by Motty Eitington, president of the Eitington Schild Co., Inc., to compromise a stockholders' suit by returning $100,000 to the company's treasury.

Mass demonstrations for union with Germany were staged by Sudeten Germans, and in one town policemen were attacked. These outbreaks, which were like the ones that preceded the annexation of Austria, increased the tension in Czechoslovakia.

Dr. Charles Claude Carpenter, a leading technician in the gas industry here, died today at the age of 80. He had invented processes for the elimination of sulphur and naphthalene-from gas and introduced the system by which Londoners pay for the heat value of the gas burned instead of the volume.

Marking a departure from previous football seasons, Manhattan's activities for 1938 will be confined to neighboring stadiums, according to the completed and revised schedule announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics.

North American wheat markets resumed their downward trend today following a steady start. A small flurry of buying developed at one time in sympathy with independent strength in Minneapolis, but when these orders dried up the markets started to react and receded quickly to close around the low points of the day.

The further drop of $13,000,000 in commercial loans reported this week by the local member banks of the Federal Reserve system, coming on top of a drop of $1,000,000 in the item last week, offers a rather sour commentary on the course of recovery so far as bank credit is concerned.

The following changes were announced by the Coast Guard today for the week ended Sept. 7: COMMANDERS Coyle, H., the Mendota, to the Bibb as Commanding Officer. Pine, J., the Bibb, to Headquarters, as member, Permanent Board.

The twelve-man team of th6 United States Senior Golfers Association took a three-point lead over Canada, with Great Britain trailing, in the international triangular team match at the Toronto Golf Club today.

The conviction is growing here that there is little likelihood of Chinese acceptance of the Japanese proposals for the creation of a safety zone in Hankow, the Chinese being motivated in obstructing the scheme by various political and military considerations.

Expressing thire belief that the irndustrial future of New York State will be such as to bring increased demands for electric power services in the years just ahead, Al. fred H. Schoellkopf, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, announced yesterday the purchase of the largest steamdriven turbine-generator acquired by the electric utility industry since 1931.

Miss Mary Ann Wiggins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell B. Wiggins of this place, was married this morning to Albert A. Giannini, son of Edward E. Giannini of this city and the late Mrs. Giannini, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

Eight more members of the American track and field team, which toured Europe this Summer, ar- t rived home yesterday aboard the Italian liner Rex. Twelve others, still in Italy, will return later. Those arriving were Mozel Ellerbee. Fred Wolcott, Bill Watson.

Sales of General Motors cars in August to dealers in the United States and Canada, together with shipments overseas, totaled 55,431 units, compared with 188,010 in August a year ago. Sales in July were 90,030. For the eight months of 1938 sales totaled 759,414, compared with 1,512,061 for the same eight months of 1937.

American Trusteed Funds, Inc., as sponsor, announced yesterday the origination of Lexington Trust Fund plans for accumulating Lexington Trust Fund shares, embodying the feature that sole discretion in the investment of the portfolio funds lies with the Trust Company of North America, as trustee.

President Roosevelt's "purge" of the party conservative and antiNew Deal Democrats will be limited for the present to the few candidates he has already marked for opposition in tle primaries, it was indicated today after a conference between the Chief Executive and Attorney General Cummings.

Eighteen States have received their share of allotments under the Emergency Construction Program, and others, including New York, are approaching the limit of "equitable distribution" of PWA funds, Secretary Ickes said today.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation deferred until tomorrow a decision upon whether to accept or reject bids opened today for 107,000 hides, the final' lot acquired by it when cattle were slaughtered during the drought of 1934.

The Social Security Board disclosed today it is preparing for Congress a detailed report on the feasibility of dozens of proposed changes in the Security Act. President Roosevelt asked last April for a study of methods of liberalizing and extending the old-age benefit system.

The Fordham football squad was sent through its first scrimmage of the year yesterday afternoon at Fordham Field after a morning drill devoted to calisthenics and signals. Coach Jim Crowley lined up a nominal first team, which worked exclusively on offense against a second unit.
Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Berenson entertained with a supper last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, the Cuban Ambassador to the United States.

A further decline in business loans-casting still further doubt upon the validity of the recent upturn in these figures, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by the member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city in their condition statement issued yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Bloom Krup, dealers in gas ranges and refrigerators, who own the building at 206 First Avenue, near East Twelfth Street, have added to their property by purchasing from the Citizens Savings Bank the rear part of the property at 407 East Twelfth Street.

Alton Benton's pitching helped the Tigers to beat Cleveland today, 4-1, snapping the Indians' streak at nine victories. Benton and Earl Whitehill, the Cleveland starter, granted only eight hits each, but Cleveland didn't get more than one in any inning.
Box-office receipts of local motion-picture theatres last week showed increases ranging from 20 per cent to as high as 45 per cent in some cases over the corresponding period for 1937.

The Senators scored a 5-to-2 victory over the Athletics today in a game that was marked by a free-for-all fight. Trouble started in the sixth inning when Buddy Myer, Washington second sacker, slid into Catcher Harold Wagner, knocking him out.

District Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County was threatened with contempt action today for his replies to questions put to him as the first witness called before the House committee investigating charges of graft and corruption against the Earle administration.

Plans for cooperation among American Jewish groups, Italian Jews and the Falasha Jews of Ethiopia, through which it is hoped the settlement of exiled Italian Jews in Ethiopia will be assisted, are being drafted by the American ProFalasha Committee.

Frederick F. Heyden, former real estate supervisor for the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, is now with William A. White Sons. Samson Rosenblatt, Herman Wacht and William Wacht have purchased the two-story business building at 421-3 South Fourth Street, Louisville, Ky., from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Public showing of the film, "Sell More Through Sight!-a film about the American psychology of buying," produced by the du Pont Company of Wilmington, Del., has been forbidden here.

The State Tax Department and District Attorney Dewey have been cooperating in investigating the income-tax returns of policy game operators and politicians connected with lotteries, and some prosecutions for income tax evasion may be expected after the Hines trial, it was learned yesterday.
The Soviet Government rejected today a suggestion made by the Earl of Plymouth in a despairing attempt to salvage the remnants of the British plan for the withdrawal of "volunteers" from Spain.

Continued gains in lettings for engineering construction are shown in the. report for the current week, during which contracts totaling $52,456,000 have been awarded, according to the Engineering NewsRecord. This is a rise of 42 per cent over the figure for last year.

Those acquainted with the internals of Democratic party politics, and even non-professionals who have been attentive readers of the newspapers, will probably find a surprising note in the Hyde Park dispatches relative to a second drafting of Governor Lehman to run for another term.

BRICKS WITHOUT STRAW, by Charles G. Norris. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) A novel of rebellious youth. BUILDING THE BRITISH EMPIRE, by James Truslow Adams. (Scribner's, $3.50.) A history from the Roman period to the end of the eighteenth century.

Boston's hopes of an immediate dash into the National League's turbulent first division ended in complete disaster at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Colonel Bill Terry firmly impressed upon Professor Casey Stengel that he simply did not have enough credentials to crash into that exclusive group.

The Treasury's announcement of this month's quarterly financing gives some idea of what the Government's new spending program will involve. Outside of the short-term discounted bills, put out by the Treasury from time to time, no new securities have been offered to raise cash in more than a year.

James Clements, 20, a Civilian Conservation worker at Beaverkill Campsite, and Mabel Edwards, 18, of Liberty, were, killed this morning when their car plunged from a highway leading into Route 17 north of here and dropped 100 feet to the rails of the New York, Ontario Western Railway.

John F. Kennedy, son of the United States Ambassador to Great Britain, returned from England yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which brought 1,981 passengers from Bremen and Channel ports.

Starting with the premise that the main object of British policy is to prevent at all costs a repetition of 1914--and there is no other explanation of the active role Great Britain is playing in the Central European conflict--the

The city's park system, which has been trebled in the last five years, will require a greatly enlarged personnel if it is to be maintained properly and protected against hoodlumism and violence, civic leaders were told yesterday on their twelfth annual tour of Bronx parks.

Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday included groups of dwellings in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. Eleven two-story dwellings to cost $5,000 each will be erected at 234th Street and Tibbett Avenue, the Bronx, according to plans filed by G. I Prowler, architect.

Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings's "The Yearling" (Scribner's) has gone into its tenth printing, bringing the total number of copies printed to date to 210,639, including the Bookof-the-Month Club distribution.

Organization of the firm of MooreMcCormack Lines, Inc., which will operate the American Scantic Line service to the Baltic Sea and the Mooremack. Lines to South America, was announced yesterday. The company is an outgrowth of the development of shipping operations of Moore McCormack, 5 Broadway.

We have completed our photographic and geological survey work at several important points in the Arctic this year, and reached the farthest north any American has ever gone by ship on the east Greenland coast.

The Countess of Warwick and William L. (Billy) Fiske, American bobsled star, were married today in the Maidenhead Register office. The Countess formerly was the wife of the seventh Earl of Warwick, motion picture actor. They were married in 1933 and divorced last February.

David O. Warner, vice president of the Woolworth Company, has purchased from the Carlton Construction Company, Inc., the builder, a ten-room dwelling on Oxford Road, Wykagyl, New Rochelle, Westchester.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bell Moreland Porter of Erie, Pa., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ross Porter, to Kurt Ernst von Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst von Bauer of University City, Mo.

Dr. Samuel B. Pray, former president of the Medical Board of the New Rochelle Hospital and founder of the pathological laboratory of the institution, died last night in the Glens Falls (N. Y.) Hospital at the age of 65.

MANHATTAN BERBERICH, VALENTIN (Aug. 28). Estate, about $5,000. To Katie Ehlers, cousin, 302 E. 44th St., about $4,000. Henry Fluegelman, executor, 749 West End Ave. BROWN, VERNON C. (Sept. 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Emily Vanderbilt Brinckerhoff Brown, widow, executrix, 375 Park Ave.
Saturday holidays for the sugar futures market will be continued during October, the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday.

Police Commissioner Valentine reminded persons yesterday engaged in the general delivery of goods of two new traffic regulations effective next Thursday in the area bounded by Fifty-ninth and Fourteenth Streets and Third and Ninth Avenues.

Miss Sophie Ginzberg, daughter of Louis Ginzberg, senior professor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, and Mrs. Ginzberg, was married yesterday afternoon at the seminary, 122d Street and Broadway, to Dr. Bernard Sidney Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gould of Dorchester. Mass.

The directors of the Chesapeake Corporation took yesterday the first concrete step toward its dissolution by authorizing establishment of a fund of $2,000,000 to cover claims or other liabilities which might arise from dissolution.

Appointment of a youthful executive committee with "complete merchandising authority and -responsibility" for the New York and New Rochelle stores of Arnold Constable Co., during the celebration of the establishment's 113th anniversary, beginning Sept. 17, was announced last night by Isaac Liberman, president of the company, at a dinner of executives and employes of the store, held in the Hotel Biltmore.
The fourth anniversary of the burning of the Morro Castle, which resulted in the loss of 124 lives, was commemorated here today in a ceremony attended by only a few persons.

Miracles do happen, even in golf, as was proved today when the Americans won five of six singles matches against the British to retain possession of the Curtis Cup, which has never been won by Britain.
Jersey City earned an even break with Syracuse tonight by coming back to win the second game, 5 to 4, in eleven innings after dropping the opener, 4 to 0.
An explanation was given in an issue of the "Red Karelia," reaching Moscow today, of dense clouds of smoke that recently were blown over Finland and Scandinavia from Russia.

Jacob B. Eckfeldt, former chief assayer at the mint, died in his home in Ambler yesterday in his ninetythird year. He became the mint's chief assayer upon the resignation of his father, whom he had assisted for many years.

Reporets of impending changes in Japanese diplomatic posts are roughly correct, although they are still not official. Apparently Toshio Shiratori, who is unacceptable to certain powerful interests in Japan, will be sent to Rome, thus eliminating him from the Japanese scene.

Imprisonment for twelve years and a $2,000 fine were imposed yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert on Nathan (Little Nadie) Kaplan of 400 East Fifty-eighth Street, who was convicted Tuesday night of sales of narcotics and conspiracy.

Morgan Annex at 11 P. M. GEROLSTEIN (Bernstein), Antwerp Sept. 20 (mails close 8 P. M.; sails midnight), from 2d St., Hoboken. Parcel post for Belgium, Belgian Congo and Luxembourg. MORMACTIDE (American Scantic), Gothenburg Sept. 21, Copenhagen Sept. 22, Gdynia Sept. 24 and Helsinki Sept. 28 (mails close 2 P. M.), sails from Exchange Place, Jersey City. Parcel post for Denmark, Finland, Poland and Sweden.

122d St. 232 W. 34x10.11; Metropolitan Life Ins Co to Superior Housing, Inc, 238 W 122d St (S17). Cathedral Parkway, 223-7, 125x100: Jayart Holding Corp to Abe Greenberg, 1,412 Fteley Ave. Bronx ; mtg $182,000 and p m mtg $25,000 ($37). 97th St, 207 E, 24.6x100.11; Frank Zuckerbrot, ref, to Bank of N. Y., 48 Wall St; foreclosure ($2).
Five craft duplicated victorious opening-day performances in their respective classes this afternoon to feature the second day of sailing in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's sixth annual Fall regatta.

Louis Waldman; American Labor party candidate for Kings County Judge, made public a letter yesterday that he had sent to Mayor La Guardia thanking him for his endorsement. Mayor La Guardia's letter was read at a Labor party ratification rally Wednesday night in Brooklyn.
Taxable motor fuel sales for June totaled 153,832,215 gallons, a decrease of 2,450,359 gallons as compared with June, 1937, it was announced today by Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner.
Henry Martyn Brigham, New York and Brooklyn attorney who retired eight years ago, died in his sleep last night in his home here. He was 78 years old.

A tense young man walked into the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank branch at 5 East Forty-second Street just after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon carrying a small black satchel containing enough dynamite to endanger the lives of the scores of persons who were there at the time.
New York City's firefighters demons,tratedc their scillbefore an audience of 12,000 in Madison Square Garden last night at the opening of the Fire Department show,
Representative Dies said in an interview today that Secretary Perkins might face a move to impeach her if she does not enforce the law under which Harry Bridges is "clearly deportable."

While debate in Congress assumes a menacing tone as Rightists and Leftists lay the blame on each other for responsibility for the events that led to the unsuccessful Nazi uprising Monday, the detailed investigation in the hands of Army Fiscal Judge Aravena is continuing behind closed doors with greater secrecy than ever.

The seventy-five-acre parking field, which the WPA is building for the city north of the World's Fair grounds, will be complete by the end of this month, Lester C. Scott, Queens field director for the Federal relief agency, announced yesterday.
In the last eight months imports of petroleum products and cotton from the United States by France increased considerably over last year's figures.
Frank Demaree's powerful bat was the deciding factor today as the Cubs clubbed the Cardinals into submission for the second straight time, 7 to 4.
W. Gordon Crawford, retired lawyer and real estate man and former government official, died yesterday at his home, 15 East Sixtyninth Street, after a long illness. His age was 70.

An informal conference of all persons involved in the charges made by a studio worker that a union official received $100,000 to put 12,000 unionists under employer control was announced today by Dr. Towne R. Nylander, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

Confirmation of reports that Capitol Distributors, Inc., has signed a five-year contract with the Schenley Products Company to act as sole distributor of Schenley domestic liquors in this city was given yesterday by H. D. Rosenberg, general manager of the Capitol company.

Residential properties on Staten Island reported sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company are as follows: Through Einar Johnson, broker, the house at 54 Eldridge Avenue, West New Brighton, to Leon Pratnicki Jr. and at 20 Clark Place to Birgith Tellesses. Waldemar Jensen bought the dwelling at 57 Constant Avenue through Hugh Cutter, broker.

Aknusti and Winston Guest's Jaguars will, meet tomorrow in the first game of the season's last major polo championship, the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament. While Greentree and Old Westbury rest for their national open championship final Sunday, these two start the most important handicap tournament polo has in this country.

Miss Edith H. Hilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hilton of Berlin, Germany, was married yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Beacon to Dr. Abraham Kaplan of this city by the Rev. Dr. Milton Steinberg.
The Newark Bears ran their winning streak to eight games today by defeating the Baltimore Orioles in both games of a double-header, 8--7 and 7--6.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Dr. Samuel Tilden Silverman, retired general practitioner and surgeon. died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 210 East Twelfth Street and was 54 years old.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has among her passengers Dr. Stephen F. Bayne, Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Dean Coulter, E. G. Vietor, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hollesen, Hans von Briesen, Professor Dirk H. van der Stucken, Mr. and Mrs. C. P. Montgomery, Mr. and Mrs. H. Reuck, Mr. and Mrs. W. Gibb and Mr. and Mrs. L. B. Johnson.

There were two recitals held here this afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. G. Huntington Hartford 2d opened their home, Seaverge, for a violin program by Professor Alessandro Niccoli, while at the Newport Historical Society Miss Louise Alice Williams of Atlanta, Ga., gave another of her Southern candlelight recitals.

With Walter Wanger's "Blockade" cooling off as a film controversy, Metro has announced plans for a more' cautious treatment of the Spanish civil war with the purchase of "A Cargo of Innocence," magazine account of the cruise of the British destroyer Tremendous as a refugee ship off the northern coast of Spain. The story was written by Eric Andrew Simson, officer-on the Tremendous, under the pen name Lawrence Kirk.

IT looks as if no Elizabethan flowering of enterprise were impending immediately in the United States if James Truslow Adams* is correct in his analysis of the causes of England's blooming under the Virgin Queen.
BOYS TOWN, from a story by Dore Schary and Eleanore Griffin; screen play by John Meehan and Dore Schary; directed by Norman Taurog; produced by John W. Considine Jr. for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer:

As seen from Nuremberg the Czechoslovak situation bears a less threatening aspect tonight than it did yesterday. Just before noon Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten Germans, returned from Prague, and his mission there is now clear.

Domestic smelters yesterday increased the price of No. 1 scrap copper from 8.50 cents to 8.625 cents a pound. The firmness in prices abroad for refined copper, which was at 10.23 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, or about unchanged from Wednesday, accounted for the advance in the scrap material.

The Western Pacific Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to sell $10,000,006 of trustee certificates of indebtedness to retire a like amount maturing on Dec. 1.

Uncle Robert, promoter of a "Stay-on-Sidewalk" campaign for school children, announced yesterday that he had invited 800 children of the lower East Side to help him celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday at 2:30 P. M. today in the stadium of Seward High School at Hester and Essex Street.

Magistrate August Dreyer, in Homicide Court yesterday, dismissed for lack of evidence a charge of suspicion of homicide against Charles Myslenick, 35 years old, of 441 East Eighty-first Street, a driver for the Department of Sanitation.

A 26-year-old mother of four children who is receiving relief from the Municipal Welfare Department pleaded guilty today before City Judge Thomas N. Fasso to a charge of selling policy numbers at her home. She was fined $50, which a friend paid.
Ebenezer Thorne Jarvis, believed to be the last surviving member of the 13th New Jersey Volunteers, Civil War regiment, died yesterday at his home here. He would have been 95 years old on Sept. 21.
The Grand Army of the Republic elected today as its Commander-inChief Robert M. Rownd, 94, of Ripley, N. Y., who ran away to the Union Army three times before he could make his enlistment stick.

Concerned over reports on the condition of his eldest son, James, President Roosevelt announced tonight that he would leave here at 11 o'clock tomorrow night by train for the Mayo clinic at Rochester, Minn.,

The marriage of Miss Barbara Babcock, daughter of Mrs. Woodward Babcock of the Mill Neck Colony and New York, and the late Mr. Babcock, to Dr. Robert S. Millen, took place today at Ben Trovato, the family home here. Because of the death, early this year, of the bride's father, the ceremony was witnessed only by members of the two families.

Robert V. White was elected president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company at a meeting of the board of managers in Philadelphia yesterday. He succeeds Samuel D. Warriner, who has been president pro tem since the resignation of Joseph H. Nuelle to become president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, effective May 15.

Patrolman Thomas Leary, campaigning against his election as a delegate to the Democratic State Convention, reported today that he "made faces" at seventeen babies and asked twenty-one voters for cigars, adding these tactics to his "Be Wary of Leary Campaign."

The United States Embassy on behalf of Ambassador William C. Bullitt asserted today that the Ambassador did not make the statement that the United States and France were "indefectively united in war as in peace," as attributed to him in Bordeaux dispatches of Sent. 3.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Lloyd Paul Stryker, counsel for James J. Hines, became involved in a bitter debate on the practice of wire-tapping yesterday in the course of arguments over defense motions for dismissal of the indictment against the Tammany leader for conspiring to shield the policy game dominated by Dutch Schultz from the law.

The War Department announced the following changes today, dated Sept. 7: BRIGADIER GENERALS Gardner, F. Q. C., U.S.A., from Fourth Coast Artillery District and from further duty Fort McPherson, Ga., to command Hawaiian Separate Coast Artillery Brigade, sailing from Charleston, S. C., about Dec. 30 for Hawaiian Department.
Pig iron output in August, according to The Iron Age, gained 23.8 per cent over that of July while steel ingot production ran about 28 per cent ahead of the previous October month's total.

The threat of rebellion by the Associated Theatre Ticket Agencies against the new theatre code subsided yesterday when Stanley C. Fowler, attorney for that group, declared that he would advise his clients to sign the pact as "modified."

A few minutes after his bride had plunged today from a fourth-story window of a hotel here, M. E. Lake, 35, an oil executive, appeared on the ledge t and despite the pleas of a taxicab driver below leaped to his death.

The National Assembly at Antioch formally approved today the statutes of the new Republic of the former Sanjak of Alexandretta which recently became an autonomous province of Syria. The more important statutes are:

President Roosevelt has taken no action to comply with the request of the special- House committee investigating un-American activities that he direct heads of various departments of the government to provide investigators,

As both leaders won their games in today's fifth round, there was no change in the relative positions of Sir George Thomas of London, former British champion, and Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, holder of the world title, in the jubilee international tournament of the Plymouth Chess Club.

Appointment of Walter S. Gard as national director of the American Junior Red Cross was announced today by Norman H. Davis, American Red Cross chairman. Mr. Gard, who has been with the Junior Red Cross for almost twenty years and assistant national director since 1930,

Burlap prices here advanced 10 to 15 points in the most active trading in several months yesterday, when cables were received from Calcutta reporting that the Indian Government will immediately institute control of mill operations. Some cables said a forty-five-hour weekly maximum would be decreed immediately, and this would be reduced to forty hours later.

The Penn Newsreel Theatre on West Thirty-fourth Street opposite the Pennsylvania Station will have its formal opening at 9 A. M. to day. The house seats 456 persons and is the only newsreel theatre south of Times Square.

The old alignment of the city against the farm and the skyscraper against the country dwelling, which has cropped up in the past, particularly in political controversies, appears likely to present itself again in the debate over the proposed State constitutional amendment to aid low-cost housing.
Five persons were killed and at least 100 injured today in the wreck of a local train carrying pilgrims from the small Breton village of Josselin, in northwestern France.

Whether the cast of the forthdoming "Hellzapoppin" is to be-under the jurisdiction of the Actors Equity Association or the American Federation of Actors promises to bring those two groups into sharp conflict.' Both are affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.
