The Department of Agriculture today estimated that this year's cotton crop would be 11,825,000 bales, dropping 164,000 bales from the estimate made one month ago. Today's figures were based on a compilation gathered from all cotton-growing areas as of Sept. 1.

Weary of this soft Eastern air, his chest constricted with speeches undelivered, Mayor La Guardia left the city last night for the South and West. He took a train for a change. That was a bit of irony. He is coming back by airplane, a chariot all too slow for this son of swiftness.

A seven-day strike of 2,500 A. F. of L. painters in Brooklyn ended yesterday with the signing of an agreement between District Council 18 of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators and the Associated Painting Employers of Brooklyn.

Campagnoli Co., Inc., which previously dealt in securities over the counter, and Joseph V. Burns, its permanent receiver, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to recover $207,800 from William G. Maguire for assistance alleged to have been given to him last year when he became president of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company.

A new light oxygen mask which is expected to enable fliers to fly easily and economically at altitudes ranging from 20,000 to 35,000 feet was demonstrated yesterday at the opening session of the semiannual meeting of the American Society of Photogrammetry in the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 156th Street.

The foreign exchange market fluctuated nervously yesterday in response to the shifting developments in the Czechoslovak crisis and finished with lower quotations for most of the important currencies. The pound sterling again received official support and kept within a fairly narrow range.
Finnish Premier Aimo K. Cajander in a radio address today disclosed that discussions had been begun between Finland and Sweden regarding revision of the International Treaty of 1921 covering

Mrs. Ruth Millson Perlmutter died yesterday in her home at 436 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, of a streptococcus infection which developed after she gave birth to a son three months ago. She was 29 years old.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 6: REAR ADMIRAL Williams, Y. S., commander Special Service Squadron, to duty as president Board of Inspection and Survey, Navy Department, about Aug. 31.

Colonel William H. Singleton, who organized the first Negro regiment during - the Civil War, which was at first refused by Abraham Lincoln, but finally recruited under Connecticut supervision, died yesterday in Des Moines, Iowa, at the age of 103, according to an announcement here today.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday he was wiling to appoint William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, as a member of the Board of Transportation, and to see that Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig was placed on the bench of a city or State court, after transit unification was accomplished.

Two debutantes were introduced to society tonight at parties which were attended by almost 1,000 persons. Miss Diana Dilworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.Dewees W. Dilworth, was presented at a dinner dance at Gloan House, the Dilworth home in Roslyn, and Miss MaryAldrichwas honored at a large supper dance at Broadhollow, in Brookville.

While most of his 350 communicants cants were vacationing this Summer the Rev. Harold S. Rambo, pastor of Adams Memorial Presbyterian Church at 207 East Thirtieth Street, and about thirty volunteer men workers saved them an estimated $2,400.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

ALL and sundry at Forest Hills, and this includes the tennis players, officials and spectators, should make up their minds as to whether or not they intend to abide by "the Official Code of the International Lawn Tennis Federation, of which the United States Lawn Tennis Association is a member."

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, said today at a press conference following the close of the Latin-American Labor Conference that he favored increased unionism throughout Latin America as a means to increase wages and thus to better living con.ditions.
Representative John J. O'Connor will be removed from the chairmanship of the House Rules Committee "under pressure from the White House" even if re-elected if he is

Editor William Allen White, stopping to inspect the show window of a men's clothing store in Emporia the other day, noticed a suit of clothes marked to sell for $18. He calculated that this suit, plus a good overcoat, could be bought for the week's wage of a printer in the offices of The Emporia Gazette.

Subscription books for the government's cash offering of $700,000,000 of bonds and notes made this morning were closed today by the Treasury after reports received late this afternoon indicated a heavy oversubscription.

The State Advisory Council on corn Unemployment Insurance set up and yesterday a committee of three to study and report to the Legislature on the practicality of a "merit-rating" system that would grant preferential tax rates to employers with stable employment records.
Renewed efforts by Insurgent batteries and tanks to break through government lines in the Caballos Mountains, on the Ebro front, were fruitless today, it was reported here.

Violence broke out today along the picket lines in this city's shopping district, where are located most of the thirty-five department stores against which a general strike was called yesterday by the A. F. of L. Retail Department Store Employes Union.

The engagement of Princess Lucia of Bourbon to marry the Duke of Ancona was officially announced today. Both are members of old noble families. The 30-year-old Princess is the daughter of Duke Ferdinand of Calabria, the head of the Neapolitan branch of the Bourbon family.

New York Stock Exchange firms are growing more discriminating in selecting personnel, according to Charles B. Harding, chairman of the committee on member firms, in a letter addressed to Exchange member houses and their registered employes.

Behind the seven-hit pitching of Johnny Vander Meer, the Reds defeated the Pirates, 5 to 3, tonight to cut Pittsburgh's league lead over the Cubs to four games and the margin over the Reds to four and a half.

The auction sale of the Old Fourth Regiment Armory site at Bergen Avenue, Mercer Street and Tuers Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday by Herman J. Bauridel for the Board of Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County was postponed for want of bidders.

Miss Katherine Besbord Bingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Watson Bingham of this place, and Dr. Allen Ledyard De Camp of Fayetteville, N. C., son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Allen Ford De Camp of Boonton, N. J., were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.

Two new high marks in the nation's provision for relief were made known here today. The cost of public relief for the needy rose during July to $258,748,000, the highest total since the Social Security Board began keeping relWif records, according to figures issued by the board.

The retail price of butter dropped to a three-year low this week-29 cents a pound for the tub variety. Shipments from creameries continue to be heavy. The city has received about 46,000,000 more pounds of butter so far this year than it had for the corresponding period of last year.

A banking group composed of Mitchell, Herrick Co., Braun, Bosworth Co., Paine, Webber Co., the Mercantie-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, the Illinois Company of Chicago and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $1,350,000 of bridge bonds of Lorain County Ohio. It paid 101.08 for the bonds as 2 1/2s. The issue, dated Sept.

Deals in Brooklyn announced yesterday included the sale of seven tenements in Williamsburg to a buyer for rehabilitation. A client of Fred A. Moehlenbrock, broker, bought from the Williamsburg Savings bank the seven sixstory houses at 116-36 Wallabout Street /and 415-17 Flushing Avenue for cash.

All members of the laboring force of the Manhattan Borough Prendent's office will go into departmental uniforms before Nov. 1, under a general order issued yesterday by Walter D. Binger, Commissioner of Borough Works.

Miss Georgette Whelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Smith Whelan of 1,220 Park Avenue, was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle on Columbus Avenue, between Fiftyninth and Sixtieth Streets, to Guy Gerard Rutherfurd, grandson of the late Levi P. Morton, one-time Governor of New York and Vice President of the United States.
The University of California Botanical Garden's second expedition to the Andes, headed by Dr. Harvey Stork and including six professors and studerts, has arrived here from New York.

Mayor La Guardia left Pennsylvania Station at 8:30 last night on the first leg of a three-week trip to Southern and Western cities. He is traveling with Mrs. La Guardia, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fowler and Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., a secretary. The Mavor arrives in ShreveDort.

Five hundred Marijuana plants some of them nine feet tail, were found growing today beside the right of way of the Saw Mill River Parkway Extension, near here, it was announced by Thomas F. Reynolds, director of Public Safety for the Westchester County Park Commission.

Despite the Court of Appeals ruling against the use of city funds to transport physically handicapped children to parochial schools Mayor La Guardia directed the Welfare Department yesterday to use part of a $200,000 appropriation voted for that purpose by the Board of Estimate.
Application to reorganize the Newark Athletic Club under the terms of Section 77B of the Federal Bafikruptcy Act was filed here today in Federal Court by officers of the club.

Miss Emma Mills gave her annual "literary morning" at the Maidstone Club today, speaking before an audience which included Mrs. W. M. Battie, Mrs. Woodin Miner, Mrs. Philip Ruxton, Mrs. Dudley Roberts, Mrs. Samuel Seabury, Miss Ethel Stetson, Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen. Mrs. John F. Erdmann, Mrs. William H. Woodin, Mrs. Lucien Tyng, Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse and Mrs. Robert Schey.

The other day we prophesied that it would take more than a bit of rough water to discourage the members of the eight teams fishing in the Atlantic coast tuna tournament, which was to have ended today.
Today at the Oxford Groups World Assembly for moral rearmament delegates from the "Nordic North" presented their pattern for a new world democracy. Sven Stolpe, Swedish labor author said:
District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey

During the week ended Sept. 7 member bank reserve balances increased $90,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from a decrease of $159,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and increases of $102,000,000 in gold stock

The general level of wholesale prices continued unchanged in the week ended on Sept. 3, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926average as 100, was 77.8, compared with 86.4 onSept. 4, 1937.

Rentals of apartments in houses in the Park Avenue district featured the Fall rush for rooms yesterday. A ten-room unfurnished apartment in the cooperative building at 340 East Seventy-second Street was leased by William J. Tingue, chairman of the board of Tingue Brown Co.; Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc., arranged the lease with Culver, Hollyday Co.. Inc.
Two steel-jacketed bullets fired from a high-powered rifle ended the life yesterday of Hilda, an 8-year-old elephant whose back was broken in a fall last week at the Prospect Park Zoo.

A few hours after a long conversation today between Count Galeazzo Ciano, Foreign Minister,- and Jules Blondel, French Charge d'Affairs, Informazione Diplomatica, official organ of the Foreign Office, in one of its periodical issues giving the Italian viewpoint about. the controversy between Germany and Czechoslovakia, says:

Despite yesterday's strength in Wall Street, continued uncertainty over the Czech situation caused today general dullness in the stock markets here. Gilt-edge issues were weak, while among the foreign bonds European loans were easier. Transatlantic shares attracted- support and United States Steel advanced.

Tom Yawkey, millionaire owner of the Boston Red Sox, tonight dug down deep to purchase the Louisville club of the American Association in a straight cash deal which will elevate Donie Bush, manager of the Minneapolis Millers, to the helm of the Colonels in the role of partowner.
In reporting a net loss of $1,796,169 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, the Pepperell Manufacturing Company today commended the Federal Wages and Hours Law.

Sep Palin drove Her Ladyship, world's champion pacing mare, to a straight-heat victory in the mayor's 2:14 pace today in the grand circuit racing at the Indiana State Fair. Her Ladyship reeled off the first heat in two minutes flat,

FIRST ROUND Upper Bracket Miss Helen H. Jacobs, Berkeley, Calif., defeated Miss Anne C, Harrison, Ruxton, Md., 6-0, 6-0; Miss Marilynn McRae Little Rock, Ark., defeated Miss Argyll Pryor Rice, Hartford, Conn., 6-1, 6-4: Miss Katharine Winthrop, Boston, defeated Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There was an accident on the Lexington Avenue subway recently. Fortunately, there was no great loss of life, but there might have been. One of the main reasons advanced for this accident was the fact that this line, like all transportation systems in the city, is undermanned.

The New York Stock Exchange suspended yesterday from dealings Detroit Edison Company general and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds due in 1952, which have been called for redemption, and ordered the following securities stricken from listing and registration:

Michael Schaap,, president of Bloomingdale's, arrived on the Italian liner Rex yesterday with Mrs. Schaap. They were in Southern France for six weeks, and Mr. Schaap said that business reports received from New York during his vacation Indicated that the store's business had been mounting steadily in the last three-months.

The new government of the Republic of Colombia, which went into office early last month, has taken,its first step toward serious consideration of the Colombian external debt situation by creation of an advisory committee of the government to negotiate with foreign creditors, it is reported here.

Thirty-four women teed off in the Westchester and Fairfield oneday golf tournament over the Innis Arden course today, but none was able to equal women's par of 71. Hampered somewhat by heavy crosswinds the players returned high scores, with the low gross prize going to Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Green Meadow.

The informal phase of the annual music period at Yaddo, P which began a fortnight ago,. came to an end tonight. Tomorrow and Sunday these will be a series of four public performances, and the outsider will be able to evaluate some of the fruits of this year's meeting.

Six craft set out at 7:30 o'clock tonight in the New Rochelle to Cornfield light vessel challenge cup race. The field included the yawl Avanti, owned by Walter N. Rothschild of the Eastern Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., which Is defending the Commodore Eugene C. Myrick Trophy.

The marriage of Miss Althene Laverne Golcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Golcher of Bloomfield, to Bert Everett Carlson, son of Mrs. Madeline Carlson of Montclair, took place tonight in the Clinton Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Sixty candidates, including fifteen lettermen, answered Coach Elton E. (Tad) Wieman's call to football practice on University Field today. The new Princeton mentor started his twenty-two days of preseason workouts with a lecture and drill on offensive tactics.

The Colonial Salt Company has become Akron's first employe-owned major industry, W. F. Ince, president, revealed today. Control of the thirty-seven-year-old $1,000,000 company passed into the hands of a group of old employes on July 1 when they purchased outright the entire common stock of the company, Mr. Ince said.

Clay Bryant recorded his sixteenth victory of the year today as the Cubs defeated the Cardinals for the third time in as many days. The score was 4 to 2. It was the Cubs' sixth straight triumph, and cut the Pirates' lead to 3 1/2 games.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, plaintiff in foreclosure proceedings against the 32 West Seventy-seventh Corporation, bought in the sixteen-story apartment house at 32-42 West Seventy-seventh Street with a bid of $1,140,000 at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday.

Following their dramatic recapture of Kwangtsi, north of the Yangtze River, on Thursday, Chinese troops yesterday pushed onward along the Hwangmei Road and intensified their flank attacks from the north against Hwangmei which have been going on for a week.
Mrs. Marie Sortino of 76 West Eightyfifth Street, New York, was arrested here on a charge of disorderly conduct this afternoon when she "picketed" the Westchester County Children's Court.

A delay in the delivery of three telegrams concerning Bill Werber's three-day suspension today enabled the Athletics' fiery third baseman to play against the Red Sox and beat them, 4-3, with a two-run homer.

Ignace Jan Paderewski is sched- uled to be heard in his first American broadcast on Sept. 25, from Lausanne, Switzerland. He has accepted an invitation to participate in an hour concert over the WJZ network at 2 P. M., Eastern standard time.

Historymaking phrases of Washington, Jefferson and Franklin D. Roosevelt were invoked tonight by Senator Tydings in a militant thrust against efforts of New Deal leaders to "purge" him from the Senate.

Automobile production for 1939 will show an increase of 25 to 30 per cent over 1938. William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Company, said before sailing this morning on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd.
While the State Department continued to follow the Central European crisis with concern today, its advices indicated no special increase of tension in that region.

Renomination of Senators Walter F. George of Georgia and Millard E. Tydings of Maryland in the Democratic primaries next week was indicated in surveys and letters received here by persons high in the party.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 9 unless specified. New Orleans to New York: Babbitt, Roper, Tillman. At San Diego: Simpson, Sept. 7; Craven, Sept. 8: Ranger.
With the approach of the weekend nervous tension in the foreign exchange market over the Czechoslovak crisis was heightened yesterday.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Demand for wool continues to languish, reflecting the quieter tone in the piecegoods markets. Manufacturers are fairly occupied against old contracts, but shipments have been diminishing.

The Distinguished Flying Cross will be awarded Lieut. Comdr. Frank Ashton Leahy, commandant of the United States Coast Guard air base at Salem, tomorrow in recognition of his feat in transferring an injured seamen from Georges Banks by air to the mainland under adverse conditions on May 21, 1937.
A prediction that the country may find the New Deal more "Bedlamite than liberal" was made by former President Hoover as he arrived here today on his way East to make two of three speeches.
Hank Greenberg's forty-seventh home run of the season paced the Tigers to an 11-5 victory over Cleveland today, keeping the Indians in a second-place tie with the Red Sox.

Greater effort at salesmanship of dining-car services was recommended last night by Robert M. Van Sant, editor of the Baltimore Ohio Magazine, at a meeting of the New York chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society, held in the Jersey City terminal of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

Turpentine firm 21 1/2c; sales 74 barrels; receipts 401 barrels: no shipments; stock 50,427 barrels. Rosin steady; sales 596; receipts 3,278; no shipments; stock 243,196. Quote; B, 3.50; D, E, $3.90; F, G, H, I, K, M, $4; N, $4.90; WG, $5; WW, X, $6.10.

Senator Davis of Pennsylvania was endorsed for re-election today by the American Federation of Labor. This action put the two major national labor organizations in different camps as the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, has endorsed Governor Earle, Democrat.
H. N. Ramsey, member of the board of directors of Gas Exhibits, Inc., left last night for Santa Barbara, Calif., where he will address the convention of the Pacific Coast Gas Association.

Miss Ellen Wells Hooper, daughter of Mrs. William T. Hooper of West Hartford, and the late Rev. Mr. Hooper, was married in St. John's Church here this afternoon to Paul Rutherford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford, also of West Hartford. The Very Rev. John M. McGann performed-the ceremony.

A decline of 112,000,000 bushels in the prospective corn crop in August, due to extensive dry weather and grasshoppers in the northern Plains area was reported today by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

The Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures centered its attention on Georgia today and as part of its inquiry asked the National Emeragency Council and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation why Earle Cocke,

Harold L. Turk, who is opposing Louis Waldman, American Labor candidate, for the Republican nomination for Kings County Judge, declared yesterday that the endorsement of Mr. Waldman by Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Man hattan established "a sharp cleavage for the guidance of Republican voters in the Brooklyn Republican primary.

The Hickey-Freeman Company df Rochester, N. Y., manufacturer of men's clothing, gave a dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania last night to more than 200 members of the sales and executive personnel of John David, Inc., which is now selling the Hickey-Freeman line.

The wheat market staged an impressive rally today as the result of uneasiness stirred up by the situation in Europe. At no time were prices below Thursday's close. Aggressive short covering and buying by houses with Eastern connections, and exporters readily absorbed profittaking and hedging sales.

Manhattan Alterations 100th St. 65 E; to 5-story tenement and store: Gabriel Stein, 116 John St, owner; I. Adelsohn, architect: cost. $13.000. 3d Ave 751; to 5-story tenement and store; estate of Jerome J. Wilson, 295 Madison Ave, owner; -F. S. Parker, architect; cost, $4,500. 109th St, 242 E; to 5-story tenement and stores; Anna Paci, 309 E 76th St. owner; Eugene Burk, architect: cost. $S.000.

A Japanese Foreign Office spokesman categorically denied press reports that the German Ambassador, Major Gen. Eugene Ott, had asked Foreign Minister Kazushige Ugaki to extend moral support to Germany on the Sudeten issue.

Formal approval of the appointment of special advisers to the Foreign Ministry has been given, according to a Foreign Office announcement which adds that Naotake Sato and Hachiro Arita, former Foreign Ministers, will be appointed to such posts tomorrow.

140th St (10-2553), n s. 420 feet e of St Anns Ave, 40x95; 603 E 140th St Corp to Celia Pismanow. 620 E 141st St; mtg $23,750. 3d Ave, 3,718 (11-2926); Edward E. Bianco to Harlem Savings Bank. 124 E 125th St. Vyse Ave (11-2998), e s, 230 feet n of 174th St, 75x100; Fenway Management Corp to Franconia Management Corp. 763 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

Students of the Wurlitzer School of Music will give free concerts this Sunday and Sept. 18 on the Mall in Central Park and at Kings Park, Queens, Sebt. 25, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. The concerts will start at 3 P. M.

Operators and investors participated yesterday as the buyers of housing properties in scattered sections of Manhattan. The five-story apartment house for thirteen families at 2,104 Amsterdam Avenue, between 164th and 165th Street, was bought by Irving Bachrach and Ira Rosenstock, operators, from Anna M. Kosinsky.

The sarcastic remark heard everywhere that the situation here is "well out of hand," is very true. Arab terrorists make nightly attacks on police stations in the principal towns, cut telephone and telegraph lines and uprdot steel poles along the main highways despite government curfew orders on all highways.

Dr. Seth B. Nicholson, astronomer of the Mount Wilson Observatory, said today that he had discovered two new moons near Jupiter, bringing that planet's total to eleven. "It seems sure that both the new satellites go around Jupiter in reverse, so my daughter, Jean,
A man identified as Michael M. Hubbert of New York City, general Eastern passenger agent for the Great Northern Railway, was found this morning hanging from a door in his room at a hotel.

CLASS A First Heat-Won by Arthur Wullschleger, Larchmont, N. Y.; Clinton R. Ferguson, Waban, Mass., second; Bud Lowe, Holyoke, Mass., third: Thomas Tyson, Chestnut Hill, Pa., fourth; Paul Birbarie, Branford. Conn., fifth. Frank Desmond, Short Hills. N. J., capsized. Time7:082??. Speed-42.107 m. p. h.

Miss Louise Lillian Fargo, daugh- I ter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Miller Fargo, became the bride of Gleed Thompson of Denver, son of 'Mrs. Cornelia G. Thompson of Santa Fe, N. M., and Roy S. Thompson of Denver, at a ceremony performed this afternoon in the garden of her parents' home here.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Sept. 8: BRIGADIER GENERAL Hartshorn, E. S., Washington, D. C., to retirement, Nov. 30.

Pleading guilty to operating a policy bank in the Bronx, three men were sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term in the penitentiary not to exceed three years by Justices Nathan D. Perlman, Frederick L. Hackenburg and Thomas J. Brady in Bronx Special Sessions.
A hosiery worker was fatally wounded today when workers attempted to prevent the moving of machinery from the plant of the Oscar Nebel Company, Inc., according to Norman Findley. chief of police.

The annual Army Relief Day to be held on Governors Island today to the blare of bugles and the roll of drums is well worthy of support. Not alone because of its military pageantry-the cadence of marching men, the flash of the "Dandy Seventh's"

Scoring an 80 over the Essex Fells Country Club course today, Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament. It was Mrs. Goss's second victory in three weeks.

While four craft continued their supremacy in impressive fashion, the victory march of Egbert Moxham Jr. in his International OneDesign Class boat Maid of Honour was finally halted this afternoon during the third day of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's sixth annual Fall regatta.

Abraham H. Schwartz, president of the Century Circuit, Inc., operators of a chain of motion-picture theatres in Brooklyn, died yesterday in Lake Placid, N. Y., according to word received here last night.

Cattle and hogs held fully steady today, but lambs tended lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Most native and Western grass lambs sold at $8.25 to $8.75. Prime steers were absent but good kinds at $10.50 to $11.50 looked as much as 50 cents higher than a week earlier. Hogs again topped at $9.35.

A client of the Frank M. McCurdy Company, Inc., has sold to James Farrell the two-story dwelling for two families at 848 East Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn. The following business and residential parcels have been sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company:

Mayor La Guardia and the Civil Service Reform Association are studying a plan to replace firemen doing clerical work and acting as chauffeurs in the Fire Department with men from appropriate civil service lists, it was learned yesterday.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell 104,183 shares in August, continuing the downward course that has been apparent since the Spring. The Exchange reported total short interest in 490 stocks on Aug. 31 as 729,480 shares, compared with 833,663 shares of 519 stocks on July 29.

State Senator Robert Hendrickson of Woodbury, a member of the New Jersey department, American Legion, received this afternoon the award of valor from the veterans' group at its twentieth annual convention here.

Fifteen horses, making up the best field of jumpers that has gone to the post anywhere in the country this year, are expected to start in the fifth renewal of the Foxcatcher National Cup Steeplechase over the famous du Pont course at Fair Hill, Md., tomorrow.
It is the season when New York, with other big cities, puts one set of institutions back on the shelf,

Predictions that new engineering developments, increases in car size and extensive alterations in the appearance of 1939 cars might mean an upward trend in prices were upset today by announcement of 1939 Plymouth prices.

With cheers and an enthusiastic "happy birthday to you," 300 boys and girls, amply supplied with tha candy, gum and toys, greeted Uncle Robert, who celebrated his seventyfifth birthday yesterday afternoon at Seward Park by being host to underprivileged children of the lower East Side.
Winners of eleven four-year scholarships to Fordham College, six of which were won by graduates of Regis High School, were announced yesterday by university officials.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson was indicted-today on charges involving "misbehavior in office" as the special October grand jury, busy for a year investigating vice and crime in this city, handed up its ninth presentment and announced that "much that is of great importance remains to be done."
A new collection of stories by P. G. Wodehouse, entitled "The Code of the Woosters," will be published by Doubleday, Doran Oct. 7. In these stories, some of which have been

Department store sales in August were 6 per cent less than in the corresponding month one year ago, and in the first eight months of the year were 10 per cent less than in the corresponding period in 1937, the Federal Reserve Board-reported today.

Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, former Austrian Chancellor, who is still detained in the Hotel Metropole here, is reported to be too ill to appear for trial before the special court that will try violators of the former Austrian Constitution.
High school students re-enacted in pageantry today at Erie Stadium the victory of Commodore Perry over the British in Lake Erie 125 years ago.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for Sept. 27 on applications and declarations by the Kentucky Utilities Company and the Lexington Utilities Company, both of Lexington, Ky., in connection with their consolidation into a corporation to be known as the Kentucky Utilities Company.

The Very Rev. Walter R. Matthews, dean of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, will spend a month in the United States this Fall. He will preach and lecture in this city, Washington and in three universities and two theological seminaries in the East.

Benjamin Locke, who upon his retirement in 1928 had been in the service of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad for fifty-seven years, forty-eight of them as an engineer, died yesterday at Lansing, Mich., according to word received here last night. He was 80 years old.
Mrs. Edith Smith Bacheller, who was active in civic, philanthropic and charitable organizations in Newark, died last night in St. Barnabas Hospital here of pneumonia.

At the solemn pontifical funeral mass for Patrick Cardinal Hayes in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the centuries-old ritual of the Roman Catholic Church for one of its most illustrious dead was performed while the Cardinal's body lay in state on a bier in front of the rail of the high altar.

The North Shore Journal, which has served Flushing and adjacent communities in Queens and Nassau Counties for ninety-seven years, will suspend publication with today's issue, it was announced yesterday by T. Harold Forbes, publisher.
The authorization certificate of Huth Co., 63 Wall Street, New York, to transact business as private bankers in New York City has been revoked, it was announced today by the State Banking Department.
W. Frazer Gibson, retired New York Stock, Exchange broker and son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Gibson, died here yesterday after a long illness at the age of 64.

ANTHONY -- Ella Taylor, widow of Gard'ner Chace Anthony, at her home, 5 Circuit Road New Rochelle, N. Y., Sept. 8, 1938.- Services Geo. T. Davis Memorial, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, 2:30 P. M., Sunday.

With many families anticipating the generally accepted Oct. 1 "moving day" and transferring their belongings to their new homes, considerable activity by transfer concerns unloading and loading vanloads of furniture and household equipment is to be observed throughout the city.

Commander Donald B. MacMilan, Arctic explorer, returned today on--the schooner Bowdoin from his seventeenth expedition into the North and told of having encountered an ice pack 5,000 square miles in area.

The Italian Government announced today that separate elementary schools for Jewish children would be opened this Fall. This assured schooling for all Jewish children, especially those of Jews converted to Catholicism, since Jewish sources had indicated that their schools could accommodate only children reared in the Jewish religion.

Albert Steiger, dean of Springfield merchants who rose from a peddler of cloth at the age of 13 to be the proprietor of a chain of department stores in Western New England, died today in his Summer home in Holyoke. He was 78 years old.

James V. Rank took another important race at the Doncaster meeting today when his 5-year-old Epigram won the Doncaster Cup, a plate race decided over two and a quarter miles. Two day's ago Rank's Scottish Union accounted for the St. Leger.

The United States captured the international triangular team match of the Seniors' Golf Association against Canada and Great Britain at the Toronto Golf Club today. Gaining a lead of 3 points in the six foursomes yesterday, the United States players won most of the twelve singles in the final day's competition.

Newark Airport need not fear competition from any airport on the East Coast. if proper improvements are made, Gill Robb Wilson, New Jersey director of aviation, said today in commenting on the efforts of Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark and Mayor F. H. La Guardia of New York, to maintain the services of the large air transport companies in their respective cities.

L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $473,211 for the fiscal year ended on June 30. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.43 a share on 276,237 common shares. It compared with $1,096,297,

Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Swaine of 1,120 Fifth Avenue, New York, who are at Silver Spring Farm, their country home here, have announced the engagement of Mr. Swaine's daughter, Miss Vivian Swaine, to Marshall M. Holcombe of Washington, D. C.

Miss Sarah Elizabeth Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mulford Martin Jr. of this city, was married to George William Purdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Purdy of Englewood, N. J., tonight in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Edgar L. Cook.

The establishment by President Roosevelt of a "one-man dictatorship" in this country which will ultimately result in a communistic form of government if the New Deal is successful in its "purge" was predicted last night by Democratic Representative John J. O'Connor.

Walt par Disney announced today that "The Sorcerer's Apprentice," previously recorded for him by Leopold Stokowski, will be the first unit of a feature-length musical cartoon, for which Deems Taylor has been engaged to collaborate with Mr. Stokowski.

Ahead from the start, Bob Pearce successfully defended his world professional sculling championship tonight in a three-mile match race against Evans Paddon of Australia on the Canadian National Exhibition waterfront.

Candidacy of Magistrate Anna M. Kross for one of the vacancies on the Supreme Court bench of the State was signalized yesterday with the initial meeting of a group of her friends who have formed an organization committee.

Paintings valued at $26,650, including Rembrandt's "Old Man With a Fur Cap," the police disclosed late last night, have been stolen from the home in Bayside Hills, Queens, of George R. Cobham, art critic and manager for Duveen Brothers, art firm of 720 Fifth Avenue.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Murdock Ward of High Acres, in the Feeks Lane colony here, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Joyce Ward.

Mrs. Frank Stoltz has sold her sixty-five acre estate at Dykemans, near Brewster, in Putnam County, N. Y., to Frederick Hirsch and Jhon Harburger, who constitute the fire of John-Frederics, designers of women's hats.

Alvin Austin Co, advertising, floor in 32-4 E 57th St; Murdock Tailors, Ltd, floor in 6-8 E, 53d St; Herbert Gordon, millinery, store in 518 Madison Ave; Dr. Henry Trattner and Dr George Trattner, in 730 5th Ave; A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker.

William G. Waldron of Stockbridge was bound over to the grand jury today at his own request after two days of hearing on charges that he stole household goods valued at $6,000 from the estate of his wife. Judge Walter B.

The Retail Department Store Employes Union, American Federation of Labor affiliate, withdrew today the Compromise offer it made before its members went on strike Wednesday and renewed its demands on the San Francisco Retailers Council for a closed shop, drastic storewide seniority and a thirty-fivehour week.

Joseph W. Harriman, former president of the defunct Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, submitted schedules in Federal court yesterday to go with his previously filed bankruptcy petition, which showed that he has no assets and that his liabilities aggregate $3,032,438.
The body of Cardinal Hayes was placed in the crypt beneath the high altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral a few minutes after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

118th St, 342 E, 256x100.10: Anna Bartels to Joseph H. Constantine, 340 E 118th St ($1). 12th Ave, 640-60. extends from 47th to 48th St, 200.10x75xirreg; Michael J. Dempsey to Benjamin Gottfried, 25 E 86th St; mtg, $41,000 ($12).

Following is the text of the address this afternoon by Chancelton Adolf Hitler before the National Socialist political leaders: I greet you this year in an especially solemn hour for us National Socialists.
A syndicate of operators represented by Rosen Zalowitz, attorneys, bought the apartment house at 2,095 Mohegan Avenue, southwest corner of East 180th Street, the Bronx.

George Gordon Paton, economist and statistician of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, will discuss "hedging" at' the annual convention of the Associated Coffee Industries of America in French Lick Springs, Ind., on Sept. 19 to 21, it was announced yesterday.

Another indication of increased employment in the railroad field was provided yesterday when J. M. Davis, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, announced that 1,000 men would be returned to work in the shops at Scranton, Pa., and Kingsland, N. J., on Monday.

Michael Balsano, 25 years old, of 2,743 West Fifteenth Street, Brooklyn, accused of killing a man during a quarrel in a barroom, was found guilty last night of manslaughter in the first degree. The verdict was returned by a jury in Kings County Court at 10:30 P. M. Judge William O'Dwyer presided.

Miss Martha Elder Leavitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey B. Leavitt of Asheville, N. C., was married to Edward Homer Nelson of New York and Nelsonville, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here by the pastor, the Rev. John H. Gardner Jr.
While the world studied the ugly possibilities of the European situaction, talk was heard today of a movement to make drastic changes in this country's Neutrality Act.

Mayor La Guardia, bound South and West on a three weeks' trip that will take him to Los Angeles for the American Legion convention,, parried questions concerning 1940 as he was interviewed by Chattanooga reporters -during a train stop late this afternoon.

Amended Order Paragraph 1, Special Order 169, dated Sept. 2, 1938, insofar as it relates to Fireman 1st grade Gustave C. Marousek, H. L. Co. 40, being granted a leave of absence, with pay, for fifteen days. from 12.01 A. M.. Sept. 6, 1938, is amended to read: "For fifteen days, from 12.01 A. M., Sept. 12, 1938."

The Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, an American evangelist to high castes in Illdia for the last thirtyone years and one of the few clergymen of the Methodist Church ever to decline the office after he had been elected a Bishop, will spend this Fall in the United States as one of the chief speakers in a "University Christian Mission." The "mission" will be conducted in fourteen American universities and colleges.

The following is the text of the opinion by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora sustaining the indictment against James J. Hines: The Court Gentlemen, the Court is ready to announce its decision on the motions addressed to it yesterday at the conclusion of the people's case by the counsel for the defendant.

Mrs. Julia G. Jacobson, philanthropist and honorary president of the Temple Beth-El congregation, died this morning in her home here. She was the widow of Julius Jacobson, late Glens Falls merchant and business leader.

When Sven Salen brought his fleet Fagelgrip across the finish line as the victor today in the third team race for the Beverly Yacht Club's International Challenge Cup, Sweden apparently had defeated America, 5 1/4 to 5, to cut the lead of the Yankee skippers for the series to 2 1/4 points with two races to sail.
Second Regional Conference of the Children of the American Revolution, Hotel Shelton, 10:30 A. M. Annual Governors Island Army Relief Benefit, Governors Island, 2:30 P. M.

Tomorrow will mark the opening of the Winter season in many city churches. There will be a resumption of the various activities, including the reopening of Sunday schools and of young people's Sunday evening sessions. Prayers will be offered for a blessing on the new public school year, which begins Monday.

A representative team of England's professional cricketers gained a five-wicket margin over an amateur eleven in the GentlemenPlayers match concluded at Scarborough today. The contest between Sir Pelham Warner's eleven and England Past and Present was drawn.

Completion of a four-year experiment to plow transatlantic cables into the bottom of the ocean to prevent them from being injured by fishing trawlers' hooks was announced yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company.
The Board of Tax Appeals upheld today a 1928 income-tax deficiency of $1,564,884 assessed by the Internal Revenue Bureau against the United Light and Power Company, a holding concern.
Foreign dignitaries and high officials of the city, State and nation paid final honor to Cardinal Hayes yesterday at the solemn pontifical funeral mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Labor was warned that a further reduction in the length of the work week might place "an embargo upon its own profitable employment" at today's session of the annual meeting of the Governmental Research Association being attended here by the representatives of fifty "good government" groups from many parts of the country.
Clipping par by four strokes, Tony Manero of Peabody, Mass., national open champion in 1936, led the field in the initial round of the Glens Falls open golf tournament today.

Spintell, a bay gelding owned Dy W. R. Hayes of Duquoin, Ill., turned in one of the fastest heats of the present Grand Circuit meet today by reeling off a mile in 1:59 3/4 in the 2:17 trot. Spintell won all three brushes without a struggle, finishing almost a quarter of a mile ahead of the next horse in the fastest mile. The purse was $1,000.

Frank E. Gannett, publisher and chairman of the National Committee to uphold Constitutional Government, issued a statement tonight saying that he could not and would not accept the Republican nomination for Governor or United States Senator. His statement added:
Arthur Lincoln Gillett, professor emeritus of the Hartford Theological Seminary, Hartford, Conn., died today at his Summer home here at the age of 79.
Early press reactions to the latest Czechoslovak proposals emphasize the contrast between them and the Sudeten Germans' Karlsbad demands.
The complete 1938 football schedules for 194 college elevens from all sections of the country will be published in the sports section of THE NEW YORK TIMES tomorrow.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Quoting from a recent editorial in THE TIMES concerning the Davis Cup matches between Australia and the United States:

Frank A. Bellucci, Corona lawyer, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of Queens, began action in Jamaica Supreme Court yesterday to have a suspended sentence given in 1935 to Mrs. Etta Reisman, after her conviction for manslaughter, revoked and a prison term imposed.

Patrick Cardinal Hayes was buried yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. His funeral was attended by all the honor and respect that a sorrowing church and people could lavish on a religious leader who was the friend of countless thousands in all walks of life.

A decided increase in air express shipments during the last month was reported by E. A. Hecker, express traffic manager of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., who came here for a meeting of airline express-representatives.

The execution by shooting of a woman spy who had penetrated into a confidential position in one of the Soviet Union's most important military institutes in Moscow was announced today by the Red Army organ, Red Star.

The city of Buffalo will be in the market on Sept. 29 with a new issue of $3,000,000 of various-purpose bonds. The financing will consist of $2,000,000 of refunding bonds, maturing serially in one to twenty years, and $1,000,000 of city contribution relief bonds, due serially in from one to ten years. Both issues will be dated Oct. 15, 1938.

W. S. S. Rodgers, president of the Texas Corporation, has been appointed chairman of the new public relations committee of the American Petroleum Institute, it was announced yesterday by the institute.

In a pink and silver setting Miss Audrey Perot Oakley and Miss Cynthia Stowe Heffron were introduced to society here tonight at a supper dance given by their respective parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lawrence Oakley and Mrs. John Marcher Heffron, at the Oakley residence in Dingletown Road.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goelet are now at Del Monte Lodge, Pebble Beach, Calif. Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kent Legare of Washington and Mrs. Legare's sister, Miss Julia D. Zimmerman, are at the Ritz-Carlton.

After beating a State parole officer on the head with a blackjack, Sam Lachow, 28 years old, of 747 East 181st Street, the Bronx, a paroled ex-convict, made a desperate bid for freedom at 6:50 o'clock last night when he jumped through the window of a southbound Lexington Avenue I. R. T. subway car as it was approaching the Fifty-first Street station.

Prolonged stoppage of the "laying-off" operation in production of leather gloves would seriously interere with seasonal shipments, manufacturers said here yesterday, and they expressed concern over the possibility that the stoppage of this operation at plants in and around Gloversville may disrupt the market.

On May 18 Attorney General Cummings said that the Department of Justice was investigating the Hague regime in Jersey City. Mr. Norman Thomas and others had charged that fundamental civil liberties had been violated there.

WPA-made clothing, with an estimated retail value of $300,000, will help keep 100,000 needy school children in classes this Winter, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson announced yesterday. More than half of the 425,000 articles of boys' and girls' clothing have been distributed and the rest will be given out by Sept. 19, Mr. Hodson said.

Two persons were killed and four were wounded yesterday when Private Luis Borges ran amuck at the Rural Guard post in Nueva Gerona, Isle of Pines. Two privates were shot and killed instantly. Captain Gomez Sicre, a private and two prison guards were wounded.

Mr. and Mrs. James H. Shoemaker of Plandome have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Virginia Shoemaker, to George Pomeroy Bassett 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bassett Jr. of Pittsburgh.
Thousands of mourners, unable to find seats or standing space inside, stood for weary hours outside the weathered gray walls of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in final tribute to Cardinal Hayes.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Augustine Bennett of this city and East Islip, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Bennett, to Edward John Martin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Thomas Martin of Utica, N. Y.
Adolf Hitler gave warning that Germany was "determined to capitulate to no one" in an address to 180,000 National Socialist district leaders at Nuremberg last night.

Jersey City's Giants picked on the cellar-dwelling Orioles tonight, scoring a double shutout victory, 1 to 0 and 4 to 0. Johnny Hubbell, brother of the New York Giants' Carl, bested Ben Cantwell in the opener, allowing the Orioles three hits to chalk up his seventh victory of the season against four defeats.

Though unsigned by three prominent active producers who do not belong to the League of New York Theatres, the new code of fair practice regulating theatre ticket sales will become effective Monday. The three producers are George Abbott, John Golden and Jed Harris.

Miss Maxine Rode, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Maxwell Rode of Brussels, Belgium, and Norman Bishop Bullard, son of Mrs. M. Bishop Bullard of Guilford, Conn., and of Henry Milton Bullard of New Haven, Conn., were married here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The Rev. Dr. Carl S. Smith performed the ceremony.

THE stadium spectators had a view of two of the top ten in an early match at Forest Hills yesterday. Husky Joe Hunt, No. 5 in national ranking, was playing Wayne Sabin, No. 6 in select tennis society. Probably the Forest Hills officials were hoping Sabin would be swept off the court in great haste.
Miss Kathryn Bishop Ward and Sidney Carton Baker Jr. of New York were married here tonight in the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church by the pastor, the Rev. Walter J. Benedict.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today on its own initiative ordered an investigation to determine whether the services of public stockyards in loading and unloading of carload shipments of livestock transported by the railroads in interstate commerce was a transportation service subject to the Interstate Commerce Act.

The Democratic party in Connecticut and Senator Lonergan, candidate for renomination, narrowly escaped becoming involved in the warfare started by President-Roosevelt to "purge" his party of conservatives, according to reports current in quarters close to Representative Herman P. Kopplemann, Senator Lonergan's New Deal rival for the nomination.

Delayed a day and a half by heavy seas kicked up by a northeaster, the third race of the six-race women's national sailing championship series for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Bowl got under way late today after the wind moderated to a twenty-one-mile breeze.

Directors of Cleveland's Academy of Medicine offered a plan today by which employed persons could pay $7 to $9 a year to insure themselves against a maximum of $126 in doctors' bills incurred in the course of hospitalization.

Bonds declined over a broad front yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Almost all groups reflected the downward movement which forced the combined price average for representative domestic bonds to the lowest level since July 11.
A strike call was issued today to 2,500 plain goods broadsilk workers in 300 shops in this city and vicinity. The stoppage will become effective Monday morning at 7 o'clock.

The Philadelphia junior girls' golf team today retained the intercity trophy by vanquishing a squad of seven metropolitan girls, 4 to 3. It was the third consecutive victory for Philadelphia in this event, but the margin was much closer than in the last two years.

Mrs. Sarah Ann Ross, who was 100 years old on May 10, died here yesterday on Barnes Road after an illness of several weeks. She was a native of Bellport and a descendant of settlers who came to Setauket from England in 1620.

The State of North Carolina signed the final papers covering its exhibit at the New York World's Fair of 1939 yesterday. Coleman Roberts, North Carolina Commissioner to the exposition, disclosed that cotton flooring, as a substitute for rugs and carpets, would be included among a number of exhibits showing the new uses to which the white staple is being adapted in North Carolina.

Addition of complete lines of boys' and girls' wear, women's shoes and sportswear, together with the opening of a downstairs store to handle boys', youths' and students' clothing and luggage, was announced by Ludwig Baumann, 500 Eighth Avenue, at a preview yesterday of the new sections on the fourth floor. The new departments.

Spokesmen of the International Longshoremen's Association submitted their demand for a fortyhour week to Atlantic. Coast ship operators yesterday. Owners countered with a demand for a reduction of dock personnel working ships.

Detailed instructions for police supervision of the polls on primary day, Sept. 20, were issued yesterday in a general departmental order by Police Commissioner Valentine. Specifically saying that all members of the force assigned to election duty on that day must "take all proper measures to prevent fraudulent voting," the Commissioner's order contained minute instructions to all police-from ranking officials to patrolmen.
Twenty-two soft coal companies won an agreement from the Bituminous Coal Commission today to withhold publication of producers' individual cost data at least until Thursday.

The United States infantry team is holding first place in the national rifle team match with the firing of the first four stages today, having 1,879 out of a possible 2,000. The United States marines, who have held this trophy since 1930, when .they took it from the infantry, are second, with 1,872.
Few persons in the large congregation realized yesterday that a part of the solemn ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral was being broadcast.
Cotton-mill activity eased last week, countering the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index declined to 117.7 from 122.2. The figure was 132.5 for the week ended Sept. 4, 1937.

Vincent Ciampa, 7 years old of 2,178 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday afternoon when he fell from a third floor fire escape at the rear of an abandoned tenement house at 2,186 Fulton Street near his home.

The 1-cent reduction in the price of the standard loaf of white bread, announced on Thursday by the Continental Baking Company, effective on Monday, will be followed by the Ward Baking Company, it was announced yesterday at the executive offices of that company in the Bronx.

While nervousness mounts in Europe, and it is clear that the hour of decision is approaching, there is fear throughout the world of some "incident" or series of "incidents" which may touch the match to the powder keg of Central Europe.
President Roosevelt departed at midnight on a special train for Rochester, Minn., to visit his eldest son, James, who is to undergo an operation for gastric ulcer on Monday at the Mayo Clinic.

Albert Stewart, New York sculptor, obtained a divorce today from his wife, the former Miss Margaret Fitzgerald of Westport, Conn. The charge was cruelty. Mr. Stewart received the custody of their only child. The couple was married in New York in 1924.

An autopsy conducted yesterday on Hilda, Prospect Park elephant, verified the facts obtained through X-ray pictures taken Thursday shortly before the animal was shot, according to Captain R. CheyneStout, director of city menageries. Broken vertebrae, fractured when the heavy beast fell into a concrete moat, made recovery impossible, he explained.

Money in circulation on Aug. 31 was $6,504,025,211, or $49.95 per capital, which was $52,167,783 more than at the end of July and $19,876,376 less than on Aug. 31, 1937, the Treasury announced today. The following table, showing the classifications of currency and comparisons with earlier periods, was made public by the Treasury:

The railroads moved today to put into effect the 15 per cent cut in wages they ordered in May. They gave notice that the new scale would become effective at one minute after midnight Oct. 1, the earliest possible date permitted under the provisions of the Railway Labor Act.
President Federico Laredo Bru today signed a decree setting up legal procedure for closing any publication that the authorities consider has printed alarming or libelous reports.

Charles S. Lobinger, as trial examiner, submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission a report on the application of the Providence Gas Company for permission to withdraw its common stock from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange.

For the first time since the World War the War Department took steps today to bring private industry into the ordnance phase of national defense when contracts totaling $7,282,455 were awarded to seventeen manufacturing concerns for anti-aircraft and high explosive equipment.

The marriage of Miss Claire Winants Hillyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Winants Hillyer of Greenwich, Conn., to Gerard Thurston Southwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Southwick of Stamford, Conn., took place here last evening at Sherry's.

Confidence in a complete victory in the State election on Monday on the part of the Republicans, -and hope for the election of the Governor and at least one of the three Representatives in Congress on the part of the Democrats, are marking the closing days of the Maine campaign.

J. Donald Budge and Miss Alice Marble made their opening appearances in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday to lead a parade of favorites in which all but one came through to their allotted brackets.

New bond financing this week was featured by the offering of $30,000,000 Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company 4 per cent convertible debentures, which marked the largest industrial loan to reach the market since the $81,000,000 Standard Oil of New Jersey securities were issued early in July.

The stock markets here were gloomy today and dullness in all sections was accentuated as the day progressed. War loans fell sharply among the gilt-edges, and foreign bonds were out of favor, with German issues weak.

Edward W. Drucker, an attorney, with offices at 225 West Thirtyfourth Street, was found dead yesterday morning in a room in the Hotel New Yorker with a bullet wound behind his right ear. Police listed the death as suicide.

Homer D. Boughner, who played for Princeton in the first intercollegiate football game ever held in this country, died last night of pneumonia. He had been active and in good health until two weeks ago. His age was 89.

The Fall tournament for the Autumn Plates, with an entry of ten teams handicapped at sixteen goals, started on Cochran Field today, with Broad Hollow defeating Gulf Stream in the last minute of play, 7 to 6.

Yesterday marked the official end t of the eleven-week Summer vaca- i tion for 40,000 teachers, supervisors and principals, who reported for duty in 1,000 elementary, vocational and high schools throughout the city.

Conclusions, were virtually reached concerning the American reply to the Mexican note of last Saturday on expropriation of United States agrarian lands in Mexico at a conference Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, held today with his chief advisers.

Yankee power slumped to five puny hits at Griffith Stadium today, but the result was the same as ever. The champions gained their second shutout conquest in as many days as they opened their farewell visit of the campaign here before a ladies' day gathering of about 16,000.

President Roosevelt sought today to spike a growing impression in some quarters of this country and abroad that the United States was in some way allied with European democracies in a "stop-Hitler" movement involving a pledge of support in the event of war.

One of the interesting features of California's $30-every-Thursday plan is the provision that the money is to be paid in scrip, every dollar of which will call for a 2-cent stamp each week. Apparently the plan is that every Thursday the California State Government will mail out-to each pensioner $30 in thirty $1 "warrants."

A large proportion of the vast mortgage-insurance business being transacted by the Federal Housing Administration now is involving liens representing more than 80 per cent but not more than 90 per cent of the assessed valuation of the homes involved.

The market for insurance on cargoes against war risks had not shown undue nervousness tonight. Although rates higher than the normal minimum of sixpence per [Pound]100 had been quoted, these were mostly still on a moderate scale.

In a relatively light turnover of shares, member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Aug. 20 represented 22.72 per cent of total volume, compared with 20.06 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Champion Lakeland Yuba, owned and handled by Charles Palmer of East Long Meadow, Mass., today won the annual specialty best-inshow award of the English Setter Association of America. The exhibition was held on the grounds of the Prune's Own Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke.

MANHATTAN BEEKMAN, HENRY R. (Aug. 23). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary E. and Josephine L. Beekman, sisters, executrices, of 38 E. 76th St., residue equally. BEER, EDWIN (Aug. 13). Estate, more than $10,000. To Elsie Beer, widow, executrix, 1,100 Park Ave., household, personal effects and life estate in residue:
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks: Gold coin and bullion.. 70,773 unchanged Reserve in foreign

The pons asinorum, the equine parodox, the definition of electricity, the explanation of the Mona Lisa smile are nothing, absolutely nothing, as compared with the great Norwegian riddle-what to do with Sonja Henie?

Lou Little's famous crying towel had been safely put away in mothballs for the coming season and Lugubrious Lou has become Lighthearted Lou. The clever Columbia maestro is not seeing Rose Bowl bids for his Lions, but he has become optimistic for a change.

Cities are noisy places and our own city is one of the noisiest. Leaving out of account the radio upstairs, downstairs or across the street (our own radio, needless to say, never annoys any one), the principal offender is unquestionably the automobile horn.
Montgomery Ward Co. reported today for August sales totaling $32,848,752, an increase of 10.6 per cent compared with August, 1937.

Government prosecutors announced today that they were investigating the recruiting of Americans for the Spanish war. Brien McMahon, Assistant Attorney General, informed the House committee investigating "un-American" activities that Justice Department agents had been ordered to look into testimony before the committee by two Americans who had served in Spain.

Behind the sparkling six-hit pitching of Atley Donald, the Bears stretched their streak to nine victories by defeating Syracuse, 4 to 1, tonight and widened their league lead to nineteen games. It was Donald's sixteenth triumph of the campaign.

In economic forecasting, the element of greatest difficulty is that of time. Wall Street, which is still trying to date its predictions after a century and a half of failure, has discovered this anew.

Three automobile groups in New York City assailed yesterday a proposal by officials of Westchester County that the county charge a toll of 5 or 10 cents on Cross County Parkway for about twelve years Ame after projected improvements have been made on the road at a cost of $1.800,000.

Mrs. Nellie McClung, a member of the Canadian delegation to the League of Nations, told the Oxford Group's world assembly here today that she felt she had received here "a letter-and it won't be found in my pocket-which I must deliver to Geneva.

Exchanges of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in August aggregated $22,005,158,331. This was a loss of 8.3 per cent from the preceding month and of 11.1 per cent from August, 1937.

Pensioned On their own applications-To take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 15. LIEUTENANT Timothy J. Delaney, 106th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Sept. 22, 1905. To take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 9: SERGEANT James E. J. Scully, 74th Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912.
Belated returns today in the contest for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from California cut the lead of Philip Bancroft, conservative, over Ray Riley to 2,469 votes.

A coroner's jury today absolved Mildred Gaydon, 25-year-old night club girl, of any blame in connection with the automobile accident in which the Count of Covadonga, former heir to the Spanish throne, suffered fatal injuries Tuesday.

Unbeaten El Chico, William Ziegler Jr.'s 2-year-old who has swept all before him, will make his last appearance of the New York season today at Aqueduct when he goes to the post in the Junior Champion, main event on the program and richest test of the meeting.

Miss Margaret Helen Mauger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Napier Mauger, was married at her parents' home here tonight to Roger Edmund Kellogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin M. Kellogg of Short Hills. The Rev. Dr. Rockwell S. Brank of the Central Presbyterian Church, Summit, officiated.

Negotiations will be resumed tomorrow between three Henleinist representatives and Premier Milan Hodza on the subject of the government's latest proposals to the Sudeten Germans, it was stated in government circles tonight.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth JaneForsyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Forbes Forsyth of this place to Richard Donald McCarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. McCarty of Orange, took place here this evening in the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew.

Boys who formed democracies, dictatorships and anarchistic "governments" at the University of Iowa child welfare station developed best under democracy, according to reports of experiments presented to the American Psychological Association today.

Dropping halt a point in his game with Mrs, R. H. S. Stevenson of London, women's champion of the world, in today's sixth round at the Guildhall, Sir George Thomas, former British titleholder, was overtaken by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in the jubilee international tournament of the Plymouth Chess Club.

Claude Passeau limited the Bees to six hits today to pitch the Phillies to a 4-to-2 victory. Lou Fette held a 2-1 lead over the Phils until the sixth inning when singles by Klein, Arnovich and Davis, followed by an error by Cuccinello on Young's grounder, gave the Phils two runs.

By further reducing its estimate of this year's cotton yield from the estimate of preceding months (in contrast with last season, when the monthly estimate was raised progressively throughout the season) the Agricultural Department on Thursday placed the probable American crop at 11,825,000 bales.

In a setting of suspense, a court room crowded with persons who had come with the expectation of seeing Tammany District Leader James J. Hines walk out free, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora upheld yesterday the indictment charging Hines With conspiracy and twelve counts of contriving a lottery.

The output or salable coal in Great Britain during the second quarter of this year totaled 54,000,000 tons, or nearly 9,000,000 less than in the preceding quarter and 6,500,000 less than in the second quarter of 1937, according to figures just issued here by the Board of Trade.
A $30,000,000 program of new projects for the development of the city's waterfront in the next six years was presented to the City Planning Commission yesterday by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie.

Directors of the General Baking Company declared an extra dividend of 10 cents a share on the common stock, plus a dividend of 15 cents. On July 1 and May 2, last, dividends of -10 cents each were disbursed.

Leading Eastern outboard pilots said it with erasers today and entered some new names on the record books as sectional amateur champions in the first half of a two-day regatta on the Schuykill River in Fairmount Park.

The International League Governors' Cup play-offs, involving the four first-division clubs, begin next Tuesday with the start of two semifinal four-out-of-seven series, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The "big city" is no more the place to seek a fortune, Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn, told Edward Crahen, 19 years old, of Connellsville, Pa., a cripple, who was arraigned before him yesterday on a charge of soliciting alms.

Vyse Ave (11-2998), e s, 230 ft n of 174th St, 75x100; Franconia Management Corp to Max Olesker, 98 Riverside Drive; due per bond. 6 per cent: $13,742. Popham Ave. 1,710 (11-2877); Margo Realty Corp to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg to Aug. 1, 1943, at 5 per cent until Aug. 1, 1939, and thereafter at 4 1/2 per cent: $96.600.
Stocks of domestic and foreign refinable crude pekoleum on.Aug. 20 totaled 285,029,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

About 52,000 Puerto Rican farmers today commenced receiving United States Treasury checks, totaling $1,500,000, for compliance with the soil conservation program last year on their farms, ranging from less than an acre to several thousand acres.

In a daylight robbery yesterday within the sight of at least one witness, two men held up a 55-year-old restaurant proprietor, took a briefcase containing $6,000 and, when he attempted to resist them, shot him in the right arm.

In a Cinderella mood the Council of the League of Nations opened its 102d session here today with the possibility..of another war subject to discussion only in its corridors. The Council confined itself to adopting its agenda, on which the war threat over Czechoslovakia does not figure, and to making several appointments.

The Daily Mail in its final edition today says the British Government shortly before last midnight decided to inform Germany "in precise and formal terms" that Britain would not stand aside if Czechoslovakia were the subject of military invasion. A diplomatic note,

Does peace hang on the word of Hitler? Is it possible that in the world of 1938 the decision of one man in one country can condemn to death millions of men who don't want to fight? One New Yorker, his eyes on the moving's headlines, was asking this question of another yesterday as they turned into Fifth Avenue below the Park. It was a sparkling day,

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cowles Booth of 179 East Seventieth Street and Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughters Miss Julia Booth, to Edward Allen Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Fleming Myers of Elizabeth, N. J.

Aroused by the appearance of persons bearing "fraudulent" press cards at a four-alarm fire in Brooklyn on Thursday, Mayor La Guardia, before departing for the West Coast Thursday night, brought the matter to Commissioner Valentine's attention, it was learned yesterday.

The Rodgers and Hart revue that was to have stared Beatrice Lillie was canceled yesterday by Harry Kaufman because, he said, the authors "find it is important to devote their entire time to 'The Boys From Syracuse.'" Mr. Rodgers,
Depletion of retailers' stocks brought out a large volume of reorders 'and an increased emphasis on spot shipment this week, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

French military authorities, prepared for action on a wartime basis, intermittently blocked traffic today on a pontoon bridge across the Rhine into Germany. Soldiers stationed on the bridge moved three pontoons out from a roadway from time to time to maintain strict control of vehicles across the river.
Yields of all field crops in Canada are better this year than in 1937, according to the first estimate of crop production issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
Marking one of the blest retail selling periods this year, retail trade here this week was estimated to be averaging about 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year.

Traeffer meats were in good demand with the exception of veal and calf foresaddles, which were slow in local markets yesterday. Pork loins and regular fresh hams were higher. Other classes were steady to strong. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller signed an order yesterday direacting the Municipal Civil Service Commission to show cause why the examinations for porters should not be canceled because of the limitation placed on the age of applicants and other alleged irregularities.
Mrs. Helen S. Fyfe Gould, the wife of Clifford A. Gould, retired manufacturer of trunk hardware, died on Thursday at Doctors Hospital after a short illness. Mrs.

A fifteen-story loft building in the heart of the fur district passed to new control yesterday when the property at 227-229 West Twentyninth Street was purchased by Albert B. Gross, who, with his brother, Max, is a large investor in realty in the section.
The Bureau of Standards today announced new standards for quality marking of gold articles to become effective Nov. 25 for new production.

Government troops on the Ebro front continued to hold their ground today in the Sierra de Los Caballos, where combined Rebel, German and Italian batteries were engaged in a terrific attempt to dislodge them, according to tonight's advices from the war zone.

Mr. and Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke gave a dinner tonight at Duckhollow House, their home here, for the exhibitors, judges and officers of the Tuxedo Kennel Club. The English Setter Association of America held its annual specialty show today on their estate.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 7: COMMANDERS (DENTAL CORPS) Cohen, D. L., Quantico, Va., to the West Virginia. Tinsley, C. G., Dental Corps, Washington, D. C., to the New Mexico, in November.

THE Middle-Western defendant of fiction is slightly handicapped at the moment by having to compete for public interest with a major metropolitan trial. However, the issue involved in "The Trial of Helen McLeod"* seemed as important in its time and place as that at stake in New York's current court sensation.
The crews of nine commercial ships flying the flags of six nations will compete in the twelfth annual International Lifeboat Race this afternoon off the Bay Ridge shore.

Now that the local tuna tournament is just about over, and the waters of the Mud Hole are quieting down a bit, we can get down to some other kinds of fishing. No one seems to know just when the finish gun will be sounded, but the competition is definitely on the wane.

George H. McCaffrey, director of research of the Merchants Association, yesterday afternoon made a strong defense of proportional representation in a radio address from Station WQXR. He pleaded With the voters of New York City to continue its operation when they go to the polls on election day.

Stocks closed at lowest levels of week with losses of 1 to 3 points in leaders; turnover, 702,990 shares. United States Government bonds eased further and closed at lows of week; other bonds also lower; transactions, $5,268,575.

Before directing Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense counsel, to call his first witness, Justice Pecora informed the jury that he had denied defense motions to dismiss the indictment against James J. Hines and warned them against drawing any inferences from his action. District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey asked that all witnesses be ordered to leave the court room.
Scoring all their points in the first half, the Detroit Lions conquered the Pittsburgh Pirates, 16 to 7, tonight in the opening game of the National Football League season.
Judge William F. Frank of the State Supreme Court died in his chambers this morning of angina pectorls. He was 63 years old and his home was in Kirksville.

The giant French transatlantic flying boat Lieutenant- de Vaisseau Paris completed a return flight from New York today after fighting headwinds and 1oor visibility from Lisbon, Portugal, on the last leg of the trip.

Henry W. Gaines, a New York lawyer who at his retirement was believed to hold the Long Island commutation record, 58 years, died here today at his home, 22 Fairview Street, after an illness of three weeks. He was 81 years old.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 3 totaled 648,039 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

With the European situation an unsettling influence, increased hedging pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday sent prices down to new low levels. All months sold below 8 cents a pound for the first time since the early part of June, ending at the bottom with losses of 11 to 14 points.

The French Government turned anxious attention today to civilian defense measures, now that the fighting forces-army, air force and navy-were prepared for any emergency that might arise from the Czechoslovak-German crisis.

The current war scare in Europe has not yet exercised a serious effect on advertising in those countries, New York agencies with foreign offices reported yesterday. American exporters, however, are beginning to query their agencies as to the advisability of launching heavy Fall campaigns at a time when public interest in Europe is so dominated by one topic.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that 3,576,000 short tons of sugar were delivered to the United States market under import quotas in the JanuaryAugust period, compared with 4,032,157 in the corresponding period last year.

The Cuban pineapple pack for the 1938 season totaled 249,000 cases to record a substantial increase compared with the 167,418 cases packed during the 1937 season, according to unofficial trade estimates reported to the Department of Commerce today by the office of the American commercial attache at Habana.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

MANHATTAN BUFFINTON, ELIOT (Oct. 25, 1935). Gross assets, $34,658; net, a deficit. Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle, attorneys, 63 Wall St. BURT, HENRY R. (Jan. 1, 1937). Gross assets, $258,606; net, $211,904. To Maggie Z. Horn Burt, widow, personal effects and life estate in residue: Henrv R. Burt .Tr.

Frederick W. Shelley, president of the Morris County Savings Bank, bought a tract of land fronting 825 feet on Harter Road, opposite the Spring Brook Country Club, Morristown, N. J. The property adjoins the buyer's residence and was bought from the Enoch Howlett estate through Eugene V. Welsh, broker.

The division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department distributed $12,865,840 in August, bringing the total for the first eight months of this year to $66,689,6 1, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner,
