A resolution urging the establishment of a Staten Island city college was presented at City Hall yesterday afternoon by a delegation of fifty-two high school seniors and college freshmen who live in Richmond.

After waiting impatiently all day, Charles J. Margiotti, former Attorney General, who made most of the graft and corruption charges forming the basis for an investigation of the Earle administration, took the witness stand this afternoon before the special House investigating committee.

With more than seventy cities already sponsoring community programs as part of the National Retail Demonstration to be held during the week of Sept. 19, the total is expected to reach more than 100 by the time the demonstration begins, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which is sponsoring the demonstration.

Miss Patricia Carrington Shewan, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Shewan of New York and California, was introduced to society here this afternoon at a reception and tea dance given by her brother, James Shewan Jr., at Strathmore, their Summer home.

A petition asking the government to exempt Americans from payment of tile foreigners' registration fee and for repeal of the 50-cent tax collected from all tourists who visit the island was presented to President Federico Laredo Bru today by the Acera del Louvre Committee.
Judge John R. Hazel, who administered the oath of President to Theodore Roosevelt, will be the guest of honor Wednesday when a plaque is unveiled in the room where the ceremony took place.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES appeared a letter from Herbert J. Hollander stating how much he and his family enjoyed their stay in New York. However, he went on to complain that the average New Yorker is not"acquainted with the streets and places."

Miss Kitty Wickes, a great-granddaughter of the late Joseph Woodward Haven and a member of the Forsyth family of New York, was married here this afternoon to Ralph Hutchinson Poole Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill.

Carlos W. Munson sold a wooded plot of more than an acre on the west side of Elderfields Road, in Flower Hill, Manhasset, Nassau County, to Johnson Olson, builders, who then resold the parcel to a client for whom they will build a colonial dwelling.

The United States six-meter yacht team made it two straight this afternoon over the sailors from across the sea competing for the BritishAmerican Cup. The final score was 23 1/4 points to 13, the Seawanhaka Corinthian sailors occupying the first three places and the next to last one-with none other than Goose.
Aviation Cadet William F. Reuther, U.S.M.C., was killed when his plane crashed and burned near Criglersville.

The Southern Combed Yarn Spinners Association is working to obtain proper permanent identification of cotton bales in cooperation with the Delta Cotton Council, according to announcement by Mildred Barnwell, secretary, following a meeting in Gastonia, N. C., at which spinners representing 1,400,000 spindles voted ratification of the 1938 cotton yarn rules and elected officers.
Parents were urged today by Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, to teach their children "common-sense rules of safety" in an effort to reduce New York's school-child death rate.

Three up-State points reported record cold weather today. In Albany, a twenty-four-year record was lowered by nine degrees when the Weather Bureau reported a reading of 36 at the city's airport at 5 A. M.

Bill Terry's supply of oxygen, which he has been pumping into his Giants in a desperate attempt to keep their slender pennant hopes ??ive, gave out simultaneously with the arrival of the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and the result was a spectacle to bring sadness to the major portion of a ladies' day crowd of 12,000.
By VINCENT J. DEO Colden Ave, e s, 150 ft n of Morris Park Ave, 50x10O; Woodside National Bank against L. M. Building Corp; due, $13,475; taxes, etc.. $395: to Max A. Gulack for $14,425.
A Westchester County sales tax and a one-cent levy on packaged cigarettes would be illegal under present State laws, County Attorney William A. Davidson reported today to the Board of Supervisors.

Miss Jane Margaret Hart, daughter of Mrs. Ray Henry Hart of this city, became the bride tonight of William du Pont Staab, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Staab of Glen Ridge, in the Forest Hill Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Paul R. Hickok officiated.

The largest freshmen class in the history of Rutgers University is expected to gather here tomorrow preparatory to the opening of the orientation period Monday morning. More than 600 applicants have announced their intention of registering, as against 539 in the entering class last year, the high record for the university.

THIS year marks the centenary of Sir Joseph Barnby, the talented melody maker who was privileged to compose the music of a well-nigh universal lullaby. To its strains millions of Anglo-Saxon children have been lulled to sleep, and its career is not ended yet. This cradle song was entitled "Sweet and Low."

A PUZZLE IN POISON. By Anthony Berkeley. 277 pp. New York: Published for the Crime Club, Inc., by Doubleday, Doran Co. $2. THE puzzle in poison-John Waterhouse's death by arsenic-never was solved by the pursuit of tangible clues alone. The most important thread through the labyrinth was knowledge of character.

While the clouds that still hover over Central Europe appear to be darkening hourly there is no change in the Soviet policy of discreet silence. Indeed, by all outward signs Moscow, which may be involved if war develops from the Czechoslovak crisis, is one of the calmest capitals in Europe and shows less concern than Washington.

British delegation quarters here tonight showed sharp annoyance with Russia and with Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff. They charge-not officially, of course, but in the corridors-that Russia is pushing toward war.

THIS is fair time not only in the New England States but in States of the South and West. Year by year State fairs, with their hundreds of exhibits, have become more imposing, while small local or county fairs continue to increase in number and importance. This year in Vermont,

New leadership, new headquarters and a more sharply pointed program are already operative in the New York League of Business and Professional Women. Mrs. Sara Sparks, successor to Mrs. Katherine Bleecker Meigs in the presidency, has retained and accelerated Mrs.

When the Fall term gets underway tomorrow, New York City will witness the opening of a new type of vocational school, devoted exclusively to the training of potential butchers, bakers, cafeteria workers, store clerks and tea room hostesses.

For the first time in four years more money was borrowed during the month of July from savings, building and loan associations for the construction of new homes than for any other purpose, the United States Building and Loan League reported yesterday.

THERE was a time when correspondence was carried on by means of wax tablets in wooden frames. After reading the message the recipient would smooth out the original inscription and enter his reply on the same surface.

Following are extracts from the more notable passages in the speech of Field Marshal Hermann Goering before members of the German Labor Front today, no official text of the address being available tonight: I had to issue certain necessary decrees that I have not found easy to issue.

Sixteen contemporary composers were represented by new works at performances this afternoon and tonight at Yaddo. These concerts were the first two of four that climax this year's music period today and tomorrow.

The extent to which the mortgage insurance business of the Federal Housing Administration has grown in this section of the country is vividly shown in a report issued yesterday on that agency's activities during the first eight months of this year in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Louis Cohen of 1,350 East Thirtyeighth Street, Brooklyn, who has been chief clerk of Special Term, Part I, of the Brooklyn Supreme Court for the last twenty-one years, has applied for retirement effective on Oct. 1. He was 70 years old yesterday.

The war-scared flight of capital from Europe to the United States rushed on yesterday, driving the pound sterling and other foreign exchanges down to cheaper levels than registered in years and carrying with it fresh shipments of gold from England to this country.
Constantine A. Oumansky, charge d'affaires of the Soviet Union here, today made public the following official statement in behalf of the embassy:

AS the World's Fair draws nearer much of America Is discovering that across the dark waters of the East River from Manhattan lies the borough of Queens. To Queens the fair is the signal for a belated coming-out party. Not that Queens has been ignored these 255 years since the Colonial Assembly divided Long Island into the counties of Kings, Queens and Suffolk.

Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace gave a supper dance tonight at the Crossroads, their Summer home here, to introduce to society their youngest daughter, Miss Patricia Grace. The guests included the young women who have made their bows this season and in June and some who are to be presented later in town, and the young men about to go to college and their house guests.

Similar style themes appear to run through all types of men's clothing for the Fall season and topcoats have not escaped the prevalent covert and herringbone influence. The covert topcoat-very dissimilar in cut, however, from its predecessor of four decades ago-is expected to be a leading seller in the coming months. It is a trim, tailored model, excellent for town wear.

Kensington House, the new fourteen-story welded steel apartment building at 200 West Twentieth Street has been completed and was opened last week. It was erected by H. A. Hyman, Inc., from plans by Emery Roth, architect.

Generally speaking, sports prognostigators have had little luck in predetermining the winner of a golf championship. It is hazardous business at best, and the approaching tournament at the Westmoreland Country Club, Wilmette, Ill., is a case in point.

LIPSTICK and powder. rouge and eye shadow, creams and lotions, perfumes-these and other intimate paraphernalia of any woman's dressing table are to be enshrined in a dazzling, dignified and impressive building of their own at the New York World's Fair next year.

A prediction that a national architecture, marking a new epoch in the history of art, would arrive with revival in building was made yesterday by Dean Leopold Arnaud of the Columbia University School of Architecture, in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

A NEW camera for aerial photography which carries enough film for 600 exposures, was recently announced. Developed and built in the laboratories of the Abrams Aerial Survey Corporation of Lansing, Mich., it weighs only sixty-five pounds when fully loaded.

The lawn of the home here of Mrs. Frank A. Hotchkiss was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of her granddaughter, Miss Julia Dyckman Andrus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hamlin Foster Andrus of Yonkers, to Frederick Franklin Moon Jr.

UNLIKE most of our recording orchestras, the New York Philharmonic - Symphony works in bursts. After a long silence, the Toscanini series came in a bunch, after which two seasons were allowed to elapse.

The writer just returned from a visit to field hospitals near the Ebro front in company with Dr. Sheehan, New York plastic surgeon, who has received the honorary rank of major in the Medical Corps for his voluntary service in Insurgent military hospitals during lass year.

THE U.S.S.R. has made available advance illustrations of twelve stamps being issued to publicize sanitariums and hospitals for Soviet workers in the Black Sea area, which is sometimes called the "California of Russia" land is noted for its climate, white beeches and historic castles.

The Republican National Committee reported today an income of $788,185 and expenditures of $794,459 in the first eight months of this year. A report to the clerk of the House for the period, ending with August showed that scores of individuals had contributed from $1 to $5,000 to the national Republican chest.

Voters of Union Free School District 1, which includes the Villages of Mamaroneck and Larchmont and the unincorporated part of the town of Mamaroneck, tonight defeated a proposal to spend $270,000 for additions and alterations to the Central School on the Boston Post Road. The vote was 945 to 503.

Men's Fall underwear is snappy in more ways than one, the new snap fastener being the chief feature of the woven shorts, replacing buttons in many styles. This type of closure is comparatively new but has already received wide acceptance among the male population, so frequently discouraged by the absence of needed buttons on shorts.

A. Rhett du Pont, member of the New York Stock Exchange, now living in Greenwich, Conn., has purchased the historic old Palmer farm, with thirteen acres, on North Greenwich Road, in Yale Farms, at Greenwich and North Castle. Edson Edson acted as brokers.

Three lines of fortifications are under construction now on the German side of the Rhine and the country is being organized for defense over an area 100 kilometers [62.1 miles] wide, declares an article published in the newspaper Paris-Soir tonight under the signature of Henri Danjou. M. Danjou writes from Prague describing what he saw flying over the Rhineland zone from Paris.
The engagement of Miss Ruth Corwin Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Wood of this place, to Philipse Iselin has been announced by her parents.

LONDON.--There is no utility war in Britain. There never has been, even under a Socialist Government, any generalattack on electric utilities by the government which, broadly speaking, has held the scales fairly between public and private ownership.

Miss Anne Exton Stone, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Stone of Coatesville, was married this afternoon to William Joseph Scarlett, son of State Senator and Mrs. George B. Scarlett of Kennett Square. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Stewart Paynter in the Episcopal Church of the Trinity at Coatesville.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Francis Beatty gave a reception this afternoon at their home here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Corning, Beatty, to John Davenport Swan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Swan of Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn.
" He stole our thunder!" was the general outcry of the Hungarian Nazis following Premier Bela Imredy's speech at Kaposvar announcing drastic land reform.

Head Coach Tad Wieman plans to mix music with scrimmages in Princeton's pre-season football training. With nearly 100 hours of intensive drills facing the sixty squad members before college opens, Wieman decided to add a little fun to the day's routine.
JAPAN, which during the early days of July was heard on sixteen meters at 7 o'clock, has shifted its American evening program to the more favorable reception hour of 9 o'clock, daylight time.

More than 75 per cent of the suites in the eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building, opened on Sept. 1 by Kensington Estates, Inc., A. Simon, president, have been rented. The house is on the former site of the Jacob H. Schiff mansion on Fifth Avenue, near Seventy-eighth Street. The structure,...

NEW YORK CITY gathers its vegetables from far and near the year around, bringing onions from Egypt and the Argentine, tomatoes from Canada and Cuba, peas from Mexico; but September harvests nearer home fill the markets with fresh and appetizing reminders of vegetable cookery in general and of the vegetable plate in particular.
Enrique Rodriguez, Mexican bandit who until yesterday was the bogeyman of four States, was free and reformed today.

President Roosevelt may call State officials to a conference on the question of dividing up the sources of taxation and reducing overlapping levies by other means, it was said in Treasury circles today. The conference was discussed as a possibility, not a certainty.

One of the most important steps in restoring normal conditions to the real estate and mortgage market was taken yesterday when the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York announced plans for pouring millions of dollars into a program to liquidate closed guarantee companies.

A Hollywood studio took official notice today of Europe's warlike temper. Warner Brothers, filming "Dawn Patrol," a story of the Royal Flying Corps in World War days, ordered the picture rushed to completion.

SAN REMO. REPORTS from Milan confirm, from other angles, the favorable auditory impressions made by the broadcasts of this Summer's opera season in the great open-air auditorium at the Castello Sforzesco.
LONDON.-After years of unsuccessful effort the British have at last struck oil in Scotland, and the first well is yielding all of ten barrels a day.

WITH this fascinating book there is but one thing wrong, and that is the title. The Napoleonic era with its Homeric conflicts on land and sea is inadequately described as a period of "danger" to Great Britain. All the world was included in the pomp and circumstance of that stupendous drama.

BUILDING THE BRITISH EMPIRE. To the End of the First Empire. By James Truslow Adams. 438 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $3.50. By WILLIAM MIacDONALD HVAVING surveyed, in a number of widely read books, American history in general and in particular, Mr. Adams has now turned his attention to the British Empire.

SKINNY. By James D. Adams, Illustrated by Richard Rodgers. 187 pp. New York: Harcourt, Brace Co. $2. BOYS in those restless enterprising years just before the 'teens who find families so difficult to cope with and sometimes wonder if parents were ever human will find the answer definitely stated in this book.

The six-story business building being erected. at 8 and 10 East Fifty - seventh Street, running through to 11 East Fifty-sixth Street, will be occupied by Jaeckel, Inc., furriers, it was learned yesterday.

Stephen Douglas Glines, a member of the investment banking firm of Glines Co., 120 Broadway, died Friday at his Summer home in Springfield, Vt., at the age of 76. He was born in Baltimore in 1861, a son of E. Kimble and Sarah Barton Glines and a descendant of Winaud de Glines, a Flemish nobleman who settled in New Hampshire in 1652, and of Colonial Governors Winthrop and Dudley.

Miss Lucille Barbara Herb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Herb of this city, was married today to Charles B. H. Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Parker, also of Mount Vernon, at the home of the bride's parents here.
Miss Mabel Mercer, daughter of Frederick William Mercer of Summit, was married to Howell North White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. White of Lakeville, Conn., here this afternoon in All Saints' Church.

Australia's most ambitious broadcast, over 111 stations and involving 26,000 miles of telephone lines, was made last night when Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons appealed for a national day of prayer tomorrow in the cause of world peace.

With 150 freshmen beginning classes on Monday, and 350 upper classmen returning to their studies on Sept. 19, St. Peter's College this year will have the largest enrollment in its history. Freshman week, a period of orientation, will begin Monday and last until Friday. The Rev. R. Rush Rankin, Professor of Ethics, will conduct a spiritual retreat for the new students.
Ash Wednesday, pacing mare from Willow Brook Farms and Beckie Dale, 2-year-old sidewheeler from the Newbrook stables, featured today's matinee at Weeauahic Park.
Although sales of leading chain store and mail order companies declined in August under a year ago, the percentage of decrease was much smaller than in preceding months.

TWO SOLDIERS. The Campaign Diaries of Thomas J. Key, C. S. A., and Robert J. Campbell, V. S. A. Edited by Wirt Armistead Cate. 277 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $2.50. THESE campaign diaries are from the western front and cover. roughly, the last year of the war.
At the Department of Sanitation yesterday afternoon it was announced that advance sales had reached $50,000 for today's baseball game between the nines of the department and the Police Department.

When William Gillette died, and the time came when his sorrowing friends must read his last will and testament, they- found that the creator of the stage role of Sherlock Holmes had left them a characteristic jest, tied up in the somber business of disposing of his Connecticut estate, with its feudal castle and its machine-age miniature railway.
Trading in wheat futures today was greatly restricted and American markets fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 cent a bushel.

THE starting backfield for Eli Yale in the Harvard game last Autumn consisted of Clint Frank, Charley Ewart, Dave Colwell and Al Hessberg. It comes to mind now because football once again is coming ' round the mountain, yes, it's coming' round the mountain"' and Ducky Pond will not be able to start that backfield or any part of it again.

Apartment seekers, particularly in the suburbs, have become more discriminating and have an unusual amount of knowledge as to how apartments should be constructed and designed, according to Raymond R. Beatty, president of Raymond R. Beatty Management, Inc.

A new course, including obstacles such as might be found on the field of battle, will be introduced during the international military jumping tests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, Nov. 5-12, it was announced yesterday by Manager Ned King.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--A host of convention delegates will invade Atlantic City during the coming week. Perhaps the largest group is the United Association of Journeymen Plumbers, Steamfitters and Helpers of the United States and Canada, which opens sessions in the Municipal Auditorium tomorrow.
WHEN Goettingen University celebrated its bicentenary in 1936 public attention was not centered exclusively upon the many famous scholars associated with the institution.

"' Women at Work" has been decided upon as the subject of a dramatic record which the Central Committee for Career Tours will publish in book form as a supplement to the task of acquainting the women of the country, during the New York World's Fair in 1939, with a half century of achievement in professional and business life.

Youth problems will have the spotlight for the third successive year when the New England Conference of State Federations of Women's Clubs holds its twenty-ninth annual meeting, opening at Portsmouth, N. H., on Wednesday afternoon.

English local authorities, who in the past few years have carried out a huge low-rent housing program, are being forced to reconsider their new plans by the reluctance of slum dwellers to move far out into the suburbs.

Clothiers have never been able to figure out why two-pants suits are popular some years and drop off in others. Depressions might be expected to have something to do with it, economy in the lean years dictating the preference for an extra pair of trousers, but this theory has not been borne out, clothiers claim. For the coming season.

Mrs. Almeron W. Smith of Plandome, L. I., former president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, has been named by Mrs. Saidie Orr Dunbar, president of the General Federation, as chairman of the federation extension committee.

Addition of Fordham to Purdue University's 1940 football schedule was announced today by Acting Athletic Director Bob Woodworth. The 1940 game will mark the sixth meeting of the Boilermakers and the Rams, who will play the rubber game in the series in New York this Oct. 15. The series will be suspended temporarily next year as the Boilermakers journey to San Francisco to meet Santa Clara.

THE other night I heard the radio in my living room asking who was King George's great-grandmother. I felt terribly pleased, because I knew the answer-Queen Victoria! In fact I remember her quite well. Then it asked how high is Mount Popocatepetl, and I was clean out of it.

" There will be no Berchtesgaden for Czechoslovakia," it has been the Czechs' proud assertion ever since Austria's fall-preceded as that was by Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's visit to Adolf Hitler's retreat in which the Fuehrer laid down the law.

As Maryland's bitter primary campaign roared into its finish drive today, with President Roosevelt urging speed on two PWA bridge projects, supporters of the New Deal closed ranks against Senator Tydings.

TO the number of gigantic dams in the West, visited by thousands of tourists annually, another soon to be added is the $100,700,000 Shasta Dam. It will be built by the Federal Government on the Sacramento River where that wilderness stream flows seaward from the Sierra Nevada Mountains. The site of the project is in Northern California.

EDWARDING the safe driver by granting him a premium rebate-approved widely in principle and already operating in thirty-four States and the District of Columbia-will not be New York State's method of encouraging accident reduction through insurance savings for deserving policy holders.
For the democracies of Europe the events of the past week have brought closer home than ever before a question from which there is no escape in the long run.
An old estate of twenty-one acres in Plainfield, N. J., soon will be transformed into a striking garden apartment village of fifty two-story colonial buildings to house about 300 families.

BUILDING fortifications is just now Europe's biggest industry. Everybody is doing it. France is extending, improving and strengthening her Maginot line, which runs from Belgium to Switzerland. or adding lighter protective wings north and south against the possibility of invasion through either of these countries. She is fortifying Corsica and her overseas possessions as far away as Annam.

Robert Stephenson Jr., 19 years old, of 509 Beverly Place, Teaneck, N. J., came home yesterday on the French liner Paris, completing as a third-class passenger a voyage begun two months ago as a stowaway on the Normandie.

Delegations from member boards in all parts of the State will begin arriving in Syracuse on Wednesday to take part in the thirty-fourth annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

The tendency toward wild hues and unconventional dress, which in recent years seemed to be revolutionizing this center of men's fashions, now appears to have been halted. A new King is on the throne-a King with all the conservative tastes of his fatherand the Auturn fashions bear the markn of his auiet restraint.

The report by the Federal Reserve Board that the demand deposits of the nation's banks are currently near the all-time high mark of the end of 1936 and that at the same time the rate of turnover of these deposits is the slowest on record again calls attention to the anomaly of our present banking situation.

LONDON.-About 7,000 men are expected to go whaling this year from Sandefjord, Tonsberg and Larvik on the Oslo fjord in Norway. Most of the factory ships and catchers leave together in September and are given a community farewell by hundreds of motor boats which escort them down the fjord to the open sea.

THROUGH innumerable picturesque elements combine to build the Paris Winter mode, they are often so cleverly camouflaged by modern technique, that it takes a regular style Sherlock Holmes to detect them.
With Sam Chapman leading the way, the Athletics today fattened their batting averages, each player getting at least one hit as the Red Sox were beaten, 15-7.

BUCHAREST. DOWN the winding Calea Victoriei of Bucharest the royal guard marches at a spanking gait, wheels into the courtyard of the palace, snaps to attention and the band begins its daily serenade of operetta tunes.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 has planned its mural project-the largest program of exterior mural painting ever undertaken-as an example which it hopes will serve to enliven American architecture and introduce life and gayety unto urban scenery, it was disclosed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

Some regulations have been presented by J. Earl Seiter in Buildings and Building Management which, he states, if properly followed, will be beneficial toward efficient heating. He advises that all windows be weatherstripped and all window frames calked and also that revolving or vestibule doors be provided at all entrances.

If there were no border, no sentry boxes, no passport or customs stations, you would know that you had passed from France into Spain. Not that the landscape is not relatively the same; it is. In Summer at least there are the same blue skies and green fields.
Perfect records were compiled by three craft in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's sixth annual Fall series, which was brought to a successful conclusion today while spotty sailing conditions prevailed.

FROM Summer lethargy, retail trade in many centers last week jumped into intense activity. By successive spurts after the holiday, sales pulled ahead of last year. Some merchants reported the best volume since Christmas. Specialty stores told of increases ranging up to 35 and 40 per cent. The demand was characterized by breadth and a definite trend toward quality.

Unless there is a turn for the worse in the European situation, the market for new capital is expected to be fairly active during the Fall. Registration statements for corporate loans amounting to about $200,000,000 are scheduled to be filed this month with the Securities and Exchange Commission

A big eighth inning which produced eight runs gave the Pirates a 14-to-7 victory over the Cardinals today to increase their lead in the National League pennant race to 4 1/4 games over Chicago and Cincinnati.

The Federal Power Commission has postponed until Sept. 27 a hearing on an investigation it instituted on July 5 into the acquisition by the New Jersey Power and Light Company on March 14 of 341,350 shares of common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company.

WHILE it may be premature in some critical quarters to speak of the art of the motion pictures, there can be no violent denial that under the guise of "prestige" pictures, Hollywood is earnestly trying to achieve classical greatness. But the sturdy esthetes of Los Angeles are under handicaps ("gigantic" and "colossal") peculiar to no other art.

Calling attention to the fact that the modern kitchen, even in its less expensive examples, is equipped for precisely the same purposes and results as the kitchen in a more elaborate and costly home, the Modern Kitchen Bureau of this city enumerates six essentials to be considered in kitchen planning.
THE Berkshire Festival of Chamber Music will celebrate its twentieth anniversary this season with a series of concerts to be given Sept. 21, 22 and 23 at South Mountain, Pittsfield, Mass.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Morton M. Lyon of Wayne, Pa., makes a contribution to current controversies in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMwE commenting on an article by this writer entitled "Basic Tenets," which represented an effort to set forth the five most important fundamental attitudes of the American people toward their government.
NEW YORK UNIVERSITY'S "Radio Workshop" opens on Sept. 19 at Washington Square North under the direction of Douglas Coulter, assistant program director of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

When news that the Sudeten Germans had decided to break off negotiations with Prague reached Palestine, the Palestinian Arab politicians, most of whom are now residing in Syria, Lebanon or Egypt, are reported to have rejoiced greatly.

W. H. Beal, president of the Aviation Manufacturing Corporation, announced yesterday that the property of Stinson Aircraft Corporation has been acquired and that manufacture of Stinson planes, with the same personnel, will be continued by the Stinson Aircraft Division of Aviation Manufacturing Corporation at Wayne, Mich.
The engagement of Miss Edith Watson Ouzts, daughter of Mrs. E. Watson Ouzts of this place and the late Joseph Pinckney Ouzts, to Thomas Roland Humphreys has been announced by her mother.

Mr. and Mrs. William LeRoy Sweet of 203 Clinton Avenue, New Brighton, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Darle Ashley Sweet, to Frederick William Hand, son of Mrs. Thomas Hand of Paterson, N. J., and the late Mr. Hand.
The estate of Robert P. Scripps, publisher, who died last Winter, was valued at $3,033,567 in an appraisement on file today. Under the will his widow, Mrs. Margaret Culbertson Scripps,
THERE are not many Brooklyns outside the United States. Most atlases, in fact, show only one, in Nova Scotia, but there is another and it is in Wellington, the capital city of New Zealand.

Retail stores have adopted a neat catch-phrase these days, in an effort to get men to acquire more complete outfits. The phrase is "balanced wardrobe" and it is the store's idea of what apparel a man should possess to be dressed satisfactorily. It is nothing like the luxurious wardrobes, however, that are occasionally outlined by expensive tailors as vital for the well-dressed man.
WAR has been both glorified and "gorified" on the screen. During the great conflagration of 1914, Hollywood helped Uncle Sam "make the world safe for democracy."
Savings and loan associations in New York and New Jersey made new. home loans totaling $5,424,000 during July, according to figures compiled by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Plans to ration gasoline in Ceylon in an emergency have been drawn up and the Food Control Department is ascertaining the requirements of the principal uses of gasoline in the colony.The motor industry, local associations and estates are being circulated.
The man who "discovered" Amelia Earhart tells here of his experiences in managing her first transatlantic flight. Captain Railey also managed Admiral Byrd's first expedition to the Antarctic.

Nine balloons will take the air tomorrow in the International James Gordon Bennett Race. With the United States. Germany and Czechoslovakia-all strong contenders in the past-not entered, the favorite was Ernest de Muyter of Belgium, winner of the last two races.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bayne Marbury of 717 Morningside Drive, this city, have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Frankie Eloise Marbury, to Marvin Elliott Hubbell of Boston and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hubbell of New Rochelle, N. Y.

Elisha Hanson, general counsel of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared tonight that but for the valiant fight for a free press waged by American newspaper publishers during the five years of the Roosevelt Administration the press of the United States might now be in the position of the newspapers in Germany.

The Westchester County Flower Show, opening at the County Center in White Plains. on Wednesday afternoon at 2, and continuing through Saturday, will combine floral and garden displays with interesting features of a first-class county fair.

With all but one of its components higher for the week ended Sept. 3, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has registered its sixth successive increase, and now stands at 85.4, its highest point since the week ended Nov. 20, 1937. The figure for the preceding week was 84.8. A year ago the index was 109.3.

WE usually visualize Oriental progress in terms of drastic change. But when we meet progress that is still held within the ancient framework of society, religion. and family custom, it is just as arresting, and it has a piquant individual interest.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra's thirty-ninth season in its home city will open Oct. 7 and close April 29. Twentyeight Friday-Saturday concert pairs are scheduled and ten Tuesday night programs.
Recently commissioned colonel in the New York State National Guard, Colonel Benjamin O. Davis,

Clothiers and hatters are making it increasingly difficult for men to get along with one top-piece by bringing out such a variety of styles that the temptation to splurge is almost irresistible. Not only that, but the cap-makers, who watched their sales drop about 75 per cent in ten years, have decided to revive this type of headwear and are waving some pretty good-looking styles in front of men.

Coming up swiftly for the last three of the nineteen hazardous jumps, Ad Lib, owned by S. A. Warner Baltazzi of Roslyn, L. I., and an 8-toshot in the betting, took the lead in the final rush to win the fifth renewal of the Foxcatcher National Cup steeplechase today.
The Contemporary Club here was transformed into a rural setting tonight for the harvest festival sponsored by the Child Study Association of America to benefit its Summer play schools.

The Federal Home Loan Bank System added forty-nine members with assets totaling $45,000,000 to its roster during the second quarter of 1938, and now has 3,955 member institutions with assets of $4,308,104,000, largely concerned with home financing.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Henry Penick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydnor Parksdale Penick of Montclair, to Philip Everngam Nuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. R. Nuttle of Denton, Md., took place this morning in the chapel of the First Baptist Church here. The Rev. Dr. Albert Cohoe, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

FOR nearly thirty years Uncle Sam has been studying the diamond back terrapin. Now he has a report to make to the nation's gourmets, to Jefferson Day diners, to all others to whom a bit of terrapin in sherry is more precious than a five-dollar United States note.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie A. Baldwin of Milbrook, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elizabeth Baldwin, to Edward Holden Morgan, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Minot C. Morgan of Greenwich.
IF one is at all acquainted with contemporary Italian thought one can hardly think of Gentile without automatically conjuring up the name of Croce. They are contemporary;

ABOUT nocturnal matters down in Greenwich Village, they are still on the informal side. On Eighth Street, the sometime Bohemia's little Broadway, they are even on the rustic side, meaning the Village Barn,

" FEARFULLY AND WONDERFULLY MADE" is the surprising and somewhat inadequate title of a highly competent treatise on human physiology. The book is intended for the intelligent layman who may wish to learn the fundamentals of the subject.

Senator Townsend, Republican, of Delaware, asserted today that President Roosevelt's intervention in Democratic primaries seemed to be designed to build a party organization which would give him a third term. The Senator, who is chairman of the Republican Senatorial campaign committee, predicted that the President would fail if this was his program.

The nomination last Tuesday of Senator Patrick A. McCarran, foe of the Roosevelt Supreme Court plan and his Government Reorganization Bill, is widely regarded in this State as another blow at the New Deal's effort to punish those who refuse to follow the President's orders.

Miss Nancy Jeanne Hutchins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton Brown Hutchins of this place and Chicago, was married here this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church to Charles Wooters Ranson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ranson of Larchmont Manor, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Ethan Allen.

Although factoring houses on the whole have not recovered from the 25 to 50 per cent drop in business they suffered last October, real recovery in their business is under way, and August business was almost equal to that of a year ago,

At least eighteen courses will be offered for the program of the evening division of commerce at Hofstra College for the term for which registration begins Monday, Dr. John H. Prime, director of the division, announced today.

A steady rise in purchases by industrial purchasing agents is making the comparisons of current expenditures with those of a year ago much more favorable, company executives pointed out here yesterday. While commitments at the end of July averaged 15 to 20 per cent below those

HUNGARY is celebrating this year the 400th anniversary of the founding of the Magyar people's chief center of Protestant education, the College of Debreczen, which since 1914 has been known as the Debreczen State University of Sciences, and the event is being commemorated by Hungary with six stamps which will be released this month.

President Lazaro Cardenas in a twentyminute speech here today opening the International Peace Conference sharply attacked the indemnity principles set forth in recent United States notes and indicated they were capable of leading to war.

The Jamaica Public Service, Ltd., a Canadian corporation which owns electric systems in Jamaica, B. W. I., reported yesterday a substantial increase in expenses as a result of a revision of the Jamaica income tax law in August. This revision approximately doubled the tax imposed by the colony on the utility.

NOT since the Civil War have Americans been so conscious of the South. Nor has the South been so aware of itself. Long before the President called it the nation's No. 1 economic problem the region between the Potomac and the Rio Grande had begun to see itself and be seen as land of problem and vast opportunity.

Four thousand persons visited St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, the day after the funeral services for Cardinal Hayes. Most of those visiting the cathedral walked behind the high altar to look at the closed door of the crypt in which the Cardinal was buried.

Two researchers from Yale University reported last week their discovery, based on exhaustive road tests made with a motion picture camera, that one out of every five American drivers allows less than a second's leeway when he passes a car on a two-lane road in the face of oncoming traffic.

Fordham University's School of Business will give an evening real estate course for men, consisting of fourteen lectures by realty experts. beginning Sept. 28 at the Woolworth Building and continuing on subsequent Wednesdays.
Ebby Gerry's Aknusti team found its scoring eye at last this afternoon and triumphed over the Jaguars, 16 to 9, to open the Monty Waterbury Cup polo tournament on Hitchcock Field.

WINNER: The Davis Cup, international tennis trophy, has since its donation in 1900 been up for competition thirty-three times. The United States has won twelve times, the British Isles nine, France six and Australia six. Last week, for the second year in succession, the United States, in the first challenge round in America since 1927, won the trophy.

The bulk of the savings and loan association business is now being done by institutions which are members of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, a report issued yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board indicates.

Many phases of the building industry will be dealt with in a series of thirty-six courses to be given in the university extension division of the Columbia School of Architecture during the academic year, 19381938, beginning Sept. 29, Professor George M. Allen, executive officer in charge, announced yesterday.
Airconditioning for submarines will make America's undersea fighting force a much more potent weapon in any future war.

THE Spanish and Sino-Japanese warfare has shown that for maximum efficiency pursuit planes should be based near the front, ready to take off immediately enemy bombers are sighted. Naturally, these advanced bases, shifting with the front, must be mobile.

Tennis-John Bromwich, Australian Davis Cup star, was only one game from defeat before he rallied to down Frank Shields, 1-6, 10-12, 10-8, 6-2, 6-2, in the national championships at Forest Hills yesterday. Robert L. Riggs also was hard pressed in beating Ronald Shayes of Great Britain, 6-3, 6-3, 4-6, 1-6, 6-4.

That the State of New York has been expending large sums of money each year on its school system in return for a "low education result" was indicated today by Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the Institute of Public Administration in New York.
ROBERT NEUMANN, whose new novel, "A Woman Screamed," will be published on Sept. 15 by the Dial Press, is now livnig as a refugee in London.
THAT these three Latin poets, Plautus in the third century B. C., Catullus.and Ovid in the first. are typically Romans, although not one of them was born in Rome, is the thesis which F. A.

WHERE Federal forces locked with Confederate troops in one of the bloodiest battles of the ??vil War seventy-five years ago, and where, twenty-five years earlier, The Cherokee Indians were driven ?? their homeland and onto their Trail of Tears," the 100-year-old city of Chattanooga, for ten days beginning Friday, will stage a Na?? Chickamauga Celebration.

With converters already reordering Spring numbers, producers of fabrics woven from a blend of spun rayon and flax predicted yesterday that these new weaves would achieve sharply expanded volume for the 1939 Spring and Summer season. The cloth was brought out this season for the first time, under Patents issued earlier in the year.
" BEATING ABOUT THE BUSH" is - a highly spiced tale of the adventures of Brian O'Brien in and around certain of those outposts of progress which still dot equatorial Africa.

North Carolina's Young Democrats, in convention today, frowned on Presidential intervention in party primaries. A resolution was adopted express sing "our complete confidence in the ability of the people of North Carolina to decide their own issues and administer their internal affairs."

Bitter attacks on the New Deal by Republican speakers; a whirlwind finish by former Governor Brann, the Democratic candidate for G6vernor; an increasingly serious revolt of conservative Republicans against Representative James C. Oliver, Townsend plan supporter,

The dog days are over, vacations are a pleasant memory and the "back-to-work" and "back-to-thecampus" movement has begun in earnest. It is a movement out of cool suits and the porous shirts and into trim, smart clothing and haberdashery.
The city's Independent Subway System has carried 1,357,887,172 passengers in the six years since it began operation on Sept. 10, 1932, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

THE children going back to school this week will be subjected to all sorts of tests-aptitude tests, intelligence tests, reading tests, health tests-but their basic mental abilities, their creative tendencies, will remain largely a mystery. Many attempts have been made to explore the child's world of feeling and imagination. Now art is being used as a medium.

The rugged masculinity of Fall styles has not been confined to clothing but has been extended to such important accessories as shoes and hosiery. More and more, grained leathers are coming to the fore, with the details of the shoe itself, particularly the toe-cap and sole, contributing to the effect of ruggedness.

Judge Frederick C. Swift, who retired two years ago after forty-six years of service as a justice of the Barnstable District Court, died here today at the home of his son, Judge Paul M. Swift, at the age of 82.

WHEN Jim Haydon returned to Edmonton after a four-year term in jail for a crime committed by another man he found his former associates decidedly unfirendly. But thanks to a syspathetic Mountie, Sergeant Lloyd Kenyon,

The Presidential yacht Potomac nosed her way last Monday morning into the harbor of the little fishing town of Crisfield, Md. On board were the President, Postmaster General Farley, Representatives David J. Lewis and T. Alan Goldsborough and other political figures.
A number of deals involving large residences in upper Manhattan, Riverdale and Hastings-on-Hudson were reported yesterday by Edgar G. Johnson, Inc., broker in the transactions.

Housewives who try to figure out the Winter heating costs as part of a monthly budget plan may be aided by estimates prepared by engineers of Anthracite Industries, Inc., on the basis of a $75 bill for coal during the entire season.

An enrollment of 48,000 students is expected at New York University as classes get under way for the 107th academic year, Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar, announced. An expanded program of courses in the graduate field will be introduced this year.
Something more than twenty-four years ago ultimatums were ricocheting about Europe. The New York Stock Exchange was closed on July 31, 1914. Not until Nov. 28 did it reopen for trading in bonds.

Robert M. Gray, 58-yearold veteran of the Rosedale Club, Toronto, won the international seniors' golf championship today, defeating a select field of players from Great Britain, the United States and Canada.

American shipyards were building 112 commercial ships of 477,205 gross tons on Sept. 1, according to the monthly report of the American Bureau of Shipping, which was issued last week. This represents an increase of seven ships and 171,125 tons for the last twelve months.

The Washington Star said in a copyrighted story today that word was circulating in army and other administration quarters that President Roosevelt had called for the resignation of Paul V. McNutt from his post of High Commissioner to the Philippines.

More than thirty-five new courses will be offered for the first time in all branches of the City Collegearts and science, technology, business and education-during the day and evening sessions in the appreaching Fall semester, it was announced yesterday.

Sir George Thomas of London, twice holder of the British chaipionship, today drew his game with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, champion of the world, in the seventh and final round of the jubilee international tournament of the Plymouth Chess Club at the Guildhall.

Only twenty-five strikes, involving 2,641 workers, were called in New York State during July, according to the records of the Mediation Bureau of the State Labor Department. The figures indicate a comparatively peaceful month, Miss Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner, commented.

Aided by cool weather, mens wear stores got a good start on the Fall selling season last week; with figures in many instances exceeding those of last year. The chief volume came on back-to-school clothes, with a fair amount of interest on new suits for business wear and with an excellent response to clearance sales conducted by some stores, retail executives said.
To appraise the success of a banquet before the principal dish has been served-in fact, before the chef has decided just what ingredients should go into it-Is no easy task.

RALEIGH, N. C.-The Blue Ridge Parkway through "The Land of the Sky" in Western North Carolina may now be completed at an early date, with the State Highway and Public Works Commission abandoning title to a link of Route 107, running from Newfound Gap through Raven's Ford to Cherokee.
UNDER a more punctilious form of government he would be Sir Burns Mantle "for services." His services to the theatre have been innumerable, exacting and unending.

Having registered their approval of matching shirts, slacks and bush-coats this Summer, sportsmen will find that haberdashers have produced these combinations in heavy fabrics for Fall. The latest offering on the market is a corduroy set, consisting of trousers, shirt and belted, four-pocket coat in standard shades, such as brown, navy blue, dark green or tan. Pieces of the set also may be purchased individually.

Among the meetings planned by Connecticut women for the coming week is an annual dinner of the Business and Professional Women's Club of New London, to be held Tuesday evening at the Casino Grill in Saybrook.

Speeding westward to the bedside of his son, President Roosevelt continued today to give his full attention to the increasingly grave European situation. He kept his secretarial staff at his side as reports from the State Department and news dispatches were handed to him at town to town along the route.
Two proceedings presenting questions as to the constitutionality of the capital stock tax and the excess profits tax are now on file on the appellate docket of the United States Supreme Court.

Thousands of mourners filed last week through St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue to view the body of Patrick Cardinal Hay6s, Archbishop.of New York. Funeral services on Friday brought to New York many members of the Catholic hierarchy of North America, among them Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia, Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago and Cardinal Villeneuve of Quebec.
Stagehand, winner of the $25,000 Narragansett Handicap last Saturday, easily scored a six-length victory today in the $10,000 added Governor's Handicap at Narragansett Park before 25,000 fans.
DR. BUTLER of Columbia University is reported to hunting "a moral substitute for war." Some one might suggest peace, of coruse--but such an obvious Ersatz would only be practicable in a sane world.

In the New Church Chapel here this afternoon Miss Emily Katherine Fetter, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Newton Cromwell Fetter of this city, was married to Kenneth William Bergen of New York. The bride's father performed the ceremony.
Directors of Fairbanks, Morse Co. have voted to redeem the cumulative convertible preferred shares, it was announced today.
The Czechoslovakian Government has awarded the contract for erection of its building at the World's Fair to Hegeman-Harris Company of New York, and work will be started at once.
The marriage of Miss Martha Cushier Ferenbach to Joseph Clary Anderson took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John Leavitt Griggs.

An ambitious squadron of outboard pilots, all optimistic about their hulls, their motors and their skill and ready to tear into existing records-that already approach a mile a minute-in frail little hydroplanes, is moving on Chattanooga.

Mgr. Michael L. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was up and about again yesterday afternoon and last evening despite an order from Dr. Raymond P. Sullivan, his physician, to spend two days in bed.

Yesterday's session of the trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, came to an abrupt halt with a demand for a mistrial, which Supreme Court Ferdinand Pecora decided to study over the week-end. The third such motion in this case, it was the first that Justice Pecora deemed to necessitate more than a minute's scrutiny.

Battle Day, 5-year-old brown gelding owned by Frederick M. Warburg of White Plains, was named hunter champion at the twenty-fifth annual Greenwich horse show, held today at the Yale University farms. Twenty-three classes occupied the program, which was staged under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds and the Greenwhich Riding Association.
HAVING had a rooting interest in the theatre as backer of "A Doll's House" and "Our Town," Hollywood's William K. Howard will play along with it, parley fashion.

An effort to Increase the efficiency of football officiating among the thirty-four member colleges of the Eastern Intercollegiate Association will be made during the forthcoming gridiron campaign through a well-organized plan that was brought forth yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin, where some 300 coaches, officials and other interested persons attended the annual rules interpretation meeting.

Miss Margaret Middleton Bradford and Edouard Sandoz, both of whom are descended from early colonial settlers, were married here this afternoon in Trinity Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. William Schroeder.

Drew University will open its seventysecond year Sept. 22, when Dr. Earl A. Aldrich, professor of English at Brothers College, will deiver the matriculation address in the university chapel at 3:20 P. M.

Brilliant sailing by Alfred E. Chase on Viking offset the superb team tactics of Sven Salen with his Fagel Grip and kept the United States in the lead tonight for the Beverly Yacht Club's International Challenge Cup.
It is literally true to say that Europe's peace has hung this week on the decision of one man. Earnest appeals were made to this man not to let the die be cast for war.

While the world has its eyes fixed fearfully on Czechoslovakia, China and Spain, a main problem before the Assembly of the League of Nations that opens Monday will be what to do about the peacetime flood of refugees.

THE Metropolitan Camera Clubs Council, 106 West Thirteenth Street, New York City, continuing its services of the Summer to photographers and member clubs, has announced an active Fall and Winter program. Six courses, four for still photo fans and two for movie makers, will be presented.

Miss Sarah Kathleen Phinney was married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church, Fort Hamilton, to Frederic McMichael Kirkland. She is the daughter of Colonel Robert Truman Phinney, United States Army, and Mrs. Phinney of Fort Logan, Colo., and Mr. Kirkland is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Richardson Kirkland of Wynnewood, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Condit, rector of the church.

Louis Waldman, Republican-American Labor party designee for Brooklyn County Court, charged yesterday that the court had failed to use its power and order a grand jury investigation in the Drukman case.

Spanish Insurgent bombing planes raked the government coast from Valencia to points north of Barcelona in a series of raids today that took attention away from locked battle lines on Catalonia's Ebro front.

Leaders took a tumble in the second day's competition to select the national champion of the Comet Class, as Roger Willcox, a Harvard sophomore and winner of the title in 1935, sailed his homemade Scud from Staten I land, N. Y., across the finish on Skaneateles Lake today in the lead of forty-six champion skippers from many sections of the United States.
More than 7,000 day session students are expected to register at Hunter College next Wednesday, according to Professor Mary Belden James Lehn, registrar of the college.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I should like to clarify some of the issues raised by the letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES signed S. M., M. D. The doctor of not so many years ago worked under idyllic conditions-no hospitals, no medical centers, no competition.

Details of the annual field-trial meeting of the Irish Water Spaniel Club of America have been cornmpleted by the committee and are announced by Mrs. Henry F. Hall of South Sudbury, Mass., secretary of the organization.

The Metropolitan Opera House will be the setting on the night of Oct. 13 for one of the first large philanthropically conceived entertainments of the new season-a benefit performance of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo.

A Milnar was a better batsman than pitcher today as the Indians suffered their third straight defeat by bowing to the Browns, 4-2. While Buck Newsom was content to do a workmanlike mound job in holding the Tribe to six hits, Milnar produced the Indian's only runs with a homer in the fifth inning with Sammy Hale on base. He also made a single, but gave St. Louis twelve hits.

A substantial expansion in trade association activities and the likely elimination of some organizations will be the logical result of the searching inquiry into such groups which the government will conduct in conjunction with its monopoly investigation, association men predicted here yesterday.
Evening newspapers here feature a Nuremberg dispatch, according to which Germany has renewed her assurances that she intends to respect Belgian neutrality.

Al Schwarz of Philadelphia annexed the Westy Hogans open trapshooting championship today after a shoot-off with William Davis of Odessa, Del1, in the final firing of the organization's thirty-first annual meeting.

Looking ahead to next season, the Yankees announced yesterday that they had procured the services of eight minor league players from two of their farm clubs. All will report to the Yankee training quarters at St. Petersburg, Fla., next Spring. Cash and other players figured in the transfers.

Miss Thayle Landers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Landers of Maplewood, was married at noon today to William J. Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. O. R. Wolf of Fairmont, Minn. The ceremony took place in the Ivy Chapel of Morrow Memorial Church, here, with the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton officiating.
The Ethical Culture Schools in New York will open their year's work on Thursday with an enrollment of more than a thousand young persons from pre-kindergarten through college preparatory age.

R. Canfield and R. Marano, with 97 each, tied for the skeet championship of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the shoot-off, Canfield scored, 24 to 23. The handicap, trophy was taken by D. Layton, the second prize going to S. F. Landers.

TO Baltimore, on an Autumn night in 1935, went the honor of being the first American town to see him act. Only Baltimore, usually a city of acute theatrical judgment, didn't seem to know this time what it was getting, or that it was an honor.

IN these days, when the reputations of orchestra conductors are mysteriously marked up and down like values on the Stock Exchange, it is comforting to come upon the man who can truthfully give us our bearings.

IT is five years since Vera Brittain stirred the minds and tore the hearts of American readers by her portrayal. at once straightforward, restrained, passionate and profound, of the generation that was destroyed or crippled or irremedially scarred by the World War.
THOSE who are so hotly disputing the merits or demerits of the Wagner Labor Relations Act will find it profitable to read how Republican Germany tried to solve its problems of labor relations.
A sprite of a person who doesn't top five feet by more than two inches is the feminine chief of the network of roads now under construction at the New York World's Fair of 1939.
Private Oni Holm, 21 years old, attached to the Sixteenth Infantry at Fort Jay, Governors Island, was a prisoner in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday on a charge of attempted robbery.

Equally prepared for its annual "Autumn training and exercises" or a sudden order to take "battle stations," Britain's Home Fleet has concentrated its strength of more than thirty warships at the far-off Scottish bases of Rosyth and Invergordon.

The Yankees made the acquaintance of Rene Monteagudo, Bucky Harris's sturdy Cuban southpaw today at Griffith Stadium, and vice versa. But the experience can hardly be said to have been mutually agreeable.

Delegates from three locals formerly affiliated with the Workers Alliance and observers from a number of others which were said to be considering secession from the alliance met yesterday to lay the foundation for a rival organization of relief recipients on a State-wide basis.

Hunts racing will come back to Long Island this week with the seventeenth meeting of the West Hills Racing Association on the esstates of Henry L. Stimson and s Thomas White near Huntington, I Saturday.

A 1.75-franc plus 50-centimes lavender semi-postal from France shows Pierre Curie (1859-1906) and Marie Sklowdoska Curie (18671933) in their laboratory and is inscribed "Pierre et Marie Curie Decouvrent le Radium, Nov., 1898" (Pierre and Marie Curie Discover Radium, November, 1898).
Thornton Wilder, winner of the Pulitzer Prize in two directionsthe novel and play-may find himself a Broadway actor in a week or so. Recently on the West Coast, he now is on his way to New York,
Chance Ray galloped over a muddy Hawthorne track today to beat Unselfish by a nose in the first running of the President's Trophy Handicap. Diavola Boy was third.

A lot of salt water anglers will be returning to their first love, surfcasting, during the coming six weeks, according to the letters we've been receiving lately. The surfcaster is the purist among the salt-water brotherhood, and after you've watched Frank Tuma or Louis Chilar of Montauk put a squid across .the water you are tempted to shove your boat rods behind you and get in some more practice with the "long stick."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has named Sept. 26 for a hearing on the proposed payment on Nov. 15 by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation of the regular quarterly dividends on its cumulative 6 per cent preferred stock, Series A; cumulative preferred stock 5 per cent series, and 5 per cent cumulative preference stock.

RELIGION, it has been said, was the chief product of Italy during the Middle Ages, and those lovers of medieval Italy, of whom there seems to be an incorrigible number left in the modern world, will derive a good deal of solid comfort from reading Jorgensen's book on an Italian girl who was alos a saint and a woman of action.

A snap of Autumn is in the sunny September air and at the signal all the flowers in the garden beds seem to have entered a blooming contest. Plants are heavy with flowers and with buds promising more color to come. Even some of the semi-tropical foliage plants are blossoming:

In a twenty-plank platform adopted here today the Republican State Committee assailed the Earle administration as an agency that had brought Pennsylvania "to the verge of moral and financial bankruptcy."

Sixty thousand persons cheered Queen Wilhelmina when the last act of the jubilee celebrations for her forty years' reign occurred at the Amsterdam stadium this afternoon after a week of festivities. On her arrival there the Queen received from two East Indian Princesses a large bouquet of fresh flowers brought from the Dutch East Indies by a Royal Air mail plane.
To meet "an increasing demand," a downtown office of the Associated Hospital Service will be opened tomorrow at 50 Broadway, Frank Van Dyk, executive director, announced yesterday.

Whether the question is to brighten up a young man's college room, lighten the luggage problem of a friend or send a suitable birthday gift, the answer is easy to find in the new array of novelties, utilitarian items and traveler's needs rapidly being unfolded in men's stores.

Fame came to the Rinky-Dinks Boys Club yesterday. Despite the concerted opposition of neighborhood girls, the prize in a raggedy doll contest (a tennis racquet) went to the seven boys who meet daily in a shack knocked together on a Batavia Street lot.

Miss Susan Doty Griesemer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Griesemer of Chevy Chase, and Arthur Davenport Thomas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas of Glen Ridge, N. J., were married this evening in the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. J. Hillman Hollister officiated.

These four beauties are typical of the Winter's style paradox with their hair coifed in a quaintly old-fashioned manner and their gowns eloquent of the modern day. The girl seated at the left, her red hair piled high on her head and curled low

Eighteen hundred A. F. of L. painters, employed by 300 independent contractors in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island were directed yesterday not to report for work until the contractors had signed agreements with their union, District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators.

IT is not often that authentic and factual information and the gift for readable and entertaining presentation are united in the same writer, which is one of the reasons why the general reader falls victim to so many picturesque but inaccurate books.
A continuance of the downward trend of foreclosures of real estate in Manhattan during the first eight months of this year is indicated in the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Connecticut Republicans and Democrats are about to hold their State conventions. The Republicans are in doleful dumps, and for good reason. Both Senators, all six Representatives in Congress, the Governor and the State House of Representatives are Democratic and likely to continue so.
IN "Triumph Over Pain," translated from the French of Rene Fulop-Miller, the amazing story of anesthesia is told with all the skill that a master dramaturge can bring to bear in evoking the past.

A primary campaign in which the Townsend old age pension plan has played a heavy role drew near a climax today, with Governor Francis P. Murphy and Attorney General Thomas F. Cheney in a struggle for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination.

" New York Panorama," first volume of the two-part "New York: A Guide to the World's Greatest Metropolis," for more than two years the main task of the Works Progress Administration Federal Writers' Project in New York City, will be published Wednesday by Random House, it was announced yesterday by Henry G. Alsberg, national director of the project.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis N. Angel of 233 West Ninety-ninth Street have announced the marriage on last Thursday of their daughter, Miss Bebe Angel, to Jerome A. Dreyer, son of Mrs. Esther Dreyer of 325 West Eighty-sixth Street and the late Albert Dreyer. After a wedding trip the couple will reside in Kew Gardens, Queens.

Miss Anne Wythe Jenkins, daughter of Captain H. E. Jenkins, U. S. N., of the Naval War College and Mrs. Jenkins was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Benjamin Robert Crosser, U. S. N., of the Great Lakes Training Station near chicago, son of Mrs. Calvin G. Crosser of New York.
Germany's "Drang nach Osten" is again exciting the chancelleries of Europe, as it did before the World War.

Production of $15,030,273 in bullion in the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1938, from treatment of 928,036 tons of ore has been disclosed in the twenty-third annual report of the Lake Shore Mines in the Kirkland Lake district. This represented an average recovery of $16.19 a ton. Last year production of bullion was $15,692,653 from 879,559 tons for an average of $17.84.

James Bridie's "The Last Trump," fresh from a triumph at the Malvern Theatre Festival, will be presented at the Duke of York's next Tuesday. Sir Seymour Hicks replaces Frank Pettingell as a Scottish financier and Simon Lack succeeds Alec Clunes; otherwise the cast is unchanged.
COMPLETE cycles of the operas of Janacek and Smetana are announced as the major part of the new season's repertoire at the National Theatre of Bruenn.

THE impression of sheer, relentless power which must still linger in the minds of those who have read "The Brothers Ashkenazi" is indubitably confirmed by this offering of thirteen short stories from the same pen.

HEAVIER production, with increasing schedules between now and late November, seems to be the order of the day here as the automotive industry speeds its efforts to stock all dealers before the announcement of 1939 cars late this month and early next.

Miss Peggy Seyburn, a granddaughter of the late John F. Dodge, one of the founders of Dodge Brothers, automobile manufacturers, was married here this afternoon to Edward M. McIlvain Jr., whose late father was a former president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

Appealing for a closer bond between the producers of the South and the consumers of the North, Mayor La Guardia in an address here tonight called for better understanding between the two sections of the country.
THE San Carlo Opera Company will begin a seventeen-day engagement at the Center Theatre Thursday night. The opening night's production will be "Carmen," with Coe Glade in the title role.

The world silicosis conference, meeting at the International Labor Office, on the proposal of the United States Government closed today after unanimously adopting its report to the International Labor Organization's governing body.
The Interstate Commerce Commission has called a hearing for Sept. 22 on the proposal submitted by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad temporarily to reduce fixed interest obligations.

Crude rubber used by manufacturers in the United States in August amounted to 38,170 long tons, compared with 32,209 in the preceding month and 41,506 in August, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Rubber imports last month were 31,099 tons, against 22,918 in July and 48,785 a year before.

Ernest Lawrence Broome, mechanical engineer and inventor of a sluice gate used in power projects, died today at his home here after a brief illness. His age was 69. Born in Central Falls, R. I., Mr. Broome obtained his engineering degree at Cooper Union.

THE Gordon Musical Association, Inc., announces a special concert by Albert Spalding, violinist, and the Gordon String Quartet this Saturday afternoon at 4 o'clock at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn. The concert hall is near the junction of motor routes 126, 7 and 43.

The marriage of Miss Cardine Elizabeth Bogert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lawrence Bogert of Meadow Spring and New York, to Thomas Hildt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hildt of Black Point, Conn., and Baltimore, took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, at Locust Valley.

Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn is continuing a program this year which attempts to bring greater reality to college preparatory work. The program, according to William Slater, the headmaster, is "an attempt to make the college preparatory life of the school's 450 students an experience more productive of intellectual curiosity than is possible when modern girls and boys are subjected to no opportunities beyond the cut-and-dried languages, mathematics, rhetoric and science in the usual curriculum."

AT a time when the American film industry is unanimously telling the world that this is--or will be-"motion picture's greatest year," it may seem a trifle heretical that any one should spy clouds on the horizon.

Americans who have been reading of such European defense measures as the general distribution of gas masks and the devising of balloon-supported nets to keep off enemy bombers have just been told that they have an even more novel problem of public protection in case of war.

Miss Eugenie La Tourette Craven and Morris Miller Davidson Jr. were married here tonight in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thornton B. Russell and by the Rev. Dr. William H. S. Demarest, former president of Rutgers University.

AS a concession to the popular belief that movie audiences resent defeatist themes in their fare, Warners have embarked upon the task of shifting emphasis from the characters of the Emperor Maximilian and the Empress Carlotta to the Indian Juarez in Bertita Harding's "The Phantom Crown," which, it now appears, will reach the screen under the title of "Juarez."
MR. DEWEY--Was it your practice, or did you ever when a leader requested a change of assignment of a patrolman or a policeman, make any inquiry as to why he wanted it?

Finis has been written to most of the great siege episodes of the Spanish Civil War. The heroic garrisons of the Alcazar, Oviedo, and Huesca have been liberated; the brave little sanctuary of Santa Maria de la Cabeza overwhelmed.

While the governments of Europe play a day-to-day game skirting dangerously close to the edge of war, an ever-growing question is: What part would the United States play if this year or the next should see history complete a full cycle and Europe revert to war as in 1914?

Police Commissioner Valentine named Captain Patrick Kenny yesterday to succeed Deputy Inspector Richard F. Oliver in command of the Fourth Detective Division. Inspector Oliver died of a heart attack at his home last Monday.

A plan to acquaint the incoming freshman with his college campus, protect his pocketbok from persistent student salesmen, and encourage his immediate participation in extra-curricular activities has been instituted at Princeton University this Fall.

The Church Charity Organization Society and the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, both of 105 East Twentysecond Street, Manhattan, will reseive the residuary estate of Robert B. Dodson of Manhattan and West Islip, following the death of his widow, Mary W. Dodson, according to his will, filed for probate here today.

A "SAFETY-LIGHT" speedometer will be incorporated by Dodge in its coming "silver anniversary". line that is promised for introduction within a few weeks, the company announced yesterday. While advance information about the models remains meager, the new speedometer indicates that additional safety will be among the features strongly accented in the new designs.

The CubanBritish commercial treaty became effective today upon an exchange of ratifications at the Cuban State Department. Juan J. Remos, the Secretary of State, represented Cuba, and Eric Cunliffe Buxton, British charge d'affairs, acted for his country.

The largest mural ever to be painted in this country, showing the development of the American Army from 1776 to the present time, is now being completed here for exhibition at the Golden Gate International Exposition at San Francisco in 1939.

Present-day conditions affecting Long Island real estate are similar to those which were responsible for the extensive land buying movement in that section during the Nineteen Hundreds, points out John W. McKeown, builder and developer of properties in the Bay Shore. Islip and Brentwood sections.

WITHDRAWAL of the Wisconsin Automotive Trade Associtation from the National Automobile Dealers Association reveals a deep rift in the lute of the principal dealer body. The action was taken due to postponement beyond 120 days of a revision of the constitution and by-laws of the of N. A. D. A. by its executive committee.
New York City's public schools will open tomorrow morning and 1,200,000 children and 40,000 teachers will enter the classrooms to open officially the new academic year.

After a Summer season in which home sales reached a high mark there is ample evidence that the Fall will be one of the most active that section has experienced in many years according-to reports received yesterday from builders, developers and brokers.
Robert H. Bryson, many years one of the leading architects of Brooklyn, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 15 Clark Street, that borough. He was 63 years old.
New light is thrown on the vexed question of the middleman and the cost of living by a recently published little volume entitled "Who Gets Your Food Dollar?" by Hector Lazo and M. H. Bletz.
LONDON.-Mrs. Florence Wilson, widow of a Kenya farmer, has won pioneer honors in the development of air transport over some of the most difficult country in East Africa.

Labor troubles again threaten to tie up the business and commerce of this great seaport as they did in the maritime strikes and general strike of 1934. Between 7,000 and 8,000 American Federation of Labor retail clerks are on strike in the city's
The third annual series of Review-of-the-News Conferences, conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, will be held in three suburban areas starting Wednesday, Sept. 28.

A man was killed and two other persons, one a woman, were painfully injured early yesterday when an 18-year-old youth, driving without a license, fell asleep at the wheel of his automobile and the car mounted the sidewalk, striking the three, who were waiting for a bus.

An Autumn-sized fleet of ninety yachts raced under Autumnal conditions today in the thirty-ninth annual Fall regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, the twenty-first contest-and last but two-of the 1938 Long Island Sound Y. R. A. championship series.
