By "conscripting" Marseille dockers of French nationality, the French Government has this week done more than merely assure the functioning of dock service-it has asserted its authority and made it clear to the workers and their unions and delegates that ultimately the law is on its side.

AN experiment seeking "the reinstatement of opera as an integral part of our contemporary theatre" will be undertaken in England this Fall. It is worth attention here, not only because some of the personnel will be drawn from this country, but also because the aspirations that underlie the undertaking may leave an impression on America's opera and lyric theatres eventually.

With builders announcing the opening of new groups of homes and several developers and brokers reporting many sales and the opening of model dwellings, Fall realty activity in New Jersey last week continued at a brisk pace.

LAST Sunday this page carried some observations on Mrs. Frank G. Logan's "Sanity in Art" movement. The group formed to further Mrs. Logan's anti-modernist campaign is now holding its first exhibition in Chicago.

The need of a world of law and order and of the development of an American system for peace was emphasized by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in accepting, in a note made public today, the invitation of Peru for the United States to participate in the eighth international conference of American States at Lima on Dec. 9.

More than 200 automobile editors of newspapers and magazines had a confidential look today at the Studebaker cars for 1939, which will be announced to the public through the newspapers in the course of the next few weeks.

How can a family live on $471 a year? That question puzzled many citizens this week after the National Resources Committee estimated in a report that the average income of the poorest third of Americansthat is, the mean income of the least fortunate 13,000,000 families 1935-36.

The Columbia football squad will engage in its first drill of the Fall season at Baker Field tomorrow in preparation for the Light Blue's fifty-ninth campaign. Quartered in the Manor House since Thursday, the squad of forty has completed all the preliminaries of posing for pictures, undergoing physical examinations and fitting equipment and is ready for immediate advanced work.

Stung by the whip anC scriving his utmost, El Chico yesterday gave proof of his championship caliber when he conceded weight to all of his opposition at Aqueduct and yet smashed home first in the $13,500 Junior Champion Stakes to maintain his unblemished record.

Fall is the season when suspenders replace, to major extent, the belt as the chief means of trousers support. This year the makers of braces have tied in very strongly with the new fabric trends, with the result that diagonal weaves, herringbone patterns and tweed effects can be purchased to match suitings. Leather and combinations of leather and fabric have a niche in the Fall picture.

The up-swept hair-do has turned out to be a mammoth bandwagon on which Paris couturiers, American designers and most of the feminine inhabitants of Manhattan and outlying districts seem to have hopped. Park Avenue, Tenth Avenue, Harlem and probably Chinatown appear to have adopted it with equal promptness and enthusiasm.

Everton gained its fifth victory in the English Football League today. Brilliantly led by young Tom Lawton, the league's leading goal scorer last season, the Lancastrians toppled Arsesnal, 2--, in a rousing battle at Highbury. Everton holds the distinction of being the only squad in the league's four divisions to have captured maximum points in the campaign.

Political eyes in the United States will be riveted on Maryland and Georgia next week, where Democratic voters in two State-wide primary elections will give the answer to the country's most interesting current question: Is President Roosevelt to salvage anything substantial out of his campaign to "purge" less than 100-per-centers from Congress or, from an immediate viewpoint, is it to be written off as a failure.

The Federal court was asked yesterday to decide whether the publishers or the authors of a song are the owners of it after its copyright expires in a suit filed by Shapiro, Bernstein Co. over "Come Josephine in My Flying Machine," a 28-year-old lyric.

WITH the increasing popularity of the Merritt Parkway, in Connecticut, State highway engineers are busy at work on the remaining portion between Norwalk and Bridgeport. Highway Commissioner William J. Cox recently announced that he expected a threemile link to Westport to be opened in time for the football season.

Dominick LaValle, manufacturer of women's fine shoes, yesterday signed a contract for substantial space in the Apparel and Accessories Building at the World's Fair, according to announcement by Joseph Love, president of Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc.

The trial of James J. Hines was resumed at 10:51 yesterday morning with Lyon Boston, son of Charles A. Boston, former president of the American Bar Association and the New York County Lawyers Association, on the witness stand. Mr.
The chief operation in the Foreign Exchange Market today was the sale of pounds sterling by holders on the European Continent who purchased United States dollars with the proceeds.
MISS BALDWIN has done it again, and better than ever. Her setting is one which most of her readers will like very much-a big, fashionable, mountain hotel, viewed from the working side.

IT is now six years since Japan, having cut off the northeastern provinces of China and set up the puppet State of Manchukuo, undertook to make an imposing modern capital for that State out of the obscure railway junction town of Changchung.

Final arrangements have been completed for the tea, bridge party and fashion show to be held Saturday afternoon at the Claremont Inn, Riverside Drive, in behalf of St. Christopher's Inn, a charitable institution at Graymoor, N. Y., conducted by the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement at Garrison.
But a breath of air, with nature cat-napping on the brink of slumber, spoiled the third race today of the British-American Cup match for the six-meter sloops.
The annual Autumn bridge party in behalf of the Mariners' Family Asylum in Stapleton, S. I., will take place on Oct. 8 at the Whitehall Club in the Whitehall Building.

Robert E. Lewis, director of men's activities and superintendent of the parish house and church buildings of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, died yesterday of a heart attack at Cornwall, N. Y. He was 52 years old.

First reorders for Fall dry goods were booked by wholesalers last week in sufficient volume to indicate which sections of the country have benefited from the moderate business upturn and which types of merchandise are needed. Dry goods selling agents and wholesale buyers both reported, however, that rural retailers were operating so cautiously that it is extremely difficult to shape merchandising policies.

In a wildly applauded speech at the Nazi congress in Nuremberg Field Marshal Goering proclaimed Germany's military invincibility and ability to withstand a blockade. He declared that the Reich would no longer permit harm to be done to its brothers in the Sudeten German area and referred to the Czechs as "a chit of a race devoid of culture." [Page 1, with extracts from speech on Page 38].

I WANTE TO TRAVEL. By John Gibbons. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Dodge Publishing Company. $3. STEVENSON'S remark, to the effect that the important thing in travel is to go rather than to arrive, has evidently been taken more literally by the writer of this book than the author of "An Inland Voyage" intended.

In a dramatic contest witnessed by crowds estimated at 400,000, the lifeboat crew of the Italian liner Conte di Savoia pulled away easily from eight competitors yesterday afternoon, winning the twelfth annual International Lifeboat Race for the fourth time in the last five years of competition.

Miss Mary Bassett Keyes, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth N. Hotchkiss and a granddaughter of Charles E. Hotchkiss, a New York lawyer, was married this afternoon to Walter Dimont Rector, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dimont M. Rector of Delanson, N. Y.
Dr. John Clement Heisler, Emeritus Professor of Anatomy at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in West Philadelphia. He was 76 years old.

Husky Jimmy Snyder, 28-year-old former milk wagon driver from Chicago, won the 100-mile national dirt track championship auto race at the New York State Fair Grounds. today before close to 70,000 cheering fans. His time was 1:11:15.

South Carolina is to have a Congresswoman for the first time but she will not have a chance to legislate unless a special session of Congress is called. She is Mrs. Bessie M. Gasque of Florence, widow of Representative Allard H. Gasque of the Sixth District, who died several months ago.

Since insuring their savings accounts with the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, home-financing and thrift institutions which have afforded their investors this protection have increased their assets nearly $600,000,000, Nugent Fallon, general manager of the corporation, announced yesterday. Accounts up to $5,000 for each investor are insured by the corporation.

The American Savings and Loan Institute, educational and research division of the thrift and homefinancing institutions, will observe this week the sixteenth anniversary of its founding in Kansas City, Mo.

Attributing the rise largely to the construction of the Eighth Avenue subway under Queens Boulevard, Franklin E. Tyrrell, broker, said yesterday that last month the Forest Hills and Kew Gardens sections of Queens had the heaviest renting volume in many years.

More than 500 courses will be given in University Extension at Columbia University this year, James C. Egbert, director, announced yesterday. An evening course in "The English Bible" will feature the program.

President Roosevelt's rebuke of the Women's Rebellion which is now crusading to bar persons on relief from voting drew a retort today from Mrs. Sarah Oliver Hulswit of Suffern, who heads the organization.
Construction of two new wings which will nearly double the present capacity of Houston Hall, student union building at the University of Pennsylvania, will be started about Oct. 1.

Police have recovered $6,000 worth of drugs and cosmetics stolen in Brooklyn on July 1, it was revealed yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court when four men were ar- of raigned on charges of suspicion of receiving stolen property before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger and held for a hearing next Thursday.

Mrs. George Johnston of Chapel Hill, N. C., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Leigh Johnston, to Robert M. Gardiner of Big Flats, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meredith R. Gardiner of Germantown.
UNDECORATED: In Rome fifteen years ago Benito Mussolini pinned the green ribbon of the Order of St. Maurice and St. Lazarus on Henri Bernstein, French playwright.

To tne accompaniment oi loua applause, Mrs. David Wagstaff, president of the Tuxedo Kennel Club, today presented the President's Trophy, signifying best in show, to Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N. Y.

Not in many years has the Ohio political situation been as complicated as it is today, with all sorts of charges flying about. Most of these do not concern directly support or opposition to President Roosevelt.
Arter talking separately with both sides in the four-day-old department store strike, Mayor Angelo J. Rossi announced this afternoon that he felt "very hopeful" of an early settlement.

Miss Harriet Ashhurst of Philadelphia, sister of Mrs. Frederick J. Stimson of Dedham, Mass., wife of the former United States Ambassador to the Argentine, and a prominent member of the Summer colony here, died last night at the Stimson residence, the Weir, on West Street. The body will be taken to Philadelphia tomorrow.
All classifications of bonds drifted to lower levels in fairly active trading yesterday on the New-York

Miss Elsie Bradley Fowler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Raymond Fowler of Hudson View Gardens, and Charles Milton Henderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ludvig Henderson, also of New York, were married yesterday afternoon in the Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw.
Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in smaller volume than in the two
Dr. Beth L. Weilman of Iowa State University, voiced a warning today before the American Psychological Association that early environment could cause feeble-mindedness in children.

A man who was born forty-three years ago in a part of Austria that is now in Rumania was held by the immigration authorities when he arrived here yesterday on the liner President Roosevelt as a man without a country.

The battleship Arkansas and the training ship Wyoming, which have been anchored in the Hudson River for the last week, embarked more than 1,000 naval reserves yesterday morning and left for a two-week training cruise to Charleston. S. C.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges. Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustments.

King Victor Emmanuel of Italy has bought an etching, "La Bella Venezia," by John Taylor Arms, noted American etcher and president of the Society of American Etchers, according to announcement yesterday by Erwin S. Barrie, Commissioner of the United States Section of the Venice International Exhibition.

MALCOLM MacDONALD, Colonial Secretary. recently dropped out of the sky into the midst of his principal problem. Palestine. After a day spent conferring with high officials in Jerusalem. he rose into a coppery Palestinian dawn and winged his way back to London to confer with the Prime Minister and to announce in a wireless broadcast that "with God's help peace will be restored in the Holy Land."
Secret tests were completed in Crum Creek Valley, near here, this week with small models of a new type of
MR. TATE served Edison as a private secretary from 1883 to 1894. The present biography covers only this period, in some respects the most active of the inventor's life.

President Roosevelt, in what was viewed as a last-minute move in the drive to defeat Senator Tydings for renomination, ordered "right of way" by the PWA for two Maryland bridge projects. Secretary Ickes wired the instructions to the regional office in New York. [Page 1].

Optimistic that his visit to Brazil will aid United States-Brazil trade relations and lead to an increase of business, Warren Lee Pierson, president of the ExportImport Bank of Washington, after a three-day visit in Sao Paulo left today for Buenos Aires.

AN OPEN LETTER TO JEWS AND CHRISTIANS. By John Cournos. 183 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $2. BY expanding his "Epistle to the Jews," which appeared in the December Atlantic into "an open letter" to both "Jews and Christians," John Cournos has simply released a bomb of greater dimensions.

On Thursday the Catholic Young Women's Club will hold a meeting in its clubhouse, 641 Lexington Avenue, to complete arrangements for the celebration of its thirty-fifth birthday, to be observed Sept. 18.

Off to a flying start on the wings of a victory over the All-Stars last week, the New York Football Giants will begin their quest of the Eastern championship of the National Football League today when they oppose the Pirates at Forbes Field in Pittsburgh.
With a labor wage controversy of the first order due to come to a head on Oct. 1 and with earnings continuing to show unsatisfactory results, the outlook of American railroads remains dark.

Fordham University begins its ninety-eighth academic year tomorrow when 800 freshmen and sophomores of Fordham College report for scholar brevis. Total university registration for the new year is expected to show a normal increase and reach about 7,800.

Three Cuban Army planes took off this morning from Camp Columbia for Mexico City as part of Cuba's goodwill representation at the celebration of Mexico's Independence Day. The planes were piloted by Captain Tomas Alvarez, Captain Florencio Ceballos and Captain Manuel Orta.

INTERNATIONALLY speaking, the London Stock Exchange is not what it used to be. Once it was one of the world's most independent and influential institutions. It set the beat for the rhythm of the world's finances, and it played second fiddle to no one.

THE eighteenth annual National Air Races are now a part of history. In many ways this year's edition of the Henderson brothers' aerial extravaganza was one of the best they have ever staged, if not actually the best.

The home owner who has a lawn to make or remake can find no better time during the entire year to undertake the job than right now. Spring lawn building is largely a matter of staying in an old rut-just as the planting of peonies in Spring used to be before the better results obtained by Fall planting became generally recognized.
President Eduard Benes broadcast td Czechoslovakia tonight an appeal for order among all factions to prevent dangers to all Europe. He also stressed his wish for friendship with Germany.

Production of silver in Mexico in June amounted to 13,612,000 ounces, compared with 6,244,000 in May, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Although figures for July are not available yet, it is reported in the trade that output in that month and in August continued at a high rate.

Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker gave a dance tonight at Penwood Farm, their place here, for Miss Nathalie Simpkins, debutante daughter of Willard S. Simpkins of Bedford Hills. Receiving with Miss Simpkins, who was attired in rose taffeta, and Mrs. Tucker were the Misses Cornelia L. Baker of Brookline, Mass., cousin of the debutante;

The course to be taken by the monopoly inquiry will be described by Richard C. Patterson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, in an address at the seventh annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Sept. 26 and 27, it was announced yesterday by Arthur R. Tucker, managing director of the institute.
Mrs. Adelaide Drusilla Brett died here last evening in her eighty-sixth year at the Memorial Hospital, to which she had been taken after breaking her leg in a fall several weeks ago.

The Netherlands press views the Czech problem calmly, although it is being followed closely, and sympathy for the Czechs is outspoken. The Netherlands shows less alarm than neighboring countries at the news from Germany.

An issue which they had hoped was won, but which has been reopened by Amendment Seven of the proposals drawn up by the Constitutional Convention, confronts a number of women's groups as a new club season begins this week.
OFF THE STRAIGHT AND NARROW. By Caroline Bayard Colgate. 256 pp. New York: Lee Furman. Inc. $2.50. AN old note of reticence runs through this book, a kind of understatement that amounts to humility.

Compared with the active role being played by Great Britain in the Czechoslovak dispute, that of France has recently appeared almost passive. Premier Edouard Daladier's government has been content to permit the British-who in a sense volunteered for the task-to take the lead in the negotiations between the Czechs and the Sudetens and with the German Government.
An old idol, on the comeback trail, gave a crowd of nearly 13,000 spectators two of the most thrilling hours ever known in the national tennis championships yesterday.
The award of three scholarships to sons of Pennsylvania Railroad employes was announced yesterday by H. A. Enochs, chief of personnel of the railroad.

THE impish Charlie McCarthy, coached by Edgar Bergen, continued his run on the wave lengths throughout the Summer while many of the veteran contenders dropped from the race. As a result, Charlie is about ten points in the lead as the new season opens, according to the latest popularity polls.
The engagement of Miss Constance Sinclair Tallmadge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hobart Tallmadge of this place, to Charles Frederick Porzig has been announced by her parents.
Some 2,500 New York women-all volunteers-have just spent three busy days helping in health registration at the city's elementary schools in advance of the troop, back to classrooms tomorrow.

A PIECE of cellophane crushed in the hand at a microphone is amplified to sound like a raging forest ffre. The rattle of a tin sheet sounds like the crash of a lightning bolt. And radio, which does these-tricks of sound to gain realism in drama, also can handle a political speech of local portent and amplify it to national importance.
IN a new volume of essays, "Self Portraits," Sigrid Undset extends her researches in the Middle Ages to include also sections of England as well as her own native Norway.

Chanting "We Want Roast Ox," several thousand hungry persons at a State Republican rally in a suburban park today broke through police lines, invaded a dining hall, hurled several tons of food across the hall and trampled it underfoot.
President Roosevelt was called upon today by John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, to make good his 1933 promise and tell the nation where he has been wrong in his New Deal program.

The full membership of the committee which will draft the tentative platform for the Democratic State Convention to be held in Rochester Sept. 29 and 30 was announced yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and national chairman.

At today's session of the Oxford Group Assembly for Moral Rearmament Bernard Bourdillon, British delegate to the 1919 Paris Peace Conference, said: "Here at Intertaken we have seen that the minorities problem in Europe is not an isolated question requiring technical skill for its solution.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, outwardly unperturbed by the grand jury indictments which yesterday charged him with "misbehavior in office," visited his office at City Hall today and conferred for nearly two hours with Joseph Sharfsin, the City Solicitor.

Mickey Haslin's fourth hit, a single to left, scored Les Powers from third base in the ninth inning today to break a 5-5 deadlock and give Jersey City's Giants a 6-to-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

State police and Tangipahoa Parish officials investigated today the shooting near his Tangipahoa River camp early this morning of James H. Morrison, a Hammond attorney, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Sixth district at the primary next Tuesday.

Feeling that those dear old doleful Dodgers had something coming to them in large quantities, the Giants opened both barrels at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and what poured out just about swept Burleigh Grimes and his befuddled flock seven lengths behind total oblivion.

Mrs. David Wagstaff, president of the Tuxedo Kennel Club, entertained at a buffet dinner tonight at Ledgelands, her home here, for the visitors and officials at the annual Tuxedo Dog Show held today at the Horse Show Ring. Mrs. George B. St. George gave a luncheon for the visitors.

An evening School of Politics, planned especially for and by business and professional women, is included among the Fall activities of the Women's National Republican Club. The first of its weekly meetings will be on Tuesday at 8:30 P. M. at the clubhouse, 3-West Fifty-first Street.

Because expert realty appraisals are of the "utmost importance" in a great many court cases, the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers has taken steps to guarantee that persons called upon for such testimony are equipped to gives proper judgment and are of unquestionable integrity with relation to that judgment, points out Herbert U. Nelson,

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in August totaled 558,634 tons, an increase of 117,064 tons over July, the year's low point, but a decrease of 549,224 tons when compared to August, 1937.
ITALY is attempting to stamp out the netting of migrating birds. The peninsula lies on two of the principal routes between Africa and Europe and hundreds of species visit it every Spring and Autumn.
New work'ss organized young Republians bid openly tonight for repreentation on the State ticket with a endorsement of Alfred L. Simon, aratoga County District Attorney, or Attorney General.

The opening of the schools in the United States means the mobilization of a peaceful-or relatively peacefularmy of about 30,000,000. This number is nearly equal to the entire population of the country at the beginning of the Civil War.
George Miner, making his first start of the fading campaign, pitched a two-hit shut-out for Syracuse today and ended the Bears' nine-game winning streak with a 2-0 victory.

SCOTLAND'S caber-tossers who can be seen at most of the Highland games, differ from the American variety as usually seen at the Caledonian games. The caber is a heavy tree-trunk, sixteen to twenty feet long, which has to be lifted and tossed.

About fifty passengers on a threecar New York Central local train, en route from Croton to Grand Central Station, were delayed for ten minutes when two of the cars were derailed at 12:53 P. M. yesterday as the train was leaving the station at 138th Street and Park Avenue.

The yacht racing season on Moriches Bay came to an end today with the sailing of the Commodores Cups events off the Speonk Shore. the final program of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club brought forty-one boats to the starting line.

Miss Barbara Russell Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshal Stearns of this place, was married to Dr. Chauncey Johnson Pattee of Montreal here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church. The Rev. Merrill Clarke, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

In an effort to stimulate private low-cost frame house construction the National Lumber Manufacturers Association has just completed here a group of eight small homes ranging in "basic cost" from $2,212 for a "garden apartment" to $3,596 for a three-bedroom house.

HOW tiny animal hairs made to stand on end, like the hair on a cat stalked by a dog, would yield television images of the same brightness and size as motion pictures is revealed in a United States patent (No. 2,128,631) granted to Ronald D. Eaton of Cambridge, Mass.

The primary campaign in Manhattan's Sixteenth Congressional District, most important of the city's primary fights, will swing into its final week today with Representative John J. O'Connor and his Democratic and Republicanopponents all making strenuous

Five officials of the United States Housing Authority are scheduled to speak in a series of lectures on contemporary housing and rehousing to be given at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, during the Fall term which begins during the week of Oct. 3.

Miscellaneous furnishings for the Fall season appear designed to add color to men's clothing. At the same time comfort and practicability have not been overlooked. Pajamas are colorful, ranging all the way from broad contrasting stripes to neat figures and geometrical patterns.

JAMES I is remembered as a good poet and a good king. In poetry he was the first of the Scottish Chaucerians and in many ways the freshest. His romantic poem of his courtship of the Lady Joan Beaufort while he was in prison ("The Kingis Quair." i. e.,
CHIEF JUSTICE WAITE'S contributions to American constitutional law and politics are to be found largely in his interpretation of police power and of the commerce clause.

The Citizens Committee of Downingtown has won its fight against the erection of a new postoffice. Charles W. Nice, chairman of the committee, said that he received a letter today from Washington stating that the Postoffice Department had abandoned a project which would have cost $80,000.
The energetic skippers of the North River Power Squadron seem to be having a good deal of success in 'making into yachtsmen practically all of the members of the Downtown Athletic Club.

Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour and her daughters sailed yesterday on the Volendam. They will be at Lausanne, Switzerland, for the Winter. Mrs. Brookfield Van Rensselaer will return from Europe next week and will be at the Pierre.

A public hearing on a Federal project for the improvement of Jamaica Bay will be held in the Chamber of Commerce Building, 1,920 Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway, on Wednesday at 11 A. M., it was announced yesterday by army engineers of the New York district.

The new Department of Music to be established at Adelphi College here at the opening of the 1938 term on Sept. 19 will have as the instructor of piano Henri Deering, noted American pianist and teacher, President Paul Dawson Eddy announced today.
There is no confirmation here tonight of troop movements on the Austro-Czech frontier that were reported in London and Paris other than those incidental to the army manoeuvres.

The Fall season of free illustrated lectures opened yesterday at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park with the presentation of the subject, "Exhibiting and Judging of Flowers," by Ethel A. S. Peckham, honorary curator of the garden.

Emil Gall's ninth-inning single chased Johnny Leshnick across the plate with a run that enabled the Bushwicks to beat the Metropolitan Baseball Association All-Stars, 2-1, at Dexter Park yesterday for the semi-pro baseball hospital fund. Thirty-eight ball players participated in the game.

THE ENJOYMENT OF MUIRDER. By William Roughead. 310 pp. New York: Sheridan House. $2.50. THAT eminent Scottish bar-, rister William Roughead has enjoyed murder for a great many years. As editor of several volumes in the Notable British Trials series and as author of "Twelve Scots Trials" and other books he has long excelled in the art of passing that enjoyment on to the public.

Charles Cruft, founder of the world's greatest annual dog show, died today at the age of 86. His first show, held fifty years ago at the Royal Aquarium in London, attracted only 500 entries, but in recent years the number has been swelled to more than 10,000.
Riverside Drive continues to provide an important share of Manhattan's realty activity. Another sale of considerable interest was consummated there yesterday.

IN THIS city is a manuscript of a book about Liszt, by one of his real and great pupils, which should be published. The author is the pianist, the late Arthur Friedheim, a man of singular integrity and idealism, capable of the most thoughtful and sober judgments.

After two defeats Great Britain triumphed, 21-16 in the third Rugby test match. against South Africa today. The Springboks led, 13-3, at half time. In the first encounter at Johannesburg, South Africa won by 26-16 and last Saturday at Port Elizabeth the home fifteen gained a 19-3 decision.

Miss Eleanora Madeline White, daughter of Mrs. Ellen Lee White of Pasadena, was married today to David Walker Wear 3d, son of Colonel and Mrs. David Walker Wear of the Hotel Astor, New York, and Binghamton, N. Y. The ceremony was performed in Trinity Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Herbert V. Harris.
TELECASTS from the NationJal Broadcasting Company's transmitter atop the Empire State Building will be discontinued for an indefinite period following a program on Friday night from 8 to 9 o'clock.

An architect points out that when planning a new home, a study of lighting fixture types that can be combined with the architectural type of the house and the plan of interior decoration will assist the owner in carrying out the motif that characterizes his home.

The International Typographical Union opened its annual convention here today with a proposed "universal five-day law" among major items of business. The "five-day law" would provide that all future union contracts call for a forty-hour weekly work period. No change in existing agreements would be sought.

Miss Caroline Wemple, daughter of Mrs. William Yates Wemple of West New Brighton, S. I., and the late Mr. Wemple, was married yesterday to Herbert Turner Lorentzen, son of Mrs. Carl Christian Lorentzen of Englewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Lorentzen, in Randall Memorial Church, Sailors Snug Harbor. S. I.

At today's meeting of the Permanent Wheat Committee, at which Premier Mussolini presided, he announced that Italy's production per acre this year was the highest ever grown and that the total crop was only

Max Bedacht, general secretary of the International Workers Order, a fraternal organization, called on its leaders yesterday to keep the membership in "a state of permanent mobilization against the threat of reactionaries" in this country and to help elect "progressive" candidates to public office.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Mr. Groome appears to have read my letter about Fanny Kemble rather hastily, as it made no criticism of the author or her book-which I had not read, but which I hear on all sides is most delightful. I was merely taking mild exception to the reviewer's characterization of the American social life of the period.
AS days grow short and nights get cool, and Autumn tints appear at home, thousands of people are packing bags for long sunny days at sea and dining and dancing under the stars in tropical ports.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be - found through the usual channels of anthologies acid books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore, to select those of the greatest general interest.

The Chamber of Deputies -today approved by a vote of 79 to 59 the emergency bill submitted by President Arturo Alessandri. Three members did not vote. The bill grants special privileges to the President, including the authority to declare a state of siege.

County zoning, covering rural as well as urban land, designed to protect natural landscape beauty and the value of homes, is rapidly gaining favor in many States, points out Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

A DDITIONAL prizes have been announced by the American Contract Bridge League for its fourth annual metropolitan championship to be held at the Park Central Hotel in New York from Oct. 10 to 16. Winners of the various events will get free transportation to and entry in the league's Winter championship, which will be played this year in Cleveland, Ohio.

Fast times, despite a choppy racing surface, marked the Maryland Yacht Club's Star-Spangled-Banner Regatta today. George F. Schraft of Newton, Mass., turned in one of the fastest times of the day, driving his Chrissie II to victory in both heats of the race for hydroplanes with 225-cubicinch displacements.

Following is the text of an address to the nation broadcast today by President Eduard Benes: I am talking to you at a moment of international difficulties, the most serious since the World War, which have entangled not only Europe but also the greater part of the world.
Maitland de Gogorza, assistant art professor at Smith College, today was fined $300 by Judge John W. Mason for operating an automobile while under the influence of liquor.

To provide both quiet and atmosphere for student lawyers, Duke University has constructed a group of five log cabins, one of which will be a central recreational hall and the other four to domicile thirty-two students.

The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee upheld one of Senator Tydings's charges concerning the Maryland Democratic Senatorial campaign tonight, denied another and delayed decision on several others.

The marriage of Miss Betsy Ross Sargent, daughter of Mrs. M. Hatch Sargent of Montclair, N. J., and of Bradley E. Sargent of San Francisco, to Lieutenant Charles Randolph Kutz, U. S. A., took place here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Miller. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Pierce Ellis.

When the President told the newspaper correspondents the other day that he would not oppose a-"liberal Republican" as against a "conservative Democrat" for Senator-provided that Republican's "heart" was right-the statement was properly regarded as a mere extension of his political fraternity.

Endorsement of the National Retail Demonstration, to be held during the week of Sept 19, as likely to be a "strong factor in stimulating business" has been expressed by Governor Lehman in a letter to Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of the demonstration committee, the text of which was made public yesterday.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has announced a varied program of free lectures on art to be given at the museum from October to January, inclusive. Although most of the lectures are arranged in sequence for the benefit of those who wish to follow a regular course of study, any of them may be attended separately.

WITHIN a block or two of Columbia University, in New York, stands a large red building which houses the Jewish Theological Seminary. In a less pretentious structure in Philadelphia, Dropsie College, young men and women are taught Hebrew and cognate learning.

Comparatively few vacancies in single-family dwellings and apartments are found in many cities throughout the country from survey reports made this year by local realty boards to the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Announcement has been made here by Mrs. C. Wilson Love of Lakeland, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Love, to Eugene H. Catron of Denver and New York.

George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, announced today that members of railroad unions would meet in Chicago on Sept. 26 to take "such action as is necessary to effectively defeat" a proposal by railway operators to put into effect a 15 per cent wage cut on Oct. 1.

During periods of conservative dressing, that is, when suit fabrics are restrained and neutral, men have usually relied upon shirts and neckwear to lend dash and color to their outfits. This season, however, haberdashers advise greater care in the choice of linen and ties in order to prevent clashes with the bold patterns of fabrics.

THE MONUMENT" is a novel reflecting a world on the brink of unimaginable disaster. If you had not before read a word by this young English novelist you would only have to get well away into the opening paragraph to realize that here is a writer of fiction who should matter.

ROGER SHERMAN. Signer and Statesman. By Roger Sherman Boardman. 396 pp. Philadelphia: Univesity of Pennsylvania Pres. $4. NOT only as a member of the Federal Convention but as a statesman who gave thirty years of his life to solving problems of government,
The busiest freshmen week in the history of Manhattan College will start tomorrow with the registration of more than 420 new students.

More than 2,000 managers of savings and loan institutions, Federal Home Loan Bank officials and appraisers are expected in Chicago Nov. 16 to 18, when the United States Building and Loan League holds its forty-sixth annual meeting.

The Japanese reported today two sweeping advances toward the PeipingHankow Railway, which they hope to cut north of Hankow, Chinese military capital, as a major movement in their effort to capture the city.

As a new academic year gets under way tomorrow morning, New York City school officials find themselves confronted with the pressing problem of how to deal with the dual job holder within the educational system.

Late Summer and early Autumn, now conceded to be the best time of the year for sowing grass seed for all lawns, is a particularly advantageous season where shaded areas or steep slopes are to be put into turf.

To the Art Editor: IN reference to Mr. Jewell's statement that "because we are Americans, we have an American art," I beg to differ. Of what kind of art does Mr. Jewell speak? Is it music, painting, sculpture? And what about the applied arts?

The annual ball for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society was given this evening under the auspices of the Rhode Island branch of the society, of which Mrs. Welch, wife of Captain Leo F. Welch, commander of the Naval Training Station, is president.
The so-called Nazi revolt in Santiago, Chile, last Monday afternoon has called attention once again to the possibility of Nazi-Fascist ideologies taking root in the countries of South America.

Slammin' Sam Snead, leading money winner of the year, slipped. into the pacemaker's place at the end of the first thirty-six holes of the $4,000 Glens Falls open golf tournament today by virtue of a sparkling 66.

Current improvement in the jewelry field indicates Christmas holiday sales may rise 5 to 10 per cent above the corresponding period last year, according to authorities in the trade. Additional orders since the closing of the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association here have been favorable, following the curb placed on buying by the 12 per cent decline in retail sales during the first half of the year.
Cohasset, last year's winner, again took first honors in the women's national sailing championship for the Mrs. Charles Francis Adams Bowl as the six-race series ended today.

The possibility that drivers and helpers employed by wholesale grocers in making truck deliveries to customers may come under the jurisdiction of the Interstate Commerce Commission rather than the Department of Labor's division set up to carry out provisions of the new Federal Wages and Hours Law

Edward J. Graham, 28 years old, an unemployed railroad worker on relief, walked into the First Precinct police station on Bay Street and Newark Avenue shortly after 3 P. M. today and told Policeman Edward Finkle that he had killed his wife.

AMERICA confers no knightshoods, reserves its triumphal processions for round - theworld fliers and Channel swimmers, has no red ribbon to adorn the lapels of its legions of honor. In its own small way, the motion picture industry tries to compensate.

A series of exhibitions illustrating progress made in combating disease and accidents will open Thursday at the Mott Haven Health Center of the Department of Health, 349 East 140th Street, the Bronx, and continue through next June.

Joe Dusek of Omaha defeated Hank Barber, Syracuse grappler in the feature wrestling bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Dusek, who scaled 283 pounds, pinned his 228-pound rival with a body slam in 24 minutes 10 seconds.

ALTHOUGH her name has never decorated a theatre marquee or drawn a single patron to the box office, Sarah Schwartz is one of the most celebrated persons in Hollywood, and has played in probably more motion pictures than any other

Into the cheering, crowded and festive city of Amsterdam last week rode an open carriage drawn by six horses, carrying a 58-year-old woman gowned in rose brocade and fur. Her entry brought to a climax a week of celebration in The Netherlands, for just forty years ago last Tuesday Wilhelmina of Orange received in Amsterdam the crown of Queen.

In capital outlay budgets covering the period to 1944 submitted to the City Planning Commission the Department of Public Works proposes the construction of fifteen bridges at a total cost of $22,000,000 and the Department of Sanitation lists new motor equipment to cost $6,500,000, it was learned yesterday.
Some of the most startling things in the day's news happen at scientific congresses. A startling thing is something that is intended

Franklin Lacy Sheldon, 26 years old, a member of a prominent family, committed suicide by gas poisoning late yesterday afternoon in the kitchen of the third floor duplex apartment of his mother, Mrs. Oakley Sheldon of New York and Bethlehem, Conn., at 170 East Seventy-eighth Street.
A FINE and thoughtful novel, clear, well balanced, truly and deeply tolerant, James Gray's history of one woman's life has a reality which leaves the reader feeling as if he
Drums rolled and bugles sounded before 2,000 persons yesterday afternoon as the annual Army Relief Day benefit was held on the polo field on Governors Island.

More this season than in former years, society women of the North Shore, Larchmont and the Connecticut shorefront colonies have been taking an active interest in yachting, and the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club on Centre Island, at Oyster Bay, where the International six-meter races are taking place, is in the midst of the busiest season it has had in many years.

The Westchester County Recreation Commission's camp for children at Freedom Plains will not be reopened next Summer, and the county will have accommodations for 250 fewer children than this year unless the camps at Croton Point are enlarged, the commission said today.

Building plots in the Oak Hill Park development near Scarsdale, Westchester County, have been sold to Dr. Henry Houghton, head of the China Medical Board of the Rockefeller Foundation in Peiping, China; and Dr. George H. Wilbur, a New York dentist, it was announced yesterday by Harold Van Buskirk, Inc., builders and developers.

Abram Frank, an employee of the Postoffice Department for fortyeight years, died Friday in Presbyterian Hospital of a heart attack after a two-weeks' illness. He was 64 years old. His home was at 325 Riverside Drive.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Daugherty of Douglaston, L. I., formerly of Wollaston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Daugherty, to Edwin Bickford Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Hinchman Brooks of Akron, Ohio.

With the opening of a training school for seamen on Hoffman's Island, New York Harbor, the United States Coast Guard adds this month another to its many assignments. To provide a "trained and efficient personnel" for ships of the American merchant marine, the Maritime Commission has completed plans for training courses of seamen and has called upon the Cost Guard to provide
IN period rooms even minor furnishings are now being brought into agreement with the general scheme, a fact which is recognized in the appearance of new period-style cabinets.
EIGHT years ago we had the first volume of the Henry Adams letters, and now, after too long an interval, comes the second, and possibly final, collection.

IN this day of social experiment at too fast a pace for human adjustment, it is good to know that one nation at least in this distracted world foresaw the future and developed over a period of years by slow and careful trial and error an equitable social plan that appears to be workable.

James J. Johnston Jr., manager of the New York State heavyweight champion, Bob Pastor, was informed yesterday that the boxer had injured his leg early in the day while chopping wood in his traing camp at Saratoga Springs.
The touring Australian graphs cricket team scored 306 runs today against H. G. D. Leveson-Gower's eleven in the concluding firstmatch of the English cricket season.

Plans for the rededication Oct. 15 of the forty-acre county-owned Poundridge Reservation in honor of the late William L. Ward, who died in 1933 after thirty-seven years as Republican leader of Westchester County, were discussed today at an open-air meeting of the committee recently appointed by the Westchester Park Commission.

Army engineers receiving testimony on a proposal to deepen the western end of the State Barge Canal closed their records today after hearing arguments by Marco Smith, representing the Associated Railroads of New York State, that the proposal might drive railroads into government ownership.

FACED with the necessity of providing adequate quarters for the student body, which had increased in the last seven years from sixty-six to over three hundred, the trustees and friends of the Longy School of Music in Cambridge, Mass., have undertaken to raise $97,000.

The New York Curb Exchange team, which topped the Wall Street Soft Ball League in the season just ended, avenged its defeat of last year at the hands of the Lamson Brothers team by defeating the champions of the Chicago La Salle Street Cashiers' League 18 to 8 in Innisfail Park on Friday night.

As a prelude to registration by classes and formal convocation, which will take place at New Jer sey College for Women during the coming week, student club officers from the three upper classes will return to the campus Monday for an all-day conference on the fundamentals of campus leadership.

Cash subscriptions aggregating about $7,539,000,000 were received for the offering of $400,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent twelve-to-fourteen-year bonds and $300,000,000 of 1 1/8 per cent four-andthree-quarter-year notes made on Thursday, the Treasury Department made known today.

After winning six straight games on the road the Cubs came home today to take a 9-to-1 defeat at the hands of Cincinnati. The victory enabled the Reds to tie Chicago for second place in the National League.

OLD NEW ENGLAND CHURCHES. By Elise Lathrop. With drawings by H. T. Welsh. 171 pp. Rutland, Vt.: The Tuttle Publishing Company. $3. IN writing about old New England churches, Elise Lathrop has not confined her study to architecture, nor has she, on the other hand, included all the ancient ecclesiastical structures of New England in her book.

Home owners, more than usually lawn-conscious this year because of the inroads of Crab Grass resulting from growing conditions particularly favorable to this enemy of good turf, are again turning their attention to the problems of lawnmaking.

As they mounted guard along the frontiers, the question ran: Could diplomacy stave off war, or would the diplomats, as twenty-four years ago,

The United States Infantry team of ten shooting members put down the United States Marines in a hard-fought battle today to win the national rifle team match, final event of the national match program in progress here for the last three weeks.

MODERN photographers lean heavily on many accesseries, but when it is absolutely necessary to get the picture few gadgets can equal the reliability and convenience of a photoflash synchronizer. The sharp,

The Bees ended a four-game losing streak today by rallying to beat the Phillies, 6 to 5. A four-run drive in the fifth inning, of which a two-bagger by Debs Garms with the bases full was the climax, won the game.

One vital aspect of the European situation was clarified in a week of high-power manoeuvring over the future of Czechoslovakia. Britain, the great Have, was brought face-to-face with Germany, the great Have-not, on the issue of the readiness of each to proceed to actual war.

The Somerset County League of Women Voters will open its Fall season with a lawn party on Tuesday, when Mrs. George V. La Monte, president of the league, entertains members and their guests at her residence at Bound Brook, N. J. Mrs. L. H. Robbins, State president, and Mrs. M. Barus, State finance chairman, will be speakers at the meeting. Mrs. Kathleen H. McClure, membership chairman of the Somerset league, is directing the program.

WHAT is believed to be the rarest egg in the world has been acquired by the Natural History Museum in London. It is the only known egg of the extinct Lesser or Kangaroo Island emu, and was found about a century ago hanging in a sealhunter's hut on Kangaroo Island off the coast of South Australia.

FOUR weeks from today, according to present indications, the new season will get underway when Martha Graham presents her dance drama, "American Document," as a benefit for the New Masses magazine at Carnegie Hall.

Following is the schedule of important political events for the coming week: Monday Maine elects Governor and members of the National House of Representatives. Maryland nominates candidates for Governor, Senate and House.

The "Legitimate" Drama, if its devotees will permit a rough simile, was then a sturdy, healthy dog, flourishing its tail, the Movie, proud of its legitimacy, little realizing that in the fast coming years the tail would be wagging the dog.
Wilson Henry Lear, a leader in the hardwood lumber distributing industry, died in Abington Memorial Hospital today after an illness of seven weeks. He was 73 years old. His home was in Glenside.

Nearly 250 boys and girls from the five boroughs, between the ages of 8 and 17, all top winners in a quiz contest conduted by the Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department, enjoyed. a motion-picture party yesterday as their prize.
ON UNDERSTANDING PHYSICS. By W. H. Watson. 146 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.25. THE sole concern of philosophy, according to Professor Watson, is the clarification of meaning.
Ten Princeton teams in three branches of sport will engage in fifty-nine contests during the Fall season, according to the program announced by R. Kenneth Fairman, graduate manager of athletics.

Another attempt by the New Deal forces to influence Georgia voters to cast their ballots against Senator Walter F. George was seen today by his supporters in the announcement that President Roosevelt on Thursday had approved an allotment of $53,000,000 of WPA funds for a two-year road-building program in this State.

The marriage of Miss Eunice Burdick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Burdick of Newport, formerly of New York, to Richard Glenn Gettell, son of Raymond G. Gettell, dean of the University of California, and Mrs. Gettell of Berkeley, took place here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church.

DESPITE appearance to the contrary, the number of those interested in philosophy and religion is growing daily, and to these the publication of a Buddhist Bible is an event of major importance. For not only does Buddhist thought meet many of the conceptions and theories of modern science but in many respects it uses almost the language of present-day physical sciences.

Cooler weather, the seasonal influence of school reopening, and the fact that last year's sharp drop in business developed at this season combined to lift retail sales figures well above those of a year ago in most districts last week. While the gains were reported most consistently in agricultural districts,
The anti-Jewish campaign has been in progress since mid-July, but the Italian people are as much at a loss to account for it today as they were eight weeks ago.

About 350 persons attended exercises yesterday commemorating the 162d anniversary of the peace conference between Lord Howe of Great Britain and John Adams, Benjamin Franklin and Edward Rutledge of the Colonial States held during the American Revolution at Billopp-Conference House at the foot of Hylan Boulevard, Tottenville, S. I.
A complete statement of the attitude the Department of Justice toward the investigation into charges against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City is expected to be made soon by Attorney General Cummings.

As a prelude to registration by classes and formal convocation, which will take place at New Jer sey College for Women during the coming week, student club officers from the three upper classes will return to the campus Monday for an all-day conference on the fundamentals of campus leadership.

Cash subscriptions aggregating about $7,539,000,000 were received for the offering of $400,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent twelve-to-fourteen-year bonds and $300,000,000 of 1 1/8 per cent four-andthree-quarter-year notes made on Thursday, the Treasury Department made known today.

After winning six straight games on the road the Cubs came home today to take a 9-to-1 defeat at the hands of Cincinnati. The victory enabled the Reds to tie Chicago for second place in the National League.

Sales increases ranging from 5 to 20 per cent over the like period of 1937 were chalked up by retail druggists and other stores cooperating in the promotion of Nationally Advertised Brands Week, which closed last night, according to reports coming into New York. Those chains here, which used extensive newspaper advertising to promote specials for the occasion, reported that they had registered a "nice gain" over last year.
Despite appropriations by the recent Congress of $712,000,000 for "farm relief," signs are becoming apparent that the "farm problem" again will be a subject of debate in the coming session.

Father Anton Koroshetz, Minister of the Interior, has suspended the newspaper Pravda for an indefinite period for printing criticisms by its Prague correspondent of Germany's attitude toward Yugoslavia's ally, Czechoslovakia.
Use of the periodic quiz by teachers to impel their students to better work has little value, according to a two-year experiment conducted in college classes at Rhode Island State College.

Livestock trading was at a low ebb today, with prices holding nominally steady, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Only a small supply of hogs was on sale, with the good and choice 190-280-pound offerings selling at $8.75 to $9.30 a hundredweight. There was a holdover of 500 hogs from yesterday. The 180-pound and heavier hogs were up 20c-35c, and packing sows, up 25c-40c. Cattle and sheep were steady.

The hands of a past master in the dangerous sport of speed boat driving clutched steering wheels this afternoon on the Schuylkill and demonstrated to oncoming beginners just how championships are won and retained.

With the prospect that more shirts will be worn with French cuffs this Fall, cuff links will become a more important adjunct of men's apparel. Jewelers have brought out a variety of styles, most of which harmonize in some way with other items, such as collar pin, tie clasp or stick-pin. Colored stones can be used to match the tone of the shirt or tie.

Reinforced by the presence of Ace Parker, who left the Athletics last week, and Boyd Brumbaugh of Duquesne and Johnny Druze of Fordham, both of whom saw service against the Giants for the AllStars, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers are rounding into shape for the National Football League campaign.

Following is the schedule of important political events for the coming week: Monday Maine elects Governor and members of the National House of Representatives. Maryland nominates candidates for Governor, Senate and House.

A friend of ours, we'll call him Frank, just returned from a bass and pickerel expedition up in the Thousand Islands area, and while there he had a grand time with these scrappers, but he had a better time watching a friend of his, whom we'll call George, making his initial venture in the sport.
Governor Lehman issued today a proclamation designated Sept. 17 as Constitution Day. He urged general observance. His proclamation read:

The campaign of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations to protect the interest of members during the Constitutional Convention at Albany was a "complete success," according to a bulletin that is being sent by the committee to every public school in the city today.

The Newark Bears closed their regular season by dividing a doubleheader with the Syracuse Chiefs today, winning the opener, 3 to 1, and bowing in the nightcap, 5 to 3. The even break gave Newark, 1938 pennant winner, a lead of eighteen full games.

Despite the highest entrance requirements ever imposed by the four city colleges-Hunter, Brooklyn, City and Queens Collegesmounting enrollments indicate that undergraduate day session registration will reach a new high of more than 21,000 students for the approaching school year, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday.
The New York Civic Orchestra, conducted by Herman Neuman, gave a concert yesterday afternoon at the Federal Music Theatre. Emma Redell, soprano, was the soloist.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa Manor of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Antoinette Corroon, to Donald V. Reed, son of Frank L. Reed of Park Hill, Yonkers, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Reed.

Emil Ludwig has written to the committee directing plans for the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Eugenio Maria de Hostos that he proposes to write a biography of that famous writer and educator.
Eddie Simms of Cleveland and Jim Howell, Harlem heavyweight, will meet in the feature bout of the season's closing card at the Queensboro Arena tomorrow night.

In a wild and woolly scoring battle that never lost its dramatic tenseness until the Giants whisked over the clinching touchdown in the last quarter, New York's hope for the Eastern championship of the National Football League turned back the Pittsburgh Pirates, 27 to 14, before 17,340 at Forbes Field today.
Hervey B. Henwood was president and general manager of the Bank of Toronto, died after a short illness here today at the age of 65.

The celebration of governor's say at Camp Smith--here this afternoon by the 369th Infantry of Harlem attracted a record crowds for the season. More than 25,000 visitors, mostly from Harlem, saw the 1,100 Guardsmen of the Negro regiment, led by Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, pass in review before Governor Lehman.

Gilbert F. Butler of Roanoke, vice president in charge of traffic of the Norfolk and Western Railway Company, died in a Baltimore hospital early today after an illness of several weeks. His age was 60.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Carleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Carleton of this place, to William H. Sawyer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Sawyer of Worcester, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission, and his associate, Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig, both Democrats, are not impressed with Mayor La Guardia's offer to have them appointed to important posts under his jurisdiction, provided rapid transit unification is achieved and the commission abolished by the 1939 Legislature, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Catharine A. Allen, Princeton's oldest resident, will celebrate her 100th birthday tomorrow. Still in possession of all her faculties, she will entertain a few relatives and close friends in observance of the centenary.

Senora Salvadora de Bayle Somoza, wife of General Anastasio Somoza. president of Nicaragua, arrived late yesterday on the United Fruit liner Quirigua, accompanied by their three children, who are to be placed in schools in the United States.

Corlear Ave (13-3406 E), s w corner of 234th St, 96x100; Rose G Moser to Riverdale Housing Corp, 551 5th Ave. Hill Ave (17-5098). e s, 170 ft s of Blssell Ave, 35x102: William H Stahl to Frederick W Eggert Jr. 719 E 243d St. Union Ave, 1,079 (10-2670); J Chris Murray, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. Hobart Ave, 2,042 (15-4246): Charles S Beller, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker yesterday ordered several minor changes on the voting machine labels and sample ballots already prepared for Essex County's primary elections, and printers estimated today that the reprinting would cost the taxpayers between $25,000 and $30,000.
Senator Carter Glass disagreed emphatically today with President Roosevelt's suggestion that poll taxes be eliminated.

Postmaster General Farley has virtually abandoned hope that Senator Tydings will be defeated in Maryland's Democratio primary tomorrow and sees as little chance for the "purge" of Senator George in Georgia Wednesday, according to information reaching his "contacts" here.

Four political supporters of James H. Morrison, the bulletmarked Congressional candidate from Sixth Louisiana district, were free on parole today after an early morning arrest on charges of carrying concealed weapons.
Leaders of Jewish communities throughout Ontario met here today to discuss plans of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee to raise $5,100,000 for destitute European Jews.

The engagement is announced of Miss and Mrs Katherine Louise Hughes, daughter Avenue, of Mrs. Arthur S. Hughes of this Mr. and city and the late Mr. Hughes, to The R Richard Francis Hopkins of Roches- of New ter, N. Y.

President Roosevelt's effort to drive Millard E. Tydings from the Senate goes to the test today in Maryland's primary. Senator Tydings and his rival, Representative David J. Lewis, pressed last minute appeals and each of their campaign managers claimed the victory.

A better understanding of the laws applying to Canadian trade is needed in order that business transactions may be conducted with a minimum loss of time, effort and good-will, the Department of Commerce stated today, in announcing the completion of a study of those laws by its Division of Commercial Laws.
Guatemala and El Salvador have canceled the credentials of their delegates to the first Women's Educational Congress of Central America, which was opened yesterday.

In addition to those who attended the regular seven masses and the 4 P. M. vespers yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, several thousand men, women and children went to the cathedral to pay a tribute near his resting place to Cardinal Hayes,

The marriage of Miss Margaret Schieffelin Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Pardee of 133 East Eightieth Street, to Dr. Talcott Bates, son of Mrs. Willard Travell of this city, and the late Rev. H. Roswell Bates, will take place on the afternoon of Oct. 13 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

The Rev. Louis Clark, retired Methodist Episcopal minister of Soquel, Calif., was elected president of the American Sunbathing Association by unanimous vote today at the seventh annual national nudist convention being held at Camp Rock Lodge, near here.
The Rev. Dr. A. E. Breen, Professor of Hebrew and Scripture at St. Francis (Wis.) Seminary for nearly a decade, died late yesterday following a major operation. His age was 75.

Prince Arthur of Connaught, second child and only son of the Duke of Connaught and grandson of Queen Victoria, who had a notable career as soldier, governor general and personal representative of successive sovereigns, died here at his home in Belgrave Square early today at the age of 55.

The opening date and the jury of the 1938 Carnegie International Exhibition of Painting were announced yesterday by Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of fine arts of the Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, where the exhibition will be held.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., informed Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein today that he would "try to force a showdown, through the Postoffice Department," for a permanent settlement in the battle for supremacy between Newark and North Beach airports.

Winfield Sheehan, former Fox production chief, and Metro-GoldwynMayer have completed basic negotiations on a one-picture deal calling for Sheehan to produce "Florian," studio representatives disclosed today, and it is expected that papers will be signed early this week.

The Yaddo music period came to an end today with two concerts. The first was presented in the morning at the Yaddo Mansion and the second in the evening at the Saratoga Spa Theatre, in cooperation with the Saratoga Springs Authority.
Beckwith Havens, who made the first flight from Albany to New York with a passenger, in a Curtiss flying boat twenty-five years ago, will re-enact the flight next Sunday, carrying the same passenger.

Short covering featured trading in corn last week on the Board of Trade here. Professional operators who had sold their grain at higher prices, started to take in their lines late in the last week in expectation that the report of the Department of Agriculture, issued on Friday, would show a substantial reduction in the indicated yield. By nature Benny Friedman is an optimist. If there is the slightest glint in a cloud Benny will discover it to be a silver lining. But as the City College coach gazed at the members of the Beaver squad at the Wayne Country Club here he reluctantly admitted: "For the first time I'm not fairly optimistic."

Miss Marie-Louise Fox, daughter of Mrs. John H. Grace of White W Plains, N. Y., and of the late David Fox of Suffern, has selected the afternoon of Oct. 4 for her marriage to Howard Frederick Van ga Bomel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Van Bomel -of Rye.

Frazier Jelke gave a large dinner at Eagle's Nest this evening. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt entertained with a tea at Beaulieu this afternoon for Captain Paul Serpette and the other officers of the French gunboat d'Entrecasteaux. Mr. and Mrs.

Army circles here understand that one of Germany's most closely guarded secrets is a new type of air bomb as revolutionary in character as it is mysterious in its composition and dangerous to enemy lives.
George Terrell, 40 years old, of 1,980 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, was killed at 4 o'clock yesterday morning by an automobile as he crossed Webster Avenue at 178th Street, the Bronx.

The Christian Church can play the same important role in preserving democratic institutions today that it did in early colonial times, when it was chiefly responsible for the establishment of representative government, the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, Stated Clerk Emeritus of the Presbyterian General Assembly,

Though dictatorships pride themselves on having achieved a degree of stability which is unattainable by democratic nations, they are really at the mercy of the mass opinion which they profess to scorn.

Henry J. Berusch has resigned as director of Lax Burgheimer Corporation and has organized the hosiery concern of H. J. Berusch Sons, Inc., in association With his sons, Howard and Philip. Offices are at 267 Fifth Avenue.

An increase of 12.7 per cent in major crimes in the first six months of this year over the 1937 period was reported today by the State Department of Correction. The rate of all crimes per 100,000 population rose from 3587.32 in 1937 to 3919.36, an increase of 9.3 per cent.

The National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today that 14 per cent of the men's apparel merchants reporting for the national business committee indicated that business in their section of the country was better than normal for August.
The German business press is intently occupied with the problem, "Wheat pact or wheat war?" and the United States stands in the foreground of the picture.

A sleek miniature speedboat weighing little more than ten pounds, of which half was accounted for in the handmade gasoline engine, raced to a new national record of 44.41 miles an hour yesterday afternoon at the fifth annual Walter Elliott Memorial meet conducted by the New York Society a of Model Engineers in Bowne Park, Flushing.

The first meet of the newly organized Duckhollow Foot Beagle Hunt, of which Angier Biddle Duke is master, was held this afternoon at Woodland Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Hunt Tilford Wagstaff in Monroe.

The giant Boeing clipper, ballasted to weigh its maximum of 82,500 pounds, easily accomplished a three-hour test flight today carrying 3,500 pounds more than yesterday when it bettered the American load record.

Shipments of gold to the United States amounted to f15,445,931 in the week ended on Thursday, so that since late July London sent out [Pound]55,500,000 of that metal, of which [Pound]42,000,000 has gone to America.

The general tendency in the foreign-exchange market here did not change this week. The pound sterling's rate fluctuated between 178.30 and 178.32 francs. The French stabilization fund easily kept the rate at this level, as the demand for foreign currencies was not large.

Hank Greenberg drove his forty-eighth and forty-ninth home runs of the season today and moved within one of the record-breaking 1927 pace set by Babe Ruth as the Tigers took both ends of a double-header from the White Sox, 10-1 and 5-3.
Tino Reboli won the fifty-mile professional motor-paced bicycle race in the national championship series at Coney Island Velodrome last night, and went into first place I in the standings.

Business activity showed further expansion in August, but the rate of increase in important lines of industry and trade has slackened in recent weeks, according to the Sepmember issue of the Survey of Current Business published by the Department of Commerce.
The Rev. Dr. Samuel McComb, rector of the American Episcopal Church in Nice, died in a nursing home here today. He will be buried in Cheltenham on Wednesday. He was 74 years old.

Chancellor Hitler now holds the world's markets in the hollow of his hand. Great Britain's financial markets remained steady but nervous this week, with dealings on a narrow basis until Friday, when the news that France was mobilizing her naval resources indicated the extreme gravity of the international situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the past two months you have carried an extensive three-cornered controversy, in which were involved Harold G. Aron, Maurice Deutsch and myself, on possible methods of solving the housing problem.
The newly formed Allied Newsdealers Association held its first public meeting last night at the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street. About 150 dealers attended.

An angry crowd stoned a group of British Fascists attempting to speak from a sound truck here today, injuring three of them. The crowd estimated at more than 5,000 surged around the would-be speakers, booing and hurling lighted fireworks, sticks, stones and pieces of coal at them.

An oriental bazaar modeled after a section of Istanbul will be a feature of the exhibition by the Government of Turkey at the World's Fair, according to plans approved yesterday by the fair's board of design.
