Scoring his first major triumph since he won the national open championship in 1936, Tony Manero of the Salem Country Club, Peabody, Mass., today captured the Glens Falls open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 281.

Magistrate Pinto in Coney Island Court the other day suspended sentence on a 19-year-old crippled beggar, collected money to send him to his small-town home and informed him that the "big city" is no longer the place to seek one's fortune.

Harvey M. Toy, president of the San Francisco Hotel Association, announced today that he had called a "law and order" meeting of representatives of local industrial and business, civic and women's groups for 11 o'clock tomorrow morning to organize against "lawless brutality and mob violence" in the department store strike which began last Wednesday.

The Bourse's tendency is one of depression but the price decline is small considering the seriousness of the international situation. This relative steadiness is accounted for by the reduced turnover and the complete lack of nervousness.

The German wholesale price index on Aug. 31 was 105.9, against 106 on Aug. 24. In the first eight months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17.

New York City residents who may still have a ringing in the ears occasionally from last September, got a slight taste, yesterday of what Los Angeles is going to get next week as more than 700 Legionnaires embarked on special trains for the twentieth national convention of the American Legion in the Coast city
Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary, broke his long silence on foreign affairs today with a warning to Germany not to misunderstand the British public mind in the present crisis.
Domingo Faustino Sarmiento, Argentine statesman and educator, was honored tonight at exercises held by the Pan American Union to mark the fiftieth anniversary of his death. Tributes by Dr. Felipe A.

Miss Jane Todd, member of the Assembly from Westchester County and vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, predicted today that women would play an important part in the Republican State convention this month at Saratoga Springs.
Who that ever studied a foreign language according to traditional cut-anddried methods hasn't chafed at the teachers who kept his nose in a grammar when he wanted to experiment and explore;

From current indications, newspaper advertising during September will make a more favorable comparison with the like period of 1937 than any month has in some time, according to reports from agencies and retail stores.
The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for August, based on the average for 1930 as 100, was 99.5, against 100.6 for July and 111.4 for August, 1937.

The money market here is extremely quiet. Last week brought no change in rates. Call money fluctuated between 2 and 2 1/4 per cent. Bank acceptances are quoted at 2?? per cent and Treasury Bills at 2 1/2 per cent.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Katherine E. Stowers of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janice Medeleene Stowers, to DeLacey Burdette Hummel of New Haven, Conn., son of Mrs. O. G. Hummel of Elkhart, Ind., and the late Mr. Hummel.
Mrs. Rigan McKinney's 9-yearold chestnut gelding Ibn B. Pat carried off the hunter championship at the Ninth Annual Soldiers and Sailors Club horse show at the Bright Home Farm today.

Interpretations of United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt's speech at Bordeaux, France, on Sept. 3, attributing to him the statement that France and the United States were "indefectively united in war as in peace" were withdrawn today by newspapermen who reported them.
If the drift of the Czech-Sudeten crisis continues to provoke alarmist apprehensions abroad, there is nothing in the conduct of Berlin street crowds to suggest a corresponding panicky feeling here.

The Good Shepherd nine of Inwood gained the final round of the senior Catholic Youth Organization baseball competition by shutting out the St. Philip Neri club of the Bronx, 5-0, at Mosholu Field yesterday. In the other semi-final,

A drop in the wholesale prices of middle-class quality fur coats will be revealed here next week at the annual fashion show of the national Fur Week Council. The following percentage price declines since the last show are expected:

Mr. and Mrs, Henry W. Lowe of 435 East Fifty-second Street have announced the engagement of Mrs. Lowe's daughter, Miss Alice Dunning, to H. Ashton Crosby 3d, son of Mrs. Atwood Violett of New York, and of the late H. Ashton Crosby Jr.

The real need of the world today to insure peace is moral and spiritual rearmament as set forth recently by thirty-three members of the British Parliament, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Of all the tributes paid to the late Cardinal Hayes the most eloquent was the silent presence of the thousands who stood in line each day as he lay in state, waiting to pass his bier and "whisper a prayer for his immortal soul," Mgr. William E. Cashin, rector of St. Andrew's Church, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A man and woman who rented a cottage near the shore of Little Peconic Bay on Saturday night were found dead of bullet wounds tonight on the beach near the cottage. After an investigation, Police Chief Otto Anrig of the town of Southold said the deaths appeared to be murder and suicide. Dr. J. Mott Heath, Suffolk County Coroner, ordered an inquest tomorrow.

The Washington Redskins, National Football League champions, today eked out a 26-to-23 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles. The Redskins' Slinging Sammy Baugh completed eight of nine passes before a dislocated shoulder forced him from the game in the second quarter.

Austria's authorities, mindful of Marshal Hermann Goering's dictum to "waste nothing," have ordered that the grass from the plots between the trees on Vienna's numerous avenues be carefully cut and collected.

The Phillies and the Bees split a double-header at Shibe Park today. Philadelphia won the first game, 11-2, when Hugh Mulcahy scattered twelve Boston hits, while his mates thumped the offerings of three visiting hurlers for sixteen safeties.

District Attorney Charles J. Ranney said today that he planned to bring J. Richard (Dixie) Davis here to testify before the Rensselaer County grand jury in connection with the slaying of Jules Martin.

More than 800 religious teachers of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn attended the annual vesbers heralding the opening of schools yesterday afternoon at the St. James Pro-Cathedral, Jay and Chapel Streets, Brooklyn.

The primary campaign swung into its final week yesterday, with James H. Fay, one of the principal figures in the only primary contest of magnitude, campaigning over the radio. Mr. Fay is fighting John J.
Dennis O'Brien, one of Corinth's oldest business men, former hotel owner, paper mill owner, banker and county and village Democratic political leader, died early today at his home here.

Establishment of a WPA project t to survey the extent and character of unemployment in the Wall Street district was urged yesterday by the Financial Employes Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. affiliate.

Murray Lifshey, at the wheel of his forty-foot Sunya II, displayed remarkably accurate skill as a navigator on tne Hudson River yesterday to win the Bear Mountain cruiser race and the Jules Heilner Trophy. Along the course from West 153d Street to Iona Island and return, a distance of fifty-eight nautical miles, Lifshey was at variance from his predicted log by only nine minutes of errors in passing the control points.
Supply contracts valued at $2,111,060 were awarded during the week ended Sept. 8 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Walton S. Smith of this place, formerly of Elizabeth, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rebecca Smith, to Arthur M. G. Moody, son of Professor Lewis F. Moody of Princeton and the late Mrs. Moody.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fleming Walsh of 40 Buckingham Road, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rhetta Louise Walsh, to John Emerson Asch, son of Mrs. William Asch, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Asch.

Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Egan of 178 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Egan, to Louis C. George, son of Mrs. Louis W. George of Woodside, Queens, and the late Mr. George.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's brief reference to the Sudeten issue in his speech this morning following upon Field Marshal Hermann Goering's address yesterday has increased the tension here and prepared everybody for a crisis.

In a speech today before 50,000 Mexican workers assembled in Mexico City's bull ring, John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, said that the United States was in danger of a fascist movement.

Near-by deliveries of lard sold last week at new low levels for the season on the Board of Trade. Liquidation by holders of September, October and December contracts was liberal, and it disclosed a lack of aggressive support until late in the week, when good buying appeared, based on the strength in corn and the strained political situation in Europe.

Warning that the present trend in our government might lead to dictatorship, with drastic curtailment of liberties, the Rev. Charles A. W. Brocklebank said yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie Protestant Episcopal Church.

To facilitate its own financing on favorable terms and for the sake of business recovery, as well as in the interest of the stability of the nation's financial institutions, the United States Government is committed definitely to continuation of its present policy of low interest rates for an indefinite period, in the opinion of Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance.

At a tea at their home this afternoon Mayor and Mrs. Charles W. Holton of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Estile Holton, to Thomas Chase Homan of Chatham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Van Ness Homan of Forest Hills, Queens.

Largely because of the increase of about 11 per cent in the price paid to farmers for milk, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose last week for the fourth consecutive period and stood on Saturday at 80.7, against 80.4 a week before.

At odds with Gilbert Miller over his forthcoming production of J. B. Priestley's "I Have Been Here Before," the Dramatists Guild charged yesterday in a prepared statement that Mr. Miller had failed to inform the playwright that his contract would be in violation of his obligation as a Guild member. Mr...

Because Mel Harder dropped a 4-3 decision after Bob Feller subdued the Browns in the opener of a twin bill, 6-2, the Indians fell a half-game behind the winning Boston club today in the American League's second-place race.

Monroe St., 244; Annie Zwedling to Central Savings Bank; mtg 512,200, not to merge in fee ($12.50). Attorney St, 147-149; Bowery Savings Bank to Leon Kritz, 159 Attorney St. ($1.50). 29th St. 227-9 W; Charles C. Moore, trustee, to Albert B. Gross, Majestic Apartments, 72d St. and Central Park West ($1,800).
Windows in seven wholesale fur shops were blown out yesterday morning by two bombs placed in doorways at 231 and 243 West Twenty-ninth Street, a fifteen-story building with two entrances.

The Republican National Committee asserted in a statement issued today that, as a result of the application of the National Labor Relations Act, the number ,of industrial strikes in 1937 more than doubled that of 1936.

After a fruitless search. of several hours for 3-year-old Donald Farrington, who disappeared from his farm home today, authorities considered the possibility that he might have been "picked up" by a passing motorist.
Louis E. Reoux, cashier of the Emerson National Bank and the oldest banker, in point of service, in Warren County, died in his home in Warrensburg this morning of a heart attach. He was 66 years old.
The trend of British domestic trade is becoming more favorable, and now there is reason for believing that the downward curve of the recession has flattened out.
The Baltimore Orioles broke their Roosevelt Stadium jinx in the nightcap of a double-header today to gain an even break with the Jersey City Giants in the International League finale.
Two important Building projects will be started in Westchester County this week. They will cost $4,000,000 and were made possible by Federal Government loans.

Representative Bertrand H. Snell of Potsdam, recently retired minority leader of the House of Representatives, will head a Republican Speakers' corps to address numerous "Constitution Day" rallies throughout the State on Sept. 17.
The volume of France's foreign trade increased in August. Imports were 3,709,000,000 francs, against 3,501,000,000 in July and 3,179,000,000 in August, 1937.

Maine, which in 1936 lost something of its reputation as the "barometer" State by electing a Republican Governor and Senator in September and being one of the two States which voted for the Republican nominee for President in November, will hold its election tomorrow.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,990,520,550.

The feeling here concerning the New York Stock Exchange remains optimistic. It is believed that but for the difficulties in Europe, the tendency of prices would be to firmness. The prospects for Fall appear to be satisfactory, owing to the measures taken by the government.
ANDERSEN-On Sept. 9. at Peekskill, N. Y., Mary (nee Addeley), beloved mother of the Rev. Henry J. Andersen, S. J., and Sister Mary Saint Tarcisius, R. G. S. Funeral on Monday. Sept. 12.

Five hundred Catholic War Veterans in the metropolitan area and representatives of other veteran groups held memorial exercises yesterday afternoon in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, to honor the Maryland troops who were killed in the Battle of Long Island 162 years ago.
The Yanks ran into something of an enigma at Griffith Stadium today as they celebrated their last appearance of the year here by losing to the Senators.
Prices of cotton declined last week into new low ground for the current recession which began early in July. The lowest prices were recorded on Saturday.
Lieutenant Harold Dietz of Bangor, Pa., 30-year-old Army Air Corps pilot, was killed in sight of his father and brother today when his plane crashed at Easton Airport during a flying circus.

The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee held today that M. Hampton MaGruder, Collector of Internal Revenue at Baltimore, had violated the Civil Service Act in calling employes of his office together and apprising them of his intention to support Representative David J. Lewis in the Maryland Senatorial race. The charge against Mr. MaGruder was filed by Senator Tydings, whose defeat is sought by President Roosevelt.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at about 40 per cent of capacity, against 44 per cent in the week before. Mills generally were idle on Labor Day, but had opportunity to make up some 16st time afterward, and thus tonnage output decreased less than would be suggested by the holiday.

An appeal for religion to concern itself with "real worship" was made by the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, in his sermon yesterday morning.
Mrs. Frederic L. Lutz heads the committee in charge of a tennis party to be held in the Cove Neck indoor court on Sept. 23 for the benefit of the Oyster Bay Visiting Nurse Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Leon Abbett of Glen Cove, L. I., and Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner Winslow White of Oyster Bay, L. I., will give a dinner dance for their debutante daughters, the Misses Margery Peabody Abbett and Sylvia Curtis White, on Saturday at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, L. I.

Results of recent studies in diseases of the thyroid gland are to be made public here tomorrow at the opening session of the Third International Goiter Conference, held under the auspices of the American Association for the Study of Goiter.

With both teams flashing power on the ground and accuracy in the air, the Green Bay Packers defeated the Cleveland Rams in the opening game of the National Football League season today, 26 to 17, before 8,247 fans.

As the site for an eight-room house for his own occupancy William Krause, plumbing contractor of Flushing, has bought from the Dooley-Stapleton Corporation a vacant plot 80 by 100 feet on the east side of 194th Street, 100 feet south of Rocky Hill Road, Flushing, L. I. The Halleran Agency was the broker.

The Park Department announced yesterday that its revenue-producing facilities, which have been greatly expanded in recent years, had increased the city's park revenues from $200,000 for the entire year of 1934 to $753,467 for 1938 to date.

At the closing session of the Oxford Group's world moral rearmament assembly today, Carl J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament, said: "Peace requires an active constructive frame of mind and spiritual force.
There will recur in hundreds of thousands of homes this morning the annual bitter-sweet disturbance arising from the reopening of school.

Mrs. Alma Mueller Steffen of 37 West Seventy-second Street, a teacher in Public School 11, 314 West Twenty-first Street, since 1918, died yesterday morning in the Park West Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 46. Her husband,
For the 166 competitors eligible to play in the forty-second national amateur championship starting on the famous Oakmont Country Club course tomorrow the zero hour has arrived.
A marked improvement in retail business last week produced the largest volume of mail orders the wholesale market has received in any week since the opening of the Fall season.

At the end of a disappointingly mild day of tennis that contrasted with the exciting episodes of Saturday, another big crowd of 10,000 spectators in the Forest Hills Stadium saw Sidney Wood fight off the dangerous challenge of Gardnar Mulloy of Miami in the national championships yesterday, to win at 6-4, 6-1, 4-6, 6-8, 6-2.

Willis Boyd Allen of Boston, lawyer, author and editor, died yesterday at Crawford Notch, N. H., at the age of 83. Mr. Allen was born in Kittery Point, Me., July 9, 1855, attended Boston Latin School and was graduated from Harvard in 1878.

Allan S. Haywood, regional director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced last night that Governor Lehman would address the opening session, at the Hotel Center, Friday, of the first State convention of unions affiliated with the C. I. O.

The United States team from the Beverly Yacht Club won the International Challenge Cup for 30-square meters craft today when Sven Salen's Fagel Grip from Sweden withdrew after fouling Alfred E. Chase's Viking on the starboard tack a few seconds after the start.
Surging back toward Kwangtsi Japanese troops threaten again to occupy that vital Hankow defense outpost north of the Yangtze River.

Being the sort of ball club that seems able to blow hot or cold with equal facility, the Giants plunged from the sublime to the ridiculous in almost world record time at the Polo Grounds yesterday as they followed up their smashing 20-to-2 triumph on Saturday over the Dodgers by going down to a humiliatin shut-out 3 to 0.

" Automatic Jack" Manders was called on in the fourth period tonight and the former Minnesota star's toe picked up 3 points which gave the Bears a 16-to-13 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in the city's inaugural of the National Football League season.

While the rank and file of Georgians seemed to accept, and verify the forecasts of recently-completed State-wide polls that Senator Walter F. George will turn back the Washington "purge" campaign in Wednesday's primary, the leading candidates in the bitterly-contested Senatorial race prepared today for last-hour whirlwind drives for votes.
The knottiest problem that has confronted Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora since he rose to the bench was still an open question in his mind late last night.
There were four major developments here today on the eve of the nineteenth League Assembly, Chancellor Hitler's Nuremberg speech and Cabinet meetings in London and Paris.

Henry B. Duncan-Clark of Chicago, retired vice president of the Middle West Utilities Securities Company, died here today at the home of a daughter, Mrs. I. K. Allen of 196 Midland Avenue. He was born in Toronto, Canada, fifty-nine years ago.
James A. Brown, retired mechanical engineer and major in the ordnance - department during the World War, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 68 years old.
Superstitious persons among the Downing Street "crisis" crowd today were heartened by the appearance of the Treasury's large black cat.
President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman will speak on the final program of the New York State Historical Association, which will hold its annual meeting at Vassar College, Sept. 15 to 17.

Walter Spencer Vosburgh, former handicapper and steward of the New York Jockey Club, who retired in 1934 after an association of nearly sixty years with Metropolitan horse racing, died in his home here today of a multiple thrombosis.

The Steuben Society of America, which carries the name of Baron von Steuben, revolutionary drillmaster and hero of Valley Forge, will celebrate the 208th anniversary of the general's birth on Sept. 17 with a dinner and patriotic exercises at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday.
The French wholesale price index on Sept. 3 was 641, against 646 a week before and 644 two weeks before. The commodities gold index was 40.5, against 41.2 and 40.9 one and two weeks previously.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Van Duzer Frazier Je Berdell gave a tea this afternoon at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Van Duzer Berdell, to Kenneth Heron Hannan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everett Hannan of Albany, N. Y.
Deals featuring investment buying and sales of holdings by savings banks in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced by real estate brokers over the week-end.

Extension of the scope of group insurance and restriction of payments of dividends by domestic life insurance companies are among the recommendations made by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, to- the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Law Revision.

A boycott by Harlem grocers and dairy products storekeepers against store sales of milk until the wholesale price of the commodity, recently raised under the Federal-State milk marketing agreement, is reduced took a violent turn last night when the plate-glass windows of two stores in the district were broken by roving squads of brick throwers..
Mr. and Mrs. George Ann. Greer of Rye, N. Y., entertained at dinner tonight at Mepal Manor, New Marlboro, in honor of their week-end guests, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Van Zandt of New York.
Prices of bonds of municipalities in California continued last week to decline, reflecting fear of the political situation in this State.

The decline in wheat prices reflects how poorly adjusted is the balance between supply and demand, and this position undoubtedly is aggravated by the present effect on futures of the United States export subsidy.

Frankie Frisch was released today as manager of the Cardinals of the National League. The announcement was made by President Sam Breadon just before the start of today's game with the Pirates. Frisch's release was effective after today's game.

MUNICIPAL Applications for the following positions in the City Service will be opened Sept. 14, and will close Oct. 5. Details will be available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Municipal Building, or in the City Record. Here are physical and residence requirements.

THE EDGE OF THE WORLD. written and directed by Michael Powell: choral effects by the women of the Glasgow Orpheus Choir; photographed by Ernest Palmer, Skeets Kelly and Monty Berman; musical director. Cyril Ray; a Joe Rock production, released by Pax Films. At the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.
Captain Charles F. Huhlein, retired manufacturer, died today in Lexington of a heart attack at the age of 80. Captain Huhlein was educated in the Louisville public schools.

Premier honors in the International One-Design Class were captured by the sloop Feather, owned by Caryl Sayre, in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's fourth and final Sunday regatta of the season on Long Island Sound today.
The Brookhattan soccer team blanked the New York Americans, 2-0, before a crowd of 3,000 at Star light Park, yesterday.
Complete isolation of Vitamin "K," diet factor necessary for coagulation of blood, was announced today by Dr. Edward A. Doisy, St. Louis University research chemist.
The Rev. Dr. James Wright Martyn of Hackettstown, pastor emeritus of the Hackettstown Presbyterian Church, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital, where he had been a patient for several days.

The Ebro battle continued today with little change. The Loyalist troops held their own at every point, while the Rebels continued vainly their attempts to hammer through, according to tonight's communique.
MANHATTAN DAVIS, MARIE STURLA (Sept. 3). Estate less than $3,500. To Cornelius A. Stula, brother, executor, 76 Pinehurst Ave., Bronx.

London notes a more optimistic undertone in Wall Street, even though business is overshadowed by European politics, and expects a strong revival in the New York market when the situation is normal again. In fact,
Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Sands Litchfield of Cantitoe Farm, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tatiana Litchfield, to James Jenkins Lowe.

With the sun sinking over the Westchester hills, a great crowd of canine enthusiasts gathered on the smooth turf of the polo field of the Westchester Country Club this afternoon, breathlessly awaiting the final award of best in show at the annual exhibition of the Westchester Kennel Club.

I J. SINGER'S solid and sturdy talent as a chronicler of his people is again displayed in "The River Breaks Up,"* the latest of his works to be translated from the Yiddish. I think it shows to even better advantage than in "The Brothers Ashkenazi," for there the author set himself a task of almost Tolstoyan proportions, while here his intentions were modest.

Miss Edna Alice Lane, daughter of of Mrs. Joseph M. Brilleman of this place and the late L. Myron Lane, was married here today to Arthur A. Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Rosenthal of 975 Park Avenue, New York, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Basch.

Jews in Palestine are showing much bravery in defending themselves against Arab attacks. Although unreported in the government's daily communiques, there are attacks virtually every night on Jewish settlements many of which are in isolated parts of the country without either police or military protection.

The Blind Brook Knights remained unbeaten in the Eastern Polo League, defeating the First Division four by 6-4 at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club yesterday. It was the sixth league victory in a row for the winners and enabled them to keep first place in the standings over the second-place Governors Island Yellows, who were also victorious.

Ratification of a contract providing higher wages and improved working conditions for employes of the Sobol Brothers service stations was announced yesterday by the Sobol Brothers Employes Union, an independent organization.
Despite official denials of a change in the Cabinet, Luis Salas Romo, Minister of Interior, resigned today. The action was believed to have been caused by the Nazi revolt of last Monday.
German industry was quiet last week. The steel cartel's refusal to cut prices helped to hold up heavy industry's stocks on the Boerse.

The Rev. Welcome Davis Carnes, pastor of the Long Hill Methodist Episcopal Church, Long Hill., Conn., since 1935, died here yesterday after an illness of six months. He was born in Zanesville, Ohio, fifty-four years ago.

A $3 rhesus monkey, henceforth to be known as Deficit, cost Henry Trefflich possibly $49.50 in damages and court costs, to say nothing of three hours and fifteen minutes wasted in a wild chase, when it led three pals in a cage-break from Trefflich's five-story animal store at 215 Fulton Street early yesterday morning.

The story of Mata Hari, classic of our feminine spy series, slowly staled because whole libraries of research piled upon her grave revealed too much about the unhappy woman. This will never be true of "K," whose execution before a Soviet firing squad has just been announced.

Mrs Morgan Cowperthwaite, In 471 Park Ave through Huberth Huberth: Mrs Henry L. Wilkinson. in 115 E 53d St through Brett Wyckoff; Joseph D. Barker, in 350 E 55th St; Jack Sadowsky, in 14 E 75th St from the Tishman Realty Construction Co: Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

ON to Oakmont! It would be hazardous to make any faint guess as to how the national amateur golf championship will finish, but the U. S. G. A. has very kindly provided a list showing how it will start. As for instance: 8:30-Roger Kelly, Los Angeles C. C. S. D. Herron, Allegheny C. C.
The Cunard White Star liner Georgic arrived from French and British ports yesterday with 1,367 passengers, among them Dean t Acheson, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

The touring "Tobacco Road" company, headed by John Barton as Jeeter Lester, will open an engagement of one week beginning tonight at the Queensboro Theatre, Elmhurst, L. I. At the Brighton Theatre, Brighton Beach, "Golden Boy" will enter tomorrow night on the second week of its engagement there. "Yes, My DarlingDaughter,"
Nineteen lusty wallops off four Philadelphia pitchers today gave the Red Sox a 12-to-7 victory in the final game of the series with the Athletics.

James Roosevelt, son and secretary of the President, underwent an operation in St. Mary's Hospital here today for a gastric ulcer, and his condition later was reported by surgeons as satisfactory, to the "tremendous relief" of his father, who traveled by special train from Hyde Park, N. Y., to be at his bedside.

Commissioner Paul V. McNutt said today that there was "no basis" for published reports that President Roosevelt had called for his resignation or that they had exchanged views with some heat over the renomination of Senator Frederick Van Nuys of Indiana, who had opposed the court reorganization plan.

Education Minister Jean Zay, in behalf of the French Government, appealed for unity between France and the United States while Ambassador William C. Bullitt, in behalf of President Roosevelt and the State Department, stood silent here today.

A formal denial of published reports that the Department of Justice had decided to drop its investigation of charges of suppression of civil liberties by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was issued today by Attorney General Cummings. His statement said:
Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons, at the request of John Curtin, leader of the Labor opposition in the Federal Parliament, today received representatives of the striking coal miners.

Society crowded the stands and club enclosure this afternoon to see the final match of the national open polo championship series at International Field, Meadow Brook Club, but as the cold wind whipped across the highly placed stands many of them left their seats and boxes to walk about or seek hot coffee and other refreshment.

President Roosevelt's, recent statement to the press that it was 100 per cent wrong to believe that the United States had entered into a kind of moral alliance with European democracies brought a sharp editorial from Virginio Gayda, authoritative fascist writer, today.

One of the greatest polo teams that has ever galloped over the turf of an American field moved into its second successive national open polo championship today. Before 36,202 spectators, the biggest crowd that has ever watched an open championship game here,

Miss Ada Spiegle, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Spiegle of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Spiegle, was married yesterday afternoon to the Rev. Dr. B. Benedict Glazer, son of Mrs. Simon Glazer of this city and the late Rev. Dr. Glazer, at Temple Emanu-El, in the Rev. Dr.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentaots, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Stocks down on the week, with prices at lowest levels since middle of August; turnover, 2,995,410 shares. United States Government obligations eased sharply; foreign issues lower; corporation bonds lowest since early July; transactions, $20,265,450.

The latest effort to determine public opinion directly on the question of relief has been made in a poll of women conducted through interviews by The Ladies' Home Journal to learn what "the women of America" think about it.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)-Second round for club championship: R. W. Dill defeated H. Blohme, 1 up; J. W. Gordon defeated C. Gower, 1 up (19 holes); D. G. Seaman defeated J. T. Doran, 2 up; G. F. Meredith defeated L. E. Miller. 6 and 5; H. B. Allen defeated A. H. Andrews, 4 and 3.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today financial statistics for 150 operating and combination holding-operating electric and gas utility companies, all subsidiaries of registered holding comnanies.

On Sept. 5, 1538, 400 years ago, injunctions were issued by Thomas Cromwell, "Lord Privy Seal, Vice Regent to the King's Highness for all his jurisdiction ecclesiastical within his realm," that one book of the whole Bible of the largest volume in English be set up in every parish church throughout the country to be read openly. On Oct. 1,
Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin gave a dinner tonight in celebration of the second wedding anniversary of their daughter, Mrs. Pierson Mapes,

Ten safety commandments for the 20,000,000 American children who are returning to school this month were issued yesterday by Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the recently organized National Center for Safety Education at New York University, in an effort to cut down the nation's traffic accident toll. Dr. Stack's rules follow:

Mayor La Guardia and his party received a warm Texas welcome when they arrived early this morning at Fort Worth, where they were met by W. Lee O'Daniel, Democratic nominee for Governor of Texas; "Mayor T. J. Harrell of Fort Worth, Representative Fritz Lanham and a group from the Fort Worth Chamber of Commerce.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in July were 8,537,713 dozen pairs, a decrease of 11.6 per cent below June and 9.0 per cent below July, 1937, according to figures issued for publication today by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Competing before several thousand persons, nearly 400 visiting firemen participated in a series of events run off here today at the thirtyseventh annual field meet of the Westchester County Volunteer Firemen's Association.
George D. Fawcett, veteran actor of the stage and screen, is critically ill at his home here with a heart ailment.
The Henleinist reply today to President Eduard Benes's appeal to the German population yesterday was the organization of anti-Czech demonstrations throughout the Sudeten areas.

Total production of shoes in the second half of 1938 will be 197,000,000 pairs, compared with 178,000,000 pairs in the last half of 1937, in the view of tanners, as shown in an industry-wide survey undertaken by the Tannere Council of America, the results of which were issued for publication today.
At the close of the fourth successive day of conferences of key British ministers, the British Government's views were summarized by a responsible source today as follows:
An underwriting group headed by J. G. White Co., Inc., will offer today 74,802 shares of $1 par value common stock of Dixie-Home Stores at $7.50 a share.

A rare silver tankard by one of New York's earliest silversmiths, Jacobus Van der Spiegel (1668-1708) has been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will be placed on exhibition today in the room of recent accessions with other newly acquired works of art.
Over the week-end the 102d meeting of the Council of the League of Nations opened in Geneva with a six-minute session, the shortest and smallest on record.

The 1939 international theatre assembly that Frank Gillmore will propose next Wednesday at the second national theatre convention would find the Societe Universelle du Theatre meeting in this country for the first time, it was learned yesterday.
All women of fashion (and what woman in her way is not?) are undergoing a hairraising experience this Fall.

St. John's Episcopal Church here will be the setting the afternoon of Oct. 8 for the marriage of Miss Barbara Louise Bourne and Horton Smith. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Floyd Tompkins, and by the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson of Princeton, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore McCurdy Marsh of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude McCurdy Marsh, to Richard Ackerman Lydecker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Ackerman Lydecker of Glen ha Ridge.

A housemaid and her husband, arrested last night as the thieves who stole jewelry and silverware valued at $5,000 from the apartment of Mrs. Juliette Maximow, widow of a Czarist Russian Ambassador, confessed that they sold most of the loot, including rare artistic pieces wrought in precious metals, for $381 to be melted down at a midtown old-gold exchange, according to the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street station.
First steps toward enactment of State legislation to supplement the new Federal wage-hour law may be taken tomorrow at a conference of Secretary Perkins with a group of State labor officials.

Paul Dean pitched with much of his old effectiveness today as the Cardinals turned back the pace-setting Pirates, 6 to 4, and reduced Pittsburgh's lead over the second-place Cubs to three and one-half games.

Tentative plans of two major broadcasting chains call for complete coverage of the speech today by Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Nuremberg, Germany. In addition to carrying the Chancellor's address in full, both systems will present English digests of the talk.

Delegates arriving here tonight for the convention of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada viewed as inevitable a clash between forces for the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization. Sessions start tomorrow.
Archibald L. Mackinnon of Hillsboro, N. H., former managing editor of The Lowell Courier-Citizen and Evening Leader, died today at a Brookline Hospital at the age of 47.

Last week was an uncertain one, with repeated reversals of the tendency in a dull market. Stocks yesterday closed active and firm. An incentive to buyers was the agreement to resume the negotiations that have been going on in Prague. Nevertheless,
Secretary Ickes flouted "red herrings" today in dedicating a monument to Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, who 125 years ago won the crucial battle of Lake Erie, off this insular village.

Declaring that the only hope for his son lies in finding another blood donor who has recovered from the same disease, Alfred Rubens of 3,100 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, appealed yesterday to find a blood donor who has recovered from streptococcus viridans, a blood stHeam infection.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.6, which compared with 80.6 the week before, 80.4 two weeks before, 79.9 three weeks before and 80.2 four weeks before.

New York's Department of Sanitation extended its cleansing operations to the Police Department yesterday when its baseball team did a thorough job on Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's boys at the Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 45,000.
George Tilton Richardson, retired editor of he Worcester Evening Post, and a widely known journalist and author, died at his home today of a heart attack.

After four lays of critical ministerial discussions in Downing Street an outline of the British Government's present policy was obtained from a responsible quarter tonight on the eve of Chancellor Hitler's speech in Nuremberg.

The time has come to will a different kind of world, or it will destroy us, the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, special preaching missioner of the Free Church Council of Great Britain, warned in a sermon yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.

Two veteran performers of the show ring, the aged chestnut gelding Tupelo, owned by Miss Eleanor Wynne, and the bay gelding Sonny, from the stables of Mrs. Gordon Wright, carried off the major honors today in the eighth annual Lawrence Farms Hunt Club show.

Last week's stock market here was irregular, fluctuating within narrow limits until it closed firmly. At the opening prices sagged, owing to professional realizing, but they recovered immediately and thereafter moved uncertainly and largely under the influence of foreign exchanges.
One-fourth of the nation's population-about 33,000,000 persons-will be going to school by the end of September, the Office of Education said today. Of these, about 22,400,
Foreign Minister Josef Beck has delayed his departure for the League of Nations meeting at Geneva to await the reaction to tomorrow's speech by Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Nuremberg, Germany.
Fourteen liners arriving today from European and Southern ports will land 4,891 passengers along the city's waterfront in one of the busiest arrival days of the season.
Big Bill Lee broke the second-place tie between Chicago and Cincinnati in the National League today by blanking the Reds, 2 to 0, before a crowd of 20,728.
The stability of commodity prices as a whole during the past Summer has been somewhat obscured by the weakness of cotton, wheat and other farm products.

Political uncertainties in Europe came last week to the fore as a major market influence and were instrumental in causing a moderate upturn in world wheat prices after all leading markets had sold at a new low level since the depression days of 1932-33.

Adolf Hitler reviewed Nazi Storm Troops and his Elite Guard, in front of whom were lined up fifty Sudeten German Storm Troopers. He spoke of the absorption of Austria and said that "to other Germans this privilege is still not vouchsafed; our hearts go out to them."

If certain laws regulating business practices were suddenly repealed as the result of the Congressional investigation of monopolies, "many weaker businesses would soon be forced to the wall and many strong corporations might grow too unwieldy to serve the public efficiently," Mark Eisner, chairman of the taxation committee of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, said last. night over Station WNYC.

A number of four-story multifamily dwellings and a private home were among the properties in Brooklyn reported yesterday as having changed hands. Included was the four-story apartment house for twenty-seven families at 2,313 Benson Avenue, which was sold by the East Brooklyn Savings -Bank to an investing client of Hy D. Agar, Inc., brokers in the deal.

As Senator Walter F. George moved into Atlanta tonight for a huge rally ending his renomination campaign, William G. McRae, Townsend Plan advocate, withdrew from the race in favor of District Attorney Lawrence Camp, the 100 per cent New Dealer picked by President Roosevelt to "purge" the Senator from the Democratic party and the Senate.

Frank B. Williams Jr. has been elected vice president in charge of the merchandising division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday. He will make his headquarters in Mansfield, Ohio. He succeeds Arthur E. Allen, who has resigned.

While government circles maintain a lukewarm attitude toward Czechoslovakia, public opinion does not allow a chance to pass without showing sympathy and a readiness to sup-port actively its trusted wartime ally and 'partner in the Little Entente.

The Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted unanimously today to seek a $1,800,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for improvements on the Cross County Parkway in Yonkers and Mount Vernon.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 7, which included only five business days, aggregated $6,156,000,000, or 9 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 5 per cent below the total for the corresponding week last year, which also included only five business days.
A lease involving a large unit of space near Pennsylvania Station featured the business rentals announced yesterday.
Fulvio Suvich, I Italian Ambassador to Washington, has been appointed head of the Reunione Adriatica,
A special dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents was authorized by the Automatic Voting Machine Corporation. Similar payments were made on July 1.

Surprisingly enough, in these combustible times, the French have produced a war film under the title "Grand Illusion" It served to re open the. Filmarte lst night and it serves to warn the British that they no longer have a monopoly upon that valuable dramatic device known as understatement.
Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 45.3 per cent of capacity this week, as compared to 39.9 per cent last week, which included Labor Day, a gain of 5.4 points, or 13.5 per cent.
Stockholders of the Carrier Corporation approved yesterday the new capital structure and financing program involving an issue of $2,500,000 of debentures.
The stock market here was generally dull today and most sections were hesitant awaiting developments in the international situation.
The Park Department reveals that its revenue-producing facilities have brought in three-quarters of a million dollars this year, to date-nearly four times as much as for the whole year of 1934.
Cheered by encouraging reports on his ion's condition after hi operation, President Roosevelt gave most of his attention tonight to the European situation.
The Federal Trade Commission has issued an order to Cohen Brothers Corporation, 498 Seventh Avenue, New York, to cease and desist from representing, through use of the words "Kashmoor" or "Cashmere,"

In the second recent deal involving property in Riverside Drive, a group of investors represented by Karl Propper has purchased from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company the six-story apartment house at 670 Riverside Drive, on the northeast corner of 144th Street.
Officers and seamen of the United States light cruiser Nashville were greeted by enthusiastic crowds at this Bnitish naval base Not e when they landed on shore leave today.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net profit of $1,018,995 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, preferred dividends of subsidiary and other charges.
While General Evangeline Booth barked semi-military commands, 500 of her Salvation Army followers today alternately prayed and sang for peace in 300-year-old Sion College/on Victoria Embankment.

Red baiting has its exact counterpart in black baiting. There are people who see Communism in every progressive movement. There are those for whom the C. I. 0. and Communism are interchangeable terms.

Welcome is the denial by Attorney General Cummings of reports that the Department of Justice had decided to end its investigation of charges that civil liberties have been repressed in Mayor Hague's Hudson County.

A decline of 14.5 per cent in style settlements to 2,231 last week was attributed to the holiday in the weekly report issued yesterday bythe research and statistical department of the joint board,. Dress and Waistmakers' Union.
Robert B. Beale, manager of turbine sales in the General Electric Company's central station department, died at his home here last night after a brief illness.
Army and navy officials were reported to be en route to Puerto Rico today to consider plans for establishing air bases at Isla Grande, across from San Juan harbor.

Marjorie O'Shea, 3 years old, of 584 East 137th Street, the Bronx, died yesterday in Lirlcoln Hospital at 5:30 P. M., an hour after she had been injured in an automobile accident at 137th Street and Brook Avenue.

Declaring that "90 per cent of the rates under which truck lines operate in this area are fair," Debney T. Waring of Washington, representing several truck lines, recommended that changes be made in only 10 per cent of tte existing rates at an ex part proceeding opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday by Examiner J. B. Johnston of the Intertsate Commerce Commission.

Mrs. Mary E. R. Matthews, widow of Edward J. Matthews, died yesterday at Post-Graduate Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 62. Mrs. Matthews, whose home was at 43-55 166th Street, Flushing, had long been prominent in civic and Democratic political affairs in Queens.

Between 1,500 and 2,000 men and women, the entire working force at the plant of Loft, Inc., at Fortieth Avenue and Ninth Street, Long Island City, walked out yesterday morning in a strike that both union and company spokesmen attributed to a jurisdictional dispute between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O.

Clinton Levering Riggs died last night of a heart ailment in the Union Memorial Hospital, which he entered Saturday. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow. He was born in New York Sept. 13, 1865. The family moved here from New York in 1866 and had been prominent in Baltimore society since that time.
The Interstate Commerce Commission granted permission today to a group of holders of Erie Railroad refunding and improvement mortgage bonds to intervene in the Erie reorganization proceedings.

Fred Moore, professional at Dunwoodie, blamed around the Hudson River C. 0. course today in 64 strokes, six under par. He paired with William Griffan, also of Dunwoodie, to win the Westchester P..G. A. one-dar best-ball tournament with a card of 28, 30-58, a record for the event.

Gaston Purcell, director of the trading' and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and James F. Caffrey, regional administrator in New York, will address a general meeting of New Jersey investment securities dealers on the subject of the Maloney Act at a luncheon of the Bond Club of New Jersey at the labert Treat Hotel, Newark, on Monday.

Leaders of the United Association of Journeymen Plumbers and Steamfitters of the United States and Canada, an A. F. of L. unit, opened today its convention here with a prediction of the early be'ginning of the "greatest boom in all history," but still saw no immediate surge of building trades employment.

Henry Armstrong, holder of the world featherweight, lightweight and welterweight championships, will relinquish the 126-pound crown today, it was learned yesterday. Mike Jacobs, Twentieth Century promoter, revealed that Eddie Mead, Armstrong's manager, had phoned from Los Angeles advising him of the fact.
The creation of employment through the thirty-hour week was demanded today by President Green of the American Federation of Labor in an address at the International Typographical Union convention.

Married thirty-three years, John Macauley, 56 years old, and his wife, 55, died five minutes apart yesterday morning in their apartment on the third floor of 444 West Thirty-fifth Street, both apparently of natural causes.
With a warning to any aggressor in Europe that he cannot count on neutrality anywhere on earth, William J. Jordan of New Zealand, acting as president of the League of Nations Council,

Although several sections of the country were reported as lagging, brisk retail trade last week brought a heavy volume of mail into the markets here yesterday, according to resident buying executives.

Representative Bruce Barton was accused last night of doing his best to "blackjack" the New Deal. Walter H. Liebman, Democratic candidate for Congress in the Seventeenth district, made the charge at a rally in the Amsterdam Democratic Club, 237 West Seventy-second Street.

Flight Lieutenant M. J. Adam, who set a new world altitude record of more than ten miles last year, and a companion were killed today when their Royal Air Force bomber crashed at Farnsborough, Hampshire, and burst into flames.
Senator Robert F. Wagner returned on the Normandie of the French Line yesterday after making the round trip and visiting Paris for only a day and two nights.

The Nassau County Board of Supervisors today authorized the appointment of Joseph H. McCloskey, Commissioner of Elections, of Freeport; to the newly- created post of Superintendent of County Buildings at an annual salary of R$8,000.

With the city's twenty-seven largest department stores and eight branches still open despite a strike that began Wednesday, a 'possibility developed today that trouble might spread to twenty-three other smaller stores, including several fashionable specialty shops and all the leading men's haberdasheries.

Putting together a string of goals in the early' part of their game on Cochran Field today, Cocie Rathborne's Ramblers shaded Seymour Knox's Aurora four 12 to 11, and reached the semi-finals of the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup polo tournament.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech has given assurance in France that there is not going to be war immediately and has provided some hope that war can be avoided.

Harry Brown, chairman of the Intercoastal Freight Shipping Association, and Edward J. Karr, freight traffic manager of the Calmar Steamship Company, left yesterday for San Francisco to attend the annual meeting of the association, which will start Sept, 19.

Thomas Wiley Keithley, formerly assistant to the director of operations of the black powder department of the du Pont company, died yesterday in Beebe Hospital at Lewes, Del., at the age of 58. He was stricken three weeks ago while
Mrs. Lion Gardiner entertained today for 100 members of the Village Improvement Society at a tea after the annual meeting, at which reports for the year were read.

The Atlantic tuna tournament came to n an end today, with Forked River a easily the winner. The team scored a total of 13 points. Second place was taken by the Manasquan River outfit with 2 tallies. Freeport and Atlantic City had 1 each.

The will of Phelps Smith, providing that his estimated $2,500,000 estate should be used for the establishment of a Northern New York college, was held valid in a decision today by Ellsworth M. Lawrence, Acting Franklin County Surrogate. The will had been contested by twenty-two cousins.

Former Mayor James J. Walker was among the 1,200 persons who gathered at Temple Beth Emeth, at 1,510 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday to pay their last respects to the late Abraham H. Schwartz, president of the Century Circuit Theatres, who died at Lake Placid on Friday.

Bishop John Mark Gannon of Erie, Pa., who went to Spain in July to make his own investigation of reported atrocities and persecution of the Church by the Loyalist Government, declared on his return yesterday that his worst fears had been substantiated.

The Committee for Industrial Organization is dying, Louis P. Marciante of Trenton, president of the New Jersey State Federation of Labor, told the delegates at the opening of its sixtieth annual convention in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here today.

The whole State political situation was thrown out of alignment yesterday by the Hines case mistrial as politicians weighed the effect the decision may have upon the nomination of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as the Republican candidate for Governor.

The gasoline price war in the Chicago area continues unabated, but the bigger companies, generally speaking, back away from the remedy proposed by some of the station owners-the fixing of prices under the State Fair Trade Act.

American methods of merchandising were described by Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., at a luncheon for foreign representatives to the Seventh. International Management Congress, held yesterday at Macy's. Mr. Straus outlined the methods of the store's bureau of standards and of the influence which it developed since its inauguration in improving the quality of goods offered the consumer.
Manhattan Alterations 3d Ave. 733 to 739; to 5-story tenement and stores; Mutual Life Insurance Co of N. Y., 34 Nassau St, owner; Charles B. Ferris, engineer; cost, $90,000.

That the Japanese have regained control of Kwangtsi, Hankow, defense outpost, was admitted by a Chinese military spokesman today. He said that the Chinese last week had re-entered Kwangtsi, "but finding the town a mere shambles as the result of Japanese bombing did not stay long."

A motorcade of thirty-five automobiles and trucks, decorated with banners and filled 'with shouting men, women and children urging the re-election of John J. O'Connor to Congress from the Sixteenth District, passed .through the streets of the East Side last night. .
With merchandise items showing only nominal price changes in August, the Fairchild Retail Price Index on Sept. 1 held unchanged at the August 1 level, it was announced. yesterday.

Two Spanish galleons, part of a fleet of treasure ships wrecked more than 300 years ago, have been located in a coral forest off the northern coast/of the Dominican Republic, Captain John D. Craig, deepsea photographer and explorer and author of "Danger Is My Business," reported yesterday on his return from a scientific expedition sponsored by Beloit University.

The multi-family dwelling, containing twenty-one apartments and four stores, at 135 Barclay Street, corner of Waverly Avenue, Newark, N. J., was sold by the Lincoln Mortgage Company to Mrs. Sarah Kaplan, who will hold it as an investment. Feist Feist, Inc., was the broker.

A debutante party that gave the "little season" a touch of color and an out-of-the-ordinary atmosphere was a Tyrolean supper dance given here tonight at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club to introduce Miss Annette R. Pittman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Wetmore Pittman of Lawrence, and Miss Mary Ide Hine, daughter of Mrs. Hugh S. Robertson of 1,220 Park Avenue, New York, and Fishers Island.

The Democratic National Committee reported to the clerk of the House today receipts of $129,511 and expenditures of $123,932 for the three months ended Aug. 31. These figures brought its receipts for the first eight; months of the year to $563,347 and its expenditures to $636,117. The expenditures total includes $86,001 listed under "unpaid obligations."

General John J. Pershing arrived in Southern France today for a three-week stay. Members of the staff of the American World War leader said his health was "very satisfying." General Pershing's seventy-eighth birthday is tomorrow. No special plans were made for the occasion.

Large national advertisers will launch extensive advertising campaigns in conjunction with premium offers next year, exhibitors at the fourth annual .Atlantic Coast Premium Buyers Exposition, opening for five days at the Hotel Astor yesterday, reported.

School days returned yesterday for more than 1,000,000 children who took their seats in the classrooms of 1,000 buildings while 38,000 teachers set into motion the city's vast free educational system.

With the filing of a preliminary report, on contributions and disbursements with the Board of Elections yesterday, it was disclosed-that Representative John ;J. O'Connor had received contributions from twenty-fbur States, the District of' Columbia, France and South America.
The World Congress Against War and Fascism opened by President Lazaro Cardenas on Saturday was marked for half an hour today by an uproar that included an attempt to use fists.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today set Oct. 21 for oral arguments on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company reorganization case.
Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday at Whitefield, N. H., of Albert Haustetter, head of the optical firm of his name at 2 East Forty-fifth Street.
Maine, one of the two anti-Roosevelt. States of 1936, gave a clean-sweep victory to all four of the Republican candidates for the top offices at stake in the nation's first election of 1938.
The following is a transcript of the proceedings yesterday at the session of court in which Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora declared a mistrial in the Hines case:

James J. Power, 33 years old, former clerk in the brokerage, firm of Granberry Co., 50 Broadway, who was accused of embezzling $15,383 from his employers, was sentenced yesterday by Judge William Allen in General Sessions to serve from two to 'five years in Sing Sing Prison.

The names of 111 of the alleged gamblers indicted on Friday after a year's investigation were made public today with a warning to the defendants that any who fled or sought to evade arrest would be held in "substantial bail" to await trial.

Choice and prime fed steers and yearlings sold at fully steady prices today but there was some weakness on common, medium and good grades, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. A two-way market developed in the hog trade.
Edward Small has signed James Whale, Universal contract director, to direct the projected remake of "The Man in the Iron Mask," scheduled to go before the cameras in January.

Holdings of fishery products in cold storage on Aug. 15 were 14 per cent greater than a year ago, and 22 per cent greater than the five-year average, the Bureau of Fisheries announced today. Holdings on Aug.

A nine-member commission to study labor relations legislation was appointed today by Governor Moore in compliance with a resolution by the Assembly requesting such action. The commission will organize at the State House here next Monday.

An outbreak of price cutting enlivened the retail liquor market here yesterday as stores in the midtown and downtown areas slashed quotations on a variety of scotches. Some of the cuts ranged as much as 90 cents below regular quotations.

While almost every policy-making official in Washington subordinated routine work to a study of Chancellor Hitler's speech this afternoon, all declined comment, in line with a policy of silence Invoked by Cordell, Hull, Secretary of State.

Gilbert Miller, theatrical producer, denied on his return from Europe. yesterday that he had left J. B. Priestley in ignorance of the fact that the producer ' had not signed with the Dramatists Guild. The Guild has charged that Mr. Miller, who will produce .the Priestley play '"I Have Been Here Before," had failed to inform the British playwright that his contract would be in, violation of his Guild obligations.

A coroner's jury recommended today that Police Chief Norman Findley of Hatboro, Pa., be held for grand jury action in the fatal shooting on Friday of Raymond Cooke, 35, a union picket, during a labor disturbance at the Oscar Nebel Company's hosiery mill.

The storm broke at Forest Hills yesterday following Sunday's lull in the national tennis championships as two of the biggest shocks of the season were recorded. Not in years has the tournament furnished so stunning a brace of surprises in an early round as were registered in the setbacks of Robert

Fourteen types of drugs and a poison used by the head-hunting Jivaro Indians of South America were brought here yesterday by Dr. Harry B. Wright, dentist and anthropologist of Philadelphia, who returned on the Grace liner Santa Rosa after a six weeks' expedition through Ecuador.

Unfair competition, for life underwriters in the form of savings bank life insurance was scored strongly today by Seneca M. Gamble of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, in an address before the Insurance Advertising Conference held at the Oyster Harbors Club.
A resolution booming Vice President John Nance Garner for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1940 was defeated at a meeting today of the executive committee of Young Democrats of the State.

Miss Alice Curtis Wren of this city, a descendant of Sir Christopher Wren and Sir Walter Scott, was married yesterday morning in the Chapel of St. Saviour of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to Lawrence Lanier Winslow Jr., son of Mrs. Winslow-of Wickliffe, Ohio, and the late Mr. Winslow of New York.
Mr. and Mrs. James O. Parsons of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Brown Parsons, to Howard A. Lockwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood of Yonkers.

The immediate impression of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech here was one of great relief so far as the foreign situation was concerned and of serious concern, coupled with great indignation, in connection with the internal Czechoslovak situation.
The dredger Karimata' which has been searching for. the gold cargo of the Lutine which was lost 139 years ago, abPnhdoned- the project today after more than three months' work.

It was a victory for the British yachts today in the third race, which was resailed for the BritishAmerican Cup. The United States six-meter craft completed the twelve-mile course with a score of 20% points to 15 for their opponents, but George Nichols's Goose, clear-cut defender of the Scandinavian Gold Cup, was disqualified and lost the 5 points she brought to the finish line.
The leading baking companies in New York City put into effect yesterday a cut of 1 cent in the price of the standard eighteen-ounce white loaf of bread.
Dr. William Goodell Frost, president emeritus of Berea College, died last night of a heart attack and lung congestion. His age was 84.

Some children love to go to school, or so it is said. Others just go. Those who started in yesterday for the first time hardly know what they think, though no doubt they will. have opinions before the week is out.

Under a hustling ride by Leon Haas through the stretch, Spillway, who runs in the colors of Joe W. Brown, got up to take a close decision in the Charentus Purse at Aqueduct yesterday. After fighting it out for a furlong he just lasted to defeat T. P. Morgan's Endymion by a head, with E. R. Bradley's Blini third.

Notices Paragraph VIII, Special Order 171, dated Sept. 7, with regard to charge of neglect of duty, on which Fireman lst Grade John W. Loeffler, Rescue Company 4, was tried on Aug. 19, 1937, being dismissed, is revoked.
Stockholders of the Atlantic Refining Company at a meeting in Philadelphia yesterday voted authority to directors to increase the bonded indebtedness of the company by not more than $50,000,000.

In one of the largest realty deals between private individuals in some years, George MacDonald, financier, has acquired from Henry L. Doherty a "substantial interest" in the latter's hotel and report properties in Florida and the Bahamas, it was announced yesterday.
The Associated Hospital Service of New York, which operates the three-cents-a-day plan for hospital care, opened yesterday a downtown office at 50 Broadway.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of unlicensed seamen, announced yesterday that the national council had recommended an assessment of $2 a member as a means of wiping out a debt of about $50,000.

Congratulating retailers on their decision to display their optimism in the National Retail Demonstration, scheduled to be held on a nationwide basis next week, Major Henry Curran, deputy mayor of New York, said yesterday their confidence in a new upward sweep of the recovery movement was "more than justifiable."
The appointment of Captain Harry N. Sadler as master of the American Republics liner Brazil, which will sail Oct. 8 on her first voyage to South America, was announced yesterday.

Officials of the State of Louisiana announced yesterday that an issue of $5,000,000 of highway bonds will be sold on Oct. 19. Bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1938, and will mature serially in 1942 to 1961.

The Senate Campaign. Expenditures Committee holds that M. Hampton Magruder, Collector of Internal Revenue at Baltimore, violated the Civil Service. Act in calling employes of his office together and apprising them of his intention to support Representative David J. Lewis in the Maryland Senatorial race. The committee says:
Senator King praised Senators Tydings of Maryland and George of Georgia today and said "there has been too much encroachment by the Executive Department on the other branches of government."

The German defense forces gave their annual exhibition twice today. This morning they paraded before their own commanders and this afternoon before Chancellor Adolf Hitler. ,Each time at least 100,000 spectators,' mostly men from the party formations, were in the Zeppelin Meadow grandstands.

The committee on instructional affairs of the Board of Education has approved a recommendation of the Board of Superintendents that the Board of Education appoint William Joseph Fitzpatrick, principal of the Chelsea Vocational High School.

The Morris Plan Bankers Association will hold its nineteenth annual convention in the Greenbrier Hotel, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., from Oct. 10 to 12, it was announced yesterday by Arthur J. Morris, founder and president of the Morris Plan Bank of New York.
The ninth annual Fall flower show of the Bank for Savings in the City of New York opened yesterday with 270 exhibits in the main banking room at 280 Fourth Avenue.

A new course in industrial accident prevention will be inaugurated beginning Oct. 4 at the New York University division of general education, in cooperation with the College of Engineering, it was announced yesterday.
Heavy reordering on Fall leathers developed yesterday when. retailers viewed the annual showing of Spring leathers sponsored by the Tanners Council of America.

Stressing the opinion that the smaller companies will always have a place in providing new designs and engineering improvements, Robert Graham, vice president of the GrahamPaige Motors Corporation, said today at a preview of the company's 1939 models for newspaper automobile editors, that independent effort in the industry would be more and more respected.

The annual tracking competition in connection with the specialty exhibition of the Obedience Test Club was held today on the estate of Henry J. Whitehouse in this town. It was open only to dogs that have acquired their C. D. X. titles and were ready for the utility class, and to dogs already carrying the U. D. suffix.

County Judge Forest Chapman probated today a codicil 'to the will of John Ringling, circus owner, disinheriting his nephews, John Ringling North and Henry Q. North, and reducing the bequests to their mother, Mrs. Ida Ringling North.

Commander and Mrs. H. H. Evans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Jane Evans Brown, to Robert Lacy Smyth, second secretary of the United States Embassy at Peiping, where the wedding is to take place in the early part of December.

A wind tunnel, capable of simulating flying conditions from sea level to substratosphere altitudes up to 37,000 feet, was dedicated at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today as a memorial to Orville and Wilbur Wright and their accomplishments in the field of aviation.

The records of the Federal Housing Administration appear to be justifying the position of those who sponsored the revival of Title 1 of the National Housing Act, permitting insurance of loans for building modernization work.

About 5,000 tons of structural steel, for a dam and power house in Oklahoma, a hangar in Colorado and smaller projects, were booked by Bethlehem Steel Corporation last week, and 2,000 tons of reinforcing bars for the United States Engineers' office at Los Angeles also was taken by the company.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Federman Filston announced yesterday the admission of Marcus J. Federman as a special partner.

Automobile production declined sharply last week. With allowance made for the holiday, daily average output eased against a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 35.1 from 39.2. A seasonal variation factor of 71.0 was used in computing the index for the week. For the week ended Sept. 11, 1937, the index was 159.9.

The volume of dollar bankers' acceptance outstanding declined $6,428,420 in August to '$258,319,612 at the end of that month, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York issued yesterday.

A huge twelve-wheeled bus, called by its manufacturers a "trolley on wheels" because of its length of forty-seven feet and its capacity of fifty-six passengers, was taken on a trial run yesterday afternoon in the vicinity of the Bronx County Building.

Crowds of persons standing in the streets heard Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech on the radio tonight. Its dramatic effect was increased by blackout tests going on as a part of the current manoeuvres.

Miss Mona Kathleen McKeag, daughter of Mr. and -Mrs. W. G. McKeag of this city, will be married the evening of Sept. 23 to Joseph Russell Martin, also of Montclair, son of Mrs. George B. Martin and the late Mr. Martin, formerly of Glen Ridge.

Borough President Ingersoll of Brooklyn yesterday endorsed Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate, who is being opposed for the Republican, nomination for Kings County Judge by Harold L. Turk. Mr. Ingersoll said he could not vote in the primary contest, but that he was looking forward to voting for Mr. Waldman on election day.
More than 500 American artists, representing virtually every school of painting, from surrealism to early primitive,

When District Attorney Thomas E.: 'Dewey and James J. Hines stepped out from the dark recesses of the- Supreme, Court building into the waning autumnal sun yesterday afternoon after the mistrial, an unofficial jury of some 3,000 persons crowded into Foley Square rendered its own verdict in its own way on the uncompleted Hines case.

The Rumanian Government's intention to curtail Germany's barter trade in favor of countries paying cash was evidenced by the recent failure of German efforts to procure 20,000 carloads of wheat in exchange for German industrial products.
Field Marshal Hermann Goering is ill and could' take no part in the military review here today. He was kept in bed at the Grand Hotel with bronchitis and a glandular inflammation.
Jean Longuet, a grandson of Karl Marx and a former French Deputy, died last night in Aix-les-Bains Clinic, to- which he had been taken after an automobile accident. His age was 62.

Maryland voters, balloting in a primary election that provided a direct test of the President's Congressional "purge," gave to Senator Millard E. Tydings, whom the New Deal opposed, a lead early this morning over Representative David J. Lewis, whom it supported for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.
Dr. George H. Leggett of 5 East Fifty-third Street and New River, Mass., died on Sunday after a brief illness. He was in his sixty-ninth year.

An order granting a jury trial in the Kings County Court to William F. McGuinness, suspended assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, and George Murphy, city-employed elevator operator, accused of conspiracy to "fix" a criminal case, was signed yesterday by Judge Peter J. Brancato.

Although traffic accidents rose slightly, fatalities declined sharply again last week and week-end as compared with figures covering the corresponding periods of 1937, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday. Slight rises in the number injured this year were also indicated.

WHAT would have happened if what did happen -hadn't happened? To take a familiar-example, suppose that on that April night when Booth flung open the door of a box in Ford's Theatre he had missed. Or suppose that his pistol-ball had entered the- brain of one of the four other occupants of the box.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society prize of $1,000 for a major symphonic work by an American has been awarded to David Van Vactor for his Symphony in D, it was announced yesterday. Honorable mention went to Mark Weasel for his symphonic poem, "The King of Babylon."

Miss Ilona Elizabeth Bucko, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bucko of New Brunswick, N. J., was married here this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church to Dr. Thomas J. Killian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Killian of Pittsfield. The Rev. Leo Shaughn essy officiated.
Miss Mary Louise Day, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gordon Day of this place, was married this afternoon to Thomas Entwistle, son of James Entwistle of New Milford, N.J.
The Swiss Government announced today that it had ordered mines prepared under all bridges and tunnels near the frontiers as "a preventive measure" against any invasion.

Plans were submitted to the State Department of Labor for constrction up-State of ninety-four factories, mercantile establishments and places of public assembly during August, according to Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

About 2,000 independent retail grocers will meet here tomorrow to discuss a sales drive to move the big packs of canned vegetables in prospect this Fall and early Winter. The meeting is under the auspices of the Independent Grocers Alliance.
Dr. Edward M. Clark, Health Officer of the village of Mamaroneck for thirty years prior to his retirement last Spring, died on Saturday at his home at the age of 76 after a year's illness.
Only disjointed fragments of Chancellor Hitler's Nuremberg speech were heard in Moscow tonight because of continuous and violent interference with radio reception.

Superior Judge Edward T. Bishop ruled today that Harry Bridges, West Coast C. I. O. leader, was not in contempt of court when he threatened a maritime strike at Los Angeles Harbor during a court fight with the A. F. of L. several months ago.

Under an agreement that gives them the right to recall their signatures not later than tomorrow afternoon, all but a few of Broadway's theatre ticket brokers signed yesterday the new code of fair practice regulating theatre ticket sales.

James H. Fay,' New Deal candidate opposing Representative John J. O'Connor for Democratic renomination in the Sixteenth Congressional District, last night accused Mr. O'Connor of injecting the "cry of communism" into the campaign to avoid -the real issues of the c.ontest. Mr. Fay spoke from Station WQXR.

David Edwards and his two sons, Harvey and Claude, all of Center Moriches, L. I., were' found not guilty by a jury in the Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday of violating the United States laws for the protection of migratory birds by allegedly "baiting" with corn the water of Terrell's River, near Brookhaven, L. I., to attract wild ducks.

It was officially announced today that all members of the Cabine; .had handed their- resignations to President Arturo Alessandri after a special meeting. It was believed the action was a result of the Nazi revolt lastI Monday.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Lieut. Col. Edwin O'Connor, Cavalry, having been detailed for duty with the organized reserves, Second Corps Area, with station at New York, by Paragraph 7.
