Special Orders 207, War Department, dated Sept. 3, is assigned to duty as assistant instructor, Cavalry Reserve Section, Second Military Area, and upon expiration of his present leave of absence will report to the executive officer for duty accordingly.

The increasing German pressure on Jews and dissenters from the Nazi system has raised the total of refugees to this country to the limit of the immigration quota, according to Joseph P. Chamberlain, Professor of Public Law in Columbia University and chairman of the National Coordinating Committee for such refugees.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with gains of 3 to 7 pointss after they had fluctuated irregularly over a ten-point range in a market dominated largely by nervousness over the European political situation.
White Plains Rd (15-3949), s e cor of Guerlain St, 34X110; Guerlain Holding Corp to Ida M. Otz, trustee, Madison, N J: installments, 5 per cent: $33,000.

Sunkist Drinks, Inc., was adjudged in contempt of court yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson for alleged violation of a 1931 injunction that protected the word "sunkist" as a trademark-belonging to the California Fruit Growers Exchange.

The democracy, understanding, charity and humanity of the late Cardinal Hayes were eulogized last night by three of his closest personal friends, David McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund; George MacDonald, Papal Marquis, and former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer. They spoke over WHN.
Trading in cash grain and futures in the world's leading markets was extremely light today, with operators awaiting Chancellor Hitler's speech, scheduled to be made after the close of the session.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, protested today to Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act, against including knitted underwear as part of the textile industry in carrying
John M. Hancock, a member of the firm of Lehman Brothers, has been elected chairman of the stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange.
The Treasury paid an average rate of 0.103 per cent on its ninety-one-day bills sold today, compared with 0.049 per cent on the Sept. 2 paper and a rate of 0.047 two weeks ago.
Speakers in New York, Hoilywood and London were heard last night in a radio broadcast celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of Fred Stone's first appearance on the stage.

30th St, 113 E; Sophia A. Olmstead to Charles de Fabre, 35 E 41st St; p m mtg, install, 5 per cent; $2,250. Same property; Charles de Fabre to John P. Finneran, 229 Madison Ave; install, 5 per cent: $8.000.

Five hundred guests, including more than 300 registered delegates, are expected today at the opening luncheon of the Second National Convention of the Legitimate Theatre at the Hotel Astor. The session will continue with a program this afternoon, another luncheon and program tomorrow afternoon, and a gala supper-and final entertainment tomorrow night.

The plain goods broadsilk industry here was completely shut down by a trike today while both sides proeeded with negotiations that promise to send many workers back to he mill Wednesday morning and he rest by the end of the week.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some months ago, an editorial appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES calling attention to the deplorable condition of the districts around the site chosen for the New York World's Fair of 1939, and its effect upon visitors, especially from overseas.

The drive against workers in the Garment Center, on the West Side between Thirtieth and Thirty-ninth Streets, who push handtrucks the wrong way on one-way streets is being continued by police of the West Thirtieth Street police station,
Commander Milton Updegraff, U. S. N., retired, widely known for his work in astronomy, died today at the Mare Island Navy Yard. He was 77 years old.

Many Italians received their first impression of the great gravity of the Czechoslovak crisis through hearing Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech on the radio this evening. It was broadcast by all Italian stations.

A young job-hunter named Vincent Dyckman Andrus, who had landed a place at the Arnold Constable Co. department store on Fifth Avenue at $14.50 a week, tried to go to work yesterday morning, but soon found his labors hopelessly interrupted by reporters and photographers, for he is the grandson of the late multimillionaire John E. Andrus.
Governor Lehman named Dr. Nolan Lewis of New York City today a member of the board of visitors of the State Training School for Boys. He succeeds Dr. Frederick Tilney, who died recently.

A preliminary estimate of the volume of production of fluecured tobacco places the total yield at approximately 60,000,000 pounds from 65,000 acres, according to a tobacco crop report for 1938 issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.
Hampered by a slushy track, John R. Cobb of England failed today by/a narrow margin to shatter the world land speed record- of 345.49 miles per hour.

The Carabineros, representing he military police of Chile, arrived yesterday aboard the Grace liner Santa Rita to prepare for the National Horse Show, which will be held at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 5-12. The team brought along ten jumpers which will see action in the show.

Wreckers yesterday took possession of the former home of John D. Rockefeller Jr., the nine-story residence at 10 West Fifty-fourth Street. The land upon which the building stands, a plot fronting 75 feet on West Fifty-fourth Street, will be used as a garden for the display of sculpture by the Museum of Modern Art, to which the plot was given by Mr. Rockefeller.

Lou Oshins is coaching his Brooklyn College team -by remote control these days. The energetic young man who handles the destinies of' the Kingamen in all sports tore a ligament in his back last Winter, complications set in and Oshins has spent the last fourteen weeks in a hospital bed recuperating from. an operation.

Stocks of storage butter in the country on Sept. 1 reached a new high record of 201,543,000 pounds, exceeding the previous peak by more than 26,000,000, according to the government's monthly report of cold storage holdings made today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

Lexington Foundation, Inc., operating a "thrift plan," yesterday consented, without admitting guilt, to a permanent injunction restraining it from violations of the Securities Act of 1933 in the marketing of its certificates.

THE ADMINISTRATIVE PROCESS, by James M. Landis. (Yale University P.ress, $2.) A study of the commissions administering the Social Security Act, the National Labor Relations Act and the Securities and Exchange Act;
A sharp break in United States Government securities and general weakness throughout the foreign section marked trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

As standard equipment for De Soto cars for 1939 a "handyshift" gear lever on the steering column was announced yesterday as the first detail made public about the company's shortly to be announced models for the coming year.

Miss Natalie Eloise Miles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Miles of Carteret, N. J., was married here to Edward S. Kucinski, son of Alexander J. Kucinski of Newark, N. J., yesterday at noon in St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Francis H. Craighill Jr.

Coney Island's thirty-fifth annual Mardi Gras opened last night with members of New York's Police, Department taking a principal part in the celebration, which was witnessed by more than 200,000 persons. The event was known officially as "Police Safety Night."

Representative Robert Low Bacon, a member of Congress since 1922, died suddenly at about 10:50 o'clock last night in the automobile by which he was returning to his home at Old Westbury, L. I., from a speaking engagement in New York City.

The strike of some 2,500 painters to force independent contractors to accept the contract recently negotiated by District Council 9 of the Painters and Decorators Union, A. F. of L., was declared "virtually at an end" late yesterday afternoon by Louis Weinstock, spokesman for the union.

Elder Ave. 1,239, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Vincenzo Napolitano; due, $11,145; to plaintiff for $1,600. By HENRY WALTEMADE Jesup Ave, 1,506, 37.6x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Jeanette Goldman; due $17,502: to plaintiff for $500.
Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, disclosed today that it was studying the possibility of insuring bank deposits above the present $5,000 limit.

Prince Arthur of Connaught will receive a military funeral Friday morning in St. George's Chapel at Windsor Burial will be near the tomb of his grandmother, Queen Victoria. Prince Arthur died yesterday at the age of 55.

John B. Ritter, about 55 years old, principal of the Collingswood, N. J., high school from 1919 until last July, was released in $1,000 bail in Common Pleas Court here today, after surrendering for trial on an indictment charging ten counts of embezzlement of school funds. No date for hearing was fixed.

After reading early dispatches on Hitler's speech this evening Mayor La Guardia said: "The same law that applies to an individual in his conduct toward society should apply to nations. When an individual goes berserk vae take him in custody and put him in a place where he can do no damage.

Columbia's football squad engaged in its first field drill of the season yesterday. Coach Lou Little sent forty players through brisk morning and afternoon sessions at Baker Field that totaled five hours. Fundamentals were emphasized for backs and linemen.

Sped by a slight tail wind and aided by perfect flying conditions, the Deutsche Lufthansa catapult seaplane Nordstern alighted on Manhasset Bay here at 9:35 A. M. with a new record of 13 hours 35 minutes for the 2,397-mile flight from Horta, in the Azores, to her credit.

Almost on the eve of the Georgia primary the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures ruled today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation acted "properly" in dismissing Edgar B. Dunlap, Georgia regional counsel, for activity in behalf of Senator George's campaign.

While baseball circles buzzed with rumors concerning Frankie Frisch, deposed manager of the Cards, and Burleigh Grimes, whose reign as leader of the Dodgers has been hanging in the balance, the Giants yesterday were getting set for the arrival of the pace-setting Pirates, who begin a three-game series at the Polo Grounds this afternoon.

Colonel Harold Lincoln Jackson, U. S. A., retired, a veteran of the war with Spain, the Philippine insurrection and the World War, died Saturday of heart disease in the Post Hospital, Fort Jay, Governors Island, at the age of 76.

The foreign exchange market yesterday went through another nervous session, culminating in an accelerated fall of the- pound sterling to a record low price for three and one-half years after the completion of Chancellor Hitler's Nuremberg speech.

The first four of the many out-oftown truants who customarily come to this city at school-opening time were in the custody of the Children's Society yesterday with nothing to look forward to today except school and perhaps an outburst-of parental wrath.
The official Polish reaction to Chancellor Hitler's speech is that it did not justify the apprehensions felt in certain European capitals. This official view was. expressed with evident relief.

Meeting and luncheon, Export Managers Club, Hotel Pennsylvania, 12:15 P. M. Address by C. S. Snider. Second National Convention of the Legitimate Theatre under the auspices'of the American Theatre Council, Hotel Astor. Luncheon 12:30 P. M.

Chancellor Hitler had a large audience in peaceful Scandinavia tonight and the general impression is that the feeling of uncertainty and unrest has not been cleared. Even if Hitler hurled no thunderbolts it is felt a storm is still in the air.

The Reorganization Bill, which failed of passage during the last session of Congress, was a "thoroughly unsatisfactory measure," Charles I. Stengle, president of the American Federation of Government Employes, declared in his annual report today to the convention of the organization here.

In what labor attorneys described as a precedent-setting case, a labor union went into the Federal District Court here today to ask for a mandatory injunction against the National Labor Relations Board.

Sidney I. Davis, in 595 West End- Ave; Henry Kronimus, in 786 Lexington Ave; Henry Doctor, in 274 W 11th St; Charles F. Noyes Co. Inc, broker. Irving S. Dorf, in 124 W 79th St; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.

The Publio Health Service undertook today a $300,000 investigation of pneumonia and its treatment in seven States. It will act in cooperation with the State Health Departments of New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois and California and the local officials of St. Louis, Denver and New Orleans.

A National Youth Administration allotment of $85,590 this year will provide employment for about 800 undergraduates at Hunter College, according to Mrs. Dean Schloss, in charge of undergraduate placements at the college. Registration for NYA part-time work will start tomorrow.

Jesse Jones, head of the Reconstruction Corporation, and Stewart McDonald, administrator of the Federal Housing Administration, returned on the French liner Normandie yesterday after a five-week vacation abroad.
Fashion advertising and fabrics are the subjects of two new evening courses announced yesterday by the Tobe-Coburn School for Fashion Careers, 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

The Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, successor to the business formerly conducted by the New York Title Insurance Company and Lawyers Title Corporation, reports admitted assets or $4,225,819 on Aug. 1,
William Keating, through Catherine Gall, in.16 Alida St; Earl Slack. through Robert S. Horsley, in 300 Westchester Ave; Yonkers leases for HOLC by Raymond R. Beatty Organization, broker.
Leslie Lady Doverdale, who had been visiting in Southampton, L. I,, is at the Ambassador before sailing for her home in London.

The National Labor Relations Board received a recommendation today from William Binger, trial examiner, that it order the Eagle Picher Lead Company, an $18,000,000 concern, and its subsidiary, the Eagle Picher Mining and Smelting Company, to reinstate with back pay 130 striking employes and eighteen others.

Supply of traefer meats was moderate with the exception of pork, which was light in local markets yesterday. All classes were in fair to good demand with the exception of veal and calf hindsaddles, which were slow. Hinds and ribs were fully steady to 50c higher; other classes steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Mrs. Margaret Fillmore, sister of Mary Miles Minter, former screen actress, on the witness stand in a civil suit today accused her mother, Mrs. Charlotte Shelby, of concealing the pistol which killed William Desmond Taylor, Hollywood director. fifteen years ago.

A public auction of unclaimed or seized imported articles will be held at the Customs Seizure Room 311; Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street, at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning. Harry M. During, Collector of Customs, announced yesterday.

Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, who visited in Sweden-and Finland after a season in London, returned yesterday on the Normandie, and both found pleasure in the fact that they could "come home" to a land removed by many miles of water from a world where the atmosphere is so tense and ominous that "one can scarcely breathe."

Herr Hitler did not declare war in the anxiously awaited speech delivered in Nuremberg yesterday, but no one who listened to that clear, harsh explosive voice coming over the air to the accompaniment of a thunderous undertone of "Sieg Heil!" received any assurance that he meant peace.
As the battle on the Ebro River entered its seventh week the Nationalists [Insurgents] announced that they had captured fourteen separate lines of Government trenches in the last three davs.
Appeals from San Francisco grocery jobbers to manufacturers here to use drop shipments in filling orders for that city were under consideration by producers yesterday.

Oak St, 27, 26x65; Alfred C. Ditolla, execr, to James Capucci. 192 Bowery; (50 cents). 110th St. 341 E. 25x138.2x irreg; Rosa Teven to Dry Dock Savings Institution; mtg $26,625 held by grantee ($2). 18th St, 408-14, 100x92; Meyer Alterman, referee, to Jacob I. Berman, trustee; foreclosure ($5).

When the bottom fishing boats began returning to dock with small tuna we were inclined to treat the matter as just another interesting freak of fishing, but when these boats continue to bring in tuna it passese beyond the freak stage.
Condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept.

Myer M. Malloy, a Richmond newsboy of thirty years ago, now part owner of four Bermuda stores, will be back at his old stand selling papers tomorrow. He is spending a vacation here and is homesick for old friends and customers.
Three members of the Peninsula Golf Club of Inwood took the top prizes today as the Long Island Golf Association held another of its oneday tournaments at the Shelter Rock Country Club.
Hone Ave (16-4451). e s. 275 ft n of Mace Ave. 75x100: Antonietta Talamini to Alfred Kimball, 2,496 Morris Ave. 167th St. 896 (10-2716); Bowery Savings Bank to Prodromos Jimroglon, 577 E 137th St.

In the present world crisis the United States has room for only one "ism" and that is true Americanism, the United Spanish War Veterans were told at the opening session of the national encampment here today.

On the complaint of the Rev. George Drew Egbert, president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, the police arrested last night the manager and five other employes of the Jewell Theatre, a motion picture house at 11 West 116th Street, charging them with acting in concert in conducting a. lottery.

A "sharp" earthquake about 2,500 miles from New York was recorded early yesterday on the Fordham University seismograph, the Rev. Joseph Lynch, head of the seismographical laboratory, reported later in the day.
Manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers reduced the value of their inventories by--5.8 per cent during the first six-months of 1938, according to estimates issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
William G. Kelso Jr., who had been prominent in the investment and securities business for many years, died Sunday in Brooklyn after a long illness. He was 57 years old.
Pittsburgh at New York-Klinger (10-5) or Blanton (11-6) vs. Schumacher (11-8) or Gumbert (12-12). Cincinnati at Brooklyn-Vander Meer (13-7) vs. Tamulis (9-6) or Posedel (8-9).

The marriage of Miss Natalie Wood, daughter of Mrs. Robert H. Wood of Essex Fells and the late Mr. Wood, to Henry Nitoll Wightman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Wightman of Upper Montclair, will -take place on Oct. 1 at Linden, the old Nicoll estate at New Windsor-onthe-Hudson, which has been in Mr. Wightman's family for 100 years.

Renewing charges made in Waahington during hearings of the Dies Congressional committee investigate ing_un-American activities, Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey denounced the Federal Theatre Project of the WPA as "a veritable hotbed of un-American activity" in a radio speech last night.

The trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, came to an abrupt halt yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora granted a mistrial after considering for forty-eight hours a plea by defense counsel charging District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey with having prejudiced their case.

Henry J. S. Hall of 825 Fifth Avenue, president of the Fellows Medical Manufacturing Company, Inc., drugs and chemicals, 26 Christopher Street, died Sunday at his Summer home in Dorset, Vt., at the age of 76.

American voters registered their choices in primary and election yesterday, but the final tallies will not cons tribute very much to the discussion, raised by the President's Labor Day speech at Denton, Md., as to whether the nation is to align itself with Mr. A or Mr. B, the "reactionaryy" or the "liberal."

Net profit in the first six months of this year of the Yokohama Specie Bank, Ltd., was 6,187,602 yen after making provision for bad and doubtful debts, rebate on bills, etc., according to an announcement yesterday by the bank's New York agency.

With orders reaching manufacturers running from 10 to 15 per cent above last year at this time, the Fall Millinery Festival, which began yesterday, has gotten off to an excellent start, Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee of the Military Stabilization Commission, said yesterday.

The number of commercial and industrial failures reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in the holiday week ended Sept. 8 was 161, compared with 226 in the preceding week and 96 in the corresponding week of last year, the mercantile agency reported yesterday.
The will of Mrs. Cornelia Livingston Pell, widow of Alfred D. Pell of New York and Tuxedo Park, was admitted to probate by Surrogate Charles E. Taylor today. Mrs.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiaries, including the Midvale Company, reported today that the dollar value of orders in August totaled $3,621,775, compared with $4,235,568 in the corresponding month a year before.
A. L. Foster, formerly in business for himself, is now associated with M. Burke. The new firm will be known as Foster Burke and will be located at 366 Madison Ave.

Charles A. Murphy, for many years a member of the bond brokerage firm of Murphy Brothers Miles, died suddenly of a heart attack at his residence, 17 Park Avenue. He was 55 years old. In the World War Mr. Murphy served overseas in the United States Navy.
Caroline Parker Smith, widely known poet and contributor to national magazines, died today. She had been Ill for many years with a disease contracted while hunting big game in Africa in 1923.

Sales of the larger department stores are now running slightly ahead of last year, but there is a mildly disconcerting reason for the increase. The public schools opened last Tuesday and the last of the suburban school pupils will be back in classrooms tomorrow.

Mrs. Nahan Franko, widow of the noted Metropolitan Opera Company concertmaster and conductor and herself a famous actress of the Nineties, died Sunday evening while attending a party at the home of Mrs. Hugo Lieber, 1,088 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by her husband's nephew, Edwin Franko Goldman, the conductor.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible lists of holders of license for service in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, as of Sept. 9, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:

While the big New York City banks were meeting a considerable retirement of their outstanding credit last week, the reporting member banks in the 100 other leading cities of the country had a better experience, this week's memberbank statement shows.
The Department of the Interior today took over control of the Matanuska Valley project in Alaska, a New Deal venture in colonization of farmers impoverished by, drought and dust storms.

Lyrmite, bay filly owed by J. J. MacIntyre of Hobby Horse Farm, Hollins, Va., won the $2,100 Reading Fair Futurity for 2-year-old trotters in straight heats and record t time today. It was the opening event of the five-day Grand Circuit meet here.

Dorothy Baker's novel, "Young Man With a Horn," is now in its fourth printing. The next Houghton Mifflin Fellowship novel to be published is David Cornel DeJong's Dutch story, "Old Haven," promIsed by-the publishers for Sept. 20.
Representative Hamilton Fish and Eugene S. Taliaferro, who ran against John J. O'Connor for Congress in 1932, both urged Republicans last night to support Mr. O'Connor in, the primaries next Tuesday.
The will of Daniel G. Dodge, filed here for probate today, left $250,000 to his widow, the former Laurine McDonald, daughter of a tugboat captain of Manitoulin Island, Ont.

Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Southworth Hathaway and, Mr. and Mrs. James Talcott gave a dance here tonight at the Apawamis Club to introduce to society their respective daughters, Miss Valerie Hathaway and Miss Mary Hope Talcott.

Stocks closed irregularly higher in quiet trading, industrial shares up 1 to 3 points; turnover, 601,960 shares. United States Government bonds declined sharply to lowest levels of current movement, foreign loans weak, other bonds also lower; transactions, $4,406,575.
The Iowa-Nebraska Light and Power Company of Lincoln has been sold to the Nebraska Hydro network for $21,465,000, it was reported in Omaha financial circles today.

Carl Oscar Alwin, composer and the last conductor of the Vienna State Opera, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie as an immigrant. He will seek citizenship here and later send for his family, which remained behind in Austria.

The Hotel Grosvenor at 35 Fifth Avenue, which prides itself on its quiet, sheltered atmosphere, was the scene last night of an unprecedented party featuring straw-hat smashing, unrestrained Back-slaping and the singing of songs of the Auld Lang Syne variety.

Swimmers who have been frightened for two weeks by sand sharks in Long Island Soudd regained their courage today after hearing a fish story told by George Pitts, 19 years old, of Rye, and corroborated by eyewitnesses.

Dr. Eugene H. Lehman, educator and former Mayor of Tarrytown, N. Y., married Elizabeth N. Meyer here today, after having obtained a waiver of the five-day law. Jacob H. Berman, local attorney, performed the ceremony.

The general level of wholesale prices in the week ended Sept. 10, as measured by 'The National Fertilizer Association's index remained unchanged. This index last week stood at 73.6, the same as in the preceding week. A month ago the index was 73.1 and a year ago it was '86.9, based on the 1926-1928 average.
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced the award today of three college scholarships to sons of its employes.
William F. Forepaugh, former president of the Herring-Hall-Marvin Safe Company of Old Farm Road; Tokeneke, died yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 64.

Mr. and Mrs. Percy W. Carey of Yarmouth, N. S., have announced Law the engagement of their daughter, Miss Genevieve Crosby Carey, to Edwin H. Betts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Betts of this city.

Sir Willmott H. Lewis, correspondent of The Times of London in Washington, will address the Bond Club of New York at its first luncheon meeting of the season in the Bankers Club on Thursday, Sept. 29.

Tad Wieman put his Tiger squad through its first stationary scrimmage of the year today on University Field, continuing to work over new plays and striving to perfect Nassau blocking technique. Dave Sidford, Rugby captain, reported as practice swung into its third day.

Mrs. Frederic D. Huntington of Katonah, N. Y., who will sail tomorrow to pass two months in France and England, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Her guests included Mrs. Holbrook B. Cushman, Mrs. George T. Newell, Mrs. Samuel Frothingham, Mrs. Dana S. Lamb and Mrs. Frank Watters Jr.
A plea that America keep out of any European war was made today in a statement approved by the board of the National Small Business Men's Association. The statement read:

The Wagner Labor Relations Act was assailed last night as a legal instrument enacted to be fair to "only one party" by Representative Bruce Barton, speaking at the first Fall campaign meeting of the Women's National Republican Club.

Balloting on the State order fixing prices to be paid to producers for milk sold in the New York metropolitan market was 86.8 per cent in favor of the plan, Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture, announced today. Out of 29,883 valid votes cast, 25,935 were in favor and 3,948 opposed.
Turpentine firm, 21 1/2c sales 136. barrels; receipts 503 barrels; shipments 219 barrels; stock 51,101 barrels.

Seven new ballets and two restorations of classics will be features in the repertoire of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which opens its nineteen-day engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday evening, Oct. 12, it was announced yesterday.

Edward / Thomson of Glens Falls, a land appraiser for the State Conservation Department from 1906 to 1929, died here today at the age of 83. Mr. Thomson had been visiting at the Summer home of a niece, Mrs. Eva Thomson Dodge of Staten Island.

One of the most important trials in this city's history has come to a thoroughly unsatisfactory end. On a point which must seem to an overwhelming majority- of laymen to be essentially technical Justice Pecora has declared a mistrial.
The Tigers' one-two punch, Hank Greenberg and Rudy York, accounted for another victory today, Detroit beating the White Sox, 4 to 3, in the major leagues' only game.

The Ford Motor Company complained to the National Labor Relations Board today that the examiner who heard charges of Wagner act violations at the company's Long Beach, Calif., assembly plant did not conduct "a full and fair hearing."

The Women's Rebellion, an anti-New Deal organization headed by Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit of Suffern, N. Y., was told by Attorney General General David T. Wilentz today that in his opinion it was inconceivable that a WPA employe or persons on relief could be adjudged a pauper and thereby denied the right to vote.

Earl De La Warr, Lord Privy Seal, arrived here by plane this evening after attending the British Cabinet meeting and had a conference tonight with the. High Commissioners of. Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and Canada and members of the Irish and Indian delegations.

One interesting fact learned here today is that the German Embassy is now almost deserted. For some time German diplomats here have been sending their wives and children back to Germany. Most embassy officials also have now returned home.

In competent quarters the impression that obtains tonight about the speech delivered at Nuremberg today by Chancellor Adolf Hitler is that he has not finally committed himself to any definite course and, theoretically at any rate, remains more or less free to favor within limits or to check a settlement between the government at Prague and the leader of the Sudeten Germans.

More than 1,000 pieces of mechanical and administrative facilities will be exhibited at the National Business Show, Oct. 3 to 8, at Commerce Hall in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street, Frank E. Tupper, president of the show, announced yesterday.
QUEENS DIETZ, JOHN (Feb. 21, 1937). Gross assets, $7,858; net, $7,263. To brother, Edward Dietz. Chief- assets, bonds and mortgages, $7,500. Edward A. Von Sothn, attorney, 87-78148th St., Jamaica.
Pensioned On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Sept. 10. CAPTAIN--Daniel F. Cashman, 50th Precinct, at $2,500 per annum. Appointed June 30, 1909.
Hollywood, which put up half of the million dollars for the moremovie-business campaign, today heard reassuring reports that the national picture business was leaping into the black from the red.
Chancellor Hitler at Nuremberg last night asserted the "oppression" of Sudeten Germans must end and the right of self-determination be given to them.

The text of Chancellor Hitler's speech, which did not, arrive in Shanghai until 3 o'clock this morning, deepened the pessimism of the official circles here, where it is felt that the prolonging of tension in Europe will serve to embolden the more radical group of Japanese.
British opinion saw a prospect of incessant tension stretching ahead of Europe tonight as a result of Chancellor Hitler's indecisive speech at Nuremberg.

Dr. Albert T. Peters, former chief veterinarian of Illinois, founder of the Big Brother Movement in Illinois and one-time district governor of the Rotary International for the State, died here yesterday at the age of 70. Born in Chicago, Dr.

The voters of this community today gave their approval to a $1,382,985 school building program, but by a decisive margin voted down a proposal to buy the Clifton Steps on the Palisades, over which a controversy has been raging here for the last month.
A contest on the floor for the Senate nomination at the Democratic State Convention, which assembles at Eastern Point tomorrow, became a certainty as the vanguard of the delegates arrived.
Professor Harry Jerome, former, chairman of the University of Wisconsin Department of Economics, died yesterday in a Madison hospital at the age of 52.
Following is the text of Chancellor Hitler's references to foreign affairs in his closing speech to the Nazi party congress tonight as translated from a stenographic report:

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's challenge to the Czechoslovak Government in his speech last night was welcomed in early German press comment today chiefly on the count that it had removed any obscurities in the situation that might be still lingering in the minds of statesmen abroad.
King Farouk, accompanied by army and air force chiefs, today started a three-day tour of the western desert defenses which extend to the frontier of Italian Libya.

As part of a long-range program to decentralize the functions of the Department of Welfare, William Hodson, Welfare Commissioner, asked the City Planning Commission yesterday for a 1939 appropriation of $2,032,000 in the capital outlay budget for the building of five welfare centers in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Maurice J. McCarthy, one-time metropolitan district and Georgetown University star, was the only one in the field of 163 golfers partioipating in the first 18-hole qualifying round 'of the national amateur championship today who was able to hurdle the Oakmont course successfully.

Almost everybody wore a grin last night at the Monongahela Democratic Club, where Jimmy Hines's picture hangs over the fireplace, as a crowd of. nearly 100 gathered to rehash the suddenly halted battle of "The Boss" versus Thomas Dewey, much to the latter's disadvantage.

The French people are facing the current crisis calmly but they are deeply concerned, according to Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, French Ambassador to the United States, who returned on the Normandle yesterday after a leave of absence.
Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced today that the Cabinet declined to intervene in the strike of 20,000 coal miners, who he said should appeal to the prescribed tribunals.
President Roosevelt today designated Sept. 25 as Gold-Star Mother's Day and called upon the nation to pay tribute to the women who lost sons or daughters in the World War:
" Hellzapoppin," the Olsen and Johnson entertainment which was scheduled to have its postponed opening in Boston last evening, will be under the jurisdiction of the Actors Equity Association.
Miss Shirley Keeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Sherwood Keeler of Loudon Woods, this place, made her debut at a dinner dance held tonight at the American Yacht Club here.
Miss Rosalind Brown of this place has chosen the afternoon of Oct. 1 for her marriage to Edward Townsend, son of Myron T. Townsend of Pelham, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Gertrude Barnard Townsend.

At the end of the second day's play, H. G. D. Leveson-Gower's eleven had scored 363 runs for eight wickets, declared, against the Australian cricket team in the closing first-class match of the English season. The visitors' first Innings netted 306 runs.
The Mengel Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday billings and bookings for August and eight months, and unfilled orders on Aug. 31, as follows:

Mrs. Edith Vreeland, 29-year-old daughter of a Hollis, Queens, Methodist pastor, was stabbed five times with a hunting knife by her estranged husband at about 9 A. M. yesterday as she came out of the Independent subway at the southeast corner of Eighth Avenue- and Forty-first Street, on her way to work at the Elizabeth Mills Reid Estate in the Herald Tribune Building, 230 West Forty-first Street.

The new one-story taxpayer building on a plot 42 by 150 feet at 219 Mamaroneck Avenue, Mamaroneck, Westchester County, was leased by the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company from the Vac Realty Company, represented by Burton C. Meighan. John J. Reynolds,
Charles C. Ross of Calgary, Alberta, former Minister of Lands and Mines in the Alberta Government, collapsed here today and died while he was being taken to a hospital. His age was 54.

MANHATTAN BLEY, KATHERINE (July 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To Henry Bley, husband, executor, 110 W. 52d St. CROWNINSHIELD, EDWARD A. (Aug. 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Francis W. Crowninshield, brother, 333 E. 68th St., residue; four minor bequests. Carl A. de Gersdorff, 3 E. 73d St., executor.

The government is registering all male citizens and material in the nation in connection with its rearmament program. Men from 20 to 50 years old must appear before local military authorities within the next few weeks.
Sales of variety stores showed a daily average in August about 5 per cent below August, 1937, the Coommerce Department stated today in a preliminary survey.

James E. MacMurray, philanthropist and former Chicago industrialist, will be married here on Oct. 4 to Mrs. Kathryn T. Smith, formerly of Mount Vernon, Iowa. Mr. MacMurray is 76 years old and Mrs. Smith 54.

Alfred M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, called upon Democrats today to put country above party and vote the Republican ticket at the November elections. In a speech prepared for a mass meeting at the close of the State Republican convention, Mr. Landon said:

With an aggressive freshman team, which substituted for a scrub eleven, furnishing some hard opposition for the first time this Fall, Fordham's football varsity was sent through its third scrimmage of the pre-season practice period at Fordham Field yesterday.

The Bees today opened a long home stay by defeating the second-place Chicago Cubs, 5-2,-behind the four-hit pitching of Jim Turner. That veteran right-hander carved out his thirteenth victory by limiting the visitors to singles as he and his mates pounded Clay Bryant for eleven safeties.

Restrictigns on the shipment of skimmed milk into the city for manufacturing purposes only were eased yesterday by the Board of Health to allow entries in greater quantities at a consequent saving to the makers of skimmed-milk products.

Connecticut Democrats, paying verbal compliments to President Roosevelt and the New Deal, prepared tonight to nominate tomorrow a State ticket which is generally regarded as conservative. Assembled in convention, they cheered a keynote speech by Senator Francis T. Maloney,
More than 100,000 Americans are in European countries likely to be affected if a great war breaks out. A majority of them are permanent residents.

The Commerce Department said today that $165,990,271 of gold came into the country during August. This total was larger than imports in recent months. Heavy shipments so far in September, however, indicate the figure will be surpassed this month.

The American Theatre Council, which for the last year has sought to harmonize the various ,branches of the theatre for the good of the industry as a whole, ran headlong into a lively dispute over stage unions and the use of their power at the opening yesterday of the council's second annual convention in the Hotel Astor.

Members of the Bureau of Fire came today to the defense of Mayor Wilson, who was indicted last week on charges of "misbehavior in office." Local 22 of the City Firemen's Protective Association, which has about 2,000 members, adopted a resolution expressing "complete and unqualified confidence" in the Mayor in all of his actions concerning the bureau.
Sparked by the hitting of Rookie Catcher Floyd Beal, Rochester shaded the champion Bears, 3 to 2, today in a twelve-inning thriller in the opening game of the Governors' Cup play-offs.
Sammy Luftspring, 146 1/2, Toronto, outpointed Frankie Cavanna, 146 1/4, East Side, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 4,000 was present.

The courtroom differences between Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey moved into the sphere of public conflict yesterday as the jurist defended his decision granting James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, a mistrial and Mr. Dewey prepared to bring the case an again as soon as possible.
" Political" prisoners, who themselves are accused of planning to start a revolution in France, asked Premier Edouard Daladier today to mobilize them if war comes.

A tour today through the scenes of some of last night's worse disorders-Eger, Falkenau, Karlsbad and Asch-leaves little doubt that the Henleinists acted on a concerted plan and tried to repeat the course of the Austrian Nazis of March 11 and overthrow the authority of this State.
Dr. Cyrus Adler, whose seventy-fifth birthday was celebrated yesterday, is an outstanding example of the type of citizen whom democratic America delights to honor.

Butter rose 3/8 cent a pound today to the highest price in a month on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, The government-financed Dairy Products Marketing Association bought 1,811,000 pounds in New York and Chicago in its market stabilization efforts.

After Prague had imposed martial law in several Sudeten German areas yesterday, following fatal disorders, the Henleinists presented an ultimatum to the government giving it six hours in which to lift the martial law.

Advertisements for the examinations for promotion to Supervising Fire Telegraph Dispatcher and promotion to Deputy Chief will appear in the City Record from Wednesday, Sept. 14, to Wednesday, Oct. 5, 1938. This advertisement will give the eligibility requirements, subjects and weights of examinations, fees and dates between which applications are to be filed.

A block of three Harlem tenements will undergo modernization as a result of a sale reported yesterday. The five-story buildings at 304-8 West 119th Street, on a plot 75 by 106 feet, were solf by Harry Shapiro to 72 Realties, Inc., for cash above mortgages of $22,500, through Fred L. Purcell, broker.

Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood have advised the committee for New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway (Gulf Coast Lines) first Series A, B, C and D and 5 per cent bonds and Series A income bonds headed by George D. Walker that as of April 1 last the -firm estimated its fee for services to be $62,213, including $2,213 disbursements, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.
The text of today's communique of the Sudeten German party containing the terms of the ultimatum to the Czechoslovak Government follows:
President Foosevelt, at the bedside of his son in Rochester, Minn., said to reporters who asked for comment on the news of

The Foreign Office spokesman, in the first: statement here on the Czech crisis, today blamed Communist activities and declared Japan's readiness to join Germany and Italy in "fighting against Red operations."
Ross A. Hull, 36, an authority on ultra-short wave radio and television, was killed tonight while conducting an experiment in his Summer cottage here.
George Uhle, veteran coach of the Buffalo Bisons, saved a 3-to-2 victory over Syracuse for his club in the opening game of their International League play-off series before 7,572 persons tonight.
W. Randolph Burgess, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York since 1930, resigned yesterday to accept a post as vice chairman of the National City Bank of New York.

Ray C. Dreher of the Boston Insurance Company today was elected president of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the closing session of the sixteenth annual convention, held at the Oyster Harbors Club here.

A budget reduction of $477,000 made by the Board of Estimate on Feb. 28 was declared illegal and void yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck in a decision directing the city to increase from $1,200 to $3,240 a year the pay of sixty-eight clerks to Municipal Court justices.

Mrs. James Graham Parsons was hostess to the Lenox Garden Club Council at Bonnie Brae, Stockbridge, this afternoon. Mrs. William Felton Barrett of Rye, N. Y., and North Agremont told of her experiences in the use of chemicals for forcing plant-growth.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Ralph Washburn of Battern ville, N. Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Washburn, to Benjamin L. Bragg 3d of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. L. Bragg Jr. of Longmeadow, Mass.

As the reels of "Devil's Party" ground out its pictured story of bloodshed and murder yesterday afternoon before 500 persons in Queens Theatre, Queens Village, two motion picture operators in the theatre's projection room fought a battle that ended with the death of one of the men.
The General Motors Corporation had 399,255 common and preferred stockholders for the third quarter of 1938, compared to 403,282 for the second quarter and to 363,675 for the third quarter of 1937.

A banking group headed by Braun, Bosworth Co. of Toledo has obtained $737,000 of general obligation sewer bonds of Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., on a bid of par for $286,000, maturing Sept. 1, 1941 to 1951, as 3 3/4s; $187,000, due Sept. 1, 1952 to 1958, as 3 1/2s, and $269,000, due Sept. 1, 1959 to 1968, as 3 3/4s, or at a net interest cost of 3.686 per cent.
The bad first impression of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Nuremberg speech is undiminished by twenty-four hours' reflection and by the clashes to which it immediately led in Czechoslovakia.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible lists of holders of license for service as Indicated in junior high schools, as of Sept. 12, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted license, as indicated:
War Admiral will be absent from the $15,000 added Gold Cup at Hawthorne Saturday, but the Admiral's "shadow" will be in the running.

News of the Sudeten riots in Czechoslovakia caused general weakness on the stock market here today despite its firm opening. Gilt-edge issues were set back, while among the foreign bonds German loans fell off. Transatlantic stocks attracted support and United States Steel advanced.

A patent covering the various uses of non-tarnishing metallic and other colored threads produced by laminating a sheet of cellulose film on each side of aluminum foil with a transparent colored adhesive, has just been granted to a Cleveland company. Claims for the product,

The trend of business, which suffered a precipitous descent, has turned upward in response to the coincidental effect of war influences, natural recovery trends and the government lending-spending program, but it is difficult to determine which has given business the most stimulation, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.

A city-wide strike tomorrow of some 3,000 members of the Retail Dry Goods Employes Union, Local 1102, C. I. O., was threatened yesterday when fifty members of the union walked out of several stores of the Greater New York Dry Goods Association.
The first cable for the BronxWhittstone vehicular bridge over the northern end of the East River will be spun at noon today. Ceremonies will be held at 147th Street and the waterfront in Whitestone.

Joseph Love, president of the Apparel and Accessories Associates, Inc., the corporate group constructing the women's apparel and accesseries building at the New York World's Fair, announced yesterday that approximately twenty-five fashion industries would be represented either by industry exhibits or individual manufacturer exhibits within the fair.

Transit Commissioner Reuben L. Haskell demanded yesterday that Mayor La Guardia tell the public how much the privately owned rapid transit lines are going to cost the city in order that the voters may know what they are voting for when they pass upon the constitutional amendment

Possibility that prices of calfskins may advance sufficiently to cause an appreciable increase in the value of calf leather occupied the attention of tanners and buyers at the opening of Spring leathers, sponsored by the Tanners Council of America, which closed yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
A solemn high mass of requiem was sung yesterday morning in memory of Cardinal Hayes by the pastor and staff of St. Stephen's Church, 147 East Twenty-ninth Street.
Gus Moreland, 27-year-old Texan, today set the pace for the qualifiers in the forty-second national amateur championship. Moreland, for the past four years A resident of Peoria, Ill.,

According to The Financial News a meeting of Lloyd's underwriters and representatives of marine insurance companies will be held in London today to discuss making all policies "free of capture and seizure." This "FCS" clause excludes all war perils from a marine policy.

1st Lt. Richard Raymond, Inf.-Res., having' been ordered to active duty at Pine Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., is by reason of physical defect, relieved from further active duty, effective Sept. 13, 1938, and will proceed to his home, 450 95th St.. Brooklyn. N. Y.

A Reuters dispatch today from The Hague, The Netherlands, said that a bill had been introduced in Parliament to give the government extraordinary powers to insure ade-, quate food supplies in wartime.

A study by experts of the separate treaties of Czechoslovakia with France and Russia has convinced them that the pacts would not necessarily require the latter countries to go to the assistance of Czechoslovakia in the event of war.
Still smarting under the thought of the time and money wasted because of the mistrial in the Hines case, Mayor La Guardia today attacked the judicial system that permitted such an occurrence.
About 3,500,000 square feet of mineral wool insulation will be used in the Metropolitan LIfe Insurance company's new apartment project on the site of the old Catholic Protectory in the Bronx.

Robert L. Fisher, secretary of the New York Stock Exchange, advised members and ember firms yesterday that those who wished to appear before the special committee on study of permissive incorporation should orrange to do so by communicating with C. G. Weber,

The suit of eleven electrical manufacturing companies against Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, of the A. F. of L., for an injunction against boycott of their products, was resumed yesterday before Special Master John Kirkland Clark in Federal Court, with the union beginning its defense.

Short interest in New York Curb Exchange stocks continued to shrink in August, the total at the month-end standing at 11,670 shares, against 13,992 on July 29. The figure is the smallest since December, 1931, when the first short position figures were published.

Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department; appointed a committee today to determine minimum wages in the textile Industry, the first to be designated under the Fair Labor Standards Act bf 1938.

Steel ingot production declined more than seasonably last week with allowance for the holiday, and the adjusted index receded to 62.8 from 67.5. A seasonal variation factor of 92.3 was used in the computation. The index was 130.7 for the week ended Sept. 11, 1937.

The response to the appeal by the management of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad that holders of $14,807,000 of 6 per cent notes due and payable on Oct. 1 consent to a threeyear deferment of payment has been so discouraging that the officers intend to accept assents to the adjustment until midnight the day before the maturity, it develloped yesterday.

Caught in the path or a soutn-bouna commuters' train on the Harlem Division of the New York Central at 8:06 A. M. today, a small roadster was thrown 100 feet into a ditch. Henry Panicca, 40 years old, of 47-43 Ninety-eighth Place, Corona, Queens, who was the only occupant of the car, was killed instantly.

Burnet R. Maybank, Mayor of Charleston, gained a 13,000 majority on the face of returns from today's Democratic run-off primary for Governor but, at the request of his opponent, Wyndham M. Manning, National Guardsmen impounded the ballots cast in Charleston County.

Army's football squad scrimmaged for the third straight day as Coach Bill Wood again sent his A players against the B squad today. The session was divided between offense and defense as both sides mixed passes freely with running plays.

Lovely Night, a 2-year-old colt owned by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, who has been chasing the shadows of such as El Chico and Johnstown in stake events, dropped down a couple of notches in class at Aqueduct yesterday and made a runaway race to win the Kittiwake Purse at seven furlongs.

Thornton Lee won a pitching duel with Pete Appleton today in the second game of a double-header, to give the White Sox a 3-to-2 victory and an even break 'with Washington. The Senators carried off the opener, 7 to 1, behind the six-hit pitching of Ken Chase.

John Fairfield Thompson, executive vice president and a director of the International Nickel Company, has been nominated to become a trustee of the Bank of New York. Ward W. Dayton has joined J. M. Holley Jr. Co. in Chicago.

Word raced around the corridors of the League of Nations palace this afternoon that incidents in Czechoslovakia had led to the proclamation of a state of emergency in eight Czechoslovak districts, and a few hours before word had reached hereafter the League Assembly's adjournment-of the Sudeten party's ultimatum.

There was feverish activity in the hangar of the Zeppelin company here today. Tomorrow the new LZ130 will be named the Graf Zeppelin, replacing the old ship of the same name, and have its firstt trial flight with hydrogen instead of the helium for which it was originally designed and built.
Announcement has been received from Munich by Dr. and Mrs. W. Reynolds Wilson of Westwood, Villanova, of the engagement of Miss Elinor Beatrice Utsch to their son, J. Cornelius Wilson 2d.

Lack of cooperation by the Legislature and insufficient funds have "sabotaged" operation of the 1933 New Jersey Minimum Wage Act, Vincent J. Murphy, secretary of the New Jersey Federation of Labor and a member of the Newark City Commission, declared here today before the sixteenth annual convention of the federation.

Clubbing Boston pitchers for ten hits, the Tigers conquered the Red Sox, 9 to 3, today to extend their latest winning spurt to six straight games. Vernon Kennedy went the distance for Detroit and allowed eight hits in registering his twelfth triumph.
Victory for Senator George in today's Georgia primary was forecast on the heels of other triumphs of members of Congress marked by President Roosevelt for defeat. [Page 1.]

The Monopoly Study of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acting under the authority of the National Temporary Economy Committee, which is conducting the inquiry into, monopolies, served today subpoenas upon J. P. Morgan Co. and several other banking and brokerage firms which may have participated in the solicitation of proxies in the fight for control of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad.
War talk from Europe received in the last five minutes of the session today sent wheat prices soaring on the Board of Trade here. A wave of general buying developed which swept all before it.

Prontodale, 2:08 1/4, bay colt by Abbedale-Tramp Nimble, and driven by Paul Vineyard, came from behind in three heats today to win the $1,858 Reading Fair Futurity for 3-year-olds pacers on the Grand Circuit card.

The big sorrel-topped right-hander from Nokomis, Ill., in pitching the Yankees to a 7-to-1 triumph over the vanishing Indians before a gathering of about 4,000, gained the signal distinction of being the first major league pitcher to round out twenty-one conquests this year and touched a new high in victories for himself as he approached the end of his fifteenth year in organized baseball.

Since the beginning of Public Works Administration aid to education in 1933, 298 schools and school additions have been started in this State with PWA help, providing 3,999 class rooms with seat for 162,039 pupils, at a cost of $96,145,000,
Mrs. Constance Swyel Hamilton, wife of Captain A. C. Hamilton, U. S. A., was found dead at Fort Clayton today with her husband's service pistol beside her.

A new type of bank check, carrying an illustreated advertising message, will be used by New York State to call attention to its scenic and recreational advantages. With the slogan, "The State That Has Everything,"
Glove sales in local stores nave attained a fast pace with the onset of cooler weather, a number of buyers reporting day-by-day gains over 1937 figures since the latter part of August.

Miss Frederika (Freddy) Bancroft of Wilmington, Del., Today advanced to the semi-finals of the Huntingtdon Valley clay court tennis championship by beating Miss Betty Morris of New York, 6--2, 6-1. The defending champion, Miss Rose Hofkin of Philadelphia, and Mrs. John A. Clegg Jr. also reached the round of four.

Formation of a trade relations department by Calvert Distillers Corporation and appointment of E. G. Hoencke as director were announced yesterday by C. F. Emerson, assistant to the president of the company.

Stricfly grain fed steers and yearlings continued to get dependable action today. Weighty steers were scarce, strictly prime kinds absent. This explained a $13 top against $13.35 on Monday, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The season's largest.

A special meeting of stockholders of Symington-Gould Corporation has been called at Rochester, N. Y., for Sept. 29 to vote on the proposed acquisition of the business, goodwill and certain assets of the McConway Torley Corporation.

A former employee of the State Insurance Fund, Daniel-J. Noonan, 34 years old, of 240 East Seventyninth Street, was arrested yesterday in the office of the District Attorney, charged with attempting to bribe an assistant of the fund's general attorney, Bernard-Botein.

Acting Mayor Newbold Morris issued a proclamation yesterday designating Saturday 'as "Constitution Day" in commemoration of the signing of the Constitution on Sept. 17, 1787, at Philadelphia. He directed that all public buildings and maritime craft 'under jurisdiction of the city "shall fly the American colors throughout the entire day."

David E. Grange returned to an active position in maritime labor yesterday as president of. the Marine Stewards and Cooks Association, an independent union that has been formed in protest against coneditions in the National Maritime Union.
A suit seeking to oust Joseph Jablonower as a member of the board of examiners of the Board of Education was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.

Reports of an additional $13,500,000 of British gold engaged last week for shipment to the United States have brought the total since July 26 up almost to $165,000,000, without counting hidden and unreported shipments.
The New York Roverettes bowed to the Phoenix Ramblers, Arizona State champions, 4 to 1, in the feature game of the women's soft ball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

Renel forces in the Gaeta sector today continued their attempts to break through the Loyalist lines. Tonight's government communique says that "precise government artillery fire prevented twenty tanks from passing the first line and destroved three of them."

With the composition of the future Cabinet still undecided by President Arturo Alessandri after intense work and numerous meetings, the law establishing special powers and a state of siege began to run its four months' course today.

Funeral services for Representative Robert Low Bacon, who died suddenly last night at the State police barracks in Lake Success while on his way home from a speaking engagement in New York City, will be held at 4 P. M. Thursday at the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City.

Net income of the Clorox Chemical Company and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on June 30 amounted to $329,050 after deprecitation, Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the statement made public yesterday.

The texts of briefs submitted to Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and Lloyd Paul Stryker, defense attorney, before the jurist declared a mistrial in the case of James J. Hines, follow:

Scandinavian countries are not as disturbed by "war -scares" as the United States, according to Eero Jarnefelt, Minister of Finland to the United States, who arrived yesterday on the liner Pilsudski of the Gdynia America Line.
Threatening weather in the morning cut ,the starting field in the Women's M. G. A. one-day tournament over the Sands Point course today to twenty-eight, one of the smallest turnouts of the season.

THE other day I happened to be in New Hampshire and I heard it said-it may or may not be true-that certain local booksellers and librarians were carrying on an unofficial boycott of the New Hampshire volume of the American Guide Series. If this is so,

William K. Page. vice president of the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, was re-elected president of the Office Equipment Manufacturers Institute at the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Miss Lorraine Walther, daughter of Mr. and-Mrs. John L. Walther of Rolling Hill, Elkins Park, was married this morning to George de Braux of Paris, son of the late Rene de Braux. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Thomas

Nervousness in the foreign exchange markets of the world turned yesterday to fear and the principal monetary units of Europe followed the downward spiral in values in effect since the Czech crisis began to take form.

At the end of the Nazi party rally after the skillfully stimulated and steadily mounting hysteria has reached its climax, it is always well to attempt to estimate the results Attained and their probable effects. There has been neither the time nor the opportunity before this.

I. N. Phelps Stokes resigned as president of the Municipal Art Commission at the monthly meeting yesterday and Edward C. Blum, vice president of the commission and president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, was elected in his place.

With C. Raymond Hunt at her helm, Lill-Singva' I, owned by Vice Commodore Daniel E. Watson of Marblehead's Corinthian Yacht Club, impressively won the second race for the President Franklin D. Roosevelt Trophy of the Beverly Yacht Club by a margin of 1 minute 20 seconds over Alfred Chase's Viking as the international racers sailed a ten-mile course in light airs today.

David I. Michaelson, counsel for the Strand-East Bay Fur Dressing Company, Inc., 233 West Twentyninth Street, one of seven fur shops involved in last Sunday's bombings, disclosed yesterday that earlier in the month he had advised the District Attorney's office of threats against his client and of criminal terrorism in the fur-dressing industry.
Seven persons were killed and nineteen injured, three gravely, in a head-on collision of a New York-to-Boston bus and a trailer truck here early today.

The Municipal Art Galleries open today the thirty-fifth in the series of exhibitions by groups of New York artists, with sculpture by eleven exhibitors in the ground floor show space and oil paintings by twenty-three others in the upstairs gallery.

Lewis Browne, author of "This Believing World," writes Macmillan, his publisher, that he has signed a contract for a Swedish edition of his latest book, "Oh, Say, Can You See!" and that this novel is selling best of all his books in England.

Out of town buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a total more than double the-figure for the preceding week and well above the number reported, for. the- corresponding week of last year,

Bridge St, 25, 24x65; Stonebridge Building Corp to 192 Sheridan Ave Corp, 295 Madison Ave; mtg held by grantee ($1). St. Marks P1, 70, 25x97.6; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to 70 St. Marks Realty Corp. 40 W 33d St; p m mtg, 20.376,...

LIEUTENANTS - William F. Gaffney, from 4th Division to Telegraph Bureau, designated as acting captain, for 15 days from 8 A. M. Sept. 16. \ From precincts indicated to Juvenile Aid Bureau, for 15 days from 8 A. M. Sept. 16:

Statements made by Justice Department officials and later denied by Attorney General Cummings, that the department had ended its investigation to determine whether Federal statutes pertaining to civil rights and kidnapping had been violated by Jersey City officials, were described here today-as "a trial balloon" by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader.
In the first six months of this year American-operated air carriers flew 2,213,634 more miles and carried 113,511 more passengers than in the corresponding period of 1937.

Mrs. Harold C. Strotz, former wife of the late Jay Gould, grandson of the noted financier, died at 11:15 A. M. yesterday, four hours after she had been found unconcious of gas poisoning in the apartment she and her husband had subleased the day before at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street.

Miss Mary Proctor Scott, 71 years old, who retired four years ago after forty-five years as a teacher in the Brooklyn public schools, was found dead in bed yesterday in her room in a four-story rooming house she owned at 487 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, under circumstances that the police recorded as suspicious.

A number of the ardent duck shooters are wondering just what is going to happen to the "baiting" prohibition of the migatory waterfowl regulation, in light of the verdict returned against three Long Island hunters on Monday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

" Financial transactions," which he alleged involved Governor Earle and Albert M. Greenfield, Philadelphia real estate broker, were referred to by District Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County in testimony today before the House committee investigating charges of graft and corruption against the Governor and thirteen associates.

Arrangements have been made for special cars to transport members of the Financial Advertisers Association from the eastern territory to the twenty-third annual convention of the association, to be held in Fort Worth, Texas, from Oct. 31 through Nov. 3, it was announced yesterday by James Rascovar 2d, vice president of Albert FrankGuenther Law, Inc., who was appointed to coordinate the transportation for this group.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, told the Women's Organization for the American Merchant Marie yesterday that he expected labor troubles on United States ships to be ended on Oct. 10. He addressed a meeting of the group in the Hotel Commodore.

The Federal Surplus Commodities Corportion has been authorized to buy up to 50,000 bales of raw cotton and up to 14,000,000 yards of cotton fabric to be given to State welfare administrations for making mattresses and comforters for distribution to relief families.
The lists of new apartment tenancies submitted yesterday indicated a continuance of the heavy demand for new quarters which has kept brokers and agents busy in recent weeks.

Re-election of Governor Lewis O. Barrows and three Republican Representatives was Maine's answer tonight to a suggestion of James A. Farley, Democratic chairman, that the State elect Democrats and "get in step" with the nation.

The lowest weekly death rate on record in this city was established in the seven days ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange tabled yesterday the report of the special committee on organization and administration, headed by William S. Muller. No action will be taken until a special meeting for the purpose is called by Fred C. Moffatt,

Colonel Benjamin F. Castle has been elected a vice president and director of the C. W. Young Management Corporation, investment counsel, effective tomorrow, C. W. Young, president, announced yesterday.

Dr. A. P. Haake of Chicago told "little business" men here today that theirs was the job of keeping their own free enterprise from being stamped out by the Federal Government. He alleged that "dictatorship is already in the making in our own country."

Rain today forced postponement of the scheduled attempts of Greyhound, world champion trotter, and Her Ladyship, world champion pacing mare, to break their records on the Indiana State fair grounds track. Sep Palin,
Funeral services for Arthur Tripp Bliss, master printer and yachtsman, who died on Sunday at Sebasco Estates, Me., will be held tomorrow afternoon at his home in Winthrop, Mass.

An igloo far greater than any ever built by Eskimos, with a temperature cooler inside than-out and with the "aurora borealis" glowing on schedule on the ceiling of the dome, while outside the sun beats down on a simulated snow exterior, will squat at the World's Fair as part of the

If Great Britain and France cart hold out against Chancellor Hitler's "war bluff" for another six months in order to put their air forces on a parity with Germany's the threat of a European conflict would be eliminated, in the opinion of General Brissaud-Desmaillet, retired commander of the French army's sixty-sixth division of "Blue Devils."

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,206,900 barrels, compared with 3,349,100 in the previous week, a decline of 142,200, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

President Roosevelt plans to leave here tomorrow for his return to Hyde Park, having received reassuring reports on the condition of his son, James, who underwent an operation Sunday for a gastric ulcer.

The decisive victory of Senator Tydings over President Roosevelt's opposition and the Republican successes in Maine were declared today by John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, to show a loss of prestige and strength by Mr. Roosevelt and a

National newspaper advertisers present "an interesting potential" for increasing newspaper linage if they are given more careful consideration by publishers in the application of rate structures, the Association of National Advertisers stated yesterday in its 1938 study of LocalNational Rate Differentials.

A new mathematical definition of chaos, which brings "utter confusion" for the first time under the control of man, was reported to the Fourth International Congress for Applied Mechanics here today. The definition is a new form of calculus.

A fickle breeze cheated the upand-coming German boat Pimm of first honors and enabled Gale of Southern Lake Michigan to win the opening-day event of the international Star Class yacht championship today.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was the reviewing officer last night for the parade which was the highlight of the second day's celebration of the thirty-fifth annual mardi gras program at Coney Island. The mardi gras will last throughout the week.

Ragi A. Lian, a member of the linen and lace importing firm of Lian Brothers, 319 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday of leukemia at his home, 117 Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several weeks. His age was 47.
The renewed crisis in Central Europe was watched with intense interest by the State Department today, but comment was reserved.
The New England Power Association authorized a dividend of $1 on account of accumulations on the 6 per cent preferred and 331-3 cents on the $2 preferred stocks. Similar amounts were paid on July 1.

World stocks of refined copper at the end of -August were 494,524 tons, compared with 523,196 on July 31, a drop of 28,672, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks increased 1,772 tons, making the net decrease in August 26,900 tons.

Engineers discovered today that a plume of spray had disappeared from the center of the Canadian Horseshoe Falls. They concluded that a big new rock slide had occurred at Niagara. L. L. Gisborn, engineer for the Niagara Parks Commission,

The WPA Federal Art Project announced yesterday that, beginning Sept. 27, it would send an art caravan on a tour of New York State. The truck will carry three small exhibitions. Judson Smith, who will be in charge, will give lectures.

The easy victory of Senator Tydings in Maryland demonstrates again that the President's influence is not in itself enough to decide the issue of a Democratic primary even in a strongly Democratic State.
John M. Killits, retired judge of the Federal bench of the Northern District of Ohio, died of heart disease today in his rooms in the New Secor Hotel. He was 79 years old.
Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh welterweight, gained the decision over Bobby Pacho of Phoenix, Ariz., tonight in a keenly contested tenround bout at the Meadowbrook Bowl. Zivic weighed 148. Pacho 147.

The National Boxing Association decided today to recognize the winner of a bout between Joey Archibald of Providence and Leo Rodak of Chicago as world featherweight champion after accepting the decision of Henry Armstrong to vacate the crown at its nineteenth annual convention today.

James McConaughey, president of Wesleyan University, will preside at the opening session of the Republican convention Thursday night and Paul L. Cornell, headmaster of Romford School of Washington, Conn., will make the keynote address.

Newspapers were advocated as the best advertising medium for premiums, if the premiums are to be distributed at the point of sale, by Kenneth Plumb of the Federal Advertising Agency, in a symposium yesterday at the opening session of the annual convention of the Premium Advertising Association of America at the HoteI Astor.

A moderate upturn in Fall business was predicted yesterday at a symposuim on the business outlook conducted by the Sales Executives Club of New York at Its opening luncheon of the season at the Hotel Roosevelt.

J. David Stern, president and publisher of The New York Post, announced yesterday the sale of $2,000,000 additional first preferred stock of the newspaper. The money, he said, will be used to pay-off existing indebtedhes.

Supply of traefer meats was about normal with the exception of pork, which was light, and hinds and ribs, which was moderate, in local markets yesterday. All classes were in fair to good demand. Pork loins steady to 50c higher;-other classes unchanged. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Profitable and unprofitable ways of handling seven new opportunities for retail fashion promotions were presented yesterday in playlet form at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion Group, Inc., held at the Biltmore Hotel. About 550 members and guests attended.

Major General Hugh A. Drum, now commandant of the Sixth Corps Area, with headquarters at Chicago, will relieve Major General Frank R. McCoy as commandant of the Second Corps Area in New York on Oct. 31, the War Department announced today.

Owing to the war danger in Europe President Konstantin Paets of Estonia has decreed prolongation for twelve months of the military "state of emergency." Premier K. Eenpalu declared Estonia must be prepared to protect the integrity and independence of Estonia against aggressors and, therefore, must continue arming incessantly.

Adding its voice to Adolf Hitler's,the Italian Government today urgently advises President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia to consent to amputation of the Sudeten limb from the body of the Czechoslovak republic as the only means of preserving peace.

Hope for settlement of the department store strike rose a degree tonight when Mayor Rossi announced that the employers had accepted a seniority clause drafted by City Attorney John J. O'Toole and that the labor representatives had taken it under advisement for a decision at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning.
William Mogey, a retired manufacturer of telescopes, died Monday at his home in Plainfield, N. J., in his eighty-third year.

The engagement of Mari Barova, Chicago mezzo soprano, and Francis Row, Hungarian baritone, for the Fall season of the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre was announced yesterday by Fortune Gallo. Miss Barova will make her first appearance as Amneris in
Heavy liquidation developed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange toward the close of the market, causing it to end with losses of 65 to 90 cents a bale under the previous finals. The cotton trade,

Victor over the New Deal Congressional "purge," Senator Millard E. Tydings jubilantly watched late returns pile up a popular plurality tonight which indicated a landslide in the State Nominating Convention on Sept. 28 when the people's mandate will be formally ratified.

The Mutual Investment Company of America, Wilmington, Del., an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 100,000 shares of $1 par value common stock, including 3,340 now outstanding, which may be reacquired and offered publicly.

Irving Berlin will sail for England today on the Normandie to contest threatened legal action by a London music publisher which might hold up the release there of the Twentieth Century-Fox musical cavalcade of Berlin. songs, "Alexander's Ragtime Band."
After its second face-lifting operation in twelve years, an elm tree said to be 350 years old was ready for another period of wear and tear today.

Walter N. Rothschild, president and general manager of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, who has just completed his twenty-fifth year with the store, has received a gold watch and a hand-illuminated scroll "in grateful appreciation of his friendly guidance and sympathetic counsel, his courageous and inspiring leadership, and his unselfish and untiring efforts in developing and training people."
The three-story building with one store and two six-room apartments at 7,120 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by a client of A. W. D. Smith, attorney, to Rocco Brognano.

The outlook for a substantial recovery in business this Fall is "reasonably favorable," Dr. William Wilson Cumberland, economist, told the New York Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants last night.
A record for air mail between Honolulu and the Canal Zone was made by a letter posted at 10:30 A. M. Wednesday and received here at 6:30 P. M. Saturday. The letter,

A last-hour wave of selling forced bond prices to new low levels for the current movement in active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. During the greater part of the day the market displayed a relatively steady undertone, many sections showing moderate improvement.

The New York State C. I. O. announced yesterday that it expected some 1,000 delegates, representing 800,000 workers throughout the State, to attend its first State convention opening at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, at 10,o'clock Friday morning.

Immediately after the Hitler speech Europe faces the danger that has haunted Governments and peoples all this uneasy year. It is plain now that the reckless appeal to passion broadcast from Nuremberg was indeed a prelude, if not a signal, for the grave events that have ensued in swift, almost inevitable sequence.
