The six=story apartment building at 88-01 to 88-31. Thirty-seventh Avenue, occupying the entire block front between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets, has been sold by 35-54 Seventy-third Street, Inc., to the Cheviot Realty Corporation Potter, Hamilton Co. negotiated the deal.

NEW YORK PANORAMA, by the WPA Federal Writers Project of New York City. (Random House, $2.50.) A volume in the American Guide Series. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ??NTERNATIONAL COOPERATION WITH REGARD TO MIGRATION FOR SETTLEMENT.

France will have its first good look at American football since World War days this Winter when Jim Crowley, coach of the Fordham University team, leads a picked squad of amateur players across the Atlantic in December for a series of five exhibition games with French rugby teams, who will have assimilated the principles of the American game.

General John J. Pershing spent his seventy-eighth birthday at his hotel in Aix-enProvence, where he is resting. The annual ceremony at the Pershing Oak, planted by the general on his seventy-fifth birthday, was held at St. Mihiel.
The two twelve-family flats on a plot 72 by 96 feet at 450-452 Wayne Street, Jersey City, N. J., were sold by the Helmar Land and Improvement Company to Hargan, Inc.
More than 1,200 persons attended today the opening of the auction here of Raymere, Summer estate of William C. Durant, former automobile manufacturer, which with all its furnishings will be sold.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Hollaman gave a dinner dance here tonight at their home, Manursing Way, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Joan Hollaman. The party took place under a marquee, erected in the sunken garden of the place, which was garlanded with Southern smilax and surrounded by cedar trees Chrysanthemums,

Plans for "unscrambling" many of the complicated utility holding systems in compliance with an edict by the Securities and Exchange Commission are proceding apace and, in many cases, it is expected that skeleton plans at least will be ready for filing on Dec. 1, the final date set by the commission.

Thomas Wolfe, the author, who underwent a major operation yesterday performed by Dr. Walter E. Dandy, brain specialist, at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, was reported tonight as "resting comfortably and progressing satisfactorily."

H. D. G. Leveson-Gower's eleven today defeated the Australian cricketers by 10 wickets in their final game in England. It was the first loss suffered by an Australian team in this country, apart from test competition, for seventeen years.

Another film series was inaugurated today with Warners announcing that they will produce a sequel to "Four Daughters" under the title "Four Daughters Come Home." The cast will include Lola, Rosemary and Priscilla Lane, Gale Page, Jeffrey Lynn,

Dr. Cyrus Adler, president of the American Jewish Committee and the Jewish Theological Seminary, received on his seventy-fifth birthday today a testimonial volume conk training hundreds of tributes from public officials, headed by President Roosevelt, and from educators and spiritual, civic and communal leaders.

Lack of breeze prevented the sailing today of the fourth race in the British-American Cup series between the six-meter sloops, and the score remains at two victories for the United States team of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and one for Great Britain, with four necessary for a decision.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday admitted to citizenship 310 aliens, of whom 137 were women. The court room was crowded with candidates for citizenship and their friends.

The battle of the Sixteenth Congressional District, where Repretentative John J. O'Connor, Democratic chairman of the House Rules Committee and a prominent figure on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, is seeking both the Democratic and Republican nominations,

Realty activity in the Bronx as reported by brokers yesterday involved a number of one and two family dwellings and a garage. Among the properties sold was the two-family house containing thirteen rooms on a plot 31 by 147 feet at 2,771 Reservoir Avenue.

James Hancock Coe, vice president of the Englewood Sewerage Company and former chairman of the New Jersey Public Utility Association, died in his home here late last night of heart disease. He was 79 years old.
A move toward liberalizing Poland's political regime is seen in the dissolution of Parliament, decreed this afternoon by President Ignaz Moscicki, who declared:

Superior Judge Edward T. Bishop to day convicted Harry Bridges, West Coast director of the C. I. O., of contempt of court in sending a telegram to Secretary Perkins criticizing another judge's decision in an A. F. of L.-C. I. O. dispute.

J. Donald Budge, the defending men's titleholder, will appear in the Forest Hills Stadium against Charles Hare of Great Britain today with the resumption of competion in the national tennis championships after a postponement of twenty-four hours.

Brooklyn animal-lovers rejoiced yesterday when Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced that Bill, the grieving male elephant at the Prospect Park zoo, soon would have a new playmate to replace Hilda, which had to be destroyed last Thursday because of injuries she suffered- on Aug. 29 when Bill pushed her into a 25-foot moat.
The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed during August totaled 222,996 tons, compared with 182,413 in August last year.

Sixty per cent of all public and private construction in this city during the last two years has been done by the WPA, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, New York City administrator of the WPA, said yesterday at the quarterly luncheon meeting of the Federal Business Association in the New York area at the Hotel New Yorker.

More than 300 persons appeared to be about evenly divided tonight at a public hearing here on a proposed ordinance by which pickets Hearing placards would be charged $50 a week by the Borough Commission.

Threats of war in Europe yesterday brought consternation to the foreign trade community here as exporters and importers began hurried preparations to cope with the difficulties which they expect; will develop as soon as fighting breaks out.

Miss Virginia Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania from her annual visit abroad. She spent three months in England, attending in London the meeting of the international council of the International Federation of University Women.

Building projects for which plans were filed in the various boroughs yesterday included a seventy-threefamily apartment structure, to be erected at 3,602-26. Kings. Highway, Brooklyn, at a cost of about $400,000.

Following the proclamation of martial law in the Sudeten areas and the death of six Germans in clashes with Czech police, German official quarters were inclined to view the Czech-Sudeten situation with fresh concern.

The Wax Museum, Inc., the same interests who operate the famous Musee Grevin in Paris, France, and the Musee Histqrique Canadien in Montreal, Canada, have leased the second .and third floors, together with a large entrance, in the building at 1,631-7 Broadway, corner of Fiftieth Street, it was announced yesterday.
Sam Williams, apprentice rider who led the field in the Spring meeting here, booted home four winners in the first, five races at the Detroit Fair Grounds today.

A bequest of $10,000 to Princeton University was made in the will of Edward R. Otheman, attorney, filed for probate yesterday. Mr. Otheman, a graduate of the Princeton class of '95, died at his home, 150 East Seventy-second N Street, on Sept. 6.

President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell of 270 Park Avenue will give a dinner dance on Dec. 27 in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Ruth Mason Bissell. Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving will return tomorrow from Southampton to their home here at 435 East Fifty-second Street.

Luncheon meeting, Kiwanis Club, Hotel McAlpin, 12:30 P. M. "Shall We Preserve Our Present Democratic Form of Government?" Representative John J. O'Connor. Luncheon, Circus Saints and Sinners, Hotel Commodore, 12:42 P. M. Initiation of Bruce Barton.

Born to golden fortune, Robert Low Bacon felt his responsibility and fulfilled it. Setting his heart upon a public career, he fitted himself for it. After an apprenticeship in local politics in Nassau County he was sent to the House of Representatives.
Mrs. Watson T. Dunmore, vice president of the National Elocutionists Association, died in her home here last night after a long illness.

The only thing lacking in the tale of sunken treasure which Captain John Craig brings back from the coast of the Dominican Republic is Long John Silver's parrot to perch on the back of his chair and croak, "Pieces of eight! Pieces of eight!"
Eddie Simms, 196 1/2, Cleveland, outpointed Jim Howell, 207 1/2, Harlem, in the feature ten-round bout at the Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, last night before a crowd of 2,000.

Sixteen foreign stars and fourteen American riders will compete in the six-day bicycle race which begins at Madison Square Garden Sunday night. Manager Harry Mendel has acquired the outstanding American stars as well as the leading foreign contenders for this grind.

An application by Dominion Stores, Ltd., a Canadian chain-store company, to delist its common shares from registration and listing, on the New York Stock Exchange was opposed today at a hearing before Charles Moore, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, by John Haskell, director of the department of stock list of the Stock Exchange.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates Sept. 13, unless specified: At San Pedro: Bridge, Winslow. At Canal Zone: Dunlap. Fanning. Navy Yard Zone: Dunlap, Winslow. Houston, Portland. Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Guantanamo: Trinity, YT-129.
Pattrick (Paddy) McGuigan, former pugilist, died today in his home here. He was 78 years old. In 1893 he fought ten rounds with Joe Walcott in Newark.

Governor Francis P. Murphy, wealthy industrialist, tonight led Attorney General Thomas P. Cheney into the home stretch in New Hampshire's tight Republican Gubernatorial primary, but slow tabulation of the big-city vote left the outcome unsettled.

Mrs. Frank C. Mason gave a luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, Mrs. Roy Howard and Mrs. Stuart McNamara. Another luncheon was given there by Mrs. Frederic Foster de Rham. Her guests included Mrs. Hackett Barney, Mrs. David Wagstaff and Mrs. J. Victor Onativia.

At a brief and simple service held yesterday morning the ceremonial recognition of the body of Mother Francis Xavier Cabrini-the last ritual before her beatification-was witnessed by high dignitaries of the Catholic Church as well as 500 girl students at the high school bearing her name.

Representatives of the towboat operating interests and the United Marine Division of the International Longshoremen's Association conferred yesterday at the Towboat Exchange, 17 Battery Place, on the union's demands for a new wage contract.

The Securities and Exchange Commission appointed today George A. McNulty as assistant general counsel. Graduated from St. Louis University and from the Harvard Law School, Mr. McNulty practiced law in St. Louis with Carter Jones from 1925 until August, 1933, when he joined the legal staff of the NRA, serving as assistant director of litigation.

Gilbert H. Montague of New York entertained with a luncheon at Beaulieu today in honor of Rolland J. Hamilton of New York. Other guests included John D. Rockefeller Jr., Herbert L. Satterlee, Potter Palmer, William Procter, Lincoln Cromwell, William Jay Schieffelin, Charles E. Sampson, Roscoe C. E. Brown, Thomas H. Powers, Franklin Robinson, William McNair and George L. Stebbins.

Graduated from St. Louis University and from the Harvard Law School, Mr. McNulty practiced law in St. Louis with Carter Jones from 1925 until August, 1933, when he joined the legal staff of the NRA, serving as assistant director of litigation.

An offer to pay his debts at the rate of 10 cents a week failed to save John Stefanski, 59, from being sentenced to jail for a month on a charge of not complying with 'State labor laws. City Judge George Woltz figured it would take Stefanski nearly 231 years to pay the $1,200 he owed.

Of the twelve jurors and two alternates who sat through four weeks of the trial of James J. Hines which ended in a mistrial, only one was found yesterday who admitted that the question by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey about the Tammany leader's posslble connection with the "poultry racket" had created an ineradicable prejudice in his mind.

Gilbert H. Montague of New York entertained with a luncheon at Beaulieu today in honor of Rolland J. Hamilton of New York. Other guests included John D. Rockefeller Jr., Herbert L. Satterlee, Potter Palmer, William Procter, Lincoln Cromwell, William Jay Schieffelin, Charles E. Sampson, Roscoe C. E. Brown, Thomas H. Powers, Franklin Robinson, William McNair and George L. Stebbins.

Fifteen commission weaving shops employing-about 300 workers, who were among the 2,500 affected by the broad-silk strike which started yesterday, will return to work tomorrow, having signed contracts today.

While hundreds of their friends looked on, Ellen Wilson McAdoo, daughter, of Senator McAdoo tonight was married to William Aifred Hinshaw, a musician, at the Beverly Hills Community Presbyterian Church.

Mayor La Guardia in a talk to about 200 persons at the Arizona Club tonight reviewed incidents of his boyhood in Arizona. His introduction to crooked politicians came through an Indian agent at Fort Whipple, he said, and his first knowledge of exploitation came from seeing gambling devices used to take the wages from immigrant laborers on the railroads.

An offer to pay his debts at the rate of 10 cents a week failed to save John Stefanski, 59, from being sentenced to jail for a month on a charge of not complying with 'State labor laws. City Judge George Woltz figured it would take Stefanski nearly 231 years to pay the $1,200 he owed.

Of the twelve jurors and two alternates who sat through four weeks of the trial of James J. Hines which ended in a mistrial, only one was found yesterday who admitted that the question by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey about the Tammany leader's posslble connection with the "poultry racket" had created an ineradicable prejudice in his mind.

Fifteen commission weaving shops employing-about 300 workers, who were among the 2,500 affected by the broad-silk strike which started yesterday, will return to work tomorrow, having signed contracts today.

While hundreds of their friends looked on, Ellen Wilson McAdoo, daughter, of Senator McAdoo tonight was married to William Aifred Hinshaw, a musician, at the Beverly Hills Community Presbyterian Church.
Republican leaders yesterday appeared less certain as to the availability of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as the party's candidate for Governor this Fall.
A Petition for the legal registration of the Communist party of Cuba was approved today by the provincial government of Havana Province.

The Fall season in the theatrical world opens this evening at the Playhouse, when the Messrs. Bushar and Tuerk, and also Mr. Brady, toss in "Come Across," a melodrama by Dr.'Guy Beauchamp and Michael Pertwee, which deals with an American gangster in London. In it are Arthur Vinton,
The executive committee of the Chicago Stock Exchange approved today the following listing applications: General Outdoor Advertising Company, INc.,
Wilbur Watson Hubbard, former president of the Hubbard Fertilizer Company of Baltimore, died at his home here late yesterday after a brief illness.

The committee on stock lists of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized listing of the following securities, of which the listing applications will be submitted to the board of governors for their information at its next meeting:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a former active railroad official, I am glad that you published the letter from "Railroader." There are parts of it on which I would like to comment:

Japanese forces hammered a few miles forward at heavy cost to themselves and Chinese armies north and south of the Yangtze River yesterday and today. The Japanese are a few miles from Hwangchwang, from which nearly all civilians have fled.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Henriette A. Werner, daughter, executrix, Shaker Heights, Ohio, residue: Nettie Kutner Fuld, Charles Kutner, 181 Claremont Ave., $1,000 each; Frances Gallas, 130 E. 82d St., $2,500.
General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff, said today that the army had developed new anti-tank guns which were improvements on foreign models, and would wipe out any enemy tank offensive.

Because Millbank, Tweed Hope, general counsel to the New York Stock Exchange, also represent one of the concerns affected by the inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission into certain investment trusts, the Stock Exchange about a month ago retained Hughes, Richards,

Old school Yankees would call the at fir results of the Maine election "a mixedup mess." The defeat of former Governor Brann by Governor Barrows seems to have tested on a clearer "straight" issue than was evident in the Congressional elections.

The performance on Oct. 6 of Clare Boothe's new play, "Kiss the Boys Goodbye," at the Henry Miller Theatre has been taken over for the benefit of the Stepney Fresh Air Camp, a branch of the East Side Settlement House. As secretary of the beneficiary, Mrs. Gordon Wilson Abbott is among the many aiding With arrangements for the event.

At the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club yesterday the following clubs were elected to membership: Golden Retriever Club of America, Roanoke Kennel Club and the Harbor Cities Kennel Club. This brings the total membership in the governing body to 227 clubs.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has received the following applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-thecounter market from New York City.
Gross assets, $80,067; net, $77,884. To Antoinette K. Brown, residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $72,336. Nevius, Brett Kellog, attorneys, 115 Broadway.
Joseph Adam Kelsey, recently elected president of the Standard Surety and Casualty Company of New York, died here this afternoon at his home, 176 South Mountain Avenue, in his eighty-first year.
Professor Samuel Alexander, whose contributions to philosophy were recognized in 1930 by the award of the Order of Merit, died today at-the age of 79.

An afternoon and night of acute anxiety ended this morning with the British and French Governments coolly seeking a new basis for the resumption of Czech-German negotiations in Prague. It was believed in London that a plebiscite under international auspices might form a part of such a new basis if peace could not be preserved in any other way.

Weather clear; track heavy. After the matinee thunderstorm that disturbed the first day's play in the national amateur golf championship here, there was an evening performance of the same kind that left the links soggy in the low spots for today's tour.
State Senator Duncan T. O'Brien died early yesterday morning in his home, 161 West Eighty-sixth Street, after being stricken with a cerebral hemorrhage Monday night. He was 43 years old.
The Draper Corporation, cotton loom manufacturers, announced today that due to increased business its Hopedale plant would go on a five-day week immediately.

The Giants' desperate last-ditch stand to retrieve that fading third straight National League pennant remained in a state of suspended animation yesterday when heavy morning rains forced a postponement of the opening clash of the three-game series with the leading Pirates at the Polo Grounds.

Announcement, has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lloyd Goldsborough of Dongan Hills, S. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth' Goldsborough, to George Herbert Schwedersky of Providence, R. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Schwedersky of Brooklyn.

Mrs. Gladys Weston Ryan, widow of John Francis Ryan of Glen Ridge, N. J., and daughter of Mrs. Walter Coleman Weston of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Weston, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Ascension to William Stanley Lamont, son of Mrs. William Stanley Lamont of Newark, N. J., and the late Mr. Lamont. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Carl Smith.

Democratic voters in the South, Midwest, Far West and on the border have, with the renomination of Senator Tydings in Maryland and even without the foreshadowed success of Senator George today in Georgia, made it abUndantly plain that they favor Congressional independence of the Executive when they believe that independence to have been honest and intelligent. This,

Miss Sarah Ford de Mott Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Warren Stevens of this place, will be married on Sept. 23 to Russell Ellsworth Watson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson, also of New Brunswick. 'The ceremony will be performed in the garden of the Stevens home by the Rev. Milton T. Stauffer, pastor of the Second Reformed Church of New Brunswick.

For improvement at once with a six-story elevator apartment house, the large plot, 167x140 feet, on the northeast corner of Broadway and Vietor Avenue, Elmhurst, L. I., has been purchased by a Manhattan building syndicate from the Broadway-Elmhurst Corporation.
Mrs. Ellis Halcomb of this city and the Barclay, Philadelphia, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Phyllis Halcomb of Malvern, Pa., to Gordon Alexander Craig.

Representatives of the French and British Governments have put pressure on President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia to accept Sudeten German demands for a plebiscite, it was declared early today in diplomatic quarters constantly in touch with the Prague Government.

Word of the Sudeten German ultimatum to the Czechoslovak Government sent a flood of selling into the New York Stock Exchange in the final hour yesterday afternoon. Transactions between 2 and 3 o'clock shot to 1,070,000 shares in a roaring market that kept the tickers busy for fifteen minutes after the close.

We cannot believe that even the strictest application of the rule of evidence compels any such result. We are equally at a'loss to understand why Justice Pecora, even if convinced as to the rightness of his view on this first point, ended the trial.

White houses, always favored by many owners as being of a standard and conservative color, appear to be growing in popularity. The trend to white is evident in a study of mortgage insurance business transacted by the Federal Housing Administration this year.
James Oleska of the Shoreview Golf Club carried off the low gross honors in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament over the Inwood Country Club course today.
Colonel Clarence R. Day, retired chief of staff of the 79th Division, died yesterday of a heart attack. He would have been 66 years old in ten days. He served in the Spanish-American and World Wars.
A total of thirty-one plots at Lido Colony, Long Beach, L. I., were sold Saturday at the auction sale conducted on the premises by J. Edward Breuer, auctioneer, a check-up yesterday revealed.

Japan has experienced some improvement in business outlook owing to further gains in export trade and the prospect of improved business in the United States, according to a weekly summary of developments in business abroad, based on cable and radio advices, issued today by the Department of Commerce.

Capital-outlay programs submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday by the five Borough Presidents ranged from $1,600,000 requested by Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn to $158,000,000 proposed by James J. Lyons of the Bronx.

Vice President John N. Garner was endorsed today by the Democratic State Convention for the 1940 Presidential nomination. The convention adopted a resolution hailing the Vice President as the "best qualified American to carry forward the banner of democracy upon the conclusion of the second term of our beloved President, Franklin D. Roosevelt."

A declaration in favor of a system of hospitals "founded, financed and controlled by the government without regard to profit, in all cities where it is practical" was made today by the New Jersey Federation of Labor in a resolution adopted unanimously at the closing session of the organization's sixtieth annual convention in the Ritz Carlton Hotel here.

Pilgrim Ave (15-4232), w s, 200 ft s of Evelyn Pl. 50x100; Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn to Frank Fine, 3,229 Westchester Ave. Parsifal Pl (18-5408) n s, 158 ft e of Siegfried Pl, 26x80; William H. Rollins to William N. Mehrhoff, 3,167 Parsifal Pl.

Dan Galgano of Green Meadow, playing with Jack Sullivan of the same club in the one-day proamateur tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association today, set a course record at the Gedney Country Club when he shot a 66 to better by one stroke a mark made by Paul. Runyan eight years ago and tied last year by Leo Diegel.
The National Boxing Association at its convention today elected Charles F. Reynolds of Providence, R. I. president to succeed Frank Hogan of Montreal.

The entire estate of James R. Sheffield, former Ambassador to Mexico, except for personal effects bequeathed to his son, will go to his widow, according to his will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. The estate was appraised at "more than $50,000." Mr. Sheffield died on Sept. 2 at his camp on upper Saranac Lake.

Kenesaw M. Landis, commissioner of baseball, today called a meeting of club representatives and league officials for Friday morning at the Roosevelt Hotel, New York City, to make world series arrangements.
The Japanese spokesman announced last night that Matowchen had been captured at 9:40 yesterday morning, thus jeopardizing the last strong Chinese boom across the Yangtze River.
President Roosevelt sped toward Washington tonight to be at the seat of government during the present crisis in Europe.
Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy in an open letter to Viscount Runciman, the British mediator, today urged a plebiscite for "all Czechoslovak nationalities."

With the majority of the rentals reported made to families from Manhattan, the ten new apartment houses near Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, L. I., are on the average now more than 65 per cent rented, it was reported yesterday by the Cord Meyer Development Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Larkin gave a supper dance tonight at Hillcrest, their home here, to introduce to society their daughters, the Misses Hope and Shirley Jane Larkin. An improvised dance floor was placed under a marquee in the gardens, which extend across the front of the estate.

Completing ten days of international racing in thirty - square - meter yachts under the colors of the Beverly Yacht Club, Alfred E. Chase's Viking annexed the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Bowl by a two-point margin over Daniel E. Watson's Lill-Singva I by finishing in third place today.
Montgomery Ward Co. reported yesterday, in their semi-annual statement covering -the six months ended on July 31, a net profit of $5,139,526 after taxes and other deductions.

Hosiery Workers stood with bowed heads today at the grave of Raymond Cooke, and then paraded quietly in front of the Oscar Nebel mill where he was shot last week in a labor disturbance growing out of the company's effort to move its machinery to a new plant at Winchester, Va.

The following Reserve officers now assigned to the 1st Division, Regular Army are attached for training to units of the 1st Military Area as follows: 368TH FIELD ARTILLERY 2d Lieut. Bror H. Anderson, F.A.-Res., 118 Arlington Ave.,-Jamestown, N. Y.
Mrs. George Hyde Clarke has come from Cooperstown, N. Y., to Mayfair House. Mrs. Elisha C. Tower and Earl C. Tower, who are arriving today on the Europa, will be at the SavoyPlaza.

The marriage of Miss Leo E. Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harriman Smith of Des Moines, to Wilbur Carver, also of Des Moines, took place at noon yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a wedding breakfast at the New Yorker.

Bennett Cerf of Random House sailed on the Normandie yesterday for Barcelona, where he will meet Andre Malraux, French author; Ralph Bates and Ernest Hemingway. He said he expected to return in a few weeks with manuscripts on Spain from at least one and perhaps each of the writers.

In the six years from Dec. 31, 1932, the New York Central Railroad has reduced the funded debt of itself and lessor companies by $128,000,000, with a consequent annual interest saving of $9,000,000, W. F. Place, vice president, announced yesterday.

After a successful day's test the new Graf Zeppelin, commanded by Dr. Hugo Eckener, assisted by Captain Hans von Schiller, landed at the Loewenthal hangar here this evening. The airship passed over many South German towns, including Munich and Nuremberg, flying so low as to be plainly visible from below.

More than 500 persons attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Astor at which plans were made for the fifth annual presentation of "Night of Stars" at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 16, through which the Greater New York Campaign of the United Palestine Appeal expects to raise $100,000

The Delaware Republican State convention nominated today George S. Williams of Millsboro, the party's candidate for the State's 'one member in the national House of Representatives. The present member is William F. Allen, a Democrat, a candidate for re-election.
Seventy Yale football players arrived here on three buses about 5 P. M. today and opened training quarters in the crew's dormitory overlooking the Thames.

No theatre ticket broker who signed the new ticket code last Monday had withdrawn his signature at 4 P. M. yesterday, the deadline set for reconsideration of the pact by the agencies, according to James F. Reilly, executive secretary of the League of New York Theatres.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 12: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS McCarthy, J. L., New London, Conn. about Jan. 15, to 15th Naval Dist., Balbo?? C.Z. McGrath, H. W., Norfolk Navy Yard Portsmouth, Va., March 1, 1939, to home relieved all active duty.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan explained yesterday that he had requested $350,000 in capital funds for the removal of forty subway kiosks because he considered them dangerous obstructions.

Senator H. Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, told the National Small Business Men's Association tonight the outstanding reason for what he termed the depressed condition of business was the Administration's attitude toward all kinds of business and those who benefit by business prosperity.

Death Anniounced Retired Fireman Henry J. Steinhoff, formerly member of Engine Co. 71, residing at 215 East 164th St., Bronx, died Sept. 12. Trial Declsions The following members of the department having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, deputy fire commissioner, on date specified,

The unofficial committee recently named by Governor Lehman to consider the possibility of reviving operation of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway held an organization meeting yesterday in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, and chose Albert Ritchie, a New Rochelle lawyer, as its chairman. Gordon Miller of Pelham was named secretary.

RKO today signed Henry C. Potter to direct "The Castles," the Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers picture, based on the life of Irene and Vernon Castle, in which Mrs. Castle, herself, will probably appear. Potter was originally a New York director.

A scrappy Eastern All-Star football team outrushed the Boston Shamrocks' professional eleven for a 7--6 victory tonight before a crowd of 20,000 at Fenway Park. The game opened Boston's gridiron season.
With a strike of 3,000 C. I. O. retail dry goods clerks called for noon today, representatives of the employers said yesterday they could not grant the union's demands and remain in business.
Essie Hanover, a bay mare from the Hanover (Pa.) Shoe Farms, today annexed the $4,600 Reading Fair futurity for 3-year-old trotters, called by many the "Little Hambletonian" of Grand Circuit racing.

The lowest bid for general construction of the new Junior and Senior High School in Glen Rock, N. J., received by the Board of Education of that borough was $245,207. It was submitted by the Allied Construction Company, according to Brown's Letters, Inc. Other low bids were:

The Board of Examinters reports that there have been placed, as of Sept. 13, 1938. upon the eligible list of holders of license as teacher of English in day secondary. schools other than junior high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Daniel J. Noonan, 240 East Seventy-ninth Street, an insurance man and former employee of the State Insurance Fund, was held in $10,000 bail yesterday by Magistrate William Farrell in Felony Court for hearing Friday on a charge of attempted bribery.

Denouncing skyscrapers as one of the most abominable of man's inventions, and slum clearance projects as merely the transferring of slums "from the body to the soul," Frank Lloyd Wright, the architect, expressed his profound pity last night -for those who have to live in New York City, "the most provincial of all provinces."

His fast ball working better than it has at any time since his return to Texas, Schoolboy Rowe and the Exporters defeated Tulsa, 3 to 1, today to give Beaumont two straight victories in the first round of the Shaughnessy play-off.

The office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, who, in the case against James J. Hines presented evidence gained through tapping telephone wires and upheld the ethics of the practice by public officers, obtained yesterday the indictment of three men on charges of wire-tapping.

Bobby Stap, 13-year-old "ancient mariner," who has stowed away four times on voyages that have taken him 20,000 free miles by sea, appeared yesterday to be on the threshold of a bona fide sea-going career, a line of endeavor said to have captured the imagination of his ancestors for the last 200 years.

The new Church Committee for China Relief began yesterday a campaign for funds for Chinese relief at the first of a series of regional conferences for leaders, held at the United Charities Building, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The grant Atlantic Refining Company has filed an amendment under the Securities Act of 1933 to its registration statement covering $25,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures, due on Sept. 1, 1953. These securities will be offered at 99 plus accrued interest from Sept. 1, 1938.

No man in the United States has a brighter political future than Mayor La Guardia of New York, according to Senator Ashurst of Arizona, who introduced the Mayor today to residents of Mr. La Guardia's boyhood home.

The Census Bureau reported today cotton consumed during August totaled 561,406 bales of lint and 70,218 of linters, compared with 449,511 and 61,805 during July this year, and 603,617 and 72,088 during August last year.

There is no intelligent argument in favor of war- as a means of settling human problems and human relationships, Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, declared yesterday in an address to 1,200 entering freshmen at a special meeting at the Adams Memorial Church, 207 East Thirtieth Street.

Adrian K. Quist of the Australian Davis Cup team followed Robert L. Riggs Jr. out of the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday as the ranks of the overseas players in the men's tournament were reduced to two survivors from the land of the kangaroo and ambidextrous stroke production.

Fred Perry, British tennis player, and his wife, Helen Vinson, the actress, paid a mysterious visit to John F. Dailey, chief assistant United States Attorney, yesterday afternoon and remained in conference for two hours.

Joseph M. Byrne, Acting City Treasurer of Newark, who was a prominent figure in Newark labor circles for many years, died last night at his home here of a heart ailment after a long illness. His age was 59.

The Civil Aeronautics Authority has started a nation-wide survey of airports, which will be the basis of a report to Congress on the advisability of Federal participation in the development and operation of a national airport system.

An assurance by Dr. Rudolf Brinkmann, German State Secretary in the Ministry of Economics, that Vienna would be the city that set the fashions for all Germany in women's dress was given at the Autumn Trade Fair here today. It caused immense satisfaction.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Isabel Ward, daughter of Mrs. Atwood Ward of 400 East Fifty-second Street, and of James Lakeman Ward of this city and Oyster Bay, to Robert H. L. Coogan, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Gordon Coogan of Madison, N. J.
Steel prices for the final quarter, which are expected to be announced this eek or next, probably will show no changes except possibly on tin plate and heavy rails, according to the Iron Age.

Turpentine firm, 211/2c: sales 35 barrels; receipts 433 barrels; shipments 108 barrels; stock 48,426 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 352; receipts 2,467; shipments 1,406; stock 249,110. Quote: S. $3.50; D, E, $3.90; F, $3.95; G, H. I, K, M, $4.05; N, $4.90-95: WG, $5,05; WW, X, $8.10.
All Europe is looking up at a seventeenth-story window, wondering whether the dictators who are walking on a ledge will jump.

The richest of the Fall meetings will get under way today with close to a quarter of a million dollars available in stake money, and nine named for the Fall Highweight Handicap, opening-day feature at Belmont Park.

Stocks fluctuated erratically in nervous trading; pivotal issues rallied and closed steadier at lower levels after weakening sharply from early gains; trading second largest of year; turnover 2,819,070 shares.
With a perseverance worthy of a greater cause, the Yankees and the Indians tried at League Park today to complete their season's schedule with the twenty-second skirmish between the two teams.

Monroe St, 112-114; Hazel Hugh Realties, Inc, to Central Savings Bank, purchase money mtg, 7 years, 4 per cent; $24,000. 119th St, 274 W; Nathan Robin to Broadway Savings Bank, purchase money mtg., 7 years, 3 to 4 percent; $19,750.

A suit charging that the management of the Susquehanna Silk Mills wasted company assets by continuing operations at a loss from March 16, 1936, to May 31, 1937, was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by Mary Lord, a stockholder.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York, in a report adopted yesterday at its first meeting of the season, at the Merchants Association rooms, urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to cooperate with carriers and local interests in considering the establishment of union truck terminals in large cities.

A long-range program for expansion of the city's rapid transit facilities, at an estimated total cost of $827,102,344, was submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday by the Board of Transportation.
A decree levying a State transfer tax of $33,336 against the estate of Bert McKevett of New York, Saltaire, L. I., and Miami, Fla, has been entered by Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins here.

Mrs. Sylva Annenberg Leichner of Fresh Meadow, former New York State champion, captured the low gross prize in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day competition over the Cherry Valley course today.

Mrs. Marguerite Polleys Krock, wife of Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died here yesterday at 1,095 Park Avenue, where she stayed during the past Summer. She had been ill more than a year. She was 48 years old.

Suits against a number of liquor retailers in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens were prepared here yesterday by the National Distillers Products Corporation as an aftermath of the liquor price war on Monday in which a number of National's domestic. liquors were of fered at off-prices.

Daniel J. McCarthy, clerk of the Sheriff's jury of New York County since 1913, died during his sleep late Monday night at his residence, the Hotel Le Marquis, 12 East Thirty-first Street. He was 68years old.

Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey announced before sailing for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday that at the end of his present term he would retire permanently to private law practice.

Farm Board experiences seem likely to be repeated in our dairy industry. Record milk production has led to the piling up of stocks of butter and cheese to the highest figures known. The Government has advanced $33,375,000 to one of the producers' cooperatives, the Dairy Products Marketing Association, to buy up surplus butter, and in addition has itself bought butter to distribute for relief purposes.

Winners in the competition in which 500 muralists throughout the country vied for the tasks of creating paintings more than 105 feet tall for the Federal Building at the World' Fair were announced yesterday.

Five debutantes and socially prominent young matrons picketed briefly yesterday the headquarters of Kenneth Simpson, Republican county leader, in the National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on the Hines case clearly demonstrates the logical incompatibility of the layman's reasoning as to what may constitute something "essentially technical" as opposed to what exemplary judicial thought considers all-pervading and of the essence.

Sought by the police of several cities as a fugitive, George B. Mahler, 33 years old, strolled on Broadway yesterday within a few blocks of the Federal Court House in Foley Square, headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, secure in the knowledge that he had "beaten" six cases in his record of eight arrests.

Headed by Harry Bridges, C. I. O. regional director, the committee for the longshoremen's union broke off negotiations late today over terms of a new contract with the Waterfront Employers Association, representing all the shipowners on the Pacific Coast.
The St. Louis Cardinals gave Mike Gonzales a flying start in his debut as a manager today by defeating the Phillies in both ends of a double-header, 12 to 9 and 3 to 2.

What is claimed to be a new approach to market evaluation was outlined yesterday by Outdoor Advertising, Inc., when John E. Brennan, director of market research, described a study entitled "Urban Markets and Retail Sales" at a luncheon to the trade press at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street.

The total cost of the Red Hook low-rental housing development, including land, will be about $12,000,000, or approximately $4,600,000 less than the $16,592,766 provided in the budget allowed by the United States Housing Authority, it was announced yesterday by Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.

Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation plays with large figures in the rapid transit program which he submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday. The proposed projects approved by his board would cost $827,102,344.

Mrs. Shepard Krech opened her home, Briar Patch, this afternoon for a bridge and tea given as a benefit for St. Luke's Episcopal Church. The committee in charge included Mrs. Krech as chairman, Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford, Mrs. Victor Harris, Mrs. N. A. Campbell, Mrs. Percy Schenck. Mrs. E. Louise Vanderbilt and Miss Edna MacLean Nash. More than 200 persons were present.

Bertrand Russell, who is coming to America to be visiting Professor of Philosophy at the University of Chicago this Winter, will arrive in New York on Sept. 26, two days before publication of his book, "Power: A New Social Analysis" (Norton).
To study the needs in the Caribbean for a navy base as authorized by the last Congress, a board headed by Rear Admiral A. J. Hepburn arrived late today from Miami by plane.

Tuesday's primary in New Hampshire and the campaign that preceded it had a curious interest, at least on the Republican side. Governor Murphy, a candidate for re-election, was opposed by Attorney General Cheney, who made certain charges against him and was somewhat less than Chesterfieldian in speech.

Charging that President Roosevelt's attempts to reorganize the Supreme Court and the structure of the Federal Government constituted two steps toward dictatorship, Representative John J. O'Connor declared yesterday that the third step, as he characterized the President's "purge," remained to be rebuked.
The German Sedta Company promises air mail and passenger service from Ecuador to Berlin in six days, via Lima, as soon as it is possible to carry out present plans.

Pensloned On their own applications-To take effect 12 midnight. Sept. 15. PATROLMEN - Gustave Scheurenbrand, 90th Precinct, at $1.500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 16, 1913. Thomas Ccnnolly, Traffic Precinct F. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 2, 1913.
J. Smith Ferebee, broker who started the golf marathon craze by playing 144 holes Aug. 5, decided today to play 576 holes from coast to coast in four days "to end this marathon golf business."

After perfect order had apparently been restored in most of the Sudeten German areas yesterday, further serious firing on the police occurred in Eger last night that developed into a pitched battle, with six killed.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 13: MAJOR GENERALS Drum, H. A.. Sixth Corps Area, Chicago, to command Second Corps Area, Governors Island. N. Y.. Oct. 31.

Pittsburgh at New York-Tobin (12-9) vs. Melton (12-13). (Only game scheduled.) American League New York at Detroit-Hadley (9-4) vs. Coffman (2-4) or Eisenstat (7-6). Washington at St. Louis--Leonard (11-13) vs. Mills (8-10).
Miss Alice L. Granbery of Bronxville, secretary-treasurer of the Reformed Church here, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. Her age was 61.
Fed steers with weight again saw good action today and the market on such kinds was firm at the season's high point, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

Plans for a theatre to produce the outstanding successes of the last twenty years at the New York World's Fair have received the approval of Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, and of the fair's amusement board, it was disclosed yesterday by John Krimsky, director of entertainment for the fair, at the closing session of the American Theatre Council's convention in the Hotel Astor.

A collection of 100 articles depicting the modern Eskimos of Greenland at work and at play was presented to the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen Rohde, former American Minister to Denmark.

Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Procter will give a dinner on Friday at Orleton Farm, Stockbridge, in compliment to the Right Rev. William Appleton Lawrence of Springfield, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Western Massachusetts.
Five members of America's Walker Cup team went down to defeat in the course of today's first and second match-play rounds in the national amateur golf championship at Oakmont.
The ultimatum sent to the Czech Government by the Sudeten party yesterday is declared here to have been drawn up without Chancellor Adolf Hitler's approval.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation purchased in the open market in August $2,160,000 of its ten-year 4 1/2 per cent convertible debentures which will mature on Jan. 1 next.
The County Center here was transformed into a bower of Autumn blooms today at the opening of a four-day flower show under the auspices of the Westchester County Horticultural Association, Inc.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek devoted the entire day yesterday at a sewing machine making garments for soldiers and refugees. She worked shoulder to shoulder with many other Hankow women doing volunteer war work in Mme. Chiang's new-life movement work center here.

Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky and Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania will return today on the United States liner Washington from the Congress of the Inter-Parliamentary Union at The Hague. Senator

The spinning of cables for the 3,770-foot Bronx-Whitestone suspension bridge, which will provide for motorists a direct, express highway connection between the World's Fair in Queens and the parkways of upper New York State and New England, was begun yesterday.

Committees representing the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association and Local 75 of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee completed work this afternoon on a new agreement for settlement of the broad silk strike among some 1,200 workers in about 125 shops.

A little more of this misty, moisty weather and the survivors in the national amateur golf championship here will be going off the first tee in lifeboats. A left-handed golfer started here and didn't get very far in the tournament. But a web-footed player probably would have been in the semi-final round by this time.

Purchase from the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation of a $200,000 twin-engine patrol boat for survey flights across the Atlantic was announced yesterday by the American Export Airlines, Inc., a subsidiary of American Export Lines, Inc.

Sailing the twenty miles from Clayton, N. Y., in a little less than twelve hours, the sloop Blue Streak, representing Massachusetts Institute of Technology, today won the first annual cruising race-of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association...

An order requiring Mrs. Emma B. Dunn of Pompton Lakes to show cause Monday why she should not be declared in contempt of court for padlocking two buildings of the Schultz Brewing Company here was obtained in Federal court in Newark today by Frank Schultz, president of the company.

By RALPH LONG 79th St. 168-70 E: 15-story apartment, 43.9x102.2; Manufacturers Trust Co against 170 E 79th St Corp; due, $425,445; to plaintiff for $300,000. 76th St, 165 W; 3 and 4-story dwelling, 20x102.2; City Bank Farmers Trust Co to Catherine E. Mulligan; due, $28,519, taxes, etc., $410: to plaintiff for $24,400.

Payment of the third quarterly installment of the Federal income tax is due today. Checks and money orders to the Collector of Internal Revenue must be mailed in time for them to arrive by midnight tonight.

Indignant because the Republican County Executive Committee of Rockland County had approved the action of its Assembly candidate, Howard P. Jones, in accepting an American Labor party nomination, Laurens M. Hamilton resigned today as a candidate to succeed himself as State committeeman.
It is John Golden's sentimental pleasure to revive this evening "Lightnin " at the Golden Theatre, with Fred Stone in the role that Frank Bacon made famous (and vice versa) in 1918.

Dr. Willis R. Gregg, chief of the United States Weather Bureau since 1934, died tonight in the Blackstone Hotel after a week's fight against a heart ailment. He was stricken with coronary thrombosis last Thursday
After reoccupying Fatarella, the Insurgent left wing today proceeded with mopping up the territory lying between this village and Asco, according to Insurgent information.
Rain yesterday forced the postponement of the second games of the International League's semifinal play-off series, scheduled for Newark and Syracuse last night, The Associated Press reported.

Friedrich Schorr, distinguished Wagnerian baritone, has been appointed vocal adviser of the Wagner department of the Metropolitan Opera Association by the board 6f directors; upon the recommendation of Edward Johnson, general manager, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Dolores Marie Moffett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Moffett of this city, was married to Alfred Davis Desnoes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Desnoes of Rockville Center, L. I., this morning in the Holy Family Church here. The Rev. Richard M. Fitzgerald officiated.
The Brookmeade Stable's Drudgery, 4-year-old brown colt trained by E. Shropshire, captured the Farmington Handicap at Rockingham Park today to pay his backers $10.28 to win.

Even if Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and his two aides had been only ordinary travelers, there would not have been the slightest diffioulty in getting places for them on the Munich plane tomorrow.
Tenants planning to move within the next few weeks took apartments yesterday in buildings in the East and West Side areas.

The semi-final brackets of the sixteen-goal Autumn Plate polo tournament were filled at the Meadow Brook Club last night when three teams moved into that place to join Cleveland, which had gone ahead with an earlier victory.

Because the proposed $30-everyThursday pensions would be payable in the first instance in "warrants" which would cost the State Government only what it cost to print them, the issuance and distribution of these warrants would not in any direct way bankrupt the California State Treasury if the scheme were adopted.

The towing and repairing of damaged automobiles has become a racket in New York, Charles P. Sullivan, District Attorney of Queens, declared yesterday. In an effort to protect motorists from "chiselers,"

Hugh Wolfe, 205-pound recruit back from Texas University, was promoted to the starting backfield when the New York Football Giants resumed work at the Bluehill C. C. for the game with the Eagles in Philadelphia a week from Sunday.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 14, unless specified: At New York: Babbitt, Roper, Tillman. At Guantanamo: Enterprise, Shaw. At San Diego. Sept. 13: Henley, Winslow. At San Pedro: Houston, Portland. Allegheny, at Philadelphia.

The three-family residence on a plot 40 by 106 feet at 1,140 Waring Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by R. Lyon to M. Vlag, through Nchring Brothers, Inc. The seller acquired the property, which is assessed for $15,500, last March.
The seventeenth annual Wissahickon Horse Show opened a four-day program today with out-of-town and especially the New York district taking the major share of blues.

Amid an ear-splitting din, equaled only at a major political convention, Bruce Barton was nominated yesterday by the Circus Saints and Sinners as the people's choice for the office of President-of Maine and Vermont.

Controversies between nazified German-Americans in the metropolitan area and those who are organized in the German-American Conference became known yesterday after the latter's refusal to extend an invitation to the GermanAmerican Bund for the celebration of German Day in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 2.

Facing a threatened general strike in consequence of their demands for a cut in wages, the nation's railroads began today a concerted drive to restrict the rate-making powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission and called on competing agencies as well as the business and financial communities for support.

Increasing activity for Massachusetts factories is indicated in the current monthly index of the Associated Industries of Massachusetts on orders. The report of F. V. Distrup for the organization notes that a very sharp seasonal upturn is indicated by the orders received during August in a representative group of Massachusetts manufacturers.

Three promotions in the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday by William McC. Martin Jr., president. Charles E. Saltzman is to be secretary of the Exchange, Charles Klem, assistant secretary, and Cecil MacCoy, assistant director of the public relations department.

Current industrial research problems and progress being made in the laboratories in behalf of business will be reviewed at the Fall meeting of the Industrial Research Institute at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., Sept. 23 and 24, it was announced yesterday by Maurice Holland, acting executive of the institute, which is an affildate of the National Research Council.

Ripley Wayne Bugbee of Pitman, N. J., vice president and art director of the Clements Company, a Philadelphia advertising agency, died of Rocky Mountain spotted fever today in Jefferson Hospital here. He was 38 years old.

Because the issue for some years has had a substantial minus net asset value, the New York Stock Exchange decided yesterday to apply to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to strike from listing the common stock of the Standard Investing Corporation. Pending action on the petition dealings will not be susended.

Major John R. Brooke Jr. was convicted tonight of the murder of his wife, Elizabeth, a former army nurse, 42 years old. The Federal jury returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree without the death penalty.

Gardiner Trowbridge of Noroton, investment banker and former member of the Darien Board of Finance, died this morning in the Stamford Hospital at the age of 48. He had an office in Wall Street, New York.

A Ku Klux Klan demonstration failed to prevent several Negroes from voting in Starke's municipal election yesterday. Men dressed in Klan regalia visited the Negro section Monday night, burned two crosses and left notes warning the Negroes to "stay out of Bradford County politics or take the consequences."
Naval circles admitted today that two bids made to build two 8,000-ton cruisers would expire tomorrow, the government having reached no decision.

The Corp Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Sherlock Davis, assistant director of the trading and exchange division, had been promoted to technical adviser to the commission on problems relating to over-the-counter markets.

Vinton Freedley, theatrical producer, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center lease. Wolfson Cristofano, Inc, tailor, floor in 2 W 56th St; DeNatale Bros., jewelry, floor in 1 Maiden Lane; Dr. Abner L. Sheppard, Dr. H. George Brodows, in 250 W 57th St; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers.

The wind held from start to finish today in the second race of the International Star Class championship series and Pimm, trim craft representing the Hamburger Flotte of Germany, led the parade of twentytwo craft home.

Mr. and Mrs. Coulter Dunham Huyler of Round Hill, Greenwich, have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Gwynne Grant, to Roland Ruutz-Rees, adopted son of Miss Caroline Ruutz-Rees of Greenwich, former headmistress of the Rosemary Hall School here.

In view of today's conference between Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain and Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany, the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League has sent a cablegram to President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, Premier Edouard Daladier of France and Mr. Chamberlain, proposing a solution of the Sudeten question by an exchange of population.
Although most families have given up their Summer residences in woodland, lake and shore communities, more than the usual number of families will make over their cottages into all-year homes.

Pedro Montanez, the Puerto Rican welterweight, and Jimmy Garrison of Kansas City, who will meet in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night brought their training practice activities to an end yesterday.

Fort Worth, Texas, was named today as the International Typographical Union's convention city in 1939. Proposals approved by the convention today included an amendment to the general laws, introduced by Frank Cozzolino of New York, defining hours of day and night work:
An influx of buyers .for drug chains in the market here next week is expected to result in substantial coverage of late Fall and holiday requirements, it was said in drug supply houses yesterday.

The San Carlo Opera, Company will open a seventeen-day season of popular-priced performances at the Center Theater tonight with "Carmen." The cast will be headed by Coe Glade, Dimitri On of rei, Leola Turner and Mostyn Thomas, with Carlo Peroni conducting.

Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick today refused to dismiss a $3,515,872 "riot damage" claim of the Apex Hosiery Company against tion of Hosiery Workers. The claim grew out of the seven-week sitdown strike at the Apex plant in the Summer of 1937.

At almost the same time that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain left Downing Street for his flight to Germany King George arrived at Euston Station, having cut short his Scottish residence because of the international situation.

It appears probable that the output of the basic iron and steel industry will continue to increase during all or most of the remaining months of this year and that the most important new demands for its products will come from the automotive industries, Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, says in the current business bulletin of the bank.

In a "surprise offensive" against Representative Patman's proposed "punitive and discriminatory" tax bill, "frankly designed to put the chain stores out of business," the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company today is launching an extensive advertising campaign for the purpose of "putting the case of the chain-store industry before the public."

The State Board of Tax Appeals began hearings at the Capitol here today on the petitions of the major railroad systems operating in New Jersey for reduction of taxes assessed against them for 1937 and 1938.

The candidacy of Magistrate Anna Moscowitz Kross for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District was endorsed yesterday by the Democratic Junior League, an organization of the wives and daughters of leading Democrats and including among its sponsors Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, Mrs. James A. Farley, Mrs. John P. O'Brien, Mrs. Caroline O'Day and Miss Frances Perkins.
Andrew Wilson Jr. was elected yesterday president of the County Trust Company of White Plains. He succeeds Arthur H. Titus, who was elected chairman of the board of directors.

The iron works at Monterrey, "the Pittsburgh of Mexico," have informed mining concerns that they expect to run out of coal today or tomorrow as a result of the strike of 4,500 men at the Rosita mine in the State of Coahuila, the property of the American Smelting and Refining Company. The strike is now in its sixteenth day.

With war showing its ugly face in Europe, Brazil began today to take stock of her resources and the possibility of supplying buyers of her products. A canvass was initiated today by the newspaper Diario da Noita.

Now repetition is the basic thing Beneath the seven arts of form and sound, And sky perfection of it. Blue and round In Summer, blue and round, the two words sing. Small flecks of cloud are only gracenotes twirled

Ellis Gimbel Jr. of Gimbel Brothers accounted for the chief net award in the New York Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament at which New York publishers acted as hosts today at the Century Country Club.

Warm August days in New Jersey promoted beer consumption and increased alcoholic beverages taxes, J. Lindsay De Valliere, director of the beverage tax division of the State Tax Department, reported today.
Attorney General Homer Cummings, faithful New Dealer, but also a practical politician, told the Democratic State Convention here today that he was willing to let "the dead past bury its dead."

The Federal farm tenancy purchase program was started in New York State today when Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture, presented to Carleton Radley of Cape Vincent, a check for $8,800 representing a Federal loan to permit him to buy his own farm.

Mrs. Gladys de Villers Mason, daughter of Mrs. Louis H. E. de Villers of Flushing and the late Mr. de Villers, was married here this morning to William Eldred Little, son of George F. Little of Great Neck and the late Mrs. Little.
A number of American anglers who went to Nova Scotia for the late run of salmon seem to have timed their visits just right, for the reports coming in are excellent.

Miss Martha Hall and Kingsley Mabon, who will be married tomorrow in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, were the guests of honor last night at a dinner given by Mr. Mabon's sister, Miss Lisa Mabon, and Miss M. Thayer Gibbons on the St. Regis Roof.

The Washington Heights section continued yesterday to be a center of real estate trading. A row of four six-story elevator apartment houses at 520, 530, 540 and 550 West 144th Street was sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Isadore Lorber, operator.

Miss Janet Harrison Kneale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harrison Kneale of Oyster Harbors, Cape Cod, Mass., will be married to James Alexander Hetherington 2d here on Sept. 30 in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation will open a new Whelan Drug Store today on Thirty-fourth Street, between Seventhand Eighth Avenues.

Final recapitulation today of the allotment of subscriptions for the cash Charles offering of about $700,000,000 of 2 1/2 per cent twelve-to-fourteen-year bonds and 1 1/8 per cent five-year notes made by the Treasury on last Thursday showed that a total of $803,751,400 of the cash subscriptions, or about $103,000,000 more than asked for. had been allowed.

BIRDS OF THE WORLD, by the staff of the Federal Writers Project, WPA, in the City of New York. (Whitman, $1.75.) An illustrated natural history. THE COMING STRUGGLE FOR LATIN AMERICA, by Carleton Beals. (Lippincott, $3.) A study of problems of policy, by the author of "Glass Houses."
Mrs. Norma Lack of Wilmington, Del., the only out-of-State entrant in the Pennsylvania women's golf tournament advanced to the semi-finals today by vanquishing Mrs. C. E. Fox of Oil City, 4 and.2.
The American Federation of Labor granted a charter yesterday to a union of professional blood donors on a promise that the union's members would refrain from strikes.

About 150 stewards attached to ships with United States registry attended yesterday a meeting of the newly organized Marine Cooks and Stewards Association in 15 Whitehall Street and approved the appointment of David E. Grange as president.

King Carol and his Crown Council sat at Sinaia Palace for more than six hours this afternoon discussing the international situation. No communique was issued and newspapers were not allowed to print a word about it.

Federal Judge John P. Nields said today that scores of holders of securities in the reorganized Standard Gas and Electric Company had written to him protesting the fees claimed by attorneys in the reorganization.

New Yorkers got their first opportunity to comment publicly on television by the same medium yesterday when the National Broadcasting Company took electric cameras out of experimental studios and conducted its first television sidewalk interview with passers-by in Rockefeller Plaza.

The retrial of Henry G. Singer, former chief assistant United States attorney of Brooklyn, on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case, in which the taking of testimony began Monday, came to an abrupt end, yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court when Justice Erskine C. Rogers declared a mistrial after it had been disclosed that one of the jurors had appeared as a witness before the extraordinary grand jury that indicted.

Deploring the misleading and exaggerated statements which it says have been made by both sides in the controversy over the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements program, the American Tariff League, in a special letter to members yesterday, warned that a "serious crisis" will develop in the near future unless the nation's foreign trade program can be "analyzed fairly, discussed thoroughly and dispassionately, and integrated with our internal economic program for labor, agriculture and industry."

A legislative program dealing chiefly with working conditions was adopted today by the American Federation of Government Employes for presentation to the next session of Congress. The action was approved unanimously by a voice vote of the more than 300 delegates,

Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate for Kings County Judge, charged last night that 50 per cent of all the persons accused of crime and placed on trial in Kings County actually were set free by the judges of the court. Mr.
Turning down two offers to return to baseball, Charlie Grimm, former manager of the Cubs, today signed a three-year contract to continue as a sports announcer for Radio Station WBBM, Chicago.
Our Paris dispatch yesterday, stating that the French are resigned to the thought of war, began on Page 1 and was continued on an inside

While automotive advertising budgets for the coming season are still incomplete, reports from Detroit indicate that radio will play a negligible part in the 1939 drives. With the exception of one major producer, Ford, it is now regarded as doubtful that any other large maker will have a network program. Spot and transcription may be used, although Chevrolet, for one, has withdrawn entirely from the latter.

Benjamin Crawford Cutler, 34year-old orchestra leader and former Yale athlete, of 311 East Fiftyfifth Street, whose car got out of control on Marie Curie Avenue near Sixty-sixth Street and plunged into the East River on Aug. 21, was fined $25 with the alternative of spending ten days in jail by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in Traffic Court yesterday. He had been found guilty of dangerous driving.

Hopes, for an amicable adjustment of the Central European crisis were strengthened here by the announcement of the plan of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain for a personal conference with Chancellor Hitler of Germany.
Mayor La Guardia is due to notify the City Planning Commission today of the maximum amount which in his opinion would be a safe total for new projects in the 1939 capital outlay budget.

Jefferson St, 18-20, 65.5x75xirreg; Lillian Cotkin to Limited Equities, Inc, 349 E 149th St; mtg $140,000. Lafayette St. 3,240. 22x85: Winoba Corp to Lafayette Estates, Inc, 16 Court St, Brooklyn; p m mtg $9,000 ($9.50). Monroe St. 112-14, 45.10x93.3; Central Savings Bank to Hazel Hugh Realties, Inc, 17 Rivington St ($27).

Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King announced tonight that he had cabled to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in London Canada's approval of the latter's plan to fly to Germany to confer with Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

The sixteenth annual Charles Hayden Trophy golf tournament, enlisting teams representing about forty investment banking firms, will be held on Friday, Sept. 23, at the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L. I., it was announced yesterday by-W. Halsted Taft, chairman of the tournament committee.

With a score of 1,476 points out of a possible 1,500, the Lower Merion (Pa.) team took first prize in the Class A event for police teams at the annual pistol tournament of the Police Association of Suffolk County here this afternoon.
The Iceland Skating Rink, atop the entrance to Madison Square Garden, opened for the season last night, and attracted a crowd of more than 700 skating devotees.

Isabella Smith, 96-year-old household servant, who had been employed by the family of the late Mrs. Ogden Brower for sixty-eight years, died early yesterday morning of pneumonia in the Mountainside Hospital.

The football Dodgers defeated the Glen Cove Sebas, 23 to 0, in an exhibition game at Municipal Stadium tonight. A crowd of 2,000 saw the Dodgers score in every period save the second. Boyd Brumbaugh, former Duquesne star, put over a touchdown, added the extra point from placement and booted a 27yard field goal.
Coffee exports from Guatemala during the 1937-38 crop year, which ended on Aug. 31, fell 6.5 per cent under those of the 1936-37 crop year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Bringing up to date for the Assembly its reports on the world's economic state, the teague of Nations. in a concise summary of the situation issued by the Secretary General yesterday, takes rather a more gloomy view than it did.

Purchases of clothing by the government and distribution to men and women on relief formed one of the subjects of discussion as national retail trade associations forming the Retailers National Council met here today for a two-day session.

Miss Sirkka Salonen, who won the title of Miss Europe of 1938 from a jury in Copenhagen in a competition of fourteen finalists, has been expelled from the Teachers Training College at Heinola, Finland, for taking part in a beauty competition.

THE new James Farrell-novel is a tremendous piece of work. As crude and cruel as its predecessors, it strikes with an even greater force than they. If there ever was powerful, credible fiction, this is it-this apparently clumsy accumulation of he saids and she said, this libelously faithful portrait of the world of Chicago Irish out of which the author himself came. The title is from A. E. Housman: "No Star Is Lost."*
Harry R. Chetham of Somerville, chief radio operator of the Police and Fire Departments and a pioneer radio operator, died today in Chelsea Naval Hospital.

The eleventh annual meeting of the board of governors of the Hebrew University has notified the local offices of Hadassah from London that Mrs. Moses P. Epstein, national president of the women's Zionist body,

Pat Abbott, Los Angeles. defeated Tom Draper, St. Louis. 4 and 3. John Goodman, Omaha, defeated Sid Richardson. Creston. Iowa. 4 and 3. J. E. French, San Francisco, defeated Lloyd Martz, Detroit, 6 and 4. Roger Kelly, Los Angeles, defeated Joe Roth. Louisville, 3 and 2. Dick Chapman, Greenwich, Conn., defeated Frank Stiedle, Memphis. 4 and 3.

The Republican Committee on Vacancies for the First Congressional District will meet here late tomorrow afternoon after the funeral services for Representative Robert Low Bacon to designate a candidate to replace Mr. Bacon in the Republican primary next Tuesday.

United States Senator Joseph O'Mahoney of Wyoming, chairman of the National Economic Committee, also known as the AntiMonopoly Investigating Committee pledged that body today "to be helpful, not hostile to business."

Boxing Pnomoter Bill Patterson announced last night he had wired Eddie Mead, manager of Henry Armstrong, in Los Angeles, Calif., an offer for the fighter to meet Fritzie Zivic -of Pittsburgh in the Newark Armory this Winter.

Parallel plans for the development of Jamaica Bay as a commercial port and a recreation center were submitted yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways and Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, to Major C. W. Ball, acting district engineer of the United States Army, at a public hearing in the chamber's headquarters, 1,920 Mott Avenue, Far Rockaway.

A technical decision of the school authorities to transfer some of the children from Public School 76 (Adee Avenue and Bronxwood Avenue) to Public School 41 (Olinville Avenue and Magenta Street) to relieve overcrowding in the Bronx is causing a school "strike."

The Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners, Inc., will hold its first Fall meeting Tuesday evening at the Bronx County Court House. Among the speakers will be Joseph Goldsmith, who will discuss the effects on real estate of measures adopted at the State Constitutional Convention.

Fifty-nine law degrees will be presented tonight to graduates of St. John's University School of Law in the gymnasium of the university's Borough Hall division, 96 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn. The Very Rev. Dr. Edward J. Walsh, president of the university, wilL deliver the principal address.

The first State convention of the Committee for Industrial Organization, intended to set up a permanent industrial union council in opposition to the State Federation of Labor, will open here tomorrow with more than 200 resolutions awaiting the attention of the delegates.
Shipments of tung oil continue in quantities sufficient for world requirements in spite of turbulent conditions in and about Hankow, the Commerce Department stated today.

Senator George went into the lead on the late count from the Georgia Senatorial primary after a nip-and-tuck race in the returns with Former Governor Eugene Talmadge, an even more direct critic of the New Deal than the Senator whom President Roosevelt marked for elimination in the party "purge" campaign. Lawrence Camp, the choice of the President, trailed throughout the count and conceded defeat.

John Dolanchuk, the man without a country, who has been living on the Atlantic Ocean most of the Summer, was spared another roundtrip crossing yesterday when he was taken from the United States liner President Roosevelt, on which he was to have been deported for the third time.
Stan Horne of Ottawa came from behind with a sparkling last-round

The estate of Roxana L. Naff has sold for cash- the Naff farm at Holmes, Putnam County, extending from Highway 216 to the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, to Richard Der Aris, through Herbert J. Gebing, broker. The entire tract is traversed by a large brook.

Prices of bonds crumbled over a broad front yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange as the financial community in general continued to appraise the German-Czech crisis in terms of dollars and cents.

Newark department stores and specialty shops were crowded tonight as the first of a series of four "open house" nights was staged. Herbert S. Waters, sales and advertising manager of the Kresge department store and president of the Newark Advertising Club, who heads a committee sponsoring the event, said the event was especially successful in attracting young couples who are unable to find time to shop during daylight hours.

The Gaumont-British Corporation of America, distributors of Englishmade pictures, which was excluded from the Motion Pictures' Greatest Year campaign, announced yesterday that it would undertake to sponsor a cash prize contest for audiences in connection with six forthcoming, G. B. pictures.

Tremont Ave, 826-830 E (11-2956); Mirlam Cahan to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg to June 19, 1943, at 5 per cent; $47,400. Brook Ave., 504 (9-2274); Kloreal Corp. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg to May 1, 1943, at 5 per cent; $15,000.

The Federal Court of Appeals granted an injunction against the Bituminous Coal Commission late today to prevent disclosure by the commission of confidential data on production costs submitted by softcoal operators as a basis for establishing minimum prices.
The National Retail Demonstration will be opened here next Monday with a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania at which B. C. Forbes, editor of Forbes Magazine, will be the sneaker.

Thomas G. Corcoran, one of President Roosevelt's closest advisers in the current "purge" campaign, visited the local WPA offices yesterday to renew an old friendship with Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator.

The Museum of the City of New York opened yesterday an exhibition of drawings, paintings and models made by members of the Junior Museum, a club conducted by the museum's department of education for children.

Electric power production declined slightly last week. But, with allowance for the holiday, daily average output increased, though less than anticipated on the basis of normal trends, and the adjusted index eased to 95.3 from 95.7. The figure was 105.2 for the week ended Sept. 11, 1937.
Mrs. Helen Grill Finletter, wife of President Judge Thomas D. Finletter of Common Pleas Court 4 in this city, died of heart disease last night at the Claridge in Atlantic City. Her age was 70.
