An orderly of the Brooklyn State Hospital for the Insane drove a stolen ambulance containing two bodies in a wild ride through nearly ten miles of Brooklyyn streets last night, terrifying hundreds of pedestrians and motorists and causing a near-tragedy to one.

Plans for the projected High School of Needle Trades, to occupy a full block and cost more than $4,500,000, were approved yesterday at the Fall meeting of the Board of Education. A "skyscraper" building of eleven stories, the school is a definite departure from anything now in the city's educational system.
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday by allotxnenc to the usual twenty-six banks and trust companies three issues of New York City short-term obligations aggrezating S36.000.000.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday a decision amending an order which autiorized the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation to issue $2,375,000 of general and refunding 3 1/4; per cent Series D bonds.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edwin Malcolm Douglas of 26 West Ninth Street of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Laura Virginia Douglas, to Robert Harriott Temple, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Harriott Temple, also of this city.

A demonstration of the caution displayed in major financial transactions, in view of the world-wide tension over the Central European situation, was given yesterday when the Atlantic Refining Company filed late in the day with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $25,000,000 of fifteenyear 3 per cent debentures in order that the registration statement would not become effective at 12:01 A. M. today.
Luncheon, Rotary Club, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Sell the Sizzle and Not the Steak," Elmer Wheeler. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 3:30 P. M. "English Furniture," Alfred Busselle Jr.

A vacant plot 70 by 70 feet on the southwest corner of Fifty-first Avenue and Gorsline Street, Elmhurst, Queens, has been sold by William T. Geissinger to Long Island Builders, Inc., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The buyer plans to erect a taxpayer on the land.

Employment reached a new peak in old Germany in August with 20,900,000 gainfully employed and labor reserves practically exhausted. In Austria, too, progress was made with 37,000 more employed than in July.

Somebody, it seems, has been trying to give the champions a very short count. At least, such was the impression gained by a gathering of 28,185 amazed spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Bill Terry's supposedly shattered Giants sent Pie Traynor's front-running Pirates sprawling all over the course in both ends of a doubleheader.

Archibald McIntyre, a retired building contractor, died yesterday at his home, 80 Van Buren Street, New Brighton, S. I., after a heart attack. He was born eighty-one years ago in Ayrshire, Scotland, and had made his home on Staten Island for more than thirty-five years.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain will be accompanied on his flight to see Adolf Hitler tomorrow by two of Great Britain's veteran civil servants.

Miss Mary Proctor Scott, 71 years old, a retired school teacher, who was found dead Tuesday in her bed in her rooming house at 487 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, died a natural death from. a cerebral hemorrhage, an autopsy in King County Morgue revealed yesterday.

" Our Karlsbad program has been taken over by events. The Sudeten problem enters a new phase-the demand for self-determination," Konrad Henlein this morning told members of Viscount Runciman's mission who, after repeated refusals, finally succeeded in seeing the Sudeten leader in his native town of Asch.

Hooks Mylin dare not send his Lafayette eleven through another undefeated season for fear that Athletic Director Eskie Clark would promptly book the New York Giants, the Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers for 1939.

MANHATTAN BAIN, JOHN JR. (Aug. 11). Estate, more than $10,000.'To Olive Love Kittle, daughter, Salt Lake City, and Marjorie Seymour Dalzell, 850 Carroll St., Brooklyn, daughter, one-half residue each; Ida C. Bain, 41 Fifth Ave., $500 annuity; Lillian West, Woodstock, N. Y., $3,000. Frederick B. Dalzell and Bankers Trust Co., executors.

The largest Summer school enrollment on-record for New York University, 9,240 students from forty-eight States and twenty-five foreign countries, was reported yesterday for the last season by Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler approved yesterday a compromise whereby the Brooklyn Trust Company will drop its appeal from a recent order surcharging it $34,000 for alleged negligence as trustee for a real_estate mortgage investment in return for cancellation of interest on the amount surcharged.

The pro - government National Unity party is the only political group preparing for active participation in the election of a new Parliament. As soon as the election date was fixed for Nov. 6 it issued a manifesto inviting the electorate to respond to PresidentIgnaz Moscicki's appeal for "popular cooperation in work of the State."
A rarely used system of second-choice voting was brought into play today to determine the Democratic nominee for Governor of Maryland.
Prime Minister Chamberlain, in a dramatic move to avert Europe's threatened war, is flying to Germany to meet Chancellor Hitler face to face. [Page 1.]

Announcement was made yesterday of the marriage on Monday in Elkton, Md., of Miss Felice Harriman Rosen, daughter of Mrs. Pierre Andre Leon Lecomte de Nouy, now at the Drake, and Felix T. Rosen of this city, to George Hull Hobson, son of Mrs. Richmond Pearson Hobson of New York and the late Rear Admiral Hobson, naval hero of the Spanish-American War.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey spent most of yesterday afternoon conferring with assistants on the next move in the case against James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, which ended in a mistrial on Monday.
The Soviet navy is beginning its customary Autumn tactical manoeuvres in the Baltic and Black Seas and the Pacific Ocean.
Third-round pairings in the National amateur golf championship tomorrow: UPPER BRACKET James Fraser, Absecon, N. J., vs. Pat Abbott, Los Angeles.

The CzechSudeten German crisis drew further away from the brink of war tonight with the announcement that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler would meet in Berchtesgaden tomorrow afternoon for a man-to-man talk.

J. P. Tomkins has sold his sixty four-acre farm, with an old, farm house, in the town of Sommers, Westchester County, to a client of the Kenneth H. Clapp Company Clayton E. Buttloph acting for Mr. Tomkins. There are two brooks on the tract.
Rockwell Kent, William Gropper and six other artists set up their easels yesterday afternoon near three busy traffic intersections and painted posters to aid-the American Relief Ship for Spain.
Thelma Lady Furness sailed on the Normandie of the French Line yesterday for her home in London, accompanied by her son, Anthony.

The Bank of Canada cut its last direct link with the Bank of England today when it accepted the resignation of Deputy Governor J. A. C. Osborne, who had resigned a secretaryship with the London institution to help launch it and appointed a young Canadian banker to succeed him.

Henry A. Rogers, who negotiated many sales of estates on Long Island, first as vice president of the old firm of Worthington Whitehouse, Inc., and later as head of the Wheatley Hills Real Estate Corporation, will join Douglas L. Elliman Co. today as vice president and head of the country department.

Albert L. Arey of Roslyn Estates, founder of the National Natural Science Camp for Boys near Canandaigua Lake, N. Y., and a former president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, died yesterday at the age of 88 in the Nassau County Hospital.

Strong optimism on retail trade prospects for the Fall and holiday season was voiced at the meeting of the board of directors of the Cavendish Trading Corporation, it was stated yesterday by A. A. McCarthy, who was named managing director of the buying agency, after his service since May, 1937, as acting director.

A brisk sixty-minute dummy scrimmage in which aerial and ground offense received special attention climaxed Columbia's third day of football practice at Baker Field yesterday. In the morning and early afternoon four sets of backs practiced blocking out the defense of skeleton lines made up of ends and tackles.
William P. Fisher, a retired New York lawyer, died here last night after a brief illness at the age of 75 He was associated for several years with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Twenty honor grants and eleven Pulitzer Free Scholarships totaling $64,310 were announced yesterday by Columbia University. All except one scholarship winner will register at Columbia College, which opens Sept. 29.

John Lardner, writer of the sports column "From the Press Box" for the North American Newspaper Alliance and eldest son of the late Ring Lardner, married Miss Hazel Cannan Hairston, newspaper woman, here today.

Consternation over the European crisis spread and deepened here and in other centers of foreign residence in China upon receipt from Tokyo of a declaration by a Foreign Office spokesman to the effect that Japan is prepared to join forces with Germany and Italy in accordance with the anti-Comintern agreement.

Czechoslovak merchandise destined for the United States is now being routed through Poland, according to word received here yesterday by the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce and retailed by them to importers.

Retail prices of food declined in the rnonth ended Aug. 16, the Bureau of Lbabor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 19231925 average, was 78.4, compared with 80.0 on July 12 and 85.5 on Aug. 17, 1937.
Melvin H. Deutsch, in 40 Tompkins Rd, Scarsdale, Westchester; Harold Grossman, in 22 Shawnee Rd; Joseph Payez, in 1 Tunstall Rd; James E. Sarver, in 106 Garden Rd; Howard L. Auerbach, broker.

Twenty honor grants and eleven Pulitzer Free Scholarships totaling $64,310 were announced yesterday by Columbia University. All except one scholarship winner will register at Columbia College, which opens Sept. 29.

John Lardner, writer of the sports column "From the Press Box" for the North American Newspaper Alliance and eldest son of the late Ring Lardner, married Miss Hazel Cannan Hairston, newspaper woman, here today.

Consternation over the European crisis spread and deepened here and in other centers of foreign residence in China upon receipt from Tokyo of a declaration by a Foreign Office spokesman to the effect that Japan is prepared to join forces with Germany and Italy in accordance with the anti-Comintern agreement.

Czechoslovak merchandise destined for the United States is now being routed through Poland, according to word received here yesterday by the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce and retailed by them to importers.

War rumors battered world markets yesterday but prices retreated in good order. In fact, a tumultuous day that saw 2,290,000 shares change hands on the New York Stock Exchange and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average drop 1.64 points to 92.97 closed on a hopeful note.

While the world's eyes are on Central Europe millions of Chinese, ground between opposing armies, innocent of any possible guilt in the disaster that has overtaken their country, are facing starvation and disease.
Melvin H. Deutsch, in 40 Tompkins Rd, Scarsdale, Westchester; Harold Grossman, in 22 Shawnee Rd; Joseph Payez, in 1 Tunstall Rd; James E. Sarver, in 106 Garden Rd; Howard L. Auerbach, broker.

With a third and lower-priced six-cylinder line added to new six and eight cylinder Oldsmobile models for 1939, C. L. McCuen, president of the Oldsmobile division of-General Motors, predicted today that business would be good for his company in the new model this coming year and said it was prepared to meet any demand of an expanded market.
While terrorism continues unabated here and greatly increased in the south of Palestine, interest in the Palestine Arabs on the part of Iraq, Egypt and Syria is rapidly diminishing.

A compromise plan for peace between the warring factions of the United Automobile Workers of America has been worked out and been found acceptable by sixteen of the nineteen members of the union's executive board, it was reported from Detroit today.

A tailored cocktail dress of gold lame in the Duke of Windsor's plaid was one of the outstanding costumes yesterday in the first Fall showing of the exclusively American designs at Milgrim's costume salon, on Fifty-seventh Street.

Gross revenues of the Chicago North Western Railway in August were estimated at $7,500,000 and net operating income was estimated at $400,000 by Fred Sargent, president, yesterday. The company's statement for July and seven months follows:
Directors of the Air Reduction Company authorized an extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly of 25 cents to be paid to its stockholders on Oct. 15.

Mrs. Edmund Pendleton Rogers of. Wheatley Hills and New York gave a supper dance here tonight at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club to introduce to society her daughter Miss Marjorie Knox Goodyear, and Miss Elizabeth Louise Dillingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dillingham of Honolulu.
By EL LOUIS HOLLANDER Franklin Ave. 1,250; 6-story tenement, 92.6x185.4; Felix A. Muldoon et al, trustees, against Chasie Realty Co; due $226,115; taxes, etc, $2,900; to planUtiff or $1,0S .

Ivor B. Clark, Inc, has arranged a permanent mortgage loan of $190,000, running for ten years, on the recently completed building at 111-23 76th Rd. Forest Hills, Queens. The loan was made by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Kew Forest, Inc, Jacob Tabor, president.

Auction of the furnishings in the home on the estate of William C. Durant, former automobile manufacturer, continued today, with the contents of the second floor of the thirty-eightroom house going for a total of $6,444.

At a press conference on Tuesday Justice Pecora commented on an editorial on this page discussing his declaration of a mistrial in the Hines case because of a question asked by the District Attorney which he deemed to be "fatally prejudicial" to the defendant.

After falling to the lowest. prices in several years, the leading foreign exchanges yesterday recovered strongly. on the news that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain was to fly to Berchtesgaden today to confer with Chancellor Hitler.
The war scare continued to dominate the world wheat market today, prices advancing to the highest levels since early in August on general buying.
Describing himself as an "incorrigible optimist for America," Senator Vandenberg of Michigan sounded a call here tonight for a return to the "realities" of republican institutions.

American travelers have been advised "unofficially and informally" by the United States Consulate here to return home "if they could conveniently alter their European travel plans." officials said today.
Scoring eight runs in the first three innings, the Boston Red Sox ended Detroit's winning streak at six games with a 9-to-2 victory today.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Flled-Against COLON HAT CORP., manufacturers of men's hats, 21 Waverly Place, by Harris Tipograph, Inc., for $103; H. M. Hubshman Bro., $500; Epstein Warshaw, $100. Frank Carlin was appointed receiver under $2,500 bond by Judge Mandelbaum.
Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday consisted largely of groups of small homes for sites in Queens. Architects also filed for a row of stores in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
A shooting attributed by the police to the resentment of a first husband over the fact that his former wife had remarried resulted last night at 2,864 Webster Avenue,

Former Mayor George J. Zimmermann died in his home here late this afternoon of coronary thrombosis. He was 56 years old. At his death, the former Mayor was at liberty on bail while awaiting a decision on his appeal
Thomas E. Millsop, president of the Weirton Steel Company, has been elected to the executive committee of the National Steel Corporation.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, after being closed for two months, reopens to the public today for the 1938-39 season with an exhibition of paintings and sculpture from the permanent collection. The works shown will remain on view through Oct. 9.
The stock market here, nervous over the Czechoslovak situation, was generally weak today, but there was an absence of any strong selling pressure and prices rallied somewhat in late dealings.

William Herbert Judson, chairman of the board of directors of the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 315 East Sixty-eighth Street. He would have been 76 years old today.
Connie Mack's Philadelphia Athletics slipped into seventh place in the American League today, handing big Buck Newsom of the Browns his thirteenth defeat of the season, 4 to 3.

All marine insurance rates were suspended yesterday by American underwriters as concerns over the prospect of war in Europe deepened in the insurance community centering in William Street, and new and higher rates probably will be established today.

Prominent persons in the political, social and business affairs of the nation will serve as pallbearers and ushers at the funeral services for Representative Robert Low Bacon, to be held tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation at Garden City.

More than pennant conscious when they rolled into Ebbets Field yesterday for a double-header, the Reds were next door to unconsciousness after the Dodgers had taken the opener, 6--2, from Johnny NoHit Vander Meer and Red Barrett on only five hits.

QUEENS GERDES, GEORGE (May 2, 1930). Assests, $18,802 gross; $11,472 net. To brother, Karl Gerdes, $10; sister, Meta Henning and brother. John Gerdes, $100 each; residue to widow, Katherine Gerdes. Outstanding holdings in jointly owned Iproperty, $11,802. Henry Schoenherr, attorney, 149 Broadway. Manhattan.

Manager Gabby Hartnett's disputed homer with the bases filled in the third inning today enabled the Cubs to wind up their 1938 relations with the Bees with a 6-3 victory. Chicago took the season's series, 12 games to 10.

The Public Works Administration has rescinded grants totaling $980,468 for two New York City projects, it became known last night. Regional officers indicated that more grants would be withdrawn if the city did not act soon to accept thirteen other projects for which PWA grants were approved on June 24.

British, Russian, French and Czechoslovak fo quarters here agreed tonight that ti, if the Czechoslovak situation be- eq came "extremely grave"-but pre- tu sumably not before-there would be es an immediate appeal to the League re of Nations.

At a luncheon today Malcolm de Lilliehood, Swedish commissioner for the International Commission for the Assistance of Child Refugees in Spain, appealed to governments for further aid in money or in kind.

Charles Kingsbury Young, concert pianist and music teacher, died here in his home at the age of 45 after a short illness. At the age of 14 Mr. Young made his first appearance on the concert stage, playing at Cooper Union in New York.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were less responsive to the Central European political news yesterday as the effects of -the government cotton loan program became more pronounced in checking selling at levels more than $2.50 a bale below the average loan basis in the South.

Everyone was out in good spirits and new clothes last evening to dedicate a new Broadway season. "Come Across," which has just come across from London, opened at Mr. Brady's Playhouse with a gat here and there, a gag everywhere and some dirty work in an operating room.

Piling through a sea roll that curled and splashed, George Nichols's allaround six-meter Goose today won the fourth race of the British-American Cup series. With Henry Morgan's Djinn in second place, the United States team scored 20 1/4 points, to 16 for the combination British quartet from Scotland and Bermuda.
Ex-Governor Frank D. Fitzgerald will seek the office again in November, opposing Frank Murphy, Democrat, who defeated him for re-election in 1936.

Any doubt that we live in times without precedent, participants in a world drama of swift surprises inspired by extraordinary personal impulses, is removed by the breath-taking decision of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to fly to Berchtesgaden to make a last appeal to Adolf Hitler to save the world from war.

The North Bergen Varnish Corporation sold to Philip Ruxton, Inc., for a consideration of $65,000, its plant on the south side of Thirtyninth Street, adjoining the Northern Railroad in the North Jersey Industrial Terminal section of North Bergen. The one-story building occupies a site with a frontage of 260 feet and a depth of 192 feet.

Supply of traefer meats was about normal in local markets yesterday with the exception of pork, which was light. All classes were about steady except medium and common lamb, which were mostly 50 cents lower.
A brief decree published' in the legal journal rescinds the amendment to the excise tax on sugar, salt, matches, lighting appliances, playing cards and mineral oils.

Representatives of milk dealers in the metropolitan New York area pledged support of the FederalState marketing program for the area at a conference today with E. W. Gaumnitz, chief of the dairy section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

After conferring with and reporting to Prince Kimmochi Saionji, 88-year-old Elder Statesmen, at his mountain villa, Premier Fumimaro Konoye told the local press their talks dealt with Japanese policy in China after the expected fall of Hankow, and diplomatic policy toward third powers. He declined to reveal details.

The Crown Council has decided to establish military control of all industries working for the national defense. It was officially explained today that measures had been taken to coordinate, nationalize and accelebrate output.

" Scarecrows for Small Gardens" was the name of a special class inaugurated this year and judged here today as part of the annual show of the Garden Club of New Canaan. Open to men only, the contest had twelve entries.

Dozens of local and State political leaders, including Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and Lieut. Gov. M. William Bray, were among 500 persons present at a funeral service yesterday for State Senator Duncan T. O'Brien in St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church, 118th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.
President Arturo Alesandri refused tonight in a letter to Minister of the Interior Luis Salas Romo to accept the resignations tendered by the Ministers Monday as a result of the Nazi rising Sept. 5.

The death of Thomas Wolfe in his thirty-eighth year must be deeply regretted. His was one of the most confident young voices in contemporary American literature, a vibrant, fulltoned voice which it is hard to believe could be so suddenly stilled.
Colonel Alexander E. Anderson, commanding the Sixty-fifth Infantry, National Guard of New York, has been commissioned as a brigadier general of the National Guard bf the United States.
Army's football squad turned out in shorts today for a dummy scrimmage. A heavy scrimmage in complete uniform had been planned, but the hot weather caused its postponement.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores for July, 1938, showed a decrease of 3.5 per cent from July, 1937, while a loss of 4 per cent was recorded from last June, the Commerce Department said today.

A heavy downpour, which might have deterred a younger and less hardy group, failed to dampen the ardor of ninety "old-timers" as the Westchester Seniors Golf Association went through with its annual Fall tournament over the Westchester Hills course today.

It will be Wednesday of next week, instead of Tuesday, that brings "You Never Know" to the Winter Garden, which has lately been making itself more intimatetwo side sections have been removed and boxes have been installed.

Circuit Judge W. T. Harrison today directed the estate of John Ringling to pay .principal and interest on a $50,000 note held by Mrs. Emily Ringling, who. was divorced by the circus owner just before he died in December, 1936.

The civil war is almost at a standstill, the lull probably presaging renewed activity while good weather lasts. The only activity reported tonight was an attempted Insurgent drive in the Guadalajara sector near Madrid, which was reported repulsed.

To Report to Chief Medical Officer The following members shall be directed to report to the Chief Medical Officer, at these headquarters, at 1 P. M. on the date specified, for examination to determine their physical fitness to operate motors and pumps on apparatus:
Three present tendencies constitute a serious threat to American civil liberties, Grenville Clark, New York lawyer, told the Chicago Bar Association, at its Constitution Week dinner tonight.

A New method of aiding persons with poor vision, if their eyes are not afflicted with organic disturbances or disease, was described today by Dr. Gustav Erlanger of the Manhattan General Hospital, New York, in a paper read before the American Congress of Physical Therapy.
For the ninth successive week engineering construction awards in the current seven-day period, totaling $53,569,000, show an improvement over the 1937 figures, with a rise of 13 per cent.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis Meredith Blagden of 176 East Seventieth Street and Sterlington, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Blagden's daughter, Miss Lydia Blagden, to Seymour Saltus, son of Mrs. Lloyd Saltus of Morristown, N. J., and the late-Mr. Saltus.

Vast transfers and adjustments in the control of important foreign properties by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were disclosed by Sosthenese Behn, president, in a report to stockholders issued yesterday.

At the opening session of the thirtyninth annual meeting of the New York State Historical Association, held today on the Vassar College campus, the association's medal for local newspapers was awarded to The Hamilton Republican of Madison County.

Yale's football squad of fifty seven candidates opened the Fal' practice season today with morning and afternoon sessions under the veteran coaches, Ducky Pond, Earle Neale, Ivan Williamson, Marshall Wells, Gerald Ford, Bill Renner and Jimmy De Angelis, freshman mentor.
Opening advances of 10 to 14 points on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were attributed to a hopeful view of the outcome of conferences between Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler.

Dr. James E. Neighbors, Poughkeepsie eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died on Tuesday at the age of 42. He was graduated from the University of Alabama and the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine. He also took a post-graduate course at the University of Vienna.

Mrs. Ottelia Taussig Ruthsnburg, a sister of the late Isaac W. Taussig, Mayor of Jersey City in the Eighties, died here last night at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Louis A. Guinzburg, at the age of 81.

Albert R. Summers has purchased for investment from the American Baptist Home Missions Society, in a cash deal, the four-story apartment for four families at 105 Berkeley Place, Brooklyn, through L. L. Yearsley, broker.

The State of California found a further increase in its cost of borrowing short-term funds yesterday when it awarded $2;812,337 of registered warrants to the Bankamerica Company on a 3 per cent basis, plus a premium of $3,052.

An Investing client of Sidney Levine, broker, has purchased from the Malsam Construction Corporation, Malcolm Brill, president, the one-story taxpayer on the northeast corner of Merrick Road and 230th Street, Laurelton, Queens, for cash above a first mortgage of $25,000.

A Federal Power Commission aminer questioned John Edward Aldred today regarding deposits by the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company with Aldred Co., New York.

The inner council of the Czechoslovak Cabinet tonight ordered the arrest of Konrad Henlein, the Sudeten German leader, as a traitor. Announcement of the action came suddenly after Herr Henlein earlier had issued a proclamation declaring the Sudeten Germans wanted union with Germany.

A reorganization program that would permit the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company to dispose of almost three-fourths of its anthracite acreage, close five mines, terminate two leases and borrow $2,500,000 for additional working capital was recommended today to the Federal District Court by Howard Benton Lewis, special master in the proceedings designed to lead to a new set-up.

John Durso, 37 years old, and his wife, Anna, 29, who were wounded Wednesday night at their home, 2,864 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, when Mrs. Durso's former husband fired several shots at them with a revolver, died yesterday afternoon in Fordham Hospital.
The British Parliament will be called into special session some time next week to hear Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's report on his Berchtesgaden conference.

With the failure of President Roosevelt to eliminate the Democrats marked for the "purge" in Georgia, Maryland and South Carolina, all of the party's Senators who sought renomination after having fought the Supreme Court Bill and other Administration measures have been successful in the primaries.

Thousands of Chinese war refugees have been aided by Japanese Catholics, particularly women's groups. Mrs. Monica Shizue Ito, Japan's leading Catholic woman, said here yesterday in an interview at the Society for the Propogation of the Faith, 109 East Thirty-eighth Street.

George D. Brooke, president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad. announced yesterday that the time for deposit of the company's $14,807,000 of 6 per cent notes in assent to a plan for three years' extension after their maturity on Oct. 1, had been advanced to Sept. 30.

The Wagner Labor Relations Act was attacked here today by delegates of the National Small Business Men's Association and by Reginald Boote of Ilion, N. Y., secretary of the National Council of Independent Unions.
New York State declared a new "open warfare" today on gooseberry and currant throughout wide portions of up-State forest areas.

Security markets throughout the world responded vigorously yesterday to the precedent-breaking efforts of Prime Minister Chamberlain of England to keep peace in Europe by personally flying to Germany..to confer with Chancellor Hitler.

Lambs broke again today, dropping values to the lowest point of the season, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. The top stood at $8. Fed steers and yearlings held steady and strictly choice and prime weighty offerings were not available. Hogs strengthened.

Pike St, 11, Delta Estates, Inc. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, purchase money mtg. $16,000. Same property, same to same, building loan mtg. $3,750. West Broadway, s w cor Warren St. Marar Holding Corp. to Metropolitan Savings Bank, purchase money mtg., due Sept. 1, 1945, 3 to 5 per cent, $12,500.

Richard A. Brennan was elected yesterday president of the Brevoort Savings Bank of Brooklyn, succeeding the late Edward Lyons. He joined the Brevoort bank as executive president a year ago after serving for several years as president of the Mortgage Corporation of New York, of which he is a director.

The six directors who represent the Eastern presidents' conference on the board of the Association of American Railroads were renominated at a meeting of the conference yesterday. They are to be reelected at the next full membership meeting of the association in the Fall.

Ralph L. Raphael, treasurer of the Keystone Bond and Mortgage Company, 32 Court Street, Brooklyn, and former chain department store executive, died of a coronary thrombosis on Wednesday at his home, the Hotel Park Royal, 23 West Seventy-third Street, Mr. Raphael was 67 years old.

A collection of 124 letters to children written by nearly a hundred famous men and women is announced by Macmillan for Oct. 18. The collection, entitled "Letters to Children," was compiled by Eva G. Connor.
After funeral services for Representative Robert Low Bacon this afternoon, the Republican committee on vacancies designated Assemblyman Leonard W. Hall of Oyster Bay as
Manuel Garcia Prieto, Marques de Alhucemas, for six years Prime Minister under the former Spanish monarchy, died today at San Sebastian. He was 77 years old.

Leases of business space were reported yesterday to have been made for New York offices of foreign firms engaged in the manufacture and importing of textiles, as well as with a number of domestic organizations in the apparel and allied businesses.
Mr. and Mrs. Fred F. Roberts of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Roberts, to A. James Fisher Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Fisher of this city.

The New Deal's unsuccessful "purge" has caused a serious break in Democratic ranks and will result in sweeping victories for the Republican party in the Fall elections, Allen W. Dulles, Republican organization nominee for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District, declared in a series of speeches last night.

A staff of 500 persons will be employed to handle the details, sort mail and check the answers in the $250,000 Movie Quiz contest which is being conducted by the motion picture industry in its current promotion campaign, it was announced yesterday.

The charges of conducting a lottery against six members of the staff of the Jewel Motion Picture theatre, 11 West 116th Street, based on a screen game for cash prizes there, will be made a test case to be parried to the -higher courts if necessary, Harry Z. Kosch, attorney for the theatre, told Magistrate Peter A. Abeles in Harlem Court yesterday.

The Vienna radio at frequent intervals throughout the day has been broadcasting bulletins on the day's events both in the Czech and the German languages particularly addressed- to the Sudeten Germans.

Ten savings and loan associations in Westchester County announced today that they were ready to lend $8,000,000 for home construction under the new Federal Home Building Service Plan, which has been tried with success in the South and Middle West but never before near New York.

The results of the President's campaign in the primaries have run so overwhelmingly against him as to suggest that the advisers to whom he now listens in these matters badly misjudged the present temper of the rank and file of the Democratic party.
President Roosevelt returned to the capital tonight and immediately went into conference with Secretary Hull to learn details of the European crisis.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low point for the year. Gold hodlings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury.
Following are the individual reports, in thousands of board feet, as issued by the various associations for the week ended Sept. 10:

Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, who is making a comeback campaign after a long lay-off, will be one of the topliners at Madison Square. Garden tonight when he meets Jimmy Garrison of Kansas City in the main bout of ten rounds.

Fortune Gallo brought back his San Carlo Opera Company to the Center Theatre last night for what the program termed a "Fall opera festival." The opening opera was "Carmen," and a large audience was on hand to welcome the company.

Senator George won a majority of the county unit vote in Georgia's primary, assuring him the Democratic renomination for the Senate, despite President Roosevelt's opposition. Former Governor Talmadge, New Deal foe who ran far ahead of Lawrence Camp, Mr. Roosevelt's choice, hinted that a contest of Senator George's victory will be filed with the Senate. [Page 1.]
Hitler devoted a large part of his Nuremberg speech to exposing the hypocrisy of the democratic nations.
Problems other than those likely to arise in event of war in Europe occupied the attention of exporters attending a meeting of the Overseas Automotive Club in the Hotel Lincoln yesterday.

The Vatican City newspaper, Osservatore Romano, called on all nations today to have "the virtue, merit and strength not to resort to force" in the Czechoslovak crisis. The newspaper asserted that moderation and eschewal of armed force in times of tension were not indications of weakness but of strength.

A declaration filed by the Southern Colorado Power Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, regarding the reduction of the amount of capital represented by its class B common stock from $4,590,000 to $750,000 and the effecting of certain transfers in the accounts of the company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Wholesale dry goods executives here are watching the crisis-inspired rise in grains and the firming trend in cotton in the belief they may turn what promises to be a fairly good Fall and early Winter business into one of real prosperity.

Taxicab service in Philadelphia came to a standstill today as 125 drivers employed by independent operators were called on strike by Local 156 of the Taxicab Drivers Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate. The 950 drivers of the Yellow Cab Company have been on strike four weeks.

Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, who resigned some time ago to return to teaching at Columbia University, ended his services with the Treasury today. He came to the Treasury to have charge of tax policies.

Debutantes and their house guests who had been attending dinners and dances on the North Shore motored tonight to the Rockaway Hunting Club at Cedarhurst to the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. William Z. Breed to introduce to society Mrs. Breed's daughter, Miss Barbara Keith Smith.
Stocks closed higher, with leaders up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,142,000 shares. All groups of bonds recovered and closed generally higher; transactions, $4,990,475..
For the third successive week the commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City have declined.
Dr. Frank Mansfield Sharpe, former Brooklyn (N. Y.) physician, died at a Madison hospital Tuesday following a heart attack at his Summer home on lower Nemabin Lake in Waukesha County.

The annual flower show of the Garden Club of Orange and Dutchess Counties will open tomorrow at the local high school gymnasium and continue through Saturday and Sunday. Mrs. Schuyler Schieffelin is chairman of the committee in charge.

Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania declared on his return from Europe yesterday on the United States liner Washington that the same people who gave President Roosevelt "an overwhelming mandate in 1932" would determine whether it would be necessary to return Mr. Roosevelt to the White House for a third term.
Lester B. Bigelow, former radio dealer here, died today in the United States Veterans Hospital at Northport, L. I., after a long illness. His age was 42.

As a result of the tense situation in Europe foreign money is coming into the United States in unprecedented volume, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, said today. He declared that there was no reason to be alarmed because of this and added that "if people want to send their money here as a haven of refuge we will take good care of it for them."
Incomplete figures on the payment of the third quarterly installment of the Federal income tax yesterday indicated a substantial increase in returns over those of the same period last year.
For the first time in two weeks Nello (Flash) Falaschi, Santa Clara rookie quarterback, took his place in the New York Football Giants' backfield.

The Hamburg-American liner New York, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has on board: Justice D. Lawrence Groner, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Gould, Robert J. McMillan, Georg von Ghika, Dr. Otto Schwerdtfeger, Mrs. Carl F. Altio, George J. Gottstein, Anderson D. Hodgdon Jr., Lucien Memminger Jr., Roger W. McIntyre. and Mrs. Anna Garbe.

In a plea for greater cooperation between business and government, Carle C. Conway, chairman of the board of the Continental Can Company and chairman of the committee that prepared the reorganization report on the New York Stock Exchange, told the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the National Petroleum Association here this afternoon that "business cannot wait for either political or other conditions to be ironed out."
Of seven Manhattan properties sold in foreclosure proceedings in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday, two were large apartment structures and the remainder tenements and smaller dwelling.

An "outlaw" strike supported by insurgent members of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an A. F. of L. affiliate, halted most interstate trucking in and out of this city yesterday. Local trucks were tied up to a lesser degree, despite efforts by roving bands of strikers in the downtown waterfront district to force trucks back to their garages.
Crossing the 100 mark for the first time since March the index of machine tool orders climbed 31.3 points last month to 120.9, the National Machine Tool Builders Association announced here today.

Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, told the special House investigating committee this evening that a Democratic legislator from Philadelphia had dictated a statement linking at least four party leaders with the alleged sale of beer and movie legislation and admitting the receipt of $5,000 as his share.

The newspaper Erzgebirgsche General-Anzeiger said Prince and Princess Max zu Hohenlohe-Langenburg, recent hosts to Viscount Runciman, were among the "refugees" streaming across the Czechoslovak frontier into Germany today.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain rode from Munich to Berchtesgaden today in a super-safe train. It is Chancellor Adolf Hitler's special one.

Miss Mary Grabhorn of Short Hills, N. J., was chosen as the "ideal" American college girl yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin. Sponsors of the contest, in which there were originally 1,000 entrants, were Saks Thirty-fourth' Street and various colleges for women.
A series of price cuts on private brand tires in- connection with department store sales events during September has the nerves of the so-called regular tire trade on edge here.

Yates Ave (16-4456), w s, 125 ft s of Allerton Ave, 50x100: Filomena Adamo to Eugene Grimm, 392 Oliver Pl. Irwin Ave. 3,650 (13-3406M); Max Wogticzky to Frances Sullivan, 3,650 Irwin Ave. Watson Aye. 2,140 (14-3808); Home Owners Loan Corp. to Lawrence Baldy, 4,118 Carpenter Ave.
Lawrenceville School's football squad reported today to Head Coach Larry Tithonen and his staff.

While Neville Chamberlain and Adolf Hitler conferred at Berchtesgaden yesterday more than 2,000,-. 000 men stood to arms in the three nations of Europe most closely affected by the Czechoslovak crisis.
Miss Joan Bersbach, daughter of Mrs. Frank J. Bersbach of Winnetka, Ill., and Archibald McGhee Foster of Lake Forest, Ill., will be married here Sept. 23 in St. Matthew's Church.

State Senator R. T. Jones of Phoenix appeared assured of the Democratic nomination for the Arizona Governorship today when his lead in Tuesday's primary increased to 1,865 votes in returns from 358 complete and 61 incomplete precincts of the State's 433.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins denied yesterday an application made by Mary Lord, a stockholder of the Susquehanna Silk Mills, Inc., for a temporary injunction restraining the company from negotiating for the sale of its Belvedere plant at Belvedere, N. J.
Control of the Panama American was transferred today to Dr. Harmodio Arias, former President of Panama, by Nelson Rounsevell, who founded the newspaper fourteen years ago.
Those of you who are planning to visit Maine for the last of the fishing and the opening of the shooting season, should find excellent sport this year.

In the home of her parents at 1,021, Park Avenue, Miss Marie Kiely was married yesterday afternoon to James M. Snowden of this city and Philadelphia, son of Mrs. Georga Grant Snowden of Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Snowden.
Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay have come to the Pierre from Tranquillity Farm, their place in Allamuchy, N. J.

Business activity in the Pittsburgh district climbed to a higher level last week. The business index prepared by the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh, was 69.3, whereas a week earlier it was 68.6. Last year for the week ended Sept. 11 it stood at 117.7.
Robert G. Cowan, who has been connected with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York eleven years, has been appointed cashier of the National Newark Essex Banking Company, Newark, N. J.,

The Stock Exchange's committee on stock list yesterday requested members to transfer all certificates of the Superior Steel Corporation common stock which they may hold registered in the name of a previous holder into their name or that of their nominee by Sept. 26 to
John R. Cobb of England won the record for land speed today when he drove his racing automobile, Railton, across the speedway here at 350.2 miles an hour.
Christian Heurich, 97-year-old brewer of .Washington, D. C.; arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa at the end of his seventy-first crossing of the Atlantic.
Undivided backing for the movement for industrial recovery was pledged today by ten national retail trade associations included in the Retailers National Council as a two-day session ended.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 15 unless specified: Chefoo to Hong Kong: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Pecos, Whipple. At New York: Decatur, Dickerson, Schenck. Chefoo to Shanghai: Pillsbury, Peary, Black Hawk.
Enfeebled to the point where they looked downright emaciated, what with their fiery Dick Bartell down in the pits with the rest of the invalids, a broken finger on his right hand in splints,
Isador Schwebel, owner of the American Lumber Company, 630 First Avenue, died early yesterday at his home, 8,756 Twenty-first Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 66.

Fredrik William Beyers, veteran South African politician who in 1928 drove through the celebrated trade treaty with Germany whereby the Union Government guaranteed thereafter that the same preferences would be given both German and British goods, died suddenly today at the age of 71.

Members of society who attended the race meetings at Saratoga and Aqueduct and many of the younger set who are on the North Shore for the debutante parties this month, were present at the opening program of the Autumn season at Belmont Park this afternoon.
In an attempt to alleviate the heavy traffic problem in the midtown area, the Police Department initiated a new "no parking" drive at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.
Sharp criticism of a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner is voiced in a brief filed with the board today by the Ford Motor Company, asking rejection of findings in the St. Louis Ford case.

The possibility of "united opposition" on the part of home owners and realty owners to the housing and transit program advanced by the recent State Constitutional Convention was forecast today by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Black Hawks, holders of the Stanley Cup, today purchased a complete forward line of Center Russ Blinco and - Wingmen Lawrence (Baldy) Northcott and Earl Robinson from the Montreal Maroons in the National Hockey League's biggest deal in several years.

When the special train bringing Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain from Munich after his flight from London to see Chancellor Adolf Hitler arrived at Berchtesgaden at 4:05 this afternoon, it was met by Dr. Otto Meissner, chief of the Chancellor's office, on the Fuehrer's behalf and by excited, cheering crowds.
Many apartment buildings in the section east of Central Park, and particularly along and adjacent to Fifth Avenue, appeared in the rental reports forwarded by brokers and rental agents yesterday.
The stock markets and financial London made a sensational all-round recovery today as sentiment improved following news of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's peace mission to Germany.

Awards have been made by the French Government to American designers and artists who participated in the 1937 International Exposition at Paris, according to announcement yesterday by Paul Lester Wiener designer and technical adviser to the United States Commission at the exposition.

The Republican Connecticut State Convention, at an early hour this morning, appeared to have agreed upon the nomination of Raymond E. Baldwin, a lawyer, of Stratford for Governor and John A. Danaher of Hartford for United States Senator.

The Commonwealth Government has approved a scheme whereby States will legislate fixing the price of flour, and the Commonwealth will impose an excise tax equaling the difference between the fixed price and the export value of wheat.

Joseph J. McMahon of the Yonkers Water Bureau, who, when Joseph P. McMahon, formerly in the same bureau, died eight days ago of heart disease, was embarrassed because friends mistook him for his namesake and telephoned to express their condolence only to find him well, also died of heart disease today in his home. He was 56 years old.

The Hungarian Revisionist League sent a message to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain at Berchtesgaden today, asking him to "urge the right of self-determination" for the Hungarian minority in Czechoslovakia.

The emergence today of Senator Borah of Idaho from his months of enforced seclusion recalled to Washington observers the fact that the Borah niche in the news did not remain vacant during the Summer; that while the Idaho veteran was convalescing, Senator Marvel M. Logan of Kentucky was receiving the press daily and speaking his mind on all manner of public topics.
Oddlot sales on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Sept. 10 exceeded purchases by 13,379 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Unnecessary high costs of handling fresh fruits and vegetables arriving at Washington Market, adding heavily to the consumer's bill for these necessities, are the subject of an article in the current issue of The Consumers Guide, a free publication of the Consumers' Counsel Division of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration in Washington.

Scoring two runs in the eighteenth inning, the Phoenix Ramblers, Arizona champions, halted the New York Roverettes, 2-0, in the star attraction of the women's softball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

Net operating income of 141 Class I railroads in July was $38,387,209, against $60,985,276 correspondingly in 1937, according to reports to the Interstate Commerce Commission. This was a decline of roughly 36 per cent. Operating revenues were $299,641,050, against $365,085,700.

Vice Chancellor Charles- M. Egan handed down today a decision continuing Daniel T. O'Regan as custodial receiver for the assets in New Jersey of Burco, Inc., a Delaware investment trust, which, it is alleged, was looted of $750,000.

At the end of a day that saw Australia qualify a representative for the semi-finals of both the men's and women's national tennis championships, Miss Dorothy May Bundy of Santa Monica sent the Stars and Stripes to the masthead of the Forest Hills Stadium yesterday with one of the most distinguished triumphs of her youthful career on the courts.

With the Federal Caravan Summer Theatre season now in the archives, some statistical figures about it have been released. The past season, which opened June 13 and closed Sept. 10, saw 1,131,600 persons attend a total of 201 free outdoor presentations sponsored by the Federal Theatre Project in the public areas of the city.
The White Sox and Athletics divided a doubleheader today, the White Sox winning the first game, 5 to 4, and the Mackmen the second, 1 to 0.

Weekly Stipend, recently shipped from Aqueduct by Mrs. S. A. Ketchell, stormed through the mud at Rockingham Park today to win the Warner purse in easy fashion from the Medway Stable's Upslala, the favorite, to pay $12.50 for $2.
The National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board plans to join with associations in the dress and other trades in combating merchandise returns, it was announced yesterday.
Sixteen passengers and the driver of a Blue Way bus bound from Boston to New York escaped today from flames which destroyed the vehicle at a filling station.

An elderly man of Colonial ancestry, who was a Communist until fifteen days ago, told a Dies Congressional subcommittee investigating un-American activities yesterday that the Communist party had a grip on 40 per cent of the workers on the WPA Federal Writers Project and that the Workers Alliance was a sort of clearing house for project job applicants through which few non-Communists could now pass.
Angus Maclachlan, an accountant of Boston, and a former resident here, died on Wednesday in Brook Hospital, Brookline, Mass.. after a two-day illness.

Managers of railroads throughout the country informed their employes today that a reduction of 15 per cent in existing rates would be made effective at 12:01 A. M. on Oct. 1, under the provisions of the Railway Labor Act.

Two metropolitan golfers, one just out of college, a Californian who does odd bits in the movies and a young man from Utah are the quartet from which the next national amateur golf champion will be chosen on Saturday.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses submitted a capital budget program for 1939 of only $6,443,000 to the City Planning Commission at the final budget hearing yesterday. He submitted no projects or estimate for the years 1940 to 1944.

General conditions: Supply of traefer meats was about normal on veal, calf and lamb, light on beef and pork, in local markets yesterday. Hinds and ribs were fully steady to strong: pork and lamb lower; veal barely steady to lower. Conditions as reported by the United States Denartment of Agriculture follow:

Contracts for naval gun barrel forgings totaling $443,773 were awarded to private corporations by the Navy Department today. This is one of the largest ordnance orders awarded by the navy to private industry since the World War.

In fine spirits, observing gayly that she felt "happy, just happy," Mme. Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan Opera singer, took the initial step yesterday toward becoming an American citizen when she filed application for her first papers at the Naturalization Bureau, 641 Washington Street.

Praise of the national retail demonstration scheduled to open next Monday in stores in more than 100 cities was voiced yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, in a letter to Major Benjamin H. Namm, chairman of the national demonstration committee.
Steamship officials said yesterday that few cancellations of passage on ships sailing for Europe had been reported as a result of the situation in, Czechoslovakia.
Nelson W. Jarvis, secretary-treasurer of the Calculagraph Company of 50 Church Street, New York, died here today at Holy Name Hospital, at the age of 60. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday.

Police of the Marine Division were searching the waters of the Hudson River between Spuyten Duyvil and Riverdale last night and early today for a man believed to have fallen from an excursion boat that had been chartered by about 1,000 employes of the New York Park Department.

Nathan Straus, United States Houstng Authority Administrator, today approved .the $7,243,000 bid of the George A. Fuller Construction Company of New York for construction of superstructures of the Red Hook low-rental housing development.

What started as a routine protest against the mass transfer of elementary grade pupils from one school to another has developed into a parents' strike that is becoming serious, it-developed yesterday.
The Rev. Francis Moffett, who served as pastor in several churches of the Rochester diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, died at his home here last night. His age was 54.

Attorney General Bennett has designated about 2,500 lawyers from among the membership of the Democratic, Republican, American Labor, and Socialist parties to act as Special Assistant Attorneys General at the polls throughout the city on primary day, next Tuesday.
Seven thousand employes of the Chrysler Corporation Plymouth Division were sent home today because a strike at the Briggs Manufacturing Company shut off the supply of automobile bodies.

Representative John J. O'Connor was attacked last night by James H. Fay, his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District, as one of those whom President Roosevelt described as "yes-but" men.

John Kasper, 16 years old, of Seward Avenue, Montrose, N. Y., has been exonerated in connection with the death of John L. Makeever, 81, a retired New York investment broker, in an automobile accident here Aug. 22.

The second day of the seventeenth annual Wissahickon Horse Show saw most of today's program devoted to children under 19, and the Claredda Farm at Shrewsbury, N. J., owned by Mr. and Mrs. Edward V. Quinn, again was outstanding in the ribbon collection.

Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill scored 86 to win the low gross prize in the women's Westchester and Fairfield one-day tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today. She led a field of twenty-six starters, one of the smallest that has competed in these tourneys, the rain having kept many golfers away.

Comparing modern history teaching with dictatorship tactics, Professor Henry Johnson, new member of the teaching staff in the Hunter College evening session, declared yesterday that curriculum specialists cast scholarship to the winds and base courses on contemporary philosophy.

The Collier Trophy, awarded each year to the person or organization which has accomplished during the year "the greatest achievement in aviation whose value has been demonstrated in actual use," has been awarded to the Air Corps of the United States Army for the fourth time since 1924.

TODAY is the fiftieth birthday of F. E. Sillanpaa. This fact may not make the average American reader pause in his daily routine, for the name of this distinguished Finnish author probably is not widely known in this country. Since, however, his birthday is being observed here with the publication of his story *"Meek Heritage," his future anniversaries are likely to be of much more interest to American readers;

The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star declared today that Prime Minister Chamberlain's policy was "not only to make an agreement with an aggressor but also to help liquidate a democratic state (Czechoslovakia) in the center of Europe."

Taking all three heats, Little Pat, 1:59 1/2, of Butler, Pa., annexed the free-for-all pace, feature of today's Grand Circuit races. His best time was 2:05 1/4 over a heavy track. Jane Azof, 1:59 3/4, was a contender in the first two brushes, but in the last mile was forced to give way to the great stretch showing of Carty Nagle.

Asserting that the Spanish Loyalist Government seeks a separation of church and State patterned after the United States, Theodore Dreiser, the novelist, guest of honor at a dinner of the League of American Writers last night, declared that "people who are religious criticize the Loyalists falsely when they say they are anti-religious."

Frankie Frisch, famed Fordham Flash and until a few days ago manager of the Cardinals, arrived in New York yesterday and immediately did what any other old ball player will do when he finds an idle afternoon on his hands. He went to a ball game.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Castle Canfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wooster Canfield of Waterbury, to Edward Waters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Waters of West Hartford.

The present recovery trend should continue through the remainder of the year and even into next Spring, but it is doubtful that it is the forerunner of a return to the pre-1929 standard of prosperity, A. W. Zelomek, economist for the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., and the Fairchild Publications, declared tonight at a meeting of the Society of Industrial Engineers, Northern New Jersey Chapter, at the Hotel Douglas.

Railroad management's appeal to the National Transportation Conference for support in its campaign for greater autonomy in rate making and consolidations was attacked by the Railway Labor Executives Association today.

George W. Bunn Sr., banker, merchant and member of a family prominent in Central Illinois history for more than a century, died yesterday at his Summer home near South Dartmouth, Mass., of a heart ailment. His age was 77.

The semi-annual report of the John Irving Shoe Corporation covering the six months ended on July 31 was made public yesterday. It shows a consolidated net profit of $40,022 after taxes, depreciation, expenses and other charges.
Poland was declared the winner today of the twenty-sixth James Gordon Bennett balloon race, which started here Sept. 11.

First New York State Committee for Industrial Organization convention, Hotel Center, 10 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. James P. Monaghan, Newbold Morris, Allan S. Haywood, the Rev. John P. Boland, Governor Herbert H. Lehman, John Brophy. Continues tomorrow at 10 A. M.

Mayor La Guardia paid a brief tribute to his father, Achille, today, when he witnessed the dedication of Point La Guardia, in the height of rocks just outside of town, in memory of the army bandmaster, who died just after the SpanishAmerican War.

The Virginia Electric and Power Company of Richmond, Va., filed today registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $37,500,000 of first and refunding 3% per cent mortgage bonds, Series B, due on Sept. 1, 1968.

A bequest to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund of THE NEW. YORK TIMES was left in the will of Maria J. M. Lawrence. filed for probate yesterday. She died Aug. 3, leaving an estate valued at "more than $10,000."

Provident Institution for Savings sold to the Congregation Emanuel for a synagogue the one-family dwelling at 157 Harrison Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 40 by 137 feet. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $4,500.

The Cleveland Indians and Boston Red Sox split a double-header today by identical scores of 3 to 2, the Tribe taking the first game and the Sox the second, leaving Boston one game ahead of Cleveland in second place.
Light-Heavyweight Champion John Henry Lewis of Phoenix, Ariz., won a ten-round decision from Jimmy Adamick of Midland, Mich., in a non-title bout at Convention Hall tonight.

A Hearst property passed to new control yesterday when the Hearst Realty Corporation, Randolph Hearst, president, sold the five-story building on a lot 25 by 102.2 feet at 325 West Eighty-fifth Street to the Greek Orthodox Church.

A broadscale movement of British reinforcements to troubled Palestine was announced here today simultaneously with reports that Egypt was taking defense precautions in North Africa in conjunction with Britain.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, Issued today, shows the following change, in francs:
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
The California Bankers Association warned its member banks today that they will not be able to accept as money any warrants that might he issued under the - "$30-everyThursday" scheme.

Today's meeting between Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Chancellor Adolf Hitler at Berchtesgaden, Germany, was only a preliminary contact, according to all information and opinion here, in a series of meetings that may develop into another peace conference.

European manufacturers, working on orders for delivery here this Fall, have stepped up production and are rushing to complete their orders sixty days or more in advance, importers attending a meeting of group chairmen and directors of the National Council of American Importers at the Hotel Astor said yesterday.

William B. (Bill) Lynch, a senior at Princeton University and varsity fullback for the last two years, fell over backward and died of acute heart disease at 6 o'clock tonight as he was completing a jog around the field with his teammates at the end of a two-and-a-half hour practice session.

Mr. and Mrs. John Kingsley Livingston of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Burr Livingston, to Robert Lincoln Goodale, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Frank Goodale of New Haven, Conn.

Communists and fascists scuffled in Piccadilly Circus tonight after the fascists allegedly had attempted to hoist the Nazi flag on top of the statue of Eros. The police cleared the area of demonstrators. Several of them were taken to the Vine Street police station.
Nearing the close of their tour, Australia's cricketers today triumphed by 61 runs in a one-day

Mrs. Neville Chamberlain prayed in Westminster Abbey today for the success of her husband's journey to Berchtesgaden to save the peace of the world. The Prime Minister's wife unobtrusively joined kneeling worshipers around the tomb of Britain's unknown warrior.

Heavy rains that left playing fields too wet for safety caused postponement of yesterday's scheduled match between Old Westbury and Roslyn in the Monty Waterbury Cup polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L. I.
The Board of Estimate at a special meeting yesterday voted $7,282,000 for the construction of three new hangars at the city's North Beach airport.

Running the third fastest six furlongs in the history of the stake, despite the impost of 131 pounds, W. F. Morgan's The Fighter yesterday captured the twenty-fifth running of the Highweight Handicap, feature of the inaugural program of the Belmont Park Fall meeting.

Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, told officers of the Westing house Electric and Manufacturing Company tonight that the naval expension program started in 1933 had put the United States in a better position to meet any emergency than anything else that could have been done.

A new financial plan for the projected Battery-to-Brooklyn tunnel, that would add $6,885,000 to its cost and reduce by $19,882,500 the amount the city hopes to get from the Federal Government as an outright grant, was submitted to the Public Works Administration yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and the New York Tunnel Authority.

The announcement that Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, well known to many New Yorkers, is to return here in late October to assume command of the Second Corps Area, will be heartily welcome to all who know the military qualities and personal characteristics of one of the most able of our general officers.

When a call for an ambulance was received late last night at Yonkers police headquarters, Lieutenant John J. McCarthy, who was on duty, learned that it was for his own brother, Joseph F. McCarthy, who died soon after the ambulance reached his home.

Gilbert Miller's protracted differences with the Dramatists Guild, extending over a period of more than two years, ended yesterday when he signed the guild's basic agreement governing the sale of plays for production on Broadway and in the motion pictures.

Sanford D. Leland Jr., manager of the merchandising department of the Texas Company, died yesterday at the Gaylord Sanitorium, Wallingford, Conn., after an illness of a year and a half, according to word received here last night. He was 39 years old.

One hundred and eighteen new mortgages totaling $4,203,087 were recorded last month in Manhattan, as compared with 107 amounting to $2,391,008 in July, according to the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, announced yesterday that a majority of the committee on vacancies had notified the board that there would be no substitution -filed for the vacancy caused by the death of State Senator Duncan T. O'Brien.

Prime Minister Chamberlain and Chancellor Hitler conferred three hours at Berchtesgaden yesterday and the former returned to a hotel. He will fly to London today to consult his Cabinet, and it was announced he would again visit Hitler in a few days. The official communique told only of a "comprehensive and frank exchange of opinion."

The 5,000-year Time Capsule, to be deposited by the Westinghouse company at the site of the New York World's Fair a week from today, at a depth of fifty feet, for opening on Sept. 23, 6939, will contain letters from Albert Einstein,

A brisk demand greeted an issue of $25,000,000 of Atlantic Refining Company fifteen-year 3 per cent debentures due on Sept. 1, 1953, that was offered formally about 11:30 A. M. yesterday by a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co.
The Simms Realty Corporation bought from the Brooklyn Trust Company a group of twenty twostory dwellings in the East Tremont Avenue section of the Bronx.

R. H. Goffe of Winged Foot led a field of seventy-seven in a one-day golf event of the New York Athletic Club at the White Beeches Country Club today. He took the Class A prize by carding an 80 over the difficult par-72 layout.

Carl Kunz, husband of the former Mrs. Stella Crater, whose first husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, vanished in 1930, was held in $2,500 bail for action of the grand jury by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Homicide Court yesterday.

In a plea for American importers to continue to place orders for Czechoslovak merchandise, George Boochever, chairman of the board of the American-Czechoslovak Cliamber of Commerce, revealed last night that many of the factories in the Sudetan area had in the last few years established branch factories in the interior of the country, insuring a steady supply of merchandise notwithstanding any trouble in that area.

Despite the humidity, Coach Jimmy Crowley, not thoroughly satisfied with the condition of his pupils, ordered the second scrimmage of the week for the Fordham football squad on Fordham Field yesterday. After a brief workout on the blocking machines, Crowley called a freshman team, then lined up his varsity.
The case against Seymour Young, trading as Renard Co., New York, has been closed by the Federal Trade Commission without prejudice, it was announced today.

Mrs. Clara Watts-Dunton, widow of Walter Theodore Watts-Dunton, poet, nowelist and critic, but best known as Swinburne's "housemate," died in Putney in the house in which Swinburne passed his last years. She was 66 years old.
Mrs. Jennie G. Lance. of Glen Gardner, wife of H. Kiefer Lance, president of the Clinton National Bank of Clinton, N. J., died yesterday in the Newark Memorial Hospital, following an operation.

By taking the fifth race today, the United States team of six-meter yachts won the British-American Cup. The score was 20 1/4 points to 16, and the match score was four contests to one. The leader today again was George Nichols's Goose of the United States quartet.

The proposed visit of 325 British steel men and their wives to principal United States iron and steel and other metal-working plants, which would have lasted throughout the, whole of October, was canceled yesterday owing to the international situation..

Traveling in imagination far out into distant space, thousands of light years away from our warscared planet, members of the American Astronomical Society opened their semi-annual meeting today at the University' of Michigan.

Demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated line, at an estimated cost of $12,725,000, is regarded by the Board of Transportation as the most urgent item on its $800,000,000 program for future expansion of rapid-transit facilities, John H. Delaney, chairman, told the City Planning Commission yesterday.

Helen Horton, buyer of bath, bar and closet accessories for W. and J. Sloane, has been placed in charge of Sloane's street floor departments, which, in addition to the aforementioned items, include gifts and lamps. Evelyn Schott will assist Miss Horton in the lamp department.

More than 1,000 persons, many of them leaders in the affairs of the nation, paid a final tribute to Representative Robert Low Bacon this afternoon at the funeral services in the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation here.
Deering Howe of Shearman Sterling was elected yesterday a director of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

Harvard's first progressive scrimmage of the football season was unimpressive today as teams A and B of the varsity alternately carried the ball against the C group in a sixty-minute session. Three touchdowns were scored against the C team, but the varsity was sluggish.

Apartments in houses on Central Park West, West End Avenue and Riverside Drive yesterday added many names to their tenant rosters as the result of continued demand for suites to be occupied by Oct. 1. Rentals in the West Side buildings follow:

Denials that the Nebraska Hydro network had offered to purchase the IowaNebraska Light and Power Company of Lincoln have been issued by L. R. King, president of IowaNebraska Light; Roy Page, vice president and general manager of the Nebraska Power Company of Omaha, and Dr. D. W. Kingsley, president of the Tri-County Public Power District.

Thomas Wolfe, author of "Look Homeward, Angel," died today of an "acute cerebral infection." He was 37 years old. The novelist underwent two operations at Johns Hopkins Hospital after his arrival Saturday. He fell ill of pneumonia in July but was recovering in Seattle when an infection began and spread to his kidneys and heart.

Research for further savings in American department store operation aimed at reduction of employee turnover and: a more aggressive attitude for improving sales of small wares was suggested in an address here today by H. I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
During the week ended Sept. 14 member bank reserve balances increased $156,000,000.
A general building trades strike appears likely in the Paris district, beginning Monday. Workers are Impatient over delay in the signing of a new collective agreement with substantial wage increases.
With portables claiming a larger share of the typewriter volume each year, new campaigns for the Fall season are placing greater emphasis on these models, according to agencies.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, telegraphed today to Milton Marks, attorney and spokesman for the San Francisco Retailers Council, asking him to confer with Mr. Green's personal representative, Meyer L. Lewis, in an effort to settle the strike called by the Retail Department Store Clerks Union, Local 1,100, of the A. F. of L. against the major department stores a week ago yesterday.

The tragedy in much "Utopian credit schemes" as California's "$30 every Thursday," lies in "the false hopes such a plan develops and in the ultimate philosophy implicit in the program," Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, told the Wisconsin-Upper Michigan Credit Conference here tonight.

The third race in the international Star Class championship regatta was called off today when, because of poor weather, the fleet of twentytwo boats failed to cover the ten and a quarter miles in the required three hours.
Bonds, with other markets, made a good recovery yesterday in sharply reduced trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

AIRCRAFT OF THE WORLD, by Eric Sargent. (Appleton-Century, $3.) A guide to their recognition. ANIMAL TALES FROM THE OLD NORTH STATE, by Lucy Cobb and Mary Hicks. (Dutton, $2.) A collection of American Negro folktales.
For six innings today at Briggs Stadium, the Yankees apparently needed only two more of their remaining games to clinch their third straight American League flag.

We have all heard of the sign in the zoo reading: "This animal is very malicious; when attacked it defends itself." The managers of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company have put themselves in that class by their public reply through advertisements to what they ball Representative Wright Patman's announced intention to "inproduce in the next Congress a punitive and discriminatory tax bill frankly designed to put chain stores out of business."

J. Richard (Dixie) - Davis, State witness against Tammany District Leader James J. Hines who testified he saw Jules Martin, lieutenantof Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer shot in a hotel in Cohoes, N. Y., will be taken up-State for his testimony- in that murder it was decided yesterday.

Germany's concern for the rights of minorities is "a leaf" from the book of Democratic principles, according to Dr. Jacob Gould Schur-, man, former United States Ambassador to Germany, who returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.
The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday shows that the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 54.10 per cent, against 54.44 a week before.

The Bridgeport Brass Company announced yesterday the completion of a new manufacturing plant at Bridgeport, Conn., for the production of brass, copper and copper-base alloys for industrial and commercial use,
Mrs. Ella E. Lewis, widow of Clifford Lewis and an active figure for many years in the city's social life, died today at her home, 30 South Twenty-second Street, at the age of 92.
With portables claiming a larger share of the typewriter volume each year, new campaigns for the Fall season are placing greater emphasis on these models, according to agencies.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, telegraphed today to Milton Marks, attorney and spokesman for the San Francisco Retailers Council, asking him to confer with Mr. Green's personal representative, Meyer L. Lewis, in an effort to settle the strike called by the Retail Department Store Clerks Union, Local 1,100, of the A. F. of L. against the major department stores a week ago yesterday.

The tragedy in much "Utopian credit schemes" as California's "$30 every Thursday," lies in "the false hopes such a plan develops and in the ultimate philosophy implicit in the program," Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, told the Wisconsin-Upper Michigan Credit Conference here tonight.

The third race in the international Star Class championship regatta was called off today when, because of poor weather, the fleet of twentytwo boats failed to cover the ten and a quarter miles in the required three hours.
Only four veterans were in the lineup of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers announced today by Coach Potsy Clark for their opening league game Sunday against the champion Redskins at Washington.

103d St, 429-435 E. 199.9x100.9: Emma L. Shaw to City of N. Y, $33,000. Same property; Carrie E. Dolan ano, execr, to same; $11,000. l14th St, 58-60 E, 50x100.11: Peter L. Fragness to Louise G. Pooles. 456 Riverside Drive. 1/2 part, mtg $27,650 ($4).

Dr. Ferdinand Hueppe, eminent bacteriologist, died today at the age of 86. In his youth Dr. Hueppe was a noted sportsman and organizer of the German Football League. He was decorated by Chancellor Hitler in 1936 for his service to the cause of physical training.
