SELDOM do the broadcasters find themselves planning to put a noted artist on the air who has never confronted their microphone, so in this day when such a virtuoso as Ignace Jan Paderewski accepts an invitation to perform, the showmen have something to talk about.

This is the season of automobile previews at the great factories of the Middle West, where men by thousands are returning to jobs. As the automobile industry prepares for its new year, the 1939 models are being disclosed, one after another, to men in charge of automobile departments of newspapers and to distributors and dealers before their unveiling to the general public.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 15: COMMANDERS Armstrong, V. S., Med. Corps, VP-3, to Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla.

Twelve destroyers, under command of Captain J. W. Bunkley, left the New York City area yesterday with about seventy-two officers and nearly 900 men of the Naval Reserve for the last Naval Reserve cruise of the season.

Representative Joseph A. Gavagan, Democratic candidate for reelection in the Twenty-first Manhattan District, who has been endorsed by the American Labor party, defended President Roosevelt's "purge" program yesterday in addressing members of various labor organizations in that district.

Yawns quickly changed to boos and applause late this week as Pennsylvania voters cupped their ears to catch the evidence which would help them decide whether a Republican District Attorney was justified in demanding a grand jury investigation of graft and corruption charges against Governor Earle and thirteen fellow Democrats.

Much interest is being evinced in the low-cost .demonstration house at 655 Carteret Street, Elizabeth, N. J., erected in connection with the fourteenth annual home show of the Elizabeth Chamber of Commerce, Joseph M. Cerrota, chairman of the show, reports.

With a program including. hunter, jumper and saddle classes, the annual Pocantico Hills Farm Fall horse show will be held on the grounds of the Sleepy Hollow Farms stables in North Tarrytown next Sunday. Horsemen and horsewomen of the metropolitan district have accorded the show an enthusiastic reception and classes have filled rapdily.

Three blues and a red were gained by two horses exhibited by M. Hartley Dodge of Madison at the tenth annual Spring Valley horse show today. Ably ridden by Bill Sabata, Dodge's Dusty Star took the jumping class for the Spring Valley Hounds in a field of thirty-five, then lost a close decision to Crittenden H. Adams's Middleton in the Corinthian event. Destiny,

In spite of the downpour that marred the program of the West Hills Racing AssoCiation this afternoon, the race ball tonight at Ben Robyn Farm, the home of Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins, was attended by a large crowd of members of society who have their country homes in the North Shore colonies.

As a barometer of the financial weather, the stock market last week turned in some disquieting readings. Under the influence of the warlike alarums from Europe it bounded wildly about and fell to levels lower than it had touched since June 25. Since June 20,

In any European conflict, oil supplies probably would be the deciding factor in the outcome. One of the remarks growing out of the World War most often- quoted is that "the Allies floated to victory on a sea of oil."

George Dunbar Shewe11, a musician and composer, died at his home in Germantown today at the age of 63. Born at Mount Holly, N. J., he began his musical career at an early age, having composed "Majestic March" when 14.

The complexities of present-day economic and social life call for higher ability and greater scientific knowledge in the management of real estate than ever before, according to Robert H. Armstrong, president of the Manhattan chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

IN the event that a $1,800,000 loan for greatly needed improve ments on Cross County Parkway is obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the county Board of Supervisors, in approving the proposed borrowing, announced last week that a toll of 10 cents per vehicle would be charged for use of the county's roa.

IN the first years of the republic, Spain's art of music flourished with intensity and abun dance, as regards both quality and quantity. In a single afternoon there could be heard in Madrid two Large orchestras, two chamber orchestras, two solo recitals or quartet concerts, besides the performances of opera, operetta or zarauela given in the various theatres.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Sept. 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

Braving the worst conditions of the season, seventy yachts assembled northeast of Execution Light today for the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Fall regatta, the twentysecond, and next to last, of the 1938 Long Island Sound Y. R. A. championship series.

Mail orders for ready-to-wear, accessories and men's and boy's wear showed a marked increase last week, due to improved retail business, according .to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell 'Company, resident buyers.

AT the age of 14, Hesketh Pearson remarks with amiable and disarming candor and the broadest of smiles, his newly retrieved prose writing showed "the germ of that raciness, gusto and vivacity" which critics have noted in his mature work; and he thus supplies the reviewer with a true comment on his book of reminiscences. Only he doesn't go far enough:
WHATEVER else is true of Charles Morgan as an artist, this is certain-he is driven, compelled to write. That must be admitted by those who, like myself, admire his work and those who dislike it.

The government's gross public debt rose to a new high of $38,407,012,443 on Sept. 15 as a result of the completion of transactions by which the Treasury sold $803,000,000 of bonds end notes for cash, according to the latest statistics available today.

The auction sale of 1,300 tax-delinquent parcels of real estate owned by Nassau County will begin Saturday at 2 P. M. in the County Police Headquarters Auditorium at Mineola, L. I. Other sessions will be held Oct. 1 and 8.

Gradual abandonment by the United States of its traditional isolationist policy and the development of effective cooperation with the British Commonwealth for self-protection were predicted in the closing discussions of the British Commonwealth Relations Conference, which ended here today.
Stanisiaus Bulziewicz of Irvington, N. J., who, thirty years ago, founded The Chronika, only Polish newspaper in Newark, died tonight in St. Barnabas Hospital at the age of 73. He helped organize St.

THE American Contract Bridge League's executive committee is considering a proposal that the 1939 Summer national championship tournament be held in New York in connection with the New York World's Fair. The national championships are decided annually in two sessions, a Summer tournament and a Winter tournament.

THE 1933 motorist, whether out in a snappy new model or a car of 1930 vintage, experiences a thrill when he crosses a covered bridge. This type of bridge definitely belongs to passing America and about each of them some aura or life of other days still clings.

THE opening of the 1938-1939 season in New York seemed appreciably nearer last week with the 'reopening of the Whitney Museum after a Summer of inactivity and the announcement by the Museum of Modern Art that it would launch three new exhibitions at once on Sept. 28.
New York City's police revolver team won the Challenge Trophy at the first annual Spring Lake Police Department pistol and revolver matches here today with a score of 1,489 out of a possible 1,500.

Mayor La Guardia led a colorful and friendly assault on San Francisee's City Hall this morning in an effort to surprise his friend, Mayor Angelo Rossi. The Mayor's peaceful invasion began when his train reached Oakland at 7 o'clock this morning.

The marriage of Miss Mary Winifred Brown, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Clark Brown of Washington, D. C., and this place, and the late Mr. Brown, to Eugene N. Foss 2d-took place this afternoon in St. Matthew's Church here.

A surprising number of small dahlias are now appearing in the Fall flower shows. Thes, miniature kinds are rapidly becoming as popular as the familiar enormous show and exhibition types. Especially are they finding favor in flower arrangements.

Saturday, May 20, 1939, has been designated as "Social Studies Teachers Day" at the World's Fair, Dr. Harold B. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced last week. The Association of Social Studies Teachers has been invited to hold its annual luncheon and conference at the Fair grounds on that day.

IN looking back over the recent Paris Winter openings several points stand out sharply. One is struck by the fact that each leading couturier has used a characteristic theme as the keynote for his or her whole collection, and that all these individual themes iave been harmonized into a homogeneous fashion symphony for 1939.

During the first fifteen days of this month, twenty-eight homes were sold in the Martha Washington Homes development on 231st Street just north of Merrick Road, Laurelton, L. I., Stewart A. Burkland, president of the Stewart-Bardick Corporation, builders and developers, announced yesterday.
