At the annual preview of Nash automaobile models for 1939, held at the country club here today, George W. Mason, president of the Nahs Kelvintator Corporation, made a plea for American inustry to cooperate in creating products for men to sell in the convictin that men would rather work than go to war.

By unanimous vote, the house of delegates of the American Medical Association today went on record as opposing the government's proposal for a compulsory sickness insurance tax. The delegates, meeting in emergency session, asserted that such a plan would lend itself to political control and manipulation.

Secretary of Labor Perkins said today that reports of the United States Employment Service on operations in August reflected a general improvement in employment throughout the country, placements reaching the highest point of the year with 265,975 jobs filled, of which more than two-thirds were with private employers.

TRUCK-LINE operators and shippers in the Middle Atlantic area last week followed with interest a protracted hearing, held in New York, at which the Interstate Commerce Commission sought evidence on which to build a minimum rate structure for truck freight charges.

THE San Carlo Opera Company opens the second week of its season here tonight with a performance of "LaBoheme." Among the new artists who will appear with the company this week are James Melton, who will sing the role of Pinkerton in "Madama Butterfly"; Mari Barova,

Miss Lillian Arlene Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert N. Edwards of Amagansett, was married this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church there to Samuel Henry Hostetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ross Hostetter of Hanover, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. O. B. Scoville.
Where does the adjective "Gargantuan" come from? It is being used in comment on Thomas C. Wolfe, whose untimely death is deplored
They are singing the praises of Hank Greenberg tonight as the Yankees leave town after their last visit of the year to Briggs Stadium.

THE OXFORD HISTORY OF MUSIC. Vol. III: The Music of the Seventeenth Century. By C. Hubert H. Parry. Second edition, with revisions and an introductory note by Edward J. Dent. 486 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $6.

The Rev. Paulus B. Frey, pastor of St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church of Richmond Hill, Queens, died yesterday at his home, 89-19 114th Street, Richmond Hill, after a fortnight's illness. He was born in Brooklyn 59 years ago.

RUMORS, as a rule, die as quickly as they are born at the corner of Forty-third Street and Times Square, where one can pick up at any time of the day or night supposedly choice pieces of gossip about the secrets of film producers here, in Hollywood and in England.

Mrs. Helen Russell Benson of Coventry Farm, Princeton, N. J., widow of R. Lawrence Benson, was married here yesterday morning to Joseph S. Clements of Miami, Fla., at the Municipal Building by Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines.

New types of water softeners have been greatly simplified in their operation, as they have no moving parts, and no automatic valves to get out of order, states the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

History and Biography ALARMS AND EXCURSIONS. By Sir Tom Bridges. 12mo. New York Longmans. Green Co. $4.20. Reminiscences of a British soldier, 1892-1937. THIS IS MY COUNTRY. By Stoyan Christowe. I2mo. New York: Carrick Evans. $2.75. The autobiography of an American from Macedonia.

PREVIEWS of the 1939 automobile offerings were held for newspaper men here this week at the majority of automobile manufacturing plants as production schedules were moved forward to stock dealers in anticipation of an increased demand for new cars this Fall.
Assurances against a sudden military stroke toward Czechoslovakia in the present stage of the German dispute with that country were reinforced today at the Foreign Office here.

Reports on the proposed reconstruction of the Socialist movement In the United States were discussed yesterday at a meeting of the national executive committee of the Social Democratic. Federation, held at 7 East Fifteenth Street.

DOZENS of private civic groups and public agencies in and near New York City are holding meetings this month to plan for what promises to be the most extensive metropolitan house-cleaning of modern times-a sort of finishing touch to recent park, highway and sanitation improvements.
ABRAHAMS--Mr. and Mrs. Harold L., announce the birth of a boy on Sept. 15 at Polyclinic Hospital. ACKERMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Emory Ackerman announce the birth of a boy on Sept. 14 at Polyclinic Hospital.

The New York City slums, social service organizations and church missions will be used as the laboratories of a new course being planked by Wagner College, Staten Island, to train students for church volunteer work, it was ,announced yesterday.

Thirteen persons were shot, one seriously, today at the strike-bounid plant of the Federal Creosoting Company when 200 strikers and I sympathizers, according to Deputy Sheriff Don Cochran, rushed a group of guards armed with shotguns.

ONE of the outstanding literary events of the Fall will be the publication simultaneously here and in England of the first definitive translation of "The Notebooks of Leonardo da Vinci," edited by Edward MacCurdy.

Puerto Rico's strategic position for a naval air base for four plane squadrons was stressed yesterday by Rear Admiral A. J. Hepburn, head of the naval commission that will report to Congress on new Atlantic and Pacific defense bases.

Uniting in an unprecedented endeavor to build public confidence in business recovery and to dramatize to the public the vital role played by the merchant and by retailing's $40,000,000,000 annual sales volume in the economic life of the country, retailers in more than 100 cities will launch a National Retail Demonstration, beginning tomorrow.

Although wheat prices were on the upgrade today there was little snap to the buying except for a brief period early. Continued warlike reports from Euorpe and unexpected strength in Liverpool were the dominating influences.
A Leo Well attorney, sportsman, civic leader and philanthropist, died today at his home in the Schenley Apartments here. He was 80 years old.
Navy scored 3312 points today to take first place in the Dinghy and Snipe Class events at the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association regatta.
Developments in Europe have caused Brazilians to consider the possibility of difficulty with Germany if it is her determination to act as protector of all people of Germanic blood.
Two debutantes were introduced to society tonight at a large dinner dance at the Piping Rock Club, the last, of the parties for the young women who selected September in the country for their debuts.

Flower shows continue in popularity this week. On Monday afternoon and Tuesday employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES are holding a Fall show in the clubroom on the twelfth floor of The Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street, to which the public is invited.

Paul Wood of the Ocean City, N. J., yacht club, today won the first of the Corinthian Yacht Club's invitation series for Star Class craft. With rain falling throughout, Wood, holder of the New Jersey class title, came from behind in his craft, the Scarab, to beat H. B. Atkin's Jubilee by 18 seconds.

MAX BRUCH's first violin concerto, in G minor, serves Columbia to introduce a new name to-its list (Masterworks Album 332). Alfredo Campoli is the soloist, with an anonymous orchestra under the direaction of Walter Goehr.
Several Cabinet and army officials today discussed measures to be taken should Russia demand the transit of troops over Rumanian territory to aid Czechoslovakia.

Dr. Ignatz Griebl, whose testimony is wanted in New York in connection with espionage cases, was examined yesterday by officials of the United States Department of Justice who arrived here a few days ago.

Demanding additional relief funds to be used to purchase clothing for the unemployed and WPA workers and their families, 800 members of the Workers Alliance surrounded the offices of William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, at 902 Broadway with three picket lines yesterday morning.

During the three Summer months of June, July and August, the Ringwopd Company announces that sixty-three-log cabins and cottages and ninety-one building plots were sold in the chain of Erskine Lakes, comprising Lakes Erskine, Cupsaw and Upper Lake in the Ramapo Mountain section of Northern Passaic County, N. J.

The situation between Britain and Italy has remained completely at a standstill ever since the unsuccessful attempt late in June and early in July to hasten the entry into force of the Anglo-Italian agreements without running counter to Prime Minister

ALBANIA'S promised adhesives commemorating the tenth anniversary of the coronation of King Zog have been received-a miniature sheet of three and a normal postage set of eight. Zog ascended the throne on Sept. 1, 1928, after having been President under a republican form of government.

Joseph P. Day announced yesterday that he will sell at auction Oct3 and 6 more than seventy par cels of New York City, Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey real estate. The sales will be held at 2:30 P. M. in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Only thirteen days of September remain and, despite all alarms, the German army has not moved into Czechoslovakia. The affair is still being handled by the statesmen. They have their ways of being deliberate; and it is possible that thirteen, and more, days can be consumed in deliberations before another critical moment is reached.
The Brooklyn College football team finished its last week of intensive practice before the start of classes with a practice game between the regulars and the reserves yesterday afternoon.

A barrage of goals gave Everton its sixth straight victory in English League soccer today, the Lancastrians defeating Portsmouth by 5-1. Everton maintained its record as the only team in the league's four divisions with maximum points for the season.

Concrete should be used as a foundation material rather than a surface for factory floors in the chemical industries, according to a report made last week to the ninetysixth meeting of the American Chemical Society in Milwaukee by Reuel C. Stratton, supervising chemical engineer, and Warren A. Hough of the Trayelers Insurance Company, Hartford, Conn.

Professor Charles Derleth Jr., dean of the College of Engineering, University of California; Dr. Otis E. Hovey, consulting engineer of New York, and Dr. Aubrey Weymouth, consulting engineer of New York, have been appointed members of the technical advisory board of the American Institute of Steel Construction.

RECAPITULATION of price changes in the American Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue's 1939 edition, to be published tomorrow, shows there have been net advances approximating $8,000 affecting used stamps of 227 governments;

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Mr. and Mrs. Julian Lowell Coolidge of Lowell House, Harvard University, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Wendell Coolidge, to Charles Stacy French of Cambridge, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Ephraim French of Lowell.
Yesterday's matinee performance of Gounod's "Faust" by the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre, though vocally somewhat uneven, moved along smoothly in conventional grooves.

Just as old grads everywhere are asking questions these days of college secretaries and athletic directors about football prospects, so are skippers of cruising boats buzzing around with queries about the new power-yacht models.

Victor F. Ridder, publisher of The Journal of Commerce and The New Yorker Staatszeitung, testified yesterday before a Dies Congressiopal subcommittee on un-American activities that the WorkerS Alliance, a union of WPA workers nd relief clients, was controlled by Communists who besieged his office with demonstrations and riots while he was Works Progress Administrator here.

Harold W. Cheel has been named general chairman of the proceedings for the twenty-second annual convention of the New Jersey Real Estate Association to be held in Atlantic City from Dec. 8 to 10, inelusive.
AT the Pan American Confer ence, to be held in Lima next December, President Oscar Benavides of Peru will announce the completion of a 400year-old South American dream.

In a torrential rain which sent the 3,000 spectators to cover, Corn Dodger, from Paul G. Mellon's Rokeby Stables, won the Long Island Hunt Cup at the annual meeting of the West Hills Racing Association today.

Home runs by Outfielders Eddie Boland and Johnny Tyler enabled the Buffalo Bisons to score by 6-5 for their third straight victory over the Syracuse Chiefs tonight in their four out of seven semi-final play-offs in the International League.

When President Roosevelt canceled all engagements and rearranged his program so that he might hurry to Minnesota last week and there await the outcome of a surgical operation on his son James, he did what almost any father would have done in similar circumstances, but he drew new attention to his close interest in the eldest of -his four sons.

THE laconism of Lynn Overman, which reached some sort of climax this year when he played a long-suffering bartender to John Barrymore's grandiloquent drunk in "True Confession," is known and admired by an ever-widening circle of picturegoers.
In the Gardens of the residence of her parents here Miss Laura Musser was married today to William Floyd 2d of New York, son of Mrs. Emily Delafield Floyd and the late Dr. Rolfe Floyd.

IT is expected that the NBC television transmitter atop the Empire State Building will be off the air from four to six weeks, while the engineers devote their time to construction work. Tests will then follow before a regular program timetable is adopted.

A series of five lectures under the auspices of the New York Women's Committee of the National Public Housing Conference will be given by Hugo Breitner, member of the Viennese Housing Authority on Tuesday evenings beginning Oct. 4, at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

Convinced that eventually the rivalry between the C. I. O. and the A. F. of L. must run its course, industrial leaders are ready to go forward with a plan for setting up machinery for periodic conferences of representatives of labor and industry whenever the labor controversy is resolved, it was learned yesterday from men who have been in the forefront of a movement initiated nearly a year ago.

In an action instituted by the Petroleum Dealers Chamber of Commerce of New York, Inc., against the Triangle Service Station, Long Island City, an order was issued yesterday by Justice Edward Riegelmann in Brooklyn Supreme Court directing the respondent to chow cause why an injunction should not be granted restraining the service station from violation of the Feld-Crawford act through Bales of gasoline below minimum prices established under ,the act.

The evolution of New York's architecture from the earliest steeproofed Colonial-Dutch houses to the skyscrapers of the present is traced in a chapter of "New York Panorama," a book recently completed by the WPA Federal Writers Project of New York.
TWICE within as many days last week Pan American Airways' big transatlantic clipper, the Boeing 314, broke the American airplane load record while undergoing tests at Seattle.

THE use of Paris's regular passenger buses as troop transports during the just-concluded army manoeuvres, and the prediction by officers that in a military crisis the buses would certainly take the place of the taxis made famous by the:' requirementsof the Battle of the Marne, have directed attention to the efficient peace-time- service provided by the vehicles, which most tourists ignore.

The foreign exchange market finished the week on a dull note, but prices sagged in yesterday's short trading period. Engagements of $6,600,000 gold in England for shipment to this country were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank,

The Salvation Army Training School for Officers, at West Trenont and Andrews Avenues, the Bronx, was reopened yesterday. the eighty cadets, as the students are called, were informally welcomed last week by Commissioner and Mrs. Alexander M. Damon,

AN infant democracy is working out its destiny in Eastern Asia. Siam, wedged between English and French colonies and at a crossroads of Japanese expansion, has definitely cast in her lot with liberal government and aims at making herself "The Land of the Free in Asia." Under her new regime she is modernizing not only her government but the country itself and her people.

Mrs. Helene P. Gans has been appointed executive secretary of the Consumers League of New York, according to an announcement by Mrs. W. Russell Bowie, president. She will succeed Mrs. Felice J. Louria, who is now acting chief of the Bureau of Enforcement of the Division of Women in Industry and Minimum Wage of the State Department of Labor.
The flow of refugees into Germany continues from the Sudeten districts of Czechoslovakia. According to official figures, the total has already reached 37,000.

WALTER CONNOLLY'S return to Broadway, and the American premiere of a play by St. John Ervine, would each be an, event. in its own right, wherefore this first Sunday morning of the new season begins with a double-header.

Miss Janet Kirk Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Eppelsheimer Hall of Merion and Fieldstone Farm, Langhorne, was married this afternoon to John James Boericke Jr., son of Mrs. Boericke of Merion and of the late Mr. Boericke.

IN "The Forest Pool" Mrs. Armer has caught and imprisoned the feeling of golden sunshine and of still, leisurely Mexican days. On his mother's sunny porch Diego dreams of jeweled humming birds in the sunlight until Popo, his little friend, wakes him to go to the forest pool through the dark woods where the red flowers hang like bells from the trees.

Mrs. C. J. Reiter, wife of the publisher of the The Hudson StarObserver, and i her 19-year-old daughter, Julieann, were abducted by three men tonight, driven about in the Reiter car for half an hour and then left tied with picture wire along the roadside.

Mistrial: A trial of no effect by reason of some error in the proceedings. The trial of James J. Hines, charged with using his power as a Tammany district leader to protect the numbers lottery racket, ended last week in a mistrial. The error, Justice Ferdinand Pecora ruled, was made by District Attorney Thomas A. Dewey
Official notification was made today that a German-Czechoslovak commercial agreement concluded in Berlin on Aug. 26 became effective as of Sept. 1.

The Ebro, one of the great rivers of Spain and the only important one that flows into the Mediterranean, has for months been stained with the blood of Loyalists and Insurgents. Last Spring, when the Loyalists fell back before General Franco's Catalan offensive, many lost their lives in the river, drowned or killed while crossing.

More than 1,000 striking truck drivers gathered in front of the New York Journal-American building at 210 South Street yesterday afternoon and unsuccessfully attempted to prevent the delivery of 450 rolls of newsprint needed for the publication of the Sunday edition of the newspaper.

Sir Malcolm Campell of England, former holder of the world land speed record, broke his own world record for speed on water today by driving his motor boat Bluebird more than 130 miles an hour over a mile course on Lake Halwil.

Football activity is slated to start this 'week on the Eastern prep school frontier, with merely a handful of teams booked for combat on Friday and Saturday. However, even though the schedule is small and does not involve many headliners, it will mark the beginning of what promises to be a banner campaign.
V. M. I. veteran and sophomore backs displayed powerful drives in the first and last periods of today's opening football game to defeat Elon College, 33 to 7, before a crowd of 3,500.

Total fur sales of fur skins during August were $3,884,350, compared with $4,831,299 in July, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc. Aggregate sales for the nine months ended in August were $26,267,984, against $39,893,155 in the corresponding period a year ago.

As the start of the Fall semester draws nearer, and with the opening game of the season only two weeks away, the New York University football team will end its training camp routine at this lakeside retreat and will return to New York City by special bus Tuesday afternoon.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Sylvia Edith Denefeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Denefeld of 225 West Eighty-sixth Street, this city, and Far Rockaway, L. I., to Dr. Eugene Rodin of Hempstead, L. I.

Announcement that the so-called engineering contracts awarded are now running well ahead of a year ago, and that for the entire year to date they also show an appreciable gain, raises the question as to whether the longawaited upturn in building activity is any closer at hand.

WASHINGTON.--An increase in the output of printed matter from the Government Printing Office here--from a value of $12,000,000 to $19,000,000 a year in the last four years--is responsible for an extensive construction program now under way.

A New York jewelry salesman reported that three men kidnapped him in the Loop during the rush hour this morning and stole gems worth $100,000. Apparently no one in the crowds n the street was aware of the crime.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Von Elm of Forest Hills gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza here, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy C. Von Elm, to John Luther Putnam of Great Neck, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Luther Putnam of Chicago.

The Real Estate--Taxpayers Federation, which was "constantly represented" at Albany during the Constitutional Convention, did much to prevent approval of proposals which it deemed harmful to realty, according to Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York and vice chairman of the federation.

ONE of the most significant offerings that radio has placed before the public in recent years is the series of performances of the Bach church cantatas initiated last Sunday by Alfred Wallenstein and broadcast over WOR Mutual.

Three new developments stand out conspicuously in city shops after a week of kaleidoscopic fashion shows. They are the up-brushed coiffure, the daring use of color, and the new shoes. These three factors contribute- heavily to the general new and different look of any one dressed up in a 1938 Fall outfit.

HUNGARY has issued a special silver five-pengo coin commemorating the 900th anniversary of the death of St. Stephen, the first King of the Hungarians. The obverse shows a profile portrait of the patron saint facing right and wearing the crown in its original state.

The view that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's visit to Chancellor Adolf Hitler may prove to be disastrous to peace instead of being a move toward it was expressed today by "Observer" in a long interpretative article in Pravda, the organ of the Communist party.
To take effect 8 A. M., Sept. 19: PATROLMAN Harold A. Southwick, from Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan, to Traffic Precinct O. Assignment to duty with Midtown Squad discontinued.

A lot of local sportsmen who want to combine hunting and fishing during their vacations have written for information on the possibilities of North Carolina for surf, fishing and bird shooting. The answer is: The possibilities are in the nature of "probabilities."

Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, will speak at the opening session of the real estate selling, renting and law course to be given by the New York Y. M. C. A., 5 West Sixty third Street, beginning Sept. 28. He will discuss what the future offers to the real estate profession.

PHILADELPHIA.--A rambling tumbledown shack in Prospect Park, ten miles southwest of Phikadelphia, has been restored as a State shrine in memory of John Morton, who cast the deciding vote in the Continental Congress which put Pennsylvania on the side of independence.

American children -living in the tropics are not retarded thereby, according to achievement tests, which show that Canal Zone pupils have a higher scholastic standing than the average students in the United States.

James Reed, president of the Association of San Francisco Distributors, accepted today an invitation from Harry R. Bridges, president of the C. I. O. International Longshoremen and Warehousemen's Union, to renew negotiations on the association's demand for a uniform contract with a single expiration date for all warehouses, instead of individual and group contracts with different dates.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, and William M. Calder, former United States Senator, joined yesterday in issuing an appeal to Republicans to vote for Louis Waldman, member of the American Labor party, for the Republican nomination for Kings County- Judge against Harold L. Turk, Republican district leader. Mr. Waldman also was endorsed by Samuel Seabury.
Rain stopped the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup polo tournament at the Meadow Brook club today, postponing once more the start of Old Westbury's defense of the title.

The Asbury Park High School eleven started its 1938 gridiron campaign today with a 6-to-0 victory over an alumni squad. The touchdown came in the final minutes after the Asbury Park varsity had taken the ball from midfield to the 3-yard line on a series of passes engineered by Klitzman and Joyce. Arthur Delson skirted left end for the score.

Citizens were reminded again this week that it is the taxpayer who pays and pays. As they dug down in their pockets for the quarterly income-tax installment they were jolted anew into the realization that it takes money to run the Federal Government.
FABRICS will play a leading role in home decoration this season, judging from the. many new patterns and weaves which have made their appearance.

Edward Dickinson Duffield, president of the Prudential Insurlance Company of America since Sept. 1, 1922, died here at 6:45 o'clock tonight at his home, 565 Berkely Avenue, from the effects I of a stroke suffered yesterday afternoon at his office in Newark. He was 67 years old.

ARE women born liars? Why have so few women the instincts of gentlemen? Do women hate one another? These three questions, which a "clever man" once put to her, Mrs. Atherton answers, amusingly if not always convincingly, in the opening chapter of this new book of theories, ideas and impressions.

Virginia Tech routed Emory and Henry, 33 to 0, in toe opening football game before 2,500 today. Al Miller lost little time in dashing across for the first touchdown. He scored again in the third and fourth sessions. Jimmy Fixx,
In winning the national amateur golf championship Willie Turnesa "realized the greatest ambition of my life," he declared today as he received the $10,000 Theodore Havemeyer Trophy.

When a dog, just a show dog, is awarded best of breed fifty times he must be a pretty good dog. Champion Nornay Saddler today gained that distinction for the Wissaboo Kennels of James M. Austin, Westbury, L. I.

Eight years ago there was not available a "single B6ook on any phase of the work of philanthropic foundations," says Dr. Ernest Vic, tor Hollis in the preface to his own book, "Philanthropic Foundations and Higher Education,"

After advancing for six weeks, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined for the week ended Sept. 10, falling to 84.5 from 85.3, the revised figure for the preceding week. A year ago the index was 106.6.
Frank Brett Noyes, who retired recently as president of The Associated Press and celebrated in July his seventy-fifth birthday, and Mrs. Noyes, celebrated their golden wedding anniversary here today.

" O wild west wind, thou breath of Autumn's being." Not wild just now. In two or three months it will begin to seal the earth in ice and wildly whistle down the hills. But now it is the good genius of the prelude to Autumn.

The Cornell University Medical College will open its forty-first year on Wednesday with an enrollment of 287 students from colleges and universities throughout the country, Dr. William Sargent Ladd, dean of the college,, announced yesterday.

Thomas G. Grace, State FHA Administrator, Colonel E. M. Podeyn, chairman of the Nassau County Board of Assessors, and other officials-were present last week at the formal opening of the new suburban home community at Hewlett, L. I., under development by W. R. Gibson, head of the Gibson Corporation and creator of the town of Gibson, L. I. Mr. Grace christened the new community "Sunbury-atHewlett."

A cooperative move on the part of canners of peas to market their current pack of 25,000,000 cases and the carry-over of 5,000,000 cases from last year will get under way in the coming month, according to word reaching the food market here yesterday from Wisconsin.
MAYO MAN: At the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., a surgeon, still wearing his operating-room clothes, last week broke the traditional reticence of a medical man

The magazine will continue in spite of the unfavorable conditions of the times, and will carry on its efforts to draw ever nearer to its "idea," to what it would and should represent. We know very well what is expected of us.

ABRAMS--SINGEER--Mr. and Mrs. J. Singer of Bronx announce the engagement of their daughter, Elaine, to Mr. Herman A. Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Abrams of Brooklyn. AIDTER--EHRENSAL--Mrs. Nathan Ehrensal of 654 West 161St., New York City, announces the engagement of her daughter, Leah, to Louis S. Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adler.

The first State convention of unions affiliated with the Committee for, Industrial Organization closed yesterday with expressions of unqualified support for President Roosevelt and the New Deal, demands that Congress "stop wasting public funds" on the Dies

A SLIGHT, soft-spoken, mild-mannered man sat on a horse-hair sofa in a living room that suggested the Edwardian era in which lingered fragments of the Victorian. A smile played almost continuously on his alert face.
FICTION I'M NOT COMPLAINING. By Ruth Adams. Liveright Publishing Corporation. A novel about a group of young teachers. SONG OF YEARS. By Bess Streeter Aldrich. D. Appleton-Century Company.
Huey Long's political heirs are carrying on, but with a machine slightly less formidable than the one he bequeathed to them when a bullet ended his life just three years ago.

AS in the United States, motorists in Great Britain are evinc ing interest in improvements of transmission. Recently a car was described before the British Association which is quite without gears or the conventional clutch.
Brookvlle (72)--Quarter-final round, club championship: G. Meredith defeated H. B. Allen, 6 and 5. John Gordon Sr. made a hole-in-one on the 140-yard eleventh hole with a spoon.

Turning on a brilliant burst of speed in the back-stretch, where she moved from sixth to first place within an eighth of a mile, Esposa, mare owned by William Ziegler Jr. of New York, today won the $15,000 added Hawthorne Gold Cup race over a mile and one-quarter.
Show Prince

Construction work on the seventh group of homes in the Green Acres development on Sunrise Highway at Valley Stream, L. I., will begin this week, Irwin S. Chanin, architect and sponsor of the development, announced yesterday.

These men, militant followers of Konrad Henlein's Nazi movement, are the spearhead of nearly 3,500,000 Sudeten Germans-puppets of Hitler, from one point of view; victims of oppression, from the other.

Johnny Downs, veteran jockey, who won the King's Plate at the Blue Bonnets track in Montreal 63 years ago, died Friday at the age of 83 in the University Heights Hospital, Bronx, after a two-days illness. He lived at 3,271 Hull Ave nue, Bronx.
RUSSIA'S erstwhile domination of Finland has apparently left a mark on the literature of that country and impressed it with certain qualities unhappily absent in Soviet fiction.
Regardless of the driving rain, ten gunners took part in the skeet shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today at fifty targets. The winner of the scratch prize was W. A. Ketcham,. who. broke 46.

" What Latin America Thinks of the Good-Neighbor Policy," the address to be given by Dr. Ricardo J. Alfaro, former President of the Republic of Panama, brings to the three coming NEW YORK TIMES Review-of-the-News Conferences one of the four authors of the Treaty of 1936 signed by Panama and the United States.

ASTOR--Marie Antoinette: Norma Shearer, Tyrone Power.* BELMONT--Avocat d'Amour: Danielle Darrieux.* CAMEO--Mother and Sons and The Bear: both Russian. CAPITOL--Boys Town: Spencer Tracy, Mickey Rooney;* Too Hot to Handle: Clark Gable, Myrna Loy, opens Thursday. CRITERION--Come on, Leathernecks: Marsha Hunt.
Tobacco is not generally considered a Canadian agricultural crop, but tobacco growers in the Dominion will receive about $18,000,000 for thier crop in October.

The steamship Panama, first of three new ships to be completed for the Panama Railroad Steamship Company at the yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company at Quincy, Mass., will be launched next Saturday.
Declaration of mistrial in the Hines case, in addition to its other consequences, has directed attention to the intricacies of court-room procedure in criminal trials.

A number of meetings are scheduled for the week by Connecticut units of civic and political groups. The League of Women Voters will hold a citizenship school on Wednesday and Thursday at the Pickwick Arms Hotel, Greenwich.
Robert Stevenson, a Chicago broker, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital of a heart attack. He was stricken on a plane en route here. His age was 60.

Led by institutional advertising, which increased more than 20,000 lines, fourteen divisions of New York and Brooklyn departments stores had linage gains during August, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc.

Court of Appeals, by a unanimous decision, nullified today the primary candidacy of Joseph F. Marchetti for the American Labor and Republican nominations for Member of Assembly from the Twentieth District of Kings County, leaving Assemblyman Roy H. Rudd to run for both the Democratic and Republican positions without oppositions.
Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet will go to London tomorrow in response to an invitation from. the British Government to discuss the Czechoslovak situation.

J. Insley Blair won the honors in the fruit and vegetable divisions of the annual show of the Tuxedo Horticultural Association today in the gymnasium of the high school here by taking thirteen first awards. David Wagstaff was second with seven firsts and Edward J. Hancy won four firsts.

Clemson alternated two teams and a few reserves today to open its football season with a 26-0 victory over a stubborn Presbyterian College eleven. Coach Jess Neely played his first team in the first and third quarters and turned over the other two periods to sophomores.

With the enrollment of the freshman class at Allegheny College last week, a new program of individualized education went into operation, culminating a seven-year faculty study to achieve a better integration and coordination of educational aims.
Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Parker Shilstone have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara De Veau Shilstone, to Philip Chandler Holden, son of Mrs. Leon Holden and the late Mr. Holden.

Mrs. John Stallman Taylor of this city and Pittsfield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Taylor, to Winthrop William Sargent, son of Mrs. Elizaeth Abbot Sargent of Pine Ridge Farm, Concord, and of the late Winthrop W. Sargent of Boston.

A large number of lending Institutions in the New York City area are noW making loans for the construction of small homes and residential properties under that phase of the amended National Housing Act covering insurance on such properties costing up to $2,500, Thomas G. Grace, New York State Director of the FHA, announced yesterday.

Mervyn Conners, White Sox rookie first baseman who was recalled from Shreveport two weeks ago, delivered three consecutive homers in the second game today as Chicago swept a double-header with the Athletics, 8 to 4 and 7 to 4.

Seventeen-year-old Warner Willcox of Staten Island, N. Y., sailed his speedy Escargot to victory in a field of thirty starters in the Comet race of the President's Cup regatta today. The race was over a fivemile Potomac River course.

With perhaps the greatest exhibition of blasting out of bunkers and putting ever put on in the forty-two. years that the championship has been played, Willie Turnesa, member of the Briar Hills Club in Westchester, today annexed the United States amateur golf crown by defeating his California rival, Buell Patrick Abbott of Altadena, actor-golfer, 8 and 7, in the final round at the Oakmont Country Club.

Judge James F. Fardy of Superior Court held today that 300 stockholders of the defunct Chicago Bank of Commerce were liable for $2,500,000 that the bank owed to more than 3,000 depositors. The stockholders include Harley L. Clarke, utilities operator, and Vincent Bendix, manufacturer of automobile parts.

Former Governor Eugene Talmadge, Administration critic, who ran second to Senator Walter F. George in Wednesday's Georgia Democratic primary, announced tonight he was filing contests in thirty counties. His contentions, if proved, would "clearly give me the election," he said.

THE new Civil Aeronautics Authority, taking over one of the fastest growing regulatory jobs of the government on Aug. 22, has snapped into its task with a speed becoming to the youthful industry whose destinies are largely in its hands.

Colgate's Red Raiders defeated the B team in a regulation practice game today, 24-6, with Howie Herman, Johnny Long and Harry Barouth scoring touchdowns and Lloyd Scoville kicking a 40-yard field goal for the winners. Ken Murphy, end, scored on a pass for the reserves.
Julian Huxley, noted British biologist, and his wife were injured
Leave of absence for three days. effective on or about Sept. 19, is granted Major Henry T. Allen, Cavalry.

The first poll tax, Tertullian records, was imposed about 4 B. C. by Caesar Augustus 'as "a badge of servility" for conquered peoples. Among the first payers of the tax, according to the same authority, were Joseph and Mary, who went up to Bethlehem to be enrolled as poll-tax payers.

Shut out for eight innings, the plucky Pirates came from behind today to score two runs in the ninth and beat the Bees, 2 to 1, in the rubber contest of the three-game series. Both teams backed up airtight pitching with errorless ball.

A new home development will be constructed on the eighty-acre tract of land known as "Cross Gates at Madison" in Madison, N. J., General Properties, Inc., developers, announced yesterday. Marcel Villanueva is the architect.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 17, unless specified. New York to Guantanamo: Babbitt, Decatur, Roper, Tillman. New Haven to Guantanamo: Badger, Herbert, Leary.

AMERICAN visitors to the British Radio Exhibition at Olympia bought some of the midget televisors, showing postcard size pictures, to take home as souvenirs of their European tours. German and other foreign visitors were equally intrigued with the $150 set which also incorporated allwave radio.

Peter Van Cortlandt Morris, 7year-old son of Newbold Morris, President of the City Council and Acting Mayor, has been ill for six weeks with Rocky Mountain fever, said to be the only case of the disease in the State at present.

The Washington Senators went on a hitting spree and collected thirty-three safe blows, including eight doubles, two triples and three home runs, to score a double victory over the St. Louis Browns today, 10 to 9 and 11 to 1.

Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. of L., was designated yesterday by the New York State Labor Relations Board as-the sole representative of the thirty-five employes at the Whitby Apartments, 325 West Forty-fifth Street, in collective bargaining with the management.

A British Prime Minister motored up the private highway to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's highland chalet, Berghof, late one afternoon this week to discuss the, fate of European peace with the creator of the Greater German Empire.

In a bleak and drab setting created by intermittent showers, five, championship awards were made today as the fourth annual New Brunswick horse show was climaxed on the grounds of the New Jersey College of Agriculture.

THE two Edwards of the Metropolitan Opera AssociationJohnson and Ziegler-will return from their European travels some time next week. It was known that Mr. Johnson had sailed for his annual jaunt around the European operatic circuit-or what is left of it-but Mr. Ziegler's sailing with Mr. Johnson was not divulged.

LONDON.--The British "backbencher" Member of Parliament (who roughly conforms to the United States member of Congress of the rank and file, but who is far less considered) is in many ways a glutton for punishment.
Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart Baker of Short Hills gave a supper dance tonight at the Short Hills Club to introduce to society their younger daughter, Miss Priscilla Baker.
" Education for Tomorrow's America" is the theme of the eighteenth observance of American Education Week which ivill be held throughout the country Nov. 6 to 12.

A trend to increasing popularity of lighter automobiles was seen by Charles A. Harnett State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, when he announced yesterday that although registrations of motor cars for the first seven months of this year were 27,534 more than in the same period of 1937, the receipts declined by $2,137,510.

PUBLIC enemy No. 1 in Northeast Australia is the dingo, or wild dog, which is held to do as much damage as all other pests put together. The dingo (warrigall in the native tongue) is about the size of the average collie dog, standing around two feet high and measuring five feet from snout to tail tip, and has jaws remarkable for their power.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora did not take official action yesterday on the request of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to transfer the next trial of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader who is charged with conspiracy in the policy racket, to the Court of General Sessions.

Mr. and Mrs. Jesse S. Phillips of this -place have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Mary Elizabeth Cannon of Andover, N. Y., to William D. Kiley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Kiley of Oneida, N. Y.
Investment bankers view with increasing alarm the tremendous growth recently of private purchasing of new security issues by life insurance companies.

THE racing dugout is enjoying a revival of interest on the East ern Shore of Maryland, as was evidenced at the recent contest for the Governor's Trophy, first offered in 1927, at St. Michaels on the Miles River.

Frank Guernsey of Orlando, Fla., national - intercollegiate champion, today advanced to the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania clay court tennis championships by beating William Talbert of Cincinnati, 6--2, 9--7.

The estate of the late Mary Strong Shattuck at Lenox, Mass., will be sold by Joseph P. Day next Saturday on the premises. The property comprises about 155 acres, with a dwelling containing twenty-nine rooms, a gate lodge, garage. stables and several farm buildings.

Representative James M. Mead of Buffalo said yesterday he was not a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor or United States Senator but would be happy to continue in the House, where he is chairman of the Committee on Postoffices.

The six-day bicycle race, long a New York fixture for the months of November and March, will start tonight at Madison Square' Garden. The grind will get under way at 9 o'clock when Miss Sonja Henie fires the starting signal.
Several new homes in the $9,000to-$12,000 price range will be ready for inspection today in two of the choice residential developments in the Port Washington area, on the North Shore of Long Island.

Several department stores have decided that the best way to meet oneprice chain competition is not by sporadic promotions but by consistent plugging of a low - price bracket with either a store or national name, it was indicated here last week.

Suggestions to improve the existing tax assessment procedure were presented before the New England regional realty conference at Worcester, Mass., last week by John C. Percival of Lowell, a member of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers.

With three weeks of Intensive practice, including five scrimmages completed, the Fordham football squad is gradually taking shape for the opening game with Upsala at the Randalls Island Stadium a week from next Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Jane Paffard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic C. Paffard of this place and Brooklyn, to John Streeter Hamill, son of Mrs. Philip W. Hamill of Stonington and New York and the late Mr. Hamill, took place here this afternoon in Calvary Episcopal Church. The Rev.

William S. Murray, Republican State chairman, left yesterday for his home in Utica, leaving it pretty well understood that as a result of a conference of party leaders the preceding day the Republican State Convention at Saratoga Springs next week would nominate District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for Governor, if Mr. Dewey before that time did not refuse definitely to take the nomination.

Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College, announced yesterday thirteen appointments and twenty reappointments to the staff of the college for the coming year. The appointments are in the ranks of instructor and tutor, while those reappointed will be instructors, tutors and fellows.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 16: MAJOR GENERAL Baker, W. C., Chief of Chemical Warfare Service, one month leave, Sept. 20.

The marriage of Mis Janet Margaret Smith, daughter of Mrs. George Harold Smith of St. Albans, Queens, and the late Mr. Smith, to Hiester Henry Muhlenberg 2d, son of Mrs. Frederic H. Muhlenberg of Reading, Pa., and the late Mr. Muhlenberg, took place here yesterday afternoon.

The largest volume of construction contracts since July, 1937, was awarded in the thirty-seven Eastern States during August, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.' The total for last month, points out the statistical firm, was $313,141,000, an increase of 12 per cent over August of last year and 30 per cent over July of this year.
Lord and Lady Leverhulme have left the Waldorf-Astoria for Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Eric Loder will return from Europe tomorrow, and will be at the Savoy-Plaza before going to Montreal.

Blonde Miss Molly Tyson, 20-yearold Temple University co-ed, today became the-first woman- ever to win the national midget outboard cham pionship when- she piloted 'her fifty. 'pound speed boat to a victory over a field of eight.

August trade figures for Greater Germany shovq an adverse balance of 64,500,000 marks. Imports were at 509,500,000 marks, an increase of 37,000,000 marks over July. Exports, at 445,000,000 marks, were 25000,000 marks less than in July, which had shown a substantial advance.
ON her own confession E. B. Ginty has been, scared to death in most of the major cities of the Eastern seaboard. Reason? Opening night panic, unadulterated and unabated throughout the years.

Reports from Chungking, seat of the Chinese Foreign Office, said today that the government had accepted the resignation of Dr. C. T. Wang as Ambassador to the United States. He will be succeeded by Dr. Hu Shih, who was graduated from Cornell University in 1914.

The city-wide finals of the Parks Department annual shuffleboard tournament, postponed, yesterday because of rain, will be held at 3 P. M. next Sunday in the North Meadow Playground, off Ninetyseventh Street, in Central Park. The contest was limited to persons over 18 years old.

Widespread endorsement by retailers and trade authorities of the decision by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to break its traditional silence and to put the case of the chain store industry before the bar of public opinion was reported here yesterday.

Attended by a bridal party of twenty-two, Miss Madelaine Dutilh Agnew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Bliss Agnew of New York, was married to Hastings Foote 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sterling T. Foote, also of New York, here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Church in New York.

The dolicate situation in Europe caused President Roosevelt to remain at he White House today. The PresiLent's concern over the crisis in Czechoslovakia was shown further today by his cancellation of a scheduled trip Tuesday to the Chickamauga National Park where he was to have made an address in connection with the dedication he restored battlefield on which Union and Confederate forces ought seventy-five years ago.

Orange Chapter, Sons of the American Revolution, today held what was announced as the first annual pilgrimage to the grave in Rosedale Cemetery here of David L. Pierson, founder of Constitution Day, who died in East Orange on July 9. Mr. Pierson helped organize the chapter and was an officer for many years.

THE phrase soup to nuts" might just as well be "fruit cup to ice cream" or "oysters to pie," since it is not always to be taken literally, but it survives to embrace a meal satisfactorily complete. And on cool days at this season, of course. soup and its hot rich savors are a very good beginning.

Officials of the new realty firm known as the Hillcrest Realty Company in Jackson Heights, L. I., report that during their first month in business they have rented many suites in various apartment houses. Among the lessees were: Joseph F.
" VOLTAIRE." by John Charpentier (Taillandier. 318 pp.. 18f), is a noteworthy biography for other reasons than the "Baudelaire" by the same author (which we reviewed here a year ago). Voltaire,

The British Cabinet divided three ways in two sessions that considered Adolf Hitler's demands yesterday. Prime Minister Chamberlain was understood to favor cession of part of the 'Sudeten district' to Germany.

WITH unemployment and economic insecurity recognized as a national problem, the roots of which go deeper than the top soil of depressions and recessions, the role of the social worker of today has become an important one.

LONDON.--Planted in 1775, the famous vine in the royal gardens at Windsor has yielded more than 1,000 bunches of grapes this year. The best bunches, some of them weighing more than two pounds, have gone to the King's table, but most have gone to hospitals and other institutions all over the country.
Historic front pages of New York newspapers are in an exhibit which opened yesterday at Arnold Constable Co. as a feature of that store's observance of its 113th anniversary.
Copper Queen, the sturdy chestnut mare owned by Mrs. Robert Augustus Chambers, turned in the finest performance to capture premier honors at the ninth Tanrackin Horse Show today.

The George Washington University Law School, which was organized in 1826, discontinued, and reopened -in 1865 and which offered the first graduate course of law in the country, will start this Fall an extended program of research in the field of public law.

ACCORDING to figures compiled by Paris Post of the American Legion, slightly more than 1,500 members of the Never-Go-Home Battalion of the A. E. F. still reside in France, although it will soon be twenty years since the World War was brought to an end by the Armistice of Rethondes.

REVIEW: As part of Coney Island's thirty-fifth annual Mardi Gras there was a parade-at the island last week of volunteer firemen from New York and Long Island. In the reviewing stand, throwing confetti at the paraders, was the familiar figure of former Governor Alfred E. Smith. He has seldom missed one of these end-ofSummer festivals.

At a tea at their home this afternoon Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stephen Pasley of this place and Burlington, Vt., announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Anne Pasley, to Thomas Magner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Magner Jr. of Rutland, Vt.

The Czechoslovakia, Government late tonight took special measures for the protection of the State during the next three months. A state of emergency, a form of martial law, will restrict many of the normal constitutional rights of Czechs.

The sudden ending of the trial of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines, on order of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora directing a mistrial, has put the Republican leaders of the State in a quandary.

Japanese forces driving westward north of the Yangtze River toward Hankow reported tonight that they had captured Hwangehwan in Honan Province and continued to within fifty miles of the important Peiping-Hankow Railway.

Defeat of the two proposed constitutional amendments prohibiting proportional representation and reapportioning State legislative districts was urged today in a statement by Israel Amter, chairman of the State committee of the Communist party.

In cooperation with architects and officials of various Federal agencies charged with housing, members of the Metal Window Institute have developed and prepared specifications for steel windows to be used in low-cost housing developments.

What they believe to be presentday tendencies toward centralization in our government were condemned tonight by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbit University, and former Governor Alfred E. Smith in addresses at a Constitution Day meeting here.

Wraith, black pacer owned by William Parkhurst of Maplewood, scored a straight-heat victory in the Class A event, feature of the weekly matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahio Park today.

FOR four successive week readers of The Times Lit erary Supplement have been confronted by the headline "Present Discontents." displayed in the biggest type used by that paper and in its mos prominent position.

LONDON.--Slowly but surely, despite the desperate efforts of private bodies, the face of London is changing. The fine old Georgian houses which once overlooked some of London's most famous squares are disappearing.

Cravat, 12-to-1 shot, and Porter's Mite, at 20-to-1, each' a stunning surprise to practically all in the crowd of 15,000 at rain-swept Belmont yesterday, smashed home first in the Jerome Handicap and Champagne Stakes, respectively, leaving in their wake a new world's record and a new discussion as to 3-year-old honors.

NOW that Shirley Temple and her parents are back in town, and the functionaries who accompanied her on her tour of the nation have returned from the vacations they all took as soon as the hegira was completed, the Fox publicity department is settling down to complacent calculation of the newspaper space garnered by their "boxoffice-number-one."
' ARTIFICLAL EYES"--that was the subject of Lord Rayleigh's recent address to the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
TO glorify the genius of Flanders, whether expressed in art, folk lore or social progress, the Belgian authorities have created a Flemish Museum in Antwerp.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

Two league games in six days are on the program for the Brooklyn Dodgers, who will open their season in the National Football League when they meet the champion Washington Redskins at Washington, D. C., this afternoon.
An interesting detail in the present international crisis is the silence Soviet spokesmen are preserving on the subject.
How Willie Turnesa marched to the national amateur golf championship: Qualified with 77, 71-?48, tying for second place, two shots behind medalist.

AT least three plays to be produced this year by the new group of. playwright-managers will speak a good word for democracy. This does not represent any deliberate plan on their part; they're not pooling their ideas.

Fourteen-year-old Miss Marion Loucks won the Good Hands event at the ninth annual Boulder Brook Club Horse Show today in a field of thirteen capable riders. Miss Loucks was selected by the judges, Mrs. Earl E. Miller and Mrs. Richard 'M. Carver, both of Darien, Conn., after the competition had lasted almost an hour.

HODGSON, CASPAR W. (Feb. 17). Estate, less than $500. To Kaspar M. Hodgson, son, Whippany, N. J.; Foresta Hodgson Wood, daughter, same address; Daphne Hodgson, daughter, 145 E. 56th St., one-third residue each. David P. Barrows, Berkeley, Calif., executor.

THE city-wide Children's Art Festival conducted in Central Park by the Public Use of Arts Committee turned the art story of a couple of weeks ago into a story that had to do for the most part with children.

A substantial portion of the public debt may be traced to demands made several years ago by real estate brokers for local improvements, in the opinion of Samuel S. Kenworthy, executive secretary of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities.

While Mayor La Guardia gave instructions by long distance telephone from San Francisco, Acting Mayor Newbold Morris late yesterday afternoon arranged a conference with strike and union leaders and employers to be held at 'City Hall tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock to endeavor to negotiate a settlement of the "outlaw" strike of truck drivers.

More and better leaders for wonen's clubs will be groomed during the coming season through the efeorts of two separate organizations which have recognized that the supply of executives equipped with modern techniques in group work is iot keeping pace with the demand.
UCH of the most informed criticism written in the last half century has appeared in fugitive literary

With the cooperation of the weather, the Dodgers yesterday avoided losing another game to the Cardinals. It was washed off the 1938 schedule. St. Louis has finished its season's business with Brooklyn.

SINCE so much of the news was foreign news last week, we might as well make it unanimous by reporting that the best of the new films came from abroad too. Their titles had an ominous sound, one being "The Edge of the World," the other--about war -- sardonically called "Grand Illusion."

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday that residential building costs are rising for the first time in twelve months. Construction costs in August, it is stated, showed a significant rise in many sections of the country, the first increase noted since August, 1937.

Willie Turnesa, upon his arrival in New York City from his brilliant success at Oakmont, Pa., will be honored at a luncheon to be given by the members of his home club, the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club, tomorrow, it was announced tonight by J. F. O'Connor of the club's board of directors.

Copy, the mongrel terrier that for the past eleven years had made the rounds of the city's station houses with his master, Robert Noerr, police reporter for the New York City News Association, died yesterday after having been struck by an automobile.

WHEN Rudolph Valentino had been billed at two West-End cinemas simultaneously and they had got back as far as "Abraham Lincoln" in the talkie reissues, I decided to board out the dog, leave a note for the milkman, and go down to the south coast for a holiday.

SOME of the running start that retail trade enjoyed on the Fall season and the National Retail Demonstration Week was lost in the week as reports again turned spotty. But to account for this there were the special circumstances of the war crisis abroad and the reappearance of warm weather. Moreover,
GROWTH OF A MAN. By Mazo de la Roche. 380 pp. Boston: Atlantic Monthly Press-Little, Browm Co. $2.50.
The Chicago Cardinals defeated the Cleveland Rams in a National Football League game tonight, 7-6, scoring on the seventh play of the game and winning on the extra point.

Warrington B. (Duff) McCulough of Philadelphia moved into the semi-finals in the George Arthur Crump Memorial Golf Tourney today by defeating Michael Strutt of London, England, 3 and 2, in the second round of match play. He conquered R. W. Dinsmore, Reading, Pa., in the first round, 2 and 1.

The Arundel Corporation, a construttion concern, reported yesterday a net profit of $899,909, before Federal income taxes, for the eight months to Aug. 31. This compares with a net profit of $850,336 in the first eight months of last year.

DAVIS--FRBEDMAN-Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Friedman announce the marriage of their daughter, Yetta, to Mr. Leo Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Davis to take place on Sept. 18, 1938, at the Jewish Center, 174th St. and Nelson Ave., Bronx.

Although hampered by rain, Army's first and second football teams scored five touchdowns today in a practice game against opposition drawn from the second and third teams and the junior varsity squad. Each of the first two eleven played two twenty-five minute periods and neither was scored upon.

THE attractions for the coming season at the Federal Music Theatre will include three series of orchestral concerts, seven madrigal concerts and four operas, according to an announcement by Chalmers Clifton, New York City director of the Federal Music Project.

Two home developments in the lower sections of Brooklyn are experiencing considerable activity. At the Richards Homes community in the Flatbush section on East Fiftysecond Street, between Avenue D and Foster Avenue, fifteen dwellings have been sold and thirty-two homes have been completed in that project.
Miss Alice Neale Gordon and E. Kenneth Sandbach were married here this afternoon in the Paris Hill Church by the Rev. Hilda Libby Ives of Portland.
The building trades unions have voted a general strike, to start Monday. The workers state they will remain at work on projects connected with national defense.

Jeff Heath continued his batting rampage today, pounding out his fifteenth home run and three singles, to lead the Indians to a 5-4 victory over the second-place Boston club. The outcome left the Tribe one game behind the Red Sox-the same place they were when the fourgame series started.

Annual Communion breakfast, New' York Archdiocesan Union of Sodalities of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Hotel Astor, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. William J. B. Daly, the Rev. Justin J. Walsh, Dr. Sylvester J. Hemleben, Mrs. Margaret Tynan, Wilma C. Riordan.

Yale closed its first week of practice today with a scrimmage which Coach Ducky Pond had planned to conduct under game regulations, but which was curtailed by rain, which fell all day. The action was stopped after fifteen minutes of hard play.

The last important primary contest in President Roosevelt's attempted "purge" of Democratic members of Congress will take place Tuesday when Representative John J. O'Connor of the Sixteenth Congressional District will face James H. Fay, New Deal candidate and choice of President Roosevelt in the primary election.

Recent Phi Beta Kappa alumni will take part in a spelling bee to be broadcast on Sept. 30 at 8 P. M. over the National Broadcasting System, according to the Autumn issue of the Key Reporter, a Phi Beta Kappa publication.

Retail trade was mixed last week, helped by weather, improved employment and better movement of farm cash in some districts, bul running sharply below last year in other areas. Unofficial estimates placed the drop in. San Franciscc volume, resulting chiefly from the retail strike there. at 50 per cent.

What may prove to be an important change in the railroad consolidation policy of this country was brought to light quietly last night in a memorandum submitted by the Association of American Railroads to a meeting of the National Transportation Conference in Washington.

Every one has heard of plowing under cotton, but plowing under copper cables in water depths up to half a mile is something new. That, however, is what is now being done with the electric nerves that thread the ocean beds and connect our continents in a web of interchanging information.

Close upon the adjournment of the World's Council of the Young Women's Christian Association, a conference of Eastern United States and Eastern Canadian Association representatives will open tomorrow night at Muskoka Lake near Toronto.

The football squads of Columbia and Manhattan engaged in a spirited two-hour scrimmage yesterday at Baker Field under a steady rain. The informal meeting brought together as opposing coaches for the first time, the two former associates, Lou Little, Lion mentor, and Herb Kopf of the Jaspers.

Philip N. Arnold, director of national sales of the Realty Marketing Company of Philadelphia, told the members of the Jersey City Real Estate Board last week that a marked improvement in demand for industrial real estate is being looked for during the Fall season.

Miss Faith Trumbull Corrigan, daughter of Mrs. Joseph E. Corrigan of New York and the late Judge Corrigan, was married to Charles Maitland Fair Jr. of New York, this afternoon at the home of her mother in Wakefield, near here.

Stephen Patti, 58 years old, an unemployed jeweler of 765 East 225th Street, the Bronx, was held yesterday in $250 bail for trial in Special Sessions, after he admitted to Magistrate Edgar Bromberger, in Bronx Magistrate's Court, that he had kicked a home relief official who had ordered him to go to work.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Dyer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriette Dyer, to Sverre Sorenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Sorenson of Atlantic Highlands.

Engineers of the Department of Docks have completed their soundings to determine the extent of the dreging that must be done on both sides of the city-owned Tiffany Street pier in the East Bronx in order to permit the use of the dock by coastwise steamers, William E. Matthews, executive secretary of the Bronx Board of Trade, announced yesterday.

Will the compromise peace proposal formulated by Philip Murray and Sidney Hillman of' the Committee for Industrial Organization and accepted by the executive committee of the United Automobile Workers of America put an end to the factional dispute within the U. A. W. A.?

Miss Nancy Lee Warner, daughter of Mrs; Henry Giebel of this place, was married to William Harvey Webster Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster of Bronxville and Homer this afternoon in the Reformed Church here.

The foreign exchange market here was much quieter today as dealers waited to see which way the international cat was going to jump. The pound sterling continued to depreciate in terms of the United States dollar.

Resolutions calling for the adoption of higher standards of practice in the real estate field in New York were adopted today by the Ral Estate Association of the State of New York at the closing sessions of its annual convention.

Tuesday is primary day in Massachusetts. Republican fortune there has been rather cruel for some years, but there is a fat list of Republican candidates for Governor. To the mind of the outlander only one of them, Leverett Saltonstall, sometime Speaker of the House of Representatives and Lieutenant Governor, is familiar.

Miss Virginia Isabel Spangler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mayne Spangler of Upper Montclair, was married to David Herman Trott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Trott, also of Upper Montclair, this evening, the twenty-fifth wedding anniversary of the bride's parents, in the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Montclair.
Astronomy has sometimes been called the most useless of the sciences, and that characterization may possibly be justified from the point of view of immediate returns in dollars and cents.

Russell E. Gardner, retired St., Louis automobile manufacturer, died in his Memphis home today after a lengthy illness at the age of 72. He was one of the country's bestknown buggy manufacturers and later turned to the manufacture of the Gardner automobile.
Residents of this place and its near-by communities are among the patrons of the Sleepy Hollow Farms Stables Horse Show, to be held here Sept. 25.

LISTENERS who wish to follow the latest short-wave news reports from European centers will find that afternoon items from London come in on the 16-meter wave at 2 o'clock, Eastern daylight-saving time, and again at 5:15 on either 16 or 19 meters.

" Rumania-has no obligation whatsoever to allow Russian armed forces to cross her territory; all statements to the contrary are false," said a government spokesman a few days ago in reply to newspaper reports of the possibility that large bodies of Soviet. troops might pass through this country to aid Czechoslovakia in case she were invaded.
THE UNLOCKED BOOK: A memoir of John Wilkes Booth by his sister, Asia Booth Clarke. With foreword by Eleanor Farjeon. Illustrated. 205 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $2.50.

All out beaten seventy yards from home after leading all the way, J. Yancey Christmas's Rough Time overtook Natty Boy in the closing strides today and won the sixth running of the Colonel Arthur J. Pierce Handicap before 25,000 at Rockingham Park.

The newly appointed High Commissioner to Canada, Sir' Gerald Campbell, and Lady Campbell will be guests of honor at a dinner to be given by the British Societies and Clubs of New York on Sept. 27 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, according to an announcement yesterday.

After two straight defeats, the champion Newark Bears came through with their first victory of the best-of-seven semi-final International League play-off series with Rochester tonight by downing the third-place Red Wings, 5--1, behind Rookie Johnny Haley's seven-hit pitching.

The engagement of Miss Elaine R. Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Miller of this place; to Willard D. Luft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Luft of Rockville Center, L. I., has been announced by her parents.

The Kant Blaze Fireproofing Corporation, Lynn, Mass., manufacturer of fireprobfing fabrics and materials, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 258,210 shares of $1-par common stock to be offered at $1.25 a share.

These are the questions which are being asked since the easy renomination of Senator George in the Georgia Democratic primaries made total Mr. Roosevelt's personal defeat in his effort to retire from Congress nine Senators who had differed with him on legislative policy.

Heavy rain fell for most of the afternoon and soaked the players as the Nassau Country Club's annual best-ball invitation golf tournament reached the semi-final round today. Percy Furber and Edwin Hoyt of Wee Burn in Connecticut, who took the qualifying medal yesterday with a 73, led the field with two victories.

That all gardeners are divided into two groups, those who swear by dahlias and those who swear at them, is one of those bright sayings which, while not wholly true, contains enough foundation in fact to give them currency.

Many an owner of a new homeor for that matter, many an owner of an old one-has stood appalled at the sight of a house which rises from the surrounding grounds as if it were about to "take off" for parts unknown.

Golf--Willie Turnesa, 23-year-old member of the Briar Hills Club in Westchester, won the United States amateur title at Oakmont yesterday by defeating Pat Abbott of Altadena, Calif., 8 and 7, in the final round.

The Brooklyn Eagles of the American Professional Football Association will see action at Albany this afternoon in an exhibition contest with the Senators. Manager Harold Lipman and Coach Ray Lynch took twenty-eight men to Albany.

The Countess of Carnarvon will be married to Geoffrey Grenfell, of London this month, it was announced today. Lady Carnarvon is the former AMiss Catharine Wendell, daughter of the late Jacob Wendell of New York, and a descendant of the Washingtons and Lees of Virginia.
Students at New Jersey College for Women are vitally. interested in the social sciences, it 'was shown during the past week when they registered for the classes which begin Monday.

Launching plans for their fourth group of houses in Westchester County, Haring Blumenthal, developers, have purchased the old Fisher Farm in Eastchester from the family in whose possession the property has remained for more than fifty years.

The national and municipal aspects of housing and related problems will be the subjects of three non-credit courses given at the New York University Division of General Education, with eighteen authorities acting as special instructors and guest lecturers, it was announced yesterday by Dean Ned H. Dearborn.

The forward pass, which carried Benny Friedman to all-America honors when he was quarterback of the University of Michigan eleven, will play an important part in City College's football attack this Fall.

A redecorated main floor devoted to the new millinery was opened yesterday by the Tailored Woman, Inc., in its shop at 729 Fifth Avenue. Also included in the new design is a facade of black marble and bronze, with display windows embodying an arrangement of folding screens, to permit division into three sections.

New courses in music appreciation, international relations and painting will be offered this year by the Westchester Workshop, comprehensive adult education project of the Westchester County Recreation Commission, which will open on Monday at the County Center here.

Pledges of undiminished loyalty to the ideals of the American form of government and continued opposition to all foreign tenets were proclaimed yesterday at various celebrations here to commemorate the 151st anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution.

One of the features of the forthcoming New Jersey State Fair, which will be held in Trenton from Sept. 25 to Oct. 1, will be the annual flower show, according to George A. Hamid, president of the fair. The-flower show is sponsored by the Trenton Horticultural Society, taking the place of theirFall show.

Superior Judge Fletcher Bowron was elevated today to the May6ralty of Los Angeles by a plurality of more than 100,000 votes over Mayor Frank L. Shaw, target of reform groups in yesterday's recall election.

The extent and variety of the real estate holdings of the city's independent Subway system were disclosed last week apropos of reports that the Board of Transportation was considering erecting a large building on some of its land.

PART of the second floor of Grand Central Palace will be set aside during the National Automobile Show, Nov. 11 through 18, for the portrayal of scientific research as it is applied in the automotive industry.

The marriage of Miss Dora Sinclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richardson Sinclair of Indianapolis, to Louis Frederic Loutrel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Loutrel of South Orange, N. J., took Place here today.

Governor A. Harry Moore, Norman Thomas and William Lyon Phelps are among the speakers scheduled to appear in the weekly Sunday services in Kirkpatrick Chapel, Rutgers University, it was announced today.
