The modern two-story building which has replaced the old St. Andrew's Hotel at the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventy-second Street will contain the first newsreel theatre in that section of the West Side, according to Mark Rafalsky Co., agents, who announced the formal opening for Sent. 23.

The following Foreign Service changes since Sept. 3, were announced by the State Department today: The assignment of William A. Smale of San Diego as Consul at Toronto has been cancelled and he has been assigned Consul at Cork, Ireland.
With a capacity enrollment of 1,250 students Manhattan College will open for her eighty-ninth year tomorrow, it was announced by the college authorities.

Although the demand for tin cans is now surging ahead in the fruit and vegetable field and coming back in other lines, weakness in tin-plate prices and correspondingly in can quotations is holding back any widespread buying movement, manufacturers reported yesterday.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota and Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, presented conflicting viewpoints last night on What is necessary to keep the United States out of the war both saw impending, before the Steuben Society dinner at the Hotel Astor, commemorating the 208th anniversary of the birth of the Revolutionary War general.
FOR the first time In its history the Institute of Musical Art will offer a four-year course leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science with a major of music.
The second annual four-ball best-ball invitation handicap tournament for members and guests of the Tamarack Country Club advanced to the semi-final round today with one major casualty.

Miss Ethel L. Kemmerer and Edgar M. Matthew Jr., both of Jamaica, Queens, were married there yesterday afternoon in the First Methodist Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Lester Ward Auman of Jackson Heights, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Howard Ross, pastor of the church.

TO continue the chronicle of the season's plans, which was begun here last week with a list of visitors from overseas who are scheduled to appear for us between now and Spring, the following is an outline of the activities thus far announced by those artists who make their headquarters permanently in this country.

The German craft, Pimm, skip pered by Walter Von Hutschler, increased its series margin over the Gale and twenty other boats today by winning the fourth and semifinal race of the Sixteenth Annual International star Class yacht championship series.

The fear "that the Czechoslovak nation will be 'sold down the street by Chamberlain and his coworkers" was expressed by Rabbi Louis I. Newman at Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday. The European crisis was also the subject of sermons by other rabbis here.

The threat of war in Europe was brought home directly to the French players in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday when they made a arrangements to comply with calbed government orders to return at once for military duty.

Jessie M. Simpson, young beauty prize winner who lost both of her legs beneath a train of the New Jersey New York Railroad on April 26, 1937, filed suit for $265,000 against the company in the Supreme Court today. Earnest M. Brita of Morristown, counsel for Miss Simpson, asked $250,000 for the girl's injuries and $15,000 for her father, George Simpson of Teaneck.

Anne O'Hare McCormick, member of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, prophesied a victory for Czechoslovakia last night when she summarized the European crisis over the networks of the National Broadcasting Company.

An appraisal of the future possibilities of steel construction will be one of the features of the sixteenth annual convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction, to be held in French Lick, Ind., Oct. 11 to 14.

According to the statistics of the United States Golf Association relating to the number of competitors that will take part in the women's national golf championship starting at the Westmoreland Country Club, Wilmette, Ill., tomorrow there will be 124 in the field.

Construction will soon begin on a group of early American-style country homes in Lowell Thomas's 2,000acre Quaker Lake community in Dutchess County near Pawling, it was announced yesterday by Byron Parks, in charge of the country department of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent for the property.

Vermont Republicans, in party convention , tonight approved a deceration that "war under this Administration" must be avoided by all means if the nation would preferve "the freedom which our sister democracies across the sea are severishly preparing to defend."

The engagement of Miss Helen MacGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David MacGregor of this city, to David L. Malcolm Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Leonard Malcolm, also of Paterson, was announced today by her parents at a tea at the MacGregor home.

The Citizens Union, in a state ment issued yesterday, urged the defeat of five of the nine constitutional amendments to be submitted at the next election and said that if the other four failed to be adopted no great harm would be done.

Percy R. McPhail, president of the Merchants Bank of Rochester for upward of thirty years until his retirement in 1924, died last night at his home here at the age of 77. Born in Toronto, Mr. McPhail came to Rochester as a boy and attended the University of Rochester, graduating in 1881.

Any war that may develop in Europe will be met with strenuous efforts to prevent any involvement on the part of the United States, Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared last night in a radio address broadcast from a studio of the National Broadcasting Company at Hollywood, Calif.

Maryland political observers are attributing the landslide Democratic primary victory of Senator Millard E. Tydings over Representative David J. Lewis to two main factors--mismanagement of the Lewis campaign and resentment, against the President's trip into the State on behalf of the defeated candidate.
LONDON.--Now that milk bars have increased the consumption of milk, the first of a chain of herring bars is to open soon in London.

The men who answered the call to arms two decades ago are moving in on Los Angeles from all parts of the nation for the annual convention of the American Legion. The week of frolic, reufiions and declarations by the lefgonnaires on the country's problemry's will start tomorrow night with religious-patriotic services and end Friday with a review of the United States Fleet and of a war drill by 399 naval planes.

THE flow of millions of Federal dollars into Maryland to build two new bridges, which President Roosevelt has stamped for "prompt attention" of PWA officials, will stimulate tour1st traffic into historic sections now off the beaten track and visited by relatively few of those who use the nation's highways to explore its beauties.

Republicans, speaking in many cities of the country last night, engaged in a broadside attack on what was declared to be the present trend toward autocracy and dictatorship. Several addresses were broadcast.

A model house, to be used as a basic pattern for thirty homes to be erected under FHA financing, has been opened at Lakehurst Manor, a new realty subdivision on the east shore of West Lake, Patchogue.

THIS is a thoroughly delightful book that could almost justify the advance ballyhoo that Dexter Fellows used to provide for a three-ringed circus. It is robust, romantic, refreshing, fabulous, facile and facetious. The action never stops-it never even slows down.

WASHINGTON--Under executive orders issued by the President in June all Federal agencies must submit to the Civil Service Commission by next Saturday, Sept. 24, positions which they want to retain in the unclassified service.

Miss Jane Haxall Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Campbell of this city, became the bride of Charles Scott Bannerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Boyce Bannerman of New York and Blue Point, L. I., at Trinity Episcopal Church here today.

A spurt in foreign inquiries for American goods resulted from the war crisis in Europe last week as importers in markets remote from the European trouble zone became fearful of their chances of getting merchandise from suppliers in England, France, Germany and other countries on the Continent.
Although accountancy is a comparatively young profession, it has attained recognition wherever business is conducted in an enlightened manner. In Great Britain,

Circe, the six-meter challenger of the Royal Northern Yacht Club of Scotland, today won the first race for the Seawanhaka International Cup, defeating the fast Goose, defender of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club by 1 minute 44 seconds over 12 miles out on Long Island Sound.

THE big bombers roar over Spain and China. dropping their tons of TNT but, with all their frightfulness, what they have done is nothing to what might be done by the bombers of a powerful nation which sent them out in mass formation,

ONE of the few unspoiled retreats for the vacationist who is traveling either with or without a car is Grand Manan Island. This large stretch of land lies at the mouth of the Bay of Fundy, for off Passamaquoddy Bay, between Maine and New Brunswick, and is a Canadian possession.

A charge that the New Deal "has merely attempted to buy Mexican friendship at the expense of Americans" was made today by William R. Castle, former Undersecretary of State, in a keynote address before the Virginia Federation of Young Republican Clubs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On my first reading of the article "An Inquiry Into the Monopoly Issue," by Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine recently, I got the idea that there was something neatly wrapped up.

The Canadian Government is ready to summon Parliament if the European situation requires it, but refuses to state its attitude in advance. That was the gist of a statement issued this afternoon by Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King.

The current European war scare carries a threat to the government's wheat acreage reduction program. Out on the high plains of the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles and of Western Kansas, farmers are in the midst of seeding Winter wheat for harvesting next year.

TO take all America for one's theme is a task which might well stagger the most audacious novelist--yet it is something very like this that Bradford Smith attempts. For his hero he has chosen a kind of modern Don Quixote. with a passion in his heart for democracy, and a valnant stubborn faith that the American Dream persists.

Under a gray, dripping, sky that seemed to lend added desolation to the scene, the last faint glimmer of a pennant hope faded out of the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday when, before 22,257 onlookers who could scarcely see through the mist, the enfeebled forces of Colonel Bill Terry were toppled in both games of a double-header by Gabby Hartnett's still hopeful Cubs.

Miss Lenora Elizabeth Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Talbot Myers of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Charles Ford Reese of Baltimore, were married here yesterday noon in St. Thomas Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

The park named in memory of Major Louis A. Cuvillier, veteran of the World War and the war with Spain, and Assemblyman representing the district that includes the park, was dedicated to him yesterday afternoon.

All children tend toward mediocrity in their aspirations, according to a study reported by Professor Harold H_ Anderson of the University of Illinois and made in collaboration with Professor H. F. Brandt of Drake University.

JOHN SINGER SARGENT drifts back into the news; floats in, as with a kind of wan wistfulness antithetical to the stir that of old must have accompanied an event of such significance as a new Metropolitan accuisition of his work.

A smoothly functioning nine from Detroit scored a 4-to-0 victory today over the Wilkinburg, Pa., team in the first game of a series of three to decide the championship of the National Amateur Baseball Federation.

Miss Linda Marion Wyckoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rapelye Wyekoff of this place, was married to Houston Hutchinson Wasson of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Washington Wasson of Nashville, Tenn., this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here.

Miss Priscilla Muriel Howes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Johnson Howes of Glen Ridge, was married this afternoon to James H. Braddock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Braddock of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Church, Montclair, by the rector. the Rev. Luke M. White.

Her-Ladyship, E. J. Baker's outstanding mare, today took undisputed possession of the world's record for pacing mares over the Indiana State Fair Grounds track when she turned the mile in 1 minute 57 1/2 seconds.

In recognition of the service of George O. Slingerland, referred to as father of the Saratoga Battlefield, Rotary Clubs in this area unveiled a plaque to his memory today at the block house on the battlefield. It is the only marker on the site to one not actually connected with the battle.
Kansas, accustomed to hide-removing campaigns and caustic personalities that smell of brimstone, will have the streamlined variety of vote appeal for its entertainment and enlightenment this Fall.

The chief problem of youth, that of selecting a life work and getting the kind, of educational preparation that will assure a job, is being worked out in Chautauqua County through the cooperative efforts of the Y. M. C. A., public schools, service organizations, newspapers, and now radio.

With the Merchants Association of New York reporting the situation arising from the trucking strike as "progressively worse," department store spokesmen declared the shortage of merchandise had already begun to be felt but would not be serious for a few days.
WITH the Fall flight of the migratory birds already in progress and the hunting season soon to arrive, photographers are once again planning to go afield in search of wildlife pictures.
An interesting apartment house project known as Kent Court is nearing completion in Summit, N J., by an investing syndicate with Joan O. Chrystal as managing agent.

Passing its production rate of a year ago for the first time in more than a year, the shoe industry turned out 41,000,000 pairs in August, and the high rate is continuing, according to trade estimates.

Parochial school children from all parts of the Archdiocese of New York filled St. Patrick's yesterday morning at a solemn high anniversary mass of requiem for Cardinal Farley, Archbishop of New York from 1911 to 1918, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of the cathedral, celebrated the mass, commemorating the twentieth anniversary of the Cardinal's death.

Italy continues hopeful that a peaceful solution of the Czechoslovak crisis may be found, although this tendency is today--as it has been since the beginning of the crisis--more pronounced on the part of public opinion than in the press.
The Maury High School eleven of Norfolk, Va., defeated Pompton Lakes High School today 12 to 0. All the scoring came in the second period, when Norfolk put over two touchdowns.

Dr. William Frederick Dey, paychiatrist, of 102 East Twenty-second Street, died here on Friday of a heart attack at the age of 56. A son of the late Rev. and Mrs. William John Dey of Simco, Ont., he was a graduate of Toronto University and for some years practiced medicine in Carlsbad, Czechoslovakia.

The first auction sale of the season at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., will be held next Thursday and Friday afternoons when English and French furniture, tapestries, Oriental rugs and decorative objects from the estates of Adele Kneeland, Lenox, Mass., and H. Mabel MacDonald of New York, and property of Mrs. William H. Max of this city will be sold.

OF interest to salon workers will be the statement from the Minneapolis Camera Club, 113 South Sixth Street, that the Seventh Annual Minneapolis Salon will be held at the Institute of Arts once again this year. The closing date for entries is Nov. 5 and the club urges all photographers who are interested to apply for their j entry blanks quickly.
Dr. B. M. Gancy, Filipino lawyer, began suit in the United States District Court today to invalidate the Tydings-McDuffie act of 1934 providing independence for the Philippines.

TWENTY pairs of concerts will be given this season in Cleve land by the Cleveland Orchestra under Artur Rodzinski, who will open the Thursday and Saturday night series, Oct. 13 and 15.

Steel casement doors designed as entrances to sun rooms and as exits leading to porches. terraces and gardens are now produced as standard units by manufacturers in the metal window industry, according to an announcement by the group's trade association. Both inward and outward swinging styles are available.

In a month marked by three blunt defeats for his "purge" in South Carolina, Maryland and Georgia, President Roosevelt's own popularity has dipped slightly with the rank and file of American voters, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by Dr. George Gallup director of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had rejected 1,125 bolts of woolen goods delivered on city contracts for manufacture into Fall and Winter coats for women and children on relief.

Bonds drifted lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in fairly active trading for a Saturday. A classes of issues participated. The turnover was $3,416,350, largest for a two-hour session in about a month, and compared with $3,069,700 on the preceding Saturday.
Hans Steinke, 222, Germany, pinned Abie Coleman, 206, New York, with a body slam in 18:25 of the featured wrestling match at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's sudden aerial trip to Berchtesgaden in the hope that personal talks with Chancellor Adolf Hitler might save European peace was the dramatic culmination of a policy of reconciliation with dictators which he adopted from the moment of his assumption of the Prime Ministership in May of last year-a policy which has been strewn with difficulties.

Under most deplorable weather conditions, the New York Athletic Club's 141st track and field meet went on as scheduled at Travers Island yesterday, but it was virtually impossible to finish it, and at the completion of the foot races a halt was called until today.

The Czech people are displaying courage and calm though the republic's existence is in peril. President Eduard Benes is reported to have given an emphatic negative to the Sudeten plebiscite proposal made by Viscount Runciman, British mediator, when'he left for London yesterday.

For the first time on record, an Australian player reached the final round of the American women's tennis championship yesterday when Miss Nancye Wynne defeated Miss Dorothy May Bundy of SantaMonica, Calif., in the Forest Hills Stadium, 5--7, 6--4, 8--6.

The New York Football Giants will rest today after several days of satisfactory drilling at their encampment at the Blue Hill C. C., Orangeburg, N. Y. Coach Steve Owen and his assistant, Bo Molenda, will travel to Washington to scout the Dodger-Redskin encounter.

PERU'S great highway from Lima to Pucalpa, described on this page, is but one of many important road-building projects in South America. Peru's program is ambitious. A decided improvement in the apartment rental market during the past few weeks is seen by William J. Demorest, executive vice president of Wm. A. White Soas. Tenants who have been deferring moving because of uncertain business conditions are now making decisions to move, and leasing is progressing rapidly in both Manhattan and the Bronx, he points out.

All bars and retail liquor package stores will be closed on Tuesday from 3 to 10 P. M., the hours when polls for primary voting will be open, it was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority.

Seven New York City policemen have received scholarships for advanced study this Fall in traffic safety at New York University's recently organized center for safety education, it was announced yesterday by Harold 0. Voorhis, university secretary.
Eight free lectures sponsored by the evening and extension division of Hunter College as part of its program of adult education will be open to the public this week in two of the college buildings.

John Strawbridge's Coq Bruyere won the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup, three-mile feature of the Whitemarch Hunt Club Fall race meet for the second year in a row at George D. Widener's estate at Erdenheim today. The crowd was held to 1,500 because of rain.

With Winter close at hand, home owners are advised by the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau to make a careful check of their heating plants. Early Fall is none too soon to have boiler and heating plants repaired. and the work can be done at this time without inconvenience to the household, the bureau points out.

The Palestine Government was forced today to abandon Bethlehem, the birthplace of Christ, and leave it to the mercy of terrorists. The action was taken after rebels entered the city, ransacked the police station and then set fire to the building and other municipal offices.

The Staten Island C. C. defeated the Union County eleven of Elizabeth by a margin of 12 runs and 9 wickets in a championship match of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association at Walker Park, Livingston, yesterday.

A newsreel of the sun, with scenes that give a new idea of what happens there as huge flame-like prominences are shot out, was shown here today before members of the American Astronomical Soclety, visiting the McMath-Hulbert Observatory of the University of Michigan.
TO us Marxmen (or is it Marxians?) a United States map is just a list of towns where something happened that we try to remember or else try to forget. For instance,

Creation by Congress of a qualified nonpartisan commission to establish fixed-tax principles, adoption of moderate tax rates to encourage private enterprise and removal of all remnants of the undistributed profits tax, which were retained in the 1938 Revenue Act, were endorsed in a poll of accountants just completed by the committee on Federal taxation of the American Institute of Accountants.

As a Democrat of many years standing, Raymond Moley, former Assistant Secretary of State and member of the original "brain trust," voiced his resentment over the radio last night at the Presidential attempt to read John J. O'Connor out of the Democratic party.

Foreign military attaches returning from East Prussian manoeuvres of the German Army said today that they attended a reception given in their honor on Friday night at Koenigsberg by General Ludwig Beck.

The terms on which the British and French Governments are reported to have agreed constitute so complete a surrender that liberal opinion everywhere will prefer to regard them as incredible until they are confirmed or explained in an official statement.

Playing in their first tournament together, Thomas E. Scholl and Trumbull Richard of the home club today turned back W. E. Stockhausen and Henry Picoli, last year's winners, by 3 and 1, to annex the annual Nassau Country Club invitation best-ball golf tournament.

William F. Brennan, a retired New York policeman who lost a leg as the result of being shot in a gun battle in which Patrolman Lawrence Ward was fatally wounded in Manhattan on May 4, 1934, died today at his home here.
Wisconsin will make nominations Tuesday for almost every Federal, State and county office. The only hold-over officials are Senator La Follette and sixteen of the thirty-three State Senators.
The bullion markets currently are contending with acute difficulties owing to the absence of a decision regarding war insurance.
The Baltimore Soccer Club opened the annual championship season of the American Soccer League at Celtic Park in South Brooklyn yesterday and beat the St. Mary's Celtics by 2-0.
Early yesterday, for the third successive Sunday, a man approached the window of the Cizy Beauty Shop, 134-02 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens, and hurled a brick through the window.

Hoarding of gold by the French apparently has not increased in the last month. The government's decision of Aug. 17 compelling gold merchants to require the names of both buyers and sellers has greatly reduced transactions, as the public now prefers to refrain from buying or selling gold.
Economic conditions in France are being subjected these days to the pressure of the international political uncertainty.

James A. Farrell, chairman of the board of the National Foreign Trade Council and popularly known as the "dean of foreign trade," will be tendered a luncheon by a number of trade groups here on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday.

Although leaders of the "outlaw" strike of three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters agreed late Saturday night to the delivery of an adequate supply of newsprint to the newspapers as well as perishable foodstuffs to the public and ballots for the primary election, newspapers faced difficulties yesterday in obtaining sufficient newsprint, with only curtailed trucking facilities permitted by the strikers.
The improvement in retail business since the first of the month was reflected in a decided upturn in the volume of calls last week for men's, women's and children's apparel and accessories.

Warners have assigned George Brent to the male lead in "Dark Victory" opposite Bette Davis and have moved the picture up to Oct. 3 on their schedule, which will put it into production before "Juarez," previously announced as Miss Davis's next vehicle.

Officials here were hopeful tonight that peace in Europe can be maintained through the conversations between the British and French at. London. The feeling was that if war cannot be avoided at this time it can at least be deferred.

By arrangement with Mayor La Guardia the Interborough Rapid Transit Company supplied 145,516 free rides in July and August to enable children from the tenement districts of Manhattan and the Bronx to visit various city parks, it was revealed in a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

J. Harvey Williams, chairman of the Republican Committee for John J. O'Connor and American Principles of Government, wrote yesterday to the fifty-seven Republican county chairmen outside New York City,

The engagement of Miss Annette Wright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl D. Wright of 180 Claremont Avenue, to Dana H. Johnson of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Early H. Johnson of Columbus, Ga., has been announced by her parents.

Mrs. Frances Smith Wyman of Cincinnati has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Edith Wyman, to Willets Prosser of Cincinnati, son of Thomas H. Prosser and the late Mrs. Prosser of Jericho, L. I., and New York.

The Works Progress Administration will complete the purchasing for its "buy-and-give" program in the clothing field this week by placing orders for $3,000,000 worth of women's, children's and infants' wear, it was announced yesterday.

Municipal Court Justice Nathan Sweedler presided yesterday at the induction of officers in the New York City Region of Young Judea at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street. More than 4001 persons attended.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Earle Meader of Monkton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Wilma Meader, to A. Carson Conklin of Keeseville, N. Y., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Conklin of Troy, N. Y.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Anita Kirsten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Kirsten of 81 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, to Dr. Samuel Raphael Cohan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cohan, also of Brooklyn.
The body of an unidentified woman who had been brutally beaten, strangled and thrown from an automobile was found in a ditch beside the Croton Aqueduct Path in Tibbets Brook Park here this morning.

The need for constant prayer to tighten the bond between man's soul and God was stressed by the Rev. B. A. E. McLaughlin yesterday morning in his sermon at the Church of the Transfiguration (The Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.
Central Maine Power Company (controlled by New England Publie Service)-August and twelve months:

Cape Cod is now on the dance map as well as in the Summer vacation guide book and is contributing its own pet diversion, entitled Cape Cod Capers, to the ballroom floors of New York for the Fall and Winter season.
Bishop Thomas E. Molloy, head of the Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn since 1922, wil celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of his ordination into the priesthood today.
French war veterans paid tribute today to the memory of Miss Evelyn Garnaud Smalley, World War nurse of New York, who tied recently in Paris.
The text of Premier Benito Mussolini's speech here today follows: Blackshirts! This, O Trieste and people of Trieste, is the fourth time I have had the fortune, the honor and the joy to speak to you.
ON returning from the battle-scarred slopes of Oakmont it was discovered that, among other communications, the postman had deposited on this desk a postcard on which was written in red ink:

Despite heavy rain this morning, the seventh annual show of the Camden County Kennel Club was staged without delay today. Keen competition marked the all-breed A. K. C. event on the former dog-racing track adjacent to Central Airport.

C. D. Asser, president of the French-German tribunal created under the Versailles treaty to arbitrate war claims, arrived yesterday on the Statendam of the HollandAmerica Line en route to Canada to visit relatives. He and his wife,

Securities of the Federal, State, local, Territorial and insular governments outstanding in the hands of nongovernmental owners on June 30, 1937, which were wholly or partly exempt from income tax, aggregated $50,522,000,000,

A TIMES reader wrote in the other day to inquire why the United States could not have super-highways like the German autobahns. Another reader replied that we already have some, and that the good ideas behind the German express roads, including the cloverleaf, were copied from American designs.

Indications continued to develop last week that the current month will register a sharp reversal in newspaper linage, with the August losses in many classifications replaced by actual gains. Several newspapers here for the first half of the month are running ahead of the like period of last year in department store and retail linage.
The only favorable feature of last week's report of the British Board of Trade is that while the turnover to date shows up deplorably in the light of the data for 1937, it is superior to 1936.

British financial markets closed uneasy yesterday after their worst week in years. Until Wednesday quotations and dealings generally had remained orderly and had made a pretense at cheerfulness, but news of the break in Wall Street and intensification of the international crisis precipitated a deluge of nervous selling.

The English-Speaking Union will give a tea tomorrow from 4 to 6 P. M. at its headquarters, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, in honor of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Norwood of London, who will sail for home on Friday.
The Pirates, aiming for the National League pennant, played through fourteen soggy innings today with the Phillies to add one victory and a tie to their standing.

The New York Board of Trade, anticipating the fact that on Thursday the new Bankruptcy Act will go into effect, is distributing to members a booklet called "Some Things Creditors Should Know," by Edwin M. Otterbourg, a director of the board, and member of the law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler Houston.
Joseph Kyle Orr Sr., fraternal leader and president of an Atlanta shoe company for more than fifty years, died today of a heart aliment at the age of 81.
" Samson et Dalila" will be presented Wednesday night, Sept. 28, by the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre in aid of the Jamaica Jewish Center.

Employes of the British-owned Salvador Railway Company have sent a petition to President Maximiliano H. Martinez requesting that he continue in power after the expiration of his present term as President.

Governor Earle and the thirteen Democratic party leaders and State officials who have been named for grand jury investigation will be called to testify before the Legislative Committee, Herbert Cohen, chairman of the committee, announced today, as preparations were made to place I. E. (Ike) Penrod, former special investigator for the State Departmeht of Justice, on the witness stand tomorrow.
Without lifting a finger in their own behalf, the Yankees today won the American League pennant for 1938, their third championship in a row.
Mr. and Mrs. John A. Burke of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret M. Burke, to Harry W: Angevine Jr., son pf Mr. and Mrs. Angevine of Glen Ridge.

Undiscouraged by the drenching they received on Saturday, 4,000 ticket-holders fared forth to Forest Hills yesterday in the face of a light drizzle, hoping to see the completion of the semi-finals of the national tennis championships.
The threat of a European war was the topic of discussion in many pulpits throughout the city yesterday. Clergymen of all denominations urged their congregations to pray for peace.

The City approved Premier Neville Chamberlain's going to see Chancellor Hitler, and the hope in financial circles is that the direct conversations with the Reich's leader will uncover Germany's grievances. Some quarters, however, fear that the visit may be taken by the Nazis as an indication that Great Britain is weakening.

Coney Island officially ended its season last night with the closing of Steeplechase Park and Luna Park, the two leading places of amusement. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning 750,000 persons were still at the Island after attending the last day of the Mardi Gras.

Acting Mayor Newbold Morris induced leaders of the "outlaw" truck drivers' strike yesterday to distribute food supplies to home relief families and ballots for tomorrow's primary election, as well as to expedite the movement of newsprint previously conceded.

The marriage of Miss Edith Anita Tompkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Tompkins of Glenbrook, this city, and John\ Albon Hornbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bingham Hornbeck, also of Newburgh, took place in the First Presbyterian Church last evening.

A tropical disturbance of "dangerous proportions" roared westward over the Atlantic Ocean tonight, its center at 7 P. M. being about 450 miles north of San Juan, Puerto Rico, and about 900 miles east-southeast of Miami.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. J. Morgan Jones of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alta Kells, to H. Seely Barclay, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Barclay of Milford, Pa.

If suffering has been a means to a worth-while end the suffering is equally worth while, the Rev. Allan I. Brown said in his sermon yesterday morning at the John Street Methodist Church, between William and Nassau Streets.

A campaign that has the double objective of nourishing a love of American music in the hearts of the American people and the establishment of a memorial to John Philip Sousa, bandmaster and composer, is being launched by a committee of men well known in musical circles, it was revealed yesterday.

The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, 407 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, sent a telegram last night to President Roosevelt asking him to remove Frank R. McNinch, chairman, from the Federal Communications Commission on the ground that he had failed to conduct a forthright investigation of "the radio monopoly" and was "purging" from his staff commission aides determined to press the investigation.

Senator Tydings, discussing the probable legislative effects of President Roosevelt's failure to oust him and others from the Senate, predicted that opponents of the government reorganization bill would be able to amend it as they wished.

The New York Civic Orchestra, conductedd by Eugene Plotnikoff, gave an all-Russian concert last night at the Federal Music Theatre. Philip Frank was heard as soloist in the Tchaikovsky violih concerto.

An overwhelming vote for a strike on the nation's railroads on Oct. 1 is said to be expected by railway labor executives and managements when the results of the balloting now in progress are disclosed in Chicago on Sept. 26.

The New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center announced yesterday that on Sept. 27 it would open an Art Adventure Fair that will demonstrate to the amateur the opportunities for leisure time recreation provided by arts and crafts.
Prices of most securities have moved lower in the last week. This includes European government bonds as well as others and even the securities of countries which would be neutral in the event of war.

The foreign exchange market here was more active this week than in the previous comparable period. Nevertheless, the sterling-franc rate maintained between 178-30 and 178-32, but the stabilization fund had to sell foreign exchanges against francs.
Connie Mack's Athletics swung their war clubs against Bob Feller and three successors today to split a bargain bill with the Indians.

Last week witnessed the seeming paradox of a decline in outstanding United States securities, together with one of the largest oversubscriptions on record for $700,000,000 in new issues. It probably will be said that subscriptions for that amount in bonds running respectively five and fourteen years, and bearing interest at only 1 1/8 and 2 1/2 per cent, were sent in before the European war crisis became acute.
Following is the list of candidates for primary nominations in the Democratic, Republican, American Labor and-Socialist parties to be voted upon tomorrow.
Finding in St. Paul of the automobile stolen from Mrs. C. J. Reiter and her daughter by their abductors brought the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the case today.

Theodore Roosevelt and Walt Whitman have been selected to represent Long Island in the Hall of Fame of the New York State amphitheatre and exhibit building at the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Meade C. Dobson, chairman of the advisory committee for Long Island.

Miss Marie Agnes Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Diedrich Hanseld Ward of this place, will be married to William Winton Goodrich Rossiter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rossiter of Bronxville, on Oct. 7 in Christ's Episcopal Church by the Rev. F. Hohly, the rector. A reception will be held at the Siwanoy Country Club.

Louis Lipsky, vice president of the Zionist Organization of America, said on his return from Europe yesterday that a considerable part of the $5,000,000 budget adopted at the recent conference of the Palestine Fdundation at Antwerp would be used to construct blockhouses and for other measures necessary for the defense of colonists in outlying districts of Palestine.
Representative James M. Mead of Buffalo told 400 members of the New York Letter Carriers Association last night that he was "not even an improbability for Governor" of New York.
Provisional President Manuel M. Borrero decorated today, on the anniversary of Chile's independence, Senora Gabriela Mistral, noted Chilean feminist, poet and writer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES'S editorial "State 'Tariff Walls' " summarized and criticized a magazine article written by me, "Eco-nomic War Among Our Statns," published in the August issue of Events magazine.
France's general wholesale price index on Sept. 10 was 644, against 641 and 646 one and two weeks before. The commodities gold index was 40.1, against 40.3 and 41.2..

Members of citizen groups who have defended Miss Dorothy C. Kahn criticized Governor Earle today for failing to reconsider her summary dismissal by the Philadelphia County Board of Public Assistance as executive director.

The Rev. Charles G. Ellis, pastor for thirty years of the Rondout Presbyterian Church in Kingston, N. Y., and pastor emeritus since his retirement in 1931, died at his home here today. His age was 72.

Bonnie Circe from the Royal Northern Yacht Club of Scotland today took her second straight race for the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup, and now needs but one more victory to carry small yacht racing's most coveted prize back again to the Clyde.
Bulletin, weekly newspaper of Hunter College, will appear today with a new editorial policy which for the first time will include evening session students on the editorial board.

William C. Daviet, who retired in July as a vice president of the Postal Telegraph Cable Company, died today in the Homeopathic Hospital here at the age of 62. He suffered a stroke Wednesday night at his home, 84 Lafayette Avenue.

Class 17. Horsemanship (children up to 19 years)-First, Miss Ann Fennessey; second, Miss Mary Poll: third, Arthur Plaut Jr.; fourth. Miss Carol Jane Adler; fifth, Miss Muriel Arthur; sixth, Miss Blanche Clark.
The July maternal mortality rate of 36 per 10,000 births was the lowest ever reported for the month, according to the State Health Department.

The Professional Horsemen's Association Challenge Cup final, one of the features of the ninth annual Boulder Rock Horse Show today, resulted in a triumph for Philip J. Bliss's chestnut gelding Modernistic, after a jump-off.
Miss Jean Farrel, debutante daughter of Mrs. Alton Farrel of New York, was introduced to older friends of the family at a tea and reception given here today at the Summer residence of her mother.

Mrs. Margaret Craine, 58, of New York City was killed and twentyfour other persons were injured early today when a Montreal-New York bus owned by the Champlain Bus Lines, Inc., crashed into the rear of a parked truck on Route 9 about a mile north of Red Hook.

In one of the closest battles in the sixteen-year history of the annual International Star Class yacht championships, the German craft Pimm, skippered by Walter Von Hutschler, with Hans Joachim Weise as crew, won the 1938 series in the final race today, finishing two points ahead of Gale from the Southern Lake Michigan fleet.
The Sudeten German "free corps," now numbering 10,000, early today attacked and badly damaged a Czechslovakia customs house at Neuhausen and seriously injured two Czech guards.

When the Board of Aldermen of Mount Vernon meets tomorrow night the project to cover the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad cut through the city will be submitted, and it is expected that legislation will be enacted to authorize an application to the Public Works. Administration in Washington to finance the improvement at a cost of $2,750,000.

The Gazeta Polska, organ of the government party, published a front page editorial today which, in effect, demanded that Czech Silesia be ceded to Poland. It declared other minority problems besides the Sudeten German issue must be adjusted in Czechoslovakia.

A fourth-period safety gave the Chicago Bears a 2-to-0 National Football League decision over the Packers before 15,172 today. Arnie Herber of Green Bay had attempted two punts and the toss from Center Darrell Lester was bad each time.

Three thousand freshmen will be welcomed to New York University by the deans, administrators and student leaders in a series of orienstation exercises that will begin today and continue at the various ti centers of the university for two weeks.

Largely because of increases in the prices of grains and metals last week under the stimulus of talk of war, The Annalist says, its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 80.8 on Saturday from 80.6 the week before. The low point for the year so far was 79.3 on Aug. 13.

The thrills and suspense of a full season were crammed into a single afternoon today as the Brooklyn Dodgers battled the world champion Redskins to a 16-16 standstill before 23,000 fans at Griffith Stadium in the gridiron inaugural here.

Major R. Ernest Dupuy, Field Artillery, United States Army, recently detailed by the War Department for duty at the United States Military Academy, has been appointed public relations officer to succeed Captain F. A. March 3d who has been acting in that capacity for the last two years.
The Namm Store, Brooklyn, is offering $100 as first prize in an essay contest being conducted this week in connection with National Retail Demonstration Week.

An appeal to President Roosevelt to provide "fresh leadership" to stave off war in Europe is made in a front-page editorial to be published tomorrow in The Globe and Mail. The editorial expresses the belief that Mr. Roosevelt could forestall a conflict "without committing his people to anything."

A recommendation that this country bulwark its defense with new destroyers, submarine, mine and air bases along its continental and insular coasts is expected in naval circles from a special committee of experts now studying the question.

Movements in the wheat market this week were erratic, the Czech news giving shorts a bad attack of nerves on Wednesday and, with an almost complete withdrawal of sellers, prices soared several pence a bushel over Tuesday.

As part of an expanded WPA education program, 20,000 teachers and administrative workers from the relief rolls will serve in the city schools and adult education centers this year, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday. About 4,500 more teachers will be taken on.
Hereafter when we think of rai?birds we'll recall the Maurice River, in that vague area known to hunters and fishermen as "South Jersey."
With rainy weather aggravating the situation, Philadelphia endured a week-end without taxicab service of any kind. Today was the fourth day of the general taxi strike.
Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, issued a call yesterday to all members of the party to vote in the primary election.

Assistant United States Attorney Robert E. Pratt, candidate for the Democratic nomination for District Attorney of Queens County, charged last night that District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan had failed to answer his charge that he had four district leaders on his staff.

Two-year-old Patrick Lyons died early yesterday in Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, apparently of the effects of drinking wine he had found on a shelf in the home of his parents at 398 Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, on Saturday.

Sultan Sidi Mohammed announced today that he and all his subjects would be on the side of France if she became involved in a European war. The Sultan's authority, nominally at least, extends to natives of Spanish Morocco, now held by the Spanish Insurgents, and Tangier, as well as those of French Morocco.
German withdrawal of some war equipment from Spain, or at least from the Spanish war front, was reported in confidential advices reaching diplomatic quarters here over the week-end.

Miss Theresa Sales, daughter of Mrs. Frank Sales of Orange and the late Mr. Sales, was married today to Dr. Alexis G. Maltzeff of New York in All Saints Episcopal Church, here, by the Rev. Clarence E. Dunham, retired rector of the church.
The weekly newspaper of the future, L. Robert Oaks, editor of The Fredonia Censor, believes, will be "breezier and smaller" and its style "more readable and swiftly running."
" If a line-up of universal character is brought on for or against Prague, let it be known that Italy's place is already chosen."
A condemned convict, Frank Tucker, aged 34, was shot and killed by a San Quentin prison guard today during an attack on another guard.

Miss Burnley Welsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Welsh Jr. of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, will be married to Edward Libby Dame, son of Mrs. Frank L. Dame of Garden City, L. I., and the late Mr. Dame, in the chantry of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, on the afternoon of Oct. 1.

The Queens-Midtown vehicular tunnel, which will connect Long Island City and Manhattan's upper thirties, is one-quarter finished Secretary Ickes was informed yesterday by Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of the Public Works Administration.

A week of extraordinary tension for European financial markets has just come to an end. Although the current situation cannot be compared with the depression and panic that ruled in June and July, 1914, the undertone of Europe's stock exchanges,has been highly nervous.

Charles Island, known in Connecticut history as a home of smugglers and a place where the militia was called to stop a prizefight, has been bought by J. Edward Slavin, sheriff of New Haven County, to establish a crime prevention club.
With managing agents reporting many buildings near the 100 per cent occupancy stage, the rush for apartments continues to cover every section of the city.

Murdock Ave (17-5096), w s, 100 ft s of Bissell Ave. 33x99: Emma Rossman to Charles Mazzullo, 916 E 231st St. 172d St (14-3776), s e cor of Manor Ave. 1OOxlOO Enarc Realty Corp to Dorothy Schaffer, 845 West End Ave; mtg., $130,500.

Official Washington remained behind a curtain of silence today with regard to the European situation. In line with the policy of President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull of avoiding comment, no pronouncements were forthcoming.

George P. Clark, a life-long resident of Greenwich, died at his home in Cos Cob last night at the age of 79. For many years he was a well known carpenter and builder here, also a founder and last president of the former Mianus Ladder and Fire 'Department.

A training course for German exporters is now in progress here under the auspices of the German Workers Front. About fifty exporters are attending the meetings Prominent economic experts, lecturning on the best methods of building up foreign export trade" have addressed the group.

In commemoration of the 142d anniversary of George Washington's Farewell Address, the Society of the Cincinnati, of which Washington was an original member and President General, placed a wreath of English ivy, at sunset today, on the sarcophagus of the President at Mount Vernon.

Preaching at solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning, Mgr. J. F. A. McIntyre, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, said that the greatest problem of the world today was the preservation of the "Christian conscience."

Associate Supreme Court Justice James Clark McReynolds and George Sutherland, retired associate justice, will return from abroad today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. The liner has 1,900 passengers.

The German wholesale price index stood on Sept. 7 at 105.6, compared with 105.9 on Aug. 31. In the first eight months of this year the highest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 106.1, in the weeks ended on Aug. 3, 10 and 17.
Enrolled party members of the city and State will go to the polls tomorrow to select at the primaries their nominees for the November election.
Soon a substantial fraction of our population will be trooping into great bowls all over the country to watch the progress of the Fall foot-
Now that Willie Turnesa has been crowned king of America's amateur golfers for 1938, but one thing remains to be done. That is to find out who the queen is going to be.

Although the index of industrial production in Canada gained slightly in July and the decline in carloadings was almost halted, employment in manufacturing enterprises showed a further pronounced drop, according to the Bank of Nova Scotia.

Sales of new automobiles during the first half of September dropped more than seasonally by comparison with August and were only about 30 per cent of the total for the like period in 1937, but dealers attribute the showing to an actual scarcity of some models, rather than to lack of public interest.

A reception for Sir Harold and Lady Macintosh of Halifax, England, will be tendered on Wednesday 'at 4 P. M. in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by the World's Sunday School Association, of which Sir Harold is president. Admission will be by special card.

The Duchess of Atholl will arrive Thursday from Canada and will be at the St. Regis. Mrs. Alfred C. Chapin is expected to come to the Drake today from Bord-de-l'Eau, her Summer home at Pointe au Pie, Quebec.

The performance of Puccini's "La Boheme," given by the San Carlo Opera Company last night at the Center Theatre, attracted the largest audience of its season here to date. Even 'the standing room nas filled to capacity, the audience numbering 3,700 persons.

The lowering of the flag at Camp Smith here this morning while the 369th Infantry band of Harlem played "The Star-Spangled Banner" officially ended the Summer training season for the New York National Guard commanded by Major Gen. William N. Haskell.

As the flag over Nassau Hall flew at half-staff today, President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University paid tribute to Edward Dickinson Duffield, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, who died yesterday at his home in South Orange. His tribute follows:

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.7, which compared with 80.6 the week before, 80.6 two weeks before, 80.4 three weeks before and 79.9 four weeks before.

The revolution needed today in the world is the inward revolution of the heart, the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, pastor of the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday morning in his sermon.

The votes in Los Angeles to recall Mayor Shaw and to adopt a picketing ordinance have much more than a local interest. Shaw is the first Los Angeles Mayor to be unseated by this device since 1909, though several attempts have previously been made to apply it.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 46 per cent of capacity, up 6 points from the week before, but the gain actually had no significance as there was a holiday in the week preceding.
Lotteries and bookmaking are legal in Germany, but the greatest gamble, one in which everybody with a healthy appetite places at least two bets every day, is the food lottery.

King Bao-Dai of Annam assured France today of his country's "profound attachment and indefectible devotion to the great protector nation." The King sent a message to the French Governor General of IndoChina expressing the loyalty of himself and his subjects.

The terms to which the British are reported to have persuaded the French to agree to present to Czechoslovakia today are felt to represent such a betrayal of this country and such abject surrender to Nazism that the first reaction here is one of sheer incredulity.

ARONOWITZ--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel (nee Wolf), announce the birth of Edith Susan, at Lying-In Hospital. BERNS--Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Berns (21) announce the birth of a daughter, Susan Carla, on Saturday, Sept. 17, at Medical Arts Sanitarium.

In a slipping and stumbling exhibition that was ended by darkness at Ebbets Field yesterday after a game and a half had been played through a drizzling rain, the pennant-pursuing Cubs found themselves one more contest behind the league-leading Pirates.

The Republican-American Labor party coalition is the only way Brooklyn can drive the Kelly Democratic machine out of the local courts, Louis Waldman, candidate for the Republican and Labor party nominations for Kings. County Judge; declared last night.

Police emergency squads were called out today to keep thousands of antiNazi demonstrators from entering Downing Street, where British and French statesmen were meeting to weigh the Czechoslovak crisis.

Edgar L. Prochnik, who was Austrian Minister to the United States at the time his country was absorbed by the German Reich, joined the faculty of Georgetown University today. He will lecture in the School of Foreign Service. Mr.

Dr. T. Stephen Quinn, a physician and surgeon here for many years, died today of pneumonia in a hospital in Waterville, Me. He was taken ill about a week ago while on a salmon fishing trip in Northern. Maine, near his Summer home at Waterville.

After touching new low levels for the current movement early last week, prices of cotton strengthened only to sag again as the week drew to an end. At the close on Saturday active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net losses of 8 to 16 points, after declines of 21 to 28 points in the preceding week.

Comparing the life of a Christian to that of an athlete struggling for a prize, the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Evans said yesterday at the WestPark Presbyterian Church, Eightysixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, that while the reward for the victorious athlete might be material, the prize for the Christian was blessedness, excellence of character and power through God.

After attending a wedding party Saturday night at the Brooklyn Home for Children, 141 South Third Street, Brooklyn, Peter Karbiner, 18 years old, a former ward of the orphanage, was found dead in an alley outside the home early yesterday morning.

The marriage of Miss Jane Elizabeth Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giles Munro Hubbard of this place and Pelham Manor, N. Y., to Arthur Knox Jr., son of Mr. Knox of Norfolk and New York and the late Mrs. May Barnard Knox, will take place on Oct. 1 in the Congregational Church here.
A revised and enlarged edition of "Yields of Bonds and Stocks" has been published by Prentice-Hall. It was written, as were the two previous volumes, by David C.
London morning newspapers generally took an optimistic view today of the AngloFrench communique on a plan for settlement of the German-Czech crisis.

The Spanish Rebels today launched their fourth counter-offensive in seven weeks in an effort to drive the Loyalist troops out of the Ebro elbow. Ever since the Loyalists, in their offensive that began on July 25, straddled that river, the Rebels have been vainly trying to dislodge them.

A "black" army of 120,000 men made a sharp, decisive thrust this evening ] in the Tennessee Valley near Louisville, threatening to wipe out the vital industrial plants of the Middle West in the mythical war being staged by the Second Army under the direction of Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum.

Fourteen yachts, barely enough for a quorum, turned out off this port today for the special regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club. A heavy northeasterly which kicked up towering seas, intermittent rain squalls and generally cold and miserable conditions made them wish they had stayed at home.
The number of unemployed in August fell to 179,000, against 218,000 at the end of July. Exceptional activity, apparently due to military consideration, continues in the heavy chemical industries.
A call for greater efforts on the part of American Jews in assisting European refugees, whose plight has become more desperate with the growing danger of war, was made yesterday by Governor Lehman.
Mayor La Guardia was beneficent to interviewers today. Puffing contentedly on a corncob pipe, the New Yorker did his best to satisfy California curiosity.
The Senators halted Hank Greenberg's home-run campaign today but bowed to Tommy Bridges's close pitching and dropped an 8-to-1 decision to the Tigers.

Preaching yesterday at the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, the Rev. John Walter Houck urged all Americans to recall the advantages they enjoy in this country, where there is freedom of opportunity and liberty of worship.

121st St, 222 W, Claudia Linard to Morris Levinson, 180 Riverside Dr (50 cents). 121st St, 320 E, Metropolitan Savings Bank to Vedan Properties, Inc, 16 Court St, Brooklyn; purchase money mtg $17,100 ($17.50).

Dr. James E. Boyle, Professor of Rural Economy at Cornell University since 1917, died here today after a long illness at the age of 64. Born in Boyle, Kan., he attended the Universities of Nebraska, Kansas and Wisconsin, receiving his Ph. D. degree from the latter school in 1904.

The trouble with the world is its' lost horizon, declared the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick yesterday in his first sermon after the vacation period at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.
Following is the text of Premier Milan Hodza's speech today on the Czechoslovak-Sudeten German crisis: You are all experiencing how we are living in the most dramatic days of our modern history.
After a skeet shoot today at Great Pine Farm, Great Barrington, Mrs. Rodney S. Jarvis entertained a cocktail party. Mrs. Thomas H. Blodgett also was a hostess.

" Around the Clock With New York's Finest," a demonstration of police activity to be staged for the benefit of the Police Athletic League, will open at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 28 and continue to Oct. 1.

NEXT June it Will be 130 years since Thomas Paine died in a house in Greenwich Village. He wanted to be buried in a Quaker cemetery, but the Quakers wouldn't hear of it, so a friend carted his body up to New Rochelle and laid it in a corner of the farm Paine had been granted by the State of New York for services during the Revolution.
In the pleasant spa of Godesberg, a few miles south of this city, the issue of peace or war over Czechovakia is likely to be decided before the present week is out.
Men who manage Industry in all parts of the world are gathering here to discuss their relationship to the social and economic problems of the day.
The shipment of equipment and materials from the Magdalena Fruit Company (a United Fruit Company subsidiary) to Costa Rica has caused considerable concern in the banana district of Colombia.

Playing in a steady, light rain, Paul Pedersen of the home club and Walter Pedersen of Shore Haven won the second annual four-ball best-ball invitation handicap golf tournament for members and guests of the Tamarack Country Club today.

The four-day program observing the 200th anniversary of the First Presbyterian Church of Mendham closed here tonight with a special service at which the sermon was given by the Rev. Dr. Laurence G. Bennett, pastor of the Basking Ridge Presbyterian Church and former moderator of the synod of New Jersey.

A call for a meeting to consider a national educational and advertising campaign to increase consumption of dairy products was issued today by the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federatoin, the American Butter Institute, the National Association of Local Creameries, the National Association of Direct Cream Shippers Creameries and the

The boom for the nomination of Assemblyman James J. Wadsworth of Livingston County for Wieutenant Governor at the Republican State Convention is progressing favorably, Frank K. Cook, of Geneseo, chairman of the Wadsworth campaign committee, announced yesterday.

Joseph Brooks, Inc. building contractor, store at 234 W 55th St; Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers. Hudson Upholstery, Inc, store at 1,648 Park Ave; Proops Management, Inc, broker. Wiss Jewelers of Newark and Renault's, ladies' wearing apparel, stores in building at Central Ave and Evergreen Pl, East Orange, N. J.; Riker Co. brokers.

Doubleday, Doran announce that arrangements with the French publishers of "Madame Curie" have been completed and that a school edition of the book will be issued next year by the Doubleday, Doran Educational Department. The textbook version will contain from 50,000 to 60,000 words from the original French of Eve Curie, edited and annotated for classroom use.

Mrs. Barbara Bird, aged 20, wife of Charles Bird, a Midwest desperado captured here recently, was released from jail after serving a thirty-day jail sentence today and was immediately taken into custody for Federal officers.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 69.5 on Sept. 14, compared with 70.4 a fortnight before, 71.4 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Dr. Sara Donnell Wolverton, physician and wife of Congressional Representative Charles A. Wolverton of New Jersey, died last night after a week's illness. Dr. Wolverton suffered a heart attack last Monday. She was born in Illinois and attended schools in Camden, N. J., and Philadelphia.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Goulard gave a tea at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathrine Goulard; to Henry M. O'Reilly, son of Mrg. Henry M. O'Reilly, also of Summit.
There will be no contests in the primary elections in Rockland County next Tuesday. A write-in campaign is being held to name a substitute for Laurens M. Hamilton as State committeeman.

The campaign in the Sixteenth Congressional District, where Representative John J. O'Connor, Democratic chairman of the House Rules Committee, has become the outstanding remaining member on President Roosevelt's "purge" list, will close tonight with a meeting of the Tudor City Civic League in Windsor Towers, Tudor City. Mr.

Members of various committees for the 1938 Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillon, which will be given on Oct. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, will hold their fimst meeting on Wednesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, 115 East Fifty-fourth Street.

A decrease of nearly 25 per cent in the number of deaths in highway fatalities in the city last month as compared with August, 1937, was reported to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

To benefit by the Lord's blessings, individuals must realize the need for God, the Rev. Dr. Zenan M. Corbe declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway at Ninety-third Street.

The Buffalo Bisons, who wound up in fourth place in the regular season pennant race, clinched a finalround berth in the International League play-offs today by defeating the Syracuse Chiefs, 5 to 3, for the fourth straight victory of their semi-final series.

Candidates for eleven public offices will be nominated in the Westchester County primaries next Tuesday. The only contest will be in the Twenty-sixth Senatorial District, where two Republicans are seeking their party's nomination to run in November against Senator James A. Garrity, Domocrat.

Eleanor G. Colgan, Brooklyn school teacher who was honored by Pope Piux X in 1909 for her services to the Italian community in the parish of the Church of Our Lady of Peace, died Friday at her home, 715 Carroll Street.
The, Foreign Office has informed the local press that it has received a message from Germany saying that all Ecuadorean journalists visiting Germany will receive special consideration.

An automobile going west on the Sunrise Highway here this morning got out of control, left the road, hurtled down a six-foot embankment and then turned over. Two occupants were killed and three were badly injured. The accident happened at Sunrise Highway and Unqua Road.
War talk and a better domestic demand for cash lard dominated the action of the market here last week. Speculators were fairly active buyers at times, as were packers.

The labor crisis remained unchanged today, pending arrangements for one meeting concerning the warehouse tie-up and the outcome of another scheduled Wednesday at Mayor Rossi's office on the department store strike.
The Daily Mail today quoted Chancellor Adolf Hitler as telling an interviewer that "this Czech trouble has got to be ended once and for all and ended now."

Major Benjamin H. Namm, Brooklyn merchant and vice president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, opened "National Retail Demonstration Week" yesterday with a radio address over WNYC announcing nation-wide plans for the emphasis of service, cooperation and confidence between merchants and consumers.

Thomas Wolfe's home town- the "Altamont" of his 'took Homeward, Angel"-paid a last tribute to him today. Brief but impressive funeral services were held this afternoon at the First Presbyterian Church.

A week of recounting ballots cast in the Democratic primary last Monday faced election officials today with the outcome of the Gubernatorial race between Attorney General Herbert R. O'Conor and Mayor Howard W. Jackson hanging on the outcome.
Loancollections of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation amounted to 94.6 per-cent of billings during August, according to Charles A. Jones, general manager.
Supply contracts valued at $4,989,082 were awarded during the week ended Sept. 15 by six Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.
The Giants and Cardinals, foiled in their plan to close their season's series at the' Polo Grounds by yesterday's rain, will play a doubleheader today, the first game starting at 1:45 o'clock.
A double victory by Irving Folwartshny featured the concluding portion of the New York Athletic Club's 141st track and field meet at Travers Island yesterday.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, who has been pretty stern about the abuse of English by his colleagues on the Board of Estimate and about certain city statutes, steeled his heart yesterday to a plea for playgrounds for city-bred dogs.
With pencil and paper, John Sweer, expert of the Naval Research Laboratory, has just finished computations which will aid future stratosphere fliers traveling above 50,000-foot altitudes.

Man's tendency to regard himself as a creditor rather than as a debtor in his relationships with fellowmen is responsible in great measure for the present chaotic state of the world, the Rev. Dr. Harry Lathrop Reed, president of the Auburn Theological Seminary, said in his sermon yesterday at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Ruth Rea, daughter of Mr. 'and Mrs. James Childs Rea of Pittsburgh, to Alfred Hunt Howell, son of Mr., and Mrs. Alfred C. Howell of 815 Park Avenue, which took place Saturday at Bakobils, the Summer home in Rector, Pa., of the bride's parents.

Although Czechoslovakia has 1,800,000 trained men available for war service, the country is determined to do everything possible to avoid war, according to Dr. Emanuel Slechta, a member of the Prague City Council and of the Czechoslovak National Committee for Organization, who arrived on the Holland-America line Statendam yesterday.
The warscare developments, with the rapidly changing judgments on the situation, entirely dominated the Boerse this week. The week's opening for stocks was dull with slight declines;...
Mr. and Mrs. Augustus T. Rush of this city have, announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Margaret Rush, to Titus Harry Lang of Maplewood.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,974,606,350. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
Prices of commodities in The Netherlands were affected this week as much as were those of securities and foreign exchange, but in a more irregular manner. .
Driving rain and a heavy mist marred the semi-final and final rounds todar in the seventh annual best-ball four-ball invitation golf tournament at The Fishers Island Club.

Police headquarters are actively investigating the whereabouts of numerous members of Nazi organizations who are reported to have been missing for many days after the unsuccessful uprising of Sept. 5.

Mrs. Loretta Werner Leamy, wife of Frederick W. Leamy, vice president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, died yesterday at her home, 944 Park Avenue, after an illness of. several months. Mrs. Leamy was a native of New York City.

Governor Davey of Ohio, in a letter made public here today, defied the Social Security Board to withhold Federal funds from the needy aged of Ohio because of alleged maladministration of the State's Division of Aid for the Aged.
Reception, Chile-American Association, to celebrate the 128th anniversary of the independence of Chile, Hotel Roosevelt,. 5 P. M.
Two parties were given today for Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Stevens, who arrived last week to visit the parents of Mrs. Stevens, Brigadier General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Gertrude Conklin of 157 East Seventy-second Street, this city, and Madison, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leander H. Conklin of Madison, to Andrew Hamilton Ransom, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Sutherland Ransom of Albany.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Maxfield of Florham Park, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine H. Maxfield, to Robert B. Gibney of Summit, son of Mr. And Mrs. James B. Gibney of Wilmington, Del.
Mrs. Irene Brazong, formerly with William B. May Co., is with Hardy Brauneis. Herbert C. Comstock Jr., formerly with Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., has Joined Williams Co., Inc.

Captain John F. Milliken, known as the father of the international lifeboat race held in New York Harbor every year, died early yesterday after a long illness at his home, 35 Lawrence Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I. He was 46 years old.

In a plea for "a little more common sense in religion," the Rev. Detlef A. Kraft emphasized common sense in church architecture as a leading adjunct to worship, in a sermon yesterday morning at St. John's Lutheran Church, Beech Avenue and 147th Street, Flushing, Queens.

Harry A. Worcester, a retired vice president of the New York Central Railroad and president of the Cincinnati Union Terminal Company, died here today at the age of 75. Mr. Worcester's railroad career started in 1885 when he became assistant station master of Grand Central Station in New York.
Inquiries in authoritative Soviet quarters here disclose no information that Russia would intervene automatically in the event of German armed assistance to the Sudeten Germans of Czechoslovakia.
Gar Wood Jr. drove his tiny speedboat over a rough Tennessee River course today to win two amateur titles in the national outboard regatta.

Among the fallacies that help to give California's $30-every-Thursday scheme its appeal in certain quarters is the belief that the jobs vacated by persons over 50 to make themselves eligible for the pension will provide an equal number of jobs for younger persons now unemployed.
Stephen F. Chadwick, a lawyer of Seattle, today won the major political battle of the American Legion convention without a vote being fired.

The State Department of Labor announced today that 10,692 placements were made in private industry by the State employment service during August, a reduction of 35.9 per cent as compared with the same month last year.

There must be no compromise of constitutional guarantees in the United States if dictatorship of the right or the left is to be avoided. Governor Lehman said yesterday in an address at the fifteenth annual Brooklyn Constitution Day celebration in the Music Grove of Prospect Park.
Mayor Dennis Michael McDonough, an unsuccessful candidate in Tuesday's primaries for the Democratic nomination for Congress, died suddenly last night at his home here at the age of 49.

News just received from Wuchow tells of a devastating bombing raid by nine Japanese planes yesterday. Many houses were wrecked and many civilians killed or wounded. Fires are still raging today because of the use of incendiary bombs.

It is when life cracks up around one and the going is rough that one finds the real meaning of religion, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers of the Broadway Congrenational Tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street said in his sermon yesterday morning.

The international situation is causing dislocation in the discount market. The outlook for bills is extremely restricted and the market is disinclined to reduce its own buying rate while the largest house quoted stiffer rates.

While prices for corn rose last week, the market made only a moderate response to the war scare. Some business with Continental Europe was reported, and Germany is credited with having purchased about 25 per cent of the 125,000,000 bushels of corn exported from this country since Nov. 1, 1937.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Halstead of Brooklyn and Huntington, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Morton Halstead, to Robinson Emery Keyes, son of Arthur H. Keyes of Rutland, Vt., and the late Mrs. Keyes.

LeRoy Briean, 35 years old, who lives at the Central Queens branch of the Y. M. C. A. in Jamaica, appeared yesterday before Magistrate Anthony Savarese in Queens Felony Court, the first defendant to be charged in Queens with putting in an unnecessary call for police c radio cars.

The money market here was tighter this week, political events having given rise to increased note hoarding. Large withdrawals of funds from the commercial and savings banks developed, but short-term rates advanced only slightly as they already had nearly attained official discount level.

Materially greater activity and nervousness prevailed this week in the foreign exchange and gold markets here than in the stock market. This was because of the movement of "hot money" to the United States.

Miss Virginia Baker Felter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Washington Felter of 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has selected Oct. 7 for her marriage to Russell Bernay Harding, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hight Harding, also of Brooklyn.
The City College football squad, after eleven days of pre-season training at the Wayne County Club in Tyler Hill, Pa., came home yesterday two days ahead of schedule.

Charges that renewed attacks on the Supreme Court by the President and his official and unofficial advisers "indicate that he is merely awaiting a more propitious time to accomplish his most cherished ambition" are made by The Republican Reporter, a publication of the Republican National Committee.
A move by the American Federation of Labor to organize workers on WPA white-collar and arts projects, where the Workers Alliance has its greatest strength, was disclosed here yesterday.

The desperate social and economic problems of the modern world would soon be solved if people would give God a paramount position in their lives, the Rev. Ernest R. Palen declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

James Hillhouse, retired lawyer, namesake and collateral descendant of the United States Senator who laid out the avenue in this city bearing his name, introduced first landscape gardening here and planted shade trees on a large scale, died at midnight tonight in the Hillhouse mansion, which overlooks Hillhouse Avenue.

Like lilacs blooming in December, the six-day bicycle race startled the staid burghers of this city by burgeoning out in an entirely unwonted season, when fifteen teams, representing several nations, set off on the grind to nowhere at Madison Square Garden last night.

Rear Admiral Wythe Marchant Parks, U.S.N., retired, died last night at his home, 5,015 Spruce Street, at the age of 82. Born in Norfolk, Va., he attended private schools there, including the Norfolk Male Academy.
An enemy more formidable than that concocted by high ranking-officers for the land and sea manoeuvres of the Third Battalion, Organized Marine Corps Reserve, routed the troops here this afternoon.
