The world's wheat market is regarded as dominated almost entirely now by fears of a war in Europe. Other influences counted for little last week, and they are not expected to be a market factor of consequence until the situation abroad becomes clear.
Factory employment in Pennsylvania increased almost 4 per cent and wage disbursements 9 per cent from July to August, according to figures released today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.
All day today plain men and women of England by hundreds and thousands filed past the simple black slab in Westminster Abbey that marks the resting place of the British Unknown Soldier.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Not all the forward-looking ideas for public service originate in the metropolis, Miniature Golf, PigglyWiggly, the Five and Ten, Curb Service, Bank Night and the Townsend Plan were born in Atlantic City, Memphis, Lancaster, the little towns along the Dixie Highway, Denver and Long Beach.
The statement of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30, issued for publication today, shows a net loss of $829,362 after all charges, taxes and reserves.
A big construction job is under way in the Berkshire Hills and it is not WPA labor that is handling it. This one has to be done in a hurry, and so Charlie Caldwell is doing it himself.

The Brazilian Commissioner to the World's Fair, Armando Vidal, plans to sail for New York via Europe in December. During his visit he will work to increase BrazilianAmerican trade, Mr. Vidal declared.

The conscious conception of the forgiveness of God is a "glorious, liberating and life-giving sensation," the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker Jr., rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
With ninety-three freshmen enrolling from thirteen States and South America, Stoneleigh College for Women opened here for its fifth year today.

From the viewpoint of markets, financial sentiment was last week exclusively dominated by the ins and outs of European diplomacy. The markets which were closest watched for their immediate reflection, favorable or unfavorable,

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity continued in relatively small volume, and were mostly municipal issues. A few miscellaneous and Joint Stock Land Bank bonds were included. Payment dates were mostly for future months.
Twentyeight members of nine Chicago families were added today to a list of victims of a mysterious poisoning which has caused one death and illness to scores of persons in Elmwood Park, a suburb.

Nine clergymen will take part in the formal installation next Friday evening of the Rev. J. Charles Pelon as pastor of the North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street, near Willis Avenue, the Bronx.

The domestic wheat situation has not been affected by the international political crisis, and the official press openly boasts of this, assailing the United States as the pace-setter of the world market.
The Amsterdam Evening Reborder has announced that beginning tomorrow the price of the paper will be increased from 3 cents to 5 cents a single copy.

Chancellor Hitler won the greatest diplomatic victory of his career just after last midnight when the heads of the British and French Governments agreed to support his full demands against Czechoslovakia to avoid another world war.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he had notified Alfred B. Jones, chairman of the New York City Tunnel Authority, that he would oppose construction of the Brooklyn-Manhattan vehicular tunnel unless adequate provision were made to handle the tunnel traffic in Manhattan.

The Middle West Corporation, Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act an application for approval of the sale of $540,660 of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds, Series A, due on Jan. 1, 1957;
" Trieste knows," said Mussolini in his speech yesterday, "that geography is not an opinion, and that it takes its revenge in the long run on those who consider it as such."

Three Lunenburg County swordfishermen were drowned Saturday night when the forty-ton schooner Nelson L. went down after striking a ledge off this Eastern Shore village. Three others rowed ashore in a dory.

The claim of the Christian church for centuries has been that cures for personal and worldly ills will not be found in political formulas, but only in the companionship of Jesus Christ, the Rev. Thomas Ayres Sparks, a member of the Cathedral staff, said yesterday in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Five men from New York arrived for the American Legion convention today as stowaways on the liner City of Newport News. They are Michael J. Flynn, past Queens County commander;
The West and.Jesse James, in the form and content of Elizabeth Beall Ginty's "Missouri Legend," are brought to the Empire Theatre tonight by Guthrie McClintic, in association with Max Gordon.

Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts, the youngest man in the United States Senate, returned on the Holland-America liner Statendam yesterday accompanied by his wife and their two sons, George, 11 years old, and Harry, 8.

Strike-ballots are now being distributed by the railway brotherhoods. It is foregone that they foreshadow rejection of the 15 per cent wage cut announced by the railroads for Oct. 1. The country will then be faced with the threat of a nation-wide rail strike.
The Red Wings made it three victories in four starts in their best-of-seven games International League semi-final play-off series today by whipping the pennant-winning Bears, 5 to 3.
Justice Owen J. Roberts of the United States Supreme Court returned on the Holland-America liner Statendam yesterday accompanied by Mrs. Roberts.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Bateman Ewart of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Jane Ewart, to Howard Weaver McCall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCall of New York and Chattanooga, Tenn.

Thomas Benton, American mural painter, declared in a statement released here yesterday that he could not have passed the drawing test of the city's examination for teachers of fine arts in the New York City high schools.

Buoyed by a rising demand for all types of foodstuffs, all divisions of grocery distribution look for continued steady gains in dollar sales volume, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday in its weekly survey of conditions in the wholesale and retail branches.

All over France tonight millions of people are saying with relief in their hearts, "And so there will not be war." For this morning the French Cabinet accepted the plan for the solution of the Czechoslovak problem negotiated yesterday in London by Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet.

Rush S. Dickson of R. S. Dickson Co., Inc., has been nominated chairman of the southeastern group of the Investment Bankers Association of America for the ensuing year, the organization has announced.

Jeff Heath's homer helped the Indians turn four hits into four runs today and gave Mel Harder his seventeenth victory of the season as the Athletics were defeated, 4-3. Harder allowed the Mackmen 12 hits, abut did not get into serious trouble until the eighth. Johnny Humphries held the visitors to none thereafter.

President Arturo Alessandri, accompanied by the newly formed Cabinet and the foreign diplomatic corps, today reviewed the annual military parade, which ended the celebration in honor of the 128th anniversary of Chilean independence.

The Finish Government sent a note of protest to Russia today against alleged violations of Finland's territory. The note said that Russian planes twice last week penetrated the frontier for twenty miles and that pubmarine manoeuvres off the Gulf of Finland were within Finnish waters.

For the third successive day and the fourth time in the tournament, play in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills was washed out by rain yesterday. In the forenoon Dr. S. Ellsworth Davenport Jr., referee, announced that the program for the day had been postponed until today, starting at 1:15.

MISSOURI LEGEND, a comedy in three acts. by Elizabeth Beall Ginty. Settings by John Koenig; staged by Guthrie McClintic; produced by Mr. McClintic, in association with Max Gordon. At the Empire Theatre.

Making a strong counter-attack, a Blue army defending the industrial Middlewest flung back the right flank of an invading Black army a distance of twelve miles and recaptured Elizabethtown, fifty miles from Louisville, tonight after the second day of the mimic war being waged by the Second Army under

The San Carlo Opera Company presented "Aida" at the Center Theatre last night and despite the bad weather the performance drew only 200 under capacity. The audience responded warmly to the spirited performance of the melodious, dramatic score.

John Lee Baldwin, who, for many years, conducted a woodcarving business on East Main Street here as a hobby, died yesterday of a cerebral thrombosis at the Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L. I., at the age of 71.

With the reduction in price of its Palm Beach suits from $17.75 to $15.50 for 1939 expected to stimulate sales, the Goodall Company, which spent $900,000 in national and cooperative advertising this year, will conduct the largest campaign in its history next year.
The banks in the 100 big cities outside New York again showed better results than did local institutions in the week ended on last Wednesday covered by last night's report.

The Hitchcock Memorial Church here was the scene of the marriage tonight of Miss Frances Lee Montague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Montague Jr. of Scarsdale, to Phillip Nance Joachim of Washington, son of Mrs. Carl A. Joerissen of Chevy Chase, Md.

An explosion of undetermined origin, followed by a fire, wrecked half of a four-family duplex house at 262-64 Delafield Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I., just before 6 o'clock last night. There were no tenants in the side of the house where the blast occurred, but two women living in the adjoining half at 264

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Benjamin J. Hill's letter, "Railroad History Recalled," contends that the business methods of the railroads in the early days were far from scrupulous, and recited in particular the case of the Union Pacific.

Lydig Ave (15-4313), s e cor of Tenbroeci Ave, 54x121; Benjamin Cohen to Sara R. Slmermeyer. 3,318 Steuben Ave. Seymour Ave (16-4384), e s/126 n of Palham Parkway North, 80x100; Doris Berkowitz to John Harmaala, 3,040 Wickham Ave.

Bob Pastor, who was scheduled to meet Gunnar Barlund of Finland in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 3, informed Promoter Mike Jacobs yesterday he would be unable to go through with the match.

Divestment of control of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company by Columbia Gas and Electric Corportion interests was foreshadowed yesterday when it was disclosed that an investment banking syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co.

COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday. Friday. For the bent names.... 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Trucking Strike Worries Trade Manufacturers and resident buying executives were seriously concerned yesterday by the local truckmen's strike. While express shipments were being forwarded, in merchandise from or to the piers,

Three new committees have been created by the New York State Bankers Association for the current year, Thomas A. Wilson, head of the organization and president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Binghamton, announced yesterday.

The most conspicuous new feature of the last half dozen years on the national scene is the lady drum-major. Big innovations aside, like social insurance and centralized government, the two outstanding novelties of recent years have been streamlining and the young woman who now walks ahead of the band, stepping high.

Bobby Stap has had for more than a year the average: run-of-the-mill desire of almost every 13-year-old boy to go to sea. But most boys finally wind up by letting the desire go unfulfilled and growing up to office jobs and other careers.

A number of properties in Brooklyn were reported yesterday as having been sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn. Among them were the two-family houses at 135 Luqueer Street and 1,071 Seventysecond Street, which were purchased by Francesca Bruno and Gyda A. Anderson, respectively.
The League of Nations Council, pressed hard by China and with Poland's chair empty, agreed tonight to begin for the first time the application of the Covenant's Article XVII against Japan.

Gracie Allen, the comedienne, will exhibit eight of her oil paintings next week at the Julien Levy Galleries, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced yesterday. She describes them as being not surrealist but rather "surrealistic."

Properties in the Bronx reported yesterday as having been sold through various brokers included two multi-family dwellings and a number of one-family homes. Among them was the twenty-fivefamily apartment house at 1,750-52 Bathgate Avenue which was sold by the Regatta Realty Corporation to the Ancott Realty Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Cuddihy gave a dinner last evening at Sherry's for Mrs. Monica Shiyuze Ito, Japanese educator, and her daughter, Miss Yuriko Ito. Among the other guests were former Governor and Alfred E. Smith,

Blackpool today defeated Brentford, 4-1, and moved into a tie with Arsenal and Stoke City in sixteenth place in the English Football 'League. Representative Sheffield and Glasgow elevens met in a friendly encounter on the Glasgow Rangers' grounds at Ibrox Park.

A thirteen-acre tract of land. the Fort Salonga section of Northport, L. I., has been purchased by George Balanchine of New York, house who is building a home thereon for his own occupancy, Edward Bialla of Edwin N. Rowley, Inc., broker who negotiated the deal, announced yesterday.

Plans for the Japanese pavilion at the World's Fair, a building modeled on a Shinto shrine of 300 B. C., were approved yesterday by the board of design, it was announced by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.

Bernard Baruch, New York banker, refused last night on his return from Europe to confirm reports that he had returned at the request of President Roosevelt to organize a system of national defense throughout American industry.

Rain forced the Army football squad indoors today, Coach Bill Wood going over the errors made in last Saturday's practice game. He explained the plays to be used against the University of Wichita on Saturday.

In a breath-taking finish, the challenging six-meter craft Circe of the Royal Northern Yacht Club of Scotland today won her third straight race for the Seawanhaka Challenge Cup, and thus the 43-year-old trophy, considered the America's Cup of small yacht racing, goes to the Clyde for the third time.

The terms which the British and French Governments have sent to Prague have not yet been revealed officially. But if present reports are accurate, and if the capitulation to the demands of Germany is as complete as it now seems to be, one thing can be said with certainty.

Rain raised havoo with the Long Island P. G. A. one-day tournament at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday, only seven teams participating in the amateurpro event and three doughty duos in the pro-pro play. The competition originally was scheduled for Lakeville in Great Neck.
The home offices here of the Prudential Insurance Company of America will close at noon tomorrow in respect to President Edward D. Duffield, who died on Saturday at his home in South Orange.

Gabriel I. Lewis, a lawyer of 80 William Street, fell dead at,Eightyeighth Street and Lexington Avenue at about 8 o'clock last night while walking to a meeting at the Young Men's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and Ninetysecond Street. Death was due to a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 54.

The Yale University Press reports that the advance sale of Marquis Childs's new book, "This Is Democracy," which will be published on Sept. 27, has gone well ahead of the advance on any -other book ever published by Yale.

The gray and dripping pall that hung over the Eastern seaboard yesterday washed out the National League schedule, eliminating planned double-headers at the Polo Grounds, Ebbets Field, in Boston and Philadelphia.

Central Park W, 385-86, 55.6x100: 385 Central Park W Corp to Irving I. Plotkin, 1.491 Flatbush Ave. Brooklyn; pr mtg, $165,000; 3 years, 6 per cent; $17,000. Madison Ave. 1,793, 25.3x60: CarmineAddeo to Giovanni Guglelmetti., 322 E 104th St; pr mtg, $7,500; due July 1, 1943, 5 per cent; S2,300.

The Prudential Insurance Company has sold Elmora Towers a fivestory elevator apartment house at 319-323 Elmora Avenue, to the R. P. Realty Company of Englewood. The B. B. Miller Management of this city were brokers in the transaction, which is understood to have involved $200,000.

Blattengeta Herouy, former Ethiopian Minister of Foreign Affairs and the exiled Emperor Haile Selassie's greatest personal friend, died in the Emperor's home at Bath today, after an illness of several months. His age was 60.

Thomas Acerra, 29 years old, of 161 Prospect Street, Brooklyn, appeared yesterday before Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Felony Court, Brooklyn, in his stocking feet to answer a charge of assault and robbery.
MANHATTAN BENEDICT, HELEN K. (Sept. 9). Estate more than $10,000. To Mrs. Francis L. Bledsoe, petitioner, 60 E. 96th St., about $60,000; Jean S. Romaine, 60 E. 96th St., $1,000.

Life begins at 76 for Paul F. Travers, artist, gold prospector and former Mamaroneck Village trustee. In a letter received today by his wife, the white-haired patriarch said he was not kidnapped when he disappeared last Wednesday, causing an eight-State police alarm to be sent out, but that he was off to Mexico to change his name and start life anew.

Classes were started yesterday morning in the seven colleges of St. John's University, Brooklyn, with an enrollment of about 10,000, including the uptown and Borough Hall divisions. The Very Rev. Dr. Edward J. Walsh, president, spoke at a mass in the morning at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Baptist, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, with students in attendance from the College of Arts and Sciences, Teachers College and Graduate School, all uptown.

Conferees representing ship lines operating out of New York and the International Longshoremen's Association were deadlocked on the question of hours in the drafting of a new wage agreement for pier workers at the close of a cdnference yesterday afternoon.

The Washington Redskins and Philadelphia Eagles are setting the pace in all departments of offensive play in the National Football League, statistics for the first weeks of play reveal. This is the first time in the history of the loop that the Eastern Division has been ahead of the Western at any stage of the season.
Continued interest in properties on Washington Heights and Harlem was evidenced yesterday when brokers reported the sale of several parcels in those sections.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, challenged Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan, yesterday to provide a plan of his own to handle the increased downtown traffic expected to result from construction of the proposed Battery-to-Brooklyn tunnel.
The financial markets responded with cautious optimism to the news of the decision of France and Britain to yield to Chanoellor Adolf Hitler's demands as a means of averting war.

Eight polo ponies escaped from their paddock this afternoon on the estate of W. H. Gaylord in Powells Lane and gave local and county police in radio cars and home owners in the Jericho and Oyster Bay colonies an exciting hour.

A cashier who had been employed by the French Line for twenty-five years and another man who was described as an accountant were arrested last night, charged with defrauding the French Line of $62,500 by means of counterfeit United States internal revenue stamps.

An answer was filed yesterday in Queens Supreme Court by the Coca-Cola Company to an injunction suit brought against it there Aug. 5 by the Pepsi-Cola Company, in which the latter sought to restrain Coca-Cola from interfering with its sales of a drink syrup.

Addressing the convocation opening the 144th year of Union College today, President Dixon Ryan Fox urged upon the student body, including 282 freshmen, a raising of the "level of satisfaction with written English" in the face of "a general debasement of standards which threatens us on every side."

In a letter to Homer S. Cummings, Attorney General, urging him to take note of the trial tomorrow in Hoboken of Herman Matson, chairman of the Hoboken Workers' Defense League, who was arrested last Thursday on a charge of "inciting to riot,"

Super-market operators were urged at the opening session of the Super-Market Institute convention today to ?? their story to the consumer by Advertising and other methods of appeal to curb taxation designed to put them out of business. This method of fighting opposition has proved highly successful -where tested, M. M. Zimmerman, executive secretary, asserted in his report on the year's activities.

Miss Margaret P. Rae, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, who had served for forty years in the city's public school system, died early yesterday morning in Caledonian Hospital, Brooklyn, following an emergency appendectomy last Wednesday.

The Holland-America liner Statendam will sail today for Plymouth. Boulogne and Rotterdam. Among the passengers will be George H. Van Buren, Dr. and Mrs. W. Thurber Fales. Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Ringers, Baron and Baroness F. S.
A musical comedy entitled "East Side, Best Side" will be presented on Friday evening at the Community House here to aid the East Side House Settlement in New York.

Commercial failures in the United States increased in the week ended Sept. 15 to 232, pun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 139 in the same week a year ago and 161 in the fiveday holiday week preceding.

Latest news being that the Godesberg conference between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain cannot take place before Wednesday, it has seemed worth while to make inquiries meantime into the effect that these negotiations over Czechoslovakia are having in other smaller countries surrounding Germany.

John E. J. Fanshawe, a former resident of Philadelphia who had lived here in recent years, died this morning in the New York Hospital and from a blood clot on a lung following an operation. He was 60 years old, a son of the late John Richardson Fanshawe of Philadelphia, and had been a member of the Philadelphia brokerage firm of Fanshawe. Cadwalader Co.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Brooklyn Roman Catholic Diocese observed yesterday the thirtieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood by celebrating a private mass of thanksgiving in the chapel of his home, 241 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn.

Trading in wheat futures today was largely of a professional character. The lessening of the menace in reports from Europe led to fairly general selling at the opening with prices declining about 2 cents a bushel, but the market was inactive thereafter.

The foreign exchange market strengthened yesterday as the news of the decision of Great Britain and France to yield to Chancellor Hitler's demands eased the fears of war which had been driving frightened capital here from Europe.

Americans who know Dr. Hu Shih will rejoice in his acceptance of a new role as Chinese Ambassador to the United States, succeeding in that role the able and popular Dr. C. T. Wang. Few of Dr. Shih's countrymen are so thoroughly representative of the best of the new and the old China.

Under the most tantalizing scoring conditions in the history of the event-a cold, raw, windy day, with occasional splashes of rain to add to the general discomfiture of the contestants-the magnificent performances of two players were outstanding features of today's qualifying round in the forty-second women's national golf championship at the Westmoreland Country Club.

Every chair was taken and every box filled yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza, where the mechanics of chic were dissected and analyzed for an exclusively feminine audience by department heads of Bonwit-Teller in their seasonal style clinic.
Tens of thousands of young, well-fed Czechoslovak soldiers, afraid of neither war nor work, are massed in formidable fortifications in readiness for shots which may signal a new European conflict.
Automobile production declined last week, countering the normal seasonal trend, and the adjusted index slumped to 25.5 from 35.1 in the preceding week and 108.7 for the week ended Sept. 18, 1937.

Attacking President Roosevelt's foreign policy, Representative John J. O'COnnor declared last night that "some think that the Chief Executive in order to perpetuate himself in office will plunge our nafinn info war".

Coach Hank Hardwick put his navy charges through their last early morning practice today and will hold but one session a day, in the afternoon, during the remainder of the week, in preparation for the opening game, with William and Mary Saturday. Both of today's sessions were in the rain, and there was light scrimmage and individual work on some of the details of the attack.

The movement to establish a new and sounder mortgage program for the State, affording protection from the faults of the old system, which resulted in the collapse of the old mortgage and guarantee companies, has been revived by the State Insurance Department, the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York, the State Banking Department and other agencies.

Urging roasters "to take the gamble out of the coffee business" by every known means of protecting profits, George Gordon Paton, statistician of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, tonight advised the members of the Associated Coffee Industries of America at their convention here toInvestigate the use of the Exchange for the protection of unwieldy inventories in these uncertain times.

Bright blooms of many colors filled the clubroom of THE NEW YORK TIMES Annex, 229 West Fortythird Street, yesterday at the opening of the fourth annual flower show conducted by THE TIMES. Twenty-five members of the organization entered more than 100 exhibits in the show, which will continue through today.

Distillers were warned today by W. S. Alexander, Administrator of the Federal Alcohol Administration, that it would be illegal for them to subsidize retail concessionaires at either the New York or San Francisco World's Fairs of 1939.

Secretary Morgenthau said today that M. H. Magruder, internal revenue collector at Baltimore, had the Treasury's approval of a statement read to non-civil service employees expressing his preference for the candidacy of Representative Lewis in Maryland's Democratic primary.

Cotton prices rallied 60 to 75 cents a bale early yesterday on the Cotton Exchange on hopefulness that the British and French acceptance of Chancellor Hitler's demands would permit a peaceful settlement of the Czechoslovak crisis. Values reacted later from the best as traders settled down to wait more definite developments abroad and liquidation in the October appeared.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Sept. 14 aggregated $7,733,000,000, or 26 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 18 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.
Employes of the Briggs Manufacturing Company, who struck Wednesday returned to work today under the terms of a settlement reached Saturday.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, charged last night that six Democratic district leaders were trying to influence enrolled Republican voters to support Harold L. Turk, Republican district leader, who is opposing Louis Waldman, American Labor party candidate And the Republican organization designee for Kings County judge.

The Social Democratic party registered huge gains in yesterday's election of 1,521 County Councilors throughout Sweden, complete returns showed today. The Councilors' importance consists in the fact that each year they elect one of the eight members of the Parliament's First Chamber.

Trading was uneven: steer hinds and ribs were in good demand and other classes only fair to most slow in local markets yesterday. Prices, though somewhat irregular, were mostly downward. Slaughter of most classes around normal. Kosher lamb opened lower and other kosher meats strong to higher.

Marking the opening of the Fall semester at New York University, 500 freshmen were welcomed to the University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering yesterday in orientation exercises

The New York Financial Advertisers will hold their first luncheon meeting of the Fall season at the Lawyers Club next Monday. Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States,

The MacGregor Arctic expedition departed from St. Johns, Nfld., late Saturday evening, bound for Port Newark, N. J., after extensive repairs were completed on the supply ship, the General A. W. Greely.

A citywide market survey, made by the Cleveland Plan Survey Committee, has disclosed that Clevelanders will spend $67,000,000 between now and the first of the year, it was stated at a mass meeting of 12,000 salesmen tonight.

A daughter, their first child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. James Daniel Thompson of Round Hill Road on Sept. 13 at the Greenwich Hospital. Mrs. Thompson is the former Miss Peggy Conklin and is known by that name on the stage and in motion pictures.
The Senators gained a split in their final series of the year with the Tigers by scoring a 12-to-2 victory today behind the five-hit pitching of Pete Appleton.

The 25 per cent increase in coach fares which the railroads in the East put in effect on July 7 has been a failure to date in the light of increasing revenues, railroad officials conceded yesterday. The refusal of omnibus companies to cooperate, it is understood, has had much to do with the unsatisfactory showing.

The General Education Board, now approaching liquidation, has spent $255, 334, 670 toward the progress of education since its inception in 1902, according to a report made public yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the board.

Three New York.City high school pupils have received freshman scholarships in the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Artsas a result of a competitive examination, it was announced yesterday by Dean E. Raymond Bossange.

In ananticipation of heavy scrimmage tomorrow Cornell's football squad was given comparatively light practice today. Signal drill, work on fundamental, a tag scrimmage between the first and second teams, heavier contact between the two top lines and passing for the backs comprised the double workout. After this week the squad will practice only once a day.

Undeterred by the heavy rain, Columbia's football squad entered its second week of training yesterday at Baker Field, continuing the double workouts and capping the sessions with a 60-minute scrimmage. Pointing for the opening game with Yale Oct. 1, Coach Lou Little decided to take advantage of the rain and water-soaked field to test his team's ball handling and play execution under adverse conditions.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today reserved decision on a protest by counsel for the General Protective Committee for the Utilities Power and Light Corporation's security holders.

The tenure of office of the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas as vicar of historic St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, at Broadway, Fulton and Vesey Streets, ended yesterday with his retirement on a pension at the age of 68.
Dr. Alexander Fraser, former Professor of Pathological History at New York University and Bellevue Medical College, died Sunday night at his country home in Beechurst, L. I.

In one hour shortly before dawn yesterday, while the Brownsville section of Brooklyn slumbered in its crowded tenements, a person described by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy as probably an "alcoholic pyromaniac," started fires in the hallways or basements of nine multiple dwellings, endangering the lives of more than 150 persons. None was killed or injured.

Mrs. Fred Wettach Jr., the former Barbara Guggenheim, recently obtained a divorce from the wellknown sportsman in Aston, Idaho, it was disclosed yesterday. At the Eatontown (N. J.) estate where they had been living Mr. Wettach said that his wife had obtained the custody of their 8-yearold son and that she had agreed unofficially to permit the child to spend six months with him each year.

The last of the contents of William C. Durant's shore estate were sold at public auction today for $1,544, raising to $111,778 the amount realized since the former automobile man opened the six-day sale last Tuesday to raise cash. Of this amount $44,000 was for his show-place home.

The United States, experts said today, will place on her economic blacklist any Sudeten territory handed over to Germany by Czechoslovakia. They added that the present trade agreement between the United States and Czechoslovakia, which went into effect April 15, would probably have to be revised if Czechoslovakia was partitioned.

Motorman Daniel Healy abruptly halted his Eighth Avenue Independent Subway local train at 10:50 A. M. yesterday, climbed down from his cab and rescued a dirty white dog that had strayed onto the southbound tracks between the 125th and 116th Street stations.

The twenty-second annual Eastern States Exposition Horse Show opened tonight in the Coliseum with a liberal entry list from the New York district. Despite an all-day and all-night rain, the Coliseum was filled.

It is "almost a compliment to a man's ability" to become afflicted with peptic ulcers, Dr. Howard Gray, Mayo Clinic surgeon, told the American Association of Railway Surgeons at their annual convention today.

First steps toward formation of a national conference of licensed beverage associations will be taken at a luncheon at the Hotel Chelsea here tomorrow with delegates from six States attending. The sessions will be held in conjunction with the sixth annual convention of the New Jersey Licensed

Running through all the speeches at today's opening sessions of the seventh International Management Congress was a note of anxiety over threats of war in Europe, coupled with a consensus that the way to political peace among nations lies through economic cooperation.

The reciprocity of interests between the countries of North and South America was stressed by John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, here today on his .arrival from Mexico.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain will resume conversations with Chancellor Adolf Hitler Wednesday at Godesberg, Germany, it was reported in official quarters here today.
Four players were shifted to the second team today in a shake-up of Penn's football team by Coach George Munger.

Points raised by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company last week in its "statement of public policy" advertisements attacking proposed Federal chain store tax legislation are disputed in a release sent out yesterday by the National Association of Retail Grocers, who favor the Federal tax on chains.

L. H. Paul Chapin, lawyer and investment counsel, who was vice president of Clarke, Sinsabaugh Co., died yesterday at his home, 215 East Seventy-second Street, of a heart attack after a brief illness.

Federal Judge H. P. Burke today ordered an Italian woman and her son to forfeit their life savings, two gold bricks valued at $1,250, to the government. Mrs. Virginia Venturoli and her son, Robert, 21, did not declare the bricks when she came through the customs.

An irregular price recovery developed yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange on a sharply reduced volume of trading. While the most marked improvement was in the pivotal foreign government dollar obligations as a result of week-end developments in the European situation, good buying also was apparent in certain sections of the domestic corporation list.

Non-ferrous metal prices were advanced again yesterday in the domestic market, making the second increase within a week. Lead and zinc prices were marked up 10 points each and refined copper 1/8 cent a pound. Yesterday's increases as well as last week's were influenced almost entirely by prices abroad, which have been advancing sharply as a result of political developments in Europe.

The "strike" of parents and children against the transfer of 180 pupils from one Bronx elementary school to another was virtually at an end yesterday with the return of all but eighteen pupils who are expected to resume their attendance tomorrow.

Excluding a few strictly choice and prime fed steers and yearlings the general market was fully 25 cents lower, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Top again remained steady at $13.35, but at $12 down the market was very slow and draggy. Lambs sold weak to lower, but hogs showed a little strength when the supply was relatively small for the initial session of the week.

The last scheduled hearing before the Transit Commission on the $23,000,000 Atlantic Avenue grade crossing elimination plan for Brooklyn was held yesterday, and the Transit Commission reserved decision. Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll went on record, the former through a presented statement and the latter in person, against the plan.
William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, selected yesterday from a group of seven models two new uniforms to be worn by the department's drivers and sweepers.

In a pessimistic mood deepened by the conviction that modern man has rubbed away his thin veneer of civilization, Justice James Clark McReynolds of the United States Supreme Court returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary last night after a six-week tour of Europe.

Canada was surprised and perhaps disillusioned by Britain's consent to the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia, but on the whole relieved that war was not to be risked over the issue. Prime Minister Mackenzie King is passionately opposed to war and the possibility of the Dominion's embroilment contained so many threats to Canadian unity that members of his government have been having sleepless nights over the prospects.

Reserving decision yesterday at the close of a second hearing on the revocation of a pawnbroker's license, Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, said that recommendations to the Police and License Departments for the tightening of rules governing pawnbrokers would be the outcome of the inquiry. Mayor La Guardia had ordered the inquiry.

War Minister Leslie Hore-Belisha ordered speedy creation of a new section in the British Army reserve today to provide warrant officers and non-commissioned officers "to fill responsible positions on mobilization."

Indicating that he still is "far from satisfied" with his inquiry into the 1935 Jules Martin slaying, Pistrict Attorney Charles J. Ranney continued his investigation today by calling a Cohoes, N. Y., physician before the Rensselaer County grand jury.

The news from London and Paris showing that amputation of the Sudeten Germans from Czechoslovakia is no longer regarded as outside the field of practical politics further relieved Italian public opinion today.
Ralph Morgan was elected president of the Screen Actors Guild by a three-to-one margin over Melvyn Douglas, a count of the ballots cast last week disclosed today.

AMERTCA AND THE STRIFE OF EUROPE, by J. Fred Rippy. (University of Chicago Press, $2.) A study of the effect of European unrest on American history. BELINDA AND THE SINGING CLOCK, by Ethel Calvert Phillips. (Houghton Mifflin, $1.75.)

This was the morning after the night before for the Yankees. Floored by the reaction to an old-fashioned Yankee victory celebration, the champions touched new lows in several directions as they bade farewell for the year to the Mound City.
This cradle of Nazism and favorite city of Chancellor Adolf Hitler is hoping eagerly that peace will emerge from Herr Hitler's next meeting with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain.

Seabiscuit, famed rival of War Admiral, is scheduled to run at Belmont Park today in what will mark the Pacific Coast star's first appearance on a New York track this year as well as his first here since the dispute over top handicap honors became acute.

After all, it won't be Robert Goldstein who presents "Spring Meeting" here, though he had been reported to hold an option. It will be Lee Ephraim and Gladys Cooper, the latter to be also a leading light of a cast that will further include A. E. Matthews, Jean Caddell and Robert Flemyng.
Bids for the construction of three 35,000-ton battleships, provided for at the last session of Congress, will be opened Oct. 19, the Navy Department announced today.

In this State, as in any other, ability, integrity and temperament, not sex, should be the determining factors in the selection of a Supreme Court Justice. Nevertheless, many have come to feel not only that the right woman may fairly aspire to so high an office but that a woman's humanitarian outlook should prove to be a healthy leaven in the administration of the law.

Their ranks thinned, the hardy riders remaining in the six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden nevertheless went through their paces with unabated speed and zeal last night. Only twelve of the fifteen teams that started the race Sunday night were left in the competition when the first series of sprints was run off last night.
Horace Trumbauer, architect who had designed college buildings, hotels, club and office buildings and many residences, died yesterday in his seventieth year.

It was officially announced today that frontier guards on the Czech border had been reinforced by special detachments of the Frontier Defense Corps. The action was taken, the announcement said, because of Czech military measures and because many Czech deserters had appeared in Polish territory.

The United States Maritime Commission announced yesterday that a fortnightly freight service between the east coasts of North and South America would be started on Sept. 29 by a fleet of six cargo ships of the American Republics Line under the management of the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc.

Luncheon, Lions Club of New York, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "The Effect of a European War Upon American Business and Finance," Major Bronson Foster. Luncheon, League of Nations Association, Town Hall Club, 12:30 P. M. Leon Jouhaux, leader of the French trade unions, guest of honor.

Despondent because his parents had overriden his wishes in the selection of a college, Burt G. Metz Jr., 19 years old, of 26 Myron Avenue, Neptune City, near here, shot himself through the head at his home this morning and died three hours later in Fitkin Memorial Hospital.

The resignation of Dr. William A. Boylan, president of Brooklyn College, who has been on a six-month leave because of illness, was accepted last night by the Board of Higher Education at a meeting held in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. The board adopted a resolution of regret.

About 4,000 men of the Packard sales force and about 250 automobile editors and special writers today heard Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, and M. M. Gilman, vice president and general manager, predict a good year for the industry and the company.

The Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employes began suit yesterday in Federal Court to compel the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company to recognize it as bargaining representative of its maintenance of way employes in compliance with an order issued by the National Mediation Board last May 21.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's next move in the swiftly changing diplomatic struggle over Czechoslovakia will be to ask Chancellor Adolf Hitler for some peaceful gesture that will reduce the present tension along the Czech-German frontier.

The International Television Radio Corporation of Jersey City has completed an arrangement with the investment firm of Mayhew Reily for distributing 1,000,000 shares of its $1-par-value common capital stock, it was announced yesterday by William H. Priess, president of the corporation.

Federal agents seized 650 ounces of narcotics today in a raid on an office suite which they said was the distributing point for much of the illegal traffic in Indiana, Illinois, Michigan and Minnesota.

The Massachusetts primary campaign, largely devoid of national issues, but boasting a record list of 1,766 candidates, closed tonight. Governor F. Hurley, a Democrat, and each of his/three opponents, Lieutenant Governor Francis E. Kelly, former Governor James M.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued a stop order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement covering an issue of 340,000 shares of common stock of Platoro Gold Mines, Inc. The commission held that the registration statement included untrue statements of material facts and failed to state material facts necessary to make other statements not misleading.

The organization of the Federal Project Workers, a union of persons on government work relief which is apparently to be associated with the American Federation of Labor, is an event that will be widely regarded with mixed feelings.

Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, today denied charges made by Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio, who accused the board of playing "dirty politics." In acknowledging receipt of Mr. Davey's letter, Mr. Altmeyer said:
The Loyalist lines continued to hold firm before attacks on the second day of the Rebel counter-offensive in the Ebro sector as the battle continued without respite, tonight's communique says.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary last night from England where he has been preparing for his new assignment as British High Commissioner in Canada.
Leslie, Lady Doverdale, will return to the Ambassador today from Newport, where she has been visiting Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse. She will sail later for her home in England.

RKO today announced the purchase of "Balloon Buster," by Frank Luke Jr., army aviator, and Norman S. Hall, as a vehicle for Douglas Fairbanks Jr. The story deals with World War lighter-thanair flying and will probably be Fairbanks's next picture for the studio.

Belated breaking of a Republican harmony pact in Hudson County and sharp factional fights in both parties for Congressional and legislative nominations elsewhere in the State promised tonight to make tomorrow's primary elections unusually lively.

Both physicians and the public cannot but approve the decision of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association to recede from its previous position and, on the whole, to endorse the Government's program with the exception of the provision for compulsory health insurance.

Speaking before the Conference of the United Lutheran Synod of New York here today, the Rev. Frederick Foerster of Jeffersonville said that individualism was one of the chief factors preventing the church from getting the support it needs to supply the real benefits of a Christian life.
American Investment Company of Illinois and Subsidiaries--Six months to June 30: Net income after interest, taxes and other charges, but before amortization of development costs, $330,876.

The advancing Japanese have occupied Hwangchwan and Shangeheng in southeastern Honan, and Wusueh, on the Yangtze, above Kiukiang, gaining thereby three strategic points in the outer defense zone of the Hankow area.

Falcon Shaw Bond, 42 years old, of 1,058 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, a former electrician in the navy who was alleged to have conducted two fraudulent stock promotion schemes, was summarily arrested yesterday in Attorney General John J. Bennett's office in this city in an investigation by Assistant State

The younger children of Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy have been sent from the London Embassy to Southern Ireland "in order to be away from any possible bombings in England in the event of sudden declaration of war," the children's grandfather, former Mayor John F. Fitzgerald of this city, revealed today.

Miss Gladys Adelaide Durand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Celestin A. Durand of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to George A. Corroon of Massapequa, L. I., which will take place here in St. Joseph's Church on Oct. 1.

The National Fertilizer Association's wholesale commodity price index rose last week to the highest level recorded since the first of August. This index in the week ended Sept. 17 stood at 73.8 per cent of the 192628 average, against 73.6 in the preceding week, 72.9 a month ago and 87.6 a year ago.

Dr. Mary G. Hood, a pioneer in the field of medicine as a profession for women, died today at the Waltham Hospital after an illness of two months. Her age was 88. She had served on the board of directors and as staff physician of the Baptist and Vincent Memorial Hospitals here.
Heavy European buying of frigorifico hides in the Argentine market yesterday lifted prices there by 3/8 cent, and sales of appreciable quantities were made at 10 7-16 cents for standard frigorificos.

THE latest Houghton Mifflin Fellowship Prize novel is a nice piece of work, intelligently managed and the first thing of its kind, so far as I know, in modern American fiction. Called "Old Haven,"* it is a story of The Netherlands written by David Cornel DeJong, who came to this country when he was a boy of 13 or so.

Lieut. Col. Joseph H. Levey, acting chairman of the British ORT organization, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to confer with American Jews on a fund-raising campaign to aid the International ORT in the maintenance of Jewish training camps and schools in Germany.

The revolt among WPA employes against the activities of the Workers Alliance, left-wing organization of the unemployed and relief recipients, gathered momentum yeterday with the announcement of the establishment of the WPA Employes Association of America.

A sharp attack on finishers for disclaiming responsibility for fabric shrinkage once the "goods have been removed from the original wrapping and subjected to any handling," was launched yesterday by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers.

Thomas Powers of New York observed his eighty-fourth birthday tonight with a dinner for a company of fifty-two at the Muenchinger-King. Eighteen canary birds sang in cages distributed about the table, which had been decorated in sunken-garden effect. There was also music by an orchestra.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Foster Clark of the Mountain Lake Club, Florida and Interlaken, Oquossoc, Me., formerly of North Attleboro, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Henrietta Foster Clark, to Dr. Dudley Buck Blossom of this city.

Approval was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission of applications by the Lone Star Gas Corporation and several of its subsidiaries for authority to make a series of transactions to revise the security structure of the Lone Star system.

Death Reported Retired Fireman Dennis Morrisey, formerely a member of Engine Co. 21, residing at 2,260 Andrews Ave., Bronx, died Sept. 17. Funeral will take place from Walterx Funeral Home, 19Gth St. and Grand Concourse. Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Tuesday, Sept. 20. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

The contemplated demolition of the old Fifth Avenue Theatre, on the northwest corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street, moved nearer to realization yesterday, when the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the owner, filed preliminary specifications for razing the theatre and reducing the Broadway frontage to a one-story taxpayer.

Tension lessened along the Florida east coast late tonight as Grady Norton of the Weather Bureau predicted the danger from a tropical hurricane would "soon be past" if the hurricane continued a reported change of course.

A meeting of 4,000 members of the three truckmen's locals, who have nearly paralyzed truck shipments here since they started their "outlaw" strike last Thursday, broke up early today in a complete deadlock, but shortly afterward Acting Mayor Newbold Morris announced that negotiations between the union and the operators would be resumed at 10:30 o'clock this morning at City Hall.
Every one of 1,010 persons who appeared in Traffic Court yesterday paid a fine, with the result that for the first time in months no one was sent to jail from that court.

A call for substitute teachers to relieve regular teachers observing the Jewish holy days on Sept. 26 and Oct. 5 was issued yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, in a circular to school officials noting that in the past the supply of substitutes on these days had been inadequate.

Comparatively light voting throughout the city, except for a few key districts where campaign rivalry has been strong, is expected to feature today's primary election in New York City and New York State.

Dartmouth's football prospects received a rough shock today when Trainer Rollie Bevan and team physician Joe Pollard announced that Dan Dacey, second-string right guard, considered by Coach Blaik one of the five most promising newcomers, will be lost to the Big Green for the rest of the season.

A cloister garden, the gift of Edward Payson Bullard of Bridgeport, Conn., to Mount Holyoke College in memory of his wife, Mary Deacon Bullard, 1896, has been announced for the college. The garden, designed by Arthur A. Shurcliff of Boston, landscape architect, will be in a sheltered corner formed by the adjoining of Mary Lyon Administration Building and the new Abbey Memorial Chapel on tne campus.
The dates for the first public sales in this country of items from the art collections of William Randolph Hearst were announced yesterday by the Hearst Executive Offices, 959 Eighth Avenue.

Representatives of the Associated Bedding Manufacturers of Greater New York signed a one-year collective bargaining agreement yesterday with Bedding Local 140 of the United Furniture Workers of America, affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, at the offices of the State Mediation Board, 366 Broadway.
The Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, reported today that Pope Pius in addressing a group of French pilgrims yesterday said that there was an evident "falsity" in the totalitarian State idea.
The Rev. John F. O'Brien, Professor of English at Villanova College, died today at the age of 45. He had been at Villanova thirteen years.
New York's Agriculture Department announced today that about 93 per cent of dairy farmers serving the Buffalo area had approved a proposed milk marketing order fixing prices to be paid producers.

Charles A. Harnett, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced today that revocations of licenses and registrations for the first eight months of the year totaled 4,133, a decrease of 145 from a similar period last year.

The stock market, completely attuned to the European situation, took cognizance of the BritishFrench proposals to capitulate to the demands of Hitler for the ceding of the Sudeten districts of Czechoslovakia to Germany to avert a new world war.
Steel operations for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 47.3 per cent of ingot capacity, according to telegraphic advices received by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Quincy, Omaha Kansas City Railroad, which on May 20 asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to abandon its entire 250 miles, of line between Quincy, Ill., and Kansas City, Mo., and to wind up its affairs,

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, reaffirmed today for the final quarter of 1938 all its prices of steel except rails, which it reduced $2.50 a ton, and all track materials, which it cut proportionately.

The winners in the National Soap Sculpture Committee's fourteenth annual competition for small sculptures in white soap were announced yesterday in the toy department of R. H. Macy Co., where the prizewinning pieces are on display.

Bert Niehoff, who played second base for the Giants twenty years ago, yesterday was named manager of the Jersey City club, Giant farm in the International League. Niehoff succeeds Hank DeBerry, who took over the club after Travis Jackson was relieved as pilot and rejoined the Giants as coach several weeks ago.

With 133 delegates representing 126 locals in attendance, the third annual international convention of the United Rubber Workers of America, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, opened here today in the Hotel Hildebrecht.

Acting Mayor Newbold Morris, who is attempting to mediate the teamsters strike, was notified yesterday afternoon by the -Publishers Association of New York City that the limited deliveries of newsprint that the strikers agreed to permit for the daily needs of tkle newspapers were falling short of reauirements.
Bobby Riggs, United States Davis Cup player, took a three-set exhibition tennis match today from Yvon Petra of the French cup contingent. The scores were 2-6, 6-2, 9-7.
Major James B. Ettridge, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, died yesterday at Walter Reed Hospital here, where he had been ill since July 3. His age was 55.

About 500 students and patrons attended the formal opening exersises at Adelphi Academy, 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. William Slater, head master, presided. He reported an enrollment of 451, the largest since 1929. The exercises were in the chapel.

Morris M. Townsend, in 1,045 Park Ave; Alfries Realty Corp, broker. Kenneth L. Bridges, Margaret J. Donaghy, in 151 E 80th St: Victor J. -Merker, in 177 E 74th St; Robert Emmet O'Boyle. in 116 E. 89th St; John J. Flynn, in 125 E 93d St; William A. Philip Thompson, in 114 E 84th St; Mrs. George' T. Mayo. Morris Becker, in 15 W 11th St; Byrne Bowman, Inc, brokers.

No tennis, No baseball games. Nothing but rain, followed by more rain. As one baseball student put it yesterday from underneath his umbrella: "The Cubs, Giants and Reds were rained out and the Pirates were rained in." Not bad. If the floods continue, the Pirates will have nothing to do except paddle right up to the world series in their war canoes.

Complaints that in East Rutherford and Lyndhurst unemployment relief has been denied to residents on strike at the Kearny plant of the United Cork Company will bring no action by Arthur Mudd, director of the State Financial Assistance commission. Mr. Mudd said today that he had no authority to interfere.

Despite the week-end weakness in Wall Street, the stock market here was generally firm today as most sections responded to the news of the AngloFrench agreement over the Czechoslovakian situation. Gilt-edge issues were steady,

President Roosevelt may make a personal appeal to the spokesmen for the nation's railroads tomorrow to withdraw their request for a 15 per cent wage reduction, it was reported authoritatively tonight.

The President, who is a great reader of the newspapers, could hardly have failed to note with deep interest the editorial suggestion of The Toronto Globe and Mail, echoed hopefully in France by Leon Blum and the Petit Journal, that he call a conference to arrange a permanent peace for Europe.

More than 200 members of the American Legion who were unable to go out to the current convention at Los Angeles were guests of the Women. World War Veterans at a reception and dance last night at the Hotel Astor.

Sharp increases in the rates on marine war risk insurance, amounting in some cases to more than 100 times the premiums charged less than a month ago, were ordered today by the joint rating committee of the underwriters.

The Celotex Corporation reported yesterday for the three months ended on July 31 a net profit of $161,319 after charges. The net was equal, after dividend requirements on 29,072 shares of 5 per cent preferred stock to 40 cents each on 312,429 shares of common. No provision for Federal income or undistributed profits taxes was necessary because of statutory deductions in excess of net profit.
Several thousand Western and Central New York farmers will face the Winter in a more weakened financial condition than they were in a year ago, Wilburn Chase, Federal Land Bank director, said today.

Cigarette prices In the retail market here yesterday continued to refleet the sharp competition that has developed with increasing intensity since the special cigarette sales tax was levied by the city.

Miss Margery Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Reid of 55 East Ninety-third Street, was married here to Richard Bolles Paddock Jr., a grandnephew of General John J. Pershing, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by the Rev. Francis X. Talbot.

The Prague Government was reported to have asked France if she would stand by her alliance in case Czechoslovakia elected to reject the AngloFrench plan for cession of the Sudeten districts to Germany. On the reply from Paris will depend Prague's answer to the proposal.

Although Moscow officials and the press remain silent on what the Soviet Union will do in the event of war, there is a growing feeling among foreign diplomats here that war is coming and that the Soviet likely will be involved.

At a meeting of the board of directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation yesterday, Edwin P. Maynard and Cary D. Waters were elected directors to fill vacancies caused by the deaths of Thomas L. Chadbourne and James H. Post.

Harvard's football sessions today involved no scrimmage. Two strenuous ones were held last week, and this afternoon there was a general review of mistakes, and then a fresh start toward the Crimson's attack.

T. J. Hill's White Cockade made his second start in three days after a long lay-off and won the Belair Handicap, a Grade C sprint of six furlongs, today. On a sloppy track, the son of Diavolo led at every post and returned $7.60 in the mutuels.

The name of Benedict Arnold,. Revolutionary hero of the Battle of Saratoga, finally has been inscribed on a monument erected at the battlefield. Arnold, who rode his black horse into the ranks of the British and turned the tide of the decisive battle of the Revolutionary

The task of teaching old dogs new tricks does not quite rate with the labors of Hercules in difficulty, but in this day and age it will suffice until something harder comes along. That is the precise problem that is confronting Harvey Harman in his first season as coach at Rutgers, one of the twin fountainheads of American football.

The Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop,of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, was the principal speaker at the opening session of the annual Fall conference of the clergy of the diocese at the Howell House here tonight.
Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Minister to London, apparently cracked today under the severe strain of watching the losing battle to preserve the country his father helped to found.

Even though the Czechs fight single-handed against Germany, Adolf Hitler may be in for a staggering surprise. Their stubborn and prolonged resistance may stir the world's admiration for the gallant underdog and other nations may be drawn in when they learn that Chancellor Hitler's army is not the German Army of 1914-18.

Pauline Frederick, star of the stage and silent pictures, died at her home today, apparently from asthma and a heart attack. Her age was 53. An inhalator squad worked for an hour in an effort to revive her. She was first stricken by an asthma attack last Friday and had been under the care of a nurse and physician.

Miss Ruth Charlotte wiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Wiss of South Orange, was married tonight to Waldron Merry Ward Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward of Summit, in Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit. The rector, the Rev. Walter O. Kinsolving, performed the ceremony.

A number of Manhattan business buildings and private dwellings were involved in leasing contracts announced yesterday. The Leonardo Da Vinci Art School, due to the need for larger quarters resulting from' increased enrollment, leased from the Brotherhood of Electric Workers, Inc., the five-story building at 130 East Sixteenth Street, through A. Q. Orza, broker. This structure is on a plot 25 by 103.3 feet.

Sudeten German refugees tonight told Czechoslovakia by radio that "with gun in hand we are going to fight for our freedom." This call to arms was sent across the Czechoslovak-German frontier from a mass meeting at which 5,000 refugees gathered in the Dresden Exhibition Hall shouting "We are going home to the Reich."

The United States appeared today to be clinging tenaciously to a non-interventionist policy in the face of the Anglo-French decision to partition Czechoslovakia, just as it did last week when the critical situation carried a threat of immediate war.
Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovak Minister to London, apparently cracked today under the severe strain of watching the losing battle to preserve the country his father helped to found.

Even though the Czechs fight single-handed against Germany, Adolf Hitler may be in for a staggering surprise. Their stubborn and prolonged resistance may stir the world's admiration for the gallant underdog and other nations may be drawn in when they learn that Chancellor Hitler's army is not the German Army of 1914-18.

Pauline Frederick, star of the stage and silent pictures, died at her home today, apparently from asthma and a heart attack. Her age was 53. An inhalator squad worked for an hour in an effort to revive her. She was first stricken by an asthma attack last Friday and had been under the care of a nurse and physician.
A thousand broadsilk workers, who have been on strike for a week, ratified today a contract negotiated with the Silk and Rayon Manufacturers Association,
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 14:

How many people in this city, which draws every day new recruits from small towns, read piously the home weekly? There must be a lot of them, and papers of that sort are always interesting for their pictures of life and society in their communities.

Retail grocery stores have sufficient stocks of non-perishable foods to carry them for two weeks, officials of chain stores and of independent retail grocery groups asserted here yesterday. Perishable goods. it was said, in an emergency could be trucked in from near-by communities by retailers using their own trucks.

The Treasury's weekly sale of approximately $100,000,000 of ninety-oneday bills today resulted in an average interest rate of 0.106 per cent, compared with 0.103 for the paper sold last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Supreme Court Justice William F. Love today signed a court order ending almost two years of "imprisonment" for Idaho, dog of Brockport; N. Y., which was sentenced in 1936 to be confined for two years after he was accused of causing a boy to drown in the State Barge Canal.

The Chile-American Association commemorated the 128th anniversary of the independence of Chile yesterday with a reception at the Hotel Roosevelt in honor of the Chilean Army and Carabinero cavalry teams, which arrived here recently to compete in American horse shows.

Increases in local fares of from 4 to 5 cents on the Forty-second Street ferry of the West Shore Railroad Company and from 6 to 8 cents on its Cortlandt Street ferry from New York City to Weehawken, N. J., were recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report by Examiner Charles M. Bardwell.

Twenty-seven candidates reported to Coach Jack McDonald today at Hofstra College for the first regular football drill of the season. The session was confined to work in the gym because of the heavy rain.

The Red Wings' semi-final Ininternational League play-off series with the champion Bears was postponed tonight by showers for the third time within a week. The Wings, who hold a 3-1 lead over Newark, will seek to close the series tomorrow night.

Germany's annexation of Czechoslovakia's industrialized Sudeten German area was pictured by Prague industrial leaders today as a move that would have far-reaching and possibly disastrous effects on the economic life of the republic.

With more than 700 guests in attendance, completion of the remodeled first floor of Franklin Simon Co. was celebrated at an informal "open house" at the store last night. The first, or street floor, was officially opened yesterday afternoon.

President Roosevelt today proclaimed the Inter-American Radio Communications Convention, signed at Havana last Dec. 13 by the United States and fourteen other American countries. Signers included Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Chile, Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Haiti, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela.

Speakers at the convention of the National Industrial Stores Association, which opened here today, appealed for modernization of company-owned stores as an aid not only to the stores but to the companies they represent.

The Bower Roller Bearing Company of Detroit and the Ahlberg Bearing Company of Chicago announced yesterday that they had concluded a ten-year contract and agreement whereby Ahlberg, with its nation-wide distribution, will become the exclusive sales representative of Bower in the industrial field.

Arthur H. DuGrenier, Inc. in International Building, Rockefeller Center. Schaff Coles, giftware. in 225 5th Ave; Leo C. Weiss, ladies' garments, in 152 Madison Ave: Marion Goldberg, millinery. in 15-19 E 26th St; Cross Brown Co, broker.
Going to the front at the start, B. M. Smith's Frozen Mask outclassed four rivals in the feature race at Rockingham today before about 7,500 enthusiasts who defied the rain.
Unemployed Negroes were warned tonight by Mayor John O. Byrd to get out of town as the result of a Saturday night race riot in which one Negro was killed, another wounded and twenty-one arrested.

Two youngsters--Miss Mollie Tyson, Temple University co-ed, and Gar Wood Jr.--drove their speed boats to new world records today on the Tennessee River. The new amateur marks were made in races against time over a mile straightaway as the closing events of the national outboard regatta.

Mayor La Guardia made a direct appeal today to members of the American Legion attending the Opening session of their national convention here to stand firmly behind the national government in whatever policy it adopted in its dealings with Germany, France and England.

Mike Belloise, 128 1/4, of the Bronx, New York State featherweight champion, knocked out Joey Wach, 127 3/4, East Side, in 2:10 of the third session of their listed eight-round feature bout on the first boxing program of the season at the St. Nicholas Palace before 3,000 persons last night.

Settlement of two labor disputes Involving the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board. Reinstatement of fifteen employes and payment of $22,291 were conditions of the settlement.
J. Edgar Hoover, addressing an American Legion banquet tonight, labeled communism and fascism "two twin horrid, spectral growths of an alien soil and an alien spirit."

Secretary Morgenthau talked at his office this afternoon with V. A. L. Mallet, counselor of the British Embassy. Also present at the conference was Archie Lochhead, who manages the Treasury's stabilization fund.

After hearing strong protests from thirty estate owners in the Purchase Community House tonight, local and State officials agreed to shelve a plan to straighten and widen Purchase Street, which winds for four miles through the estates between Westchester Avenue and Lake Street.

Police made fifty-five arrests of pickets during the first day of the building trades strike, which began this morning in the Paris district, as called by the Central Union Council. The tie-up is 80 per cent complete on union jobs, the remainder being exempt as "official" or national defense work.
Charles Frederick Scott, publisher of The Iola Register, who had served as a Kansas Representative from 1901 to 1911, died last night at the age of 78.

Samuel M. Friedman sold to the Twelfth Street Realty Company thefour-story flat with three stores at 541 Bergenline Avenue, West New York, on a plot 303 by 95 feet. The sale was subject to a $24,600 mortgage held y the Hoboken Bank for Savings.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that 4,222,935 pounds of steel has been placed in position in the construction of the new passenger and cargo liner which is being built at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company as replacement for the Leviathan.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation has exercised its remaining options on the capital shares of Loft, Inc., the latter company told the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The investment trust took up 275,000 shares at $1.50 a share and 100,000 shares at $2, making the total consideration $612,500.

Fog and rain blanketed the harbor yesterday, delaying ocean liners carrying nearly 3,000 passengers, numerous freighters and other craft. In the city and the metropolitan area the intermittent and heavy rainfalls flooded cellars and roadways.

Rises in traffic accidents and numbers of injured were offset last week by a drop in fatalities, as compared with figures covering the corresponding period last year, the safety bureau of the Police Department showed.

Driving to this village, only three miles from the frontier, one must pass through the strong line of fortifications built as the first line of defense; Just before formidable barbed wire entanglements, liberally interspersed with tank traps, a group of German peasant women in blue aprons were cutting tall grass with long handled sickles.

Plans were filed in the Bronx yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for the fourth group of structures in the institution's proposed development on the grounds of the old Catholic Protectory.

24th St, 327 E, 25x98.9; Leopoldine Knuth to Broadeagle Realty Corp, 154 E 79th St; mtg $8,500 ($3.50). 124th St, 206 E, 27.10x100.11; /Pauline Holding Corp to Paul J. Siegener, 38 W 96th St; mtg $7,500 ($5).

" Blue and Gray Day" featured the observance today of the Chickamauga celebration here, when Confederate and Union veterans joined hands in a memorial service on the battlefield where seventy-five years ago they were locked in struggle.

Trading in steer beef fair, most other classes slow, in local markets yesterday. Choice and prime steer beef in very moderate supply, other grades normal. Supplies of other classes liberal. Fresh pork cuts mostly weak to lower, calf and veal weak to lower. Other classes mostly unchanged. Kosher beef opened strong to higher. Other kosher meats mostly steady. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow.

The monthly meeting of the Trade Association Executives in New York City, to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania next Tuesday, will be devoted to a discussion of "Studies of the Temporary National Economic Committee, with Special Emphasis Upon the Trade Association

An advance of $1 a ton in pig iron for delivery in the fourth quarter of this year, effective on Sept. 27, was announced here late today by the Interlake Iron Corporation, a leading Northern producer.

Following is the list of nominees of the Democratic, Republican, American. Labor and Socialist parties designated in the primary election yesterday. Where more than one name appears in the same district the result was inconclusive at the time this edition went to press. Asterisk denotes incumbent.

Assemblyman Leonard W. Hall, unoposed Repulican designee for Representative, "conceded" his "defeat" tonight for the party nomination for Assemblyman in the Second district to Norman F. Penny of Manhasset, also an organization designee, who was nominated by write-ins.

Sir John Weir, K. C. V. O., physician to King George VI and senior physician of the London Homeopathic Hospital, England, today was elected a member of the Homeopathic Medical Society of the State of Pennsylvania.

A number of interested sportsmen have written us recently on the prospects for duck shooting this year, and every one seems to be enthusiastic. The reports from the Canadian breeding areas are also very encouraging, and a number of Maine sportsmen say the young birds hatched in that State bad a fine rearing season.

Twelve years ago Harvard expected a beating by Geneva in its opening game and got it, 17 to 6. Not since then has a first-day opponent been regarded so seriously as is Tuss McLaughry's Brown eleven, which will come to the stadium Oct. 1.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 19: COLONEL Alfonte, W. A., Inf., Philippine Dept., to headquarters, Presidio of San Francisco, Calif: to sail from Manila about Oct. 31.
County Register William F. Condon of Yonkers defeated Joshua M. Fiero Jr., also of Yonkers, in the primaries today for the Republican nomination for State Senator in the twenty-sixth district.
Conferences on proposed new age contracts for pier workers and towboat employes failed to produce agreement yesterday and answere announced for future scussions.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 20, unless specified: At Hong Kong: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards, Paul Jones. At Guantanamo: Bagaducs, Trinity, YT 129.

Deputy United States Marshal Charles L. Parker died last night in a Panama hospital of a heart attack. His age was 62. Born in Washington, D. C., on Aug. 16, 1876, he was one of the few remaining members of the Society f Incas, composed of those engaged in construction of the Panama Canal in 1904.

Many of us can look back nearly a quarter of a century, with that eheu fugaces! feeling that afflicts people in the so-called prime of life, to the days when the Lewisohn sisters unexpectedly transformed a social settlement's dancing and dramatic classes into a theatre that drew the carriage trade from far uptown.

Mayor Charles 0. Martens, Republican, who will be his party's candidate for his eleventh consecutive two-year term, was unopposed in the primary election here today, as was the only Democratic candidate, Edward J. Finneran.

Executors of the estate of Henry W. Breyer, ice cream manufacturer, today challenged an estate tax deficiency' assessment of $10,732,916 and asked the Board of Tax Appeals to order -a refund of $195,293, which they said represented an overpayment of taxes.

The three candidates for nomination for Representative in the Sixteenth Congressional District, John J. O'Connor, Democratic incumbent; James H. Fay, his opponent for the Democratic nomination and unopposed for the Labor party nomination, and Allen W. Dulles,
