A large group of bers of the Artists and Golf Assaociation braved the into mittent rain to participate in annual Fall one-day tournament the organization at the Not Hempstead Country Club today.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Janney, daughter of Mrs. Cornelius Lynde of this place and of Laurence A. Janney of Stamford, Conn., to Walter Miles Harvey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey of New York.
Twelve persons were killed and more than 100 injured early today in the collision of two Southern Pacific passenger trains on a siding at Tortuga, a switching point eleven miles east of here.

Japanese casualties in the Yangtze Valley since the middle of July have been more than 70,000, General Cheng Chen, commander of the Central China war area, reported today, according to a Central News Agency dispatch from the South Yangtze front.

The conditional reply yesterday of the Prague government to the Anglo-French proposals to end the Central European crisis reached financial circles too late to enter as a market factor, but it is doubtful if its interpretation one way or another would have cut down the price strength which ruled throughout the day.

The apartment rental report comprised of lists of new tenants submitted yesterday by brokers and agencies represented a cross-section of residential neighborhoods on both East and West Sides of Manhattan and included buildings in Westchester and Long Island.

The first of the week's three musicals will make its appearance tonight at the Winter Garden. It is "You Never Know," and is identified in show business as the "Cole Porter show," that gentleman and Robert Katscher having written the music to a book by Siegfried Geyer and Karl Farkas, derived from the Geyer comedy, "Candle-Light;" seen here in 1929.

After brief funeral services in the Princeton University chapel today, attended by more than 2,000 persons, the body of Edward Dickinson Duffield, president of the Prudential Insurance Company, chairman of the board of trustees of Princeton University and former acting president of the university, was buried in Princeton Cemetery alongside those of his father, brother and first wife.

Representatives Bert Lord, Walter G. Andrews and John Taber won Republican contests by goodsized margins over Mayor Benjamin Ash of Johnson City, Malvin L. Payne and Charles P. Russell, respectively, all adherents of the Townsend plan.

In spite of the rain, the twentyourth annual flower show arranged ?y the American Dahlia Society opened yesterday at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, with more han 1,000 exhibits. The exhibition, which included 329 competitive classes, will close today.

The plot of vacant land, comprised of about 55,000 square feet, on Horace Harding, Boulevard, Ninety-fourth Place, Ninety-third Street. and Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, L. I., was sold by-the Edbro Realty Company, representing the estate of the late Edward W. Browning, to an investing client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., co-broker in the deal with Raymond E. Ryan.

The United States is turning Scott Field, the nation's interior air station, into a new nerve center and "brain factory." Last July the War Department announced it was shifting its headquarters staff here from Langley Field, Va., and transformation of what was an empty nest for blimps into the head station of the "GHQ" air force is under way now.

The ninety-second year of classes at City College will begin today when more than 8,000 students report to the College of Liberal Arts and Science, the School of Technology and the School of Business and Civic Administration.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May denied yesterday a motion by Councilman Abner C. Surpless to void a meeting of the Republican Judiciary Committee which previously had named former Supreme Court Justice Charles H. Kelby as chairman of the Second district's judicial convention in the old Appellate Division court room in Brooklyn on Oct. 3.
Weakened by rain, the front of a three-story brick house collapsed today. The wall dropped like a curtain, revealing one man dressing and another in bed. They were the only occupants.

The production division of the American Management Association will have a conference to discuss methods of keeping unit costs down at the Hotel Pennsylvania Nov. 9 and 10. A panel of manufacturing executives representing twelve major industries will tell of production methods and how they have brought about cost reductions.
The War Department announced today that many reserve officers had passed the requiredd examination and that 188 would be commissioned second lieutenants in the army air corps.
A proudly smiling Mayor La Guardia led almost 1,000 Legionnaires employed by New York City in a onehour march today as his city's contribution to the twentieth annual parade of the American Legion.

Deploring the "surrender" of France and Great Britain to. Hitler, Leon Jouhaux, general secretary of the General Federation of French Workers, declared yesterday that, despite this, the Western democracies would be forced to come to the assistance of Czechoslovakia in the event of war.

A chorus of protests has been evoked by a proposal to send koalas, the native bears, to the San Francisco Exposition as part of an exhibit including wallabies, wombats, ant-eating echidnas and parrots.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 17: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Silverman, M., Med. Corps, the Beaver. to Navy Recruiting Station, Pittsburgh, Pa., in November.

An unusual deal in which a New York manufacturer bought from a New England insurance company an important business property in Atlanta, Ga., was reported here yesterday. The transaction involved the twostory store building at 197-99 Peachtree Street, which has just been leased by the F. W. Woolworth Company for thirty years at a rental said to aggregate about $1,200,000.

Mrs. Edna Dickerson Andrews of New York died at the Westerly Hospital in Westerly today. The daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edmund A. Dickerson of Brooklyn, she was the widow of William H. Andrews of New York and Buffalo, former president of the Pratt Lambert Company.

The "strike" of- fifty children against their transfer from-one.elementary school in the Bronx o another, which has caused school authorities growing anxiety since the Fall term began, was officially ended yesterday when the parents agreed to send their children back to school.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State- Chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, State Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut as additional members of the committee on resolutions which will draft a tentative platform for presentation to the Democratic State Convention at Rochester next week.

Following is the text of the address of Premier Benito Mussolini here tonight: Blackshirts! I return among you in the twentieth year of (World War) victory, exactly sixteen years after my speech announcing the march on Rome.

Children representing seventeen different nationalities, who have worked and played harmoniously together during the Summer at the Avenue A Children's Gardens, sang and danced in a pageant of the nations in a celebration of harvest day at the gardens yesterday afternoon.

A new book of' stories by Ralph Bates, entitled "Sirocco," will be on the Spring list of Random House. A "Directory of Periodicals of Special Interest to the Blind" has been published by the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street.
Two platforms on the lower level of the Grand Central Terminal will be extended to make the boarding of trains easier for commuters, it was announced yesterday.

An attempt to smuggle heroin concealed in an ice cream container into the office of the United States marshal in the Federal Building at Foley Square was frustrated last Friday by an alert counterman employed in a Baxter Street restaurant, it was revealed yesterday.

The six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden was still anybody's race, or, at least, almost anybody's, as the pedal-pushing athletes remaining in the grind churned their way into the third twenty-four hour session last night. Competition since the start of the grind on Sunday night has been exceedingly close, and last night was no exception as the surprisingly fresh cyclists continued their endless circuits of the pine saucer.

Charles Gardner, who has held more than a half dozen public offices here, but never has been on the public payroll because all the jobs were nonsalaried, ended a whirlwind primary campaign today for the Democratic nomination for Sheriff.

Francois Latrychef de la cordon bleu, Chevalier of the Legion of Honour, Maitre Chef des Cuisines of the Hotel Savoy of London, which according to those conversant with such matters makes him the ranking chef of Europe, sat down to dinner here last night as the guest of honor of the American Culinary Federation, every member of which is a chef and an epicure.

Total traffic during August on the subway and elevated lines operated by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was 68,038,234, a decrease of 3,126,594, or about 4.39 per cent, compared to the corresponding period last year, according to the monthly report submitted by Thomas. E. Murray Jr., I. R. T.receiver, to Federal Judge Robert P: Patterson.

The combination of an unfamiliar course and a steady, heavy rain wasn't enough to hold back Richard F. Francis of the Merion Cricket Club as the thirty-fourth annual championship tournament of the United States Seniors' Golf Association got under way today at the Apawamis Club.

Perhaps it is just his natural modesty, but Captain Bill Wood, the new Army coach, refuses to admit that the Cadet eleven will be better than its immediate predecessor. However, nearly every one at the Point disagrees with him most wholeheartedly.

Miss Gertrude Marion Noonan, daughterr of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Noonan of this place, and Ernest Grant Keefer, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Keefer of Troy, were married here this morning in St. Patrick's Church by the Rev. J. B. McGarry, an uncle of the bride.

Distribution of major electrical appliances is about to enter a new stage of development where manufacturers will concentrate on sales of groups of products instead of the old method of selling items individually, Paul B. Zimmerman, vice president in charge of sales for the Norge Company, said yesterday. He spoke to members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at the group's weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Trading in city realty announced yesterday included a number of residential parcels up town. The five-story apartment building at 870 West 180th Street, one block north of the George Washington Bridge, was sold by the Fenswill Realty Corporation to a client of William L. Rosan, through Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers.

Reports of Czechoslovakia's acceptance of the Anglo-French proposals for the Sudetenland had a strengthening influence on the stock market here today, so prices Improved generally. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, while among the foreign loans German and Austrian bonds rose sharply, but Czechoslovak issues weakened.

Gerard M. Dahl, chairman of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, dropped yesterday a $3,100,000 suit which he had brought in. Supreme Court against the Chase National Bank and Albert H. Wiggin, formerly chief executive officer of the bank.
The United States Hotel, an old time show place here and one of the largest hotels in-the world, which had previously been sold for taxes, has again been sold by the city,

The Indians bowled over Washington, 9 to 1, today to continue a nip-andtuck race with the Red Sox for second place in the American League. Hal Trosky led the Cleveland attack on three Washington pitchers-Emil Leonard, Rene Monteagudo and Elon Hogsett-with three singles. Roy Weatherly, who has replaced Earl Averill in center field, contributed a triple and Bruce Campbell a double.
Representatives of thirteen large groups associated with the building industry, as well as several Federal agencies and one Canadian governmental bureau interested in home construction,

Exemption of most of the 90,000 home needleworkers in Puerto Rico from provisions of the Wages and Hours Law and enactment of a differential for that territory are sought by Blanton Winship, Governor of Puerto Rico, it was announced today by Elmer F. Andrews, WageHour Administrator.

G. Ward Price, special correspondent of The Daily Mail of London, and confident of Chancellor. Adolf Hitler, declared in a radio address from Cologne, heard here last night, that the German army would march into Czechoslovakia by the end of this month if Herr Hitler's demands were not satisfied.

Sentence was suspended in Special Sessions yesterday for Thomas Bradley, 16 years old, of 100 West Ninety-sixth Street, and Thomas Dunne, 17, of 216 West 104th Street on their conviction on a charge of having interfered with Emil Nomberg, a special officer of the I. R. T., last May 23,...

Alfred Haag, research director for the United States Maritime Commission, said today that the commission planned a wholesale expansion of shipping service between the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific coasts and all parts of central and South America.

In the first driving scrimmage of the season the Yale varsity today scored- three touchdowns against the third eleven, and the second varsity drove across two against the fourth team. Eddie Collins, given Al Wilson's right halfback berth,

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against MAUER TRADING CORP., furs, 252 W. 29th St., by Landes Evnine Bros., Inc., for upward of $250; Mount Vernon Fur Dressing Co., Inc., upward of $250; Eitingon-Schild Fur Corp., upward of $250.

JOHN STEINBECK has almost as many man ners as there are letters to his name. He can be tender. He can be tough. He can be waggish, cunning, sentimental, callous. He can turn on the weeps or the heat with equal ease, and combine the saccharine and the sordid without batting an eye.

The Weather Bureau posted storm warnings along the Atlantic Coast tonight from Virginia Capes to Atlantic City, including lower Chesapeake Bay. The bureau said that a tropical storm, attended by northeast winds reaching gale force, would hit the Virginia Capes section tomorrow and the Southern New Jersey coast tomorrow afternoon or night.

Sister Mary Geraldine Shevlin, for nineteen years Superior to the Bayley High School, died on Sunday at All Souls Hospital after a long illness, in her eightieth year. She had been a Sister of Charity in the New Jersey community for sixty-two years.

Rallies of approximately $1 a bale on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday resulted from increased foreign and Wall Street buying as foreign and Wall Street buying as expectations gained ground that Czechoslovakia would accept the Franco-British proposals and the stock market strengthened.
The Chesapeake Ohio Railway served notice yesterday to "holdouts" that it would not buy 6 per cent notes of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad which will mature on Oct. 1.

Launching their last stand of the 1938 campaign in hostile territory today, the champion Yankees suffered their first setback of the season at Comiskey Park. The White Sox triumphed, 5 to 4, before a crowd of 2,000.

General merchandise valued at more than $1,000,000 is tied up in Philadelphia garages and shipping rooms because of the truck drivers' strike in New York City, it was estimated today. Meyer R. Brody, Motor Freight Corporation official, said all truck lines were stopped becausee deliveries simply cannot be made in New York."

It was a case of the pitcher going to the well once too often today when Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Philadelphia, six times winner of the women's national golf crown, met defeat in the opening round of the championship, the only real upset in the thirty-two matches that kept

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Milburn have announced from their home in Beverly Hills; Calif., the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Milburn, to Henry Donnelly Keresey of 9 East Ninety-third Street, this city, son of Mrs. Mary Donnelly Keresey, also of this city.

Salem voters had the novel opportunity today of nominating for re-elECtion a candidate whose term still has two years to run. The term of City Treasurer Arthur S. Taylor, Republican, was to have expired this year, but by enactment of the 1936 Legislature the terms of Treasurers In cities of this size were extended to five years.

The quiet but determined efforts of the committee headed by Senator Sheppard of Texas to enforce the letter and reawaken the spirit of the Civil Service and Corrupt Practices Acts are unique and remarkable in New Deal Washington. Because of dramatic events both foreign and domestic they have not attracted the attention that otherwise they would.

Bleecker St, 190; 6-story tenement, 25x98; Etta F. Goldberg against Serra Realty Corp; due, $2,688; taxes, etc, none; subject to $20;000 mtg; to plaintiff for $20,100. By WALTER M. JACOBSON 76th St, 323 W; 4-story dwelling, 20x102.2; Chemical Bank and Trust Co, trustee, against Trustwell Realty Corp: due, $12,792; taxes, etc, $287; to plaintiff for $18,500.

Prospective buyers were invited yesterday by the government to attend a style show which will be held at noon today in the office of the United States Marshal's office preliminary to a sale at auction tomorrow of Frenchmade gowns and coats which were recently confiscated in the case of Marcel Rochas, Inc., whose vice president, Guy Font de Joyeuese, was convicted of smuggling.

Turpentine firm, 20 1/4c; sales 87 barrels; receipts 737 barrels; shipments 315 barrels; stock 49,881 barrels. Rosin firm; sales 84; receipts 3,056; shipments 1,718; stock 258,304. Quote: B. $3.50; D. E. $3.80; F. G. H. I. K, $3.95; M, $4,00; N, $4.85; WG, $5.00; WW, X, $6.00

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at Nantucket, Mass., of Judah Howe Sears of the Boston Sears family, who had recently made his home at 321 East Fifty-fourth Street in this city. Mr. Sears, who was 68 years old and had long been in poor health, died of a heart attack in a cottage he had rented for the Summer.

Miss Jean Reid Wadley, daughter of Arthur Case Wadley of 375 Park Avenue, was married to-Malcolm Ludlam Pearson yesterday afternoon in All Souls Unitarian Church. The Rev. John H. Lathrop of Brooklyn performed the ceremony.

Primary contests for municipal nominations in new Jersey cen tered yesterday in Bayonne, Harrison, Elizabeth and Plainfield. In Bayonne, the forces of Carl A. Ruhlmann, Republican city leader for the last fifteen years, lost to those of Frank C. Davis, ininsurgent chief, for control of the Republican county committee in the municipality.
A requiem mass for John C. Judge, Brooklyn lawyer, was held yesterday at the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, Sidney Place and Joralemon Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Judge died in his sleep Friday.
The surgeon who operated on James Roosevelt at the Mayo Clinic did very well by his patient, but not so well by the

Harry ness. L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, reported today to Senator Sheppard, chairman of the special committee to investigate campaign expenditures, that only one of fifteen charges of improper political activity in Kentucky had been found valid, after thorough investigation of alleged concerted efforts by WPA officials to coerce WPA workers in that State.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General of New York, told the National Association of Securities Commissioners today that "the Whitney scandal has taught the public to stop and think before investing." Mr. McCall directed the investigation that resulted in the conviction of Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, on charges of grand larceny.

The recent action of the American Medical Association in endorsing part of the program of the President's Conference on Health is gratifying to the Administation, but the action will not stop the Department of Justice from presenting its case against the District of Columbia Medical Society, Attorney General Cummings said today.

The first authoritative picture of the line likely to be taken by the joint Congressional-executive investigation of "monopoly and the concentration of economic power" will be presented to a meeting of New York Trade Association executives next Tuesday.

Members of the New York Financial Writers Association will entertaain Louis F. Holtzman, a member of the news staff of The Wall Street Journal, at a luncheon today in Busto's Restaurant. 11 Stone Street.
Mr. and Mrs. Warren Pershing, who returned recently from their wedding trip, were guests of honor last night at a dinner given in the St. Regis Roof by Prince Serge Obolensky.

Dr. J. Clarence Kanigsberg of this place died in his sleep at his home last night at the age of 38. Born in Montreal. he was graduated from McGill University in 1926, studied in Vienna and Budapest and in 1930 opened an office in Freeport.

Courtlandt Nicoll, former New York State Senator, who until last Feb ruary was president of the Museum of the City of New York, died at 7 o'clock tonight while taking a nap before dinner at his country home here. He was 58 years old.

Extreme most bitter cautiousness is shown by The Yorkin commenting on the Anglo-French both are wary in condemning the plan before it is published officially and fully, they nevertheless discuss the proposals for the decession of the Sudeten areas with definite misgiving.

Germany become involved in hostilities and severed from overseas by a t blockade, she has sufficient cereals to feed men and livestock and for industrial consumption for about eighteen months-this independently of her 1939 crop and deliveries
Chagrin, sarcasm and disappointment were voiced in the Brazilian press today over the "abandonment" of Czechoslovakia by France and Great Britain.

Miss Lura Quackenbush Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. B. Anderson of this place, has chosen Oct. 11 as the date of her marriage to Philip Charles Backer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Backer of Bound Brook.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday transferred the case of James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, and five of the eight other defendants' in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy lottery conspiracy indictment for a new trial in General Sessions.

The investigation into charges, that Norman Thomas was kidnapped when he attempted to speak in Jersey City virtually has been completed but the inquiry into whether civil liberty laws have been violated there still is going on, Attorney General Homer S. Cummings said today.

Czechoslovakia will fight for her vital interests in any event, it was asserted here tonight by the Czech Minister, Zdenek Fierlinger. "In no way is she considering this proposal [the Anglo-French plan] binding upon her," he de- faith clared.

President Roosevelt appealed today to a committee of railway presidents and leaders of standard railway unions to unite in a broad program for legislation that would rehabilitate the railway industry.
Luncheon meeting, Traffic Club of New York, Hotel Biltmore, 12:15 P. M. "Passenger Traffic," H. W. Siddall.

Holders of more than 50 per cent of Central Railroad of New Jersey general mortgage 4 and 5 per cent bonds have assented to a plan for disposal of land near Bayonne, N. J., which constitutes part of the security behind the bonds.
The Clean Government faction of the Republican party, backed by the Rev. Lester H. Clee, early today claimed a sweeping victory in the Essex County primaries over the Suburban Republican League.

At the ninetyfifth meeting of the German Society of Natural Scientists and Physicians here additional data on experiments with the new preventive serum against hoof and mouth disease has been revealed by Professor Waldmann, the serum's codiscoverer.

Stocks continued to advance and closed higher, with leaders up 1 to 4 points in heavier trading; turnover, 1,198,310 shares. United States Government bonds closed sharply higher; foreign bonds rallied and closed with widest gains since March; corporation issues also higher:

Al Reid, 128, Bronx, earned the decision over Joey Fontana, 130 1/4, Brooklyn, in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before a crowd of 4,000. In the eight-round semi-final, Jimmy Lancaster, 131, Wilmington, Del., drew with Harold Valan, 130 3/4, Brownsville.

President Roosevelt wrote William I. Myers today that it was with "sincere recret" that he accepted his resignation as governor of the Farm Credit Administration. Mr. Myers had asked to be relieved today, so that he could return to the College of Agriculture at Cornell University.

Visiting buyers reported in town during the week ended yesterday numbered considerably less than in the preceding week. However, the total was well ahead of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 976, as against 1,400 in the previous week and 701 in the same period last year.
Concrete moves to humanize air and gas warfare and an inconclusive debate on Palestine marked today's sessions of League of Nations Assembly committees.

Returns for the third quarter of this year from income and excess profit taxes paid in the Third District, which includes all of Manhattan north of Twentythird Street, show an increase for the first twenty days of September over returns made during a similar period in 1937, Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the district, announced yesterday.

The Annalist index of business activity advanced 4.2 points in August, reflecting further domestic recovery, according to the monthly survey of domestic business conditions in the current issue of The Annalist.

Bellaire Kitty, chestnut mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Reed A. Albee of Larchmont, N. Y., scored in the second session of the annual- Eastern States Exposition Horse Show in the Coliseum tonight. Bellaire Kitty led among the three-gaited saddle horses in an event dominated by entries from the metropolitan district.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, departing this afternoon for Cherbourg and Southampton, will have among her passengers Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, the tennis player; Professor L. M.

Conditions in the construction industry in New York State improved from the middle of July to the middle of August, Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner, reported today. She reported that employment advanced 6.2 per cent, payrolls 7.6 per cent, and man-hours 3.8 per cent. The information was obtained from reports of 1,700 concerns which send statistics each month.

In view of the broader powers granted to the Federal Trade Commission under the Wheeler-Lea amendment, there is no danger of drastic national legislation for the regulation of advertising being enacted in the near future, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared last night at the first meeting of the season of the Advertising Women of New York, Inc., at the Advertising Club.

The game of diplomacy was being played for high stakes in various European capitals tonight, and a postponement of twenty-four hours in the second meeting between Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain tightened the tension.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange interpreted the turn of events abroad with the sharpest advance in quotations in several months. All groups participated in the broad upswing, with United States Government and foreign dollar obligations the conspicuous leaders.

Rigoletto" with Ivan Petroff in the title role was presented last night at the Center Theatre by the San Carlo Opera Company. Among the other principals were Lucille Meusel as Gilda, Charlotte Bruno as Maddalena, Dimitri Onofrei as the duke,

Two big seven-run innings gave the Red Sox a double victory over the Browns today, 12 to 8 and 7 to 2, and strengthened their hold on second place in the American League. They now lead Cleveland by one game.

The official opening of the ninety-sixth annual Mineola Fair here by Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, which was scheduled for this afternoon, was postponed until 3:30 P. M. tomorrow

Rules of the New York Stock Exchange have been modified so that a member who leaves the floor temporarily does not lose the priority of a bid or offer. He may transfer it to another member, having the same privilege that specialists have had.

So far as they go, the results of the July increase in passenger fares on the Eastern railways tend to confirm the judgment of those on the Interstate Commerce Commission and elsewhere who maintained that the railways made a mistake in seeking an increase.

A committee of the Publishers Association of New York City is to meet with Acting Mayor. Newbold Morris at 11 o'clock this morning to discuss the difficulties their newspapers are experiencing in continuing publication with the diminishing supplies of newsprint permitted by the striking teamsters.
Mrs. Herbert C. Pell has come from Tuxedo Park to the Berkshire, where she will be for the season.

Norman Bentley, Inc., mechanical novelties; E. Arthur Riordan, delivery service; Jack Lieberman, textiles; Dr. Alexander Katz and Somerset Fabrics, Inc., textiles: Milton Schwartz, textiles, additional space; Department of Agriculture and Commerce of Puerto Rico, renewal on space for identification and information bureau; leases in 1,457 Broadway through Ruford D. Franklin, representing the owner of the building.

The Sixteenth Infantry from Governors Island and the Eighteenth Infantry from Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island will begin to concentrate today, together with other units of the First Division, at Camp Dix, N. J., for annual Fall field training and manoeuvres.
Pitcher Ray Ortez allowed his infielders and an outfielder to play cards as he hurled the Phoenix (Ariz.) Lettuce Kings to the championship of the American Softball Association tonight.

The Manhattan football team spent more than an hour in yesterday's rain testing its defense against a scrub combination equipped with Notre Dame formations as preparations for the game with St, Bonaventure at Randalls Island Stadium Saturday continued.

Some day there will no doubt have to be a vehicular tunnel from the Battery to Brooklyn. Such a tunnel would be a logical feeder-and also a logical digester-for the waterfront loop around Manhattan which will be created when the West Side Highway and the East River Drive are completed and interconnected.

News of the reported Anglo-French "solution" of the Czech crisis has been received in. Egypt with widely divergent reactions. Two distinct schools of opinion are already apparent. One eulogizes Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain as a self-sacrificing hero whose only

Finance Minister Paul Marchandeau appealed to French patriotism in this difficult hour to stop the hoarding of needed currency and to assure early payment of taxes. He said that in recent days the people had been putting money aside to use for emergencies, and he asked that these funds be put into circulation by the purchase of short-term bonds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor La Guardia recently announced that he had selected two high places for Chairman Fullen and Commissioner Fertig of the Transit Commission, so that the commission might be abolished. Commissioner Haskell, an ex-jurist known for his integrity and independence of character, can apparently shift for himself.

Plans were filed yesterday for a six-story apartment structure on the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, formerly occupied by six old-law tenements, known as 20-26 Columbus Avenue and 101-05 West Sixtieth Street.

Mayor Herbert Kruttschnitt announced here today that a New York syndicate, which plans to construct a large garden apartment house project on the Ollemar tract here, has signified its intention of taking title to a portion of the estate on Oct. 18.

Sewell Stokes, co-author of the play "Oscar Wilde," which has been shown in Paris and privately in London, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Laconia, accompanied by two members of the cast, John Buckmaster and Harold Young. Norman Marshall,
John Moir, a senior partner in the old Chase Sanborn Company from 1913 to 1929, when it was merged into Standard Brands, Inc., died this morning of a heart attack in his Chestnut Hill home.

BOUT noon yesterday John Bromwich of Australia probably was thinking that he would have to take out citizenship papers, buy a house on Long Island and settle down here if he hoped to finish out that national tennis championship at Forest Hills.

General selling developed today in the wheat market, due largely to the continued more favorable character of the political news from Europe. Speculators, however, regarded the situation as still sufficiently uncertain to justify taking a stand on the bear side, and short covering and commission-house buying developed on the weak spots.

A contest for musical family groups will be conducted on the Mall in Central Park at 8:30 tonighf, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Parks. According to the rules, each group must consist of at least three members of any age related by birth or marriage.

While the institutional angle has been creeping more and more into liquor advertising in recent months, large-scale campaigns devoted mainly to the aims and ideals of distillers have been held back because of the business slump, liquor executives reported yesterday.

Representative John J. O'Connor won the Republican nomination for Congress, but was defeated by James H. Fay in the Democratic primaries in New York. Rain cut down the vote in the city and up-State. [Page 1.]

BONDY. LEWIS (Sept. 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Fannie Bondy, widow, 210 W. 78th St., residue; Eugene L. Bondy, son, New Rochelle, executor; three minor bequests. CAMPBELL, MARGARET L. (Aug. 25). Estate, approximately $9,000. To Loretta Ahern, 150 E. 165th St.; Marion Stone, Los Angeles; Frank Travis, 139-26 88th Road, Jamaica, L. I.; Edna Cooney,

Two disciples of Father Divine, who had sought to vote under the names of "John the Baptist" and "Love and Do Right," were barred from voting in today's primary election when they appeared at the polling place in the Fifth District of the First Ward here.

Although an all-day downpour of rain held the voting to a minimum, former Senator W. Warren Barbour won the anticipated easy victory for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate in the New Jersey primary election yesterday, in which - William Harvey J. Ely, formerly State WPA Administartor, was unopposed for the Democratic nomination.

The Rev. Dr. Calvin W. Laufer, editor of many Presbyterian hymnals and author of 125 hymns, most of which are in wide use in the churches of America, died today in Germantown Hospital, less than a half hour after he had been admitted.
It begins to look as if President Ford Frick will have to build an ark to float his National League clubs to the completion of their schedules.
Miss Doris Spence, daughter of Mrs. A. Pyott Spence of this place, became the bride tonight of Norman Low Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Norman Kennedy of Short Hills.
The Federal Trade Commission charged today that twenty producers of agricultural and chemical lime in Southeastern States were attempting to fix the price of their products.
Real estate appraising is developing into a science and valuations are made today for owners, builders and prospective buyers and sellers on a more accurate basis than heretofore.

Closing with a powerful rush in the final sixteenth, A. C. Compton's Superstition gained a neck decision in the Chestertown Purse, the best event of today's card. With Jockey F. Scheih alternating in whipping and hand-riding, the gelded son of Apprehension defeated the Calumet Farm's Vain Bo, with H. P. Headley's Scarer third in the six-furlong test for juveniles.

Mrs. J. B. Walker, Dublin. Ireland, defeated Mrs. Tim Lowry, Chicago, 7 and 5. Mrs. Estelle. Lawson Page, Greensboro. N. C., defeated Mrs. Erlc Phillips, Lamb. ton Mills, Ont., 4 and 3. Mrs. Harriet Randall, Indianapolis, defeated Mrs. C. R. Harbaugh, Cleveland, 4 and 3. Miss Ellamae Williams, Chicago, defeated Mrs. R. M. Torgerson, Forest Hills, N. Y., one up, 20 holes.

Stocks of domestic and foreign refinable crude petroleum on Sept. 10 totaled 282,457,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This showed a decrease of 2,462,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 2,148,000 and 314,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

Dr. Franklin D. Seward of Rutherford, N. J., past president of the New York State Society of Optometrists; died at the Nyack Hospital this morning from injuries suffered in an automobile accident last Friday night near Letchworth Village, in which George W. James of Rutherford, who was with him, also received fatal injuries.

Prague's reply to the Anglo-French proposals for the settlement of the Sudeten issue ended another day of acute tension here. It was marked by uncertainty and misgiving mingled with feelings of resentment and chagrin.

A tea in compliment to Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge, whose festival of five concerts opens here tomorrow afternoon, was given this afternoon by Mrs. Willem Willeke at Mountain House. There were 200 guests.

At 9:30 o'clock this morning the municipal ferryboat Queens, gayly bedecked with flags and banners, will pull out of her slip t the Battery with more than 500 high school boys and girls aboard for the waterfront course in civics conducted by the New York City educational system.
The march of Polish troops across the Czech frontier and the occupation of the Teschen district is considered inevitable here in case of the Sudetenland annexation by Germany.

The National Labor Relations Board today announced certification of the Newspaper Guild of Detroit, a Committee for Industrial Organization affiliate, as the exclusive collective bargaining representative for all employes of the Times Publishing Company, Detroit, publishers of The Detroit Times, excluding those eligible for membership in eleven craft organizations.

The coalition candidate for Governor, whose strategy was consolidation of Governor Philip F: La Follette's \opposition in the Fall election, trailed in the Republican race, but led in the Democratic party early today on Incomplete returns from yesterday's Wisconsin primaries. The returns indicated an unusually heavy Republican party vote.

So concentrated on foreign war news during the last several days has been the attention of financial circles that the domestic situation has been overlooked almost entirely. Frequently some doubts have been raised as to the underlying strength of the business recovery, and recently they have been on the increase. However,

Willard F. Kolbe, at 17 Robin Hill Rd, Scarsdale; Max J. Raff, at 13 Murray Hill Rd, Scarsdale; Claude Woessner, at 56 Stratford Rd, Scarsdale; J. P. Luce, at 40 Wright Place, Eastchester; Chauncey B. Griffen, broker. R. C. Kleinberger, through Myron L. Blum Co., at 13 Maple Street, Hartsdale; Arthur C. Stanley, at 77 Brambach Rd, Scarsdale; James Schucker, through Elliott Rates, Inc., at 14 Bacon Ct, Bronxville;
Consumption of Lake Superior iron ore in August exceeded 2,000,000 tons for the first month this year, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.

Yesterday's primary election in the city was extremely orderly, none of the intimidation of other years being,in evidence in the early hours of the voting. Up to an hour before the closing of the polls only five arrests had been made.
Mrs. Priscilla Chase Morris Phinney, portrait painter and philanthropist, died yesterday at her home in West Medford. She was the widow of Joseph Warren Phinney.
Vienna's Nazi district leader has opened a public subscription for the benefit of refugees from Czechoslovakia and money is being collected from door to door for them.

Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate--To take effect 12 midnight. Sept. 19: PATROLMEN-Thomas J. Connolly, 30th Precinct, at $924 per annum. Appointed June 21, 1926. Herman S. Siekmann, 40th Precinct, at $1,116 per annum. Appointed Dec. 19, 1923. Richard F. Wood, 123d Precinct, at $768 per annum. Appointed July 3, 1928.

Scholarships totaling $30,210 have been awarded for the new academic year to ninety-two students in Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, it was announced yesterday. The recipients, who come from twenty-seven States and Puerto Rico,

A supplemental report on transactions in equity securities in July by officers, directors and principal stockholders of various companies was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The first indication of conflict between Catholicism and Nazism in Austrian Germany was disclosed in a pastoral letter read yesterday from Catholic pulpits.

Plain-garbed Amish and Mennonite farmers from the tobaccogrowing valleys of Lancaster County told an education. committee of the Pennsylvania Legislature today that they wanted to keep their children out of high school so they could work in the fields and avoid worldly contacts.

Bergen County put 440 voting machines into use for the first time today with little or no difficulties in districts in Hackensack, Fairview and South Hackensack. Some difficulties cropped up when the electrical appliance controlling the automatic features of the machines failed to work but the machines were operated manually until the trouble was corrected.

Warners today announced the loanout deal providing for Bette Davis to play the Scarlett O'Hara role in Selznick-International's "Gone With the Wind" as nearly completed. Warners' representatives disclosed that contracts will be signed as soon as a shooting schedule is worked out which will not conflict with Miss Davis's two forthcoming films at Warners.

135th St, 525-527 E (9-2263), Pap Realty Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, installments, 3 per cent; $41,329. Giles Pl (12-3258), w s 200 n of Cannon PI, 206x111; Carmelo Turiano to the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 110th and Amsterdam Ave, installments, 4 per cent; $11,000.

The National Republican Club at 54 West Fortieth Street approved unanimously last night a report of its State affairs committee condemning Senator Robert F. Wagner on the basis of his record in Congress and urging his defeat in what-. ever election contest he might enter this Fall.

A memorial to John Philip Sousa, possibly a home for American musicians and composers, has been proposed by a group of his friends. Such a monument would not only honor "The March King," but would symbolize an era of American history, an outlook on life we shall hardly know again.

David John Tulloch, assistant controller of- the Carson Pirie Scott Co. department, store, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 49 years old. Born in the Shetland Islands, Mr. Tulloch's family operated the largest wholesale- and general store in the islands.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Young of this place have announced the engagement of Mrs. Young's daughter, Miss Rosemary Isobel Gengler, to Sergeant Curtis C. Davis, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Davis of Bristol, Va.

A 22-year-old woman, whom the police listed later as Mrs. Rhoda Schwartz of the Belle Hotel, Toledo, Ohio, was killed about 5 o'clock last night by a ten-story drop from the window of her room at the Hotel Langwell, 123 West Forty-fourth Street, to a rear courtyard.

An innovation in insurance advertising was launched here today by W. A. Alexander Co., large local multiple line general agency, in a series of display newspaper advertisements designed to sell to the public the value of sound insurance counsel as against "bargain" policies and to increase the prestige of its representatives.

New pneumonia cases in the city increased from 111 for the previous week to 190 for the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, by Thomas J. Duffield, registrar of records. Deaths from this disease totaled 47.

Hearings in connection with the Federal Trade Commission's investigation of chain broadcasting, monopoly in the broadcasting industry and related matters will open on Oct. 24 and continue for five or six weeks before the special committee appointed to supervise the inquiry.

Edward E. Bradley of Stonington, who retired in 1928 as vice president and general manager of the Atwood Machine Company, makers of silk and rayon throwing machinery, died this morning in the Jane Brown Hospital, Providence, R. I., after an emergency operation performed there last week.

Amid a general her convictionn that the Czech crisis is rapidly approaching a peaceful solution, the Italian press continues to voice the fear that Great Britain and France are planning to exclude minorities other than the German from the benefits of the

Benito Torres, 25 years old, a mulatto, killed eight members of his family and wounded three others at Palma Soriano, Orente Province, last night. The dead were his mother, stepuncle, three sisters, 10, 14 and 16 years old, and three brothers, 18, 5 and 2 years old. He wounded a sister, 7, and two brothers, 14 and 3.

Drastic changes were made in the Cornell backfield today, Walt Matuszczak taking the blocking post in place of the veteran Bob Rose, ahd Hal McCullough replacing George Peck at wingback. Carl Snavely described the changes as "experiments."

State Health Commissioner Edward S. Godfrey Jr. warned Hudson River communities today to "provide proper treatment of sewage or face legal proceedings." "The serious pollution of the Hudson River by untreated sewage of municipalities," Dr. Godfrey said,

After a period of silence, dating from primary election day, Lieutenant Governor Thomas Kennedy, defeated for the Democratic nomination for Governor, joined tonight with Philip Murray, vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, in urging labor in Pennsylvania to support the.State Democratic ticket in November.
After Prague had replied yesterday to the French-British plan to partition Czechoslovakia, saying that the proposal was unacceptable in the form submitted and suggesting arbitration at The Hague,

The Bureau of Mines estimated today that the market demand for domestic crude oil in October would be 3,366,800 barrels daily. This would be 77,500 barrels less than the estimate for September and 7 per cent less than the actual demand in October last year.

Nationally advertised brands have little to fear from super-market operators, providing their prices to consumers are "right," and based on reasonable profits over actual costs, William H. Albers, president of the Super Market Institute, told delegates at the second session of the institute convention at the Hotel Sherman today. As evidence, he cited the steady increase in sales of goods of this type by institute members.

ANDREWS--On Tuesday. Sept. 20. at Watch Hill, R. I.. Edna Dickerson, wife of the late William H. Andrews and sister of Mrs. Mabel D. McIlvaine. Services at her residence in Watch Hill on Thursday, Sept. 22, at 2 P. M. (D. S. T.). Interment private. Trains leaving New York at 10 A. M. (D. S. T.) will be met at Westerly, R. I. Return trains at 3:47 and 4:48 (D. S. T.).

Imports of $42,761,000 gold were received here yesterday, according to the daily report of the Federal Reserve Bank. For the first time since Aug. 25 no new engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were reported.

With the blessing of Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the Archdiocese of New York, the Rev. John B. Kelly, chaplain of the Catholic Writers Guild of America, has. started work on a biography of Patrick Cardinal Hayes, it became known yesterday.

Montgomery C. Smith, Superintendent of Schools in Hudson since 1922, died here today at the age of 60. Mr. Smith was born in London, but passed most of his life in this country. He was graduated from Groton School in 1897 and .Syracuse University in 1901.

John P. Ellison has been appointed head of the New York branch of Thomas Cook Son (Bankers), Ltd., to succeed W. F. Brown, who had held the office since 1923. Mr. Brown retired on Sept. 1 and a testimonial dinner was given to him by the firm in recognition of his forty-five years of service.

J. G. White Co., Inc.; Baker, Watts Co., Stein Brothers Boyce and the Colonial Bond and Share Corporation, as agents appointed to receive tenders of the debentures of thirteen mortgage companies, interest on which is guaranteed by the Maryland Casualty Company, announced yesterday that tenders of more than $7,000,000 of the debentures had been received from more than 2,500 investors in all parts of the country.

Deserted by its allies, geographically isolated, convinced by urgent inquiries in Paris and Moscow that military help will not be forthcoming from France, or from Russia, even if the Czech armies resist to the death the enemy massed at the gates, the Czech Republic seems to be faced with only two alternatives to suicide, both almost as agonizing.

Many of the players entered in the 108-hole medal-play tournament which starts today at the Fenway Golf Club at White Plains went through final practice rounds yesterday. A total of $13,500 in prizes will be at stake.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tonight postponed his departure for his second meeting with Chancellor Adolf Hitler until Thursday, to allow time for an effort to induce Czechoslovakia to change her mind about the Anglo-French proposal for cession of her Sudeten areas to Germany.

Rain and no contests resulted in the smallest turn-out of voters in many years in Rockland County today for the primary election. Except for a few minor contests over committeemen.there was little interest.

The old-line Republican faction led by DAvid Baird Jr. was running up a 6-to-5 lead for their candidates over those of the insurgent Republican League for Clean Government in the early returns in the party's primary in this county late tonight.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for the twelve months to July 31, issued for publication today, shows a net income after all expenses and charges, of $35,246,663. Total operating revenues were $137,504,290, while operating expenses, including taxes and depreciation, amounted to $110,382,629.

Mayor La Guardia, who is in Los by Angeles, endorsed an ultimatum issued last night by Acting Mayor Newbold Morris to the truck drivers to end in twenty-four hours the "outlaw" strike that has almost paralyzed shipping here since it was started last Thursday.

Robinson, 60, stage and movie tap dancer, was released on his own recognition tonight after he had been arrested on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon. Detective Lieutenant Rex Huston said Mr. Robinson drew a pistol, for which he carries a police permit, and struck Paul Moffat, University of Southern California football player, after their cars collided.

The Red Cross announced today that the first shipment of flour to women and children refugees in Spain will be made Oct. 8. The shipment will consist of 40,000 bags weighing ninety-eight pounds each. The flour comes from wheat turned over to the Red Cross by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation.

Funeral services were held yesterday in Front Royal, Va., for Everett Friscoe Moore, public relations director of the-Beneficial Management Corporation of Newark, N. J., who died Friday at his home in Freedom, N. H., at the age of 50. He was chairman of the membership committee of the American Association of Personal Finance Companies.

President Roosevelt said today that he would take no part in elections involving opposing political parties and explained that he was talking principles rather than practical politics when he announced recently that he would not object to the

Convicted recently by a jury in Kings County Court of having acted as the "finger man" in the hold-up of his brother-in-law's trucking establishment, at 350 Leonard Street, Brooklyn, on March 4, Frank Swan, 23 years old, of 387 Sumlter Street, Brooklyn, was sentenced yesterday by Judge George W. Martin to five to ten years in Sing Sing Prison.

Declaring that the American people must choose between "political, paternalistic enterprise" and the encouragement of private initiative, George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, yesterday warned that present Administration methods lead in the direction of price-fixing of all commodities, regimentation and ultimately the loss of personal liberty of every citizen.

The Empire State Travel Association was organized here today at a meeting of representatives from villages, cities, regional organizations and convention and travel bureaus from throughout New York State.

Residents, along 'this section of the Hungarian-Czechoslovak border failed tonight to share the confidence of their fellow-countrymen that Czechoslovakia would return any territory to Hungary without war.
An agreement was reached today by attorneys of the Cleveland Tankers, Inc., and the seventeen seamen ending a sit-down strike which began on the Great Lakes tanker Crudoil Sept. 13.

Substantial recasting of retail import operations in Czechoslovakia would follow acquisition of the Sudeten area by Germany, with indications that merchandise orders will be diverted to Poland, Scandinavia, Holland and England, it was predicted here yesterday by department and chain store executives who have been importing Czech merchandise.
A Federval marketing order has been signed by fifty-one handlers of milk supplying the New York metropolitan area, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.

A second test of strength between Democratic factions headed by Senator Crawford Jamieson and Leo J. Rogers, former assistant prosecutor, was the feature of the primary balloting in Mercer County today. As the polls closed at 9 o'clock tonight both groups expressed confidence of victory, but political observers expected the Jamieson slate to win.
BIG SHOW, by Charles Cooke. (Harper, $2.50.) A novel about circus life. BROWN HILLS, by Judy Van der Veer. (Longmans, Green, $2.) A record of life on the author's ranch in Southern California.

The campaign headquarters of James H. Fay, New Deal Democrat who defeated Representative 'John J. O'Connor, were in pandemonium early this morning when it became apparent that Mr. Fay had won the Democratic nomination in the Sixteenth- Congressional District.

Delegates of the National Czechoslovak Societies of America, representing more than 1,500,000 Americans of Czech and Slovak descent, laid preliminary plans today for uniform action and support of Czechoslovakia in its crisis.

Charles H. Sullivan, Democratic leader of Suffolk County, apparently retained domination of his party forces today in a hotly contested primary fight. Late tonight Mr. Sullivan's forces claimed victory for their county committee candidates-in fifty of the seventy-odd contests in which they were opposed by adherents of Robert N. Gilmore of Babylon.

Tonight's Defense Ministry communique reports heavy Insurgent attacks throughout today on the Ebro front by Italian divisions. The net result, it is reported, was the loss of one hill near Gandesa but stiff resistance elsewhere.
To Fire College The following Lieutenants shall report at the Fire College 32-02 Queens Boulevard. Long Island City, at 10:30 A. M., on the following dates: Groups 3 or 7-Ellmination System-Oct. 3,

The prospect that at least two women, Magistrate Anna Moskowitz Kross and Miss Ruth Lewinson, may be candidates for Supreme Court justice at the coming election prompted Miss Lena Madesin Phillips; president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, to urge women yesterday to unite to support women candidates, regardless of party, at the coming election.

The licenses of all Jewish traveling salesmen and agents expire at the end of this month, as decreed July 6. The Institute for Study of the Jewish Question reports that of a total of 265,000 agents and traveling salesmen in Germany, 110,000, or approximately 40 per cent, are full Jews, although Jews number less than 1 per cent of the Reich's population.
Gutzon Borglum, sculptor, explained today how a wooden "muffler' would be wrapped around the great stone face of Theodore Roosevelt during the 40 below Winter weather of the Black Hills.

The primaries in Cape May County failed to stir the interest of the voters, or of the politicians, and as a result there was no effort made to count the votes cast. Aside from the lack of interest in the outcome of the voting, the heavy rains all afternoon and tonight kept many of the voters from the polls.

For about 70.000 residents of Greater New York and ??mewhere between two million and eleven million other Americans one interest supersedes all others from the middle of August to the middle or latter part of September. That interest is hay fever, due in about eight cases out of ten to the floating pollen of the ragweed.

The Nepsco Appliance Finance Corporation, Augusta, Me., has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act covering the issue of not in excess of $400,000, including the amount now outstanding, of Nepsco 3 per cent deferred debentures and not to exceed $1,200,000, including the amount outstanding, of promissory note.
Paddy Reilly, 11-year-old dog, received the life-saving badge of the Boy Scouts of America at a ceremony held at City Hall yesterday afternoon, Acting Mayor Newbold Morris conferring the award.
Senator O' Mahoney today blamed failure of corporate law to keep abreast of business development as one of the reasons why Federal licensing of corporations was needed.

Offered by the union local at the plant of the B. F. Goodrich Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, a resolution "imploring" President Roosevelt to seek a third term was adopted unanimously today at the third annual convention of the United Rubber Workers of America, an affiliate of the C. I. O., meeting in the Hotel Hildebrecht here.

The nine-room house on a large plot at 123 Brookdale Avenue, New Rochelle, Westchester County, was sold by Jenny Ellinger to John McKeon, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Mrs. Clifford A. Wolf, broker, negotiated the sale.

Japanese ship lines will immediately make sharp reductions in their overseas fleets, particularly in transpacific express freight services, it was learned today. The action is attributed to a decision at Tokyo to "cover the shortage of bottoms in the coastal services resulting from the expiration of chartered foreign tonnage schedule," apparently for China service.

The program for adjusting on a permanent basis the foreign indebtedness of the Republic of Poland nears completion with the announcement today of an offer of definitive settlement to the holders of the Republic's 7 per cent bonds of the Stabilization Loan of 1927 (dollar tranche).

Mr. and Mrs. James Wallace Hand of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Mooney Hand, to Franklin Alexander McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. McCarthy, also of Elizabeth.

The Dresdner Nachrichten reports from Prague that a high-ranking Czech flying officer was arrested for revealing in a bar while drunk that a tri-motored airplane was waiting to carry President Eduard Benes out of the country.

Federal Judge Guy L. Fake reaffirmed today two previous decisions in which he had ruled against further deductions in income-tax payments for 1918 by the KellySpringfield Tire Company. Kelly-Springfield had filed for a deduction of $799,106 from its 1918 income-tax payment, charging it had incurred losses and was forced to make changes in its plant at Cumberland, Md., to carry on wartime production and that it was not allowed sufficient amortization.
Miss Grace Marie Fiske, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Fiske, who have their Summer home in the Smith Lane colony here, was introduced to society today at a

Declaring that the White House had encouraged "the un-American" sitdown strike and had stopped recovery in its tracks by driving capital into "the refrigerator," William Allen White told a large gathering of business men tonight that they were faced with the choice of bankrupting themselves to feed a growing army of the unemployed or putting over-capitalized industries through "the wringer."

Police Chief Edward Quirk of Yonkers said today he was convinced that the body found this morning floating in the Hudson River off the foot of Dyckman Street, Manhattan, was that 'of Sarkis Hortian, 45 years old, sought in the murder of Mrs. Alice Dubossi, 38, of 207 Dyckman Street. He added that he considered the case closed.

Thomas J. Shaughnessy, an attorney, formerly a football and hockey player at Notre Dame and one time president of the Shamrocks Chicago hockey team, was fatally injured early today when he fell down a flight of stairs at the Printers Club, 8 North Wells Street. His skull was fractured.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,239,050 barrels, compared with 3,206,900 in the previous week, an increase of 32,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 205,250 barrels fewer than the calculation of 3,444,300 daily for September by the Bureau of Mines.

Arthur Cowenberghs, 55 years old, of 254 Park Place, Brooklyn, and John Arras, 49, of 91-55 Chicot Court, Ozone Park, Queens, were held in $15,000 bail each yesterday by Magistrate Farrell in Felony Court after they had pleaded not guilty in the alleged theft of about $60,000 through the use of counterfeit Internal Revenue stamps at the French Line offices, where they were employed. A hearing was set for next Tuesday.

George P. Northrop of Newark, chess editor of The Newark Evening News, who had been an important figure. in the chess world for forty years, died here yesterday in the Holy Name Hospital. On Nov. 19 he would have been 74 years old.

" The old attitude of 'educate me if you can,' which was supposed to characterize the American undergraduate, I think we have largely got rid of here," said President Neilson of Smith College at the opening college assembly of the sixty-fourth academic year this morning.
The strong dissension that has reigned for the last three weeks between the two most important Arab rebel chiefs in Palestine, Abdul Rahim Haj Mohammed and Arif Abdul Razik, has been settled.

Charles S. Howard's handicap champion Seabiscuit was defeated through the mud at Belmont Park yesterday, but marked himself more than ever as a thoroughbred of top class. William Woodward's Isolater was the winner of the $6,050 Manhattan Handicap, but he had to run the best race of his career to get home first by a head at the end of a mile-and-a-half run in the remarkably fast time of 2:31.

Governmental "red tape" and tonnage Measurements for ships are the two shief hinderances to expansion of ?e American merchant marine, ??ear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commis?in, told the twelfth annual con?ntion of the Propeller Club of the united States here today.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra season will open on Thursday evening, Oct. 20, at Carnegie Hall, and John Barbirolli, permanent conductor, will direct a program consisting of Weber's "Freischuetz" overture, Sibelius's "Swan of Tuonela" and "The Return of

One man was killed and several were wounded when two bombs exploded today in the B'nai B'rith headquarters in Krakow. Another bomb burst in a building belonging to the Teachers Union in Lodz, killing one man.

Hans Kolb, 24 years old, an expert skier, of 330 East Fifty-sixth Street, received a suspended sentence but was placed on probation for three years yesterday by General Sessions Judge Bohan after he had pleaded guilty to the charge of sending an annoying letter to Dr. George Rothenberg of 4 East Ninety-fifth Street.

Edward J. Sullivan, general A. F. of L. organizer on the Great Lakes, said today that Great Lakes seamen affiliated with the A. F. of L. would oppose efforts of President William Green to start a new National Seamen's Union under the leadership of Harry Lundeberg.
George W. Corner Jr., treasurer of the Baltimore Equitable Society, churchman and former president of the Young Men's Christian Association, died today at the age of 76.

Superintendent William B. Mills and nine members of the staff of the Philadelphia County Prison at, Holmesburg were indicted today as an- aftermath of the "baking" to death a month ago of four hungerstriking convicts in the stifling violation block of the prison.

While thousands of civilians were being evacuated, imaginarily, from the devastated area fifty miles east of Louisville and 300 patriotic volunteers stayed behind with improvised gas masks as civil guards, a Blue Army continued its counterattack this morning against an invading Black Army, and by tonight had scored a ten-mile gain in the Second Army's mimic war.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Sept. 15 increased in all five trade divisions, as compared with the same week of 1937, according to the weekly summary prepared by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:

102d St, 312 W, 19x100.11; Herbert M. Palmer, et al, to Rexhold Realty Corp, 55 Liberty St; ($11). Same property, Rexhold Realty Corp to Josephine G. Brimboeuf, 142 W 70th St, mtg $7,500 and p m mtg $3,500; ($5.50). Columbus Ave. 950, 25.1x100; the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Kotinco. Inc, 522 5th Ave, p m mtg, $15,341 and bldg loan, $13,100; ($15.50).
Bitterness arose yesterday in several primary contests in the city, notably the O'Connor-Fay race, over distribution of circulars designed to influence voters against a candidate.

Representatives of the London and Manchester Chamber of Commerce and of traders handling shipments of wheat and coal will send a deputation to the Board of Trade tomorrow to protest the big increases in marine war risk insurance, ordered yesterday by a committee of underwriters.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., have received the award of a new issue of $425,000 of water bonds of La Grange, Ill., on a bid of 100.37 for a fixed rate of 3 per cent. The bonds are to be dated Sept. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on Sept. 1, 1942 to 1968.

A consolidated net profit of $1,789,293 was reported yesterday by the Plymouth Oil Company for the first eight months of this year. This is after deductions for depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges.
With ten deaths due to the storm recorded today, large rivers rising toward flood peaks and many small rivers overflowing, New England faces the threat of serious floods.

The Rev. Dr. Oliver J. Hart, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church of Washington, D. C.. was elected Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware tonight at an adjourned session of the diocesan convention.

Mrs. Grace Ohmer Cochran of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred I. Ohmer of Dayton, Ohio, was married this afternoon to Haley Fiske of New York, son of Mrs. Haley Fiske of Bernardsville, N. J.. and of the late Mr. Fiske.

A free-for-all fight at Hunters Point and Skillman Avenue, near the plant of the Spring Products Corporation in Long Island City, where a strike is in progress, resulted yesterday in the stabbing of three Negroes, one of whom was taken to the hospital, and the arrest of three persons on charges of felonious assault.

Responsible leadership in world affairs, in business, in industry, even in the home, springs only from good management. The growing recognition of this fact is emphasized by the sessions of the Seventh International Management Congress now meeting in Washington.

William A. Lockwood, general counsel for the New York Curb Exchange, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a memorandum urging that it refuse to grant the Application of the Providence Gas Company for the termination of unlisted trading on the Curb in the company's common stock.

After adopting'a platform calling for changes in the State Government and hearing Secretary of Agriculture Wallace urge them to "carry your State for the Democratic ticket," Vermont Democrats adjourned their State convention tonight.

The orchestra of the New Friends of Music has completed its organization and has rounded out its schd-' ule of New York appearances for the coming season, it was announced yesterday by I. A. Hirschmann, president and founder.

At a luncheon given yesterday at the Century Club by Homer SaintGaudens, director of fine arts of the Carnegie Institute, in honor of this year's members of the Carnegie international jury of award, Sydney Lee, British member of the jury, read a communication addressed to Mr. Saint-Gaudens from

Probably few Americans supposed that the two great democracies, commanding an- overwhelming superiority of resources and of armed power, could accept so total and so completely humiliating a defeat as was recorded in the reported conclusions reached in the early hours of yesterday morning.

Suggestions intended to give brokers additional protection in dealing with the problems of "long sales" and "short sales" were contained in a letter sent yesterday to members by the New York Stock Exchange.

KINGS BURLEY, GRACE E. (April 16, 1938). Gross assets, $966; net, $637. To cousins, Francis G. and William Scollay, one-half of residuary estate each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $673; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $293. Arthur Kellman, attorney, 1 Hanson P1.

Former Governor James M. Curley, veteran of four decades of Massachusetts political warfare, tonight held an apparently decisive lead for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination. Leverett Saltonstall,

Brooklyn had more contests for district leaderships in yesterday's primaries than all the other boroughs combined. In the Democratic primary, eleven district leaderships were at stake and six Republican leaderss were seeking to retain their posts.
Here in the Rhineland the stage is all set for the second meeting of the two men in whose hands rests the fate of Czechoslovakia and with it the prospect of present European peace.

The New York Athletic Commission at its regular meeting yesterday announced that it would recognize the winner of a fifteen-round bout between Mike Belloise and Joey Archibald as the featherweight champion of the world.

Opening this afternoon, the twentyseventh annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the Greenwich, Riverside, Hortulus and Green Fingers garden clubs and the Little Garden Club of Rye, N. Y., and the Women's Club Gardeners cooperating, attracted a large attendance from Greenwich and near-by towns and cities, in spite of intermittent heavy showers.
Chairman Dies of the House Committee on Unamerican activities announced today that- he would form a "league for peace and Americanism" to combat subversive influences.

Twelve properties in the Bronx were sold at auction yesterday in the Third Avenue Salesrooms. Included were six homes which were bid in at $500 each, by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff. Details of the auction follow:

Delegates from six States approved today plans to form a national conference of State licensed beverage associations. The delegates from New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio, Delaware and New Jersey gathered this afternoon at the first of a

A plan under which liquor importers and distillers would form a joint organization for enforcement of the Feld-Crawford price contracts in this city will be laid before members of the executive committee of the National Alcoholic Beverage Importers Association by Harry Lourie, secretary of the group, at a meeting here today.

Queen Wilhelmina, in opening the new session of Parliament, in a speech from the throne stressed the necessity of combating unemployment, haste In completing new defense works here and in the East Indies and another increase in taxes designed to effect more just distribution of the burden by lowering indirect taxes.

Joe Beggs kept the champion Newark Bears in the International League play-offs tonight by blanking the Rochester Red Wings with five hits for a 3-0 victory. The triumph was the Bears' second against three for the Red Wings in the semi-final best-of-seven series.

Some aspects of the agrarian land controversy were discussed today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Dr. Francisco Najera, the Mexican Ambassador. Afterward Mr. Hull said it would be a few days before he reached a final decision concerning the note to Mexico that is being drafted on the subject.

Heads of some of the largest building supply companies in the country met Thursday with administration officials on plans for a housing program which, experts believe, holds greater potentialities for pulling the country out of economic difficulties than any previously advanced.

The new class of 400 freshmen was welcomed to Queens College W. yesterday at an assembly addressed War by Dean Margaret V. Kiely and student leaders. A message from President Paul Klapper, who is recovering from an illness, was read by Dean Kiely in which Dr. Klapper said:
Vacant plots, a store and warehouse structure, a garage and a number of one and two-family dwellings figured in sales of New Jersey properties reported by brokers yeste-day.

Promotion of millinery styles for the Winter season will be concentreated in the week of Oct. 17, When showings will be held in stores throughout the country. The event, which will be sponsored by the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, will feature the slogan, "The New Millinery Glorifies Winter."

A police raid on the headquarters of the Breton autonomy party at Rennes, Ile-et-Vilaine Department, reminded Frenchmen today that they have two autonomy problems of their own--in Brittany and in AlsaceLorraine.

The record for postponements of play in national tennis championships was equaled yesterday when, for the fifth time, rain forced cancellation of the program at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
The Spanish Ambassador and Senoa de los Rios held a reception tonight at the embassy in honor of Dr. Edward K. Barsky, chief of foreign medical aid in Spain.

Mayor La Guardia sent invitations yestetday to members of the new Civil Aeronautics Authority and other Federal aviation authorities to attend large air transport parade over New York City on Oct. 3 to open National Air Travel Week.

The Port of New York Authority was called on today by the Holland Tunnel Toll Reduction Association to cut its passenger automobile charges from 50 to 35 cents for the Holland Tunnel and other interstate vehicular crossings it controls.

Twelve properties in the Bronx were sold at auction yesterday in the Third Avenue Salesrooms. Included were six homes which were bid in at $500 each, by the Home Owners Loan Corporation, as plaintiff. Details of the auction follow:

Delegates from six States approved today plans to form a national conference of State licensed beverage associations. The delegates from New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Ohio, Delaware and New Jersey gathered this afternoon at the first of a

A plan under which liquor importers and distillers would form a joint organization for enforcement of the Feld-Crawford price contracts in this city will be laid before members of the executive committee of the National Alcoholic Beverage Importers Association by Harry Lourie, secretary of the group, at a meeting here today.

Sanford Z. Kaye of Athens, Pa., has purchased for occupancy from the William H. Meyer Construction Company the recently completed colonial dwelling at 120 Remington Road, in Munsey Park, Manhasset, L. I. The house contains ten rooms and three baths and occupies a plot 115 by 125 feet. L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. were the brokers.
Nearly 250 flat-bottomed rowboats from the two lakes in Central Park were rushed to the inundated districts in Queens last night by the Department of Sanitation.

The peak of the storm passed over New Jersey in the late afternoon, leaving its mark along the shore and inland as the worst in fifty years, and meeting the home-going Jersey commuters just in time to disrupt their return from New York to examine the damage.

Secretary Woodring is considering a suggestion that bald pates cover the best brains of the army and that promotions should come from this group. The theory was advanced by Major Wilton B. Persons and Captain Lawrence J. Carr in a letter entitled "Brain Directive."

Unable to agree today upon a formula under which the proposed 15 per cent wage reduction for railway employes would be abandoned by the carriers while a joint plan for a broad legislative program for railway. rehabilitation was being. worked out, spokesmen for the carriers and the standard unions deferred further parleys.

The Port Washington-New Rochelle ferryboat Reliance, which normally accommodates about thirty automobiles, postponed its scheduled trip yesterday afternoon because of the storm. It remained at its Long Island dock for a little while.
Charles Thomas Woollen, controller of the Consolidated University of North Carolina, died here this morning of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

Van Nest Ave, 1,205, dwelling, 20.5x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Gregorio Policella, due, $6,280: to plaintiff for $500. By HUGH A. McGORRY JR. Wellman Ave, 2,885, 25?95; Margaret E. Gibbons against Louise Nandal, due, $4,633, taxes, etc, $355; to plaintiff for $3,500.

Persons with colds should stay indoors during this stormy weather, Dr. John L. Rice, City Health Commissioner, warned yesterday. The Commissioner said there was danger that a head or chest cold would develop into grippe or pneumonia if the sufferer remained in wet clothing for a long time.

James M. Curley, active in Massachusetts politics since the turn of the century, and Leverett Saltonstall, descendant of an old Massachusetts family, tonight mapped their battle lines in the fight for the State's Governorship.

The Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., through its Jamaica Bay protest committee, will ask Mayor La Guardia to remove from office William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, and will recommend that the City Council- investigate his department.
A beaten favorite in three previous starts, the Bomar Stable's Detroit Bull finally got home in front today to win the $900 Frosty Morn Handicap, feature race at the Fair Grounds.

Lester Chase, 21 years old, of 99 Elliott Street, New Haven, Conn., was killed and three other persons were seriously injured late last night when two automobiles were in a head-on collision on the Hutchinson River Parkway here.

A formal order transferring the new trial of James J. Hines, Tammany leader in West Harlem, and others from the Supreme Court extraordinary term to General Sessions was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler and Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Britain will arrive here tomorrow, the Briton with the Czechs' acceptance of the German demands for their elimination as a Central European factor. The two men will proceed at once to the business of dismembering the present Czechoslovak State and will finish it as soon as possible.
