Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, tendered the hockey writers of this city a dinner at the Hotel Belvedere last, night at which he outlined his idea of a play-off system for the league. The loop, with only seven teams ue Baseball American League YESTERDAY'S RESULTS Chicago 5, New York 2. Boston 8, St. Louis 4.

The Bryn Mawr Horse Show, acheduled to start today, was postponed until 2 P. M. tomorrow, because of the heavy rain. After the first event, for 4-yearolds and under and 5-year-olds who never had won a ribbon, was captured by Joseph A. Hale's

Stocks extended gains moderately, closing slightly higher for third consecutive day; turnover, 1,025,220 shares. United States Government and corporation bonds closed higher; Czech loans off 6 to 81/2 points; other foreign issues higher; transactions, $7,424,100.

Threats of a Cabinet crisis over the Frenc-British proposals that forced Czechoslovakia to surrender her Sudetenland to Adolf Hitler arose last night against the government of Premier Edouard Daladier:

Willie Turnesa's "Mary Ann," charmed putter which he lost in the excitement of winning the national amateur golf championship,, speeded to Turnesa's home in Elmsford, N. Y., today aboard a mail train.

H. L. Mencken, editor and critic, rendered a two-ply decision yesterday discontinuing a "$50,000 libel suit." brought by the American Civil Liberties Union against The American Mercury for statements contained in an article published in the magazine in December, 1936.

Funeral services for Courtlandt Nicoll, former president of the Museum of the City of New York, will be held at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow in the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street, of which he was a vestryman.

A terrific wind, touching 100-mile-an-hour hurricane force, tonight swept across New England, lashing sea water high into the streets of coastal cities, causing at least eighty known deaths and hundreds of injuries and resulting in damages reaching into tens of millions of dollars.

The stock market accepted without any show of violent fluctuations the complete capitulation of the Prague Government to the AngloFrench plan designed to ward off war. Slightly higher prices ruled throughout the day, with closing quotations in the favorite issues fractionally higher and a few scattered stocks registering wider gains.

John R. Wildman, a former Professor of Accounting at New York University, who had been a member of Haskins Sells, certified public accountants, for the last twenty years, died yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home in Upper Montclair, N. J. He returned on Monday on the Queen Mary after five weeks in Europe.

A study of the extent of unemployment in the paper industry and a drive to reduce this unemployment were' urged today by George G. Cobean, president of the National Paper Trade Associatioin, as an initial step in lessening government competition with private business.

Lady Carnarvon and Geoffrey Grenfell were married today at a London register office. Lady Carnarvon, the former Miss Catharine Wendell, daughter of the late Jacob Wendell of New York, is a descendant of the Washingtons and Lees of Virginia.

An investigation to determine reasons for the increase in costs of operating retail stores, over a period of years was authorized last night by the Metropolitan Controllers Association, and a. committee was named by Leo C. Levin, vice president and controller of Emily shops, Inc;

The text of the speech of Anthon? Eden, former British Foreign Secretary, delivered at the annual dinner last night of the Stratford-on-Avon branch of the English Speaking. Union, was transcribed by the Columbia Broadcasting System as follows:

Following is the text of the address before the League of Nations Assembly tonight by Premier Juan Negrin of Spain: On behalf of the Spanish delegation I am about to make a statement and submit a request to this assembly.

Your correspondent yesterday crossed the Ebro into the fighting zone of the river's elbow, where the roar of war did not relax for a moment. I passed through four of the nine towns taken by the government troops in their surprise drive of July 24--Mora de Ebro, Benisanet, Miravet and Pinell. In all a wavering but stubborn current of civilian life went on almost as usual.

" You Never Know" is what they have dubbed the musical show that turned up at the Winter Garden last evening. There is something grimly prophetic about that title. For, by and large, this is a Cole Porter tune verein, with Clifton Webb, Lupe Velez and Libby Holman at the top of the program and credits enough to stretch

John H. Acheson of this city and St. Petersburg, Fla., head of the chemical research firm of Acheson Industries, Inc., died yesterday morning at his New York home, 4441 Madison Avenue. His age was 44.

Another well-known certified public accountant who had been a member of Haskins Sells for twenty years died on Tuesday. He was William Purcelle Bickett of this city, whose death occurred at his Summer home in Blowing Rock, pointed N. C.

An unusual sort of pre-preview of its 1939 models was held here this afternoon, when the Hudson Motor Car Company presented its offerings for the new-model year in the form of colored drawings by artists of .the three series of cars which will make up the line.
Feeling that the Administration had been slighted by the programmakers for the International Management Congress, which heard today how Germany had "rationalized" its social problems,

The hotly contested primaries in New York's Sixteenth have ended in a somewhat fantastic fashion. The local Democratic organization, which only a year ago, through its chosen candidate for Mayor, was heatedly denouncing the American Labor party as red-tothe-core and made-in-Moscow, now finds itself lined up with the American
Mrs. Chichester du Pont has arrived from Wilmington, Del.. and has joined Mr. and Mrs. James P. Mills at the Weylin.

Home runs by Hank Greenberg and Charley Gehringer enabled the Tigers to sweep a double-header with the Athletics today, 8 to 6 and 3 to 0. The nightcap was called at the end of five innings because of darkness.

Paddy Reilly, dog mascot of the Humane Society, found himself in some dazzling canine company yesterday afternoon. He Is spending a busy week, this being National Dog Week, but his often-tried patience showed no signs of weakening.
The German eagle flew today over Czechoslovak towns in Sudetenland following the announcement that Prague had acceded to the Anglo-French proposals.
Norman Spadone, 29-year-old son of a retired banker, shot and instantly killed his estranged wife, May, 25,

The sunwashed bleacherites at Comiskey Park today were warning the Yankees against the Pirates-and not without cause. For the American League champions dropped their sixth straight game, bowing to the White Sox in a nose dive that has no parallel in the managerial reign of Marse Joe McCarthy. The count was 5 to 2,

During weeks of incomparable tension the Czech people remained outwardly calm. It was a grim and resolute calm. The reaction, therefore, was all the stronger this evening when the forced surrender of the Czechoslovak Government to Anglo-French pressure became known.

New colors are the latest fashion developments in men's clothing and Furnishings, several hundred retailers, who paid $50 each to attend the Esquire-Apparel Arts fashion forum and retail seminar yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, were told.

The Chinese report they repulsed the Japanese assault on Tienchiachen yesterday in one of the most severe battles in the Yangtze Valley hostilities. Japanese forces from Kwangsi have been pounding toward Tienchiachen for six days and at one time were within three miles of their goal, but Chinese military reports say they have withdrawn the badly battered vanguard several miles.

The annual flower show at the Westcheste and Fairfield Horticultural Society continued today despite heavy rain and wind. Mrs. Reinhard Siedenburg entertrained for luncheon in honor of Mrs. William H. Cary of New Canaan; Mrs. Earl E. Saracia,

A sharp break in Czechoslovak bonds provided yesterday the only weak spot in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. All other sections of the foreign group as well as the entire domestic list advanced.

A record total of 52,871 students have registered in the New York City vocational high schools, a gain of 20 per cent over last year, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, reported yesterday.

Nothing tangible came of Tuesday's White House conference between President Roosevelt, the railway managers and the railway union leaders. The intimation that the President would name a commission to study the matter and perhaps to canvass, more thoroughly than has yet been done, suggested what may be the result.

So certain of victory in Czechoslovakia were Nazi Germans tonight that the problem of making Rumania, with her rich oil and wheat supplies, the next to ripen for a change was already occupying Nazi minds.

Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, testified before the House Investigating Committee today that he had been told $1,000 bills had been distributed among Democratic. State Senators who had been "good boys."

The Securities and Exchange Commission is prepared to take up its work under the Chandler, Act, which amended the Federal Bankruptcy Act and placed upon the commission certain responsibilities and duties in connection with corporation reorganizations under Section 77b.

Leaves Without Pay PATROLMEN-Philip Stein, 34th Precinct, 1 day, from 8 A. M., Oct. 5; Louis Alderstein, 40th Precinct, 3 days, from 4 P. M.,, Oct. 25; Louis Alderstein, 40th Precinct, 1 day, from 8 A. M., Oct. 5; Paul Brody, 41st Precinct, 2 days, from 4 P. M., Sept. 26; Kain Herskovitz, 42d Precinct, 2 days, from 8 A. M., Sent. 26: Nathaniel Greenspan.
State Relief Director Arthur Mudd said today many persons were "viewing unemployment relief as a kind of social security" and relief costs were rising as a result.
The Automobile Club of New York issued yesterday a list of highways in the metropolitan area, Connecticut and Massachusetts that have been closed by floods and storm damage in the last three days.

Premier Juan Negrin of (government) Spain, in a dramatic move in the League of Nations Assembly tonight, announced that "the Spanish Government has just decided on immediate and complete withdrawal of all non-Spanish combatants taking part in the struggle in Spain on the government side."

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton-spinning industry operated in August at 76.2 per cent of capacity on an eighty-hour-week basis, compared with 70.2 per cent in July this year and 85.2 per cent in August last year.

Samuel Bryant, for the last nineteen years treasurer of the American Baptist Home Mission Society of 23 East Twenty-sixth Street, New York, and treasurer also of several Christian colleges, died in his home here this morning after an illness of nine months. He was 62 years old.

The bulk of the apartment leases reported yesterday were for quarters in West Side buildings, many of them on West End Avenue and Central Park West. On the East Side a number of the lessees took large suites, including penthouses and duplexes.
The tropical hurricane that roared up from the south yesterday vented its fullest force locally at the middle of Long Island. The devastation exceeded anything ever before experienced there.

The defeat of Louis Waldman for the Republican nomination for Kings County Judge in Tuesday's primary was interpreted yesterday as considerably weakening the county leadership of John R. Crews, who formed a coalition with the American Labor Party not only on the county ticket but also in a number of the Congressional, Senatorial and Assembly districts.
President Roosevelt, still suffering from a cold, remained in the White House today but continued to receive visitors and otherwise transact executive business.

Former Supreme Court Justice Joseph W. O'Hara of Ohio died in his home here early today at the age of 75. He had been in failing health since May. Justice O'Hara, who belonged to an old Cincinnati family, was a former members of the Board of Education and at has death was district counsel for the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

A sharp fall in Czechoslovak bonds was the most prominent feature in a generally cautious stock market here today. Great Britain's gilt-edge loans sagged but among the foreign government bonds German issue were steady.
Carl G. Schmidt, former president of the State Music Teachers Association, died yesterday afternoon in St. Elizabeth's Hospital here.

Rains and floods more devastating than those of last July swept Westchester Countyy today as the climax of a five-day downpour, the worst in the thirty-one years that New York City has kept weather records at Kensico Dam.

The smallest crowd that has attended the races in New York this season braved the storm that swept Belmont Park yesterday and, among other things, saw Mrs. Clyde Phillips's At Play win the Westchester Claiming Stakes over six furlongs of the Widener course.

Following is the text of the speech of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, at the League of Nations Assembly in Geneva yesterday, as broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company throughout the United States and transcribed from the air.

The buildings at Baileys Beach were swept away today in the worst storm in the city's history. Damage along the waterfront caused by the hurricane was extensive and will exceed $1,000,000. Streets in the lower part of the city were flooded, boats were tossed from their moorings and stranded in the streets.

The Navy uniforms will be different this year, with jerseys of gold. But the blue that was taken out of the jerseys has been transmitted to the midshipmen coaching staff, which views the coming season with dour looks and fears for the worst.

Turpentine firm, 201/4c; sales, 216 barrels; receipts, 356 barrels; shipments, 341 barrels; stock, 49,896 barrels. Rosin firm; sales, 221; receipts, 2,052; shipments. 346; stock, 260,010. Quote: B, $3.50; D, E, $3.80; F, G, H, I, K, M, $4.071/2; N, $4.90; WG, $5.05; WW, X, $6.

Tiemann Ave (16-4397), w e. 143 ft n of Pelham Pkwy N. 60x100; Christopher A. McGregor to Edwin Gould Foundation for Children, 595 Madison Ave. Jackson Ave (10-2637), ?? w c of 161st St, 100x25; Edward Pious, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly over a range of about 50 cents a bale yesterday in response to moderate orders either way while the trade waited for further clarification of the outlook in Europe.

Edwin A. Weis, Inc, upholsterers, through Julian E. Gordon, Inc., agent, two floors in 847 Lexington Ave; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener. Inc., brokers. Simplicity Pattern Corp, sublease from American Type Founders Corp, floor in 104-12 E 25th St; Spear Co, Inc, and Morgan Barry, Inc, co-brokers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order permitting Harry Reid, Max McGraw and B. B. Robinson as the general protective committee for security holders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation to intervene in proceedings having to do with reorganization plans for the corporation and integration of the system under Section 11 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

" Little drops of water," if they continue to fall as they did yesterday, probably will float the Pirates safely into Pennant Harbor, with Skipper Pie Traynor scarcely having to put a finger's pressure on the wheel of the Buccaneer craft.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions FRENCH CO., INC., interior decorators and dealers in antiques and objects of art, 210 E. 57th St.-Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $2,234,076, exclusive of capital stock, and assets of $3,414,660.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, today will ask Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler for permission to distribute $1,000,000 to certain creditors of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.
The five-story brick dwelling, with twelve rooms and four baths, at 29 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by A. H. Laidlaw to Walter Morrow, a client of L. L. Yearsley, broker, for occupancy.

The National Administration's financial policies were attacked today by President George Barton Cutten in his convocation address at the opening of Colgate University. Asserting that they were "robbing the unborn," he added:

Although there has been no marked alteration in business conditions in Canada from those of recent months, the outlook remains clouded by the gravity of conditions in Europe, the Bank of Montreal says in its current business summary.

The gleam of lights seen dimly rocking in Long Island Sound about four miles out gave hope tonight for the safety of twenty passengers and a crew of nine on board the ferry steamer Park City, which had been missing about six hours after leaving here at 2 P. M.

The foreign exchange market continued yesterday to rally on the strength of the lessened prospects of a European war, but engagements of gold abroad for shipment here were resumed. A consignment of $1,300,000 gold was engaged in London yesterday, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank.
The founder of the republic of Czechoslovakia escaped by a few months the fate that has fallen on his successor. Masaryk had the good fortune to die in time to die happily and rest in peace.

Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould will give a reception on Nov. 3 at their home, 160 East Seventy-second Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Edith Kingdon Gould, to the older friends of the family. They will also give a dance on Nov. 26 for the debutante and her young friends.

The Hudson River and its tributaries, swollen by four days of continuous rain, rose near the top of their banks tonight. Government weather observers predicted the Hudson would reach flood stage at Albany by tomorrow afternoon, but minimized the seriousness.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will observe on Saturday the beginning of his fifth year in office, but will mark the day by "work as usual," his associates at Police Headquarters reported yesterday. Mr. Valentine will be the only Police Commissioner in many years, excepting only Richard E. Enright, to serve as long as four full years.
With plenty of work accomplished with a wet ball, Carl Snavely took his Cornell boys into the drill hall this afternoon, where they ran through signals in full regalia except for basketball shoes.

At 8:30 o'clock this evening the Messrs. Olsen and Johnson unleash themselves and "Hellzapoppin" in the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. This is the knockabout revue that includes in its cast Barto and Mann, the Radio Rogues, Bettymae and Beverly Crane, Hal Sherman, Ray Kinney, the Aloha Maids.

Clifton Reeves, an engineer and inventor, died of a heart attack last night at his home near here. His age was 62. At the age of 22 he was designing and building engines for the Pennsylvania Railroad, the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and the dupont Powder Company.
Official comment in regard to the possibility of active Soviet intervention to aid Czechoslovakia is being withheld in Tokyo on the ground that this question is still too hypothetical to be treated.

Following a two-hour workout today the New York Football Giants broke camp and left for New York. The team went through a strenuous session in defensive tactics in preparation for its encounter at Philadelphia on Sunday.

The rapidly fading war scare in Europe was reflected today in the grain markets in a lower level of wheat prices. Relative firmness in Liverpool caused a fractionally higher opening on the Board of Trade here,...
The statement of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $22,434,383 after charges, taxes and reserves.

Initial approval of a plan under which liquor importers and distillers would seek to end price wars in this city by forming a joint organization for enforcement of FeldCrawford contracts was voted yesterday at a meeting of the executive committee of the National Alcoholic Beverage Importers Association.

Strictly choice anil prime fed steers and yearlings sold steady today, but it was a slow and draggy trade on the rank and file of offerings with market mostly weak to 25c lower, reports the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs were weak to 10c lower, but Spring lambs held steady.

Walter H. Close, retired woolen merchant, who died Jan. 23, 1937, left-a net estate of $1,349,204, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. The principal beneficiaries are the widow, two sons and a daughter.
G. Fred Pearson lawyer and former publisher of The Halifax Chronicle, died in his home here early today after a long illness. He would have been 61 years old on Oct. 6.

Britain and France are buying an armistice of Germany, the price of the delivery being her power over Czechoslovakia. This is the inner meaning of present events, which represent a deep humiliation to the AngloFrench entente by a triumphant Germany.
Racing over a deep, holding track, Dixieland, representing D. B. Midkiff, caused a mild upset in the running of the Jarrettsville Purse, outstanding event on today's program.
Charles Walzer, operator, has purchased for cash above a firstmortgage of $81,000 the four-story apartment building at 222 Christie Street, corner of Broad Avenue, Leonia, N. J.

Pepperell Manufacturing Company announced yesterday a shortening of discounts by 21/2 per cent on its Red Label sheets and pillowcases, and offered October, November and December shipments at the new price.

A reduction in the size of Congress and increases in the salaries of its members, to relieve them of economic worry and thus effect a more efficient House, was proposed yesterday by Representative Bruce Barton at a luncheon of the West of Central Park Association in the Hotel Empire.

The methods of the Fashion Originators Guild in the women's dress business were likened to those of Chancellor Hitler in Germany by Ruben J. Martin, a government attorney, in final argument today before the Federal Trade Commission on the commission's complaint against the guild.

Miss Lillian Gish returned on the French liner Ile de France yesterday after a vacation in Europe that included tours through Germany and Czechoslovakia. She said the drama of current world events dimmed the most brilliant efforts of any theatre and that "all you see or hear in Europe is war; no one wants it but everyone is ready for it."

Dr. John J. Shober and Robert T. Schuenemann will coach the backs and ends respectively of the Pennsylvania junior varsity football team, H. Jamieson Swarts, athletic director, announced today. The appointments complete Penn's football staff for 1938.

Although Harvard is not scheduled for its opening football game until a week from Saturday, Coach Dick Harlow continued to drive the entire squad today. Harlow is doing little experimenting with his first team, and, while the backs are constantly being shifted about, is holding to his opening-day line, which includes Green and Daughters, ends;

All except two of the 145 stalwart linksmen who braved yesterday's downpour to begin play in the thirty-fourth annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship tourney were stymied by torrents of rain. and a devastating wind today.

The lower prices announced on Monday for rails and fastenings may have been made as an inducement to railroad buying, without which there can be no approach to profitable operations of steel companies having a large capacity in these products, according to The Iron Age.

Dr. and Mrs. J. Alexander McCreery of Greenwich, Conn., entertained tonight at a dinner at the Elkridge Kennels and a supper dance at the Baltimore Country Club in honor of their twin debutante daughters, Miss Joan McCreery and Miss Lalande McCreery.

The average collection rate of twenty metropolitan stores in August was 40.20 per cent, compared with 40.08 per cent a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Seven concerns reported increases, twelve had decreases and one had no change from a year ago.

In another warlike speech delivered at Treviso against the now customary background of wildly cheering crowds and military preparedness, Premier Mussolini once again put himself on record as "insisting on an integral solution" of the Czech crisis that will extend to all minorities the same benefits granted to the Sudeten Germans.

At the second and closing day of the twenty-fourth annual flower show arranged by the American Dahlia Society at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx, it was announced yesterday that the president, vice president and secretary and treasurer of the society had been re-elected by mail ballots.

John A. Mitchell, since 1931 City Controller of Elizabeth, died early today at the Winfield Scott Hotel here at the age of 52. He suffered a heart attack late last night while listening to primary election returns at the Democratic campaign headquarters in the hotel. He had been active in the successful campaign of Police Judge James T. Kirk for the Mayoralty nomination.

The heavy drop in the government's revenues from commercial taxes, reflecting business conditions earlier in the year, was continued through July and August, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

So much of Paragraph 9, Special Orders 203, dated Aug. 31, 1938. relating to Capt. John J. Healy, Inf.-Res., as orders him to active duty at Pine Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., effective Sept. 10, and relieving him effective Sept. 22, is amended so as to order him to active duty at Pine Plains Military Reservation, Great Bend, N. Y., effective Sept. 10, and relieving him, effective Sept. 23.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for an apartment house on West Twenty-fifth Street to cost $175,000. Details of these and other plans follow:

Ducky Wucky Medwick drove in all the runs today as the St. Louis Cardinals shut out the Bees, 4 to 0, in the first game of a scheduled double-header. Paul Dean, in his second stalt since a short term in the Texas League, allowed the Bees but seven hits, all singles.

Two narrow escapes by the defending champion and the runner-up and the elimination of the last four British players and of three American Curtis Cup stars were the features of the second and third rounds in the women's national golf championship at the Westmoreland Country Club today.

Samuel Mann, who identified himself as a stockholder in Hearst Consolidated Publications, Inc., had a suit on file in Superior Court here today seeking recovery of more than $53,000,000 in behalf of himself and other stockholders.

Insisting he was speaking for himself and not for the President, Harry L. Hopkins gave support today to the candidacies of Culbert L. Olson for Governor and Sheridan Downey for the Senate upon his arrival here on a WPA projects inspection tour.

One of the many important issues raised for the French by cession of the Sudeten area and settlement of the Czechoslovak question is the ownership of the Skoda armaments factory, located in Pilsen, with branches in other parts of the country.

Sunlit garden apartments soon will rise on a fifty-acre site in Brooklyn where only a few months ago rows of tenements and old factories stood. Construction work on the first units of the Red Hook low-rent housing development will be started on Monday by the George A. Fuller Construction Company, the New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday.

Sales of realty in Manhattan reported yesterday by brokers included contracts for properties in Harlem. The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, sold to a client of Hyman Hyman, attorneys, the five-story apartment house containing sixty rooms at 23 West 112th Street.

Manhattan's football squad engaged Columbia in a short, spirited scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday as a final contact session for the Jaspers' opening game Saturday against St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island. In a heavy rain the first and second Lion and Jasper elevens opposed each other simultaneously at opposite ends of the field.

All previous records for postponement in the national tennis championships were broken yesterday when the violent rain storm soaked the stadium courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills in spite of their tarpaulin covers and made play impossible before tomorrow.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a message received yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal, called upon American Jews to engage in "sacrificial, national self-taxation" to provide $5,000,000 during the year for settlement and defense of the Jewish community in Palestine.

The tremendous growth. of investment trusts and investment companies in the boom era in the late Twenties, when speculative activities were at their peak, was shown in another chapter of its study which the Securities and Exchange Commission sent today to Congress.

There were 1,845 fewer railroad train accidents in the six months through June, 440 fewer deaths and 5,211 fewer persons injured than in the first half of 1937, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

Just as labor has been deceived by the Wagner act, so will the United States eventually discover that "many of the so-called 'liberal' pol icies enacted into laws ate not really working out for the public good," T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation,

New York virtually was transformed into a typical hurricanebelt city yesterday afternoon as driving rain, swept by a gale of sixty-eight-miles an hour, lashed across the city, leaving in its wake. a damaged and flooded metropolis.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain is flying to Godesberg on the Rhine this morning, taking not only the submission of Czechoslovakia to Germany's demands of last week but also a whole set of demands of his own.
Following is the text of the com munique in which the Czechoslovak Government tonight announced its acceptance of the Anglo-French plan for meeting Chancellor Adolf Hitler's demands:

Importers concerned about the rate of duty they will have to pay on merhcandise on order in the Sudeten area once that district is taken over by Germany made numerous calls to import organizations for advice yesterday.

Mrs. Annie Elms, 99 years old, who was once a performer at Tony Pastor's Theatre and now is known to many in the theatrical world as Mother Elms, was taken from an Avenue B bus at Chatham Square yesterday afternoon suffering from : amnesia and sent to Bellevue Hospital for treatment.

Frank I. Frayne, veteran character actor, died last night at his home at 224 Brooklyn Avenue here after five weeks' illness. He was a member of a family long well known on the American stage. His age was 75.

What was described in some quarters today as a precedent for the distribution of surplus agricultural commodities to charitable agencies without direct return to the growers marked a court decision upholding the government's right to assess producers engaging in interstate commerce.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., told the Supreme Court today that its "operations, relations and labor practices are exclusively and entirely intrastate" and that it should not be subject to the National Labor Relations Act.
Arguments as to the best bore for upland game shooting have waged for years, and the man who has become accustomed to the cylinder bore has no use for the modified choke.

Of the hundreds of stories of adventures in the storm which filtered out of Long Island last night, one was about Livingston Gibson and his wife, Negro servants employed by Mrs. George H. Townsend, Westhampton Beach.
Eric K. Palmros has joined Amott, Baker Co., Inc., as the firm's Syracuse representative. Nelson Coty will be in the New York City department of the cormpany.
While railroad service throughout the metropolitan area was slowed up as a result of yesterday's storm,by far the most severely hit section was Long Island.
The American Legion today reiterated its demand for a larger army, a navy second to none and expressed itself as unalterably opposed to a referendum on war.

Confirmation of last week's report that they would make a picture with Eddie 'Cantor was given today by RKO, when announcement of the comedian's signing was made. The deal calls for one picture, with no options, for which Cantor will receive $100,000 and a share in the profits.
Miss ?? Taylor Price will have her twin sister, Mrs. Andrew Marckwald of Morristown, N. J., for her ?? of honor at her marriage to Robert Miner Gillespie, which will take place here on Oct. 10.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced today that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Alton Railroad Company, would not pay on Oct. 1 the interest then due on its 3 per cent refunding bonds and was seeking to develop a plan to reduce fixed charges.
Another auditor of the State Insurance Fund for Employes was arrested yesterday on evidence obtained by Bernard Botein, general counsel to the fund, in an investigation ordered by Governor Lehman.

Miss Elizabeth Jane Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spencer Hart of this place, was married to Paul Gannon Downey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Downey of Chicago, this afternoon in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev.

The Red Sox beat the Browns, 8 to 4, today to sweep a three-game series, centering their attack on one big inning-a five-run fifth. Jimmy Foxx clouted his fortyseventh home run of the season with a mate aboard to start that rally.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Sept. 20: COLONEL Bennett, E. E., C.A.C., 62d C. A., Ft. Totten, N. Y., to Third C. A. Dist., Ft. Monroe, Va., about Dec. 1. MAJORS Gebhardt, E. G., Dental Corps, promoted to grade of lieutenant colonel, with rank from Sept. 10. 1938.

In its annual statement for 1937, released yesterday, the Singer Manufacturing Company reported for the full year a net profit of $14,302,906 -after taxes, expenses and other charges. This was equivalent to $15.89 each on the 900,000 shares of $100 par capital stock outstanding.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since I, an English visitor, have been here I have heard on all sides approval of the Czech cause as a just one. Such it undoubtedly is. At the same time there appears to be in this country increased condemnation of both Britain and France because they are prepared to explore every means to avoid war.
Princeton football players, resting after yesterday's scrimmage, retired to the R. O. T. C. riding hall today for a non-contact drill out of the driving rain that hindered the previous two workouts.

Fatal accidents on bus lines hate been reduced 36 per cent in ten years largely through a drivers' safetyprogram, Marcus Dow of Cleveland said today in a report tb the convention of the National Association of Motor Bus Operators.

Lump-sum payments under the Federal old-age insurance program in this State have passed the $1,000,000 mark, Mrs. Anna M. Rosen- with berg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced yesterday.

H. W. Siddall, chairman of the Trans-Continental Passenger Association and the Western "Passenger Association, offered yesterday figures to show that the increasing of passenger fares did not increase revenues.
Listings have been authorized by the committee on stock list of the Exchange for several issues. Authorization does not mean that the securities will be admitted immediatelv to dealings.

William Scott, 34 years old, a laborer, of 246 East Third Street, was sentenced to serve 192 days in the workhouse by Magistrate Louis Brodsky yesterday after he had pleaded guilty to charges of driving while intoxicated, leaving the scene of an accident, driving without an operator's license and without a registration certificate.

Plans for raising the Presbyterian sesqui-centennial fund for Christian education call for concentration of the campaign from Nov. 1 to April 1, next, in and about New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, Pittsburgh and St. Louis, it was announced here today at the semi-annual meeting of the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

THERE was no sign of Pie Traynor in the Pirate hostelry yesterday noon. They said he had gone out. They didn't know what for. It couldn't have been for a breath of air. It might have been for a bucket of water. A man could get a bucket of water down the back of his neck by walking ten yards in the open in any direction about that time.

Mayor La Guardia paid his first visit to a motion picture studio today when he inspected the plant of Walter Wanger Productions in Hollywood as the guest of the youthful producer who flew with him on the Italian front during the war.

Water and sky are resolutely blue. The birches, gathered in white groups along The bank, look down into the Lemonweir And preen, or stand indifferently and stare, Or restless, whisper the same sibilant tongue They spoke when the Americas were young. Here in these miles the New World still is new.

Riverside Hospital on North Brothers Island in the East River was without lights or heat or a means of communicating with the mainland for a short time after 8 o'clock last night when the extremely high tide completely covered the island with water for about a half hour, according to Health Commissioner Dr. S. S. Goldwater.

The St. Joseph Lead Company today increased the operating schedule of its Southeastern Missouri mines and mills from six days every other week to four days each week. It employs about 2,500 men at a minimum wage of $5.50 for an eight-hour day at its properties in Bonne Terre, Leadwood, Desloge, Flat River and Mine La Motte.
The marriage of Miss Barbara Hart of New York, daughter of Mrs. EdWard Robertson Hart of this city and of the late Mr. Hart, to Herbert Gordon Dyke,

A new artificial silk, superior to natural silk or any synthetic rayon in its fineness, strength and elasticity has been patented here by the late W. H. Carothers, chemist of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company. For the past month, du Pont officials have maintained a complete silence,

Memorial services for the deceased members of this department will be held at the Firemen's Monument, 100th St. and Riverside Drive, Borough of Manhattan, on Sunday, Oct. 9. The Fire Chief and Commissioner, in affording the officers and members of the department this opportunity to honor the memory of their deceased comrades, requests that all members who are off duty on that day volunteer to take part in the services.

Factional rows, Republican and Democratic, were decided in a number of New Jersey counties in Tuesday's primary. The interest in most is only local. The decisive victory of Mr. Clee's Clean Goverrment group in Essex County is an exception.

-Frederic Foster de Rham, vice president and trust officer of the Fulton Trust Company of New York, who has been a prominent member of the Tuxedo Park colony for many years, died at his home here at 8 o'clock tonight of a stroke of appoplexy. He was 54 years old.

The 10,000-ton British cruiser Devonshire and the destroyers Afridi and Cossack, three of the most modern warships in the Mediterranean Fleet, which arrived here Monday for a four-day stay, were suddenly ordered to Alexandria, Egypt, this morning.

More than fifty women walked into the vault room of the United States Marshal's office yesterday to attend what had been advertised as a fashion show but what looked more like an old-fashioned rummage sale.

The Anglo-French deal with Adolf Hitler for the surrender of the Sudeten region of Czechoslovakia was denounced as "the diplomatic Sedan of the democracies" at a meeting of more than 5,000 persons in the Royal Windsor Palace, 53 West Sixtysixth Street, last night, and the prediction was made that it would lead ton another World War.

City parks were reduced almost to shambles and thousands of trees in the five boroughs were mowed down, tilted at dangerous angles, stripped of their limbs or left nearly leafless by the storm yesterday, and in many instances the falling trunks and -storm-strewn

Dictionaries and encyclopedias differ in some essentials on the distinction between a cyclone and a tornado. They are in agree ment, however, that except in geographical usage a cyclone, a typhoon and a hurricane are one and the same.

Electric power production gained last week. Daily average output rose when the seasonal trend was unchanged, and the adjusted index advanced to 97.7, a new high for the year. This compares with 95.3 for the preceding week, and 104.2 for the week ended Sept. 18, 1937.

A much superior English League eleven decisively defeated the Irish League representatives, 8-2, today in the second match of the season's inter-league soccer series. It was England's thirtyfourth victory in forty games played since the two countries first met in these contests. The Irishmen have been successful on only two occasions, four games being drawn.

Winds of near-hurricane force imposed a costly toll on harbor shipping yesterday, mostly in the form of inconvenience and delay. Actual damage was slight, as all shipping had ample.-warning of the storm's striking hour.

Prospects that the recent reciprocal trade treaty entered into between this country and Czechoslovakia will have to be revised as the result of the cession to Germany of the Sudeten industrial area were seen today by Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper.

Joseph Husband, author and advertising man, died in a hospital here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 53. For the last two years he had been living at the Hotel San Rafael, 65 West Forty-fifth Street.

Army's huge riding hall was taken over by the cadet football squad today. Coach Bill Wood sent the A and B squads into the big building where he conducted dummy scrimmage among four teams. He also included a speed workout for the line, while the backs worked on passes.

French Co., Inc., one of the largest dealers in antiques and art objects in the world, filed a petition yesterday through Mitchell Samuels, its president, for permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.

A proposal for the reorganization of the Pittston Company, a "vertical trust" organized by the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen to control a vast system of coal production, distribution and sale, was issued yesterday following a meeting of the holding agency's directors.
Pope Pius, on receiving a group of French pilgrims today, recommended prayer as the only hope for Europe. He asked the Catholic churches of Rome to pray for peace Sunday.

The British Broadcasting Corporation, which supplies Britain with all its radio entertainment and news, is prepared to go on a war basis under which it will scrap all regular programs and supply news broadcasts at fifteen-minute intervals, it was said tonight in The World's Press News, trade paper of the British press.

ACHESON--John Huyler, on Sept. 21, at his residence, 823 Madison Ave., son of Margaret Maher and the late Dr. Edward G. Acheson,. and father of Cornell Acheson. Services at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church Chapel, 73d St. and Madison Ave., Thursday at 2 P. M.

Lashing widespread areas along the Atlantic seaboard that were already suffering flood conditions from days of drenching rain, a tropical hurricane passed along the coast from Cape Hatteras to Nantucket yesterday to cause scores of deaths and incalculable property damage.

Nine scholarships and prize awards were announced yesterday at the exercises marking the opening of the forty-first year of the Cornell University Medical College, York Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street. Dr. William Sargent Ladd, dean of the college, announced that eighty-one new students for the first-year course were included in a total en7 rollment of 287.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Monday in Vienna of Dr. Franz J. A. Torek of this city and Montclair, N. J., a specialist in throat surgery who was formerly president of the American Association for Thoracic Surgery.

The Republican campaign this year will enlist all of its important speakers, including former President Hoover, who will deliver three major addresses, the Republican National Committee announced today.

The State of Maine will be in the market on Sept. 30 with an issue of $1,000,000 of 2 per cent highway bonds, it was announced yesterday. The bonds will be dated Oct. 1, 1938, and will mature serially on Oct. 1, 1940 to 1949.

Centre St, 174, 27.2x157.11; Simon Finkelstein to Ralph G. Kretschmar, 775 Park Ave; p m, 10 years, 4 per cent; $10,000. 116th St, 105-7 E, 40.O1xl00.11; One, Inc. to N. Y. Savings Bank, p m, due and nt as per bond; $19,500.

A suggestion that President Roosevelt invite the heads of European nations to a conference in the United States in an attempt to solve present international problems came today from Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher.

Czechoslovak Government and municipal bonds fell 15 to 16 points in the market today after British news agencies reported the Prague government had capitulated to the British-French demand for the cession of Sudeten German areas to Germany.
The whole Rumanian press condemns the Anglo-French plan to partition Czechoslovakia, especially as it is believed here that its acceptance will have wide

Safety at sea has been taken out of the realm of legislation and is ?? the direct responsibility of ship lines, according to Captain J. G. Johnson, vice president of the Sinclair Navigation Company. Captain Johnson spoke yesterday before the marine section of the National Safety Council at a meeting at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.
Paul Barrese, 15 years old, was killed by a hit-and-run driver Sunday afternoon near his home at 2,500 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn. He was dragged eighty feet and his skull was fractured.

A New Deal victory and defeat for the local leadership of both major parties came as the result of the primary contests in the Sixteenth Congressional District, in which Representative John J. O'Connor won renomination in the Republican party but lost the Democratic nomination.

At the request of defense counsel the hearing of a charge of inciting to riot against Herman Matson, 38 years old, of 812 Willow Avenue, Hoboken, was adjourned today until Oct. 7 by Police Recorder Frank Romano here. Edward Stover, attornev representing Matson,

A wind which reached gale force in Central and Western Orange County caused thousands of dollars in damage today and from early morning until late in the eve ning forced State officials to block or detour traffic on Route 17, the Federal highway connecting New York City with Western cities, because of fallen trees, telegraph poles and debris.

The striking truck drivers, who have almost completely tied up shipping in the Port of New York for the last week by their "outlaw" walkout, and the trucking operators, agreed shortly 'after last midnight to a four-day truce.
Except for the breaking of Czech school windows, no anti-Czech disorders were reported here today. At the largest school whose windows were broken, sixty stones were counted inside.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey obtained yesterday indictments charging manslaughter against three part-owners of the tenement house at 302 East Houston Street in which, three months ago, a middle-aged man and his wife were burned fatally in a fire which swept through the structure at an early-morning hour.

A hurricane that started at 2:30 P. M. today and continued in full force for four hours, left destruction about the city Roofs were blown off, plate-glass windows smashed and most of the big elm trees which dotted the city were leveled.

Development of a personal sense of humor and of humility to avoid our own tendences toward dictatorship was urged by President Jamee L. McConaughy of Wesleyan Uni. versity in his address at the matriculation service here today.

Miss Camilla Morgan and Remsen Ditmars Donald, who will be married on Saturday in St. Luke's Church, Peapack, N. J., were the guests of honor last night at a ner dance given by Mr. Donald's mother, Mrs. George Donald, on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

In the midst of negotiations looking toward a settlement of the "outlaw" truck drivers' strike, Acting Mayor Newbold Morris encountered added worries last night when he received word that his two sons, Peter, 7 years old, who is ill with Rocky Mountain fever;

Three dwelling properties in the Bronx are reported sold by Eugene J. Busher Company, Inc., brokers. The four-family house at 1,250 Stratford Avenue, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, was purchased by a client of Abraham Kriegsfeld, co-broker, from a client of Cardozo Nathan, attorneys;

The budget, which Treasurer R. G. Casey introduced this afternoon, reverses budgetary trends since 1932. Chiefly to defray the cost of the defence program, the Lyons i Government for the first time will be compelled to impose a fairly widespread increase in taxation.
If our neighbor The Sun were to amuse itself assembling copper pennies in neat piles of ten coins each, what would be the final,

The largest advertising campaign in its history will be launched in the second week of October by P. Ballantine Sons, Newark, with the major portion of the budget going into. newspapers. The drive, which will continue for one year, calls for large-size space in 150 newspapers in 110 cities in the area in which the company has distribution.

William McIlroy, district agent for Canadian Pacific Railroad and Steamships, will retire Sept. 30 after forty-seven years of C. P. R. service. He has been in active charge of the office here since May, 1922.

Representatives of British shipping interests today protested to Ronald Cross, Parliamentary Secretary to the Board of Trade, against the recent heavy increases in marine war risk insurance. They were assured that, the situation was being carefully considered by the government.

Belmiro Vadeverde, who is alleged to shave beheaded the Integralista uprising of May 11, has bolted from the jail at which he has been confined. His escape, which became known several days ago, was confirmed today by the chief of police. In talking to newspaper men the police chief stated that an investigation had been ordered by the government.

When Deputy Mayor Curran weighs the question of playgrounds for dogs against playgrounds for babies there can be only one answer. It is the one he has just made to a dog-loving correspondent. There won't be any dog playground, at least not this year.
Vice Admiral John Roderick Segrave, British naval representative to the League of Nations from 1920 to 1923, died today at the age of 66.
Representative Samuel B. Pettengill of Indiana will address a luncheon of the New York State unit of the National Conference of Investors in the Hotel Astor tomorrow.

The field in the six-day bicycle race was closely bunched through last night as the rugged pedallers churned their way into their fourth successive night of riding at Madison Square Garden. The pace was undiminished, and the cyclists, buffeted though they have been by falls and collisions, nevertheless showed no signs of letting up in their arduous going.

The Great Lakes Regional Advisory Board received today at its semiannual meeting here a forecast of a 7.3 per cent drop in carloadings of commodities in the Great Lakes area during the last quarter of 1938.
Radio, telephone and telegraph communications suffered in the New York area yesterday as the storm swept along the coast, ripping down lines and cutting off power supplies.

A vehement protest against TVA as a government subsidized project that crucifiess" coal, injures private coal mining enterprise and reduces employment was made before the convention of the National Industrial Stores Association by John D. Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association, today.

James W. Thornton has, been promoted from vice president to executive vice president and A. C. Ebbesen has been advanced to merchandising and advertising manager of William Jameson Co., Lionel Marks, president, announced yesterday. Paul B. Fischer has been made assistant to the president.

Advanced detachment of the First InBrigade, First Division, United States Army, arrived at storm-swept Camp Dix today to make final preparations for the arrival of the brigade tomorrow for annual manoeuvres.
A warning to Americans to be on guard against "attempts at racial and religious discrimination of the Hitler pattern" came today from State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh.

John A. Keliher, 71, former Representative in Congress and, since 1917, Sheriff Suffolk County (Boston), died late last night of a heart attack while primary returns showed he was as a waging a losing battle against City Councilor John F. Dowd for renomination for the office he had held twenty-one years.

Howard Whitfield of Red Bank, N. J., president of the Whitfield Paper Works of New York, died Tuesday in Stamford, N. Y., where he was on a vacation, according to word received here yesterday. He was 67 years old.
A power failure on the lines of the Consolidated Edison Company plunged parts of Manhattan and all of the Bronx into darkness about 8:45 o'clock last night.

Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Army Air Corps, and Sergeant Samuel Hynes, his crew chief, were instantly killed near here at 1:20 o'clock this afternoon when their Northrop attack plane crashed from an altitude of 400 feet while they were attempting to land at the Lockheed Airport one mile and a half from the center of Burbank.

A QUARTER century of California history is packed into George R. Stewart's big novel called "East of the Giants,"* one of the most satisfying books of its kind we have had since "Northwest Passage." Mr. Stewart isn't another Kenneth Roberts but neither is Kenneth Roberts another Mr. Stewart, so the score is about even.

The twenty-second annual Bryn Mawr hound show opened today on the water-logged horse show grounds with a northeast storm raging all day. The floor of the huge tent in which the show opened was almost a sea of mud due to a driving rain which swept across the spacious grounds, but the show went on.
The French liner Ile de France will sail today for Plymouth and Havre with the following among the passengers: General Georges Brissaud-Desmaillets, Erich Von Stroheim, Al Trahan,

Arlington C. Hall, builder, who purchased a large plot of land at 246th Street and Fieldston Avenue in the Fieldston section of Riverdale from the Hubbard estate, has enlarged his holding by purchasing from the Parkway Heights Company, Edward C. Delafield, treasurer, an additional plottage of 28,000 square feet.

The Princeton Theological Seminary opened its 127th year today with an enrollment of 220 students. Dr. Robert E. Speer of Lakeville, Conn., president of the board of trustees, gave the opening address in Miller Chapel on the campus.

" Good News"--With a Difference From a strictly market viewpoint the news of the decision of the Czech Government to capitulate to the demands that it cede the Sudeten area to Germany was favorable. Prices, quite naturally, improved as the threat of war seemed to recede.

Riding into the teeth of a lashing gale which caused heavy track damage and cancellation of the Rockingham Park card at the end of the sixth race. Eddie Robart, youthful apprentice jockey from Pawtucket, R. I., today outrode the weather to win two feature races.

MANHATTAN CLOSE, WALTER H. (Jan. 23, 1937). Gross assets, $1,504,392: net, $1,349,204. To Louise Palmer Close, widow, $10,000 and life estate in residue; Walter H. Close Jr., son, $20,000, life interest in $20,000 trust, remainder interest: David Palmer Close, son, same; Rita Florence Suzanne Close, daughter, life estate in $20,000 and remainder interest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,475,048. Spence, Hopkins, Walser Hotchkiss, attorneys.

New York Giants vs. Cincinnati Reds, double-header, at Polo Grounds, Eighth , Avenue and 157th Street.......1:45 P. M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, double-header, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn,

A plan of reorganization for the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation calling for the segregation of the concern's telegraph system from its cable and radio systems and leaving out any provision for the holders of preferred and common stocks of the corporation was submitted yesterday to the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York.

Carl W. Hamilton, art collector, dropped yesterday in Supreme Court his $2,000,000 suit against Lord Joseph Duveen of Milbank, internationally known art expert, and others. Whether any out-of- St court settlement had been reached was not disclosed.

Drastic revision of Soviet foreign policy--turning its back on Europe, its eyes on Asia--was foreseen tonight by some diplomats as a probable result of the successful Anglo-French pressure on Czechoslovakia to give Adolf Hitler new territory.

THE DEAD GO OVERSIDE, by Arthur D. Howden Smith. (Greystone, $2.50.) A novel about the slave trade. EAST OF THE GIANTS, by George R. Stewart. (Holt, $2.50.) A novel about a New England girl who ran away to share the fortunes of a Spanish don in old California.

Plans for the construction of at least one and- possibly two of the three bridges originally included in the Maryland program,. which has enlisted the support of President Roosevelt, were revived today with the announcement - that Maryland bankers are prepared to cooperate in financing the State's contribution to the project...

A deal whereby the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company will buy $600,370 of foreign steel from Davis Co., Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, was disclosed in a listing statement made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Battery Park, which usually takes the best and worst of weather across its flat reaches, was badly battered by the storm. Waves flooded over the seawall under the wind's driving force and several trees were leveled.

Anthony Eden, former Foreign Secretary; Winston Churchill, a Conservative, and Sir Archibald Sinclair, leader of the Liberal party, today condemned the government's foreign policy of the past few days as dishonorable and extremely dangerous.

Following is a list of nominees of the Democratic, Republican and American Labor parties in contested districts throughout the State. Where there was no contest the nominee is not listed. There were no contests in the Socialist party.

The Blue Army continued to deliver smashing blows tonight on that retreating Black Army which, in the Second Army command post exercise, was assumed to have been threatening to cleave the United States in a drive for the Middle West Sunday night.

The Census Bureau has estimated the population of the United States on last Jan. 1 at 129,818,000, it was said today by Secretary Roper. This represented an increase of 941,000, or seven-tenths of 1 per cent,

The Eastern Ice Yachting Association, formed last year, met last night at Ruppert's Brewery, with delegates from sixteen clubs as well as individual members attending. George Ruppert, who has been interested in the sport for many years, was host at a dinner following the session.

Integration of industry and labor, of business and the public and of business men themselves. is one of the chief needs confronting business' today, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, declared in his annual report,- sent out to members of the association yesterday.

It was officially announced here today that the Polish Minister in Prague had presented a virtual ultimatum to Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta declaring the Polish Government expects Czechoslovakia to settle the problem of the territories inhabited by Poles in the same manner as the territories with a German population.

Luncheon, New York Rotary Club, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Our Vast Invisible Government", Dr. M. Lyle Spencer. Luncheon, Soroptimist Club, in honor of Magistrate Anna M. Kross, Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, 12:30 P. M.

Forrest H. Figsby, a partner of Ernst Ernst of New York, accountants, died this morning in the Ossining Hospital of acute leukemia after more than four years of impaired health due to heart disease. He would have been 56 years old on Oct. 17.

In a formal report to SupremeCourt Justice, Aron Steuer, Referee B. Leo Schwarz reported yesterday that a Harlem. apartment owner had been defrauded of $30,578 in a mortgage loan transaction and that testimony before him indicated that other property owners had been fleeced in the same manner.

Because of the illness of Hizi Koyke, who is suffering from laryngitis, Fortune Gallo will present Enya Gonzales, 19-year-old Philippine soprano, in the title role of "Madame Butterfly" at the Center Theatre tonight. This will be Miss Gonzales's operatic debut in this country.

A warm, Autumn sun smiled today on much of the Middle West, where rain has fallen for the last fifteen days. Records showed two other periods of fifteen days with a trace of rain in the past, three of sixteen and one of seventeen.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and-Mrs. C. Randolph Simmen of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bettina Sherwood Simmen, to John Herbert Connors, son of Mrs. John Connors of Lake Katonah, formerly of White Plains, and the late Mr. Connors.
A daughter was born here last Friday to Mr. and Mrs. Laurance Spelman Rockefeller of 115 East Soxty-seventh Street and Pocantico Hills, N. y. Mrs. Rockefekker is the former Miss Mary French
Rain made it impossible to start the 108-hole golf tournament slated to get under way yesterday at the Fenway Golf Club, White Plains, N. Y., for the big purse of the year--$13,500.

Margaret Mitchell is preparing for presentation to the World Center for Women'd Archives the bibliography of source material she used in writing "Gone With the Wind" (Macmillan). The archives headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore announces that the collection of data on and by Amelia Earhart will be enlarged by George Palmer Putnam, who has promised to present several more documents relating to the late flier.
Plans for one of the largest buildIngs of the World's Fair, approved by the fair corporation's board of design, were announced yesterday by Vasily V. Bourgman, Soviet Commissioner.

Inquiries from abroad for American-made gas masks have reached suppliers here in quantity since the war scare in Central and Southeastern Europe, but no orders have resulted, exporters said yesterday. The requests for quotations began arriving during the Nazi congress at Nuremberg and reached a peak late last week. After that they started to fall off.

The committee on ensemble musical training and scholarship of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society issued an appeal for funds yesterday in order that its work may not be curtailed this Winter. The committee enables talented young people to study with the first desk men of the orchestra and eventually to graduate into positions with orchestras throughout the country.

Civics used to be something that a student learned out of a book against his will. If in mature life he failed to exhibit something called "civic spirit," one of the-reasons must have been that he associated the term with dull and dreary hours. In New York City,...

Byron (Whizzer) White led the Pittsburgh football team into town yesterday to complete preparations for the encounter with the Dodgers at Ebbets Field tomorrow night. The Pirates will work out this morning at De Witt Clinton Field.

Center St, 174, 155x27x irreg; Ralph G. Kretschmar to Simon Finkelstein, 1,592 Jessup Ave ($45). 7th Ave, 255, 21.4x79.2; 23d St Holding Corp to Fredk V. Littlefield, 223 Fairview Ave, Bogota, N. J., et al.

Prague capitulated to AngloFrench pressure early yesterday morning and agreed to accept the partition plan. Announcement of the decision evoked spirited demonstrations, hostility to France and threats of a general strike today, and put the government in jeopardy.

Late returns from the Wisconsin primaries showed that Governor Philip F. La Follette remained the best vote getter among aspirants for his office, although the Republicans exceeded his Progressive party's total vote by more than 62,000 votes.

Ending Russia's silence, Maxim Litvinoff, only Foreign Minister of a great power present at this League Assembly session, took the platform today to appeal, over the head of governments, to public opinion-especially in Britain and France-in favor of Czechoslovakia and peace through the maintenance and execution of the League covenant's coercive provisions and the Czech alliances with France and Russia.

The pixies took charge of the President's Democratic party "purge'; after it had been nationally repudiated and divested of any danger to coordinate government. For their playground the "little folk" chose the Sixteenth Congressional District of New York City

The Rubicon Operating Corporation has purchased for investment from the Prudential Insurance Company of America the six-story Wingrey garden apartment house, known as 30 Locust Hill Avenue, Yonkers, said to be one of the largest of its type in that community.

BERNSTEIN, JULIE E. (Sept. 14).. Estate, more than $10,000. To Rachel Eppinger, sister, 1,125 Park Ave., $10,000 in trust and equal share in residue with Rose Fox, sister, same address. De Witt Millhauser. Harrison, N. Y., executor.

Members of the Super Market Institute, meeting for the final session 'of their second annual convention here today, heard from a wholesale grocer that there was "more money" to be made in the super-market field. The speaker was J. E. Grosberg, secretary of the institute and president of Central Markets, Inc. of Schenectady, N. Y.

The large "complimentary" vote for Wy. Warren Barbour, Republican, and William. Harvey J. Ely, Democrat, as candidates for the United States Senate drew wide attention yesterday in New Jersey as the results of Tuesday's primaries were recapitalated.

The Southern Railway announced today the award of contracts for new equipment to complete a $15,000,000 reconstruction program. A. T. Stovall, assistant traffic manager, said the company had ordered six Diesel-electric two and three car trains from the St. Louis

The world production of tin in July amounted to 11,600 tons, making a total of 94,300 for the first seven months of this year, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council. For the first seven months of last year output was 110.500 tons.
Exhibitors at the Empire Exhibition at Glasgow generally express satisfaction with the business inquiries received so far. They report a tremendous trade in the purchase of samples.

Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates-Twelve months to Aug. 31: Net income after expenses and charges, $1,346,926, equal, after prior preference stock dividend requirements, to 64 cents a share on the outstanding 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock.

The French capital was stirred tonight by rumors of a partial Cabinet crisis. The government made haste to deny rumors, which gained currency through radio announcements in English, that Paul Reynaud, Minister of Justice;

George McCurrach, of 234 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, formerly for fifty years associated with the neckwear manufacturing firm of James McCurrach Bros., died on Wednesday in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital after an operation.

More than 150 inhabitants of a fishing village in this community, whose homes were destroyed by the storm, were being quartered today in Montauk Manor, a Summer hotel which was recently closed for the season.

The city's parks and parkways suffered $450,000 damage in Wednesday's storm, according to an estimate made yesterday by William H. Latham, Park Department engineer. Much of the destruction was done to trees in all the five boroughs.

Awards for work on a number of public and semi-public projects, including, highways, slum-clearance, and airport development are largely responsible for a rise of 95 per cent in the engineering construction contracts in the current week over the same week of last year, according to the Engineering News-Record.

BRONX COHEN, ROBERT (March 25). Gross assets, $28,586; net, $27,764. To Fannie Cohen, widow one-third residue; Sylvia Cohen, Martha and Dorothy Cohen, daughters: Paul Joseph Cohen son one-sixth each. Chief assets, other miscellaneous property. $28,083. Joseph Goldberg, attorney. 51 Chambers St.

A move to seek changes in practices of resident buying offices was begun by members of the Garment Salesmen's Guild, Inc., organization of dress salesmen, at a meeting last night in the Hotel Piccadilly.

A Detroit- attorney indicated today that Mrs. Laurine McDonald Dodge may contest the will in which her husband, the late Daniel G. Dodge, heir to an automobile fortune, bequeathed her $250,000 of a $10,000,000 estate.

Clayton S. Coggeshall has been appointed manager of the turbine division, central station department, of the General Electric Company, Schenectady, succeeding the late Robert B. Beale. The Textile School of New York, a division of the Abbe Institute, has added to its faculty Jack Jarmack of Cluett Peabody Co., Inc.;

The third annual Fall conference of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking will be held in Minneapolis on Oct. 13,'Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar of this city, president of the society, reported yesterday.

An application of the Lehigh Valley Railroad for authority to pledge through June 30, 1939, as collateral security for a promissory note or notes of' $1,000,000 to the order of the Philadelphia National Bank and

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Prophecy has always been a dangerous business but a necessary ones At present we have a whole new crop of business prophets foretelling the direst happenings to the world. Perhaps they are right. We hope they are wrong. At any rate, how do they know?

With substantially normal power and light service restored last night through the use of emergency and substitute facilities, the Consolidated Edison Company had all available manpower working on the job of putting back into commission the Hell Gate and Port Morris plants, which were disabled Wednesday night by the hurricane.

A special meeting of stockholders of the S. R. Dresser Manufacturing Company has been called for Dec. 1 to vote on a plan of recapitalization which provides for conversion of present Class A and Class B shares into one class of capital stock. The plan also provides for absorption of the Clark Brothers Company, a wholly owned subsidiCompany, a wholly owned subsidiary.

United States Weather Bureau officials were puzzled today at the intensity and duration of the hurricane and indicated on the basis of reports from the, stricken areas that it was unprecedented in the bureau's records.

Shortage developed this week in a number of divisions of the wool goods markets, notably in worsted coverts, according to the weekly summary of the New York Wool Top Exchange, issued yesterday. Jobbers were asking and getting a 25-cent-a-yard premium for spot deliveries of coverts.

J. Weinstein Rubin Building Company, who submitted the low bid of $1,317,240, were awarded the contract for construction of the new Central Needle Trades High School for the Board of Education of the City of New York.

Lazarus Vhite of the White Construction Company has purchased from Frank Mandel the tvelveroom and five-bath dwelling at 24 Pryor Lane, Larchmont, Westchester. This is a colonial-type house, with a large garage adjoining, on the second floor of which there are two apartments.

25th St, 209-11 E, 55x98.9; Rankuye Realty Co to John M. Geiger, 3,236 Schley Ave; pr mtg, $55,000, 3 yrs, 6%; $3,000. 151st St, 512 W, 50x99.11; Tibbe Holding Corp to Charles Benowitz, 60 E 96th St: pr mtg, $50,000, due Sept.' 1, 1941, int per bond: $5,000.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Boyce Bannerman of New York and Blue Point, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Bannerman, to Hugo A. Hilgendorff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilgendorff of this city.

Professor L. H. Newburgh of the University of Michigan told the Manitoba Medical Association convention today that 50 per cent of the persons diagnosed as suffering from diabetes are "just gluttons, only they won't admit it."

An air of what might be described as cordiality under restraint marked Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's reception to the Rhineland today. Official Germany is well aware that the British Prime Minister is here playing a role far from popular in his own country and there is no desire to display an enthusiasm that might add to this.

Lewis M. Dabney Jr., counsel for-the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the commission had a subpoena for Howard C. Hopson in proceedings to determine the relationship between the Utilities Employes Securities Company and various companies in the Associated Gas and Electric System but had been unable to serve it.

The third week in September seems to be the week of hurricanes in the United States, statistics for the past twelve years would indicae. While this appears to give substance to the existence of what are generally known as 'equinctial storms with the autumnal equinox, so far been adduced to link these storms with the autumnal equinox, which comes this year at exactly 12 o'clock noon, Eastern standard time, today.
Van Corlear P1. 15; Emanuel Silverstein, referee, to Dollar Savings Bank; foreclosure ($6.50). 50th St. 544 W; Evelyn A. Pitschke to 54 W 50th St Corp. 50th St, 546 W; same to 546 W 50th St Corp.
Official German news agency dispatches tonight reported Czechoslovak troops had fired on celebrating Sudeten Germans of the Eger frontier district, killing sixteen men and women.

Figures compiled by Isaao R. Halliday, president of the Stock Clearing Corporation, indicate that semi-weekly c earnings of transactions on the New York Stock Exchange, instituted on Sept. 1, have eliminated about half of the deliveries that were necessary under the daily clearing system.

To mark the twentieth anniversary of the start of the famous Argonne drive in the World War and the rescue of the Lost Battalion, a three-day celebration will start here tomorrow with a gathering at City Hall. Deputy Mayor Henry H.

The tenant rosters of apartment houses on Park Avenue yesterday continued to provide the items of chief interest in the Fall rush for rooms. With many buildings filling up on the approach of the traditional Fall moving day, the renting activity extended to other leading East and West Side thoroughfares and adjoining streets.

Rear Admiral Sinclair Gannon, U. S. N., commandant of the Eleventh Naval District, San Diego, Calif., and Mrs. Gannon have sent to friends here invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Sinclair Gannon, to Otto Lang, Internationally known skiing, exponent.

Tend- t ers for $100,000,000 of the Treas- r ury's' ninety-one-day bills were s invited today by Secretary Morgenthau. The bids will be received up s to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, on Monday, at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches.

Sixty beaver colonies manning dams in Palisades Interstate Park were credited today with having saved three arterial highways from serious flooding in yesterday's storm, preventing the certain destruction of at least one bridge and retarding the erosion of hundreds of acres of soil.
President Roosevelt's attempt to "purge" the Democratic party's Congressional nominees of some who were regarded as opposed to the New Deal will be a major issue in the Republican State campaign.
Shed no tears for Clipper Smith. Poor Clipper! He lost twelve letter me from a year ago, including such standouts as Stopper, Stoviak, Raimo, Mellus, Olivar, Bell, Missar and McKenna.

The British retreat from the League of Nations covenant's automatic coercive obligations advanced another step here this afternoon while Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain was talking with Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Coach Herb Kopf applied the finishing touches to the Jaspers' preparations for tomorrow's inaugural with St. Bonaventure at Randalls Island Stadium, in a two-hour drill yesterday at Manhattan Field. They reviewed their 'offensive and defensive formations against the Notre Dame plays used by the Bonnies and rehearsed kick-offs.

So-called "controversial" subjects, such as history, civics and econom ics, are rapidly gaining popularity with applicants for New York City teaching licenses at the expense of the "classical" subjects, like English, mathematics or foreign languages, Dr. Louis Marks, chairman of the board of examiners, reported yesterday.

Arthur W. Savage, 83, inventor and founder of the Savage Arms Company of Utica, N. Y., was found dead here today from a bullet wound. A pistol was at his side. Ben Wells, a police detective, said Mr. -Savage left a note which stated:

The old St. James Building at 1,133 Broadway has taken on new life. Workmen are now putting the finishing touches on a $300,000 modernization job there for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the owners, and the exterior of the seventeen-story structure has regained some of the freshness and charm which made it one of the outstanding office buildings of its neighborhood when it was completed in 1896.

Decreases in sales of both taxable and non-taxable motor fuel in July, compared with the same month last year, were reported today by the State Tax Commission. Taxable gasoline sold was 168,391,120 gallons, a drop of 9,128,429.

John F. Tracey, former city deputy tax commissioner, died yesterday of pneumonia in his home at 132-06 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, Queens. He was 74 years old. He had been in the city tax department forty years before his retirement in 1933.

The New York World's Fair site, with about fifty buildings in various stages of construction, withstood the hurricane on Wednesday with scarcely any damage, except for light floods and a few blown-down trees, an inspection showed yesterday.
Trade here picked up sharply yesterday after Wednesday's storm, but merchants agreed that the results this week have been so unfavorable as to cast doubt on a September sales gain.
Few cancellations of merchandise orders were received in the wholesale markets here yesterday as a result of the flood conditions in the New England area following Wednesday's hurricane.

A strike that hinders the movement of goods into a great city is not merely the business of the employers and employes who share the responsibility for it. It is everybody's business. Neither side has the right to bludgeon the public into submission.

It sounds a good deal like a primary election in Titipu when a prominent Democratic member of Congress is defeated for renomination in the Democratic primary and is successful in the Republican primary.

Catalina de Garcia, lyric soprano, will appearing recital tonight at the Hotel McAlpin. Ralph Jerome Cannaday, composer-pianist, and Reed Lawton, baritone, will appear in joint recital at Steinway Hall tonight.

Miss Duryea, Colorado Scott and Holyrood Perry captured the light harness events today at the annual Queens-Nassau Fair.
