Miss Duryea, owned and driven by Al Provenzano of New York, had to go four heats to take the 2:25 trot, the final brush bringing together the three winners, Hattie Hanover, H. M. S. and the eventual victor.

Trading in local markets yesterday greatly delayed owing to late arrivals of livestock and poor transportation due to floods and washouts. Calf hindsaddles were weak to lower but other classes of traefer meats showed little change. Due to the Jewish holidays, "Rosh Hashanah," there will 'be no kosher kill Monday and Tuesday;

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Sept. 22 unless specified: Acushnet, Indian Head to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. via Quantico, Dahlgren. Arkansas, at Tompkinsville, via Delaware Bay. Bushnell, at Canal Zone, Sept. 20. Cuttlefish, at Newport. Enterprise, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

As chairman of the national advisory committee of The Ladies Home Journal small-house competition, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will present at 3:30 P. M. today in the magazine's office in Rockefeller Center the first prize of $1,500 to Herbert W. Neumann of Jamaica and Herbert Struppmann of Woodhaven, Queens, joint winners. The nineteen prize-winning drawings are on display at the office.

Three terms of office apparently have not hurt Governor Phil La Follette's popularity. The Progressives have renominated him for a fourth term by 4 to 1 over the candidate of the Milwaukee Socialists and the Farmer-Labor Progressive Federation.

The Warsaw government will take no action on the question of the Polish minority in Czechoslovakia until after the Godesberg conference. The Poles expect Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to do for Poland what he has done for Germany, obtaining Prague's consent to the restoration of Teschen, Silesia.

There is speculation here as to where the twelve tons of gold bars, which reached Basle last night by eight planes from London, have really gone. The gold-worth about 60,000,000 Swiss francs-was forwarded by train to Berne, but there it was said to be only "in transit" and no destination was stated.
The hurricane and the sea combined to give to picturesque Cape Cod the same treatment suffered yesterday by more populous Long Island.

Councilman Michael Quill of New York City, president of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, who "would rather be called a Red by the rats than a rat by the Reds," defended his organization today against charges of radicalism during a speech before the international convention of the United Rubber Workers of America here.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock entertained at dinner at Eastover, Lenox, tonight to celebrate his birthday. Guests were his sister, Mrs. John Hubbard of Paris, Harris Fahnestock Jr., his daughters, Patricia and Aileen Fahnestock, who are staying at Eastover; Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana,

Pie Traynor and his Pirates probably will look back on yesterday as the date when they went deeply Into debt to the Dodgers, for the Merry Men of MacPhail salaamed to the league leaders twice at Ebbets Field in one of the most crucial of all so-called crucial doubleheaders.

Richard Kelly, former president of R. Hoe Co., Inc., 910 East 138th Street, the Bronx, the world's largest manufacturer of newspaper printing presses and maker of much other printing machinery, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, 211 East Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.

Two students at Northfield Seminary, Miss Norma Stockberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stockberger of Meriden, Conn., and Miss Audrey Lucas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grant R. Lucas of Yonkers, N. Y., were killed instantly and two others were seriously injured last night when a tall brick chimney crashed during the height of the hurricane.
Amid the confusion that marked his life of late, Douglas Corrigan, the "wrong-way" flier, today signed a contract with RKO to appear in "Born to Fly," which will be his life story.

Looking like so many refugees emerging from a cyclone cellar, the Giants and Reds crept out into the bright sunlight that flooded the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwih put the National 'League's mired pennant race in motion again.

Leaders of the army and navy today paid tribute to the memory. of Major Gen. Oscar Westover, chief of the Army Air Corps, who was killed with his sergeant-observer yesterday in a plane crash at Burbank, as arrangements were made to give him burial in the Arlington National Cemetery at Washington.

What was said to be the largest mass movement of passengers by air in the history of aviation took place yesterday and last night when four of the major airlines of the nation pooled equipment and personnel in an effort to supplement the storm-crippled railway service between New York-and Boston.

Magistrate Myers A. Paige relented after he had found Frederick von Laak, 40 years old, a building superintendent, guilty of disorderly conduct in Harlem Court yesterday and reversed his ruling when the defendant explained that he feared the conviction would interfere with his becoming a citizen.

About l9 320,000 factory wage-earners were added to employment rolls in August, the largest gain for an August in recent years except in Fe 1933 .and 1935, according to a statement issued today by Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor. The August figures included v 65,000 seasonal cannery workers.

The first session of the auction sale of English and French furniture, tapestries and other decorative objects from the estates of Adele Kneeland of Lenox, Mass., and H. Mabel MacDonald, also property of Mrs. William H. Hax and other owners, drew a total of $8,067 yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue.

In the face of refusal to testify on the part of a brakeman who, according to his own statements, threw a switch which caused the accident, a coroner's jury here today fixed no blame for the wreck near Niland Tuesday.
State Agricultural Commissioner Holton V. Noyes said today that the Buffalo milk marketing order, fixing minimum prices to be paid milk producers. will become effective Oct. 1.

The Scherman Development Corporation, Isaac Scherman, president, sold to the Allenhurst Holding Corporation, Abraham Leichter, president, the nine four and five-story houses at 315 to 321 West Fifty-seventh. Street extending through to 316 to 324 West Fiftyeighth Street, according to a deed recorded yesterday.

RING LARDNER once wrote a story about a R man who had an uncontrollable passion for reading aloud items of casual information-particularly scientific information-that he discovered in odd corners of the papers. Each item, Ring Lardner said, struck that man like a bolt from the blue.

With the consent of Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey released yesterday Mrs. Maria Griebl, wife of Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, fugitive head of an alleged German spy ring, from bail of $5,000, which was fixed for her on June 20 when she was held as a material witness in the case.

Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's Lincoln,. aged gray gelding from Old Westbury, L. I., captured the blue in the first touch-and-out event of the Bryn Mawr horse show which got under way late today. The Whitney horse had to do perfect work to get the judges' nod over seventeen other jumpers.

It was inevitable that, with the very large economic as well as political issues that have been at stake in Europe's political controversy, financial markets should have moved this week in an atmosphere of bewilderment.

The leisurely way of the dread tropic hurricane in building up its fury and dealing out its death and destruction was imprinted unforgettably in the mind of a motorist who toured the whole length of Long Island at the height of the storm.

Big Bill Lee, ace right-hander for the Chicago Cubs, today became the first National League pitcher in twenty-seven years to twirl four consecutive shut-outs as the Cubs kept on the heels of the first-place .Pittsburgh Pirates by sweeping a double-header from the Phillies, 4 to O-and 2 to 1.

Yale's football squad returned Tscht to New Haven late today, two days stand earlier than expected, when a portion of its training quarters at balls Gales Ferry was washed away by a hall the Thames River.

Harry Hurwit, architect, has purchased from Herman E. Brookman, operator, the five-story dwelling at 213 West Seventieth Street through the Hidalgo Management Corporation, broker. He intends to use the lower part of the building for his residence and remodel the upper floors for small apartments.

At 12 o'clock noon today, Eastern Standard Time, the sun, in its apparent southward migration through the sky, will stand exactly over the equator, dividing day and night into exactly twelve hours each. This means, of course, that the Autumnal equinox, or "equal night," comes this year at exactly noon.

Governor George H. Earle offered today Pennsylvania's "every possible aid" to the States hit by last night's storm. The Governor directed his assistant secretary to telephone the Governors of New York, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Maine.

Establishment of a government bonding service to bond postal officials was recommended by Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York City, in an address before the convention of the National Association of Postmasters today.

A new edition of "Who's Who in America,"' for the years `1938-39 will be- issued Monday, it was announced yesterday. The 2,929 page volume is the twentieth edition published biennially since 1899 andcontains 31,545 sketches of prominent men and women, of whom 2,545 appear for the first time in the pages of the reference book.

In building public friendship through a sound program of public relations it is esesntial for every company, large or small, to bear in mind the thought that the check book affords no substitute for personal effort on the part of the management, Philip B. Niles,

More optimism has become apparent among advertising agencies in recent weeks as a greater number of accounts have hurriedly revised Fall plans and released fairly substantial campaigns. At the same time, more companies have already started on 1939 advertising programs than had begun at this time last year, agency men reported.

Peter Kane, Briton, outpointed Jack Jurich, American contender from California, to win the British flyweight title before a crowd of 40,000 today. Kane weighed 111 pounds, Jurich 109. Kane will be recognized in Great Britain as world champion.

The Hon. Edward- Astley, elder son and heir of Lord Hastings, Melton Constable Park, Norfolk, England, who is in this country on a year's tour by auto to study American customs and institutions, told yesterday of his first three weeks in New York State and -New England and of his future plans.

While Japanese troops continued to hammer the back door of the vital Tienkiachen fortifications, on the north bank of the Yangtze, about 100 miles below Hankow, Japanese gunboats had manoeuvred yesterday through mine fields in the river above Wusueh, assailed positions only six miles.-below Tienkiachen and begun shelling Chinese troops on both banks of the Yangtze.

Mrs. Marico Nitobe, formerly Mary Patterson Elkinton of Philadelphia, o died today at 8:30 A. M. (6:30 P. M. Thursday, E. S. T.), at the age of 82. She was married in 1891 to the late Dr. Inazo Nitobe, former member of the House of Peers and an official of the League of Nations.

Henry D. Weber, 61 years old, who was driven from his home on Hawthorne Road, Old Greenwich, when the flood waters rose last night, and took refuge with his wife in the home of a neighbor; Mrs. H. L. Fish, died of a heart attack this morning at 8 o'clock.

The Mayflower Doughnut Corporation, which for a number of years, has operated a luncheonette in the Astor Theatre Building, has leased two stores and space on the second floor of Loew's State Building, on the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street, for a similar enterprise.

Inspired by its record for 1938 in which it climbed from sixth to fourth place in the industry and produced 8 1/2 per cent of the automobile total, the Buick division of General Motors presented at a press preview today a completely redesigned line of cars,
Winifred W. Windlo, treasurer and general manager of the W. W. Windlo Company, Inc., Millbury, Masss, was elected yesterday to membership in the New York Wool Top Exchange.
The more than ordinarily successful debuts of two talented young vocalists gave added luster to last night's performance of "Madama Butterfly" by the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre.

The fifth auditor to be accused of defrauding the State Insurance, Fund was arrested yesterday at the order of the Bernard Botein general attorney for the fund, who has been investigating the frauds at the instigation of Governor Lehman.

The marriage of Miss Ann Carroll Baxter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Baxter of Brooklyn and Bay Shore, L. I., to John de Lacey Regan, son of Mrs. John F. Regan, also of Brooklyn and Bay Shore, and the late Mr. Regan, took place yesterday morning. in the Church of Holy Innocents, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, Mgr. James T. Kelty.

The Boston Bees bunched most of their hits in two innings today to sweep a double-header from the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5 and 4-1, while winding up the season's competition against the Western clubs.

New York City checked up yesterday the damages of Wednesday's storm and found them heavy. There were ten, persons dead, five injured and two reported missing. Insurance companies reckoned their loss at $5,000,000 and estimated the total cost of the storm much higher.

Quebec Province set the death toll -at two tonight, as residents struggled to return to normal living after the fierce storm of rain and wind that disrupted communications and left city streets and country roads littered with debris last night.

The Schermerhorn branch of the Brooklyn Trust Company, which for several years has occupied quarters at 41 Flatbush Avenue, will move early in December to 65-71 Flatbush Avenue on the corner of Lafayette Avenue and Rockwell Place, as a result of a lease arranged by Pyle-Gray Realty Estate Company, Inc., broker.

Irving M. Taylor, assistant general passenger agent of the New York Central System, with an Office in New York, died today of a heart ailment in his home here after a sixmonth illness. His age was 56.

George Condit Van Roden, a jeweler, who designed the insignia of the Daughters of the American Revolution. died yesterday at the age of 76. For some time he had charge of the insignia department of J. E. Caldwell Co., but since 1903 had been a member of the firm of Combes Van Roden.

William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, was the principal speaker last night before the senior margin clerks section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. The gathering was the first of the Fall-Winter season.

With the break in the weather yesterday, polo officials, trying to finish the Waterbury Cup tournament, hoped to be able to resume play tomorrow and were certain that, baring more rain, Sunday's semi-final match between Greentree and Aknusti would be held at International Field.

Indications point to an active Fall market for plumbing and heating equipment in view of reports showing that sales of bathtubs, sinks, boilers and radiators have not fallen off as sharply as some other household commodities, reports the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.
Liquor price wars in New Jersey which have disrupted the industry in the State will soon be effectively terminated under plans of D. Frederick Burnett, State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner.

With more than 1,500 extra men at work in local communities, officials of Westchester County reported today that all parkways and county roads had been reopened. and most of the telephone and lighting service had been restored throughout the county.

In the face of an appeal from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, calling upon craft union members in Pennsylvania to help re-elect Senator James J. Davis by "a most decisive majority," the craft unions today threw their support to his Democratic opponent, Governor George H. Earle.

With the opening game only two lays away, and with the change in weather, Army's football squad went through a spirited practice today, as the Cadets prepared for Saturday's contest with the University of Wichita.

Action taken by the Community Councils of New York, Inc., for the removal from office of William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, on grounds of incompetency and waste, were attacked yesterday by J. B. Vandever, secretary of the Broadway Association.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Nineteen members of the Cardinals arrived at-Newark Airport last night after a flight from Boston, made necessary because of the disrupted train service between Boston and New York. From the airport they were whisked to New York by bus to entrain for Chicago, where they-open a series with the Cubs tomorrow.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Sept. 20: COMMANDRR Muller, F. W., Med. Corps, the Holland, to the Relief, in November. LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Moncure. J. P., 14th Naval District, to Navy Yard. Pearl Harbor, T. I. Lanols, E. J., Med. Corps, New Orleans, La., to the Holland.

War risk insurance rates, including air risk on shipments of jewelry and securities, between Britain and Czechoslovakia were quoted at ??5 and [Pound]100 in a new schedule announced tonight by the joint rating committee of marine underwriters.

Amid tremendous demonstrations of patriotic enthusiasm Premier Milan Hodza's "capitulation government" resigned yesterday morning. By last night a new government of "national concentration and defense" had been born under General Jan Syrovy, Inspector General of the Army.

Competition in the thirty-fourth annual United States Seniors' Golf Association championship tourney swung back to normal today, and 148 linksmen saw action as Charles H. Jennings of Garden City shot into the lead for the title at Apawamis.

During the week ended Sept. 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $411,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $571,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks,

With broadcasting facilities in the New York area restored to normal yesterday, after wires and power supplies had been cut off by the hurricane on Wednesday, the microphone of WJZ was switched into various points of the stricken area to bring eyewitness reports of the hurricane disaster.

Negotiations for joint development of the Great Lakes-St. Lawrence seaways and power project, revived by the United States last May with a new basis for agreement and urged again by President Roosevelt in his Ontario speech in August, received a further setback today.
The farmer in the dell-lower East Side version-had his own county fair yesterday, with a variation from the traditional blue-ribbon awards to make life interesting for the champions.
While the Federal Government's debt has been increasing rapidly since the depression began, the debts of State and local governments have declined since 1933, the Twentieth Century Fund has reported.

Miss Dorothy W. Hafner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Hafner of Malba, Queens, was married last night at the home of her parents to Miguel A. de Capriles of Hempstead, son of Mrs. A. M. de Capriles and the late Mr. de Capriles. The Rev. Hubert S. Wood of St. George's Church, Flushing, performed the ceremony.
Joseph F. Cooney, manager of Igoe Brothers, manufacturers of wire materials, with offices at 529 Washington Street, died yesterday at the Peck Memorial Hospital following an operation.
An entire floor, consisting of about 30,000 square feet of space, at 521 West Forty-third Street, has been leased by the May Knitting Company, through Spear Co., Inc., brokers.
Mr. and Mrs. Binnie Morison of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cristal Morison, to George Henry Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Baker of Leeland, Fla.

166th St. (9-2388) n s, 127 ft e of Park Ave, 95x101; Morris Horwitz to 435 E 166th St. Realty Corp. LORING PL, 2,307 (11-3225); Anna K. Seykora to Clara Heise, 2,307 Loring P1; mtg $14,500. 237th St, 715 E (17-5046); Harry I. Kohn, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

Lacking adequate reserves and support, Major Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Second Army manoeuvres here, withdrew two National Guard divisions of his Blue Army from the front tonight, 'streamlined" them and then pushed them around the flanks of the imaginary Black Army invading the United States.

Local football fans who have read and heard of the exploits of Byron (Whizzer) White will have their first opportunity to witness the scholarly athlete from Colorado in action tonight at Ebbets Field. The famed triple-threat man is slated to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates against the Brooklyn Dodgers in a National Football League encounter under the floodlights.

Thirty-eight passengers and crew of the United Fruit liner Antigua suffered minor injuries when the ship ran into the hurricane during the New York to Santiago voyage. The injured received treatment aboard.

Major John P. Street, executive secretary of the New York State Canners Association, died here tonight at the age of 69. A graduate of Rutgers College in 1889, he became associated with the Connecticut State Agricultural Experimental Station and worked on the State's Pure Food and Drug Act.

Elliott Underhill, a pilot of Easern Aeronautical Corporation, based at Newark Airport, flew here from Providence yesterday morning and viewed the devastation left in the wake of the storm which swept through Connecticut and Rhode Island late Tuesday night.

While the city of Boston and its surrounding territory started today to dig its way out of the wreckage and debris left by yesterday's hurricane, the relief forces of Massachusetts and New Hampshire faced the new peril of constantly rising waters and flood conditions in the Merrimack and Connecticut River Valleys.

The livestock market undertone was better today, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Cattle, however, were no higher, generally speaking, but a little more active at the week's low time. Only a sprinkling of strictly good, choice and prime steers and yearlings were available and these moved readily, mostly to outsiders.
October was proclaimed today by Governor Lehman as Highway Safety Month. He recommended the subject as an appropriate theme for clergymen and public speakers.

Two person were in a critical condition in Eastern Long Island Hospital today as the result of injuries received in the storm. Emmett Young, 35 years old, stepped outside his home in Southold for a moment and the roof to his house blew off and fell on him. He is suffering from severe bodily and internal injuries. Chris Leicht,
James C. Purcell, former Philadelphia County commander of the American Legion, died in Presbyterian Hospital here yesterday. He had been overcome by smoke durin an firs at his home.

The body of a man identified as Harry P. Kinney, head keeper of the Central Park Zoo, who disappeared from the excursion steamer Robert Fulton on Sept. 15, was' washed ashore at Englewood Cliffs this morning.

The navy destroyer Henley and the intercoastal freighter Washingtonian were damaged seriously when they collided in San Diego Bay Channel late last night. The Henley, inbound, crashed into the outward-bound Washingtonian off its starboard bow. Bow plates of both vessels were smashed in and the starboard anchor, motor boat and davits of the Henley were torn away.
Nine Democratic Senators, with an original inclination toward independent thinking and new provocation therefore, have been renominated; and most if not all of them will be reelected.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company filed yesterday plans for two more units in its housing project for the old Catholic Protectory grounds in the Bronx. The latest plans in the development provide for two eight-story houses at a total cost of $1,750,000.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted with conditions a series of applications by the American Light and Traction Company and four subsidiaries-the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, the Grand Rapids Gas Light Company,

In a paper read today before the National Association of Securities Commissioners in the Hotel President, Jerome N. Frank, economist and member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested that a large volume of industrial long-term loans, "because of their inelasticity, may threaten to impair the profit system."

Plans of the Department of Sanitation to dump refuse in Jamaica Bay on a large scale have been postponed indefinitely because of opposition from residents of the section, Commissioner William F. Carey said yesterday.

While the actual damage was far greater, insurance company officials estimated yesterday a loss of $5,000,000 here and vicinity due to the hurricane. They said the $5,000,000 covered insurance on buildings, boats, cargoes, piers and the merchandise, automobiles, trucks and goods in transit damaged.

Creation of 500,000 new WPA jobs, an increase of $360,000,000 a year in work relief wages and a $5,000,000,0000 public housing program were advocated today by the general executive board of the Workers Alliance as part of "a nation-wide assault Ion the ramparts of depression."

The Chilear Government l reached today in agreement with the National City Bank, it was announced, whereby a short-term loan of $15,800,000 expiring on Nov. 27. next, in accordance with arrangements made in 1933, will be extended another five years with a sinking-fund payment of 1 per cent.

The Supremus filly Drift Along, owned by Hal Price Headley and trained by his capable nephew, Duval, was a driving winner of the Lion d'Or Handicap, feature event yesterday at Belmont Park, which looked spic and span regardless of damage by the storm.
The navy announced today that the airplane carrier to be constructed under the recent Naval Expansion Act would be named Hornet. The name was selected by President Roosevelt in 1936.

Aubrey Williams, acting administrator of the Works Progress Administration, announced today that $696,356,000 had been spent in the purchase of materials and equipment for WPA projects during the threeyear period ending June 30, 1938. One-third went for stone, clay and glass products used principally in building and road construction.

With the prospect of their candidacies based on the assumption that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will be the nominee for Governor, two up-State newspaper publishers, Edward H. Butler of The Buffalo Evening News and Jerome D. Barnum of The Syracuse Post-Standard, are under consideration for the Republican nomination for the full six-year term in the United States Senate, it was learned yesterday.
A Netherland passenger plane in the regular Prague-Rotterdam service was forced to land in German territory yesterday by Reich authorities, it was announced here today.

Henry R. Luce of Stamford, publisher of Life, Time and Fortune magazines, has bought for occupancy the former J. Rich Steers property on Upper King Street here. The brokers were Banks Cleveland of Greenwich and Hickernel Romeyn of New York.

The strain of recent events upon France's finances became a factor in determining her position in the international situation today. The tension affected the franc, which went down to 178.39 to the pound sterling, with a 5-franc premium on forward rates.

Emergency repair crews were busy yesterday throughout the New York area, Long Island and New England restoring communication links with the thousands of telephones and telegraph offices put out of operation by the storm of Wednesday.

Allan Sproul, first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of th New York, has been designated manager of the open-market account of the Federal Reserve Systern, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed W. Randolph Burgess, who resigned as a vice president of the Reserve Bank last week to become vice chairman of the National City Bank.

A banking group headed by Field, Richards Shepard, Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $6,120,000 of refunding bonds of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, on a bid of 100.016 for $5,835,000 as 3 $285,000 as 31/2, or at a net interest cost to the county of 3.736 per cent.

Thomas A. McGoey has been appointed director of Columbia University residence halls, a new post created this year by an administrative reorganization putting dormitories and dining halls 'under single control, it was announced yesterday by President Nicholas Murray Butler.
Today's statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday shows the ratio of net reserve to notes. and deposit liabilities as 53.32 per cent, against 4.10 the week before.

America's big three of women's golfMrs. Estelle Lawson Page, Miss Patty Berg and Miss Marion Miley and a young newcomer from the Pacific Coast, Miss Peggy Graham, today made their way into the semifinal round of the forty-second national women's championship on the sun-drenched Westmoreland Country Club course.

Felix Frankfurter, 56-year-old Harvard law professor and intimate adviser of President Roosevelt, is the leading choice for appointment to the United States Supreme Court in an Institute survey of American lawyers, according to the results of a survey made public yesterday by Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Arthur Kavanagh, retired vice president of the National City Bank of New York, died last night of a stroke at his home on North Cobb Road at the age of 80. A native of Brooklyn, Mr. Kavanagh was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kavanagh.

An alarm was broadcast by the police of Massachusetts and Rhode Island yesterday for F. Van Wyck Mason, writer, who left Nantucket Wednesday afternoon in a private plane for Floyd Bennett Airport, Brooklyn. He carried with him the corrected proofs of a 700-page historical novel.

The Oxford University Press announces for publication early in 1939 "The Literary Works of Leonardo da Vinci," a new edition, partly rewritten and brought up to date, of the edition edited by Jean Paul Richter, which has been out of print for over thirty years.
A few minor traces of Wednesday's hurricane were visible in the schedules of shipping yesterday, but steamship men considered that they had "weathered" the storm with particularly good fortune.

A conservative trend which may have surprising results of national significance at the November elections is discernible in this traditionally radical seaport city and throughout the entire progressive State of Washington.
Progress, opportunities and responsibilities of research will be surveyed today and tomorrow at the Fall meeting of the Industrial Research Institute at the Westchester Country Club, Rye,

On orders from President Roosevelt every Federal agency equipped for the. job was pressed into storm relief service today as the Americah Red Cross estimated at 10,000 the number of families in distressed circumstances in New York and New England in the wake of floods, storms, fires and high seas.

Mr. and Mrs. DeForest Grant, who passed the Summer at their place at Bar Harbor, have returned to their home here at 962 Fifth Avenue. Mr. and Mrs. J. Ledlie Hees have come to the Delmonico from Sacandaga, N. Y.

As communications began to be re-established last night after the worst storm in the history of the northeastern section of the country, the list of dead from Wednesday's hurricane reached a total of 441, including at least 250 dead in Rhode island alone.

Mrs. Nancy Higginson Dorr, widow of John Van Nostrand Dorr of New York and founder of the Riverside School, died at Asbury Park, N. J., yesterday in her eightyninth year. She had been ill for about a year.

At a friendly three-handed game of hearts in the Executive Mansion here last year Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., Philadelphia contractor, related that Governor George H. Earle was to get part of the profits on a $3,000,000 contract for construction of the State Finance Building, Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General,

Mayor La Guardia spent a quiet day here today after a strenuous round of activities in connection with the annual convention of the American Legion. After devoting his morning to correspondence and a telephone conversation with New York, the Mayor. drove with former Judge Ben B. Lindsey of Denver,

A vivid picture of the destruction wrought by swiftly rising waters in Providence, R. I., was given last night by L. D. Lacy of Pelham Manor, just returned from that city. He was stranded on the second floor of a hotel there.

A further break in Czechoslovak loans was the feature of a somewhat dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market for Czech issues, incidentally, reflected that for Austrian bonds early this year when Austria was absorbed by Germany, and the tendency was to appraise the Czech obligations now in terms of the outstanding defaulted German bonds.

One Missouri relief client has unbounded faith in President Roosevelt's fishing ability. This man. had requested late in July more of the fish distributed by the. Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation. The supply, however, had become exhausted.

After passing through one of the most trying twenty-four hours in their history, during which service on many lines was discontinued or preceded at a snail's pace over dangerously weakened tracks, railroads serving New York City's commuters announced late yesterday that, with few exceptions, trains were operating again on normal schedules.

Argentine butter and casein producers have asked their government to allow them to liquidate their export bills at the "free market" rate instead of at the lower fixed rate on export bills imposed by the government, the Commerce Department reports.

As a climax to the third and final day of the twenty-seventh annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, Greenwich and Rye Garden Clubs, a "beetle's hop" similar to the annual butler's ball in New York, took place tonight in the boys' lounge of the Greenwich Y. M. C. A. where the show has been staged.
The traditional rule of American democracy that secrecy must prevail at the polls did not hold true at the primary election Tuesday in the Third district of the town of Fort Ann, Washington County.
Production of lead in the United States in August amounted to 25,547 tons, compared with 31,488 in July and 46,965 in August, 1937, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

Ground for the statement recently published in London that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's leadership was on the wane in Rebel territory and that he might soon be replaced was found by this writer on a visit to the Ebro war zone, whence he returned yesterday.

The general level of wholesale prices rose in the week ended on Sept. 17, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.3, compared with 77.9 on Sept. 10 and 87.4 on Sept. 18, 1937.

164th St, 316 E, 2-story dwelling, 22x88.7x irreg.; Home Owners Loan Corp against Ida Davis, due, $5,138; to plaintiff for $500. Story Ave, s s. 205.4 W Castle Hill Ave, 4 parcels vacant land, 100x100; Knickerbocker Federal Savings and Loan Assn against Story Homes, Inc, due, $15,610; to plaintiff for $750 each parcel.

Two men were shot to death and a girl, two policemen and a robber were wounded today in a battle between police and bandits during the holdup of a handbook establishment in a garage on the North Side.

Miss Charlotte Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Barnes of this place, was married tonight at the home of he parents to John Davidson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Davidson Jr. of Upper Montclair. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Phelps Noyes, pastor of Central Presbyterian Church, Montclair, officiated.

Trade associations of a new type, comprising a sort of "department of state" for industry, must be establislied in recognition of industry's "changed responsibility toward the sixety of which it is a part and to which it must answer,"

Maryland is to have a new bridge, at Havre de Grace, representing the modified survival of its original three-bridge program. Plans for the Morgantown Bridge, the site for which was inspected and approved by President Roosevelt, have been abandoned as involving a sacrificial readjustment of approved PWA projects which the State was not prepared to make.
Several State departments swung into action today to repair the damage and relieve the suffering caused by the floods in various sections of New York.

Mrs. John C. Norris, Who perished in the storm at Narragansett Pier, was of for many years a social leader in Philadelphia and at Narragansett. On hearing of her death and that of her son, John C. Norris Jr., 33 years old, several members of the family left by plane for Rhode Island.

The cotton trade was puzzled over the significance of various developments in the European political situation yesterday with the result that trading was limited on the Cotton Exchange. Prices responded to a moderate volume of orders and gradually declined from opening advances of 1 to 3 points to close with losses of 4 to 6 points for the day.

AFTERTHOUGHTS OF THE U. S. S. R., by Andre Gide. (Dial, $1.50.) A reply to critics of the author's "Back From the U. S. S. R." THE CAPTAIN'S CHAIR, by Robert Flaherty. (Scribner's, $2.50.) A story of life among the Eskimos, by the man who filmed "Nanook of the North."

Under smiling blue skies, fashionable Westhampton Beach -- what was left of it--emerged today from the storm's ravages with a toll of fifteen dead and at least thirty-one persons still missing. The damage to property was beyond any estimating.

Announcement was made yesterday of the signing of a ten-year agreement between several hundred chain and independent motion-picture theatres and the Building Service Employes International Union covering more than 3,000 cleaners, porters, watchmen, charwomen and others of the cleaning staffs. This group,

Aided by better weather and special promotions, store sales here during the first half of National Retail Demonstration Week advanced irregularly and on several days were substantially ahead of the corresponding dates in 1937, a check of several of the larger establishments showed today. The record for the full week,

Price changes that included a reduction of $122 were made yesterday by Graham-Paige Motors Cor- t portion on the company's new cars for 1939. The drop of $122 from the price of a similar 1938 model ap' plied to the four-door sedan, according to the announcement. Delivered with full equipment at Detroit, the four-door sedan will cost $965.

SINCE getting a close look at Whizzer White, the fair-haired football fellow from Colorado, this observer had been puzzled up to a moment ago. He looked very much like another fellow in some other game, a fellow who has been around for some time. It just came to mind. Bucky Walters, the pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds. Except that the Whizzer has larger hands,

Five bands, a police parade and brilliant sun greeted 20,000 persons at the gates of the Fair Grounds here this morning on the third day of the ninety-sixth annual Mineola Fair being held this week by the QueensNassau Agricultural Society.

Wickham Steed, noted journalist, charged today that his interview in the current issue of The British Paramount Film News had, been deleted because he attacked Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy.

The paralysis of shipping relaxed here yesterday when representatives of truck drivers and truck operators resumed negotiations for a new contract. Meanwhile, the business community took advantage of the four-day truce in the disastrous seven-day "outlaw" strike of drivers to rush goods from congested piers and freight terminals and that build up surplus stocks against a possible renewal of the strike next week.
Robert R. Dearden Jr., president and editor-of the United States Review, a newspaper of the insurance business, died of a heart attack at his home on Oak Lane last night. He was 67 years old.

Purchases of 4,000 tons of surplus new and old erop packed dried peaches in California under a renewed purchase program will be undertaken by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, -the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today.

For the First time this year factory activity of the automobile industry is above the comparable 1937 figures, according to Automotive News. This journal reports an estimated production this week of 25,254 units, compared with 21,116 last week, and 23,222 this week a year ago.

Portions of the bunting from which the first flag of Liberia was made, and which have long been in the possession of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, a philanthropic organization contributing for many years to the advancement of the African Republic, will be presented to the government at Monrovia as a gesture of good-will.

It is now pretty well established on authentic testimony that it was her French ally that initially failed Czechoslovakia in this crisis, creating a situation that superficially leaves the onus on British rather than on French shoulders.

The railway mail service yesterday was forced to use airplanes, trucks, steamers and buses to keep some sort of communications available to New England and Long Island, John H. Hardy, superintendent of the service in New York, said yesterday.

It is difficult to see what social function is served by investment trusts that are themselves chiefly speculative vehicles. Investment trusts justify their existence when they supply the small investor with an investment more diversified and more stable than
W. Newbold Ely Jr.'s Pantysgallog Nimrod of Ambler, Pa., was chosen best Welsh Foxhound in the second day's showing of the Bryn Mawr hound show.

The will of Thomas Wolfe, young novelist, whose fame was worldwide at the time of his death on Sept. 15 in Baltimore, was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The estate was valued at "less than $5,000."

The Brooklyn-Manhattan vehicular tunnel, leading project on Mayor La Guardia's program of major improvements, has been rejected for PWA funds by Federal authorities, but a grant of $12,000,000, the amount sought for the tunnel, has been approved for the proposed $28,000,000 Circumferential Parkway in Brooklyn and Queens, Park Commissioner Robert Moses informed the Board of Estimate yesterday.

Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, former chairman of the board of the Tennesseee Valley Authority, will speak on "Cost Accounting in Public Business," at the annual dinner which will close the seventh annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America to be held Sept. 26 and 27 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Postmaster General Farley, speaking as national chairman of his party, told Ohio Democrats tonight that "this is another Democratic year" and urged the party to "close ranks." "These were sharp and hardfought primary contests," Mr. Farley recalled in an address before the Democratic State Convention.
The British Government suddenly redoubled its air-raid precautions today as Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Chancellor Adolf Hitler began their meeting on the Rhine.

Chancellor Hitler and Prime Minister Chamberlain conferred for three hours yesterday at Godesberg and will meet again today. They apparently had not found irreconcilable difficulties, but many questions were still undecided. Mr. Chamberlain issued an appeal to the populations of all countries concerned to remain calm, and asked that local conditions in Czechoslovakia remain orderly.

Pleas for more emphasis on production and less upon redistribution of income, sand for greater stress on initiative and less on security, were voiced today by speakers at the International Management Congress, which at a dinner tonight heard Daniel S. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, warn that "willful minorities," by unfair trade practices, were "bringing the house down on their own heads."

The Bears, on the verge of elimination from the International League play-offs four days ago, came back to tie the semi-final series at three games each by beating Rochester, .7 to 1, tonight behind the five-hit patching of Atley Donald.

The New York County Committee of the Communist party announced last night the withdrawal of its forty-two candidates in Manhattan and its "whole-hearted endorsement" of the American Labor party candidates.

MANHATTAN BRISBIN, VIOLET L. (Sept. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Florence E. Wood, daughter, Paterson, N. J., $1,500; Frederick W. Lind, Lyndhurst, N. J., $5,000; three minor bequests. Winfield Bonynge, East Orange, executor. CORNER, IDA ELIZABETH (Dec. 25, 1937). Estate, less than $10,000. To Guaranty Trust Co., 140 Broadway, as executor of John C. Hicks.

The fourth successive weekly decline in business loans of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City was shown in the condition statement of these banks as of Wednesday, issued yesterday. The decline,

Major highways in the metropolitan area, Eastern New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania which had been closed by hurricane damage were again open to motor traffic, the Automobile Club of New York announced late yesterday afternoon from information provided in part by affiliated clubs in the areas affected.
The new Bankruptcy Law, described by Justice Department officials as the first comprehensive revision of bankruptcy statutes since 1898, became effective today.
The German press today displayed a new nationality map of Czechoslovakia that is captioned, "This Polygolet State Must Be Removed."

Sidney Chase, 19 years old, of 99 Elliot Street, New Haven, Conn., died today in White Plains Hospital as a result of injuries suffered yesterday when two automobiles collided on Hutchinson River Parkway, Scarsdale. He was the driver

Members of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, will hold their annual convention here at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria on Oct. 10, it Mas announced from the organization's headquarters in Washington yesterday.

An agreement between trustees of the Munson Steamship Line and the United States Maritime Commission, which is expected to lead to reorganization of the line, was approved late yesterday afternoon by Federal Judge Alfred D. Coxe.
This year's Philippine rice crop of 118,558,898 bushels is 30 per cent higher than that of a year ago, almost entirely because of better yields, the Department of Commerce has reported.

Business activity in the Pittsburgh district showed extensive gains last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production, shipments and trade all shared in the advance.

The total of loans and securities of all insured commercial banks in the United States and possessions dropped from $37,194,239,000 on Dec; 31 to $35,974,647,000 on June 30, a decrease of $1,219,592,000, or 3.3 per cent, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today in its ninth report of bank assets and liabilities.

Owing to limited finances, the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department will appoint no more than four or five industry committees by Jan. 1, it was announced. today by Elmer F. Andrews, administrator.

The foreign exchange market turned weak again yesterday as all financial markets yielded to misgivings over the course of the Czechoslovak crisis. French francs were especially weak under the combined influence of a poor statement by the Bank of France and rumors of dissension in the French Cabinet.

The Inland Steel Company met today the reductions in prices of railroad track materials announced recently by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation. Prices of other products will continue unchanged for fourth-quarter delivery, except that rounds for seamless tubing will be $45 a gross ton, reduced from $50.
Sir Arthur Henry Crosfield, 73 years old, was killed today after falling from a railroad train near Le Muy on the line from Toulon to St. Raphael, according to information reaching here.

A tenpoint Americanization program, which included criticism of the Department of Labor's policies on labor, backed the activities of the Dies committee and called for the deportation of Harry Bridges, West Coast union leader, was unanimously adopted today at the closing business session of the national convention of the American Legion.

Mrs. Evelyn D. Carter of 9,670 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, died Wednesday night in the Mublenberg Hospital, Plainfield, N. J., of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Sunday night at Mountainside, N.'J. She was 42 years old.

A series of week-end blackouts began tonight instead of tomorrow and will last until Tuesday, but the projected "alarms" have been postponed. As a result Vienna looks like a sepulcher tonight-and it is just about as cheerful.

The intent of the Administration in Washington to tax income from C State and municipal bonds without a constitutional amendment, recently reported by the Treasury Department, was assailed sharply yesterday by Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the conference on State defense, at a meeting of municipal bond dealers.

July revenues of the manufactured and natural gas utilities in the United States amounted to $52,717,900, a decrease of 2.4 per cent from revenues of $54,001,000 reported in the same month a year ago, according to the American Gas Association.
Stocks drifted narrowly and lower, with closing prices of pivotal issues off 1 to 2 points in second slowest trading of the month; turnover, 467,300 shares.

Marine insurance underwriters said yesterday that, despite a protest by British shipping interests to government officials over the higher war risk rates quoted in the last two weeks, importers and shippers here have made no joint protest and in only a few instances have complained of the higher rates.

Having won the first legal battle in an effort to enforce the law to limit corporate ownership of land to 500 acres, Attorney General Fernandez Garcia sailed today for New York en route to Washington to confer with Interior Department counsel on further litigation, including monopolies.

Two armed thugs escaped at 1:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon after seizing a $2,400 payroll which William Boyar, cloak manufacturer, was making up in his fifth-floor plant at 115 West Twenty-seventh Street. Mr. Boyar,

George Abbott announces that because of "misinterpretation and misrepresentation of the arrangement" he has cancelled the loan from ticket brokers for financing "The Boys Frm Syracuse." Explaining that he had sent checks to the brokers, Mr. Abbott says he did not want to be put in the light of opposing the new ticket code.
